column2: SCHOLL--Hannah Holzman, died May 1, 2007, at Cabrini Hospice. Born in the Bronx, New York. Beloved wife of Harold M. Scholl, devoted mother of Eric and Roger. B.A., Hunter College 1948, M.A. 1949, Ph.D. 1959, Teachers College, Columbia University, in Speech Science and Correction. Professor of Speech Pathology and Linguistics at East Stroudsburg State College, East Stroudsburg, PA, (retired) Co-Author, Children With Conduct Disorders, Basic Books, 1991, Speech and Language Faults of Schizophrenic Children, 1972. Member, Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine, American Speech-LanguageHearing Foundation. Memorial service Friday, May 4, 12:15 pm at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street. Donations if desired, to CARE Program at Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, 331 East 70th St., New York, NY 10021. Hannah went to sleep and never woke up. She will be missed dearly.

A Sports of The Times column in some copies on Sunday, about the continuing problems with steroids in Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly to the origin of a rule covering ''conduct detrimental'' to the sport. The top professional leagues included a conduct clause in their governing agreement in 1896, and baseball historians say the notion probably emerged before that. The concept was not created by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who was elected baseball's first commissioner in 1920, and who is credited with rigorous enforcement of the conduct clause.

Panel Inclined to Find Wolfowitz Broke Bank Rules Members of a World Bank panel investigating the conduct of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, are leaning toward finding that he violated bank rules against conflicts of interest when he arranged a raise and promotion for his companion, bank officials said. PAGE A6 Deputy Asks Olmert to Quit The day after a government panel criticized Prime Minister Ehud Olmert's actions in Israel's war last year, his deputy, Tzipi Livni, called on him to quit. But after she said she would work within his Kadima Party to succeed him, Kadima legislators reportedly still backed him. PAGE A10 Justice Department Inquiry The Justice Department is investigating whether a former aide to Alberto R. Gonzales improperly tried to fill vacancies for prosecutors at the agency with Republicans loyal to the Bush administration. PAGE A18 Afghans Fault a U.S. Attack A recent American bombing raid in Afghanistan killed at least 42 civilians, including women and children, and wounded 50 more, an Afghan government inquiry found. PAGE A12 French Candidates Debate In a confrontation that could tip the scales in the vote on Sunday, Nicolas Sarkozy and Ségolène Royal went after each other in a lively face-to-face debate. PAGE A8 Remembering Barbaro Dr. Dean Richardson, who tried to save Barbaro, last year's Kentucky Derby winner, at work this week. The undefeated Curlin is the early favorite for the Derby on Saturday. SPORTSTHURSDAY, PAGE D1

A JOURNAL UNDER MURDOCH? Rupert Murdoch usually gets what he wants, but he may need some of his trademark patience to convince the board of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, to accept his $5 billion offer to buy the company. [Page A1.] The Dow Jones board said that it would take no action on the bid by Mr. Murdoch, the chairman of News Corporation, but it did not reject the offer, leaving him some wiggle room. [C1.] A deal for Dow Jones could allow thousands of its employees to cash out their stock options for a tidy profit. [C4.] Already, some investors, perhaps acting on insider information, have made a bundle by purchasing options in recent weeks speculating that Dow Jones shares would rise. [C4.] SECRET CODE IS NOW JUST A CODE -- A throng of tech-savvy Internet users have banded together over the last two days to publish and widely distribute a secret code used by the technology and movie industries to prevent piracy of high-definition movies. [A1.] FOOD IMPORT LABELED INCORRECTLY -- A Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to American pet food suppliers avoided inspections partly because it did not correctly disclose its shipping contents to Chinese export authorities, according to American regulators. [C1.] CHOPPED LIVER, THINKING AHEAD -- Zingerman's, in Ann Arbor, Mich., is both a beloved local deli and $30 million enterprise with a gourmet catalog and nationwide mail-order business. Its owners attribute the growth to a rare commodity in the food business -- planning ahead. [C1.] I.R.S. CURTAILS OFFSHORE AUDITS -- The Internal Revenue Service is curtailing audits of many people who use offshore tax havens because agents fear they cannot meet a three-year deadline for finishing an examination. [C1.] DON'T SKIP THIS COMMERCIAL -- How do you create a campaign for TiVo, the digital video recording device that helps people avoid advertisements? TiVo has hired an agency known for broad humor, and it has created commercials inspired by the ''TiVo Man,'' the cartoon character with an antenna on his head. Look for movie critic Gene Shalit, above, and others sporting antennas. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] VYING FOR ABN AMRO -- The fight for control of ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, brings head to head the chiefs of Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, two very different individuals. [C13.] MAKINGS OF A POSSIBLE DEAL -- The Dolan family's $10.6 billion bid to buy Cablevision Systems, the company they founded, was the result of persistence and a private meeting with the two board members who had rejected previous buyout offers from the family. [C3.] MAGNA IN TALKS WITH AUTO UNIONS -- The Canadian auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna's workers to their ranks. [C13.] SHRINKING NOTEBOOKS -- Ultraportable notebook computers -- supercompact, lightweight laptops that slip into briefcases as easily as a legal pad -- have made the jump from Europe and appear to be finding favor with American tastes. [C11.] LESS ENERGY, MORE SPEED -- Scientists at I.B.M. are reporting an advance in chip making that could increase the speed of semiconductors and reduce their energy consumption. [C3.] TIME WARNER RIDES CABLE EARNINGS -- Time Warner, the world's largest media company, raised its 2007 forecast after surging cable television earnings helped first-quarter profit beat analysts' estimates. Net income declined 18 percent, and sales rose 9.2 percent. Profit was dragged down by a 27 percent decline at the film division, which failed to produce a hit to beat last year's ''Harry Potter'' DVD release. [C3.] SPRINT REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS -- The Sprint Nextel Corporation, the wireless carrier, reported a quarterly loss, fueling concern that the company was losing market share to its rivals. [C2.] ANOTHER NEW HIGH FOR THE DOW -- Shares jumped again on Wall Street, and the Dow Jones industrials past 13,200 for the first time after a strong reading on factory orders helped spur investor optimism. [C15.] WOLFOWITZ'S CONDUCT -- The World Bank committee investigating the conduct of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, are leaning toward finding that he violated the institution's rules against conflicts of interest when he arranged a pay raise and promotion for his companion, bank officials said. [A6.] WARNINGS ON SUICIDE -- The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug makers to add warnings to antidepressant medications, saying the drugs increase the risk of suicidal behavior in some young adults. [A17.] AHOLD SELLS U.S. FOODSERVICE -- The Netherlands-based grocery store operator Royal Ahold said that it had agreed to sell the distributor U.S. Foodservice to private equity firms for $7.1 billion. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. A federal judge signed off on a $1.53 billion jury verdict in favor of Alcatel-Lucent in a digital music patent dispute against Microsoft. Judge Rudi M. Brewster of Federal District Court in San Diego concluded that Microsoft's Windows Media Player software infringed on patents owned by Lucent Technologies, an American telecommunications equipment maker acquired last year by Alcatel of France. (AP)

The Shade Store, an online retailer of moderately priced window treatments, now has a showroom at the Conran Shop in Manhattan. Samples of the company's entire line of shades, drapes and blinds will be available there, but only the more modern products will be on display, reflecting the Conran Shop's aesthetic, said Ian Gibbs, one of the Shade Store's owners.
GUNDELL--Peter F. September 28, 1925-May 3, 1997. 10 years ago today. Loved, remembered, and missed, now and always. The Gundell Family

To the Editor: David Brooks says all the Republican Party needs to cure what ails it is something or someone unorthodox enough to ignite the public's interest (''Grim Old Party,'' column, April 29). He then claims that my boss, Dr. James Dobson, limits the free exercise of unorthodoxy in social policy by ''whacking'' anyone who proposes it. Balderdash.

The Security Council has ruled that 700 former Bosnian police officers dismissed by United Nations police trainers after the 1992-1995 civil war for misconduct or alleged involvement in war crimes can reapply for law enforcement work, though not necessarily the same jobs they had. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador to the United Nations, president of the council in April, said in a letter to Bosnian authorities that the country's standards for recruitment and selection were now acceptable and that individuals could regain police jobs as long as they met those standards. In recent years, 260 of the officers have protested their firings, saying they were guilty only of minor misconduct. Mr. Jones Parry said that his letter should not be interpreted as guaranteeing reinstatement. WARREN HOGE

FISHMAN-Stuart 72, ended his 11-year odyssey into worlds unknown, dying peacefully on May 1, with thoughts of his unwavering Ellie giving him final peace. He will be remembered for his ever-caring soul, the incarnation of a gentle man, by his adoring wife Eleanor, his sons Robert and David and their wives Susan and Nancy, his grandchildren Daniel, Jack, Matthew, Emily and Benjamin, his sister Jacqueline and husband Gerald, and scores of extended family and friends whom he touched and cared for ceaselessly. His pain over, the world can finally mourn him and honor the kind and graceful years he shared with us all. We have lost a patriarch, a tireless community servant, and a selfless spirit who those left behind can hope to emulate. Funeral services will be held at 12:30pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Donations can be made to Stuart's most passionate cause, Friends of the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library, 1125 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 11557 $(6$)FISHMAN--Stuart. Finally the suffering is over! You always set an example for me on how to live one's life -family first, caring for friends and concern for the community. It's easy for me to understand why I was so proud that you were by big brother. I will always love you, miss you and think of you everyday. Jackie Kaminsky

A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the Dutch designer Tord Boontje misidentified the work shown in an accompanying photograph. It was the 7-by-11-inch brass-plated steel panel called ''Ivy 1,'' which sells for $59, not a curtain made of Tyvek called ''Until Dawn.''

A books column in Weekend on Friday, about several books on Shakespeare released to coincide with his birthday last month, referred incorrectly to the porter's actions in ''Macbeth.'' He opens the gate; he does not knock on it.

In an effort to protest the elimination of the position of book review editor at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, the National Book Critics Circle, which represents around 700 book reviewers, and some local booksellers are organizing a demonstration in front of the newspaper's offices in Atlanta this morning at 10. Readers, booksellers and critics are invited to join a ''Read-In,'' bringing their favorite books to read in front of the paper's offices on Marietta Street. As part of a newsroomwide reorganization, the newspaper recently consolidated the job of the book review editor, held for the last nine years by Teresa Weaver, under a new post coordinating movies, music and books coverage. ''Without an official champion for books within the paper, the quality of books coverage is endangered!'' reads an announcement on the National Book Critics Circle's Web site. MOTOKO RICH

My colleague Dennis Overbye has started working out the logistics of getting to Gliese 581c, the Goldilocks planet (not too hot, not too cold) that's the best prospect yet for extraterrestrial life. But could we expect to find intelligent beings there? Since we haven't detected any electronic signs of life from that neighborhood, are the prospects grim of finding anyone at home?
Kunal Sah, 13, hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will bring attention to the plight of his parents, who were deported to India.
Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.
How must it feel to drive for Honda's Formula One team? First of all, you're saddled with the gnarliest livery on the grid, which wouldn't matter so much if it were fast.

Certified used cars have become popular with buyers over the past five years, offering reassurance from manufacturers that consumers won't get stuck with a lemon. But Christopher Jensen, who wrote about certified pre-owned programs for The Times, found some consumers who discovered that certification did not protect them entirely.

E-mail is cheap and instantaneous, meaning we get deluged with messages about the candidates' thoughts on just about everything -- especially each other. E-mail has become the weapon of choice in the war to win over the netroots and anti-war grassroots.
Jennifer Kohns and Gregory Rathe speak of meeting on motorcycle night at a Chelsea bar, and then riding in a direct line to the altar.

Microsoft and Yahoo are in talks about a joint venture or some other form of cooperation, according to people briefed on the talks. The discussions are part of a continuing dialogue that the two companies have been holding for more than a year, but are still in preliminary stages, these people say.

I had an interesting note from a woman in Boulder named Rachel who put up a green "Save Darfur" sign on her lawn. Her home-owner association has ordered her to take it down. She sent out an open letter:
Mortgages are suddenly hard to get. And that is why those hoping that the real estate decline is almost over should not take comfort from the fact that mortgage loan applications are strong.

Calling for quick action on enabling legislation for his long-range growth plan for the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today invoked the ill-fated past of the Second Avenue Subway and other major transit projects that did not survive shifts in the city's political and financial winds.
[Update | 8:56 AM ET No storm, just calm. No new high-profile names were dropped in a TV interview with a woman accused of running a Washington-area prostitution ring, The Associated Press reported.]

The journalistic standards spelled out in The Times's 1999 "Guidelines on Our Integrity" are a supplement to the paper's "Ethical Journalism" handbook of 2004, which is a more complete compilation of ethics rules for news staffers. I think readers may find that the specificity of the 1999 guidelines makes them particularly interesting.
News flash from the White House: President Bush is not "the commander guy" after all.
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Apr. 29 column, "All the President's Press."
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's May 4 column, "The Aussie 'Big Dry.'"

About two years ago, the state's Lobbying Commission settled with Syracuse University over gifts the school had made to various state officials with which it did business. One of those officials was Jeffrey Lovell, at the time a senior policy adviser to then-Gov. George E. Pataki, now an aide to Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, both of them Republicans.

Rupert Murdoch's bombshell $5 billion bid for Dow Jones has a lot of legal types talking make-up. More specifically, they're talking about Revlon, the subject of a 1985 ruling that helped define a corporate board's duties when a company is up for sale. Dow Jones, like The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has a dual-class share structure that gives majority voting power to its controlling family and insulates it from the whims of Wall Street. But the Bancroft family's initial resistance to News Corp.'s overture raises questions. What are the board's responsibilities when a controlling family rejects offers that minority shareholders would jump at? In particular, how do the so-called Revlon duties play into these situations?

Consolidated Edison today filed an application with the New York State Public Service Commission to raise electricity rates. Starting next April, the typical residential customer would pay 17 percent more, while the typical business would pay 10.7 percent more.
Author Sara Davidson talks to two medical scientists about how the body ages and the research on trying to extend our healthy life span.

He planted a vineyard; and he drank of the wine, and became drunk, and lay uncovered in his tent. And Taylor, 16, the daughter of Hasselhoff, who once starred on "Baywatch," saw the drunken nakedness of her father.

John Gambling, who plays host to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg every Friday on his WABC talk show, said today that City Council members have called the proposed water rate increase "just another tax." What did the mayor think of that? Here's a rough transcript of Mr. Bloomberg's reply:
You're about to meet a guy who's already had two killer ideas.

For most out-of-towners fond of a porch swing, a beach blanket or a wandering Sunday stroll, the phrase "New York Minute" has come to mean a peculiarly local delirium of impatience that results in the shrinking of time itself.

With the Motorola proxy showdown set for Monday, billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn appears to have a new ally. ClearBridge Advisors, a money manager owned by brokerage firm Legg Mason, said it would support his bid for a seat on the cellphone maker's board -- something the company has adamantly opposed in a series of increasingly hard-edged announcements. "Given recent events at the company, we believe it is in the best interest of all shareholders to have a new representative on the board," ClearBridge said in a press release. The firm did not say which "events" it had in mind, but Motorola has been struggling mightly in the past few months. In March, it slashed its revenue forecasts announced a management shake-up.

As leaders from about 60 nations gathered at a conference in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt, on Iraq's future, American and Iranian officials have been watched closely for any signs of direct dealings. Those signs have been trickling out all week in the careful language of diplomacy.

It happens every spring: The Mets sign a second baseman in the off-season. He struggles early on. And then, because of injury, he slides into the starting role and delivers key hit after key hit. Last year, it was Jose Valentin. Everyone had given up hope on him after his miserable first six weeks. This time around, it is Damion Easley, who replaced the injured Valentin at second base.

Updated. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has wrapped up his weekly radio discussion with John Gambling on WABC. They started taking calls near the end -- starting with a guy on a cellphone who said he was in (near?) the Holland Tunnel. Subject: cost of the mayor's congestion pricing proposal. The second and last caller asked if Mr. Bloomberg would support an anti-war protest in the city. Mr. Bloomberg focused on safety and security issues in his reply.
Coming on the market in two months is perhaps the most state-of-the-art house to ever be built in central London.
Is Abu Ayyub al-Masri, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq, dead or alive?
The boss is not all powerful, particularly at a proud institution where others have their own power bases.
The wide-open nature of the campaign for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination is reinforced by the disparate reactions among conservative journalists and bloggers to last night's debate.

When our architects, Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, met with us to review preliminary sketches, they had three designs for us to consider. The first was a two-part house that Paul loved but that was large, expensive to build and, in my view, provided a little too much privacy.

The terrorist known as "Carlos the Jackal" will stand trial once again in France, a judge announced today. This time, he faces charges in attacks that killed 12 people from 1982 to 1983. A European news site reports that one of the three attacks allegedly targeted Jacques Chirac, who was then mayor of Paris. If he's convicted, the punishment will be a moot point: Carlos is already serving a life sentence.
While the candidates were prepping for the debate, the staffs and surrogates were prepping for the debate about the debate that is the spin cycle.
In the West Wing, the talk was of negotiations with Syria, but the East Wing bustled with activity in anticipation of a state dinner for Queen Elizabeth II.
This debut feature by the filmmaking team of Dominique Abel, Fiona Gordon and Bruno Romy earns two adjectives that rarely go together: breezy and bold.
There's another media megadeal in the air.
So what would Rupert Murdoch do if his $5 billion bid to buy Dow Jones comes to pass?

British music group EMI, home to Robbie Williams and Coldplay, said on Friday it had received a number of takeover approaches, following a report that private equity firm One Equity Partners had joined the list of suitors.
Unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent in April, and employers added the fewest number of jobs since 2004.
CVC Capital Partners and PAI Partners offered 12.8 billion euros ($17.4 billion) for Altadis on Friday, topping Imperial Tobacco Group's bid for the Spanish maker of Gauloises cigarettes.
The vivid sense of time and place is the best thing about the initially promising, ultimately irritating psychological thriller “Civic Duty.”
“Race You to the Bottom,” about a pair of thoroughly unlikable 20-somethings, is self-consciously edgy and romantically limp.

Federal authorities arrested a Credit Suisse investment banker on Thursday and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.

Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.

UBS's announcement Thursday that it would shutter its hedge fund following losses at the unit was an embarrassment both for the bank and for John P. Costas, who gave up his post as chief executive of investment banking to run the hedge fund for the company.
May 4 - At the Republican debate, many of the running themes provided a window into the party's ideological ferment.

A former partner in New York law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad, accused by the government of paying illegal kickbacks to class-action clients, has asked a federal court in Los Angeles to dismiss the fraud charges against him. The motion could undermine much of the government's case against Milberg Weiss, The Los Angeles Times noted.

Starbucks chairman and founder Howard Schultz, through his venture capital firm, has made a strategic investment decision that is rare, if not unprecedented, The Red Herring reports. He put money into two companies with opposing missions: one that promotes so-called typosquatting, the buying of Internet domain names that closely resemble big brand names, and another that combats it.

Fengo, a mobile social network, announced on Thursday that it has raised $5.7 million in its first round of venture capital financing, led by Trilogy Equity Partners. Other investors included Khosla Ventures and Index Ventures.
“The Flying Scotsman,” which tells the story of cyclist Graeme Obree, is a conventional underdog sports movie that should have been much more gripping.

Television broadcaster Ion Media Networks on Thursday approved a takeover offer from NBC Universal and hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, despite three opposing board members and threats from a dissident group of shareholders.

Macquarie Bank and its partners said shareholders owning 36 percent of Qantas Airways, Australia's largest airline, have agreed to their A$11.1 billion ($9.1 billion) takeover offer, due to expire Friday. The buyout will fail unless the group reaches 50 percent by 7 p.m. in Sydney Friday. The bidders held about 33 percent of the airline yesterday, they said in a statement.

It was curtains for AMC Entertainment's market debut, as the theater chain's owners yanked its planned $789-million initial public offering from the stock market Thursday rather than cut the proposed share price in response to tepid investor demand at its asking price.

Radio network Westwood One has tapped investment bank UBS to identify potential buyers in anticipation of putting itself on the block next month, The New York Post reported. Westwood One is apparently waiting for shareholder approval for its pending content syndication deal with CBS Radio, tentatively targeted for May 15, before it formalizes an auction.
A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group is in takeover discussions with ABN Amro Holding, after last week saying it may launch a $98 billion hostile bid for the Dutch bank.
“The Treatment” is a movie with its heart and head in the right place. Too bad its aesthetic sensibilities and technical coordinates are not as well situated.

The New York Post notes that Friday is the deadline for Henry Kravis to receive final offers in the wild auction for Primedia Enthusiast Group, a process that has gotten a lot more complicated now that two potential suitors -- tabloid publisher American Media and the firm owned by billionaire supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle -- are reportedly in merger talks of their own.
Interactive Brokers Group late Thursday priced its initial public offering at $30.01 per share, near the high end of the expected range, raising roughly $1.2 billion.
Tony Hayward's honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.
Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.

Former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois wrapped up three grueling days on the witness stand Thursday with an emotional denial that he had approved millions of dollars in payments now at the heart of a racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black.

Since their extradition from Britain in July, three London bankers - known as the NatWest three - have been living in a peculiar limbo, as they await trial in Houston his fall on charges stemming from the collapse of Enron.
The Paper Mill Playhouse, which has been struggling with a $2.8 million shortfall, said its fund-raising campaign had reached the $1 million mark.
Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, acquired 37 subsidiaries of the bankrupt Yukos oil company at an auction on Thursday, expanding Rosneft's already large footprint in the industry.

In announcement that took Canada's financial industry by surprise, Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.
HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the world's largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hanson's stock price.

Benedict XVI travels on Wednesday to Brazil, in his first trip as pope to Latin America, home to nearly half the world’s Catholics. He arrives at a time of paradox for the church there. With Catholicism in decline in Europe, the developing world is seen as the future of the church. Yet the church in Latin America faces many challenges – which Benedict is expected to address in his four days in Brazil.

It is amazing how much of the show’s comedy from the ’90s holds up.
What I'm wearing now, the platform wedge sandal, Burt's Bees and more.
It was a long day in Texas, but the Yankees won't complain. Since that homer by Hairston, they grabbed back the lead to win Game 1, 4-3, and then cruised in the second game, 5-2.

The first Republican presidential debate between a field of 10 presidential hopefuls highlighted a party in flux as it struggles to figure out how to retain the White House for a third consecutive term. While several of the candidates invoked Ronald Reagan, a few tried to distance themselves from President Bush on Iraq.
The essence of Maui: crystal blue water, big surf, emerald fairways and brilliant sunsets.
Home to Honolulu and Waikiki, Oahu offers visitors and second-home owners a quintessential Hawaiian experience.
If ever a movie had a case of the blues and the blahs, it’s “Spider-Man 3,” a sequel that is fizzled rather than fizzy.
“Paris Je T’Aime” could be described as a cinematically literate travel brochure. But the Paris we see is not so prettified that it looks and feels unreal.
Even though “Lucky You” is sometimes dull and generally thin, there is something winning about the movie’s genial lack of ambition.

Manny Ramírez stood and admired his second homer of the game as it flew into the right-center-field bleachers in the eighth inning to help the Boston Red Sox to an 8-7 victory against the Seattle Mariners last night at Fenway Park.
The utility asked state regulators for permission to raise electricity rates substantially in New York City and most of Westchester County, starting next April.
The outcome was a sharp rebuke to Tony Blair and an embarrassing debut for Gordon Brown, a Scot who is expected to become Britain’s next prime minister.
The alleged cell of smugglers procured powerful, armor piercing bombs and other weapons from Iran, the military said.
Pope Benedict XVI met today with Mohammad Khatami, who spoke earlier in the day about the “very deep” wounds between Muslims and Christians.
The world will need to divert from today’s main energy sources within a few decades, the top body studying climate change has concluded.
Israeli officials say that some of the American ideas, a set of modest goals to improve relations between Israel and the Palestinians, are unlikely to be implemented.
Golden State became the first No. 8 seed to beat a No. 1 seed in an N.B.A. seven-game series, dismissing Dallas in Game 6 on Thursday night.
The Yankees survived injuries, a firing and a rainout to win three games in Texas and nudge their record closer to .500.
Damion Easley smoked a three-run home run in the ninth inning, as the Mets stomped the Arizona Diamondbacks for their 11th consecutive victory at Chase Field.
If ever there was an event that cried out for name tags, it was Thursday night’s Republican debate.

A 1-year-old boy whose father died in Iraq weeks before he was born was killed yesterday afternoon after he was accidentally run over by his mother’s sport utility vehicle near their home in the Bronx, according to the police and relatives.

A state agency that advocates for mentally ill people has sued New York City in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, alleging that psychiatric patients at Kings County Hospital Center endure squalid conditions and inhumane treatment.

A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani — not Senator John McCain — made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Friday about the spouses of the French presidential candidates referred incorrectly to the source of a 1995 quote by Cécilia Sarkozy, wife of the conservative candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, who said: “I don’t see myself as a first lady. That bores me. I am not politically correct.” She spoke in an interview with a French television magazine, not on a television show.

A picture caption on Tuesday with a theater review of “Jump!” and “Realism,” at the Kirk Theater on 42nd Street, misspelled the surname of an actress shown in “Jump!” She is Meredith Zinner, not Ziner.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the reduction in space for book reviews in some newspapers in the United States, and the emergence of Web sites that offer reviews, misstated the title held at Touchstone Fireside, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, by Trish Todd, who commented on the changes. It is editor-in-chief, not publisher.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a crackdown on gun violence in Baltimore referred incorrectly to the trend in the rate of violent crime in the city. While shootings are up 36 percent this year compared with last year, violent crime — also including rape, robbery and assault — is down 15 percent. It is not rising.

A front-page article yesterday about an online revolt against efforts by a trade organization to remove a secret antipiracy code from the Web erroneously included one Web site among those that received requests to remove the code. Wikipedia did not receive such a letter.

A picture in the auto sales chart in Business Day on Wednesday was published in error. It showed a Nissan Altima Coupe, which is not on the market yet, rather than the Altima sedan, which had a 12.4 percent drop in sales in April. (The error first occurred in the sales chart on Jan. 4.).

A listing on Wednesday about the amount of money presidential candidates raised in Texas during the first three months of this year omitted two Republican candidates. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, raised $1,054,050, placing him fourth on a list of 17 candidates. Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, raised $11,225, ranking him 14th.

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about plans to condense versions of “Charlie’s Angels” into three-and-a-half- to five-minute episodes misstated the length of the original program, including one episode in which the cast was shown solving a crime. The program was 60 minutes, not 30.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the victim’s testimony in the Manhattan trial of Peter Braunstein, a former magazine writer accused of sexual abuse and kidnapping, misidentified the publication from which the victim, a 36-year-old woman, resigned. It was W, not Women’s Wear Daily.
A music review on Tuesday of the group Opus 21, at Symphony Space, misspelled the given name of the composer of “Thaw,” a work the group played. He is Mark Dancigers, not Marc.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on April 24 about mock elections held in Bhutan as a practice for parliamentary elections next year incorrectly described the status of King Jigme Singye Wangchuck. He abdicated late last year as part of his effort to move the country toward modernity; he did not recently announce plans to do so.

A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani — not Senator John McCain — made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed into law a prison overhaul that adds more than 50,000 beds to a crowded system, even as critics warned that it failed to solve the most pressing long-term problems. Lawmakers reached the $7.8 billion deal last week in the hope of satisfying federal judges who have threatened to release inmates early if the state failed to address crowding. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, said the plan contained provisions that would help break a cycle in which 70 percent of released convicts returned to prison after committing further crimes or violating their parole.

A group of Klamath River tribal leaders, commercial salmon fishermen, owners of recreational businesses and the Klamath Riverkeeper Group sued in federal court in Northern California on Wednesdaysaying two PacifiCorp dams on the river cause widespread blooms of toxic algae. The suit contends that the reservoirs behind the Iron Gate and Copco Dams in Northern California threaten salmon fishing and pose a health threat to humans. The suit wants PacifiCorp to stop operating the dams in a way that causes the blooms. A PacifiCorp spokeswoman, Jan Mitchell, said the company did not comment on pending litigation.

Former workers at the now-closed Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant won a partial victory when an advisory board recommended making it easier for them to win compensation for work-related cancers, but only if they worked at the plant from 1952 to 1958. The panel recommended that health experts study people who worked at the plant after 1958 to see if they should be included. The recommendations go to the federal Health and Human Services Department. The plant, northwest of Denver, made triggers for nuclear weapons.

President Bush said he intended to nominate a federal budget analyst, Kerry N. Weems, to run Medicare and Medicaid. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Weems would become administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, succeeding Dr. Mark B. McClellan, who resigned in October. Mr. Weems, 50, has spent almost half his life at the Department of Health and Human Services. Since early 2005, he has been deputy chief of staff for Michael O. Leavitt, secretary of health and human services. Mr. Bush also announced that he planned to nominate an aide, Tevi D. Troy, as deputy secretary of health and human services. Mr. Troy, 40, was deputy director of policy for the Bush-Cheney campaign in 2004 and now coordinates the president’s Domestic Policy Council.

Five men accused of belonging to a self-styled militia were indicted Wednesday on federal explosives and weapons charges after raids that uncovered an arsenal of homemade hand grenades and firearms, the authorities said. The men remained in jail without bail after a federal agent testified this week that they were planning a machine-gun attack on Mexicans. Defense lawyers indicated they would fight the charges against the men: Raymond K. Dillard, 46, Adam L. Cunningham, 41, and James R. McElroy, 20, all of Collinsville; Bonnell Hughes, 57, of Crossville; and Randall G. Cole, 22, of Gadsden.

Prosecutors say that during the 13 hours Peter Braunstein held a woman captive and sexually assaulted her in her Chelsea apartment in October 2005, he used chloroform, a gun, a military-style mask and other menacing paraphernalia to terrorize her.

Clear Channel Communications, the nation’s largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.
Their starter for Saturday’s game against the Diamondbacks is to be determined, but the Mets seem to be inclined to bolster their bullpen for a few games.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 3 — Word began rippling through the small Onondaga reservation on the outskirts of the city last fall: a music teacher at the elementary school had been suspended, charged with sexually abusing two of his female students.
starter, T. J. Ford, left Tuesday night’s Game 5 after he injured his neck. Backup, José Calderón, sprained his right ankle in the closing seconds of Game 5.

HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the world’s largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hanson’s stock price. “HeidelbergCement is currently reviewing its options with respect to its interest in Hanson, including the possibility of seeking to acquire the company,” HeidelbergCement said. Acquiring Hanson would increase HeidelbergCement’s revenue by more than two-thirds, add operations in Australia and bolster its range of products like crushed rock, concrete pipes and bricks.

The Supreme Court of Canada rejected an appeal from Wal-Mart Canada over efforts to unionize another store in Quebec. As is always the case, the high court offered no reasons for its decision. The court’s move appears to open the way for the automatic certification of a store in Gatineau, a city across a river from Ottawa. “We’re disappointed but not surprised, because the Supreme Court rarely hears cases like this,” said Yanik Deschênes, a spokesman for Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart wanted a court order requiring that Quebec’s labor board conduct a secret ballot of employees. The United Food and Commercial Workers has asked for automatic certification under Quebec law based on the number of union membership cards it signed at the outlet.

Nortel Networks reported a smaller first-quarter loss as sales rose and the company booked an accounting gain related to a shareholder lawsuit. Nortel, which makes telephone equipment, said it lost $103 million, or 23 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31. That was better than the loss of $171 million, or 39 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The company said its net loss in the quarter included a $54 million gain related to an adjustment to the share portion of a class-action settlement with its investors.

Negotiators for the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Union’s telecommunications ministers agreed to a compromise that could limit mobile phone roaming charges for 450 million European consumers by the end of the summer. The agreement would cap roaming charges at 0.45 euro a minute for outgoing calls, 0.20 euro for incoming and 0.29 for wholesale, excluding value-added taxes.

Unilever, which owns brands like Knorr soup, Dove soap and Ben & Jerry’s ice cream, reported an increase of just 1 percent in first-quarter profit, but underlying growth beat expectations. The company said net profit increased to 1.1 billion euros ($1.46 billion), from 1.06 billion euros a year earlier. Sales climbed 2.1 percent, to 3.54 billion euros ($4.82 billion). Underlying sales, excluding acquired or discontinued businesses and factoring out currency fluctuations, advanced 5.7 percent, beating the company’s target of 5 percent growth. Patrick Cescau, the chief executive, above, said that the company faced “significant headwind from rising agricultural commodity costs,” which might require price increases. But he said he was confident that the combined benefit of internal growth and improved efficiency would put the company in a good position to reach its objectives for 2007.

Belgian French-language newspapers were back on Google after agreeing that the search engine can link to their Web sites, the first signs of a thaw in a copyright dispute. But neither has so far settled a major part of the dispute: the use of newspaper article links on Google News. In February, Google lost a lawsuit filed by the newspapers, forcing it to remove headlines and links to news articles posted on its Google News service and stored in its search engine’s cache without the copyright owners’ permission. In a joint statement, Google and the newspapers’ copyright group Copiepresse said they had decided that Google could once again list the newspapers on the search engine.

Norilsk Nickel of Russia bid 5.3 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) for the nickel and gold producer LionOre Mining International, topping an earlier bid of 4.6 billion Canadian dollars ($4.1 billion) made by Xstrata of Switzerland. Norilsk said its bid was 21.50 Canadian dollars a share, all in cash, higher than Xstrata’s bid of 18.50 Canadian dollars. Analysts said they expected Xstrata, based in Zug, Switzerland, to respond with a new bid. LionOre, based in Toronto, has operations in Australia, Botswana and South Africa. Norilsk, based in Moscow, is one of the world’s largest producers of nickel and palladium.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s proposal sharpens her own political positioning by confronting the White House.
Officials in other states said Florida’s move would only create more chaos around the nominating process.
The candidates offered contrasts on an array of social issues in a debate that highlighted a party in flux.

The embattled University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has hired a new general counsel, Lester Aron. Mr. Aron is a member of the Newark law firm Sills, Cummis, Epstein & Gross. He represents about three dozen New Jersey school districts and serves as a trustee of Kean University. Mr. Aron replaces Vivian Sanks King, who resigned in 2005. A federal monitor is overseeing the operations of the university under an agreement with the United States attorney’s office that allowed the school to avoid federal prosecution for Medicaid fraud. The monitor, Herbert J. Stern, criticized the university in July for its delay in hiring in a new general counsel.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Norwich has agreed to pay $300,000 of a $1.2 million settlement to resolve a sex abuse claim dating to 1992, according to its lawyer. The diocese will pay the money to settle a claim by Joshua Hethcote, of Coventry, who filed a lawsuit in 2005 against the diocese, claiming he had been sexually assaulted by the Rev. Eugene Orteneau of St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Storrs. The Society of Jesus, the clerical order to which Father Orteneau belonged, will pay the remaining $900,000 to settle the claim, said the lawyer, Joseph Sweeney. In the lawsuit, Mr. Hethcote, 31, said he was assaulted in 1992, when he was about 16 and was a member of a church youth group. His lawsuit said the diocese knew about the assaults and disregarded numerous complaints. The settlement is the third in eight months by the diocese, which has paid a total of $3.4 million to settle the claims. Three other lawsuits are pending.

A legislative ethics panel yesterday agreed to investigate whether a state assemblyman from Hudson County violated conflict-of-interest laws when state grant money was given to a day care program headed by his estranged wife. Assemblyman Brian Stack, left, a Democrat who is also the mayor of Union City, said he welcomed an investigation by the Legislative Ethics Committee. Mr. Stack’s wife, Katia, heads Union City Day Care, which has received at least two $100,000 state grants in recent years.

A Queens man has been arraigned on charges of killing his girlfriend in Jackson Heights last month after she tried to break up with him, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Shane Tomlinson, 20, of Springfield Gardens, was charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of Chameka Miller, 18, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Tomlinson shot Ms. Miller April 15 after a confrontation at her home on 77th Street.

A springer spaniel that overturned his owner’s fishing boat in a Putnam County lake swam to shore and brought help to rescue him, fire officials said yesterday. The dog, named Bucky, was in a small boat on Lake Gilead with his owner, Al Lotrecchiano, 72, on Wednesday afternoon when the dog put his paw on the side of the boat, flipping it over about 400 yards offshore, officials said. Bucky swam to shore and ran to his lakeshore home, barking, said Darryl Johnson, the Carmel fire chief. About the same time, a neighbor called 911 after hearing Mr. Lotrecchiano’s cries for help; when rescuers responded, Mr. Lotrecchiano’s wife, Dimmy, told them that Bucky had returned without her husband, and the group returned to the lake, where they found Mr. Lotrecchiano. “Thank God the dog did what the dog did,” said Mr. Lotrecchiano, who was treated for hypothermia at a hospital.

The former postmaster of Dover pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to misusing more than $10,000 in Postal Service funds, federal prosecutors said. The postmaster, Phillip J. Hall, 51, of East Orange, admitted that he had a postal worker do five weeks of carpentry work at the home of his ex-wife while the worker was on Postal Service time. Mr. Hall also said he allowed five employees to donate vacation time to his ex-wife, and then falsified their attendance records to show that they were working at times when they were not on duty. As a result, his ex-wife — who is also a postal worker — got an extra two months of leave, he admitted. He also admitted taking cash in exchange for steering business to a contractor.

A Brooklyn man was arraigned yesterday on charges including burglary and assault in connection with a police chase and bus crash that injured eight children and four adults, prosecutors said. The man, Thomas Hernandez, 43, of De Kalb Avenue, was held without bail after his arraignment in Criminal Court, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He is charged with crashing into a school bus, which rolled onto its side, on Douglaston Parkway in Little Neck on Tuesday while fleeing the police, Mr. Brown said. The police said officers were pursuing Mr. Hernandez after he burglarized an officer’s house in Flushing and stole his sport utility vehicle.

An Elmwood Park woman has been charged with aggravated manslaughter for shaking her 3-month-old baby to death, Bergen County authorities said yesterday. According to prosecutors, the police received an emergency call from the apartment of the woman, Laura Devita, 24, on Feb. 11 and arrived to find her son unconscious and not breathing. The infant was taken to Hackensack University Medical Center and pronounced dead that afternoon. An investigation revealed that Ms. Devita had repeatedly shaken the baby in an attempt to make him stop crying, the authorities said. She was ordered held in $50,000 bail yesterday and ordered to have no contact with children unless supervised by child welfare workers.

Acting Governor Richard J. Codey signed legislation yesterday clearing the way for the expansion of two regional airports. The bill will allow the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to sign a 93-year lease of Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and expand the airport’s operations to ease congestion at other New York area airports. The legislation, which also allows for expansion at an airport in New Jersey, was needed under the rules that created the Port Authority, a bistate agency run by New York and New Jersey that controls the region’s biggest airports. About 300,000 passengers used Stewart Airport last year, and authority officials have said it could expand to handle 1.5 million passengers annually.

A highway patrolman who was parked on the shoulder of the Long Island Expressway was seriously injured early yesterday when his patrol car was struck by another car whose driver was drunk, the police said. The patrolman, Officer Edwin Martinez, suffered head injuries and was taken to Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, where he was in serious but stable condition last night. Officer Martinez had been patrolling a construction zone on the expressway, near Exit 43 at South Oyster Bay Road in Syosset, shortly after midnight when he pulled over a car driven by Andrew Mericle, 27, of Oyster Bay, for speeding, the police said. A car driven by Yookyung Kim, 19, of Bayside, Queens, rear-ended the officer’s car, which then hit Mr. Mericle’s car, the police said. Mr. Mericle and Mr. Kim were treated for minor injuries at the scene. Mr. Kim was charged with driving while intoxicated and arraigned in First District County Court in Hempstead. Mr. Kim’s license was suspended, and bail was set at $15,000 bond or $5,000 cash.

It is no small task to pass the time at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison in Ossining, N.Y., for male criminal offenders considered among the most dangerous in New York. But for nearly two decades, prosecutors say, one convicted drug kingpin has found a novel use for his time — dabbling in island real estate.

The Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus, who late last year announced plans to form a party to rescue the country from confrontational politics, said he had decided to give up the plan, “bowing to the practical aspects of the situation.” He won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize for helping poor women escape poverty by offering micro-credit through his Grameen Bank. Mr. Yunus issued his statement after he met Fakhruddin Ahmed, head of the army-backed interim government. Mr. Yunus said he felt that the interim government, which had restored relative calm in the country after deadly political violence last year, would be able to steer Bangladesh to progress.

Amadou Toumani Touré has been re-elected with an absolute majority of votes cast in Sunday’s election, according to official results. Foreign observers said that overall the vote was free and fair. Mr. Touré first seized power in a 1991 coup and won international acclaim for handing over to an elected president the following year. He made a comeback as a civilian in 2002 and has since worked to secure foreign investments and improve agriculture and transportation.

A special appeals panel in Athens upheld the 2003 terrorism conviction of Alexandros Yiotopoulos, who led a Marxist terrorist group for 27 years, starting in 1975 with the assassination of the Athens C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch. The court upheld sentences for 12 other members of the November 17 terrorist organization but cleared two additional suspects because the crimes they were convicted of had fallen outside the statute of limitations. Named after a 1973 student uprising that was crushed by the tanks of a military junta that ruled Greece, November 17 killed 23 people, including American and British diplomats and military officers. It disbanded after a botched bomb attack in 2003.

Police officials barred journalists from marching to commemorate World Press Freedom Day, saying it was prohibited under an emergency decree banning political demonstrations. Journalists had planned 10 separate marches throughout the nation to underscore what they say are increasing restrictions on the news media and a growing number of arrests, jailings and attacks involving journalists.

Fugitive army recruits tried to hijack a plane to the United States and killed an army lieutenant colonel they took hostage in the failed attempt, the Interior Ministry said. Two escaped recruits were arrested after the aborted hijacking. It began in the pre-dawn hours when they commandeered a bus carrying several passengers to get to a plane on the tarmac, said a ministry statement. Others who had been held hostage on the bus were unharmed, it added. The two arrested were among three army recruits who escaped from their base on Sunday after killing a fellow soldier and wounding another, the ministry said. The third was captured earlier.

Five days before the restoration of power-sharing in Northern Ireland next Tuesday, the Ulster Volunteer Force, the oldest pro-British paramilitary group, said it was renouncing violence, in the latest sign of progress toward peace. The Protestant group said it was putting its arms “beyond reach” and stopping military training.
The Yankees need a pitcher for Monday, and Matt DeSalvo - who was taken off the 40-man roster in January - will make his major league debut.

Five soldiers were ambushed and killed in the western state of Michoacán late Tuesday during an anti-drug operation, a brazen sign that drug dealers are willing to fight the military as it tries to rid the state of narcotics, the authorities said. Heavily armed men, whom investigators believe to be drug-cartel henchmen, opened fire on the soldiers at 11:30 p.m. as they were driving in pickups through Carácuaro, 85 miles south of the capital, Morelia. One gunmen was also killed in the ensuing exchange of fire. President Felipe Calderón has sent more than 6,000 soldiers into the state as part of a crackdown on drug traffickers that has failed to slow the pace of gangland-style executions.
Stuart W. Bowen Jr. originated investigations of waste and corruption in Iraq that have repeatedly embarrassed the Bush administration.
Maintenance and construction was to resume on subway tracks and tunnels after workers had more than four days of safety review prompted by two deaths.
The long, fastidious reach of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia now extends to perhaps the riskiest industry of all: groceries.
Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.
Scientists hope a test for the variant will enable physicians to assess patients at risk more accurately.

ALBANY, May 3 — Alan Newton, a former bank teller from the Bronx, was freed from prison in 2006 after serving 22 years for a rape he did not commit. For more than a decade, Mr. Newton had asked the authorities to test his DNA against the physical evidence from the crime scene, only to be told that the evidence could not be found.
There was a rare direct conversation between representatives of the two antagonistic nations today at a conference on Iraq.
American officials denied claims from Iraqi officials that other leaders of the insurgent group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had been killed.
He was one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts and the only astronaut to fly in all three of NASA’s earliest manned space programs.
The banker is charged with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.
Judith Enck, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s deputy secretary for the environment, says she decided to work for Mr. Spitzer because she wanted to make rather than influence environmental policy.
To the Editor:.
The capricious system of tariffs that raise the price of goods are all too often based on outdated political considerations that defy logic and good sense.
Lawmakers should protect the positive aspects of campaign calls, while getting tough on their use as an election-season dirty trick.
Closing the door to family-based immigration would be unjust and unworkable, and a mockery of the values that conservatives profess.
Rupert Murdoch shared his opinions on The Wall Street Journal and on the family that owns the company.

ALBANY, May 3 — An upstate assemblyman was removed from his post as ranking member of the Assembly Committee on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse on Thursday after revelations that he slept at the home of a 21-year-old female intern last month after a night of heavy drinking.
If the United States attorney scandal has made one thing clear, it is that the riskiest job in the Bush administration is being a prosecutor investigating a Republican member of Congress.
In the series, Buffalo has converted only 3 of 25 chances, including 1 of 13 in two losses at Madison Square Garden.
The lawyer for the ousted radio host Don Imus said that he would file a $40 million lawsuit against CBS next week, accusing it of breach of contract.
Local leaders called a meeting in an effort to calm residents after a violent week.
The chief called an episode in which police clashed with immigration demonstrators the “worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years.”
Investigators are visiting food and pet food makers that use vegetable protein concentrates imported from China to make sure that the additives are not contaminated.
Democrats are fighting for a measure that would require intelligence agencies to produce a study on the effect of global climate change on national defense.
The bullpen blew a victory for Andy Pettitte for the third time this season, but the Yankees rallied to win the first game of a doubleheader.
The Cablevision Systems Corporation, which has agreed to be taken private by its controlling shareholders, reported slower first-quarter subscriber growth.
The top American commander in Afghanistan said he was investigating claims of civilian casualties a day after the Afghani president said such losses would not be tolerated.
Even as universities are agreeing not to accept cash incentives from student lenders, dozens of college alumni associations are taking payments from loan companies.
The House of Representatives voted to extend hate-crime protection to people victimized because of their sexuality, which may set up another veto showdown.
Lanny Bassham, does not play golf. He does not have a degree in sports psychology. But his appointment book has become crowded with the names of PGA Tour players.
Plans to open a public school dedicated to the study of the Arabic culture have become a test of tolerance.
After turning UBS’s investment bank into one of the elite on Wall Street, John P. Costas gave up the chief executive’s post to run a hedge fund for the company.
Recently, the rapper known as Busta Rhymes has been a regular on the police blotter.
Zarqa, Jordan, known as a cradle of Islamic militancy, is now a breeding ground for would-be jihadists.
President Bush said his threat would apply to any measures that “allow taxpayer dollars to be used for the destruction of human life.”
The payments, worth millions of dollars, are at the heart of a racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black.
Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is relying on a vast grass-roots network built by his constituents, whose boundless energy has driven recent economic growth.
Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash.
Three Democratic senators introduced a bill that would require brokers and lenders to act in the interest of borrowers.
Teuflesberg may not be the fastest or most talented horse in this year’s Derby. But he is clearly the biggest bargain.
Floyd Mayweather Sr., who nurtured his son’s career but is now estranged from him, will attend his son’s fight courtesy of tickets from his opponent, Oscar De La Hoya.
The services sector expanded at a faster pace than expected in April and productivity in the first quarter improved more than forecast.
Wal-Mart Stores disclosed for the first time its annual contributions to workers’ retirement accounts, profit sharing program and stock purchase plan.
CBS said that quarterly earnings fell about 6 percent but revenue still beat expectations with help from its publishing division, Simon & Schuster.
J. Robert Bradley’s deep, swooping, octave-leaping voice and charismatic presence made him one of gospel music’s most important figures.
Starbucks said Thursday that its fiscal second-quarter profits jumped 18 percent as the company opened 560 new stores in an aggressive global expansion.
No new cases of a serious brain infection have been reported among patients a multiple sclerosis drug since the government allowed it back onto the market.
Nine years after they led Toms River, N.J., to a Little League championship, Todd Frazier and Casey Gaynor are trying to lead Rutgers to the College World Series.
A federal appeals court has denied a request by the Internet phone company Vonage Holdings that it order a retrial in the patent infringement case brought against it by Verizon Communications.
Electronic Data Systems, the technology services company, reported a sharply higher quarterly profit as revenue from contracts increased.
Merchants worried after a three-alarm fire at Eastern Market, the social and commercial “town center” of Capitol Hill.
Queen Elizabeth II, on her first visit to the United States in more than 15 years, celebrated the 400th anniversary of the first permanent English colony in the New World.
Paul D. Wolfowitz said that he had helped arrange a generous pay and promotion package for his companion as “a settlement of her potential claims” if she sued for being relocated against her will.
The changes are intended to incorporate lessons from the World Trade Center collapse in revising a code whose origins date to the city’s early days.
Making their first playoff appearance since 1994, the Golden State Warriors have plenty of experience with losing. But they are still learning how to lose gracefully.
A handful of schools are abandoning one-to-one computing programs as educationally empty — and worse.
Three British men are awaiting trial in Houston this fall on charges stemming from the collapse of Enron.
Human rights groups are seeking to prevent the Canadian military from placing prisoners in Afghan custody after catching them in raids or in combat.

(Disney Channel) HIGH SCHOOL MUSICAL: THE CONCERT More than 100 million children, teenagers and (admit it) parents have watched “High School Musical” — in which a brainiac and a basketball player step out onstage and relegate the drama-club darlings to understudy oblivion — since the movie first hit the Disney Channel in January 2006. Its soundtrack was that year’s top-ranking album, with more than 3.7 million copies sold. And then came the concert tour, above, in which Vanessa Anne Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu, Monique Coleman and Drew Seeley strutted their triple-platinum stuff. This special ventures behind the scenes with the performers and some of the screaming concertgoing masses.

TOMPKINS--Harold. We mourn his passing. We will miss him enormously. The Club; The Walking Group $(6$)TOMPKINS--Harold, Justice, 74. Died of pneumonia, May 2nd, 2007. A very dedicated humanitarian, born in NYC, graduated from Syracuse University and Cornell Law School. Father of his loving son, Laurence Alan Fish Tompkins, and endeared husband of Frances Fish Tompkins for 48 years. A private practitioner and an Assistant NY State Attorney General in the Litigation Bureau, who represented the MTA during the 1980 transit strike. He was elected a Civil Court Judge in 1981 and became a Supreme Court Justice in 1986. He authored over 200 published opinions on cases involving the First Amendment, patients' rights to control their treatment and sanctions against frivolous lawsuits and governmental authority. He retired in 2003. A dedicated supporter of Bar Association activities, he was Executive V.P. of the Respect for Law Alliance, a Director of the Jewish Lawyers Guild, Chairman of The Young Lawyers Section of the NY State Bar Association and frequent lecturer at NY County Lawyers and NY State Trial Lawyers Associations. For many years he was a member of the Board of Governors of Harmonie Club and the Board of Directors at Park Ave. Synagogue. Services at 10am, Sunday May 6th, 2007, at Park Ave. Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York City. $(6$)TOMPKINS--Harold. The Directors, Officers and Trustees of The Jewish Guild for the Blind note with sorrow the death of Judge Harold Tompkins, husband of Frances Tompkins, an esteemed Trustee of The Guild. We extend our deepest sympathies to the family. Pauline Raiff, Bd. Chairman Alan R. Morse, Pres. & CEO

A year ago, some fateful missteps by Barbaro in the Preakness Stakes resulted in him shattering his right hind leg, eventually leading to him being euthanized in January. But the sad ending appears not to have swayed most horse racing fans about the safety of the sport.

Each time the Yankees won the World Series in the 1990s, they rolled past the Texas Rangers in the first playoff round, winning all their games at the Rangers' home ballpark. In this decade, the Yankees have never had a losing record here for a season. The way things are going, they may never lose here again. The Yankees swept a doubleheader at Rangers Ballpark on Thursday, winning by 4-3 in the afternoon and 5-2 at night. They have 10 consecutive victories in this stadium, and they probably wish they could stay.

Opens today in New York and selected cities Directed by Douglas Mackinnon 96 minutes ''A washing machine on wheels'' is the derisive description officials of the World Cycling Association give to the revolutionary racing bike designed by the Scottish cyclist Graeme Obree (Jonny Lee Miller) in ''The Flying Scotsman.'' In 1993 Mr. Obree broke the one-hour world record on his homemade contraption, built from scrap metal and washing-machine parts and nicknamed Old Faithful. The powers that be were not amused and frantically invented rules to try to disqualify him.

A picture in the auto sales chart in Business Day on Wednesday was published in error. It showed a Nissan Altima Coupe, which is not on the market yet, rather than the Altima sedan, which had a 12.4 percent drop in sales in April. (The error first occurred in the sales chart on Jan. 4.)

Frank Stella, known as a superstar painter, has always played with space in his art. In recent years his explorations have expanded. ''The Ship,'' a 2007 model for a pavilion made from Fiberglas and carbon fiber, is among the works included in ''Frank Stella: Painting Into Architecture,'' one of two Stella exhibitions (the other one, ''Frank Stella on the Roof,'' is upstairs and outdoors) that opened this week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Roberta Smith's review, Page 34.

GERSCHWER--Honorable Seymour, known as Sy, died peacefully at his home in Brooklyn on May 2, 2007. He was 82. A graduate of Brooklyn College and St. John's University School of Law, he was elected as a Civil Court Judge in 1984 and served as a Criminal Court Judge and Acting Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn for the entirety of his ten-year term. After his retirement in 1995 he continued to serve as a Judicial Hearing Officer; he worked in that capacity on April 24, his 82nd birthday, the week before his death. Prior to his election to the bench he had a successful career in the electronics industry and was a longtime civic leader. He is survived by his wife, Margaret, who was with him at the time of his death, sons Lawrence, Scott and David, daughters - in - law Barbara, Rorie and Mara, and grandchildren Stephanie, Jake, Adam, Steven, Benjamin and Caroline. There will be a service on Friday, May 4, 2007, at 11:30am at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

BINI--Mario Pio, died on April 26th, 2007, in NYC from lung cancer. Survived by son Michael Bini and son and daughter-in-law Mark and Christiane Cabot Bini, and former wife Katherine Bini (all of NYC), his sister Emma Bolognesi, brother Valerio Bolognesi, both of Bologna, Italy. A University of Bologna engineering graduate, Mario emigrated to the US in the 1960s and worked in the City's garment center for 40 years: first as a pattern maker, then fashion designer, later technical director. Mario, who had a passion for thoroughbreds, wine and all things family was Liz Claiborne Suits technical director at the time of his passing. The funeral is Friday, May 4, at 11am at St. Columba Church, 343 West 25th Street. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the AHRC NYC Foundation, 83 Maiden Lane, NY, NY 10038.

HAMILTON--Marcia Fuller, (54) died peacefully on May 2, 2007, at Greenwich Hospital with her four beloved daughters and her husband by her side. The dignity, courage and beauty she upheld during her battle with cancer have been an inspiration to us all. Born August 3, 1952, in Coronado, California, she was the youngest of four children born to Ruth and Captain Harold Fuller, USN Retired. She is survived by her three siblings, James Fuller of Orlando, Florida; Richard Fuller of Seattle, Washington; and Laura Fuller Bates of Hythe, England. Marcia spent her early years in Alexandria, Virginia, before moving to New York City. She was a television producer before her marriage to Peter Hamilton in 1982. A woman of great style and taste, Marcia was a world traveler living in Tokyo and London before settling with her family in Greenwich, Connecticut in 1991. Motherhood and family life were Marcia's calling, and nothing brought her greater pleasure than life with her four daughters Katie (23), Betsy (20), Charlotte (18), Lucy (8), and her husband Peter, whom she referred to as her hero during her illness. A gracious and beautiful woman, Marcia had a wonderful sense of warmth and humor that will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She lived her life with high standards that will remain in the hearts of her daughters forever. The Hamilton family would like to thank all of the care givers who attended to Marcia at home, Greenwich Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering these past two years and to the extended Greenwich community without whose endless support the family would not have survived. A Requiem Eucharist celebrating her life will be held at 10:30 am on Saturday, May 5, 2007, at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, in Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations in Marcia's memory may be made to the Oncology Department of Greenwich Hospital or to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.

President Bush said he intended to nominate a federal budget analyst, Kerry N. Weems, to run Medicare and Medicaid. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Weems would become administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, succeeding Dr. Mark B. McClellan, who resigned in October. Mr. Weems, 50, has spent almost half his life at the Department of Health and Human Services. Since early 2005, he has been deputy chief of staff for Michael O. Leavitt, secretary of health and human services. Mr. Bush also announced that he planned to nominate an aide, Tevi D. Troy, as deputy secretary of health and human services. Mr. Troy, 40, was deputy director of policy for the Bush-Cheney campaign in 2004 and now coordinates the president's Domestic Policy Council. ROBERT PEAR

POSTON--Tom. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts mourns the loss of its beloved alumnus Tom Poston, AADA Class of 1947, a virtuoso performer whose comedic talents charmed audiences for 60 years. The Academy communities in New York and Los Angeles extend their sincere condolences to his widow, Susanne Pleshette, and his three children, Francesca, Jason and Hudson. Samuel Davis, Chairman of the Board Roger Croucher, President and CEO James Warwick, President, Los Angeles Division

To the Editor: Reading Maureen Dowd's critique of George J. Tenet (''Better Never Than Late,'' column, May 2), you would think that back in February 2003 everything on the Iraqi threat was clear as could be. The fact is Mr. Tenet was only as good as the intelligence his agency was providing him.

To the Editor: Re ''Playing Chef in a Little Kitchen on the Shore'' (April 20): If Gary Sullivan and Mark Young married in 2005, why do you refer to Mr. Young as Mr. Sullivan's ''partner'' rather than his spouse? Using the former term tends to suggest that married same-sex couples are somehow less married than their different-sex counterparts, whom you would never call ''partners.'' Even such a seemingly benign distinction may foster a lingering sense of second-class citizenship that Times usage should not reinforce. Jeffrey S. Trachtman Brooklyn, N.Y.
WADLER--Scott Dr., died peacefully on April 28th after a long illness. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 6th, at the Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave. at 12:30 pm.

Liu Xiang of China, Félix Sánchez of the Dominican Republic and Bershawn Jackson of the United States, three of the world's leading male hurdlers, were entered yesterday in the Reebok Grand Prix on June 2 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. That meet and the Prefontaine Classic on June 10 in Eugene, Ore., are the most important international track competitions in the nation. Liu won the Olympic gold medal in the 110-meter hurdles in 2004 and set the world record, 12.88, seconds last July. Sánchez has won an Olympic gold medal and two world championships in the 400-meter hurdles. Jackson ranks second in the world in the 400 hurdles. FRANK LITSKY

Charles Burchfield is so lovely. This artist, who died in 1967, brought a visionary intensity to the depiction of pastoral scenes inspired by the landscape of his native Ohio, blending elements of Chinese scroll painting and the lessons of modernism. Later he painted the semirural environs of Buffalo after landing a job there as a designer for a wallpaper company. The splendid exhibition at the D C Moore Gallery represents both periods in his career, featuring a series of recently rediscovered, large-scale works in watercolor and charcoal. Most of them are composite constructions in which collages of additional strips of paper, or earlier paintings or parts of paintings and drawings, are included in an enlarged composition. (Above, Mr. Burchfield's ''Blue Dome of June.'') Artists have always extended and transformed drawings and paintings with additional sheets of paper and canvas. After all, it can be tough to contain an idea to a single square or a rectangle. But what distinguishes Mr. Burchfield's collage compositions is his peculiar brand of imagination. Charming, often in a childlike or naïve way, his paintings have a playful intensity reminiscent of the illustrative work of William Blake. Incandescent trees, rhapsodic sunsets, waves of fluffy, undulating clouds and luminous sunlight falling over fields of flowers are commonplace for this artist, who evoked the transcendent qualities of nature. (Through June 22, D C Moore Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, 212-247-2111, dcmooregallery.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

A special appeals panel in Athens upheld the 2003 terrorism conviction of Alexandros Yiotopoulos, who led a Marxist terrorist group for 27 years, starting in 1975 with the assassination of the Athens C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch. The court upheld sentences for 12 other members of the November 17 terrorist organization but cleared two additional suspects because the crimes they were convicted of had fallen outside the statute of limitations. Named after a 1973 student uprising that was crushed by the tanks of a military junta that ruled Greece, November 17 killed 23 people, including American and British diplomats and military officers. It disbanded after a botched bomb attack in 2003. ANTHEE CARASSAVA
