Pakistan and Afghanistan, intent on ending a blame game over the Taliban insurgency, have drafted plans for a gathering of tribal elders, intellectuals, writers and politicians in August. The Pakistani interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, left, on a visit to Kabul to meet the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said Pakistan had nominated about 350 prominent figures to attend the jirga, or tribal council. The Afghans will draft a similar list.

Supporters of a 26-year-old chimpanzee are going to court to declare him a “person.” They say that will allow the chimp, Hiasl (pronounced HEE-zul), to receive donations for his upkeep. The animal sanctuary where he has lived for 25 years is bankrupt. Donors have offered help but by Austrian law only a person can receive personal donations. “He has a real personality,” said Eberhart Theuer, a lawyer leading the suit. “This is an individual. You just have to look him in the eye to see that.”.

Financial markets reacted with concern to a threat by President Hugo Chávez to nationalize the banking system. Mr. Chávez said Thursday that banks should finance industry at a low cost. “If banks don’t agree with this, it’s better that they go, that they turn over the banks to me, that we nationalize them and get all the banks to work for the development of the country and not to speculate and produce huge profits,” Mr. Chávez said. Venezuela’s currency, the bolívar, fell more than 3 percent in unregulated trading to about 3,950 to the dollar, traders said, and investors sold government bonds amid fears that a state takeover of banks could weaken the economy.

The government, whose spending on AIDS drugs has skyrocketed as more patients have needed costly, patented medicines, overrode the patent held by the pharmaceutical company Merck on the antiretroviral drug efavirenz. The cost of Merck’s drugs has been $580 annually per patient. Brazil said the company had offered a 30 percent discount, but the government opted instead to buy the generic version from India for less than $170. For years, Brazil has considered exercising its rights under international trade rules to make or import generic versions of patented AIDS drugs, but has until now backed away, fearing trade retaliation from the United States. For more than a decade, Brazil has provided universal free access to drug treatment for people with AIDS. Almost one in four patients in Brazil are now taking efavirenz. With the new price, Brazil estimates that it will save $237 million on efavirenz by 2012 when the patent expires. Thailand, which also has an ambitious AIDS treatment program, overrode Merck’s patent on the same drug in November.

A British judge delivered what some experts called a signal verdict against African corruption, ordering the former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba, left, and 19 others to return at least $46 million it said they had stolen while in power in the 1990s and early this decade. The London judge, Peter Smith, ruled that Mr. Chiluba, in power from 1991 to 2001, “was uniquely positioned to stop corruption” in government, but that he elected instead to join in it. Zambia’s government sued in London because it alleged that Mr. Chiluba and his associates had bought assets in Britain and elsewhere in Europe. Mr. Chiluba said in a statement that he did not recognize a British court’s authority in Zambian issues, arguing that the case circumvented Zambia’s justice system. Other African experts said the verdict, the first against a current or former head of state, could set an anticorruption precedent.

A former warlord who is now mayor of Mogadishu vowed to take all guns away from private citizens, a huge task in a city brimming with military weapons. Mohamed Dheere was named mayor last week as part of a government push to keep relative peace in a city ravaged by fighting with insurgents. “The first thing I will do is to improve security,” Mr. Dheere said at his inauguration. “No weapons will be allowed to roam freely in the city, and no guns will be fired.”.
A federal judge rejects the city’s argument that documents will taint potential jurors in lawsuits related to 2004 arrests.

An article on April 5 about details of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s first New York State budget included erroneous information from a Spitzer aide about the position of fish pathologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation. (The error first appeared on Feb. 5 in the Empire Zone column, about Mr. Spitzer’s first month in office.) The budget adds one position to those that already exist; the fish pathologist to be hired will not in fact be the state’s first.

A front-page article on Thursday about the effect of climate change on gardening misidentified the host of a symposium, “Gardening in a Changing Climate.” It was the New York Botanical Garden, not the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

An article yesterday about the military’s investigation of claims that civilians were killed or wounded by recent American air strikes in Afghanistan misspelled the surname of the top American commander there, who said he is reviewing the incident. He is Gen. Dan K. McNeill, not McNeil.
An article on Thursday about the tone Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken in political debates misstated the year he became mayor of New York. It was 1994, not 1993.

A front-page article on April 22 about Russian news coverage misstated the date that a state television network, Rossiya TV, led its newscast with a report about President Vladimir V. Putin’s attending a martial arts competition with the Belgian actor Jean-Claude Van Damme. It was Sunday, April 15, not Saturday, April 14, though an earlier edition of Rossiya’s newscast in St. Petersburg did report on the event that Saturday.

An article yesterday about Secret Service protection provided to Senator Barack Obama referred imprecisely to such protection given to Senators John Kerry and John Edwards in 2004. While they indeed were each provided with the Secret Service detail in February, it was while they were both still seeking the presidential nomination; they were not being protected as the Democratic nominees at that time.

Because of an editing error, a picture on the cover of Arts & Leisure this weekend of the dancer Aesha Ash, with an article about the small number of black ballerinas in classical troupes, appears in mirror image.

A chart yesterday about changes in the dates of Democratic primaries and caucuses from 2004 to 2008 misidentified the time frame for the selection of the District of Columbia’s delegates to the party’s nominating convention. While Washington does hold a primary before the Jan. 14 caucuses in Iowa, the results are nonbinding; the actual delegate selection will not take place until February.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about Rupert Murdoch’s strategy to acquire Dow Jones & Company, the parent of The Wall Street Journal, misidentified the university where Lou Ureneck, who discussed the implications of the bid, is chairman of the journalism department. It is Boston University, not Boston College.

The Transportation Security Administration is trying to find a computer hard drive with Social Security numbers and bank and payroll information for 100,000 employee records. The agency said it realized on Thursday that the drive was missing from a controlled area at its headquarters. “It is unclear at this stage whether the device is still within headquarters or was stolen,” a statement said. The agency asked the F.B.I. and the Secret Service to investigate, the statement said. The drive had information on employees who worked for the Homeland Security agency from January 2002 to August 2005.

Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, asked the Homeland Security Department to develop tougher guidelines to ensure that truckers transporting gasoline and other hazardous materials are fit to work. The announcement capped a week of fallout from the crash of a speeding tanker that collapsed a busy highway interchange in Oakland. According to documents from the Motor Carrier Safety Administration, the tanker or its driver, James Mosqueda, have been cited 27 times since 2004 for violations like unsafe brakes and tires and carrying more gasoline than the truck was rated for.

The lawyer for a former astronaut accused of racing across the country to attack a romantic rival received an additional 60 days to file claims that she was insane. A judge also gave the lawyer, Donald Lykkebak, access to audiotapes of the astronaut, Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, at her arrest. Captain Nowak’s trial on charges of attempted kidnapping, battery and burglary is to start on Sept. 24.

A Philadelphia police officer was arrested and charged with sexually assaulting a man at a traffic stop. The officer, Michael Paige, an 18-year veteran of the force, pulled over a car in Fairmount Park for an unspecified reason on March 16, the police said. He took one of the two men in the car to a secluded area of the park and had “nonconsensual sexual activity” with him, the police said. Officer Paige, 40, has been suspended with intent to dismiss, the police said. His lawyer, Gerald S. Stanshine, said that the two men were allowed to drive away and that the accuser later returned to the park to look for the officer. He declined to comment further.

A new prosecutor has reopened the investigation into the unsolved killings of nine women in New Bedford in the 1980s. Investigators dug up the driveway and the patio at the former house of a onetime suspect. The backhoe, shovels and dogs began digging at the house where the former suspect, Kenneth Ponte, lived, neighbors said. District Attorney Samuel Sutter of Bristol promised to reopen the case in his election campaign last fall.

A Louisiana State University student told another student that he was planning a violent attack against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the police said. The student, Richard R. Wargo, 19, of Shreveport, was held on $1 million bail. Mrs. Clinton is scheduled to speak today in Baton Rouge at the National Conference of Black Mayors, and the police said it was unclear whether the attack was planned for that visit. Chief Ricky Adams of the L.S.U. police said Mr. Wargo had asked another student whether he wanted to commit arson, a “terrorist act” that he described as a “national event.” “He reportedly went on to say it was political and it involved Hillary Clinton,” Chief Adams said.
An Ecuadorian day laborer is caught in a collapsing trench while working in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn.
A man convicted in one of New York City’s most notorious police brutality cases  will settle in Staten Island after serving a five-year sentence.
Signed in the off-season to upgrade the bench and provide a safety net at second base, 37-year-old Damion Easley has done both and then some.
WKXW’s “Jersey Guys” earn ire of union president after warning of an impending “ticket blitz.”
“It didn’t matter how long I worked or how hard,” said one of ten former officers involved in the federal suit. “I was ostracized.”
Tim Wakefield pitched seven innings and David Ortiz homered to lead the visiting Boston Red Sox to a 2-0 victory against the Minnesota Twins last night.
Nets guard Jason Kidd, who was born in San Francisco and grew up a Warriors fan, said he was amused by the team’s surprising victory Thursday.
A dispute has cropped up on the right: Does Darwinian theory actually support conservative philosophy?
A state dinner in honor of Queen Elizabeth II will be a collision of cultures — Texas swagger and British prim.
Significant progress toward stabilizing and reducing global warming emissions can be achieved at a relatively low cost using known technologies.
The nation will need policies — and leaders — to reconnect economic growth with rising living standards, for all.
Every citizen in the nation should have the confidence that there is tangible evidence — a hard copy, if you will — of every vote.

From Thomas L. Friedman’s column on April 27: Albert Einstein won the Nobel Prize for his “services to theoretical physics and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect,” not specifically for relativity.
A judge ruled that Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Pakistani citizen, was a flight risk and denied him bail.
Mary Ann Hall caught the go-go wave of the Civil War when she built and managed one of Washington’s finest bordellos.
Still clawing its way out of the ruins of its brutal past, Cambodia has come face to face with an extraordinary new future: It seems to have struck oil.

In a case that seems to get more contentious by the day, Greg LeMond, the champion cyclist and a few other investors have filed suit against the developer of an elite Rocky Mountain ski and golf resort.
Some of the most striking moments of a debate among Republican presidential candidates centered on two topics: abortion and evolution.
The future of financial news may lie in its global reach, supplied by media giants and distributed digitally.
At least 238 subway workers have been killed on the job since 1946, according to a recent review by New York City Transit.
Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.
A largely invisible struggle between lawyers and their clients comes at the same time as a legal battle over the Bush administration’s detention policies.
Bank of America asked a federal court to prevent the Dutch bank ABN Amro from selling its Chicago subsidiary, LaSalle Bank, to rival bidders.
Queens Borough President Helen Marshall’s actions in the aftermath of a fatal incident are called “inappropriate and potentially divisive.”
YouTube said it would begin placing ads alongside clips from some of its most popular contributors and share revenue from those ads with them.
Kinko’s metamorphosis from a free-wheeling group of copy centers to a buttoned-down subsidiary of FedEx is not going off without a hitch.
In November, the Red Sox beat the Yankees in their bid to sign Japanese star Daisuke Matsuzaka. Soon Japanese baseball fans could experience the teams’ rivalry up close.
The small businesses that struggle the most with health insurance may be the smallest of all: those with only one employee.
Small businesses may become a central issue in the debate over the problem of Americans without health insurance.
Only 40 percent of American marines and 55 percent of soldiers in Iraq say they would report a fellow service member for killing or injuring an innocent Iraqi.
Three dozen current and former players were being sought, people familiar with an inquiry said, raising the prospect that baseball will be thrown into turmoil.
Only 3 percent of capital gains go to people who make less than about $50,000.
Golden State’s Stephen Jackson was ejected twice in the series against Dallas and the Warriors have fined him for arguing with referees. Nonetheless, he has become a star.
In a speech, the union president will also call for a “real debate” about whether mayoral control of schools should continue past 2009.
Presidential candidates’ calls to end the war are in conflict with efforts by legislative leaders to extend financing.
As the World War II generation ages, a Bronx-based Honor Guard is called upon for a growing number of funerals.
A crowded boat full of Haitian migrants capsized Friday off Turks and Caicos, flinging them into shark-infested waters.
In April, Jackson County in Oregon did the unthinkable. It closed all 15 of its public libraries, because their operating money is gone.
Concerns of collusion inspire tighter rules on auctions for valuable tax medallions.
French New Yorkers are taking advantage of a rule change that allows them to vote in French elections a day early.
A sociologist, she opposed assessing technology solely on the basis of mathematical models that failed to take account of societal factors.
Paul G. Vallas will run a school district where buildings are ruined, teachers are missing and thousands of students might return suddenly.
Tiger Woods and Vijay Singh will be paired in the final group of the third round of the Wachovia Championship, bringing together two of golf’s greatest rivals.
Last month, National Football League Commissioner Roger Goodell suspended Jones, the troubled Tennessee cornerback, for the 2007 season.
Many people said the most significant development of two days of high-level talks on Iraq was the evidence of a more humble face of American diplomacy.
The 20 horses set to run in Saturday’s Kentucky Derby were tested for erythropoietin Wednesday, the first surprise prerace test in the Derby’s history.
Authorities at a Bay Area college said that at least 74 students might have paid someone to change lower grades to higher ones.
The proposals range from the removal of specific checkpoints in the West Bank to the deployment of better-trained Palestinian forces.
When Ben Wallace’s Bulls meet his old team, the Pistons, the former Detroit center he will serve as the standard bearer for each team’s progress this season.
Newly released recordings provide the richest and rawest account yet of the car accident that seriously injured the New Jersey governor.
Mr. Scott was one in a long line of actors who portrayed Tarzan, the vine-swinging hero of the jungle created by the writer Edgar Rice Burroughs.
The company’s request for the first rise in rates since 2004 was met with wide criticism.
Unlike efforts in other states, the plan would be financed largely by a new tax on gross business receipts.
School districts plan $691 million in new taxes just weeks after the State Legislature earmarked $900 million in aid.
Businesses significantly pared back hiring last month, a sign that the job market may be starting to feel the drag of slower economic growth.
American soldiers detained 16 men who were accused of procuring powerful, armor-piercing bombs and other arms from Iran, the American military said.
Lou Lamoriello, the Devils’ chief executive, president, general manager and interim coach, indicated that he planned to hire another coach after the end of the season.
Freddie Roach had an eight-year career as a boxer, but it was not until two years after he retired, in 1988, that he started feeling the symptoms of Parkinson’s syndrome.
The biggest impediment to widespread embrace of Internet eyeglass shopping might be that the glasses still aren’t cheap enough online.

A front-page article on Wednesday about an academic study that detected a racial bias in the foul calls of referees in the National Basketball Association noted that The New York Times had asked three independent experts to review the study and materials from a subsequent N.B.A. study that detected no bias.
This year’s Kentucky Derby is wide open. But there is a way to find a winner: follow the jockey’s choice of horse.

BMW Oracle temporarily broke the tie at the top of the challengers’ table of the Louis Vuitton Cup, coming from behind to defeat Luna Rossa Challenge.

This weekend Mannes College the New School for Music is presenting “Le Nozze di Figaro,” a repertory staple.

Public broadcasting executives are defending the right of the filmmaker Ken Burns to tell the history of World War II as he sees fit, in the face of escalating complaints.
If you are going to invest extra money in a greener lifestyle, there are plenty of ways to do so that don’t necessarily involve going to the mall.
The Department of Education will try to open Khalil Gibran Academy at an alternate location in September.

Yahoo is shutting down Yahoo Photos and asking users to move instead to its photo-sharing site Flickr, which emphasizes community features.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,350 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
The Los Angeles Philharmonic played a substantive program at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday, including a rare performance of Sibelius’s “Lemminkainen Suite.”
Brett White, who became chief executive of CB Richard Ellis in 2005, has brought the international commercial real estate firm to its present success by following a plan made in 1991.
F. Murray Abraham’s glinty-eyed grandpa persona is perfect for the voice-over of “Sharkland,” an installment of “Nature” that appears on PBS.
Reforesting wasted mine sites would replace failed industrial methods with a system that mimics nature.
Changing dog demographics present a welcome opportunity to bury old stereotypes and restore small dogs to their rightful place in canine history.

After 9/11, with America’s role in the world more uncertain than ever, would it not make more sense to provide the voters with regular, predictable, serious access to their next president?
The New York Mets were warming up to play and I was warming up to sell a food item as famously American as baseball and apple pie.
An investment currently being marketed to the rich is trying in essence to hedge a hedge fund, and the approach is bound to be offered to the rest of us soon.
Annie Gosfield writes music that ranges from improvisatory and serendipitous to carefully notated. But running through much of her work is a fascination with noise.

Bridge is not known for its poignant stories. But one with a happy ending — and a new beginning — concerns Samantha Eisenstein, daughter of the New York bridge expert Glenn Eisenstein.

9 P.M. (Hallmark) A STRANGER’S HEART (2007) Bring out the tissues. Billed by Hallmark as a “touching story about a second chance at life ... and love,” this feel-good weepy stars Samantha Mathis (above, far left, with Mary Matilyn Mouser) as a magazine reporter who receives a long-awaited heart transplant, only to find that she can’t stop dreaming about a young girl she has never met. Turns out that another heart recipient (Peter Dobson) has the same dreams. Which leads them to ask, “Who is the girl, and what’s her connection to us?” Bet you can guess.
The approach, which is said to have come from Thomson Communications,  came just three days after the News Corporation made a $5 billion offer for Dow Jones.
Thomson Corporation of Canada is said to have made “a preliminary approach.” Shares of Reuters jumped 26 percent.

A church scaffolding serves as a handy metaphor for the paradox of Riverside, the capital of a theological movement that has been slowly deteriorating.
It has taken 88 months, or nearly three-quarters of the decade, but the American stock market is finally back to where it ended the last decade.
Salama al-Zaid hosts “Mubasher FM,” a radio show that has powerful backing from Saudi Arabia’s king and is remarkable for what it says about the country.
A “pacifist anarchist” asks political demonstrators to respect police officers, and draws suspicion from N.Y.P.D. investigators.
Given a choice between Donald Fehr’s Major League Baseball Players Association and hundreds of other unions (including my own), I’d choose baseball’s.
Nicolas Sarkozy, the possible next president of France, has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.
Our health care system has eroded badly, but it has not collapsed. So we do nothing.
Born during the dot-com boom, beliefnet is a company that by all rights should have died with all the other failed ventures when the bubble burst.
The cold-war-era terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal, already serving a life sentence, will be tried in connection with four bombing attacks in France in 1982 and 1983.
There is a sense of breathless anticipation before some concerts at Carnegie Hall. Evgeny Kissin lived up to that excitement at his Carnegie appearance on Thursday night.
An article on Thursday about the tone Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken in political debates misstated the year he became mayor of New York. It was 1994, not 1993.

One of the best starters in the major leagues this season pitched Friday night at Chase Field. Oh, and Randy Johnson pitched, too. That title used to belong to Johnson year after year, but now it fits John Maine, who held the Arizona Diamondbacks to one run in six innings in the Mets' 5-3 victory, their 12th in a row at Chase Field.

Opening in Seattle The Seattle Art Museum, right, reopens to the public downtown today after an $86 million renovation and expansion designed by the architect Brad Cloepfil. Admission will be free during a 35-hour marathon of festivities, which begins at 10 a.m. and includes music and dance performances. (Visitors must obtain timed entry tickets.) Mr. Cloepfil's exterior -- ribbed panels of stainless steel and glass -- is intended to allow views of the Olympic Mountains and Elliott Bay, and to create interplay between the landscape and collection strengths like Northwest Coast Indian art. The addition also includes a soaring lobby that currently displays Cai Guo-Qiang's installation of nine cars tumbling through space. The inaugural exhibition, ''SAM at 75: Building a Collection for Seattle,'' includes about 100 of some 1,000 newly donated works. The museum also opened an $85 million sculpture park on the city's waterfront in January. Vegas Meets Miss M. Bette Midler, below, will succeed Celine Dion as the headliner at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Dion, whose show, ''A New Day,'' has taken in more than $500 million in the 4,100-seat Colosseum, announced in January that she would end her nearly five-year run by December. Ms. Midler said she agreed to a two-year contract, requiring her to perform 100 shows a year on a five-night-a-week schedule for 20 weeks beginning Feb. 20. ''I think it'll be my usual outrageous, flamboyant, over-the-top show,'' she said. Tickets range from $95 to $250. Footnotes ''Ecce Cor Meum'' (''Behold My Heart''), a choral oratorio written by Paul McCartney, was named album of the year Thursday night at the annual Classical Brit Awards. The award is Britain's most prestigious for classical music. Prizes of $100,000 each have been won by the librettist Jeremy Desmon and the lyricist Joe Iconis, recipients of the 17th annual Kleban Award for most promising musical theater librettist and most promising lyricist. The prize is given by the Kleban Foundation, established in 1988 under the will of Edward L. Kleban, the lyricist of ''A Chorus Line.'' ''Called to Account,'' the British play that uses the real words of real people to question Prime Minister Tony Blair's justification for Britain's involvement in the American-led invasion of Iraq, has extended its run through June 9 at the Tricycle Theater in London. It was to close on May 19. ''My Trip to Al-Qaeda,'' Lawrence Wright's show about his experiences writing ''The Looming Tower and the Road to 9/11,'' which ended its run at the Culture Project on April 14, will have two more performances at Town Hall, on June 5 and 6.

A chart yesterday about changes in the dates of Democratic primaries and caucuses from 2004 to 2008 misidentified the time frame for the selection of the District of Columbia's delegates to the party's nominating convention. While Washington does hold a primary before the Jan. 14 caucuses in Iowa, the results are nonbinding; the actual delegate selection will not take place until February.

It was an abrupt and humiliating end for one of Britain's biggest corporate leaders who had turned a small company on the verge of bankruptcy into one of the world's biggest oil producers. John Browne who was knighted in 1998 and made life peer in 2001 by Prime Minister Tony Blair, unexpectedly resigned from BP on Tuesday after losing a court battle with a London newspaper over the disclosure of his relationship with a younger man.
HERRMAN--Jeff. Not a day goes by. Forever yours Mary

After rejecting three previous offers, Cablevision has accepted a $10.6 billion buyout proposal from its founding family, the Dolans. Under the terms of the deal, the family will pay $36.26 a share for the cable TV provider, which also owns Madison Square Garden. The deal, first proposed at a secret meeting in March between the Dolans and the board's special committee, is a chance for the family to finally win full control of the company it founded in 1973.

An article yesterday about the military's investigation of claims that civilians were killed or wounded by recent American air strikes in Afghanistan misspelled the surname of the top American commander there, who said he is reviewing the incident. He is Gen. Dan K. McNeill, not McNeil.

Rupert Murdoch was the man in the news this week as word got out that he wanted to buy Dow Jones & Company. Reuters said it had received a friendly takeover offer, while Cablevision said it was finally ready to accept the Dolan family's buyout offer.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about Rupert Murdoch's strategy to acquire Dow Jones & Company, the parent of The Wall Street Journal, misidentified the university where Lou Ureneck, who discussed the implications of the bid, is chairman of the journalism department. It is Boston University, not Boston College.

As Gilbert and Sullivan might sing, he is the very model of a modern chief executive. Brett White, who became chief executive of CB Richard Ellis in 2005 -- about a year after the company went public for the second time -- is tall and rangy, with a broad smile. But looks aside, he has brought the international commercial real estate firm to its present success by following a plan made in 1991. After Mr. White, 47, released a stellar first-quarter earnings report on Wednesday, Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs raised their projections for the company, and JPMorgan Chase put it on its list of hot stock picks. The shares fell 40 cents yesterday, to $37.43.

The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox extended their rivalry all the way to Asia in November, when the Red Sox beat the Yankees in their bid to sign the star Japanese pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka. Next March, Japanese baseball fans could experience the rivalry up close. As reported by The New York Post yesterday, Major League Baseball is in preliminary negotiations with several teams, including the Yankees and the Red Sox, about playing exhibition games in China next March and opening the regular season in Japan, according to several individuals briefed on the negotiations.

TOMPKINS--Harold. We are saddened by the loss of our esteemed and beloved colleague. Board of Justices, N.Y. County $(6$)TOMPKINS--Harold, Justice, 74. Died of pneumonia, May 2nd, 2007. A very dedicated humanitarian, born in NYC, graduated from Syracuse University and Cornell Law School. Father of his loving son, Laurence Alan Fish Tompkins, and endeared husband of Frances Fish Tompkins for 48 years. A private practitioner and an Assistant NY State Attorney General in the Litigation Bureau, who represented the MTA during the 1980 transit strike. He was elected a Civil Court Judge in 1981 and became a Supreme Court Justice in 1986. He authored over 200 published opinions on cases involving the First Amendment, patients' rights to control their treatment and sanctions against frivolous lawsuits and governmental authority. He retired in 2003. A dedicated supporter of Bar Association activities, he was Executive V.P. of the Respect for Law Alliance, a Director of the Jewish Lawyers Guild, Chairman of The Young Lawyers Section of the NY State Bar Association and frequent lecturer at NY County Lawyers and NY State Trial Lawyers Associations. For many years he was a member of the Board of Governors of Harmonie Club and the Board of Directors at Park Ave. Synagogue. Services at 10am, Sunday May 6th, 2007, at Park Ave. Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York City.

Bobby Abreu was healthy, but his batting average was not. Abreu, batting third as the designated hitter last night, raised his average to .252 after going 3 for 5. He said that it was easier to handle a slump when the team was winning; the Yankees swept three games from Texas earlier this week before losing to the Mariners last night, 15-11.

SAMUELS--Jack Donald, 71, a hero and inspiration to his friends and family, he passed away on May 3, 2007, due to complications from abdominal surgery. Jack leaves behind his wife, Janet, two children, Don and Stephanie, their spouses, Sherri and Michael, four grandchildren, Andy, Myke, Nicole and Emily, and countless friends and admirers, including Fran Yeoman, the mother of Don and Stephanie. Born in New York City on December 24, 1935. Jack attended Columbia Grammar, Brown University and Columbia Law School. Jack worked in the Department of Justice as a special assistant to the Deputy Attorney General, Byron R. White. He was also an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He had a varied and successful legal career in both New York and California. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend whose wisdom and quick wit provided comfort and humor to those who knew him. Because of him, the world is a brighter and more enjoyable place. His was a life well lived and now he should have the rest which he richly deserves. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to The Brown Sports Foundation, Box 1925, Providence, Rhode Island 02912.

The Thomson Corporation of Canada has approached Reuters, the provider of financial data, about a possible takeover, people close to the situation said yesterday. Reuters said it had received a ''preliminary approach'' but would not identify the bidder. The approach ''may or may not lead to an offer being made for Reuters,'' the company said. Thomson declined to comment on ''rumors and speculation.''

To the Editor: Re ''Republican Candidates Hold First Debate, Differing on Defining Party's Future'' (news article, May 4): Most striking about the first Republican debate is not what the candidates said but what they looked like: 10 white men in dark suits arrayed across the stage. Their homogeneity does not reflect well on the diversity of the G.O.P. or its views.

SAROSDY--Will. In Loving Memory. June 7, 1985 -May 5, 2006. It's been a year since you left us, Will. We grieve the loss of your wonderful, loving presence, just as we celebrate the joy of having shared your remarkable, tooshort life. We know the pain of depression was too intense for you to bear. While we now struggle with the pain of grief, we know you are at peace and suffer no more. We think of you every day and miss you more than words can express. You were an angel sent to us by God and now you are home. We love you always and forever. Mom, Dad, Frank, Grace and all of your loving grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins, friends, teammates and young swimmers. To learn more about Will, visit his memorial website: http://Will-Sar osdy.memory-of.com

From Thomas L. Friedman's column on April 27: Albert Einstein won the Nobel Prize for his ''services to theoretical physics and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect,'' not specifically for relativity.

Chinese authorities detained the general manager of a Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to pet food suppliers in the United States. The manager of the Xuzhou Anying Biologic Technology Development Company has denied any knowledge of how melamine, an industrial chemical, was mixed into its pet food supplies. He says his company has never exported any wheat gluten and that his products are sold only on the domestic market.

Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' chief executive, president, general manager and interim coach, indicated Friday that he planned to hire another coach after the end of the season, which may come as early as Saturday. Lamoriello, 64, said last season that he would never coach again. He replaced the first-year coach Claude Julien on April 2, with three games remaining in the regular season. Lamoriello also coached after Larry Robinson resigned Dec. 19, 2005.

To the Editor: Re ''Making a Killing,'' by Mike White (Op-Ed, May 2): I agree that we all should indeed ''pause to consider what we are saying with our movies about the value of life and the pleasures of mayhem,'' whether it be in fictional form in the movies or on TV, and more important, in real life as we watch the events of the war in Iraq unfold.

An article on April 5 about details of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's first New York State budget included erroneous information from a Spitzer aide about the position of fish pathologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation. (The error first appeared on Feb. 5 in the Empire Zone column, about Mr. Spitzer's first month in office.) The budget adds one position to those that already exist; the fish pathologist to be hired will not in fact be the state's first.

A two-hour ''Grey's Anatomy,'' half of which laid the groundwork for a possible spinoff, made ABC No. 1 in Thursday's ratings. The episode, in which Addison (Kate Walsh) encounters a new cast of flirtatious doctors in a Santa Monica clinic, attracted 21 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, doing especially well among adults 18 to 49. CBS ranked second over all, winning the 8 p.m. hour with ''Survivor: Fiji'' (10.7 million) and coming in second with ''CSI'' at 9 (18.9 million) and ''Shark'' at 10 (12.7 million). NBC was third, filling two hours with episodes of ''My Name is Earl'' (7.6 million), ''The Office'' (7.4 million) and ''Scrubs'' (4.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

To the Editor: Re ''Spying on Americans'' (editorial, May 2), about the proposed update to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act: This legislation, submitted in response to Congressional request, seeks to find a bipartisan way forward to protect American lives from the plots of terrorists, while at the same time protecting the rights and privacies afforded to Americans.

Cablevision agreed to carry Major League Baseball's Extra Innings package of out-of-market games, charging customers $159 for the season. Cablevision joined Time Warner, Comcast and Cox, which own the InDemand distribution service, and which together made a similar deal last month. Charter, another major cable operator, also agreed to a deal.

A front-page article on April 22 about Russian news coverage misstated the date that a state television network, Rossiya TV, led its newscast with a report about President Vladimir V. Putin's attending a martial arts competition with the Belgian actor Jean-Claude Van Damme. It was Sunday, April 15, not Saturday, April 14, though an earlier edition of Rossiya's newscast in St. Petersburg did report on the event that Saturday.

The rookie starter Phil Hughes was to have his injured hamstring examined last night by Dr. Stuart J. Hershon, who would determine whether Hughes should have a magnetic resonance imaging test. ''It's frustrating,'' said Hughes, who was removed from the game in Texas on Tuesday with a no-hitter in the seventh inning. ''I try not to look back too much and think what might have been.'' JOE LAPOINTE
PANKRAC--Fred A. Happy May 5th Birthday, dearest Freddie. Love you. Miss you. Your loving sister, Blanche

To the Editor: Re ''Wolfowitz's Big Mistake'' (column, May 3): David Brooks says that Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, ''now argues that the scandal involving his girlfriend's pay raise is 'plainly bogus.' '' He asserts: ''Wolfowitz has a point. The conflict of interest charge is out of proportion to the hubbub.''

PETERS--Jeffrey of Roslyn, NY on May 4, 2007. Survived by his wife of 28 years Barbara (Korman), his children Charlee Cook (David), Fred and Samantha, his sister Franne Visslailli, his brother Jonathan, brothers - in - law Jeffrey Korman, Jimmy (Helene) Korman and Lance Korman, and father-in-law Larry Korman (Angela). He was a kind, loving husband, father and brother, a distinguished attorney and an exceptional friend to all who knew him. Funeral is at Guttermans in Woodbury, NY, Sunday, May 6, at 12 Noon. Donations can be made to the Brain Tumor Foundation.

The German metal and engineering industry averted a potentially damaging strike by agreeing to the largest wage increase in years, another indication of the health of the largest European economy. The agreement, struck after 19 hours of negotiations, will give 800,000 workers at some of the biggest German industrial companies in the southwestern state of Baden-Württemberg, including DaimlerChrysler and Porsche, a 5.8 percent pay increase plus additional payments over a 19-month period. An agreement for one region typically sets a precedent for the rest of the country.

Pope Benedict XVI met Friday with Iran's former president, Mohammad Khatami, who spoke earlier here about the ''very deep'' wounds between Muslims and Christians. The two men had been scheduled to meet here last fall, but the meeting was canceled in the uproar over a speech the pope had given that offended many Muslims.

A Dutch court blocked ABN Amro's sale of LaSalle Bank in Chicago to Bank of America, part of a big banking deal. The judge said ABN Amro first needed to secure shareholders' approval. Barclays has negotiated a friendly acquisition of ABN Amro for $87 billion At the same time, making any counteroffer less likely, ABN Amro agreed to sell LaSalle. Shareholders at ABN Amro pressured the board last month to consider a rival approach by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Financial markets reacted with concern to a threat by President Hugo Chávez to nationalize the banking system. Mr. Chávez said Thursday that banks should finance industry at a low cost. ''If banks don't agree with this, it's better that they go, that they turn over the banks to me, that we nationalize them and get all the banks to work for the development of the country and not to speculate and produce huge profits,'' Mr. Chávez said. Venezuela's currency, the bolívar, fell more than 3 percent in unregulated trading to about 3,950 to the dollar, traders said, and investors sold government bonds amid fears that a state takeover of banks could weaken the economy. SIMON ROMERO

Playwrights Horizons has announced the last show of its 2007-8 season: a musical version of the 2004 movie ''Saved!,'' about the wacky goings-on at a Christian high school, starring Celia Keenan-Bolger (''Les Misérables''). Michael Friedman of the Civilians theater company will write the music and collaborate on the lyrics with John Dempsey (''The Witches of Eastwick'') and Rinne Groff (''The Ruby Sunrise''), both of whom will also write the book. Gary Griffin (''The Color Purple'') will direct. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Also surviving are 11 grandchildren and his first wife, Sheila W. Lummis. He was predeceased by his parents, John and Anita, and his sisters Betty and Anne. An article on April 5 about details of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's first New York State budget included erroneous information from a Spitzer aide about the position of fish pathologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation. (The error first appeared on Feb. 5 in the Empire Zone column, about Mr. Spitzer's first month in office.) The budget adds one position to those that already exist; the fish pathologist to be hired will not in fact be the state's first.

To the Editor: Re ''A Vestige of the Past Shutters Its Stalls'' (news article, April 30): The city must find a way to encourage the use of the bridle path in Central Park for horseback riding. With the closing of the Claremont Riding Academy, horses will no longer be available for rent in Manhattan and the bridle path will no longer be used for its stated purpose.

A British judge delivered what some experts called a signal verdict against African corruption, ordering the former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba, left, and 19 others to return at least $46 million it said they had stolen while in power in the 1990s and early this decade. The London judge, Peter Smith, ruled that Mr. Chiluba, in power from 1991 to 2001, ''was uniquely positioned to stop corruption'' in government, but that he elected instead to join in it. Zambia's government sued in London because it alleged that Mr. Chiluba and his associates had bought assets in Britain and elsewhere in Europe. Mr. Chiluba said in a statement that he did not recognize a British court's authority in Zambian issues, arguing that the case circumvented Zambia's justice system. Other African experts said the verdict, the first against a current or former head of state, could set an anticorruption precedent. MICHAEL WINES

BARBANEL--Dr. Charles J., died May 2, 2007, age 70, adored companion to Ellen, loving father of Eric, devoted grandfather of Joshua, and beloved brother to Laura and Judy. Psychiatrist in private practice, formerly of Booth Memorial Hospital and Long Island Jewish Hospital. His warmth, kindness and sense of humor will be much missed by all. Services at 10:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at West 91st Street, Manhattan, 212-769-4400. Contributions may be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center in his memory. May his memory be a blessing.

A loving man of generous spirit, boisterous good humor, and powerful intellect. ''Hark, hear the cannons roar!'' We will miss you. Beverly, Julie Brin, Margaret Pennsy, David Erie, Saul Lehigh, Eleanor, Robert, Samuel, and Marcus. Services at 9am, Sunday May 6th at Bernheim Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ.

SUSSMAN--Herman (Hy) R. Born in Poland on February 14th, 1920, Herman Sussman died on May 3rd, 2007, in Boca Raton, FL after living for over 50 years in Great Neck, NY. Mr. Sussman graduated from New York University and Columbia Teachers College. He was a successful businessman who was also an avid fine art and rare book collector. Among his many civic accomplishments, he served as a trustee and Mayor of Great Neck Village. He is predeceased by his first wife of 39 years, Claire Sussman, and his second wife, June Sussman. He is survived by his children Alex and Edna Sussman and Barbara and Marc Rowin, grandchildren Michael, Jason, Craig, Carl, Matthew and Eric, his brother Irving Sussman, his sister Shirley Kaplan and his companion Marlene Taft. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. Private services will be held on May 6th, 2007.

A front-page article on Thursday about the effect of climate change on gardening misidentified the host of a symposium, ''Gardening in a Changing Climate.'' It was the New York Botanical Garden, not the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

Responding to the pet food recall in the United States and greater concerns about possibly tainted food supplies, China said Friday that it had begun carrying out nationwide inspections of wheat gluten to screen for contamination, according to the state-controlled Xinhua News Agency. A spokesman for the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine said the inspections began on Monday, with regulators testing for a chemical used in rat poison as well as melamine, an industrial chemical that is believed to have killed or sickened thousands of pets in the United States and South Africa.

To the Editor: ''Help, by the Book'' (editorial, May 1) applauds the State of Washington for taking steps to hold down textbook costs and Rice University for making materials, written by a ''consortium of writers,'' available for free online use. As a professor and textbook author, I wonder what kind of incentive you propose to offer the people who write these materials. Preparing a textbook entails extensive research and writing. Weekends and evenings disappear, as a writer tries to perform the day job of teaching and conducting research, while managing to write a quality product.

The government, whose spending on AIDS drugs has skyrocketed as more patients have needed costly, patented medicines, overrode the patent held by the pharmaceutical company Merck on the antiretroviral drug efavirenz. The cost of Merck's drugs has been $580 annually per patient. Brazil said the company had offered a 30 percent discount, but the government opted instead to buy the generic version from India for less than $170. For years, Brazil has considered exercising its rights under international trade rules to make or import generic versions of patented AIDS drugs, but has until now backed away, fearing trade retaliation from the United States. For more than a decade, Brazil has provided universal free access to drug treatment for people with AIDS. Almost one in four patients in Brazil are now taking efavirenz. With the new price, Brazil estimates that it will save $237 million on efavirenz by 2012 when the patent expires. Thailand, which also has an ambitious AIDS treatment program, overrode Merck's patent on the same drug in November. CELIA W. DUGGER

An article yesterday about Secret Service protection provided to Senator Barack Obama referred imprecisely to such protection given to Senators John Kerry and John Edwards in 2004. Jason DeParle (April 22) does an important service by putting a human face on migration. But economic remittances are not the only things migrants send back to their homelands. They also send back social remittances. Depending on what they have witnessed, migrants often demand more from their governments. They want institutions that work, political voice and jobs that are allocated on the basis of merit, not on whom you know. This is a piece of the puzzle that development planners and world bankers should not overlook.

An article on April 22 about five composers who were asked to write the music for a Roman Catholic Mass referred incorrectly to a difference between that Mass and the Greek Orthodox one — a difference cited by the composer Ivan Moody. Don Watson raises some of the best milk-fed lambs on the planet. The ones that don’t make it to Chez Panisse are rented out as lawn mowers in Northern California. Watson says his Wooly Weeders can digest noxious plants and manage steep hillsides and tightly spaced vineyards while leaving behind rich fertilizer. Vintners, like the Mondavi family, have hired them to snack on leaves that drain nutrients from grapes. Others use them to prevent brush fires. Lately, the most interesting rum to surface in the States is from the French island of Martinique. Unlike most rum, which is made from molasses, Martinique’s rhum agricole is made exclusively from fresh sugar-cane juice. In addition to the sugary aroma, a tinge of herbal, floral or vegetal flavors evoke the island’s rain forest. Depaz, Rhum Clément, Rhum JM, Neisson and La Favorite are labels offering clear, unaged rhum blanc and amber, wood-aged rhum vieux. Don’t bother using rhum agricole in your mojito, though; it doesn’t work. Try a Ti Punch (short for “petit”) instead.[?][?][?]Jordan Mackay.

Regulars at Aloria Berri — recently named the best bar in Spain by the prominent guidebook Gourmetour — used to tease its owner, José Ramon Elizondo, that they had to cross the desert to eat his alta cocina en miniatura. Actually, just a river. His place is a short walk from San Sebastian’s Old Quarter, on the other side of the Urumea River, in the emerging neighborhood of Gros. Once the province of working families and car-repair shops, Gros has become a draw for locals looking for an alternative to the city’s popular pintxo (tapas) bars. And besides, “everyone knows the best pintxos are in Gros,” says Elizondo, whose txirristra de mar (an architectural concoction of mackerel, vegetables and foie gras) took first prize in the National Tapas Competition in 2006. Around the corner at El Lagar (above), a modern dark-wood-and-chalkboard wine bar, you can have an excellent blood sausage croquette or seared foie gras with a hard-to-find bottle of Aalto from the Ribera del Duero or a Vega Sicilia. When Enrique Garcia Caceres opened El Lagar in 2004, he had in mind a rustic, quiet place. But actually, he helped put Gros on the map. Aloria Berri: Calle Bermingham, 24; 011-34-943-290-818; www.alonaberri.com. El Lagar: Calle Zabaleta, 55; 011-34-943-320-329; www.el-lagar.net.[?][?][?]Christian L. Wright.

A limited-edition T-shirt from Johnny Cupcakes is one of the few things that can’t be bought in Manhattan. Cupcakes (a k a John Earle) and his upcake-and-crossbones logo took Boston by storm last year when he and his dad outfitted a storefront on tony Newbury Street to look like a bakery, with antique refrigerators, baking racks, a hulking 1930s dough mixer and a cast-iron wood-burning oven from the 1890s. The T-shirts have a Magnolia Bakery-like following: In October, more than 500 aficionados lined up to buy Cupcakes’ $55 monster tees. “People like what no one else has,” Earle says. “That’s why I number my shirts and don’t repeat my designs.” Earle has also cooked up day-of-the-week undies and skateboard decks, available at his store as well as online. Go to www.johnnycupcakes.com.[?][?][?]Rebecca Voight.

O'BRIEN--Reginald P., of Cape Cod and Manhattan died February 28, 2007. Survived by his wife, Monica; daughter Alexandra; granddaughters Brianna, Casey, Dory and Bailey; brother John R.; sisters Adrienne and Madeleine. He was predeceased by his son Christopher. Funeral is at 11am, May 12, Holy Trinity R.C. Church, West Harwich, MA. St. Catherine of Genoa and Bishop Dubois, St. Benedict College; proud Veteran, loving friend to all.

In a case of particularly bad timing, Gov. Eliot Spitzer flew to California last week to raise campaign funds. Rushing to California to raise money is not illegal or even uncommon for a New York politician. But Mr. Spitzer's trip came while he has been chastising legislators back home for failing to reform the state's shameful campaign fund-raising system. From Mr. Spitzer's point of view, such fund-raising is crucial to his success as governor today, not his success as a candidate four years from now. That's because he has chosen to use his own campaign funds to fight for his agenda in Albany. This is a very unusual step for a governor to take. But Mr. Spitzer says it is necessary to the overcome the well-financed opponents of initiatives he regards as essential.
Sparkling, fresh ingredients -- with a kick.

WADLER--Scott M.D. The Board of Directors of the Cancer Research and Treatment Fund mourns the death of Dr. Scott Wadler. Dr. Wadler was a member of our Medical Advisory Board and the first occupant of the Richard T. Silver Distinguished Professorship of Hematology and Medical Oncology at Weill Cornell Medical College. He was an earnest friend who was always willing to share his medical expertise and he had a talent for explanation for those with questions. In his life work, he gave encouragement and understanding through his support and participation in educational and research opportunities that addressed the needs of all people with cancer. A brilliant physician, he was taken too soon from his colleagues, friends and family who will miss his smile, compassion and easy way with words. Richard J. Rose, President Richard T. Silver, M.D., Medical Director $(6$)WADLER--Scott, M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Cornell Medical College and New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center mourn the passing of Dr. Scott Wadler, the Richard T. Silver Distinguished Professor of Hematology and Medical Oncology at Weill Cornell Medical College and head of the solid tumor service and director of clinical trials research at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. He was also founder of the New York Cancer Consortium, an NIH-sponsored cancer clinical trials group. An innovative research scientist with a genuine love of medicine and learning, Dr. Wadler helped develop new therapies for gastrointestinal and gynecologic cancers. A kind and caring physician beloved by his patients, students and colleagues, he will be much missed. Our deepest condolences to his family. In his memory, the Scott Wadler Memorial Fund for Clinical Research has been established. Donations in his memory may be made payable to NYPH/WCMC and sent to: Development Office, Attention: Gloria Kao, 525 E. 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10021.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 21, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. EDITH WHARTON, by Hermione Lee. (Knopf, $35.) This meticulous biography shows Wharton's significance as a designer, decorator, gardener and traveler, as well as a writer. TOO CLOSE TO THE SUN: The Audacious Life and Times of Denys Finch Hatton, by Sara Wheeler. (Random House, $27.95.) The story of the man immortalized in ''Out of Africa.'' HALFLIFE, by Meghan O'Rourke. (Norton, $23.95.) In these dynamic poems, O'Rourke narrows her eyes to discern intelligence from chatter. THE PESTHOUSE, by Jim Crace. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $24.95.) A cataclysm has devastated Crace's America of the future, but even on a dying planet, boy meets girl. A MIRACLE OF CATFISH: A Novel in Progress, by Larry Brown. (Shannon Ravenel/Algonquin, $24.95.) After Brown died in 2004, his editor reverently pared this last, unfinished novel to a workable length, but otherwise didn't alter it. HELPLESS, by Barbara Gowdy. (Metropolitan, $24.) A literary thriller about a pedophile who kidnaps a girl he imagines is being molested. THE HOUSE ON BOULEVARD ST.: New and Selected Poems, by David Kirby. (Louisiana State University; cloth, $50; paper, $18.95.) Kirby believes in the seamlessness of ''high'' and ''low'' art. A FAR COUNTRY, by Daniel Mason. (Knopf, $24.) This novel's impoverished heroine seeks her brother amid the cruelties of a third-world city. THE WORLDS OF LINCOLN KIRSTEIN, by Martin Duberman. (Knopf, $37.50.) Kirstein, who died in 1996, was a novelist, poet, critic, historian and, above all, America's ballet visionary. Troublesome Young Men: The Rebels Who Brought Churchill to Power and Helped Save England, by Lynne Olson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) Some little-known Tories boldly opposed Neville Chamberlain's appeasement policies. THE DAY OF THE BARBARIANS: The Battle That Led to the Fall of the Roman Empire, by Alessandro Barbero. Translated by John Cullen. (Walker, $24.95.) Romans vs. Goths, A.D. 378. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

ROMANOV--H.I.H. Prince Nikita, died after a long illness on Wednesday, May 3rd. He would have been 84 on May 13. He was the great-grandson of Emperor Alexander the III and Empress Maria Fedorovna. He was also the great-nephew of the last Tsar. His grandparents were Grand Duchess Xenia, daughter of Alexander the III and Grand Duke Alexander Mihailovich, grandson of Nicholas I. His parents were Prince Nikita and Princesses Marie, born Ilarionovna VorontsaraKova. Born in London, Nikita and his brother Alexander spent their early years in England. Later he earned a MA in History at the University of California at Berkeley and taught History at San Francisco State College. He was also co-author with Robert Payne of ''Ivan the Terrible'' (1975) and of Rocanov's ''Apocalypse of Our Time'' In 1978, a philosophical commentary. He leaves a wife of 46 years, Janet, and a son Theodore. Alexander's widow, Maria Kondratovna also survives. Service will be announced later.

A museum is a perfect place to hear the viola da gamba player JORDI SAVALL. For one thing, his playing has a tactile quality and a rich palette of color. For another, his specialty is delving into music of the past and making it come vividly alive. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, accompanied by harpsichord and theorbo, he is giving back-to-back concerts in conjunction with the ''Barcelona and Modernity'' show. (He is Spanish.) The first will feature lesser-known works by Ortiz, Murcia and others; the second will focus on Marin Marais, the 17th-century French musician portrayed by Gérard Depardieu in the film ''Tous Les Matins du Monde,'' for which Mr. Savall provided the soundtrack. Wednesday and Thursday at 8 p.m., (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $55, $100 for both concerts. ''Popular virtuoso'' is a technically accurate if slightly misleading term for both Mr. Savall and PIERRE-LAURENT AIMARD, the smart and gifted pianist who has made engaging musical lecture-tours out of several of his solo recitals in his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall. He has two more this week, studded with short bits of thorny and marvelous repertory (Ligeti, Boulez, Beethoven, Stockhausen): not ''popular'' by most definitions, but the first one is already sold out. Thursday and Friday at 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $40 to $48 (sold out on Thursday). A focus of the new music scene every year is the New York City Opera's estimable VOX program, offering orchestral readings of excerpts from operas in progress by 12 composers. The program sometimes leads to a production with another company. It's also a chance to get a sense of the breadth of what's being written today, as opposed to what ends up being staged. The two-day event starts next Saturday afternoon with works by Robert Aldridge, John Zorn and others; in the evening four other small companies (Music-Theater Group, Encompass New Opera Theater, the Center for Contemporary Opera and American Opera Projects) will present more new operas. At noon, Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 992-8484, nycopera.com; free.

To the Editor: In ''As Pace of Deportation Rises, Illegal Families Are Digging In'' (front page, May 1), you tell the heartbreaking story of the Mancía family, which seems at first to have been torn in two by immigration enforcement. Mr. Mancía is free to return to Honduras with his wife. The American Dream is so valuable, however, that he chooses to hang on to the dream, even if it means breaking his own family in two.
A picture caption on April 22 with a review of ''The Grand Surprise: The Journals of Leo Lerman,'' misspelled the given name of the actress shown with Lerman in 1952. She is Luise Rainer, not Louise.

''Saturday Night Live'' had a Lazarus-like reincarnation in the 1990s -- fallow years succeeded by great ones -- and you can indulge your nostalgia for them all in '' 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' IN THE '90s: POP CULTURE NATION'' (NBC, Sunday night at 9). This special includes clips from the sketch franchises ''Wayne's World,'' ''Church Chat'' and ''Sprockets,'' as well as interviews with Al Franken, Will Ferrell, Dana Carvey and the show's executive producer, Lorne Michaels, among others. On a distinctly more somber note: IFC will show Eric Steel's chilling documentary ''THE BRIDGE'' (Monday, 11 p.m.). After reading a story in The New Yorker about suicides on the Golden Gate Bridge, Mr. Steel trained his camera on the bridge over a period in 2004 and captured images of people leaping from it. He then tracked down the families and friends of his subjects to try to decipher what activates the suicidal urge. The answers are obvious -- mental illness, severe depression -- but the investigation is harrowing. Another serious documentary effort arrives in the form of ''WHEN KIDS GET LIFE,'' on ''Frontline'' (PBS, Tuesday; check local listings). According to Human Rights Watch, more than 2,000 prisoners in the United States are serving sentences of life without parole for murders committed when they were teenagers. The documentary profiles five such juvenile offenders, including a young man who was 15 when he murdered his mother and stepfather after years of sexual abuse. The flaws of jurisprudence receive dramatic treatment in a new show on BBC America, ''INNOCENT'' (Thursday at 8 p.m.). It focuses on a team of young law students, led by a handsome professor (Lloyd Owen). They grapple with ethics and adulthood as they work to help the wrongly convicted. Think of ''The Paper Chase'' meets the Innocence Project.

Jackie Skrzynski's ''Boy Napping With Bear,'' above, is part of the ''Borderland'' exhibition, which also includes work by Jennifer Muskopf. May 12 through June 9. Love is a universal language, at least according to the cockeyed optimists. But what about ambivalence? Is paralyzing romantic two-mindedness -- the kind Stephen Sondheim hymned as the ''God-why-don't-you-love-me-oh-you-do-I'll-see-you-later blues'' -- the same in every culture? Anthropologists in search of answers may want to check out the latest incarnation of the long-running Off Broadway musical ''I LOVE YOU, YOU'RE PERFECT, NOW CHANGE'' at the Westside Theater. Starting Wednesday this popular 11-year-old date show about the mixed blessings of singleness and marriage will be interpreted by a Mandarin-speaking Chinese cast, in alternating performances with the existing English-language production. Like the original ''I Love You,'' this imported version, which recently ended a run in Shanghai, is directed by Joel Bishoff, but it has been jiggered to reflect daily life in metropolitan China. It will be performed with English supertitles and features Lin Yilun, a pop star and television host known as ''the Latin prince of China.'' Through June 3, 407 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com; $66 to $100 for the Mandarin show, $75 for the English-speaking cast. A revival of ''BEYOND THERAPY,'' the 1981 CHRISTOPHER DURANG play about neurotics in uncertain pursuit of commitment, makes the case for the theory that semi-love (or is it semi-hate?) goes beyond words. Or spoken words anyway. This take on Mr. Durang's story of a man, a woman, his boyfriend and their crazier-than-thou therapists is presented in American Sign Language by the New York Deaf Theater. Garrett Zuercher directs. Two voice actors will be on hand to interpret for nondeaf audience members. Through May 20, Actors Theater Workshop, 145 West 28th Street, Manhattan, third floor, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $25.

Jason Marquis pitched so poorly last September that he won none of his five starts, lost four of them, compiled a 7.25 earned run average, didn't appear in the St. Louis Cardinals' first playoff series against San Diego and was left off the roster for the league championship series and the World Series. Great prelude to being a free agent.

SUSSMAN--Herman (Hy) R. Born in Poland on February 14th, 1920, Herman Sussman died on May 3rd, 2007, in Boca Raton, FL after living for over 50 years in Great Neck, NY. Mr. Sussman graduated from New York University and Columbia Teachers College. He was a successful businessman who was also an avid fine art and rare book collector. Among his many civic accomplishments, he served as a trustee and Mayor of Great Neck Village. He is predeceased by his first wife of 39 years, Claire Sussman, and his second wife, June Sussman. He is survived by his children Alex and Edna Sussman and Barbara and Marc Rowin, grandchildren Michael, Jason, Craig, Carl, Matthew and Eric, his brother Irving Sussman, his sister Shirley Kaplan and his companion Marlene Taft. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. Private services will be held on May 6th, 2007.

Bachelor pads that redefine the alpha male's natural habitat.

In a case of particularly bad timing, Gov. Eliot Spitzer flew to California last week to raise campaign funds. Rushing to California to raise money is not illegal or even uncommon for a New York politician. But Mr. Spitzer's trip came while he has been chastising legislators back home for failing to reform the state's shameful campaign fund-raising system. From Mr. Spitzer's point of view, such fund-raising is crucial to his success as governor today, not his success as a candidate four years from now. That's because he has chosen to use his own campaign funds to fight for his agenda in Albany. This is a very unusual step for a governor to take. But Mr. Spitzer says it is necessary to overcome the well-financed opponents of initiatives he regards as essential.
Dish towels to display.

To the Editor: Rachel Donadio's report on ''The Iron Archives'' (April 22) laments the ''re-secretization'' of the former Soviet archives and refers to recent Congressional efforts to protect access provided by the Freedom of Information Act to American archives. As someone who has worked with the documents of both countries, I can attest that Washington has never ''de-secretized'' important historical holdings in the first place. Just this week, my appeal for some F.B.I. documents over 60 years old was rejected because they might ''disclose the identities of confidential sources.'' Some questions of United States policy making that will never be resolved by Soviet archives could be answered quite easily with a reasonable relaxation of American rules. I suspect that would be a threat less to our national security than to our national mythology. Peter N. Carroll Belmont, Calif.

Performances by URBAN BUSH WOMEN, the all-female, mostly black company founded by Jawole Willa Jo Zollar in 1984, can sometimes feel polemical, but the intensity and passion of this dynamic group is always worth returning to. One of the draws of the company's forthcoming season at the Joyce is a new work by the talented and young Camille A. Brown. But it's also worth making a special trip for Ms. Zollar's powerful ''Walking With Pearl: Africa Diaries'' and ''Walking With Pearl: Southern Diaries,'' which both draw from the writings of Pearl Primus, a modern dance pioneer of the 1940s; it's an education and a pleasure all at once. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday through Saturday at 8 p.m., 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $36. More dance history this week comes courtesy of JODY SPERLING, who has created many pieces based on the work of Loie Fuller, a dancer and actress who in the late 19th and early 20th centuries employed light and costumes of diaphanous silk to create exotic forms and effects. Ms. Sperling's work is an unabashedly contemporary interpretation of the kind of theatrical magic Fuller created, but it conveys the pictorial splendor and theatrical illusionism that delighted audiences of her time. In a brief season at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, Ms. Sperling offers two signature solos and two new works: ''More Cheap Tricks,'' inspired by 19th-century variety shows, and ''Roman Sketches.'' Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 3 and 8 p.m., 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, fourth floor, (212) 352-3101, timelapsedance.com; $20, $15 for students and 65+. In an unusual collaboration the WENDY OSSERMAN DANCE COMPANY will dance amid the exhibition ''Fairy Tales,'' a photographic series by MIWA YANAGI at the Chelsea Art Museum. Ms. Osserman's ''Disguised'' will explore themes in Ms. Yanagi's photographs, and the intriguing question of musical and physical responses to visual art will be the subject of a postperformance discussion. Thursday at 6:30 p.m., 556 West 22nd Street, chelseaartmuseum.org; $16, $8 for students and 65+.

The almost yearly cycle of flooding along the Passaic River and in the Delaware Valley has prompted a coalition of Republicans and Democrats in the State Assembly to push for a $1.7 billion bond referendum on the November ballot that would allow the state to buy homes that could be in the path of future floods. The bond issue, which would allocate up to $175 million a year for the next 10 years, would draw on a fraction of the state sales tax. The money would also help preserve open space, farmlands and historic trusts. The measure was announced on Wednesday in Fairfield, an Essex County community that flooded last month.

When Greg Scheinman and his wife, Kate, moved to Houston four years ago, they were expecting their first child. Scheinman, an independent filmmaker, had no projects in the works and was uninspired. ''Houston is not exactly the hotbed of entertainment,'' he said.

OKIN--Louis. Passed away peacefully on May 4th, 2007. Born August 25th, 1912, he grew up in Chattanooga, TN and the Bronx after his family immigrated from Russia. He attended NYU on a football scholarship and graduated from its law school as a member of Its law review. In addition to a successful legal career, he served on the New York City Tax Commission, City Council, and Civil Court. He will be remembered with deep respect, love, and affection by his wife, Anne, children, Elizabeth and Steven, their spouses, Jak and Carolyn, five grandchildren, Adam, Jared, Michael, Rebecca and Rachel, brother, Harry, sister, Reba and many other family members and friends. Services will be held at the ''Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave at 11:15am on Sunday May 6. Donations in his memory can be made to Congregation Shearith Israel, 8 West 70th St, NY, NY 10023. $(6$)OKIN--Louis. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to his family. Peter Neustadter, Parnas

To the Editor: Re ''Seeking Fans, Ballet Scrambles for a Killer App'' [April 22]: Claudia La Rocco rightly suggests that many arts organizations, including dance companies, are simply repackaging their own material again and again without reaching out more broadly. Oddly, some of the more exciting and innovative possibilities went unmentioned and are untried by many organizations these days.

IN recent weeks, Beltway wise guys have amused themselves with a distinctively local version of the TV show ''Survivor,'' pitting Attorney General Alberto Gonzales against Paul Wolfowitz, the World Bank chief. Who will be first banished from the swamp? Will it be Mr. Wolfowitz, the embattled former deputy defense secretary, over allegations of favored treatment to his girlfriend, a former World Bank official?
Picnic knives with snap.

Hamas, which leads the government of the Palestinian Authority and dominates its legislature, on Saturday poured scorn on American proposals to increase Palestinian movement and Israeli security. A day after the proposals, including removing some West Bank checkpoints, became public, a Hamas spokesman in Gaza, Fawzi Barhoum, said, ''We forcefully reject this abject and terrorist plan because it calls for killing the Palestinian people and legalizing the occupation of Palestinian territory.''

THE recent heavy storms that left downtown Manville, N.J., under 10 feet of water; filled the basements of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and flooded rivers and downed power lines in Connecticut may have provided a glimpse of our future. Climate change is accelerating, and the prognosis for the region is alarming, as it is for the rest of the world. No matter how effectively we begin to curb our greenhouse-gas emissions now, we are destined to see significant climate changes because these gases remain in the atmosphere for a long time. We cannot delay planning for the environmental and human calamities that lie ahead. All over the world, according to the 2007 scientific report of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, ''it is very likely that hot extremes, heat waves and heavy precipitation events will continue to become more frequent.'' But we need look no further than our own backyard to find evidence of warming. Since 1950, average summer temperatures in New York City have increased by seven-tenths of a degree per decade, but for the last 20 years, by more than two degrees per decade.

HYTIER--Adrian Doris, formerly Lichtenstein Dale Professor of French at Vassar College, where she taught from 1959 to 1997, died suddenly at her home in Poughkeepsie on April 18, 2007. Professor Hytier also taught for a short period at Columbia University and at the University of California, Davis. She was born in Iran, where her father, Jean Hytier, a prominent specialist of twentieth - century French literature, was a university professor. She grew up in Algeria and Paris, graduated summa cum laude from Barnard College in 1952 and received the doctorate in History from Columbia University in 1958. Known primarily as a scholar of the eighteenthcentury, Adrienne Hytier also published books on the Vichy regime, the history of warfare, and the nineteenth-century diplomat Arthur de Gobineau. She served on the Board of the American Society of Eighteenth Century Studies from 1971 to 1974, and for many years was editor of the French section of The Eighteenth Century: a Current Bibliography. Adrienne Hytier will be remembered for her Voltairian sense of humor, her passion for great literature and her dazzling flower garden that had become a Poughkeepsie landmark.
GORDON--Howard B. 4/6/275/9/06. One long year without you. Forever loved, forever remembered. Your Family and Friends.

The 23-year-old Polish actress Alicja Bachleda-Curus has had a busy career in Eastern European film and television since she was 16. Now she is about to make her American debut with an indelible performance in ''Trade'' (Sept. 7), as a victim of international sex trafficking. Although the movie's narrative is fiction, it was inspired by ''The Girls Next Door,'' an article by Peter Landesman that appeared in The New York Times Magazine in 2004. ''Trade,'' which stars Kevin Kline, runs on dual narrative tracks that ultimately converge. One concerns the ordeal of Ms. Bachleda-Curus's Veronica, a young mother from Poland, and Paulina Gaitan's Adriana, a 13-year-old Mexican. In the other, Mr. Kline's federal insurance investigator, for reasons of his own, helps Adriana's older brother, played by Cesar Ramos, trace her captors to a house in New Jersey, where her virginity will fetch a high price.
