There are, in my experience, two kinds of cooks: those knowledgeable enough to make it up as they go along, and those who wouldn't dream of setting out without a road map. Sadly, I am among the latter. It's no coincidence that I like to bake: I find precision reassuring. Just give me instructions, and I'll carry them out, to the letter.

The pioneering Swiss metal band CELTIC FROST is about a quarter-century old, and after decades of splits and revivals and cult adoration it may be more popular than ever -- or in any case more celebrated. Last year Celtic Frost released ''Monotheist'' (Century Media), a savage and spooky album that reminded metal fans how influential this band has been: Scores of face-painted Scandinavian screechers owe it a debt, and so do mainstream goth-rock acts like HIM and Evanescence. (One imagines that many of Celtic Frost's fans in the metal underground would prefer that this last debt remain unrepaid.) On Monday and Tuesday the reinvigorated Celtic Frost comes to the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, along with the dark but quirky -- and surprisingly resilient -- band TYPE O NEGATIVE. 8 p.m., 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; $25. Also this week: the start of the first HIGH LINE FESTIVAL, a music and arts celebration knee-deep in corporate sponsors and organized by David Bowie. The lineup seems an awful lot like business as usual: a few well-established alt-rock bands -- this week the headliners are ARCADE FIRE, AIR and THE POLYPHONIC SPREE -- playing big rooms. (How is this different from any other week in New York? Why is the booking so conservative? And didn't the smiley faux-gospel singers in the Polyphonic Spree wear out their welcome years ago?) Maybe this will seem more exciting in practice than in theory. Schedule and ticket information, highlinefestival.com. Arcade Fire, Wednesday at 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall; $35.50. Air, Thursday at 8 p.m., Madison Square Garden; $36. Polyphonic Spree, Friday at 6:30 p.m., Grand Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street; $35.

To the Editor: Michael Winerip (''Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard,'' Parenting, April 29) had some poignant but probably misplaced sympathy for the résuméd, well-groomed, suburban kids whom he interviews for Harvard. I am a walking embodiment of this type (and a member of the new Harvard class of 2011), but I think that articles like Mr. Winerip's feed into the fervent but delusional belief that there is no greater reward for a hard-working, successful high school student than admission to a top-flight Ivy. Why feel sorry for the girl who got up at dawn to commute to a research job in a NASA lab? It is clear she has the intelligence, acumen and work ethic to succeed in this world, and will no doubt attend a fine school. She is clearly a lucky one, whether by virtue of innate intelligence, careful rearing or old-fashioned elbow grease.

To the thoughtful discussion of antisecularism, we could usefully add the distinction between religious identity and religious ethics (Russell Shorto, April 8). Narrowing religions to questions of identity is something that even the Bible critiques. Such identity politics is not only a source of tension; it has bred the ''kill the infidel'' mentality that erupts into religious violence. Religious ethics, on the other hand, enjoins people to be responsible for the lives and well-being of others, to care for the widow, orphan and stranger -- values that can form the core of a consensus among culturally diverse people. In this light, it is small wonder that lay religious groups committed to social justice are on the rise at the same time that church attendance is falling.

During a ceremony at Teterboro Airport last Thursday, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a bill that authorizes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to expand two airports -- one in each state -- to relieve air congestion. The bill will allow the Port Authority to purchase the lease of Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., about 70 miles north of Manhattan. The law allows the Port Authority to expand outside of its current jurisdiction area, a 25-mile radius from the Statue of Liberty.

Jorge Sosa hopped among three teams in six months. Atlanta had no use for him last July. The Cardinals buried him in their bullpen. The Mets picked him up, boosted his confidence and gave him a shot in spring training to join the rotation. Sosa rewarded their faith in him Saturday night. Making his first start since June 20, 2006, Sosa was charged with two runs in six and one-third innings and Shawn Green homered and knocked in three runs as the Mets rolled to a 6-2 victory against the Arizona Diamondbacks at Chase Field. The win put them in position Sunday to record their third consecutive four-game sweep here.

Robert A. Kotick, chief executive of the video game maker Activision, was cleared in March of intentional wrongdoing following a board investigation into potentially backdated stock options at the company. But Activision said it will still ask Mr. Kotick and nine other current or former employees to return profits from options granted from 1994 to 2006.

If you've ever entered a caffÃ

Richard Pearshouse, 32, of Toronto, Canada, a policy analyst for the Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network: ''For the last two and a half years I've been living in Canada. Over the Christmas holidays, I went back to Sydney to visit my family and friends -- and also because it was my father's 60th birthday. It was a surprise visit for Dad. I flew early on Christmas morning, in time to wake up my father. On Boxing Day, we went up together to the Blue Mountains, to a swimming pool I had been to when I was growing up. It's actually a stream of running water, in Blue Mountains National Park. It's at the bottom of a sandstone ravine, surrounded by gum trees -- a really quiet place. I was just thinking how good it was to be back home again, to be with my family, to be back in the bush.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

By the time Richard Jefferson secured the Nets a spot in the Eastern Conference semifinals late Friday night, the perils of a rocky regular season seemed to be but a scuff on their shoes. The sixth-seeded Nets will begin their series against the second-seeded Cleveland Cavaliers today brimming with confidence after a 4-2 series victory against the third-seeded Toronto Raptors.

SPRINSON--Dr. David, 96. The Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics at Columbia University Medical Center mourns the death of our esteemed colleague, Emeritus Professor Dr. David Sprinson, on February 28th, 2007. Born in the Ukraine on April 5th, 1910, Dr. Sprinson earned the B.S. degree from City College in 1931, the M.S. degree from New York University in 1936, and the Ph.D. degree from Columbia University in 1946. He was appointed Assistant Professor at Columbia University in 1951 and rose to become Professor in 1958; after retiring in 1978, he continued research at St. Luke/Roosevelt Hospital Center for an additional twenty years. Dr. Sprinson elucidated the chemical pathways by which sugars are converted to the amino acids, their regulation, and interconversion of steroids. He was a Career Investigator of the American Heart Association, a member of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, and was awarded the Doctor of Science Honoris causa by Columbia University. Dr. Sprinson is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Helen Yeargain; their three children, and three grandchildren. Our deepest condolences are extended to Professor Sprinson's family. Arthur G. Palmer, Ph.D., Acting Chair

Dane Cook is a successful stand-up comic with a burgeoning film career in pop comedies like ''Employee of the Month'' and this summer's ''Good Luck Chuck'' (Aug. 24). There's nothing funny about his work in the offbeat thriller ''Mr. Brooks'' (June 1). The movie stars Kevin Costner in the title role, a wealthy, upstanding business executive with a secret life as a reluctant, puritanical serial killer, and William Hurt as Mr. Brooks's mysterious alter ego, who eggs him on with chilly glee. Who in his right mind would want to compete against those two? Mr. Cook does, and when he's on screen, you can't look at anyone else. His character isn't just nasty, he's the apotheosis of vile. A voyeur with a zoom lens, he enjoys taking naughty snaps of a lusty couple in the high-rise across the street who don't believe in closing the curtains. Unexpectedly catching Mr. Brooks in the bloody act of bumping them off, he proceeds to blackmail him, but not for money. What he really wants is to get up close and personal with Mr. Brooks's murders, and demands to be taken along for the thrill.

David Rieff's excellent article about immigrant unrest in France's blue-collar suburbs omitted one important fact about French history (April 15). Today's working-class French suburban dweller can often trace his ancestry to former French colonies that existed from the mid-1800s until the early 1960s. Now, a century and a half after France colonized large portions of the Muslim world, the bitter fruits of that colonial era are obvious.

An article on April 22 about a DVD of the first season of the television series ''Maude'' misstated the date a two-part episode about abortion was broadcast. It was a few months before the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade in January 1973, not after.

In Rare Company Chipper Jones of the Braves is closing in on 2,000 hits (1,978). With a career .305 average, he is one of four switch-hitters in history with a .300 average (minimum 1,500 games played). Frankie Frisch, Pete Rose and Roberto Alomar are the others. The Padres will visit Atlanta for a four-game set that starts tomorrow night. No Time to Unpack Outfielder Ryan Langerhans was traded twice in less than a week. On April 29, he was sent to the A's from the Braves, then on May 2, he was traded to the Nationals. In 1977, Dave Kingman played for the Mets (N.L. East), the Padres (N.L. West), the Angels (A.L. West) and the Yankees (A.L. East), becoming the first player to wear four uniforms in four divisions in the same season. Langerhans has a long way to go for the record; there are now six divisions. Nice to See You The Astros visit the Reds for a four-game series that begins tomorrow. Roy Oswalt, who beat the Reds last Wednesday and has an 18-1 record against them in 23 games, is set to start the opener. Here are other active pitchers who have a certain team's number: WATCH LIST Some of Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel's critics called him crazy for moving his best starter, Brett Myers, right, to the bullpen last month. Crazy like a fox, now that closer Tom Gordon is on the disabled list. Myers, who has averaged more than 12 strikeouts per nine innings this season, had his first save Thursday and has allowed one earned run in nine relief appearances. Gordon had three blown saves in eight chances. Injuries to Reggie Sanders and Ryan Shealy should give Billy Butler plenty of time to establish himself as a big-leaguer. With the much-ballyhooed Alex Gordon hitting .169 more than a month into the season, Butler, who was hitting .337 with six homers at Class AAA, may turn out to be the Royals' top rookie this season. Craig Counsell and Tony Graffanino have been keeping third base warm for the Brewers prospect Ryan Braun. But those two were hitting a combined .231 with one home run. Braun was hitting .366 with eight homers at Class AAA. More impressive than those numbers in the offense-happy Pacific Coast League, though, is Braun's plate discipline. He has struck out 9 times and walked 11 times in 93 at-bats. Statistics through Friday night. (Sources by Atlanta Braves 2006 Media Guide; STATS, LLC; Baseball-library.com. )

DEUTSCH--Edith, died May 1 at age 67 years. Beloved wife of Alex Deutsch (deceased), loving mother of Adam and his wife Francine, and cherished grandmother of Eliana and Samuel. She will be forever in the hearts of her family and friends. Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in NYC.

MERRILL STUBBS ''It's always fun to experiment with something that's unpronounceable,'' says Merrill Stubbs, who sampled avgotaraho, Vacherin Fribourgeois and other just-hitting-the-radar finds for her column, ''The New Staples'' (Page 66). Savoring the role of culinary sleuth, she continually surveys her favorite specialty stores, like Brooklyn's D'Vine Taste, in search of ''ingredients that are not well known but will soon be discovered.'' That doesn't mean Stubbs, who is also hard at work testing recipes for an upcoming New York Times cookbook, is a food snob. Her favorite staple is something that most can relate to: roasted garlic and onion jam, which she slathers on pork roast and even on pronounceable cheeses.

Kork-Ease, the platform wedge sandal that took retail by storm last year with a combination of nostalgia, comfort and groove, has turned up the hip factor this season merely by growing an inch in height. Still, that single inch, while brilliantly simple, may also be simply brilliant. According to shoppers, if mothers are happy to walk around in the original version, their daughters can virtually sprint in the new four-inch Bette wedge. Look for Christina Aguilera in the French pink suede version, Sandra Bullock in the gold ($185 at www.ravinstyle.com).

CHAMBERLIN--Dorothy Jamieson, Delray Beach, FL, 102 years old, of 2105 Southwest 10th Court, Delray Beach, FL. formerly of Lakeville, CT, died April 11, 2007 at the Abbey Delray Health Center. In 1927, she graduated from Skidmore College. She was the wife of the late Mac A. Chamberlin who passed away on December 23, 1973. Mrs. Chamberlin and her husband Mac owned and operated the Wake Robin Inn in Lakeville, CT from 1945 to 1973. In 1964, the Chamberlins expanded their resort hotel business with the purchase of Surfside Apartments in Delray Beach, FL. Dorothy Chamberlin is survived by her sons, Winthrop Chamberlin of New York City and John Chamberlin of Leadville, CO, daughter-in-law, Lee and her grandchildren, Brandon, Felicity and Ned. Mrs. Chamberlin managed her own stock portfolio until she was 90 years old. She continued to drive to her summer home in Lakeville, CT until the early 90s and attributed her longevity to the fact that she did not play bridge. Memorial donations may be made in Mrs. Chamberlin's honor to The Dorothy Chamberlin Fund for Low Income New Yorkers, Community Service Society, 105 East 22nd Street, New York, NY 10010. $(6$)CHAMBERLIN--Dorothy J., The extended family of Orb Management expresses its deepest sympathy to our cofounder Winthrop D. Chamberlin on the death of his dear mother. May she rest in peace. $(6$)CHAMBERLIN--Dorothy J. The last generation, a widow who encouraged and courageously supported all our endeavors, A source of strength and solace, her wisdom and grace will sorely be missed. Barnet L. and Phyllis Liberman $(6$)CHAMBERLIN--Dorothy J. The officers and employees of Printing House Fitness Center express our deepest sympathy to the owner of our club, Winthrop D. Chamberlin and his family on the passing of his mother, Dorothy J. Chamberlin at 102. May her memory be a blessing. $(6$)CHAMBERLIN--Dorothy J. The Members and Employees of TruFresh LLC and its affiliates, Winterlab Scientific and Peacock Canning, note with sorrow the death of Dorothy Chamberlin, mother of our beloved co-founder, Winthrop D. Chamberlin. We extend our sincere sympathy to the family.

If Flannery O'Connor had reimagined ''Baby Doll'' while listening to John Lee Hooker, the result would be ''Black Snake Moan.'' The writer and director, Craig Brewer (who also made ''Hustle & Flow''), is a provocateur who's at his most heartfelt when he's at his most outrageous. The film's poster -- a mockup of a comic-book cover showing a scantily clad Christina Ricci wearing a chain held by a glowering Samuel L. Jackson, who towers over her -- so freaked out some people that, without even seeing the movie, they condemned it as misogynist. Others who did see it simply found it ludicrous.

An article on April 22 about five composers who were asked to write the music for a Roman Catholic Mass referred incorrectly to a difference between that Mass and the Greek Orthodox one -- a difference cited by the composer Ivan Moody. The word filioque (''and from the son''), which appears in the Catholic liturgy but not in Orthodox liturgy, occurs in the Credo section, not the Sanctus.

For years the customers of Burt's Bees, the all-natural skin care company with the unnaturally big cult following, clamored for sunblock. But because the company found it difficult to make an all-natural sunscreen with titanium dioxide that wasn't stiff and tacky, it wouldn't oblige. Now, with the help of technology and a little hemp-seed oil, Burt's Bees has produced Chemical-Free Sunscreen. The new SPF 15 sunscreen was so coveted that during the company's Bee-utify Your World tour earlier this year to promote natural products for skin and hair, it was the one sample that kept being stolen from displays. For shoppers who prefer to stay on the legal side of the pale, a 3.46-ounce tube costs $15 at www.burtsbees.com.

The United States men's under-17 national team, despite a 3-2 loss to Jamaica on Friday, clinched a berth in the FIFA U-17 World Cup when Trinidad and Tobago defeated Canada, 2-1, in an earlier game in Kingston, Jamaica. Costa Rica and the United States have advanced to the World Cup, which will be played in South Korea from Aug. 18 to Sept. 9. One more qualifier will emerge from among Canada, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago after games today.

This house in Pleasantville was one of the three ''Usonian'' homes designed by Frank Lloyd Wright as part of a community intended to reflect a modernist lifestyle and a connection to the natural world. Johanna Cooper, a 35-year resident of Usonia, has curated an exhibition about the community and its architect, ''Frank Lloyd Wright and Usonia: An Experiment in Living.'' Through June 24. Hours: Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. The Studio: An Alternative Space for Contemporary Art, 2 Maryland Avenue. www.thestudiony-alternative.org or (914) 273-1452.

When they hit the far turn in the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby, Elizabeth Jones Valando could not have asked for more: Nobiz Like Shobiz was moving quickly toward the leader, Hard Spun. Valando, 82, watched as Nobiz Like Shobiz pulled to four lengths behind at the top of the stretch. She had bred the colt and named him in honor of her late husband, Tommy, a music publisher and Broadway show backer. She also had turned down an offer to sell the colt for $17 million to Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai.

LEVERE--Dr. Richard D. The faculty of the Department of Medicine of New York Medical College and its affiliated hospitals and clinics from all over the Metropolitan New York region mourn the passing of Richard D. Levere, M.D., M.A.C.P. our esteemed colleague. Dr. Levere served as Chairman of the Department of Medicine at New York Medical College from 1977-1993 and Director of Medicine at Westchester Medical Center following a distinguished career as Chief of Hematology and Vice-Chairman of Medicine at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn. We wish to express our deepest sympathies to his entire family at this time of loss. William H. Frishman, M.D., M.A.C.P. Chairman Department of Medicine New York Medical College Director of Medicine Westchester Medical Center Valhalla, New York

JUST before the start of a T-ball game last summer, my son Christopher threw me a curve. As we walked toward our dugout, he stopped short, digging his cleats into the dirt around second base. He stood there frozen for a moment, staring through nervous eyes at a bunch of fellow 5-year-olds taking practice swings and fielding ground balls.

Buoyed by reports of possible mergers and acquisitions, stocks surged last week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to another record close on Friday. Last week, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation offered to buy Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion, and the Thomson Corporation of Canada made a takeover approach to the Reuters Group. In addition, there were reports on Friday of talks between Microsoft and Yahoo about a business partnership -- some said even a merger. And earlier in the week, Cablevision's board said it had accepted a buyout offer from the Dolan family, the company's founders -- subject to approval by shareholders, excluding the Dolans, officers and executives of the company.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Waiting Game on the Draft's Longest Day,'' April 29: The Times paid an inordinate amount of attention to the former Notre Dame quarterback Brady Quinn, who was drafted by the Cleveland Browns at No. 22. Barely any attention was paid to higher draft choices. I find this mystifying, but it is an indication of how Notre Dame is regarded among college football fans.

Calvin Borel began his career as a jockey when he was 8, riding at unsanctioned racetracks in Louisiana. He said he dropped out of school four years later when he was 12, intent on getting his education at the racetrack. Everything he did he did with one goal in mind: to become a successful jockey, which is the only thing he ever wanted to be. Borel's longtime quest reached a zenith Saturday at Churchill Downs as he won his first Kentucky Derby, guiding Street Sense to victory.

To the Editor: As the old saying goes, ''never kick a skunk,'' so I will not quarrel with Pamela Paul's callow review of ''Consumed'' (April 8), other than to acknowledge that I did confound the two Jennifers (Aniston and Lopez) and associated director Steven Soderbergh with the wrong blockbuster movie (neither mistake impacted my argument).

The incestuous teenage brother and sister of ''Les Enfants Terribles'' -- the delicate, effeminate Paul and the boyish, bossy Elisabeth -- are a study in complementary contrasts, a little like the men who actually made the 1950 movie. The writer, Jean Cocteau, had already written and directed ''La Belle et la Bête'' and ''Le Sang d'un Poéte.'' The director, Jean-Pierre Melville, who helped write the screenplay, had made only one film, but would go on to direct inventive and challenging gangster movies like ''Le Samourai'' and ''Le Cercle Rouge.'' There was only one chance for Cocteau's dreaminess to mesh with Mr. Melville's cleareyed practicality, and ''Les Enfants Terribles'' was it. The picture -- which would become the inspiration for ''The Dreamers'' by Bernardo Bertolucci -- is mesmerizing and unsettling: Paul (played by Edouard Dermithe, whose cheekbones appear to have been carved out of wax) moons first for a schoolboy classmate and later for a pretty, no-nonsense model who could be the schoolboy's twin. (Both characters are played by Renée Cosima.) Elisabeth (Nicole Stéphane, below, her eyes capable of the coldest calculation and appraisal) does nothing but lecture and berate Paul -- yet even her sharpness has a doting, cloying quality, as if, to keep Paul in her nest, she needed to cling to him with her talons.

Forty years after it first appeared in the L. L. Bean catalog, the women's French Sailor shirt, knit from fine Peruvian cotton that doesn't fade or fray, is enjoying a fashion renaissance. Stylish shoppers are snatching up the seaworthy topper, which comes in six color varieties. Due to demand, the company has recut the shirt in a Henley style, in addition to the classic crew neck and the popular quarter-zip pullover. This season, kids can be equally chic in pint-size versions of the original. Best of all, the shirt is easy to wear and to afford. The price range for women's shirts is $29.50 to $34.50; the price range for children's sizes is $14.50 to $19.50 (at www.llbean.com).

Jim Luttrell of The Times highlights some critical moments of the race. Curlin, the second favorite, drew the dangerous No. 2 post and was bumped early as the pack made its move for the rail. Hard Spun, breaking from the No. 8 post, was unimpeded and outraced Stormello for the lead. Street Sense was forced to check slightly, then Calvin Borel waited for the pack to pass and moved sharply to the rail. Hard Spun raced free of the pack coming off the turn and set quick fractions with Sedgefield, Teuflesberg and Cowtown Cat pressing the pace. The closers relaxed well back: Curlin, who had shown an ability to race on the lead and from behind in his brief career, was 14th; Street Sense was 19th; and Imawildandcrazyguy was 20th. Nobiz Like Shobiz moved to fifth but could not advance. Street Sense's path was blocked by Sedgefield. In need of luck as much as talent, Street Sense found it when Teuflesberg lugged out and faded badly. That gave him the opening he needed. Street Sense surged through and then moved around Sedgefield. Only Hard Spun stood in his way. Street Sense moved wide and easily overtook Hard Spun, then slid to the rail as Borel started to celebrate early. Hard Spun held on for second. Curlin, who had encountered trouble, moved five wide and got up for third. Imawildandcrazyguy ran wide the whole way and was in the middle of the track at the end.

Laura Anne Lyons, a daughter of Eleanor Fitzgerald Lyons and Joseph L. Lyons of Okatie, S.C., was married on Friday to Gregory French Karrh, a son of Paula French Karrh and J. Randolph C. Karrh Sr. of Swainsboro, Ga. Msgr. Michael J. Dempsey, a cousin of the bride, officiated at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Bluffton, S.C. Mr. and Mrs. Karrh, both 43, work in Bluffton for New Jersey-based residential home builders. She is a residential sales consultant for new homes for K. Hovnanian Companies; he is a service technician for Toll Brothers. The bride graduated from Fordham. The bridegroom graduated from the University of Georgia.

Franklin D. Raines, former chairman of the mortgage giant Fannie Mae, suffered a setback last week in his legal battle to hold onto as much as $84.6 million in bonuses. Mr. Raines was ousted from Fannie Mae in 2004 over accounting mistakes at the company. The Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight has accused Mr. Raines and other top Fannie Mae officers of manipulating earnings to maximize their bonuses.
MARCUS--Lawrence N. Admired by many, adored by his daughters. Susan, Jane, Ann & Lynn

It almost seems dangerous to put these two pictures by the elusive French filmmaker Chris Marker on a single disc: this is an exploding world in one compact package. Mr. Marker's 1983 ''Sans Soleil'' is a travelogue of sorts, the story of one man's journey -- his delightfully fictional name is Sandor Krasna -- told through letters he has written to the woman who narrates. She reads these letters, which consist of loops of seemingly disconnected observations (''The Japanese invented CinemaScope 10 centuries before the movies''; ''History throws its empty bottles out the window''), as a soundtrack to the movie's drifting yet vivid collage of images. Mr. Marker shows us women in a West African marketplace, first timid about meeting the gaze of his lens, then defiantly challenging it; a pile of broken Japanese dolls being burned in an offering to the goddess of compassion; scraps from Alfred Hitchcock's ''Vertigo.'' Confounding and seductive, a meditation on memory, history and ritual, ''Sans Soleil'' is a handbook of the infinite ways in which it is possible to experience the world.

I STUMBLED over the accordion in the basement, its case already as deep in water as I was -- water pouring in from foundation crevices, billowing up through floor tiles into the fringed magenta rug and, more repulsively, backing up from the street through the sewer cap that we had opened in a feeble attempt to drain away the flood. The April northeaster had hit New Jersey, and we were in its path. The accordion, which had belonged to my father-in-law, had been there for the eight years since his death. I could almost hear him say to my husband, ''Richie, it's O.K. to get rid of it now.'' But my husband couldn't bring himself to do it, despite the cracked bellows, keys and valves that rendered it beyond reasonable repair. It sat on the floor behind the bar, untouched. Now the muddy, insistent waters lashed at the seams of its old case, worming their way into the blue velvet interior.

''Dirty Dancing'' celebrates 20 years with a new edition, and a bunch of John Wayne vehicles, including ''The Quiet Man,'' arrive in spiffed-up versions (Tuesday). Guillermo del Toro's lovely fairy tale, ''Pan's Labyrinth,'' comes to DVD (May 15). Criterion releases Shohei Imamura's brutal tale of the pursuit of a serial killer, ''Vengeance Is Mine'' (May 15). James Brown, Marvin Gaye (below), the Rolling Stones, Lesley Gore and the great surf-rock duo Jan and Dean, as your hosts -- now that's what we call a party! -- shake up the legendary '60s concert movie ''The T.A.M.I. Show'' on DVD at long last (May 15). Three from Howard Hawks (May 22): Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck as an egghead and a showgirl in ''Ball of Fire,'' his retelling of ''Snow White''; John Wayne, Dean Martin, Angie Dickinson and Ricky Nelson in Hawks's greatest achievement, ''Rio Bravo''; and -- finally -- the release of the original ''Scarface,'' with Paul Muni and a bowling scene you'll never forget. Criterion releases Kenji Mizoguchi's ''Sansho the Bailiff'' (May 22) and Jean-Pierre Melville's overwhelming drama of the French resistance, ''Army of Shadows'' (May 15). Dustin Hoffman gives one of his most praised performances as a paroled con in ''Straight Time'' (May 22). And Peter O'Toole, in the raw, affecting ''Venus'' (May 22), gives a great performance.

When a movie is praised for teaching a worthy moral lesson, that's usually a good reason to steer clear. But the lessons of the colorful, exciting 1950 western ''Broken Arrow'' stay with you because they're learned at such a hard price. The director, Delmer Daves, doesn't resort to preaching to deliver the message about the poisonousness of racism. He lets this stirring movie tell its own story and trusts the audience to get it. For the DVD release, Fox has restored Ernest Palmer's gorgeous Technicolor photography and, in a very classy move, something just as important: the name of the blacklisted screenwriter, Albert Maltz, whose work, in 1950, had to be credited to a front.

Those seeking a lesson in how to shake people up for money may want to take a page from the playbook of Hilary M. Weston, who has led fund-raising efforts for the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto. Mrs. Weston apparently knew which buttons to push when she approached the Canadian businessman Michael Lee-Chin several years ago to donate money for a new museum wing. He agreed to be the lead donor for the wing, which is called the Michael Lee-Chin Crystal.

Street Sense, the 9-2 favorite, became the first Breeders' Cup Juvenile champion to win the Derby. Nikki Blonsky, the astonishing imp who plays Tracy Turnblad in the new movie version of ''Hairspray'' (July 20), has a back story almost as good as Tracy's. For anyone unacquainted with John Waters's 1988 movie or the hit Broadway musical, Tracy is a heavyset teenager in 1962 Baltimore who longs to be one of the cool kids on the Corny Collins television dance show and ends up its star. Ms. Blonsky, now 18, is a heavyset teenager from Great Neck, N.Y., with many school productions on her résumé but no professional experience. Told last year that New Line Cinema was conducting a national search for the perfect girl to play Tracy in its film adaptation of the musical, she made a video of herself doing two of the show's numbers and snail-mailed it to the studio's New York address. Not sure who it was intended for, a young man in the mailroom posted it on the production's MySpace site, where the casting director watched it and summoned Ms. Blonsky to audition for the director, Adam Shankman.

ONE giant cardboard box held hundreds of power cords, coiled like snakes, and a tower of computer monitors, wrapped in plastic, stood six feet high. Piled on a wooden pallet were electronic relics -- like a Soundesign combination record player-radio-eight-track player. Montclair's biannual electronic-waste collection had been under way for less than an hour, and dozens of residents had already dropped off carloads of so-called e-waste.

JENNY--Morris. A year ago God saw that you were getting tired and the cure was not to be. He put his arms around you and whispered, ''come with me''. A golden heart stopped beating, hard working hands at rest. God broke our hearts to prove to us He only takes the very best. We will never stop missing you. Loving wife Gail, sons Charles and Robert and the entire Jenny and Gershfamily.

To the Editor: It's a pity that ''Budget Airlines: Adventures in Low-Cost Travel (Affordable Europe, April 22) by Matt Gross didn't point out that the train can often be a cheaper and much more pleasant alternative to low-cost flights in Europe. I will be traveling from Brussels to Nice via TGV (train à grande vitesse, or very fast train). The trip, booked in advance, cost less than a no-frills airline ticket after taxes and surcharges. It will take a little longer, but not too much when you consider the time spent traveling to and from the regional airports that low-cost airlines usually use.

Jason DeParle (April 22) does an important service by putting a human face on migration. But economic remittances are not the only things migrants send back to their homelands. They also send back social remittances. Depending on what they have witnessed, migrants often demand more from their governments. They want institutions that work, political voice and jobs that are allocated on the basis of merit, not on whom you know. This is a piece of the puzzle that development planners and world bankers should not overlook.
STANWELL--Ann, died May 4, 2007. Actress, artist, and loyal friend to animals and people. Deirdre Owens

To the Editor: Fernanda Eberstadt, writing about Carmen Laforet's post-Spanish Civil War novel, ''Nada'' (April 15), remarks that ''the idea that there might be a lone woman in what seems the unrelievedly male pantheon of Spanish novelists of the post-Civil War era ... was like discovering an extra story built in a house you thought you knew.''

THE recent heavy storms that left downtown Manville, N.J., under 10 feet of water; filled the basements of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and flooded rivers and downed power lines in Connecticut may have provided a glimpse of our future. Climate change is accelerating, and the prognosis for the region is alarming, as it is for the rest of the world. No matter how effectively we begin to curb our greenhouse-gas emissions now, we are destined to see significant climate changes because these gases remain in the atmosphere for a long time. We cannot delay planning for the environmental and human calamities that lie ahead. All over the world, according to the 2007 scientific report of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, ''it is very likely that hot extremes, heat waves and heavy precipitation events will continue to become more frequent.'' But we need look no further than our own backyard to find evidence of warming. Since 1950, average summer temperatures in New York City have increased by seven-tenths of a degree per decade, but for the last 20 years, by more than two degrees per decade.

To the Editor: As a former rider of a fixed-gear bicycle (with a front brake, by the way), I was generally annoyed by Jocko Weyland's focus on hipsters and fashion in his April 29 article, ''Unstoppable.'' These things may be what are making fixed gears trendy, but Kyle Fay got to the real source of fixed-gear fanaticism, which is ''being one with the bike.'' On a fixed gear, the power from your down stroke is returned to your legs on the up stroke of your pedals. This is unnerving at first but addictive and empowering. Whether your bike is beautiful or not, if you can't relate to it as an extension of yourself you're going to be thrown off your fixed gear. I received my first fixed gear after the death of my mother, and the feeling of my bike being alive, giving back to me and walking alongside me (the pedals never stop turning) cheered me in ways I can't describe. Mira Friedlaender Park Slope, Brooklyn To the Editor: As a longtime traffic safety advocate, I shudder to think of cyclists riding ''brakeless'' bicycles in any high-traffic-density area. Indeed, a city bicycle should have all the equipment possible to ensure not only the cyclist's safety but that of the pedestrians sharing these crowded urban spaces. Bette Dewing Upper East Side To the Editor: Your article about fixed-gear bicycles without brakes neglected to mention that riding without a brake is illegal in the state of New York; see Vehicle and Traffic Law 1236(c). Tom Ace Lone Pine, Calif. To the Editor: More than half a century ago in pre-Communist China, I once owned a ''fixie'' just like those described by Jocko Weyland in ''Unstoppable.'' It was the most pleasurable bicycle I had ridden in my high school days. I had a wonderful time racing against automobiles in the narrow streets of Shanghai until one day I came face to face with an oncoming trolley. Fortunately the trolley operator stopped short as I tried to slow down. The body of my bike was bent, but I was not hurt except for a few bruises on my leg. That was the end of my romance with a ''fixie.'' Timothy Tung Gramercy

To the Editor: ''Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 29), resonated with me, as I have just completed the college admissions process with my high school senior.

It's been eaten by Japanese noblemen for centuries; it contains phytins, which are thought to prevent cancer; and it's said to be impervious to the Heimlich maneuver. We're talking about the magic of mochi, a chewy dough made from pounding glutinous rice that's traditionally filled with something sweet and baked. For years, regulars at Nobu have been whispering ''the mochi'' to conclude a satisfying meal. But lately the gospel is spreading. Mochi-wrapped ice cream is at Whole Foods, and it's available as a topping at the frozen-yogurt chain Pinkberry. It's also popping up at restaurants like David Chang's Momofuku SsÃ

JUST before the start of a T-ball game last summer, my son Christopher threw me a curve. As we walked toward our dugout, he stopped short, digging his cleats into the dirt around second base. He stood there frozen for a moment, staring through nervous eyes at a bunch of fellow 5-year-olds taking practice swings and fielding ground balls.

BUCKLE UP The News -- The governor of New Jersey, Jon Corzine, paid a $46 fine for failing to wear a seat belt the night his state vehicle crashed, nearly killing him. Behind the News -- The Chevrolet Suburban he was riding in last month was traveling at 91 miles an hour as he rushed to a meeting between Don Imus and members of the Rutgers women's basketball team. Mr. Corzine was thrown from the front passenger seat to the back, breaking his left femur, his sternum and 11 ribs. Leaving the hospital in a wheelchair last week, 18 days after the accident, he acknowledged: ''I set a very bad example.'' SLOW DOWN The News -- The California Highway Patrol says the driver of a gasoline tanker was speeding when he crashed, causing a fire that destroyed a vital highway interchange near downtown Oakland. Behind the News -- The driver, James Mosqueda, 51, lost control on a curve in what's known as the MacArthur Maze early last Sunday and hit a guardrail before overturning with a full load of gasoline, the authorities said. He walked away with second-degree burns. But the fire buckled a concrete and steel overpass, sending it crashing on Interstate 880. Contractors hope to have a ramp connecting the two highways reopened by next weekend. BUNT NEXT TIME? The News -- Chipper Jones, the third baseman for the Atlanta Braves, hit a line drive to the rookie Colorado Rockies shortstop Troy Tulowitzki, who turned it into an unassisted triple play. Behind the News -- The game was tied when Jones came to the plate in the seventh inning with Atlanta's Kelly Johnson and Edgar Renteria on base. On a 3-2 count, Jones hit a line drive at Tulowitzki, who caught the ball, stepped on second base to double up Johnson and then tagged Renteria as he ran toward second. The Rockies won, 9-7, in the 11th inning. ''It kind of just fell in my lap,'' said Tulowitzki of the 13th unassisted triple play in major league history. DON'T CHEAT The News -- Dozens of students at the United States Air Force Academy and at the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University were caught cheating, with some being expelled or suspended. Behind the News -- At the Air Force Academy, a group of cadets, all freshman, were found to have cheated on a weekly multiple choice test by sharing answers on the Internet. Fifteen were expelled, 3 resigned and 13 more were placed on probation. At Duke, pictured above, a judicial board found that 34 business graduate students had cheated on a take-home exam; 9 face expulsion and the rest face lesser penalties, including suspension and a failing grade in the course. TELL THE TRUTH The News -- John Browne, the longtime chief executive of BP, resigned abruptly last week after acknowledging he lied to a court about a younger man with whom he had a sexual relationship. Behind the News -- Mr. Browne, 59, transformed BP into one of the most successful global companies. But his downfall came after he admitted he lied to a judge when he tried to block a London tabloid from printing allegations of wrongdoing made by the man. Mr. Browne told the court he met him by chance in a park; news reports said they met through an escort service. His resignation cost him more than $30 million in lost retirement and stock benefits.

To the Editor: Re ''Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 29): Having just graduated from Harvard last year, I can attest that a degree from this institution does not automatically bestow the solid values, sense of self or well-defined interests that are essential to a productive and happy life. If anything, running in the proverbial wheel fast enough to get past the modern Harvard admissions gods gives almost no time for introspection at an impressionable age.

To the Editor: I take issue with ''Live Near a Highway? Don't Expect Quiet,'' the April 15 letter regarding sound barriers. First, the Connecticut Legislature's Transportation Committee approved $10 million to build new sound barriers, not merely to study where they should be built. The Department of Transportation has already completed such a study, based on scientific decibel counts.
Or muffins.
To the Sports Editor: I am no Red Sox fan, but it seems that the hubbub over Curt Schilling's sock is a bit ridiculous (''Welcome to Red Sock Nation,'' April 27).
KALLIR-FRANK--Lilian, May 6th, 1931-Oct. 25th, 2004. You are in our thoughts and hearts, today and always. Happy 3rd birthday in Heaven.

Now that the word ''interim'' has been removed from James M. Cornelius's title at Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, he will have to pay more money for his living expenses. When Mr. Cornelius was interim C.E.O., Bristol-Myers was spending $25,500 a month for a furnished apartment in New York for Mr. Cornelius, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

INTERNATIONAL 3-25 A Trail of Toxic Medicine Government officials in Panama unwittingly mixed a poison, diethylene glycol, into 260,000 bottles of cold medicine, resulting in at least 100 deaths. Records and interviews link this and three such mass poisonings around the world to Chinese companies that exported the poison as glycerin. 1 U.S. Damage Control in Iraq Unclassified documents suggest that senior American officers viewed the killings of Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005 as a potential public relations problem that required an immediate, if misleading, response. 1 A Subdued Exit for Blair Tony Blair of Britain, who is expected to announce the schedule for his last weeks as prime minister on Thursday, prepares to leave office burdened by an unpopular war and down in the ratings. 8 Last Jabs in French Race Ségolène Royal and Nicolas Sarkozy ended their campaigns for the French presidency with biting personal attacks on each other. 4 Attacks Across Afghanistan A wave of suicide attacks in four provinces of Afghanistan killed two police officers and wounded a NATO soldier and two other Afghan policemen, officials said. 14 Hidden Exiles in Lebanon At least 3,000 of the 400,000 Palestinian refugee families living in Lebanon failed to get refugee status, without which they cannot get identification cards, graduate from school, legally marry, hold a job, or set foot outside of their rundown camps. 12 Hamas Assails U.S. Plan Hamas, which leads the government of the Palestinian Authority and dominates its legislature, poured scorn on American proposals to increase Palestinian movement and Israeli security. 12 NATIONAL 26-35 Antiwar Groups Affect Debate The Iraq deliberations in Congress have lurched from a symbolic resolution rebuking the president's strategy to timetables for the withdrawal of American troops. Behind the scenes, an elaborate political operation organized by a coalition of antiwar groups and fine-tuned to wrestle members of Congress into place one by one has helped nudge the debate forward. 1 Gun Rights Consensus Ends In March, for the first time in the nation's history, a federal appeals court struck down a gun control law on Second Amendment grounds. There used to be an almost complete scholarly and judicial consensus that the Second Amendment protects only the states' right to maintain militias. That consensus no longer exists. 1 Kansas Tornado Kills Nine A wave of tornadoes ripped through Oklahoma and southwest Kansas the day after a tornado tore through the town of Greensburg, Kan., killing at least nine people and leveling most of the city. 35 SPORTSSUNDAY 1-12 Street Sense Takes Derby Street Sense charged from 19th place to claim the Kentucky Derby. Street Sense, a 9-2 favorite, became the first Breeders' Cup Juvenile champion to win the Derby. SP1 NEW YORK/REGION 37-43 Newark On the Rise After four decades of economic stagnation and unbecoming publicity, Newark, New Jersey's largest city, is enjoying the kind of psychic rebirth that has helped transform other downtrodden cities into nesting grounds for the young, creative and well-heeled. 37 Chess 43 Weather 32
