LANE--Mildred. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Mildred Lane, beloved mother of Clifford Lane, whose generosity on Long Island enables us to renew and enrich Jewish life in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mildred's children Clifford and Randi, Stewart and Bonnie, Arlene and Daniel Fisher, and to her entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O

All dates are subject to change. May Opened Missing Victor Pellerin The title of Sophie Deraspe's documentary refers to a Montreal artist who disappeared in the early '90s after burning his work. Waitress Adrienne Shelly, who was murdered last November, directed, wrote and stars in this comedy about a small-town waitress (Keri Russell) who bakes pies flavored to match her many moods, moods that take a downturn when she finds that she's pregnant by her lout of a husband (Jeremy Sisto), although she becomes seriously enamored of her obstetrician (Nathan Fillion). With Cheryl Hines. [Article, Page 11.] Away from Her The Canadian actress Sarah Polley directs her first feature film, an adaptation of an Alice Munro story about a couple (Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent) whose marriage of almost 50 years is threatened by Alzheimer's. Civic Duty An unemployed accountant (Peter Krause) suspects the Muslim graduate student next door (Khaled Abol Naga) of being a terrorist. When the F.B.I. won't listen, he takes matters into his own trembling hands. Jeff Renfroe directs. The Flying Scotsman Jonny Lee Miller stars as Graeme Obree, a champion bicycle racer who built his mount out of washing-machine spare parts but later suffered some biopic-friendly mental health problems. Douglas Mackinnon directs; with Laura Fraser, Billy Boyd and Brian Cox. L'Iceberg A studied, Tati-like comedy from the team of Dominique Abel, Fiona Gordon and Bruno Romy, about a middle-class wife and mother (Ms. Gordon) whose priorities are drastically altered after she survives a night locked in the cold storage room of the fast-food restaurant she manages. The Last Time A cynical salesman (Michael Keaton) finds himself falling for the gorgeous wife (Amber Valletta) of his new partner (Brendan Fraser). A comedy-drama-thriller, directed and written by Michael Caleo. Lucky You Making its third and final appearance on this list, Curtis Hanson's romantic drama, originally scheduled for release in March 2006, concerns an aspiring singer (Drew Barrymore) who meets a professional poker player (Eric Bana) in Las Vegas. Robert Duvall co-stars. Paris Je T'Aime Twenty short films by 20 filmmakers celebrating the 20 arrondissements of Paris. Among the talents involved: Olivier Assayas, Gurinder Chadha, Alfonso Cuarón, Alexander Payne, Gérard Depardieu, Joel and Ethan Coen and Wes Craven. September Dawn The deadly 1857 confrontation of a Mormon militia and a wagon train of Arkansas settlers near Mountain Meadows in southwestern Utah, recounted in a film directed by Christopher Cain and starring Terence Stamp, Jon Voight and Dean Cain (the director's son). Spider-Man 3 Peter Parker (Tobey Maguire) discovers his dark side when his Spider-Man suit turns black and his sunny personality takes a turn into surliness. His girlfriend, Mary Jane Watson (Kirsten Dunst) is devastated, but the local supervillains (Thomas Haden Church as Sandman, Topher Grace as Venom) see an opportunity to get back in the game. Sam Raimi directs; with James Franco, Bryce Dallas Howard, James Cromwell, Rosemary Harris and Theresa Russell. [Article, Page 4.] The Treatment Chris Eigeman stars as a New York City prep school teacher with a controlling psychoanalyst (Ian Holm) and a wealthy, young, widowed lover (Famke Janssen) in Oren Rudavsky's adaptation of Daniel Menaker's 1998 novel. With Blair Brown, Roger Rees and Harris Yulin. Wednesday Allegro From Denmark, the tale of a concert pianist (Ulrich Thomsen) who finds that fame has not brought him happiness. Christoffer Boe directs. Brand Upon the Brain! The director Guy Maddin takes his acclaimed performance piece -- a pseudo-autobiographical fantasy that requires a live narrator and a pair of sound effects artists -- on the road, beginning in New York, where the guest narrators will include Isabella Rossellini and Suzanne Vega. Day Night Day Night After making the world film festival tour, Julia Loktev's New York indie returns to the city of its conception for a commercial release. Luisa Williams plays the enigmatic lead character, identified only as ''She,'' who is preparing an earth-shaking act of terrorism. I Don't Want to Sleep Alone Tsai Ming-liang, the minimalist filmmaker who has shot most of his work (''The Wayward Cloud,'' ''Goodbye Dragon Inn'') in Taiwan, returns to his native Malaysia for his most recent study in stalled desire. Mr. Tsai's eternal leading man, Lee Kang-sheng, plays someone who is badly beaten when a con game goes wrong; he has two competing caregivers, a shy young worker (Norman Atun) and a brassy waitress (Chen Shiang-chyi). Looking for an Icon A documentary by Hans Pool and Maaik Krijgsman that looks at the history behind four famous photographs that became political symbols, including Eddie Adams's unforgettable 1968 image of the point-blank shooting of a Viet Cong prisoner. Friday Casting About The agony of the audition, as depicted in a documentary featuring footage of 180 actresses competing for three roles in a movie. Barry J. Hershey directs. Delta Farce Dan Whitney, known professionally as Larry the Cable Guy, joins D J Qualls and Bill Engvall as National Guardsmen who think they're heading to Iraq but accidentally get dropped off in Mexico. Hilarity ensues under the direction of C. B. Harding (''Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie''). The EX One little mistake, and Zach Braff finds himself married to his pregnant girlfriend (Amanda Peet), living in Ohio and working for her father's advertising agency. Jesse Peretz directs this instructional comedy; with Charles Grodin and Mia Farrow. Georgia Rule Your chance to compare two generations of major movie stars as Jane Fonda, playing a flinty Idaho farmer, takes over the care of her spoiled, unruly grandchild, played in a major stretch of her acting talent by Lindsay Lohan. With Felicity Huffman, Dermot Mulroney and Garrett Hedlund; the direction is in the practiced hands of Garry Marshall. The Hip Hop Project A profile of Chris Rolle, also known as Kharma Kazi, who runs a program for aspiring young rappers in New York City. The Other Conquest Released in Mexico in 2000, Salvador Carrasco's epic film recounts the Spanish invasion of the Aztec empire. With Damián Delgado, José Carlos Rodríguez and Elpidia Carrillo. Provoked The Bollywood superstar Aishwarya Rai stars in the true story of an abused wife who set her husband on fire. Jag Mundhra directed a cast including Naveen Andrews, Miranda Richardson, Rebecca Pidgeon and Robbie Coltrane. The Salon Vivica A. Fox fights City Hall to keep her neighborhood beauty salon open when the Department of Water and Power threatens to seize her land for a development project. Mark Brown, who wrote and produced ''Barbershop,'' directs as well this time. With Terrence Howard and Monica Calhoun. ShowBusiness: The Road to Broadway Dori Berinstein's documentary follows four shows through the course of the 2003-4 Broadway season -- ''Wicked,'' ''Taboo,'' ''Caroline, or Change'' and ''Avenue Q'' -- building up to the big moment when all four are nominated for Tony Awards. 28 Weeks Later Juan Carlos Fresnadillo (''Intacto'') directed this sequel to Danny Boyle's zombie hit of 2000, ''28 Days Later.'' A decent interval has passed, and the United States Army is helping the beleaguered British set up a safe ''Green Zone'' in central London. Do we smell allegory here? With Robert Carlyle, Rose Byrne, Jeremy Renner and Catherine McCormack. May 16 The Changeling The director Jay Stern has designed his indie adaptation of the Jacobean revenge play by Thomas Middleton and William Rowley as ''period-piece pulp fiction.'' May 18 Brooklyn Rules Three friends with different priorities (going to law school, joining the mob, loafing around) grow up in Brooklyn in the '80s. Michael Corrente directs from a script by Terence Winter; with Freddie Prinze Jr., Scott Caan and Jerry Ferrara. Captivity Already notorious for its grisly bondage billboards in Los Angeles, this is a ''Saw''-like story of a man and a woman who wake up to find themselves being held prisoner in a dark, dank cellar, with no idea what they're doing there. The audience, however, has its suspicions. The unlikely director is Roland Joffé, who seems to have lowered his sights since ''The Killing Fields.'' Even Money The veteran director Mark Rydell (''The Rose,'' ''On Golden Pond'') climbs back into the saddle for a story of gambling addiction and how it destroys the lives of three people. The name-heavy cast includes Kim Basinger, Forest Whitaker, Danny DeVito and Kelsey Grammer. Fay Grim Hal Hartley, the cinematic poet laureate of Long Island (''Trust,'' ''Simple Men'') now living in Berlin, offers a sequel to his whimsical-paranoid ''Henry Fool'' of 1997. Parker Posey returns as the friend and lover of Henry, the mysterious literary genius, left on her own with his son when he disappeared. She gets word that the Parisian police have recovered portions of the manuscript of Henry's lost masterpiece, and flies off to investigate as a C.I.A. operative (Jeff Goldblum) stays on her tail. With James Urbaniak and Saffron Burrows. Flanders Set in the blood-soaked fields of World War I, Bruno Dumont's film is a contemporary story about a peasant farmer (played by a nonprofessional actor, Samuel Boidin) who returns from a distant, inhumane war. Will his love for his childhood sweetheart (Adélaïde Leroux) prove to be enough to have saved him from savagery? Mr. Dumont's stark, brutalist, sometimes comically literal work puts off many viewers, but he's one of the few French filmmakers of his generation with a point of view. Once The critical hit at this year's Sundance festival is an Irish film, directed and written by John Carney, about a Dublin street musician (Glen Hansard of the Frames) who teams up with a Czech immigrant (Marketa Irglova) with musical ambitions of her own. Private Property Tension mounts between a middle-aged woman (Isabelle Huppert) and her adult twin sons (the brothers Jérémie and Yannick Renier) when they refuse to move out and allow her to lead a life of her own. Joachim Lafosse directed this French-language family drama. Severance ''The Office'' meets ''Hostel'' in a British splatter comedy about a bunch of office drones forced to attend a weekend retreat at a hunting lodge in the Carpathians. But the woods are full of dead-eyed Serbian guerillas, and soon both the blood and the smug wisecracks are flying. Christopher Smith directs; with Toby Stephens and Laura Harris. Shortcut to Happiness Stephen Vincent Benet's story ''The Devil and Daniel Webster'' gets another film treatment. Alec Baldwin is the uncredited director and also plays a leading role, though the star is Anthony Hopkins, as a writer who sells his soul to a more alluring Devil than usual, played by Jennifer Love Hewitt. With Dan Aykroyd, Kim Cattrall and John Savage. Shrek the Third The lovable animated ogre with the voice of Mike Myers is back and in a moral bind. Forced to take over the throne when his royal father-in-law falls ill, he can't imagine ever leaving his precious bog. But duty calls, in the zaftig form of Princess Fiona (Cameron Diaz). With the voices of Eddie Murphy, Antonio Banderas, Rupert Everett, Julie Andrews, and Justin Timberlake. Chris Miller is the director, with Raman Hui. The Wendell Baker Story The Wilson brothers team up, with Luke Wilson as the title character, an ex-con who gets a job at a nursing home where the adorable oldsters (Seymour Cassel, Harry Dean Stanton and Kris Kristofferson) advise him on how to win back the girlfriend (Eva Mendes) he lost during his prison term. Andrew Wilson and Luke Wilson are the directors; another brother, Owen Wilson, turns up as the home's evil head nurse. May 23 The Boss of It All Lars von Trier takes a vacation from the moral excoriation of the ''Dogville'' trilogy to create a funny, tiny, but no less thought-provoking comedy about an actor (Jens Albinus, the cult leader in ''The Idiots'') who is hired to impersonate a fictive corporate head: an imaginary ''no man'' invented by the actual boss of the company (Peter Gantzler) to take the heat for unpopular decisions. With the radiant Iben Hjejle, not much seen in the United States since her turn in ''High Fidelity.'' I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal A profile of the Mauthausen concentration camp survivor and Nazi hunter, who helped build cases against 1,100 people, including Adolf Eichmann and Josef Mengele. Directed by Richard Trank; narrated by Nicole Kidman. 9 Star Hotel The Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar documents the Palestinian workers who cross illegally into Israel for work, often risking their lives. Orange Winter The scandal-plagued Ukrainian presidential election of 2004 and its aftermath of unrest and repression, as documented by the Ukrainian-American filmmaker Andrei Zagdansky. May 25 Amu A young woman of Indian descent is torn between her loyalty to her adoptive parents in Canada and the powerful sense of homecoming she feels when she visits Delhi. Shonali Bose's film was censored in India for daring to refer to the riots in Delhi that followed the assassination of Indira Gandhi in 1984. Angel-A The French director Luc Besson (''La Femme Nikita'') once promised that he'd quit after 10 features; this is the 10th. It's a duet starring the lovable French-Algerian comedian Jamel Debbouze as a Parisian deeply in debt to gangsters; he prevents Angela, a tall, blond Dane (Rie Rasmussen) from killing herself, and earns himself a new protector. There is a plot twist, subtly tipped by the title. In glorious black-and-white, photographed by Thierry Arbogast. Bug Tracy Letts's 2004 Off Broadway play, set largely in a sordid Western hotel where a returning soldier (Michael Shannon) manages to convince his bartending neighbor (Ashley Judd) that his body is being devastated by a ''bug'' he caught in the Middle East. William Friedkin (''The Exorcist'') directed. [Article, Page 31.] The Golden Door The immigrant experience of the early 1900s as scrupulously and poetically recreated by the Italian filmmaker Emanuele Crialese (''Respiro''). Vincenzo Amato plays the poor Sicilian farmer who packs up his family and sets sail for America. With Charlotte Gainsbourg, who seems on board mainly to justify the French co-production money. Hollywood Dreams The indie stalwart Henry Jaglom (''Always'') presents his new discovery, Tanna Frederick, as a small-town girl from Iowa who goes to Los Angeles in search of the usual fame and fortune. With Justin Kirk, Karen Black and Melissa Leo. Paprika From one of Japan's masters of anime, Satoshi Kon, comes a many-layered science fiction tale, built around a headphonelike device that allows scientists to tap into and influence people's dreams. The title character is a pert redhead who appears when dreamers need guidance, which is pretty often, given the scary dream, a sort of mad parade of imaginary characters, in which they've been trapped. Pirates of the Caribbean: At the End of the World Widely expected to be The Big One this summer, Gore Verbinski's film will be the final chapter in the ''Pirates'' franchise. Chow Yun-Fat joins the cast (Keira Knightley, Orlando Bloom, Geoffrey Rush) as a Chinese pirate who takes the side of Captain Jack (Johnny Depp) against an ever more demented Davy Jones (Bill Nighy). And even Keith Richards puts in an appearance. June June 1 And Then Came Love When her little boy pleads for a daddy, a single mother (Vanessa Williams) decides to track down the anonymous sperm donor who made him possible. Kevin Daniels, Eartha Kitt, Stephen Spinella and Ben Vereen co-star in this romantic comedy directed by Richard Schenkman. Crazy Love Dan Klores's documentary recounts a famously bizarre tabloid romance of the 1950s, featuring a married lawyer whose love for a Bronx beauty led to some hideous and improbable consequences. Day Watch The Russian director Timur Bekmambetov follows his creative contemporary vampire story, ''Night Watch,'' with a livelier sequel. Who will acquire the all-powerful ''Chalk of Fate'': the good spirits on the day watch or the evil entities who rule at night? Four Lane Highway The life of a college town layabout (Fred Weller) takes a radical turn when he decides to drive to New York to attend the gallery opening of an ex-girlfriend (Greer Goodman). With Elizabeth Rodriguez and Reg Rogers; written and directed by Dylan McCormick. Gracie An inspirational story inspired by the Shue family and set in the antediluvian '70s, where a plucky 16-year-old named Gracie leads the national campaign to make high school soccer available to girls. Directed by Davis Guggenheim, whose last film was the documentary ''An Inconvenient Truth.'' With Elisabeth Shue, the director's wife, and her brother Andrew; both are among the film's producers. Knocked Up The director Judd Apatow tries to top his ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin'' with a comedy about a young and ambitious entertainment journalist, played by Katherine Heigl, who faces some tough decisions when she becomes pregnant after a one-night stand with a likable loser (Seth Rogen). Paul Rudd co-stars. [Article, Page 4.] Mr. Brooks Kevin Costner struggles to remain relevant, starring as a beloved small-town businessman who harbors a secret identity (played by William Hurt) as a serial killer. Bruce A. Evans directs; with Demi Moore and Dane Cook. [Article, Page 11.] Pierrepoint The sly British actor Timothy Spall stars as Britain's most celebrated executioner in the 1950s, a family man whose day job is delivering groceries. Adrian Shergold directed from Jeff Pope's script; with Juliet Stevenson and Eddie Marsan. Ten Canoes Rolf de Heer, one of Australia's most original filmmakers (''Dance Me to My Song''), worked with the Ramingining Aboriginal people to create this imaginative collage of folk tales and tribal history. June 6 12:08 East of Bucharest From Romania, the country that gave us ''The Death of Mr. Lazarescu,'' another mordant comedy. The scene is a television studio, where a variety of guests, all with different recollections, share their memories of the downfall of Nicolai Ceausescu in 1989. Corneliu Porumboiu directs. June 8 BELLE TOUJOURS The veteran Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira dares to imagine a sequel to Luis Buñuel's 1967 classic ''Belle de Jour.'' Forty years later two of the protagonists in that film, the bourgeois housewife turned happy hooker (Bulle Ogier, stepping in for Catherine Deneuve) and her husband's discreet best friend (Michel Piccoli, returning to the role he created), meet for dinner in a private room at a traditional Paris restaurant. They alternately reminisce and bicker, as the candles lighting their encounter burn to nubbins. Hostel: Part II This time it's three female American exchange students who are lured into a Slovakian den of torture. The director, again, is the uninhibited Eli Roth, who, in a Tarantino-like move, has invited two cult actors from the violent Italian ''gialli'' thrillers of the 1970s to join the cast: Luc Merenda and Edwige Fenech. And in-joke tops in-joke, with a cameo by the director Ruggero Deodato (''Cannibal Holocaust'') as a character named Fulci, a nod to the cult director Lucio Fulci. La Vie en Rose Marion Cotillard plays France's most famous torch singer, Edith Piaf, in a biography directed by Olivier Dahan (''La Vie Promise''). A solid supporting cast includes Sylvie Testud, Pascal Greggory, Emmanuelle Seigner and Gérard Depardieu. [Article, Page 11.] LET'S GET LOST A revival of Bruce Weber's 1988 documentary, about the ravishing youth and frightening old age of the jazz trumpeter and vocalist Chet Baker. Ocean's Thirteen Time for Steven Soderbergh to repay Warner Brothers for letting him make ''The Good German'' in black and white. The third, and as of now final installment in this franchise about frisky crooks led by George Clooney, introduces a slimy casino owner played by Al Pacino. With Brad Pitt, Matt Damon, Ellen Barkin, Bernie Mac, Casey Affleck, Scott Caan, Elliott Gould and Don Cheadle. Surf's Up If its summertime, it's penguin time. In this 3-D animation from Sony, Shia LaBeouf lends his voice to a little penguin with big dreams of winning the annual Penguin World Surfing Championship. Ash Brannon and Chris Buck directed; additional voices include Jon Heder, Zooey Deschanel, Jeff Bridges, James Woods and Mario Cantone. You're Gonna Miss Me Keven McAlester's documentary follows the early success and sad decline (into drugs and mental illness) of a pioneering acid rock musician, Roger Kynard Erickson, also known as Roky, of the 13th Floor Elevators, who is playing music again. June 13 Lights in the Dusk Finland's master of deadpan comedy, Aki Kaurismaki, directs the story of a shy night watchman (Janne Hyytiäinen) who is drafted as the fall guy in a robbery attempt. June 15 CHALK Troy Schremmer plays a high school history teacher struggling to survive his first semester at a rough and tough high school in Austin, Tex. Mike Akel directed in the ''mockumentary'' style of Christopher Guest's films. Eagle vs. Shark A pair of lovable losers get together in a New Zealand comedy, with a trailer that suggests ''Napoleon Dynamite'' did good business down under. Taika Waititi is the director. Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer Still as fantastic as ever in their second feature, the four superheroes (Ioan Gruffudd, Jessica Alba, Chris Evans and Michael Chiklis) confront a new nemesis in the form of the Silver Surfer (Doug Jones, best known as Guillermo del Toro's favorite stunt player). Tim Story directs. Fido ''Zombie Comedy,'' having apparently become a genre unto itself, gets another iteration in this Canadian movie, set in an alternate 1950s where the zombie population has been drafted as domestic help. Carrie-Anne Moss is a housewife who develops a dangerous affection for her major-domo, Fido, played by Billy Connolly. Andrew Currie directs. GYPSY CARAVAN From the writer, producer and director Jasmine Dellal, a look at the Gypsy Caravan concert tour, following Roma musicians from Spain, Macedonia, Romania and India as they come together for a North American tour. Photographed by the indefatigable Albert Maysles (''Grey Gardens''). JHOOM BARABAR JHOOM The red-hot Bollywood star Abhishek Bachchan (the husband of even red-hotter Bollywood star Aishwarya Rai), stars as a soccer fan with terminal cancer who decides to visit England for one final season and meets a female soccer fan with terminal cancer. Only in Bollywood. With Mr. Bachchan's imposing father, the veteran Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan. Shaad Ali directs. MACBETH The Australian filmmaker Geoffrey Wright earned some international notoriety while giving the young Russell Crowe's career a boost with the skinhead drama ''Romper Stomper'' in 1992; he's back with a Shakespearean adaptation set among the gangs of Melbourne. (Not so original: Ken Hughes did it with ''Joe Macbeth'' in 1955 and William Reilly with ''Men of Respect'' in 1991.) Nancy Drew Emma Roberts (daughter of Eric, niece of Julia) plays the teenage sleuth as Warner Brothers attempts to reconfigure the ancient franchise for contemporary tweeners. The setting is Los Angeles as Nancy investigates a spooky old house where a movie star was murdered. The trailer suggests that lots of shopping is also involved. With Tate Donovan; directed by Andrew Fleming (who made the pretty terrific ''Dick'' in 1999).[Article, Page 10.] RAISING FLAGG Alan Arkin as a cantankerous farmer, engaged in an endless dispute with his neighbor (Austin Pendleton), who convinces himself that he's dying as a result of the conflict and summons his family to his bedside. With Barbara Dana, Lauren Holly and Glenne Headly; Neal Miller directs. June 20 MANUFACTURED LANDSCAPES The winner for best documentary in the 2007 Canadian film awards, Jennifer Baichwal's film follows the photographer Edward Burtynsky to China, where he plans to capture the environmental consequences of China's economic explosion. WHITE PALMS Szabolcs Hajdu's film brings back memories of the vital, politically charged Hungarian cinema of the '70s and '80s. Mr. Hajdu's brother, the professional gymnast Miklos Zoltan Hajdu, stars as a promising young athlete whose life is taken over by the pre-Glasnost Hungarian government. Raised like a precious farm animal, he has nowhere to turn when the system of state subsidies collapses, except to a teaching gig in Canada. Excellently shot by Andras Nagy, the film courageously resists the standard sports movie clichés of triumph and redemption. June 22 Black Sheep Zombie sheep, it seems, in a splatter comedy from New Zealand. Jonathan King directs. BROKEN ENGLISH Single and 30-ish, Nora Wilder (Parker Posey) is starting to panic. But then she meets an enchanting Frenchman (Melvil Poupaud) who promises to introduce her to a new world of culture and romance. Zoe R. Cassavetes directs; with Drea de Matteo, Griffin Dunne, Josh Hamilton and Justin Theroux. [Article, Page 3.] DOA: Dead or Alive All evidence to the contrary, somebody still seems to think that basing movies on video games is a good idea. This one is about four female martial artists invited to participate in a no-holds-barred tournament on a tiny Pacific island. Jaime Pressly is in it, with Eric Roberts. Corey Yuen, the veteran Hong Kong action director, is at the helm. Evan Almighty Hilarity ensues when God (Morgan Freeman) commands a newly elected congressman (Steve Carell) to start building an ark in his Virginia backyard. Universal has a lot riding on this big-budget (reportedly $175 million) sequel to the 2003 ''Bruce Almighty.'' Directed by Tom Shadyac, with John Goodman, Lauren Graham and Wanda Sykes. Klimt A biographical pageant staged around the diffident figure of the Austrian artist Gustav Klimt (John Malkovich) by the director Raoul Ruiz. Saffron Burrows plays Klimt's muse, Lea de Castro; Nikolai Kinski is Egon Schiele. LADY CHATTERLEY Pascale Ferran, a French filmmaker who made an impressive debut with ''Coming to Terms With the Dead'' in 1994, returns from a 12-year absence with an adaptation of the second draft of D. H. Lawrence's novel (it was the third draft that became the much censored classic). Marina Hands is the aristocratic Englishwoman who discovers the natural world through the ministrations of her gamekeeper (Jean-Louis Colloc'h). A big critical favorite in France, it won five Césars (the French Oscars). A MIGHTY HEART Angelina Jolie plays Mariane Pearl, the wife of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was kidnapped and killed while investigating terrorism in Pakistan. The prolific Michael Winterbottom directs. NOW AND LATER A fugitive financier (Keller Wortham) meets a sympathetic Latina (Shari Solanis) who, through a series of philosophical discussions, introduces him to the notion that money might not be everything. Philippe Diaz, a transplanted Frenchman, directs. THE REAL DIRT ON FARMER JOHN The odyssey of John Peterson, an Illinois ''farmer, artist and revolutionary thinker'' who turned his father's farm into a hippie haven in the 1960s, only to be driven into bankruptcy by the farm debt crisis of the '80s. Vilified by the locals, he leaves home and wanders through Central America, eventually returning to his homeland and creating another, more sophisticated commune on the same property. Taggart Siegel directs this documentary. You Kill Me The appealingly low-key suspense craftsman John Dahl (''The Last Seduction'') returns with the tale of a professional hitman (a bald-headed Ben Kingsley) who becomes a mortuary assistant in a misguided attempt to go straight. With Luke Wilson and Téa Leoni. June 27 Ghosts of Cité Soleil Asger Leth's documentary about the gangs that run the slums of Port au Prince, Haiti, begins as a sociological study but takes on an unexpected dramatic element, when two brothers, both gang leaders, begin to compete for the affections of a French social worker. Live Free or Die Hard Bruce Willis, 52, hobbles back into action more than a decade after ''Die Hard: With a Vengeance'' as John McClane, the New York cop who always seems to find himself at the center of terrorist attacks. This time the threat is on the Internet in the form of a monster virus that threatens to shut down the country's entire infrastructure. Leaving no cliché unturned, McClane's sidekick is a young Asian-American computer hacker (Justin Long). Len Wiseman, of the ''Underworld'' films, directs. June 29 Death at a Funeral Frank Oz directed this comedy of errors set at and around a funeral in Britain. Peter Dinklage plays a mysterious stranger, who appears amid the family bickering and threatens to reveal a devastating secret. With Matthew Macfadyen and Rupert Graves. Dr. Bronner's Magic Soapbox Sara Lamm's documentary tells the story of an extravagant eccentric, Dr. Emanuel Bronner, who introduced Dr. Bronner's Magic Soap, the favorite shampoo of the flower people and still a big seller. Evening Susan Minot's novel ''Evening,'' as adapted by Ms. Minot and Michael Cunningham (''The Hours'') and directed by the Hungarian director and cinematographer Lajos Koltai (''Fateless''). Vanessa Redgrave is the dying matriarch, trying to make sense of her life as her family gathers around her. With Claire Danes, Toni Collette, Patrick Wilson, Hugh Dancy, Meryl Streep and Glenn Close. ONE TO ANOTHER The actor-turned-director Jean-Marc Barr and his co-director, Pascal Arnold, filmed this French feature about provincial youths and the complicated sexual situations they find themselves in. With Lizzie Brocheré and Arthur Dupont. Ratatouille A French rat dreams of becoming a French chef, in an animated film directed by Brad Bird, who was responsible for ''The Incredibles.'' Among the voices: Janeane Garofalo, Ian Holm, Peter O'Toole and Brian Dennehy. Vitus Tired of the attention he's getting, a 12-year-old prodigy (Teo Gheorghiu) stages a fall and pretends his special abilities have left him. With Bruno Ganz as the foxy grandpa; Fredi M. Murer directs this Swiss feature. July July 4 FLYING: CONFESSIONS OF A FREE WOMAN Jennifer Fox, a New York documentary filmmaker, turns her camera on herself and her love affairs with two men, one in Switzerland and one in South Africa. And to put things in context (the film runs six hours), she talks to women from other countries who lead lives far more circumscribed than hers. License to Wed In order to get married in the church of their choice Mandy Moore and John Krasinski have to survive a grueling marriage preparation course given by the church's autocratic pastor (Robin Williams). Let's hope it's worth it. Ken Kwapis directs. Rescue Dawn The director Werner Herzog expands his documentary short ''Little Dieter Needs to Fly'' into a fictionalized feature. Christian Bale stars as Dieter Dengler, an American pilot who was shot down over Vietnam and managed to escape from a Vietcong prison camp. With Jeremy Davies and Steve Zahn. Transformers Delaying that Proust adaptation his public has been clamoring for, the director Michael Bay (''Armageddon'') draws his source material this time from a line of toys. Shia LaBeouf plays the requisite human figure, a wily teenager who takes on an army of invading robots from outer space. Tyrese Gibson and Megan Fox lend support. July 6 The Gronholm Method Seven businessmen applying for work at a mysterious corporation discover they must survive a series of strange tests, known as the ''Gronholm Method.'' An Argentine film directed by Marcelo Piñeyro that sounds like it's in the same enigmatic vein as Fabián Bielinsky's ''Aura'' and ''Nine Queens.'' Introducing the Dwights A shy 21-year-old is at the center of a battle between the sweet young woman who loves him and the mother, a professional comedian, who dominates him. With Brenda Blethyn, Khan Chittenden and Emma Booth; Cherie Nowlan directs this Australian comedy. Joshua A preternaturally intelligent child (Jacob Kogan) may or may not be behind the series of tragic accidents that strike his prosperous New York family, starting when Mom and Dad (Vera Farmiga and Sam Rockwell) bring home a new baby sister. George Ratliff (''Hell House'') directs. July 13 Drama/Mex From Mexico, three interlocking stories of love and jealousy set in the decaying resort town of Acapulco. Gerardo Naranjo directs; with Fernando Becerril and Diana Garcia. 1408 From a Stephen King story of the same, uh, number, the hair-raising tale of a supernatural researcher (John Cusack) resolved to spend the night in a haunted hotel room. Samuel L. Jackson and Mary McCormack co-star; the director is the Swedish Mikael Hafstrom (''Derailed''). Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix It's Harry's fifth year at Hogwarts (already!) and the princeling wizard must confront both a renewed threat from the evil Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) and an outbreak of academic rivalry among the staff. The motto of the series continues to be ''let no British actor remain unemployed'': Helena Bonham Carter, Robbie Coltrane, Michael Gambon, Brendan Gleeson, Richard Griffiths,Jason Isaacs, Gary Oldman, Alan Rickman, Fiona Shaw, Maggie Smith, Imelda Staunton, David Thewlis, Emma Thompson and Julie Walters are among the cast. Interview Steve Buscemi directs and stars in an adaptation of a 2003 feature by the assassinated Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh. Mr. Buscemi plays a veteran political reporter who feels humiliated when an editor assigns him to write a profile of a soap opera star (Sienna Miller). Laura Smiles A suburban housewife (Petra Wright) deals with the repressed trauma of her lover's death almost a decade ago by throwing herself into a series of degrading affairs. Jason Ruscio directs; with Kip Pardue and Jonathan Silverman. My Best Friend A work-obsessed art dealer (Daniel Auteuil) has 10 days to prove to his business partner that he has at least one close friend, so he hires an amicable taxi driver (Dany Boon) to teach him how to make friends. With Julie Gayet; directed by Patrice Leconte (''The Hairdresser's Husband''). Talk to Me Don Cheadle stars in the true story of Ralph Waldo (Petey) Greene Jr., a Washington D.J. who became a voice for African-Americans in the city. Kasi Lemmons directs; with Chiwetel Ejiofor, Mike Epps and Martin Sheen. The Strangers Scott Speedman and Liv Tyler settle into their new vacation home but are interrupted by three masked intruders who proceed to do horror movie things to them. With Kip Weeks as ''Masked Stranger''; Bryan Bertino directs. Tekkonkinkreet The animated adventures of a pair of street kids, set in a Tokyo of the dystopian future called ''Treasure Town.'' Michael Arias directed -- reportedly, the first Westerner to direct a Japanese anime -- from the Japanese comic book by Taiyo Matsumoto. July 18 Live-In Maid The deteriorating relationship between a wealthy Buenos Aires woman (Norma Aleandro) and her servant of 30 years. (Does it mean something that the actress who plays her is named Norma Argentina?) Directed by Jorge Gaggero. July 20 Arctic Tale A walrus and a polar bear grow up in the vast northern wilderness, in this summer's cool-down documentary from the producers of ''March of the Penguins.'' Queen Latifah narrates. Fierce People Diane Lane as a drug-addicted, part-time masseuse who schemes to get herself and her teenage son out of the Lower East Side and into an exclusive gated community, where things don't look that much better. Dirk Wittenborn adapted his own novel; with Donald Sutherland, Kristen Stewart and Anton Yelchin. Directed by Griffin Dunne. Goya's Ghosts No one is expecting the Spanish Inquisition, least of all the beautiful Inés (Natalie Portman), the daughter of a prosperous merchant and the mistress of a haunted painter named Goya (Stellan Skarsgard). Milos Forman directs this period drama, starring Javier Bardem, José Luis Gómez, and Randy Quaid as King Carlos IV. Hairspray John Waters's 1988 camp comedy, about a Baltimore teenager who strikes a blow for civil rights, comes full circle -- now, it's a movie again, albeit one with a PG rating and a Broadway score. Mr. Waters of course has been kept far away from this potential cash cow, and the direction has been turned over to the former choreographer Adam Shankman. John Travolta, in Divine drag, stars as the teenager's concerned mom; with Michelle Pfeiffer, Queen Latifah, Christopher Walken, Amanda Bynes, and a newcomer, Nikki Blonsky, as Tracy Turnblad.[Article, Page 11.] I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry Adam Sandler and Kevin James as a pair of testosterone-oozing firemen who, for reasons having something to do with insurance (and a lot to do with getting the plot in motion) must pretend to be a happily domestic gay couple. You guessed it: hilarity ensues. Directed by Dennis Dugan from a script by Barry Fanaro and the team of Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor; with Jessica Biel, Steve Buscemi, Dan Aykroyd and Ving Rhames. Prisoner A self-reflexive splatter film? Julian McMahon of ''Nip/Tuck'' plays a Hollywood director who is scouting locations at an abandoned prison when he's abducted by a mysterious figure who calls himself the Jailer (Elias Koteas). Now he must answer for his sins, which might include making films like this one. Written and directed by David Alford and Robert Archer Lynn. The Camden 28 Anthony Giacchino's documentary revisits the case of the Camden 28, a group of antiwar Vietnam veterans arrested in 1971 for breaking into a draft board office. July 27 Adrenaline Robert Archer Lynn, the director of this thriller, claims to have brought off the longest continuous shot in American movie history, thanks to his handy JVC GY-HD100U camcorder: a single, 90-minute take that comprises this movie's entire running time. David Alford, who wrote the screenplay with Mr. Lynn, stars as the owner of a spanking new Jeep who must drive around town following the orders of a mysterious caller -- or the caller will kill his child. I Know Who Killed Me When the police rescue young Aubrey Fleming (Lindsay Lohan) from a brutal kidnapper, she comes home with a drastically different personality, so different that her parents (Julia Ormond and Neal McDonough) come to believe her claim that she is someone else entirely, and the real Aubrey remains in danger. Chris Sivertson directs. Molière The hot young French actor Romain Duris plays the great playwright in a biographical fantasy from the director Laurent Tirard, who imagines Molière involved in some ''Tartuffe''-like shenanigans in the home of a wealthy man (Fabrice Luchini) with a beautiful wife (Laura Morante). With Edouard Baer and Ludivine Sagnier. No End in Sight To explore the causes of the current situation in Iraq, Charles Ferguson's documentary draws on witnesses from inside the Bush administration, including the former deputy secretary of state Richard L. Armitage and Lawrence Wilkerson, once chief of staff to Colin L. Powell. No Reservations The Australian director Scott Hicks, still looking for another ''Shine,'' tells the story of a famous chef (Catherine Zeta-Jones) whose priorities change when she is put in charage of her young niece (Abigail Breslin). It's a remake of the 2001 German film ''Mostly Martha.'' With Aaron Eckhart, Bob Balaban and Patricia Clarkson. Skinwalkers Timothy (Matthew Knight) is about to turn 13, at which point his werewolf genes will kick in. Luckily he belongs to a clan of good werewolves (Barbara Gordon, Elias Koteas) who will do what they can to protect him from the bad sort (led by Jason Behr and Kim Coates). James Isaac directs. The Simpsons Movie Yes, a movie with the Simpsons in it. As usual Homer must save the world from a disaster of his own devising. And that's about all the studio is saying. David Silverman directs, with the usual voice cast: Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, Hank Azaria and Harry Shearer. [Article, Page 10.] This Is England The British director Shane Meadows (''Once Upon a Time in the Midlands'') relates a story from his 1980s childhood, in which he is befriended by a gang of skinheads. With Thomas Turgoose and Stephen Graham. THE WILLOW TREE Blind for 38 years, an Iranian man regains his eyesight after an operation in Paris. But can he ever really return to the country of his birth, now that he literally sees it in a different light? Majid Majidi, not the most challenging of the Iranian filmmakers (''Baran'') but certainly the most open to the West, is the director of this 2005 production. August Aug. 1 El Cantante Marc Anthony as the salsa musician Hector Lavoe, battling drug addiction with the help of his wife, Puchi (Jennifer Lopez). Leon Ichaso (''Piñero'') directs. Summer '04 A middle-aged woman finds herself competing with an adolescent girl for the attentions of the bachelor next door. From Germany; directed by Stefan Krohmer. Aug. 3 Becoming Jane Having run through the Jane Austen novels, the British cinema now turns to Jane herself, played by Anne Hathaway as a frisky young woman who has a romance with a visiting Irish lawyer (James McAvoy). The usual suspects appear in support: Julie Walters, James Cromwell, Maggie Smith, Ian Richardson. Directed by Julian Jarrold.[Article, Page 3.] The Bourne Ultimatum Matt Damon returns as the former C.I.A. officer in search of his own identity; this time he finds a journalist (Paddy Considine) who claims to know all about the shadowy branch of the agency that scrubbed his mind and turned him into a killer. With David Strathairn, Joan Allen and Julia Stiles; Paul Greengrass directs from a script by Tony Gilroy. Charlie Bartlett Anton Yelchin plays the title character, a rich kid who fancies himself the unofficial psychiatric counselor of his high school. Jon Poll, long an ace comedy editor, makes his directing debut. Hot Rod Andy Samberg becomes the latest ''Saturday Night Live'' cast member to land a movie; he plays a young man with stepfather issues and a fixation on jumping over 15 school buses with his motorcycle. Resurrecting the Champ A promising young sportswriter (Josh Hartnett) finds a former boxing champion (Samuel L. Jackson) living on the streets and tries to help him put his life back together. But because this is a movie, the writer discovers a lot more about himself and his own recent decision to leave his wife and young son. Rod Lurie directs. Summer Palace According to Variety, this is the first mainland Chinese film to feature full frontal nudity and to depict the Tiananmen Square demonstration, but the real reason that the director, Lou Ye (''Purple Butterfly''), got in trouble with the Chinese authorities is that he didn't ask permission before entering his feature in last year's Cannes festival. The Ten Ten, as in those pesky Commandments, all of which come in for some good-natured ribbing in this episodic comedy directed by David Wain. The all-cameo cast includes Jessica Alba, Famke Janssen, Gretchen Mol, Winona Ryder and Liev Schreiber. Underdog A merely mortal beagle acquires superpowers, as well as the voice of Jason Lee, when a mad scientist accidentally involves him in an experiment. The CGI effects are spookily realistic in the trailer. With Peter Dinklage, Patrick Warburton and James Belushi; directed by Frederik Du Chau (''Racing Stripes''). [Article, Page 1.] Aug. 10 Bratz The poofy-lipped, shopaholic dolls in their first movie, introducing youngsters all over the world to the importance of having a ''passion for fashion.'' Oddly this is not CGI; the characters are played by human beings: Malese Jow, Skyler Shaye, Janel Parrish and Nathalia Ramos. The tweener king Sean McNamara (''That's So Raven'') directed. Chak de India After the celebration of cricket in ''Lagaan'' here's a Bollywood movie about field hockey. Shahrukh Khan (''Devdas'') is the disgraced former player who finds a route to redemption by coaching a girls' team. Shimit Amin directs. Crónica de una fuga From Argentina a story from the dark days of the 1970s, involving the kidnapping of a soccer player. Directed by Israel Adrián Caetano. Daddy Day Camp Fred Savage, the former child star of ''The Wonder Years,'' all grown up and directing a sequel to Eddie Murphy's 2003 hit, ''Daddy Day Care.'' Eddie wasn't available this time, so the filmmakers got the next best thing: Cuba Gooding Jr. Hilarity, it goes without saying, ensues. Rocket Science Sounds like the indie distributors are still chasing the next ''Napoleon Dynamite.'' This one is about a shy teenager (Reece Daniel Thompson) with a stuttering problem who joins the debate team, hoping to win the respect of the girl of his dreams (Anna Kendrick). The fiction feature debut of the documentary maker Jeffrey Blitz (''Spellbound''). Rush Hour 3 The director Brett Ratner delivers up a second sequel to his 1998 buddy picture, about a straight-arrow Chinese cop (Jackie Chan) and a frisky New York City detective (Chris Tucker). This time they're in Paris, battling, it says here, the Chinese Triads. But it's the supporting cast that fascinates: Max von Sydow and Roman Polanski. The Signal A mysterious signal sent out over the television, radio and cellphone networks turns most Americans into crazed killers. (No, that signal is not titled ''The View.'') David Bruckner, Dan Bush and Jacob Gentry directed this three-part film. Stardust An adaptation of Neil Gaiman's fantasy novel, in which the heroic young Tristran (Charlie Cox) leaves his cozy English village in pursuit of a fallen star, discovers instead Claire Danes, a damsel in need of rescuing from the evil heirs of a dying king (Peter O'Toole). With Michelle Pfeiffer as a witch and Robert De Niro as the captain of a flying pirate ship. Matthew Vaughn (''Layer Cake'') directs. 2 Days in Paris The actress Julie Delpy is the director and co-writer of this bilingual comedy, in which a French woman (Ms. Delpy) takes her American boyfriend (Adam Goldberg) to meet her parents (played by Ms. Delpy's actual parents) in Paris. L'hilarité s'ensuit! Aug. 15 Love for Sale An attractive and unscrupulous young woman (Hermila Guedes) returns to her hometown in rural Brazil, where she creates a scandal among the tradition-bound residents. Directed by Karim Ainouz (''Madame Satã''). Aug. 17 Havoc Expecting to participate in a paint-ball tournament, five friends instead find themselves facing a psychotic killer in an abandoned prison. Next time, rent the GPS unit. With Jason Lewis; Robert Archer Lynn directs. The Invasion Yet another adaptation of Jack Finney's novel ''The Body Snatchers,'' about aliens who are able to turn themselves into perfect human replicas, minus all feelings of compassion. Appropriately the setting has been shifted to Washington, where a perceptive psychiatrist (Nicole Kidman) has begun to suspect that not all is well. Oliver Hirschbiegel, last seen on these shores with ''Downfall,'' his German-language Hitler film, directs. The King of Kong Last year, spelling bees. This year, video game championships. Seth Gordon's documentary follows the decades-long struggle for dominance among Donkey Kong players. Penelope Fresh from her whippin' in ''Black Snake Moan,'' here's Christina Ricci as a fairy tale princess with a (prosthetic) nose like a pig's. Richard E. Grant and Catherine O'Hara are her wealthy parents, auditioning suitors for the unfortunate young woman. Mark Palansky directs; with James McAvoy and a cameo by one of the film's producers, Reese Witherspoon. [Article, Page 3.] Superbad More than 10 years and an apprenticeship with Woody Allen separate Greg Mottola's promising first feature, ''The Daytrippers,'' from this, his second. Michael Cera and Jonah Hill are best friends, determined to spend at least one night on the wild side before college. Wedding Daze Formerly titled ''The Next Girl I See'' and ''The Pleasure of Your Company,'' Michael Ian Black's film is about a young man (Jason Biggs) who, after being dumped by his longtime girlfriend, impulsively proposes to a waitress (Isla Fisher). Aug. 22 Out of the Blue The true story of a lone gunman who terrorized a small town in New Zealand, leaving 13 dead after his rampage. Robert Sarkies directs; Matthew Sunderland plays the shooter. Aug. 24 The Comebacks The losingest college football coach in recorded history (David Koechner) assembles a new team of misfits and losers, hoping for the best. Tom Brady directs this comedy with Carl Weathers, Andy Dick and Dennis Rodman. Good Luck Chuck Noticing that every woman he sleeps with goes on to marry her next beau, the enterprising Stu (Dane Cook) starts renting himself out as a good luck charm, until Jessica Alba comes along. Directed by Mark Helfrich. [Article, Page 11.] The Hottest State Ethan Hawke directs this indie feature, based on his novel, about an aspiring actor (Mark Webber) who gets dumped by his girlfriend (Catalina Sandino Moreno), a hopeful singer-songwriter. With Laura Linney, Michelle Williams, Sonia Braga and Mr. Hawke. The Last Legion As the Roman Empire collapses, its last emperor, 12-year-old Romulus Augustus (Thomas Sangster), looks for a way of escaping to Britain, where the last loyal legion is said to be found. Doug Lefler directs; with Aishwarya Rai and one of those Briton-heavy supporting casts considered essential for tales of ancient Rome: Colin Firth, Ben Kingsley, Peter Mullan, John Hannah and Iain Glen. Aug. 29 The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun An eccentric Dane donates his rundown chateau to the Russian Orthodox Church to use as a monastery. This documentary by Pernille Rose Gronkjaer follows the first year of transition, as the spectacularly bearded Mr. Vig faces off with the tiny Russian nun in charge of the project. Aug. 31 Bordertown The director Gregory Nava, who nudged Jennifer Lopez toward stardom with ''Selena,'' reunites with her for a fictionalized treatment of the plague of unsolved murders of women in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. Ms. Lopez plays a Chicago reporter looking into the killings, and somehow finds NAFTA implicated. With Antonio Banderas and Sonia Braga. The Brothers Solomon Bob Odenkirk (''Mr. Show'') tries again to translate his offbeat humor to the big screen; this one at least sounds funnier than ''Let's Go to Prison.'' A comedy about two nerdy brothers desperately searching for wives, in hopes of fulfilling their promise to their dying father that they will give him grandchildren. With Will Forte, Jenna Fischer, Will Arnett and Kristen Wiig. Death Sentence James Wan, the director of the moralizing torture tale ''Saw,'' returns with another story of righteous vengeance, as a father (Kevin Bacon) sets out to kill the gang members who attacked his family. Halloween The director and musician Rob Zombie offers a straight remake of a crucial bit of Americana, John Carpenter's 1978 ''Halloween.'' Scout Taylor-Compton steps into the (metaphorically) big shoes of Jamie Lee Curtis, as the plucky babysitter faced with an escaped homicidal maniac. The casting suggests a certain camp approach: Malcolm McDowell, Brad Dourif, William Forsythe, Udo Kier, Danny Trejo, Dee Wallace Stone and Adrienne Barbeau. Ladrón que roba a ladrón Joe Menendez directed this Spanish-language comedy about a pair of thieves who plan to rob the mansion of a television infomercial magnate. With Fernando Colunga and Miguel Varoni. Tre Daniel Cariaga plays the title character, a Santa Monica slacker whose casual seduction of a married woman (Alix Koromzay) leads to complications for everyone around them. Eric Byler, of the accomplished ''Charlotte Sometimes,'' directs this indie feature. The Wedding Director The endearingly rumpled Italian actor Sergio Castellitto plays a famous filmmaker who, thanks to a series of coincidences, ends up in Sicily videotaping the wedding of the wealthy young woman (Donatella Finocchiaro) with whom he's secretly in love. Marco Bellocchio directs. Wristcutters: A Love Story Sent to a bureaucratic purgatory for suicides, Patrick Fugit searches for the woman he once loved, helped by new friends Shea Whigham and Shannyn Sossamon. Goran Dukic directs. September Sept. 5 Addicted A thriller centered on a peculiar notion: A car accident leaves two brothers in a coma; when one of them wakes up, he believes he's the other guy -- the one married to Sarah Michelle Gellar. Joel Bergvall and Simon Sandquist directed this remake of the Korean film ''Jungdok.'' Salvador Allende Patricio Guzmán, the Chilean filmmaker best known for his epic documentary ''The Battle of Chile,'' presents a profile of the doctor-turned-politician who became a perceived threat to the United States when elected president of Chile on a socialist platform. Sept. 7 The Bubble The ''bubble'' in Eytan Fox's film is the city of Tel Aviv, which he sees as isolated from the country's greater struggles. The bubble breaks when an Israeli soldier falls in love with a Palestinian man, and tries to find a way to keep him in Tel Aviv. Hatchet More stranded tourists, more backwoods butchery, this time in the Louisiana bayous. Adam Green directs. In the Shadow of the Moon Members of the Apollo mission teams tell their stories in a documentary by David Sington. The Nanny Diaries The roman à clef about a college student (Scarlett Johansson) who goes to work as a nanny for an Upper East Side couple identified as Mr. and Mrs. X (Paul Giamatti and Laura Linney). Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini direct. Shoot 'Em Up An unapologetic action film, starring Clive Owen as a mysterious gunman who manages to deliver Monica Bellucci's baby during a shoot-out, and then must protect her and the child from a demented master criminal, Paul Giamatti. Michael Davis directs. Trade A Texas policeman (Kevin Kline) teams up with a Mexican teenager (Cesar Ramos) to find the boy's younger sister, kidnapped by an international ring of human traffickers. With Alicja Bachleda-Curus. Marco Kreuzpaintner directs. [Article, Page 11.]

On Dec. 12, 1948, The New York Times published an article about crowds ''in holiday mood'' blocking traffic in an old Connecticut village of stately colonial homes. Nearing completion on Ponus Ridge in New Canaan was the ultramodern, all-glass house of the flamboyant modernist architect Philip Johnson. Nothing like it had been seen in these conservative, well-heeled parts. Actually, nothing like it had been seen anywhere, for Johnson's private architectural folly was one of the 20th century's most innovative modern buildings. Few people have ever been inside the 1,728-square-foot glass-and-steel residential structure until recently. Following a limited number of preview tours that started in April, the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which was given the house by Johnson in 1986, will celebrate the official opening of the 47-acre estate to the public with a gala picnic on June 23.

When Lisa and Dustin Hoffman were married 26 years ago, they vowed to stay together over hither and yon. Miles later, the pact has steadfastly kept: from locales exotic to mundane, Ms. Hoffman has packed and unpacked her family of eight (she and Mr. Hoffman have four children; he has two children from a previous marriage). She's become such a proficient globe-trotter that this year she created a travel-friendly line of skin care products, Lisa Hoffman Night & Day 24 Hour Skincare. ''Most people shop for upcoming seasons,'' Ms. Hoffman said. ''I shop for upcoming locations.'' Ms. Hoffman, 52, has a predilection for enduring classics: gorgeous woven bags by Bottega Veneta, simple Prada cashmere cardigans (''I bought them in every color -- they're great for airplanes'') and Lanvin flats. Here in the dressing room of her Manhattan apartment, she wears vanilla linen trousers by Ann Demeulemeester, a silk blouse and link necklace by Marni, a yellow Prada cardigan and Bottega Veneta shoes. Her Maurice Lacroix watch and ring were gifts from her husband. ''I tend to mix and match,'' she said, ''but my kids yell at me if I match too much.''
To the Editor: Re ''A Candidate, His Minister and the Search for Faith'' (front page, April 30):

Morgan Spurlock, the gadfly activist who permanently turned my children against McDonald's in ''Supersize Me,'' has now branded himself. His label, MORGAN SPURLOCK PRESENTS, is serving up ''CHALK,'' a mockumentary about a year in the life of three novice high school teachers. Mike Akel, the film's director and a writer, taught in Texas with the other writer, Chris Mass; the two channeled their daily frustrations and the absurdities of their world into the film. While uneven in the way that indie-financed movies can be, and bumpy in its improvisational style, ''Chalk'' has plenty of heart and a good dose of humor. Having done the festival circuit, the movie opens on Friday at the Nuart in Los Angeles, and across the country after that. The real documentary ''THE HIP-HOP PROJECT'' tells the inspirational story of a group of New York teenagers who use hip-hop as a vehicle for coping with difficulties in their lives, transforming them into tales told through music. The program was created by a formerly homeless youngster, Kazi, who became a mentor to other troubled teenagers, notably two named Princess and Cannon, who work on creating an album in the film. The hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons and the actor Bruce Willis donated a recording studio to the project too. The movie was screened at last year's Tribeca Film Festival to enthusiastic audiences. ThinkFilm will release it in a dozen cities on Friday. All the profits will go to youth organizations.

DEBORAH GARRISON'S first book of poetry, ''A Working Girl Can't Win,'' did remarkably well, selling 30,000 copies when even some Pulitzer Prize-winning poets are lucky to sell one-tenth that. The poems were about young women in love, out of love, making love and working in Manhattan. Most were written when Ms. Garrison was in her 20s and childless, living in the East Village and climbing the career ladder at The New Yorker. And then, just as she was being lauded as one of those hip young postfeminist urban women portrayed in ''Ally McBeal'' and ''Sex and the City,'' Ms. Garrison gave birth to her first child and moved to New Jersey.

Eve Lynn Brensike and Richard Abraham Primus are to be married today in Dearborn, Mich. Rabbi Shai Held is to officiate at the Dearborn Inn. The bride, 32, and bridegroom, 37, are faculty members of the University of Michigan Law School; she is an assistant professor of criminal law and he is a professor of constitutional law.

SIEGEL--Max W., 94, on April 24, 2007. A humble but passionate man, who aspired to make the world a better place and inspired others to do the same. He worked hard for good candidates and good causes, most recently the Working Families Party. Max grew up in Brownsville. In the 1930's he became a union organizer. After serving in WWII, Max moved the family to Long Beach, L.I. where he was active in reform politics. He and his wife, Sara, ''retired'' to Costa Rica, then Florida, moving back to NYC to live at Carnegie East House in Manhattan. Max leaves behind Sara, his beloved wife of 71 years, twins Mark (of Peterborough, Ontario) and Dorothy (of Brooklyn, NY), and grandchildren, Elizabeth Abram, Samuel Abram, and Joel Siegel.

To the Editor: I'm probably only one of 10,000 aging hippies eager to point out that ''Easter Everywhere,'' the title of Darcy Steinke's book, reviewed by Stephen Metcalf (April 22), is a reference to the legendary 1967 album by Roky Erickson and the 13th Floor Elevators. Douglas Milburn Houston

An article last Sunday about the film actress and director Sarah Polley referred incorrectly to the setting of ''Avonlea,'' the Canadian television series in which she starred. It was set on Prince Edward Island, not the prairie.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Study of N.B.A. Sees Racial Bias in Calling Fouls,'' May 2: First, the paper by Justin Wolfers and Joseph Price does not answer the important question: Do blacks draw more fouls because they commit more fouls? The N.B.A.'s reciprocal study gets closer to the answer by determining the race of the officials calling each foul. But a better method would be to look carefully at each game and correlate the fouls that were called and those that were missed, with the race of the players and the officials.

BRUCK--Eva. We celebrate your beautiful life. We will always love you and miss you. Wendy, Andrea, Mark, Marc, Lauren and Rachel $(6$)BRUCK--Eva, on May 4th, 2007. Beloved wife of Stuart, devoted mother of Natalie and Spencer, and daughter of Zoltan and Clara Doman. Eva was loved by her family and friends, and respected by her colleagues. Her extraordinary heart and selflessness will be missed by all. In addition to her countless friends, she is survived by her brother Andrew, her brother-in-law and sister-in-law, Lewis and Geraldine Alperin, her uncle Laszlo Doman, her nephew James, and her nieces Amy and Lauren Alperin. We will miss you and always think of you, but we will always remember your spirit, laughter, dignity, grace, and smile. There will always be part of you in our hearts. Funeral on Monday, May 7th at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Eva's name to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

Retumba! -- an Afro-Caribbean dance and percussion group -- performs as part of ''Mamapalooza,'' a Mother's Day celebration and concert; with art, book fair and children's activities, presented by the Motherhood Foundation and Westchester County Parks. May 12, 1 to 6 p.m. Free. Kensico Dam Plaza, north end of the Bronx River Parkway. (914) 864-7275. www.westchestergov.com/parks.

Dr. Jennifer Elyse Madan and Jeffrey Phillip Cohen are to be married today at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Gerald Zelermyer is to perform the ceremony. The bride, 30, is a fellow in pediatric neurology at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx and is to begin a fellowship in epilepsy there in July. She graduated from Tufts and received her medical degree from the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in Piscataway, N.J. She is the daughter of Carol and Jeffrey Madan of Marlboro, N.J.

The chief executive job at Oakley Inc. comes with keys to the chairman's Mercedes and all the discount sunglasses you want. D. Scott Olivet received a $1,000-a-month car allowance last year but was also allowed to drive a 2005 Mercedes SL65 that belonged to his boss, Jim Jannard.

Island hopping, at least from Oahu to Kauai and Maui, will be easier starting in July, when the Hawaii Superferry catamaran begins daily service from Honolulu. After six years of planning and more than a few battles with environmentalists, the ferry (below) has been cleared to operate between the three islands, which are now linked only by commercial airliner service. ''The Superferry will change both the social and commercial environment of the islands,'' said John Garibaldi, president of Superferry. ''For the first time, neighboring islands will be able to get their product to Oahu.''

ONE giant cardboard box held hundreds of power cords, coiled like snakes, and a tower of computer monitors, wrapped in plastic, stood six feet high. Piled on a wooden pallet were electronic relics -- like a Soundesign combination record player-radio-eight-track player. Montclair's biannual electronic-waste collection had been under way for less than an hour, and dozens of residents had already dropped off carloads of so-called e-waste.
To the Editor: Re ''Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 29):

Kate Anne Kaltman DeScherer, the daughter of Jennie L. DeScherer and Richard K. DeScherer of New York, is to be married today to Edwyn Patrick Ossa, the son of Patricia Stypula of Newark, Ohio, and the late Julio E. Ossa. The ceremony will be at the William Aiken House, a 19th-century mansion in Charleston, S.C. Richard A. Brown, the Queens County district attorney and a friend of the bride and her family, is to officiate by a special order of the Probate Court of Charleston County. The bride, 30, is studying for a master's degree in nursing at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston. She graduated from the University of Virginia.
A weekend away is supposed to be relaxing. We took the guesswork out of dining -- and dressing -- in three summer destinations. Getting a Saturday-night reservation in high season is up to you.

Marion Cotillard is 31 but so in demand in her native France that she already has more than that many movies on her résumé. Thanks to the mingy distribution of foreign films here, American audiences probably know Ms. Cotillard, if they know her at all, as Russell Crowe's spirited Provençal love interest in ''A Good Year'' or the beautiful war widow hellbent on payback in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's ''Very Long Engagement.'' Those roles hint at Ms. Cotillard's range, but nothing she has done before comes close to the daunting complexity of her work as the French singer Édith Piaf in Olivier Dahan's biopic, ''La Vie en Rose'' (June 8). Ms. Cotillard is on screen for most of the movie's 140 minutes, and no matter how big and fierce her performance becomes, it never feels less than real. It's such a scarifying portrait of a brilliant, destructive woman that the scenes onstage, in which she simply stands and sings (she's a master lip-syncer) come as a relief. As Mr. Dahan tells it and Ms. Cotillard plays it, the tiny woman with the deep, throbbing voice who was called the Little Sparrow is so eaten by addiction and the traumas of her harsh early life that in success she's often a monster, abusing friends and colleagues with such lacerating force she makes you want to duck.

WEINSIER--Philip, April 28, 2007, age 91, at home and, as always, with class. Handsome, beloved husband of the late Joan Tuby Weinsier, cherished and treasured father of Michael Weinsier (Marcy) and Wendy Segal (Danny) and loving and adored grandfather of Matthew and Jacqueline. Sweet, kind sonin-law of Evelyn Tuby and admired brother-in-law of Suellen Globus. Loving brother of the late Grace Maslow and Shirley, Saul and Randolph Weinsier. ''Ace'' was his name, golf was his game and race horses were his passion. Graduate of Washington and Lee University, WWII Army Lieutenant. The last of the great gentlemen, with humor 'til the end. A gracious man. Funeral private. Donations can be made in his name to the American Cancer Society or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care.

There is something unusual about several of the key players in this spring's big hockey tournaments: they come from New York State. After several decades when the state produced a smattering of top players, some kind of tipping point seems to have been reached. Ryan Callahan, a rookie from Rochester, has emerged as an inspirational player for the Rangers this postseason.
