BROWN--Arline Bezner. Daughter of Anna and Jack Bezner, husband of Gerry Brown, stepmother of Karen and David Brown and stepgrandmother of Brian and Michael Brown. Passed away December 1st, 2006. Interment was at Ceder Park Cemetery Mausoleum on December 3rd, 2006. Donations can be made to the United Cerebral Palsy of Florida.

YOUNG--Sara S., 92, widow of former Colonel Roger A. Young, peacefully May 3rd at her home in Key Largo, FL. Survived by daughter Polly, granddaughters Sara and Suzy, step-grandson Sam, seven great-grandchildren.

Call it plane travel, unplugged. Pared-down flights at super-cheap rates, which have been all the rage in Europe for years, will show up in the United States when Skybus Airlines (www.skybus.com) starts domestic operations on May 22. For budget-minded passengers, the compromise seems minimal; reservations must be made through the Web site (no customer relations phone number exists) and there are extra fees for services that are usually part of the fare -- like bag check ($5 each for two bags, $50 for additional ones), soft drinks and seating requests. But the flights are cheap. Really cheap. One-way fares start for as little as $10, with a top one-way walk-up fare of $330 (all flights must connect in Columbus, Ohio). Skybus is not serving the New York area, but is flying to nine other cities, including Richmond; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Greensboro, N.C.; San Francisco; and Seattle. Tourists who want a break from the slot machines now have the option of bowling in Las Vegas 24 hours a day. Last month, Red Rock Casino, Resort and Spa, about 10 miles off the Strip (www.redrocklasvegas.com), opened a 72-lane bowling center (below). The center has a pro shop, an arcade, meeting rooms, a deli, a lounge and bar, dart boards, billiard tables, a shuffleboard table, plasma televisions and, surprise, slot and video poker games. There is also a 12-lane, nightclub-like V.I.P. suite, which can be subdivided into four or eight lanes for private parties. Three-hour V.I.P. rates range from $1,500 to $4,500; catered food and bottle service are available. Regular rates start at $3 per adult per game. All Holiday Inn hotels -- nearly 1,000 -- will begin serving Rainforest Alliance certified coffee to guests by June. At least 30 percent of the beans used to make the coffee will be grown on farms that have met strict environmental and social standards on issues like worker protection and biodiversity conservation (www.rainforest-alliance.org). HILARY HOWARD

PICASSO'S ''DEMOISELLES D'AVIGNON'' turns 100 this year, and to celebrate, there's a tribute opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art that traces its evolution. It's still a shocker, even after a century of art whose only ambition has been to top what Picasso did. Eight feet square, it's an acrid billboard of five preening prostitutes, naked, although you might not realize it because they're like cut crystal, blending into the background. They glare, one of them holding open the curtain of the bordello; we're their johns. Picasso is said to have repainted the scarified women on the right, with faces like masks, after seeing African art in Paris. In so doing, he opened a universe of savagery and primitivism. Whores and barbarians: he also linked them as social outcasts. Feminists have had a field day decoding the misogyny. If it's not the greatest 20th century painting, it remains the most radical because it changed art more than any other. Before it paintings at least had to pretend to be decorative and cogent. Afterward anything went. It's useful to recall that in 1907 Picasso was a rising star. His dealer saw this picture and thought Picasso had lost his mind. Matisse figured it had to be a joke. But then he realized it wasn't -- realized its immense implications -- and adjusted his art accordingly. Out of all this came Cubism and many of the other isms of the early century, which is to say modernity. In the Modern's previous incarnation, the painting was hung on a wall by itself, to concentrate our gaze. In the current Modern it shares a room crowded with art, diluting the impact. This small exhibition should restore, at least temporarily, our focus and remind us just how astonishing this picture has remained across a century. Through Aug. 27, (212) 708-9400, moma.org.
The 36 Hours column on April 22, about Dublin, misstated the location of the Fashion and Design Market there. It is on Cow's Lane, not Cow's Land.

Lisa Sanders's emotional response to her patient's emergency is a common experience to all primary-care physicians (Diagnosis, April 22). Every time one of my patients develops a life-threatening medical problem, my natural inclination is to blame myself for not having picked up on the problem earlier. This happens most commonly when having made the diagnosis would have depended on speaking to the patient carefully and listening to the answers. Sometimes this means picking up on a nuanced statement or tonal inflection. In other words, something that takes time and caring to understand.

TOMPKINS--Harold. Distinguished Jurist, a wonderful and kind friend. Cheryl and Albert Lefkovits $(6$)TOMPKINS--Harold, Justice, NYS Supreme Court, Retired. The Respect for Law Alliance, Inc., notes, with sorrow, the passing of one of its esteemed Founding Director and former Executive VicePresident. We are mindful of his loyal support and devotion to our Mission, his respectful treatment of lawyers and litigants in his Courtroom and his dedication to the Court and to his Country. General Arthur Gerwin President and Chairperson Judge Gregory W. Carman, Judith A. Livingston, Esq. Co-Vice Chairpersons $(6$)TOMPKINS--Harold, Justice, 74. Died of pneumonia, May 2nd, 2007. A very dedicated humanitarian, born in NYC, graduated from Syracuse University and Cornell Law School. Father of his loving son, Laurence Alan Fish Tompkins, and endeared husband of Frances Fish Tompkins for 48 years. A private practitioner and an Assistant NY State Attorney General in the Litigation Bureau, who represented the MTA during the 1980 transit strike. He was elected a Civil Court Judge in 1981 and became a Supreme Court Justice in 1986. He authored over 200 published opinions on cases involving the First Amendment, patients' rights to control their treatment and sanctions against frivolous lawsuits and governmental authority. He retired in 2003. A dedicated supporter of Bar Association activities, he was Executive V.P. of the Respect for Law Alliance, a Director of the Jewish Lawyers Guild, Chairman of The Young Lawyers Section of the NY State Bar Association and frequent lecturer at NY County Lawyers and NY State Trial Lawyers Associations. For many years he was a member of the Board of Governors of Harmonie Club and the Board of Directors at Park Ave. Synagogue. Services at 10am, Sunday May 6th, 2007, at Park Ave. Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York City.

JUST before the start of a T-ball game last summer, my son Christopher threw me a curve. As we walked toward our dugout, he stopped short, digging his cleats into the dirt around second base. He stood there frozen for a moment, staring through nervous eyes at a bunch of fellow 5-year-olds taking practice swings and fielding ground balls.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of walls in the history of warfare misstated the length of time the Berlin Wall lasted. It fell after 28 years, not 18, having stood from Aug. 1961 to Nov. 1989.

Chien-Ming Wang's audition for the Yankees took place in a gymnasium in Taiwan seven years ago. It rained that day, so Wang's workout was moved indoors. Wang threw for about a half-hour before he was offered a $1.9 million signing bonus. He accepted. From that humble start, Wang has developed into an unusually cool pitcher. He barely blinks, he seems as if he never sweats and he throws an overpowering sinker that drops like a bowling ball off a cliff. Hitting Wang's sinker feels like connecting with a weighted baseball.

BELLOS--Irving L., died on April 27, 2007. Beloved father to Jeffrey and Susan, grandfather to Jeremy, husband to the late Elaine, brother to Beatrice and Renee and special friend to Hannah and Doris. You were the best father I could ever have. You were: selfless, devoted, bright, responsible, supportive, skeptical, and passionate about many things. We love you and we will miss you.

1. Nicole Farhi has mapped out her own Silk Road. When the Turkish-born, French-raised designer isn't in her London office honing her clothing and home-furnishings collections, she's combing Italy, France, Belgium, Asia and North Africa for fabrics and antiques to sell in her Nicole Farhi and 202 stores in London, New York and Dubai. ''I love designing clothes, but the home line is my recreation,'' she says. ''So I don't mind if I work all week on fashion and spend weekends antiquing and seeing the potters who make my tableware, etc.''

I STUMBLED over the accordion in the basement, its case already as deep in water as I was -- water pouring in from foundation crevices, billowing up through floor tiles into the fringed magenta rug and, more repulsively, backing up from the street through the sewer cap that we had opened in a feeble attempt to drain away the flood. The April northeaster had hit New Jersey, and we were in its path. The accordion, which had belonged to my father-in-law, had been there for the eight years since his death. I could almost hear him say to my husband, ''Richie, it's O.K. to get rid of it now.'' But my husband couldn't bring himself to do it, despite the cracked bellows, keys and valves that rendered it beyond reasonable repair. It sat on the floor behind the bar, untouched. Now the muddy, insistent waters lashed at the seams of its old case, worming their way into the blue velvet interior.

Days after news reports revealed that the county's 9/11 memorial, ''The Rising,'' had left out one resident, the family of another county victim came forward. The victim, Mary Teresa Caulfield, 58, a resident of Eastchester and an executive assistant at Marsh & McLennan, the insurance company, was at work in her office in the north tower of the World Trade Center. A mother of two sons, she had lived with her husband, James, in a garden co-op apartment in Eastchester since December 1984, and was recognized on the 9/11 memorial clock in the Town Hall complex. But she was not included on the county's soaring memorial sculpture at Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla.
LEE--Nita Abrahams. Missed and remembered by all you left behind. Baby Neale lovingly named for you.

THE recent heavy storms that left downtown Manville, N.J., under 10 feet of water; filled the basements of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and flooded rivers and downed power lines in Connecticut may have provided a glimpse of our future. Climate change is accelerating, and the prognosis for the region is alarming, as it is for the rest of the world. No matter how effectively we begin to curb our greenhouse-gas emissions now, we are destined to see significant climate changes because these gases remain in the atmosphere for a long time. We cannot delay planning for the environmental and human calamities that lie ahead. All over the world, according to the 2007 scientific report of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, ''it is very likely that hot extremes, heat waves and heavy precipitation events will continue to become more frequent.'' But we need look no further than our own backyard to find evidence of warming. Since 1950, average summer temperatures in New York City have increased by seven-tenths of a degree per decade, but for the last 20 years, by more than two degrees per decade.

An article on April 22 about the writers Kingsley and Martin Amis omitted a word in a quotation from Kingsley's biographer, Zachary Leader. He referred to Kingsley as ''the finest British comic novelist of the second half of the 20th century,'' not the finest comic novelist.

Thomas L. Friedman writes that America can regain its global stature by pursuing ''green'' policies (April 15). But reducing carbon emissions is only one, albeit critical, step. We must also lead by example in numerous other areas like respect for the Geneva Convention and human rights in general, support for international organizations and responsible nuclear disarmament. Such a comprehensive policy will lend moral authority to the United States and give legitimacy and greater effect to the use of our mailed fist if we are compelled as a last resort to use it.

I am going to Paris in August with my 13-year-old daughter. How can I make the best of perhaps the worst month to go? -- Barb Silver-Holt, Stonington, Conn. Many tourists avoid the city in August, fearing hot weather and empty streets. But while it's true that many Parisians skip town and some boutiques and restaurants close, the lack of crowds can be a blessing. You may not avoid ''Da Vinci Code''-clutching crowds clamoring to see the ''Mona Lisa'' at the Louvre, but streets are less teeming and the notorious traffic is not as exasperating.

To the Editor: Re ''For $82 a Day, Booking a Cell in a 5-Star Jail'' (front page, April 29): Do society's ''haves'' deserve easier punishment than its ''have-nots?'' Apparently California believes so.

QUICK--Perry Day. Died on May 1st, 2007, age 61, at his home in Washington, DC. A prominent economist in Washington for three decades, Dr. Quick was a Vice President and Head of the Washington office of CRA, International, and former Partner and National Director of the Economics Consulting and Quantitative Analysis Division of Ernst & Young. Beloved by his surviving family: his wife, Linda Donaldson, his children by a former marriage, Elliot and Abby Quick, his step-daughter, Katie Flegal, his mother, Barbara Marshall, and his brother, Tim Quick. A memorial service will be held in early June at the Unitarian Universalist Church of Arlington, VA, 4444 Arlington Boulevard, Arlington, VA. Memorial gifts may be made in Dr. Quicks memory to the Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center, Georgetown University, Washington, DC, in support of the work of Dr. John Marshall in Colorectal Cancer Research.
The On Language column on April 22, about ''varmint,'' misstated the magazine in which President Bush used the word in 2004. It was Field & Stream, not Outdoor Life.

In ''Waitress'' (May 2) Nathan Fillion plays the funny-Valentine love object of Keri Russell's pie-baking genius, and does it so deftly you wonder why more directors of romantic comedy haven't snapped him up. The last film by Adrienne Shelly, who was murdered in her Greenwich Village office last November, ''Waitress'' spices its humor with some decidedly tangy elements. For one thing the romance between Ms. Russell and Mr. Fillion is highly inappropriate, yet he carries it off with a light touch, quirky enough to feel just right. Mild mannered and good looking -- with a nose that suggests ski jump without quite being one -- Mr. Fillion is a realistic romantic lead. Unlike the pretty hunks or brooding glamour boys women are usually invited to lust after, he seems like the sort of cute-guy-down-the-block you might actually end up with. Not that Ms. Russell's Jenna is likely to. A waitress and chief pie-maker at the local diner, she is newly pregnant by an abusive husband she badly wants to leave. Mr. Fillion's Doc Pomatter is the new obstetrician in town, having traded life in Connecticut for this tiny Southern backwater where his wife, also a doctor, is doing her residency.

To the Editor: The lead article in the New Jersey section of April 29 asks, ''Should Immigration Be a Police Issue?'' The answer is obviously no. If you include illegal immigration, the answer is more complicated, and poses additional questions. For example, what if a large influx of illegal immigrants places excessive burdens on the housing stock, the hospitals, schools, social agencies and law enforcement agencies on communities throughout the land? How many immigrants can this country absorb in a given period of time without changing its very character, and should this matter?

FINKLE--Nettie S., passed peacefully on May 1st, 2007, shortly before her 100th birthday. Devoted wife of the late David Finkle. Nettie is survived by her children Marc and Sara Finkle, Ann Miller, Patty and Mark Klein, 14 grandchildren, 27 great grandchildren, two greatgreat-grandchildren. An outstanding member of the Palm Beach community, Nettie served on many local committees and was honored by several charitable organizations. She was dearly loved by her family and by a multitude of friends. Nettie will be missed and remembered for many years to come. Memorial Service to be held Thursday, May 3rd, 11am, Temple Emmanuel, Palm Beach, FL. Interment is private.

To the Editor: Re ''Is the U.S. Protecting Foreign Artifacts? Don't Ask'' by Jeremy Kahn [April 8]: In the article on the State Department's Cultural Property Advisory Committee, a lawyer argues that the panel makes life difficult for dealers and collectors by trying to prevent the trade of objects ''that are produced in the hundreds or multiple hundreds of items.''

A new gilded age was in full bloom at the 25th anniversary lunch of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy last Wednesday. Extravagant hats are always a signature of the event. This year the favorite colors were white, ivory, beige and black etched in white. Attended by 1,240 guests, the lunch raised $2.3 million. Over the years, the committee has raised more than $28 million.
Ray Baldwin has had it. The first selectman of Trumbull, he has seen the Pequonnock River flood dozens of homes and downtown three times in the last year -- most recently in the April 15 northeaster.

Once the center of East Berlin, Mitte -- the area around the Hackescher Markt S-Bahn station -- is now an upscale neighborhood with a low-key vibe. The architecture is a mix of East German prefab, concrete construction and beautiful 18th- and 19th-century buildings whose inner courtyards feed into one another, shielding many of the best-loved galleries, stores and restaurants from the street. Big German brands like Hugo Boss have opened concept stores on the graffitied main drags, but locals head for the more personal establishments, often hidden behind closed doors. Anna Winger

To the Editor: Terrence Rafferty's entertaining essay on the shifting definition of movie detectives (''A Gumshoe Adrift, Lost in the '70s,'' April 15) elucidates well the transformation of Raymond Chandler's Philip Marlowe from Howard Hawks's noirish treatment of ''The Big Sleep'' to Robert Altman's revisionist take on ''The Long Goodbye.'' It's interesting to note that both films were written (co-written in the case of ''The Big Sleep'') by the talented screenwriter Leigh Brackett. Taking nothing from Robert Altman, perhaps it also took a woman of Ms. Brackett's unique perspective to help recast the masculine Marlowe in an era defined in the public imagination more by Watergate and self-actualization than light and shadows and single malt Scotch. Nat Moss Brooklyn

Dr. Emily Flora Gregory, the daughter of Rona H. Gregory of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Joel W. Gregory, who lived in Montreal, is to be married today on Cape Cod to Daniel Jacob Hopkins, a son of Dr. Alice S. Prince of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. B Smith Hopkins III. Rabbi Barbara Penzner officiated at the vacation home of the bridegroom's mother in Orleans, Mass. The bride and bridegroom met at Harvard, from which they graduated magna cum laude and where he received a master's degree in political science.

A reader asked the Ethicist if it was wrong to refuse a doctor's request to allow two medical-school residents to be present in the examining room (April 15). The Ethicist instructed the patient to recognize that he was part of a larger medical community and should do his fair share to support it. But the marketplace is equipped to handle this situation: a student of mine, with a unique case of appendicitis, received a discount on his surgery bill by agreeing to delay the appendectomy an hour so that the hospital could assemble a group of surgical students to watch the procedure. Why not use the straightforward rules of economics and ask for a discount if medical students are in tow?

To the Editor: Lucy Ellmann's dismissive review of Henning Mankell's ''Depths'' (April 15) treats the book, set in neutral Sweden during World War I, as if it were simply a fantastical story of a man torn between two women. Judging that ''it seems needlessly offensive to bring up a real war at all,'' Ellmann narrows the novel to ''a dreamy little allegory'' without considering how this fable works as a dystopian parable about violence, hierarchy and power.

For the same reason that a four-minute single isn't necessarily more satisfying than a two-and-a-half-minute one, we don't really need a director's cut of Tom Hanks's blissful 1996 love letter to '60s pop, ''That Thing You Do!'' The new version clocks in at about two and a half hours, compared with the reet, petite 108 minutes of the original. Fortunately, though, both versions are included here, and while Mr. Hanks's director's cut is worth a fast-forward through (particularly for the way it fleshes out, albeit telegraphically, an interracial romance between two of the characters), the original is the one to watch. ''That Thing You Do!'' follows the rapid rise and even dizzier fall of a fictional pop group from Erie, Pa., around 1964. The band has its lead-singer dreamboat (played by Johnathon Schaech); its good-natured, unassuming drummer (Tom Everett Scott, right, with Charlize Theron); and its No. 1 fan and booster (a heartbreakingly luminous Liv Tyler). They called themselves the Wonders, never stopping to think they are courting that dangerous and undesirable modifier ''one-hit.'' But even though that one hit is their destiny -- its title is the same as the movie's, and it was written by the gifted Adam Schlesinger of the New Jersey band Fountains of Wayne -- Mr. Hanks isn't giving us a cautionary showbiz tale but a buoyant examination of the power that pop songs can have over us.

I STUMBLED over the accordion in the basement, its case already as deep in water as I was -- water pouring in from foundation crevices, billowing up through floor tiles into the fringed magenta rug and, more repulsively, backing up from the street through the sewer cap that we had opened in a feeble attempt to drain away the flood. The April northeaster had hit New Jersey, and we were in its path. The accordion, which had belonged to my father-in-law, had been there for the eight years since his death. I could almost hear him say to my husband, ''Richie, it's O.K. to get rid of it now.'' But my husband couldn't bring himself to do it, despite the cracked bellows, keys and valves that rendered it beyond reasonable repair. It sat on the floor behind the bar, untouched. Now the muddy, insistent waters lashed at the seams of its old case, worming their way into the blue velvet interior.
The old midlife cliché was ''the crisis.'' Today middle age is life on a cusp. How we age -- physically, cognitively, emotionally; as sexual creatures or as media consumers -- is how we live.

To the Editor: Your April 29 editorial ''Storm Warnings'' refers to my August 1988 article about Westchester's waterways. I called for a ''watchman of the waterways'' to represent the needs of our county's rivers and streams. We still need such a position, with the power to be effective. Flooding and pollution are even worse problems now. And we're seeing the impact of global warming on climate change. Open space is being destroyed one parcel at a time. The destruction of trees and excavation in the Mamaroneck River watershed along Route 287 in White Plains is the most recent example.

LAZARUS--Lester ''Roy'', inspired Opera Director dies at age 76. Roy Lazarus, performer, opera director, and educator, died of cardiac arrest on April 13th in Maine where he had made is home since 1986. A brilliant performer, he went on to translate his insight and approach to performance into a truly valid and usable stage technique which influenced countless numbers of students. His career spanned some 60 years and covered all aspects of the operatic and musical theater genres. Heard on national radio at age 15 as ''The Boy Basso from Brooklyn,'' he went on to be educated at Syracuse University. Returning to the stage in New York City he was engaged as Al, one of the four cowboys in the original Broadway production of Frank Loesser's musical ''The Most Happy Fella.'' The show's hit song ''Standin' On The Corner'' created one of the most memorable moments in Broadway history. The quartet subsequently appeared on the ''Ed Sullivan'' and ''I Love Lucy'' shows. He also appeared on Broadway in ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and often worked with Don Adams and Carol Burnett at Green Mansions in the Adirondacks. In his late 20s he focused on opera and sang for several years with the New York City Opera. In the mid 1960s he taught at the Juilliard School. Ultimately, he became Professor of Opera at the Oberlin Conservatory of Music in Ohio where he founded and directed the Oberlin Music Theater. This important summer festival helped train a generation of young artists. The roster of opera houses around the country is testimony to the success of his program. Mr. Lazarus directed opera companies across the United States. In recent years he taught voice in Maine and continued to coach various established artists. Roy Lazarus is survived by his son Steven and grandson Joseph of Peoria, AZ, his son David and grandsons Matthew and Paul of Castle Rock, CO and his sister Bernice of Boca Raton, FL. He will be deeply missed.

Rachel Dretzin, an award-winning filmmaker, spoke to 10 men and women about sex in their middle years. Their statements are excerpted from her documentary, ''Naked,'' which was made for the The New York Times Magazine and can be viewed at nytimes.com/magazine.

DEBORAH GARRISON'S first book of poetry, ''A Working Girl Can't Win,'' did remarkably well, selling 30,000 copies when even some Pulitzer Prize-winning poets are lucky to sell one-tenth that. The poems were about young women in love, out of love, making love and working in Manhattan. Most were written when Ms. Garrison was in her 20s and childless, living in the East Village and climbing the career ladder at The New Yorker. And then, just as she was being lauded as one of those hip young postfeminist urban women portrayed in ''Ally McBeal'' and ''Sex and the City,'' Ms. Garrison gave birth to her first child and moved to New Jersey.

Joanna Faye Bloom and Brett David Lindenbach were married at the Municipal Building in New York on Friday by Blanca Martinez, a marriage officiant in the City Clerk's office. Dr. Bloom, 32, is keeping her name. She is a postdoctoral fellow at Rockefeller University in New York, where she studies the molecular genetics of yeast. She graduated from Middlebury and received both a master's degree and a doctorate in basic medical sciences from New York University.

BRADLEY--William L. September 6, 1918-April 29, 2007. The Rev. Dr. William Lee Bradley, President Emeritus of the Edward W. Hazen Foundation, of Concord, NH, and Randolph, NH, died in Concord of complications from Alzheimer's disease on April 29, surrounded by his family. Born in Oakland, CA, to Kathryn Lee Culver and Dwight Jaques Bradley, he was married to Paula Anne Elliott, a former New Hampshire State Representative (1992-1998; 2000-2002). In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sons, James Choukas-Bradley (Melanie) of Chevy Chase, MD, Dwight Bradley (Lauren) of Chugiak, AK, and Paul Bradley (Robert Abel) of New York, NY, a stepbrother, Royal Whiting, of Newtown, CT, and four grandchildren: Sophia, Alice, Jesse, and Dan. Before joining the Hazen Foundation, he was on the Faculty of Hartford Seminary, Hartford, CT, and served as an officer of The Rockefeller Foundation in Bangkok, Thailand and New York, NY. A memorial services was held on May 2 at Gorham Congregational Church, Gorham, NH, and a second service of celebration will be held on July 29, at the Randolph Church, Randolph, NH. Memorial gifts may be sent to the William L. Bradley Scholarship Fund, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115.

This trim, tense, little-known 1948 noir, one of 10 included in the Warner Brothers set ''Film Noir, Volume 4,'' is an anomaly among the more prestigious pictures directed by Fred Zinnemann (whose best and best known include ''From Here to Eternity'' and ''The Nun's Story''). In the wordless sequences when the lead, Van Heflin (right, with Mary Astor), wanders deserted Los Angeles alleys and back streets, the shadows and seemingly abandoned buildings hovering over him (the movie was shot by Robert Surtees), ''Act of Violence'' becomes a distillation of noir itself. Even if Mr. Heflin were the last man on earth, he'd still be pursued by his own guilt. This fine, underrated actor plays a family man, successful building contractor and decorated war pilot who spent a year in a German prison camp. His life, the picture of middle-class success, begins to crumble when a tall, limping stranger (the great Robert Ryan, evoking terror and pity in the way only he could) shows up in his small California town. The man was Mr. Heflin's closest Army buddy, and the possessor of the secret that gives the lie to his model-citizen persona.

County health officials issued a warning last week after a rabid cat was found near 757 Armonk Road in Mount Kisco. The cat was described as white with a black tail, a black mark on one ear and a black patch on its back. Anyone who had had contact with the cat was asked to call the health department at (914) 813-5000. Rabies is treatable if caught early, but deadly if not. It can be transmitted through a bite or the animal's saliva. ''If the saliva was to get into a cut or a mucus membrane like the eyes or mouth, we would want to evaluate that exposure,'' said Mary Landrigan, a spokeswoman for the county Health Department.

ADAMS--Reverend Dr. Ann Bamford, longtime Associate Minister at the Wellesley Hills Congregational Church, in Wellesley Massachusetts, died early Thursday morning at the age of 52. She had battled bravely against cancer for two and a half years. Dr. Adams served her community both in her pastoral role at the Hills Church, and also, with great advocacy and conviction, served on the board of the Wellesley Housing Authority, connecting deeply with tenants of Wellesley's public housing. She was still active on the Housing Authority at the time of her death. She was active in numerous church and civic organizations, including the Boston City Mission Society and as a Director of the Massachusetts Conference of the United Church of Christ. Known for the freshness, candor, and great faith of her original prayers, Adams reached out well beyond the Wellesley community through her website Prayerswork.com which offered a daily prayer, and a blog which chronicled her life with cancer with a humor and endurance that encouraged many cancer patients across the country and the world. Many of these prayers have been collected in her book Prayer At Work (Chapel Place Press). Adams leaves her son, Thomas Craig Bailey Adams, and her husband, Reverend Craig B. Adams, of Otisfield, Maine. The Rev. Mr. Adams, is Minister Emeritus of the Wellesley Hills Congregational Church. In addition to her son, Adams is survived by her father, Richard Bamford and stepmother Dee Bamford of Connecticut. Adams mother, Mary, predeceased her daughter. Adams is also survived by a brother, Benjamin Bamford, and sister, Jane Bamford Kennedy, her aunt Cynthia Adams Johnson, and stepdaughter Catherine Jordan and her family, and stepson Martin Adams and his family. Adams was born on October 11, 1954 and moved many times as a child, graduating from E.O. Smith High School in Storrs, Connecticut in 1972. Adams graduated from Wellesley College with the class of 1976, Phi Beta Kappa, with a degree in Economics. She continued her education at Yale, graduating in the first class of Yale's School of Management in 1978. Adams was working in the investment community in New York City when she felt called to ministry. She earned her M. Div and D. Min. at Andover Newton Theological School and served at the Wellesley Hills Church in Wellesley, Massachusetts, for over 19 years. Additionally, Adams served as Interim Associate Minister at Hancock United Church of Christ, in Lexington, and at Babson College, in Wellesley, where she was Protestant Chaplain. Despite her grave illness, Adams delivered the eulogy for legendary economist Carolyn Shaw Bell, who was memorialized at Wellesley College, this past January. Bell had been Adams' advisor while studying at the College. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the ''Ann Adams Revocable Trust'' and sent to Miriam T. Dever, Trustee, 11 Class Street, West Roxbury, MA 02132. A memorial service will take place at the Wellesley Hills Congregational Church in Wellesley at 1 pm on Monday, May 7th, following a private committal.

NATHAN--Henry Louis, died peacefully on May 2, 2007 at age 87. Beloved husband of Sophie, dear father of Claude and daughter-in-law Myriam. Private service was held according to his wishes. He will be forever missed.

WEISS--Lawrence S., born in New York City, November 7, 1921, son of Alexander and Bess Weiss has passed to a better place May 3, 2007 after a brief but difficult illness. Loving, devoted husband, father, and grandfather, he was admired, loved and respected by all who knew him. A child of the depression, member of ''The Greatest Generation'', he graduated from City College of New York. After graduation he served his country with pride and honor in World War II as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps. Following the war, he completed post graduate training in Optometry at Columbia University, and began to pursue his career. Larry met and married his lifelong partner, the love and light of his life, Alice in 1958. The couple settled in Jackson Heights, NY, and raised two children, Jeffrey and Carla. He passed on his zest for life, his diverse interests, and his continual quest for knowledge to his children and grandchildren. His life was his family, and that remained so until his passing. His spirit remains in all of our hearts. We will all be together again one day. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Larry's memory to the Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Boulevard, Woodbury, NY 11797.

Lawyers questioning the validity of a computerized alcohol-testing machine will have the opportunity to review the device's source code to help determine if it is more reliable than a traditional Breathalyzer, the State Supreme Court ruled last week. But the court said the defendants in the case must pay for the testing. There are more than 10,000 open drunken-driving cases because of the challenge to the reliability of the machine, the Alcotest 7110, which is used in 17 of the state's 21 counties. Drivers with a blood-alcohol content of 0.08 percent are considered to be above the legal limit to operate a vehicle.

Marcia Anne Yablon, a daughter of Joan and Charles M. Yablon of New York, is to be married today to Charles Gordon Zug IV, the son of Sara G. Zug of Gladwyne, Pa., and Mr. Zug III of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Kayelily Middleton, a nondenominational minister, is to officiate at Fearrington House, a restaurant and inn in Pittsboro, N.C., with Rabbi Andrew V. Ettin taking part. Mrs. Zug, 29, is to become an assistant professor of family law and Native American law in August at the University of South Carolina School of Law, in Columbia, S.C. Until last month she was an associate in the New York office of Steptoe & Johnson, a Washington law firm. She graduated from Dartmouth and received her law degree from Yale.

To the Editor: Re ''P.E. Classes Turn to Video Game That Works Legs, Not Thumbs'' (front page, April 30): A nation full of physically healthy children (and adults) would be wonderful. But is this the goal of our schools' gym classes, even at the expense of promoting healthy social and intellectual development?

GILPIN--Laura Crafton, an award winning poet and crusader for hospital reform, died Thursday, February 15, in her home in Fairhope, Alabama, at 56. Laura was a gifted poet and her first book of poems ''The Hocus-Pocus of the Universe'' received the Walt Whitman Award in 1976. Laura had also recently completed a second book of poetry, ''The Weight of a Soul''. Laura became a registered nurse in 1981 and joined the founding staff of Planetree, a pioneering organization dedicated to humanizing patient care in hospitals. For over 20 years she worked passionately to promote this vision. Laura's indomitable spirit, her kindness, her droll humor, her brilliant intellect and her love of celebrations are legendary. Laura is survived by her fiance Bill Davis, her mother, Bertha Burghard, her brother Robert Crafton Gilpin, Jr., her sister, Elizabeth Darbro and several nieces and nephews. Charitable contributions can be made to Planetree's Laura Gilpin Kindness Fund by calling: (203) 732-1365.

Floyd Mayweather Jr., from Grand Rapids, Mich., entered the ring at the MGM Grand Garden Arena on Saturday night wearing a huge white sombrero -- a pointed, if witty mind game aimed directly at Oscar De La Hoya, his Mexican-American opponent whose World Boxing Council super-welterweight belt he took by force in a 12-round split decision. The sartorial message did not seem to bother De La Hoya, who used his power in the early rounds to overpower the smaller Mayweather, who seemed perplexed and with no ready answer for De La Hoya's punches.

Thank you, Michael Pollan, for lifting the essence of the farm bill out of the brackish waters in which it sits (April 22). The quality of meals served to schoolchildren could be vastly improved with a farm bill that supports the very nutritional standards the U.S.D.A. has mandated in its much heralded food pyramid and ''wellness policy.''

Innovative design and delicious food meet at Proef, Marije Vogelzang's design studios/restaurants in Amsterdam and Rotterdam. Weekend visitors can participate in her oddball creations, such as salads whose ingredients were grown in the dark. Vogelzang became interested in food as a material while studying industrial design. She now creates ''food concepts'' for events for clients ranging from HermÃ

LAFORSE--Marty. Husband, father, stepfather, gramps, zadie, beloved friend. Master teacher, passionate historian, writer, artist, gardener, story teller, volunteer. Gentle, wise and kind. Louis, Kurt and Jackie, here he comes!

LAZKO--Dolora, 68, born Grozny to the late Judith and Louis Suarez. Much loved niece and cousin and colleague at Beach Channel High School. Services at noon Sunday, May 6, at Weinstein Kirschenbaum, 1153 Coney Island Avenue at Avenue H.

It's hard to tell without the benefit of seeing Terry Eagleton's body language and facial expressions whether he was pulling Deborah Solomon's leg when he said, ''If I want to read a book, I write one myself'' (April 22). But what does seem clear is that Eagleton was having some posthumous fun with Benjamin Disraeli. According to an early biographer, upon being asked whether he had read a novel by George Eliot, Disraeli famously replied, ''When I want to read a novel, I write one.'' No joke there; Disraeli, when he wasn't busy being Britain's prime minister twice, published no fewer than 16 works of fiction, not to mention one additional book he left unfinished at his death.

MEYER--Manfred. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished Board member, father of our member, David Meyer. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Steve Graber, President $(6$)MEYER--Manfred M., died May 3. Devoted husband of the late Eva, beloved father of Paulette and David Meyer, and grandfather of Rachel and Jack. Funeral was held in Israel, Shiva Sunday through Thursday morning in NY.
MARKFIELD--Patricia Ellen. 8/5/1947-5/5/1996. Precious Ellen. Loved beyond measure -missed beyond words. You were our special long stemmed rose. Lovingly, Mommy and Dale

MAYER--Manfred. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a distinguished community leader and YU Guardian who, with his late wife, Eva, established a course in Jewish History at Stern College for Women, and had a long and generous relationship with our institution. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his children, David and Paulette Mayer, and his grandchildren, Rachel and Jack. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees

For those of you who love baseball and have never watched a game here, I say only this: Do not pass Go, do not collect $200, get thee here as fast as you can. If God were an architect - and who knows, He could be - I'm convinced that He designed AT&T Park. Just finished taking a lap around the main concourse, which, between the foul lines, is uncovered and allows fans to gaze at the Bay Bridge, the Bay and dozens of souvenir shops/tasty concession stands (I'm eating one of these right now)

In an article in today's Science Times, Gina Kolata reports on research showing that obesity is largely determined by genetics, a message that is at odds with popular conceptions of weight loss. What does that say about society's obsession with dieting?

If they finally find a mate for Lonesome George, what should she be called? I suggest Eve in my Findings column about George, the famous giant tortoise from Pinta Island in the Galapagos. For decades, he was thought to be the last of the Pinta species, but biologists now think there's probably at least one more mixed in with the tortoises on another island. They hope to find one next year, preferably a female they could take back to George's pen.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has been battling Senator Barack Obama of Illinois for primacy in the Democratic field of presidential hopefuls, and now she is taking the battle to Chicago - his home turf and her former hometown.

It is cap-and-gown season, and for the presidential candidates, that means the opportunity to spend May weekends delivering speeches at colleges and universities that are carefully selected to fit a strategic purpose.
You could tell from the background music that played beforehand - alternating recordings of James Brown and Gregorian chant - that this was going to be an unusual debate.
Matt DeSalvo is wearing No. 14 tonight in his major league debut for the Yankees. Maybe they should have given him No. 45.
The short life of a highly-caffeinated beverage known as Cocaine has come to an end.

On Feb. 8, 2004, George W. Bush proudly proclaimed to Tim Russert on "Meet the Press," "I am a war president." Like an 8-year-old playing with toy soldiers, Bush, an Air National Guard dropout, looked at war with vicarious enthusiasm. Contrast the attitude of the nation's "peace presidents" - supreme commanders who led the nation to victory in the greatest wars the country faced: men who had experienced the grim reality of battle and wanted no part of it.

Senator Hillary Clinton's current opposition to the war in Iraq is enough to satisfy members of her overwhelmingly anti-war party, despite her support for the invasion four years ago. While three quarters of Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll last month said the United States should have stayed out of Iraq, seven in 10 of them still expressed a favorable opinion of Mrs. Clinton. The poll was conducted before Mrs. Clinton's call last week to deauthorize the war.
The New York Public Library is hosting a debate tonight between the author Christopher Hitchens and the civil rights leader the Rev. Al Sharpton. The question: Is God great?
When we met with Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, our architects, the next day for breakfast, I wasn't expecting much.
The power to pardon traditionally belongs to the president. But Representative Duncan Hunter, who is seeking the 2008 Republican nomination, isn't waiting for Inauguration Day.

An anonymous commenter, responding to my previous column, suggested that my title "Our Lives as Atoms" is "more than a little puzzling," and wondered "Where will all this lead us?" I've written about the amplified polarization of opinion in the political blogs, and about the abuse at Abu Ghraib prison, which had a disturbingly eerie resemblance to famous experiments at Stanford University 36 years ago. What does any of this have to do with atoms? Fair question. I'd like to start my answer by telling you about a strange phenomenon in Spitsbergen.Spitsbergen is a Norwegian island in the Svalbard archipelago. It has spectacular mountains, abundant glaciers and desolate tundra, where stones are littered over a flat and mostly featureless terrain. In places on this tundra, the stones are arranged in a remarkable way; they lie not in a chaotic, haphazard jumble but in an ordered array of hauntingly beautiful, nearly perfect circular piles. You really have to look at a photo to believe it.

Diane Cardwell, The Times's City Hall bureau chief writes in our sibblog, The Empire Zone, that a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises, the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.

Relations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and members of the Legislature have been notably more sour during the last few weeks, as the governor butted heads with lawmakers over campaign reform, school districts, and other issues.
Photobucket, a four-year-old, rapidly growing Web company, is in advanced talks to be acquired by Fox Interactive Media, a division of the News Corporation, reports Brad Stone of The New York Times.

At a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises (Surprise! He's doing really well, with 91 percent kept), the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.
Harry Hurt quarterbacks three plays as a "Paper Jet." He didn't run for daylight, but he didn't fumble either.
The Times's Harry Hurt III learns how to defend himself in a class on ki chuan do. (Producer: Erik Olsen)
The Times's Harry Hurt III heads to the Shawangunk Mountains to try his hand at rock climbing. (Producer: Erik Olsen)
Harry Hurt III attempts a specially choreographed 15-second routine with a ballerina from the New York City Ballet.
Harry Hurt III takes on a well-prepared opponent at the Fencer's Club in Chelsea.
Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.

Private equity chiefs worried about a much bigger tax bite can take some comfort -- though it's unclear just how much -- from Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus. The Democratic lawmaker from Montana told the National Press Club on Monday that his committee is "nowhere close'' to drafting a bill that could affect the amount of tax that private equity funds and hedge funds have to pay. Mr. Baucus called recent reports that such legislation is already being drafted "pure speculation," according to Bloomberg. "People need to keep their shirts on here."

In Nascar, Jeff Gordon started on pole in Richmond, his third straight pole, but faded in the final 15 laps to finish fourth. His Hendrick Motorsports teammates, Jimmie Johnson and Kyle Busch, finished one-two. Hendrick drivers are four-for-four in Car of Tomorrow races. ESPN takes a closer look at the team's domination.

Motorola chief executive Edward Zander and activist investor Carl Icahn have been at each other like "antsy pugilists trying to work the media for a prefight edge," writes Roger O. Crockett in BusinessWeek. And Monday is fight day: Motorola's annual shareholder meeting in Chicago.

After tipping over a glass filled with red wine because - for the gazillionth time - I caught the sleeve of my jacket on the edge of one of those paper tablecloth tops, my next blog came into sharp focus: annoying restaurant practices.
It's the buyout deal that wouldn't die.

Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum giant, had a relatively low-key public reaction Monday to Alcoa's surprise $33 billion hostile bid, saying in a short press release that it would "consider the proposal." Canadian politicians may not be so measured. The uninvited offer from Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, is likely to rekindle a national debate in Canada about the recent surge in foreign takeovers of large Canadian companies and whether it represents a threat to the country's economic prestige -- not to mention a potential loss of lucrative underwriting, accounting and legal work for the nation's financial professionals.
What's left behind after most natural disasters is usually death, destruction and a lingering curiosity about what could have caused it.

Perhaps in advance of the just-announced Assembly oversight hearing at which they will be appearing tomorrow, officials at the Empire State Development Corporation issued a press release today announcing the consolidation of some of its many, many subsidiary development corporations.Of all the state's hundreds of public authorities, the development corporation is one of the biggest and most sprawling and controls some of the biggest pots of money. According to the release, it is dissolving 13 subsidiaries and collapsing 25 others into a single holding company "to promote good corporate governance and ease oversight burdens."

I was never very impressed with Akimbo, the set-top box that was going to give you access to any TV show ever aired, on demand, via the Internet. The problem wasn't the concept; it was that they couldn't get the rights to any decent shows.

While J. Christopher Callaghan, the former candidate for state comptroller, stole the show at the 107th Legislative Correspondents Association dinner over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzer's video had its moments.

In what may be the end of a months-long battle for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, the national steakhouse chain said on Monday that it has agreed to a sweetened $94.6 million buyout offer by the Patina Restaurant Group. Patina's newest bid, which raised the cash per share to $11 from $9.25, bested a rival $84 million proposal by the Landry's Restaurant Group.

In retrospect, it's clear that we in the news media let the public down in the run-up to the Iraq war. This was the point of Bill Moyers' recent documenary, "Buying the War." Michael Getler, as experienced and savvy a journalist as any, has a thoughtful take on the documentary, and I recommend it. Getler writes in part:
Pictures from the flyby of Jupiter by the New Horizons spacecraft.
The Liberty Mutual Group, a home and auto insurer based in Boston, said Monday it had agreed to buy the Ohio Casualty Corporation for $2.7 billion.

The revelation - dropped by Christopher Hitchens in an interview with New York magazine - that Karl Rove is an atheist has enabled the Bush administration to, at long last, deliver on its 2000 campaign promise to "change the tone" in Washington. Exhibit A: "I've never said this before, and never will again, but I'm with Karl Rove," writes The American Prospect's Ezra Klein on his personal blog. (Hitchens told New York, "Karl Rove is not a believer, and he doesn't shout it from the rooftops, but when asked, he answers quite honestly. I think the way he puts it is, 'I'm not fortunate enough to be a person of faith.' ")

Peter S. Kalikow, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority since 2001, announced this morning that he would resign when Gov. Eliot Spitzer names his replacement, after six eventful years at the helm of the nation's biggest and busiest mass transit system.

Jacques Chirac leaves office after two terms as France's president, largely deemed a failure. He gets credit in France for standing up to President Bush over Iraq, but on the domestic front it was a time of drift, with efforts on reform collapsing as soon as protesters took to the streets. Voters rejected the European Union constitution he supported. He decided against seeking a third term only when polls made clear he could not win.
Thirty-six companies have decided to join forces in a push to extend health insurance to all Americans, The Los Angeles Times reported today.
The Times's Adam Nagourney looks at how California, armed with an early primary, is changing presidential politics:

A week after AT&T's chief executive said he would step down, the head of the telecommunication company's mergers and acquisitions team announced he also will retire. James Kahan, the senior executive vice president for corporate development who helped spearhead $200 billion in deals, including the acquisition of BellSouth, will step down on June 30, the company announced Saturday.
Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, had a clear message for the White House Sunday - the clock is ticking.
Greed is still good.

The nation's military, in its search for the next surveillance system, bioterror vaccine or robot warrior, has decided to take a peek into the garage. Through a program that recently emerged from an experimental phase, the Defense Department is using some of the nation's top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies, which have not traditionally been a part of the military's vast supply chain.

Can you hedge a hedge fund? An investment currently being marketed to the rich is trying in essence to do just that, and the approach is bound to be offered to the rest of us soon, The New York Times reports.

State Senator Antoine M. Thompson of Buffalo, a freshman Democrat, made a fiery speech on the Senate floor last week, denouncing a bill to increase legislators' salaries when it came up for a vote in his chamber. He cited the lack of raises for Buffalo city workers, police officers, teachers and sanitation workers, and said, "I can't in good conscience vote for myself, or anyone else, a raise."

Synergies aside, is Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company really about the media mogul's desire to acquire the patina of respectability that has eluded him as he built his News Corporation empire?

A former Credit Suisse banker accused of running a $7.5 million insider trading ring from April 2006 until this February was denied bail yesterday at a hearing in federal magistrate court in Manhattan. Magistrate Judge Theodore H. Katz said that the banker, Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Pakistani citizen, met "virtually every criteria" as a flight risk.

In a possible transAtlantic combination of defense contractors, Britain's BAE Systems is in final negotiations for the $3.5 billion purchase of Armor Holdings, a United States maker of military and heavy vehicles, Humvee armaments and soldier body armor, according to The Wall Street Journal. The deal with BAE would pay Armor Holdings shareholders about $88 a share, or a 7 percent premium to the company's closing price Friday of $82.15 a share, the report said.

The investment group whose bid of 10.8 billion Australian dollars ($8.9 billion) for Qantas collapsed over the weekend said Monday it might make a new bid for the airline, as regulators sought clarification that the old offer was indeed dead.

Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners discussed possible changes to their bid for Clear Channel Communications over the weekend, The Financial Times reported, citing undisclosed sources. A price increase was unlikely, the newspaper said, but other terms could change ahead of Tuesday's shareholder vote on the proposal.
ABN Amro rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its LaSalle Bank unit from a group led by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, as the biggest takeover battle in the financial-services industry intensified.

Are hedge fund managers fees getting too rich for investors' blood? While managers of these regulated investment pools are getting richer -- they took home an estimated $14 billion last year -- there are grumblings among some investors that their returns are not worth the fees.
KPMG has quit as auditor of the bankrupt subprime lender New Century Financial, which has hired forensic accountants to investigate how the company valued its stake in mortgage-backed bonds.

Predicting the next buyout target has become a cottage industry on Wall Street, with analysts seeming to churn out lists of suggestions -- usually based on a screening of stocks according to set criteria -- on a weekly basis. Dan Primack of PEHub said he has gotten ahold of one such leveraged buyout model produced by Goldman Sachs for its institutional clients, and it apparently offers some intriguing candidates that private equity funds might be considering.

Berkshire Hathaway's Warren Buffett said he would "love'' to find a $40 billion acquisition and would "figure out a way'' to come up with $60 billion for the right deal, Bloomberg News reported. Speaking at his company's annual shareholder meeting in Omaha over the weekend, he also suggested that he might hire up to four people as chief investment officers when he steps down.

A takeover battle for the EMI Group, the British music company, may be in the offing, but Warner Music, which has been interested in EMI for years, will not be among the bidders.The Financial Times reported that three private equity firms in the United states -- Fortress, Cerberus and One Equity -- are set for a 3 billion pound ($5.98 billion) takeover battle during the next two weeks for control of EMI, the world's third-biggest music group.

Alcoa, the world's No. 1 aluminum company, said Monday it would make an unsolicited bid it valued at $33 billion for Alcan, a Montreal-based rival. Alcoa said the proposed bid came after lengthy negotiations between the two aluminum giants failed to produce a mutually agreed deal. "This offer follows almost two years of discussions between our companies regarding a variety of potential business combination transactions, including unsuccessful board-level discussions of a merger transaction last fall," Alcoa's chief executive Alain J.P. Belda said in a statement. "We are very disappointed that those efforts did not result in a negotiated transaction -- a conclusion we would have strongly preferred."

The Carlyle Group is one of two bidders expected to put in final offers to buy the Devonport submarine dockyard near Plymouth in Britain this week. Final offers for the Devonport Management Limited, the company that runs the submarine refueling and maintenance yard, are due on Tuesday following a first round of bidding that valued it at about 350 million pounds ($697 million).

The trustees of the pension fund at Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, are demanding that the private equity bidders planning to take over the company commit 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) to its pension plan.

Dominick's, the Chicago-area grocery chain, is not for sale, the chief executive of Safeway, its parent company, told The Chicago Tribune. But at the same time, Safeway is not going to rapidly expand the size of the chain, which was cut to 83 stores earlier this year when it closed 14 "underperforming" stores, said the executive, Steven Burd, who engineered Dominick's acquisition in 1998 in a deal then valued at $1.9 billion.
As activist investors like Carl Icahn, who is currently waging a proxy war with Motorola to gain a seat on its board, become more determined, the companies' boards are apparently getting softer.
With more than $2 billion in cash to burn, Sears Holdings' chairman Edward Lampert told shareholders Friday the retail giant is considering numerous possibilities for acquisitions or investments.

The Dutch bank ABN Amro, the subject of one of the largest takeover battles in history, said Monday it had rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its Lasalle Bank subisidiary from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland, finding it "did not constitute a superior proposal" to a previous bid from Bank of America. Nevertheless, ABN said it would allow shareholders to vote on the competing bid and others, as required by last week's ruling in an Amsterdam court.

With its three Atlantic City casinos being eyed by potential buyers, Trump Entertainment Resorts said Thursday that its first-quarter loss shrank, despite increasing competition from slot-machine parlors in Philadelphia and New York. Perhaps more worrisome news is that potential white knights have yet to materialize.

Netgear, a Santa Clara, Calif. maker of equipment that lets customers set up household Internet networks, agreed to buy closely held Infrant Technologies for $60 million to gain access to its data storage products. Additionally, Netgear may pay as much as $20 million in cash over three years if Infrant meets revenue goals, Netgear said Thursday in a statement.

In the eat-or-be-eaten world of banking, Greater Bay Bancorp's network of Bay Area community banks became a snack Friday for giant Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo agreed to pay about $1.5 billion in stock for the East Palo Alto, Calif., holding company, which is better known to most customers for its individual banks, including Santa Clara Valley National Bank, Mid-Peninsula Bank, Peninsula Bank of Commerce and Mount Diablo National Bank.

Start-ups preparing to go public and the bankers backing them are hoping for a merry, merry month of May. The Red Herring notes that bankers are hoping to raise $1.4 billion this week with six new stocks coming to market, and have $1.3 billion lined up for the following week.

A start-up, Mig33, has snagged $10 million in funding for its mobile Internet telephony and instant-messaging services, the Red Herring reported. The funding, led by Accel Partners and RedPoint Ventures, and which included Technology Venture Partners, is expected to be announced Monday, the publication said.
'‘Radio Golf,’' the final chapter in August Wilson’s monumental look at the black experience in 20th century America, is a play forged by illness.

About.com, a Web information service owned by The New York Times Company, plans to announce Monday that it has bought ConsumerSearch.com, a Web site that compiles reviews of consumer products, for $33 million.

Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, has acquired and absorbed Radar Communications in Boulder, Colo., a consulting company specializing in market research that seeks to better understand consumer behavior. Financial terms were not disclosed.
President Bush welcomed Queen Elizabeth II to the White House with remarks that celebrated the values that have bound the United States and Britain across the Atlantic and across the centuries.

"Spider-Man 3" set box office records this weekend despite getting mostly luke-warm reviews. "300" and "Wild Hogs," which were both surprise hits for the movie industry, also managed to be hot at the box office without critical acclaim.
Astronomers reported that they had seen the most powerful stellar explosion ever recorded.
Thunderstorms and soaking rain produced flooding today in parts of Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas.
Bank officials said that the special committee was still working on a punishment recommendation.
At least 16 members of Ehud Olmert’s governing coalition voted against the Israeli prime minister, abstained or were absent.
Violent protests ended with hundreds of people arrested, hundreds of cars gutted and hundreds of windows smashed in several cities across in France.
Hong Kong authorities said today that the Chinese government is providing little information about it.
The senator said the Japanese had done far better than Detroit companies to develop energy efficient vehicles.
“We honor our traditions and our shared history,” President  Bush said.
Showing a bit too much of your working life too soon may cause some people to give up on you before they recognize your talents.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 7 — The man who shot and killed two American military trainers on Sunday, and wounded two others, was a soldier of the Afghan National Army, the Afghan Ministry of Defense confirmed today.
Peter S. Kalikow said today that he intended to step down as soon as his successor is approved.
Jon S. Corzine said that his prolonged absence from a job that he loves was driving him “stir crazy.”
The Republican debate may not have been one for the history books, but it did have its share of exchanges, moments that people are likely to refer back to as this campaign unfolds.
Nearly every day a sheik stops by his old villa, which has been turned into a military base, to ask for his home back.
The June election for parliament will determine how much elbow room Nicolas Sarkozy has to enact his ambitious economic reforms.

A 15-year-old Queens girl placed her newborn son in a plastic bag and hid him in a closet in her home, where he remained until her mother, looking for the source of an odor, discovered his body yesterday morning, a law enforcement official said.

The authorities impounded two police vehicles as part of their investigation into the killing of a homeless man, the police said yesterday. The authorities declined to explain how the vehicles might be connected to the April 28 death of Rene Javier Perez, 42, whose body was found on the side of a road in Bedford. Just an hour before he was discovered, the police here had responded to a 911 call placed by Mr. Perez from a coin-operated laundry, the Mount Kisco Police Department said in a statement. Officers reported the incident closed “after determining Rene Perez did not have a police matter,” the department said. The Westchester County medical examiner’s office declared the death a homicide.
Up to 60 members of an elite squad that fired rubber bullets during an immigration rally are no longer on the street.
GOLF.

An article on April 21 about the removal of a mechanical ventilator from Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey eight days after he was seriously injured in a vehicular crash misstated the title of Dr. Ken Rodriguez of Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, who discussed milestones for patients who have been removed from ventilators. He is the chief of orthopedic trauma, not orthopedic medicine.

An article on Wednesday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to redevelop the Willets Point business district in Queens misstated the given name of the owner of the Crown Container Company, one of the businesses in the area, who opposes the plan. He is Jerry Antonacci, not Joey.

An article and picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to re-establish coral reefs referred incorrectly to the networks of pipes on which coral is grown in the Mote Marine Laboratory in Florida. The pipes are made of PVC, not iron. The article also carried an incomplete list of American territories where corals occur. Besides Florida, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, corals also grow in warm and cold water in several other areas, including American Samoa and the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the first debate of the Republican candidates for president referred incorrectly in some copies to Duncan Hunter, one of the 10 participants. He is a current — not former — congressman from California.

A picture in some copies on Friday with the Public Lives column, about Judith Enck, deputy secretary for the environment for Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, was published in error. The picture was of Carol Ash, the new state parks commissioner — not Ms. Enck.

A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a Congolese military tribunal clearing an opposition politician of inciting armed insurrection misspelled the name of the city in which the tribunal met. It is Kinshasa, not Kinshasha.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the given name of the former director of Mr. Black’s company who testified that she and other directors were misled about millions of dollars in payments to Mr. Black and other executives. She was Marie-Josée Kravis, not Marie-José.

Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about a rethinking of interpretation of the Second Amendment was omitted in some copies. The complete article is reprinted today on Page A18. It is also online: nytimes.com/national.

An obituary on Friday about Walter M. Schirra, Jr., an early United States astronaut, misstated the publication date for “The Real Space Cowboys,” which he wrote with Ed Buckbee. It was 2005, not 1971.

An article on Sept. 30 about a lawsuit to force the Department of Veterans Affairs to add the Wiccan symbol to the list of approved emblems for headstones included erroneous information from the suit about a Pentagon survey of Wiccan participation in the military. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on April 23 about the suit’s settlement.) There were more than 1,800 Wiccans in the Air Force, not in all of the armed forces. (The Pentagon did not survey the entire military.).

A theater review on April 20 about “The View From K Street Steak,” at Altered Stages in Chelsea, referred incorrectly to the setting at the start of the play. While the first scene is titled “Reno,” the play is set, according to the program, at a political retreat at a Hilton Head spa and resort “and similar expense-account playgrounds.” The retreat is not in Reno, Nev.

A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a Congolese military tribunal clearing an opposition politician of inciting armed insurrection misspelled the name of the city in which the tribunal met. It is Kinshasa, not Kinshasha.

A map on Tuesday with an article comparing two PCB-removal projects by General Electric — one on the Hudson River in New York and the other on the Housatonic in Massachusetts — misspelled part of the name of a city near the G.E. factory in Hudson Falls, N.Y. It is Glens Falls, not Glen Falls.
The whistle-blower’s story opens a window, lawmakers say, onto how the Bush administration resisted calls to improve oversight of the student loan industry.
Improper hard-sell tactics have persuaded Medicare recipients to sign up for private health plans that cost the government, officials say.
Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory on Sunday over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years. Turnout was 84 percent of France’s registered voters.
Narciso Rodriguez’s candor about his money problems is being rewarded as Liz Claiborne acquires his upscale label.
Eighteen months ago, the crew and support staff of Victory Challenge were on the verge of unemployment. Their mood is now less grim.
Liberation theology, which the pope once called “a fundamental threat,” retains its appeal in Latin America.
World Bank officials said the committee investigating misconduct charges against Paul D. Wolfowitz would eventually find that he violated bank rules barring conflicts of interest.
Two car bombs exploded near a police checkpoint just north of Ramadi today, an Iraqi official said.
Tim Duncan had 33 points and 16 rebounds — 8 offensive — and Tony Parker added 32 points to lead the San Antonio Spurs to a rough-and-tumble  victory.
If America gave up its position as the regulatory gold standard, foreign companies might have far less incentive to list their shares on American exchanges.
To the Editor:.

An 18-year-old woman was killed when the car in which she was riding skidded off the Grand Central Parkway shortly after 1 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The accident occurred near Roosevelt Avenue when the car hit a center barrier, struck a tree and caught fire, the police said. The 18-year-old driver and two other passengers, a 16-year-old boy and an 18-year-old woman, were injured and were in stable condition at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, the police said.

Two men were struck and injured by trains late Saturday and early yesterday, one by a subway in Brooklyn and one by a commuter train in Queens, the police said. The first man, 26, was found on the L train tracks near the Grand Street station in East Williamsburg shortly before 11:30 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. He had been struck by a train and critically injured and was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center. It was unclear how he had come to be on the tracks, but criminal activity was not suspected, the police said. The second man, identified as Eduardo Zenteno, 19, of Brooklyn, was on the Long Island Rail Road tracks between the Woodside and Shea Stadium stations when a westbound train struck him about 4:30 a.m. yesterday, according to Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman for the railroad. He was in serious but stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center yesterday, she said.

A 20-year-old man was fatally stabbed during a fight in Jamaica shortly after midnight yesterday, the police said. The man, whose name was not released by the police, was stabbed at Las Playitas, a restaurant at 170-03 Jamaica Avenue, the police said. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

A leak that sent millions of gallons of raw sewage spilling into the Hudson River north of New York City has been fixed, but officials yesterday warned boaters, water skiers and divers to stay out of the water in the area through today. A 48-inch pipe broke Friday afternoon, apparently ruptured by a tree that had come loose during a landslide near the Greystone train station in Yonkers, officials said. Mary Landrigan, a spokeswoman for the Westchester County Health Department, said yesterday that workers had fixed the pipe, but that 7.5 million gallons of sewage had spilled. On Saturday, she said officials believed that the sewage had contaminated the Hudson from the northern Bronx through Westchester as well as in southern Rockland County. She said that drinking water was not affected by the problem, and that the sewage should dissipate within days.

A man was stabbed and shot to death during a fight outside a club in Bushwick yesterday morning, the police said. The fight occurred shortly after 3 a.m. at the Groove Lounge, the police said. Patrons spilled outside the club, and witnesses said they heard several gunshots. The victim, Luis Ruiz, 24, of Clinton Hill, a single father who worked in Manhattan in computer graphics, had visited the club for the first time that night, said Noemi Galletti, his landlord and friend. “Someone called him to come over because they were having a party there,” she said. Another man was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center with a head injury, but he was in stable condition yesterday, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

A bill designed to give parents greater access to information about their children who are in residential health facilities was signed into law yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer. The law, spurred by the death of a 13-year-old autistic boy this year, requires the facilities to notify parents and guardians within 24 hours of events affecting the children’s health and safety. The boy, Jonathan Carey, died in February while under care at the state’s Oswald D. Heck Developmental Center. The authorities have said an aide was trying to restrain Jonathan in a van when he stopped breathing. Two aides have been charged with manslaughter and have pleaded not guilty.

Senator Charles E. Schumer yesterday called for an inquiry by the federal Government Accountability Office, the investigative arm of Congress, into the tight gasoline market, saying oil companies should do more to upgrade production facilities. Gas prices have been driven higher in recent months by unexpected refinery shutdowns, which have been reflected in government data showing falling gasoline inventories at a time of year when most analysts think they should be rising.
