The Bad Plus ''Prog'' (Do the Math/Heads Up) The decisive jolt of a downbeat -- like someone slamming two fists on a table -- provides the chief sensory experience of ''Prog,'' the fifth studio release by the Bad Plus. It's a simple thing, this impact, and not at all representative of the technical exertion that surrounds it. It's also one of the ways in which this band, which once issued a live album called ''Blunt Object,'' distinguishes itself from other acoustic piano trios in jazz an anywhere else.

BID FOR DOW JONES CRITICIZED -- Members of the Ottaway family, which owns a minority stake in Dow Jones & Company, released scathing statements yesterday saying that a takeover by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation would ruin Dow Jones and its crown jewel, The Wall Street Journal. [Page C1.] INVESTORS ASSIST PENTAGON -- The Defense Department is using some of the nation's top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies, which have not traditionally been a part of the military's vast supply chain. [C1.] CELLPHONE ADVERTISING LAGS -- Short multi-episode cellphone series, like the ''Smallville Legends'' series from Warner Brothers Television Group, are growing in popularity. But advertising, which studios rely on for profit, been slow to migrate to the supersmall screen. [C1.] 3-D PRINTING AT HOME -- In a few years, it will be possible to download three-dimensional plans online, then push the print button. Hours later, a solid object -- a replica of the lost battery cover for your cellphone, perhaps -- will be ready to remove from your printer. [C1.] NEW ABSURDITY IN VIOLENCE -- In the last couple of weeks, the ''Lazy Sunday'' parody on ''Saturday Night Live'' has been supplanted by something even more viral and revealing of the popular mindscape. On YouTube it has been given the tag ''SNLOCmeme.'' Link by Link. [C4.] REPLAY THAT PLAYOFF GAME -- The National Basketball Association is preparing to announce a new video download store that allows fans to download playoff games from this season and last for $3 apiece. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi [C9.] AN ALMA MATER CELLPHONE? -- A start-up company called Sonopia is trying to apply the concept of affinity groups to the cellphone market, as banks have long done with credit cards. Instead of sharing space on the screen with a brand name like Sprint, Verizon or T-Mobile, an alumni association or nonprofit group can put its own logo on the phone. [C7.] JOURNALISTS TO SUE HEWLETT -- In an unusual step for the news media, three journalists whose private phone records were scrutinized by investigators working for Hewlett-Packard intend to sue the company for invasion of privacy. [C4.] BID FOR QANTAS FALTERS -- Qantas Airways said that it considered a takeover bid for the airline to have failed after regulators refused to step in and save it. But the bidder, a private equity-backed group named Airline Partners Australia, said it would appeal the regulators' decision. [C4.] RECORD FIRST, PRINT LATER -- Audio books are fast, inexpensive and easy to record, leading publishers to look to the audio format to fuel interest in paper books that are not quite ready for the printing press, like one from Mignon Fogarty, above, who is host of a popular podcast called Grammar Girl. [C6.] LIMIT ON CREDIT SCORE CLAIMS -- A proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit means that Suze Orman, the personal finance guru, can no longer claim that the credit-score kit with her name and face on it can actually improve the creditworthiness of the person who buys it. [C6.] OPRAH'S PRESIDENTIAL PICKS -- Oprah Winfrey's book club can catapult titles to the top of best-seller lists, but does her magic touch extend to the realm of presidential politics? Last week, for the first time, Ms. Winfrey endorsed a political candidate, Senator Barack Obama, Democrat from Illinois. [C6.] INFLUENTIAL WHO? -- Time magazine declared ''You'' the person of the year, paying homage to everyone who had blogged or contributed to sites like YouTube, MySpace and Wikipedia. This year Time again reached out to ''You,'' asking the online community to choose the most influential person in the world. The winner was Rain, a 24-year-old South Korean singer whose real name is Jung Ji-hoon. [C6.] AUTOMATED RADIO RATINGS -- Philadelphia is the first American city to abandon the pen-and-ink diary system of collecting radio ratings data. Philadelphians being surveyed by Arbitron, the ratings-measurement firm, now wear pager-size devices that register hidden audio tones in nearby radio sound. [C4.]

NADLER--Paul S. His school mates and friends of the Horace Mann School class of 1947 note with profound sorrow the loss of Paul Nadler a fine human being whose wit, brilliance and warmth will be sadly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family whom he loved so much and of whom he was so proud. Paul left you various things, but the most important is a good name that will follow you always.

Shannon Wright ''Let In the Light'' (Quarterstick) Shannon Wright is an example of that shocking, spooky thing: a natural. She sings, writes songs, and plays guitar and keyboards. Yet ''Let In the Light'' isn't a great guitar record (or piano record); outside of a few brilliant songs it's not even a great songwriting record.

Mobile carriers like Verizon, which pitches seamless viewing from computer to television to cellphone, and Cingular, which has an exclusive with ''The Sopranos,'' conjure a world in which people are glued to their cellphones. But, only 656,000 users out of 207 million customers downloaded video to their mobile devices. On the tiny, tiny screen, users watched news segments like ''Where in the World is Matt Lauer?,'' above, and other TV highlights, but only 250,000 viewed a full show or film, well out of the top 10. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The State Ethics Commission said Friday that it was fining one of Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno's top aides, Jeffrey Lovell, for receiving tickets to college basketball games in 2003. This came almost two years after the state's Temporary Commission on Lobbying settled with Syracuse University over gifts the school had made to various state officials with whom it did business -- including tickets to Mr. Lovell, then a top aide to Gov. George E. Pataki. The tickets' total value exceeded the $75 legal limit for such gifts. Syracuse eventually agreed to pay $5,000 to the Lobbying Commission and amend its lobbying report to acknowledge that it had broken lobbying rules.

To the Editor: Re ''Matters of Faith Find a New Prominence on Campus'' (news article, May 2):

A theater review on April 20 about ''The View From K Street Steak,'' at Altered Stages in Chelsea, referred incorrectly to the setting at the start of the play. While the first scene is titled ''Reno,'' the play is set, according to the program, at a political retreat at a Hilton Head spa and resort ''and similar expense-account playgrounds.'' RAININ--Kenneth, Entrepreneur and Philanthropist, is Dead at 68. Kenneth Rainin, an unstoppable entrepreneur who built his fortune founding scientific and medical products companies and who later parlayed his wealth and management expertise into many charitable causes, died on Wednesday, May 2, 2007 at his home in Piedmont, California. He was 68. The son of William and Betty Rainin, he was born in Cleveland, Ohio in 1938. He graduated from Ohio State University before enlisting in the Army. Mr. Rainin entered the business world shortly after his discharge from the US Army. At the age of 25, he founded Rainin Instrument Company which initially distributed laboratory instruments and supplies. Mr. Rainin secured the rights to sell a line of laboratory pipettes, and through design improvements, built the Pipetman into the dominant brand of pipettes used in laboratories. Later Mr. Rainin developed his own line of ergonomic pipettes which are now recognized as the standard around the world. Pipettes were not his only business interest; other ventures included intraocular lens manufacturing, food manufacturing, wine production and the gaming/ hospitality industry. Mr. Rainin was also involved in many civic and cultural activities. Among his greatest passions was the San Francisco Ballet, which he served as Former Chairman of the Executive Committee. He created the Kenneth Rainin Foundation which supports research at the UCSF Medical School and the Cleveland Clinic Foundation. Many would argue his greatest talent lay in design and innovation. He used these talents to build his businesses, as well as two of the world's most elegant motor yachts, each christened Rasselas, named after Samuel Johnson's epic fictional character, The Prince of Abyssinia, who traveled throughout ancient Arabia in search of happiness. Mr. Rainin is survived by a daughter, Jennifer Rainin, a son, Jesse Rainin, two grandsons and a brother, Edgar Rainin. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 14th at 4:00 p.m. at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the UCSF Foundation -Center for Colitis and Crohns Disease, 44 Montgomery Street, Suite 2200, San Francisco, CA 94104.

Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, has acquired and absorbed Radar Communications in Boulder, Colo., a consulting company specializing in market research that seeks to better understand consumer behavior. Financial terms were not disclosed. John Winsor, who led Radar, and 12 Radar employees will join the Boulder office of Crispin Porter. Mr. Winsor will become the co-director of the cognitive and cultural studies department at the agency, which is being renamed the cultural radar department; Tom Birk, the previous director, will be the other co-director.

To the Editor: In ''An Invisible War'' (column, May 3), Bob Herbert describes the lone sacrifice paid by soldiers and their families for the Iraq war. He uses Paul Rieckhoff, a veteran and the head of the advocacy group Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America, to provide tangible observations that nonmilitary Americans are totally disengaged from the war.

Bone Thugs-n-Harmony ''Strength & Loyalty'' (Interscope) It wasn't always clear that the members of Bone Thugs-n-Harmony would get a chance to make a comeback, but it was always clear that they deserved one. Everything about their story is implausible: their rapid rise (thanks to the patronage of Eazy-E), their eerie sing-rap style (still being imitated today), their defining hit (''Tha Crossroads,'' a near-perfect lament that became part of the soundtrack of the 1990s), even their hometown (Cleveland, which wasn't known as hip-hop hotbed and still isn't).

An article on Wednesday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to redevelop the Willets Point business district in Queens misstated the given name of the owner of the Crown Container Company, one of the businesses in the area, who opposes the plan. He is Jerry Antonacci, not Joey.

BRUCK--Eva. We celebrate your beautiful life. We will always love you and miss you. Wendy, Andrea, Mark, Marc, Lauren and Rachel $(6$)BRUCK--Eva. Faithful and loving friend, we will miss you and remember always the joyous times we shared. Love, Marian, Steven and Evan Levine $(6$)BRUCK--Eva, on May 4th, 2007. Beloved wife of Stuart, devoted mother of Natalie and Spencer, and daughter of Zoltan and Clara Doman. Eva was loved by her family and friends, and respected by her colleagues. Her extraordinary heart and selflessness will be missed by all. In addition to her countless friends, she is survived by her brother Andrew, her brother-in-law and sister-in-law, Lewis and Geraldine Alperin, her uncle Laszlo Doman, her nephew James, and her nieces Amy and Lauren Alperin. We will miss you and always think of you, but we will always remember your spirit, laughter, dignity, grace, and smile. There will always be part of you in our hearts. Funeral on Monday, May 7th at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Eva's name to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

An article on Sept. 30 about a lawsuit to force the Department of Veterans Affairs to add the Wiccan symbol to the list of approved emblems for headstones included erroneous information from the suit about a Pentagon survey of Wiccan participation in the military. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on April 23 about the suit's settlement.) There were more than 1,800 Wiccans in the Air Force, not in all of the armed forces. (The Pentagon did not survey the entire military.)

Danspace Project's executive director, Laurie Uprichard, is ending her 15-year tenure on June 30 to direct the International Dance Festival Ireland in Dublin. Danspace, an important presenter of contemporary dance at St. Mark's Church in the East Village, has established a search committee for her replacement, who will be responsible for programming after the organization's 2007-8 season. Ms. Uprichard's exit continues a trend of leadership turnover among experimental downtown theaters; since 2004, the Kitchen, Performance Space 122 and Dance Theater Workshop have all come under new artistic direction. The Danspace search committee will be headed by the board treasurer, Marianne Pohle, contributions manager for Altria Corporate Services, and the board's vice president, the choreographer Gina Gibney. CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

LEONARD--Neil J., 75, died May 3. Leaves behind wife Harriet, daughter Elizabeth, son-in-law Michael Mahon, grandson Tanner. A longtime promotion writer for the New York Times. We've all lost our most-informed, passionate, generous and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend.

Arrogant, brutal, an authoritarian demagogue, a ''perfect Iago'': the president-elect of France has been called a lot of unpleasant things in recent months and now has five years to prove his critics wrong. But what is certain is that Nicolas Sarkozy, who won Sunday's runoff election, is one of the most polarizing figures to move into Élysée Palace in the postwar era. He is a whirling dervish of ideas who inspires hope and fear. Even many members of his own party, the Union for a Popular Movement, are holding their breath in anticipation of what his presidency may bring. ''Other politicians don't want to take risks, but he will take any risk,'' said Brice Hortefeux, one of Mr. Sarkozy's closest friends and political allies.

Joe ''Ain't Nothin' Like Me'' (Jive/Zomba) One of Joe's signature songs is ''I Wanna Know,'' a sublime slow jam. He teamed up with 50 Cent's G Unit for a club-conquering collaboration, ''Wanna Get to Know You.'' And this new CD, No. 2 on Billboard's album chart, begins with a song called ''Get to Know Me.'' Near the end comes ''You Should Know Me.'' Think he's trying to tell us something?
CLARK--John Holley, 88, on April 17, 2007. Husband of Eleanor, father of Ben and Chris, grandfather of Harry. Memorial May 12, at 5pm, The Cathedral School, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

Last year Time magazine declared ''You'' the person of the year, paying homage to everyone who had blogged or contributed to sites like YouTube, MySpace and Wikipedia. This year Time again reached out, asking online participants to vote for the person they considered the most influential in the world.

Critic Says Levee Repairs Show Signs of Flaws Some of the most celebrated levee repairs by the Army Corps of Engineers after Hurricane Katrina are already showing signs of serious flaws, a leading critic of the corps says. The critic, Robert G. Bea, a professor of engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, said the most troubling was erosion on a levee by the Mississippi River Gulf Outlet, a navigation canal that helped channel water into New Orleans during the storm. PAGE A17 Early Primary Changes Race California's move of its presidential primary to Feb. 5 has not just altered candidates' tactics; it has led them to turn their attention to issues, debates and controversies that have historically drawn little attention in the usual early playing fields of Iowa and New Hampshire. Six soldiers and a journalist were killed by a roadside bomb in Diyala Province. Eight people were killed in the storm. PAGE A17 A True Hollywood Climber Spider-Man marked his return to the screen by breaking box-office records. Mr. Sarkozy promised a break with the past, a new style of leadership and a renewal of relations with the United States and the rest of Europe. Wolfowitz, the bank president, failed to complete its review on schedule, but bank officials said the panel would eventually find that he violated bank rules barring conflicts of interest. The researcher's story opened a window onto how the Bush administration repeatedly resisted calls to improve oversight of the $85 billion student loan industry. A1 Tactics of Insurers Are Faulted Insurance companies have used improper hard-sell tactics to persuade Medicare recipients to sign up for private health plans, known as Medicare Advantage plans, that cost the government far more than the traditional Medicare program, federal and state officials and consumer advocates say.A1 California's Sway in Primaries In the months since California and about 20 other states changed the dates of their primaries, major presidential campaigns have sought to measure how the early nominating contests will shape their tactical calculations. But California is likely to wield additional clout this time around, altering the dialogue of the contest to issues that have historically drawn little attention. The scope of destruction has also shocked the remaining population and emergency officials. The Yankees' internal discussions about signing Roger Clemens provide a glimpse into the changing power structure at the top of the organization. In March, the daughter of George Steinbrenner, Jennifer, filed for divorce from Steve Swindal, the chairman of the board, whom the 76-year-old Steinbrenner had chosen as his successor. Since then, it has been unclear who would take over the organization or whether Steinbrenner's sons would have a bigger role.

When the news that Roger Clemens was a Yankee again circulated throughout Madison Square Garden yesterday during the Rangers-Sabres showdown, the logical reaction was that Mark Messier would surely be skating in the third period. He didn't, of course. Not that even his presence would have necessarily changed the outcome. As gallantly as the Rangers tried to force overtime, their 5-4 loss eliminated them from the Stanley Cup playoffs and chiseled another number into the long list of negative numbers that live in Rangers history, not to mention Rangers infamy.

Graduate of Columbia in 2001, Arthur was the Press Secretary for Andrew Cuomo. Survived by his mother, Myra, brother, Robbie, and many loving friends and relatives. Donations can be sent to a charity of your choice. Services were conducted by Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.

An obituary on Friday about Walter M. Schirra, Jr., an early United States astronaut, misstated the publication date for ''The Real Space Cowboys,'' which he wrote with Ed Buckbee. It was 2005, not 1971.

The Sea and Cake ''Everybody''(Thrill Jockey) Voices usually become deeper and wiser as singers get older, but not Sam Prekop's. In the 12 years he has spent making records with the Sea and Cake, and making his own albums in the intervals, his singing has floated up like a balloon. His syllables come out in light puffs of generalized pitch, stylized and consistent and full of will.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the first debate of the Republican candidates for president referred incorrectly in some copies to Duncan Hunter, one of the 10 participants. He is a current -- not former -- congressman from California.

GINA--Anne Sardi, died peacefully on May 3rd in Stamford, CT. Her parents were Vincent and Eugenia Sardi, founders of Sardi's Restaurant. She was a graduate of Barnard College, and worked for Governor and Mrs Averell Harriman. She was the wife of Architect Francis X. She is survived by a son Peter, daughter Susan, and grandchildren Jennifer and Michael.

Speaker Sheldon Silver and fellow Assembly Democrats quietly introduced legislation late last month that would grant lawmakers a raise of nearly 21 percent, increasing their base pay to the second highest in the nation among state legislators. No, this was not announced in a press release.
FADER--Alexander T., age 39, died April 29th. Devoted husband of Lorita Chung, father of Ester and Ezra, beloved brother and son.

A picture in some copies on Friday with the Public Lives column, about Judith Enck, deputy secretary for the environment for Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, was published in error. The picture was of Carol Ash, the new state parks commissioner -- not Ms. Enck.

An article and picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to re-establish coral reefs referred incorrectly to the networks of pipes on which coral is grown in the Mote Marine Laboratory in Florida. The pipes are made of PVC, not iron. The article also carried an incomplete list of American territories where corals occur. Besides Florida, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, corals also grow in warm and cold water in several other areas, including American Samoa and the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

McCARTHY--Jane Aufsesser Lisberger, 84, writer, artist, philanthropist, died May 1 in Exeter, NH. Survived by her children Steve, Lin, and Jody Lisberger, and Emily Vitale, and sister Betty Sonneborn.

An article on Sept. 30 about a lawsuit to force the Department of Veterans Affairs to add the Wiccan symbol to the list of approved emblems for headstones included erroneous information from the suit about a Pentagon survey of Wiccan participation in the military. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on April 23 about the suit's settlement.) There were more than 1,800 Wiccans in the Air Force, not in all of the armed forces. (The Pentagon did not survey the entire military.)

An article on April 21 about the removal of a mechanical ventilator from Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey eight days after he was seriously injured in a vehicular crash misstated the title of Dr. Ken Rodriguez of Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, who discussed milestones for patients who have been removed from ventilators. He is the chief of orthopedic trauma, not orthopedic medicine.

Speaking of public authorities and economic development, a labor-backed group called New York Jobs With Justice has taken a closer look at another, especially convoluted and under-examined kind of authority: Local business-promotion agencies known as industrial development authorities. IDAs, as they are known, account for more than half of all the authorities on state books, according to this handy list put out by the state comptroller's office. In a nutshell, IDAs are set up, usually with the consent of state lawmakers, to support the development of everything from manufacturing facilities to hotels to horseracing tracks. The deal is, the IDAs give developers a tax break, or financing through tax-exempt bonds, in exchange for the promise of creating jobs and economic activity.

Despite two crowded fields of presidential aspirants, voters remain unhappy. Each party lacks a candidate with the ability to unite and excite its diverse factions-while also projecting the electability needed for the fall 2008 race. So we're now hearing wistful talk that two Tennessee senators-turned-Hollywood-stars might join the race: Fred Thompson for the Republicans, Al Gore for the Democrats. Neither man, alas, can answer his party's prayers.

Among Republicans, making fun of the French seems to always be en vogue. But while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign has worked to quell comparisons to Ségolène Royal, the socialist candidate who lost Sunday's French elections, some Republicans are suddenly eager to associate themselves with the French.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today persuaded a federal judge to freeze the profits of a Hong Kong couple who made $8 million by buying stock in Dow Jones from April 13 to April 20, and then selling it last Friday. The 415,000 shares they bought accounted for 3 percent of the volume during the period.

Plenty of readers disagreed furiously with my Monday column about Senator Clinton's candidacy, warning that we should be wary of keeping the White House in any one family. You can see (or add to) the reader comments if you scroll down a bit and hit the comment tab.

Richard Grasso's retirement may have just gotten a bit more pleasant. The former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange won a partial legal victory on Tuesday when an appeals court threw out four rulings against him in a suit over his $190 compensation package. The reversal was on technical grounds, The Associated Press said; Bloomberg News reported that the state of New York can still go to trial against Mr. Grasso on other claims. A spokesman for New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, as New York's attorney general, first sued Mr. Grasso to seek the return of the money, said the state planned to appeal Tuesday's decision. But the final decision on an appeal will be up to New York's current attorney general, Andrew Cuomo.

Times Square makes up only 0.1 percent of New York City's area, but accounts for 5 percent of the city's jobs and 10 percent of the city's economic output -- more than the combined gross domestic products of Bolivia and Panama -- and is far more popular around the world than the Eiffel Tower in Paris, at least as measured by Google hits.

With news about the music industry getting worse every day, the National Association of Recording Merchandisers met last week to, as the Chicago Tribune put it, "figure out how to halt a slide in CD sales while providing music fans with new reasons to shop at a store."

Well, that was fast. Less than a week after Dow Jones confirmed receiving a $5 billion takeover bid from News Corporation, a Hong Kong couple stands accused of insider trading in Dow Jones shares before the approach was made public. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission said the couple spent $15 million to engage in "highly profitable and highly suspicious" trades in Dow Jones shares from April 13 to April 30. When the bid was announced on May 1, Dow Jones's shares shot up by 58 percent.

A hint for start-ups hoping to be acquired by Google (and what start-up doesn't?): Don't try to bamboozle the Internet giant. The warning came from Google's acquisitions chief, Salman Ullah, during a conference for venture capitalists in Monterrey last week. The Red Herring's Scott Martin wrote about the event Tuesday on the magazine's blog.

The world's exchanges cannot seem to buy each other fast enough. The latest example of the global consolidation is last week's $2.8 billion offer by Deutsche Borse of Germany for the International Securities Exchange, a New York-based options exchange.

Supervoting shares can be either good or bad for ordinary investors. Or they can be good at first, and bad later. Or vice versa. Given the potential hazards, should investors accept these kinds of dual-class share structures, in which not all shareholders are created equal, and some essentially call the shots?

Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that its first-quarter profit grew 5 percent from last year, helped by gains in its asset management business. Revenue from the firm's core financial advisory work, which includes helping to arrange mergers, remained essentially flat from a year ago.

Some top universities may be getting caught up in a wide-ranging congressional examination of the tax treatment of hedge funds and private equity firms. The scrutiny from Washington has been a prime concern for many buyout chiefs, who fear that cherished tax loopholes may be closed. (PEhub, writing about the topic Tuesday, poked some fun at such concerns, noting "the horror of being filthy rich instead of obscenely rich.") On Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that, in addition to looking at how private equity and hedge funds are taxed, the Senate Finance Committee also discussed offshore investments of pension funds, foundations and universities including Harvard, Yale and Stanford.
Notes from higher end real estate:

Kenneth Griffin doesn't shy away from unloved assets. As the market for subprime mortgages -- loans to homeowners with weak credit histories -- began to fall apart this year, his $13.5 billion fund, the Citadel Investment Group, snapped up assets in the industry. Now, Citadel is putting a chunk of money into a beaten-down technology company. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990's, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3com's stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.

Paul Poiret, the subject of the new costume exhibition at the Metropolitian Museum of Art, was one of the worldliest of the worldly, at least as the world looked right after the First World War. He was as famous for his elegant, Oriental dresses as he was his dazzling costume parties, including one, "La Mille et Deuxième Nuit," that featured live monkeys and parrots, as well as actors hired to play beggars and rug merchants as 300 guests dined on lobsters, goose liver and 900 liters of Champagne. Poiret sat on a throne.

Speaking in Iowa Monday, Senator John McCain said it would be "tough" for a candidate who supports abortion rights to win the G.O.P. nod.

A rash of alarming headlines regarding the Spanish property market in recent weeks are enough to give anyone the impression that the market is on the verge of collapse. The event that inspired the doom-and-gloom articles was a share price correction of property companies quoted on the Madrid stock exchange. But, according to one expert, falling stock market confidence is not the same as a housing market crash.

For years, there's been an annual happening on sites like Chowhound, where, for months before it actually happens, people eagerly inquire if the Red Hook Ball Fields - the city's top spot for pan-Latin street eats - are open for business yet.

More than 1000 Delegates from more than 160 nations began meeting today in Bonn to decide what kind of treaty should replace the 10 year old Kyoto Protocol, which expires in 2012. That program, which sets targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in developed nations, was never signed by the United States (the worlds largest emitter) and did not apply to China and India (two other major polluters) because they are developing nations.

Australia's richest man, James Packer, will split his Publishing & Broadcasting empire into two listed gaming and media companies and return 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.7 billion) to shareholders, sending the firm's stock up 6 percent, Reuters reported Tuesday. Mr. Packer, who took control of Publishing and Broadcasting following the death of his father, said he would separate the company's fast-expanding gaming and casino operations from its traditional businesses of television and magazines to raise the stock price and pursue growth.

France's LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the world's largest luxury goods group, plans to buy $30 million worth of initial public offering shares in China's Belle International Holdings, according to a deal prospectus. Belle, which is China's largest retailer of women's shoes, intends to raise up to $1.1 billion to add about 1,000 outlets a year in China.

CBSNews.com has been getting so many vitriolic comments about Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, that it has taken the unusual step of blocking all reader comments on its stories about Mr. Obama.

Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, said first-quarter profit rose 30 percent on record earnings from its securities unit. The bank outpaced European rivals UBS and Credit Suisse Group as record revenue from sales and trading spurred investment banking earnings.

Deal making in the metals sector is flourishing. The Financial Times's Alphaville blog reported Tuesday that Arcelor-Mittal, the steel empire run by Lakshmi Mittal, is considering a deal for AK Steel, a smaller Ohio-based rival. Arcelor-Mittal may offer as much as $4.5 billion, or $40 a share, Alphaville said. Shares in AK jumped 3.5 percent to $32 in New York on Monday as news of the impending deal appeared to emerge.

The star witness in the criminal case against the former media baron Conrad M. Black, F. David Radler, took the stand Monday and portrayed himself as a close partner of Mr. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will float a proposal this summer to address controversy over shareholder democracy and hopes to have new rules in place by fall, in time for corporate annual meetings in 2008, the agency's chairman, Christopher Cox, said Monday.
Marsha Mason will star when Playwrights Horizons presents the world premiere of “A Feminine Ending” next fall.

Solaicx, a developer of solar wafers, said on Tuesday it had received an additional $27.1 million in funding, giving it the funds it needs to increase production. The firm said it had developed a new process for making single-crystal silicon wafers-designed specifically for solar panels-more efficiently and cheaply.

Vascular anticoagulant drug developer Portola Pharmaceuticals raised $70 million in a third round of venture financing from a deep-pocketed group of hedge fund and crossover investors. The firm will use the cash to fund late stage clinical trials, and prepare for an initial public offering in its next capital call.
Daniel Evans and Jenna Russell will reprise their roles when the Menier Chocolate Factory of London production of “Sunday in the Park With George” opens next year in New York.
Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, on Monday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

Few dresses have attained the glamour than the dress that Carolyn Bessette wore to marry John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1996. But its designer, Narcisco Rodriguez, has since fallen on hard times. In a rare move in the fashion world, however, he asked for help.

A judge Monday denied a request by the Broadcom founders Henry Nicholas and Henry Samueli and other company directors to dismiss a lawsuit filed by investors accusing them of improperly backdating stock options. Judge Manuel Real of United States District Court in Los Angeles made the ruling without further comment. Judge Real last month denied a similar motion by the company to dismiss the case for lack of merit.

A former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband are expected to plead guilty this week to charges stemming from an insider-trading case that prosecutors say was part of the largest such scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

Deutsche Bank said Friday that it is selling its North American headquarters in Manhattan for $1.18 billion to the Paramount Group, a real estate firm. Deutsche, the latest company to take advantage of a sizzling commercial real estate market, bought the 1.6 million-square-foot 60 Wall St. from J.P. Morgan Chase in July 2001.
The actor known for his portrayal of Theodore (Beaver) Cleaver in “Leave it to Beaver” will be joining the cast on June 5.

“The Coast of Utopia” was named best play by the New York Drama Critics’ Circle; “Spring Awakening” and “In the Heights” shared Lucille Lortel Awards for outstanding musical.

The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday for Motorola's shareholders meeting, with some hope that he would be elected to the board. But by late in the day, as the politics played out, Mr. Icahn conceded that he had lost his proxy fight and had failed to garner enough support from large funds to become a director.
BHP Billiton once considered a possible suitor for Alcoa, which began a hostile bid of its own for Alcan, may become a target itself.

What used to be a profitable partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has degenerated into a cross-country blame game. Lenders in California say big investment banks encouraged and pushed them to make risky loans. On Wall Street, bank executives say mortgage lenders became sloppy and did not pay enough attention to fraud.

The largest shareholder of the Rinker Group, an Australian building company, said it had approved a $14.25 billion bid from Cemex, the Mexican cement company. Perpetual, a fund manager in Sydney that owns a 10.5 percent stake in Rinker, said it would accept Cemex's amended offer.

The military contractor BAE Systems said it had agreed to buy Armor Holdings, a maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, for $4.1 billion. BAE Systems, based in London, agreed to pay $88 a share for Armor Holdings, a 7 percent premium over its closing price Friday. BAE is also assuming $388 million in debt.

The buyout group bidding for Qantas Airways of Australia on Tuesday declared its offer of 11 billion Australian dollars ($9 billion) had lapsed after deciding not to pursue a legal case to keep the takeover alive. The group, Airline Partners Australia, said it believed "that Qantas shareholders need more certainty and, accordingly, it has determined that its bid should be treated as having lapsed on May 4, 2007."

The Macquarie Bank, Australia's largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alinta's agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power.

Zurich Capital Markets agreed to pay $16.8 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of alleged market-timing of mutual funds. The S.E.C. said that between 1999 and 2003, Zurich Capital, a unit of Zurich Financial, made $11 million by helping four hedge funds that were defrauding mutual funds through illegal market timing.
Tamyra Gray, a contestant from the first season of “American Idol,” will appear as Mimi in the long-running  Broadway musical.
“When Kids Get Life” turns out to be no more prosecutorial than the usual PBS fare.
Millions of Iraqis have fled their country, creating the largest Mideast refugee problem since 1948.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Many would-be top chefs face a challenge that most lawyers, engineers or nurses do not: few jobs in their chosen field pay enough for them to retire their student loans. As a result, as many as 11 percent of graduates at some culinary schools are defaulting on federal student loans. The national average for all students last year was roughly half that, at 5.1 percent.
Carl Pavano talked after the game and said he would meet with Dr. Frank Jobe on Wednesday in California. A couple of writers reminded him he was actually seeing Dr. Lewis Yocum.
Richard Flanagan’s stunning new novel gives us a world headed toward irredeemable disaster.
The apology was the first formal acknowledgment by American authorities that the killings by marines after a suicide attack in March were unjustified.
Chris Albrecht contended that he assaulted a girlfriend in Las Vegas as a result from a lapse in his sobriety.
André Boisclair’s resignation further destabilizes a movement that was left in shambles after the elections.
Six people have been arrested on allegations of plotting to kill soldiers at an army installation, an official said today.
The leaders of Northern Ireland re-established a local authority made up of once implacable foes.
Undone by a pair of two-out errors, the Mets proceeded to allow six consecutive Giants to reach base, culminating in Bengie Molina’s second homer of the nine-run inning.

The board that regulates rents for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments proposed tentative increases last night of 2 to 4.5 percent on one-year lease renewals and 4 to 7.5 percent on two-year leases, which could mean smaller increases than last year’s when the board holds a final vote next month.

Early yesterday afternoon, a peahen — a female peacock — escaped from a 20-foot-high gilded bird cage that had been constructed inside the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, causing a brief stir as organizers of the annual Costume Institute gala clumsily chased her about the Great Hall. The bird, an indentured guest with pristine white feathers, seemed to be setting a tone for the untamed evening that was to come.
It is unclear if the action will be seen as a compromise that satisfies both Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s conservative base and neighboring countries.

A 60-year-old man was arrested last night after he fired a .22 caliber rifle in a village courtroom in Rockland County, the police said. No one was injured when, the Ramapo Police Department said, Leo Lewis, a party in a civil case in the village court in Sloatsburg, pulled out the rifle and fired a single shot toward the front of the courtroom. Mr. Lewis had been scheduled for a hearing around 6 p.m. at the Sloatsburg courthouse, which also serves as the village hall. The police said it was unclear if Mr. Lewis was aiming at anyone. They said he ran out of the courtroom after the shot, and a Sloatsburg court officer and Ramapo police officer gave chase. The Ramapo officer fired one shot during the chase, but it did not hit anyone, the authorities said. A civilian outside the building helped the officers catch Mr. Lewis. No charges had been filed as of late last night.

A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiner’s office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to her torso. Firefighters were called to the home, on Rochester Avenue, about 1:30 a.m. and discovered the body of the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. The woman’s 5-year-old daughter, T’kyha Douglas, was treated for smoke inhalation, the authorities said.
Rudolph Giuliani did not cite values as a theme of his campaign at a gathering of conservatives Monday.
For the next three days, the Mets have a front-row seat to watch Barry Bonds, baseball’s most polarizing figure, make his way toward Hank Aaron’s home run record.

The European Commission forecast that economic growth would be faster than expected this year for nations using the euro and for the full European Union, with unemployment dropping to the lowest levels in 15 years. It estimated 2.6 percent growth in 2007 for the 13 nations using the euro, up from an earlier forecast of 2.4 percent, and 2.9 percent growth for the entire 27-nation union, rather than the previously expected 2.7 percent, as a result of increased investment and household spending.

The military contractor BAE Systems said it had agreed to buy Armor Holdings, a maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, for $4.1 billion. BAE Systems, based in London, is making its purchase through its American subsidiary of the same name. The company agreed to pay $88 a share for Armor Holdings, a 7 percent premium over its closing price Friday. BAE is also assuming $388 million in debt. Stock in Armor Holdings, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., rose $4.45, or 5.4 percent, to $86.60 a share. The deal expands BAE’s presence in the potentially lucrative market for armored Humvees, personnel carriers and other military equipment.

The largest shareholder of the Rinker Group, an Australian building company, said it had approved a $14.25 billion bid from Cemex, the Mexican cement company. Perpetual, a fund manager in Sydney that owns a 10.5 percent stake in Rinker, said it would accept Cemex’s amended offer. On April 11, Cemex gained the approval of Rinker’s board after raising its offer 22 percent, to $15.85 cash a share, in a bid that, if successful, would propel Cemex from the world’s third-largest cement producer to No. 1. Cemex announced on Sunday that it was extending the offer by three weeks, to June 8.

The buyout group bidding for Qantas Airways of Australia on Tuesday declared its 11 billion Australian dollars ($9 billion) offer lapsed after deciding not to pursue a legal case to keep the takeover alive. The bid group, Airline Partners Australia, said it believed “that Qantas shareholders need more certainty and, accordingly, it has determined that its bid should be treated as having lapsed on May 4, 2007.” The group, which includes Macquarie Bank and the private equity firm Texas Pacific Group, said it would not pursue a legal case over a clause in its offer which it claimed would have pushed acceptances above 50 percent by Friday’s deadline.
In his major league debut, pitcher  Matt DeSalvo left with a lead after seven innings, but a home run by Seattle’s Adrián Beltre cost the Yankees the game in the ninth.

The Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alinta’s agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power. Alinta, based in Perth, Australia, is seeking further information on the revised offer. Macquarie, based in Sydney, said its proposal included three options, one of them an all-cash bid. Macquarie did not disclose further details. Both Macquarie and Babcock plan to break up the utility, which has a nationwide network of gas and power lines, and generates electricity at five plants. Alinta rejected Macquarie’s earlier offer on March 30.
The auto and home insurer reached a definitive agreement to buy the Ohio Casualty Corporation for $2.7 billion.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 7 — At 10:47 p.m. on April 28, a homeless Guatemalan man known to roam the streets, plucking cans and bottles from trash cans and causing trouble when he was drunk, dialed 911 from the pay phone at a Laundromat here.
Corrections: For the Record

A theater review yesterday about “Bad Blood” (“Malasangre”), at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater on West 47th Street, misspelled the surname of the actor who plays Don Augusto. He is Felipe Javier Gorostiza, not Corostiza.
For Rangers forward Brendan Shanahan, the concept of a next season is something he will wrestle with in the coming weeks.
Brad Penny struck out a career-high 14 and allowed only five base runners in seven shutout innings to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-1 victory against the host Florida Marlins.
hockey.
Astronomers reported that they had seen the brightest and most powerful stellar explosion ever recorded.
Despite a new look at the Players Championship golf tournament, one thing has not changed: No one is quite sure what it is.
The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn failed to get enough votes to be elected to Motorola’s board.
The Bush administration is debating how to refashion nuclear deterrence to counter the threat from terrorists.
With the dollar weak, Irish investors find that New York apartments cost less than in Dublin but rent for more.
European governments signaled that they would let the U.S. choose the bank’s next chief  if Paul D. Wolfowitz resigned soon.
One of the highest-ranking officials in the Police Department will be transferred in the wake of a violent confrontation at an immigration rally last week.
Pressure is building on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to move forward on legislation to help salvage a rift in the Iraqi government.
Trade policy cuts to the heart of the Democrats’ identity and how they view their party’s past and envision its future.
Paul E. Steiger, the paper’s top editor who knew of Rupert Murdoch’s offer, is said to have decided not to publish any news of it.
A deadly accident in an illegal basement is deemed an accident.
A partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has now degenerated into a cross-country blame game.
Sabres Coach Lindy Ruff was not about to make any antagonistic remarks about the Ottawa Senators Monday; there is already enough bad blood between these teams.
Prosecutors say a former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband were part of the largest insider-trading scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.
President Bush and the first lady played host to Queen Elizabeth II and 130 other A-list guests on Monday night.
Houston coach Jeff Van Gundy has one year left on his nonguaranteed contract, meaning the Rockets have the right to terminate it after June 30.
F. David Radler portrayed himself as a close partner of Conrad M. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.
The success of Alcoa’s hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York City’s rule prohibiting students from bringing cellphones to public schools was “rational,” rejecting an effort by parents who had sought to overturn the ban. In a 50-page decision, the justice, Lewis Bart Stone, said the court could decide only whether the rule was a reasonable way to prevent students from using cellphones in school and that he could not suggest a different rule, even if he preferred one. “The court finds that banning possession in the school is not an irrational method to accomplish such goal,” he wrote. Justice Stone also rejected a claim that the rule violated students’ and parents’ constitutional rights. “Neither the state nor federal constitutions include any express constitutional right to bear cellphones,” he wrote. Norman Siegel, above, a lawyer for the parents, said they were considering an appeal. “We will not rest until the ban is lifted,” he said. David Cantor, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said the city was pleased with the decision.

The Supreme Court suspended proceedings against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, Pakistan’s suspended chief justice, before a five-judge panel known as the Supreme Judicial Council. The council began hearing accusations of misconduct and abuse of power against Mr. Chaudhry after President Pervez Musharraf suspended him in March. Mr. Chaudhry, meanwhile, went to the Supreme Court to challenge the council’s authority and impartiality. In addition to halting the council inquiry, the Supreme Court also recommended that Mr. Chaudhry’s complaints be heard by the full Supreme Court. The decision followed a mass rally in support of Mr. Chaudhry over the weekend.

Both houses of the State Legislature passed legislation yesterday to sharply restrict the relationships between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students. The legislation follows an investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, into hundreds of colleges, lenders and alumni associations that have admitted to or are suspected of steering loans to prospective students in exchange for gifts, trips or payments from lenders. The bill, which Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to sign, prohibits colleges from soliciting or accepting any gifts or money from lenders in exchange for recommending them to students, and prohibits lenders’ staff members from working out of college financial aid offices, among other provisions.
To succeed as the new leader of France, Nicolas Sarkozy will need to keep his own impatience, and his destructive penchant for divisive rhetoric, under firm control.

President Horst Köhler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by a terrorist from the far-left Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. Mr. Köhler met last week with the man, Christian Klar, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for the murder of a German prosecutor in 1977. The meeting drew protests from conservative politicians, who said Mr. Klar had shown no remorse for his crimes. Speculation that he might be freed rose after a fellow gang member, Brigitte Mohnhaupt, was released in March after serving 24 years in prison for murders in the 1970s. The president also denied clemency to another member, Birgit Hogefeld.

After nearly a year of negotiations, Viacom, the giant media company, signed a 15-year lease yesterday with Trinity Real Estate for about 400,000 square feet for offices and production facilities at 345 Hudson Street, the real estate company said. The annual rent was believed to average in the mid-$40 range per square foot over the life of the lease. Early next year, Viacom plans to relocate some 1,000 employees from several buildings in Midtown, including its MTV Networks Entertainment Group, which includes Spike TV, Comedy Central and TV Land.
Chevron is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known oil kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein.
Recent revelations have shown just how corrupt and costly the student loan business has become.

An explosion destroyed a section of a pipeline in Ukraine carrying Russian natural gas to Europe. No injuries were reported, and technicians quickly rerouted the gas to other pipelines. In a telephone interview, Ihor I. Kroll, a spokesman for the Ministry of Emergency Situations, played down the possibility of sabotage. But later in the day, the minister for transport, Mykola Rudkovsky, said on Ukrainian television that the pipe might have been sabotaged as “part of a planned attempt to destabilize” the country, the Interfax news agency in Russia reported. Russia provides about a quarter of Europe’s natural gas, 80 percent of which is pumped through aging pipes on Ukraine’s territory. Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, said its customers in Europe would not be affected.
An Iraqi sheik stops by his old villa, which has been turned into a military base, to ask for his home back.

Several baseball bat manufacturers, baseball coaches, parents and players filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to overturn New York City’s recent ban on metal bats in high school baseball games. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claims the new law “unjustifiably prohibits the use of bats that are preferred by the vast majority” of players, coaches and teams and that are already regulated by national high school sports officials. The City Council, which approved the ban last month over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s veto, said baseballs fly off metal bats faster than they do off wooden ones, making them more dangerous. Officials of the city Law Department said they would evaluate the lawsuit thoroughly.

The Department of Education has extended a deadline for surveys measuring satisfaction in the schools from May 18 to June 1, officials said. The surveys, for parents, teachers and students from grades 6 to 12, are part of a $2 million city effort. The Education Department’s Web site said the auditing giant KPMG, which produced the survey, was not able to send out all copies on time, but promised all parents should receive them sometime this week. A spokesman for KPMG said the “extended deadline ensures the broadest possible participation.” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the project last week, calling it “the most extensive effort in the history of American education to solicit a community’s ideas and views about their public schools.”.

New York University received $650 million Friday from Royalty Pharma, a privately held New York company, for rights to a portion of its royalties from the drug Remicade, an anti-inflammatory agent used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. Jan Vilcek and Junming Le, researchers at N.Y.U.’s School of Medicine, helped develop the monoclonal antibody that led to the drug, in collaboration with Centocor, a biotechnology company. Since Remicade came to market in 1998, the university has received about $365 million in royalties from it, including about $90 million last year. In 2005, Dr. Vilcek, a professor of microbiology, pledged to give N.Y.U.’s medical school $105 million. The Remicade royalties have helped place N.Y.U. among the universities collecting the most royalties annually.

Sheik Hasina Wazed, a former prime minister who had been briefly barred from returning to Bangladesh after she was accused of speaking against its military-backed interim government, arrived in the Dhaka, the capital, and thousands of supporters cheered, beat drums and sprinkled her with rosebuds. The government lifted a ban on the return of Sheik Hasina, who held the office from 1996 to 2001, on April 25, seven days after it barred her homecoming from a visit to London and the United States amid reports in the news media that the government wanted to exile her. “It’s my country,” she said at the airport after arriving from London. “It’s my home.” Asked if she feared arrest, she said the authorities had made “a mistake” in imposing the ban. “I don’t think they are going to repeat that mistake,” she added.

The Hebrew University of Jerusalem announced the discovery of the grave and tomb of King Herod, who ruled Judea for the Romans for around 34 years after his appointment as “King of the Jews” by the Roman Senate in approximately 40 B.C. In a brief statement, the university said the discovery was made at Herodium, where Herod, also called Herod the Great, had a hilltop fortress palace. It said it would give further details at a news conference today. The newspaper Haaretz said on its Web site that the tomb was discovered by a professor at the university, Ehud Netzer, who has conducted archaeological digs at Herodium since 1972.

Twenty-two elementary school students sustained minor injuries yesterday morning when two school buses collided in central New Jersey, the authorities said. A driver of one of the buses was also hurt in the crash, which occurred about 9 a.m. in Monroe Township. The authorities said the collision, near the intersection of Buckelew Avenue and Schoolhouse Road, occurred when a bus that had stopped to pick up children was rear-ended by another bus. The students, some of whom were removed on backboards and wearing neck braces, were treated at four area hospitals. The injuries included facial cuts and complaints of back and neck pain. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The police and the city medical examiner said yesterday they were investigating the death of a 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman who was burned when a fire broke out in her home, but who also suffered puncture wounds to the front and back of her torso. Firefighters were called to 39 Rochester Avenue about 1:30 a.m. and found the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. Her 5-year-old daughter, T’kyha Douglas, suffered smoke inhalation and was treated at Kings County Hospital Center, the authorities said.

A homeless man admitted yesterday that he fatally shot a painter in 2004 after workers asked him to remove his belongings from beneath an overpass, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Boyd, 47, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to manslaughter and is expected to receive a 23-year prison sentence, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The painter, James Gaviglia, 38, was one of four workers sent to repaint the overpass at Northern Boulevard and Grand Central Parkway. Mr. Gaviglia was shot three times with a .45-caliber pistol. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Congress needs to demand rigorous policing of the Medicare Advantage program to ensure that abuses do not continue.

BOSTON, May 7 — The highest court in Massachusetts upheld a $2 million libel verdict on Monday against The Boston Herald and one of its reporters for articles that said a Superior Court judge had made disparaging comments about crime victims and that he was lenient with criminals.
Fearing that lower-cost prescription drug imports from other countries could pose risks to consumers, the Senate voted on Monday to preserve current restrictions.
An Arkansas school district is still riven by racial conflict, and some question how much progress has been made.
Thanks to inexpensive airfares and cheap beer, places like Prague have become popular destinations for celebrating stag parties.
Tampa Bay’s new ownership, in its second season, is trying to expand the regional profile of one of baseball’s weakest franchises.
A military spokesman said the soldier had suffered from mental problems but that he had been cleared for service by Afghan National Army doctors.
The maker of Jim Beam announced it would voluntarily adopt stricter ad rules to help curb under-age drinking.
The Yankees planned for Carl Pavano and Kei Igawa to hold down spots in the rotation. Yesterday, both were making plans to leave town.
Chris Albrecht was charged with domestic assault and battery after an altercation with a girlfriend, a police spokesman said.
Johnson & Johnson’s hopes for an early return on its acquisition of Conor Medsystems were dashed by the failure of Conor’s heart stent design in a medical trial.
In his acceptance speech, Nicolas Sarkozy signaled his desire to end tension with Washington.
Edgar M. Bronfman Sr. has resigned from the World Jewish Congress, which has been in disorder for three years since accusations of financial improprieties surfaced.
For would-be top chefs, there are few jobs that pay enough for them to retire their student loans.
Russell W. Kruse achieved fame for thinking up and building the business of auctioning classic cars.
In tapes played at a trial,  Tarik Shah, a bassist, ninja and would-be terrorist, is heard planning  an Al Qaeda combat training center in New York City.
Steep new postal rate increases for periodicals will inflict undue hardship on small independent magazines.
Combining, skiing, parachuting, snow kiting and parasailing, participants in a new sport called speed flying or ski fly, descend mountains, reaching speeds up to 70 miles an hour.
Americans charged more purchases to their credit cards and took out more car loans, Federal Reserve figures show.

The Board of Regents at the Smithsonian announced the members of the search committee charged with finding a new secretary of the institution. The chairman of the committee is Alan G. Spoon, a regent and managing general partner of Polaris Venture Partners. Other members are Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California; L. Hardwick Caldwell, chairman of the institution’s National Board; Anne d’Harnoncourt, a regent and director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; Walter E. Massey, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta; Jeffrey Minear, administrative assistant to Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.; and Roger W. Sant, a regent and chairman emeritus of the board.

A state judge in New Orleans suspended the criminal cases against nearly 100 people over concerns that they cannot get adequate representation from the city’s indigent defenders office. Judge Arthur Hunter Jr. halted prosecutions of 98 defendants and ordered the release of 20 who had been held in jail. Last month, he suspended prosecution for 42 other poor defendants. The charges were not dropped, he told dozens of defendants in his court, but until they get lawyers they will not be prosecuted.

Justice Department officials said they would not object to a Congressional grant of immunity to a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who played a central role in the dismissals of federal prosecutors. The decision appeared to increase the likelihood that the aide, Monica Goodling, will soon appear before a Congressional panel, under a grant of immunity, to answer questions about last year’s firings of eight United States attorneys.

It is safe to eat pork and chicken from animals whose feed was mixed with contaminated pet food that sickened or killed cats and dogs, Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns said in Chicago. Testing found that the contaminant, the industrial chemical melamine, was so diluted that any human exposure from the meat or eggs of the animals would be thousands of times lower than the level considered safe, Mr. Johanns said in comments to the Organic Trade Association. Based on the testing, the government lifted a quarantine on nearly all of the 20 million chickens held from market last week after the feed contamination was discovered. Those animals now may be slaughtered and enter the food supply. About 6,000 hogs still were being held pending additional testing.
The Yankees have gotten the headlines and the hope. They will have to wait several weeks to see if signing Roger Clemens actually gets them much-needed victories.

Massachusetts has sued the federal government, accusing energy regulators of failing to tighten standards that could reduce heat-trapping gases and eliminate the need for major new power plants. The suit, filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, challenged the government’s March 7 decision not to strengthen efficiency requirements for heating, ventilating and air-conditioning systems. Massachusetts also brought the case that led the Supreme Court to rule on April 2 that environmental officials have the power to regulate greenhouse gas emissions.

In a letter to the archbishop of Canterbury, the Anglican Archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, harshly criticized the Episcopal Church for what he called an “insulting and condescending” response to demands by primates of the worldwide Anglican Communion to establish a parallel oversight structure for disaffected congregations and dioceses in the United States. Archbishop Akinola arrived in Virginia late last week to install a new bishop for one such structure, rejecting requests to cancel his trip from the archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of the communion, and the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism. Archbishop Akinola dismissed concerns that he was exacerbating tensions over a longstanding dispute regarding the church’s liberal stance on homosexuality, blaming instead the Episcopal Church for the crisis.

ALBANY, May 7 — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that his office was investigating “very troubling, serious, systemic conflicts of interest” in the way the comptroller’s office has managed the state’s $145 billion pension fund.

Two top officers of an oil services company pleaded guilty to bribing Alaska lawmakers with cash and the promise of jobs, contracts and favors for their backing on bills supported by the multinational firm. Bill J. Allen, chief executive of the firm, the VECO Corporation, based in Anchorage, and Rick Smith, a vice president, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to extortion, bribery and conspiracy to impede the Internal Revenue Service. Prosecutors say Mr. Smith, Mr. Allen and five state lawmakers conspired to buy the lawmakers’ support with money and other financial benefits.

A device left in a casino parking garage exploded, killing a man who tried to pick it up off the top of his car, the authorities in Las Vegas said. The device exploded shortly after 4 a.m. Monday on the top floor of a parking garage, below, behind the Luxor hotel-casino, on the south end of the Las Vegas Strip, said Officer Bill Cassell, a police spokesman. He declined to describe the device. The blast was not a terrorist act but apparently the murder of a man who worked at a business inside the hotel, he said, adding that the case was being investigated as “a homicide with an unusual weapon.” There was little damage around the vehicle and the hotel was not evacuated, the police and a hotel official said.
A new bill would provide money for combat operations through midsummer, with the rest of the funds withheld until commanders provide a report on conditions.
Friendly governments in France and Germany could help the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company expand its work in the U.S.
People.
Last season, Cavs guard Sasha Pavlovic’s poor defense landed him on the bench. But as evidenced against the Nets on Sunday, he’s improved drastically since then.
Clear Channel postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.
Sun Microsystems will revamp its Java software to compete more effectively in the market for Internet-connected mobile phones.
During his tenure at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Peter Kalikow confronted labor unrest, scandal and the beginning of the first major transit expansion in decades.
The lack of basic details revives questions about whether China is willing to share information about health and food safety issues.
Almost four years after being severely injured in a car crash, Ben Rubeor scored a team-high 46 goals this season for defending lacrosse champion Virginia.
Ms. Blow’s gift for identifying and promoting new talent was occasionally overshadowed by her own Surrealist plumage.
Three former employees of Michael Chow’s elegant Chinese restaurants have filed a lawsuit filled with bizarre allegations.
Johnnie Burton, the top federal official overseeing Gulf of Mexico oil and gas drilling, will retire, effective at the end of this month.
The 20,000 items that end up in the lost-and-found in Grand Central Terminal each year are a mix of memorable and mundane.
The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group agreed to be bought by the Patina Restaurant Group for $94.6 million.
The financial data provider confirmed that it had approached the board of the Reuters Group about a possible takeover.
The city has built two new parks along the South Bronx waterfront, but questions remain about how they will be maintained.
Five Swiss sailors say they have made history by sailing from Spain to Staten Island in a solar-powered catamaran.
Swedish-based Victory Challenge beat out Desafio Español by the slim margin of seven seconds to claim the last available spot in the semifinals of the Louis Vuitton Cup.
The death toll from a tornado that nearly obliterated Greensburg, Kan., climbed to 10 on Monday,
Emergency landings, chronic delays and millions of dollars in losses — and that is just the month of April.
Many people fear more violence to come if Nicolas Sarkozy makes good on campaign promises to push through divisive legislation in his first 100 days in office.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,361 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Street Sense seems to have some trainers thinking twice about taking him on in the Preakness Stakes on May 19.
WASHINGTON, May 7 — Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, were the guests of honor Monday at a state dinner at the White House.
Managers at the former parts-making operation of General Motors said they were working to cut costs and to expand sales to companies other than G.M.
A $27 billion bid by Alcoa for a Canadian aluminum rival, Alcan, buoyed blue-chip issues.
Tampa Bay reliever Juan Salas was suspended for 50 games after becoming the first major leaguer this year to flunk a drug test.
Despite previous predictions of delays, the co-chairman of the state Board of Elections said new machines could be ready for the 2008 presidential election.
A new coalition of evangelical Christian leaders asked Congress on Monday to strengthen border controls but also give illegal immigrants ways to gain residency.
Parliament gave initial approval to a constitutional amendment to make the presidency a popularly elected post, which could rekindle tension with secularists.
After four races in the Car of Tomorrow, Dale Earnhardt Jr. joined the list of critics of the new racecar, which is being phased into the Nextel Cup series this season.
The auto and home insurer reached a definitive agreement to buy the Ohio Casualty Corporation for $2.7 billion.

AIR TRAVEL DELAYS ARE UP Delays on domestic flights rose in the first quarter, with 25.25 percent of flights arriving late, compared with 21.35 percent in the first quarter of last year, the Bureau of Transportation Statistics said yesterday. The number of lost or otherwise mishandled checked bags rose in March — to 7.71 per 1,000 passengers compared with 5.81 per 1,000 passengers in March 2006.

(Sundance Channel) ART FROM THE ARCTIC Between 2003 and 2005 David Buckland, a British filmmaker, organized three sailing expeditions to the high Arctic as part of his Cape Farewell project, a collaboration among artists, educators and scientists created to focus attention on climate change. This film follows those expeditions as artists like the sculptors Max Eastley and Rachel Whiteread, the photographer Alex Hartley and the writer Ian McEwan are inspired by the otherworldly sights and sounds. Above, an installation by Heather Ackroyd and Dan Harvey.

THE CLAIM Aspirin can reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease. THE FACTS Doctors have long said that an aspirin a day can help ward off heart attacks. But what about Alzheimer's? The claim that aspirin can prevent the disease stems from the notion that Alzheimer's is caused by inflammation that disrupts proteins in the brain. It's believed that aspirin, and possibly other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, may reduce or head off that process.

The continuation of the Our Towns column in The Metro Section on Sunday, about wildlife and mortality at West Point, N.Y., was omitted in some copies. The column by Peter Applebome can be found at nytimes.com/nyregion by using the writer's name as the keyword.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Europe Joins Effort to Oust Wolfowitz From World Bank Leading governments of Europe, mounting a new campaign to push Paul D. Wolfowitz out as World Bank president, signaled that they were willing to let the United States choose the next head of the World Bank, but only if Mr. Wolfowitz stepped down soon. A10 Car Bombs Kill 25 in Iraq Successive suicide car bombs hit a police checkpoint near Ramadi, the provincial security chief said, killing 25 people and dealing a blow to a city considered a showcase for the strategy of integrating insurgents into the Iraqi security forces. A14 NATIONAL A16-23 A City Remains Divided Years After Desegregation Fifty years after an epic desegregation struggle at a high school in Little Rock, Ark., the school district is still riven by racial conflict, casting a pall on this year's ambitious commemorative efforts, just as a federal judge declared Little Rock's schools finally desegregated. A1 Post-Culinary School Challenge The rise of celebrity chefs has been good for culinary schools. But would-be top chefs face a challenge that most lawyers, engineers or nurses do not: few jobs in their chosen field pay enough for them to retire their student loans. A21 Christians on Border Policy A new coalition of more than 100 largely evangelical Christian leaders and organizations have asked Congress to pass bills to strengthen border controls but also give illegal immigrants ways to gain legal residency. A16 Obama Speaks to Auto Industry Senator Barack Obama of Illinois delivered a stern message to Detroit auto companies, saying they had done little to lessen the nation's dependence on foreign oil and needed to improve the fuel efficiency of their vehicles. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Irish Invest in New York After Economic Boom After a long period of economic growth in their country, the Irish are flush with cash and are lining up to spend it on condominiums in Midtown Manhattan, often years before they are built. In some cases, entire buildings or large blocks of apartments in unfinished high-rises are being sold to Irish investors hungry to own a little piece of New York City.
