To the Editor: Re ''Coal's Energy Potential Is an Engineering Challenge Now'' (May 1): Your article highlights a fundamental error in the way we have approached energy policy. The economic model that we use focuses inordinately on the direct cost of electricity generation. This is like deciding to buy a house based solely on the monthly mortgage payment, without considering property taxes, utilities and insurance.

To the Editor: Re ''Scientists Look to Vaccines in the War on E. Coli'' (May 1): We could turn to vaccinating babies and cows to prevent E. coli. We could run infected cattle carcasses through an acid bath to kill the germs. We could add still more rigorous inspections and government regulations to our feedlots and slaughterhouses. Or we could just turn our cows out to pasture and practice rotational grazing, and let the sunshine and fresh air do our disinfecting for us. It sounds simple because it is. Charnan Simon Madison, Wis.

To the Editor: Re ''In Moscow in 1996, a Doctor's Visit Changed History'' (May 1): The article on Dr. Michael E. DeBakey concludes with Boris N. Yeltsin's tribute describing him as ''a magician of the heart'' and ''a man with a gift for performing miracles.'' Yet Dr. DeBakey's gift to Mr. Yeltsin, Russia and the United States started with an act of human kindness, befriending a group of isolated Russian physicians in Mexico City during the height of the cold war.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column last Tuesday, about direct talks between Morocco and the Polisario Front under terms of a Security Council resolution, referred incorrectly to the area Morocco annexed in 1979. It was the Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony that Morocco hopes to incorporate as an autonomous province -- not the Front, a group seeking Western Sahara's independence.

An explosion destroyed a section of a pipeline in Ukraine carrying Russian natural gas to Europe. No injuries were reported, and technicians quickly rerouted the gas to other pipelines. In a telephone interview, Ihor I. Kroll, a spokesman for the Ministry of Emergency Situations, played down the possibility of sabotage. But later in the day, the minister for transport, Mykola Rudkovsky, said on Ukrainian television that the pipe might have been sabotaged as ''part of a planned attempt to destabilize'' the country, the Interfax news agency in Russia reported. Russia provides about a quarter of Europe's natural gas, 80 percent of which is pumped through aging pipes on Ukraine's territory. Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, said its customers in Europe would not be affected. ANDREW E. KRAMER

To the Editor: Re ''A Simple Need, All Too Often Unmet'' (May 1): As an older citizen, with frequent ''calls to nature,'' I appreciate Jane E. Brody's informative commentary about the shortage of public bathrooms. Many times I have had to use the protection of a tree because there was nothing more available nearby. And who hasn't been caught on an extended train ride, when you know you are going to be in trouble?

The New York Drama Critics' Circle has named "The Coast of Utopia" by Tom Stoppard the best play of the 2006-7 season. The accolade for best musical went to "Spring Awakening," with music by Duncan Sheik and book and lyrics by Steven Sater; the award for best American play went to "Radio Golf" by August Wilson. A special citation was awarded to the revival of R. C. Sherriff's "Journey's End."

ALCOA MAKES BID FOR RIVAL Alcoa made an unsolicited $27 billion offer for a rival, Alcan of Canada, which would propel it to the top spot in the aluminum industry, a position it surrendered just months ago. The announcement came after unsuccessful attempts by Alcoa to negotiate a friendly merger over the last two years with Alcan. Shares of Alcan, which is based in Montreal, rose 34 percent. An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the winners of the National Magazine Awards misstated the name of the Web site that won in the general excellence online category. It is Beliefnet.com, not Belief.net. The article also referred incorrectly to the winner in the leisure interests category, ''Reading: A Love Story'' in O, The Oprah Magazine. It was a special section devoted to reading with articles by many writers. It was not by Amy Gross, the magazine's editor in chief. The article also misidentified the category in which Vanity Fair won an award for an article by William Langewiesche about the massacre of Iraqis by United States marines. It was public interest, not columns and commentary. (As the article noted, Vanity Fair also won a columns and commentary award for three columns by Christopher Hitchens.)

Jerry Mathers, best known for his portrayal of Theodore (Beaver) Cleaver in the 1950s family comedy "Leave it to Beaver," will be joining the cast of "Hairspray" on June 5. Mr. Mathers will play Wilbur Turnblad for three months. This will be the Beev's Broadway debut.
WINTER--Marvin S., May 7th 1999. Time has not dimmed your memory. You remain an inspiration to us all. The Winter Family

To the Editor: Re ''Coral Is Dying. Can It Be Reborn?'' (May 1): The coral farming and transplantation efforts described in Cornelia Dean's article may prove useful in restoring individual patches of reef in popular tourist sites. However, such labor-intensive and costly coral reef restoration work is no match for the threat that global climate change poses to coral reefs worldwide.

The Board of Regents at the Smithsonian announced the members of the search committee charged with finding a new secretary of the institution. The chairman of the committee is Alan G. Spoon, a regent and managing general partner of Polaris Venture Partners. Other members are Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California; L. Hardwick Caldwell, chairman of the institution's National Board; Anne d'Harnoncourt, a regent and director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; Walter E. Massey, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta; Jeffrey Minear, administrative assistant to Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.; and Roger W. Sant, a regent and chairman emeritus of the board. HOLLI CHMELA

Kaboom indeed. In a cascade of superlatives that belies the traditional cerebral reserve of their profession, astronomers reported yesterday that they had seen the brightest and most powerful stellar explosion ever recorded.

The Mets spent so much time in the field during the fifth inning of Monday's game that they could have counted how many fans were sitting in Section 108 and most of 109. Anything to distract them from Giants stampeding around the bases. In all, 12 Giants came to the plate, and surprise, surprise, Barry Bonds played only a minor role. Undone by a pair of two-out errors, the Mets proceeded to allow six consecutive Giants to reach base, culminating in Bengie Molina's second homer of the nine-run inning, and they lost, 9-4, at AT&T Park.

A front-page article last Tuesday about new sectarian political problems and violence in Iraq misstated the number of United States service members killed from hostile actions in April, as reported by the Defense Department. It was 96 -- not 104, which included eight who died in non-hostile incidents.

A picture on Sunday with a sports article about the relationship between Jets safety Erik Coleman and his mother was published in error. It showed No. 36 of the Jets, defensive back David Barrett -- not Coleman, who is No 26.

A new study has found that adolescents who use condoms the first time they have intercourse do not go on to have more sexual partners than others, and that they have lower rates of sexually transmitted diseases than those who do not use condoms the first time. Beginning in 1994, the researchers studied a sample of 4,018 teenagers, all of whom completed three interviews about their sexual behavior over a period of six to eight years. All had had sexual intercourse by the second year of the study. Participants were tested for chlamydia and gonorrhea in 2001 or 2002.

Both houses of the State Legislature passed legislation yesterday to sharply restrict the relationships between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students. The legislation follows an investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, into hundreds of colleges, lenders and alumni associations that have admitted to or are suspected of steering loans to prospective students in exchange for gifts, trips or payments from lenders. The bill, which Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to sign, prohibits colleges from soliciting or accepting any gifts or money from lenders in exchange for recommending them to students, and prohibits lenders' staff members from working out of college financial aid offices, among other provisions. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

The ''Amazing Race'' teammates Eric Sanchez and Danielle Turner took home the $1 million grand prize Sunday as the 11th installment of the series came to a close, giving CBS a slight lead for the night in total viewers. Nielsen estimated that the finale drew 10.5 million viewers, ranking second in the 8 p.m. hour behind ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (11.6 million). ABC remained the night's leader among adults 18 to 49, aided by ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (16.9 million). CBS's ''Without a Trace'' (14.6 million) was the most-watched show in the 10 p.m. hour but third in the 18-to-49 demographic after both ''Brothers & Sisters'' (11.3 million) and the second half of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live in the '90s'' special, which attracted 7.9 million total viewers from 9 to 11. NBC finished about even with Fox in third for the night. On Friday, ABC's ''20/20'' received only a minor lift in its ratings despite a highly promoted interview with Jeane Palfrey, the so-called D.C. Madam. The news magazine garnered 7.9 million total viewers, third in its 10 p.m. time slot and just above its average this season (7.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

An article in Business Day on April 25 about a decision by Virgin Atlantic Airways to order 15 Boeing 787 planes misstated the model that another airline, British Airways, is considering. It is the 747-8, not the 747-800.

House Democrats may push ahead this week with a new war spending bill that would provide money for combat operations through midsummer, with the rest of the funds sought by President Bush withheld until commanders in Iraq provide a report on conditions there. Senior Democratic officials say the proposal, which is still being put together and could reach a floor vote by the week's end, is an attempt to provide the Pentagon with the money it needs while keeping pressure on Mr. Bush over his conduct of the war.

An article in Business Day on Friday about Norway's use of investment funds to advance an ambitious ethical code misspelled the surname of the country's finance minister, who discussed the investment approach. It is Kristin Halvorsen, not Halverson.

Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in France's deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls in the nearby pasture stayed away. ''A vague resemblance to the look of George W. Bush on his Texan ranch,'' is how the left-leaning newspaper Libération described Mr. Sarkozy, who was elected president on Sunday, beating the Socialist candidate Ségolène Royal in a runoff. The newspaper dismissed the event as a media stunt, saying, ''Everything for the image, right up until the last minute.''

Justice Department officials said they would not object to a Congressional grant of immunity to a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who played a central role in the dismissals of federal prosecutors. The decision appeared to increase the likelihood that the aide, Monica Goodling, will soon appear before a Congressional panel, under a grant of immunity, to answer questions about last year's firings of eight United States attorneys. DAVID JOHNSTON

BERG--Gerard, died peacefully on May 6 surrounded by his family. He is survived by his two daughters, Natalie and Alison and his brother Henry. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Holocaust Memorial Museum at USHMM.org.

Esther Lee joined Euro RSCG Worldwide, New York, part of Havas, as chief executive for North America and president for global brands, new posts. She had been senior vice president and chief creative officer at the Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta. Brett Gosper, president at McCann Erickson U.S., New York, part of McCann Erickson Worldwide, was named president for the Europe, Middle East and Africa region, based in London, as well as chairman and chief executive for the United Kingdom Group. He assumes duties from Rupert Howell, who left. Michael McLaren, worldwide director for global accounts at McCann Erickson, New York, succeeds Mr. Gosper in the McCann U.S. post. McCann Erickson is part of the McCann Worldgroup unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Todd Riddle, a group creative director at Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, was promoted to creative director for the Minneapolis office. He succeeds Kerry Feuerman, who resigned after 13 months in the post.
RADOWITZ--Jesse. May 3, 1977 to May 6, 2007. Beloved son and brother. Funeral service 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.
She gave me a look that only a mother could give a child. PRESIDENT BUSH, on the reaction of Queen Elizabeth II after he nearly said she had visited in 1776. [A21]
WIRKMAA--Lydia. It is with deep sorrow that we announce the death of Lydia Wirkmaa. A graveside service will be held in Kensico Cemetery, Saturday May 12th at 1 pm.
The maker of Jim Beam says it will adopt stricter ad rules to help curb under-age drinking. Advertising, Page C3.

President Horst Köhler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by a terrorist from the far-left Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. Mr. Köhler met last week with the man, Christian Klar, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for the murder of a German prosecutor in 1977. The meeting drew protests from conservative politicians, who said Mr. Klar had shown no remorse for his crimes. Speculation that he might be freed rose after a fellow gang member, Brigitte Mohnhaupt, was released in March after serving 24 years in prison for murders in the 1970s. The president also denied clemency to another member, Birgit Hogefeld. MARK LANDLER

JOSEPH--Philip, M. 75. Died on May 2, 2007 in Bradenton FL where he recently retired from Larchmont, NY. Philip loved racing sailboats, traveling in Europe with friends and family members, and running his sheet metal factory in Brooklyn. He is survived by his loving wife Cynthia (Broadhead) of 36 years, four devoted daughters, their spouses, and five grandchildren. His daughters are: Karen Joseph of Queen Creek, AZ; Karen Selman of New Rochelle, NY, Deborah Roller of Tucson, AZ; and Jennifer Joseph of San Diego, CA. A Memorial Service will be held at Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his honor to Tidewell Hospice Care, 800-959-4291.

The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday for Motorola's shareholders meeting, with some hope that he would be elected to the board. But by late in the day, as the politics played out, Mr. Icahn conceded that he had lost his proxy fight and had failed to garner enough support from large funds to become a director.

An article in some copies of Business Day on Saturday about the pet food recall in the United States misstated the time frame in which Xinhua, China's official news agency, reported that the Chinese government was inspecting wheat gluten for chemicals that might have sickened thousands of pets given food containing Chinese ingredients. The Xinhua report was made in early April, not at the end of the month, and said inspections started at the beginning of April, not at the end.
BRUCK--Eva. Faithful and loving friend, we will miss you and remember always the joyous times we shared. Love, Marian, Steven and Evan Levine
CONE--Ronald P. of Manhattan, died suddenly January 15, 2007. Memorial Mass, Church of the Holy Cross, 329 West 42nd Street, Wednesday, May 9, 2007, 7pm.

After four races in the Car of Tomorrow, Dale Earnhardt Jr. said he had had enough. On Monday, Earnhardt, the sport's most popular driver and among the most influential, joined the list of critics of the new racecar, which is being phased into the Nextel Cup series this season. ''It's going to take a lot of time to figure it out, but right now, it's about the most frustrating thing I've ever had to deal with in this sport, and I've had to deal with some pretty frustrating things,'' Earnhardt said a day after finishing 13th in the Jim Stewart 400 at Richmond International Raceway. ''It'll frustrate you pretty easily.''

It is cap-and-gown season, and for the presidential candidates, that means the opportunity to spend May weekends delivering speeches at colleges and universities that are carefully selected to fit a strategic purpose. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and a Republican whose Mormon faith has given some Christian evangelicals pause, chose to deliver a commencement speech on Saturday in Virginia at Regent University, which was founded by the evangelist Pat Robertson. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, is focusing on black institutions, perhaps a reflection of how she and Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, are scrambling for black voters. Last Saturday, she gave the commencement address at Wilberforce University in Ohio. Later this month, she will speak at the historically black Dillard University in New Orleans, where she can address the student body in a city whose devastation she often cites in assailing the Bush administration's response to Hurricane Katrina.

Q. Why is cesium used in atomic clocks? A. Cesium clocks measure time by counting the tick-tock cycles of atoms of the metallic element cesium. But the cycles are not pendulum swings; instead, they are the extremely fast vibrations of the atoms when exposed to microwaves in a vacuum.

NADLER--Paul S. His school mates and friends of the Horace Mann School class of 1947 note with profound sorrow the loss of Paul Nadler a fine human being whose wit, brilliance and warmth will be sadly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family whom he loved so much and of whom he was so proud. Paul left you various things, but the most important is a good name that will follow you always.

BOOTH--Alice. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Alice Booth. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her children, Margaret and Jane and other members of her family. Allen J. Ross, President

FUDIM--Allan, beloved husband of Sherry and cherished father of Elissa; adored brother of Bonnie Fudim and Barry Fudim. Services Wednesday, May 9th, 1:30pm at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W150 Route 4E, Paramus, NJ. For directions kindly call (201) 843-9090.

The long ago quarterback and retired heart surgeon was 58 when he discovered how much he knew about human frailty, just not his own. ''The doctor wasn't following the advice he gave about exercising, eating well, doing what you need to do,'' Arthur Roberts said. ''I had never been sick a day in my life and still had the athlete's mentality, where you think you're indestructible. It turned out I wasn't.''

To the Editor: Re ''Clemens Returns, and So Does Hope for Yankees'' (front page, May 7): So Roger Clemens is coming back to the New York Yankees. I am a Yankee fan, but prorated or not, $28 million is a lot of money for a pitcher soon to be 45.

FRYER--Warren R., of Manhattan survived by his partner George Foltrauer. His daughters, Christine, Janet, Lynn and grandchildren, Luke and Olivia May-Fryer. A memorial service will be announced later.

The Supreme Court suspended proceedings against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, Pakistan's suspended chief justice, before a five-judge panel known as the Supreme Judicial Council. The council began hearing accusations of misconduct and abuse of power against Mr. Chaudhry after President Pervez Musharraf suspended him in March. Mr. Chaudhry, meanwhile, went to the Supreme Court to challenge the council's authority and impartiality. In addition to halting the council inquiry, the Supreme Court also recommended that Mr. Chaudhry's complaints be heard by the full Supreme Court. The decision followed a mass rally in support of Mr. Chaudhry over the weekend. SALMAN MASOOD

ESCOTT--Mary Ryan. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart New York City deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional colleague, dedicated Alumna and treasured friend. A valiant woman with a vibrant faith and a devoted Child of the Sacred Heart, the Sacred Heart community will cherish the memory of MiMi's loving spirit and remember her entire family in perpetual prayer. $(6$)ESCOTT--Mary R., on Monday May 7. Loving mother of Paul Anthony Escott and Michael James Escott. Beloved spouse of the late Michael Escott. Cherished sister of Jamie Ryan Gans, Nancy Ryan Beha and James A. Beha. Devoted aunt to nine nieces and nephews and seven greatnieces and great-nephews. Mimi was a talented artist and a kindergarten teacher at the Convent of the Sacred Heart. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of St. Ignatius, 980 Park Avenue, on Friday 10 am. Burial at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury. Contributions in Mimi's memory may be made to the Convent of Sacred Heart, One East 91st Street, NY, NY 10128.

ABITBOL--Mollie. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of Mollie Abitbol, adored mother of Honorary Board member, Diane Fogg. Our hearts and prayers are with her and her family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Fredric Mack, President Michael Goldstein, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

The Yankees have gotten the headlines and the hope. They will have to wait several weeks to see if the signing of Roger Clemens actually gets them much-needed victories. As fans and the news media herald Rocket Re-Entry, the players who will welcome Clemens around June 1 are taking a more pragmatic approach. They realize that the pitcher whom they will call a teammate for four regular-season months, two of the months at age 44 and two at 45, will probably be different from the one whose likeness will hang in Cooperstown five years after he really -- no, really -- retires.

GOULD--Gerald B. The Directors, Officers and employees of H.G. Wellington & Co., Inc. mourn the passing of our friend and colleague of over 32 years. His talent, civility, and kindness will be missed greatly. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family. The Board of Directors

HART--Kitty Carlisle. Memorial celebration for Kitty Carlisle Hart at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th St. at noon on June the 12th. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dramatists Guild Fund in honor of Kitty Carlisle Hart.

A front-page article on Thursday about negotiations between the White House and Congress over a new war-spending measure carried an inaccurate transcription by the White House for a comment by President Bush, who had criticized Congress for trying to use an Iraq spending bill to mandate troop withdrawal. Mr. Bush said, ''I'm a commander guy,'' meaning he was siding with military commanders, not politicians. He did not say, ''I'm the commander guy.'' The White House issued a corrected transcript on May 4 after reviewing a recording.

To the Editor: Re ''Plan B? Let's Give Plan A Some Time First'' (Op-Ed, May 6): Frederick W. Kagan, one of the proponents for the current ''surge'' of United States troops into Baghdad, tells us not to worry about a Plan B if Plan A fails, because ''there cannot be one.''

Nicolas Sarkozy was elected President of France, by a margin of six percentage points, defeating Ségolène Royal by assembling a majority of older voters, high earners, farmers and professionals. Young voters, those lower paid and the unemployed cast most of their ballots for Ms. Royal, according to a nationwide election day poll conducted by Ipsos. Ms. Royal's appeal for female solidarity during the campaign did not persuade a majority of women. Older women gave two-thirds of their votes to Mr. Sarkozy, and younger women were evenly divided between the two candidates. However, Ms. Royal was preferred by 55 percent of women ages 35 to 59.

Turnout of registered voters is typically high in France for presidential elections, but Sunday's election was the highest since 1988. Runoff elections have had some of the highest turnouts. A sampling of recent elections:

A biographical sketch on April 18 about Henry Lee, a victim of the Virginia Tech massacre, misstated the year he graduated from high school and became an American citizen. It was 2006, not 1999. The sketch, and an article the same day about the victims, also misstated the country from which he emigrated. It was Vietnam, not China.

The Web site at CBS News has been getting so many vitriolic comments about Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, that it has taken the unusual step of blocking all reader comments on its stories about Mr. Obama. The CBS decision highlights the ways in which presidential campaigns, news organizations and the general public are grappling with the growing influence of the Internet on politics. There is no rule book for resolving clashes among the anything-goes ethos of the Web, the efforts by candidates to harness it to their ends and the standards that mainstream journalism has tried to impose on what appears under its banner.

To the Editor: Re ''When Pennies Fail to Pay the Bill, a Bronx Man Pushes for Change'' (news article, May 4): The refusal of a restaurant owner to accept pennies comes as no surprise, and has less to do with discrimination than the trouble that pennies have become.

HOSIOSKY--Ellen N., D.M.D. Died on April 18, 2007 at home after a brief battle with cancer at the age of ninety six. She was the loving and devoted wife to Issai Hosiosky who died in 1998. Ellen was truly a pioneer for women educationally and professionally. She graduated from Columbia Dental School with honors and became the first woman on their teaching staff. Ellen had a true passion for learning and that passion did not stop with dentistry. She studied all forms of medicine and incorporated that knowledge into her dental practice. Her love for learning is only surpassed by her willingness to pass that knowledge on to others. Dr. Ellen Hosiosky was truly a charitable person, not only with her money, but more importantly with her time to help others. She will be missed.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has been battling Senator Barack Obama of Illinois for primacy in the Democratic field of presidential hopefuls, and now she is taking the battle to Chicago -- his home turf and her former hometown. Mrs. Clinton was in the city yesterday for a breakfast with Mayor Richard M. Daley (who has already endorsed Mr. Obama), and also met with local black ministers. But she had to cancel a fund-raiser because of Senate business.
To the Editor: ''Seeing No Progress, Some Schools Drop Laptops'' (front page, May 4) is a good reminder that technology can't solve all problems, or even many of them.

Your children are going to camp far from home this summer, but you can't get off work or justify the expense of an extra plane ticket just to fly them there. Should you trust the airlines to take care of them if they fly alone?
So what do you think? Can a puppy save Darfur? My column benefited tremendously from this journal article, and I encourage you to look it up.

Pardon my modest blush while I do something here that may appear uncomfortably self-serving. A recurrent theme in your replies to these columns has been how much people miss my old show(s) and how they wish they could see them now. A recent commenter confessed to a life-long "crush" on Katharine Hepburn and just learned that I did two full shows with her on my ABC late-night show. Another writer, Hepburn-smitten, would "give anything" to see them. You, sir (as I recall), can give considerably less than that. And you could probably see them today. Another writer suggested that DVDs of the shows would be a good idea. I don't know which of us should be embarrassed but DVDs are already out here.

One week ago, the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued arrest warrants on charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity for Ahmad Muhammad Harun, Sudan's former interior minister who oversaw the Darfur Securty Desk, and Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, a leader of the Janjaweed militia. Mr. Harun is now Sudan's minister of humanitarian affairs. The two men seem to be rather small fry compared to Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the Sudanese president, but it's a step in the right direction. Too little, too late, of course, for the hundreds of thousands who've been tortured, raped and murdered in the Darfur region over the past four years.

In the dying days of the Bush presidency, it looks as though Congress and the president are engaged in one of their repeated tussles over control of foreign policy. The Constitution has always provided the potential for conflict, of course. Dividing up powers means that neither branch of government likes what they get. But it usually takes a dramatic event or a catastrophe (you can decide which of those the current occupation of Iraq is) to stir up the conflict.

Mitt Romney's campaign confirmed to ABC News today that his wife, Ann Romney, donated $150 to Planned Parenthood in 1994. The news comes just two days after reports resurfaced that Rudolph W. Giuliani donated $900 to Planned Parenthood during the 1990's-and the day before Mr. Romney is scheduled to receive a "Political Leadership Award" form Massachusetts Citizens for Life.

An criminal inquiry in Brazil has concluded that two Americans were responsible for piloting a private jet into a collision with a commercial airliner in September 2006, according to O Globo, a Brazilian newspaper.

Bill Clinton plans to be a First Husband for the 21st century: A post-modern, post-ego presidential spouse who doesn't earn an income of his own, but rather pays the bills from family savings and does what he can to help the missus down in the Oval Office.

FORT DODGE, Iowa -- Mitt Romney criticized today comments made by the Rev. Al Sharpton about Mormonism and his candidacy, calling the remarks "bigoted" and proof that "bigotry still exists in some corners."

For my story in today's newspaper about Pizzeria Mozza, I talked to several of its ardent fans, and a theme that came up repeatedly in their comments - comments that didn't wind up working their way into the story - was that Mozza seemed more like a New York restaurant than a Los Angeles one. These fans stressed that the two cities' restaurant cultures were very different.

There's been no shortage of theories as the investigation continues into the death of Bob Woolmer, the Pakistani cricket coach who died hours after his strongly favored team lost to a neophyte squad from Ireland.
A nanosecond is one-billionth of a second.
Dear My Times Beta tester,
In recent years, Barry Bonds has not made it a habit of playing in day games after night games, but he is in today's lineup.

Barry Bonds hit his 745th home run last night. Tom Glavine won his 294th career game. Feeling left out, Manager Willie Randolph accomplished his own milestone, winning his 200th game as Mets manager. For those interested, he ranks seventh on the franchise's all-time list and is pretty much assured of sliding into sixth within the next few months and all the way up to fourth early next year.

The day after the Mets played bald, Carlos Beltran, "the Barber of Sheaville" (that was the New York Post's back page headline when Rey Sanchez received a haircut during a game), walked around the clubhouse with a digital camera. He stuck the camera about two feet away from John Maine, today's pitcher, who was sitting on the couch. The usually unflappable Maine burst out laughing.

Circuit City confirmed today that one of their employees tipped off authorities to the Fort Dix suspects in January 2006. The employee works at the Mount Laurel, N.J., branch, but has yet to step forward.

Xelerated, a maker of processors for network routers and switches, has landed $23 million in financing from a group of investors led by Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund.

A week ago, there was a disastrous crash on the Gumball 3000, an annual rally through Europe that advertises itself as "3,000 miles of adventure with the most eccentric group of thrill-seekers imaginable, partying every night with the who's who of international society and pop culture." As you would expect, most of the participants drive exotic cars.

There were campaign-style buttons passed around last night at a gathering of former Al Gore donors in Washington, but they did not augur a presidential run by Mr. Gore (to the disappointment of some). "Al Gore Reunion 2007," they read.
Imagine that there was a way to know what Natalie Portman was doing all the time. Would indulging in that be ... weird? Would you do it anyway?

In which your correspondents track the unusual verbiage of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a highly precise public speaker who often uses words or phrases that rarely alight upon the ears in normal conversation, and occasionally Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, who appears to be picking up some of his boss's habits.
Oh, lordy, how long I've been waiting for this!

John Edwards has made poverty a top issue as he stumps for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So his connections to Fortress Investment Group, a highly profitable hedge fund and private equity firm with several executives on Forbes' latest billionaires list, have provoked quite a bit of interest from campaign watchers. Asked about his decision to join Fortress as a senior adviser in 2005, Mr. Edwards told The Associated Press on Tuesday that he did it "mainly in order to learn about the relationships between financial markets and poverty."

Cravath Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm, is putting its white shoe firmly in the bankruptcy business. The firm, which frequently counsels companies in multibillion-dollar mergers, said Wednesday it has formed a corporate restructuring and insolvency group and hired Richard Levin, a former partner at Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, to lead it. The move comes as Skadden and other law firms with established restructuring practices have been recruiting new talent, anticipating that the long lull in large corporate bankruptcies might be nearing an end.
Mafia clans are known to fight over turf, but credit for a double murder? F.B.I. documents cited by The Associated Press today recount a conversation between two rival families.
Pop star Prince has confirmed that he'll be looking this summer for a house to buy in London, where he will kick off a 21-concert tour on Aug. 1st.

It's not Walter Cronkite, but still : National Review White House correspondent Byron York questions the "article of faith in Republican circles that Congress should not impose deadlines on the U.S . troop presence in Iraq." He writes at The Corner:
Why are prescription drugs so expensive? One reason is that the system does not encourage price competition.

In the wake of less-than-stellar reviews of his speech last week, Fred D. Thompson is working on "Stump Speech 2.0" for a second shot this weekend, report Jonathan Martin and Mike Allen at Politico.com. "Friends working on the speech say it will include more of a call to arms than the entertaining but unfocused after-dinner address Thompson gave to an eagerly expectant audience Friday night at the Balboa Bay Club and Resort in Newport Beach, Calif.," they write. Mr. Thompson is slated to appear in Northern Virginia on Saturday before the Council for National Policy, an organization of conservative leaders.

Citigroup's consumer operations have lost nearly half of their senior management in the last 18 months, The Financial Times reported. Several of these high-level employees have left for J.P. Morgan Chase, while three others joined Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm co-founded by Bob Willumstad, a former chief operating officer at Citi.
Storekeepers praise the Moss model even as they turn away from it.

Who does Rupert Murdoch need to win over in his $5 billion bid to acquire Dow Jones? To answer that question, The New York Observer drew up a family tree of the Bancrofts, who control the publishing company through a special class of stock. Family members include a champion power-boat racer, a retired American Airlines pilot and the head of a Texas private equity firm.

Once narrowly focused on a mobile blog publishing application, Intercasting of San Diego now hopes to be the largest intermediary between mobile phone carriers and social networking sites. Its investors have shown their support for the second time, providing $12 million in new capital to support Intercasting's growth initiatives. Venrock Associates, the venture capital vehicle of the Rockefeller family, led the new round.

The story behind the firing of two Dow Chemical executives for allegedly being "involved in unauthorized discussions with third parties about the potential acquisition of the company" became even more bizarre - and clouded - as the two men sued Dow Chemical, contending that they were defamed. The company, in turn, has sued both men.

The Fortress Investment Group is taking Florida East Coast Industries private in a deal valued at $3.5 billion. The buyout agreement follows Fortress's announcement that it has closed on the first $2.8 billion of a new $5 billion private equity fund.
A hedge fund that has a stake in Alcoa wants the company to drop its $33 billion hostile bid for its Canadian rival Alcan so that it can be bought instead.
The rural wireless telecom service provider Alltel is being courted by at least three groups of private-equity buyers about a potential purchase, according to The Wall Street Journal.

VMware, EMC's fast-growing virtualization software unit, plans to offer 10 percent of its stock in an initial public offering. But a report from The 451 Group asks: If VMware's newly enriched founders should leave the company, will the juggernaut they created keep its momentum? Though comparisons with similar publicly traded companies is difficult, analysts at The 451 Group estimate that VMware could be valued at $7 billion or more once its shares begin trading.
The German software maker SAP said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy OutlookSoft, a planning, budgeting, forecasting, and consolidation software maker that competes with Oracle.
Morgan Stanley is in talks with foreign money managers, including the ING Group, to sell its South Korean asset management firm in a deal local media valued at up to $220 million, Reuters reported.

Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused Tuesday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdoch's takeover offer.
A raging fire in Griffith Park has forced evacuations of homes and city landmarks.

Goldman Sachs and Coller Capital are among the firms raising secondary buyout funds, that acquire private equity portfolios rather than portions of companies as appetite for these kinds of investments seems to be hitting a high. Financial News cites estimates that $15 billion has been raised this year for secondary funds, more than the amount raised in the last two years combined.

The share price of Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, jumped Tuesday on renewed speculation of a buyout. The stock climbed $2.77, or 7.2 percent, to $41.28 after rising as high as $42.19.

The ruling by a court of appeals Tuesday dismissing some of the claims brought against Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, is likely to make it more difficult for the state of New York to force him to return the bulk of his pay package.

Bank of Montreal, which said last month that it would report a pretax loss of as much as 450 million Canadian dollars ($407 million) from trading natural gas, placed two New York bankers on leave. A natural gas trader, David Lee, and Bob Moore, executive managing director of commodity products, are on leave as Bank of Montreal conducts an "external review,'' a spokesman, Ralph Marranca, told Bloomberg News.

Oaktree Capital Management, a buyout firm with $40 billion of assets, plans to take over Fu Sheng Industrial of Taiwan, the world's biggest maker of golf-club heads, for 28.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($851 million).

A New York design house, Proenza Schouler, is close to scoring a much-needed cash injection from a European luxury firm, The New York Post reported. While Proenza Schouler's founders, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, have experienced an almost meteoric rise in fashion circles, they have been looking for additional financing after buying out a German venture capitalist, Markus Hofels, last year, The Post said.

Days after an analyst's report suggested that BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, could become a target for private equity buyers, speculation surfaced that the company is considering a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group.

A former Credit Suisse banker charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring will be released on $1 million bail Wednesday after a federal magistrate judge questioned the strength of the government's case.

The chief executive of the boutique investment bank Keefe Bruyette & Woods, adding his voice to the growing chorus of those warning of the dangers of the current buyout boom, said that the private-equity frenzy could end as badly for investors as the technology-stock bubble did.
An activist hedge fund, Schultze Asset Management, vowed Tuesday to press Movie Gallery to take steps to increase shareholder value.
BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. The shares rose to a record.

Conrad M. Black's longtime business partner, F. David Radler, testified Tuesday at Mr. Black's criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International.

Two Fidelity brokerage units have agreed to pay $400,000 in fines to settle regulatory complaints accusing them of producing misleading sales materials for two archaic Fidelity mutual funds that were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.

Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, spoke to hundreds of marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle on Tuesday amid rumblings about his company's struggle to compete against Google in online advertising and about its efforts to court Yahoo for some sort of partnership.

The Warner Music Group posted a wider quarterly loss Tuesday and said it would cut about 400 jobs as it shifts resources to increase digital distribution of music and video. The announcement comes as Warner's hopes for a deal with its British rival, the EMI Group, are fading in the face of private equity bids for EMI.

Tyco International, which plans to split into three companies in coming weeks, reported lower quarterly earnings Tuesday as revamping costs reduced earnings but a low tax rate helped results beat Wall Street expectations.
Dressing rooms in the Hamptons, reimagining cardboard, far outside the box, rare rugs and more.
The fanny pack: it's not just for Michelin guides.
Purists don’t dare race in trail running shoes. Enter trail racing shoes with stickier, firmer soles and less weight than everyday trail running shoes.
The modern slipper chair, as distinctive as ever.
Brazilians, even those who don’t normally pay much attention to religious matters, are gearing up for the arrival of Pope Benedict XVI’s arrival in Sao Paulo.
Cape Town's beaches, parks and gardens are a perfect playground for children and families.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Rates were left untouched for the seventh straight meeting, suggesting the economy is headed toward a soft landing.

Two of the world's largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.
This documentary about four World Press Photo contest winners defines icon to mean a still image so searing that it supplants memories of the event it was supposed to record.
“Day Night Day Night,” a movie about a suicide bomber, may be serious, and it is certainly sure of itself. But it is also maddeningly, purposefully evasive.
Guy Maddin’s “Brand Upon the Brain!” is a baroque entertainment with one foot in silent cinema and the other gingerly toeing the sound waves.
In “Allegro,” the past is a shadowy night town whose geography is continually rearranging itself.
In “Falling Man,” Don DeLillo examines 9/11 and its aftermath as experienced by a self-absorbed couple.
In this update on his April article about a do-it-yourself method of learning about wine, Eric Asimov reports on what he has found while making his way through two mixed cases.
The comments were the latest in a series of sharply worded Russian criticisms of American foreign policy.
The raids, conducted four weeks ahead of the meeting, amounted to a show of force against potential protesters.
Lightning is one of three “root causes” identified in a long-awaited investigation into the 2006 explosion.
The bill gives the F.D.A. new power to police drug safety and order changes in drug labels.
Webdenda.
The arrests today suggested that the British police were beginning to piece together how the plot worked.
A dispute broke out today between the Roman Catholic Church and the Brazilian government about abortion.
Can a supporter of abortion rights, even one with caveats and qualifications, make it to the top of the Republican Party in 2008?
In a visit to Baghdad, the vice president urged Iraqis to pull together urgently on such divisive issues as oil revenues, political militias and provincial elections.
After another feverish day in this country’s amazing bull run, share prices in China broke records again today.
Tennessee is among a small group of states that have scrutinized lethal injection, and the case has thrust the state into a national debate.
The fire in Griffith Park scorched more than 800 acres, forcing the evacuation of a few hundred people.
Tom Glavine allowed only Barry Bonds’s 745th career home run in seven innings Tuesday night as the Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants.
For the second straight game, the Cavaliers outhustled, outmuscled and outshot the befuddled Nets, shocking them into retreat Tuesday night.
Doug Mientkiewicz may be the Yankees’ hottest hitter, and he singled to start the team’s first two scoring rallies Tuesday night in a victory over the Texas Rangers.
Today’s new rich dropped millions of dollars on Tuesday, ignoring auction house estimates and paying whatever it took to take the right image home.
Carlos Beltrán, the Mets’ center fielder/resident barber, deployed his razor on the heads of teammates, including the newly shorn Shawn Green.
Throughout his season-long funk, David Wright has maintained an even keel in public. But this wasn’t the case during Monday night’s game against the Giants.
Corrections: For the Record

A theater review on Thursday about “Coram Boy,” at the Imperial Theater, misstated the definition of the term Coram boy. It refers to a child abandoned by his parents, not an orphan. (It is derived from the name of Thomas Coram, who in the 18th century established the Foundling Hospital to care for abandoned children in London.).

About half a million voters are eligible to cast ballots today to pick a new president from two colorful candidates, after a first round of voting last month did not produce an outright winner. The choice is between a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, José Ramos-Horta, who campaigned for East Timor’s independence from Indonesia in exile and became prime minister last year, and Francisco Guterres, a former guerrilla commander who fought against Indonesian rule and has served as parliamentary speaker. Both have pledged to accept the results of the vote. Next month, the young nation will vote for the more powerful post of prime minister.
A shooting in Rockland County raises concern about the vulnerability of the 1,250 village and town courts across New York State.

An appeals court freed a well-known human rights defender, Umida Niyazova, after she read out a damning confession that also impugned Human Rights Watch, the independent New York-based group she worked for. Ms. Niyazova, an independent Uzbek journalist who worked as a translator for the group, was convicted of distributing Islamic extremist propaganda and sentenced to seven years in prison last week after a two-day trial that was condemned by the European Union and the United States. Standing in a cage in the courtroom yesterday, she pleaded guilty and said: “I sincerely regret the crimes I have committed unintentionally. I’m deeply disappointed in some people and international organizations I have worked with.” Pointing at Andrea Berg, who heads the Human Rights Watch office in the country, Ms. Niyazova continued: “And our work, Andrea, was biased and harmed my people.” Ms. Berg sat stony-faced, and afterward was crying and refused to comment.

André Boisclair, left, the leader of the separatist Parti Québécois, resigned, further destabilizing an independence movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March. “The current conditions don’t allow me to do this anymore,” he said. The party was poised to have a strong showing in the elections, with some even predicting a win for the separatists, who want Quebec to be a nation. But instead they had their worst showing in decades. When he was elected party leader in November 2005, Mr. Boisclair, 41, made headlines for being openly gay and for admitting to having used cocaine while a cabinet minister. His relative youth also marked a departure from previous sovereignty leaders, most of whom traced their roots to the party’s founding in the late 1960s. He fought back tears as he announced his resignation, ending it with a familiar rallying cry among separatists: “Vive le Quebec!”.

President Jacques Chirac made his last major public appearance as he laid a wreath at the Arc de Triomphe in Paris to commemorate the Allied victory over the Nazis in 1945. Mr. Chirac, who steps down next Wednesday after 12 years in office, is to hold his last meeting with his ministers today. After a three-day vacation in the Mediterranean, Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s newly elected president, is to join Mr. Chirac at a ceremony tomorrow in Paris to commemorate the abolition of slavery. When Mr. Chirac, 74, moves out of the Élysée Palace next week, it will be to an apartment on the Left Bank opposite the Louvre. It is being lent to the Chiracs by the family of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, who was assassinated in Beirut in 2005. Mr. Chirac was a close friend of Mr. Hariri.

At least 39 people died late Monday when a bus carrying 103 textile workers collided with a tractor-trailer truck in northern Lesotho, a police spokesman said. The accident occurred while the bus, traveling between Maputsoe, a garment-making center on the South Africa border, and Fobane, a village about 15 miles south, was on a winding road. One or both vehicles may have been speeding, the police said.

A report sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations, the nongovernmental, nonpartisan organization with headquarters in New York, said the United States should devote significant resources and diplomatic effort to developing ties with Angola, the second largest oil producer in sub-Saharan Africa after Nigeria, and strategically important for ensuring a steady supply of oil and the stability in the oil-rich Gulf of Guinea region. It noted that Angola had one of the world’s fastest-growing economies but remained one of the world’s least-developed countries. “Cronyism and the labyrinthine bureaucracy that businesses must navigate to turn a profit frighten away all but the most courageous investors,” the report said.

The police arrested a 40-year-old native of Bosnia, now a Norwegian citizen, on suspicion of committing war crimes against Bosnian Serbs while serving in an ethnically Croatian military unit in 1992. The man, who in keeping with Norwegian police practice was not identified, faces up to 21 years in a Norway prison if convicted on charges of assault, rape and illegal detention at a prison camp during the wars over the former Yugoslavia. The police have said they are investigating 70 immigrants to Norway who are suspected of war crimes in a number of countries. The arrested man arrived in Norway with his family in 1993 and received citizenship in 2001.
“Why I Ride: The Art of Bicycling in New York,” which examines the experience of bike riding, is showing at four locations in Lower Manhattan.
Two days after they were ousted from a promising playoff run, the Rangers had their traditional breakup day, but it did not include much talk of breaking up.
The diary Peter Braunstein wrote while on the run from police is being used at his kidnapping and sexual abuse trial to refute his argument of mental illness.
Former President Bill Clinton also endorsed recent decisions by Thailand and Brazil to break patents held by American pharmaceutical companies.
Regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information about Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.
The Iraqi prime minister’s national security adviser told lawmakers that a pullout would be catastrophic.
Haleh Esfandiari,  the director of the Middle East program at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, had endured repeated interrogations about her work.
Two Dow officials, who were fired after the company accused them of conspiring in a buyout, have sued the company for defamation, and Dow has sued them right back.
Next year’s $16.9 billion budget for New York City’s public schools will send far more money to schools serving difficult populations.
Six Muslim men had vowed to  attack the base and “kill as many soldiers as possible,” authorities said.
China and South Korea have shown restraint since news of the offering appeared, while officials in Tokyo tried to play down the gift’s significance.

A District of Columbia Superior Court judge has issued a temporary restraining order halting the firing of a firefighter and the suspension of another — both of whom treated the former New York Times reporter David E. Rosenbaum, who died after being beaten and robbed while walking in Northwest Washington on Jan. 6, 2006. Washington’s new fire chief, Dennis Rubin, had ordered the disciplinary action a week ago, increasing the suspensions recommended by a fire department trial board. The judge, Robert Tignor, agreed with the union representing the firefighters that Chief Rubin had violated department rules and the union contract. The city’s inspector general found that the two firefighters failed to recognize that Mr. Rosenbaum had suffered a head wound and instead believed he was drunk.

Gov. Rick Perry said he would not veto a bill that would block state officials from following his order requiring that sixth-grade girls receive a vaccine for the human papillomavirus, a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer and genital warts. Mr. Perry, a Republican, defended his February executive order requiring the vaccine, but he acknowledged lawmakers’ overwhelming disdain for his action. A veto almost certainly would have been overridden by the Legislature, which has questioned the safety, efficacy and cost of the vaccinations, and said the mandate intruded on families’ lives.

The police in Fresno arrested a college student suspected of opening fire at an apartment in a dispute over a video game console, killing one man and wounding two others. The student, Jonquel Brooks, 19, of Hayward, was taken into custody after intense phone negotiations involving the police, his parents and a lawyer, said Chief Jerry Dyer of the Fresno Police Department. The apartment complex is across a street from the stadium at California State University, Fresno.

A federal judge in El Paso threw out an indictment accusing an anti-Castro Cuban militant of lying to immigration authorities about how he entered the United States. The judge, Kathleen Cardone, said the government’s interpretation of an April 2006 interview with the defendant, Luis Posada Carriles, was “so inaccurate as to render it unreliable as evidence of defendant’s actual statement.” Mr. Posada, a 79-year-old former C.I.A. operative, was to stand trial next week in Texas on immigration fraud charges. Cuba and Venezuela want him extradited in the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner that killed 73 people, but the United States has refused. Mr. Posada has denied involvement in the bombing.

The world’s scientists plan to compile everything they know about all of Earth’s 1.8 million known species and put it all on one Web site, without charge and open to everyone. The effort, the Encyclopedia of Life, will include species descriptions, maps, videos and links to entire genomes. Its first pages of information will be shown today in Washington, where the effort, expected to take 10 years, is being announced by some of the world’s leading institutions. Two foundations have given $12.5 million to pay for the first two and a half years of the project.

A Navy helicopter on a training flight struck a power line and crashed in a rugged area of the Nevada desert east of Reno, killing all five crew members, the Navy said. Navy investigators were on the scene to recover the bodies. The SH-60F helicopter was flying out of Naval Air Station Fallon, a base spokesman said.

A team that includes the University of California won the management contract for Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory despite past problems at that laboratory and a second nuclear weapons laboratory at Los Alamos, N.M., under the university’s management, the Energy Department announced. The university is in partnership with Bechtel National. The seven-year contract allows a maximum payment of $45.5 million a year depending on performance, with possible extensions for 13 more years. The annual budget of the laboratory is $1.6 billion.
The resignation of the official was made public two days before the education secretary is to testify before Congress.
Iraqi Vice President Tariq al-Hashimi’s threat of a walkout suggests that pressure for compromises on the Constitution is mounting.
Two drug companies are paying doctors millions to prescribe drugs that regulators say may be unsafe.
Desperate for a fresh look, the Suns unveiled a new lineup and finally solved the San Antonio Spurs, beating them in Game 2 of the Western Conference semifinals.
Investigators are seeking medical records from two of the game’s premier sluggers, and other players.
First Lieutenant William T. Kallop testified at a military hearing that he found only unarmed people, including women and children, among the dead.
Quarterly profit rose at its two main units but the company reported weakness in overseas markets for its QVC cable shopping channel.
The cosmetics maker reported a narrower quarterly loss as a result of cost-cutting and a slight increase in sales.
Prosecutors say the diversions defrauded shareholders of Hollinger International out of more than $60 million.
The governor of Kansas said that the National Guard is struggling to respond to disasters at home.
The two companies said they settled their patent-infringement lawsuits and signed a long-term patent cross-license agreement.
Tyco reported lower quarterly earnings as revamping costs reduced earnings but a low tax rate helped results beat expectations.
The biggest beneficiary of a U.N. program designed to help poor countries combat global warming has been China.
The decision reflects the military’s concern that recent civilian casualties have led to widespread ill will.
The investment bank said first-quarter profit increased 5 percent from the quarter a year ago, helped by gains in its asset management business.
Jose Padilla and his co-defendants stand accused of participating in a group that, the government says, sent money, goods and recruits abroad to assist “global jihad.”
Oh, to be a university financial aid administrator on the loose in Manhattan.
Vice President Dick Cheney  is reaching out to moderate Arab leaders for help in bringing stability to Iraq.
cycling.
The Warner Music Group said it would cut about 400 jobs as it shifts resources to increase digital distribution of music and video.
Two days after agreeing to rejoin the Yankees, Roger Clemens wore pinstriped pants and a Yankees cap while throwing from a mound at the University of Kentucky.
In New Jersey, would-be terrorists prepared an attack through practice at firing ranges,  computerized ballistic simulations and paintball in the woods.
The deployment of 10 additional Army brigades would allow the Army to maintain heightened troop levels in Iraq into next year.
The biggest lender in Germany said first-quarter profit rose 30 percent, lifted by its debt and equity trading businesses.
A planned airport is at the center of a debate over whether to keep the Panhandle relatively quiet or to seek development.
The company posted a higher quarterly profit on growth in its licensing operations as well as increased contributions from toys and comic book publishing.
The largest wildfire in Georgia history, which broke out on April 16, has scorched 18 houses and more than 101,000 acres.
Religious leaders in New York City and five other cities are launching a movement to provide sanctuary to illegal immigrants facing deportation.
New York’s sewage treatment workers competed in the annual Sludge Olympics in Jamaica, hoping to advance to October’s national championships in San Diego.
The video game maker said it lost $25 million in its fourth fiscal quarter as it dealt with the introduction of new game consoles.
Despite being overwhelmed by his former employer BMW Oracle Racing on Tuesday, Matt Wachowicz looked fulfilled as he celebrated his new Spanish employers’ place in the semifinals.
The Devils will need to address two issues this off-season: hiring a coach and signing a top-line center, who may or may not be Scott Gomez.
Key senators said Tuesday that they had agreed on the outlines of a bipartisan bill that would toughen border enforcement and provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrants.
Internecine brawls are evidence that all is not well inside Zimbabwe’s only opposition party of note.
Bobby Abreu is among the most patient hitters in baseball. But he has struggled lately, and for the moment he seems better suited to bat seventh than third.
Chris Albrecht said he would take a leave of absence after being charged with assaulting a girlfriend in Las Vegas.
Josh Beckett became the first seven-game winner in the majors as the Boston Red Sox beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 9-2, last night in Toronto. The Blue Jays lost their seventh in a row.
The Major League Soccer players union released salary information last week that showed that the league’s more than 90 developmental players each earn less $20,000.
The pharmacy services provider said first-quarter earnings rose 24 percent on strong revenue growth.
After three decades serving as the unconventional prelude to the major championship season, the Players Championship has been moved into May and out of the shadow of the Masters.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released a letter yesterday urging Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to reconsider limits on the use of gun trace data compiled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The limits bar the bureau from releasing gun-trace data except to police officials and prosecutors working on a particular crime. The mayor sent a copy of the letter to members of Congress. He wrote that although the chief argument supporting the limits concerns protecting the anonymity of undercover officers, no one “has been able to identify a single instance when trace data compromised the anonymity of an officer or the integrity of an investigation.” Erik Ablin, a Justice Department spokesman, said the limits were in keeping with the bureau’s “longstanding policy of disclosing firearms trace results only to the law enforcement agency that recovered the crime gun.”.

A man charged with operating on animals without a license was offered a deal yesterday to avoid prison time by completing a psychiatric program, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching an operation on a Boston terrier named Burt. Prosecutors deployed a so-called undercover cat, known as Fred Wheezy to his family and Detective Fred to his public. Fred was not harmed in the course of duty, but he later ran into traffic and was killed. Mr. Vassall was offered a deal to plead guilty to felony charges of practicing unlicensed veterinary medicine and scheming to defraud. Under the deal, he must complete a three-year outpatient mental health program and refrain from working with animals or children or in health care, prosecutors said. Mr. Vassall was given until May 22 to decide.

Two men were sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 15 years to life in prison for their roles in the murders of two undercover police detectives in 2003. The men, Mitchell Diaz, 22, and Jessie Jacobus, 21, members of a robbery ring prosecutors called the Stapleton Crew, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder charges within days of the killings. Both testified at the trial of Ronell Wilson, who was convicted on federal capital murder charges and sentenced to death for shooting the detectives, Rodney J. Andrews and James V. Nemorin. Mr. Diaz confessed to providing the gun, and Mr. Jacobus confessed to accompanying Mr. Wilson to rob the detectives.
The transformation of a large Bronx high school into small schools has meant the end of adequate English as a Second Language classes for hundreds of students.

New York City hopes to expand private ferry service from Manhattan to the Rockaways in Queens as a way to relieve traffic congestion and provide quicker commuting for residents in one of the most remote areas of the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The city’s Economic Development Corporation will ask private ferry operators to propose service for one or more routes that would, at a minimum, run weekdays during peak commuting hours. Operators will have about six weeks to submit responses. The price for the service will depend on the proposals, but officials said they hoped it would cost about the same as express bus service, about $4 each way.

A woman accused of killing her newborn daughter was unaware of her pregnancy and has no memory of giving birth, her lawyer said in State Supreme Court yesterday. The woman, Laura Sergio, 25, has been charged with second-degree murder. The police found the baby, who was said to have died of hypothermia and asphyxiation, on the back porch of the family home in Bay Ridge on April 7. In an interview, a lawyer for Ms. Sergio, Thomas Cascione, described the case as “a classic neonaticide,” a term used to describe the killing of a baby by the mother within 24 hours of birth. In such cases, the mother is generally in denial of her pregnancy. Ms. Sergio was ordered held without bail.

Mayor John Fabrizi said yesterday that he would not run for re-election as leader of Connecticut’s largest city, completing a public fall that began when he admitted last year to using cocaine since taking office in April 2003. Mayor Fabrizi, 50, has been under fire since he made the admission last June, although at the time he said he had been drug-free since late 2004. Mr. Fabrizi’s withdrawal came one day after State Representative Christopher Caruso, a Bridgeport Democrat, said that he intended to challenge the mayor in the primary. Rick Torres, who lost to Mayor Fabrizi four years ago, is expected to run as a Republican. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Yahweh ben Yahweh was the charismatic leader of a religious, black separatist sect and was convicted of conspiring to murder white people as an initiation rite.
The Homeland Security Department said it would go ahead with national standards for driver’s licenses, despite a high level of opposition to the idea by state legislatures.
The North Koreans have a way of making even patient people apoplectic.
A federal appeals court in Washington refused Tuesday to revisit a March decision striking down parts of a gun control law there.

AGENCY, Mo., May 8 (AP) — Five Missouri River levees burst on Monday, sending a deluge that submerged the town of Big Lake on Tuesday. Thousands of people in the region fled their homes because of warnings that the flooding could near the devastation of 1993.
The plan would provide $30 billion for combat operations through midsummer, but require a second round of Congressional votes in July.
Bill Gates spoke to marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle amid rumblings about a deal between Microsoft and Yahoo.
Purdue Pharma agreed to pay $19.5 million to settle complaints that it encouraged physicians to overprescribe its painkiller OxyContin.
Diego Corrales once held four world boxing championships and was remembered most for a pair of brutal lightweight bouts two years ago.
The agreement settles complaints that misleading sales materials were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.
The cable channel is said to be a serious contender to acquire new episodes if NBC decides not to renew the series.
Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. endorsed the request by Paul D. Wolfowitz, the World Bank president, for more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct.
The banker, charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring, will be released after a federal judge questioned the strength of the government’s case.
Inventories rose a smaller-than-expected 0.3 percent in March while sales rose to their highest in a year and a half.
The day that a parent will be able to conceive, design and print out a toy without leaving home is an impending certainty rather than a far-fetched possibility.
The bill gave fresh momentum to a movement that seeks to raise wages through legislation.
Bernard Weatherill, widely known as Jack, presided in the House of Commons from 1983 to 1992.
Under a proposed law in New York State, young children who have been battered and exploited by pimps and johns on the street would no longer be charged with prostitution.
The $1.25 billion proposal is intended to help the state maintain its status as a pre-eminent place for research.
An ad campaign for the first federally approved over-the-counter weight-loss drug tries to lure customers without overpromising.
Investors sought buying opportunities and adjusted their holdings ahead of the Federal Reserve’s meeting Tuesday on interest rates.
The waterfront park that stretches from Jamaica Bay to Sandy Hook in New Jersey is in worse condition than any other national park, according to a new survey.
In the New York governor’s camp, there has been grumbling that the endorsement comes despite Hillary Clinton’s failure to support him during budget battles.
The biggest off-season change for the Giants’ Mathias Kiwanuka was not his move to the linebacker position, but a trip he took to Uganda to reconnect with his family.
Democratic leaders must make promised measures to restore habeas corpus a priority and members of both parties must vote on principle, not out of fear of attack ads.
A man on death row is the first inmate to face execution since the state reviewed the step-by-step instructions for carrying out death sentences.
Airbus will provide a test for Nicolas Sarkozy and clarify whether he is a free-market reformer or an economic nationalist.
Thomson’s $17.5 billion offer for Reuters could create a major rival to Bloomberg in the market for financial data.
The announcement pushed the company’s stock to its highest point in more than six years.
Charles Barron has opted to run for Brooklyn Borough President, forgoing an anticipated congressional run in 2008.
Quarterly profit rose 27 percent on the surprise hit movie “Wild Hogs” and higher advertising rates at ABC television.

(TCM) STAGE DOOR (1937) Turner Classic Movies continues its salute to Katharine Hepburn on the centennial of her birth with four of her best-known films, starting with the Academy Award-nominated “Stage Door” (1937), about a society beauty with Broadway dreams who moves into a boardinghouse full of actresses, played by Ginger Rogers, Lucille Ball, Eve Arden and Ann Miller, then largely unknown. Starting at 10, Hepburn joins forces with Cary Grant in three classic comedies: “Bringing Up Baby” (1938), above, about a scatterbrain who uses her pet leopard to catch the attention of a starchy paleontologist; “Holiday” (1938), in which a freethinker engaged to a millionaire’s daughter decides that her sister just might be a better match, at 1:15 a.m.; and “The Philadelphia Story” (1940), about an ice princess socialite on the verge of remarrying who is forced to rethink everything, at 3. At midnight there’s Hepburn’s first television interview, on “The Dick Cavett Show,” from 1973.

Tom Glavine arrived at AT&T Park on Tuesday afternoon to find that the Mets' clubhouse had turned into a barbershop. As he walked toward his locker, he saw a bald Mike Pelfrey, a crew-cutted Joe Smith and a flat-topped David Wright, then peered into the bathroom to see Carlos Beltrán wielding an electric razor. ''What the hell is going on around here?'' Glavine said, with a laugh.

PAYING DOCTORS TO GIVE DRUGS -- Amgen and Johnson & Johnson, two of the world's largest drug companies, are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses. [Page A1.] SARKOZY'S APPROACH TO AIRBUS -- Airbus, Europe's proud but ailing plane maker, will provide a test for France's president-elect, Nicolas Sarkozy, and clarify whether he is, at heart, a free-market reformer or an economic nationalist determined to prop up France's industrial patrimony. [C1.] CHINA REAPS THE BENEFITS -- A United Nations program is supposed to help the developing world combat global warming by transferring billions of dollar from rich countries to poor countries. But the biggest beneficiary is no longer so poor: China received most of the money last year. [C1.] DOW JONES LEAK INQUIRY -- Federal securities regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple accused of making millions of dollars by buying the company's shares shortly before news of Rupert Murdoch's takeover offer. [C1.] CLAIMS AGAINST GRASSO REJECTED -- A New York appeals court dismissed four of six legal claims brought against Richard A. Grasso for his pay package of $190 million over eight years as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. [C1.] SECOND CONTAMINANT IN PET FOOD -- A second industrial chemical that American regulators have identified as a pet food contaminant may have been intentionally added to animal feed by Chinese producers seeking larger profits, according to Chinese chemical industry officials. [C3.] A CONSPIRACY TO DIVERT MILLIONS -- Conrad M. Black's longtime former business partner testified at Mr. Black's criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International. [C3.] NOW THE LAWSUITS -- Two officials of Dow Chemical, who were fired after the company accused them of conspiring in a buyout, have sued Dow Chemical for defamation, and Dow has sued them right back. [C1.] YES, IT'S A DIET PILL -- A marketing blitz with a budget estimated at more than $150 million in the first year is seeking to persuade skeptical dieters that a new over-the-counter pill can help them lose weight. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C2.] STRONG QUARTER FOR CISCO -- Cisco Systems reported a 34 percent growth in quarterly profits that it attributed to strong demand for high-speed Internet service. Cisco, the largest maker of networking equipment, said that its revenue increased 21 percent. ''Momentum remains very strong,'' said John T. Chambers, above, Cisco's chairman and chief executive. [C9.] ENVISIONING THOMSON-REUTERS -- Thomson, the Canadian electronic information company, sketched out the details of its offer for the Reuters Group, the financial and general news service. The company would challenge Bloomberg for leadership in the financial data field. [C6.] SIGNS OF A COMEBACK -- Springfield, Mass., has endured closed mills, increased crime, population declines and the threat of bankruptcy proceedings. Now there are glimmers that the city has finally turned the corner. [C7.] A FLAT DAY AWAITING THE FED -- Wall Street battled back from sharp losses to close mostly flat as investors sought opportunities and adjusted their holdings ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting today. [C10.] WOLFOWITZ SEEKS MORE TIME -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. endorsed the request by Paul D. Wolfowitz, the World Bank president, for more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct, a delay that could give the Bush administration time to negotiate his voluntary resignation. [A6.] LIVING WAGE IS LAW IN MARYLAND -- Maryland has approved the nation's first statewide living wage bill, giving fresh momentum to a movement that seeks to raise wages through legislation. [A21.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. AMAZON.COM, THE ONLINE retailer, and I.B.M. said they had settled all their patent-infringement lawsuits and signed a long-term patent cross-license agreement. (REUTERS) DEUTSCHE BANK, the biggest lender in Germany, said that its first-quarter profit rose 30 percent, lifted by its debt and equity trading businesses.
