On Monday, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' seized the title as the night's highest-rated show among adults 18 to 49, while NBC's ''Heroes'' continued to falter with ratings below its prehiatus levels. Nielsen estimated that the ''CSI'' spinoff drew 17 million total viewers during the 10 p.m. hour. For the night, CBS and ABC tied for first. ABC posted an advantage in total viewers as ''Dancing With the Stars'' dominated from 8 to 9:30 (19.1 million). NBC was third among adults 18 to 49 but fourth in total viewers behind Fox. Though ''Heroes'' remained No. 1 in the highly competitive 9 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 demographic, it ranked third in total viewers in the time slot (11.1 million), just head of Fox's ''24'' (10.9 million). During the first full week of May sweeps, which ended Friday, ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' won every night in both total viewers and among adults 25 to 54. ''World News'' drew an average of 8.1 million viewers, while NBC's ''Nightly News With Brian Williams'' ranked second with 7.5 million. CBS's ''Evening News With Katie Couric'' was in third, averaging 6.1 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

A theater review on Thursday about ''Coram Boy,'' at the Imperial Theater, misstated the definition of the term Coram boy. It refers to a child abandoned by his parents, not an orphan. (It is derived from the name of Thomas Coram, who in the 18th century established the Foundling Hospital to care for abandoned children in London.)

As depicted in Tsai Ming-liang's ''I Don't Want to Sleep Alone,'' Kuala Lumpur is a city of smoky alleyways and empty, half-lighted streets, where a few solitary, sad-looking souls stand out from the crowds. In other words, it is not so different from Taipei, whose unreliable plumbing and ambient anomie have fueled Mr. Tsai's imagination in the past. His Kuala Lumpur -- the capital of his native country, Malaysia, but not a city where he has filmed before -- is a polyglot metropolis of drifters and immigrants. The three main characters speak Chinese, Malay and Bengali -- or would, if they ever said anything. The protagonists in Mr. Tsai's films are about as likely to speak as he is to move the camera. When either thing happens, you take note, but for the most part the movies manage quite nicely in stillness and silence.

MEYER--Manfred H. BarIlan University and its American Friends mourn the passing of Manfred H. Meyer z''l. An esteemed Honorary Alumnus, Manfred Meyer and his late wife, Eva, z''l, established the Rabbi Dr. Jacob Hoffman chair in the History of Halacha in honor of Rabbi Jacob Hoffman and the Nathan and Sara Meyer Outreach Program for the Dissemination of Judaism in the Ludwig and Erica Jesselson Institute for Advanced Torah Studies at Bar-Ilan University. Mr. Meyer will be greatly missed by all his friends and admirers. We extend heartfelt condolences to his son, David (Paulette), and the entire family. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Peter Rzepka, President, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University

Chocolates for Mother's Day can come in an elegant navy blue silk faille box, like this assortment from Cova, a chocolatier in Milan that has been in business since 1817, first next to La Scala opera house, and since 1950 on the chic Via Montenapoleone. The bonbons are extremely traditional -- no wildly experimental truffles here -- but they offer deep, chocolaty satisfaction, occasionally played off against creamy hazelnut gianduja. The chocolates are $45 for seven ounces at Caviar Russe, 538 Madison Avenue (54th Street), (212) 980-5908 or (800) 692-2842; caviarrusse.com. Other assortments are also available.

There was no conflict of interest in Gov. Jon S. Corzine's conduct during labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic and financial relationship, an ethics panel reported on Tuesday. Mr. Corzine, a Democrat, appointed the Ethics Advisory Panel last month to review his actions in the talks after questions were raised about his relationship, before he became governor, with Carla Katz, the president of Local 1034 of the Communications Workers of America.

The versatility of the olive has been proven in a newfangled way. Crisp but delicate little ''petals'' of dried tapenade, or olive paste, can be used for snacking, dipping and artfully garnishing a slice of tomato, a disk of fresh goat cheese atop a salad, a portion of poached fish, scrambled or poached eggs, or a risotto. They are made at Moulin du Calanquet, an artisanal olive farm in St.-Rémy-de-Provence, France. The green ones are mild and herbaceous, the black are earthier and saltier. Fairway sells them in boxes of about 60 (1.25 ounces) for $6.99.

SPIER - ALBANO--Frances Disosway, 97, died in peace at home in Manhattan on May 2, 2007. From an old New York family, one branch dating to Staten Island in the 1700s another to Massachusetts in the 1600s, she lived her entire life in New York City, within blocks of where she was born, also at home. A graduate of The Brearley School, widely traveled, she was first married to Charles L. Stillman, of Time Inc., then to Lester C. Spier, M.D., and lastly to Salvatore Albano, all deceased. She was the proud mother of three devoted children Charles L. Stillman, Jr. (deceased), Stanley Wells Stillman, and Louise Stillman Lehrman and two stepdaughters -Marcia Ann Spier (deceased), and Carol Spier Riley. Her children gave her 15 grandchildren and 29 great-grandchildren. In addition she is survived by one niece and three nephews. A memorial service is planned for Monday, June 4th, at 3:00pm, St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street, NYC 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be to St. James Church, clergy discretionary fund, or to her cherished Huguenot Society of America, Staten Island Fund, in memory of Frances Disosway Johnson, 122 East 58th Street, New York, NY 10022

Here are a couple of new ways to have someone else do the shopping and cooking. The Dish's Dishes, started less than a year ago by Jill Donenfeld, a Columbia graduate who worked at Little Giant on the Lower East Side, employs six young cooks, among them Jared Lewin, right, shopping in the Union Square Greenmarket, and Josie Gordon, above, cooking in a couple's Upper East Side kitchen.

Is there a dish in this city -- nay, world -- that can hold your attention when an octave-challenged woman is braying into a microphone, apparently convinced that nothing more than a lack of exposure kept her from Gwen Stefani's career? I'm not sure. But I know it's not on the menu at the new restaurant Spotlight Live, where the spirit of ''American Idol'' meets a high-low, erratically executed hodgepodge of pigs in a blanket ($10); filet mignon with wild mushrooms ($32); steamed halibut with lemon grass ($29); spaghetti with meatballs ($18); and spicy orange beef ($21). Onstage is a succession of ebullient amateur acts. Subtract the ebullience and what's on the table is pretty much the same.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released a letter yesterday urging Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to reconsider limits on the use of gun trace data compiled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The limits bar the bureau from releasing gun-trace data except to police officials and prosecutors working on a particular crime. The mayor sent a copy of the letter to members of Congress. He wrote that although the chief argument supporting the limits concerns protecting the anonymity of undercover officers, no one ''has been able to identify a single instance when trace data compromised the anonymity of an officer or the integrity of an investigation.'' Erik Ablin, a Justice Department spokesman, said the limits were in keeping with the bureau's ''longstanding policy of disclosing firearms trace results only to the law enforcement agency that recovered the crime gun.'' DIANE CARDWELL

Gov. Deval Patrick on Tuesday unveiled a $1.25 billion proposal intended to help the state maintain its status as a pre-eminent place for stem cell research and other life sciences. The money would provide grants for university and hospital scientists, establish special research centers to make their work faster and more efficient, and train workers for biotechnology businesses.

VOSE--Elliott Evans, of New York City and Quogue, New York, died on Saturday January 13th of pneumonia. He was a graduate of Phillips Academy Andover 1942, Yale College 1945w and the Yale Law School 1950. He served in the US Navy on a PT Boat in the Pacific during World War II. After practicing law at Winthrop, Stimpson, Putnam and Rogers he joined the Singer Corporation and later the Grumman Corporation where he retired as a Senior Vice President. He served as President of the Quogue Field Club and the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, New York. He was a former Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Southampton Hospital. He is survived by his wife Ann Cogswell Vose and three stepdaughters, Esme Murphy Klopp, Aleta Murphy Gleason, and Nona Murphy Collin, and five grandchildren, Eugenie and Francis Gleason, Katherine Elliott Collin, and Harrison and Esme Klopp. A private memorial will be held. In lieu of flowers the family would be grateful for contributions sent in Elliott's memory to the Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meeting House Lane Southampton, NY 11968, or a charity of one's choice.

An article on March 29 about the breakup of two illegal Internet sports gambling operations, in New York and New Jersey, gave an erroneous identification from prosecutors for the hometown of Joseph Pasquale, one of those accused of leading the New Jersey operation. He is from Brick, N.J., not Mantoloking. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on April 2; this correction was delayed until the reporter returned from vacation and verified the information.

The future of the long-running drama ''Law & Order'' may not be on NBC. To the Editor: Eric Asimov and his panel of gin adjudicators overlooked a mixture of spirits that is my candidate for the perfect martini (Gins of The Times: ''No, Really, It Was Tough: 4 People, 80 Martinis,'' May 2). It's called the San Francisco martini and may have originated at the bar in the Mark Hopkins hotel, where I discovered it some years ago. In my experience, it has never been surpassed for the subtlety of its juniper flavor, its silky smoothness and its pleasurable kick: five parts vodka to one part gin and no frilly French vermouth. Charles Michener New York To the Editor: Congratulations on Step 1. You have identified the gin that goes best with Noilly Prat. But as you wrote, ''What is a cocktail but a blend of disparate elements?'' You should now repeat the experiment with at least a few other dry vermouths, which I think are as variable in flavor as gins. My favorite vermouth for a martini is Boissière extra dry. If you buy good gin and poor vermouth you can't get a good martini. After matching vermouths and gins, then you can match the best combinations of gin and vermouth for a grand-prize winner. Doug Bly Rockville, Md. To the Editor: It may surprise Mr. Asimov to learn that an important reason people drink vodka martinis rather than the real McCoy is the fear of severe headaches that the gin version engenders. I am one of those sufferers, and I must admit that I violate the proscription occasionally to experience the nirvana of a true martini. The ensuing suffering is occasionally deemed worthwhile. David T. Mintz Scarsdale, N.Y. To the Editor: I greatly enjoyed the article on the martini, although perhaps not as much as I would have had I been invited to the tasting! The article neglected to mention olives, which are the classic ''third ingredient'' in this cocktail. The salty, oily addition of (precisely) three high-quality green olives completes this classic drink. Jesse Hackell Suffern, N.Y.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about Chien-Ming Wang's pitching effort in the Yankees' 8-1 victory against the Seattle Mariners referred incorrectly in some copies to Wang's postgame comments. He spoke to reporters in English, not through an interpreter.

Andrea Tsakanikas, who owns a property management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., saw homeowners' attitudes toward hurricane preparation change dramatically after severely damaging storms hit the state in 2004 and 2005. ''We saw a huge change,'' said Ms. Tsakanikas, owner of Florida Luxury Rentals, which manages 56 homes in Fort Lauderdale, including many waterfront properties. ''Owners added shutters if they didn't have them, or installed impact-resistant glass to protect their homes. I can't think of a house now that isn't protected. I couldn't say that two years ago.''

LAWTON--Nancy. Noted artist Nancy Lawton died in Albany, NY, on May 5th, 2007, after a courageous five-year battle with cancer. She was 57 years old. Ms. Lawton studied art at California State University at San Jose, and received her MFA at the Massachusetts College of Art, Boston, in 1980. Graphite and silverpoint drawings were her milieu. In 1982 Ms. Lawton's drawings caught the attention of Gene Baro, curator at the Brooklyn Museum, and the following year Baro organized a solo retrospective of her drawings at the Museum and purchased eight for its collection. Today, Ms. Lawton's drawings also reside in the collections of the Art Institute of Chicago, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and the Albany Institute of History and Art. She has been represented by Hirschl & Adler Modern, New York, since 2001. Ms. Lawton is survived by her husband, Dr. Richard Enemark, Headmaster of the Doane Stuart School in Albany; her two children, Faith and Forrest; her father, Edward Lawton, of Santa Clara, CA; and her sister, Carol Lawton, of Fremont, CA. A memorial service will be held at a future date. The family requests that donations in Ms. Lawton's memory be made to the American Cancer Society or the Campaign for the Doane Stuart School, in lieu of flowers.

At least 39 people died late Monday when a bus carrying 103 textile workers collided with a tractor-trailer truck in northern Lesotho, a police spokesman said. The accident occurred while the bus, traveling between Maputsoe, a garment-making center on the South Africa border, and Fobane, a village about 15 miles south, was on a winding road. One or both vehicles may have been speeding, the police said. MICHAEL WINES

An entry in the Transactions column of the Square Feet pages of Business Day last Wednesday about a recent lease at 17 Battery Place South in Manhattan misstated the annual rent. It was $31.44 a square foot -- not $44 a square foot, which was the asking price before the deal was signed.

When Martha and Elton Hyder of Fort Worth began building a vacation home in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, in 1959, people there still got their water from an ancient spring, and telephones were scarce. ''We had to go to the hotel down the street to use the phone, and we only had water from 6 to 10 in the morning.'' Mrs. Hyder recalled. ''We learned quickly to fill up the bathtubs first thing and bathe the children, then keep the rest of the water for later. That was San Miguel back then.''

A front-page article on Friday about the decision of a few school districts nationwide to phase out school-issued laptops, which they say hinder rather than help student achievement, gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for part of the name of a private boarding school in western Massachusetts that eliminated its five-year-old laptop program in 2002. It is the Northfield Mount Hermon School, not Herman.

A report sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations, the nongovernmental, nonpartisan organization with headquarters in New York, said the United States should devote significant resources and diplomatic effort to developing ties with Angola, the second largest oil producer in sub-Saharan Africa after Nigeria, and strategically important for ensuring a steady supply of oil and the stability in the oil-rich Gulf of Guinea region. It noted that Angola had one of the world's fastest-growing economies but remained one of the world's least-developed countries. ''Cronyism and the labyrinthine bureaucracy that businesses must navigate to turn a profit frighten away all but the most courageous investors,'' the report said. CELIA W. DUGGER

JACOBSON--Alvin, of Cortlandt Manor passed away Tuesday, May 8th, 2007. He was born on February 8, 1929 in the Bronx and was the son of the late Louis and Rosalind Jacobson. Alvin was the devoted husband of Anita Weinrib Jacobson, whom he was married to for 55 years, and the beloved father of Debra, Seth and Fran Jacobson, and Beth Deckert. He was also predeceased by his daughter Lois Jacobson, and is survived by eleven grandchildren and three step grandchildren. Following in his mother's footsteps, Alvin was a great supporter of the Gan Yavne Youth Village in Israel, where his contributions were used to build a new dormitory for the college. He had many accomplishments during his life including being an active race horse owner, of which several were champions. Following his mother he held the position of President of Jay Company for 30 years, a large distributor of trims to the fashion industries, and also was owner of Alvin Jacobson Realty, and of Croton Realty and Development with holdings both in NYC and Westchester county. He was a graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and Kansas State University, from which he graduated in three years with a degree in business. He also served in ROTC while attending school. Alvin was an avid card player, gardener and birder. Services are scheduled for Thursday, 10:00am, at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester with interment to follow in the Cedar Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Gan Yavne Village would be appreciated, 212-367-8125. For information please call The Garlick Funeral Homes, 914235-5341

Doug Mientkiewicz spoke at length about his hitting before the Yankees played the Texas Rangers last night. Mientkiewicz, the Yankees' first baseman, explained the nuances of his swing, his mind-set and his health. Then he simplified it. André Boisclair, left, the leader of the separatist Parti Québécois, resigned, further destabilizing an independence movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March. ''The current conditions don't allow me to do this anymore,'' he said. The party was poised to have a strong showing in the elections, with some even predicting a win for the separatists, who want Quebec to be a nation. But instead they had their worst showing in decades. When he was elected party leader in November 2005, Mr. Boisclair, 41, made headlines for being openly gay and for admitting to having used cocaine while a cabinet minister. His relative youth also marked a departure from previous sovereignty leaders, most of whom traced their roots to the party's founding in the late 1960s. He fought back tears as he announced his resignation, ending it with a familiar rallying cry among separatists: ''Vive le Quebec!'' CHRISTOPHER MASON

A music review on April 23 of the singer-songwriter Loreena McKennitt, at Radio City Music Hall, misstated the timing of PBS's showing of a concert of hers recorded in Spain in September. It has in fact already been shown, in March.

The police arrested a 40-year-old native of Bosnia, now a Norwegian citizen, on suspicion of committing war crimes against Bosnian Serbs while serving in an ethnically Croatian military unit in 1992. The man, who in keeping with Norwegian police practice was not identified, faces up to 21 years in a Norway prison if convicted on charges of assault, rape and illegal detention at a prison camp during the wars over the former Yugoslavia. The police have said they are investigating 70 immigrants to Norway who are suspected of war crimes in a number of countries. The arrested man arrived in Norway with his family in 1993 and received citizenship in 2001. WALTER GIBBS

INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Iraqi Adviser Seeking Patience From Congress Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser to Iraq's prime minister, undertook what may have been his most challenging mission yet: trying to persuade American lawmakers who have all but run out of patience that more patience is required. A1 House Democrats moved to try to build support for a war-spending proposal that would provide $30 billion for combat operations in Iraq through midsummer, but require a second round of Congressional votes on beginning a troop withdrawal or continuing the war. A16 Power Sharing in Ulster Paying tribute to the thousands of victims in one of Europe's bloodiest sectarian conflicts, the leaders of Northern Ireland drew a formal line under decades of hostility and strife, re-establishing a power-sharing local authority of once implacable foes. A8 Reformers Split in Zimbabwe As President Robert G. Mugabe's 27-year rule enters what many analysts call a terminal phase, the selfproclaimed democratic opposition is near its nadir. The Movement for Democratic Change is split into two opposed factions, warring over ideology and prestige. A1 Pope Makes Latin America Trip Pope Benedict XVI is scheduled to arrive for his first foray into Latin America, hoping to stanch the church's steady loss of followers in the region. But some faithful wonder if an 80-year-old pontiff from Germany can speak to their needs. A3 NATIONAL A17-22 Debate With White House After Kansas Tornado For months, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas warned that the state's National Guard was ill-prepared for the next local disaster because of large deployments of its soldiers and equipment to Iraq and Afghanistan. Ms. Sebelius said the Guard's emergency response to the recent deadly tornado was too slow, prompting a debate with the White House, which initially said the fault rested with her. A1 New Advocacy for a Disability Convinced that more couples would choose to continue their pregnancies if they better appreciated what it meant to raise a child with Down syndrome, a growing group of parents are seeking to offer their own positive perspectives. A1 Divide Over Immigration Bill Key senators said that they had agreed on the outlines of a bipartisan bill that would toughen border enforcement and provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrants, but they remain deeply divided on many of the details. A18 Education Official Steps Down The head of the federal Education Department unit responsible for oversight of the federal student loan program, Theresa S. Shaw, will step down next month, the department announced. A21 SCIENCE/HEALTH Massachusetts Research Plan Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts unveiled a $1.25 billion proposal for helping the state maintain its status as a pre-eminent place for stem cell research and other life sciences. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Six Muslim Men Charged In Plot to Attack Fort Dix Federal authorities charged six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia with plotting to attack the Fort Dix Army base with automatic weapons and possibly even rocket-propelled grenades. According to secretly taped conversations, the men vowed ''to kill as many soldiers as possible.'' A1 Churches Fight Deportation Religious congregations in New York and four other cities will announce a campaign today to provide sanctuary to illegal immigrants who have been targeted with deportation. The campaign recalls a movement that challenged United States policies in Central America in the 1980s. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Anemia Drugs Pushed The drug companies Amgen and Johnson & Johnson are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for prescribing anemia medicines, which regulators say may be unsafe at commonly used doses. Critics say the payments give doctors an incentive to prescribe the medicines at levels that increase risks of heart attacks or strokes. A1 Former Dow Executives Sue Two former executives have sued Dow Chemical, claiming they were defamed. Dow Chemical, in turn, is suing them. The two executives, Romeo Kreinberg and J. Pedro Reingard, were dismissed after they were accused of speaking with third parties about a possible sale of Dow. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: The Democrats' pledge; saving, not victimizing, children; science fiction sneaks up; Carla Anne Robbins on wrestling nuclear genies back into the bottle. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E8 Obituaries B9 TV Listings E9 Weather A20

After my column Thursday lamented the lack of a photogenic puppy that could focus public sympathy on the Darfur genocide, I had this remarkable email from an American who until recently worked in Sudan. Call ABC News -- finally they'll cover the story!

Sports Illustrated has a terrific column about Mia Farrow, the champion of the campaign to pressure China to behave better in Darfur. Mia has been relentless on Darfur and has used her megaphone to back the "genocide Olympics" campaign. The idea isn't to boycott the Olympics, but to make China realize that its Olympic dream will be marred if it continues to underwrite genocide in Sudan.

That great pipe-puffing philosopher of the Nixon presidency, John Mitchell, once famously observed: "Watch what we do, not what we say." In other words, forget the rhetoric and pay attention to the more telltale actions of what eventually became a disgraced administration.

So President Bush, it seems, confounded expectations and managed to keep it together for Queen Elizabeth II's state visit this week. He didn't slobber, chug-a-lug from an Evian bottle, spew bits of buttered roll or engage in any impromptu shoulder massages.

Then the Village Voice raised questions about whether he got a discount on four diamond rings commemorating the Yankees' recent World Series rings. Could the week get any tougher for Mr. Giuliani?

MySpace has it out for Iowa and New Hampshire. First, the social networking site announced that it would hold the first primary of 2008, letting its users pick their favorite candidate throughout the first two days of January. Now it's trying to break the early primary states' monopoly on intimate, unrehearsed meetings with the candidates by offering all 66 million of its unique monthly visitors the chance to participate in town hall forums with the presidential candidates.

Just when everyone expected to arrive at the first European race of the season - notice I avoid using that phrase "the start of the European season," since this particular European season will only last two races before the circus moves on for the start of the North American season?! - and everyone expected to see all sorts of new motor homes representing various states of team dreams of grandeur...and when everyone expected that the most ostentatious display of the motor home art would likely come from McLaren, it turns out that the greatest example of motor home decadence yet to appear in the paddock comes from the team one least expected to see it come from: Ferrari. (That run-on Jamesian sentence, by the way, would be accept nowhere else today outside this blog.... My apologies.)
A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times reviews "I Don't Want to Sleep Alone," set in the slums of Kuala Lumpur.
A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times, reviews "28 Weeks Later," the sequel to the 2003 film "28 Days Later."
Joe Torre, the Yankees manager, said Thursday that his brother, Frank, has returned to the intensive care unit of an area hospital due to an infection that followed a recent kidney transplant.
Rich and poor countries are deeply divided on many fronts, but perhaps none more so than on the question of who should do what about human-caused global warming.

Overstock.com, which has a huge short position, has drawn my attention a few times in the past. (For blogs, see here. For columns, see here, here, here, and here.) I am attracted to the story because Patrick Byrne, the chief executive, has engaged in what he called a jihad against naked short sellers, who sell the shares without borrowing them, and has had some political success. I am more impressed by his jihad-making activity than by his corporate management, but he is certainly different from your average chief executive. He has sued an analyst firm, a hedge fund and most of the major Wall Street firms. An S.E.C. investigation is pending.

If you want to start an argument in the wine world - and believe me, it's not hard to do - all you have to do is mention the word terroir. It is one of the most overused, overworked, misunderstood and misrepresented clichés in wine, though it does have some stiff competition.

Following the publication Wednesday of my article on Pizzeria Mozza, I received several e-mails from readers that represented the kind of discussion - quibbles, observations, suggestions - that should be seen by more eyes than just my own. It's the kind of discussion encouraged by, and often present on, this blog.
Items collected from California's freeways and shoulders are shown in this public service announcement.
F. David Radler must have known that testifying against his boss of 30 years wouldn't be easy. But did he think it was going to get as heated as it did today?
The Empire Zone weighs in with more news from the sizzling debate over the state budget. Is it $121 billion? Is it $123.9 billion?
When Jorge Posada batted for the Yankees in the fourth inning, the message beside his picture on the scoreboard said that he led the American League with a .360 batting average.

The online marketing firm 24/7 Media on Wednesday disclosed that it has hired Lehman Brothers to help it assess "strategic alternatives," adding credence to rampant speculation that the company is up for sale. The New York Post reported this week that both WPP Group, the London-based advertising and marketing group, and software gaint Microsoft were "leading contenders" to buy 24/7, which has a market capitalization of about $560 million.
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.

Facing criticism from unions and lawmakers, the private equity industry has found a passionate champion on the Internet. The only problem is that it's unclear who that person is. Percywalker.com, a financial blog of murky provenance, has entered the debate on the taxation of "carried interest," a big source of fees for the people who run private equity funds. The blog claims to be written by a billionaire named Percival X. Walker, but when contacted last year by Forbes magazine -- which failed to find any mention of Mr. Walker in public documents -- the operator of the blog said: "I lack the desire to establish that I even exist."

With Paul D. Wolfowitz today getting more time to respond to charges that he mishandled his companion's reassignment and pay package, it seemed like a good time to take a look at the woman in question, Shaha Ali Riza.
We've begin to think they might want to add a few words to the traditional wedding vow: " 'Til death -- or insider trading charges -- do us part."

Yankee Stadium's upper deck has a classical sweep. Despite the remodeling of the 1970s, the look is traditional, with three rows of lights above the highest rows of seats and only the sky above the lights. On most days.
Time for The Empire Zone's budget minute, where we distill a new 205-page budget analysis [pdf] from the comptroller's office into four bullet points.

A former Morgan Stanley compliance lawyer and her husband pleaded guilty to insider trading in federal court Thursday, the latest pleas in a wide-ranging investigation that has touched employees at some of Wall Street's top firms.

For the second consecutive game, Jason Giambi was not in the Yankees lineup due to a bone spur on his left heel. Manager Joe Torre said Giambi had a 10:30 a.m. appointment with a foot specialist but was expected back in time for this afternoon's game with Texas.
Wil Nieves, the backup catcher for the Yankees, broke an 0-for-22 streak Wednesday night when he singled during the Yankees' 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.
Last night, a Palestinian minister appeared to answer a torrent of outrage when he announced the suspension of a children's television show starring a Mickey Mouse clone who spouts Islamist slogans.

In the great quest to name Lonesome George's new mate, I think the most promising new suggestions have come from those who know him best: the biologists who've been studying him. But readers also came up with some excellent nominations.

Cogentrix Energy, an electricity producer owned by the investment bank Goldman Sachs, has put 14 power plants up for sale, the energy industry Web site SparkSpread reported Thursday. Cogentrix itself, which Goldman acquired in 2003 for $115 million, is not up for sale, the Web site said.

The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was "a phenomenal achievement," Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.'s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journal's Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that "in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well."
New shows in New York include "Deuce" and "God's Ear."
British Prime Minister Tony Blair announced that he would leave office on June 27 after a decade in power.

"Web 2.0," as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people's travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn't supply their materials.

Nine years after the math whizzes at Long Term Capital Management found themselves on the brink of a market-rattling collapse -- which they narrowly averted thanks to a huge bailout by a consortium of banks -- some of the hedge fund's former employees are having a reunion of sorts. Bloomberg reports that Eric Rosenfeld, one of Long Term Capital's co-founders, has joined with the fund's former chief financial officer, Robert Shustak, and its former controller, Bruce Wilson, to open Quantitative Alternatives, which Bloomberg describes as a hedge fund that "uses computers to pick investments." The fund apparently uses humans too: The Rye Brook, N.Y.-based firm is currently hiring research analysts and traders.

The discovery of slightly elevated amounts of tetrachloroethylene, an industrial chemical also known as perc, in the water supply in Hollis, Queens, dredges up memories of past scares about the safety of the city's water supply.
There are dozens or hundreds of huge Web 2.0 ideas that have yet to materialize.

Strategies to stem Iraq's insurgency can be debated, but few would disagree that no matter what tack is taken, the violence there is not about to come to a halt anytime soon. So the United States is taking steps to try to save more lives when the enemy lands a blow.
By MARJORIE CONNELLY
I would like to travel to Oaxaca, Mexico and experience the festival of Día de los Muertos at the end of October/early November this year. Which groups offer good tours for this event?
Last night's Yankees' lineup had a slightly different look. Jason Giambi was not in it for the game against Texas at Yankee Stadium due to a bone spur on his left heel.
Back so soon?

Rudolph W. Giuliani is about to test decades of Republican precedent. Rather than walking the abortion tightrope ("hate it" personally, support choice as public policy, but would nominate "strict constructionist" judges), Mr. Giuliani plans to forthrightly express his support for abortion rights in upcoming appearances, report The Times's Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora. Will his strategic primary choices and post-9/11 leadership image be enough to help him clear this traditional hurdle?

Her arrival at a fashion show usually set off a current of excitement: "Ah, there's Isabella. What's she got on?" It could be a McQueen couture dress, corseted and padded, so as to show off her figure. She wore McQueen better than anyone else; the clothes were realized on her in a way they were not on other women, and probably because she understood their entire aesthetic history. The meeting of Izzy Blow and Lee McQueen must have been one of those moments when you would have gladly consented to be a fly, just to observe the action. How would he have reacted to this woman? Knowing Izzy, she would have been smoking, the red lipstick stain going well up the paper. She would have almost certainly been wearing one of Philip Treacy's hats; she had already recognized his talents. And her enthusiasm and energy would have been limitless, and a little terrifying.

Prime Minister Tony Blair has announced that he will leave office on June 27 after a decade in power in which he sacrificed his popularity to the war in Iraq and struggled at home to improve schools, policing and hospitals.

Coming soon from London-based development company YOO: three 26-storey towers for a total of 343 luxury beachfront residences in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico that are scheduled for completion the end of 2009. The full-ownership development, called Icon Vallarta, includes 336 one-, two-, and three-bedroom apartments as well as seven individually designed ocean-view villas.
See the churches, lofts, galleries, museums and silos where you can hear music, far from New York's madding clubs.
“Casting About,” from the documentary filmmaker Barry J. Hershey, is a record of casting calls for actresses in a dramatic feature that Mr. Hershey wrote but has yet to direct.
In “Duck,” Philip Baker Hall is a lonely widower who finds a purpose in life when an orphaned duckling comes his way.

An illegal Hamascot? The Los Angeles Times editorial page encourages Disney to sue Hamas over "Farfur, a Mickey Mouse clone that until recently hosted 'Tomorrow's Pioneers,' a kids' television show on Hamas' Al Aqsa TV station." The editorial quotes the "cartoon rodent" as saying, "We will liberate Al Aqsa, inshallah; we will liberate Iraq, inshallah; and we will liberate the Muslim countries invaded by murderers." Could Disney's ferocious army of copyright lawyers bring down a sponsor of international terrorism? Maybe:
Giving “inspirational” a good name, Matt Ruskin’s vibrant and soulful documentary “The Hip Hop Project” sets its universal message to an inner-city beat.
Written and directed by Mark Brown, “The Salon” is a battlefield of finger-snapping, head-thrusting attitude.

Even as its stock is riding high off the success of the iPod and anticipation of the iPhone, Apple will face some restive shareholders at its annual meeting Thursday, TheStreet.com reported. Labor unions who own Apple shares through pension funds, have put up proposals that require options to be priced on the day they are granted to eliminate the practice known as backdating; that give investors a nonbinding vote on executive compensation, known as "say on pay"; and that tie executive bonuses to the company's stock performance.

In the continuing battle over Biosite, a maker of laboratory medical tests, Inverness Medical Innovations has raised its bid to $92.50 a share, topping a rival bid by Beckman Coulter. Biosite said Thursday that it had received a letter from Inverness, which already holds a stake of about 5 percent in the company.
The documentary “ShowBusiness” makes one marvel at the stamina of artists who devote themselves to a world of many miseries and few rewards.

Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, on Wednesday defended his unsolicited offer for Dow Jones, which has run into opposition from the Bancroft family, the company's controlling shareholders, and from Dow Jones employees.

Following a report that Alltel, a rural wireless telecom service provider, is being courted by a slew of private equity firms, TheDeal.com suggests that the company might be too healthy to be a viable candidate for a leveraged buyout.

ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barrett's departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

In an era of skyrocketing pay for chief executives and growing shareholder angst about it, a handful of C.E.O.s are opting to draw a $1 paycheck or none at all. Seven C.E.O.s in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index were paid $1 or less in 2006, including Apple's Steven P. Jobs and Google's Eric Schmidt.

Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. "Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class," Skip McGee, Lehman's head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

Wall Street brokerage firms are on edge awaiting a decision next week by the Securities and Exchange Commission's chief, Christopher Cox, that could put nearly $300 billion of their client's money in limbo.

Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last fall losing some $6 billion, has agreed to pay more than $716,000 to settle charges of violating securities rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city's attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West's, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

Taking another step toward leaving bankruptcy, Northwest Airlines said a majority of its creditors has approved its reorganization plan. Based on its unofficial count, 97 percent of the creditors that voted approved Northwest's plan, the airline said.
May 10 - The Curve is a pleasant and logical descendant of the Pearl.

In its IPO Report, MarketWatch.com notes that public offerings from Chinese companies listing in the United States are being well-received on Wall Street, although two new listings last week had mixed results.

The torch, it seems, has been passed. During an annual meeting that The Chicago Tribune notes was more noteworthy for its symbolism than its substance, Tribune's chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, welcomed the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell to the Tribune board on Wednesday and all but said goodbye to its largest, most antagonistic shareholder, California's Chandler family.

The pace of mergers and acquisitions in the biotechnology industry is expected to continue at a torrid pace through 2007, said panelists at the Biotechnology Industry Organization conference in Boston on Wednesday. The bullish forecast was issued after a recent Ernst & Young report found that biotech deals in the United States were valued at a record $23 billion in 2006 while high premiums drove the value of acquisitions to the second highest level in history.

That was fast. The online video site Joost, the latest venture by the founders of Skype, has raised $45 million in funding from four venture capital and media groups, just a week after introducing the service.

CVRx raised $65 million in a fourth round of funding as the company is poised to launch a pivotal clinical trial to win approval for the first implantable device for modulating high blood pressure. The deal brings total funding in the six-year-old company to $125 million.

UniCredit, Italy's biggest bank, is on the hunt and has Societe Generale and Capitalia in its sights. The bank, which just 18 months ago shelled out $21 billion to take over the HVB Group of Germany, said it is considering making a move either on the French bank or the Italian lender, which is controlled by a group of investors including ABN Amro.

3i, the publicly listed British private equity firm, reaped a record 2.4 billion pounds ($4.8 billion) in sales proceeds from its investments in the past financial year, but expects returns from assets disposals to slow.
A subsidiary of Russia's state-controlled oil company Rosneft bought the remaining production and refining assets of bankrupt Yukos on Thursday at an auction for 165.5 billion rubles ($6.42 billion).

A defense lawyer in Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, on Wednesday by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.
Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.

Shares of TomoTherapy, a venture-backed maker of medical devices, rose 20 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq. It was the year's second-largest initial public offering of a life-sciences company.

Frank Stronach, the chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International, confirmed Wednesday that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, have made a bid for Chrysler, the struggling American unit of DaimlerChrysler.

Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by Tribune, Gannett and McClatchy. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.
Photos from the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Benefit Gala "Poiret: The King of Fashion."

Morgan Stanley agreed Wednesday to pay nearly $8 million to settle federal fraud charges stemming from its reported failure to get retail stock investors the best prices possible on more than a million over-the-counter transactions.

General Electric said Wednesday that it had paid 126.3 billion yen ($1.05 billion) for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credit's stock, the company said. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.
Images from "Poiret: King of Fashion" at the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute.

Venture investors are searching for a new model for alternative energy deals, and partnerships with private equity funds may be part of the solution, The Deal reports. These investors want to get high returns on early developments so they are not diluted when the time comes for raising capital for building production facilities. Volatile energy prices only add to the uncertainty. "It's a very difficult balancing act for venture capital investors in energy right now," the head of the energy ventures group at Portland, Ore.-based law firm Stoel Rives tells The Deal.
The Roundabout Theater Company will open is 2007-8 season with a new production of “Pygmalion,” starring Jefferson Mays as professor Henry Higgins.
ABC’s new series takes young, handsome protagonists and plunges them into an adult world of terrorism and government deceit.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Selections from an anthology subtitled "Seventeen Comics From an Unpleasant Age."
Pope Benedict XVI gave the first substantial press conference of his two year papacy, 35,000 feet above Algeria (on a plane that was still 4,600 miles from his destination, Sao Paulo).

With very low vacancy rates for apartments in New York, real estate brokers say radical solutions among young, well-educated newcomers to the city are becoming more common. Some new arrivals have even made homes in unoccupied office space.
The area of New York City where officials this week found industrial chemicals in the drinking water has had problems with contamination by the same chemicals for several years.
The Israeli prime minister said that the killing of civilians in Qana was a turning point that delayed a resolution.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 10 — President Hosni Mubarak met with Israel’s foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, today and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a peace proposal initiated by Saudi Arabia and endorsed by all members of the Arab League.
The president also said he would veto the House plan, approved on a 221 to 205 vote, which only pays for the next two months of the Iraq war’s costs.
House Democrats questioned the attorney general’s leadership of the Department of Justice.
The vice president framed the troops’ efforts as part of the fight against global terrorism and made no promise that an end was in sight.
After months of coy hints, Prime Minister Tony Blair made the announcement today as part of a closely choreographed and protracted farewell.
A marine testified that he urinated on the bloody remains of one of five unarmed Iraqi men in Haditha whom his squad leader fatally shot in late 2005.

The General Electric Company said today that it had paid 126.3 billion yen or $1.05 billion for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit Company. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credit’s stock, the company said in a statement. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

More than $100,000 worth of illegal steroids were confiscated from a pharmacy yesterday by the New York State Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement, officials said. The authorities were led to a Lowen’s Pharmacy in Brooklyn as part of an investigation by the Albany County district attorney. The investigation so far has led to the prosecution of at least 20 people. Christopher Baynes, an assistant district attorney for Albany County, said that investigators found large amounts of Chinese growth hormone and testosterone that had not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration at Lowen’s Pharmacy. As of last night, no charges had been filed, Mr. Baynes said.

Slightly elevated levels of an industrial chemical have been found in the water supply of as many as 64,000 Queens residents, prompting officials to recommend the use of bottled water for drinking and cooking until the source is determined.
Starter Mike Mussina, regaining his health, worked six innings and gave up two runs and three hits as the Yankees breezed by the Rangers Wednesday night.
A sea change in the art market was stunningly apparent Wednesday night at Christie’s sale of Impressionist and Modern art.

Gardasil vaccine protects against cervical cancer caused by a sexually transmitted wart virus for at least three years and also prevents lesions that can grow into vaginal and vulvar cancer, two studies said. A third study found that the virus might cause a significant number of throat cancers. Gardasil protects against the four strains of the human papillomavirus, or HPV, that cause 70 percent of cases of cervical cancer. The cost of the vaccine, manufactured by Merck, is $360 for six months. That may be too high in poorer countries where HPV is the biggest threat, some experts have said.

The convicted killer Philip R. Workman was executed, the first execution in the state since the release of new state procedures for administering lethal injections. Mr. Workman, who had been on death row since 1982, was executed after the United States and Tennessee Supreme Courts refused to issue a stay. Mr. Workman’s last-minute appeals included challenges to the state’s revised lethal injection protocols. The protocols were released last week after a 90-day review and moratorium on executions.

The House approved legislation that proposes $39.8 billion for the Homeland Security Department next year. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure over its pro-union provision. The measure, which passed 296 to 126, would strike a provision in the 2002 legislation creating the department that allowed the president to waive collective-bargaining rights for department workers.

Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski signed into law legislation creating “domestic partnerships” for same-sex couples starting Jan. 1. Mr. Kulongoski, a Democrat, also signed into law a bill that outlaws discrimination based on sexual orientation, effective the same date. The domestic partnership law enables same-sex couples to enter into contractual relationships with many benefits of marriage. The other law bans discrimination against gay men, lesbians, bisexuals and transgendered people in employment, housing and access to public accommodations.

The Pentagon is setting up an experimental civilian Language Corps, recruiting about 1,000 foreign-language speakers who would volunteer to help the government in times of war and national emergencies. The languages to be included in a three-year pilot program have not been chosen. Robert Slater, who heads the Pentagon personnel office’s security education program, said: “The federal government can’t possibly identify, hire and warehouse professionals with skills in 150 languages. So it’s invaluable to be able to respond in emergencies, whether international or national.”.

South Korea plans to break ground for the world’s biggest solar power plant as it tries to diversify its power sources and use cleaner energy, the government and developers said. The $170 million plant, being built in Shinan, near the southwestern tip of South Korea, is part of an effort to seek new and renewable energy sources and is scheduled to be completed by late 2008. The plant will produce more than 27,000 megawatt-hours of electricity a year, enough to supply 6,000 to 7,000 households, said Kim Ji Hun, president of the Korean subsidiary of SunTechnics, the German solar power company that will build the plant. It will be operated by Dongyang Engineering and Construction.

The investment firm Oaktree Capital Management said it had offered to buy the world’s largest golf club maker, the Fu Sheng Industrial Company of Taiwan, in a deal worth about 28.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($852 million). Oaktree is offering investors 37.50 Taiwan dollars a share in a cash offer for the whole company. Fu Sheng makes clubs for Callaway, left, as well as TaylorMade, Titleist and Wilson brands. The bid is at a 15.7 percent premium to the average 30-day closing price of Fu Sheng’s shares. Fu Sheng’s stock closed 6.91 percent higher yesterday at 36.35 Taiwan dollars a share. The retail market for golf club heads, worth more than $4 billion, is growing globally with the United States making up half of sales and Japan about a third. Oaktree hopes to help Fu Sheng increase sales at its other businesses, like industrial air compressors.

BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. Income climbed to 2.51 billion euros ($3.4 billion), from 2.01 billion euros a year earlier, BNP Paribas said. Revenue rose 21 percent, to 8.21 billion euros. Profit beat the 2.06 billion euros expected by analysts. BNP Paribas’s stock rose 3.65 euros, to 91.15 euros. Pretax profit at the corporate and investment bank rose 12 percent. Earnings at the French branch network declined 2.2 percent, while pretax profit at BancWest, a unit based in Hawaii, slipped 20 percent. Excluding Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, earnings at BNP Paribas’s international retail bank decreased 5.3 percent.

Shares of the mining companies BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Group soared amid speculation about possible takeover bids. Chris Lynch, president of BHP’s carbon steel unit, neither confirmed nor denied speculation that the resources company would make an offer for Rio Tinto. “We’ve obviously looked at a lot of different things,” he said. Mr. Lynch was responding to speculation that BHP, which is based in Melbourne, Australia, could buy Rio Tinto after the market seized on an analyst’s report this week. A Rio Tinto spokesman, Nick Cobban, said the company “is not aware of any approach by BHP Billiton.” Stock in Rio Tinto traded as high as 4,000 pence ($79.71) a share in London before closing up 10.7 percent, to 3,660 pence.

Enel, an Italian utility, said first-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 12 percent, fueled by increased foreign sales and cost cuts. Net income climbed to 943 million euros ($1.28 billion), or 16 cents a share, from 842 million euros, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Enel, which is bidding for the Spanish utility Endesa, sold power in Eastern Europe and Russia in the period to make up for falling electricity demand at home. Costs were reduced by 7.2 percent, helping offset a drop in Italian sales. Sales declined 5.1 percent, to 9.73 billion euros. The bid for Endesa values the company at 43.7 billion euros and will give Enel access to another 22 million customers. The deal will create a platform to sell electricity across borders when the EU energy market opens to competition on July 1.

An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Gordon Scott, an actor who played Tarzan in the 1950s, misspelled his surname at birth. He was Gordon W. Werschkul, not Werschkull. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his surviving brother. He is Rafield Werschkul, not Rayfield.

The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about research into the discrepancy between stock market returns and individual investors’ returns, misstated the average yearly dollar-weighted return for a hypothetical investor who bought 100 shares of a company at $10 a share, then a year later bought 100 more shares when the share price was $20, then sold all 200 shares when the price fell to $10 a share at the end of that second year. The investor’s average yearly return was a negative 26.8 percent, not a negative 16.8 percent.

A police officer who broke up a fistfight in front of his Queens home in August became the target of a murder plot, the authorities said yesterday, when a man he arrested that day tried to hire a hit man from his Rikers Island jail cell.

An article in the special Personal Health section on May 1, about sexually transmitted diseases, misidentified the viruses that cause herpes, the most common sexually transmitted disease in the United States. They are strains of H.S.V., or herpes simplex virus — not H.P.V., or human papillomavirus.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column last Thursday about lawsuits over the ownership of the 16th-century diptych “Adam and Eve,” by Lucas Cranach the Elder, misstated the name of the organization that now owns it. It is the Norton Simon Art Foundation, not the Norton Simon Foundation. The report also misstated the painting’s history. The foundation bought it in the mid-1960s directly from an heir to the Stroganoff dynasty of Russia. It did not buy it at auction.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 1 about an accounting technique used by New Century Financial misstated the year that the company’s chief financial officer, Edward F. Gotschall, stepped down from that job. It was 2004, not 2006. (Mr. Gotschall is still with the company as a vice chairman.).

An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the arrests of six men in New Jersey on charges of plotting to attack the Fort Dix Army base referred imprecisely to the relationship between three suspects — the brothers Eljvir, Dritan and Shain Duka — and a fourth, Mohamad Shnewer. Mr. Shnewer’s sister is married to Eljvir Duka, so only Eljvir — not all three Duka brothers — is legally Mr. Shnewer’s brother-in-law.

Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the six suspects in the Fort Dix case misstated which two of the suspects are brothers-in-law. Eljvir Duka and Mohamad Shnewer are related, not Mr. Duka and Agron Abdullahu. The article also misstated the number of Mr. Shnewer’s sisters. He has five, not two.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 16 about airline food in the special Business Travel section incorrectly attributed comments about a private-jet company, New York Aviation, and about business travelers in general. The comments, “We’ll go into the city and get dinner at Le Cirque if people want it,” about the services New York Aviation provides, and “As long as there’s booze on board, they’re happy,” referring to business travelers, were by Jack Gentile, founder of New York Aviation — not by Hector Adler, senior vice president for customer experience at Eos Airlines.

Picture captions in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of “Radio Golf,” at the Cort Theater, reversed the identities of two actors. In the picture on the cover of the section, the actor on the right was James A. Williams, not John Earl Jelks. In the picture with the continuation of the review, the actor on the left was Mr. Jelks, not Mr. Williams.

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with the Advertising column about cellphones affiliated with particular organizations carried an incorrect credit. The photograph was by Evan J. Thomas — not Michael Caulfield/Wire Image.com for CNN.

An appeals court of the United Nations war crimes tribunal overturned a 2005 conviction for complicity in genocide against a former Bosnian Serb officer, Vidoje Blagojevic, saying it had no proof that he had known of the “genocidal intent” of the perpetrators of the 1995 massacre of Muslims at Srebrenica and provided only logistical support. The court reduced his prison sentence to 15 years from 18, and upheld several related war crimes charges.

An appeals court raised the 2005 prison sentence of a Dutch businessman, Frans van Anraat, to 17 years from 15 for selling chemicals to Saddam Hussein. The chemicals were used in poison gas weapons in the 1980s and against Kurdish villagers. Prosecutors had demanded a conviction for complicity in genocide, but the appeal judges rejected that, saying Mr. van Anraat was driven not by genocidal intent but by greed.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said Chinese officials had informed it that a pig epidemic was under control in Laosi, in southeastern Guangdong Province. China’s Ministry of Agriculture is conducting tests to determine if the disease is porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that began attacking North American and European swine farms in the late 1980s and is the costliest virus for swine herds in the United States. The disease does not infect humans, the United Nations agency said. China reported a similar epidemic of the pig disease to the agency in September.

Left-wing rebels blew up a police truck in Santander Province, killing nine federal officers in one of the worst guerrilla attacks on security forces this year, the authorities said. A police commander said the officers were providing security for workers eradicating coca crops used in cocaine.

Roberto de Jesús Guerra Pérez, a correspondent of the Miami-based PayoLibre and Nueva Prensa Cubana Web sites and for Radio Martí, a United Stated-financed anti-Castro outlet, was released after spending nearly two years in prison on a charge of “disturbing the peace” for taking part in an anti-government protest, the pro-democracy coalition known as the Assembly to Promote Civil Society said in a statement. Twenty dissidents have been freed since President Fidel Castro handed over power to his brother, Raúl, nine months ago, according to the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation.
The attorney general has told aides he believes he has weathered the storm over the prosecutor dismissals.

Heavily armed gunmen stormed a boat just before midnight on Tuesday and seized four American subcontractors in the southern Niger Delta, industry officials said. A Chevron spokesman, Femi Odumabo, termed it a “robbery case.” It brought the number of foreigners kidnapped in the southern oil-producing region in the last 10 days to 32. Earlier Tuesday, militants staged coordinated blasts on three pipelines in the region, the most damaging assault on the country’s oil infrastructure in more than a year. Nigeria has a total production capacity of three million barrels per day, but protests and militant attacks had reduced oil production by 680,000 barrels before the bombings on Tuesday. The Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta, the region’s largest militant group, claimed responsibility for the blasts but not for the Americans’ kidnapping, but it said it was encouraging “all groups to attack all facilities and oil workers” before the inauguration of Umaru Yar’Adua as president on May 29 after an election last month condemned as fraudulent. Voting did not take place at all in many areas of the impoverished Delta region.

Seven soldiers on patrol in the predominately Muslim southern province of Narathiwat died when a bomb exploded near their vehicle. The authorities said it was the deadliest attack against security forces this year and blamed Muslim insurgents.
The company reported a 6.2 percent higher profit on gains at its movie studio and cable networks, including Fox News Channel.
Nine prominent professors are leading an effort to rethink the culture of undergraduate teaching and learning at Harvard.

State prison officials will let a Muslim correction officer wear a skullcap while on duty as part of a settlement of a federal lawsuit claiming that it was unconstitutional for the state to refuse to make religious accommodations for prison guards. The deal, announced yesterday, came after the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit last year on behalf of an officer who said New York’s Department of Correctional Services ordered him in 2005 to stop wearing a kufi, or knitted skullcap, to his job.

A police commander and the owner of an auto yard were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing items from vehicles that had been seized, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said. Sgt. Barry Halpern, 51, of Kenilworth, a 24-year veteran of the Irvington Police Department and commander of the auto squad unit, was charged with second-degree official misconduct and third-degree theft. Mark Minett, 51, of Tinton Falls, the owner of MTS Towing in Irvington, was charged with third-degree theft, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. An inquiry began in January 2006 after several people reported items like laptop computers and power tools missing from their cars. Sergeant Halpern is being held in $50,000 bail and Mr. Minett is being held in $30,000 bail.

The organizers of PrideFest, the gay-themed street fair that generally accompanies the city’s gay pride parade on the last Sunday in June, voted on Tuesday night to tell city officials that they would cancel this year’s festival unless they could find a better location. The members of Heritage of Pride, which organizes the festival and the parade, have said that the previous site, in the West Village, was cramped and dangerous, and that they wanted to move to Chelsea. On April 27, city officials denied permission for the change and urged the organizers to keep the event at the original site. The city’s comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., has sent the mayor a letter urging the city to reconsider.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reached a $51 million deal yesterday to allow one of its tenants, Orient Overseas International Ltd., which is based in Hong Kong, to sell its lease of a Staten Island marine terminal to the board of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, which is buying the lease as an investment. In return for signing off on the $470 million transaction, the authority will receive $16 million in cash, up to $5 million to cover construction costs and a commitment from the pension board to invest $30 million in the Howland Hook terminal.

A 3-year-old boy was found lying unharmed next to his father’s body on Tuesday afternoon near their house in East Patchogue, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Carlton Shaw, 38, had been shot in the chest and was found in a yard next to his house on Amsterdam Avenue about 4:45 p.m., the police said. The shooting was under investigation yesterday.

A woman yesterday admitted fatally beating her father with a hammer in a November 2004 attack, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, of Long Island City, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin admitted repeatedly striking her father, John Martin, 67, in the head in their apartment. She had told the police that he had been killed in a break-in, Mr. Brown said. In exchange for her plea, Ms. Martin will be sentenced to 20 years in prison, Mr. Brown said.

The public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, introduced legislation yesterday that would require the city’s health department to create an online database of birth statistics, including the number of delivery procedures, like Caesarean sections, performed at hospitals. She said the database would help expectant parents choose a hospital. State law requires hospitals to provide women with maternity information, but surveys by Ms. Gotbaum in 2005 and 2006 found that many were not in compliance.
A stubborn brush fire burned nearly a fifth of Griffith Park, in Los Angeles, before firefighters brought the blaze under control on Wednesday.

A real estate investor who was to begin a federal prison sentence next month was run down by a car yesterday and severely injured, the police said. The investor, Steven Green, 42, was struck outside a club, Posh, about 1:30 a.m. while crossing 51st Street, between Ninth and 10th Avenues. The driver fled, the police said. After a fire in one of his buildings in Florida, federal prosecutors charged him with using a false Social Security number to apply for a loan and failing to file tax returns. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced in February to two years and nine months in prison. He was in critical condition yesterday at St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, but his lawyer, Louis Cherico, said his prognosis was good.

The City Council passed legislation yesterday requiring the Buildings Department to notify the Fire Department when alteration permits are issued for buildings. The bill was submitted after a 2006 Bronx fire in which two firefighters were killed when a floor collapsed in a building that had undergone renovations, though the cause of the collapse is still under investigation. The bill passed 51 to 0, and the mayor is expected to sign it.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that he was dusting off his old campaign Web site to promote his work, public and private, on the issues he cares about.

8 P.M. (BBCA) INNOCENT This British import from the producer of “State of Play” follows a team of law students as they re-examine the cases of those they believe wrongly convicted of serious crimes. Lloyd Owen (above, far left) plays their leader, Professor Jon Ford, a champion of the underdog who has established a legal center for those with nowhere else to turn. His team: the idealistic Adam (Luke Treadaway); the passionate Beth (Ruth Bradley); Nick (Oliver James), a charmer; Sarah (Christine Bottomley), who harbors a wealth of useless information; and Andrew (Stephen Graham), on sabbatical from a police department, who just might help the others grow up.

Shirtless and barefoot in his living room two summers ago, Kelly Slater was demonstrating the bodyweight movement inside a radical surf maneuver. I was interviewing Slater about his ongoing rivalry with Andy Irons for an article that ran in PLAY last summer, and Slater radiated balance and calm as he flowed across his floor like a tai chi master. One year later, on surfing’s 2007 World Tour, Slater is showing the same form. Two competitions have been completed, with Irons finishing last in the first one and second in the next — typically erratic. Slater, meanwhile, landed a respectable third and then a fifth, putting him right on target for what many expect to be a slow, steady march to a ninth world title.

The triathlon season is in full swing, but it’s not too late to start training to compete in one, even if you’re starting from the couch. First-timers should focus on the sprint events, such as the popular

Personal heart-rate monitors, which read your pulse and send the number to a wrist-watch-like display, were once balky and pricey. They’re now inexpensive, (starting around $50), reliable and featherweight. One sportswear company, Numetrex, is developing a workout shirt with heart-rate monitoring capabilities woven into the fabric. But does your average athlete need so much data? “Sure,” says Lindsay Hyman, a coach with Carmichael Training Systems who works with elite and professional athletes. “Heart rate helps you refine your training and track your fitness.” Most sporting goods stores sell monitors. To learn how to train with one, click around the Internet. The Tri-eCoach.com site has an estimable overview, as does the Flora London Marathon, which also, for $2.38, offers a downloadable heart-rate monitor guide.

Writing narrative nonfiction is grueling, lonely work haunted by the question of whether anyone will read the finished book. ''You're always worried, 'Am I just banging my head against the wall?' '' said Robert Whitaker, who on Tuesday night was awarded the J. Anthony Lukas Work in Progress Award for ''Twelve Condemned to Die: Scipio Africanus Jones and the Struggle for Justice That Remade a Nation,'' to be published by Crown. Those who persevere, though, are ''working toward an enormous good,'' said Garrison Keillor, the host of this year's Lukas Prize Project Awards, presented at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. He was romantic about unknown writers working in obscurity: ''They are at work at computers, with books stacked on the floor, around them and on tables, and notes, legal pads, scribbles, index cards and Post-it notes and a whole great, beautiful chaos of material, and they are just trying to get the job done.''

An appeals court of the United Nations war crimes tribunal overturned a 2005 conviction for complicity in genocide against a former Bosnian Serb officer, Vidoje Blagojevic, saying it had no proof that he had known of the ''genocidal intent'' of the perpetrators of the 1995 massacre of Muslims at Srebrenica and provided only logistical support. The court reduced his prison sentence to 15 years from 18, and upheld several related war crimes charges. MARLISE SIMONS

Costello; Sr. Nancy McAward, O.P., and Patrick J. McAward. Mrs. Quinn is a graduate of Dominican Academy in Manhattan, NY and the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, NJ.
