Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, May 11, 11:00am, Sacred Heart Church, Bay Head, NJ. Burial on Saturday, May 12 at 12:30pm, Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to their parish of St. Aloysius Church, Church St., Livingston Manor, NY 12758.

There are many eco-friendly home-improvement products on the market and plenty of contractors who know how to use them properly. But finding the right ones can be tricky. Frankly Green, a consulting partnership in Plainfield, N.J., makes it a little easier. Audra Frank, who has been in the painting industry for decades, and her business partner, Karen Halo, steer homeowners to experienced contractors and sell green products like Safecoat, above, a line of paints that come in many finishes, from flat to semigloss. The pair work in the tri-state area, as well as in Maryland and Virginia, but will consult by phone, and can recommend retailers in other parts of the country who sell eco-friendly supplies. For information: (800) 293-2212 or frankly-green.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

FED SEES A SLOWING ECONOMY The Federal Reserve acknowledged that the economy was slowing, but offered little hint that it was ready to lower interest rates anytime soon. The central bank kept the benchmark interest rate on overnight loans at 5.25 percent -- the same level it has been for almost a year. [Page C1.] THE AIRLINE FLIES IT; HE OWNS IT Steven Udvar-Hazy owns more airplanes than any airline in the world. A billionaire three times over and one of the most powerful players in commercial aviation, he is founder and chief executive of a Los Angeles-based company that leases planes to airlines all over the world. [C1.] HBO CHIEF AGREES TO RESIGN Time Warner announced that the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, Chris Albrecht, had agreed to resign at the company's request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot. [C1.] QUESTIONS FOR RESPECTED BANKER David K. P. Li of Hong Kong, who is expected to be questioned by authorities about a possible insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones, is an aristocratic banker who combines wealth, political influence and public service. [C1.] WITNESS'S CREDIBILITY ATTACKED A defense attorney in Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors. [C3.] A LOSS REPORTED BY TXU The TXU Corporation said that it swung to a loss in the first quarter after revenue fell 28 percent and it took a charge to cancel coal-fired power plants, a condition of the company's pending $32 billion sale to private owners.[C2.] MAGNA CONFIRMS CHRYSLER BID The chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International confirmed that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, had made a bid for Chrysler. [C3.] SLOWER PROFIT GROWTH AT TOYOTA Toyota reported another year of record profit but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending. Toyota said its net profit jumped about 20 percent in the fiscal year ended in March, but forecast only a 0.4 percent rise in the current year. The slowdown ''is temporary, as we are planting the seeds'' of future growth, said Toyota's president, Katsuaki Watanabe, above. [C3.] EUROPEAN NAVIGATIONAL SATELLITES The European Commission is abandoning plans to build a satellite navigation system in partnership with private industry. The commission is likely to propose the project be wholly financed by the public sector. [C2.] MICROSOFT AND CAREERBUILDER Microsoft said that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by three big media companies. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising. [C11.] PROFIT 6.2% HIGHER AT NEWS CORP. The News Corporation, which disclosed a surprise bid for Dow Jones & Company last week, reported 6.2 percent higher quarterly profit on gains at its movie studio and cable networks, including Fox News Channel. By far the largest contributor to earnings and revenue growth in the latest quarter was movie and television production, whose profit jumped 82 percent, thanks in part to home video sales of ''Borat'' and the theatrical release of ''Night at the Museum'' and other movies. [C4.] STRENGTHENING THE F.D.A. The Senate passed a bill that gives the Food and Drug Administration new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers. [A1.] MONEY, DRUGS AND INFLUENCE The intersection of money and medicine -- such as payments by a drug company to a prescribing physician -- has become an especially contentious issue in psychiatry, where increasing fees paid to doctors have coincided with the growing use of a relatively new class of drugs. [A1.] BATTLE OF BRITAIN'S TABLOIDS Two free tabloids in Britain are fighting a battle on the streets of London by trying to disprove their competitor's circulation claims. Advertising. [C4.] DRUG TESTING AT WORK A growing number of employers are establishing workplace drug programs, including testing workers for drug use, as a way to prevent accidents and lost productivity caused by substance abuse. Small Business. [C6.] INTEL VS. A.M.D. The fierce rivalry between the chip makers Intel and Advanced Micro Devices is ratcheting up as both companies claim superiority in technology used for notebook computers. [C5.] MARKETS REGAIN STRIDE Wall Street wobbled, then regained its stride after the Federal Reserve told investors what they expected to hear: that inflation is still too high for comfort, but that the central bank is holding interest rates steady. [C13.] MORE TIME FOR WOLFOWITZ The World Bank board, bowing to pressure from the Bush administration, agreed to give Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, slightly more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct before the board decides his future. [A8.] VERIZON CUTS TIES WITH SINGER Verizon has ended its advertising affiliation with Akon, a smooth, Senegalese-American R&B singer, whose conduct in an amateur video circulating online recently seemed to cross a line for the telecommunications company. The move by Verizon has sent a chill through the ranks of touring pop artists and agents. [E1.]

ENSIGN--Richard P. Airline Pioneer. If you have ever enjoyed a glass of champagne or cup of coffee on an airline, used frequent flyer miles, paid less than full fare for your children to fly, or said, ''The Only Way to Fly,'' then you have benefited from Richard Ensign's life. Dick Ensign, a pioneer of the airline industry passed away peacefully on May 1 with his wife, fellow airline pioneer Margaret Ensign, at his side. He was born on January 20, 1919 in Salt Lake City, Utah. He received a B.S. degree in 1941 from the University of Utah where he was VicePresident of the student body, a member of Skull and Bones, the honor society, Owl and Key, leader of the band, and President of Pi Kappa Alpha. He received an MBA from the University of Washington in 1954. Dick began his career at Western Airlines in 1940, loading bags on DC-3 airplanes, and went on to be a member of the Board of Directors. Inbetween he was Vice-President of Passenger Services, where he pioneered many service-related innovations, including developing the first mobile airline serving cart for which he received a patent. He also introduced frequent flyer miles, childrens fares, wine, champagne and coffee on board, and developed Champagne, Fiesta and Hunt Breakfast flights. In 1958, he was awarded the Wine Institute's award for his ''renowned champagne flights'' and for his contributions to ''gracious dining and wine service aloft.'' He also received the Coffee Brewing Institutes Golden Cup Award. In 1971 Dick left Western for Pan American Airlines where he was Senior Vice President of Marketing, Executive Vice-President for World Wide Operations and a Member of the Board of Directors. He returned to Western in 1975 as Executive Vice-President and went on to become a Member of the Board of Directors. He retired from Western in 1981 and became a senior advisor to the President of Caterair as well as the Marriott Corporation. He sat on numerous boards including the Aero Club of Southern California, the Governor's Committee on Tourism, the US Departments of Commerce Advisory Board, Marriott-Japan, Caterair, Korea and the Pacific Area Travel Association. At the University of Utah, he was the Chair of the National Advisory Council, the University's distinguished alumnus in 1976, and the National Fund Raising Chairman from 198283. He also received the Distinguished Services Award from Florida International University in 1973 and Pepperdine University's Ambassador Award in 2001. He is listed in Who's Who in America and the World. Dick believed in service to others, enjoyed music and tennis and loved his family. He is survived by his wife, the former Margaret Hinckley also from Salt Lake City, Utah, five children; Judy, Janie, Rick, Jim and Margee, ten grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Services will be held in Malibu, California and he will be buried in Utah. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be sent to the Joash Foundation c/o Dr. Wesley Moore, UCLA 200 Medical Plaza, Suite 510-6, Los Angeles, California 90095-6908.

Yee-ha!, an irreverent damask wallpaper hand-printed by the wallcovering company Studio Printworks, has gun-toting cowboys on horseback, oil rigs, football helmets and butterflies. Paul Loebach, its designer, describes it as an ''American cultural fantasy,'' and has given the 11 color combinations appropriately tongue-in-cheek names like Oil Slick (silver on a black background) and Blood Brothers (red on red), above. It will be presented at Bklyn Designs, a three-day show starting tomorrow at 10 a.m. at St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, and two other Dumbo locations. A list of venues is at brooklyndesigns.net. For information on Mr. Loebach's wallpaper: (201) 795-9540, extension 21. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

Moderate Republicans gave President Bush a blunt warning on his Iraq policy at a private White House meeting this week, telling the president that conditions needed to improve markedly by fall or more Republicans would desert him on the war. The White House session demonstrated the grave unease many Republicans are feeling about the war, even as they continue to stand with the president against Democratic efforts to force a withdrawal of forces through a spending measure that has been a flash point for weeks.

SHEPARD--Burton L, on May 8, 2007 at age 89. Beloved husband of Sarah, survived by his son Barry, daughter-inlaw Susan, granddaughters Allison, Jacklyn, and Rebecca, stepchildren Susan and Michael Berkowitz. Burton was a devoted husband and father, highly accomplished CPA, loyal NY sports fan, and persevering golfer. An eternal optimist, Burton believed hard work and desire could conquer all of life's challenges. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Association, Alzheimer's Association or American Parkinsons Disease Association.

CLARKE--Merrie Hevrdejs, 48, died on Saturday, May 5, at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford after a courageous battle against breast cancer. Merrie remains in the hearts of her husband, Richard H. Clarke, of Westport; her brother, Frank J. Hevrdejs, of Houston and Pebble Beach, California; and her sister, Patricia M. Hevrdejs, of Portland, Oregon. Merrie was an accomplished designer with numerous high - profile projects to her credit -but her greatest source of pride was her two sons, Julian Patrick Clarke, age 12, and Sean McLean Clarke, age 10, also of Westport. She devoted countless hours to supporting them in their educational and athletic endeavors, learning to love the game of baseball, especially: She will remain, forever and always, their angel in the outfield. Merrie earned a degree in architecture from Washington University in St. Louis and worked as a senior designer at KPF Interior Architects in New York City on projects including the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and the ABC building on Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. She also worked for the Washington, D.C., San Francisco, and New York City offices of Studios Architecture, most recently as an associate principal. While living in Northern California, she established her own firm, M Interiors, as well as the Clarke Powell Design Studio, and was an instructor of design at the California College of the Arts in San Francisco. Merrie also brought her high professional standards and unstinting energy to philanthropic and volunteer work, including as a member of the boards of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, California, as well as to projects for the St. John's Episcopal Church Building Committee in Ross, California. Merrie's parents, Beatrice and Frank Hevrdejs, and sister Jill predeceased her. Merrie will be remembered with a great and eternal love by both family members and the enormous group of people lucky enough to have called her a friend. A memorial service for Merrie Hevrdejs Clarke will be held on May 18 at 1 pm at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York City. Donations in her memory may be made to the Merrie Hevrdejs and Richard H. Clarke Cancer Research Endowment with checks to the Yale Cancer Center, 157 Church Street, New Haven, CT 06510. Development Director: christopher.pates@yale.edu

Floyd Mayweather's split decision against Oscar De La Hoya in Saturday night's superwelterweight title fight generated 2.15 million pay-per-view buys -- eclipsing the 10-year-old record for the second Evander Holyfield-Mike Tyson fight. Mark Taffet, an HBO senior vice president, said the figure was based on reports from cable and satellite operators serving more than 80 percent of the 61 million homes that can order, up from the usual 50 percent.

LAWTON--Nancy. Noted artist Nancy Lawton died in Albany, NY, on May 5th, 2007, after a courageous five-year battle with cancer. She was 57 years old. Ms. Lawton studied art at California State University at San Jose, and received her MFA at the Massachusetts College of Art, Boston, in 1980. Graphite and silverpoint drawings were her milieu. In 1982 Ms. Lawton's drawings caught the attention of Gene Baro, curator at the Brooklyn Museum, and the following year Baro organized a solo retrospective of her drawings at the Museum and purchased eight for its collection. Today, Ms. Lawton's drawings also reside in the collections of the Art Institute of Chicago, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and the Albany Institute of History and Art. She has been represented by Hirschl & Adler Modern, New York, since 2001. Ms. Lawton is survived by her husband, Dr. Richard Enemark, Headmaster of the Doane Stuart School in Albany; her two children, Faith and Forrest; her father, Edward Lawton, of Santa Clara, CA; and her sister, Carol Lawton, of Fremont, CA. A memorial service will be held at a future date. The family requests that donations in Ms. Lawton's memory be made to the American Cancer Society or the Campaign for the Doane Stuart School, in lieu of flowers.

CLARKE--Beaufort James Barron. The Empire State Pride Agenda Board and Staff mourns the loss of our Board member, supporter and good friend, Beau Clarke, who passed away April 29, 2007. Our sincere condolences go to his family and many close friends. Beau was well known for his philanthropy to the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community. His dedication, passion, energy and friendship will be greatly missed.

A police commander and the owner of an auto yard were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing items from vehicles that had been seized, the Essex County prosecutor's office said. Sgt. Barry Halpern, 51, of Kenilworth, a 24-year veteran of the Irvington Police Department and commander of the auto squad unit, was charged with second-degree official misconduct and third-degree theft. Mark Minett, 51, of Tinton Falls, the owner of MTS Towing in Irvington, was charged with third-degree theft, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. An inquiry began in January 2006 after several people reported items like laptop computers and power tools missing from their cars. Sergeant Halpern is being held in $50,000 bail and Mr. Minett is being held in $30,000 bail. JOHN HOLL

AMES--Camille O'Brien, 89, died on May 1st, 2007, in Asbury-Solomons Health Care Center, Solomons, Maryland. Mrs. Ames was the daughter of the late Frank and Estelle Schlaudecker O'Brien, Sr. Camille O'Brien Ames was a graduate of Mt. de Chantel High School in Wheeling, WV. She worked in the Administrative Offices of Olgebay Park and joined the Avon Corporation as District Sales Manager. She joined her sister in New York in 1960 and became Executive Secretary for the law firm Moynahan and Wachsmith, Counsel to Time-Life Corporation. Soon thereafter she joined New Century Educational Corporation as Administrative Assistant to the President and Secretary of the Corporation at that time. She returned to Wheeling in 1989. She is the beloved mother of Tony Ames of Washington, DC; loving sister of Frank A. O'Brien, Jr. of Wheeling, WV, the late Richard O'Brien, Aileen O'Brien Murphy and Katrine Rempe; and grandmother of Kristin Wiley of New York, NY, and Angharad Ames of Washington. Grave side services will be held at the convenience of the family.

An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain's top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.

An article on April 26 about efforts to encourage people to learn to fly referred incorrectly to a new category of airplanes, light sport aircraft. They are indeed being built. It also referred incorrectly to sport pilot licenses. There are no distance restrictions on them.

A May 3 editorial on ''Reforming the F.D.A.'' inaccurately suggested that nuclear utilities do not pay for oversight by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The N.R.C. gets about 80 percent of its budget from fees paid by the utilities.
BLUM--Raphael. Dear cousin of the late Erich Holzer. Services Friday, 11:30am, at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

A woman yesterday admitted fatally beating her father with a hammer in a November 2004 attack, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, of Long Island City, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin admitted repeatedly striking her father, John Martin, 67, in the head in their apartment. She had told the police that he had been killed in a break-in, Mr. Brown said. In exchange for her plea, Ms. Martin will be sentenced to 20 years in prison, Mr. Brown said.

The other day Judi Roaman was explaining why she closed her business of five years -- an Anne Klein store on Newtown Lane in East Hampton -- and opened a new one in the same location: ''How many black pants can a girl sell?'' In her new home furnishings store, which opened last week, there are black tapered candles and some rather goth woven black plastic bags (with Jacquard skulls and spiders), but most of what's there is wildly colored. ''This is all about color and change and not being cookie-cutter,'' said Ms. Roaman, right. Hers is the only American store that will sell the English designer Lisa Whatmough's Squint furniture, vintage pieces upholstered in a riot of old and new fabrics (sort of an aristocratic rock star look). Sofas, right, start at $12,500; wing chairs are $7,500; an Egg chair is $9,500; a lamp in vintage Japanese kimono fabric, above, is $2,500. Plastic cutlery made in a Baroque Italian silver pattern, far right, comes in rainbow colors ($25 for a four-piece setting); French colored glasses and plates ($8 to $12) do, too. Lisa Corti cotton quilts, top right, are $350 to $450. J. Roaman, 48 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, N.Y., (631) 329-0662. PENELOPE GREEN

Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the six suspects in the Fort Dix case misstated which two of the suspects are brothers-in-law. Eljvir Duka and Mohamad Shnewer are related, not Mr. Duka and Agron Abdullahu. The article also misstated the number of Mr. Shnewer's sisters. He has five, not two.

A 3-year-old boy was found lying unharmed next to his father's body on Tuesday afternoon near their house in East Patchogue, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Carlton Shaw, 38, had been shot in the chest and was found in a yard next to his house on Amsterdam Avenue about 4:45 p.m., the police said. The shooting was under investigation yesterday.

URVATER--Arthur. died on Monday, May 7th, 2007 at the age of 87 in St. Petersburg, Fl, formerly of Yorktown Heights, NY. Beloved husband for 61 years of Lucile nee Slabotzky. Loving father of Robert (Alison) and Richard (Tracy). Predeceased by daughter Beatrice (Richard Bula). Cherished grandfather of Michael (Brenda), Tom, Aimee, Ellen, Jeffrey and Brian. Donations can be made in Arthur's memory to the Deborah Heart and Lung Center, 200 Trenton Mills, NJ 08015.
To the Editor: Re ''From China to Panama, a Trail of Poisoned Medicine'' (front page, May 6):

Between now and the time that Roger Clemens joins their roster, the Yankees will search for a disability policy to insure him against a season-ending injury. It is not certain they will get one, or that it will be affordable. ''It's up to our risk-management department to consider it,'' said Brian Cashman, who has witnessed the sharp rise in disability insurance rates during his 10-year tenure as the team's general manager.

An appeals court raised the 2005 prison sentence of a Dutch businessman, Frans van Anraat, to 17 years from 15 for selling chemicals to Saddam Hussein. The chemicals were used in poison gas weapons in the 1980s and against Kurdish villagers. Prosecutors had demanded a conviction for complicity in genocide, but the appeal judges rejected that, saying Mr. van Anraat was driven not by genocidal intent but by greed. MARLISE SIMONS

KORALL--Burt, age 76, music journalist, beloved husband of Paula for 43 years, dear father of Andrew Korall, Diana and David Cohen, loving son-in-law of Gertrude Swetsky, and cousin of Sandra Yorn. Cherished grandfather of Alyssa, Ryan, and Gabrielle. He was one of a kind and will be sorely missed. Services will be private.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,365 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week: HARRISON, James W. Jr., 47, Col., Army; Missouri; United States Command and General Staff College SABALU, Wilberto Jr., 36, Master Sgt., Chicago; United States Military Police School DIXON, Robert J., 27, Specialist., Army; Minneapolis; First Infantry Division RATEB, Sameer A. M., 22, Sgt., Army; Absecon, N.J.; 82nd Airborne Division
The On Education column yesterday about Columbus High School, misstated its location. The principal says the Bronx school considers Pelham Parkway to be its home. The school is not in Pelham Bay.

The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about research into the discrepancy between stock market returns and individual investors' returns, misstated the average yearly dollar-weighted return for a hypothetical investor who bought 100 shares of a company at $10 a share, then a year later bought 100 more shares when the share price was $20, then sold all 200 shares when the price fell to $10 a share at the end of that second year. The investor's average yearly return was a negative 26.8 percent, not a negative 16.8 percent.

CHESLEY--Vivien C., passed away Saturday, May 5th at DeWitt Nursing and Rehabilitation Facility in New York City. Upon graduating from Missouri School of Journalism in Columbia, Missouri, she worked for the United Press in New York City. Afterwards she edited articles for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association. Her family survives her in Mankato, Minnesota.
To the Editor: Re ''Answering Al Qaeda,'' by Clark Kent Ervin (Op-Ed, May 8):

WALTCHER--Azelle (Brown). March 27, 1925 -May 6, 2007. Beloved wife of Irving, loving mother of Jeffrey and Dan (Barri), grandmother of Genevieve, Thomas, Sarah and David, sister of Richard Brown, devoted friend to so many and Professor of Mathematics for over 40 years at Hofstra University. Azelle was an alumna of Barnard College and she received her Masters and Ph.D. from New York University. A great supporter of Barnard, she served on the President's Advisory Council until her passing. We will miss Azelle's sparkling blue eyes, open mind and keen intellect. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Nature Conservancy New York (4245 N. Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA 22203, www.nature.org.)

Picture captions in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of ''Radio Golf,'' at the Cort Theater, reversed the identities of two actors. In the picture on the cover of the section, the actor on the right was James A. Williams, not John Earl Jelks. In the picture with the continuation of the review, the actor on the left was Mr. Jelks, not Mr. Williams.

INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Moderates in G.O.P. Warn Bush on His Iraq War Policy Moderate Republicans gave President Bush a blunt warning on his Iraq policy at a private White House meeting, telling the president that conditions needed to improve markedly by fall or more Republicans would desert him on the war. A1 After a day of talks in Iraq with the country's fractious political leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said that he detected ''a greater sense of urgency'' among them on issues that the Bush administration sees as the key to sustained progress against insurgent and militia groups. A12 Afghans Claim Civilian Deaths Afghan officials said that airstrikes called in by the American military against Taliban fighters killed 21 civilians on Tuesday, the latest in a series of episodes involving claims of noncombatant casualties that have strained relations with the Afghan government. A10 Obstacle to Bush Missile Plan The Democratic majority in Congress is moving toward budget cuts to slow a Bush administration plan to break ground on one of two missile defense bases in Europe. A5 Germany Safeguards Group of 8 Four weeks before leaders of the world's big industrial nations are to gather at a Baltic Sea resort in northern Germany, the police conducted sweeping raids on the offices and homes of left-wing campaigners whom they suspected of planning to disrupt the meeting. A14 NATIONAL A20-30 Senate Passes Drug Bill Giving F.D.A. More Control By a vote of 93 to 1, the Senate passed a bill that gives the Food and Drug Administration new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers. A1 Giuliani on Abortion Rudolph W. Giuliani is planning to offer a forthright affirmation of his support for abortion rights in public forums, television appearances and interviews, aides said. A29 Ban on Lender Gifts Advances The House of Representatives voted to ban gifts and payments by student loan companies to universities, showing bipartisan resolve to clean up the $85 billion industry. A22 Indictment in 1965 Killing A grand jury in Alabama handed up an indictment in a killing that helped inspire the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965 in the latest in a wave of prosecutions of crimes from the civil rights era. A20 SCIENCE/HEALTH Money's Role in Prescribing The intersection of money and medicine and its effect on the well-being of patients has become one of the most contentious issues in health care. Nowhere is that more true than in psychiatry. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Portraits Emerge In Fort Dix Terror Plot A portrait of five of the men suspected in a terror plot against an Army base in New Jersey began to emerge a day after their arrests. Relatives of the three brothers arrested said they could not believe the charges. Another suspect had grown so religious that his father said they had become estranged. And the wife of a fifth suspect said he had been keeping up an exhausting routine of work, sleep and prayer. A1 Renters Cope With Squeeze Radical solutions to New York's tight real estate market are becoming more common among young, well-educated newcomers to the city, brokers say. While young people in New York have always sought roommates to make life more affordable, they are now crowding so tightly that they may be violating city codes. A1 Hospital Plan Do-Over? Republican and Democratic leaders of the New York Legislature want Gov. Eliot Spitzer to reconsider a plan approved last year to close, merge or shrink dozens of hospitals across the state. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Interest Rate Unchanged The Federal Reserve acknowledged that the economy was slowing, but offered little hint that it was ready to lower interest rates anytime soon. South Korea plans to break ground for the world's biggest solar power plant as it tries to diversify its power sources and use cleaner energy, the government and developers said. The $170 million plant, being built in Shinan, near the southwestern tip of South Korea, is part of an effort to seek new and renewable energy sources and is scheduled to be completed by late 2008. The plant will produce more than 27,000 megawatt-hours of electricity a year, enough to supply 6,000 to 7,000 households, said Kim Ji Hun, president of the Korean subsidiary of SunTechnics, the German solar power company that will build the plant. It will be operated by Dongyang Engineering and Construction. CHOE SANG-HUN

FISHER--Naomi Rubin, died May 8, 2007 aged 85. Cherished wife of David, mother of Paul (Margaret Reid) and Robert (Yasmin Khakoo) and grandmother of M. Caitlin, Jeremy, Gillian, Alex, and Aliya. She has lived under the cruel cloud of Alzheimer's disease for nearly 15 years. But those fortunate enough to remember her before her affliction knew a gentle and loving woman with remarkable skills as a journalist. Her creative imagination inspired her to synthesize a play-byplay account of a baseball game (Brooklyn Dodgers, of course) entirely with lines from Shakespeare; her versatility enabled her to write radio scripts for the Office of War Information, and to work as editor of Soviet Russia Today and of Consumer Reports, to win high regard as a labor journalist -a reporter for the NMU Pilot, an editor for Trade Union Service and New York bureau chief for Federated Press; and when McCarthyism made labor journalism untenable, she was able to adapt to her craft the field of medical journalism, first as a writer for the American Heart Association and for the Arthritis Foundation, then as Managing Editor of Emergency Medicine and Manuscript Editor of Hospital Practice. Underlying all was a peerless sense of craft and of the shape of language. A colleague once remarked, ''Naomi can spot a typo across the room, even if she can't speak the language.''

Henry and Eliza, Back on Broadway The persnickety professor Henry Higgins and the courageous Cockney Eliza Doolittle will be at each other's throats once again in September, when the Roundabout Theater Company opens its 2007-8 season with a new production of George Bernard Shaw's ''Pygmalion.'' The play, which inspired the musical ''My Fair Lady,'' will star Jefferson Mays as Higgins. Mr. Mays, who won a Tony Award in 2004 for the solo show ''I Am My Own Wife,'' is currently playing Private Mason, the witty and fastidious cook, at the Belasco Theater in the revival of ''Journey's End'' under the direction of David Grindley, who will stage ''Pygmalion.'' Additional casting is to be announced. Previews of ''Pygmalion'' will begin on Sept. 14 at the American Airlines Theater, where the official opening is scheduled for Oct. 11 for a run through Dec. 16. Austria Returns Munch Art to Mahler Family In the conclusion of a restitution battle spanning six decades, an Edvard Munch painting was presented yesterday to Marina Mahler, the granddaughter of the composer Gustav Mahler. It was given to Ms. Mahler by Austria's minister for culture, Claudia Schmied, who said returning the painting, ''Summer Night on the Beach,'' (at right, with Ms. Mahler, left, and Ms. Schmied), to its rightful owner was a ''historic duty,'' Agence France-Presse reported. Given in 1916 to Alma Mahler, the composer's widow, the painting was lent to the Belvedere museum in Vienna in 1937, a year before Austria was annexed by Germany. Her stepfather, a Nazi sympathizer, sold it to the museum in 1940. After World War II Alma and her granddaughter began the fight to reclaim the painting. Rolling Stones Move On The Rolling Stones, responding to protests from animal-rights proponents, have decided to move their July 14 concert in Belgrade to a vast public park instead of the city's racetrack, where their music might upset hundreds of horses, The Associated Press reported. Last month officials of the Hippodrome racecourse, below, said some skittish horses might be given tranquilizers to spare them the impact of high-decibel rock. P. Diddy, Tom Jones and Nelly Furtado have been added to the lineup of the July 1 concert in London commemorating the 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, the BBC reported. Led by $312,000 for a 1975 Travis Bean electric guitar once owned by Jerry Garcia, a Grateful Dead memorabilia auction fetched more than $1.1 million in San Francisco on Tuesday, Reuters reported. Johnny Hallyday, France's answer to Elvis Presley, has decided to end his self-imposed exile in Switzerland now that his tax-cutting friend Nicolas Sarkozy has been elected president of France, Agence France-Presse reported. In an interview with RTL radio, Laetitia Hallyday, the performer's wife, said, ''Nicolas Sarkozy's policies will certainly lead us to come back to France.'' Last year, in a bombshell announcement, Mr. Hallyday, 63, said he was moving to Gstaad to escape France's high taxes. Music Director Leaves Santa Fe Opera Alan Gilbert, below, mentioned as a possible successor to Lorin Maazel as music director of the New York Philharmonic, has stepped down after four years as music director of the Santa Fe Opera, PlaybillArts reported. Mr. Gilbert, born in New York in 1968 to two Philharmonic violinists, has a thriving international career as a conductor. In leaving the Santa Fe Opera, he said in a statement that the position of its music director ''unfortunately requires a time commitment that at the present I feel I am unable to make.'' Lilly Prize Goes To Lucille Clifton Lucille Clifton has won the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, established in 1986 and awarded annually by the Poetry Foundation. In announcing the award, Christian Wiman, editor of Poetry magazine and chairman of the selection committee, said: ''Her poems are at once outraged and tender, small and explosive, sassy and devout. She sounds like no one else, and her achievement looks larger with each passing year.'' Her prize will be presented on May 23 at the Arts Club of Chicago. Ms. Clifton, 70, who lives in Columbia, Md., and teaches at St. Mary's College of Maryland, won a National Book Award in 2000 for ''Blessing the Boats: New and Selected Poems, 1988-2000'' (BOA Editions). Footnotes The former Georgia prosecutor Nancy Grace is leaving Court TV after a decade, Reuters reported. In a statement, the channel said she had asked to be released from her contract. Leaving her daily show, ''Closing Arguments,'' she will focus on her primetime legal show, ''Nancy Grace,'' on CNN Headline News, which is, like Court TV, owned by Turner Broadcasting System. The San Francisco Ballet, celebrating its 75th anniversary next year, will dance at New York City Center from Oct. 8 to 19, 2008.

Doug Flutie, Ahmad Rashad and Reggie Williams were named to the College Football Hall of Fame. Flutie was a Boston College quarterback (1981-84), Rashad -- then known as Bobby Moore -- an Oregon running back and wide receiver (1969-71), and Williams a Dartmouth linebacker (1973-75). All went on to productive careers in professional football. Nine other players from major colleges were elected: Tom Brahaney, an Oklahoma center (1970-72); Dave Brown, a Michigan defensive back (1972-74); Jeff Davis, a Clemson linebacker (1978-81); Johnnie Johnson, a Texas defensive back (1976-79); Rex Kern, an Ohio State quarterback (1968-70); Anthony Thompson, an Indiana running back (1986-89); Wilson Whitley, a Houston defensive tackle (1973-76); Richard Wood, a Southern California linebacker (1972-74); and Chris Zorich, a Notre Dame defensive tackle (1988-90).

THE increase in the number of trail races -- and runners -- is as steep as Pikes Peak. This year, there are nearly three times as many trail races planned as in 2000, with roughly 50,000 more participants, according to the American Trail Running Association.

LUKE--John A. Sr. Former president and chief executive officer of Westvaco Corporation, died on Monday, May 7. He was 81. According to his family, Mr. Luke died of complications following a brief illness. The son of the late David L. Luke, Jr. and Priscilla Warren Luke, Mr. Luke is survived by his wife, Joy Carter Luke, his brother David L. Luke III and half-sister Melinda Luke, his children, John A. Luke, Jr., William H. Luke, Hope L. Hetherington and their spouses, Kathleen Luke, Cynthia Luke, and John Hetherington, and his grandchildren, Lindsay A. Luke, Elizabeth C. Luke, John A. Luke, III, Whitney Joy Luke, Kells L. Hetherington, Jane S. Hetherington, J. Luke Murphy and Gordon T. Murphy. He was predeceased by a daughter, Jane L. Murphy, and a sister, Priscilla Luke Vail. Mr. Luke enjoyed a distinguished 43 year career with the pulp and paper company his family founded more than 100 years ago. He helped guide the business as president during which time the company expanded its international presence and strengthened its leadership in environmental stewardship. He was highly respected as a leader in the paper industry and as a strong advocate for free and fair international trade. Colleagues and coworkers appreciated his unwavering integrity and his effective combination of strength and warmth. Mr. Lukes great-grandfather built the familys first pulp mill on the Potomac River in 1888 and later founded the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company. In 2002, Westvaco merged with the Mead Corporation. Today, MeadWestvaco is a global leader in premium packaging and packaging solutions for consumer products. John A. Luke was born on November 30, 1925 and graduated from The Hotchkiss School and Yale University. He served in the United States Army Air Corps from 1943 to 1945. During his career with Westvaco, Mr. Luke earned numerous awards and recognitions for his leadership role in the paper industry and service with a variety of industry and environmental organizations. A memorial service will be held on May 16 at 11:30am at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Lupus Research Institute, 330 Seventh Avenue, Suite 1701, New York, New York, 10001.

With help from the former Bee Gee Barry Gibb, below, the final four ''American Idol'' contestants faced off Tuesday, as the show lifted Fox to another ratings victory on the night. Nielsen estimated 24.5 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m., noticeably down from a year ago (29.9 million) but still far ahead of the No. 2 show during the hour, CBS's ''NCIS'' (13.7 million). At 9 Fox's ''House'' remained almost as dominant as ''Idol,'' matching its ratings among adults 18 to 49 while attracting 21.5 million total viewers. In second place at 9 ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show (16.5 million) saw the country singer Billy Ray Cyrus eliminated after his mambo and foxtrot failed to delight the judges on Monday. ABC and CBS finished about even for the night as runners up. NBC ranked fourth, although its 10 p.m. offering, ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' did lead the hour over all (10.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

The quilts created by the women of Gee's Bend, Ala., a rural African-American community, have been exhibited in museums across the country and are now collectibles. This week a limited-edition collection of rugs inspired by those quilts, pieced together from vintage textiles and kilims, arrived at ABC Carpet & Home. The quilters will collect a royalty from the rugs; each bears the name of the woman whose work inspired it and the year her quilt was made. Roman Stripes ($5,599), below left, about 8 by 11 feet, was based on a 1967 quilt by Plummer T. Pettway; Housetop ($3,699), right, 7 by 8 feet, was inspired by a 1975 quilt by Linda Pettway. At ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000 or abchome.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

FALKOWITZ--Bernie. Our sincerest condolences and warm wishes go to the Falkowitz family for the loss of Uncle Bernie. We will always carry him in our hearts. Love, Justin, Jenny, Lynn, Doug, Isabelle and Mack

Vince Carter has settled for fadeaway after fadeaway after fadeaway in Cleveland, and the empty thud of his misses has echoed the Nets' playoff plight. Just as Carter is searching for his shot, fans are searching for a competitive series in the Eastern Conference playoffs. The first round ended in 18 games. There was only one series that did not end in a sweep -- the Nets defeating the Toronto Raptors in six games. Out West, the first round took 23 games, which included the Golden State Warriors' thrilling, six-game upset of the Dallas Mavericks.

The organizers of PrideFest, the gay-themed street fair that generally accompanies the city's gay pride parade on the last Sunday in June, voted on Tuesday night to tell city officials that they would cancel this year's festival unless they could find a better location. The members of Heritage of Pride, which organizes the festival and the parade, have said that the previous site, in the West Village, was cramped and dangerous, and that they wanted to move to Chelsea. On April 27, city officials denied permission for the change and urged the organizers to keep the event at the original site. The city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., has sent the mayor a letter urging the city to reconsider. ALEX MINDLIN

An article in the special Personal Health section on May 1, about sexually transmitted diseases, misidentified the viruses that cause herpes, the most common sexually transmitted disease in the United States. They are strains of H.S.V., or herpes simplex virus -- not H.P.V., or human papillomavirus.

CONWAY--James J. Jr., former Chairman and Chief Executive of the Long Island Savings Bank, died on May 6, 2007 of complications after a long illness. Jim Conway was married to Dolores (Dee) Gilhooly for 53 years, was the father of five children and grandfather of 18, and was an accomplished banker, lawyer, and athlete. He was 78 years old. Mr. Conway was born in Rockaway and grew up in Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Prep, the College of the Holy Cross and Fordham Law School. Mr. Conway was a longtime resident of Manhasset, New York; Quogue, New York; and Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Conway served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Long Island Savings Bank from 1978 until 1992. The Bank's assets grew tenfold under his leadership, and the book value of the savings bank increased over 1,500 percent. In addition, Mr. Conway led the bank through a difficult period in the financial services industry and successfully led the acquisition and integration of several failed thrifts from the FDIC. Mr. Conway had a reputation as a dynamic leader with a range of expertise, from home mortgage lending to real estate finance and development, to sophisticated financing and asset-related funding techniques. Long Island Savings Bank converted from mutual ownership, went public, and was subsequently acquired by Astoria Federal Savings. Jim Conway was well known for his generosity. He made many of his gifts to help others in a quiet way, neither seeking nor valuing public recognition. There are countless individuals with stories of favors, big and small, where Jim Conway stepped in during a time of need. While he supported many charities and community works, his favorite causes were education and youth programs. Jim Conway and his wife and family were longtime supporters of Little Flower Children's Services, an agency providing educational, foster care, family counseling and adoption services. Jim Conway was an active athlete and sports fan. He played competitive baseball and basketball in high school and college and was offered a professional baseball contract at a young age. He was a passionated participant in everything he did and played competitive golf until late in life. Jim Conway pursued with a passion a lifelong interest in horse racing where he displayed his competitive drive, street smarts, and luck. He was an owner or part owner of many leading trotters and thoroughbreds, enjoying considerable success over many years. One of his horses, Kash Minbar, was a repeat winner of the American Trotting Championship and set national and world records in the mile, mile-and-aquarter and mile-and a half. One of his thoroughbreds, Greenwood Lake, was the favorite to win the Kentucky Derby in 2000 after having won the Florida Derby, the Remsen and the Champagne Classic. Unfortunately, Greenwood Lake suffered a career-ending broken leg two months prior to the Kentucky Derby. The caption under Mr. Conway's photo in his senior yearbook at Holy Cross called him ''Lucky Jim'' and noted that he was known for his intelligence, his charm and sense of humor, his athletic skill, and pointed out that he liked to dance. In many ways the editor of the Holy Cross yearbook captured the essence of Jim Conway's life. The only thing that editor missed was his love and devotion to his wife Dee and his pride and enjoyment of his family. In addition to his wife Dee, Mr. Conway is survived by his five children: James J. Conway III of Matinecock, NY, Susan Conway Petrelli of Harrison, NY, Kevin J. Conway of Plandome, NY, Brian J. Conway of Newton, MA and Traci Conway Clinton of Plandome Manor, NY; two daughters-in-law, Denise Conway and Karen Conway; two sons-in-law, Joseph Petrelli and Matthew Clinton; 18 grandchildren; a sister, Janet Conway Sands of Woodbury, CT. (Eddie) and a sister-inlaw, Ruth Conway of Landrum, SC. Mr. Conway was predeceased by his beloved sister Marge, and brother, Bobby. The wake for James Conway will held be at Fairchild & Sons Funeral Home at 1570 Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, New York. (Thursday, May 10 from 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm). There will be a memorial mass at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset at 5 pm on Friday, May 11. The family will be holding a private burial service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Little Flower Children's Services; 2450 N. Wading River Road; PO Box 9000; Wading River, NY 11792.
To the Editor: Re ''Two Parties, One Law,'' by Arnold I. Burns (Op-Ed, May 3):

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column last Thursday about lawsuits over the ownership of the 16th-century diptych ''Adam and Eve,'' by Lucas Cranach the Elder, misstated the name of the organization that now owns it. It is the Norton Simon Art Foundation, not the Norton Simon Foundation. The report also misstated the painting's history. The foundation bought it in the mid-1960s directly from an heir to the Stroganoff dynasty of Russia. It did not buy it at auction.

The City Council passed legislation yesterday requiring the Buildings Department to notify the Fire Department when alteration permits are issued for buildings. The bill was submitted after a 2006 Bronx fire in which two firefighters were killed when a floor collapsed in a building that had undergone renovations, though the cause of the collapse is still under investigation. The bill passed 51 to 0, and the mayor is expected to sign it. RAY RIVERA

"Web 2.0," as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people's travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn't supply their materials. It seems to me, though, that we haven't even scratched the surface. We've picked the low-hanging fruit, but there are dozens or hundreds of huge Web 2.0 ideas that have yet to materialize.

A marine testified on Wednesday that he urinated on the bloody remains of one of five unarmed Iraqi men in Haditha whom his squad leader fatally shot in late 2005 moments after a roadside bomb had killed one of their comrades. The marine, Sgt. Sanick Dela Cruz, said at a hearing here that he had acted in anger over the death of Lance Cpl. Miguel Terrazas, known as T.J., whose convoy was hit by a bomb planted by Sunni Arab insurgents.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said Chinese officials had informed it that a pig epidemic was under control in Laosi, in southeastern Guangdong Province. China's Ministry of Agriculture is conducting tests to determine if the disease is porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that began attacking North American and European swine farms in the late 1980s and is the costliest virus for swine herds in the United States. The disease does not infect humans, the United Nations agency said. China reported a similar epidemic of the pig disease to the agency in September. KEITH BRADSHER

LAST Friday afternoon, Jamie Gray, the owner of the Brooklyn design boutique Matter, stood in an empty storefront in Lower Manhattan, scraping away at a stubborn plastic UV filter that covered the front window. The work was punishing -- ''hopefully there won't be any scratches or blood loss,'' he said, though he ended up calloused and bleeding -- and very time consuming, considering he had less than two weeks left until the opening of Matter's new Manhattan branch. A lot of problems remained to be dealt with, including glass doors he had trouble mounting on the display cases, and the important shipment of Established & Sons furniture stuck in customs limbo. But Mr. Gray had been through worse in the last few months, he said. When he set out to find a Manhattan space in February, he was lucky. ''I called the right agent on the right day,'' he said, and found this storefront, which he decided he had to have. He was soon shaking hands on a deal for the property and envisioning an opening that would coincide with the design bacchanalia around the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in May. Two hours later the deal fell through. ''For three weeks I was scrambling,'' he said. ''And then they changed their minds; I got the space. So it has a happy ending. Or a happy beginning, anyway.''

The most patriotic moments at Yankee Stadium can also be the most confining. Seconds before ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' and ''God Bless America'' are played, police officers, security guards and ushers turn their backs to the American flag in center field, stare at fans moving through the stands and ask them to stop. Across the stadium's lower section, ushers stand every 20 feet to block the main aisle with chains.

BENENSON--Marjorie L. She died in Deerfield Beach, FL. May 6, 2007, age 93. Mother of Richard Benenson and the late Karen Allinson, motherin-law of Thea Benenson and Richard Allinson, sister of Monroe Lipton. She also leaves four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. After a long and healthy life our Auntie Mame has died. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave and 81st St. on Friday, May 11 at 1pm. Reception following at the home of Richard and Thea Benenson.

Giuliani to Support Abortion Rights After months of giving ambiguous signals on abortion, Rudolph W. Giuliani is planning to offer a forthright affirmation of his support for abortion rights in public forums, television appearances and interviews in the coming days, despite potential consequences among some conservative voters already wary of his views, aides said. PAGE A29 Ban of Lender Gifts Advances The House voted 414 to 3 to ban gifts and payments by student loan companies to universities, showing resolve to clean up the $85 billion industry and how politically potent the issue of paying for college has become. PAGE A22 HBO Chief Quits After Arrest The chief executive of Time Warner's HBO unit, Chris Albrecht, resigned at the company's request in the wake of his weekend arrest in Las Vegas. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Questions on Afghan Deaths Afghan officials said American attacks killed 21 civilians on Tuesday; the American military said it could not confirm the report. PAGE A10 A Stronger Papal Warning on Abortion Benedict XVI arrived in Brazil, starting his first papal trip to Latin America with strong words against abortion. On the plane from Rome, the pope appeared to go further than the Vatican had before on the contentious issue of Roman Catholic politicians who favor abortion rights when he suggested that Mexico City legislators who recently voted to allow abortion in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy had excommunicated themselves. PAGE A3 Fed Leaves Rate Unchanged The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, but acknowledged that the economy was slowing. The overnight rate of 5.25 percent has been the same since the Fed began its ''pause'' almost a year ago. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Prosecutor Speaks Out The former United States attorney in Kansas City, Mo., said he was pushed to resign last year over politically sensitive cases. Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales is said to be confident he will survive the prosecutor dismissals. PAGE A30

BAUMEISTER--Matthew C. 4/5/86--5/11/05. Dearest Matthew, it is now 2 years since we have held you or seen your beautiful smiling face. We suffer your absence with every breath we take there is no escape from the pain of this loss. We had imagined so much happiness for you. For all that you have lost we also grieve. You are loved and remembered every day, every hour, every minute. Sometimes the things we love the most we can no longer touch. Missing you. Mom, Dad and Jared.
Vice President Dick Cheney began his Middle East trip with a visit to Baghdad to press Iraqi leaders on political progress. Page A12.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 16 about airline food in the special Business Travel section incorrectly attributed comments about a private-jet company, New York Aviation, and about business travelers in general. The comments, ''We'll go into the city and get dinner at Le Cirque if people want it,'' about the services New York Aviation provides, and ''As long as there's booze on board, they're happy,'' referring to business travelers, were by Jack Gentile, founder of New York Aviation -- not by Hector Adler, senior vice president for customer experience at Eos Airlines.

THE slipper chair, typically armless, upholstered and low to the ground, is a versatile piece of furniture, as comfortable in the bedroom as it is tucked into a corner of a library or next to a fireplace. Unobtrusive and usually small in scale, it can be pulled out for extra seating. The chairs come in a wide range of prices. Although slipper chairs have a reputation for being traditional, the new ones are just as likely to have a modern shape or contemporary upholstery. 1. The Gaucho Chair is covered in a floral cotton fabric and sits on legs stained to resemble wenge wood. Its seat is wider than those of some other slipper chairs; $499 at (800) 606-6252 or cb2.com. 2. West Elm's slipper chair is covered in a summery white leather; $499 from (888) 922-4119 or westelm.com. 3. Milo, right, and Cooper, left -- small, lightweight chairs with loose seat and back cushions and very short legs -- can be pushed around easily; $2,775 from Donghia to the trade (not including the cost of seven yards of upholstery fabric), (800) 366-4442 or donghia.com. 4. The Microsuede Slipper Chair comes with a matching bolster pillow, in red and other colors, and is available online only; $249.99 at (800) 591-3869 or target.com. 5. Inspired by the spare lines of Danish modern design, McGuire's Danish Cord Slipper Chair has a rattan pole frame and a woven cord base; price starts at $2,995. For information and locations: (800) 662-4847 or kohlerinteriors.com. 6. The Lydell Tufted Slipper Chair from Martha Stewart Furniture with Bernhardt has cherry wood finish legs and costs $825. For locations: (888) 562-7842 or marthastewart.com. 7. The Thompson Slipper Chair, shown in dark brown mohair with steel legs, has an unusually voluptuous profile; $1,425 from Desiron, 151 Wooster Street (Greene Street), (212) 353-2600 or desiron.com. 8. The Gabrielle Chair has a tufted back; $2,955 from Ralph Lauren Home. For information and locations: (888) 475-7674 or rlhome.polo.com.

Eric Guiomar, a cardboard furniture maker, discovered his vocation by accident. In 1993, while working as a photographer in Paris, he needed an armchair for a photo shoot, but could not afford to buy one. So he made one instead, out of cardboard boxes he found on the street. Soon after, he quit his job as a photographer. Mr. Guiomar, 41, who calls himself a cartonniste, now sells custom designs like the $600 chair, above left, and gives classes at his Paris-based studio, Bleuzen. (The compact disc storage system, above right, which sells for $1,400, was made by Sabrina Santagata, a student.) His film ''How Things Are Made: Cardboard Furniture,'' just released on DVD ($35), will be shown May 18 at 8 p.m. at the Staten Island Museum. For information: statenislandmuseum.org; vinestreetworks.com. ELAINE LOUIE

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 1 about an accounting technique used by New Century Financial misstated the year that the company's chief financial officer, Edward F. Gotschall, stepped down from that job. It was 2004, not 2006. (Mr. Gotschall is still with the company as a vice chairman.)

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with the Advertising column about cellphones affiliated with particular organizations carried an incorrect credit. The photograph was by Evan J. Thomas -- not Michael Caulfield/Wire Image.com for CNN.
GEORGE--Sally. Born May 9, passed away on May 31, 1991. In my thoughts daily. In my heart and soul forever. I miss you so ... With Love, Catherine

An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain's top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.
To the Editor: Re ''France Under New Leadership'' (editorial, May 8):

An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Gordon Scott, an actor who played Tarzan in the 1950s, misspelled his surname at birth. He was Gordon W. Werschkul, not Werschkull. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his surviving brother. He is Rafield Werschkul, not Rayfield.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reached a $51 million deal yesterday to allow one of its tenants, Orient Overseas International Ltd., which is based in Hong Kong, to sell its lease of a Staten Island marine terminal to the board of the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, which is buying the lease as an investment. In return for signing off on the $470 million transaction, the authority will receive $16 million in cash, up to $5 million to cover construction costs and a commitment from the pension board to invest $30 million in the Howland Hook terminal. KEN BELSON

PHILLIPS--Samuel F. May 8th, 2007 of Somerset, NJ. Uncle of Edward Budd and Fred Stein, great-uncle of Debbi and Jay Baum, and Jeffrey Stein. Services Thursday, 12:30pm, at BloomfieldCooper Chapels, Manalapan, NJ. Interment Wellwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Sam's memory to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

LEI--Taiwai. We mourn the passing of Taiwai Lei, beloved daughter of Heng Mao Li and Kai Qu Dai. Taiwai was born October 12, 1978 in Shanghai and passed away May 8, 2007 in New York after a courageous battle with lymphoma. She received her B.S. at Cornell University and studied at Columbia University for her MBA. Taiwai was an avid reader and always loved a healthy intellectual debate. She had a wonderful eye for style and made everything around her as beautiful as she was. Her incredible zest for life spread joy to all around her. She will be sorely missed by all whose lives she touched, especially Erik with whom she shared a true love. A memorial service will be held at Chun Fook Funeral Services on May 11, 2007 from 3:30 until 7:00 pm.
A report in the Currents column last Thursday gave an incorrect telephone number to order the Butch & Harold line of wall decals. The number is (212) 712-0616.

The young smoothies are on top: In a week packed with successful new releases, Billboard's top two albums are by the 24-year-old R&B crooner Ne-Yo and the Sinatra-esque 31-year-old Michael Bublé. Ne-Yo's ''Because of You'' (Def Jam) opened at No. 1 with 251,000 sales, and Mr. Bublé's ''Call Me Irresponsible'' (Reprise) moved 212,000 to reach No. 2, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The veteran Canadian progressive-rock band Rush sold 93,000 copies of its 18th studio album, ''Snakes & Arrows'' (Atlantic), bowing at No. 3. Tori Amos's new ''American Doll Posse'' (Epic) reached No. 5 with 54,000 sales; Miranda Lambert's ''Crazy Ex-Girlfriend'' (Columbia) is No. 6 with 53,000; and the country singer Blake Shelton's ''Pure BS'' (Warner Brothers) moved 48,000 to open at No. 8. Avril Lavigne's ''Best Damn Thing'' (RCA), the No. 1 album for the last two weeks, fell to No. 4 with 86,000 sales. BEN SISARIO

More than $100,000 worth of illegal steroids were confiscated from a pharmacy yesterday by the New York State Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement, officials said. The authorities were led to a Lowen's Pharmacy in Brooklyn as part of an investigation by the Albany County district attorney. The investigation so far has led to the prosecution of at least 20 people. Christopher Baynes, an assistant district attorney for Albany County, said that investigators found large amounts of Chinese growth hormone and testosterone that had not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration at Lowen's Pharmacy. As of last night, no charges had been filed, Mr. Baynes said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

KOMITO--Carrie, on May 9, 2007, age 102 years. Mother of Avodah K. Offit, M.D., sister of Tessie Karper, grandmother of Michael Offit, M.B.A., and Kenneth Offit, M.D., M.P.H., great-grandmother of Anna, Caroline, Tristan, Wyatt and Lily. Wife of the late Abraham Komito, Deputy Chief Engineer, Borough of Brooklyn. For 70 years impresario of The Aladdin Hotel, Woodbourne, NY; sometimes investor in Manhattan real estate. During the last five years of her productive life, authored three books of reminiscences. Private burial.
To the Editor: Re ''My Daughter, the Burger-Flipping Penguin,'' by Michelle Slatalla (Thursday Styles, May 3):

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the arrests of six men in New Jersey on charges of plotting to attack the Fort Dix Army base referred imprecisely to the relationship between three suspects -- the brothers Eljvir, Dritan and Shain Duka -- and a fourth, Mohamad Shnewer. Mr. Shnewer's sister is married to Eljvir Duka, so only Eljvir -- not all three Duka brothers -- is legally Mr. Shnewer's brother-in-law.

Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington State signed the nation's first law Friday to ban "D.W.T." - driving while texting with a cellphone, BlackBerry or other mobile device. New Jersey is considering similar legislation, which would make drivers who text and drive subject to fines.

I wrote an extended essay about poverty, at home and abroad, for the latest New York Review of Books. Read it and comment below.

Jay L. Kriegel, who was Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff's right-hand man in the city's unsuccessful effort to secure the 2012 Olympics, starts work on Monday as a senior adviser to The Related Companies, a major property developer, and its chairman and chief executive, Stephen M. Ross.
While reading through the comments on the Gumball 3000 post, I was surprised to find a few from participants, recent and past -- at least they said they were.

Tooling around Texas, I noticed that not only is the new Tundra much bigger than a Prius (as Micheline Maynard pointed out in her last post), but it's also bigger than a Tundra. Check it out. The truck on the right is a first-generation Tundra.

I recently called up Lufthansa Miles & More to reserve a flight using my miles from the program. Lufthansa said that I had enough miles for the flight, but that there were no seats available. I was able to make online bookings for the seats I wanted - as long as I paid for them. Is this a typical problem? Why am I storing up all these miles if I can't use them?

The Friday press conference returned to a discussion of Nick Heidfeld's drive on the Nordschleife last month. That is significant. The questions came not only from the official FIA interviewer, but from journalists and...another driver.
A young Iraqi woman who chronicled the daily struggles of life in Baghdad is fleeing with her family.
Photographer Joachim Ladefoged speaks about his work with Iraqi refugees in Damascus.
As she spends more time on the campaign trail, Michelle Obama is appearing in support of her husband but is also campaigning for herself.

Former President Bill Clinton narrates a short biographical film about Hillary Rodham Clinton.

As we sat waiting in Sarasota Airport for our flight, I was riding a roller coaster of emotions. One moment I was elated that we had made extensive progress on our house plans, the next I was depressed that the plans weren't perfect.
Nir Rosen reports on the refugee crisis at Al Tanf on the Syrian border with Iraq.
