In case you thought the Yankees had somehow traded for Miguel Cabrera from the Florida Marlins without anyone noticing, there's a friendly reminder on your Times box score page nearly every day.
How Jonathan Coulton's song became a viral hit.
Physicists are putting the final touches on the biggest and most expensive scientific experiment on Earth.
The good ol' days of rebellion were back today in Delhi, India, where the 150th anniversary of India's first revolt against British rule was celebrated.

Considerable amounts of ink and pixels have been devoted lately to characterizing Barack Obama as the presidential candidate of the hedge-fund set. A Financial Times article last month quoted an anonymous United States businessman as saying, "The whole of Greenwich is backing Obama" -- a reference to Greenwich, Conn., the leafy suburb that many hedge fund managers call home. (That breezy statement turns out to be quite untrue, as we will see later.)

Rudolph W. Giuliani began his effort today to show a more consistent, if liberal, persona on the campaign trail, telling a conservative crowd in Houston that he favored abortion rights, gay rights (domestic partnerships but not marriage) and certain restrictions on guns.
Readers respond to David Brooks's May 11 column, "The Human Community."

The more we hear about climate change, the more we hear about how business, government and green-minded consumers are going to collaborate to create a low-carbon economy. Politicians and chief executives say these initiatives could get us there within two or three decades.

YouTube is magnetic. The average user spends nearly 30 minutes there, just hanging out. Part of the draw is the thick, lush, humid comments section. It's like a rainforest in there with, yeah, tons of bugs and some predators, but also plenty of dense and fascinating flora.

Like fedora-sporting reporters in old movies, hedge fund employees lately have been known to jump up from their courtroom seats as rulings are issued to get breaking news back to headquarters. But they're not rushing to the bank of payphones in the lobby (which probably aren't there anymore anyway). "These guys are texting the hedge fund, so they can short the stock" of whatever company just lost a patent suit, Ron Laurie, of Inflexion Point Strategy, an intellectual-property investment bank, told the trade publication IP Law and Business.

Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, one of the law firms advising Dow Jones as it considers a takeover bid from News Corporation, said Friday it hired a new corporate partner for its mergers and acquisitions practice. John E. Sorkin, previously a partner at Latham & Watkins, joins Fried Frank in its New York office.

The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday accused a prominent investment-banking executive in Pakistan of taking part in a $7.5 million insider trading ring along with a former banker at Credit Suisse. In an amended complaint filed in federal court in Illinois, the S.E.C. said Ajaz Rahim, the country head of investment banking at Faysal Bank Limited of Pakistan, with making about $5 million in illegal profits by trading in TXU options before the Texas utility announced its $45 billion sale to two private equity firms.
The online travel site Orbitz Worldwide "isn't a bad company," Kevin Kelleher writes on GigaOM.com. It is nevertheless a contender for "the worst I.P.O. candidate of the year," he concludes.

My column today, arguing that such things as clubs charging $350 for a bottle of booze are simply ways that money is redistributed from the wealthy, provoked a telephone call from a reader who told me I "write like a Republican." He did not mean it as a compliment, but did seem to take for granted that Republicans would be the kind of people to patronize such establishments.

In their search for the next takeover candidate, analysts and investors seem to be casting an eye on SunTrust Banks. Part of the reason is a recent comment from James Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, who said on a conference call Monday that his firm is ready to buy a domestic regional bank. Speculation immediately turned to SunTrust, which has a major presence in the Southeast, a market that J.P. Morgan may be targeting for growth.
"I thought it would be much, much bigger," said one of my companions.

Bristol-Myers Squibb said Thursday that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government, a move meant to end a federal antitrust investigation of the drug maker's botched efforts last year to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

Two months after Thailand blocked YouTube over video clips it said insulted the King, a response emerged from its owner, Google, in a letter released by the nation's communications minister. Google has not commented so far.
Effects of the merger weighed on the bottom line, but the company said it expected full-year revenue growth of 4 to 6 percent.
As thousands of parents arrived for graduation ceremonies, it was hard to tell the tears of joy from those of sadness.

Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings sweetened its all-stock offer for CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in hopes of fending off a competing bid from the IntercontinentalExchange. The revised offer, announced early Friday, values CBOT at about $9.2 billion, Bloomberg News reported.

Last month I visited India and wrote about the horrific sex trafficking situation there, through the story of a woman named Meena who had been imprisoned in a brothel herself, was bred, and then had her daughter prostituted as well. Meena is an incredibly gutsy woman, and she was able to rescue her teenage daughter, Naina.

DES MOINES, May 11 -- Mitt Romney expanded on his belief in evolution in an interview earlier this week, staking out a position that could put him at odds with some conservative Christians, a key voting bloc he is courting.

The Times's Michael Luo assesses the state of Mitt Romney's candidacy, detailing hurdles such as skepticism about his ideological shifts and Mormon faith, as well as strengths including a proven fund-raising capacity and even greater skepticism about his chief rivals, Senator John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani (who, as Katharine Q. Seelye pointed out Thursday, has been having a rough week).

As Thomson lays the groundwork for a blockbuster merger with Reuters, the Canadian company said Friday it will sell its education and career units to two private equity funds for about $7.75 billion in cash.

The Wall Street Journal editorial page thinks Rudy Giuliani's decision to run as a pro-choice presidential candidate will damage whomever emerges as the eventual Republican nominee in 2008: "As if Republicans don't have enough problems, their presidential candidates and interest groups seem eager to re-stage a fight over abortion the American public doesn't want to hear. Blame both Rudy Giuliani and his conservative critics, but
A mystery company outbid the state-controlled Rosneft  for assets belonging to what was once Russia’s biggest oil producer.

KB Home, the fifth-largest homebuilder in the United States, received an offer worth 580 million euros ($782 million) for its 49 percent stake in Kaufman & Broad, the biggest home builder in Paris and the surrounding region.

Goldman Sachs said Thursday that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1 after it emerged that he had lied during legal proceedings about how he met a former lover, had resigned from the Goldman board. Mr. Browne, who helped build the London-based BP into one of the largest oil companies in the world, had been a Goldman director since the investment bank went public in May 1999.

Certain neighborhoods in Brooklyn seem to have become the most blog-rich areas of the United States, according to a recent informal survey by the blog Outside.in. So where better to take the pulse of this rapidly growing community of writers, thinkers and observers than the second annual Brooklyn Blogfest?

Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, plans to file to list its first publicly traded fund by the end of June, BusinessWeek.com's Deal Flow blog reported, citing people familiar with the transaction. The Washington-based firm will list a leveraged finance fund made up primarily of mortgage-backed securities on the Euronext.

Opie and Anthony, who ended up on satellite radio after being fired from a New York radio station for mixing transgressive sex and religion, have sparked a new uproar. This time, it is over mixing transgressive sex and politics.

David G. Neeleman, the founder of JetBlue Airways, reluctantly agreed to step aside as the company's chief executive Thursday. The move marked a turning point in the short history of the upstart airline, but it also gave new life to recent speculation that the low-cost carrier might be a candidate for a takeover. JetBlue's shares rose 4.7 percent after the move was announced.

Google, which last month announced a deal to buy online ad firm DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, said that while it has become more comfortable doing big acquisitions, it still sees small technology deals as its primary thrust for buying businesses.

Terra Firma, the private equity group run by British financier Guy Hands, doubled the size of its aircraft leasing business on Friday with the acquisition of San Francisco-based Pegasus Aviation Finance for $5.2 billion.
The largest institutional shareholder of Wendy's International is urging the hamburger chain to sell itself to the highest bidder, The Wall Street Journal reported.

As the hew and cry over rich executive pay intensifies, members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

A federal jury in Brooklyn on Thursday acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of the A. B. Watley Group, a day trading firm, of securities fraud in what became known as the "squawk box" case.
Scenes from the Historic Old Northeast neighborhood of St. Petersburg, Fla., a front-porch kind of place close to downtown.

China will allow the country's commercial banks to buy stocks abroad, in a move that may release some of the nation's 35 trillion yuan ($4.6 trillion) of savings on overseas equity markets for the first time.
Private investment firm Oaktree Capital Management is set to be the first firm to list on Goldman Sachs's new private market set to launch this month, according to press reports.

Apple chief Steven P. Jobs faced a barrage of questions from shareholders about the company's handling of stock option grants and its policy of executive compensation, during a an annual meeting Thursday. But Mr. Jobs, with his typical flair for showmanship, elicited laughs and applause during the meeting despite rankling questions.
NeuroVista, a Seattle medical device company developing treatments for epilepsy, has raised $33.8 million in a second round of funding led by Advanced Technology Ventures and Delphi Ventures.
Whole Foods Market has confirmed that antitrust regulators appear have serious issues with the company's planned $700 million cash purchase of rival grocery store chain Wild Oats Markets.

Penthouse International settled charges of accounting fraud and financial reporting violations, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday. Former Penthouse executive Charles Samel and former shareholder Jason Galanis also agreed to each pay $60,000 to settle accounting fraud charges, the S.E.C. said.

A flurry of banking deals in South Korea's asset management sector are in the offing, as a law that allows banks to bring asset management under the same roof as other financial services is expected to go into effect.

The SLM Corporation, the student loan provider better known as Sallie Mae, on Thursday said two regulators are probing trading in its stock prior to its April 16 announcement that it would be taken private in a $25.2 billion deal.
The well-kept turn-of-the-century houses in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, charmed Darcey Steinke.
In an era of mammoth buyouts, private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus are apparently determined to exercise control in their bid for British retail chain New Look.
Public pension funds have long been big investors in private equity. Now, some big Canadian pension funds are taking a page from the private equity playback and taking the lead in buyouts.

The board of Australian energy company Alinta on Friday recommended shareholders accept an A$8 billion ($6.64 billion) takeover offer by investment bank Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power, potentially ending a bidding war with Macquarie Bank.

American Golf, the country's largest golf course owner and operator, is on the block and may fetch more than $1 billion, according to The Deal.com. The company, which manages more than 160 courses, is owned by private equity affiliates of Goldman Sachs and prominent real estate investment business Starwood Capital Group.
Those hoping for transformative merger for the Ford Motor Company were disappointed Thursday when the troubled automaker poured cold water on the notion that it might be considering a deal.

JMP Group, a San Francisco-based investment bank, sold nearly 8 million shares at $11 apiece in its initial public offering. The shares represented a stake of about 38 percent in the company, according to its prospectus.
Venture capitalists are enjoying growing prominence and swelling investment coffers, and they are taking and receiving credit for considerable job and wealth creation.

The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology was sentenced Thursday to a year and one day in prison for his role in a stock options backdating scheme, becoming the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes.

F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

The American International Group has filed a bondholders' lawsuit against Tyco International to stop the conglomerate's planned bond tender offer, accusing Tyco of trying to buy back its debt on the cheap.

Amid concerns that the recent buyout boom could take an ugly turn, yet another law firm is gearing up to be in the right place at the right time if and when it does. O'Melveny & Myers said Thursday that it hired a trio of bankruptcy specialists and the co-chair of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan's restructuring practice in preparation for portfolio company blowups involving its private equity and distressed-debt fund clients.

VTB, Russia's second-largest bank, raised about $8 billion in its initial public offering, which drew heavy interest from the country's institutional and retail investors. The bank sold a 22.5 percent stake in what was the largest I.P.O. of the year and Russia's third-largest stock sale ever.
When British Prime Minister Tony Blair steps down on June 27, he's expected to retire to his home in Connaught Square, an elegant central London base near Marble Arch.
News on the Ensemble Studio Theater’s “Marathon 2007” and Tamyra Gray’s return to Broadway.
Salifou Yankene, a former child soldier from Ivory Coast who is seeking asylum in the United States, faces a long road to healing.
This season, dresses are a swinging affair, with silhouettes that float far from the body and high above the knee.
A co-op can prohibit subletting the space and can probably decline to reimburse the shareholder.
Is it permissible for a tenant to display a religious symbol in the window that is visible from the outside?
Bill Clinton recently filmed a five-minute video, which is being sent to new and old allies, narrating Hillary Rodham Clinton’s biography and lavishing praise on her.
The Vatican and the Brazilian government seem to be at an impasse in their efforts to negotiate a new accord that would regulate the Roman Catholic Church’s status and presence in Brazil.
If you’re lucky, you inherit more than just the fashion gene.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

The Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers. Films that appear to glamorize smoking will risk a more restrictive rating, and descriptions of tobacco use will be added to the increasingly detailed advisories that accompany each rated film.
“Georgia Rule,” directed by Garry Marshall from a script by Mark Andrus, swerves and spins, taking its predictable plot in some surprising directions.
The best jokes in “The Ex,” a scattershot screwball satire of job insecurity, upward mobility, political correctness and yuppie marital tensions, have claws that leave scratches.
The characters in the western “Disappearances” speak in biblical cadences. The movie’s code, however, is the same kill-or-be-killed law of the jungle.
With its tone of unremitting gentility “Provoked” may be the most restrained wife-beating drama ever to grace a movie screen.
Justice Department lawyers said they were no longer asking to limit the lawyers to a total of three visits with detainees.
A majority of Iraq’s parliament has signed a petition for a legislative timetable governing a withdrawal of American troops from Iraq.
After the ceremony, Benedict XVI called for more forceful evangelization efforts throughout Latin America.

HONG KONG, May 11 — José Ramos-Horta won a decisive victory in East Timor’s presidential election this week, a significant move toward creating genuine multi-party democracy in the country and breaking the dominance of the political organization that largely led its struggle for independence, analysts and election observers said today.
Rudolph W. Giuliani said that he favors abortion rights, certain restrictions on gun ownership and gay rights.
Today, as parents arrived for graduation ceremonies, it was hard to tell the tears of joy from those of sadness.
The fighting put new strains on the Palestinian “unity” government in which both parties participate.
Barack Obama presents himself as a force of political nature ready to be swept into the White House. Yet at the same time, he seeks to lower the lofty expectations that have elevated his candidacy.
Up to 40 National Guard troops will begin patrolling 13 PATH stations in New York and New Jersey starting next week.
The men, charged with plotting to attack Fort Dix, were arrested on Tuesday after a 15-month investigation.
Firefighters struggled today to prevent a wildfire from reaching homes on the edge of Santa Catalina Island.
A police oversight body ruled today that 11 officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 27-year-old Brazilian electrician would not face disciplinary hearings.
The vice president warned that the U.S. was prepared to use its naval power to keep Tehran from disrupting oil shipments or gaining nuclear weapons.
Mr. Brown planned a busy campaign to persuade Britons of his suitability for the job of prime minister.
A 37-year-old police officer was arrested last night in connection with the fatal shooting of his girlfriend on a Queens street after she broke up with him, the police said.

An off-duty police officer was arrested for fatally shooting his 22-year-old girlfriend in the head last night on a Queens street, according to Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. The girlfriend reportedly wanted to break up with the officer, investigators said. Witnesses said they saw the officer and his girlfriend fighting on the street, near the intersection of Atlantic Avenue and 82nd Street, shortly before 8 p.m. The woman broke away from the conversation, then the man took out his gun, ran up to her and shot her in the head, according to witnesses. She was declared dead at the scene. It was unclear last night what the charges against the officer would be. The police were not releasing the names of the officer or the woman.

One man was fatally shot and another was critically wounded yesterday afternoon in an apartment building at 1143 Noble Avenue, the police said. The men, who were not identified by the police, were found in a hallway of the building at 2:42 p.m. One of the men, who had been shot in the head, was declared dead on arrival at Jacobi Medical Center. The other man, shot in the torso, remained in critical condition last night at Jacobi.

RICHMOND, Va., May 10 (AP) — Virginia’s attorney general has warned Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg about a new law that will prevent the mayor from sending undercover private investigators to buy guns in Virginia.
Oleg Saprykin helped the Ottawa Senators further shed their label as underachievers and get a jump on the rival Buffalo Sabres.
Lawyers for Peter Braunstein presented what they said was scientific evidence that his transformation from successful media writer to sex abuse suspect was due to schizophrenia.
A Manhattan Supreme Court justice ruled Thursday that Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, can carry the NFL Network on a digital sports tier.
A tunnel project is meant to cure decades of transportation frustration by realizing the long-held goal of connecting the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal.

Nearly six months after the bodies of four prostitutes were found in a ditch on the outskirts of Atlantic City, tips have slowed to a trickle. The task force investigating the deaths, which used to gather every day after the gruesome discovery, now meets only twice a week.

The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the world’s tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Laden’s relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team).

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger will propose privatizing the state’s lottery as a way to generate money to pay down debt and finance his public works spending and health care proposals, a spokesman said. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, will detail the lottery proposal on Sunday when he revises his budget for the coming fiscal year, said the spokesman, Adam Mendelsohn. Under the plan, the state would lease the lottery to a private company in exchange for as much as $37 billion in either a lump sum or in payments.
If keeping intelligent tabs on the Brooklyn Public Library is what passes for bookish these days, then Dionne Mack-Harvin is a consummate librarian.

A terminally ill woman who sued the United States government over the right to use medical marijuana, as state law allows, said she was dropping her five-year legal battle. The woman, Angel M. Raich, 41, of Oakland, said in a statement that she had decided to concentrate on radiation therapy to treat a brain tumor, rather than appealing a federal court ruling that she was not immune to federal prosecution despite California law. “I’m not a quitter, so this was a hard decision,” said Ms. Raich, who has never been prosecuted. She said she intended to take her battle to Congress.

A Mexican immigrant jailed on a drug trafficking charge was freed in a plea deal after the authorities learned that a federal agent had him pose for a demeaning photograph wearing a sombrero and holding a Mexican flag. The immigrant, Jorge Hernandez-Villalvazo, a native of Mexico with permanent United States residency, was arrested in April 2005 on a charge of conspiring to traffic in cocaine. District Attorney C. Colon Willoughby Jr. of Wake County said the photo had been taken by a Drug Enforcement Administration agent assisting in Mr. Hernandez-Villalvazo’s arrest.

Jurors in Santa Ana convicted a Chinese-born engineer of conspiring to export United States military technology to China. The engineer, Chi Mak, was also found guilty of being an unregistered foreign agent. He faces up to 35 years in prison. The authorities say Mr. Mak, a naturalized citizen, took thousands of pages of documents from his employer, Power Paragon of Anaheim, and gave them to his brother, who prosecutors say passed them along to Chinese authorities for years. Gregory W. Staples, an assistant United States attorney, said the government might use the verdict to try to negotiate plea bargains with members of Mr. Mak’s family who are awaiting trial this month.

The federal Merit Systems Protection Board has ordered the Smithsonian Institution to reinstate a whistle-blower fired in 2002. The board rejected an appeal from the Smithsonian, ruling Wednesday that “the administrative judge made no error in law or regulation” in finding that the whistle-blower, Michael D. Cross, had been fired for reporting illegal activities at the National Air and Space Museum, specifically that supervisors had told employees to do work outside their official duties.

Texas State University’s plan to build the nation’s largest “body farm” of cadavers has been delayed over concerns that buzzards drawn to the area could endanger nearby planes. The university, in San Marcos, between Austin and San Antonio, had hoped to begin burying bodies later this year on a 17-acre site near the San Marcos Municipal Airport. But after meeting with the airport’s commission on Tuesday, the university dropped the plan. The site was to have included vulture-proof cages to protect exposed bodies. The farms are used by scientists to study human decomposition to help the police better determine time and manner of death in crimes.

Eric J. Deutsch, president of the Downtown Alliance since 2005, will leave the organization for a private-sector job, the alliance announced this week. Mr. Deutsch, former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, will leave the Downtown Alliance, a business improvement district, on June 1 and become managing director at the Clarett Group, a real estate development company. The alliance did not announce a replacement yesterday.

A civilian employee of the Police Department and two of his friends were charged yesterday with stealing about $30,000 worth of property that belonged to defendants and crime victims, prosecutors said. The employee, Kevin Byrd, 36, of Springfield Gardens, Queens, faces charges including grand larceny, forgery and criminal possession of stolen property, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Mr. Byrd was the evidence and property control specialist for the 28th Precinct, in Harlem, Mr. Morgenthau said. He said that from October 2006 until January, Mr. Byrd forged vouchers for property and cash, and stole personal items, including a dead man’s wedding ring. Mr. Byrd’s friends — James Goorahoo, 37, of Springfield Gardens, and Jermal Williams, 36, of Laurelton, Queens — were also charged with grand larceny. Pretending to be crime victims, they exchanged the fake cash vouchers for checks at Police Headquarters, then split the money with Mr. Byrd, prosecutors said.

Kennedy Valve, an Elmira-based company that has been manufacturing fire hydrants since the 1890s, pleaded guilty yesterday in Chemung County Court to illegally dumping more than two tons of lead-contaminated waste from 2001 to 2004 in a county landfill that was not licensed to handle hazardous material. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said the company claimed the material was not hazardous when it applied for a dumping permit. Samples of the waste were subsequently sent for analysis to laboratories that confirmed that it contained lead, Mr. Cuomo said. The company was fined $300,000 for unlawful dealing in hazardous wastes and agreed to pay $1.5 million to finance a lead removal program for children. Kennedy Valve is a division of McWane Inc., a manufacturer that has been convicted of safety and environmental violations in several states.

New York City’s largest fire union announced yesterday that its members had voted to ratify a 24-month contract that gives raises totaling 8.16 percent. The union, the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said the vote was 4,037 to 3,115 to approve the deal, which raises starting pay by $9,900 to $35,000 and increases base salary after five years on the job to $68,475. The deal is retroactive to Aug. 1, 2006 and runs through July 31, 2008. To help finance the raises, the agreement calls for new firefighters to receive lower night differential pay and six fewer paid holidays each year during their first five years on the job.

A St. Albans man was arraigned Wednesday night on charges of robbing the bishop of a Queens church and later assaulting a woman and an off-duty police officer at a restaurant, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Oluwafemi Olowofela, 25, of 194th Street, was charged with robbery, burglary and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Olowofela is accused of robbing the Rev. Melvin Artis, 67, at gunpoint on Tuesday afternoon inside the Greater Universal Highway Deliverance Church on Linden Boulevard. He is also charged with attacking a 43-year-old woman later that day, and fighting with Officer Malik Kirkland, who came to her aid and apprehended him, Mr. Brown said.

State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli issued a report yesterday that said the state budget is $2.9 billion larger than previously thought, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s budget director, Paul E. Francis, responded that the comptroller’s numbers were inaccurate because he counted capital spending items not traditionally included in the budget. The governor’s office has estimated the budget at $121 billion, while the comptroller’s estimate is $124 billion, leading to a dispute over how much the state is spending. “The next step toward budget reform has to focus on spending restraint,” said Mr. DiNapoli, above. Mr. Spitzer opposed Mr. DiNapoli’s appointment to the comptroller’s office after the resignation of Alan G. Hevesi, saying that Mr. DiNapoli, then a Democratic assemblyman, did not have the knowledge of finance necessary for the job, but recently he has been more conciliatory.

In a contentious meeting yesterday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission unanimously approved a plan to install touch-screen monitors in all 13,000 city cabs over the next several months. About 200 cabs have been experimenting with the monitors, which allow riders to pay by credit card, check news stories and map where the cab is going. Many drivers oppose the monitors, arguing that the technology is costly and will allow officials to check up on them.

Newly elected and appointed public officials will not receive taxpayerfinanced pensions under legislation signed yesterday by Gov. Jon S. Corzine. The law is meant to help control property taxes, which average $6,330 per homeowner, twice the national average. The law requires new officials to participate in a 401(k)-type retirement plan. It also bars, as of Jan. 1, contractors like municipal lawyers and engineers from receiving public pensions.

Bob McDonnell, the attorney general of Virginia, has warned Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg about a new Virginia law that will prevent the city from sending undercover private investigators to buy guns in Virginia. In an attempt to stem illegal guns entering New York, the city has sued gun dealers in other states, including Virginia, after conducting undercover operations that sought to reveal violations of gun laws. In a letter written last month, Mr. McDonnell advised Mayor Bloomberg that a new law makes undercover purchases by non-law-enforcement entities a felony. Jason Post, a spokesman for the mayor, said the city would continue to “develop innovative and aggressive ways to keep New Yorkers safe.”.

The police are investigating a threatening message found on a Connecticut College chalkboard Wednesday that seemed to make reference to the recent deadly rampage at Virginia Tech. Discovered at 6:34 a.m. by a campus security officer, the chalked message said, “V.T.” and “I can kill more than that.” Eric Cardenas, a spokesman for Connecticut College, said the New London police and the campus safety department were investigating. “At this point, our best assessment is that it was a very ill-advised prank, but we’re taking it seriously,” he said. Classes at the private four-year college end this week, but Mr. Cardenas said the Fanning Hall classroom, where the message was found, would not be used again this semester. Compiled by John Sullivan.

An article on Wednesday about an ethics panel report clearing Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, of conflicts of interest in conducting state labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship referred incorrectly to The Times’s efforts to reach the governor’s office for comment. The reporter sent an e-mail message to a Corzine spokesman; he did not place phone calls. (The message was never delivered because of technical problems, but the reporter was not aware of that until the next day.).

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the producer Scott Rudin referred incorrectly to the release date of his movie “The Manchurian Candidate.” It was released in July 2004; it was not among his movies that were released near the year-end holidays that year.

Because of an editing error, the NYC column last Friday — about Peter Kaufman, who takes action against air-conditioned commercial buildings that waste energy by keeping their doors open in the summer — referred incorrectly in some copies to comments from Robert W. Walsh, New York’s commissioner of small business services, on proposed legislation that would fine violators. His comments — that before resorting to bans and fines, the city should educate the wastrels about the harm they do — should have been rendered as a paraphrase, not as a direct quotation.

A music column on May 1 about the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival referred incorrectly to a song performed by Bonnie Raitt, “God Was in the Water.” It is by Randall Bramblett and Davis Causey, not by Ms. Raitt.

An article in The Arts yesterday about winners of the Lukas Prize Project Awards, which recognize excellence in nonfiction writing, misspelled the name of the foundation that jointly administers the prizes with the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. It is the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University — not Neiman.

An article in Business Day on Monday about two minority partners in Dow Jones & Company who criticized a takeover attempt by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation referred incorrectly to the ownership of Dow Jones’s Class B stock, which has 10 times the voting power of a regular share. The Ottaway and Bancroft families are the largest owners of Class B shares, they are not the sole owners. (Shareholders were given Class B shares in the 1980s.).

A theater review on Monday about “Beauty on the Vine,” at the Harold Clurman Theater, referred incorrectly to the play’s sponsorship. Donna Karan contributed one costume and Lancôme made a small financial contribution. The play is not sponsored by “various cosmetic and fashion companies.”.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the heavy debt incurred by culinary students who rely on student loans misstated the name of the California school attended by a student who returned to New York to help pay her bills. It is the California Culinary Academy, not the California Culinary Institute. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the format of the ShawGuides to culinary schools. It is published online; it is no longer a book.

A report in the National Briefing column in some editions on Tuesday, about the Smithsonian Institution’s search for a new secretary, referred incorrectly to the status of Walter E. Massey, a member of the search committee. His reappointment to the board of regents is pending before Congress; he has not been a regent since his term ended in March. The report also misstated the title of Roger W. Sant, also on the search committee. He is chairman of the regent executive committee, not chairman emeritus.

A report in the Sports Briefing column yesterday about the College Football Hall of Fame’s newest inductees misidentified the university affiliation of Herb Deromedi, a coach who will be enshrined. He coached at Central Michigan, not Eastern Michigan.
Vince Carter said Thursday that he was playing like garbage, a rare admission for a star guard who generally chafes at criticism.
Tayshaun Prince scored 23 points and Chauncey Billups added 21 last night, and the visiting Detroit Pistons rallied from a 19-point deficit to beat the Chicago Bulls
hockey.
The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin pleaded guilty to criminal charges that the firm had misled doctors and patients.
The agreement clears the way for early passage of some pending trade accords and improves prospects for others.
Sarah Lee tied the course record with an eight-under 63 and  Mi Hyun Kim Kim was one back after a bogey-free 64 in the first round of the Michelob Ultra Open.
Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.
Joost, a start-up that delivers television programming over the Internet, said that it had received $45 million in financing.
After months of being beaten up over a service meltdown at the company he founded, David G. Neeleman reluctantly agreed to step aside.
A federal jury in Brooklyn acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of securities fraud charges in what became known as the “squawk box” case.
After emerging as the Mets’ most reliable left-handed reliever last season, 30-year-old Pedro Feliciano has not allowed an earned run this season in 13 1/3 innings.

Isabella Blow, the colorful and influential British fashion editor, talent spotter and aristocrat who died in a hospital in Gloucestershire on Monday, ended her life by drinking the herbicide paraquat, The Times of London reported on its Web site. It said that at the opening of an inquest into her death yesterday, the deputy Gloucestershire coroner, David Dooley, reported that after Ms. Blow, 48, was “found in a poorly state” on Saturday and taken to the hospital, “she told doctors she had taken paraquat, and tests proved positive for this liquid.” Further toxicological tests are to be done before a full inquest in October.
The Blue Devils earned their first top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which begins Saturday. Yet the team is still haunted by last year’s rape allegations.
Many conservative Christians are concerned about Mitt Romney’s religion and his recent shift on abortion rights.

José Ramos-Horta, the prime minister and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, held a commanding lead in the country’s presidential runoff election on Wednesday. With 90 percent of the ballots counted, he had 73 percent of the votes against 27 percent for his challenger, Francisco Guterres, the president of the governing Fretilin party and the speaker of Parliament, said Maria Angelina Sarmento, a spokeswoman for the National Election Commission.

Survivors of a capsizing last week that killed at least 61 Haitian migrants say a patrol boat from Turks and Caicos, a British territory in the West Indies, rammed them, towed them into deeper water and abandoned their overturned sailboat in the shark-infested waters. They said their boat, loaded with an estimated 160 people, was minutes away from the territory when the patrol boat rammed them in the predawn darkness. The Turks and Caicos government has said it will not comment until two investigations are completed. Britain’s Foreign Office also declined to comment. At the United Nations in New York, Michèle Montas, a Haitian who is the spokeswoman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, described the capsizing as “a tragedy” and said “it could have been avoided.” She said the issue was between the Turks and Caicos Islands and Haiti.

More than 5,000 people poured into the streets of several cities to protest a crackdown on leftist groups before a Group of 8 meeting in the city of Heiligendamm next month. The police in Hamburg clashed with demonstrators there, arresting eight people. Some opposition leaders criticized the raids, saying the police were trying to intimidate legitimate opponents of the meeting.

The United States has halted some aid to Sri Lanka as human rights abuses rise in the renewed civil war, Richard A. Boucher, the assistant secretary of state for South and Central Asia, said as he wrapped up a three-day visit. He said Washington was concerned by a spate of abductions and killings attributed to each side in the conflict, as well as freedom of the press. Britain last week suspended $3 million in debt relief aid, citing rights abuses and mushrooming military spending.

A roadside bomb killed 10 soldiers patrolling in western Valle del Cauca Province, the authorities said. They blamed the leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The rebel group was also blamed for a road bombing a day earlier that killed nine policemen in central Santander.
Education Secretary Margaret Spellings argued at a House hearing that she lacked legal authority to clamp down on many abuses in the student loan industry.

The United States has requested the extradition of the reputed Tijuana drug kingpin Benjamín Arellano-Félix, left, now in jail in Mexico for arms possession, so he can be tried in California on trafficking charges, his lawyer said. The recently elected president, Felipe Calderón, has broken with practice and extradited other major traffickers, and Mr. Arellano-Félix is said to be one of the last captured Mexican drug barons yet to be tried in the United States. His lawyer, Américo Delgado, said he planned to appeal the extradition request, from the United States Attorney’s Office in San Diego.
The general in charge of the marines who killed 24 civilians in Haditha, Iraq, said his staff hid information.
NBC took the first steps toward rebuilding its prime-time schedule by ordering five new hours of drama programs, which will be part of the fall schedule.
Benedict XVI did not refer to abortion in his address to young Brazilians or in a formal meeting with Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
Congress is looking into potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do lucrative work for companies whose pay they help devise.
Utah point guard Derek Fisher put his daughter’s health before the playoffs Wednesday, missing most of the game. He then returned to seal the win for the Jazz.
President Bush offered the concession even as he threatened to veto a House plan approved Thursday on a 221-to-205 vote.
President Bush has yet to acknowledge the reality in Iraq that Congressional Republicans and even administration officials like Defense Secretary Robert Gates now seem to tacitly accept.
Bowing to safety concerns, government medical advisers urged on Thursday that additional restrictions be put on the use of drugs that treat anemia in cancer patients.
Pacman Jones plans to appeal his year-long suspension by citing other players who have been involved in off-the-field misconduct and received lesser penalties by the N.F.L.
A man was convicted Thursday of murdering seven people at a restaurant in 1993, a crime that shook a quiet suburb and stumped investigators for years.

The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the world’s tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Laden’s relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team).
The United States made a disastrous miscalculation when it started automatically trying youthful offenders as adults instead of handling them through the juvenile courts.
A former Morgan Stanley employee and her husband pleaded guilty to insider trading charges, while another couple was arrested and charged in a separate case.
Nascar’s most popular driver announced that his future would not include racing for Dale Earnhardt Inc.
European leaders said that Paul D. Wolfowitz would face a no-confidence vote next week by the World Bank’s board.
The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers.
The Interpublic Group of Companies posted a larger-than-expected quarterly loss yesterday as it struggled with high salary costs and weak revenue in Europe and Asia.
The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology became the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes.
The first round of the 2007 Players Championship will be recalled for Rory Sabbatini’s latest dig at Tiger Woods, the No. 1 player in the world.
The defendant is a powerful former alderman who in the 1980s led a bitter rebellion of white politicians against the city’s first black mayor.
Some much needed changes at the agency now seem likely to gain full Congressional approval and become law.
It would be a fine gesture if both Floyd Mayweather and Oscar De La Hoya dedicated some portion of their treasures to aid indigent boxers.
Members of the New York metropolitan region’s Albanian-American community are struggling to understand the motivations of the suspects accused of planning an attack on Fort Dix.
Vonage said that its quarterly loss narrowed and sales rose 64 percent amid a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left its future in question.
Purdue University has begun a new inquiry into a professor who claims to have generated nuclear fusion in a desktop experiment.
City officials are asking developers if they want to build apartments pressed up on the side of the Brooklyn House of Detention.

The American International Group has filed a bondholders’ lawsuit against Tyco International to stop the conglomerate’s planned bond tender offer, saying Tyco was offering a below-contract price for its debt.

DOWNERS GROVE, Ill., May 10 (AP) — The food and household products maker Sara Lee Corporation said Thursday that its third-quarter profit nearly tripled on revenue growth in its international beverage, bakery, household and body care segments.

The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1 after it emerged that he had lied during legal proceedings about how he met a former lover, had resigned from the Goldman board.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales stuck to his past assertions that the firings were appropriate.
A large, distant supernova offers a glimpse into the making of the very atomic stuff out of which we ourselves are made.

EchoStar Communications, parent of the Dish Network satellite television service, said yesterday that its quarterly profit rose 7 percent as subscriber growth helped overcome higher marketing costs in the face of tough competition.
Residents said the death toll was much higher than the official figure of 21, and may be as high as 50 or even 80.

The American International Group, one of the world’s largest insurers, said yesterday that its profit rose more than 29 percent in the first quarter on strong growth in underwriting results and investment income.
Mr. Maiman was a physicist who, in 1960, demonstrated the world’s first laser, a device small enough to fit in his hand.
Aides say Gov. Jon S. Corzine is itching to return to the business of government — but he is limited in what he can do.
Sales were dismal, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on consumers.
Perennial losers, the Milwaukee Brewers have the best record in the majors and are hoping to end a 25-year playoff drought.

Ken Griffey Jr. hit his 569th career homer yesterday, a two-run shot that tied him for ninth place on the career list and helped the Cincinnati Reds get a breakthrough 9-5 victory against the visiting Houston Astros.
British officials are greatly concerned about the continued ability of Al Qaeda leaders to direct terrorist operations across the world.
California is beginning to address the issue of deaths caused by accidents involving objects on highways.
A strategy announcement by Google is less a shift than a new message — a way for the company to talk about its initiatives in a way shareholders can readily understand.
The European Central Bank signaled that it would lift borrowing costs as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation.
Bristol-Myers Squibb said that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government.
President Bush is opting to continue with Gen. Peter Pace for a second term during a critical phase in the Iraq conflict.

LONDON, May 10 — ABN Amro, the Dutch bank that is the target of one of the world’s largest takeover battles, said Thursday that Hugh Y. Scott-Barrett, its chief financial officer, had handed in his resignation, amid other departures from the bank.
The fence is part of a plan to prevent raids by militants, despite opposition from Afghanistan.
To the Editor:.

To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The area where city officials found an industrial chemical in the drinking water last week has had problems with contamination by the same chemical for several years.
With the Tour de France approaching this summer, the sport of cycling is taking brutal spills in corporate suites.
The Israeli prime minister said that the killing of civilians in Qana was a turning point that delayed a resolution.
Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Michael B. Enzi worked together in an unusual display of bipartisanship to make the bill passable.
New York State is forcing the closure of a power plant whose emissions have been linked to acid rain and smog.
Vice President Dick Cheney made no promise that an end to the fighting was in sight, a stark contrast to an earlier assessment than the insurgency was in its “last throes.”
The media conglomerate Viacom said that its first-quarter profit fell 36 percent, dragged down by revamping charges and higher costs at its MTV Networks.
Tyler Hamilton of the U.S. and Joerg Jaksche of Germany were suspended by their team Wednesday following pressure to ban riders implicated in the Spanish doping scandal.
The group demanded that President Bush impose sanctions against the Sudanese government for its failure to rein in the violence.
A State Senate committee passed a bill that would make New Jersey the first state to abolish the death penalty since states began reinstating their capital punishment laws more than 30 years ago.
The Treasury Department sent a letter to Michael Moore, a provocative filmmaker, to investigate whether he had violated restrictions on travel to Cuba.
The local government has cleaned up a boulevard that once symbolized effervescent intellectual life in Caracas.
Twelve candidates are in a wild scramble to head the nation’s ninth-largest metropolis, long troubled by crime, scandals, racial polarization and government gridlock.
A man convicted in the murder of a record store owner in 1985 will receive a new trial on charges of second-degree murder.
The change had been sought by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan to circumvent Turkey’s powerful secular establishment.
Gino Pariani played for the United States on the 1950 team that produced one of the greatest upsets in World Cup history.
David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination and was again called a liar.
A wealthy developer and the venerable auction house are at war as the Sotheby’s building awaits a buyer.

(Sundance) MUTUAL APPRECIATION (2005) This “wonderful independent film” directed by Andrew Bujalski “looks like something that just came out of a time capsule, but there’s nothing dusty about it,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, comparing its “artfully artless, low-fi vibe” to the French New Wave and the East Village film scene of the late 1970s. Alan (Justin Rice, above), a musician whose band has just broken up, arrives in New York in pursuit of a rock ’n’ roll career. Seung-Min Lee, at his left, plays Sara, a radio D.J. who would like more from Alan than he wants to give; Mr. Bujalski is Lawrence, Alan’s best friend; and Rachel Clift is Ellie, Lawrence’s girlfriend — and the woman Alan would take, if he could. “It’s the sort of unassuming discovery that could get lost in a crowd or suffer from too much big love, and while it won’t save or change your life, it may make your heart swell,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “Its aim is modest and true.”.

An article last Friday about the Flint Hills Scenic Byway in eastern Kansas misspelled the name of an anti-alcohol campaigner who was active a century ago in the area. She was Carry Nation, not Carrie, although she and others sometimes used that spelling.

Washburn Gallery 20 West 57th Street, Manhattan Through June 29 Myron Stout was one of those marvelous independent spirits who came of age with Abstract Expressionism. Abstract Expressionism was big, extravagant and self-obsessed. Stout's work was small, intimate and spare. Among midcentury geometric painters like Burgoyne Diller, Ilya Bolotowsky and Stuart Davis, he was the most poetic.

Off to War: Kim Cattrall And Daniel Radcliffe When Kim Cattrall of ''Sex and the City'' meets Daniel Radcliffe of ''Harry Potter'' the result will be ''My Boy Jack,'' a film to be shot in Ireland in July. Under the direction of Brian Kirk (''The Tudors''), this ITV production will be based on David Haig's adaptation of his play of the same title about Rudyard Kipling and his family. In it, Kipling and his wife, Caroline (Ms. Cattrall), search for their son, John (Mr. Radcliffe), who vanished in World War I. Charlie Chaplin Camera To Be Auctioned The camera used by Charlie Chaplin to film movies, including ''The Kid'' (1921) and ''The Gold Rush'' (1925), will be offered at auction by Christie's in London on July 25, the BBC reported. Chaplin bought the camera, a Bell & Howell 2709, above, considered a classic of the silent era, for his Chaplin Studios in Hollywood. The camera is expected to fetch $140,000 to $180,000. Marathon of Plays Works by Stephen Adly Guirgis and Neil LaBute, among others, will be in ''Marathon 2007,'' Ensemble Studio Theater's 29th festival of new one-act plays, from May 31 through June 30 at the theater. The festival will offer nine world premieres and one New York premiere in two series, running in rotating repertory for 16 performances each. Tamyra Gray, who finished fourth in the first season of ''American Idol'' and then played a recurring role in ''Boston Public'' and make her Broadway debut in ''Bombay Dreams,'' will join the cast of ''Rent'' in the role of Mimi Marquez at the Nederlander Theater for six months beginning on May 29. Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp, who originated the roles of Roger David and Mark Cohen in the long-running hit (and its movie version), will return to the cast for six weeks beginning on July 30. Austin Festival Lineup Bob Dylan and His Band, Bjork, the White Stripes, the Killers and Arctic Monkeys are scheduled to perform at the Austin City Limits Music Festival in Zilker Park in Austin, Tex., from Sept. 14 to 16. Also among the 130 acts on eight stages will be Joss Stone, the Decemberists, Amy Winehouse and Kaiser Chiefs. Organizers said last year's festival drew 200,000 people. New Contest to Seek 'Great American Band' Simon Fuller, the British-born creator of the ''Idol'' series of singing competitions and former manager of the Spice Girls, is planning a new televised contest, Reuters reported. Given a go-ahead by Fox, this one will be, as its tentative title says, ''The Search for the Next Great American Band.'' Groups of all ages, styles and genres will vie for the ''Next Great American Band'' title and a recording contract. Like ''American Idol,'' the show will conduct nationwide auditions, and a panel of judges will narrow the hopefuls to 10 semifinalists who will perform in front of a studio audience in a weekly elimination contest. Reuters said Fox might begin broadcasts in the fall when ''American Idol'' is off its schedule. Footnote John R. Lane will retire next May as director of the Dallas Museum of Art. The museum announced yesterday that he will be succeeded by Bonnie Pitman, its deputy director since 2000.

Switchyard Guild & Greyshkul 28 Wooster Street, SoHo Through tomorrow Lisi Raskin's New York solo debut stretches drawing to installation size and projects it beyond the gallery. Guild & Greyshkul's windows are covered by graphite images of what look like dark clouds, facing the street, with each sheet of paper turning ragged at the top, like barbed wire, allowing a weird orange light to filter through from inside.

The changeability of Miles Davis has become a defining notion, seemingly as crucial to his legend as the music he made. It's one reason that Apple featured him in its ''Think Different'' advertisements a decade ago, alongside Bob Dylan and Picasso, chameleons with whom he is often compared. That quality also provides the premise for two concerts presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center this weekend under a mildly patronizing banner, ''The Many Moods of Miles Davis.'' Each concert will feature two ensembles and cover two incarnations of Davis's career. Tonight that means bebop and ''The Birth of the Cool,'' courtesy of the trumpeter Ryan Kisor, a member of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra; and then the exploratory post-bop of the 1960s, courtesy of another trumpeter, Terence Blanchard. (Each artist will lead a quintet.) Tomorrow night promises more cognitive dissonance. While Nicholas Payton will fill the Davis role on the landmark album ''Kind of Blue,'' the electric bassist Marcus Miller will reprise his own role in the music of the 1970s and '80s. Of course, there is some incongruity to conjuring Electric Miles on Jazz at Lincoln Center's stage. (Wynton Marsalis, the organization's artistic director, has characterized Davis's post-'60s output as a product of commercial capitulation.) Partly for this reason, the tribute may not do enough to emphasize the clarity of vision behind all those so-called moods. So it seems appropriate to note the concurrent club engagement of 4 Generations of Miles, involving veterans of Davis's employ. In chronological order of service, they are the drummer Jimmy Cobb, the tenor saxophonist George Coleman, the bassist Buster Williams and the guitarist Mike Stern. Their collective experience stretches as far back as the late '50s and runs up through the early '80s. Change will animate their music, to be sure, but continuity seems likely to play a part too. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, 212-721-6500, jalc.org; $30 to $120. 4 Generations of Miles performs tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 10, with a midnight set tonight and tomorrow, Iridium Jazz Club, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, 212-582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $35, with a $10 minimum.) Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, of conflicts of interest in conducting state labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship referred incorrectly to The Times's efforts to reach the governor's office for comment. The reporter sent an e-mail message to a Corzine spokesman; he did not place phone calls. Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Barry J. Hershey Not rated; 86 minutes ''Casting About,'' from the documentary filmmaker Barry J. Hershey (''The Empty Mirror''), is a record of casting calls for lead actresses in a dramatic feature that Mr. Hershey wrote but has yet to direct: a seemingly Hemingwayesque drama involving a wounded combat photographer, a nun, a dancer and a painter's model. From its opening montage of head shots through its fragments of auditions and between-performance chatter, ''Casting About'' is a solid documentary about how art is made.

An article in The Arts yesterday about winners of the Lukas Prize Project Awards, which recognize excellence in nonfiction writing, misspelled the name of the foundation that jointly administers the prizes with the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. It is the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University -- not Neiman.

Opens today nationwide Directed by Mark Brown 92 minutes In ''The Salon'' the normally vivacious Vivica A. Fox seems as artistically depleted as her surroundings: an urban beauty shop where cutting hair and cutting remarks go hand in hand. As Jenny, the beleaguered owner of a Baltimore beauty shop catering primarily to African-American women, Ms. Fox plays moderator to a relentless stream of high drama and low wit.

Kennedy Valve, an Elmira-based company that has been manufacturing fire hydrants since the 1890s, pleaded guilty yesterday in Chemung County Court to illegally dumping more than two tons of lead-contaminated waste from 2001 to 2004 in a county landfill that was not licensed to handle hazardous material. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said the company claimed the material was not hazardous when it applied for a dumping permit. Samples of the waste were subsequently sent for analysis to laboratories that confirmed that it contained lead, Mr. Cuomo said. The company was fined $300,000 for unlawful dealing in hazardous wastes and agreed to pay $1.5 million to finance a lead removal program for children. Kennedy Valve is a division of McWane Inc., a manufacturer that has been convicted of safety and environmental violations in several states. ANTHONY DePALMA

A music column on May 1 about the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival referred incorrectly to a song performed by Bonnie Raitt, ''God Was in the Water.'' It is by Randall Bramblett and Davis Causey, not by Ms. Raitt.

An exhibition of sweets as imagery and medium Lehman College Art Gallery 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, at Goulden Avenue Bedford Park, the Bronx Through Tuesday In its history, sugar has been the source of about as much misery as pleasure. ''Sugar Buzz,'' organized by Susan Hoeltzel and Nina Sundell, mostly skips the health and history lessons, however, and goes right to the giddy and whimsical aspects.

On the drive east to Walla Walla, there is no doubt that you are approaching wine country. Vineyards are visible from the highway and just in case you weren't sure, there is a big sign announcing that you are in wine country. I've lived in Washington for about 20 years and the profile of this area has really been raised for wine lovers. There are well over 50 wineries in Walla Walla now, and actually a number of tasting rooms are right downtown, which is about 10 blocks from my house. I've been to perhaps a half-dozen. Wineries from this region make a lot of cabernets, merlots and meritages, or red blends, but you also see some good rieslings and chardonnays. The big season for wine tourists started in mid-April and wineries put on events throughout the summer. The barrel tasting in early May is huge, and all the wineries open their doors with food and, of course, wine. As a vacation rental, this house attracts a lot of visitors coming for long weekends from Seattle.

The police are investigating a threatening message found on a Connecticut College chalkboard Wednesday that seemed to make reference to the recent deadly rampage at Virginia Tech. Discovered at 6:34 a.m. by a campus security officer, the chalked message said, ''V.T.'' and ''I can kill more than that.'' Eric Cardenas, a spokesman for Connecticut College, said the New London police and the campus safety department were investigating. ''At this point, our best assessment is that it was a very ill-advised prank, but we're taking it seriously,'' he said. Classes at the private four-year college end this week, but Mr. Cardenas said the Fanning Hall classroom, where the message was found, would not be used again this semester. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

STATEMAN--Ruth. Devoted wife of the late Daniel, wonderful mother of Keith and the late Ethan, and beloved grandmother. Funeral services Sunday, May 13, at 12 noon, Temple Beth Shalom, Flushing, New York.

To the Editor: Lawrence Downes (Editorial Observer, May 7), suggests that New Orleans has reverted to an earlier form of the American economy: one in which the abuse of labor is common, poverty is rampant and individuals are forced out of necessity to organize along racial lines.

The federal Merit Systems Protection Board has ordered the Smithsonian Institution to reinstate a whistle-blower fired in 2002. The board rejected an appeal from the Smithsonian, ruling Wednesday that ''the administrative judge made no error in law or regulation'' in finding that the whistle-blower, Michael D. Cross, had been fired for reporting illegal activities at the National Air and Space Museum, specifically that supervisors had told employees to do work outside their official duties. HOLLI CHMELA

Opens today nationwide Directed by Matt Ruskin 90 minutes Giving ''inspirational'' a good name, Matt Ruskin's vibrant and soulful documentary ''The Hip Hop Project'' sets its universal message to an inner-city beat. Named for the New York City youth program founded in 1999 by Chris Rolle, known as Kazi, a Bahamian orphan forced to grow up on the streets of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the movie follows his efforts to encourage at-risk teenagers to express themselves in verse rather than violence.

'ANYTHING GOES' (Tonight through Sunday) These days, anything goes, and that includes very young actors performing Cole Porter. This production is by the Pied Piper Children's Theater of NYC. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 4 p.m., Holy Trinity Church, 20 Cumming Street, near Broadway, Inwood, (212) 544-2976; $10; $7 for under 16 and 65+. 'BUG BOY BLUES' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Kafka for kids? That's roughly the idea behind this show by Lisa Railsback, which explores the mind of young Gregor Samsa, subject of ''The Metamorphosis.'' (Through June 3.) Tomorrow at noon and 2 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m., the Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 352-3101; $12; $10 for 12 and under. 'DANCE MAKERS & GROUND BREAKERS' (Tomorrow) Both these artistic categories are represented by children in this celebratory evening, which showcases the creativity of 80 students who have spent the last nine months in choreography workshops at Loco-Motion Dance Theater for Children. At 7 p.m., the Miller Theater, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, loco-motiondancetheatre.org; $10. 'EBONY BLACK' (Tomorrow) Though based on ''Snow White,'' this new musical isn't at all like the fairy tale or the Disney version: for one thing, the heroine isn't white. Produced by NY Artists Unlimited and Montauk Theater Productions/Shooting Star Theater, it centers on a dark-skinned young woman who is mistakenly sent to a cold, rich Hamptons matron seeking a daughter. (Through May 26.) At the Seaport District Cultural Association Performing Space, southwest corner of Beekman and Front Streets, Lower Manhattan, (212) 242-6036, NYartists.org; $10; $5 for under 12. Reservations advised. 'HOOFERS ON PARADE' (Tonight through Sunday) Busby Berkeley's 1930s films were the inspiration for this musical, an exuberant collaboration between the youth troupe Downtown Art and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Expect lots of toe-tapping. (Through May 20.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m., Downtown Art, 61 East Fourth Street, sixth floor, East Village, (212) 479-0885; $8; $5 for students. 'THE SANDWICH KID: A FILM ABOUT SIBLINGS AND DISABILITIES' (Tuesday) The JCC in Manhattan will present this documentary in which Jace King, 12, interviews children about living with siblings who have disabilities. The film is also a personal odyssey for Jace and his mother, Keri Bowers, the producer: Jace's older brother, Taylor, has high-functioning autism. At the screening the JCC will show artwork by Justin Canha, a 17-year-old with autism. At 8 p.m., 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, (646) 505-5708, jccmanhattan.org; $25; $20 for members. MARIA SANGIOLO (Sunday) Folk singers are often associated with the 1960s generation, but this one is firmly devoted to today's young. Ms. Sangiolo will entertain children 3 and up with an interactive concert at the Jewish Museum. At 2 p.m., 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3337, thejewishmuseum.org. Tickets: $15; $10 for under 12; $12 and $8 for family-level members. SKATE FOR HEALTH DAY (Tomorrow) Rollerblade, in conjunction with more than a dozen skating schools across the country, is offering free group in-line skating lessons; no charge for equipment. The Central Park Skate School is taking part. Information and registration (required): freeskatelesson.com. 'SPRANG THANG' (Tonight through Sunday) Ma Rainey, Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday and Dinah Washington will be reincarnated by teenagers in this new musical by Goldee Greene, performed by the students of the Amas Musical Theater's Rosetta Lenoire Musical Theater Academy. (Through May 20.) Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow at 3 and 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., the Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 352-3101; $20; $13 for students and 65+. 'STEP RIGHT UP!' (Tomorrow and Sunday, Tuesday through Thursday) ''Above the boardwalk'' might be the subtitle for this edition of the Big Apple Circus, which recreates an amusement park by the sea. (Through May 28.) Tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 and 4:30 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday at 11 a.m.; Thursday at 11 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. Cunningham Park, Francis Lewis Boulevard and Union Turnpike, Hollis Hills, Queens, (212) 307-4100; $14 to $37. 'TAINAH -- AN AMAZON ADVENTURE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) The New York International Children's Film Festival presents this Brazilian movie about Tainah, an 8-year-old orphan who must find a way to stop a group of poachers in the Amazon rain forest. (In English, for ages 5 to 10.) At 11 a.m., 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 349-0330, gkids.com; $10.75; $7 for children and 65+. TEACH YOUR CHILD TO RIDE A BIKE (Tomorrow) This two-hour workshop, sponsored by the Parks and Recreation Department and the organization Bike New York, promises to eliminate both skinned knees and frayed nerves. To be held in a variety of locations in the five boroughs (it will be repeated on May 19 and Memorial Day), from 10 a.m. to noon, the class will teach children how to balance and how to start, stop and steer. Participants must have their own helmets and bicycles. Free, but preregistration required: BikeNewYork.org/safety--ed/classes/teach--child.html. YOUTH TRACK & FIELD & WELLNESS JAMBOREE (Tomorrow) Young athletes can show their stuff in this competition, from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., sponsored by the New York Road Runners Foundation and Mount Sinai Medical Center. Events for ages 4 to 10 are in the morning; those for 11 to 15 are in the afternoon. Everyone takes home a ribbon and a T-shirt. A fair will offer free health tests. At the Icahn Stadium, Randalls Island, (212) 423-2227, nyrrfoundation.org.; free.

State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli issued a report yesterday that said the state budget is $2.9 billion larger than previously thought, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer's budget director, Paul E. Francis, responded that the comptroller's numbers were inaccurate because he counted capital spending items not traditionally included in the budget. The governor's office has estimated the budget at $121 billion, while the comptroller's estimate is $124 billion, leading to a dispute over how much the state is spending. ''The next step toward budget reform has to focus on spending restraint,'' said Mr. DiNapoli, above. Mr. Spitzer opposed Mr. DiNapoli's appointment to the comptroller's office after the resignation of Alan G. Hevesi, saying that Mr. DiNapoli, then a Democratic assemblyman, did not have the knowledge of finance necessary for the job, but recently he has been more conciliatory. DANNY HAKIM

The artists' collective known as Assume Vivid Astro Focus takes over John Connelly Presents this month with a slightly ridiculous ensemble: an installation of wrapped objects and text-based 3-D wallpaper covering the gallery walls, ceiling and floor; a dark subterranean corridor of pulsing music and flashing neon sculptures; and a cordoned-off room of psychedelic wallpaper, sculptures, video, balloons, streamers and stuffed toys. The room is used for periodic, often bawdy performances, which are part of the installation. Audience members slip under sheaths attached to wallpaper, left, to look through peepholes for a view of the room. I saw Philly, a gender-confused romantic who likes to sing, dance and lament lost loves. The show over all is the antithesis of the polished displays in pristine white galleries that abound throughout Chelsea, and in some ways that is the point. The wallpaper, music, flashing lights, 3-D glasses and other gizmos are used to immerse viewers in a world in which layers of images and ideas collide. Sometimes it can all seem like nonsense, a contrived mess by a bunch of small-minded, overcaffeinated adolescents. But it also paints a vision of what, to some, paradise might be: a playful Technicolor world of roaming, free-formed ideas. (Through June 30, John Connelly Presents, 625 West 27th Street, Chelsea, 212-337-9563, www.johnconnellypresents.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

CLARKE--Beaufort James Barron Clarke was born in Tupelo, Mississippi, on September 11th, 1946, and passed away on April 30th, 2007 in London. His education included a Bachelor of Arts from George Washington University and a Juris Doctor from The University of South Carolina. He worked at Shearman & Sterling in New York and was the Chairman and CEO of ICON Capital Corp in New York, the fifth largest independent leasing and financing company in the United States. Beau was well known for his great philanthropy and contributed to the Empire State Pride Agenda, GLAAD, the Elton John Foundation and the Gay Human Rights Foundation among other charities. Surviving members include his ex-wife Linda Clarke and his sister Lauren Evans, her husband and her two children. In lieu of flowers, please feel free to make a donation to the Empire State Pride Agenda by contacting: menselman @prideagenda.org or calling 1-212-627-0305. Friends and Family

More than 5,000 people poured into the streets of several cities to protest a crackdown on leftist groups before a Group of 8 meeting in the city of Heiligendamm next month. The police in Hamburg clashed with demonstrators there, arresting eight people. Some opposition leaders criticized the raids, saying the police were trying to intimidate legitimate opponents of the meeting. MARK LANDLER

It is one of the enduring features of the modern Republican Party: Since the rise of Ronald Reagan and the empowerment of the social conservatives, the party has formally stood in firm opposition to a constitutional right to abortion and the Supreme Court decision that established it. Yes, there were always Republicans who broke with party orthodoxy on the issue, from New England moderates like Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine to pragmatists like Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California. But the party's platform, if anything, grew less pliant on abortion over the years. And the party invariably nominated presidential candidates who embraced, rather than challenged, the full ''pro life'' position. (Just as the Democrats did, on the ''pro choice'' side.)
