June is Gay Pride month, so we can expect the usual variety of special events around the city leading up to the Pride Day march on June 24. But since this is New York, we don't have to wait till next month -- there's fabulous gay entertainment whenever we want. For example, Gayfest NYC, a new monthlong festival that presents the works of emerging gay playwrights. The festival, produced by Bruce Robert Harris and Jack R. Batman for Sunny Spot Productions, includes three staged productions and two world premiere readings. Among the offerings is ''A Kiss From Alexander,'' starting May 24, in which a director stages a campy musical called ''Alexander Was Great!'' based on that world conqueror. When Alexander (now wandering the afterlife seeking the spirit of his mortal true love) learns that he is being portrayed as a gossipy, man-hungry queen, he intervenes -- dramatically, of course. The show, which was nominated for several Joseph Jefferson Awards after a 2005 Chicago production, has a book and lyrics by Stephan DeGhelder and music by Brad Simmons. The festival has a serious side too: the other productions are ''Revolution,'' by Michael D. Jackson, a docudrama about events leading up to the Stonewall riots of 1969, and ''Competing Narratives,'' a drama by A. B. Asher about three men (above from left, Sebastian La Cause, Michael Vaccaro and Matthew Boston) challenging one another's beliefs about race, sexuality and identity. The festival also intends to donate some proceeds to a scholarship for students at Harvey Milk High School, a New York City public school that focuses on gay teenagers' needs. The festival is dedicated to the memory of Patrick Quinn, the former president of Actors' Equity Association, who died of a heart attack in September. (Through June 2, TBG Arts Center, 312 West 36 Street, third floor, Manhattan, 212-352-3101, theatermania.com; $18; $45 to $50 for festival passes. A schedule of events is at gayfestnyc.com.) STEVEN McELROY

Omega the Unknown, a Marvel character who had his own series in 1976 and 1977, is returning. The character will be revived by the author Jonathan Lethem. Marvel approached Mr. Lethem after the publication of his novel ''The Fortress of Solitude'' (2003), which included several comic book references, including one about Omega, a mute alien with a strange link to a 12-year-old Earth boy. (Above, a cover from a new issue of the Omega series.) The mini-series, not yet scheduled, will run for 10 issues, the same number as the original series. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

TURNBULL--David, died peacefully at home in Cambridge, MA on April 28, 2007, at 92 years. Loving husband for 52 years of Carol, who died in 1999; father of Lowell, (Randi Greenwald) Murray, and Joyce McDonald (Michael); grandfather of Ian and Derek Turnbull and John and Scott McDonald. Gordon McKay Professor of Applied Physics Emeritus, Harvard University; thesis advisor to more than 40 Ph.D. students. Recipient of the Japan Prize, Franklin Medal, TMS Bruce Chalmers Award, ASM Sauveur Memorial Award, MRS von Hippel Award, Acta Metallurgica Gold Medal, APS International Prize for New Materials, AIME Hume-Rothery Award, honorary Sc.D.s from Case Western Reserve University, Universite Claude Bernard (Lyon, France) and Monmouth College, and other honors for his contributions to materials science. Coeditor, Solid State Physics series, 1954-1994. Member, National Academy of Sciences; Fellow, American Academy of Arts and Sciences. David Turnbull Lectureship, endowed by his friends, has been awarded annually by MRS since 1992. Memorial service at noon, September 17, Appleton Chapel, Harvard Memorial Church. Donations in his memory may be made to Materials Research Society, 506 Keystone Dr., Warrendale, PA 15086 Attn: John Balance f/b/o David Turnbull Memorial Fund.

In the latest attempt to exert pressure on Sudan over the killing in the Darfur region, a group of conservative to moderate Republicans in Congress demanded Thursday that President Bush impose sanctions against the government for its failure to rein in the violence. In a three-page letter sent to the White House, 15 members of the House urged Mr. Bush to ''follow your instincts'' and ''authorize the actions you outlined on April 18,'' when Mr. Bush promised that the United States would impose sanctions on Sudan if its government did not take action soon on Darfur.

LaKisha Jones, 27, below, the single mother who rose from working at a bank in Fort Meade, Md., to the top four on this season's ''American Idol,'' was voted off the competition on Wednesday, as Fox dominated another night in the ratings. The results show at 9 p.m. drew 27.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, far exceeding the 12.8 million who tuned in to the runner-up in the hour, CBS's ''Criminal Minds.'' CBS finished second for the night, leading the 10 p.m. hour in total viewers with ''CSI: NY'' (12.7 million). ABC's ''Lost,'' despite reduced ratings, remained the winner at 10 among adults 18 to 49, and ABC finished close behind CBS in that demographic for the night. Fox's ''Bones'' finished first at 8 (10 million), outdrawing the season finale of CBS's ''Jericho'' (7.8 million), which tied with NBC's ''Thank God You're Here'' (5.3 million) for last place in the hour in the 18-to-49 set. NBC was fourth over all, just ahead of the CW, whose ''America's Next Top Model'' (4.9 million) ranked first at 8 in the younger demographic of adults 18 to 34. BENJAMIN TOFF

Ken Burns has agreed to add Hispanic veterans' stories to ''The War,'' his PBS film on World War II, in the face of continuing criticism from Hispanic groups that said they felt slighted by the omission of Latino contributions from the work, to be broadcast in September. Mr. Burns had previously insisted that his completed 14 1/2-hour film would not be changed. The agreement, reached after 14 hours of negotiations, was announced by Mr. Burns's Florentine Films, the Hispanic Association of Corporate Responsibility and the American GI Forum, which represents Latino veterans. According to a press release, it ''equally recognizes that the artistic decisions of what appears in his film are his and his alone to make.'' The association's chairman, Manuel Mirabal, said that until the agreement, ''We didn't have Mr. Burns' commitment to work on this himself, we didn't have an agreement that stories of Latino World War II veterans would be within the credits, in effect integrated into the body of the film he had already completed, and we did not have a clear acknowledgment by Mr. Burns that this was an important part of the story.'' Mr. Burns was flying to France, where the work will be shown at the Cannes Film Festival, and not available for comment, a spokesman said. ELIZABETH JENSEN

LEVY--Franklin. The members, Board of Governors and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time board member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Nancy, and his family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

IF you love the outdoors but are bored just lying in the sun, try traipsing the wilderness as a citizen scientist -- no degree required. Summer is high season for the kind of naturalists' adventures that pair amateurs with researchers to collect information and restore wild areas. On one level, it's volunteer work -- making a contribution to scholarship or cleaning up an environment. On another, it's a good time in the outdoors with like-minded people. The grande dame of citizen science projects, the National Audubon Society's Christmas Bird Count, started in 1900 when the ornithologist Frank Chapman proposed counting birds instead of shooting them in traditional Christmas Day hunting contests. Writing in Bird-Lore, the precursor of Audubon magazine (motto: ''A bird in the bush is worth two in the hand''), he urged readers to make the count a success by ''spending a portion of Christmas Day with the birds and sending a report of their 'hunt' to Bird-Lore before they retire that night.'' Today more than 50,000 observers take part in the count every year.

Rising prices for the metals in demand from growing economies - aluminum, copper, zinc, tin, nickel and lead - have been driving a surge in metal mergers, as witnessed by Alcoa's $27 billion bid for Alcan and the takeover talk surrounding Rio Tinto.

An article in Business Day on Monday about two minority partners in Dow Jones & Company who criticized a takeover attempt by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation referred incorrectly to the ownership of Dow Jones's Class B stock, which has 10 times the voting power of a regular share. The Ottaway and Bancroft families are the largest owners of Class B shares, they are not the sole owners. (Shareholders were given Class B shares in the 1980s.)

Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Dori Berinstein 102 minutes The documentary ''ShowBusiness'' follows four Broadway musicals from rehearsal through the 2004 Tony Awards: ''Caroline, or Change,'' ''Taboo,'' ''Avenue Q'' and ''Wicked.'' On top of the usual challenges (fund-raising, rewrites, tryouts, marketing), they all had to endure scrutiny by a Greek chorus of theater critics and gossip columnists. (The rogues' gallery includes Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, critics for The New York Times, and The New York Post's dapper scorpion of a theater columnist, Michael Riedel.)

A front-page article on Tuesday about the heavy debt incurred by culinary students who rely on student loans misstated the name of the California school attended by a student who returned to New York to help pay her bills. It is the California Culinary Academy, not the California Culinary Institute. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the format of the ShawGuides to culinary schools. It is published online; it is no longer a book.

BAUMEISTER--Matthew C. 4/5/86--5/11/05. Dearest Matthew, it is now 2 years since we have held you or seen your beautiful smiling face. We suffer your absence with every breath we take there is no escape from the pain of this loss. We had imagined so much happiness for you. For all that you have lost we also grieve. You are loved and remembered every day, every hour, every minute. Sometimes the things we love the most we can no longer touch. Missing you. Mom, Dad and Jared.

Because of an editing error, the NYC column last Friday -- about Peter Kaufman, who takes action against air-conditioned commercial buildings that waste energy by keeping their doors open in the summer -- referred incorrectly in some copies to comments from Robert W. Walsh, New York's commissioner of small business services, on proposed legislation that would fine violators. His comments -- that before resorting to bans and fines, the city should educate the wastrels about the harm they do -- should have been rendered as a paraphrase, not as a direct quotation.

It took Twyla Tharp just eight years to go from the choreographic anonymity of her first work, ''Tank Dive,'' to fame. The reason for that rise was her 1973 ''Deuce Coupe,'' made for the Joffrey Ballet, set to music by the Beach Boys, and now widely regarded as the first piece to bring modern-dance attitudes and movement to the world of classical ballet. Tomorrow afternoon there is an unusual opportunity to see not just ''Deuce Coupe,'' above, but also three other rarely performed works that Ms. Tharp made between 1970 and 1976. The event, a college showcase at the Joyce Theater, happened almost by accident. Ginger Montel, the associate director of Twyla Tharp productions, happened to mention to Linda Shelton, the executive director of the Joyce, that five university dance departments in the New York area were learning pieces by Ms. Tharp. Ms. Shelton decided that it was too good an opportunity to pass up and offered the Joyce for a one-off performance. It's a wonderful chance to glimpse something of Ms. Tharp's early artistic development: the structural rigor of ''The Fugue'' (three dancers performing 20 variations on a 22-count theme); her first use of music as choreographic impetus in ''Eight Jelly Rolls''; the highbrow-lowbrow mix of ''Deuce Coupe''; and the inventive partnering and incorporation of social dance in ''Country Dances.'' The institutions involved -- Barnard College (Ms. Tharp's alma mater), Hunter College, the Juilliard School, Marymount Manhattan College and Sarah Lawrence College -- were all taught these pieces by former Tharp company members, some of whom danced in the original productions. ''We've been making a concerted effort to make it financially possible for colleges to get Twyla's works,'' Ms. Montel said. ''Having the presentation at the Joyce is the cherry on top of the icing on top of the whipped cream.'' (Tomorrow at 2 p.m., 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, 212-242-0800, joyce.org; $20.) ROSLYN SULCAS

The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the world's tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Laden's relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team).

Mel Stottlemyre spent the afternoon at the incomparable Elliott Bay Book Co. in Seattle's Pioneer Square, meeting fans and signing copies of his autobiography, Pride and Pinstripes, written with John Harper. Then Stottlemyre, the former Yankees pitcher and pitching coach, came by Safeco Field to see his old team for the second day in a row.

Fred D. Thompson, the "Law & Order" star and subject of much speculation about his presidential ambitions, is practically above our head right now, speaking to a secretive group of conservative heavyweights and activists.

It was an absolute zoo after the GP2 race in Barcelona today as Bruno Senna, Ayrton's nephew, won the race in only his third GP2 race and with not quite three years of car racing behind him. He moves to third place in the series, which is a Formula One support race, and a final stepping stone to the highest level of racing. I wrote a little about Bruno after the first GP2 race in Bahrain, so I thought I should continue with the theme. In fact, I could not avoid the theme this time.

I wrote a story for the Sunday paper about Derek Jeter, who's leading the A.L. in batting average and hits. Doug Mientkiewicz compares Jeter to his former teammate, Paul Molitor, who finished with 3,319 hits. Jeter has 2,200 hits, with no end in sight.

Imagine this Sunday's breakfast menu as a rather limited buffet. You can take huge, belly-busting helpings of presidential politics, but you might have to scrape at the bottom of the tray to get much of anything else.

Went into the Brewers clubhouse this morning to catch up with outfielder/fellow unabashed Eagles fan Kevin Mench, who I covered in Dallas two years ago. On the way out, I couldn't help but notice that photographs of the umpiring crew, along with short biographies underneath, were stuck to the back of the door.

Jose Reyes finally relented. No more hair. He emerged from the players' lounge this morning rubbing his newly-smooth head with an I-told-you-so grin on his face. He wasn't resisting, he said, and it had nothing to do with his 14-game hitting streak ending last night; he was just waiting until the day after he shot footage for a reggaeton video. Didn't want to look silly for that. So he came in this morning and asked the team's regular barber, Jordan, (and not the higher-priced Carlos Beltran or Carlos Delgado), to buzz off his curls for the first time in about five years. It took about 10 minutes.

On Thursday at Houston Baptist College, Rudolph W. Giuliani tried out his new political strategy of confronting head on his departures from the traditional G.O.P. platform. The Times's Marc Santora and Adam Nagourney report that the speech "appeared to reflect two calculations by his campaign."
Some pretty rare birds have been spotted this spring at ball parks around the country.

Aiming to underline the church’s concern for poverty and other social problems in Brazil, Pope Benedict XVI declared on a visit to a drug rehabilitation center here Saturday that God would punish drug dealers.
VH1’s fizzy “Flavor of Love Girls: Charm School Starring Mo’Nique” emphasizes strength as much as delicacy and decorum.
A look at one Chappaqua couple who agreed to allow scores of strangers into their home to benefit the local historical society.
With “Delta Farce,” his second movie vehicle, the Southern-fried comedian Larry the Cable Guy takes ever greater risks to advance his career.
Seven U.S. soldiers and an Iraqi army interpreter came under coordinated attack today in a Sunni stronghold south of Baghdad.
At least 27 people were killed in clashes related to the suspension of the chief justice of the Supreme Court.
Jarrod Washburn allowed six hits and a walk in eight innings, striking out six to silence the Yankees as they begin a rough patch of their schedule.
From the first 3-pointer to the last dramatic dunk, Baron Davis and his Warriors were playing against the scoreboard as much as they were playing against the Jazz.
Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark said that he would endorse Senator Barack Obama for president on Monday.
An apartment complex’s management and engineers did not take the necessary emergency action to keep a nearly century-old retaining wall from collapsing two years ago.

The filmmaker Michael Moore has asked the Bush administration to call off an investigation of his trip to Cuba to get treatment for ailing Sept. 11 rescue workers for a segment in his film, “Sicko.” Mr. Moore, who made the documentary “Fahrenheit 9/11” attacking the president’s handling of the Sept. 11 attacks, said in a letter to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. that the White House might have opened the investigation for political reasons. In the letter, which Mr. Moore posted on the liberal Web site the Daily Kos, he also said: “I understand why the Bush administration is coming after me — I have tried to help the very people they refuse to help, but until George W. Bush outlaws helping your fellow man, I have broken no laws and I have nothing to hide.”.
NASA officials said that the hail-pocked tank for the next shuttle mission had been repaired.

Andruw Jones and Jeff Francoeur homered on consecutive pitches in the sixth inning last night to help the Atlanta Braves end their longest streak without a home run in 24 years, and Manager Bobby Cox tied Sparky Anderson for fourth place in career victories with a 4-1 victory against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

A New Jersey man was ordered to stay away from Elie Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and Nobel Prize-winning author, for the next three years when he appeared in court to face charges of assaulting Mr. Wiesel, 78, at a San Francisco hotel Feb. 1. The man, Eric Hunt, 22, of Vernon, N.J., was extradited from New Jersey on Thursday. Mr. Hunt’s lawyer, John Runfola, said he was weighing an insanity defense. “Eric has an undiagnosed psychiatric disorder,” Mr. Runfola said. “He is not a Holocaust denier.” Mr. Hunt has been charged with attempted kidnapping, false imprisonment, battery, stalking, elder abuse and hate crimes. The charges carry a maximum sentence of seven years in prison and a $10,000 fine, said the prosecutor, Alan Kennedy.

Senator John McCain has dismissed his New Hampshire campaign manager. The man, Jim Martin, had run Mr. McCain’s campaign in the state and was part of Mr. McCain’s 2000 victory there. But the campaign decided to replace him with Jim Barnett, who had been a top political operative. Mr. Barnett had served as the executive director of the Vermont Republican Party and joined the McCain campaign as the regional political director.

The Postal Service’s new rates take effect Monday. The cost of a first-class stamp, which covers letters weighing up to one ounce, will increase to 41 cents from 39 cents, while the cost of each additional ounce will decrease to 17 cents from 24 cents. Items placed in mailboxes after Saturday’s pickup must reflect the new prices. Also available will be the Forever Stamp, currently 41 cents, which covers the one-ounce letter rate regardless of any future increases. More information on pricing for domestic mail and new international rates can be found at <a href=

Two small planes collided over suburban Cincinnati, raining debris onto roads and backyards and killing three people on board, federal investigators said. The Federal Aviation Administration had no information about the aircrafts’ flight plans. The planes’ pilots were not required to file plans and apparently were not in contact with air traffic controllers, the agency said. The victims included two people aboard a Cessna 172, and the pilot of the other plane, a Beechcraft Bonanza. No injuries were reported on the ground, but several roads were closed because of the debris.
Jorge Sosa pitched well yet again for the Mets, as he lasted six and two-thirds innings, allowing two runs and four hits.
The business, Cambria Car Wash, was connected to city water lines while at the same time using water from a well.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg laid out the framework for a national energy policy and accused Washington lawmakers of “passing the buck” on meaningful reforms.
auto racing.
The Gambino crime family conspired to kill a Queens couple for robbing Mafia social clubs in the early 1990s, a federal jury decided in a split verdict.

An article yesterday about mounting pressure on world leaders to help bring an end to the violence in Darfur misspelled the given name of a film director who has tried to step up pressure on Sudan’s government. He Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

An article on Wednesday about public financing of stem cell research in Massachusetts referred incorrectly to financing plans in New York. Although Gov. Eliot Spitzer at one time proposed spending $1 billion, a budget agreement with the Legislature in March reduced the figure to $600 million.

A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about the 50th anniversary of desegregation in Little Rock, Ark., misspelled the surname of the photographer in some copies. He is Michael Stravato, not Stavato.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a Hong Kong couple accused of insider trading in connection with a bid for Dow Jones & Company by the News Corporation referred imprecisely to the actions taken by Dow Jones. While the company is gathering information internally and is cooperating in an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it is not conducting an internal investigation focusing on a director, David K. P. Li.

A front-page article last Saturday about a dispute among some conservatives over whether Darwinian theory undermines or supports conservative principles erroneously included one social Darwinist among Victorian-era social Darwinists who adopted evolutionary theory to justify colonialism and imperialism. Herbert Spencer opposed both.

An article yesterday about mounting pressure on world leaders to help bring an end to the violence in Darfur misspelled the given name of a film director who has tried to step up pressure on Sudan’s government. He Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

A listing on Thursday of American service members killed in Iraq erroneously included two servicemen who died recently. James W. Harrison Jr., 47, a colonel with the United States Command and General Staff College, and Wilberto Sabalu Jr., 36, a master sergeant with the United States Military Police School, were killed in Afghanistan, not Iraq.

An article on the Street Scene pages of Business Day on April 6 about a program geared toward training female lawyers to become directors of companies misstated the percentage of Fortune 500 companies that have women on their boards. It is 88.4 percent, not 14.6 percent. (Women held 14.6 percent of the board seats on Fortune 500 companies in 2006.) Catalyst, the research company that compiled the statistics, pointed out in an e-mail message this week that the article had misstated the findings.

The Saturday Interview in Business Day last week, with Brett White, the chief executive at the real estate company CB Richard Ellis, referred incorrectly to acquisitions the company made in the 1990s. It bought investment management and commercial mortgage brokerage firms, not a pension fund and a commercial bank.

An article yesterday about events in Iraq, including closing arguments in a trial of six colleagues of Saddam Hussein in attacks that killed as many as 180,000 Kurds in the 1980s, misstated the date of Mr. Hussein’s execution. It was Dec. 30 of last year, not in January.

An article in some copies on Tuesday about proposed tentative rent increases for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments included an outdated schedule for the board’s final vote. It is now expected June 26, not June 22. The article also misstated the number of public hearings to be held on the increases. (The same error appeared in an article on April 25 about reports that building owners’ costs and revenues rose in the last year.) There will be two hearings, not three.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of genes in weight gain misstated the publication date for an article in the journal Science describing the biological controls over body weight. The article was published in 2003, not 2000.

The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the significance of Roger Clemens’s signing with the slow-starting Yankees, referred incorrectly to the timing of a pivotal play in the team’s 14-2 defeat on Thursday by the Texas Rangers. The Rangers took the lead when the Yankees failed to execute a rundown in the fifth inning, not the fourth inning.
Tomas Holmstrom scored with 4 minutes 54 seconds left in the third period, when the puck hit him while he was standing in front of goalie Jean-Sébastien Giguère.

Serbia’s pro-West parties reached a power-sharing deal to form a new government, said Tomislav Nikolic, the hard-line Parliament speaker lawmakers elected this week. The agreement averts the possibility that his ultranationalist Radical Party will regain power. The independent broadcaster B-92 said that the agreement was reached in an overnight meeting between President Boris Tadic and the caretaker prime minister, Vojislav Kostunica, whose talks on a cabinet had been deadlocked for nearly four months after an inconclusive election, and that it included a plan to replace Mr. Nikolic as speaker, the No. 2 post in the country. If the government is not formed by Tuesday, new elections would have to be called, which would benefit the Radicals.

Two Indian officers of the South Korean steelmaker Posco were being held hostage by opponents to a plan to build a plant in eastern Orissa State, which they said would displace 20,000 people, the police said. The Posco officials were to meet with farmers about acquiring their land. The steel plant, approved by the federal government last year as a special economic zone, would be the largest single foreign investment in India.

A Hanoi judge sentenced two democracy activists to up to five years in prison, bringing the number imprisoned this week to five as the government continued a crackdown on dissidents. The two, Nguyen Van Dai and Le Thi Cong Nhan, both lawyers and part of a new generation of Internet-based political activists, were found guilty in a four-hour trial of “spreading propaganda against the state.” In March, the Rev. Thaddeus Nguyen Van Ly, a Roman Catholic priest and one of the best-known members of Vietnam’s small dissident community, was sentenced to eight years for antigovernment activities.

The Federal Court said the government may not deport an Algerian accused of having ties to Al Qaeda until it revised its law on detaining foreign-born terrorism suspects. The Algerian, Mohamed Harkat, was arrested in Ottawa in 2002 and became one of five Muslim men held without charges or a trial under the detention measure, the security certificate system, introduced late in 2001. In February, the Supreme Court found the measure unconstitutional and gave the government a year to change it. Mr. Harkat was released under restrictive conditions after the ruling as the government continued his deportation process.

Parliament set May 27 for a nationwide referendum on re-electing President Bashar al-Assad for another seven-year term, a vote he is sure to win. Mr. Assad is the sole candidate in the yes-or-no referendum.

The Constitutional Tribunal, Poland’s highest court, struck down as unconstitutional crucial parts of a new law championed by the conservative government of President Lech Kaczynski and his twin, Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski, that would have required up to 700,000 Poles in a number of professions to be screened for past collaboration with the Communist-era secret police. Previously, only lawmakers, government ministers and judges were required to reveal involvement. Among the sections the tribunal said violated the Constitution’s guarantee of equal treatment was one to screen all journalists, publishing-house executives and private-school teachers. The court said the law could be applied only to individuals and not collectively.

The government said it would send federal troops to an eighth state, Veracruz, on the Gulf Coast, to battle drug traffickers. The announcement came after gunmen from a suspected drug gang killed four bodyguards for family members of Gov. Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico State vacationing in Veracruz.
The demand for a free vaccine against cervical cancer has been so high that physicians can’t satisfy all the requests.
The Justice Department withdrew one of its proposals to tighten restrictions on lawyers representing detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
During an evening ceremony, students shared hugs and in quieter moments they spoke of feelings of guilt.
By the time Monica M. Goodling resigned, she had revamped personnel practices at the agency.
The Pentagon is looking into whether Defense Department officials might have engaged in improper fund-raising.
Regulators are again knee-deep in insider trading cases, with profiteers spanning the globe, from Hong Kong to lower Manhattan.
The United States’ top intelligence official has endorsed a study by spy agencies about the impact of global warming on national security.
Rudolph W. Giuliani said that Republicans needed to be tolerant of dissenting views on abortion rights, gun control and gay rights to retain the White House.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange raised its bid to acquire its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, by 16 percent.
The second major Southern California brushfire this week continued to burn on Santa Catalina, but Avalon, the island’s major town, appeared to have been spared.
Two Mavericks team officials confirmed that Dirk Nowitzki, who led the Dallas Mavericks to a 67-victory season, will be named the N.B.A.’s most valuable player.
When the Mets began their game against the Brewers Friday, José Reyes still had a full head of hair.
For the Sabres to have come this far — not to the Eastern Conference finals, but simply to still exist in Buffalo — required the most memorable play in franchise history.
The $7.75 billion deal comes as the Canadian information company ponders a merger with Reuters.
Barry Bonds is rapidly approaching Hank Aaron’s revered home run record, and Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, must decide how to respond.
This season has seen the Jazz’s Deron Williams in the spotlight and Dee Brown on the fringes, a change in roles since the two played together at the University of Illinois.
The makers of Equal and Splenda reached an undisclosed settlement over Splenda’s slogan “made from sugar, so it tastes like sugar.”
The father of one of the Fort Dix terror plot suspects says he has received daily death threats and lost customers.
Dale Earnhardt Jr. was back in a racecar Friday. But the firestorm he created by announcing  he would leave Dale Earnhardt Inc. continued to blaze.
Excerpts from a speech delivered on Friday by Rudolph W. Giuliani at Houston Baptist University.
Tiger Wood’s golf was so imprecise Friday at the Players Championship that he nearly missed the cut before making it with a shot to spare.
Alfred D. Chandler Jr. argued in almost two dozen books that the emergence of professional management propelled modern capitalism.
The weak retail spending and a big rise in gasoline prices were seen as delivering a double whammy to the economy.
While Kennedy was built to handle international flights, growth in the last year has been driven largely by domestic flights added by Delta, JetBlue and others.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,376 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans this week:.
Musicians at open auditions by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority hoped to be selected as entertainers.
The report reinforced longstanding suspicions that smugglers, insurgents and corrupt officials control significant parts of the country’s oil industry.

On May 1, members of a Police Department riot control unit violently and unnecessarily dispersed participants in a pro-immigrant march. It was the biggest fiasco since the last time the L.A.P.D. clashed with a minority group.
Just as spring follows winter, the annual progression of mayfly hatches on Eastern rivers provides a boost to the spirits of trout fishermen.
John Edwards said that he would call for Americans to “raise their voices” on Memorial Day against the Iraq war.
Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones is hoping to persuade the N.F.L. Commissioner to reduce the season-long suspension he received for off-field conduct.
Mitt Romney is by far the wealthiest of the Republican presidential hopefuls.
The Virginia Legislature has tailored a new law to try to stop New York City’s use of private investigators who pose as shoppers and videotape illegal gun purchases.
Policy makers in Washington kept their eyes on inflation, but held rates steady. In Hollywood, the M.P.A.A. tossed smoking into its ratings system.
The world and the citizens of Iran are watching to see how its leaders treat Haleh Esfandiari, an advocate of improved relations between Washington and Tehran who was arrested this week.
Giovanni Passannante, who tried to kill the king of Italy 120 years ago, is becoming a cause célèbre 97 years after his death.
The world is a classroom for Matt DeSalvo, the 26-year-old Yankees rookie pitcher who has written a novel and has plans for another.
The purge of nine United States attorneys is part of a long chain of evidence that Alberto Gonzales does not have the ability or the moral compass to do his vitally important job.
More legislators are worried about the dangers of driving while texting with a BlackBerry or other mobile device.
Prosecutors dropped criminal charges against two men who set off fears of terrorism by placing electronic advertisements for a cartoon in Boston.
The vice president's sharp warnings appeared to be part of a two-track administration campaign to push back at Iran while leaving the door open to negotiations.
Investors interpreted a government report of milder inflation as a signal that the Fed might consider cutting interest rates later this year.
A psychologist’s pioneering studies of youth violence led him to conclude that television had a significant role in prompting destructive behavior.
The presidential election of Mr. Ramos-Horta, the prime minister and a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, was a significant move toward creating genuine multi-party democracy.
Auburn University’s Rural Studio program is still about hands-on projects using any items hands can be gotten on.
A Mexican doctor removed drug traffickers’ fingerprints, substituting skin from their feet, to help the traffickers avoid arrest, authorities said.
Edward J. Ludwig, head of Becton, Dickinson, spoke about his company’s product line and its acquisition of GeneOhm Sciences last year.
Viola da gamba virtuoso Jordi Savall brought music fit for the ears of kings to the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday.
In addition to rallying support from its traditional low-caste base, the Bahujan Samaj Party aggressively wooed upper-caste Brahmins.
The headquarters building for Yukos oil company was sold for a startling price to an unknown buyer.
The news that President Bush would give the commencement address at St. Vincent College was not universally welcomed.

(Cinemax) AMERICAN DREAMZ (2006) This comedy directed by Paul Weitz (“In Good Company” and, with his brother, Chris, “About a Boy”), in which a bumbling American president (Dennis Quaid) signs on to judge a television talent show in an effort to boost his popularity, appears just as the “American Idol” season is nearing its climax. Above: Hugh Grant plays the Simon Cowell-esque host; Mandy Moore is the contestant-next-door with the voice of an angel who’s hiding some arsenic under all that lace. And Willem Dafoe, doing his best Dick Cheney impersonation, is the president’s chief of staff, who thought up the publicity stunt in the first place.

SALZMAN--Jacob A., of New York City died on May 8, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Ida Salzman. Cherished father and father-in-law of Richand Susan Salzman, Anita and Myron Pulier, Robert Salzman and Lori Brooks. Grandfather of Eric, Greg and Tara, Annie and Matt, Rachel and Scott, Talia and Aramie. Great-grandfather of Jake, Will, Chloe, Georgia, Abe, Naomi, Tabitha and Lily. Jack was grateful for and appreciated every minute of his extraordinary 94 years. Devoted to the family he and Ida created, Jack was an avid cellist and amateur chamber musician. His passion for music was a source of joy and friendship. A brilliant, creative attorney, he ran for Congress (American Labor Party 1936). He practiced law for more than 50 years in downtown Brooklyn joined by his three children. His legal craftsmanship and advocacy had a deep and lasting impact on the lives of his clients. Jack fought all his life for a better world and never gave up hope that it would happen. Donations may be made in his name to: Opus 118 at the Harlem School of Music, a classical music program for public school children, 103 East 125th St., New York, NY 10035, Attention: Philip Willis. 212-831-4455

The United States Hockey Hall of Fame, which has been closed for more than a year because of financial difficulties, will remain in Eveleth, Minn., and will reopen in late May or early June, the Hall's board of directors announced. Under a reorganization plan approved by the board, an Eveleth-area group will run the Hall museum and be responsible for its financing. The Hall's selection and induction operations will be assumed by USA Hockey, the sport's American governing body. PAT BORZI
BADER--Nathan. Dear Daddy, Good night sweet prince. All my love, Ann

INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Billions in Oil Is Missing In Iraq, U.S. Study Says Between 100,000 and 300,000 barrels a day of Iraq's declared oil production over the past four years is unaccounted for and could have been siphoned off through corruption or smuggling, according to a draft American government report. A listing on Thursday of American service members killed in Iraq erroneously included two servicemen who died recently. James W. Harrison Jr., 47, a colonel with the United States Command and General Staff College, and Wilberto Sabalu Jr., 36, a master sergeant with the United States Military Police School, were killed in Afghanistan, not Iraq.

Several years ago, Thomson sold its once-vast newspaper holdings to concentrate on the more lucrative business of selling the high priced data and news that professionals need to do their jobs. But while it dominates the distribution of electronic information to several professions, including law and accounting, it is the No. 3 provider to the financial services industry. On Tuesday, however, the Canadian-based Thomson outlined a $17.5 billion cash- and-stock bid for the Reuters Group, the long-established British provider of financial and general news.Thomson's ability to finance the bid was bolstered yesterday when two funds agreed to buy its educational unit for $7.75 billion.

An article yesterday about events in Iraq, including closing arguments in a trial of six colleagues of Saddam Hussein in attacks that killed as many as 180,000 Kurds in the 1980s, misstated the date of Mr. Hussein's execution. It was Dec. 30 of last year, not in January.

JetBlue Airways has become known for its February service meltdown at Kennedy Airport, which helped push its founder, David Neeleman, from the chief executive's job this week. But it would be a mistake to think the only challenge facing his successor, David Barger, is making the jets run on time. Mr. Barger, 49, needs to do that -- and much more. Raising fares, for one, which will be hard for JetBlue because it is expanding its fleet and thus the supply of seats to sell.

To the Editor: Re ''Give the Arab Peace Initiative a Chance'' (Op-Ed, May 11): Prime Minister Fuad Siniora of Lebanon claims that ''the July war proved that militarism and revenge are not the answer to instability; compromise and diplomacy are.''

An article on Wednesday about public financing of stem cell research in Massachusetts referred incorrectly to financing plans in New York. Although Gov. Eliot Spitzer at one time proposed spending $1 billion, a budget agreement with the Legislature in March reduced the figure to $600 million.

A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about the 50th anniversary of desegregation in Little Rock, Ark., misspelled the surname of the photographer in some copies. He is Michael Stravato, not Stavato.

The government said it would send federal troops to an eighth state, Veracruz, on the Gulf Coast, to battle drug traffickers. The announcement came after gunmen from a suspected drug gang killed four bodyguards for family members of Gov. Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico State vacationing in Veracruz. ANTONIO BETANCOURT

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a Hong Kong couple accused of insider trading in connection with a bid for Dow Jones & Company by the News Corporation referred imprecisely to the actions taken by Dow Jones. While the company is gathering information internally and is cooperating in an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it is not conducting an internal investigation focusing on a director, David K. P. Li.

SCHULMAN--Barney, age 77, on May 11th, 2007. Beloved husband of June, devoted father of Lynn, Irene and Barry Cohen and Alan. Loving grandfather of Jason and Michelle Cohen. Brother of Ralph. Service is Sunday, 12:15pm at ''Schwartz Bros.Jeffer'' Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY.

A front-page article last Saturday about a dispute among some conservatives over whether Darwinian theory undermines or supports conservative principles erroneously included one social Darwinist among Victorian-era social Darwinists who adopted evolutionary theory to justify colonialism and imperialism. Herbert Spencer opposed both.
The last big pieces of the Yukos oil company, including its headquarters building, were sold yesterday to an unknown buyer. Page C8.

The Saturday Interview in Business Day last week, with Brett White, the chief executive at the real estate company CB Richard Ellis, referred incorrectly to acquisitions the company made in the 1990s. It bought investment management and commercial mortgage brokerage firms, not a pension fund and a commercial bank.

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential hopeful, has assets estimated at $260 million to $350 million, including money set aside for his children and grandchildren, his campaign advisers said yesterday in discussing his personal financial disclosure statement. Mr. Romney, who is by far the wealthiest of the hopefuls, has been given a 45-day extension by the Federal Election Commission to file his disclosure report, because not all the information needed for it is available, Kevin Madden, a spokesman for the campaign, said.

An article in some copies on Tuesday about proposed tentative rent increases for New York City's one million rent-stabilized apartments included an outdated schedule for the board's final vote. It is now expected June 26, not June 22. The article also misstated the number of public hearings to be held on the increases. (The same error appeared in an article on April 25 about reports that building owners' costs and revenues rose in the last year.) There will be two hearings, not three.

To the Editor: In ''Playing 'Survivor' in Washington'' (Week in Review, May 6), you say that ''several key officials in this administration have stayed in their jobs well beyond their perceived expiration dates'' and that ''Mr. Bush has a reputation for standing firm by his charges -- something his supporters laud as loyalty and critics decry as blindness and arrogance.''
The Golden State Warriors have turned this year's N.B.A. playoffs into the world's biggest pickup game. The Bay Area is their playground. Oracle Arena is their asphalt.

Will Richard A. Grasso get to keep his money after all? A New York appeals court certainly gave Mr. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, hope this week when it dismissed four legal claims brought against him by the New York attorney general. By turning back a claim brought by the attorney general that Mr. Grasso's pay was unreasonable under the law governing nonprofits, the judges, who ruled 3-to-2, cast doubt on the attorney general's authority to try the case.

The Federal Court said the government may not deport an Algerian accused of having ties to Al Qaeda until it revised its law on detaining foreign-born terrorism suspects. The Algerian, Mohamed Harkat, was arrested in Ottawa in 2002 and became one of five Muslim men held without charges or a trial under the detention measure, the security certificate system, introduced late in 2001. In February, the Supreme Court found the measure unconstitutional and gave the government a year to change it. Mr. Harkat was released under restrictive conditions after the ruling as the government continued his deportation process. IAN AUSTEN

To the Editor: Re ''The Incredible Flying Granny Nanny'' (Thursday Styles, May 10): I thought I was alone in my situation of navigating the East Coast to make sure my son was in good hands. As a political consultant in New York City who lives in Durham, N.C., I, too, have a flying granny nanny: my mother, who is known to my 18-month-old son, Benjamin, as Granny Franny.

Joe Torre fields dozens of questions before every game, most about his own team, and some about the opposition. In the dugout at Safeco Field on Friday, Torre was asked about Jarrod Washburn, the starter for the Seattle Mariners. Torre, the Yankees' manager, offered a standard compliment for a pitcher who finds a way to succeed without throwing hard: ''He's got a belly full of guts.'' Torre has seen enough of Washburn to make that evaluation, and he may be wistful for pitchers like him.

The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the significance of Roger Clemens's signing with the slow-starting Yankees, referred incorrectly to the timing of a pivotal play in the team's 14-2 defeat on Thursday by the Texas Rangers. The Rangers took the lead when the Yankees failed to execute a rundown in the fifth inning, not the fourth inning.

Movies that feature smoking will come with a warning on the package. The Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday changed its film ratings system to include smoking as a factor alongside violence, sex and drug use in assessing the suitability of films for young viewers. The move responded to pressure from health organizations and state attorneys general to get smoking out of films that are open to children and teenagers. Movies in which tobacco consumption is glamorized or pervasive now risk more restrictive ratings, and information about smoking scenes will be added to explanations that come with ratings.

Students wandering into some college auditoriums on Sept. 23 may receive a few unexpected lessons on subjects like the nature of Bohemian love, consumptive heroines and life in a garret. The Washington National Opera said it planned to simulcast a live matinee performance of Puccini's ''Bohème'' to 14 college campuses and 2 high schools. The feed to the institutions will piggyback on an outdoor broadcast at the Washington Monument, an annual event begun two years ago.

TRAVEL The Flight From Iraq Millions have fled Iraq, creating the largest Mideast refugee problem since 1948 and depriving the country of the very people who might have rebuilt it. MAGAZINE

With ''Delta Farce,'' his second movie vehicle, the Southern-fried comedian Larry the Cable Guy takes ever greater risks to advance his career. The first is sharing major screen time with two supporting stars. Larry plays, well, Larry, a restaurant server whose girlfriend has been impregnated by another man. Larry's buds in the Army Reserve, Bill (Bill Engvall, the comedian's ''Blue Collar Comedy'' co-star) and Everett (D J Qualls, whose birdlike appearance alone inspires chuckles), also have troubles. Bill's a harried, beer-sodden husband; Everett's an ex-cop living in a storage space with an inflatable doll. Neither character threatens Larry's sizable screen presence.

WEISEL--Lucy, on May 7th, 2007. Beloved aunt, sister and daughter. For services call Riverside Memorial, NYC.

To the Editor: ''Psychiatrists, Troubled Children and the Drug Industry's Role'' (front page, May 10) is a wake-up call to all physicians and their professional organizations. The American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry recently established a task force to examine this complex issue.

O'BRIEN--Reginald P., of Cape Cod and Manhattan died February 28, 2007. Survived by his wife, Monica; daughter Alexandra; granddaughters Brianna, Casey, Dory and Bailey; brother John R.; sisters Adrienne and Madeleine. He was predeceased by his son Christopher. Funeral is at 11am, May 12, Holy Trinity R.C. Church, West Harwich, MA. St. Catherine of Genoa and Bishop Dubois, St. Benedict College; proud Veteran, loving friend to all.

An article yesterday about mounting pressure on world leaders to help bring an end to the violence in Darfur misspelled the given name of a film director who has tried to step up pressure on Sudan's government. He Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

SALAMONE--Alfred W. ''Al'', 83, passed away May 6 in Key Biscayne, FL. Survived by his companion Maxine and his brother Frank and family of Harrison, NY. Son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Salamone. Al, a lifetime member of Westchester, NY Professional Golfer Association, a retired Army captain having served in five Theaters of war and landed on D-Day in France during WWII, received the Purple Heart for his outstanding military service, served as a member of the board at Rye Bank and Professional Golfer Association. During his active playing years, he won many outstanding tournaments. A past member of a Surf Club in Miami Beach, he will be missed by his friends and family.

LATTIMER--John Kingsley. The faculty and staff of the Department of Urology Columbia University and the J. Bentley Squier Urological Clinic NY Presbyterian Hospital join us in mourning the passing of our chairman from 1955-1980, John Kingsley Lattimer, M.D., M.Sc. A visionary leader, whose passionate commitment to the care of his patients, to the education of future Urologists, to the institutions he served, to his colleagues and the field of Urology set an example that has influenced all who were fortunate enough to come to know him. His advances in Pediatric Urology and the treatment of renal tuberculosis are among his many accomplishments which affected the lives of thousands of children and adults worldwide. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Jamie, his children Evan Lattimer, Jon K. Lattimer, M.D. and Gary Lattimer, M.D. and his entire family. Mitchell C. Benson, M.D. Chairman Carl A. Olsson, M.D. Chairman Emeritus Department of Urology Columbia University J. Bentley Squier Urological Clinic

An article on the Street Scene pages of Business Day on April 6 about a program geared toward training female lawyers to become directors of companies misstated the percentage of Fortune 500 companies that have women on their boards. It is 88.4 percent, not 14.6 percent. (Women held 14.6 percent of the board seats on Fortune 500 companies in 2006.) Catalyst, the research company that compiled the statistics, pointed out in an e-mail message this week that the article had misstated the findings.

ERGAS--Leonard S. Beloved brother of Jerry. Loving uncle of Bonnie Cheskes and Elizabeth Melillo. Adored great-uncle of Travis and Nicole Melillo and Brooke Cheskes. Services Sunday, 10 am, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, East Farmingdale, L.I.

WEISS--Jeanne (Nana) on May 11, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Edward, loving mother of Vivian Hammer and her husband Glenn, adoring grandmother of Rachel and Edward. She will be remembered for her love of family and many friends. Service Monday, 11:30am at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

After several Canadian resource giants, particularly the nickel mine operator Inco, fell into foreign hands through takeovers, speculation focused on the Montreal-based aluminum producer Alcan. But, because of potential antitrust issues, few anticipated that Alcoa of Pittsburgh would be the likely buyer. But on Monday, Alcoa surprised the industry with a hostile bid for Alcan valued at $27 billion. Perhaps even more surprising was the news that the two companies had negotiated a friendly merger for about two years without the talks leaking out.

CBS took Thursday night, as ABC's preview of ''Traveler,'' its new series about friends who become fugitives after setting out on an ill-fated road trip, finished last in its time slot. Nielsen estimated that ''Traveler'' drew just 8.9 million viewers at 10 p.m., despite following ''Grey's Anatomy,'' the night's highest-rated show (19.1 million). CBS won at 10 with the season finale of ''Without a Trace'' (14.4 million), normally shown on Sundays; NBC was second with an episode of ''ER'' (9.2 million). CBS also won at 8 with ''Survivor: Fiji'' (13.6 million) and finished a close second at 9 with ''CSI'' (18.6 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC led for the night, with CBS and NBC second and third. BENJAMIN TOFF

To the Editor: Re ''U.S. Pays and Apologizes to Kin of Afghans Killed by Marines'' (news article, May 9): It was rather disappointing to read that the value of an innocent Afghan life is a mere $2,000 -- the amount the United States paid for each death.

Policy makers in Washington kept their eyes on inflation, but held rates steady. In Hollywood, the Motion Picture Association of America tossed smoking into its ratings system. NOT BUDGING The Federal Reserve signaled on Wednesday that it would not be reducing interest rates anytime soon, despite signs that economic growth has slowed sharply.

Stepping up his antiwar stance, John Edwards said yesterday that he would call for Americans to ''raise their voices'' on Memorial Day against the Iraq war and would say that patriotism required supporting the troops by bringing them home. Mr. Edwards said in a telephone interview that, in a commencement speech to be delivered today at New England College in Henniker, N.H., he would call on Americans to ''come together and speak out in a way that will end the war.''

Aspen Isn't Laughing The United States Comedy Arts Festival, the biggest event of its kind in the country, is leaving Aspen, Colo., after 13 years, The Denver Post reported on Friday. A spokeswoman for HBO, the event's sponsor, said the festival would not be in Aspen in 2008, citing costs and the dwindling number of hotel rooms. Since 1995, the comedy festival, held in February and March, brought Robin Williams, Jerry Seinfeld, Steve Martin, Whoopi Goldberg, Billy Crystal, Larry David and others to that mountain resort town. ''Space is limited, and it's incredibly expensive,'' an HBO spokeswoman said of Aspen. ''Many of the properties also require four- or five-day stays, which is difficult, and expensive too.'' There were unconfirmed reports that HBO would move the festival to Santa Barbara, Calif., but the HBO spokeswoman said only that Santa Barbara was one of several possibilities. Rebirth in Lebanon The Italian conductor Riccardo Muti, below, will begin a season of summer festivals in Lebanon that were canceled last year because of the war between Israel and Hezbollah, Middle East Online has reported. Mr. Muti will conduct an orchestra at the Roman temples of Baalbek and play the piano at the Beiteddine Festival near Beirut. The Lebanese tourism minister, Joseph Sarkis, said that all four of his country's major annual art festivals would be revived this summer, despite the country's continuing political crisis. They take place in Baalbek, Beiteddine, Byblos and Tyre. Coppola's Comeback Francis Ford Coppola's ''Youth Without Youth,'' the first film he has directed since 1997, will have its world premiere at the RomeFilmFest in October, Variety reported. The film, produced, adapted and directed by Mr. Coppola, left, is based on a 1976 novel by the Romanian-born writer and scholar Mircea Eliade. It stars Tim Roth as a 70-year-old Romanian who attracts the interest of the Nazis after he is struck by lightning and apparently given immortality. The film was shot in Romania and will be released in the United States in December. Radio Drama The 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center will stage the American premiere on Monday night of two radio plays by the Irish short-story writer William Trevor. ''Going Home'' and ''Mr. McNamara,'' based on stories that Mr. Trevor wrote in 1972 and 1976, are directed by Ciaran O'Reilly, the producing director of the Irish Repertory Theater in New York. Search for Missing Ashes The search for a rocket carrying ashes of the actor James Doohan, who played Scotty the engineer on ''Star Trek,'' continues almost two weeks after it was launched in New Mexico, Reuters reported. A rocket carrying remains of the actor, who died two years ago at 85; the ashes of the astronaut L. Gordon Cooper Jr.; and several experiments blasted off on April 28. A spokeswoman for the Houston-based Space Services Inc. said the rocket had descended into a rugged area of New Mexico that a search team had been unable to reach. Gibson's Rehabilitation A California judge praised Mel Gibson, below, on Friday for his rehabilitation after his arrest for drunken driving last year, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Gibson, the actor and director, was arrested for driving under the influence in Malibu, after which he subjected the arresting officers to an expletive-laden, anti-Semitic rant. Mr. Gibson, 51, who later apologized for his remarks, was sentenced to three years' probation, fined $1,300, and ordered to attend Alcoholics Anonymous meetings five days a week for four and a half months, then three times a week for seven and a half months. At a hearing in Malibu to assess his progress, Judge Lawrence Mira said he was impressed with Mr. Gibson's commitment. ''I truly believe the rehabilitation that is being effected in this case is effective, and I don't want to do anything to interrupt that,'' he said, in explaining why Mr. Gibson was not asked to appear for the hearing. Mr. Gibson must appear at an Aug. 23 hearing for a final progress report, Judge Mira ruled. No China Tour for the Met The Metropolitan Opera has scrapped plans for what would have been its first tour of China, citing the logistical challenges of performing Tan Dun's ''First Emperor'' there with the tenor Plácido Domingo in 2008.

In the box score, LeBron James can be titillating, with his talent etched amid triple doubles on paper; and yet his wow factor rarely leaps off the page. The visual of James is less thrilling than the print image of James. Stylistically, he is a brute, a Bam-Bam at the piano keys. He drives to the basket as if clearing brush. He dribbles as if he is splitting coconuts. He is wholesale force, not big-ticket finesse.

SWANTON--Eileen D., 96, died on Thursday May 10, 2007 at Franciscan Oaks Health Center in Denville, NJ. She is survived by her children and their spouses Patricia and Thomas G. Noonan of Hamburg, NJ and Norman F. and Elise Swanton of Greenwich, CT, nine grandchildren and twenty-five great-grandchildren. All services are private, donations being accepted to Franciscan Oaks, 19 Pocono Rd., Denville, NJ 07834.

An article in some copies on Tuesday about proposed tentative rent increases for New York City's one million rent-stabilized apartments included an outdated schedule for the board's final vote. It is now expected June 26, not June 22. The article also misstated the number of public hearings to be held on the increases. (The same error appeared in an article on April 25 about reports that building owners' costs and revenues rose in the last year.) There will be two hearings, not three.

Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark said yesterday that he would endorse Senator Barack Obama for president on Monday. Mr. Booker's endorsement is a coup for Mr. Obama. As mayor of New Jersey's largest city, Mr. Booker is widely considered the most influential black elected official in the state, and his decision ends months of speculation over whether his support would go to Mr. Obama's rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of genes in weight gain misstated the publication date for an article in the journal Science describing the biological controls over body weight. The article was published in 2003, not 2000.

''With two carrier strike groups in the gulf, we're sending clear messages to friends and adversaries alike. We'll keep the sea lanes open. We'll stand with our friends in opposing extremism and strategic threats. We'll disrupt attacks on our own forces. We'll continue bringing relief to those who suffer, and delivering justice to the enemies of freedom. And we'll stand with others to prevent Iran from gaining nuclear weapons and dominating this region.'' VICE PRESIDENT DICK CHENEY [A6]

LEFF--Martin. The Woodcrest Club of Syosset, NY, deeply mourns the loss of beloved longtime member, Martin Leff, and extends its sincerest sympathy to his family. Our condolences to his wife, Eleanor, as well as to all of the many people who loved him. He will be greatly missed by all of the members and staff of the Woodcrest Club.

Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones met yesterday with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, hoping to persuade Goodell to reduce the season-long suspension he levied last month on Jones for his off-field conduct. Jones and his lawyers contended that his suspension was too harsh compared with those received by a long list of players who have been arrested or charged since 2000. Jones has been arrested 5 times and questioned by the police 10 times, but has never been convicted, since he was drafted sixth over all in 2005.

MILLER--Ruth. Poet, writer, scholar. Born in Chicago in 1921, departed February 21, 2007 at her Jerusalem home, beloved and honored mother Hadea Kriesberg and Matthias. Treasured friend to many in America and Israel, professor at SUNY Stony Brook, prize winning author of ten books on subjects including Emily Dickinson, Saul Bellow, and African-American literature. Donations in her name to: Yad LaKashish, Lifeline for the Old, 14 Shivtei Israel Street, PO Box 28, Jerusalem 91000 Israel.
MALKIN--Lillian Fish, 91, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Forest Hills, Queens and Fort Lee, NJ, on May 10, 2007. Beloved wife, devoted mother, loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

SPRING spurs migration and for a couple of months now a great river of birds has been streaming toward us, our local woods, backyards and beaches filling up with song. For some of us spring also means a return to old battles, as we wage our local fights to make sure that the returning birds will have both the place and space to rear their young. In recent years the plight of piping plovers has taken center stage, famously pitting drivers of recreational off-road vehicles against conservationists and inspiring bumper stickers that read ''piping plovers taste like chicken'' and even a song titled ''Fifty Ways to Kill a Plover.'' There have been some gains won in the effort to save the birds, whose population has been increasing along the New Jersey and Massachusetts shores, but there is still much work to be done along the rest of the Northeast, including in Connecticut and on Long Island.

In the strange world of New York State politics, it is sometimes possible to take a wrong step in the right direction. If that makes no sense elsewhere, it is perfectly understandable in Albany. There, the new comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, has proposed a plan to begin public financing of state campaigns, starting with the race for comptroller in 2010. Public financing, in which smaller campaign donations from individuals would be matched in statewide races, is a great idea for New York. And Gov. Eliot Spitzer has pledged to promote some kind of public financing as part of his general overhaul of state government.

Corzine that would redirect federal transportation funds to the Trans-Hudson Express Tunnel.

Neoclassical Colonial $870,000 CONNECTICUT: 35 Wordins Lane, Trumbull A 1937 brick colonial with four bedrooms, two and a half baths, an attached two-car garage and a two-story barn on 1.13 acres. Andrea Pirrotti (owner), (203) 685-6291; www.lacrocerealty.com TAXES: $11,616 a year PROS: The house is tucked at the end of a barely traveled lane opposite a nature preserve. Upper East Side Co-op $325,000 MANHATTAN: 448 East 88th (between First and York Avenues), #5A A one-bedroom, one-bath apartment with 10-foot ceilings and a decorative fireplace. Gregory Hall (212) 848-0460, Maggie Leigh (212) 500-7029, the Corcoran Group; www.corcoran.com MAINTENANCE: $808 a month PROS: Original moldings and hardwood floors give this well-priced apartment prewar charm. Every room, including the kitchen and bathroom, has a window and gets good light. The bedroom has two good-sized closets. CONS: The kitchen counters and cupboards could use updating. The building is a long way from the nearest subway, and the climb to the fifth floor might be too daunting for some. Bay Shore Colonial $1,699,999 SUFFOLK: 19 Overlea Court A renovated 1930s colonial with three bedrooms, three and a half baths, and walls of windows in the family room, living room and formal dining room. The yard has a pool and a patio shaded by mature wisteria vines. To the Editor: Re ''A Split Emerges as Conservatives Discuss Darwin'' (front page, May 5): Evolution is the study of how species change, how new species originate and how living species adjust to environmental change -- knowledge essential to the survival of present and future generations as they cope with climate change.

An article last Sunday in T: Living magazine about a table with a stainless-steel trough that can hold bottles of beverages on ice misstated the price of a bottle of Dom Pérignon Oenothèque Champagne at www.sherry-lehmann.com. It is $285, not $195.
FISCHER--Alva. Loving wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of Ronald (Patti), Richard (Beth), and Debra. Adoring grandmother of Simon, Dena, and Marlee. Services were private.

LANDOR--John Henry M.D., Ph.B. Beloved husband of Mary Gibbons, died January 4th, 2007 at home in Monterey, MA. Professor of general surgery and practicing surgeon, he had a long and productive career which included extensive research in gastrointestinal physiology. Survived by six children from his first marriage, two stepchildren, four grandchildren and five step-grandchildren. Memorial service on August 4th, 2007 in Monterey, MA. Contributions can be made in his memory to the Massachusetts Audubon Society.

To the Editor: ''India Made Easy'' by Jonathan Allen (March 25) caught my attention, as I recently returned from a trip to India myself. Even though I had a great time, this is what I learned: Whether you go for seven days or for a month, there is nothing easy about India. The numbers are daunting: well over one billion people in a country one-third the size of the United States.

WHEN Betsy Isles received a phone call in early February asking if she would be willing to put her 19th-century Italianate farmhouse on a house tour, it all seemed comfortably far off: The tour date wasn't until May. She would have plenty of time to get ready. The cause was a good one. Proceeds from the tour -- tickets are $70 for members, $80 for nonmembers -- would benefit the local historical society. Besides, Mrs. Isles and her husband, Chris, love their home. Fascinated by local history, they were willing to open up their house, where they have lived 15 years, to fellow history buffs. In fact, Mrs. Isles's only initial concern about participating was that the upstairs of the house remained off limits to visitors; the idea of strangers peering into the rooms of her two teenagers was a bit much.
ROLLER--Mildred. Dear Mom, my 2nd Mothers Day without you. I miss you and love you every single day. Love, Cheryl

LAST year, when my son Sean was 12, he started to shoot baskets, watch too much television and have his first major crush. He said ''my bad'' after forgetting homework and plunged his size-seven feet into sneakers before bolting without a jacket. All of this astonished me -- not because he was growing up, but because he was leaving the land of special needs that he and I had inhabited for such a long time.

THE organ music, disco ball, strobe lights and blindingly bright neon seem out of sync with the fashions and norms of today, but the roller skaters zipping around the Rink in Montvale do not seem to care. Roller skating indoors may not be trendy, but there is something to be said for its simple pleasures. Yet the Rink in Montvale is scheduled to close June 3 to make way for a housing development, and roller skating fans in northern New Jersey will soon have to find something else to do or someplace else to skate. They can't go to the Rink in Bergenfield; it's now a Sears hardware store. They can't go to Skater's World in Wayne; it's now an Office Depot.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Positions Available: $12,900 to Start, Advancement Possible,'' May 9: I don't think that any Major League Soccer developmental player would appreciate Commissioner Don Garber's statement that they are apprentices akin to those engaged in a minor league sport. Nor should their clubs.

GALLANT--Herbert, 84, on Friday. Beloved husband of Geraldine; cherished father of John, Brenda, Robert and Ilze; grandfather of Lawrence and Brad; born to Frank and Frances. Graduated Harvard, summa cum laude 1944. President of Gallant for over 50 years.

To the Editor: Re ''Dear S.E.C., Reconsider Arbitration'' (Fair Game, May 6), about mandatory arbitration in the securities industry. As an NASD arbitrator, I find that the arbitration process generally favors customers. I believe that this is due to the fact that arbitration considers equity in addition to the law.
COHEN--Linda. To a wonderful mother, you will be dearly missed, and you will always be with us. Love Todd and Ricky

To the Editor: George R. Hendrey and Stephen Pekar wrote in ''Local Forecast: Bad'' (Op-Ed, May 6) of the need for an ''international institute'' based in New York where experts ''can put their knowledge together to prepare for future climate change.'' There is also much that individuals and community groups can do to help mitigate some of the disastrous effects of ''climate-driven perils.''

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the history of Israel's difficulties in Lebanon referred incorrectly to a commission that issued a scathing report on Prime Minister Ehud Olmert's handling of the war with Hezbollah last summer. It was a government commission, not a parliamentary committee.

CLEMENT--Samuel Prescott Bush, son of Stuart Holmes Clement and Margaret Livingston Bush Clement, was born 29 December 1921 in Buffalo, NY, and died peacefully 4 May 2007 in Bloomfield, CT. Mr. Clement, known as ''Pres'', attended Foote School, graduated from Pomfret School in 1940, attended Williams College, and graduated from Colorado College in 1949. He taught at Pomfret and at St. Louis Country Day School. After a second bout of tuberculosis, he retired from teaching and began a career as a professional photographer and artist. He was a member of Photographers of America and did work for the Yale Divinity, Law, and Medical schools, the Yale baseball team, and Yale class reunions as well as portrait photography, weddings, and school yearbooks. His paintings have been exhibited annually at the High Peaks Artists Association in Keene Valley, NY, of which he was president for twenty years. As a young man, ''Pres'' was a strong baseball pitcher and first baseman. A resident of New Haven, CT, for many years and a seasonal resident of Keene Valley, NY, he was a member of the Yale University Glee Club hand bell group in New Haven, performed in local Gilbert & Sullivan productions, and sang with the Williams College Octet Alumni. He was an active and dedicated Class Secretary at Pomfret and an effective fundraiser for several other nonprofit organizations. While a resident of Litchfield, CT, he was a member of St. Michaels Church. Previously, he had been a member of St. Thomass in New Haven and most recently Old St. Andrews in Bloomfield; seasonally he attended the Keene Valley Congregational Church. He was also a member of the Adirondack Mountain Reserve, the New Haven Lawn Club, and the Keene Valley Country Club. Predeceased by his wife of fortynine years, Harmony Twichell Clement, ''Pres'' was devoted to his large, extended family and his wide circle of friends. He is survived by his children Harmony C. Spongberg and her husband, Stephen, of Chilmark, MA; Margaret C. Green of Washington, CT; Samuel Prescott Clement and his wife, Barbara, of Wellesley, MA; granddaughter Harmony S. Spongberg of Charlotte, VT; brother Stuart H. Clement; sister Mary B. Clement Estabrook; and many cousins, nieces, and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Pomfret School chapel, Pomfret, CT on Sunday, 3 June at 11:30 am. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Class of 1940 Scholarship Fund, Pomfret School, P.O. Box 128, Pomfret, CT, 06258-0128 Attn. Development Office. Carmon Windsor Funeral Home has care of services.
A SIMPLE thank-you today, to the mothers in my life. To my wife, first, who has given us four children.

Sandya T. Magge and Ketan P. Jhaveri were married yesterday at the Pittsburgh Marriott City Center. Samudrala V. Charyulu, a Hindu priest, officiated. The bride, 29, is studying for an M.B.A. at Columbia. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received a master's degree in public health from Johns Hopkins. From May 2004 to June 2006, she was a marketing researcher for the American Red Cross national headquarters in Washington. She is a daughter of Susheela and Tandav Magge of Murrysville, Pa. Her father is a mechanical engineer for Westinghouse in New Stanton, Pa.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 28, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. BECAUSE A FIRE WAS IN MY HEAD, by Lynn Stegner. (University of Nebraska, $24.95.) Stegner's protagonist is a self-destructive hussy who leaves a crowd of broken people in her wake. TEENAGE: The Creation of Youth Culture, by Jon Savage. (Viking, $29.95.) Generational insurrection from the 19th century to the mid-1940s, with Oscar Wilde, Peter Pan, Hitler Youth and Sinatra. LATER, AT THE BAR: A Novel in Stories, by Rebecca Barry. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) The small-town regulars at Lucy's Tavern carry their loneliness in ''rough and beautiful'' ways. THE JOY OF DRINKING, by Barbara Holland. (Bloomsbury, $14.95.) A funny, carefree history of alcohol, ''the social glue of the human race.'' BIGGER DEAL: A Year on the New Poker Circuit, by Anthony Holden. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A lot has changed at the World Series of Poker since Holden, a reporter who became a participant, described it in ''Big Deal'' in 1990. THE DREAM OF THE POEM: Hebrew Poetry From Muslim and Christian Spain, 950-1492. Translated, edited and introduced by Peter Cole. (Princeton University, cloth, $50; paper, $19.95.) The adaptation of classical Arabic meters to Hebrew gave rise to a seductive poetic renaissance. THE CIGARETTE CENTURY: The Rise, Fall, and Deadly Persistence of the Product That Defined America, by Allan M. Brandt. (Basic Books, $36.) Cigarettes in culture, science, politics and law, by a Harvard professor of medical history. RETHINKING THIN: The New Science of Weight Loss -- and the Myths and Realities of Dieting, by Gina Kolata. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Kolata, arguing that physique is largely dependent on genetics, asks if being fat is really unhealthy. THICK AS THIEVES: A Brother, a Sister -- a True Story of Two Turbulent Lives, by Steve Geng. (Holt, $24.) Her troubled brother's elegy for the New Yorker writer Veronica Geng. SEND: The Essential Guide to Email for Office and Home, by David Shipley and Will Schwalbe. (Knopf, $19.95.) An amusing account of the ways to botch e-mail and advice on how to avoid them. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
