Charles Dickens's 19th-century characters are about to be brought to life in a decidedly 21st-century manner -- as animatronic figures in a new theme park based on the author's books and life. Opening May 25, Dickens World (www.dickensworld.co.uk), in Chatham, Kent, England (where Dickens spent most of his childhood), will introduce visitors to life in Dickensian times -- from the architecture and street scenes to the smells and sounds. The attraction, about an hour southeast of London, includes rides, a shopping mall, a themed restaurant and a theater, all in one building. Visitors can experience a harsh Victorian schoolroom (like the one attended by Oliver Twist), and take a boat ride in the dark through London's sewers. The ghost of Ebenezer Scrooge will make an appearance in the haunted house, and there will be a Fagin's Den play area.

To the Editor: Gia Kourlas's article is an excellent examination of the problems facing African-American women in ballet. A historical example came to mind: the celebrated teacher Syvilla Fort (1917-75), who is perhaps best known for choreographing the dance to John Cage's first work for prepared piano. But her primary love was ballet, and she sought work as a ballerina unsuccessfully for several years before joining Katherine Dunham's troupe.

To the Editor: In ''Who's Watching Your Money?'' (Op-Ed, April 30), Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, argues that the Supreme Court decision in Watters v. Wachovia Bank leaves customers of national banks exposed to predatory subprime lenders and prevents states from addressing lending abuses. He's wrong on both counts.

To the Editor: Some recent letters have expressed concern over the presence of the Franciscan Friars of the Renewal counseling in front of abortion clinics (''Musical Monks, Protesting Abortion,'' April 29). I would like to respectfully elaborate on our work with women in crisis pregnancies.

LEHMAN--Laura, of NYC, Caracas, Miami Beach and Tucson, died May 10, 2007, at age 86. Loving mother of Elena (Alan) Hilfer, Stanley (Yvette) and Carol (Jon) Howe, grandmother of Gabriel, Vanessa, Daniel, Andre, and Matthew. Predeceased by Ignacio, her husband of 49 years.

In his rush to achieve a state of samadhi, Russell Simmons apparently skipped right over the principle of ''ahimsa,'' which, simply put, means to do no harm (Deborah Solomon, April 29). Hardly the sentiment behind so many of the rap lyrics advocating violence, misogyny and homophobia that Simmons seems to defend.

To the Editor: In ''High Stakes in the Catskills'' (Op-Ed, April 29), Kim Elliman and Nathan Berry challenge the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe's environmental commitment. Our tribe has a long, rich and meaningful tradition of respecting, protecting and preserving natural resources. We agree that the watershed should be protected.

A review on April 29 about ''George Kennan: A Study of Character,'' by John Lukacs, referred incorrectly to the people whom Kennan, as part of his diplomatic duties in Prague, turned away from the American legation there in March 1939 when the Germans entered the city. They were various inhabitants of Prague, not Americans.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about residential towers on Central Park West, gave an incorrect cross street for the apartment building at 1040 Fifth Avenue, which is cited as an inspiration for the design of 15 Central Park West. It is East 85th Street, not 84th Street.

WERTHEIMER--Nettie, on May 9, 2007 at the age of 105. She arrived at Ellis Island from Poland when she was one and a half in 1902. She had an illustrious career in her volunteer work for Bachurei Chemed Synagogue in Long Beach, American Red Magen David, Amit Women, Y eshiva University and Israeli Bonds. She worked for many decades at each of these organizations in positions of significant responsibility. Her husband Manuel predeceased her in 1960. She is survived by her son Ralph, her daugher Esther, daughter-in-law Margalit, granddaughters Manda Kristal, Gail Palmer and their husbands Lenny and Mark respectively, great-granddaughters Ariella Kristal, Danielle Kristal, great grandsons Alexander Kristal, Scott Palmer and Adam Palmer.

For the next three weeks the Sundance Channel turns over its Monday night ''Docday'' slot to the Israeli filmmaker Amos Gitai and his ''House'' trilogy, documentaries made in 1980, 1998 and 2005 about a house in Jerusalem and the people whose lives it has touched. In the first film, ''HOUSE'' (Monday, 9 p.m.), we meet the former owner, a Palestinian doctor whose family fled the house (for the second time) in 1948 and never returned; the Algerian Jewish couple who lived there for two decades and have moved to an apartment that they profess, unconvincingly, to love; the new Israeli owner who is turning it into a McMansion; and the Palestinian workers tearing it apart. The portrait that emerges from this 50-minute documentary, which Israel's state-owned channel commissioned and then refused to show, is amazingly rich, exposing not just ethnic and religious hatreds but also the tensions among generations and economic classes on all sides. But the essential impasse is always there, expressed most poetically by a Palestinian stonemason who, after explaining that to survive he must work for people he hates, says: ''If 36 Arab states haven't managed to counter Israel, what can our words do? They fly away on the wind.'' At least nine network series have their season finales this week. Some are sure to return (including ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC and ''Medium'' on NBC) and some are on the fence, but one is definitely saying goodbye: Sunday night is your last chance to take a trip to ''7TH HEAVEN'' (CW, 8 p.m.).

A man of integrity and principal, respected and loved by many. Memorial services at Riverside Chapel on Monday, May 14 at 9:30am. Friends may visit at home, Monday thru Wednesday, from 5pm to 8pm.

To the Editor: In ''In Praise of General Tso'' (May 6), Jeff Vandam celebrates a habit that he surely shares with plenty of New Yorkers -- the near-daily ordering of food delivery. He ponders the way the types of delivery menus present in certain areas can indicate the neighborhood's ''hotness,'' but I wonder if he ever ponders the effects his packaging-heavy eating habits have on one area in particular: our country's landfills. David Dartley Stuyvesant Town

An entry in the hardcover advice best-seller list on Page 32 of the Book Review today, for ''The Loved Dog,'' omits the name of the writer with whom Tamar Geller collaborated on the book. She is Andrea Cagan.

To the Editor: In ''High Stakes in the Catskills'' (Op-Ed, April 29), Kim Elliman and Nathan Berry challenge the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe's environmental commitment. Our tribe has a long, rich and meaningful tradition of respecting, protecting and preserving natural resources. We agree that the watershed should be protected.

LAST year, when my son Sean was 12, he started to shoot baskets, watch too much television and have his first major crush. He said ''my bad'' after forgetting homework and plunged his size-seven feet into sneakers before bolting without a jacket. All of this astonished me -- not because he was growing up, but because he was leaving the land of special needs that he and I had inhabited for such a long time.

Deirdre Anne Cahill, a daughter of Sheelagh and William T. Cahill of Bangor, Pa., was married yesterday to John Fitzgerald Swagerty, a son of Ann and Terry C. Swagerty of Roseburg, Ore. The Rev. Robert Beloin, the Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale University, officiated at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Brooklyn. The bride, 28, and the bridegroom, 29, work for Forest City Ratner Companies, the real estate developer in Brooklyn. She is a project analyst in the government and public affairs department; he is a project manager in the retail development group.

To the Editor: Re ''Storm Warnings'' (editorial, April 29): The residents of the sound shore communities under water are on top of the socioeconomic spectrum -- especially those here in Rye. Are they so well-to-do that they can easily absorb being flooded out at every serious rainstorm?

SUMMERFIELD--Jack D., 79, Communications Professor, writer and loving father. During his career, Summerfield managed radio and TV stations (WGBH, WRVR and KPBS), won numerous national awards including the Peabody, volunteered in the Peace Corps and passionately taught college students. He is survived by his children Edward Ford, Jenna Lynn and Jacki Mariani; and grandchildren Haley Marie and Madison Claire. His humor and generosity will be missed by all. Donations in his memory may be made to NYIT Jack D. Summerfield Memorial Award, NYIT Office of Development, Northern Boulevard, P.O. Box 8000, Old Westbury, NY 11568.

To the Editor: Here's another building you can add to your list of survivors from the 1939 World's Fair (''The Fair Lives On,'' F.Y.I., April 8), and it's sitting over here in Jersey City: The White Mana Diner at 470 Tonnele Avenue (Route 1 at Manhattan Avenue) was the ''diner of the future'' at the 1939 World's Fair, manufactured by Paramount Diners. Louis Bridges bought it and moved it to Jersey City, reopening it as the White Manna in 1946. The building is now a landmark. Andy Sydor Jersey City

ROBERTS--Ralph., on May 8, 2007 of Wellington, FL. Husband of Betty (Sampson); father of Jane (Steven Lindemann), Nancy (David Gillece), Jimmy (Sandra Mayer); grandfather of Jeremy, Benjamin, Judah and Memmie Lindemann; Casey and Patrick Gillece; Jackson, Aidan and Daniel Roberts. Contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.
IMPOSTURE By Benjamin Markovits. 200 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. Paper, $13.95.

In the strange world of New York State politics, it is sometimes possible to take the wrong step in the right direction. If that makes no sense elsewhere, it is perfectly understandable in Albany. There, the new comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, has proposed a plan to begin public financing of state campaigns, starting with the race for comptroller in 2010. Public financing, in which smaller campaign donations from individuals would be matched in statewide races, would be a great idea for New York. And Gov. Eliot Spitzer has pledged to promote some kind of public financing as part of his general overhaul of state government. Mr. Spitzer argues, however, that coaxing lawmakers into reforming the present system takes top priority. Unfortunately, that shoves public financing, which would bring New York in line with more progressive states, into the future.

To the Editor: Re ''Poet, Mother, Editor, Wife,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 6): Although Deborah Garrison is clearly bright and so well balanced in her life, I shuddered -- after reading her poetry -- over the fact that she is the poetry editor for Knopf.

MANIS--Irving. Died on May 1, 2007. Adored husband, father and grandfather. Funeral services were held on Sunday, May 6, at Cedar Park (Beth El section) Township of Washington, NJ. He will be missed and loved forever.
If you're lucky, you inherit more than just the fashion gene.

THE organ music, disco ball, strobe lights and blindingly bright neon seem out of sync with the fashions and norms of today, but the roller skaters zipping around the Rink in Montvale do not seem to care. Roller skating indoors may not be trendy, but there is something to be said for its simple pleasures. Yet the Rink in Montvale is scheduled to close June 3 to make way for a housing development, and roller skating fans in northern New Jersey will soon have to find something else to do or someplace else to skate. They can't go to the Rink in Bergenfield; it's now a Sears hardware store. They can't go to Skater's World in Wayne; it's now an Office Depot.

To the Editor: So many taxi drivers talk on their cellphones while driving that I actually thought they were permitted to do so, as long as they do not use handheld models. I learned from ''And Forget the Tip'' (F.Y.I., April 15) that this is not the case. It is a violation. I think it would be a public service to publicize this to taxi riders. It presumably is known to the drivers, but many, many ignore it, probably because so few suffer any penalties. A driver would soon stop this dangerous practice if his tips disappeared, and points on his license did appear. Jacquelyn K. Schwimmer Upper East Side

''When you're dealing with the Clintons in '08, you essentially have two candidates -- her and him -- and he's going to have to have a Boy Scout report card, given his history. He can definitely help her, but that also means he can hurt her.'' DOUGLAS BRINKLEY, the presidential historian, who is not affiliated with any campaign. [27]

BUTLER--Sr. Mary Ellen S.C., a beloved member of the Sisters of Charity of New York for 47 years entered into eternal life on May 11, 2007. Dear daughter of the late Marguerite (nee Klauberg) and Edmund Butler. Loving sister of Marguerite Butler, DC (Emmitsburg, MD) and the late Margaret Haggerty, Edmund and William Butler. Also remembered by many nieces and nephews. Wake on Monday 2-8pm at the Convent of Mount Saint Vincent, (Prayer service at 6:30pm). Funeral Mass, Tuesday 10am in the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception at Mount Saint Vincent. Burial at St. Joseph Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471.

LEFF--Martin. The Woodcrest Club of Syosset, NY, deeply mourns the loss of beloved longtime member, Martin Leff, and extends its sincerest sympathy to his family. Our condolences to his wife, Eleanor, as well as to all of the many people who loved him. He will be greatly missed by all of the members and staff of the Woodcrest Club.

To the Editor: I would like to thank Gregg Easterbrook for the kind things he says about ''The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable'' (April 22). But I also can't help pointing out some of his many misrepresentations.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Vilnius, Lithuania: After a Dark Era, a City Looks West and Sees a Future'' (Next Stop, April 29) by Clifford J. Levy: It may interest readers to know that on the ''Street of the Jews'' in Vilnius sits a bust of the Gaon of Vilna, the renowned leader and scholar of the 18th-century Vilnius Jewish community.

FINK--Shirley, 88. Died May 10, 2007. Survived by sons Michael and Larry Rosenbluth, daughters-in-law Susan Finkelstein and Barbara, grandchildren Lindsey, Emma and Daniel, and sisters Gertrude and Adele. Adoring wife of Leonard Rosenbluth, then Julius Fink and companion Phil Greenberg. Shirley had a smile for everybody.

MORTGAGE lenders have given borrowers mixed signals in recent months. Many are tightening the terms under which they offer money, even to buyers with good credit. But borrowers who clear that bar may find some user-friendly products. Late last month, for instance, Washington Mutual, one of the nation's biggest banks, introduced a new mortgage that offers more flexibility than many other loans, analysts say.

To the Editor: Re ''A Tale of Two Cities'' (May 6): Fortunately for my family, we did not live in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, where the construction operations for Robert Moses' Cross Bronx Expressway steamrolled one apartment building after another. Fortunately for my family, we lived in the path of the proposed Cross Brooklyn Expressway at a time when the Moses steamroller was losing momentum, and would not destroy our home.

To the Editor: George R. Hendrey and Stephen Pekar wrote in ''Local Forecast: Bad'' (Op-Ed, May 6) of the need for an ''international institute'' based in New York where experts ''can put their knowledge together to prepare for future climate change.'' There is also much that individuals and community groups can do to help mitigate some of the disastrous effects of ''climate-driven perils.''

TURNBULL--David, died peacefully at home in Cambridge, MA on April 28, 2007, at 92 years. Loving husband for 52 years of Carol, who died in 1999; father of Lowell, (Randi Greenwald) Murray, and Joyce McDonald (Michael); grandfather of Ian and Derek Turnbull and John and Scott McDonald. Gordon McKay Professor of Applied Physics Emeritus, Harvard University; thesis advisor to more than 40 Ph.D. students. Recipient of the Japan Prize, Franklin Medal, TMS Bruce Chalmers Award, ASM Sauveur Memorial Award, MRS von Hippel Award, Acta Metallurgica Gold Medal, APS International Prize for New Materials, AIME Hume-Rothery Award, honorary Sc.D.s from Case Western Reserve University, Universite Claude Bernard (Lyon, France) and Monmouth College, and other honors for his contributions to materials science. Coeditor, Solid State Physics series, 1954-1994. Member, National Academy of Sciences; Fellow, American Academy of Arts and Sciences. David Turnbull Lectureship, endowed by his friends, has been awarded annually by MRS since 1992. Memorial service at noon, September 17, Appleton Chapel, Harvard Memorial Church. Donations in his memory may be made to Materials Research Society, 506 Keystone Dr., Warrendale, PA 15086 Attn: John Balance f/b/o David Turnbull Memorial Fund.

To the Editor: Re ''A Prince of Pulp, Legit at Last'' by Charles McGrath [May 6]: Would Philip K. Dick be amused or annoyed by the cult that has arisen since his death? Dick wrote some great science fiction, and some that wasn't so great. So have other genre writers. But it saves a lot of time and a lot of reading to anoint a single science-fiction writer as the only one worthy of consideration. That may even explain why people make bad movies out of his stories; perhaps they think his prestige will rub off on them.

Fort Dix, the Army base in Burlington County, has begun more stringent vehicle and identification checks in the wake of the arrest of six men accused of plotting an attack there, a base spokeswoman said. ''It might take a little big longer to get on post,'' the spokeswoman, Carolee Nisbet, said. But she said the security level on the 50-square-mile base has not increased and remains at Alpha, the ''normal vigilant level.''

To The Editor: Thank you to Joshua Kurlantzick for including the American Jewish World Service in ''21st-Century Religious Travel: Leave the Sackcloth at Home'' (April 29). Readers may have been left unclear, however, about the kinds of travel experiences the organization has to offer. Service travelers and volunteers -- from teens to retirees -- have the opportunity to immerse themselves in developing communities in Africa, Asia and Latin America.

STRAUSS--Lawrence M.D., died on May 10th. He is survived by his beloved companion Esther Schwinger, children Leslie Strauss of Sausalito, CA and Bob Strauss and grandchildren Jillian and Kelsey Blakkan-Strauss of Muskegon, MI, sister and brother-in-law Bobbie and Judge Simons of Florida, sister-in-law and brother-in-law Wilfred and Sandra Calmas of Chestnut Hills, MA and nephews Larry and Cary Simons, Richard, James, and Steven Calmas and nieces Mona and Randy Simons. He was the loving husband of Myrna who died in 1995 after 50 years of marriage. Larry celebrated life with unmatched enthusiasm as a caring healer, mentor, devoted husband, beloved companion and nurturing father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Following graduation from Columbia University, where he also excelled at multiple varsity sports, he graduated from Medical School in Massachusetts, and then went on to become one of the founding fathers of North Shore Community Hospital and a much respected and loved personal physician in family practice in Great Neck, NY. Following his retirement he continued his education at CW Post, Long Island University, with active involvement in the Hutton House Lectures, where he was an advisory board member emeritus. As a poet extraordinaire and tireless pursuer of knowledge, his joie-devivre was matched by his all consuming kindness, generosity, and compassion for family, friends and patients. He was truly a man for all seasons.
Chapter 6

The Weekend in New York column on April 29 about former speakeasies referred incorrectly to the attention that one bar, Bill's Gay Nineties, has received from guidebooks. It is included in the Zagat New York City night life guide; it has not been overlooked by Zagat.
A SIMPLE thank-you today, to the mothers in my life. To my wife, first, who has given us four children.

What CHARLES ROSEN has to say about Beethoven's piano music is worth an afternoon of close attention. In celebration of his recent 80th birthday Mr. Rosen will give a lecture on Beethoven on Sunday at the 92nd Street Y and will play this composer's last three piano sonatas. The pieces, especially end to end, pose enormous problems for the head and for the hands. Given Mr. Rosen's powers of explanation, the first part of the afternoon ought to be at least as valuable as the second. Lecture at 1:30 p.m., concert at 3 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500, 92y.org; $40, $25 for 35 and under; free lunch for series subscribers. Concerts by MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS and the SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY on Thursday and Friday at Carnegie Hall revisit the idea that exceptional orchestral music is made not by the exceptional orchestra or the exceptional conductor, rather by exceptional chemistry. Man and ensemble found each other a number of years ago, with each party subsequently propelled to levels of success not previously enjoyed by either. On Thursday the orchestra will play Stravinsky, including the great Symphony in Three Movements, and then the Tchaikovsky First Symphony. Stravinsky's loyalty to his immediate predecessor and compatriot began early and never flagged. Friday's program is an odder combination: Copland's ''Short Symphony,'' five Mahler songs with the baritone Thomas Hampson and Richard Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra.'' At 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $29 to $98.

An article April 22 on alternatives to popular European vacation destinations referred imprecisely to beer brewing in Bruges, Belgium. Although beer brewed elsewhere in Belgium by Trappist monks is widely available in Bruges, Trappist monks do not brew beer in the city.

To the Editor: A minor point to some, perhaps, and tangential at least, but in Francine Prose's review of Jim Crace's ''Pesthouse'' (April 29), with which I take no major exception, she refers to ''Hell's Angels'' in the possessive form. This is incorrect. The Angels subscribe to the theory that there is more than one ''hell.'' We'll all likely find out at some point whether this is truly the case -- many folks believe they already have, as Prose points out -- and whether or not grammatically correct, there is no apostrophe in Hells Angels. Again, a minor point to some -- but not to the Angels. Jim Fryman East Hampton, N.Y.

In terms of museum exhibitions, the art world is having something of a Left Coast moment. On Sunday the Hammer Museum at the University of California, Los Angeles, unveils ''EDEN'S EDGE: 15 L.A. ARTISTS,'' the first show organized by Gary Garrels, the museum's chief curator and deputy director of exhibitions, since he came to the Hammer from the Museum of Modern Art in 2005. The show's cross-generational span departs pleasantly from today's youth mania, which is as strong in the art world as elsewhere. The artists range from the venerable ceramic sculptor Ken Price to relatively recent arrivals like Elliott Hundley, Rebecca Morales, and Stanya Kahn and Harry Dodge. Through Sept. 2, hammer.ucla.edu. Next Sunday the Orange County Museum of Art in Newport Beach, Calif., opens a retrospective of the California-born, New York-based abstract painter MARY HEILMANN. The 75 works from 1972 to the present will trace the evolution of Ms. Heilmann's distinctively intuitive geometry and casually offhand painting process, below, and feature her work in ceramics as well as furniture design, film and music. Through Aug. 26, ocma.net. Meanwhile back East, on Friday the Philadelphia Museum of Art will open a retrospective of the graphic work of the American modernist WILLIAM H. JOHNSON (1901-70). It is the first show to bring together the watercolors, woodcuts and silk-screens from his two-part career. Johnson spent the 1920s and '30s in Europe, evolving an expressionist-landscape style influenced by Munch. Returning to the United States in 1938, he added modernist geometry and color to faux-folk representations of African-American life, creating images as audacious as anything else being made in New York at that time. Through Aug. 12, philamuseum.org.

Q. I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a seven-unit building in Manhattan. The landlord has emptied the four apartments above me, and he lives in two apartments below me. For the last three years, he has warehoused the upstairs apartments, which had been rent-stabilized, but has allowed friends and religious students to stay there rent-free. Is he allowed to do this? A. ''If a landlord chooses not to rerent vacant apartments, that is the landlord's prerogative,'' said Joel E. Abramson, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. ''Of course, if the landlord does rerent the units, and they are still subject to rent stabilization, they must be rented in accordance with those regulations.''

SCHAFER--Dr. John F. (Jack). Dr. Jack Schafer passed away May 5th, in Santa Rosa California, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 86 after a very short illness. Jack was a plant pathologist with a productive career improving grain crops. He received a doctoral degree at the University of Wisconsin and began his career with a 19-year stint (1949-1968) on the faculty of Purdue University as a core member of a well-known Purdue-US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Small Grain Breeding Team with Ralph M. Caldwell, Leroy E. Compton and Fred L. Patterson. A parade of improved wheat, oat and barley varieties produced by this team attracted the attention of farmers, first in Indiana (home of Purdue) and eventually in all the states that grew these small grain types. ''Knox'' wheat, released in 1953, became the leading soft wheat in the US. After release of ''Arthur'' and ''Arthur 71'' Purdue-USDA soft wheat comprised over 80% of the US soft wheat acreage and greatly increased wheat yield. This Purdue team also issued hundreds of scientific publications conveying significant disease, insect and genetic discoveries. Many graduate students trained by this world famous foursome are now serving in important industry and academic positions in the US and abroad. Jack Schafer was the last living member of the original team. Jack left Purdue to head the Plant Pathology Department at Kansas State University (1968-1972), followed by eight years as head of the Plant Pathology Department at Washington State University, following his dad, Edwin Schafer, to become the first father-son pair to be department heads at the University. In 1974, while at WSU, Jack was consultant as a wheat disease expert on a trade mission to China shortly after President Nixon opened trade relations with that country. Following a short-term assignment to the USDA Integrated Pest Management Program in Beltsville, Maryland, Jack moved to the University of Minnesota, where he was the Research Leader at the USDA-Agricultural Research Service Cereal Rust Laboratory from 1982-1987 when he retired. In recognition of his research and service to plant pathology, Jack was made a fellow of the American Phytopathological Society (APS) and also served as APS president. Jack is survived by his wife Joyce of Santa Rosa, daughter Patricia South and husband Walter of New York City, son Jim and wife Andy of Paradise, CA, and four granddaughters, Claire Hines, Ruth Kmiecik, Marsha Schafer, and Amanda Schafer, and sister Judith Hiss of Akron, OH. He was preceded in death by daughter Janice and brother George. There will be a memorial service on May 18th at 2:00pm at Vineyard Commons in Santa Rosa, California and a graveside memorial service will be in August in Pepin, Wisconsin. Memorials should be sent to the Washington State University Department of Plant Pathology Graduate Student Travel Fund, or to the American Phytopathological Society Foundation directed to graduate student travel.

I certainly resonate to Lisa Sanders's (Diagnosis, April 22) feeling that she had been ''punched in the chest'' as she realized that while focusing on her patient's immediate problems, she had missed an enlarged prostate. However, I was taken aback that she avoided her usual practice of visiting patients in the hospital, because she worried that ''he would be as angry with me as I was with myself.''

To the Editor: As a resident of Jackson Heights, Queens, I feel compelled to protest the sensationalistic tone of ''Knives on the Streets'' (May 6). A nonresident could easily get the impression that gang members are practically lurking on every street corner in Jackson Heights. In fact, that is very far from the truth, and I feel entirely comfortable walking home to my apartment from the Roosevelt Avenue stop as late as 2 in the morning. Judith Natkins Jackson Heights, Queens

Cape Town has endless possibilities for children, including penguin-watching at Boulder's Beach, above, in nearby Table Mountain National Park. Plus: A report on how the travel industry is targeting expectant parents with ''babymoon'' packages -- getaways to take before the kid arrives. In an audio slide show, Henry Fountain talks about a father-son trip to see English football in London. nytimes.com/travel

SPRING spurs migration and for a couple of months now a great river of birds has been streaming toward us, our local woods, backyards and beaches filling up with song. For some of us spring also means a return to old battles, as we wage our local fights to make sure that the returning birds will have both the place and space to rear their young. In recent years the plight of piping plovers has taken center stage, famously pitting drivers of recreational off-road vehicles against conservationists and inspiring bumper stickers that read ''piping plovers taste like chicken'' and even a song titled ''Fifty Ways to Kill a Plover.'' There have been some gains won in the effort to save the birds, whose population has been increasing along the New Jersey and Massachusetts shores, but there is still much work to be done along the rest of the Northeast, including in Connecticut and on Long Island.

This season, dresses are a swinging affair, with silhouettes that float far from the body and high above the knee. In tent, trapeze and baby-doll shapes, these dresses give lots of coverage on top and maximum exposure on the bottom: it's a good year for great legs (and a fantastic year for expectant moms who may be covering an early baby bump). Wear them from cabana to gala, from day to night, but most of all, wear them.

The Zagat Survey, known for rating hotels, restaurants and hot spots in cities like London, Shanghai and Paris, now covers Disney World, too. The Zagat Walt Disney World Insider's Guide (www.zagat.com; $15.95), rates and reviews Disney's six Orlando theme parks in categories that include hotels, rides and attractions, golf, shopping and dining. Robin Pope Safaris (www.robinpopesafaris.net), which operates out of South Luangwa National Park in Zambia, is offering family-friendly safaris at three of its facilities: Nkwali Camp, Robin's House and the Luangwa Safari Houses. Children observe animals in their natural habitat and participate in guided nature walks. They also visit a local school. Rates for Nkwali Camp start at $240 a night for ages 12 to 16 and $160 a night for ages 7 to 11. Adult rates start at $380 a person. Rates at the Luangwa Safari houses start at $1,040 a night for a family of four. Families visiting Waterville Valley, N.H., might be interested in visiting the Margret and H. A. Rey Center (www.reycenter.org) and the Curious George Cottage, once the summer home of the creators of the celebrated children's book series about the curious monkey (right). It offers nature walks, writers' workshops, art shows and activities for children. Three times a month, the center has astronomy nights. On Aug. 10 and 11, the Curious George Cottage Family Festival will include nature walks, lunch with Curious George characters, games, tethered hot air balloon rides, a croquet tournament and a clambake (www.waterville.com). Grande Isle Resort on Great Exuma, Bahamas (www.grandisleresort.com), offers the Junkanoo Kids Club. Each two-hour session (twice a day, five days a week), costs $20 a child, and includes pirate-inspired arts and crafts for ages 3 to 12. Villa rates start at $380. HILARY HOWARD

WHEN Betsy Isles received a phone call in early February asking if she would be willing to put her 19th-century Italianate farmhouse on a house tour, it all seemed comfortably far off: The tour date wasn't until May. She would have plenty of time to get ready. The cause was a good one. Proceeds from the tour -- tickets are $70 for members, $80 for nonmembers -- would benefit the local historical society. Besides, Mrs. Isles and her husband, Chris, love their home. Fascinated by local history, they were willing to open up their house, where they have lived 15 years, to fellow history buffs. In fact, Mrs. Isles's only initial concern about participating was that the upstairs of the house remained off limits to visitors; the idea of strangers peering into the rooms of her two teenagers was a bit much.

To the Editor: Re '' 'Top Chef' Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt'' (front page, May 8): Our daughter has learned the hard way about going into debt to the tune of almost $20,000, and now barely makes a living wage working in a good restaurant.

King Abdullah II of Jordan will meet with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday in the West Bank in an attempt to push along Israeli-Palestinian talks about peace. It will be the king's first visit to the occupied territory, which Jordan ruled until 1967, in seven years. King Abdullah has been traveling the West and the region urging Israel and the Palestinians to make more rapid progress toward solving their long dispute with the help of the Arab League initiative. He has been arguing that the conflict only feeds extremism in the Muslim world and that time is running out before a serious, new round of violence.

IT seems that a one-week trip to the shore, with days spent digging for clams and nights spent camping under the stars, has long ago ceased to be enough of a diversion for families planning their summer getaways. Now, the options range from cooking lessons in Italy (with even toddlers getting some kitchen time) to marionette-making courses in Prague to ''volunteer vacations'' that include trips to orphanages in China. ''Family travel continues to grow as more and more parents, particularly those working full time, view vacations as a way to 'reunite' the family, more than an occasion for rest and relaxation,'' said Peter Yesawich, chief executive of Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, a travel marketing firm. According to the 2007 National Leisure Travel Monitor, a yearly report by the company, family travel will be up this summer, as nearly 40 percent of adults plan to take a vacation with children, up from 32 percent five years ago.

ROTMAN--Art, of Arkville, NY and Montclair, NJ, born in Montreal, Canada in 1926. Loving husband of Anita Schecter Rotman; devoted father of Stephen (Minna Shulman), Laurie (Henry Barber), and Carol (Labe Richman). Adored grandfather of Daniel, Rachel, Maia, Zoe, Anna, Katie, Carly and Ben. Beloved uncle, brother, brother-in-law, and a special friend. Art was the immediate past executive director of the world-wide Jewish Community Centers Association. He was an avid outdoorsman, tree farmer and philanthropist. Funeral will be held at 11am on Sunday, May 13th, at Sharey Tefilo-Israel Cemetery, 432 Orange Rd., Montclair, NJ. Shiva will be held at 47 Oakwood Ave., Upper Montclair, NJ on Sunday, immediately following the funeral and on Monday evening. Donations to the New Israel Fund are welcomed. $(6$)ROTMAN--Arthur, November 29, 1926 to May 10, 2007. The death of Arthur Rotman, president emeritus of Jewish Community Centers Association, is a great loss to his family, his colleagues, and the entire JCC Movement, which he served so ably and with such dedication. After many years at local JCCs, Rotman joined JCC Association as the organization's chief professional officer in 1976. From then until his retirement in 1994, he worked tirelessly to enhance the Jewish nature of JCCs and to support the status and professionalism of Jewish communal work. His deep involvement with the Commission on Maximizing the Jewish Educational Effectiveness of JCCs transformed the JCC, making it a premier institution of Judaic engagement. His deep commitment to Jewish life and community made him a giant in the field. Our sincere condolences to his wife Anita, his children Laurie, Stephen, Mina, Carol and Labe, and eight grandchildren. Alan P. Solow, Chair Allan Finkelstein, President JCC Association

Here's a story Hallmark probably wouldn't want you to hear. It's about the ''mother of modern Mother's Day'' - Anna Marie Jarvis. As a girl growing up in West Virginia in the 1870s, she once heard her mother end a Sunday school prayer with these words: ''I hope that someone, sometime will found a memorial Mother's Day commemorating her for the matchless service she renders humanity in every field of life. She is entitled to it.'' She picked fights with public figures over Mother's Day issues, railed against ''charlatans'' and ''termites,'' was denounced in the florist trade press and got arrested for disrupting a meeting of the American War Mothers, whom she accused of profiteering on sales of Mother's Day carnations. Anna was devoted to her mother. When she died in 1905, Anna, now a single, 41-year-old businesswoman, made a solemn graveside vow: ''By the grace of God, you shall have that Mother's Day.'' A mocking 1938 Time article portrayed Jarvis as a bitter, homebound ''spinster'' fighting a losing war against ''unscrupulous florists and confectioners.'' As she once told a reporter: ''This is the paradox of my life. My greatest success is also my greatest defeat.'' She walked the streets of Philadelphia with petitions to rescind Mother's Day and was eventually committed to a sanitarium. She died in 1948 at the age of 84 - blind, penniless and childless. Her care had secretly been paid for in part by florists. Were they grateful to her, or just happy she was locked away? Or both? Nine years later, as a result of Jarvis's vigorous campaigning, President Woodrow Wilson signed a joint Congressional resolution proclaiming a national Mother's Day on the second Sunday of every May. Be careful what you wish for. In the coming years, Jarvis watched with disgust as her holiday became ''desecrated'' by commercialization. The front room of Jarvis's Philadelphia house had been kept as a shrine to her dead mother. As she once wrote: ''Mother's Day is to remind us of our duty before it is too late.'' The National Retail Foundation estimates that Americans will spend nearly $16 billion on Mother's Day this year. Anna Jarvis might well agree: That's a lot of guilt!

It seems that James Traub (April 29) takes what the Islamists say essentially at face value. It was naïve reporting like this that, before the Islamic revolution in Iran, lulled the United States into accepting Khomeini and abandoning the shah. No one can seriously say that either Iran, the U.S. or the Middle East is better for the change.

To Catch a Thief Mets shortstop José Reyes is on a blistering pace on the base paths. His 20 steals lead the league and put him on pace for about 95 for the season. That would make him the first player to steal more than 90 bases since Rickey Henderson had 93 in 1988. Vince Coleman stole 81 that year, but no one has stolen more than 80 since. From Bad to Worse This was a tough week for the Toronto Blue Jays. On Thursday, Roy Halladay gave up eight runs in five innings as the Blue Jays lost to Boston, 8-0, their ninth defeat in a row. Earlier that day, closer B. J. Ryan had reconstructive elbow surgery, which will keep him out until the middle of next season. Then, on Friday, the Blue Jays snapped their losing streak with a 5-1 victory against Tampa Bay but lost Halladay for four to six weeks after he had an emergency appendectomy. Doby Gets His Due Less than three months after Jackie Robinson broke Major League Baseball's color barrier in 1947, Larry Doby became the first African-American to play in the American League when he suited up for the Indians. On Aug. 10, a little less than four months after baseball honored Robinson, the Indians will honor Doby, who died in 2003, with a pregame ceremony. The Indians will wear Doby's No. 14 for the game against the Yankees. THE WATCH LIST Chris Capuano, below, is scheduled to start twice this week, which is good news for Brewers fans. Capuano is 5-0 with a 2.31 earned run average. But better than that, the smooth-sailing Brewers have not lost this season when he has started, covering seven starts. Cubs fans should not become too excited about ÁNGel PagÁn, who homered and went 2 for 3 in his first game of the season. Pagán never stole fewer than 27 bases in a full minor league season, but he hit .247 in 77 games last season, with an on-base percentage of .306. If the top prospect Félix Pié could get only four at-bats in his last week before being demoted, it does not figure that Pagán will play much. The Devil Rays' James Shields is 3-0, and batters are hitting .198 against him. Real deal or no? He was streaky as a rookie last year (3.60 E.R.A. in June; 6.49 in July; 2.78 in August; 5.96 in September). But Shields is still just 25, and those 49 strikeouts -- fourth in the A.L. -- do not lie. Through Friday night. (Sources by Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, Baseball-reference.com.)

Mahler: Symphony No. 3 Michelle DeYoung, mezzo-soprano; Chicago Children's Choir; Chicago Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Bernard Haitink. CSO Resound 901 701; two CD's. IF only because of the Eighth Symphony, so different from its siblings in mood, overall texture and proportions, it has never been easy for a conductor to be a Mahler generalist. The range is simply too broad, and even works with superficial similarities, like the Second and Third Symphonies, make radically different demands on their interpreters. But an age of specialization has turned up masters of individual works, and in the Third Symphony, James Levine and Bernard Haitink are perhaps the most persuasive maestros of the day.
PERLSTEIN--Jeanne S. Mother dear, 26 Mother's Days without you. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen, and Suzanne

Strauss: 'Four Last Songs,' Scenes From 'Salome' and 'Capriccio' Nina Stemme, soprano; Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, conducted by Antonio Pappano. EMI Classics 3 78797 2; CD. THOUGH opinions about the various productions presented at the Bayreuth Festival last summer were sharply divided, there seemed to be consensus that Nina Stemme's portrayal of Isolde in Christoph Marthaler's production of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' was the festival's vocal highlight. Ms. Stemme, an alluring and fiery Swedish soprano, combined cool Nordic colorings with fearless emotional intensity to make a vocally blazing Isolde.

THE organ music, disco ball, strobe lights and blindingly bright neon seem out of sync with the fashions and norms of today, but the roller skaters zipping around the Rink in Montvale do not seem to care. Roller skating indoors may not be trendy, but there is something to be said for its simple pleasures. Yet the Rink in Montvale is scheduled to close June 3 to make way for a housing development, and roller skating fans in northern New Jersey will soon have to find something else to do or someplace else to skate. They can't go to the Rink in Bergenfield; it's now a Sears hardware store. They can't go to Skater's World in Wayne; it's now an Office Depot.

Manu Ginóbili's shiner bloomed immediately under his left eye, a dark mark of pride. In a series of bandages and bruises -- on faces and egos -- Ginóbili finally got into the fray Saturday night. He had struggled in the Spurs' first two games of the Western Conference semifinal against the Phoenix Suns.

Erika Katherine Mikkelsen, a daughter of Mary and Curt Mikkelsen of Seattle, was married yesterday to Michael John Halford, the son of Margaret and William M. Halford of Edmonton, Alberta. The Rev. Dr. Forrest Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The bride, 32, is the associate general counsel at Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, in Yonkers. She graduated from Stanford and received her law degree from the University of California, Berkeley.

THAT'S A LOT OF NAKED PEOPLE The News -- More than 18,000 people stripped off their clothes and posed nude for the photographer Spencer Tunick in Mexico City's famous square, the Zócalo. Behind the News -- Mr. Tunick specializes in shooting big groups in the buff. Over the years, he has staged similar mass photo shoots around the globe -- in New York, Switzerland, Chile, Brazil, Spain, Finland, Australia and other places. So, what's it all about? ''I just create shapes and forms with human bodies,'' Mr. Tunick explained to The Associated Press. ''It's an abstraction, it's a performance.'' THE SUM OF ALL THINGS The News -- Scientists from around the world plan to compile everything they know about the Earth's 1.8 million known species and put it all on one Web site. Behind the News -- The site will be free and open to everyone; the information is expected to fill an estimated 300 million pages. The mammoth effort is being spearheaded by seven of the world's top scientific institutions, including the Smithsonian Institution. And those 300 million pages may just be the beginning. Scientists estimate there may be eight million species on the planet, more than three-quarters of them undiscovered. NOTHING BUT THE TRUTH The News -- The Justice Department said it would not object to a Congressional grant of immunity to a former top aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who played a central role in the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors. Behind the News -- Monica Goodling, the former aide, refused to appear before the House Judiciary Committee, citing her constitutional right to avoid self-incrimination. But the department's decision appeared to increase the likelihood that she will appear before the Congressional panel, which is investigating last year's firings. A VERY BIG PAYCHECK The News -- Steve Jobs, the legendary chief executive of Apple, was the nation's highest paid chief executive last year, according to the latest issue of Forbes magazine. Behind the News -- Mr. Jobs, 52, one of Apple's founders, earned a nominal salary of $1 a year, but according to Forbes, he realized $647 million from vested restricted stock. Overall, the magazine found that the chief executives of America's 500 biggest companies earned an average of $15.2 million each. Apple recently reported an 88 percent increase in profit for its latest quarter on sales of Macintosh computers and iPods. A FIERY DEATH REVEALED The News -- Astronomers reported that they had seen the brightest and most powerful stellar explosion ever recorded. Behind the News -- The astronomers said the supernova may be a completely new type of explosion, theorized but never seen before, that would explain how the earliest and most massive stars in the universe died and strewed new elements across space to fertilize future stars and planets. They were left to speculate about what caused the explosion, in a galaxy 240 million light-years away. ''It doesn't get any more exciting for a theorist,'' said one of those theorists.

A BRITISH man was under arrest in Macedonia last week after a crash killed an elderly couple during the cross-European Gumball 3000 rally, which was cancelled after the accident. The 30-year-old Briton, Nicholas Morley, was participating in the 3,000-mile rally through 16 countries when his Porsche 911 collided with a Volkswagen Golf near Struga, about 120 miles south of Skopje, the capital of Macedonia. The couple in the Golf, Vladimir and Margarita Cepuljoski, died at a local hospital.
RUDERMAN--Abe. 1910-1982. Still with us in spirit, he lives in our hearts and thoughts. David and the Family

If the thought of a traditional summer camp -- complete with canoeing and marshmallow roasts -- makes your teenager yawn, why not try a more adventuresome approach? According to Peg Smith, chief executive of the American Camp Association, there has been a 59 percent increase in travel camp programs since 2000. ''Parents want to introduce their kids to new cultures and ideas now that the world is more global,'' she said. ''On these programs, they can experience new life skills in a nurturing camp environment.''

BAEDER--Andrew M.D., Aged 98 years, of Budapest on May 9, 2007. Holocaust Survivor. OB/GYN -NYU Medical Center and Manhattan State Hospital. Devoted companion of Jane Meshel for 28 years. Cherished father of Dr. John Baeder. Loving brother of Magda Weisz. Beloved uncle of many nieces and nephews. Dr. Baeder loved music, was a painter and has written several books. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Dr. Baeder's name to NYU Medical Center.

To the Editor: Re ''Where Are All the Black Swans?'' by Gia Kourlas [May 6]: I take exception to the premise that American dance companies have a ''diversity problem.'' As a former professional ballet dancer, I can tell you that the requirements for entering a professional-level dance company are quite exacting and, because of the nature of this art, inflexible. These do not mean skin color but body type, height and ability, attributes that cannot be compromised without diminishing the entire company.

''I have never made a distinction between my feature films and my 'documentaries,' '' WERNER HERZOG once stated. ''For me they are all just films.'' Starting on Friday FILM FORUM is giving audiences ample opportunity to consider this claim with a two-week, 35-title retrospective that brings together his greatest nonfiction hits (''Grizzly Man,'' 2005) with more obscure works, some dating to the mid-1960s. Although many of the rarer titles are available through Mr. Herzog's Web site, wernerherzog.com, in a six-disc box that will set you back 150 euros (more than $200), this bounty has not yet hit the rental market. In addition to ''Grizzly Man'' and ''The Wild Blue Yonder'' (2005), series highlights include ''Lessons of Darkness'' (1992), a vision of the apocalypse by way of post-gulf war Kuwait; and ''My Best Fiend'' (1999), a portrait of the actor Klaus Kinski, with whom Mr. Herzog worked and famously battled. Also very much worth a look are ''The Great Ecstasy of Woodcarver Steiner'' (1974), a snapshot of a ski-jumper (or ''ski-flyer'') that brings out the poetic sportscaster in Mr. Herzog, and the politically controversial ''Ballad of the Little Soldier'' (1984), which sympathetically considers the plight of Miskito Indians, some as young as 10, fighting Nicaragua's Sandinista government. Supplementing the series is a tasty sidebar of nonfiction films chosen by Mr. Herzog. Among the top-flight selections are Jean Rouch's cinéma-vérité masterwork ''Les Maîtres Fous'' (1955), which explores post-colonialism and madness in Africa; Chris Marker's sublime ''Sans Soleil'' (1983); and two from Errol Morris, ''Gates of Heaven'' (1978, about a pet cemetery) and ''Vernon, Florida'' (1981, about the town of the same name). Years ago Mr. Herzog fulfilled a promise he made to Mr. Morris with a gesture immortalized in another sidebar selection, Les Blank's aptly titled ''Werner Herzog Eats His Shoe'' (1979). Friday through June 7, Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212) 727-8110, filmforum.org; $10.50, $5.50 members.

Recently the manic cries of Jim Cramer, the financial commentator, had the effect of a lullaby on Terry J. Lundgren, the chief executive of Federated Department Stores, the parent company of Macy's. Mr. Lundgren was far from pleased last December when Mr. Cramer rated Federated a sell during the ''Sell Block'' segment of his ''Mad Money'' show on CNBC. The company's holiday sales performance was weak, Mr. Cramer said.

A letter writer (Letters, April 29) wrote to complain about the Ethicist's response to a reader (April 15) who declined to be examined in front of medical students. Nominations for the 2007 Tony Awards are to be announced on Tuesday. Broadway will continue to hum along, but except for the summer openings of ''Xanadu'' and ''Grease,'' a new season won't begin in earnest for a while. Many smaller companies are waiting in the wings, hoping, perhaps, that a lull in Midtown might mean a larger audience for less traditional fare. As if on cue, several unusual festivals are opening after Tuesday's announcement. Those who recognize Karol Wojtyla as Pope John Paul II may also know that in his younger days he was a man of the theater in his native Poland. Beginning on Wednesday the Storm Theater will present THE KAROL WOJTYLA THEATER FESTIVAL, made up of three plays written by the actor-playwright-pope. One of these, ''Our God's Brother,'' tells the story of a man who must choose between an artistic vocation and a religious path, a struggle Wojtyla may have known well. Through June 17, 145 West 46 Street, Manhattan, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $15 to $30. Also beginning Wednesday is WORD OF MOUTH, a four-day festival of site-specific plays, recitations and poems to be performed in lobbies, mezzanines and other areas of the World Financial Center. One program, ''Girls Just Wanna Have Fund$,'' is a slate of six short works about women and wealth. Since the center is a public space, the festival's creators will ask passersby to stop, look and listen, and that should be worth watching in its own right. Through Saturday, West Street, south of Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505, worldfinancialcenter.com; free. The Ensemble Studio Theater will also contribute to the Wednesday openings with SHATTER, a lineup of four new one-act plays written and directed by the company's four directors in residence. Among the shows is ''The Last Day,'' based on the 1953 short story by Richard Matheson (with Jed Orlemann and Marilee Talkington). Adapted and directed by Justin Quinn Pelegano, the play imagines a group of New Yorkers facing extinction. Through May 22, 549 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $15.

Jon Mooallem's article (April 29) literally and figuratively opened my eyes. PEACHEY--Rosalyn Joy (Robinson), 49, died May 2, of cancer. She will be lovingly remembered as a devoted wife, proud mother and inspirational Director of Childrens Choirs at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in NYC.

When Alain J. P. Belda, chief executive of the aluminum producer Alcoa, tapes video messages for his company's employees, he often does five takes. But that is not the result of any shortcomings before the camera. Mr. Belda, who was born in Morocco but raised mainly in Brazil and Canada, is proficient in five languages: English, Portuguese, French, Spanish and Italian. Conveniently, Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, has operations in countries where those languages are spoken.

On the Onondaga Nation near Syracuse, Jeanne Shenandoah adores lacrosse. All eight of her brothers played it. She scours the papers for scores of the local indoor team. But when it comes to women playing the game that her Iroquois forefathers originated centuries ago, the conversation turns tense. ''This is a precious, sacred area for me,'' she said in a room at the Onondaga Communications Office where she works. ''To our community and families, lacrosse is a sacred medicine.''

WHITE--Carla. Died peacefully at home in NYC, May 9, 2007. Ms. White devoted her life to artistic exploration and growth as a jazz singer. She was born in Oakland, CA and raised in Bellport, NY. Completing two years at London's prestigious Webber-Douglas Academy of Dramatic Art, Ms. White returned to New York City, embarking upon a 30-year career for which she garnered critical praise: ''One of the most impressive performers to come along in years...an unusually accomplished interpreter,'' Howard Reich, Chicago Tribune; ''A singer who blends interpretive intelligence with a solid musical grounding and a sure sense of swing,'' Don Heckman, Los Angeles Times. Career highlights include New York's Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, Town Hall and the Texaco Jazz Festival; The Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C.; the Ottawa International Jazz Festival; the Chattanooga Riverbend Festival; and the Mellon Jazz Festival in Philadelphia. Success is playing with the musicians I love to play with in situations where the audience is receptive and appreciative,'' Ms. White said. She is survived by her mother, Mrs. Frederick Ayer of Seattle, WA, and three stepbrothers, James, Anthony, and Frederick Ayer and her partner Anne Stamper. Ms. White was predeceased by her father, brother and sister, Penny and Miles White. A memorial celebration will be held June 8, 2007 at St. Peters Church 619 Lexington Avenue at E. 54th St. NYC at 5:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation and the Jazz Foundation of America.

BREITMAN--Jeffrey K. Died April 26, 2007 of heart failure at age 49. Most dearly beloved son of Ruth and Robert Friedman and the late Harold Breitman. Loved and adored by his sister Joanne Breitman Singer and her husband Eric. Brother Martin Friedman (Toinette), his nieces and his sister, the late Anne Friedman. All who knew Jeff respected and thought highly of him. He was intelligent, caring, loving and kind. A fine gentleman. He will be missed.

To the Editor: ''Who wouldn't want a swashbuckling lion slayer stopping in between safaris to recite poems and embrace her under the mosquito netting?'' Florence Williams asks in her review of ''Too Close to the Sun,'' by Sara Wheeler (April 29). Well, I wouldn't. I prefer reliable men who are there when you need them rather than being on safari. And I am hardly the only woman who finds ''untamable men'' about as ''alluring'' as warthogs. Felicia Nimue Ackerman Providence, R.I.

''Are you restless like me?'' Tom Gabel of Against Me! sings in ''Up the Cuts,'' a song from his band's next album, ''New Wave,'' due in June. Hey, who isn't? Short attention spans pace 21st-century culture: Web-surfing, sampling, channel-hopping, multitasking. Even live rock music, although it's tied to the limitations of a fixed number of musicians on a stage in real time, jumps all over the place. That explains the improbable triple bill at Roseland that Against Me! shares with Cursive and Mastodon on Thursday. And it's a good part of the charm of Deerhoof, which headlines Irving Plaza that same night. DEERHOOF's music juxtaposes the tricky structures of progressive rock -- odd meters, dissonant counterpoint, sudden stops and starts -- with brief stretches of pop, funk or psychedelia. The songs switch from soft to loud, from sweet to fierce, from sparse to overstuffed and back. At one moment, Satomi Matsuzaki (on bass) sings a perky melody; the next, Greg Saunier on drums and John Dieterich on guitar are churning out a sinewy riff; then all three mesh in something danceable. Somehow, the music becomes more than a technical feat; all those ideas arrive with a silly exuberance. 9 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; $16.50 in advance, $17 on Thursday. The Roseland bill brings together multiple constituencies. MASTODON is on the progressive end of metal, assembling grand concept albums and songs that slam away for a while, rev up even faster, flaunt twin guitars and might even swerve toward a melody. AGAINST ME! merges the drive and earnest political intentions of punk with touches of Southern rock. The indie-rock of CURSIVE, a band from Omaha, is harder to pin down; its songs embrace bruising post-punk dissonance, swinging trumpet lines and an Anglophile streak that includes both the Kinks and the Cure, all stoked with an impassioned discontent. 6:15 p.m., Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; $25.

Stacy Elizabeth Kantor and Dr. Daniel Russell Lefton were married last evening by Cantor Ronald Broden at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The bride and bridegroom work at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan; she is a registered nurse in the neurosurgical intensive care unit, and he is a neuroradiologist.

5 Dead and 3 Missing In Attack on U.S. Patrol A coordinated attack on seven American soldiers and an Iraqi Army interpreter south of Baghdad left five of them dead and three missing, the United States military said. The attack occurred near Mahmudiya, a rural area that is a stronghold of Qaeda militants and that has proved difficult to control. An extensive search for the missing three began immediately after the attack, military officials said. Eugene J. Cornacchia, the acting president of St. Peter's College in Jersey City since December, will be formally introduced as its 22nd president on Monday, becoming the first layperson to run the college. Dr. Cornacchia, who previously served as the provost, was tapped to run the college after the Rev. James N. Loughran, the previous president, died in a fall in his campus residence on Dec. 23.

Re ''Revisiting The Times's Coverage of the Duke Rape Case'' (April 22): In trying to defend The New York Times, you actually expose the serious ideological bias of the Duke rape case reporting. The reporter Duff Wilson focused in on 33 pages of a 1,850-page report. These 33 pages were written such that an unbiased reporter could conclude that the prosecutor had a substantial case against the Duke lacrosse players. But what about the other 1,817 pages?
KALLIR-FRANK--Lilian, May 6th, 1931-Oct. 25th, 2004. Everyday is Mother's Day. Your ''Big Baby'' misses you.

Seventy-three companies considered potentially responsible for polluting the lower Passaic River have agreed to pay for a $37 million study, conducted by the federal Environmental Protection Agency, that will identify contaminants along a 17-mile stretch of the river and recommend possible cleanup approaches. The agreement, announced Tuesday, may be the first step in removing poisons like mercury, DDT and dioxin from a part of the Passaic, from Garfield to Newark Bay.
WEXLER--Melissa Ann. May 9th, 1958-September 12th, 1981. Dear Missy, we miss you everyday, especially on your Birthday. Love, Mommy Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri & Larry

HOLBROOK--Ruth Price, of East Blue Hill, ME died May 1, 2007. She was born on November 9, 1911 in Walpole, MA and was predeceased by her husband, Luther Gardner Holbrook in 1979 after a long and happy marriage. Ruth graduated from Wheaton College in Norton, MA in 1934. Her only son, Henry Gilbert Holbrook died two months before her. She is survived by three daughters; Deborah, Penelope, and Sarah, son-inlaw, Abbott Cutler, daughterin-law, Sherry Holbrook; nine grandchildren, six greatgrandchildren and two stepgreat-grandchildren. Flowers are gratefully declined. Memorials may be made to the East Blue Hill Village Improvement Society or to the charity of one's choice. A memorial service will be held at the East Blue Hill Church, East Blue Hill, ME on Saturday, June 2, 2007 at 11 am. www.bragdonkelley.com.

On Monday night dolled-up audience members will compete with high-flying dancers to see who can manage the biggest spectacle at AMERICAN BALLET THEATER's spring gala program at the Metropolitan Opera House. Highlights include a new pas de deux by Brian Reeder, one of ballet's most engaging contemporary choreographers. The work is set to Chopin's Waltz in A minor, Op. 34, No. 2, which will be performed by the pianist Lang Lang, making his debut with the company. But the real draw here is the dancers: Diana Vishneva, Ethan Stiefel, Alessandra Ferri (in her final Ballet Theater season), David Hallberg, Nina Ananiashvili, Herman Cornejo -- the list goes on. 6:30 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, abt.org; $27 to $140. LAWRENCE GOLDHUBER probes a different sort of excess in the New York premiere of ''7 Deadly Sins: Gluttony,'' the Dance Theater Workshop debut of the delightfully pointed and expansive Mr. Goldhuber and his BIGMANARTS company. The troupe's star power includes Robert La Fosse, Keely Garfield, Jamie Bishton and Arthur Aviles. The show features another New York premiere, ''A Match Made in Heaven''; the world premiere of ''Hoody,'' an urban take on Little Red Riding Hood; and ''Dances With Wolves,'' a duet for Mr. Goldhuber and Ms. Garfield. Wednesday through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $12 to $20. If you still want more, head to Mo Pitkin's on Friday for midnight burlesque, with UNKLE DAVE MONSTER as host and performances by the likes of VERONIKA SWEET THE MAFIA PRINCESS and RUBY VALENTINE. The show is part of the fourth annual soloNOVA Arts Festival. Wednesday through June 3, 34 Avenue A, East Village, (212) 777-5660, terranovacollective.org; $10.

To the Editor: Re ''Poet, Mother, Editor, Wife,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 6): Although Deborah Garrison is clearly bright and so well balanced in her life, I shuddered -- after reading her poetry -- over the fact that she is the poetry editor for Knopf.
