ANOTHER day, another record-breaking sewage spill. This time in Yonkers, where eight million gallons from a broken pipe spewed into the Hudson River last weekend in what officials called the worst such incident in the history of Westchester County. For swimmers, kayakers and fishermen in the New York City area, including Westchester and Rockland Counties, it was especially bad because many of them were exposed before they heard the news.

BORD--Marilyn. The family and friends of Marilyn (''Mickey'') Bord mourn her death on May 3rd. During and after her career as a special education teacher, she volunteered for the Alvin Ailey Dance Company. In the 1950's she dyed and sewed costumes. Later she became the company's archivist. She also volunteered with the South Street Seaport and a local veterinarian. She loved to attend theatre, opera and concerts and travel. She is survived by her brother, Marshall, and wife Linda, her cousin Bruce and wife, Dale, cousin Susan and husband, Dick, cousins Mindy and Richard and their children and grandchildren.

A toddler squeals with delight alongside a jumble of boulders, plunking herself thigh high into a sloshing emerald pool within inches of dozens of honking African penguins that squirt in and out of the water like large self-propelled watermelon seeds. This sparkling cove at Boulders Beach, less than an hour outside Cape Town, South Africa, is part of Table Mountain National Park, and one of the most protected places along False Bay for kids -- and birds -- to swim. Squint your eyes and you could be in the Seychelles. It's just one of many places -- drive-up beaches, malaria-free open spaces and casual cafes -- that make Cape Town an easy place for families to decompress. South Africa's safari lodges may dangle attractive kid bait, like hunts for the ''little five'' (elephant shrews and rhino beetles among them), but they also have safari rules like ''no talking,'' and ''sit still.'' In Cape Town, children can make noise when they see animals, swim next to them, and even touch some.

To the Editor: Tara McKelvey's review of my book, ''Bigger Than Life'' (April 29), brings to mind the adage ''Be careful what you wish for.'' No small thing to be reviewed in The Times, and for that I'm grateful. No doubt, either, that McKelvey is entitled to her opinion. But if the book is ''confused'' and ''uneven,'' that's one thing; quite another to misrepresent the events, or my account of them, in the way she does. Since she devotes five paragraphs to synopsis and only one to critique, she's obligated, I think, to get it right. It may be true, for instance, that I wandered the gathering after my father's memorial service in a ''trance'' of grief and shock -- but to say my state was ''Valium induced'' is purposefully inaccurate and snide.

WRIGHT--Ruth Martin, Columbus, NC resident of Tryon Estates, died April 22, 2007. Formerly of Rockville Centre Long Island, Fairfield, CT, Westfield, NJ and Pittsburgh, PA. The widow of Robert H. Wright. She is survived by sons Robert H. Wright Jr. Cooper L. Wright, John M. Wright, brother Dr. Robert S. Martin and their families. Memorials may be made to a charity of your choice.

To the Editor: Re ''Doctors Reaping Millions for Use of Anemia Drugs'' (front page, May 9): So two drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors who prescribe anemia medicines that lack effectiveness and put a patient's health at risk. This is not a surprise because it reflects our broken health system, a system driven by greed.

Hannah Emery, 7, a second-grader from Arvada, Colo.: ''First we went to Oklahoma, then we were going to leave by Tuesday to go to the beach in Texas, but my dad had to stay in Oklahoma until Thursday because he had to work. We would have had only one little part of the day to go to the beach, so we went to the sand dunes where we would be closer to home, and we would get two days. I have three brothers. We just bought the kites. My little brother, Lucas, had a SpongeBob kite; Ian had a kite that you can use with two hands; and Kyle had a dragon kite. Mine was a My Little Pony kite. Kyle and Ian didn't get their kites up. They kept trying it, and since they couldn't get it in the air, they went to the river. My mom held my kite and I started running and she let go. It goes up really high. I got it up like six times, twice for a long time, and the other times just for a minute.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Some executives are much more hands-on than others. That was made clear last week during a panel discussion titled ''Power Couples -- How They Live and Work'' at the 92nd Street Y in New York. When the talk turned to raising children, Evelyn Lauder, senior corporate vice president of the Estée Lauder Companies, said her husband was ''an amazing dad, and he did change diapers'' when their two sons were babies. The husband in question is Leonard A. Lauder, the 73-year-old chairman of Estée Lauder.
ROGERS--Reita B., 1918-2005. Not a day goes by without missing you. We were all so lucky to have our red-headed Momma. Happy 2nd Mother's Day in heaven. R.I.P. Love, Beth, Jeff and John

An article last Sunday about the cultural and political implications of the act of kissing referred incorrectly to the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, who refused to apologize to clerics in his country for kissing the gloved hand of an elderly woman. It was Iran's former president, Mohammad Khatami -- not Mr. Ahmadinejad -- who visited Pope Benedict XVI in the midst of the controversy.

HOSIOSKY--Ellen N., D.M.D. Died on April 18, 2007 at home after a brief battle with cancer at the age of ninety six. She was the loving and devoted wife to Issai Hosiosky who died in 1998. Ellen was truly a pioneer for women educationally and professionally. She graduated from Columbia Dental School with honors and became the first woman on their teaching staff. Ellen had a true passion for learning and that passion did not stop with dentistry. She studied all forms of medicine and incorporated that knowledge into her dental practice. Her love for learning is only surpassed by her willingness to pass that knowledge on to others. Dr. Ellen Hosiosky was truly a charitable person, not only with her money, but more importantly with her time to help others. She will be missed.

Judith W. Lynn and Joel M. Levy were married on Tuesday by Rabbi Joel Levine at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla. The bride, 56, will continue to use her name professionally. She is an associate broker at Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy in Manhattan and at Coldwell Banker Realty in Philadelphia. She is on the board of trustees of the Jewish Family and Children's Services of Greater Philadelphia. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from Temple University. She is the daughter of Belle G. Wishneff of Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., and the late Burton Wishneff.

The swallows have returned to Capistrano, the Cardinals are back in St. Louis, and some pretty rare birds have been spotted around the country this spring. Big game birds are roosting as usual in the Bronx. But are they Glorious Fly Swatters or Pinstriped Money Grubbers? We won't know until October. Excited New Englanders have reported sighting a Golden Gyro Flicker. This exotic creature may have migrated from its native Asia in search of the famous Greek sandwich for which it is named. It has certainly feathered its nest in the Boston area. On Chicago's north side, Wrigley's Huffin Puffin scolds his Feckless Flock. Among the newly hatched Flushing Meadow Larks is a covey of Randolph's Mossbacked Coots. Pictured here are the Gray-Whiskered Franco, the Rusty-Winged Glavine and the Cuban Geezer. Last seen nesting with Orioles and more recently thought to be extinct, the incredible Shrinking Slammer has been spotted in Texas. And out west, the ill-tempered Giant Bay Bird, or Balco's Bare-Faced Lyre, chews out an inquisitive News Hawk.

JAMES--Sheila. Tierney-Advertising Executive died peacefully at home after a brief illness. Her career spanned four decades in print, television and cable advertising. She was president and proprietor of Harbor Associates, located in Greenwich, CT. In addition to her responsibilities at Harbor, she served as consulting producer on the Joan Rivers Show ''Can We Shop'' and was on the adjunct faculty of New York's Fashion Institute of Technology. She is survived by her husband Stuart James; two sons, Morgan F. James, of Whitefish, Montana, and Owen P. James, of Greenwich, CT and two grandsons Nicolas and Noah James, of Whitefish, MT. A memorial service will be held May 15, 1:00pm at the Leo Gallagher Funeral Home in Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, request memorials be sent to The Benedictine Grange, 42 Dorethy Road, Redding, CT.

This early on, the 2008 presidential race has so many unknown candidates it has dark horseflies on its dark horses. But maybe you're among the fully one-quarter of Americans who, in a CBS News poll last month, said they were actually paying a lot of attention to this stuff. If so, the quiz below should be a snap. Right? TOM KUNTZ 1. Here are the lower-tier Republican presidential hopefuls. Match names with faces: Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas John H. Cox, Chicago businessman Former Gov. Jim Gilmore of Virginia Rep. Duncan Hunter of California Former Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas Rep. Ron Paul of Texas Rep. Tom Tancredo of Colorado (One point for each correct match -- potential 8 points.) 2. A lot of people know that Mitt Romney, the Republican who was governor of Massachusetts, is a Mormon, but did you know that six candidates are Roman Catholic? Who from the list below isn't? A. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut B. Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York C. Former Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska D. Gov. Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico E. Tommy Thompson F. Brownback G. Cox (Correct answer: 3 points) 3. Who has been least associated with presidential politics? A. Paul Tsongas B. Ron Paul C. Pat Paulsen D. RuPaul (Correct answer: 1 point) 4. Match the potential health risk with the politician: Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois; Fred Thompson former Republican senator of Tennessee; Giuliani; Huckabee. A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma B. Adult-onset diabetes C. Prostate cancer D. Past smoking (One point for each correct match -- potential 4 points) 5. Match the eyebrow-raising quote with the speaker: Tommy Thompson, Obama, Giuliani, Romney and Yosemite Sam. A. ''Freedom is about authority. Freedom is about the willingness of every single human being to cede to lawful authority a great deal of discretion about what you do.'' B. ''I'm in the private sector and for the first time in my life I'm earning money. You know, that's sort of part of the Jewish tradition.'' C. ''In case you missed it, this week, there was a tragedy in Kansas. Ten thousand people died, an entire town destroyed.'' D. ''I'm not a big-game hunter. I've made that very clear. I've always been a rodent and rabbit hunter. Small varmints, if you will.'' E. ''Ya better say yer prayers, ya flea-bitten varmint! I'm a-gonna blow ya to smithereenies!'' (One point for each correct match -- potential 5 points) 6. Match the politician -- Tommy Thompson, Tancredo, Paul, Gravel -- with the descriptive phrase found on his official Web site: A. ''No amnesty for illegal immigrants'' B. The ''one exception to the Gang of 535'' on Capitol Hill C. ''The reliable conservative'' D. ''More like Cicero than Quixote'' (One point for each correct match -- potential 4 points) 7. Pomp my Ride. Match the candidates with how they say they roll: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York Former Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona Rep. Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio Giuliani Obama Dodd Romney A. 2005 Ford Mustang convertible B. ''For security reasons, we drive in Secret Service vehicles but the Service lets us use a Ford hybrid when we're home...'' C. Ford Escape hybrid, a compact S.U.V. D. Chrysler 300C, a full-size sport-luxury sedan E. ''I don't drive, I navigate.'' F. Cadillac CTS, a midsize luxury sedan G. Ford Focus compact (One point for each correct match: potential 8 points) 8. Fred Thompson? Tommy Thompson? What's the diff? A. Fred hasn't declared candidacy. B. Fred, from Tennessee, has a better southern drawl than Hillary Clinton. C. Tommy advocates trimming welfare more than John Edwards. D. Fred spends a lot less money on a trim than John Edwards. E. All of the above, probably (Correct answer: one point) Answers: 1) Brownback, G; Cox, H; Gilmore, F; Hunter, A; Thompson, D; Huckabee, E; Paul, C; Tancredo, B; 2) C; 3) D; 4) Obama, D; Thompson, A; Giuliani, C; Huckabee, B; 5) Thompson, B; Obama, C; Giuliani, A; Romney, D; Yosemite Sam, E; 6) Thompson, C; Tancredo, A; Paul, B; Gravel, D; 7) Clinton, B; Edwards, C; McCain, F; Kucinich, G; Giuliani, E; Obama, D; Dodd, C; Romney, A; 8) E There are a total of 34 possible points. If your score -- or political-obscurity quotient (P.O.Q.) -- is: 0-9 You never miss an episode of ''Judge Judy.'' 10-18 You have heeded John McCain's admonition to ''Get a life,'' and may actually know who he is. 19-27 You are a C-Span caller with the TV volume up too loud. 28-34 You are a model citizen, political pro or someone with entirely too much time on your hands.
FISHER--Naomi, passed away on Tuesday, May 8, 2007. Beloved mother, grandmother, loving wife and sister. We will truly miss her. We were privileged to have her as part of our family. The Khakoo's

Brahms: 'Ein Deutsches Requiem' Dorothea Röschmann, soprano; Thomas Quasthoff, baritone; Rundfunkchor Berlin; Berlin Philharmonic, conducted by Simon Rattle. EMI Classics 3 65393 2; CD. TRIBUTES to God slip into two categories. There is the act of penitential abstinence: a sacrifice of the senses that turns self-denial into a triumph of love. There is also the thought that man-made beauty is the greatest gift of all. Brahms was not a terribly religious man, but his music is a kind of wrestling match between the two ideas. His lyrical inspiration needs no explanation. His drier, more belligerent moments tell us about a man who acknowledged his own natural effusiveness without fully trusting it.

Before his first pitch Saturday, Matt DeSalvo had already won over his manager. In the Yankees' next series, Manager Joe Torre said during batting practice, DeSalvo would start and Darrell Rasner would be skipped. When the game began -- only the second of his career -- DeSalvo rewarded Torre's faith. He allowed two runs over six and two-thirds innings for his first major league victory, helping the Yankees defeat the Seattle Mariners, 7-2, at Safeco Field.

To the Editor: Re ''Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, April 29): As the parent of a high school junior, I am very conscious of the articles devoted to college admission. The application process is depicted as a game in which students and their families are expected to seek any advantage to ramp up the applicant's ''presentability.'' What increasingly seems to be lost is the individuality and, often, integrity of the student. What about a student's aspirations, passions and sense of fun?

AT 20 weeks pregnant, Courtney Monardo, a 40-year-old processor for a mortgage company in Scottsdale, Ariz., was -- to quote Madeleine Kahn in ''Blazing Saddles'' -- ''so tired.'' ''After work, I'd sit down on the couch, take a cat nap, eat dinner, and I'd be in bed by 8:30,'' she said.

David Letterman The last time the Queen of England was in the United States was 1991. And an awful lot has changed since 1991. The last time she was here President Bush was fighting a war in Iraq. An employee at Circuit City busts up a terrorist ring. And I'm thinking, ''Well, no wonder I can never get a salesman to help me pick out an answering machine. He's out chasing Al Qaeda guys.'' Jay Leno At a commencement speech over the weekend, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney told students that they should all get married. But he said, unlike Rudy Giuliani, don't go overboard. A couple of times is fine.

I recently called up Lufthansa Miles & More to reserve a flight using my miles from the program. Lufthansa said that I had enough miles for the flight, but that there were no seats available. I was able to make online bookings for the seats I wanted -- as long as I paid for them. Is this a typical problem? Why am I storing up all these miles if I can't use them? -- Christian Caryl, Tokyo Yours is a frequent lament. As I have often reported, airlines sometimes make it hard to redeem miles for tickets on the flights you want, especially if they can sell all the seats to fare-paying travelers. It is therefore wise to plan well in advance and ask which flights, or routings, you can get an award ticket on. You might have luck with another Star Alliance carrier, such as Air New Zealand, Singapore Airlines, All Nippon Airways or Thai Airways International, which should all accept Lufthansa miles.

To the Editor: Re ''Poet, Mother, Editor, Wife,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 6): Although Deborah Garrison is clearly bright and so well balanced in her life, I shuddered -- after reading her poetry -- over the fact that she is the poetry editor for Knopf.

WHEN Betsy Isles received a phone call in early February asking if she would be willing to put her 19th-century Italianate farmhouse on a house tour, it all seemed comfortably far off: The tour date wasn't until May. She would have plenty of time to get ready. The cause was a good one. Proceeds from the tour -- tickets are $70 for members, $80 for nonmembers -- would benefit the local historical society. Besides, Mrs. Isles and her husband, Chris, love their home. Fascinated by local history, they were willing to open up their house, where they have lived 15 years, to fellow history buffs. In fact, Mrs. Isles's only initial concern about participating was that the upstairs of the house remained off limits to visitors; the idea of strangers peering into the rooms of her two teenagers was a bit much.

Dr. Evelyn Joyce Hsieh and Dr. Joseph Anthony Donroe were married Friday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Paul M. Mayer, a priest associated with the Federation of Christian Ministries, officiated. Next month, the couple will begin medical residencies at Yale-New Haven Hospital, she in internal medicine and he in internal medicine and pediatrics.

Back from his space travels, Charles Simonyi, a multimillionaire and a former executive at Microsoft, is taking up a new challenge: serving as chairman of the trustees at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. Albert Einstein was a longtime faculty member at the theoretical research institute, where he sought to gain greater knowledge of the physical universe. Mr. Simonyi spent $25 million getting closer to the universe on a 14-day trip on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft last month.

A SIMPLE thank-you today, to the mothers in my life. To my wife, first, who has given us four children.

Melissa Costiere Holsinger, a daughter of Lorraine and John R. Holsinger of Hackensack, N.J., is to be married today to John-Paul Ryan Anderson, a son of Sandra and H. Charles Anderson of Boise, Idaho. The Rev. John J. Ranieri, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Queen of All Saints Church in Brooklyn. The bride, 29, will keep her name. She is an associate at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, the New York law firm. In August, she is to become a law clerk for Judge Aleta Arthur Trauger of the Federal District Court in Nashville. The bride graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received her law degree from New York University.

An article last Sunday about Robert Caro and his biography of Robert Moses referred incorrectly to Co-op City, one of the middle-income housing projects that Moses developed. Co-op City, in the Bronx, was built on the site of the defunct Freedomland amusement park; Moses did not tear down tenements to make room for it.

SAYRE--Nancy Bond, 77, of Delray Beach, FL, Chatham, MA, and a longtime resident of Rumson, NJ, passed away on November 17, 2006. Mrs. Sayre is survived by her husband of 55 years, Stuart Sayre and by her children, Libby, Stephen and Casey and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 19, 2007, at 11:00 am, at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, NJ.

popular support for the Afghan government and creating severe strains within the NATO alliance. 1 Shift in Chinese Abortions As Chinese society has rapidly changed, so has the face of abortion: unmarried women, including teenagers, are having more and sometimes multiple abortions, according to studies and health experts. 1 27 Die in Pakistan Clashes At least 27 people were killed and more than 100 injured in Karachi in clashes set off by the arrival of the chief justice of Pakistan's Supreme Court, who was suspended by President Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani interior minister said. 6 Iraqi Party Changes Name The Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, one of the country's most powerful Shiite parties, announced that ''revolution'' would be dropped from its name and that Iran's top cleric would cease to be the party's dominant leader. 6 A coordinated attack on seven American soldiers and an Iraqi army interpreter south of Baghdad left five of them dead and three where he is expected to shift his attention from the specific issues facing the church in Brazil to the challenges in the whole of Latin America. 4 Model City Grows in India The Indian government is financing improvements to the town of Nagpur and other ''second tier'' cities, hoping to help them modernize and attract more international investors. 3 NATIONAL 18-27 Earmarks and Religion An analysis of federal records shows that religious organizations are hiring professional lobbyists to pursue the narrowly tailored individual appropriations known as earmarks, and the number of earmarks The Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, one of the country's most powerful Shiite parties, announced Saturday that ''revolution'' would be dropped from its name and that Iran's top cleric would cease to be the party's dominant spiritual leader. The change -- made to the party's platform at a meeting here on Friday, leaders said -- reflected an effort by the group to shore up support among nationalist Iraqis and American officials who have questioned its loyalties because of its Iranian roots.

LAST year, when my son Sean was 12, he started to shoot baskets, watch too much television and have his first major crush. He said ''my bad'' after forgetting homework and plunged his size-seven feet into sneakers before bolting without a jacket. All of this astonished me -- not because he was growing up, but because he was leaving the land of special needs that he and I had inhabited for such a long time.

To the Editor: The corporate/nonprofit hybrids of the ''fourth sector'' (''Make Money, Save the World,'' May 6) are a sure-fire formula for confusion, conflict of interest, deception and outright fraud. They join ''eco-friendly tourism'' and ''carbon credits'' for guilt-stricken, environmentally conscious travelers.

RAFFERTY--Natalie (Rice), widow of the late Bernard Rafferty of Farmington, CT, died Thursday, May 3, 2007 at her home. She is survived by her two children, Kathleen Lamborn and Christopher Rafferty, and five grandchildren.

BOWERS--Akiko Kobayashi, born Tokyo, Japan, died May 4, 2007, Pompton Plains, New Jersey. A graduate of Kobe College, she came to New York to study business at NYU in 1961. She was the first female Director of Protocol to the Japanese Ambassador to the United Nations. In 1970, she married Dr. John Z. Bowers, then President of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation. Their mutual love for Japan and Asia led to many fruitful and fondly remembered years spent researching, translating and editing his scholarly works. Her philanthropic endeavors included the John Z. and Akiko K. Bowers Distinguished Professor and Dean's Chair at the University of Maryland Medical School, and endowed scholarships at Dr. Bowers' alma maters, Gettysburg College and the University of Maryland. The Metropolitan Museum of Art and Gettysburg College include heirlooms from her family in their collections. Her memoirs ''East and West, When the Twain Meet -a Life'' were published in Japan in 1999. In 2003 she received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Gettysburg College. In itself, her life was a bridge between the East and West.

HELFAND--Marilyn (Sherman), 94. Died May 11, 2007. Daughter of the late Lena and Sol Sherman, beloved wife of the late Jack Helfand, mother of Marshall Helfand and Ronna Helfand, grandmother of Laurie Helfand and Scott Helfand, great-grandmother of Zachary Jonathan Lacher, sister of Dr. Bernard Sherman (Edith) and Jeanne Freedman (the late Bernard). The family requests that gifts in Marilyn's honor be sent to: The Marvin Tiger Foundation, 44 Court Street, Suite 700, Brooklyn, NY 11201, or the charity of your choice.

Re ''Final Thoughts About My Tenure and The Times's Future'' (May 6): Thank you, Byron Calame, for your good work during your two years as the public editor. The work that you have done as the public editor and as a journalist has been important for our participatory constitutional democracy. My grandmother arrived in this country at age 14. She always told us to read the newspaper. She said that she learned the language of this country and "its ways" by reading a daily metropolitan paper. My father instilled this habit in us. To this day, I am an avid cutter and collector of newspaper clips. Several of your pieces are in my files for further reference.

To the Editor: Re ''Paris Gives Itself a Futuristic Transplant'' [May 6]: Sam Lubell's article is the best discussion I have seen of the huge Rive Gauche development. As a part-time resident of Paris, I disagree with the critic you quote who said, ''I might be able to live there.'' Not unless I were satisfied with a shiny, clean, modernistic neighborhood that is also boring and inconvenient.
Oscar Pistorius of South Africa, who had both legs amputated below the knee when he was 11 months old, wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics.
Members of the Schalk family of Oceanside, N.Y., talk about their jobs as airline mechanics and why they made a change.
David V. Aguilar, the chief of Border Patrol, has managed to steer clear of the critics dogging other Bush administration officials these days. Instead, he has a union calling for his head.

From the politics-meets-art/weirdness file: The Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli has hired the top campaign ad gurus for President Bush and Senator John Kerry from 2004, but this time to square off again as part of his installation in the upcoming Biennale in Venice.

When 10 Republican presidential candidates assemble on a stage Tuesday night in South Carolina for their second debate, viewers will get a reminder of how the sheer size of the field in both parties limits the opportunities for probing questioning.

Add another consultant to the list of those advising Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: John Kao, a corporate communications consultant who is based in San Francisco and advocates using the techniques of musical improvisation to get the creative juices flowing and leave competitors in the dust.

Not to take any words out of my colleagues' mouths (or blogs), but I can safely say that the one player we miss most around here is Cliff Floyd, who returns to Shea for the first time tonight as a member of the Chicago Cubs. A few days before players were scheduled to report to spring training, a few other beat writers and I were walking around the Mets clubhouse and I recall having a moment of silence in front of Cliff's corner locker that was then occupied by David Newhan.
The Times's Bill Carter reports from Radio City Music Hall, where NBC presented its 2007 fall lineup.

Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota is preparing for a return to the Senate after a brain hemorrhage in December, and fellow Democrats say they fully expect Mr. Johnson to be a candidate for a third term next year.

We caught up with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on his way out of a meeting with Gov. Eliot Spitzer about the mayor's plans to make the city more livable and evironmentally sound. (He needs the governor's help for some of it, especially congestion pricing.) Mr. Bloomberg was mum about his plan's reception -- "I'm optimistic we'll that find a ways to get his support, but his staff wants to look at it first" he said -- but he did take another swing at the question of whether he would consider running for governor in 2010.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, who has been under fire from politicians in both parties, was assailed today by several dozen of his classmates at Harvard Law School, Class of 1982.

David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, isn't too happy with the recent revelation that N.B.A. referees appear to have a racial bias in the way they call fouls. He's questioned the validity of the statistical analysis by Justin Wolfers, an assistant professor of business and public policy at the Wharton School, and Joseph Price, a Cornell graduate student in economics, which suggests that white and black referees call fouls preferentially against players of the opposite race. The N.B.A. insists that its own analysis (of different data) reveals no such bias, although other experts who've seen both analyses say that the Wolfers and Price study is more convincing.

Presidential candidates now jockeying for position might take comfort when they recall Franklin D. Roosevelt's perilous route to the Democratic nomination. Even F.D.R., one of America's most successful presidents, had to work long and hard to get his party's support for the job. And the last night of that effort was the longest and hardest of all.

When it comes to executive pay on both sides of the Atlantic, Jean-François Théodore is probably not shouting "vive la difference." Financial News points out that Mr. Theodore, who was head of Euronext and is now deputy chief executive of the newly merged NYSE Euronext, was paid less than one-fifth what his new boss, John Thain, earned last year.

If you own shares in a takeover target, you might want to pin your hopes on a public company being the buyer. That is because these kinds of acquirers usually pay more in an acquisition than private equity firms do, according to a study cited by Mark Hulbert in The New York Times. The study, conducted by finance professors and called "Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?", found that, on average, target shareholders receive 55 percent more if a public company instead of a buyout shop (or shops) is paying the bill.

Dubious about the power that Bill Clinton has to woo Democrats to support his wife's presidential campaign? The Empire Zone's Danny Hakim reports on how Bill Clinton's powers of persuasion were on display up in Albany today, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and others endorsed Senator Clinton's candidacy.
Senator Hillary Clinton appeared just after noon today on the lofty steps of the state Capitol wearing a magenta jacket and surrounded by a phalanx of seven men in dark suits.

As aluminum giant Alcan considers how to react to the hostile $27 billion from Alcoa, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group has a suggestion that harkens back to the era when legwarmers were the height of fashion (though we hear they are making a comeback). The analyst, John C. Tumazos, is floating the idea that terms of the deal could be flipped so that Montreal-based Alcan buys New York-based Alcoa. Such a tactic first gained currency in the 1980's, when it became known as the Pac-Man defense, after the popular video game in which the player could change roles and go after his or her pursuers.

Nasdijj, the make-believe American Indian and perpetrator of what the LA Weekly exposed as the Navahoax, is back. Remember him? Remember "The Blood Runs Like A River Through My Dreams," and the Esquire article that made him a National Magazine Award finalist?
When all else fails, face the facts. And the fact was we needed to build a smaller house.
Steam rises from the cooling towers of Schwarze Pumpe power plant, Germany. Jockel Finck/AP

Although it may seem as if Barack Obama has been running for president ever since his big speech at the 2004 Democratic National Convention, yesterday in fact marked his first appearance on the Sunday gabfest circuit since his official announcement. He talked with George Stephanopoulos on ABC's "This Week." So how did the "rookie" do?

The most amazing aspect of Daimler's giveaway of Chrysler is that it is considered good news by all. Ford and General Motors shares are up, despite the fact that Chrysler is deemed essentially worthless. Daimler bonds are up on the news, and the company's bond rating may be increased, despite the fact that it no longer will have Chrysler assets available to help provide the money to repay the bonds.

One of the classic scenes on the international auto show circuit took place in 2003, when Chrysler's then-president, Wolfgang Bernhard, roared onto the stage in Detroit astride a thundering, gleaming-silver motorcycle called the Tomahawk.

A 41-second video of a BBC reporter shouting at someone in rather unhinged fashion was posted on YouTube late last week as part of a campaign to discredit a documentary the British network is preparing about The Church of Scientology.
The Four Seasons Ocean Residences, a 719-foot luxury vessel featuring 112 private residences, will be unveiled in London on Wednesday.
A consortium that includes a founder and Silvio Berlusconi’s family is buying the Dutch TV company Endemol for $3.6 billion.
A complete list of winners for the 2007 Tony Awards, with links to the original New York Times reviews.

Is it coincidence that the boom in leveraged buyouts is being accompanied by a surge in suspicious pre-deal trading activity and a rise in insider-trading cases? Some research by FinancialWeek suggests there may be a connection between the two trends.
Good Samaritans in the great state of Alaska are helping passengers escape their cruise ship, which is stuck and listing after running aground 15 miles southwest of Juneau.

The winner of the auction for Chrysler, Cerberus Capital Management, is widely refered to as a private equity shop these days. But the firm's longtime legal adviser, Schulte Roth & Zabel, reflects Cerberus's roots as a hedge fund -- and one that knows its way around a bankruptcy courtroom. Schulte Roth, which counseled Cerberus in the Chrysler negotiations, is known as one of the top legal advisers to hedge funds, and it claims to represent more than one half of the 100 largest hedge funds listed in Institutional Investor. On many occasions, it has advised Cerberus when it bid for assets of bankrupt companies (or when Cerberus's portfolio companies tumbled into bankruptcy protection themselves).
A few notes on trade and wages.

Primedia agreed on Monday to sell about 70 magazines, including Motor Trend, Hot Rod and Surfer, to Source Interlink, a company controlled by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, for about $1.2 billion in cash.
Matthew Purdy, who leads the investigative reporting team, is answering questions May 14 to 18.

Last week Mr. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver bumped into each other in the Capitol, and the two men, who cannot resist pushing each other's buttons, took a moment to discuss a New York Post story that said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was mulling a bid for governor in 2010.
Satellite photos from around the world show the impact that fishing trawlers are having on the ocean bottom.

Two former executives at Siemens were convicted Monday of bribery and assisting bribery for their involvement in multimillion-dollar payments to officials at an Italian utility. The verdict came in the first trial over a series of scandals at the company.
- Tobin Harshaw
The Defense Department has decided to make it impossible to reach 13 Web sites from its network, citing an overabundance of "recreational traffic."
Wine is now being made in nontraditional areas like Brazil’s desert, challenging centuries-old grape myths.

Some Bancroft family members want to meet Rupert Murdoch to discuss his $5 billion offer for Dow Jones but they face stiff opposition from other relatives, The Financial Times reported. Mr. Murdoch has been pressing for a meeting with the Bancroft family, which controls the publishing company through a special class of stock, since they rejected his $60-per-share offer for the company and its flagship Wall Street Journal nearly two weeks ago.
The German engineering giant was ordered to pay $51 million in the first trial in a series of scandals.
Congressional Republicans evidently have found an Iraqi withdrawal plan they can accept.

Members of the family that founded Ford Motor are discussing the possibility of selling some of their controlling stake in the company, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people with direct knowledge of the talks. Bloomberg said that Bill Ford, Ford's chairman, told the company's directors about the family members' views before last week's annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del. As has been previously reported, some family members have sought to hire an investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners as an outside financial adviser.

Leonard Forman, the former chief financial officer of The New York Times Company, is joining a media-focused investment firm Veronis Suhler Stevenson in another sign that private equity continues to lure retired public company executives, the New York Post reported Monday. Mr. Forman plans to join Veronis's board of advisers, which already has nine former industry and government leaders, to help the firm identify deals in the specialty media sector.
A hedge fund, Alexandra Investment Management, said on Friday it was hiring John Hock as president and partner.

The Valentino Fashion Group said Friday that it had been approached by several private equity firms interested in buying a stake in the Italian fashion house, but said it had not received a formal offer. The chairman, Antonio Favrin, who made the comments at the company's annual shareholders meeting Friday in Milan, did not name any of the potential suitors for the firm, which controls Hugo Boss.

The consortium that wants to buy and break up ABN Amro on Monday published confidential details of its offer, which the Dutch bank rejected last week. The consortium, which includes Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander, and Fortis, said their proposal had "lower execution risk" than an agreed deal between ABN and Britain's Barclays Bank and was worth more.

Mylan Laboratories has agreed to buy the generic drug unit of Merck, the German drug maker, for 4.9 billion euros ($6.7 billion) in cash. The acquisition will make Mylan the world's third-largest maker of copycat versions of drugs, after Teva Pharmaceuticals of Israel and Novartis of Switzerland.

WallStrip, the online television show that strives for a mix of "Squawk Box" and "Saturday Night Live," is reportedly in talks to be bought by CBS for about $5 million, according to New York media blog Jossip. The blog said that as part of the deal, which is expected to be announced this week, WallStrip's presenter, Lindsay Campbell, will become "the next Amanda Congdon: frontin' for CBS' Web initiatives."

As lawmakers continue to scrutinize the hedge fund industry, a recent surge in the hiring of lobbyists and stepped-up contributions to political action committees by managers in the $1 trillion hedge fund industry and top officials of private-equity groups probably comes as no surprise.

Spain's Telefonica has reached a deal to sell the Dutch TV company Endemol, creator of the "Big Brother" show, for 2.63 billion euros ($3.55 billion) to a consortium including the Mediaset media empire controlled by the family of the former Italian Premier Silvio Berlusconi, Mediaset said in a statement.

Despite the Chicago Board of Trade's formal rejection of the Intercontinental Exchange's bid, following a higher offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, investors were betting that the battle for control of the Chicago derivatives exchange wasn't over.

Guessing who's behind The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, a satirical blog by an anonymous writer calling himself the Fake Steve Jobs, has become a parlor game in Silicon Valley, with several journalists, former Apple employees and even Steve Jobs himself topping the list of suspects.

The trial of Conrad M. Black has brought to the surface the simmering tensions that grew between the publishing magnate and his former partner, F. David Radler. The New York Times's Richard Siklos notes that it has also provided a reminder that, for the modern media mogul, a good No. 2 is hard to find.

As deal making in the fast-food industry continues to heat up, an ice cream maker, the Cold Stone Creamery, and a fast-food operator, Kahala are teaming up to form a holding company they hope will be able to compete with private equity firms for a greater share of the sector.

Citigroup said Friday that it had hired Chris Gammons from a rival, Deutsche Bank, to be its managing director focused on covering Asia's fast-growing private equity firms, which have become big fee-payers in the region.

The initial public offering of Everquest, a fledgling financial-services company, is a blatant attempt by Bear Stearns to unload its mortgage bets on unwitting retail investors, argues BusinessWeek's Matthew Goldstein.

More company executives may face criminal charges as a result of ongoing federal investigations into stock-option backdating, the Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman, Christopher Cox, said Friday. "We have a substantial number of investigations under way [including] cases that are maturing to the point of potential criminal action," Mr. Cox told reporters at a securities conference.

A number of analysts and industry watchers are predicting that Orbitz Worldwide's $750 million initial public offering will end in tears, as DealBook noted Friday. Among the reasons that detractors think the online travel site's I.P.O. will flop are its complex financial arrangements with its parent, Travelport, as well as the company's history of losses.

Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up, said Friday that it had raised an additional $45 million - from a venture capital firm as well as its chairman. Buzz surrounding the surrounding the company, which will start producing its first vehicle, a zero-emissions, two-seat roadster, later this year, is already deafening, with a list of high-profile buyers already lining up to snag a model.
Scientists are putting the final touches on a 17-mile-long particle accelerator that will attempt to create forces and particles that existed shortly after the Big Bang.

The Scottish whiskey distiller Whyte & Mackay is about to become the latest target of India's growing global aspirations. Vijay Mallya, the Indian beer magnate, is expected to sign a deal to buy Whyte & Mackay this week, according to The International Herald Tribune.

Stockholders of Compass, the catering company, are to receive a further 500 million pound ($991 million) payout as a result of the company's sale of its Selecta vending business for 772.5 million pounds to the private equity arm of Allianz.

Writers sometimes praise the poetry of science, but they haven't composed many memorable verses on the topic. As an inspiration for odes, the lab is no match for love. But there are exceptions, and here's one of them.
News that a Russian-born billionaire is buying a stake in Houston's Lyondell Chemical fueled an 11 percent surge in shares of the company on Friday in anticipation of a possible takeover.

Family control of Sam's Wines and Spirits has ended with a deal announced Friday to sell 80 percent of the third-generation business to a Chicago private-equity firm. The deal with buyout shop Arbor Investments provides Sam's with access to capital that would allow it to expand at a time when Internet sales are putting pressure on wine-and-spirits stores.
Seasoned managers know one of the coldest truths of corporate life: A new chief executive means a scramble for survival in executive suites.
The first production of the hit musical, with an all-South African cast, some new costumes, choreography and songs, is to open in previews in Johannesburg next week.
Ewan McGregor returns to the stage this fall as the villainous Iago at the Donmar Warehouse in London in a new production of Shakespeare’s “Othello.”

DaimlerChrysler confirmed Monday that it would sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management of New York, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies. The price being paid is $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler. Of that sum, DaimlerChrylser itself will receive only $1.3 billion, and the German automaker said Monday that the transaction will actually result in a "net cash outflow" of about $678 million.

As Rupert Murdoch trains his sights on Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, another veteran of the British newspaper wars is betting on the future of lower-profile print publications.
A look at the critical hits and misses from the 2006-2007 Broadway season.
DaimlerChrysler agreed today to sell an 80.1% stake in the struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, which specializes in restructuring troubled companies.
Narrative — not usually a popular downtown inclination — was surprisingly alive on the final program of “Motion Makers,” part of the recent “La MaMa Moves!” festival.

Progress by September - that was the latest mandate from some nervous Republicans to President Bush over the war in Iraq. However, nobody in Washington seems to agree on what progress actually means - or how, precisely, it might be measured.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Bob Marley’s singing sons have latched on to their father’s vocal style and his mix of idealism and pleasure.
Paul J. McNulty’s Congressional testimony helped ignite the uproar over the dismissal of several U.S. attorneys.
The University of Texas said that the director of financial aid at its Austin campus had more ties to a student loan company than were previously known.
Prosecutors asserted that Jose Padilla aided terrorists and went to Afghanistan to train with the Al Qaeda network.

HARTFORD, May 14 — The battle over same-sex marriage reached Connecticut’s highest court today, with judges confronting two basic questions during oral arguments: Does the state law that provides for civil unions for same-sex couples create a fundamentally inferior status for gays and lesbians, compared with marriage? And do homosexuals constitute a class of people with special protection against discrimination under state law?.
Iran appears to have solved most of its technological problems and is now beginning to enrich uranium on a far larger scale than before, officials say.

The Spurs’ Bruce Bowen, who has made a career of frustrating oppenents with his defense, earned a mild rebuke from the league for his foul in Game 3 when he kneed Phoenix guard Steve Nash in the groin.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 14 — An American soldier was shot dead and four other Americans were wounded in Pakistan today after a meeting among Afghan, Pakistani and NATO officials at the Afghan-Pakistan border Afghan and NATO officials said. The meeting had been called to try to resolve recent clashes between the two neighboring countries.
The Al Qaeda group that claimed responsibility for the attack warned that the soldiers would never be found.
Hani al-Qawasmeh, resigned Monday, and four more Palestinians were killed in fierce factional gun battles.
People entrenched in one field are tweaking their careers through extension schools attached to colleges and universities.
For Hillary Rodham Clinton,  the race for the Democratic nomination is about likeability as well as toughness.
The current unrest is among the most serious challenges to face Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
Voters went to the polls in the Philippines today to elect senators, congressmen and local officials, amid reports of election-related violence and allegations of fraud.
Polls show that the Japanese remain divided on the Constitution’s prohibition against a full-fledged military.
DaimlerChrysler confirmed today that it would sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management of New York.
Carlos Boozer and the Jazz shoved and scraped to slow down the Warriors — and then Derek Fisher put a sweet finish on a victory that put Utah on the brink of the Western Conference finals.
Iran’s Foreign Ministry confirmed that Haleh Esfandiari had been arrested, saying that it was “based on law.”
Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said “a credible third-party candidate” for president would benefit the United States.
Several Republican officials privately suggest that Joseph N. Mondello, the state’s Republican Party chairman, has worn out his welcome.

An article on Wednesday about the annual New York City sewage workers’ competition misstated part of the name of an organization of wastewater professionals that founded a national competition, the Operations Challenge, to which New York State’s winners will progress. It is the Water Environment Federation, not Foundation.

A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Gayfest NYC, which presents the works of emerging gay playwrights, misstated the middle initial of one of the festival’s producers. He is Jack W. Batman, not Jack R.

A dance review on April 16 about the Boris Eifman Ballet, at City Center, misstated the history of Mr. Eifman’s new ballet, “The Seagull.” Its American premiere was in March at the University of California, Berkeley — not at City Center in April.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an art review of “The Sculpture of Louise Nevelson: Constructing a Legend,” at the Jewish Museum, reversed the credits. The photograph of “First Personage” was from the Brooklyn Museum, and the picture of “Mrs. N.’s Palace” was from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A sports article last Monday about Victory Challenge’s performance in the America’s Cup challengers series referred incorrectly to a past Cup competitor that was used as the model for a prized yacht of Jan Stenbeck, the founder of Victory Challenge. Endeavor, on which the prized yacht Sophie is based, challenged for — but did not win — the America’s Cup in 1934.

A listing of credits on Wednesday with a film review of “Day Night Day Night” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about several people who worked on the movie. Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor. The editors were Julie Loktev and Mr. Taylor — not Ms. Lotkev and Leslie Shatz, who was the sound designer. The production designer was Kelly McGehee — not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.
Corrections: For the Record
tennis.

The driver of an overloaded minivan lost control of the vehicle early yesterday on the Harlem River Drive in northern Manhattan, the police said, and one of 10 people on board, a 14-year-old boy, was killed when it hit a light pole.

A Glen Cove man has been arrested after a six-car crash on Glen Cove Road in Old Brookville on Saturday that killed a woman and left several other people seriously injured, the police said. The man, Jeff B. Moss, 43, who the police said was operating his vehicle at a high rate of speed, was charged with criminally negligent homicide after the crash, which occurred shortly after 3:30 p.m. The woman, Antonia Brancia, 60, of Mansfield, Conn., was killed when her car was struck by Mr. Moss’s sport utility vehicle, the police said. The crash began a chain reaction in which four other cars crashed, the police said.

A Massapequa man has been charged after an accident on Thursday night that killed a woman as she stood at the foot of her driveway, the police said. The man, Robert Fowler, 57, was charged with leaving the scene of an accident, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The police said the woman, Nina Sharma, 49, was standing at the end of her driveway in East Meadow, waiting for her husband to take out the trash before they took an evening walk. The police said she was struck by Mr. Fowler’s Dodge Ram van and thrown or dragged about 65 feet.

The father of a 2-year-old was charged yesterday with endangering the welfare of a child after he left his son locked in a parked car overnight, the police said. The father, Daniel Ribot, 32, took the boy, Adonis, to his second birthday party on Saturday night in Paterson. About 2:30 a.m. yesterday, the man placed the sleeping child inside his black Lexus parked at a gas station lot in Passaic, not far from the party, said Lt. Luis Guzman of the Passaic Police Department. When Mr. Ribot woke up in his Clifton home at 11:30 a.m., he realized he was missing both his child and his car, Lieutenant Guzman said. Mr. Ribot called the police in Clifton, who called the police in Passaic. The Passaic police found the car with Adonis screaming inside it, Lieutenant Guzman said. The police said they were still investigating and Mr. Ribot could face further charges.

A motorcyclist was thrown to the pavement and killed yesterday after she struck a man who had run into traffic on the West Side Highway at 56th Street in Manhattan, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released but who was said to be in her 30s, was traveling north on the highway shortly after 9:30 a.m. when the crash took place, the authorities said, even though she applied her brakes and swerved to try to avoid a collision. The man suffered a broken leg, the police said. The police did not release the pedestrian’s name.

State officials say they have nearly finished a tree-removal effort intended to counter damage created by the tree-killing Asian longhorned beetle, which they say has destroyed more than 20,000 trees in New Jersey. The beetles were first found in Hoboken and Jersey City in 2002, spread to parts of Middlesex and Union Counties and were blamed for the destruction of more than 21,500 trees. Under the program, state foresters remove infested trees and replace them with new ones, 4,130 so far, according to the Agriculture Department. The remaining infested trees are on one property in Linden, whose owner has not consented to their removal, said Jeff Beach, a department spokesman. The beetles infest hardwood trees like maple and elm, and foresters replace those with species that do not appeal to the insect, like oak and cherry.

A 16-year-old has been arrested in connection with the fatal shooting of a man who was found dead in the side yard of his house in East Patchogue last week with his 3-year-old son sleeping next to him, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The teenager, Terraine Slide of Medford, was charged with murder and burglary, said Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick. He was charged in connection with the shooting of the man, Carlton Shaw, 38, a restaurant cook whose body was found on Tuesday. The police said Mr. Shaw, who had been renovating the kitchen in his house, was shot during a burglary attempt.
A sale to Cerberus Capital Management, which specializes in restructuring troubled companies, could be announced today.
For more than a thousand years, Venice had gondolas but never a female gondolier. Now there is Alexandra Hai.
When Bode Miller’s cousin shot and killed a police officer in a roadside confrontation Friday in New Hampshire, it was the bloody culmination of a bitter and long-running feud.
Testimony and notes from the vice president of human resources at the World Bank were “devastating” to Paul D. Wolfowitz’s case, according to a bank official.
As more workers become sick, many regard Rudolph W. Giuliani’s leadership after 9/11 as having come with a human cost.
Jesse Allen was  trying to win a job with the Jets this weekend when he was supposed to be collecting his college diploma from Virginia Tech.
A proposal would expand the state’s database of DNA samples to include people convicted of most crimes.
It now looks as if the huge U.S. trade deficit, which swelled to a record $765.3 billion last year, could gradually decrease.
The Yankees have fallen so far behind the Boston Red Sox in the standings, that every game seems to take on an urgency not usually found this early in the season.
Joe Torre will spend the Yankees’ day off Monday at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital with his brother who is recovering from a kidney transplant.
The Social Democrats took a decreased share of the vote as three opposition parties, particularly the new Left Party, made significant gains.
Two bills making their way to the Senate floor could make a constructive start toward reducing this country’s dependence on oil imports and its emissions of greenhouse gases.
Department of Education officials seem more interested in kowtowing to lenders than anything else.
Georgetown attackman Brendan Cannon led his team to victory against Princeton. But his inspiration comes from a fallen former teammate.
For Cerberus Capital Management, buying Chrysler is just the logical culmination of an automotive strategy it has pursued for years.
Phil Mickelson once again became the No. 2 player in the world Sunday by winning The Players Championship, closing with a 3-under 69 for a two-shot victory.
The explosion in the use of three anti-anemia drugs to treat cancer and kidney patients illustrates much that is wrong in the American pharmaceutical marketplace.
Muhammad al-Daini, a Sunni Arab member of the Iraqi Parliament, has offered a well-practiced pitch that emphasizes the need for American troops to withdraw.
The intensive search continued as violence flared anew, with at least 55 people killed in two car bombings.
Mullah Dadullah, probably the Taliban’s foremost operational commander, was killed in a joint operation by allied forces.
The results announced Sunday came after intensive diplomatic pressure for Armenia to avoid another flawed election.
In the aftermath of Josh Hancock’s death, baseball teams are reviewing their policies regarding alcohol in the home and visiting clubhouses.
Luol Deng had 25 points and 13 rebounds on 10-of-15 shooting from the field, helping the Bulls narrow the Pistons lead to 3-1 in the best-of-seven series.
Jason Kidd had a triple-double on Saturday, an occurrence so common that it sounded like old news before the sentence had even been typed.
Scott Niedermayer scored 14 minutes 17 seconds into overtime Sunday in Detroit to lift the Anaheim Ducks over the Red Wings.
Michael R. Bloomberg has fueled speculation that he will run for president by sharpening his national profile and delivering speeches across the country.
Starter Oliver Pérez enabled the Mets to rebound from Saturday’s blowout loss with a dominating performance.
The suicide rate among Native Alaskans was three times that of nonnative Alaska residents in the last three years, according to a recent study.
Pope Benedict XVI urged the Latin American clergy to feed people’s spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty.
For two congregations proud of their mainstream reputations, whispers of sleeper cells within their walls have been troubling.
As relatives in Guatemala mourn the loss of their son, police in Westchester County are a focus of an inquiry into his death.
Jeff Gordon overcame an overheating engine and, with steam pouring out of his racecar, pulled away to win the Dodge Avenger 500 at Darlington Raceway.
Officials from Iran and the U.S. announced that the American ambassador to Iraq would meet with his Iranian counterpart in Baghdad in coming weeks.
The Mets sent the right-handed starter Mike Pelfrey to Class AAA New Orleans, in hopes that he will resume throwing his fastball much lower in the strike zone
Consumer spending has been the powerful and dependable engine of the current economic expansion.  Until last month, that is.
About 300 rock paper scissor experts flew to Las Vegas to compete for the $50,000 first prize in the sport’s national championship.
The main beneficiary of the New York Guard, critics say,  is a group of politicians who often skip meetings but proudly show off their quasi-military credentials.
Accusations that the government did little to stop political clashes that killed 39 put pressure on Pakistan’s president.
Four days after being called up from Class AAA Fresno, the San Francisco rookie Fred Lewis went 5 for 6 and hit for the cycle as the Giants powered past the host Colorado Rockies yesterday, 15-2.
It was an inauspicious start to the king’s efforts to breathe life into the Arab peace initiative and to revive the Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.

Jason Varitek and Eric Hinske scampered home when closer Chris Ray dropped the toss at first base on what could have been a game-ending groundout yesterday as the Boston Red Sox completed a six-run rally in the ninth inning for a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
In preparing for Game 4, the Suns realized that the toughness they lacked was less about bumps and bruises and more about sharp decision-making and mental fortitude.
The secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff, argued that other countries, no matter how friendly, could not decide who entered the United States.
The passage of a ballot proposal increases the likelihood that the George W. Bush Presidential Library will be built on the campus of Southern Methodist University.
Rafael Nadal became the first player to win the Rome Masters three consecutive times by beating Fernando Gonzalez of Chile 6-2, 6-2 on Sunday.
Dense spoke from wildfires in Florida and Georgia confused birds, sent haze traveling hundreds of miles, and forced the closure of two interstate highways.
Nicolas Hernández scored early in the first half yesterday and the Colorado Rapids defeated the short-handed Red Bulls.
As president, Barack Obama says he would repeal President Bush’s cuts to pay for health care, without suggesting other tax increases.
Mr. Gordon was blacklisted during Hollywood’s anti-Communist crusade in the 1950s.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,377 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of following American on Friday:.
King Malietoa succeeded to the Malietoa title in 1940 and was the world’s third-longest-serving sovereign.

Mother-in-law of Sy Reisman and Nancy Mills. Cherished grandmother of Nancy, Richard, Jodi, Kenny, Jeorjie, Jim, Gus, Rosie, and Nina. About 4,000 American ground troops, supported by surveillance aircraft, attack helicopters and spy satellites, swept towns and farmland south of Baghdad, searching for three American soldiers who disappeared Saturday after their patrol was ambushed, military officials said. The Islamic State of Iraq, an umbrella insurgent group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, said it had captured the three soldiers and claimed responsibility for the attack, but offered no proof. BY KIRK SEMPLE, PAGE A6

Jonathan Sackett joined Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas, as chief digital officer. He had been senior vice president and director for digital operations at Draft FCB, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Tarik Sedky joined Y&R Advertising, New York, part of the WPP Group as chief digital officer. He had been managing director for account management at Atmosphere BBDO, New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group.

Last week Mr. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver bumped into each other in the Capitol, and the two men, who cannot resist pushing each other's buttons, took a moment to discuss a New York Post story that said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was mulling a bid for governor in 2010. In the hallway, Mr. Bruno jovially told Mr. Silver he had just seen Mr. Spitzer, who seemed ''preoccupied with Mike Bloomberg.''

Michael Bublé ''Call Me Irresponsible'' (Reprise) Michael Bublé's third studio album is the Big One, in which the Canadian singer and upscale heartthrob emerges as a thoroughly contemporary pop traditionalist. Respectful of forerunners like Frank Sinatra and Bobby Darin, but not beholden to them, it finds musical common ground among Sinatra, Kenneth Gamble and Leon Huff, and Leonard Cohen. It is the kind of record that Harry Connick Jr. might make if he took his recording career seriously and didn't insist on being a jack-of-all-trades.

Musicians From Marlboro Metropolitan Museum of Art When the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont first sent its performers on tour under the Musicians From Marlboro banner in 1965, one of the participants was the violinist Arnold Steinhardt. A year earlier, Mr. Steinhardt had co-founded the Guarneri String Quartet, now one of chamber music's most enduring ensembles. The quartet regularly plays at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but when Mr. Steinhardt appeared there on Friday night, it was as mentor to a current crop of young Marlboro musicians.

American String Quartet Weill Recital Hall Looking back was the theme of Friday's Walter W. Naumburg Foundation concert at Weill Recital Hall -- part of a series celebrating past winners of its prestigious prize. And the American String Quartet, which won in 1974, did just that.

SCHNEIER--Yetta, 94, of Manhattan and Boca Raton. Died May 11, 2007. Wife of the late Nat Schneier. Mother of Alan Schneier and wife Leah and Maxine and Joseph Copulsky. Adoring grandmother of Erica, Dena, Nicole, Adrienne, and Ilene and greatgrandmother of Sydney, Gabriel, and Alexander. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends.
To the Editor: Re ''Harvard Task Force Calls for New Focus on Teaching and Not Just Research'' (news article, May 10):

TOP SELLER ONLINE -- For the first time since online retailing was born a decade ago, sales of clothing have overtaken those of computer hardware and software, suggesting that consumers have reached a new level of comfort buying merchandise on the Web. [Page C1.] A STRUGGLE FOR COURIC -- Eight months into Katie Couric's job as the first woman to anchor a network newscast on her own, her ''CBS Evening News'' has not only settled back into its long-held position of last among the evening news broadcasts, but also regularly falls short of the newscast that Ms. Couric replaced. [C1.] IT'S UPFRONT WEEK -- Beginning today, big broadcasters will reveal their prime-time lineups for the new season in a week of lavish, star-filled presentations that will help determine how billions in advertising dollars are spent. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C1.] DOES THE JOURNAL MAKE MONEY? -- Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Wall Street Journal, does not break out separate revenue figures for it. Analysts and current and former company officials say it operates in the black, but barely, and maybe not for long. [C1.] MORE OIL INSTABILITY -- About a quarter of Nigeria's oil production, which typically totals about 2.5 million barrels a day, has been shut down since January 2006 as a result of the latest wave of violence in the unstable delta region, forcing up international oil prices at a time when global supplies are constrained. [C2.] INTERNET RADIO'S PROBLEM -- Internet radio sites are global by nature, streaming musical programs digitally to users all over the world. But there is no one-stop global shopping for royalty collections, which means they must negotiate separate agreements in each territory or directly with music labels. [C3.] A BET ON SMALLER PAPERS -- As Rupert Murdoch trains his sights on Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, another veteran of the British newspaper wars is betting on the future of lower-profile print publications. [C3.] MYLAN TO BUY A MERCK UNIT -- Mylan Laboratories has agreed to buy the generic drug unit of Merck, the German drug maker, for $6.7 billion in cash. [C3.] CENSORSHIP AT THE RITZ -- The Ritz-Carlton chain is known for offering many fine services to its guests, and now it may be time to add book censorship to the list. [C6.] RADAR WAS RIGHT -- After being accused by Radar magazine of stealing an article, the Chilean magazine Cosas said it had been hoodwinked by a reporter and has withdrawn the issue from newsstands. [C6.] MAKING CAR BUYING EASIER -- One of the most dreaded buying decisions is becoming still tougher. Auto manufacturers now sell about 280 different cars in the United States, and that number is growing. Jan Renner, left, is chief executive of a site called DriverTV.com, which may have a solution to the problem of choosing a car. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C7.] ART IN PLACE OF ADS -- Steve Lambert, a conceptual artist, plans to add his own quasi-commercial twist to a type of software that blots out commercial messages. His add-on will replace the display ads -- which are usually papered over with blank windows -- with curator-picked artwork from contemporary artists. [C8] EDITOR RETURNS TO PCWORLD -- The International Data Group removed the chief executive of its largest-circulation computer magazine, PC World, and reinstated its top editor, who had quit days earlier over the executive's decision not to run an article critical of an advertiser. [C8.]

Linkin Park ''Minutes to Midnight'' (Warner Brothers) In retrospect, it's clear that the stratospheric success of Linkin Park marked the end of an era. Two eras, actually. With the rise of Linkin Park, the great (or not-so-great) rap-rock boom of the 1990s had one last hurrah. And with the release of group's 2000 debut album, ''Hybrid Theory,'' which sold more than nine million copies in the United States, the great CD sales boom of the 1990s had one of its last hurrahs, too.

RIGG--Cynthia W. Cynthia, who passed away on May 12, was the beloved wife of Abe Frajndlich and the devoted and doting mother of Lucas. With grit, grace and her everpresent humor, she waged a heroic, five-year battle with cancer. Throughout her illness, Cynthia remained a fiercely loyal friend to everyone, and she leaves a legacy of love and caring. Her life was our gift. She is mourned by family and her friends throughout the world. She will always be our role model. With Love, Her Friends

He will be greatly missed. Service is Monday, at 10:30am at The Star of David Memorial Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Ave, West Babylon, NY. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in Robert's memory to the charity of your choice. For further information, please call (631) 454-9600.

The father of a 2-year-old was charged yesterday with endangering the welfare of a child after he left his son locked in a parked car overnight, the police said. The father, Daniel Ribot, 32, took the boy, Adonis, to his second birthday party on Saturday night in Paterson. About 2:30 a.m. yesterday, the man placed the sleeping child inside his black Lexus parked at a gas station lot in Passaic, not far from the party, said Lt. Luis Guzman of the Passaic Police Department. When Mr. Ribot woke up in his Clifton home at 11:30 a.m., he realized he was missing both his child and his car, Lieutenant Guzman said. Mr. Ribot called the police in Clifton, who called the police in Passaic. The Passaic police found the car with Adonis screaming inside it, Lieutenant Guzman said. The police said they were still investigating and Mr. Ribot could face further charges. ALAN FEUER

SCHAFER--Dr. John F. (Jack). Dr. Jack Schafer passed away May 5th, in Santa Rosa California, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 86 after a very short illness. Jack was a plant pathologist with a productive career improving grain crops. He received a doctoral degree at the University of Wisconsin and began his career with a 19-year stint (1949-1968) on the faculty of Purdue University as a core member of a well-known Purdue-US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Small Grain Breeding Team with Ralph M. Caldwell, Leroy E. Compton and Fred L. Patterson. A parade of improved wheat, oat and barley varieties produced by this team attracted the attention of farmers, first in Indiana (home of Purdue) and eventually in all the states that grew these small grain types. ''Knox'' wheat, released in 1953, became the leading soft wheat in the US. After release of ''Arthur'' and ''Arthur 71'' Purdue-USDA soft wheat comprised over 80% of the US soft wheat acreage and greatly increased wheat yield. This Purdue team also issued hundreds of scientific publications conveying significant disease, insect and genetic discoveries. Many graduate students trained by this world famous foursome are now serving in important industry and academic positions in the US and abroad. Jack Schafer was the last living member of the original team. Jack left Purdue to head the Plant Pathology Department at Kansas State University (1968-1972), followed by eight years as head of the Plant Pathology Department at Washington State University, following his dad, Edwin Schafer, to become the first father-son pair to be department heads at the University. In 1974, while at WSU, Jack was consultant as a wheat disease expert on a trade mission to China shortly after President Nixon opened trade relations with that country. Following a short-term assignment to the USDA Integrated Pest Management Program in Beltsville, Maryland, Jack moved to the University of Minnesota, where he was the Research Leader at the USDA-Agricultural Research Service Cereal Rust Laboratory from 1982-1987 when he retired. In recognition of his research and service to plant pathology, Jack was made a fellow of the American Phytopathological Society (APS) and also served as APS president. Jack is survived by his wife Joyce of Santa Rosa, daughter Patricia South and husband Walter of New York City, son Jim and wife Andy of Paradise, CA, and four granddaughters, Claire Hines, Ruth Kmiecik, Marsha Schafer, and Amanda Schafer, and sister Judith Hiss of Akron, OH. He was preceded in death by daughter Janice and brother George. There will be a memorial service on May 18th at 2:00pm at Vineyard Commons in Santa Rosa, California and a graveside memorial service will be in August in Pepin, Wisconsin. Memorials should be sent to the Washington State University Department of Plant Pathology Graduate Student Travel Fund, or to the American Phytopathological Society Foundation directed to graduate student travel.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an art review of ''The Sculpture of Louise Nevelson: Constructing a Legend,'' at the Jewish Museum, reversed the credits. The photograph of ''First Personage'' was from the Brooklyn Museum, and the picture of ''Mrs. N.'s Palace'' was from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
To the Editor: Re ''Save the Darfur Puppy'' (column, May 10):

Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, the Westchester Democrat, has something to add to the campaign finance bill now being batted around between Governor Spitzer, for whom it is a top priority, and Mr. Bruno, for whom it is not. Mr. Brodsky wants the bill to fill a hole created last summer when state and federal courts struck down a century-old law banning party committees from giving cash to candidates of their own party during a primary. (It was originally passed to stop the Tammany Hall machine from dominating primaries, which in Democratic-dominated New York were often tantamount to a general election; the courts now say the ban is unconstitutional, small comfort to long-dead Boss Tweed.)

PODELL--George W. Passed away peacefully on May 11 at age 93. Loving husband for 51 years of Laurette. Proud and adoring father of Howard and Judith. You'll always be in our hearts. Grave side services Monday, May 14, 2pm at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.
