Contributions in her memory may be made to the Rapoport Torah Fund of the Drisha Institute for Jewish Education, 37 West 56th St, NY, NY 10023 or to the Rapoport Torah Fund of the Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY 11576.

''Shrek the Third,'' which opens on Friday attended by the usual toys and marketing tie-ins, may also gain considerable revenue with its soundtrack. The ''Shrek'' soundtrack sold 2.4 million albums, and ''Shrek 2'' sold 1.2 million. A film's showing at the box office does not guarantee musical success: ''Happy Feet'' sold only 342,000. So, what does ''Shrek the Third'' offer? Songs from Fergie, Harry Chapin, and a version of the 1970 hit by Sly and the Family Stone, ''Thank You (Falletin Me Be Mice Elf Again),'' by Antonio Banderas. SHELLY FREIERMAN
A takeover of Chrysler by Cerberus would mark the return to the industry by two executives who once ran auto companies. Page A16.

To the Editor: George Prochnik (''Hail to the Analysand,'' Op-Ed, May 6) rightly points out the utility of a Freudian inquiry into the deeper personal motivations of ''divinely inspired'' leaders like Woodrow Wilson and George W. Bush. But psychoanalysis alone cannot fully illuminate those motives, whose manifold spectrum of meanings can be captured only in the broader social and political context of their resonance with mass constituencies and the cultural zeitgeist.

One of the most wanted members of the Taliban, Mullah Dadullah, who was close to its leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, and who had links to Al Qaeda, was reported killed in a joint operation by Afghan security forces, American forces and NATO troops in south-central Afghanistan. He was probably the Taliban's most important operational commander, and he was thought to be responsible for ordering numerous assassinations, kidnappings and beheadings. BY TAIMOOR SHAH and CARLOTTA GALL, PAGE A8

Brooklyn Philharmonic Brooklyn Academy of Music The Brooklyn Philharmonic has earned a well-deserved reputation for adventurous programming, including ambitious multidisciplinary collaborations. On Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the orchestra inaugurated a three-year partnership with the Ridge Theater, a New York company known for innovative multimedia presentations, with a staged performance of the Polish composer Henryk Gorecki's Symphony No. 3. The two institutions previously worked together in a 2003 concert version of the John Adams opera ''The Death of Klinghoffer.''

A sports article last Monday about Victory Challenge's performance in the America's Cup challengers series referred incorrectly to a past Cup competitor that was used as the model for a prized yacht of Jan Stenbeck, the founder of Victory Challenge. Endeavor, on which the prized yacht Sophie is based, challenged for -- but did not win -- the America's Cup in 1934.

Rufus Wainwright ''Release the Stars'' (Geffen) The trend for Rufus Wainwright lately has been steady inflation: bigger themes, larger canvases, a ballooning conviction in his own voice and songs. His fifth album, ''Release the Stars,'' opens with a pregnant question -- ''Do I disappoint you in just being human?'' -- and builds to operatic dimensions, replete with religious and apocalyptic language.

ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- Reports this week will provide data on consumers. The government releases its consumer inflation report, and the Labor Department reports the Consumer Price Index for April (Tuesday) and weekly jobless claims (Thursday). The University of Michigan releases its consumer sentiment index on Friday. On the industrial side, the Commerce Department reports on housing starts for April, and the Federal Reserve reports on industrial production for April (Wednesday). Freddie Mac, the mortgage company, reports on mortgage rates, and the Philadelphia Federal Reserve manufacturing index reports on regional manufacturing conditions (Thursday).

To the Editor: I read with great interest ''Telling Bogus From True: A Class in Reading News'' (Education page, May 9), about the professor who teaches students to make critical judgments about the reliability of news items.

Maurizio Pollini Carnegie Hall Some people live faster than others. Schubert's life, it can be argued, was not tragically short but was lived at high velocity. Then there is Maurizio Pollini, who plays piano music at such speed that we can only stand by the roadside and try to catch glimpses of it whizzing past. Elegant, thoughtful and vastly cultured, Mr. Pollini seems to exist in a time continuum all his own. I am sure he hears his own playing with perfect clarity. I wish I could keep up with him.

A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Gayfest NYC, which presents the works of emerging gay playwrights, misstated the middle initial of one of the festival's producers. He is Jack W. Batman, not Jack R.

A dance review on April 16 about the Boris Eifman Ballet, at City Center, misstated the history of Mr. Eifman's new ballet, ''The Seagull.'' Its American premiere was in March at the University of California, Berkeley -- not at City Center in April.

Wilco ''Sky Blue Sky'' (Nonesuch) Where did all the weird noises go? On Wilco's pensive new album, ''Sky Blue Sky,'' the band takes its latest tangent by going back -- though only partway -- toward its old Americana.

COHEN--Arlene Hochman Meyer of New York City and Bondville, VT died on May 13, 2007 in New York City. Arlene was born on March 25, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY to Robert and Lillian Hochman. A graduate of the High School of Music and Art, Arlene received her BA from Connecticut College in 1952. She married John Meyer on January 18, 1953. During her years in Norwich, CT Arlene worked as a teacher in Head Start and the Norwich School System. Arlene joined her husband's sportswear manufacturing company as the Director of Design and Marketing. Together they brought John Meyer of Norwich to national prominence. Following John Meyer's death in 1974 Arlene moved to Manhattan and remarried the late Lawrence M. Cohen of Greensboro, NC in 1977. A long time supporter of educational, cultural and Jewish organizations, Arlene made significant contributions to the Lyman Allyn Museum, Connecticut College, The National Council of Jewish Women, United Jewish Appeal, American Friends of the Israel Museum and the Weitzman Institute. Arlene divided her time between New York City, Greensboro, NC and Stratton, VT. A loving mother and grandmother, Arlene is survived by her three children, Elise A. Meyer (Henry Feuerstein), Robert A. Meyer (Jessica Meyer), and Emily Meyer-Sacks (Joshua Sacks) and her six adored grandchildren: John, Amanda, Abigail, James, Hallie and William. Funeral services will be held on May 14, 2007 at 11am The Conservative Synagogue in Westport, CT; Arlene will be interred at the Hebrew Benevolent Cemetery in Preston, CT.

''This legislation will help us bring the guilty to justice and exonerate those who have been wrongly accused.'' Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York on his proposal to expand the state's DNA database to include more convicted criminals, and to allow more access to inmates challenging their convictions. [A1]

Rocking the Gondola Alexandra Hai is the first woman authorized in Venice to operate a gondola, despite objections from some longtime gondoliers. A court recently ruled she could propel a boat around the canals, but only for guests of one hotel. PAGE A4 Pope Calls for Feeding Spirit Pope Benedict XVI, in Aparecida, Brazil, condemned capitalism and Marxism as marginalizing God and urged the Latin American clergy to feed people's spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty. PAGE A10 Violence in Karachi Increases Pressure on President A day after clashes claimed 39 lives in Karachi, analysts said the violence -- and accusations that the government had done little to stop the killings -- had put renewed pressure on President Pervez Musharraf. News reports said government troops had been in the city, but had not taken action. PAGE A3 Trying It On, Online For the first time in online retailing, the sales of clothing have overtaken those of computer hardware and software, suggesting that consumers have reached a new level of comfort. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Wall St. Journal and Its Profit Profit margins that do not equal those of other big newspapers and a poor outlook for 2007 may have opened the door for Rupert Murdoch to bid. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 CBS Still Backing Couric Eight months after Katie Couric took over ''The CBS Evening News,'' the program is back in a distant third place. A motorcyclist was thrown to the pavement and killed yesterday after she struck a man who had run into traffic on the West Side Highway at 56th Street in Manhattan, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released but who was said to be in her 30s, was traveling north on the highway shortly after 9:30 a.m. when the crash took place, the authorities said, even though she applied her brakes and swerved to try to avoid a collision. The man suffered a broken leg, the police said. The police did not release the pedestrian's name. THOMAS J. LUECK

DaimlerChrysler reached an agreement early today to sell the struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, for $7.4 billion. The deal unwinds a 1998 merger that was meant to create a trans-Atlantic automotive powerhouse. DaimlerChrysler scheduled an 8 a.m. E.T. news conference to discuss the sale.

An article on Wednesday about the annual New York City sewage workers' competition misstated part of the name of an organization of wastewater professionals that founded a national competition, the Operations Challenge, to which New York State's winners will progress. It is the Water Environment Federation, not Foundation.

FLEISSNER--Erwin, 70, died on May 12, 2007 at home. Devoted husband of Judith Friedlander, loving father of Jennifer (Joshua Kates) and Katie, adoring grandfather of Ezekiel, devoted brother of Robert and son-in-law of Sadie Klein, mother of his deceased wife Norma. Distinguished molecular biologist and academic dean, Erwin spent over 20 years in cancer research at Memorial SloanKettering and 11 years as Dean of Sciences and Mathematics at Hunter College. A humanist as well as a scientist, in retirement he wrote Vital Harmonies: Molecular Biology and Our Shared Humanity. The Family will be receiving visitors on May 15, 16, and 17, 5-9pm. A memorial service will take place at Hunter College, May 30. Check Hunter College's Website, Events, for details.

Discontent is rising with Joseph N. Mondello, the state's Republican Party chairman, ahead of the party's New York City fund-raiser on Thursday featuring John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani. Several Republican officials privately suggest that Mr. Mondello has worn out his welcome even with his ally Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, who is said to want a more forceful partner in his battles with Gov. Eliot Spitzer. And names of possible replacements have been circulating, including those of former State Senator Ray Meier of Utica, who lost a Congressional bid last year, and Edward Lurie, executive director of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee. ''The early concern is he has not been upstate, other than Albany,'' one upstate Republican senator said. ''And those are concerns among county chairmen and elected officials.''

Bruce Bowen has made a career of frustrating opponents with his tenacious defense while provoking their suspicion -- if not outrage. In three games of this testy Western Conference semifinal series against the Phoenix Suns, the Spurs forward has managed to do both, but has yet to incur a major penalty from the N.B.A. After investigating Bowen's foul in Game 3 when he kneed the Suns' Steve Nash in the groin area during a play in the beginning of the second half, the N.B.A. didn't suspend Bowen or fine him. On Monday, the league upgraded the foul to a Flagrant 1 penalty, according to an N.B.A. spokesman.
NUSSBAUM--Max. The Diamond Manufacturers & Importers Association of America mourns the passing of our member and dear friend Max Nussbaum.

To the Editor: While Planned Parenthood counts abortion rights advocacy as part of our most important work, ''Abortion Rises Anew for Giuliani'' (news article, May 8) did not include the heart and soul of our mission.

On the southern wall of Al-Aqsa Islamic Society here is a mural painted by local schoolchildren. In 18 different languages -- from Arabic to Swahili -- it depicts the world's various ways of saying ''love,'' ''hope'' and ''peace.'' The mosque itself is an immaculate structure, four stories high and with a colorful frieze adorned with ornamental arabesques. It is the best-kept building in its North Philadelphia neighborhood, a blighted urban landscape dominated by the crumbling brick pile of the abandoned Gretz brewery across the street.

A listing of credits on Wednesday with a film review of ''Day Night Day Night'' included incorrect information from the film's distributor about several people who worked on the movie. Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor. The editors were Julie Loktev and Mr. Taylor -- not Ms. Lotkev and Leslie Shatz, who was the sound designer. The production designer was Kelly McGehee -- not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.

Do these Mets appreciate their opportunity to be one of the most memorably nicknamed teams in baseball history? If these Mets, alias the Hairless Wonders now that virtually all their scalps have been sheared like sheep, were to win the World Series, they would deserve to be remembered for their shiny skulls the way the 1906 Chicago White Sox, dubbed the Hitless Wonders, have endured in baseball lore for having won the World Series with the lowest team batting average in the American League that year: .230.

Coldwell Banker, Parsippany, N.J., part of the Realogy Corporation, selected McKinney & Silver, Durham, N.C., part of Havas, as its national creative agency. The assignment, with spending estimated at $50 million to $75 million, had been at the Kaplan Thaler Group, New York, a unit of the Publicis Groupe. Pioneer Electronics USA, Long Beach, Calif., part of the Pioneer Corporation, shifted the creative account for its flat-panel plasma TV sets, with worldwide spending estimated at $50 million, to TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, from RPA, Santa Monica, Calif. The TBWA/Chiat/Day office in the Playa del Rey section of Los Angeles will handle the assignment, which had been at RPA since July 2003.

GALLANT--Herbert, 84, on Friday. Beloved husband of Geraldine; cherished father of John, Brenda, Robert and Ilze; grandfather of Lawrence and Brad; born to Frank and Frances. Graduated Harvard, summa cum laude 1944. President of Gallant for over 50 years. Member Harvard Club 62 years, founding member Sewane Club. He will be loved and missed forever. Services Tuesday 1pm at Mount Lebanon.

ZEITLIN--Edwin. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club record the passing of our longtime member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Edith, son Andrew (Elaine), sister Joyce Berger (Arthur), granddaughters Samantha Zeitlin and Beth Shaw (Ronnie) and the entire family. Attilio Petrocelli, Pres. Roger Blumencranz, Sect'y

The Yankees have fallen so far behind the Boston Red Sox that every game seems to take on urgency, even this early in the season. That is what made their Sunday so discouraging. The Yankees were playing the Seattle Mariners, but there was no escaping the shadow cast by the Red Sox from across the country. When Boston scored six runs in the ninth inning to win their game, some of the Yankees noticed on the scoreboard at Safeco Field.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Taliban Operational Leader Is Killed in Afghanistan The man who probably was the Taliban's foremost operational commander, Mullah Dadullah, was killed in a joint operation by Afghan, American and NATO forces in Helmand Province, according to an Afghan official and NATO. A8 Jordan's King Postpones Visit A rare visit to the West Bank by King Abdullah II of Jordan was called off at the last minute because of bad weather, Palestinian officials said, and in Gaza, serious fighting between Palestinian factions continued. A10 Sunni Offers Plan to Congress In meetings in Washington with members of Congress, Muhammad al-Daini, a Sunni Arab member of the Iraqi Parliament who says he has survived eight assassination attempts, has offered a pitch that emphasizes the need for American troops to withdraw. A8 Pope Assails Economic Tacks Pope Benedict XVI, in a major speech in Brazil, condemned capitalism and Marxism as ''systems that marginalize God'' and urged the Latin American clergy to feed people's spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty and halt the Roman Catholic Church's steady decline in the region. A10 Pakistan Clashes Press Leader After political clashes killed 39 in Karachi, analysts said the violence -- and accusations that the government had done little to stop the killings -- had renewed pressure on the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. A3 U.S. Seeks to Keep Data Deal In an effort to reduce the odds that terrorists will enter the United States, the Bush administration is asking the European Union to lift its objections to the sharing of airline passenger information with American intelligence agencies, the secretary of homeland security said. A3 Iran and U.S. Lobby in Mideast The diplomatic tussle between Iran and the United States intensified as leaders from both countries toured Middle Eastern capitals, seeking to shore up relationships, even as signs of new cooperation over Iraq emerged between them. A6 NATIONAL A12-17 A Weaker Dollar Expected To Aid Growth in Economy A weaker dollar is helping to make American goods and services more competitive in foreign markets. As a result, the vast disparity between what Americans import and export is expected to narrow, which would allow trade to contribute to economic growth in the United States for the first time in more than a decade. A1 Chrysler Unit May Be Sold DaimlerChrysler may be on the verge of selling the struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, a private investment firm, unwinding a 1998 merger that was meant to create a trans-Atlantic automotive powerhouse, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said. A1 For Cerberus Capital Management, the 15-year-old private equity firm, buying DaimlerChrysler is the logical culmination of an automotive strategy that it has pursued for several years. And for two of its top executives, the deal will be a triumphal return to an industry that not so long ago forced them out. A17 Rash of Native Alaskan Suicide The suicide rate among Native Alaskans was three times that of all Alaska residents and nearly four times higher than the national rate from 2003 to 2006, according to a study conducted for the Alaska Statewide Suicide Prevention Council and other groups. Suicide among Native Alaskans is commonly linked with depression, alcoholism and cultural stress. A12 Land Sale for a Bush Library The prospect of the George W. Bush Presidential Library's being built on the campus of Southern Methodist University received a lift o when voters in a Dallas suburb passed a proposition that paves the way for the city to sell a piece of parkland to the university. A12 Obama Talks of Tax Cuts If elected president, Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat, said he would seek to repeal President Bush's tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans and use the money to pay for health care. But he did not suggest he would raise other taxes to pay for expanded services. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Ground Zero Illnesses Cloud Giuliani's Legacy Most agree that Rudolph W. Giuliani presided over ground zero in the days after 9/11 with decisiveness, determination and self-confidence. But today, with evidence that thousands of people who worked at ground zero have become sick, many regard Mr. Giuliani's triumph of leadership as having come with a human cost. A1 Serving in the New York Guard While there are many loyal members the New York Guard -- a little-known volunteer corps dating to World War I -- critics contend that among the organization's main beneficiaries is a small cadre of politicians who rarely show up for meetings but proudly show off their quasi-military honorifics. A1 Mayor's Trip Fuels Speculation Despite multiple denials, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has increasingly fueled speculation that he will run for president by sharpening his national profile and delivering speeches across the country. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 U.S. Companies Look Abroad This year, for the first time, the 500 companies that make up the benchmark Standard & Poor's stock index may generate more than half of their sales in foreign countries, as a weaker dollar helps to make American goods and services more competitive in foreign markets. A1 Wall Street Journal's Woes Despite weekday circulation of more than two million, The Wall Street Journal has lagged behind most major papers in profit margins. High-cost journalism and changes in its ad sales strategy produced a performance that makes its publisher, Dow Jones & Company, attractive to Rupert Murdoch. C1 Clothing Tops Online Sales For the first time since the birth of online retailing, clothing sales, which hit $18.3 billion last year, have overtaken those of computer hardware and software, suggesting that consumers have reached a new level of comfort on the Web. C1 Business Digest C2 ARTS E1-8 Author Revisits Kennedy Case Vincent Bugliosi, the prosecutor who put Charles Manson behind bars, has turned his attention to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in his exhaustive new book, ''Reclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy''. It includes 20 years of research, more than one million words, hundreds of interviews, thousands of documents and more than 10,000 citations. The Mets sent the right-handed starter Mike Pelfrey to Class AAA New Orleans yesterday, in hopes that he will be able to resume throwing his fastball much lower in the strike zone and can rummage up some lost confidence. ''You have to win to be here, and I didn't do that,'' Pelfrey said before the game. ''I think it's for the better.''

BENALLOUL--Maurice. How sad we are at the passing of such a kind, sweet man. Our deepest sympathy to our dear friends Albert and Vickie and the entire Benalloul family. Mindy and Ron Horowitz Dari, Eric and Perri
To the Editor: Re ''The Democrats' Pledge'' (editorial, May 9):

There are two glass-door refrigerators in the narrow visitors' clubhouse at Yankee Stadium. One is filled with bottled water and juices, while the other has a more varied selection: sports drinks, protein shakes, soda, diet soda, lemonade and chocolate milk. When visiting players are thirsty, they can choose from more than a dozen beverages. But the one product that players cannot secure in the clubhouse is a cold beer. The Yankees, who banned alcoholic beverages from the home clubhouse several years ago, removed them from the visitors' side nine days ago.

Joe Torre will spend the Yankees' day off Monday at New York-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital with his brother Frank, who is recovering from a kidney transplant. Frank Torre, 75, received a kidney from his daughter, Elizabeth, on May 1. He was in intensive care last week as he battled an infection.

SHELTON--Miss Frances Elizabeth was the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Shelton and was born in Decatur, Alabama on January 24, 1919. After graduating from high school, she visited New York City with her mother and ultimately decided to enroll at The Julliard School based on that fateful visit. She was awarded a Diploma in Piano and a minor in Organ from The Julliard School. During her lifetime, Miss Shelton performed in recitals in New York City, in Toronto, Canada, and throughout Florida. She also taught at La Guardia High School of the Performing Arts for 20 years. Miss Shelton is a descendant of an early Virginia family and was a very active member of several societies. She was a member of the United Daughters of the Confederacy for 53 years and was the current New York Division President prior to her death. She was also a member of the New York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) and served as its Regent from 1988 to 1991 and was its Chapter Historian prior to her death. Miss Shelton also served as New York State DAR Historian from 1998 to 2001. She was also an active member in several other societies including: the Jamestowne Society; the Colonial Dames of America; the Sons and Daughters of the Pilgrims; the Huguenot Society of America; and, the oldest woman's club in America, Sorosis. Miss Shelton was also listed in the social registry. Miss Shelton leaves innumerable friends and appreciative former students as well as family in whose hearts and memories she will remain forever. A memorial service and burial is planned for May 19, 2007, at 11:00am at Roselawn Gardens of Memory and Funeral Home in Decatur, Alabama. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent benefiting both the UDC and DAR to the Frances Shelton Memorial Fund, Po Box 230657; New York City 10023.

Gretchen Wilson ''One of the Boys'' (Sony BMG Nashville) In 2004, Gretchen Wilson became country music's rowdiest new star. On her excellent and unpredictable debut album, ''Here for the Party,'' she gleefully proclaimed herself a ''Redneck Woman,'' and millions of fans played along. But the 2005 follow-up, ''All Jacked Up,'' was a disappointing exercise in semiotics: the signifiers (no surprise, she's pro-Budweiser and anti-Paris Hilton) overwhelmed the songs.

Form held almost perfectly in the first round of the championship, which is taking place in Stillwater, Okla. Although a few lower ranked players held their opponents to draws, there were no major upsets as happened last year when Hikaru Nakamura, the 2005 champion, lost in the first round to Joshua Friedel. Nakamura got a measure of revenge this year by beating Friedel in the first round in a titanic struggle. The games can be seen live or be replayed here at Monroi.com.

So I'm waiting out a rain delay here in Chicago, finishing up a meal in the press dining room, when I head for the elevator and bump into... George Steinbrenner's daughter, Jenny Swindal. She was quite pleasant, as she's always been the times I have seen her. Apparently it's just a social visit with some friends. No sign of her soon-to-be ex-husband, Steve Swindal, who remains a general partner but has lost his power within the organization. She still calls herself Swindal, by the way.

The After-Party The candidates seemed to mix it up more in this debate than in the previous one in California. They were certainly more willing to challenge each other, while some candidates seemed to vanish from the conversation. The willingness of the candidates to criticize each other and of the debate moderators to give more airtime to the top tier could presage some dropping out in the near future. Or they could be a prelude to even sharper disputes in the debates ahead.

In the debate over Rupert Murdoch's bid for The Wall Street Journal, one obvious question is how a Murdoch purchase would affect the Journal's excellent coverage of China. Seven Journal reporters in China just weighed in on this, telling the Bancroft family: Don't sell!

Back in 2000, when he was trying to appeal to moderates, Senator John McCain positioned himself against the religious right. His chief targets were Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson, whom he described as "agents of intolerance."

Globespotters is a new site where International Herald Tribune reporters and editors (and readers too!) can share up-to-the-minute tips and recommendations about what's happening in the places they live and visit. Let Globespotters help you get the most out of the world's great cities.

AIRPORTS: This is a good introduction to London, as it will get you used to the idea that everything seems to cost more, take more time and be more complex here than elsewhere. For starters, London has five airports, so pay attention to where you're landing!

Relatively quietly, reports on the 2006 Bordeaux vintage have filtered in and the reviews, while somewhat mixed, are pretty good. Last year, if you recall, the limits of hype were tested daily as wine pundits competed to see who could froth at the mouth most excessively in praise of the 2005's.

Before Rudolph W. Giuliani became a national symbol of the fight against terrorism, he had his own expert overseeing the New York City's emergency preparedness, including readiness for terrorist threats. Now that former city official, Jerome M. Hauer, is in a heated battle with the Giuliani campaign over whether the Mayor - or Mr. Hauer - was responsible for the decision to place the city's emergency command center near the World Trade Center towers before 9/11.

For years now, Sen. Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, has been generating admiring news stories by publicly distancing himself from the Bush administration. Sunday morning he did it again by inching still further away from the hapless president.

Joseph J. Lhota, who was a deputy mayor and top aide during Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's two terms, said this afternoon that it was preposterous for Jerome M. Hauer to deny responsibility for the recommendation to place the city's emergency operations center in 7 World Trade Center, which was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001.

THE AIRPORT: The Hong Kong International Airport, also known as Chek Lap Kok, (www.hongkongairport.com) is organized and fast, with clear English signage. On good days, I've made it from plane to taxi in less than half an hour. (Tip: Though others say the exchange rate is better in town, I usually do the most convenient thing and change my money right after leaving customs). Facilities, including toilets, are wheelchair-friendly, and there are services for the hearing- or seeing-impaired.

AIRPORTS: Leonardo DaVinci Airport (a.k.a Fiumicino) is dirty and chaotic, a somewhat disheartening entry point to one of Europe's most aesthetically pleasing cities. Don't take it personally. When arriving in Rome: Luggage handling at Fiumicino Airport can be notoriously slooow, with waits for checked baggage delivery often 30 minutes to an hour - although this is improving. Frequent travelers to Rome do not check luggage if they can help it! When leaving Rome, queues to check in are often long. If you have a frequent flyer card, you can often go to the much calmer business class check-in. As of May, 2008, travelers to the U.S. flying on U.S. airlines check in and go through passport control at a new facility called Terminal 5, rather than at Terminal C, the main international terminal for flights leaving Europe. Leave extra time since check in at Terminal 5 requires a bus ride to the gates, and also for considerable confusion. Two things to keep in mind: 1. Only taxis are permitted to drive directly to Terminal 5; so if you take a train or a bus to the airport you and your luggage will have to take a shuttle bus from the main terminals to Terminal 5. 2. Alitalia and Delta code share all of their flights; where you check in depends on which airline is operating your flight.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer was not pleased to hear Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno claiming that the Senate's new upstate revival plan is the first such plan offered this year.

AIRPORTS: For years flying into Thailand meant stepping into the charmless, somewhat crusty hallways of Don Muang airport. It was a quick and dirty experience but surprisingly efficient. Now things are more complicated. If you're on an international flight you're likely to arrive at the sprawling new airport, Suvarnabhumi (airport code BKK), which is east of the city. Don Muang carries the airport code DMK and is used mainly for domestic flights. Study your tickets carefully, especially if you're changing planes (it takes at least an hour to travel between airports). Here's the most important thing to know about Suvarnabhumi: it's pronounced Sawana-phoom. If you pronounce it the way it's spelled, no one will understand you. Peak time for international flights at Suvarnabhumi is the evening. Check-in lines, especially for Thai Airways, which now uses the single check-in line system, can be very long. This system apparently saves Thai Airways money, but at peak times you can wait an hour or longer.

Limited Brands announced Tuesday that it was selling its 67 percent stake in Express for $548 million and that it would weigh a sale of its Limited Stores business. With the sale to the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, the company will focus on its Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works businesses, among others. The streamlining plan was announced as the company also lowered its guidance for the first quarter. In afternoon trading, Limited shares were down 4 percent.

We're talking about Carlos Zambrano, the Cubs' burly right-hander who, if he cannot work out an extension with Chicago, will become the most coveted pitcher on the free-agent market come November.

We've learned long ago not to try to make predictions about what can happen in these very free-for-all events, but there are a few things to watch for.

An extraordinary meeting in March 2004 in the hospital room of Attorney General John D. Ashcroft has been reported before. Today, Mr. Ashcroft's deputy, James B. Comey, recounted the meeting for the first time.

Perusing the comments from Micheline Maynard's last post on the Chrysler sale, I noticed three recurring themes. Two of them dealt with Chrysler's poor interior design and reliability. But by far, most of the comments mentioned something about the hybrid issue.
Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno rolled out a lengthy plan to revitalize the upstate and used the occasion to tweak Gov. Eliot Spitzer for not doing likewise.

When Peter G. Peterson retires at the end of next year, he will be able to relax in some luxurious digs. The co-founder of private equity giant Blackstone Group has just shelled out $37.5 million to buy media mogul David Geffen's 12-room duplex penthouse on Fifth Avenue in New York, city records show. The New York Observer, which noted the deal on its real estate blog, points out that Mr. Geffen bought the apartment last year for $31.5 million. That's a 19 percent markup in a year -- a respectable return even in private equity circles.

The Rev. Jerry Falwell, who founded the Moral Majority and built the religious right into a political force, has died. Rev. Falwell credited his Moral Majority with getting millions of conservative voters registered, electing Ronald Reagan and giving Republicans Senate control in 1980.

Media deals may be all the rage these days, but some analysts are seeing fodder for potential takeovers in the software industry as well. Kirk Materne and Daniel Cummins of Bank of America ran the numbers and found eight big software companies with low-enough stock values to make them attractive takeover candidates, even if the acquirer shelled out a 25 percent premium to the current price. The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked "inevitable."

Taiwan's military is testing out some new moves this week in drills meant to prepare for the possibility of a Chinese attack. Today, six fighter jets landed on a highway for a scenario that left official runways destroyed in the fighting.China and Taiwan, which split in 1949 after a civil war, appear to be far from conflict, although there are plenty of political frustrations over Taiwan's attempts to be recognized as an independent nation. China has threatened invasion if Taiwan goes too far on that count.
Before Mullah Dadullah, one of the Taliban's top commanders, was killed over the weekend, he was able to leave a warning behind for his enemies.
A trip across Japan's culinary universe.

The other day on Fox News Sunday, Rudolph W. Giuliani blamed a former aide for the decision to put the city's emergency command center at 7 World Trade Center, where it was destroyed on 9/11. Now the aide, Jerome M. Hauer, the former director of emergency management, has fired back, giving Lloyd Grove of New York magazine a February 1996 memo that shows he argued for a Brooklyn location. He says the mayor overruled him.

Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journal's newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company -- all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.
