Add another consultant to the list of those advising Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: John Kao, a corporate communications consultant who is based in San Francisco and advocates using the techniques of musical improvisation to get the creative juices flowing and leave competitors in the dust. Mrs. Clinton paid Mr. Kao $70,000 to advise her during her Senate re-election campaign in 2006, but the payment did not appear in her financial filings until the end of the first quarter of this year.

FORMATO -- Anthony A., M.D. on May 13, 2007. Beloved Husband of Dr. Mary Louise (nee LaRotonda) Formato. Son of the late Amato and Mary Formato. Brother of Teena Prata, Gloria Fidanzato and the late Vincent. Dr. Formato was a graduate of Fordham University and Downstate Medical School. He served his Internship and Residency at St. Vincent's Hospital NYC, of which he was also an Attending Physician and former President of the Medical Board and Chief of Rheumatology. He was a Knight of Malta and a Air Force Veteran. Reposing Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St. NYC on Wednesday 2:00 to 5:00 & 7:00 to 9:00PM. Mass of Christian burial Thursday 10:00AM, Our Lady of Guadalupe at St. Bernard's Church. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Vincent's Hospital Endowment Fund, 153 West 11th St, NY, NY 10011 would be appreciated.

SATTY--Glenn J. on May 13, age 58 after a courageous battle with melanoma. Beloved brother, uncle, cousin, friend, teacher and colleague. Glenn enlightened and enriched those of us who were fortunate to know him. He was an unforgettable personality, generous, inventive, inquisitive, entertaining, and the consummate host. He was a truly independent thinker. He pursued elegant solutions and encouraged others to do the same. In his limited time, he lived a full and rewarding life, worked hard, traveled the world. He savored the best of everything. He graduated from Hobart William Smith Colleges, went on to a masters degree in mathematics from Stamford, and masters and Ph.D. degrees in philosophy from Boston College. He taught mathematics at the Lawrenceville School, Northeastern University and Hobart College. He then moved to the financial services field where he spent the balance of his career, holding positions of increasing responsibility beginning with O'Connor Partners. He was a Principal of SBC/OC, Managing Director of Human Resources at UBS/Warburg, and Global Head of Education, Development, Sourcing and Assessment. Glenn was Chief Operating Officer of Arbitrade Holdings, and then became Senior Vice President, Chief Technology Officer and member of the Executive Committee for the Knight Trading Group in Jersey City. He was in charge of operations and control for Telluride Asset Management, a multistrategy hedge fund that he co-founded in 2002. Glenn served as a Governor of the Pacific Exchange and an advisor to the MIT program in Financial Engineering and Fairfield University School of Business. Most recently he worked as an independent consultant to major financial service firms. The family would appreciate donations in his memory to Hobart and William Smith College, Geneva, New York.

The government said distemper appeared to be a cause in the wave of deaths of seals this spring in the Caspian Sea. At least 933 dead seals have washed ashore in Kazakhstan in recent weeks, most of them pups. The deaths have raised concerns about seals in the sea, which contains extensive industrial pollution and is a major transit route for oil and the site of a network of oil-pumping platforms. Laboratory tests confirmed the presence of the distemper virus, the Environmental Protection Ministry announced, according to the Russian news agency Interfax. Environmentalists have warned for years that exposure to oil and heavy metals in the sea had weakened the seals' immune systems. C. J. CHIVERS

SHAPIRO--Doris Mintz, 89, of West Hartford, CT, died on Sunday evening, May 13, 2007 after a long illness. A lifelong reader and keen observer of American history and politics, Mrs. Shapiro worked as a librarian at Trinity College, Hartford, before retiring 28 years ago. She was married for 53 years to Isaac Shapiro, who died in 1995. Born in Hartford, she was the daughter of the late David and Rose (Marholin) Mintz. Mrs. Shapiro graduated from Hartford High School and received her bachelor's and master's degree from Mount Holyoke College. Her 1940 graduate thesis examined leadership of the American women's rights movement. After retirement, Mrs. Shapiro was a devoted volunteer at the Deborah Library of Congregation Beth Israel, in West Hartford. She is survived by her three daughters and their families: Joan and Franklin Green of New York City; Phyllis Shapiro and Partha Bagchi of Readington, NJ; and Ruth Shapiro and Bruce Frankel of Larchmont, NY. Mrs. Shapiro was a loving grandmother to her four grandchildren: Jeffrey Green and his wife, Amy von Sydow Green, Julia Green and her fiance Andy Shane, Max Frankel, and Alison Frankel and to her great-granddaughter, Kitty Silveria Green.

An obituary on Saturday about the economic historian Alfred D. Chandler Jr. misspelled part of the name of the place of residence of his daughter Mary (Mimi) Chandler Watt. It is Dinas Powys, Wales, not Dina.

Dressed in ratty sport coats and dirty T-shirts, Uzbek men clutching yellow job contracts squeezed recently into packed buses heading for cities to the north in fast-urbanizing Kazakhstan and on up to Russia. Kazakh officials say that approximately 4,000 Uzbek migrants cross each day to the Kazakh side of this tiny frontier town. In recent weeks, the number of migrants has spiked sharply, border guards say, in response to the economic vitality in Kazakhstan and Russia and the worsening economic and political conditions in the rest of Central Asia.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the arrest of two Rutgers University seniors on burglary charges referred incorrectly to their campus. It is the Livingston campus, and it is in Piscataway, N.J. -- not in Livingston.

SALTZ--Louis A., of Bayside, NY, died on May 11th, 2007. Survived by his loving wife Rochelle, he was a devoted father of Susan, Emily and Brian, and cherished grandfather to Julie, Julian, Sam, Bailey and Katy. Services Wednesday 11:15 am at Sinai Chapel, Horace Harding Blvd, 162nd St, Flushing, Queens.

Steve Nash has won two trophies, but they are the wrong kind for his team-first sensibility and his basketball legacy. On Monday night, Nash played with piercing eyes peering out from either side of his bandaged nose, furiously trying to bring his Phoenix Suns to back against the San Antonio Spurs in Game 4 of the Western Conference semifinals.

State voters will decide in November the future of the nation's first statewide school voucher program, which would provide families with $500 to $3,000 per child for private school tuition. The Legislature narrowly adopted the program in February. Opponents, including teachers' unions, the National PTA and the N.A.A.C.P., said the program would harm public schools and gathered more than 124,000 signatures to force Utah's first referendum since 1974. Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr., a Republican who initially recommended combining the referendum vote with the primary election on Feb. 5 to save money, signed an executive order last week setting the vote for Nov. 6. The governor has asked legislators to provide money to help local governments pay for the election. MARTIN STOLZ
DANIEL--Elsa Musliner. Gone a decade. Remembered fondly for her caring and dedication

From the politics-meets-art/weirdness file: The Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli has hired President Bush's and Senator John Kerry's top advertising gurus from the 2004 campaign, but this time to square off as part of his installation in the coming Biennale in Venice. Mark McKinnon, who was Mr. Bush's top advertising strategist, is producing commercials for a mock presidential campaign by Sharon Stone (we're not making this up). And Bill Knapp, the senior ad maker for Mr. Kerry, and his colleague Jim Mulhall will make spots for her mock opponent, the French writer and philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy.
A music review and a picture caption yesterday about the pianist Maurizio Pollini, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the date of the recital. It was Saturday, not Friday.

''We believe they pretty much have the knowledge about how to enrich. From now on, it is simply a question of perfecting that knowledge.'' MOHAMED ELBARADEI, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, on Iran's progress with uranium. [A1]

STEFFEN--Jonathan F., formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, died of a massive embolism following ankle reconstruction in Philadelphia, PA on April 15, 2007 shortly before his 37th birthday. He was born in North Tarrytown, New York on April 28, 1970 and was a graduate of Mamaroneck High School. Prior to forging a career as a tennis professional, he trained at the Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy and attended Monmouth University, where he was a two-time Northeast Conference A Flight Singles Champion, a four-time MVP and held the team record for alltime career victories. In 1994, he was the Number 4 ranked men's single player in the USTA's Eastern Region and held rankings in the top 20 throughout the 1990's. Throughout his career, Steffen was the head tennis professional at the Westchester based Joel Ross Tennis Academy, Beckwith Pointe Country Club, the former Eldorado Resort Club and Pelham Country Club. He was also the assistant tennis professional at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale. Earlier, he traveled cross country with a top 100 women's singles player, coaching her in the 1992 and 1993 U.S. Open tournaments. His love of the game was most obvious in his development of junior players. He infused many talented juniors with his passion for tennis, and stood out in his field for providing special consideration to families who faced financial inequities. Many of his students won tennis scholarships to top colleges and universities, playing Number 1 on their teams. Steffen was buried in a private family ceremony in Creve Coeur, MO on April 20, 2007. A private celebration honoring his joyful and generous spirit will be held in Westchester. He is survived by his mother Anne Steffen of Philadelphia; his father Fred Steffen of Chicago; his sister Sally Steffen and brother-in-law Geoffrey Herrera of Philadelphia; and his most beloved former wife, Irena Briganti, of New York. Donations in his memory can be sent to: The Jonathan F. Steffen Memorial Fund at Monmouth University, 400 Cedar Avenue, West Long Branch, NJ 07764.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a bid by the equity group Cerberus Capital Management to buy a controlling interest in Chrysler referred imprecisely to the timing of Chrysler's acquisition of Jeep. It was added in 1987 with Chrysler's purchase of American Motors; Jeep was not part of Chrysler when it received a federal bailout in 1979.

New York and New Jersey have often been bit players in the presidential nominating process, with their primaries typically occurring after the nominees have been settled upon. But the 2008 campaign may be different, with both states planning to hold their primaries on Feb. 5, when a slew of others, including California and Texas, are also holding theirs.

NAUMBURG--Marian Opton, died at home in her sleep, May 13, 2007. The daughter of the late Milton and Harriet Opton, and the wife of the late C. Frank Naumburg, she is survived by her brother, Edward, three nephews, and their families. Patron, gourmet, friend and stubborn survivor, she will be missed. Services to be held later in the year. Gifts in lieu of flowers may be made to the New York Society Library.

WEINSTEIN--Harvey J., 82, adored and devoted father and grandfather. Cherished by his children Lori, Mark, Deb, and Dan; Celebrated by his grandchildren Justin, Chloe, Jessica, Kyle, Rachael, and Hunter; Loved by his longtime partner Susan, her children Gail and David, and as ''Pop'' by Bridget, Lucy, Lena, and Lila; Dedicated uncle to Liz, David, George, and Eve. Revered by everyone whose life he touched. He enlisted in the Marines at the age of 18 and throughout his life was dedicated to the goodness of his country. He was a hero to many, humble to all, intelligent, thoughtful, a true leader. He believed in fairness, and championed those less fortunate. He was successful in all endeavors, business, charity, personal, family. He was the consummate model of integrity, commitment, wisdom, and compassion. He mixed it all up with a grand sense of play and humor. We will carry his torch of goodness and are grateful for the blessing of his extraordinary life. Carpe Diem! Donations are welcomed in his honor to The Doe Fund, 232 E. 82nd St., NY, NY 10028 (www.doe.org). Memorial services are Sunday, August 5th at 4PM, Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55th Street. $(6$)WEINSTEIN -- Harvey. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of The Jewish Home and Hospital mourn the passing of Harvey Weinstein, beloved partner of Susan Glickman, Vice Chair of The Jewish Home System Board and Chair of our Lifecare Community Services Division. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Susan and their combined families on the passing of this brave, caring and wonderful man. Gene D. Resnick M.D. Chair, System Board Jewish Home and Hospital Audrey S. Weiner, DSW, MPH President and CEO Jewish Home and Hospital $(6$)WEINSTEIN--Harvey. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Harvey Weinstein. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Howard F. Sharfstein, President

A group of Catholic Democrats in Congress objected yesterday to Pope Benedict XVI's suggestion that lawmakers who support abortion rights should be excommunicated. In a pointed response, 18 House Democrats suggested that the pope was out of line, saying religious interference in politics contravened the freedoms upon which the United States was founded. Among those signing the statement were Representatives Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut, Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island and Carolyn McCarthy of New York. ''Religious sanction in the political arena directly conflicts with our fundamental beliefs about the role and responsibility of democratic representatives in a pluralistic America,'' they said in a statement.

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about ''Patina du Prey's Memorial Dress, 1993-2007,'' at Artists Space in Soho, misidentified the Artists Space Web site. It is artistsspace.org.

A United Nations human rights official said he was barred from visiting an immigration detention center in New Jersey yesterday. It was the second time he was denied access to an American immigration jail on a weeklong monitoring tour. The official, Jorge Bustamante, the United Nations special rapporteur on the human rights of migrants, said he was informed over the weekend that his visit to detained immigrants in the Monmouth County Correctional Institution in Freehold, scheduled for yesterday, had been canceled. Mr. Bustamante said he had received no explanation.

An article on Saturday about the arraignment of a New York police officer on murder charges in the killing of his estranged girlfriend misspelled the surname of the assistant Queens district attorney who spoke in court. She is Annette Almazan, not Almaza.

RUBINO--Edith, of Riverdale, died on May 10. Born in Germany in 1917, she moved to New York in 1938 where she pursued a lifelong career in nursing. Predeceased by her brother John. She was the beloved sister - in - law of Florence Rubino. Beloved aunt of Elliott Rubino (Cindy), Randy Herman (Larry), Robert Rubino (Janice), and Richard Rubino (Donna); and great-aunt of Jillian, Matt, Katie, Steven, Daniel and Aaron. She also leaves behind dear cousins and many good friends. Funeral Service on Tuesday, May 15 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 10 am. Burial at Mount Moriah Cemetery of New Jersey. Donations may be made in her memory to Hebrew Tabernacle Congregation, 551 Ft. Washington Ave., New York, NY 10033.

A picture caption last Tuesday with an article about disciplinary action against Los Angeles police officials after a clash at an immigration rally referred incompletely to a scene at the rally, where officers used force to break up the crowd. The man pictured on his knees with police officers standing over him was a photographer for KCAL-TV in Los Angeles, Carl Stein -- not one of the people who the police said had tried to provoke them.
The Times's Bill Carter reports from Carnegie Hall, where CBS presented its 2007 fall schedule.

The United States, the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gasses, never signed the Kyoto Protocol, the program by which most developed nations pledged to reduce emissions. Now the nation's governors and mayors are promising to do what their national government has avoided.
The Times's Bill Carter reports from Carnegie Hall, where CBS presented its 2007 fall schedule.
President Hugo Chavez's ambitious land reforms have injected the poor with optimism, and brought dread to the wealthy.
With the Yankees these days, it's really best to look at the minor league affiliates.

Sebastien Bourdais again tested the Toro Rosso, today at the Paul Ricard circuit in the south of France. Like his last test, it was pretty difficult to compare his times to other Toro Rosso drivers. Scott Speed drove the car yesterday at the same track, and he had some mechanical problems and ran only 53 laps, setting a fastest time of 1m08.143. Today, Bourdais set a fastest time of 1m07.743, but he ran 142 laps and encountered no mechanical problems.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Golden Door," about a poor Sicilian crossing the Atlantic at the turn of the century.
The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Once," about a Dublin street musician and the Czech woman he falls for.
Stroke is the third leading cause of death in the United States, but many strokes that could be successfully treated are not.
"You should sue your publisher."
Some days we just can't resist a challenge, especially when it comes to music. Today's one of them.

Jim Dwyer wrote a lengthy and comprehensive article in March detailing the extensive and secretive surveillance conducted by the Police Department, starting more than a year before the 2004 Republican National Convention.

Later this month - or it could be next month - a group of three judicial "wise men" in the Netherlands should finally settle the fate of a very unlucky woman named Lucia de Berk. A 45-year-old nurse, de Berk is currently in a Dutch prison, serving a life sentence for murder and attempted murder. The "wise men" - an advisory judicial committee known formally as the Posthumus II Commission - are reconsidering the legitimacy of her conviction four years ago.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders gathered in the Red Room of the Capitol today for their second public meeting since the budget was passed six weeks ago.
Through our own fault, our architect had designed a house too big and too expensive - just plain too much.
You can take the man away from the Minnesota Fishing Opener, but you can't take the Minnesota Fishing Opener away from the man.
Mark these dates. The Democratic National Committee today released the days, sponsors and locales of the six debates it is sanctioning this year, one a month beginning in July.

When Fox News tried to set up a Democratic presidential debate with the Congressional Black Caucus, it watched its effort crumble after bloggers and liberal groups complained that Democrats should not appear on a network that, they said, had a history of belittling Democrats and promoting Republicans on its airwaves.

Deutsche Bank has become the latest western financial institution to attract interest from a Middle Eastern investor after Dubai's International Financial Center built a significant stake in the German bank, the Financial Times reported. In a statement on Wednesday, DIFC Investments, the center's investment arm, said it had acquired a 2.2 percent stake in Deutsche Bank, becoming one of the bank's largest shareholders.

Congressional testimony is great fun for journalists, both those who wear press passes and those who wear pajamas. Given the bare-bones style of Capitol grillings and the disjointed manner of recorded testimony, anyone who wants to analyze the event can feel free to give the commentary his or her personal little spin. Yesterday's stunning comments by James Comey, the former deputy attorney general, were of course no exception. For the sake of argument, let's use this New York Times news report as a neutral baseline against which we can judge the blogospheric reaction:
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's May 16 column, "Failing by Example."

Interesting Q-and-A on the Wine Spectator web site with Robert Bohr, the wine director at Cru restaurant in Manhattan. Robert has many sensible things to say, but among his points I find this statement particularly interesting:

Yet again, carried interest is at the center of controversy. The carry, as it is called, is essentially the portion -- usually 20 percent -- of private equity funds' investment profits that flow to the funds' managers as a kind of performance fee. Some people, including lawmakers and labor groups, have recently questioned whether the carry deserves to be taxed at the lower capital gains rate (as it usually is) or whether it should be taxed as ordinary income (which the private equity industry naturally thinks is an awful idea).
Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.
Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.

Fidelity Investments has generally behaved disgracefully in the context of Darfur. It has large holdings in PetroChina (which in turn buttresses the Sudanese government), yet it has refused to hold any dialogue with the divestment movement. There are legitimate arguments Fidelity could make (Berkshire-Hathaway has tried to make them), but Fidelity has essentially stonewalled. That's one reason for the movement to boycott Fidelity.
The debate over the third building that collapsed at ground zero on Sept. 11, 2001, is back.
Roll call votes in the Senate typically transpire with little fanfare and are filed away in the Congressional record, seldom to be dusted off ever again.

What has the recent run of private equity megadeals meant for the United States economy, the middle class and income inequality? It's hard to say for sure -- at least that was the sense we got from watching the witnesses who testified Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee. Still, that didn't stop both lawmakers and some of the witnesses from offering their opinions on the matter, which has come into focus as labor organizations have raised questions about buyout funds, which acquire public companies in hopes of selling them after an operational or financial overhaul, and whether they are good for United States workers.
Yesterday, I wrote about my experiences as a judge in the Modern Marvels Invent Now competition.
"I'm absolutely crushed," a reader wrote in today, saying he had just read the article in the Dining section about the speciousness of truffle oil. "What a shock and disappointment."
Our recent post about the future of historic preservation in New York City elicited a fascinating comment from Dr. Mark Klein* who offered this intriguing recollection:

Fred Thompson is impressing some in the blogosphere with his quick and pointed video response to the filmmaker Michael Moore, who asked the not-quite presidential candidate to debate health care.Mr. Moore is facing criticism for bringing 9/11 workers to Cuba to highlight what he calls the superiority of health care there. In response to Mr. Moore's invitation to debate, Mr. Thompson quickly released this video. Thompson's performance suggests that should he run, he might have a leg up on some of the less blog-savvy campaigns.

Time Warner may have fended off Carl Icahn's calls for a four-way breakup of the company, but that doesn't mean the media conglomerate isn't still considering some major changes. An analyst at Bear Stearns thinks a sale of Time Inc., the world's largest magazine company, is high on the list of restructuring moves under consideration.
What the future may hold for the next incarnation of Chrysler is certainly open to speculation. But there is no argument the company could certainly use some new product. A.S.A.P., please.
Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.
Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.
A source close to the Spitzer administration says that a deal has been reached between the governor and Legislative leaders on legislation to make human trafficking a felony in New York state.

Arcelor Mittal, the world's largest steelmaker, angered Arcelor minority shareholders with buy-out terms below the current market price on Wednesday after announcing its first-quarter results, Reuters reported. Arcelor Mittal, formed by Mittal Steel's takeover of Arcelor, said it would offer eight Arcelor Mittal shares for seven Arcelor shares, or an exchange ratio of 1.143, for the 6 percent of Arcelor it did not already own.
The simmering tensions between organized labor and the United States private equity industry may be coming to a boil.

The judge overseeing the bankruptcy case of New Century Financial, the subprime lender, rejected the federal government's effort to oust its management on Tuesday but agreed to appoint an examiner to review its accounting.

Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, has purchased a big stake in Anadarko Petroleum, according to regulatory filings, suggesting the billionaire investor is betting on further consolidation in the oil services sector. Icahn Management, one of Icahn's investment vehicles, took a stake of about 3.1 million shares in Anadarko, worth about $133.5 million as of March 31, the filing said Tuesday.
Who won Tuesday night's Republican presidential debate? Pretty much everybody, according to the blogosphere. The bad news: pretty much everybody lost, too.

Merrill Lynch said that Dow Kim, executive vice president and co-president of its global markets and investment banking group, will leave this year to start his own investment firm. Merrill said it expects to be a client of Mr. Kim's new firm.

When John Browne, the former chief executive of BP, resigned from Goldman Sachs's board of directors last week, it was hard to escape the conclusion that Goldman had inadvertently contributed to a nasty episode of homophobia, Matthew Lynn writes in a Bloomberg News column.
Sometimes, unsubstantiated deal chatter is right on the money.

The Thomson Corp.'s $17.2 billion acquisition of the Reuters Group, the global news and financial data service, comes in the middle of an information revolution as easy distribution over the Internet has turned news and data into a commodity. Media companies, including newspapers, cable companies and financial publishers, are all struggling to turn their content into new services that their customers are willing to pay for.

After a week of news dominated by abortion on the G.O.P. side, security has come back into the fore. As they said they would, Fox News producers tried to drive a substantive debate, and differences among the candidates were especially stark, and sometimes emotional, on the question of interrogation techniques. From The Times's Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora:
The  deal values the eye-care company at $4.5 billion.

The Bank of America filed an appeal with the Dutch Supreme Court on Tuesday over a ruling this month that froze the company's $21 billion purchase of the LaSalle Bank from ABN Amro. "We're confident that the Dutch Supreme Court, when presented with all the facts, will overturn the decision" of the Amsterdam Superior Court, Scott Silvestri, a Bank of America spokesman, told The Associated Press.

Permira Advisers, Europe's biggest leveraged buyout fund, agreed to buy 29.9 percent of the Valentino Fashion Group from Marzotto family members in a deal that values the Italian fashion company at 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion).
Wendy's International, the fast-food chain that put itself up for sale last month, hired J.P. Morgan Chase and Lehman Brothers for advice on evaluating potential buyers.
Chuck, meet Eddie.

The Fortress Investment Group became the first American hedge fund and private equity firm to report quarterly earnings Tuesday, and the disclosures highlighted the difficulties the public markets have in dealing with businesses whose income streams are volatile and difficult to predict.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has emerged as one of three foreign front-runners bidding for a piece of Air Canada Technical Services, battling against the lone Canadian contender in the top four, Gerald Schwartz's Onex, The Globe and Mail reported.
Hedge fund registration is back on the menu.
An interview with Michael Sykes, inventor of the Enertia house.

Starting June 1, 2007, a change in British law means that every property seller will have to produce a Home Information Pack at a cost of several hundred pounds. The packs are aimed at giving buyers more information from the outset so they can make an informed decision early on in the purchase. The goal is to reduce the number of aborted transactions that take place. All packs must contain evidence of title, standard searches, an energy performance certificate, among other information.
Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman whose pronouncements continue to jolt world markets, has signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm.

Steven Roth's hopes of establishing a beachhead on the West Coast were dashed earlier this year when he lost the high-stakes contest to acquire Equity Office Properties and its nationwide portfolio of prime office buildings to the Blackstone Group.
Is ABC going where no network has gone before? On Tuesday, it confirmed that a sitcom based on Geico's cavemen commercials would be in their fall schedule.
A homebuyer in Spain came across a nightmarish find this week.

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway on Tuesday revealed stakes in Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific. -- five weeks after the billionaire said he had invested in three railroad companies but would not disclose the names of two.

By hiring a veteran investment banker, Blake Jorgensen, as its chief financial officer, Yahoo sent out signals that there is deal making in its future, but analysts and industry observers seemed unable to decide what kind.

Fireworks have so far been rare at annual shareholder meetings this year. With stock indexes near their record highs, investor anger, not surprisingly, has been muted. But Wednesday's annual meeting of shareholders of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, may be an exception.

A London private equity firm, the 3i Group, said Tuesday it plans to list its specialist-quoted private equity investment business on the London Stock Exchange, raising at least 400 million pounds ($793 million) for growth capital investments in publicly traded companies in Britain and Europe.
Stock in Insulet, a diabetes treatment developer that became the second diabetes-focused health care company to go public in the past few days, rose in its first-day of trading Tuesday.
The business software maker Oracle made yet another acquisition on Tuesday with a $495 million deal to buy Agile Software, which specializes in software that helps companies manage crucial products.
Visa hired Joseph W. Saunders to find a chief executive for the company as it prepares for an initial public offering and he found -- drum roll, please -- himself.

Forgoing earlier plans for an initial public offering, a medical device maker, Asthmatx, said it has taken on $50 million in new funding from a strategic investor, Olympus Medical Systems, to fund regulatory approval and commercialization of catheter-based products to treat asthma. Olympus joins previous venture investors including Polaris Venture Partners and Menlo Ventures.

MySpace is buying Flektor, a new service that allows users to create widgets from photos, video and text, according to TechCrunch. The report follows the announcement last week that MySpace, which is own by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, is acquiring Photobucket for between $250 millon and $300 million.

The Russian nickel giant stalking LionOre Mining International is not retreating, but said it is outraged that the company agreed to such an unusually large break-up fee as part of a sweetened takeover bid of 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion) from Xstrata.
Smarter looks for older women.

UniCredit and Capitalia, two of the largest Italian banks, confirmed Tuesday for the first time that they were in merger talks, but said no accord had been reached. The shares of Capitalia, which is considered by investors as the takeover target in any deal, rose 40 cents, or 5.3 percent, to 7.91 euros, valuing the company at 20.5 billion euros, or $27.8 billion.
Ms. Murphy, who has been dogged by a history of absences from Broadway shows, missed Saturday night’s performance of “LoveMusik” as well as the Sunday matinee.
Whether romantic or not, evenings on a patio or terrace are more enjoyable with appropriate lighting. Some suggestions to set the mood for summer.
A hospital group is trying a radically new method to avoid costly mistakes, charging a flat fee that includes follow-up care.
This season's trends in appliances, fixtures and design.
Images from “Material Journeys” at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and from “African Vision” at the National Museum of African Art in Washington.
Stars of the London production of Tom Stoppard's "Rock 'n' Roll" will reprise their roles when the prizewinning play opens on Broadway in the fall.
The National Design awards, hotel-quality flowers, nightspots in Los Angeles, a “Global Warming Action Kit” and the Design on a Dime auction.
The new consulate in Little Rock, Ark., is one of several opened or planned in recent years where immigration from Mexico has soared.
A journey from Berlin to Bamberg in search of Germany's elusive home brews.
Twenty-five to 40 colleges that have traditionally been perceived as being a notch below the most elite have seen their cachet climb because of the astonishing competitive crush at the top.
The Times tasting panel sampled selections of pinot noir, the red wine made famous by the movie “Sideways.”
In many restaurants across the country, the truffle flavor advertised on the menu comes not from the actual product but from a laboratory-made ingredient.
Paul D. Wolfowitz wants the World Bank to drop or soften a charge of misconduct  in exchange for his resignation as president, officials said.
Under the plan, lenders would provide up to $1 billion each in loans to upgrade energy-hungry systems.
LONDON, May 16 — He had been cast as the warrior prince, the royal who, like a Shakespearean namesake, would lead his troops “unto the breach” of southern Iraq.
At least 19 Palestinians were killed in fighting between Fatah and Hamas as rage rises on both sides.
The documents reveal police surveillance of protesters at the 2004 Republican convention in New York.
The fire forced authorities to shut down parts of major highways and evacuate about 2,500 homes.
Nicolas Sarkozy was inaugurated as France’s 23rd president today, saying he had a mandate for change in France.
The Senate today soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq.
Test scores improved, officials reported, but many high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts.
Street battles between militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces erupted in three cities  on a day of wide-ranging violence.
Hamas fighters killed six during the raid today as fierce fighting between the Palestinian factions continued.
Sony posted its worst quarterly loss in four years today, but said it expects a record profit this year.
The hedge fund acquired a 15.24 million-share stake in Citigroup, raising speculation that the fund might push for changes.
A debate showed the three top candidates maneuvering to emphasize their credentials on national security.
A mysterious bearded collector paid $72.8 million for Mark Rothko’s “White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose)” at Sotheby’s on Tuesday.
Michael Nutter won the Democratic primary for mayor Tuesday, effectively guaranteeing him the position in a city that has not had a Republican mayor since 1952.
Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm.
The capture of three 10th Mountain Division soldiers by terrorists in Iraq will only unite America and strengthen the military’s determination, soldiers said Tuesday.

Congress should repeal a law that puts first-time offenders behind bars for at least five years for possessing tiny amounts of crack cocaine, the Sentencing Commission said. Enacted during the crack epidemic of the 1980s, the law imposes the mandatory minimum sentence for possessing five grams of crack, which weighs the same as five paper clips. It takes a hundred times the amount of powder cocaine to result in the same prison term as for crack, the commission said.

The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has reached agreements with two more universities under which they will adopt a code of conduct governing relations they may have with student loan companies. Mr. Cuomo’s office found that Drexel University, in Philadelphia, was due to receive more than $250,000 from a loan company. That money will now be distributed to students who borrowed from that lender, according to Mr. Cuomo’s office. The investigation also found that Timothy Lehmann, the director of financial aid at Capella University, an online institution based in Minneapolis, received more than $12,000 as a consultant to one lender. Twenty-four colleges and universities have adopted Mr. Cuomo’s code of conduct.

Perfect weather, a lively crowd that nearly filled the stadium and a game-winning hit by Brendan Harris. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays got everything they needed for a successful debut at Disney World on Tuesday night.

A federal appeals court rejected a challenge to a decision by Los Angeles County in 2004 to remove a cross from the county seal. The court turned aside claims that deleting the image of the cross was a display of hostility toward Christianity. The Board of Supervisors voted in 2004 to remove the cross after the American Civil Liberties Union threatened to sue based on the claim that the cross was a government endorsement of Christianity.
The online social network will work with state attorneys general who have requested the identities of members who are known sex offenders.
The burly and excitable Chicago pitcher Carlos Zambrano shut down the Mets through eight innings of the Cubs’  mauling at Shea Stadium.
The company is hoping that Halo 3 will increase the Xbox 360’s momentum in the gaming market.

Governors could order federal facilities to lower their flags to honor troops killed in action under legislation passed by the House. Representative Bart Stupak, Democrat of Michigan, said he sponsored the bill after failing to persuade President Bush to issue an executive order on the issue. The bill passed 408 to 4 and now goes to the Senate; parallel legislation has been introduced.

Congress should repeal a law that puts first-time offenders behind bars for at least five years for possessing tiny amounts of crack cocaine, the Sentencing Commission said. Enacted during the crack epidemic of the 1980s, the law imposes the mandatory minimum sentence for possessing five grams of crack, which weighs the same as five paper clips. It takes a hundred times the amount of powder cocaine to result in the same prison term as for crack, the commission said.

A federal lawsuit was filed claiming violations of wage and overtime laws at a New Bedford leather company where an immigration raid took place in March. The suit asserts that workers were denied overtime pay and wages for unpaid time spent in the factory. The suit, filed by Greater Boston Legal Services, also asserts that employees who worked a shift for Michael Bianco clocked out for 15 minutes and then returned for a second shift working the same job, but for Front Line Defense, a company the suit says is headed by the wife and daughter of Michael Bianco’s owner, Francesco Insolia. Mr. Insolia and his family could not be reached for comment.

The space shuttle Atlantis returned to the launching pad with hundreds of white spots on its external fuel tank the only evidence of two and a half months of repairs from hail damage that postponed the year’s first flight. The spots showed where technicians sprayed on new insulation foam, hand-poured foam on other areas and sanded down spots. The launching is now planned for no earlier than June 8.
The heroism of firefighters on 9/11 has been etched into the memories of most New Yorkers. But not for Peter Braunstein, a defense psychologist testified at his trial yesterday.

The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said first-quarter net income fell 43 percent on losses from derivatives and higher mining costs. Profit declined to $11.3 million from $19.9 million a year ago, Iamgold said. Profit per share fell to 4 cents, from 13 cents, as Iamgold issued shares to pay for its acquisition last November of its rival Cambior for $1.1 billion. Sales more than tripled, to $146.4 million. Iamgold’s cash cost of producing an ounce of gold rose 54 percent, to $416, from a year ago on higher labor and fuel costs.

Vivendi said its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, spurred by demand for its World of Warcraft video game and subscriber growth at the pay-television unit. Net income rose to 932 million euros ($1.27 billion) from 707 million euros ($957.5 million) a year earlier, Vivendi said. First-quarter sales rose 5.3 percent, to 5.02 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.77 billion euros ($6.47 billion) a year earlier. Profit at Vivendi Games surged to 107 million euros ($145 million) from 23 million euros ($31.1 million) a year earlier. The unit sold almost 2.4 million copies of the expansion pack to World of Warcraft the first day it went on sale in January. Profit at the pay-television unit Canal Plus jumped fivefold, to 164 million euros ($222.1 million). Profit at the mobile phone unit SFR, Vivendi’s largest business, slipped 3.5 percent, to 643 million euros ($871 million). Profit was down at the Universal Music Group, hurt by falling CD sales.

A trade panel in Washington gave final approval to antidumping duties ranging up to 44.30 percent on imports of polyester fiber from China used to make ski jackets, pillows and sleeping bags. The panel, the International Trade Commission, voted 6-to-0 that low-priced imports of the fiber from China had materially injured American producers. The vote clears the way for the Commerce Department to issue a final antidumping order this month. China exported nearly $111 million worth of the fiber to the United States in 2006, up from about $30 million in 2004.

HeidelbergCement, a German concrete maker, has agreed to buy Hanson, a British supplier of building materials, for £7.85 billion ($16 billion). HeidelbergCement will pay £11 ($21.80) a share for Hanson, a premium of 29 percent over Hanson’s share price on May 2 when HeidelbergCement first said it might bid. With the purchase, HeidelbergCement will increase its revenue by two-thirds, expanding in the United States and bolstering output of aggregates, pipes and bricks. “The companies are a perfect fit and overlaps are minimal,” HeidelbergCement’s chief executive, Bernd Scheifele, above, said in a conference call with analysts. “Hanson strengthens our operations in the U.S., U.K. and Europe and adds a business in Australia.” Hanson has 26,000 workers in 14 nations and derives half its sales from North America.

The Swiss mining company Xstrata increased its offer for LionOre Mining International of Canada to 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion), trumping a bid from Norilsk Nickel of Russia. Xstrata’s bid, worth 25 Canadian dollars ($22.54) a share, is 16 percent more than the 21.50 Canadian dollars ($19.38) offered on May 3 by Norilsk, the world’s largest nickel miner. A statement on LionOre’s Web site said it’s board recommended shareholders accept the offer by Xstrata, which is based in Zug, Switzerland. Norilsk, based in Moscow, would not say whether it planned to raise its offer.
Carlos Ruiz homered with two outs in the ninth inning last night to give the host Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory against the Milwaukee Brewers.

The Books of The Times review yesterday, about “The Pesthouse,” by Jim Crace, misstated the name of one character at several points. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Franklin, not Francis. The review also misspelled the surname of a writer who was described in the review as part of “the crowning trio of living British writers,” along with Mr. Crace and Barry Unsworth. He is Ian McEwan, not McEwen.

A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq.

An article yesterday about the resignation of Paul J. McNulty, the deputy United States attorney general, misstated the given name of another Justice Department official, the former director of the executive office for United States attorneys, who left his job over the department’s handling of the firings of several federal prosecutors. He is Michael A. Battle, not William.

A picture caption on Sunday with a sports article about the Nets’ 96-85 playoff victory on Saturday against the Cleveland Cavaliers gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the player going up for a layup. He was Jason Kidd of the Nets, not his teammate Richard Jefferson.

A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq.

An article in Science Times yesterday about the construction of particle detectors under parts of France and Switzerland misstated the weights of the Atlas detector and the Eiffel Tower. Each one weighs about 7,000 tons, not pounds.

A sports graphic yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Oscar Pistorius, a South African athlete who wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, carried incorrect renderings in some copies of the “take-off” phase of running. A corrected version can be found online. (nytimes.com/pages/sports/other/index.html).

The About New York column on Saturday, about the relationship between the New York Yankees and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, misspelled the surname of a Yankees spokeswoman in some copies. She is Alice McGillion, not McGillon.

The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about the vaccine for human papillomavirus, misstated a condition caused by two variants of the virus. They cause 90 percent of cases of genital warts, not genital herpes.

An article on Saturday about a speech by Rudolph W. Giuliani in Houston misstated the name of the academic institution where the speech took place. It is Houston Baptist University — not Houston Baptist College, which changed its name in 1973.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the daily closing of the stock market misstated the given name of a strategist at JPMorgan Private Bank who discussed factors that could affect the performance of shares. He is Jack Caffrey, not James.

An article on May 3 about plans to redevelop Pier 40 on the Hudson River into an entertainment complex misstated the year the pier was built as a commercial shipping terminal for the Holland America Line. It was 1963, not 1954.

A listing of credits last Wednesday with a film review of “Day Night Day Night” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about several people who worked on the movie, and a correction in this space on Monday misstated the given name of one of the film’s editors and misspelled her surname at one point. She is Julia Loktev, not Julie Lotkev. (Ohers working on the movie: Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor, who was an editor along with Ms. Loktev. Leslie Shatz was the sound designer, not an editor. And the production designer was Kelly McGehee — not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.).

Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said a resolution would be introduced this week calling on the Security Council to create a tribunal to judge the killers of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister who was assassinated in a Beirut car bombing in 2005. The action was in response to a request from Fouad Siniora, the current prime minister, whose government is locked in a struggle with pro-Syrian forces that are against an international court. A United Nations investigation has linked the assassination to the Syrian security services. Saying he endorsed the decision to act now, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said, “I am of the view that there should be no impunity for the perpetrators of political assassinations.”.

The government agreed on a $16 billion plan that will triple the number of day care centers for children under age 3 to 750,000 by 2013. Germany now lags behind its neighbors in providing day care, with just 13.5 percent of toddlers under 3 in nursery schools, compared with the European average of 35 percent.

Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he hoped that Nicolas Sarkozy, who takes over as France’s president today, would drop his opposition to Turkey’s joining the European Union. Mr. Sarkozy, who argues that Turkey is culturally not a part of Europe and that most of its territory is in Asia, vehemently opposes Turkey’s membership. “This approach of Mr. Sarkozy comes from prejudices,” Mr. Erdogan said, addressing a media conference in Istanbul. “Mr. Sarkozy has to overcome these prejudices.” Mr. Erdogan’s remarks were the first to directly address the implications of Mr. Sarkozy’s election for Turkey. “Turkey’s E.U. membership is the peace project of the 21st century,” Mr. Erdogan said, “an alliance of East and West.”.

A rancher, Vitalmiro Bastos de Moura, left, was convicted of ordering the killing of Dorothy Stang, the 73-year-old American-born nun and advocate for the rain forest and peasant farmers who was shot to death on a jungle road in 2005. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison, the maximum penalty. The case was seen as an important test of justice in the largely lawless Amazon region. Of nearly 800 land-related killings in the Amazon state of Pará over the last 30 years, only four of the powerful masterminds behind them have been convicted, and none are behind bars. After the murder of Sister Dorothy, the government sent 2,000 troops to the zone and announced a logging ban on millions of Amazon acres. “Justice was done,” said David Stang, Sister Dorothy’s brother, who flew to Brazil for the two-day trial.
Suspected hit men for a drug gang killed a man in Tijuana and wrapped him in Christmas gift-wrap in one of the more unusual of Mexico’s daily rash of murders.

The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the group’s decision to exclude debt relief as a form of aid was “factually unjustified.” It said the debt relief it provided had helped African governments put more children in school and improve health. France, too, has disputed the organization’s exclusion of debt relief.

A joint Afghan and American patrol was ambushed in eastern Nuristan, the most remote province, leaving seven Afghan soldiers dead, four missing, and five American and three Afghan soldiers wounded, NATO said.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Legislature are negotiating what could be the most significant overhaul of public authorities in years.
horse racing.
The fighter jet was on a routine training mission from an air base in Atlantic City when it dropped the flare at the Warren Grove Gunnery Range in Ocean County.

The City Council on Monday approved an ordinance that gives the city the power to sue any Connecticut resident who fails to report a missing gun that is used in a crime in Hartford. The ordinance requires gun owners to report missing firearms to the police within 72 hours or face civil penalties. The mayor of Hartford, Eddie Perez, said the Council decided that it could not wait for legislation pending at the state level that would help control the problem, The Hartford Courant reported.

A reward has been offered for information leading to the arrest and conviction of vandals who have been spraying anti-Semitic graffiti on homeowners’ garages and advertising signs during the past several weeks. Swastikas and anti-Semitic slurs have been painted on the garages and on signs for an Israeli fair in five incidents reported since April 1. The UJA/Federation of Westport, Weston, Wilton and Norwalk has offered a $2,500 reward for information leading to a conviction, said Steven Friedlander, the group’s executive director.

The Jets signed five free agents, including Jesse Pellot-Rosa, a former basketball player at Virginia Commonwealth. The Jets also signed defensive back James Ihedigbo, cornerback Rayshaun Kizer, linebacker Jared Newberry and wide receiver Renard Stevens. All five players received tryouts at rookie minicamp last weekend.Pellot-Rosa, who tried out at wide receiver, helped lead the Rams to a Colonial Athletic Association title and a first-round upset of Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament in March.

A drug abuse counselor at a state prison camp in the Adirondacks has been charged with running a methamphetamine lab at his home, according to the state police. John Boyle, 33, of Port Henry, was arrested after a raid at his home on May 8. Mr. Boyle is a drug counselor at the Moriah Shock Incarceration Correctional Facility, a minimum-security prison outside Mineville, near Lake Champlain. A state police investigator said tubing, glass jars and other containers that are usually used to illegally produce methamphetamine were found in the house. Linda Foglia, a spokeswoman for the Department of Correctional Services, told The Press-Republican of Plattsburgh that the department would suspend Mr. Boyle.

The former office administrator of the Interfaith Center of New York, a nonprofit educational organization, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $55,000 from the group by charging personal expenses to business credit cards, prosecutors said. Denyce Norment, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with grand larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, and she pleaded not guilty at her arraignment. Prosecutors said Ms. Norment charged personal expenses, including a cruise and tickets to a Beyoncé concert, to Interfaith credit cards from April 2000 until October 2004. The bills were discovered after Ms. Norment was laid off in 2004, Mr. Morgenthau said. Ms. Norment’s lawyer, Frederica L. Miller, said yesterday that some of the charges were approved by Interfaith and that documentation concerning some of the bills was lost when the office changed locations. “She is absolutely not guilty,” she said. “I am confident the charges will eventually be dismissed.”.

The city has agreed not to sell a vacant firehouse in Brooklyn, ending a four-year battle between the Bloomberg administration and community activists and local leaders. Engine Company 204 on Degraw Street in Cobble Hill was one of five units closed or relocated during budget cuts in 2003, leaving their firehouses empty. The changes set off emotional debates over the future of the buildings, whose communities prized their distinctive structures and histories. Yesterday, Councilmen Bill de Blasio and David Yassky, both of Brooklyn, and the borough president, Marty Markowitz, announced that the city had agreed to put the Degraw Street building up for lease for a community use to be determined. The City Council’s land use subcommittee approved the deal and the potential sale of three of the other firehouses, with a provision that the buildings be used to benefit their communities. The fifth closed firehouse, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been approved for sale to the Henry Street Settlement for moderate-income housing.

A state appeals court has dismissed a civil judgment against the Police Department that stemmed from a 1992 altercation between police officers and demonstrators in Orchard Beach, in the Bronx. The original verdict, in which a jury awarded $81 million to seven plaintiffs, was reduced by the trial judge in 2004 to $635,000, city officials said. In a ruling released yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court found that videotapes of the confrontation did not support the contention that the police had acted improperly. After reviewing the tapes, the judges said that the police were justified in their belief that the protest could escalate and that officers “appropriately tried to quell a quickly unfolding, potentially explosive situation.” Mark Kressner, the plaintiffs’ lawyer, said they would appeal on the grounds that the trial jury made the correct decision after carefully reviewing the evidence. “The jury had the opportunity to see those tapes over a three-week period in slow motion, with explanation of what occurred off camera,” he said.

A Bronx man who opened fire at a crowded playground two years ago has been convicted of fatally shooting a 10-year-old girl during the attack, prosecutors said yesterday. Rene Bonilla, 22, was convicted of murder and attempted murder on Friday in State Supreme Court for killing the girl, Naisha Pearson, and wounding Leonardo D’Eaza, 19, during a Labor Day block party on Sept. 5, 2005. Prosecutors said that Mr. Bonilla went to the playground in Mott Haven to kill Mr. D’Eaza because Mr. D’Eaza had beaten him in front of Mr. Bonilla’s girlfriend. After Mr. Bonilla started firing — striking the girl once and hitting Mr. D’Eaza five times — a crowd chased Mr. Bonilla to the roof of a building, where he was arrested, prosecutors said.

A 13-story hotel in Midtown was evacuated early yesterday after a fire broke out in a first-floor luggage room, fire officials said. Four civilians and four firefighters were treated for minor injuries after the fire at the Ameritania Hotel on West 54th Street near Broadway, fire officials said. Firefighters responded to a call of smoke in the lobby of the midprice hotel at 2:18 a.m., and the fire was declared under control an hour later, fire officials said.

NICELEY--Vivian ''Elaine''. On Saturday, May 12, 2007, Elaine Niceley of Glenn Dale, Maryland, beloved wife of Christopher Niceley; devoted and adored mother of Karen Louise Niceley and Kelly Lyn Niceley, died suddenly of a heart attack. She was the daughter of the late Donald and Eldora White of the Bronx, NY, and sister of the late Richard C. White. She is also survived by her cousin, Reverend Bernard Ruffin and other cousins; her brothersin-law, Bruce and Ted Niceley, and dozens of close friends who loved her dearly. Family will receive friends at the Robert E. Evans Funeral Home, Rte 450 and Race Track Rd, Bowie, MD on Thursday, May 17, 2007 from 2-4 and 6-8pm. A memorial service will be held 11am, Saturday, May 19 at Asbury United Methodist Church, 11th and K Sts NW, Washington DC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in Elaine's name to the Caron Foundation, PO Box 150, Wernersville, PA 19565, www.caron.org

''Pinot noir demands much of both vine grower and winemaker,'' wrote Jancis Robinson in ''The Oxford Companion to Wine.'' But as challenging as the grape may be, once it is in the bottle, it often becomes the most forgiving of wines. Pinot noirs are typically safe choices, especially in restaurants, when a party of four, for example, may order a diverse assortment of dishes and seek a wine to accompany them all.

The city has agreed not to sell a vacant firehouse in Brooklyn, ending a four-year battle between the Bloomberg administration and community activists and local leaders. Engine Company 204 on Degraw Street in Cobble Hill was one of five units closed or relocated during budget cuts in 2003, leaving their firehouses empty. The changes set off emotional debates over the future of the buildings, whose communities prized their distinctive structures and histories. Yesterday, Councilmen Bill de Blasio and David Yassky, both of Brooklyn, and the borough president, Marty Markowitz, announced that the city had agreed to put the Degraw Street building up for lease for a community use to be determined. The City Council's land use subcommittee approved the deal and the potential sale of three of the other firehouses, with a provision that the buildings be used to benefit their communities. The fifth closed firehouse, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been approved for sale to the Henry Street Settlement for moderate-income housing. RAY RIVERA

It seemed like déjà vu all over again when John Rossant and his Italian wife, Antonella Caruso, stumbled on the 18th-century Château de Livry in Normandy. The couple had already bought and restored one dream weekend home, Casa Fizie, a rectangular stone house on five acres between the towns of Todi and Orvieto in Italy's Umbria region. In the mid-1990s, the couple spent about 18 months completely redesigning its interior and adding a pool and large garden, all with the help of Mr. Rossant's uncle, James Rossant, a New-York based architect.

Lindsay Lohan Sued By Photographer Lindsay Lohan, below, and her mother, Dina, have been sued by a freelance photographer who maintains that Ms. Lohan struck him with a car on March 13 on Ninth Avenue, between 12th and 13th Streets, in the West Village, The Associated Press reported yesterday. According to the lawsuit, the car, a BMW, was owned by Mrs. Lohan, but Ms. Lohan, 20, was driving it with her mother's permission. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court, the Bronx, where the photographer, Giovanni Arnold, lives, said he ''sustained severe and permanent personal injuries'' because the Lohans were ''negligent, careless and reckless.'' His lawyer, Marc Mauser, said that Mr. Arnold suffered injuries to both knees and was seeking unspecified monetary damages for pain, suffering and lost wages. He said Mr. Arnold was in front of the BMW when Ms. Lohan put it in reverse, then shifted to drive, throwing him on the hood and then to the ground. He said she stopped to check on Mr. Arnold before leaving. A lawyer for the Lohans was not immediately available for comment. Rocky Tosses in the Towel Sylvester Stallone, below, pleaded guilty yesterday to taking restricted muscle-building hormones into Australia, The Associated Press reported. In a letter to the Downing Center Local Court in Sydney, Mr. Stallone, star of the ''Rocky'' and ''Rambo'' movies, said: ''I made a terrible mistake, not because I was attempting to deceive anyone, but I was simply ignorant to your official rules. I feel terrible that my breach of your rules has set a poor example to members of the public, whose opinion I cherish dearly.'' Mr. Stallone did not appear in court. His plea was entered by his lawyers. He was accused of bringing banned substances into Australia after a customs search of his luggage on Feb. 16 turned up 48 vials of Jintropin, a human growth hormone product. The maximum penalty is a $91,500 fine and five years in prison, but Mr. Stallone faces a maximum penalty of $18,000 on each of the two charges because the case is being heard by a local, not a federal, court. Deputy Chief Magistrate Paul Cloran said Mr. Stallone would be sentenced on Monday. Tintin Goes Digital Stephen Spielberg and Peter Jackson will use the digital 3-D technique known as performance capture when they direct and produce three Tintin feature films for DreamWorks. Each filmmaker will direct one of the movies, but the studio would not say which of the two would direct the third, Variety.com reported. Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Jackson were described as longtime fans of Tintin, below, the beloved Belgian boy reporter and hero of comic strips and scores of books created by Georges Remi (1907-1983) under the pen name Hergé. Variety reported that WETA Digital, Mr. Jackson's special-effects house in New Zealand, had produced a 20-minute test reel. Mr. Spielberg said, ''We want Tintin's adventures to have the reality of a live-action film, and yet Peter and I felt that shooting them in a traditional live-action format would simply not honor the distinctive look of the characters and world that Hergé created.'' Fanny Rodwell, Hergé's widow and the president of Hergé Studios in Brussels, which sold the film rights to DreamWorks, said, ''We couldn't think of a better way to honor Hergé's legacy than this announcement within days of the 100th anniversary of his birth, May 22, 1907.''

Steve Tisch, one of the Giants' owners, said the team's October game against the Miami Dolphins in London -- the first N.F.L. regular-season game to be played outside North America -- would serve as a litmus test for the league's plan for more international games. The N.F.L. has recently floated the idea of adding a 17th regular-season game so that each team can play outside the United States. The league has also talked of playing the Super Bowl abroad. The ideas are so new, and their possible implementation so far down the road, that they haven't been discussed in depth, Tisch said.

To the Editor: Re ''Curing the System,'' by Atul Gawande (column, May 10): There is even a simpler system than the Massachusetts-style reform discussed by Dr. Gawande. That proposal introduces economic burdens for the new system while maintaining those of the old.

An article yesterday about the resignation of Paul J. McNulty, the deputy United States attorney general, misstated the given name of another Justice Department official, the former director of the executive office for United States attorneys, who left his job over the department's handling of the firings of several federal prosecutors. He is Michael A. Battle, not William.

In a season rich with contenders, ''Spring Awakening,'' a dark rock musical based on a 19th-century German play about sexually anguished teenagers, led the field yesterday with 11 Tony nominations, including chances at best musical and director and recognition for two actors. The show's move to Broadway had seemed an artistic gamble, but in the musical category it is followed by another Off Broadway transfer: ''Grey Gardens,'' about the eccentric Little and Big Edie Beales, which picked up 10 nods, including shots at best director and Tonys for two performers.

Amgen shares were battered again yesterday after Medicare proposed to sharply curtail reimbursement for the company's biggest selling product, the anemia drug Aranesp. Some analysts said the proposed restrictions, announced late Monday, could cut use of the drug by as much as half. But the Medicare effort is likely to face opposition from some doctors and patient groups, who say such drugs help cancer patients cope with chemotherapy.
To the Editor: Re ''The Curious Cook: The Five-Second Rule Explored, Or How Dirty Is That Bologna?'' (May 9):

Stars of the London production of Tom Stoppard's "Rock 'n' Roll" will reprise their roles when the prizewinning play opens on Broadway in the fall. Under the direction of Trevor Nunn, and with a cast including Brian Cox, Sinead Cusack, Rufus Sewell, Nicole Ansari and Alice Eve, the drama covers the yearsfrom 1968 to 1990 in Prague, where a rock band stirs resistance to the Communist regime, and in Cambridge, England, where love and death affect the family of a Marxist philosopher.

SHAPIRO--Doris Mintz, 89, of West Hartford, CT, died on Sunday evening, May 13, 2007 after a long illness. A lifelong reader and keen observer of American history and politics, Mrs. Shapiro worked as a librarian at Trinity College, Hartford, before retiring 28 years ago. She was married for 53 years to Isaac Shapiro, who died in 1995. Born in Hartford, she was the daughter of the late David and Rose (Marholin) Mintz. Mrs. Shapiro graduated from Hartford High School and received her bachelor's and master's degree from Mount Holyoke College. Her 1940 graduate thesis examined leadership of the American women's rights movement. After retirement, Mrs. Shapiro was a devoted volunteer at the Deborah Library of Congregation Beth Israel, in West Hartford. She is survived by her three daughters and their families: Joan and Franklin Green of New York City; Phyllis Shapiro and Partha Bagchi of Readington, NJ; and Ruth Shapiro and Bruce Frankel of Larchmont, NY. Mrs. Shapiro was a loving grandmother to her four grandchildren: Jeffrey Green and his wife, Amy von Sydow Green, Julia Green and her fiance Andy Shane, Max Frankel, and Alison Frankel and to her great-granddaughter, Kitty Silveria Green. $(6$)SHAPIRO--Doris Mintz. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Doris Mintz Shapiro, beloved mother of Joan Shapiro Green, whose involvement in UJA-Federation's Women's Executive Circle strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Joan and Franklin; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

To the Editor: Re ''The Witness Next Door'' (column, May 14): For some time now, Nicholas D. Kristof has been goading our collective conscience into doing something about Darfur. At first glance, our ability to sit and watch all of this unfold is incomprehensible. By now, it is pretty clear that nothing short of military intervention is going to have much effect.

Friedman, the dean of Pace's law school, will become interim president.
To the Editor: Re ''A Sweet So Sour: Kool-Aid Dills'' (May 9):

To the Editor: Re ''Addicted to L-U-V,'' by Nora Ephron (Op-Ed, May 13), is a fantastic boon to those of us who have struggled with Scrabble addiction. When I play Scrabble on the Internet, I lose all track of time. I promise myself I'll just play one game, and the next thing I know, the sun is coming up and my eyes are a shade of crimson.

The Fairway Markets have teamed up with the U.S.O. to assemble six gift packages for troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. The assortments called Mulberry Street on the Go (Genoa salami, roasted peppers, Parmigiano-Reggiano, Italian bread and more) and Bissle of New York on the Go (Hebrew National salami, mustard, rye bread, rugelach and so forth) are $69 each. Other packages are $20 to $60. Shipping is $14 if addressed to a specific person, free if in a general group shipment. The markets will donate all proceeds to the U.S.O. Orders may be placed at fairwaymarket.com.

A sports graphic yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Oscar Pistorius, a South African athlete who wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, carried incorrect renderings in some copies of the ''take-off'' phase of running. A corrected version can be found online. (nytimes.com/pages/sports/other/index.html)

Every summer, it's the same battle: Gardeners will try almost anything to keep nibbling wildlife out of their gardens. And for second homeowners, keeping prized gardens away from voracious critters can be a constant battle -- one fought with fences, stinky sprays and odd home concoctions. Tom Castronovo, the editor and publisher of The Gardener News, a monthly newspaper in Liberty Corner, N.J., says deer alone can cause extensive damage if given free rein. ''They can do tens of thousands of dollars in damage in the blink of an eye,'' he said.

STRASSMAN--Natalie Krieger on May 14, 2007, at 96 years young. Beloved wife of the late Solomon, devoted daughter and sister, wonderful mother, adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Survived by daughters and their husbands Judy and Eric Herbst, Toby and Harold Weinberger, grandchildren and their spouses James and Erica Weinberger, Karen Weinberger, Elisabeth and Emmanuel Buzay, Andrea and Jacques Paul, Seth Herbst, and greatgrandsons Eli and Nate Weinberger. She spent the last years of her life surrounded by the family she loved and that loved her so.

A French judge has ordered the designer John Galliano to pay 200,000 euros, or about $270,000, to the photographer William Klein, who filed a lawsuit earlier this year accusing Mr. Galliano of appropriating Mr. Klein's photographic style for a series of magazine ads. The judge, Claude Vallet, ruled that Mr. Galliano's ads, which ran in French Vogue and other magazines, too closely mimicked a technique Mr. Klein has used in which he paints vividly colored lines and circles on oversized contact sheets. Mr. Klein, in a telephone interview, said he was extremely happy with the decision, delivered at the end of March. ''I got a check a week later,'' he said. He added that he does not consider the use of his imagery to be a tribute to him, comparing such a suggestion to someone sleeping with another man's wife. ''Is that paying homage to your wife?'' he asked, laughing. A spokeswoman for Mr. Galliano in Paris declined yesterday to comment on the decision. RANDY KENNEDY

A Bronx man who opened fire at a crowded playground two years ago has been convicted of fatally shooting a 10-year-old girl during the attack, prosecutors said yesterday. Rene Bonilla, 22, was convicted of murder and attempted murder on Friday in State Supreme Court for killing the girl, Naisha Pearson, and wounding Leonardo D'Eaza, 19, during a Labor Day block party on Sept. 5, 2005. Prosecutors said that Mr. Bonilla went to the playground in Mott Haven to kill Mr. D'Eaza because Mr. D'Eaza had beaten him in front of Mr. Bonilla's girlfriend. After Mr. Bonilla started firing -- striking the girl once and hitting Mr. D'Eaza five times -- a crowd chased Mr. Bonilla to the roof of a building, where he was arrested, prosecutors said. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

HORSE RACING ANOTHER CANDIDATE FOR PREAKNESS -- While the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense had his final workout at Churchill Downs for the Preakness Stakes yesterday, the field expanded by one when the owners of Circular Quay, the Louisiana Derby champion, said he would be entered. It appears Street Sense will face eight challengers. The owners, Michael and Doreen Tabor, notified Pimlico Race Course officials yesterday that Circular Quay would try the mile-and-three-sixteenth route. Circular Quay finished sixth in the Derby, and is the second horse trained by Todd Pletcher to compete in the Preakness, the middle jewel of the Triple Crown. Pletcher will also saddle King of the Roxy, the Santa Anita Derby runner-up.

EPAND--Harold, 89, loving husband to Marjorie (Peggy) Crane Epand, passed away in Denver, Sunday May 13. The former President/Owner of Brite Electric Sales Corp in NYC, Harold, born January 23, 1918, served in WWII in England as Captain in the Army Air Corps. In 1946 he married Jacqueline Rosenberg and lived in Manhattan, Crestwood and Larchmont, NY before retiring to Rancho Mirage, CA. Jacqueline died in 1992 and in 1994 Harold married Peggy. Known for his selflessness, dry humor, intelligence, down-to-earth practicality and evolved wisdom, this man's man will be missed terribly by all who knew him. He is survived by his sister Rosemary Lentz, two sons and daughters-in-law, Raphael L. and Lorraine Epand of Raanana Israel and Leonard R. and Joan Epand of Old Greenwich, CT, and eight grandchildren. Additionally, he is survived by stepchildren Henry and Suzanne Crane, Cathy and Salvatore Trentalancia and David and Carla Crane and their seven children. Funeral: 1pm, May 16th, Parkside Chapel, Rego Park.
FRANKEL--Pauline. Dear life long friend, gone but not forgotten. Gladys and Monroe $(6$)FRANKEL--Pauline. Independent and elegant to the end. Admired forever. Love to our cousins. Laurie and Ellis
