To the Editor: With regard to last week's letter recommending olives as a classic ingredient in a classic martini: Sorry, but if we are talking martinis, it's either a twist of lemon or nothing. Olives, as my Tanqueray-drinking Dad taught me, are for the so-called ''vodka martini,'' a classic imposter. Susan Volchok New York
Boston WHAT: A two-bedroom condo

SHANER--Elizabeth B. (Carole) of Bronxville, NY, died on May 7, 2007. ''A Merry Heart Doeth Good Like A Medicine''. With these words Elizabeth Shaner embroidered her legacy in a needlepoint created as a thirteen year old in 1929. Throughout her life, she uplifted our hearts and expanded the creative possibilities of all who knew her, with gifts in art, music and dedication to the welfare of others. Born June 16, 1916 in Newport News, VA. Philadelphia College of Art, degree in graphic design. Columbia Teachers College, B.S. in Art Education. Her career spanned over 45 years, the first 10 as advertising designer and art director for various retail stores in Philadelphia, PA. Married in 1951 to Luther Shaner, Jr. she became a devoted wife and mother to a son, Jonathan. With the passing of her husband, she became a music library assistant with Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, NY in 1970. As a music librarian and later, as art exhibit coordinator of the main library, Mrs. Shaner focused her talents helping students and the community to become immersed in the worlds of classical music and fine art in a career spanning over thirty years with Sarah Lawrence. An accomplished musician (violin and viola) Mrs. Shaner performed with the Philadelphia Youth Orchestra, Westchester (NY) Symphony, the Sarah Lawrence Orchestra, and chamber music groups in Westchester County. Her lifelong commitment to giving included support of advocacy and civil rights, protecting the environment, and delivering medical and human services to people worldwide but also emphasized tireless support of friends and colleagues in times of need. Mrs. Shaner is survived by her son Jonathan of Framingham, MA. Services are private.
KLAPHOLTZ--Anne. March 22nd, 1902 to May 16, 1994. Remembered. Francene

The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has reached agreements with two more universities under which they will adopt a code of conduct governing relations they may have with student loan companies. Mr. Cuomo's office found that Drexel University, in Philadelphia, was due to receive more than $250,000 from a loan company. That money will now be distributed to students who borrowed from that lender, according to Mr. Cuomo's office. The investigation also found that Timothy Lehmann, the director of financial aid at Capella University, an online institution based in Minneapolis, received more than $12,000 as a consultant to one lender. Twenty-four colleges and universities have adopted Mr. Cuomo's code of conduct. JONATHAN D. GLATER

The About New York column on Saturday, about the relationship between the New York Yankees and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, misspelled the surname of a Yankees spokeswoman in some copies. She is Alice McGillion, not McGillon.

To the Editor: After reading what I believe were all of Frank Bruni's reviews for The New York Times, I couldn't help noticing that women chefs fared significantly less well than men. Clearly, there are fewer female chefs in restaurant kitchens, but under Mr. Bruni the ratio of women to men dramatically decreases as the stars handed out increase. In roughly 150 reviews, not one woman chef ever received three or four stars from Mr. Bruni, while in the lower orders -- the one- and no-star categories -- no less than 12 women chefs were cited. And though Mr. Bruni did award two female chefs with two stars (both outside of Manhattan), in both cases he failed (or forgot) to mention that the chef was a woman.

LATTIMER--John Kingsley, M.D., M.Sc. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Dr. John Kingsley Lattimer. Emeritus professor and chairman of the Department of Urology at Columbia University Medical Center and urologist-in-chief at NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital/Co lumbia from 1955 to 1980. Dr. Lattimer was a greatly influential and inspiring leader who was deeply committed to the care of patients, education of students, and advancement of urology. His contributions to the treatment of renal tuberculosis improved the lives of numerous children and adults worldwide. Under his direction, the Squier Urological Clinic developed into one of the nations top urological programs. A graduate of Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Dr. Lattimer served as president of the American Urological Association and the International Society of Urology. He is the author of several books on urologic and historic topics. Brilliant and charming, he will be much missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the entire Lattimer family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Lee Goldman, M.D. EVP and Dean Columbia University Medical Center $(6$)LATTIMER--John Kingsley, M.D. The Kidney and Urology Foundation mourns the passing of our esteemed friend. The tradition of the Lattimer Award in Urology will continue and his presence will be greatly missed. Shirley Baer Executive Director

Delta Airlines has provided new food options at Terminal 2 at Kennedy Airport. A Balducci's satellite, the store's first such outlet, has self-service units with salads and first-rate sandwiches (including smoked salmon on baguette and smoked chicken and avocado), as well as yogurts, small containers of seasoned couscous and cold Asian noodles, pastries and fruit. Balthazar croissants are sold, and breakfast egg specialties and hot pressed sandwiches can be ordered at the service counter. But on a recent morning a well-stuffed hot corned beef and pastrami sandwich that needed more mustard was not heated through. Salads and sandwiches are mostly $6.49 to $7.49. A Todd English Bonfire steakhouse is to open in the terminal next month.

A federal lawsuit was filed claiming violations of wage and overtime laws at a New Bedford leather company where an immigration raid took place in March. The suit asserts that workers were denied overtime pay and wages for unpaid time spent in the factory. The suit, filed by Greater Boston Legal Services, also asserts that employees who worked a shift for Michael Bianco clocked out for 15 minutes and then returned for a second shift working the same job, but for Front Line Defense, a company the suit says is headed by the wife and daughter of Michael Bianco's owner, Francesco Insolia. Mr. Insolia and his family could not be reached for comment. KATIE ZEZIMA

The Books of The Times review yesterday, about ''The Pesthouse,'' by Jim Crace, misstated the name of one character at several points. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Franklin, not Francis. The review also misspelled the surname of a writer who was described in the review as part of ''the crowning trio of living British writers,'' along with Mr. Crace and Barry Unsworth. He is Ian McEwan, not McEwen.

A state appeals court has dismissed a civil judgment against the Police Department that stemmed from a 1992 altercation between police officers and demonstrators in Orchard Beach, in the Bronx. The original verdict, in which a jury awarded $81 million to seven plaintiffs, was reduced by the trial judge in 2004 to $635,000, city officials said. In a ruling released yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court found that videotapes of the confrontation did not support the contention that the police had acted improperly. After reviewing the tapes, the judges said that the police were justified in their belief that the protest could escalate and that officers ''appropriately tried to quell a quickly unfolding, potentially explosive situation.'' Mark Kressner, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said they would appeal on the grounds that the trial jury made the correct decision after carefully reviewing the evidence. ''The jury had the opportunity to see those tapes over a three-week period in slow motion, with explanation of what occurred off camera,'' he said.

Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he hoped that Nicolas Sarkozy, who takes over as France's president today, would drop his opposition to Turkey's joining the European Union. Mr. Sarkozy, who argues that Turkey is culturally not a part of Europe and that most of its territory is in Asia, vehemently opposes Turkey's membership. ''This approach of Mr. Sarkozy comes from prejudices,'' Mr. Erdogan said, addressing a media conference in Istanbul. ''Mr. Sarkozy has to overcome these prejudices.'' Mr. Erdogan's remarks were the first to directly address the implications of Mr. Sarkozy's election for Turkey. ''Turkey's E.U. membership is the peace project of the 21st century,'' Mr. Erdogan said, ''an alliance of East and West.'' SABRINA TAVERNISE

This week, on my blog, I've been writing about the inventions I saw at last week's Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing. The grand prize ($25,000) went to something called the Enertia house, which was invented by an engineer and former log-home architect, Michael Sykes. It's a design for a home that heats and cools itself, with benefits both the homeowner and the environment.
To the Editor: Re ''Debate on Amputee Sprinter: Is He Disabled or Too-Abled?'' (front page, May 15):

GOOD--William D. 74, died May 13, 2007 after a long bout with cancer. He is survived by wife, Mary, his children: daughter Marybel and husband Denis Giblin, son Jonah and spouse Maria, and son John and former spouse, Vivian, as well as nine grandchildren, brother Robert and wife Mary Sue of Colorado, sister Cecilia and husband Ralph Sirico of Pennsylvania, along with numerous nieces, nephews, their children, and an incredibly large number of lifetime friends. Viewing Wednesday, 3:30-8:30pm at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10:30am. Born in Bronx, NY, Bill attended the local Catholic schools, and Cardinal Hayes H.S. where he was proud of his athletic experience on the track team. He served in the Korean War after high school, and was awarded the Silver Star, maintaining contact with his Marine Buddies over the years. Returning from service, he attended Iona College where he became a major part of the College Young Christian Students. Upon graduation he served as a Y.C.S. national leader for several years. After marriage, he and wife, Mary worked with the Edmundite Fathers in their Selma, Alabama mission for three plus years, working with the parish community and participating in Civil Rights activities. Returning to New York, Bill worked helping welfare mothers attain high school equivalency diplomas. He then worked at Payne Whitney Psychiatric Hospital, where he taught adolescents with emotional problems. Bill completed his work life at the NY Blood Center, where he claimed he never had one bad day at work in twenty three years. His inspiration for his life and work was his faith in Jesus Christ and his whole hearted desire to share in the mission of God. In lieu of flowers, Bill expressed that donations be sent to his parish on the Lower Eastside of Manhattan, the Church of St. Mary, 440 Grand Street, New York, NY 10002 or Cardinal Hayes Alumni Track Association, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx NY 10451.
To the Editor: Re ''House Panel Considering Cuts in Budget for Missile Defense'' (news article, May 10):

A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq.

Peppercorns' color palette has gotten brighter. Red ones, rarely seen outside India, are being imported, freeze-dried, by Bart Delicatessen, a company in Bristol, England. The most common black variety of peppercorn is the fully matured, oxidized dried berry of the Piper nigrum plant. White peppercorns are the same berry, with the outer hull removed in a water bath before drying. Milder green peppercorns are the immature berries, sold freeze-dried.

Despite competition from several season finales, ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' remained the show to beat on Monday, dominating from 8 to 9:30 p.m. with an average of 19.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates. Following the dancing competition, the second-to-last installment of ABC's ''Bachelor'' attracted a solid 10.9 million viewers from 9:30 to 11, helping ABC seal its lead for the night over all. Among adults 18 to 49, however, ABC's margin of victory was slim. ''Dancing With the Stars'' shared the title of highest-rated show in the demographic with NBC's ''Heroes'' at 9 (11.4 million) and CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' finale at 10 (16.4 million). The hourlong series finale of CBS's ''King of Queens'' trailed close behind with its best ratings among adults 18 to 49 since December 2004, drawing a total of 13.5 million viewers at 9. CBS finished second for the night. Its season finale broadcasts of ''How I Met Your Mother'' at 8 (7.8 million), followed by ''Two and a Half Men'' at 8:30 (10.1 million) ranked No. 2 in their time slots among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

THOMSON ACQUIRES REUTERS -- The Thomson Corporation's $17.2 billion acquisition of the Reuters Group was announced, a confirmation of Thomson's success turning an Ontario newspaper chain into a financial information powerhouse. [Page C1.] The trustees charged with overseeing the integrity and independence of the Reuters Group endorsed the sale, but some employees said they feared the quality of Reuters's journalism would be diminished. [C8.] PAY-RELATED PROPOSALS AT AMR -- There may be fireworks at today's annual meeting of shareholders of AMR, the parent of American Airlines. Four shareholder proposals, including two related to executive pay, will come up for a vote. [C1.] TYCO TO PAY INVESTORS $3 BILLION -- Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced. The settlement, described as the largest payment ever by a company in such litigation, comes after one of the nation's most notorious cases of fraud. [C1.] LIFE AFTER THE AIRLINE INDUSTRY -- Financial difficulties in airlines have taken a toll on many of the industry's longtime workers, who have begun to look elsewhere to revive their interest in going to work. [C1.] SIGNS OF A SLOWDOWN -- Businesses kept a lid on prices again last month, and wage gains were scant for most working Americans, signs consistent with an economy in the midst of a slowdown. [C3.] AMGEN SHARES TUMBLE -- Amgen shares were battered again after Medicare proposed to sharply curtail reimbursement for the company's biggest selling product, the anemia drug Aranesp. [C3.] MOTOROLA'S NEW MODELS -- Motorola is hoping to revive its business prospects with some slick new mobile phones, including a sequel to its hit Razr phone and a new keyboard-equipped messaging phone. [C3.] LOBBYIST TURNS ENFORCER -- A lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers nominated by President Bush to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission will receive a $150,000 departing payment from the association when he takes his new job, which involves enforcing consumer laws against members of the association. [A1.] MAKING TAX-FREE INCOME TAXABLE -- Congress is considering closing a loophole that allows nonprofit groups to avoid paying taxes on income earned through offshore hedge funds. Many universities, foundations and pension funds would be affected. [A15.] ABC'S FALL FORECAST: UPBEAT -- ABC this fall will replace darker, complicated series that viewers and advertisers disdained with more upbeat, accessible fare. Examples of the 12 new shows include ''Dirty Sexy Money,'' about an ''absurdly wealthy'' family in New York, and a sitcom (featuring Dash Mihok, above) based on the misunderstood cavemen characters from television commercials for Geico insurance. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C6.] CBS will follow its stated goal of taking its prime-time schedule in unexpected directions with fall series exploring unusual themes like vampires and singing casino workers. [E3.] 'OPIE AND ANTHONY' ARE SUSPENDED -- XM Radio, the satellite provider, imposed 30-day suspensions on the hosts known as Opie and Anthony after the pair participated in an on-air discussion that imagined sexual assaults on Condoleezza Rice and Laura Bush. [E2.] MARKETS GIVE BACK GAINS -- Wall Street gave up a huge advance and closed mixed after an unimpressive snapshot of the housing market unsettled investors. [C9.] TRIAL OVER 'SAHARA' ENDS -- A trial over the failed big-budget movie ''Sahara,'' pitting the novelist Clive Cussler against a production company, came to an end after three and a half months, but with an unsatisfying Hollywood ending: neither side truly won. [A14.] SEEKING A DEAL ON WOLFOWITZ -- The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door to him resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board dropped its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office. [A8.] BETTER FOOD INSPECTIONS -- More people and organizations are calling for an overhaul of the way the Food and Drug Administration inspects food, in the wake of a series of cases of food contamination over the past year. [F1.] BAD NEWS FROM 2 BIG RETAILERS -- Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot posted quarterly results that presented a troubled outlook for retailers. An article on Saturday about a speech by Rudolph W. Giuliani in Houston misstated the name of the academic institution where the speech took place. It is Houston Baptist University -- not Houston Baptist College, which changed its name in 1973.

BIRNBAUM--Robert, a loving husband, father, grandfather and cherished one of many, passed away on May 12, 2007. Bob was born in Brooklyn in 1938 and enjoyed life in Los Angeles, New York and Seattle with a loving family by his side. He was an accomplished TV producer, and touched the lives of all of his family and friends across the country. We will celebrate his great life and strong spirit on Wednesday, May 16, 2007 at 5pm at Riverside Memorial on 76th Street at Amsterdam in Manhattan.

An article last Wednesday about the James Beard Foundation awards misstated the status of the Manhattan restaurant Xing, which won an award for best restaurant design. It is open, at 785 Ninth Avenue (52nd Street); (646) 289-3010. It has not closed.

On the first Sunday of May, motorcyclists assemble on Main Street in Paterson, N.J., near the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. John the Baptist for the annual motorcycle Mass and blessing of the bikes. Msgr. Mark Giordani, a Harley-Davidson enthusiast who founded the Christian Riders motorcycle club, started the event in 1969 at his first parish, and he has been celebrating the Mass and blessing at the cathedral since 1987.

Periodically -- about twice a year, by my calculation -- someone tries to breathe new life into the movie musical by putting together a lavish song-and-dance spectacle like the ones they used to make, full of big numbers and bigger emotions. (See, most recently, ''Dreamgirls'' and, before too long, ''Hairspray.'') Against this trend, ''Once,'' a scrappy, heart-on-its-sleeve little movie directed by an Irishman named John Carney, makes a persuasive case that the real future of the genre may lie not in splashy grandeur but in modesty and understatement. Filmed with more efficiency than elegance on the streets of Dublin, Mr. Carney's movie, a favorite at Sundance earlier this year, does not look, sound or feel like a typical musical. It is realistic rather than fanciful, and the characters work patiently on the songs rather than bursting spontaneously into them. But its low-key affect and decidedly human scale endow ''Once'' with an easy, lovable charm that a flashier production could never have achieved. The formula is simple: two people, a few instruments, 88 minutes and not a single false note.

AS anyone with a hard-core shopping habit knows, there's a moment after you've zeroed in on your object of desire when all reason ebbs. It doesn't matter that those strappy sandals are a little too tight, a little too high-heeled and a lot too expensive. A euphoric cloud obscures common sense, especially if they're on sale. I can attain a similar state of mind while shopping for dinner, and recently I did. In the produce aisle was a basket of plump, velvety morels, the first of the season. They were spore-ishly seductive: their matte, furrowed skin was taut, their fragrance fresh and earthy, like a rainy walk in the woods. So what if the bill for the half pound I checked out with was $30? Their season is all too fleeting (from May to mid-June). And besides, I rationalized, cooking morels at home is cheaper than going out for them.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Shifts Tactics in Fight Against Afghan Drug Trade For years the Bush administration has ignored drug trafficking in Afghanistan, even as drug money financed the Taliban. Now that the United States has shifted resources to fight the drug trade, its efforts have been frustrated by corruption in the Afghan government and criticized as belated half-measures that are unlikely to have much impact. A1 Possible Wolfowitz Compromise The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door to his resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board drops its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office. A8 White House Names 'War Czar' The White House said President Bush ended his search for a so-called war czar to carry out Iraq and Afghanistan policy by offering the job to an active duty three-star Army general. A9 Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton said for the first time that they would support legislation to curtail major combat operations in Iraq by March 31, 2008, cutting off financing for all but a limited mission of American forces. A9 Newly declassified data shows that as additional American troops began streaming into Iraq in March and April, the number of attacks on civilians and security forces there stayed relatively steady. A10 Nazi Archive to Be Released Eleven countries that govern a closely guarded Nazi archive agreed to share electronic copies of the documents, a decision that could speed up access by historians to material about 17.5 million people who passed through concentration camps. Comey, testified that President Bush intervened in March 2004 to avert a crisis over the National Security Agency's domestic eavesdropping program. A1 New Set of Elite Schools A swath of 25 to 40 universities traditionally perceived as being a notch below the most elite, have seen their cachet climb because of the astonishingly competitive crush at the top. A1 Republican Candidates Debate The Republican presidential candidates met for a debate that showed them all maneuvering to emphasize their credentials on national security and as reliable conservatives. A17 Keeping the Faith Under Wraps Among the most popular religions to have flowered since the 1960s, Wicca -- a form of paganism -- still faces a struggle for acceptance, experts and Wiccans said. A12 Negotiating Immigration Bill With the new Congress poised to take its first vote on immigration, senators from both parties stepped up the pace of negotiations in hopes of cutting a deal on a bill that would increase enforcement at the border and offer legal status to undocumented workers. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Port Authority to Consider Making City Tolls Cashless Anthony E. Shorris, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the agency would consider financing a study to determine whether ending toll collections on the six New York City tunnels and bridges it operates would reduce traffic bottlenecks. He said the agency hoped to usher in a new pricing system. B1 Bono in Co-Op Dispute Bono, the lead singer of U2 and a globe-trotting activist for social causes, has become involved in a battle that may be as intractable as loan burdens in the developing world -- a Manhattan co-op dispute. A1 Overhauling Public Authorities Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the New York Legislature are negotiating legislation that could lead to the most significant overhaul of the state's public authorities in years, perhaps ever. C1 Tyco Settles Fraud Lawsuit Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced, helping put to rest one of the nation's most notorious cases of fraud. DETRE--Jean, died on May 5, 2007, in New York City, after a brief illness. Writer, world traveler, courageous spirit. Author of several books and articles, including A Most Extraordinary Pair: Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin, published by Doubleday, 1975. Member of PEN. Recipient of the Millay Colony award. Jean is survived by her sisters, Betty Kronsky and Ann Spruyt.

A listing of credits last Wednesday with a film review of ''Day Night Day Night'' included incorrect information from the film's distributor about several people who worked on the movie, and a correction in this space on Monday misstated the given name of one of the film's editors and misspelled her surname at one point. She is Julia Loktev, not Julie Lotkev. (Ohers working on the movie: Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor, who was an editor along with Ms. Loktev. Leslie Shatz was the sound designer, not an editor. And the production designer was Kelly McGehee -- not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.)

The former office administrator of the Interfaith Center of New York, a nonprofit educational organization, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $55,000 from the group by charging personal expenses to business credit cards, prosecutors said. Denyce Norment, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with grand larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, and she pleaded not guilty at her arraignment. Prosecutors said Ms. Norment charged personal expenses, including a cruise and tickets to a Beyoncé concert, to Interfaith credit cards from April 2000 until October 2004. The bills were discovered after Ms. Norment was laid off in 2004, Mr. Morgenthau said. Ms. Norment's lawyer, Frederica L. Miller, said yesterday that some of the charges were approved by Interfaith and that documentation concerning some of the bills was lost when the office changed locations. ''She is absolutely not guilty,'' she said. ''I am confident the charges will eventually be dismissed.''
DILL--Rita Cummins, died 50 years ago today. Adored and beloved mother, whose memory is forever in my heart. Peter L. Dill

The scenario presented to the 10 Republican presidential candidates was chilling: Three American shopping malls had been bombed, producing scores of casualties. Terrorists with detailed knowledge of another imminent and deadlier attack had been captured and taken to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The question: How far can the authorities go in interrogating the terrorists to get information to avert a fourth attack?

LAZARUS--Charles Y. died peacefully at his home in Columbus, Ohio on Monday, May 14, 2007. He lived a long and full life as a decorated veteran of WWII; a distinguished retailer; a community leader; an advisor to mayors, governors and presidents and a dedicated family man. A memorial service will be held in his honor on Friday, May 18, 2007 at Temple Israel.

The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the group's decision to exclude debt relief as a form of aid was ''factually unjustified.'' It said the debt relief it provided had helped African governments put more children in school and improve health. France, too, has disputed the organization's exclusion of debt relief. CELIA W. DUGGER

PHILLIPS--James McQuiggan. James (Jim) Phillips formerly of Scarsdale, New York and Point O' Woods, New York, died of colon cancer on May 13, 2007. He was 37 years old. Jim attended Scarsdale schools, graduated from Salisbury School in Connecticut and Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania. After graduation, he lived and worked in New York City and then moved to San Francisco in 1997. He was employed at Kensington Investment Group in Orinda, CA before his illness and lived in San Francisco. Jim was a surfer, a reader and a courageous young man in dealing with his disease. He is survived by his mother, Barbara Phillips of Walnut Creek, Ca, his sister, Julia Boszhardt of San Francisco as well as several aunts, uncles, cousins and a nephew Dillon. He will always be remembered as a loyal, caring person. Services will be held at The Church of St. Vincent de Paul in San Francisco on Wednesday, May 16th at 9:15 am. No flowers are allowed at the church. You may contribute to a charity of your choice.

BLACK--Daniel James,former chemical and pharmaceutical firm executive and U.S. Army veteran, died Friday in Manhasset, New York, from the complications associated with cancer and its treatment. He was 75. Born in Asbury Park, New Jersey in 1931, to Daniel Joseph Black and Julia B. (Palmer) Black, Black grew up in Brooklyn. His education at The Cooper Union and New York University, from which he received his B.S. degree in 1956, was interrupted by his enlistment in the U.S. Army, where he served three years as a sergeant in active duty in the Korean War. Black began his career in 1956 at commercial and municipal construction firm Frederick Snare Corp., where he was assistant to the treasurer. In 1960, he joined Carter-Wallace, Inc., a diversified healthcare company known for innovative products such as Arrid (the first aerosol deodorant) and Rise (the first pressurized shave cream). From his initial position as tax manager, Black rose to become, by the early 1970s, Carter-Wallace's President and Chief Operating Officer, the position he held until his retirement, in 1997. Under Black's long stewardship, the company originally known for 'Carter's Little Liver Pills', grew to join the Fortune 500 by the early 1990s. Daniel Black was a man of great intellect and intense curiosity. His pursuit of knowledge and understanding was unrelenting. Besides leading a successful business career, Dan Black was, at various points in his life, a recognized mineralogist, a voracious reader of history, a horticulturalist, a collector of rare books and fine art, and a golf enthusiast, among many other interests and avocations. He served on the board of trustees of Mount Holyoke College and on the board of overseers of the NYU Stern School of Business. But most importantly of all, Dan Black was devoted to, and adored, his wife of 48 years, Marilyn (Russo) Black, and his three children: Deborah of Mill Neck, New York; Daniel R. Black, of Port Washington, New York; and Peter F. Black, of Manhattan. He is survived by his wife, three children, and four grandchildren, who, together with the many friends whom he treasured, will hold him close to their hearts forever.

An article in Science Times yesterday about the construction of particle detectors under parts of France and Switzerland misstated the weights of the Atlas detector and the Eiffel Tower. Each one weighs about 7,000 tons, not pounds.

STEFFEN--Jonathan F., formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, died of a massive embolism following ankle reconstruction in Philadelphia, PA on April 15, 2007 shortly before his 37th birthday. He was born in North Tarrytown, New York on April 28, 1970 and was a graduate of Mamaroneck High School. Prior to forging a career as a tennis professional, he trained at the Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy and attended Monmouth University, where he was a two-time Northeast Conference A Flight Singles Champion, a four-time MVP and held the team record for alltime career victories. In 1994, he was the Number 4 ranked men's single player in the USTA's Eastern Region and held rankings in the top 20 throughout the 1990's. Throughout his career, Steffen was the head tennis professional at the Westchester based Joel Ross Tennis Academy, Beckwith Pointe Country Club, the former Eldorado Resort Club and Pelham Country Club. He was also the assistant tennis professional at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale. Earlier, he traveled cross country with a top 100 women's singles player, coaching her in the 1992 and 1993 U.S. Open tournaments. His love of the game was most obvious in his development of junior players. He infused many talented juniors with his passion for tennis, and stood out in his field for providing special consideration to families who faced financial inequities. Many of his students won tennis scholarships to top colleges and universities, playing Number 1 on their teams. Steffen was buried in a private family ceremony in Creve Coeur, MO on April 20, 2007. A private celebration honoring his joyful and generous spirit will be held in Westchester. He is survived by his mother Anne Steffen of Philadelphia; his father Fred Steffen of Chicago; his sister Sally Steffen and brother-in-law Geoffrey Herrera of Philadelphia; and his most beloved former wife, Irena Briganti, of New York. Donations in his memory can be sent to: The Jonathan F. Steffen Memorial Fund at Monmouth University, 400 Cedar Avenue, West Long Branch, NJ 07764.

To the Editor: Re ''Clean Power That Reaps a Whirlwind'' (''The Energy Challenge'' series, Business Day, May 9): There are problems with the Clean Development Mechanism, to be sure. The most troubling aspect of it is not that China has used it effectively, but that it has so far failed the countries, like those in Africa, that will be hardest hit by climate change.

A picture caption on Sunday with a sports article about the Nets' 96-85 playoff victory on Saturday against the Cleveland Cavaliers gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the player going up for a layup. He was Jason Kidd of the Nets, not his teammate Richard Jefferson.

An article on May 3 about plans to redevelop Pier 40 on the Hudson River into an entertainment complex misstated the year the pier was built as a commercial shipping terminal for the Holland America Line. It was 1963, not 1954.

Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said a resolution would be introduced this week calling on the Security Council to create a tribunal to judge the killers of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister who was assassinated in a Beirut car bombing in 2005. The action was in response to a request from Fouad Siniora, the current prime minister, whose government is locked in a struggle with pro-Syrian forces that are against an international court. A United Nations investigation has linked the assassination to the Syrian security services. Saying he endorsed the decision to act now, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said, ''I am of the view that there should be no impunity for the perpetrators of political assassinations.'' WARREN HOGE

MICHAELS--Audrey J. beloved mother of John Ehrlich, grandmother of Andrew, Adam and Matthew, passed away May 11, 2007. A lifelong New York resident, Audrey Michaels was a vital force in the classical music business in a prolific career spanning more than 60 years. The first copy girl in the music department at the New York Herald Tribune, working with Virgil Thomson and other distinguished critics. She then became Public Relations Director of the National Concert and Artists Corp (NCAC). In 1956 she moved to Columbia Artists Management as Director of PR, and in 1963 formed Audrey Michaels Public Relations, serving as its President until her death. She helped shape the careers of hundreds of internationally renown artists. Funeral services will be held on Thurs, May 17 at 11AM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

To the Editor: Re ''Only Halfway There'' (column, May 13): Thomas L. Friedman says that none of the current initiatives regarding moving to alternative energy go far enough (for example, Senator Christopher J. Dodd's call for a ''corporate carbon tax'' and Senator Barack Obama's call for tougher fuel economy standards). I agree.

The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about the vaccine for human papillomavirus, misstated a condition caused by two variants of the virus. They cause 90 percent of cases of genital warts, not genital herpes.

HUTCHINSON--Dorris J., Ph.D, Microbiologist, 88 years of age formerly of Bronxville on May 9, 2007. Dr. Hutchinson was a pioneer in cancer research at Sloane-Kettering Institute. She attended the University of Western Kentucky, received a scholarship to study Bacteriology at the University of Kentucky, and earned her Ph.D at Rutgers University. In 1951 Dr. Hutchinson received an appointment to Sloane-Kettering Institute, where she worked for 40 years. Memorial services will be held at the Reformed Church in Bronxville on June 2 at 10:30am and in Carrsville, KY on July 4 at 9:30am.

IF you grew up eating deviled eggs, they are probably a favorite comfort food, something you don't think too hard about. If, like me, you did not, they have an oddly exotic air and making them is a treat.

After worries of cutbacks due to financial problems, Opera Orchestra of New York announced a full season of three Carnegie Hall performances next season: Verdi's ''Due Foscari'' on Dec. 13, Bellini's ''Sonnambula'' on Feb. 27 and Puccini's ''Edgar'' on April 13. The company said it would also hold a gala on March 6 celebrating the 100th Opera Orchestra performance at Carnegie by its founder and music director, Eve Queler, and added that it would institute supertitles. Three months ago Ms. Queler said Opera Orchestra might have to cut back its season because of slow ticket sales and lagging fund-raising. The company is known for presenting rarities and young singers who go on to major careers. DANIEL J. WAKIN

THE spring obsession in Istria is wild asparagus. Throughout the peninsula, which juts into the Adriatic across from Venice -- just a ferry ride away -- people are walking through open fields and along roadsides, carrying the stout sticks they use to shove aside the brambles that hide the precious, knitting-needle-thin stalks. For many in this section of Croatia, any free nutrition is good nutrition. And for those who are better off it's simply a matter of getting the best food, directly from the land.

Back in 2002 when I was in the thick of conducting interviews with groups of mothers for my book "Perfect Madness," I began to think that it would be a great idea to turn the tables and interview groups of dads. After all, I was listening almost daily to mothers venting (in the nicest possible way) about their lazy, self-indulgent, oversexed, under-involved husbands; there had to be, I thought, another side to the story.

WASHINGTON - A favorite pastime of political scientists and pollsters is compiling lists of the best presidents. The results vary widely, as the judgments of history conflict with contemporary sentiments. Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and F.D.R. always finish high on the lists, with more controversial choices like Truman and Reagan often thrown in.

Augusta Souza Kappner, who has been president of the Bank Street College of Education since 1995, will step down at the end of the 2007-08 academic year.Dr. Kappner, known almost universally as Gussie, was the lone mayoral appointee on the Panel for Education Policy three years ago to vote against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to end social promotion -- and distributed research to other panel members showing that, despite their political popularity, policies requiring struggling student to repeat a year do not help their educational outcomes.

Bleary-eyed, the Mets reported to Shea Stadium this morning not long after they left. On his way in, Billy Wagner tapped Jason Vargas, today's starter, on the shoulder and said, "Eight and two-thirds" innings. Everyone, I'm sure, would agree with him.

Federal prosecutors may soon charge "a number" of current and former employees of prominent securities firms with taking part in a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to short sellers, according to BusinessWeek, which cites undisclosed sources. If they do, it could shed some light on a shadowy but profitable corner of Wall Street. BusinessWeek's Matthew Goldstein writes that the securities-lending business generates about $10 billion in fees for investment banks each year.

Unhappy with XM Radio's decision to suspend Opie and Anthony, fans are canceling subscriptions by the hundreds, smashing satellite radio receivers and posting tons of angry comments. There are also a reports of companies pulling ads.

This week, on my blog, I've been writing about the inventions I saw at last week's Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing.

Carried interest works in the venture capital business pretty much the same way it works in private equity. But as Congress reconsiders how this income source is taxed, venture capitalists are insisting that for them, it's a world apart. It's all part of an effort "to escape taxation," Adam Lashinsky writes in Fortune magazine.

Last year's record for global deal activity could be a short-lived one, if the predictions of a group of deal makers surveyed by Mergermarket turn out to be correct. Many of the bankers, buyout professionals and chief executives said in the survey that they expect to see continued strength in 2007 in both mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. In fact, more than half of the respondents are looking for another increase this year in M&A among large-cap companies. Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last year's. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

In the battle against global warming, there is no more beloved phrase in Washington than "energy efficiency." Mandating energy-efficient appliances costs nothing in the budget and sounds painless to voters. Who could be in favor of energy inefficiency? Congress is working on legislation now to tighten standards further -- and touting all the money that consumers will save.

A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore "strategic alternatives," 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didn't already own.
