But, in any case, please post your comments on my Thursday column about the way the U.S.'s position in the world community is beginning to resemble Wolfowitz's position at the World Bank.

TechTarget, a venture-backed company that produces technology-focused Web sites, magazines and conferences, priced its initial public offering late Wednesday at $13 per share, in the middle of the expected range. The 7.7-million-share offering, representing a stake of about 20 percent in the company, included 6.4 million new shares and 1.3 million sold by existing shareholders. The company said it expected to raise about $75.2 million in the stock sale.

I've been writing this week about the inspirational finalists in the Invent Now competition for amateur inventors. Turns out the second-prize winner ($10,000) was born, as so many inventions are, out of a real-world need.
The world’s second-largest marketing services provider will pay about $649 million for an Internet advertising company.

The cry from major league teams for pitching help has rarely seemed so full-throated. Out of necessity, teams must rely on journeymen and young, untested prospects - like the Mets did with Mike Pelfrey, now in the minors after going 0-5 with the big club. At PLAY, we were talking about how serious a problem the dearth of quality pitching is for Major League Baseball, and whether officials need to somehow address it.

Alliance Data Systems, which administers credit card programs for major retailers, said Thursday it agreed to be acquired by Blackstone Group in a deal it valued at $7.8 billion, including assumed debt. Blackstone will pay $81.75 in cash for each share of Alliance Data, about 30 percent more than the stock's Wednesday closing price. If approved by shareholders, the buyout would end Alliance's six-year run as a public company and put it back in the hands of a private equity firm. Alliance was formed in 1996 by Welsh Carson Anderson Stowe, which combined two businesses it bought from J.C. Penney and Limited Brands.

The costs of complying with Sarbanes-Oxley governance regulations dropped 23 percent last year to $2.9 million for big companies, the second large decline in a row, the Financial Times reported, citing a survey by Financial Executives International of 200 companies.

Blackstone Capital Partners said on Thursday it would buy Alliance Data Systems, a provider of transaction, credit and marketing services, for $7.8 billion including debt. It will pay $81.75 per share in cash, which it said was a premium of about 30 percent over Alliance Data's closing share price of $62.96 on May 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Images from "Ike Taiga and Tokuyama Gyokuran: Japanese Masters of the Brush" at the Philadelphia Museum.

The two Koreas took a long-planned step towards reconciliation today when trains crossed the demilitarized zone for the first time since the armistice that ended the fighting in the Korean War and created the zone in 1953.
Alliance, a provider of transaction, credit and marketing services, will be sold for $7.8 billion.
- Tobin Harshaw

It doesn't take a brilliant strategist to suggest that candidates try to gloss over unfavorable parts of their pasts, but "one of the striking features of the 2008 campaigns is the pungency of the various elephants in the various rooms" of the leading candidates, writes The Times's Mark Leibovich.
He's back.

Until recently, Marie-Josee Kravis, the economist, charity fund-raiser and wife of private equity bigwig Henry R. Kravis, and Conrad Black, the one-time chief of Hollinger International, on whose board Ms. Kravis once sat, pursued a similar path.

When Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal hits New York to check up on his Citigroup stake, he might have another investment to consider. The Telegraph reported Wednesday that Saudi billionaire was rumored to be making a takeover play for InterContinental Hotels Group, whose stately New York flagship, The New York Post notes, is just steps from the Park Avenue headquarters of Citigroup.

Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is also circling.

Chalet Edelweiss (above) is an exclusive new conversion of a lovely Swiss chalet situated in the picturesque resort of Château d'Oex. Originally constructed in 1999, the chalet has been converted to just five spacious apartments.

On Monday evening at Chrysler's offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of "Ask Dr. Z." Mr. Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, became famous last summer as that affable German fellow with a walrus mustache, who answered questions about cars on a Chrysler Web site.

DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday.

In the coming weeks, the Securities and Exchange Commission must decide a series of critical issues worth billions of dollars to the business community, from how far to cut back accounting rules to whether it should side with investment banks or shareholders in a Supreme Court case.
Bill Clinton talked to Andrew C. Revkin after announcing his new plan to fight climate change at the Large Cities Climate Summit in New York last May.
The Carlyle Group is planning to go head to head with European rival Permira Advisers for control of Valentino Fashion Group, the Italian company that controls Hugo Boss, according to Reuters.
It's war in the world of inkjet printers and cartridges as Kodak gets into the business.

Yet another group of hedge fund shareholders is on the move, this time urging Prudential Chief Officer Mark Tucker to break up Britain's second-biggest insurer. New Star Asset Management Group, Jupiter Asset Management and Canada Life of London, which together oversee about $91 billion, say Prudential's British division is dragging down faster-growing units in Asia and the United Sates. Earnings in Britain fell 7.9 percent in 2006, while profit in Asia jumped 20 percent, according to Bloomberg News.
Will more bidders emerge for Bausch & Lomb, the troubled eye care firm that said Wednesday it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from Warburg Pincus?

Carl C. Icahn has bought a $122 million stake in CSX, joining Warren Buffett and TCI Fund Management in purchasing railroad shares. Mr. Icahn held 2.68 million shares of Jacksonville, Fla.-based CSX, the nation's third-largest railroad, as of March 31, according to filings Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and hedge fund TCI also detailed their purchases in the industry, which they disclosed in the past month.

Wall Street's largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.
Belle International Holdings and shareholders raised HK$8.7 billion, or $1.1 billion, in the largest initial public offering abroad by a Chinese consumer company, according to Bloomberg News.

Boston Scientific is in talks to settle 1,350 product liability suits it inherited when it bought Guidant last year, the Wall Street Journal reported. The suits allege that Guidant sold several models of implantable defibrillators after learning of defects in the devices that caused them to fail, the paper said.

New Century Financial, the largest subprime lender in bankruptcy, received another offer for its loan-servicing unit that tops the initial $133.3 million bid by Carrington Capital Management, a lawyer said. Company attorney Suzzanne Uhland told Bankruptcy Court Judge Kevin J. Carey in Wilmington, Del., that the new offer makes it possible to hold an auction for the unit, considered New Century's most valuable asset.

General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks. And, according to The Flint Journal, Navistar International might be interested in a deal for the unit. "We are considering options for our medium-duty truck business to better position the unit for growth," a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, told Bloomberg News.

This is bound to be creating some buzz down on 85 Broad: John C. Whitehead, who retired as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs in 1984, called current compensation levels at the giant securities firm "shocking" and said he was "appalled" at Wall Street pay in general. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Mr. Whitehead, 85, urged his former employer to curb bonuses, even if it means losing some valued employees. "I would take the chance of losing a lot of them and let them see what happens when the hedge fund bubble, as I see it, ends," he told Bloomberg earlier this week.

Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission hit Canadian pharmaceutical company Biovail with a so-called Wells notice, the company's embattled founder, Eugene Melnyk, revealed Wednesday that he also received one.
The owner of New York's Plaza hotel announced plans Wednesday to buy the New Frontier hotel-casino on the Las Vegas Strip and replace it with a $5 billion multiuse complex.

J.P. Morgan's asset management joint venture in China announced on Wednesday that it had fired a senior fund manager who is under investigation by a Chinese regulator for allegedly manipulating share prices. China International Fund Management, which is 49 percent owned by J.P. Morgan Asset Management, said in a statement on Wednesday that it had dismissed Tang Jian, the manager of one of the company's main equity funds.

While the sums that angel investors typically provide to hopeful start-ups may be dwarfed by the investments that their later-stage colleagues drum up, their returns are far from bite-sized. In particular, one group of angel investors -- individuals who put up seed money for fledgling companies based on a smile and a shoeshine -- is seeing its numbers and importance growing.

Presidential contender John Edwards earned $479,512 in 2006 for his work advising Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm, and sold several million dollars in assets to personally invest in Fortress funds, according to personal financial disclosure forms released Wednesday by the Federal Election Commission.

The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan said it agreed to buy into two water supply and distribution companies in Chile, in what it called its first infrastructure investments in South America. Financial terms were not disclosed. Teachers' will acquire Aguas Nuevo Sur Maule and a 50 percent stake in Empresa de Servicios Sanitarios del Bio-Bio.

Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting on Wednesday two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay. The Allied Pilots Association had sponsored a resolution to give stockholders an advisory vote on executive compensation each year. Votes representing about 59 percent of AMR's shares went against the proposal.

Acxiom, a data-management company, is being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private, the chief executive of Acxiom, Charles D. Morgan, announced Wednesday. In a deal worth $2.25 billion, a partnership being formed by the equity firms ValueAct Capital and Silver Lake Partners will pay $27.10 a share in cash, Mr. Morgan said.

Walgreen said Wednesday that it planned to buy Take Care Health Systems, which operates in-store health clinics, as it moves to offer more patient services in its drugstores. The terms of the all-cash deal, which is expected to close next week, were not disclosed.

Green tech may capturing all the headlines in venture capital deals these days, but a broad renaissance in vaccine research and development is nonetheless capturing the attention (and cash) of V.C.'s and big-name charities like the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Following is the text of statements released by the World Bank’s executive directors and Paul D. Wolfowitz announcing his resignation.
Images from "Biographical Landscape: The Photography of Stephen Shore, 1969-79" at the International Center of Photography.
Taking a cue from the makers of TVs, washing machines and other products, Geisinger Health System in central Pennsylvania essentially guarantees its workmanship with a 90-day warranty.
Additional images from "Shrek the Third," including new characters.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Well, the Yankees won the nightcap, 8-1, and all is well again... for the moment. They're 18-20, and as Derek Jeter said, their next game starts "in about 45 minutes."

Although it is still early, grandmasters Ildar Ibragimov, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Stripunsky hold the lead in the Frank Berry United States Championship being played in Stillwater, Okla. Each player has two points after winning their second round games. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.
The second design in the presidential one-dollar coin series, featuring John Adams, is to be released Thursday by the United States Mint.
Paul D. Wolfowitz’s departure, which will occur on June 30, ended weeks of furor over charges of favoritism toward a bank employee who is his female companion.
Friends and critics wonder if Paul Wolfowitz’s tenure at the World Bank was doomed from the outset.
Senators Chuck Schumer and Dianne Feinstein said the attorney general is too weak to run the department.
Belarus, one of the world’s most repressive states, was outvoted in favor of Bosnia, a late entry.

SDEROT, Israel, May 17 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert paid an unannounced visit to this border town on Thursday night to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.
The president fervently defended the man who had stood by him more steadfastly than any other European leader.
The immigration-reform legislation would provide an opportunity “right away” for millions of illegal aliens to correct their status, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
A powerful thunderstorm that drenched much of the Northeast last night helped shrink a huge wildfire that has burned through 14,000 acres of pine forest in southern New Jersey since Tuesday.
France’s new president hopes the appointment  will smooth the introduction of his ambitious reform program.
The United States ambassador to Iraq said today that he was “ready to sit down” any time with Iranian officials for talks on ways of stabilizing Iraq.

The  Suns, hampered by suspensions to their top forwards, exploded at the opening tip of Game 5 against the San Antonio Spurs. But it wasn’t enough to overcome the absence of Amare Stoudemire and Boris Diaw.
Gordon Brown has emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Tony Blair as prime minister of Britain
Trains crossed the border between North and South Korea today for the first time in 56 years.
The airstrike today was a retaliation for rocket attacks on Israel fired by Palestinian militants in Gaza.
In his third game for the Mets, Jorge Sosa threw a gem, allowing one hit and one run in seven-plus innings after a rain delay of 3 hours 7 minutes.
Buyers at Christie’s last night made it the most successful sale of postwar and contemporary art ever.

Despite scoring only 6 points in the fourth quarter, the Nets still beat the Cavaliers and staved off elimination Wednesday night thanks to a brew of stout defense, good mojo and Cleveland’s own shooting woes.

Heavy thunderstorms across the region last night caused nearly 30,000 customers in Westchester County to lose power, Consolidated Edison officials said. The hardest-hit towns were Cortlandt, New Castle, Bedford, Ossining and Mount Vernon. In northern New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas reported that about 7,000 customers lost power.

A gun rights group said yesterday that it would double the number of guns it planned to give away at a raffle tonight to raise money for two Virginia gun shops being sued by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The group, the Virginia Citizens Defense League, made its announcement after officials in Fairfax County, Va., said the contest had to be modified to comply with state law. The league organized the “Bloomberg Gun Giveaway” raffle to poke a thumb in the eye of Mr. Bloomberg, who the league believes has unfairly taken aim at legitimate gun dealers. Mr. Bloomberg has called the giveaway’s organizers “sick people.” The raffle was originally open only to customers at the two stores, who received raffle tickets for every $100 they spent. But yesterday, the league opened the contest to anyone, as required by state law. The prizes — a Para-Ordnance handgun and a Browning A-Bolt Varmint Stalker rifle, each worth about $900 — are legitimate under state law, county officials said. New York officials have sued more than two dozen gun dealers in five states in an effort to reduce the flow of illegal guns.

An article in some copies yesterday about the debate by the 10 Republican presidential candidates at the University of South Carolina in Columbia referred incorrectly to support for the war in Iraq among the candidates. One of them, Representative Ron Paul of Texas, opposes it; they do not all support the war. The article also misidentified the home state of another candidate, Representative Tom Tancredo, in some copies. It is Colorado, not Arizona.
A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about plans for three Tintin movies misspelled the given name of one of the filmmakers. He is Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

A picture caption on Monday with a sports article about the reaction of a community in New Hampshire to the deaths of a police officer and a cousin of the ski racer Bode Miller in a violent confrontation misspelled the cousin’s given name. It was Liko Kenney, not Leko. The error also appeared in the article in some copies.
Corrections: For the Record

An article on Sunday about the extensive medical care that Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey received at Cooper University Hospital in Camden after a traffic accident on April 12 misstated the date of Mr. Corzine’s release in some copies. It was April 30, not May 1.

A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Monday, about the arrest of a man from Glen Cove, N.Y., on homicide charges in connection with a fatal six-car crash on Long Island, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the town where the crash occurred. It is Old Brookville, not Old Brookfield.

An article yesterday about the Maison Tropicale, a small house built in 1951 by the French designer Jean Prouvé that is on display in Long Island City, Queens, pending an auction in June, referred incorrectly to another Maison Tropicale at the Centre Pompidou in Paris. It is in fact already on exhibit; the exhibition is not pending.

A picture caption on Tuesday about clashes between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza referred incorrectly in some copies to the unidentified Palestinian shown standing in the burned offices of Fatah in Gaza City. The person is a woman.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about an investigation by Swiss authorities into a money laundering case linked to the military contractor BAE Systems referred incorrectly to a report in The Guardian, the British daily, about a Syrian financier, Wafic Said, a potential witness in the case who the newspaper said might have acted as a middleman for payments. The Guardian said the authorities “will be able to examine” the accounts of Mr. Said, not that they were already doing so.

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of an article about a decision by members of the Schalk family to find alternatives to their jobs as airline mechanics gave incorrect identifications in some copies for three Schalk brothers at a family get-together. They are from left: Glenn, Chuck Jr., and Greg.

A theater review in Weekend on Friday about “Couples,” a group of eight short plays at WorkShop Theater Company on West 36th Street in Manhattan, misidentified the actors in “Right Sensation” and misidentified a character. The actors are Jacqueline M. Raposo and Michael Anderson — not Cailin McDonald and Anthony Aibel, who appear in “Invisible Woman.” The character played by Ms. Raposo is Paula — not Susanne, a character in “Invisible Woman” that is played by Ms. McDonald.
An article in some copies yesterday about primary voting for mayor of Philadelphia misstated the last year the office was held by a Republican. It was 1952, not 1948.
The Acxiom Corporation s being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private.
tennis.
The Yankees are negotiating a buyout of the general partner Steve Swindal in which the team would pay him about $5 million in exchange for his leaving the organization.

A psychiatrist said yesterday that Peter Braunstein, a writer accused of sex abuse, was suicidal after his arrest. She said he told her he did not care how his trial turned out because he was going to kill himself anyway.
The current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.
Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and former Senator John Edwards both reported close to $30 million in assets.
Ford Models of Manhattan recently turned to the inelegant universe of untamed chat rooms, grainy photographs and fuzzy videos on YouTube to find two potential models.
Some New Yorkers are wondering about the new name for what used to be the Madison Square Garden theater.
The Word of Mouth Festival is a four-day event that includes theater, poetry and music.
In a new approach, citations from news reports, images and video will be combined in results of a single query.
The online store, to be introduced later this year, will allow people to play music on almost any personal device.
Forget the North Korean nuclear crisis. What has many South Koreans in an uproar these days is the “Toefl crisis.”
A hospital group is trying a radically new method to avoid costly mistakes, charging a flat fee that includes follow-up care.
James B. Comey, who testified about domestic spying, has made a great amount of trouble for the White House.
Paul D. Wolfowitz wants to be cleared of wrongdoing before he resigns as the World Bank’s president.
The board that oversees New Jersey’s pension investments is perilously close to not having enough members to conduct business.

President Néstor Kirchner threatened to crack down on private rail operators for failing to make upgrades after commuters frustrated by constant delays in train service to Buenos Aires’s poor suburbs set fire to parts of the city’s Constitución station on Tuesday, looted nearby shops and clashed with the police, who responded with rubber bullets and tear gas. The passengers’ anger came to a head in the evening rush hour when a train broke down on a track just outside the station, blocking other trains from leaving the station, which serves some 300,000 commuters daily. Buenos Aires area commuter rail lines were privatized in the 1990s, and passengers have complained for years about the failure of the new operators to provide timely service on often crowded routes.

President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev proposed limited political reforms in the oil-rich country he has headed since the Soviet era, including shortening future presidential terms to five years from seven and strengthening the powers of Parliament. The proposals are seen as part of Mr. Nazarbayev’s preparations for a power transfer in 2012, when his term ends and he is expected to leave office. Under his proposal, the president would have to seek lawmakers’ approval for his choice of a prime minister, who in turn would have the right to nominate ministers. He also proposed increasing the number of seats in the Parliament, with political parties having a bigger role.

A roadside bomb struck a convoy carrying African Union peacekeepers in Mogadishu, killing four Ugandan soldiers in one of the deadliest attacks on the peacekeeping force since it arrived in March, the authorities said. Uganda has about 1,400 soldiers in Somalia, officially as the vanguard of a larger African Union peacekeeping force although so far no other countries have sent reinforcements. Previously, one Ugandan soldier had been killed and four wounded in the government and Islamist fighting.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, cemented his bid to replace Tony Blair as Labor Party leader and prime minister when he steps down next month. Mr. Brown, left, the party’s overwhelming favorite, had faced the outside possibility of a symbolic challenge from John McDonnell, a leader of the left wing. Late yesterday, Mr. McDonnell conceded that he had been unable to muster sufficient backing from party lawmakers for his challenge, leaving Mr. Brown as the only candidate. The final tally of support for Mr. Brown among the Labor Party legislators is to be announced today.

A stalled train got a helpful nudge from hundreds of passengers after the engineer asked them to get out and push the train to the next electricity pole, 60 yards away. There the train was able to restart and resume its trip, a railway official said. The train, traveling between Banahi and Raghunathpur, stalled when an electrical connection snapped.

Nine defendants in the Madrid train-bombing trial began a hunger strike, joining four others who stopped eating last Thursday to protest the trial, the prison authority and a lawyer for the suspects said. Javier Gómez Bermúdez, the presiding judge, ejected two of the original hunger-strikers from the Madrid courtroom yesterday after they slumped to the floor, apparently weak from dehydration. He said he would authorize prison officials to force-feed them, if necessary. He added that the trial would “not be suspended under any circumstances.” The 13 men, mainly Moroccans, are among 29 suspects who have been on trial since Feb. 15 on charges connected to the bomb attacks on Madrid commuter trains that killed 191 people in 2004.
These Western Conference semifinals have been a conflict between innovation and tradition, youth and experience, and now, thanks to Robert Horry’s flagrant foul, good versus evil.
New shelters reflect an increasing awareness of the disproportionately high number of gay youths in the homeless population and the special problems they face.
The Jazz has survived a late-season slump that cost it homecourt advantage in the first round, won Game 7 on the road in Houston to advance, then beat the Warriors despite averaging 23 turnovers.
Hewlett-Packard’s effort to transform its personal computers into more stylish devices has started to pay off.
The decline of abortions in New York while Rudolph W. Giuliani was mayor mirrored a national trend.
President Hugo Chávez is redistributing his country’s farmland  in a process that is both brutal and legal.
Lino Urdaneta, a minor league pitcher who was on the Mets’ 25-man roster two days ago, tested positive for a performance-enhancing substance and was suspended for 50 games.
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays are playing a three-game series at the Disney’s Wide World of Sports complex in Orlando, Fla., with hopes of building a regional identity.

BUFFALO, May 16 — A 49-year-old factory worker pleaded guilty Wednesday to murdering three women, effectively closing a case that involved at least a dozen rapes dating back about a quarter century and the wrongful imprisonment of another man for more than two decades.
A suspected serial arsonist has unnerved Newport, R.I., which is part colonial village and part summer playground for the wealthy.
On a day of wide-ranging violence that underscored the grave security situation across much of Iraq, militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces fought openly.
The fire was the fourth time in the last eight years that military exercises near the Pine Barrens in southern New Jersey left residents feeling as if they live in a war zone.
Senators said that they were close to agreement on a new system of selecting immigrants that would give greater weight to education and to job skills.
At least 19 Palestinians were killed in fighting between Fatah and Hamas as rage rises on both sides.
The 67-to-29 vote demonstrated that a significant majority of senators remained unwilling to demand a withdrawal of forces.
The Bloomberg administration envisions the equivalent of five Empire State Buildings rising on the Far West Side.
Practical or not, a lot is riding on the outcome of a huge new particle accelerator nearing completion in Europe.
Merrill Lynch named two senior executives, adding them to the list of potential successors to the chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal.
The incident came amid heightened concern about the high number of civilian casualties in Afghanistan as NATO and American forces battle insurgents.
Military officials detained several local residents and recovered equipment that might have belonged to the missing American soldiers.
Frank Carulli, the odds maker for Pimlico Race Course, made Street Sense the 7-5 favorite in the morning line for the 132nd running of the Preakness Stakes.
If Zimbabwe is to brake its headlong descent into tyranny, the leaders of neighboring African countries will have to bring strong political and economic pressure.

General Electric is recalling 2.5 million dishwashers because of a wiring problem that could cause fires. The recall includes dishwashers sold under the brands Eterna, GE, GE Profile, GE Monogram, Hotpoint and Sears-Kenmore. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said consumers should stop using the devices immediately and contact the company for a free repair or a rebate toward a new dishwasher. For more information, visit www.geappliances.com or call (877) 607-6395 .

California’s $3 billion stem cell agency withstood a last-ditch legal challenge by abortion opponents and other critics when the State Supreme Court declined to review a lower court’s ruling that upheld the agency’s constitutionality. The decision clears the way for the agency, the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine, to dole out billions in research grants that had been held up by the litigation.

The state attorney general’s office will not file criminal charges against a former Congressional candidate whose campaign mailed letters to Hispanic immigrants warning that they could be deported or jailed for voting. The candidate, Tan Nguyen, was trying to unseat Representative Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat. Ms. Sanchez beat Mr. Nguyen, a Republican, to earn a sixth term representing the 47th Congressional District in Orange County. “We had to prove that they intended to intimidate lawfully registered voters,” said Gary Schons, a senior assistant attorney general. “We found no evidence that they intended to intimidate lawfully registered voters. In fact, the first line of the letter said, ‘If you’re a lawfully registered voter, we encourage you to vote.’ A lot of people missed that.”.

Two advocacy groups filed a federal lawsuit against a West Texas school district on behalf of eight parents who say a Bible course violates their religious liberty. The groups, the American Civil Liberties Union and the People for the American Way Foundation, sued the Ector County Independent School District in Odessa, asking it to stop teaching the course. The Ector school board approved the course, a high school elective, by a 4-to-2 vote in 2005.
More than half of high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts like the effect of the cotton gin on the slave economy or the causes of the Korean War.

Congress is fashioning bills that would explicitly outlaw collusion between lenders and schools while closing loopholes that the two have routinely used to enrich themselves at the expense of students.
Boone Pickens, the billionaire oilman, said his foundation would donate $100 million to two schools, but with serious conditions attached.
An agreement between New York State lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer broke a deadlock on an issue that many thought should have been resolved long ago.
Questions have been raised about how far Iraq’s new Shiite-dominated government can carry the process of holding Saddam Hussein-era officials to account.
The figure sheds further light on the extent to which Daimler seems willing to go to sell its American unit.

There are clues in the testimony of a former deputy attorney general and in earlier testimony by Alberto Gonzales that suggest that the president initially ordered broader surveillance than he and his aides have acknowledged.
The data offered a mixed picture of the economy’s health, but most economists are still expecting tepid growth.
Rudolph W. Giuliani’s campaign is gambling that security can trump social issues like abortion in the Republican primaries this year.
Revising the traditional system of measuring TV ratings is gaining urgency, as billions of dollars of commercial time are at stake.
Pennsylvania voters overwhelmingly rejected a plan to reduce property taxes in return for higher local income taxes as a way of financing school districts, officials said.
General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks.
Cole Hamels came up short in his bid for a perfect game, but the Philadelphia Phillies completed their season-long climb to .500.
Al Hurra has come under criticism from U.S. lawmakers for its broadcasting of views of leaders from militant Islamist groups.
Britain announced that Prince Harry would not, after all, be heading out with his regiment when it deploys to the Basra region in Iraq.

Mr. Frank was the public relations executive who in 1966 devised the strategy by which New York City’s police union turned back Mayor John V. Lindsay’s attempt to create a civilian complaint review board.
In becoming the No 1.-ranked player in women’s golf, Lorena Ochoa has often spoken about the need to sacrifice, as she did Tuesday at Montclair State University in New Jersey.

A report released yesterday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The report, based on a survey that department researchers conducted in 2005, found that stores in Harlem were half as likely to stock low-fat dairy products and seven times less likely to sell common vegetables, said Andrew Tucker, a Health Department spokesman. Mr. Tucker said city officials were working with store owners to encourage them to offer more healthful foods.

A Syracuse man was sentenced yesterday in Onondaga County Court to 20 years to life in prison for his seventh conviction on drunken-driving charges since 1982. “I don’t think there is anything I can do to protect the public from you and your conduct except to put you away for a long time,” Judge Joseph Fahey said as he sentenced the man, Ronald Daggett, 43. Mr. Daggett was convicted in February of riding a motorcycle while drunk and impaired by drugs in connection with a near collision with a minivan on a Syracuse street in September 2005. He was involved in an alcohol-related crash that killed another man in 1982 and was subsequently convicted in 1987, 1991, 1997 and 1999. Prosecutors said he was also convicted of a misdemeanor alcohol-related offense in 1983. His lawyer, Paul Carey, said Mr. Daggett was mentally ill and needed “intensive psychiatric treatment, not to be warehoused away in a prison cell for the rest of his life.”.

The Department of Education has placed a turbulent Bronx charter school on probation to address problems of teacher turnover, a department spokeswoman said yesterday. The International Leadership Charter School, a high school on Exterior Street in Kingsbridge, is under investigation by its trustees after complaints that resulted in a student walkout last week. Since the school opened in September, all eight of its original teachers have resigned or been fired. All have been replaced. The principal, Elaine Ruiz Lopez, was removed from management duties last week and is currently handling “long-term projects” like fund-raising, a school spokesman said. The Department of Education oversees 38 publicly financed but privately managed charter schools in the city. Twenty other charter schools are authorized by the state or the State University of New York.

The Rockland County Legislature voted unanimously on Tuesday night to ban smoking in private cars with children under 18. Dr. Jeffrey Oppenheim, president of the County Board of Health, said Rockland was the only county in the state to approve such a law. County Executive C. Scott Vanderhoef has 30 days to sign or veto the measure; so far he has not indicated a decision. Similar measures have been passed in Keyport, N.J., and Bangor, Me.

A Springfield Gardens man was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges that he robbed a clothing store on Monday and critically injured a security guard during the getaway, prosecutors said. The man, Philip J. Zabriskie, 53, of 133rd Avenue, was charged with first-degree robbery and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with robbing the Pretty Girl clothing store in Jamaica on Monday afternoon, Mr. Brown said. When Mr. Zabriskie and two accomplices tried to flee, a guard, Awali Khouroupra, tried to stop them by holding onto the hood of their minivan, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with knocking Mr. Khouroupra to the pavement as he drove off, causing a severe head injury. Mr. Khouroupra is on life support.

A former clerk at the State Motor Vehicle Commission office in East Orange has been sentenced to five years in state prison for selling drivers’ licenses to unauthorized people, Attorney General Stuart Rabner announced yesterday. The clerk, Lawrence McCross, 29, of East Orange, pleaded guilty last June to conspiring to commit official misconduct. He admitted to issuing about 25 licenses to people who did not present any of the required identification documents, for an average fee of $2,500.

The union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a contract deal with New York City. The new contract provides raises of more than 23 percent and also establishes a new executive principal position that will pay bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to principals who agree to work for up to three years in a troubled school. The union, the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, said that the ratification vote was 3,633 to 266. The deal, which is retroactive to July 1, 2003, and runs through March 5, 2010, will increase the starting salary of elementary school principals to $123,456 from $100,242. The maximum base pay for high school principals will rise to $154,295 from $125,282. Starting salaries for assistant principals who work all year rather than just the 10 months that schools are in session will rise to $108,869 from $88,398, and their maximum salary will be $130,100, up from $108,869.

Four people were killed in unrelated cases in less than 12 hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, the police said. The figure is unusually high for a year in which an average of less than one homicide per day has occurred, though Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly pointed out yesterday that “one day doesn’t make a trend.” In the first killing, Donnell McFarland, 18, of Brooklyn was shot in the head at 7:30 p.m. at the corner of Linden Street and Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, the police said; James Kelly, 16, of Linden Street has been arrested. In the second, a young man of 18 who was not identified by the police was shot in the back shortly before 11 p.m. on Tuesday in front of 570 Blake Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. Three hours later, Emrand Hossain, 19, of Queens was stabbed in the chest at the corner of 28th Street and Hoyt Avenue in Astoria. And shortly before 3 a.m., a man of 19 was shot on University Avenue in the Bronx. There were no arrests as of last evening.

The Rudin family has been selected as the developer for a site on Seventh Avenue owned and occupied by St. Vincent’s Hospital, which is relocating, hospital officials announced yesterday. Under the plan, the hospital will move from its current location, on Seventh Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets, to Seventh Avenue between 12th and 13th Streets, said Michael Fagan, a hospital spokesman. He said a modern hospital would replace the current collection of buildings. Once the new building is open, the current site will be redeveloped and the Rudins will pay St. Vincent’s an amount to be determined in part by the type of project approved by the city, Mr. Fagan said. He said the money would go toward the cost of the new hospital, estimated at $650 million.

It’s time for the N.B.A. draft lottery, when the dregs of the league gaze to the heavens — and watch the Ping-Pong balls flutter — in hope of a quick fix. For this go-round, coming on Tuesday, one question hovers over the proceedings: Greg Oden or Kevin Durant? A dominating big man or a perimeter wizard who can also excel inside?.

As they sweat and drip through a summer workout, few athletes fret about overdrinking. (They’re probably more concerned about parched shriveling.) But even in hot weather, some people develop hyponatremia — or water overload. During the London Marathon, held on an unseasonably warm day in April, the lone fatality was due to brain swelling from overdrinking.

Single-track mountain-biking trails have long been a fixture of the backwoods. But a push for trails closer to home has prompted municipalities like Seattle, Minneapolis, Pittsburgh, Tucson and Salt Lake City to legitimize the sport in parks within city limits. In New York, $100,000 in government financing built four miles of single-track path in Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, where a grand opening will be celebrated this Saturday. “The face of the sport is changing,” said Chris Bernhardt, a consultant with the International Mountain Bicycling Association. “Urban terrain is receiving more attention than traditional wilderness trails in some areas.” At Highbridge, New York City’s first legal mountain-biking area, twisting trails, jumps, banked turns and stunts occupy woods formerly famous for homeless encampments and used hypodermic needles.

On a nationally prominent team of 12-year-old baseball sensations, Jarrod Petree was the kid with the golden arm. When PLAY visited with him last year in Apopka, Fla., Jarrod and his travel-ball team, the Central Florida Express, were midway through what would be a stellar season, ending with 60 wins and just 6 losses. Jarrod would go 14-0 on the mound and hit .412. Yet the pile of victories was not enough to convince the overworked volunteer head coach, Ben Nichols, to take the Express into another year. The team dissolved last fall, but has been mostly reconstituted for 2007 under the leadership of Tim Petree, Jarrod’s dad, and Joe Winker, the father of a talented outfielder named Jesse, who is Jarrod’s best friend.

Bill Cosby, below, will be the host tonight when the Jazz Foundation of America holds its sixth annual benefit concert, ''A Great Night in Harlem,'' at the Apollo Theater. Dave Brubeck, Buddy Miles, New Orleans Mardi Gras Indian Chiefs, Dr. Billy Taylor, Gil Noble, Danny Glover, Roy Haynes and Paul Shaffer are among those appearing or performing. This year's show is a musical timeline of the art of jazz. ''It is the first time someone has done a history of the music in a long time in this kind of way,'' said Wendy Oxenhorn, executive director of the foundation. ''The show starts out with drumming in Africa.'' The concert proceeds benefit jazz and blues musicians who are in crisis, the foundation's mission for more than 18 years. Since Hurricane Katrina, the organization has aided more than 3,000 musicians and their families affected by that catastrophe. FELICIA R. LEE
An article in some copies yesterday about primary voting for mayor of Philadelphia misstated the last year the office was held by a Republican. It was 1952, not 1948.

Seven Grand, a new nightspot in downtown Los Angeles, borrowed its plaid carpet, toile wallpaper and taxidermy from Scottish and Irish whiskey culture. The imposing display cases that hold the liquor, though, were left behind by the long-gone Brock's Jewelry Emporium. Cedd Moses, the president of 213 Inc., which owns the building and its second-floor whiskey bar, credited the inspiration not just to ''an increased interest in whiskey'' at the company's other bars but to his desire to be a ''community catalyst'' for the downtown neighborhood. Ricki Kline is the bar's designer. Seven Grand, 515 West 7th Street, Los Angeles, (213) 614-0737, www.sevengrand.la. KATHRYN HARRIS

KOELZER--George J. Born March 21, 1938 in Orange, NJ passed peacefully on May 14, 2007. A prominent trial attorney, arbitrator, and mediator, he is well respected in courtrooms across the country. He tried hundreds of jury trials over more than 40 years as a member of the New York, New Jersey, and California bars. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Patricia A. Koelzer of Pasadena, CA, his son, James P. Koelzer of Los Angeles, CA.

Nine defendants in the Madrid train-bombing trial began a hunger strike, joining four others who stopped eating last Thursday to protest the trial, the prison authority and a lawyer for the suspects said. Javier Gómez Bermúdez, the presiding judge, ejected two of the original hunger-strikers from the Madrid courtroom yesterday after they slumped to the floor, apparently weak from dehydration. He said he would authorize prison officials to force-feed them, if necessary. He added that the trial would ''not be suspended under any circumstances.'' The 13 men, mainly Moroccans, are among 29 suspects who have been on trial since Feb. 15 on charges connected to the bomb attacks on Madrid commuter trains that killed 191 people in 2004. VICTORIA BURNETT

INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Wolfowitz Now Negotiating Terms for His Resignation After six weeks of combating efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began to negotiate the terms of his possible resignation, in return for the bank dropping or softening the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said. A1 Unity Fractures in Gaza Gaza City was shuttered and 19 Palestinians were killed as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments during fighting between Fatah and Hamas as their unity government continued to fracture. A1 Land Seizure in Venezuela President Hugo Chávez is carrying out what may become the largest forced land redistribution in Venezuela's history, building utopian farming villages for squatters, lavishing money on new cooperatives and sending army commando units to supervise seized estates. A8 Senate Rejects Bill on Iraq War Congressional Democratic leaders signaled they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring. A16 Four days into a manhunt for three American soldiers abducted in Yusufiya, Iraq, military officials said they had detained several residents who confessed to taking part in the attack and recovered equipment that might have belonged to the soldiers. A16 Prince Harry Kept From Iraq After weeks of speculation about the risks to him and the soldiers under his command, Britain announced that Prince Harry would not be heading out with his regiment when it deploys to the Basra region of Iraq. A17 NATIONAL A18-23 Exposure to Nerve Gas May Have Hurt Troops Scientists working with the Defense Department have found evidence that a low-level exposure to sarin nerve gas -- the kind experienced by more than 100,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 -- could have caused lasting brain damage in former service members. A20 Efforts to Cut Energy Use A coalition of 16 of the world's biggest cities, five banks, one former president and companies and groups that modernize aging buildings pledged to investments of billions of dollars to cut urban energy use and releases of gases linked to global warming. A18 Democrats Agree on Budget House and Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement on a $2.9 trillion budget for 2008 that envisions a return to budget surpluses by 2012 and assumes that some of President Bush's tax cuts will expire. A20 Shelters for Gay Youths A small number of shelters for gay youths have opened nationwide in the past four years, reflecting an increasing awareness among child welfare advocates of the disproportionately high number of gay youths in the homeless population and the special problems they face. A18 Racial Generation Gap Emerges With the number of nonwhite Americans above 100 million, demographers are identifying an emerging racial generation gap. A21 Students Improve in History Federal officials reported that students in 4th, 8th and 12th grade scored higher on an American history test than they did five years earlier, although more than half of high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts. Kelly said. B1 Pact on New Felonies New York State lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer said they had agreed to make sex and labor trafficking felonies, breaking a deadlock on an issue many thought should have been resolved long ago. Stealing a page from the Soviet playbook, the current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's turbulent final years as first lady? While Mrs. Clinton, a New York Democrat, frequently invokes husband Bill on the stump, she has managed to avoid any mention of his impeachment and the unpleasantness leading to it.

To the Editor: In ''We Try Harder (but What's the Point?)'' (Op-Ed, May 16), Michael Kinsley observes that the financial side of ''business'' is difficult to understand and leaves one wondering ''what the point is and why people who do it need to get paid so much.''

For a loyal George W. Bush Republican, James B. Comey has made a remarkable amount of trouble for the White House. As deputy attorney general in 2003, he appointed his old friend Patrick J. Fitzgerald as independent counsel in the C.I.A. leak case, leading to the perjury conviction of Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, I. Lewis Libby Jr.

RUMSEY--Charles Cary Jr., 1911-2007, died May 15, age 96. Husband of Mary and father of Charles, Peter, and Celia. Grandfather to Celia and Alita. Great-grandfather to Nicole, Kevin, and Dean. Charles was the son of Charles Cary Rumsey, the noted sculptor and polo player and Mary Harriman Rumsey, sister to Governor Averill Harriman. Attended St. Paul's School and graduated Harvard in 1934. Services to be held on Saturday, May 19 at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 9 Carlton Ave, Port Washington, NY 11050 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association, P.O. Box 11454, Alexandria, VA, 22312.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, cemented his bid to replace Tony Blair as Labor Party leader and prime minister when he steps down next month. Mr. Brown, left, the party's overwhelming favorite, had faced the outside possibility of a symbolic challenge from John McDonnell, a leader of the left wing. Late yesterday, Mr. McDonnell conceded that he had been unable to muster sufficient backing from party lawmakers for his challenge, leaving Mr. Brown as the only candidate. The final tally of support for Mr. Brown among the Labor Party legislators is to be announced today. ALAN COWELL

ABRAM--Michael R., 58, Loving husband, father, son, brother, friend and a sweet caring man. Family, friends, music and solving problems were the most important things in his life. Michael's greatest accomplishment was being a great father and his greatest joy was turning people on to good music. Michael's life was a celebration of all that he cared about. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Siegel, children Samuel and Elizabeth Abram, parents Irv and Blanche Abram, and Sage and Lenore Bassett, brothers David Abram and Tom Trouillot, sisters, Anne Marie Bracken and Rachel Abram Weiner, and his best friend Marvin Rosenberg.

LIPNER--Leon I. of Hollis Hills, NY born March 19, 1920, in Brooklyn, NY to Max and Esther Lipner died May 15, 2007. Graduate of Brooklyn College, MBA from Adelphi University. Merchant Marine officer in World War II. Beloved husband of Alice (Fein) for 67 years. Devoted father of Chester and Eileen and Marshall and Susan. Much loved grandfather of Marci and Colin, Kenneth and Lisa, Jay and Carol and Stephanie and Scott. Proud great-grandfather of Nicole, Ethan, Dylan, Mya, Rachel, Sydney, Emma and Madison. Certified Public Accountant since 1947 and respected founding partner of Lipner, Sofferman & Co., LLP where he practiced accounting for over 50 years. Emeritus Professor of Accounting and Taxation at Adelphi University. Member of New York State Society of CPA's and AICPA, Arbitrator/ Mediator with American Arbitration Association and NASD Board of Arbitrators. He was an unforgettable, generous personality, who enjoyed traveling the world with his beloved wife Alice. An avid tennis player and reader, he loved the New York Times crossword puzzles. He will be loved and missed forever. Services will be held Friday, May 18, 2007 at 12:00 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck, NY (opposite Great Neck train station). Contributions in his memory may be made to Jewish War Veterans of the U. S. A., National Headquarters, 1811 R Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20009 or to the Hospice Care Unit of the Margaret Tietz Nursing & Rehabilitation Center, 16411 Chapin Parkway, Jamaica, NY, 11432.

Stoppard's 'Rock 'n' Roll' Comes to Broadway Stars of the London production of Tom Stoppard's ''Rock 'n' Roll'' will reprise their roles when the prizewinning play opens on Broadway in the fall. Under the direction of Trevor Nunn, and with a cast including Brian Cox, Sinead Cusack, Rufus Sewell, Nicole Ansari and Alice Eve (right, with Ms. Cusack), the drama covers the yearsfrom 1968 to 1990 in Prague, where a rock band stirs resistance to the Communist regime, and in Cambridge, England, where love and death affect the family of a Marxist philosopher. The play will open at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater on Nov. 4, after previews beginning on Oct. 19. ''Rock 'n' Roll'' won the London Evening Standard and London Critics' Circle Theater Awards for best new play, and Mr. Sewell won the Olivier, London Evening Standard and London Critics' Circle Awards for his performance as a young academic who returns to his native Czechoslovakia and becomes a dissident. Mr. Stoppard's most recent Broadway production, ''The Coast of Utopia,'' received 10 Tony Award nominations this week. American Academy Honors The author John Updike, the sculptor Martin Puryear and Michael R. Bloomberg, mayor of New York, received special awards yesterday when the American Academy of Arts and Letters inducted nine new members. The 250-member academy gave Mr. Updike its gold medal for fiction and Mr. Puryear its gold medal for sculpture. The mayor was given an award for distinguished service to the arts. The nine new members included the artist Robert Irwin, the architect Billie Tsien, the writers Deborah Eisenberg, Mary Gordon, Allan Gurganus, Jim Harrison, Harper Lee and Annie Proulx and the composer Steven Stucky. Vandals Hit Sculpture Of Little Mermaid (Again) ''The Little Mermaid'' in Copenhagen has been attacked again, The Associated Press reported. A frequent target of vandals, the bronze statue created by the Danish sculptor Edvard Eriksen in tribute to Hans Christian Andersen was defaced for the second time since March. On Tuesday it was found with its face, left arm and lap doused with red paint. Next to the statue, a magnet for tourist photographers, a wooden picture frame was placed with green letters spelling ''av,'' Danish for ''ouch.'' The police said they did not know who had defaced ''The Little Mermaid'' or if the act was connected to overnight clashes between them and rock-throwing youths near Christiana, the city's bohemian district. Footnotes The documentary filmmaker Les Blank, below, has been chosen as the 48th MacDowell Medalist. He will be honored in a ceremony on Aug. 12 in Peterborough, N.H., at the MacDowell Colony, site of a renowned artist residency program. ''Stumbling on Happiness'' by the Harvard psychologist Daniel Gilbert won the $20,000 Royal Society Prize for Science Books, the BBC reported. Published by Knopf, the book is a best seller about the ways people try to make themselves happy. Professor Gilbert said, ''There are very few countries, including my own, the U.S., where a somewhat cheeky book about happiness could win a science prize -- but the British invented intellectual humor and have always understood that enlightenment and entertainment are natural friends.''

DAIL--James Russell ''Rusty'', 33, of Manhattan, formerly of Lovettsville, VA, died Friday, May 4, after a long battle with melanoma. Rusty is survived by his parents, Margaret Armstrong, of Waterford, VA, and James R. Dail, of Diamond Head, MS; his partner, Zengyan ''Yen'' Feng, of Manhattan; his paternal grandmother, Marie Dail, of Alexandria, VA; and numerous family and friends. Rusty graduated from Loudoun County High School in 1992. He spent his sophomore year of high school in the Orkney Islands, Scotland and his senior year in Kassel, Germany. Rusty held a B.S. in Systems Engineering from the University of Virginia (1996) and an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School (2002). Rusty traveled to over 50 countries, and lived in seven. He spoke six languages. After graduating from college, Rusty spent a year in the Peace Corps in West Africa, teaching mathematics. In 2002, after receiving his MBA, he moved to Seoul, Korea, where he worked as a Global Strategic Consultant for Samsung Electronics. A memorial service will be held Saturday at 11am, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, with reception following. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to Rusty's chosen charity, the Children's Cancer Research Fund.
DeLANEY--Irene Dolbear. November 20th, 1922May 17th, 1977. Thanks. The Delaney Family.

Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who just six years ago told a divorce court he had only $7,000 in assets under his control, has amassed a net worth of more than $30 million, much of it from paid speeches. Former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who has spent the last three years crusading against poverty, also reported about $30 million in assets. His income included nearly half a million dollars for advising an elite investment fund and $40,000 for directing a poverty studies program at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

EVENINGS on a patio or terrace or in the yard -- whether romantic or not -- are always more enjoyable with the appropriate lighting. Candles, lanterns and outdoor lamps are all good choices. But beware: Some kinds of lighting are not safe in some outdoor areas. (Candles are especially dangerous near dry wood, or when it is windy.) For those areas, there are battery-operated lanterns, as well as a new floor lamp that operates on solar power, providing enough light for hours of outdoor reading. 1. Big stone-shaped candles in slightly varying shapes and sizes; $25 to $50 from Takashimaya, 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street), (212) 350-0100. 2. White metal Chinese-style lanterns, which hold votive candles, come in 17-inch ($20) and 13-inch ($15) sizes; from Pier 1 Imports, (800) 245-4595 or pier1.com. 3. Battery-operated lanterns, with paper shades in cylinder, diamond and globe shapes, come in red and blue patterns and in white. They take four AA batteries each and run for about 15 hours; $16 each from potterybarn.com or (888) 779-5176. 4. Zoe, a six-foot-tall L.E.D. lamp for the garden or the patio, looks like a traditional floor lamp but operates on solar power, without wires or batteries. It can be staked into the ground and shines for up to seven hours after being charged by the sun for 11 hours; $2,100 at CITE, 131 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 431-7272. 5. A red metal lantern, which takes a single candle, hangs on a three-footed floor stand; $150 from the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (866) 755-9079 or www.conran.com. 6. The May Day candle is the size and shape of a flashlight; $18 at MoMA Design Store, (800) 447-6662 or momastore.org. 7. Red pepper-shaped candles are $15 to $20 each from Takashimaya, 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street), (212) 350-0100. 8. The Savannah chandelier, made of galvanized iron wire, holds six tapers. It can be used outdoors in a protected place; $79.95 from Crate and Barrel, (800) 967-6696 or crateandbarrel.com. 9. A birdhouse-shaped candle, which sits on a 19-inch-tall bamboo stake, is $10 from the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (866) 755-9079 or www.conran.com.

Since the inception of the National Design Awards program in 2000, when it was announced with much fanfare at the White House, the awards, overseen by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, have been a mixed bag. While it's nice to see designers like Morris Lapidus honored for their work, the awards have never become as prestigious as the Pritzker, known as architecture's Nobel Prize, and they have often seemed to lack focus. When last year's winners were announced, Bruce Nussbaum of Business Week finally said what many were thinking when he wrote on his blog that, as a tool for promoting innovation, ''the National Design Awards are a failure.'' Perhaps this year's jury, which included the irreverent architect James Wines, the downtown design fixture Stephen Burks and Caterina Fake, a founder of the photo-sharing site Flickr.com, got the message. Some of the winners announced on Tuesday were predictable: Antoine Predock, in the lifetime achievement category; Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates, in a category called design mind; Peter Walker, the World Trade Center Memorial landscape architect; the graphic designer Chip Kidd; Apple's Jonathan Ive, in the product design category; and Adobe Systems, for corporate achievement. But there were also a couple of surprises. Boston's experimental Office dA won the architectural design award, over a local favorite, Enrique Norten, and the Lower East Side architecture firm Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis (partners Paul Lewis, Marc Tsurumaki and David J. Lewis are shown above, from left, with their 2000 Geltner Loft project) won for interior design over the powerhouse David Rockwell. PHILIP NOBEL

A Springfield Gardens man was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges that he robbed a clothing store on Monday and critically injured a security guard during the getaway, prosecutors said. The man, Philip J. Zabriskie, 53, of 133rd Avenue, was charged with first-degree robbery and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with robbing the Pretty Girl clothing store in Jamaica on Monday afternoon, Mr. Brown said. When Mr. Zabriskie and two accomplices tried to flee, a guard, Awali Khouroupra, tried to stop them by holding onto the hood of their minivan, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with knocking Mr. Khouroupra to the pavement as he drove off, causing a severe head injury. Mr. Khouroupra is on life support.

BLAKELY--Dominique Alice, 19, of Pelham, NY, died on May 13, 2007. A 2005 graduate of Pelham Memorial High School, Dominique was a talented singer and actress who starred in many school plays and musicals. At Connecticut College she sang in the college's jazz band and performed with an a cappella group. In her brief life, Dominique made many friends and was at the center of a large family that will always remember her brightly burning spirit and loving heart. Dominique is survived by her mother, Nicole Browning, and her step-father, Steve Rifkin; her twin 17-year-old siblings, Elodie and Hunter; her father, Michael Blakely, and her loving grandparents, aunts, uncles, and cousins. A viewing will be held Thursday, May 17, from 6pm to 9pm at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home at 20 Cedar Street in Bronxville, NY. A service will be held Friday, May 18, at 4:30pm, at Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Avenue, in Pelham, NY.

An entry in the Skin Deep column last week, about ''Beauty on the Vine,'' a play about plastic surgery, referred incorrectly to an annual list of the celebrity features most in demand among the patients of Drs. Toby G. Mayer and Richard W. Fleming, surgeons in Beverly Hills. Jessica Alba's nose and Scarlett Johansson's lips were among this year's three most popular for each of those facial features; neither was the most popular.

THIS year's Kitchen and Bath Industry Show, held last week in Las Vegas, brought together more than 1,000 manufacturers from around the world, but the wares they showed were playing to very different audiences. Hundreds of small, independent Asian manufacturers turned up -- for the first time, a whole pavilion was formally dedicated to the Chinese -- offering components and products generally aimed at the lower end of the market, even when their styling suggested higher ambitions. The Taiwan company Justime, for example, offered modern, European-style bath and kitchen faucets for $25 to $150 (www.justime.com).

The Department of Education has placed a turbulent Bronx charter school on probation to address problems of teacher turnover, a department spokeswoman said yesterday. The International Leadership Charter School, a high school on Exterior Street in Kingsbridge, is under investigation by its trustees after complaints that resulted in a student walkout last week. Since the school opened in September, all eight of its original teachers have resigned or been fired. All have been replaced. The principal, Elaine Ruiz Lopez, was removed from management duties last week and is currently handling ''long-term projects'' like fund-raising, a school spokesman said. The Department of Education oversees 38 publicly financed but privately managed charter schools in the city. Twenty other charter schools are authorized by the state or the State University of New York. JULIE BOSMAN

The J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles has chosen three new board members with considerable experience in art and scholarship, signaling continuing efforts to restore the institution's reputation. Under the trust's previous president, Barry Munitz, the Getty's board had been criticized because few members had a background in art. The Getty's image has been damaged in recent years by a state investigation into its finances and a perception that it has strayed from its museum roots. The new members include Frances Daly Fergusson, the recently retired president of Vassar College, who is now an art professor there. Dr. Fergusson earned master's and doctoral degrees in art history at Harvard. The other new members are Paul LeClerc, the president of the New York Public Library, and Neil Leon Rudenstine, the former president of Harvard, who is now the chairman of ARTstor, a nonprofit organization that maintains digital archives for the study of art and other disciplines. RANDY KENNEDY

STERN--Sam, of Great Neck and Boca Raton died Wednesday, May 16th, 2007 at age 84. Survived by beloved family: wife Ruth, sons Eric and Fred, grandchildren Derek, Joanna, Candace and Jeremy. Burial Thursday, May 17th, at 1 PM, Mount Hebron, Flushing.

The Rudin family has been selected as the developer for a site on Seventh Avenue owned and occupied by St. Vincent's Hospital, which is relocating, hospital officials announced yesterday. Under the plan, the hospital will move from its current location, on Seventh Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets, to Seventh Avenue between 12th and 13th Streets, said Michael Fagan, a hospital spokesman. He said a modern hospital would replace the current collection of buildings. Once the new building is open, the current site will be redeveloped and the Rudins will pay St. Vincent's an amount to be determined in part by the type of project approved by the city, Mr. Fagan said. He said the money would go toward the cost of the new hospital, estimated at $650 million.

A report released yesterday by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The report, based on a survey that department researchers conducted in 2005, found that stores in Harlem were half as likely to stock low-fat dairy products and seven times less likely to sell common vegetables, said Andrew Tucker, a Health Department spokesman. Mr. Tucker said city officials were working with store owners to encourage them to offer more healthful foods.

For those who want to take a personal stand against climate change, Gaiam Real Goods of Broomfield, Colo., is offering the Global Warming Action Kit($99), above. It includes ''The Solar Living Sourcebook,'' by the company founder, John Schaeffer, and a showerhead that uses 1.4 gallons a minute instead of the typical 2.5 gallons. ''You're saving a gallon a minute,'' said Bill Giebler, the company director. ''Over a 10-minute shower, that's a lot of water.'' There is also a solar-powered flashlight, three 13-watt fluorescent bulbs, rechargeable batteries and a charger, a stainless steel water bottle and a solar-powered hat fan. For information: (800) 919-2400 or the parent company's Web site, gaiam.com. ELAINE LOUIE

PCs, like automobiles, can become something entirely different with just a few tweaks and additions. Take the Pioneer BDC-2202. Today your PC is just a DVD-playing, file-storing computer. Tomorrow, with the help of this Blu-ray drive, it becomes a high-def hot rod. This $300 drive, available next month, can both read and write Blu-ray discs along with standard DVDs and CDs. The BDC-2202 records BD-R discs -- standard writable discs -- at 5X (five times the speed of the first Blu-ray recorders) and writes double-layer Blu-ray discs at 2X. The drive also includes software that can record video from camcorders directly to DVD or Blu-ray discs.

An article yesterday about the Maison Tropicale, a small house built in 1951 by the French designer Jean Prouvé that is on display in Long Island City, Queens, pending an auction in June, referred incorrectly to another Maison Tropicale at the Centre Pompidou in Paris. It is in fact already on exhibit; the exhibition is not pending.
SEGAL--Harriet, of Teaneck, NJ, died May 15, 2007, age 85. Services Friday, May 18, 11:30am, Eden Memorial Chapels, Ft Lee. 888-700-3336.

The CW's seven-year old drama, ''Gilmore Girls,'' made its farewell on Tuesday, drawing its best ratings of the season in its target demographic of adults 18 to 34. Opposite Fox's ''American Idol'' at 8 p.m., ''Gilmore Girls,'' according to Nielsen's estimates, also ranked second in the hour in the 18-to-49 demographic, while finishing in last place in total viewers (4.8 million). By comparison, ''American Idol'' drew 23 million in the hour. Fox dominated the night over all, winning the 9 o'clock hour as well, with ''House'' (21.6 million), which actually posted the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC finished second for the night, as the ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show at 9, which eliminated Ian Ziering, earned its largest audience of the season (18.1 million). With Kenny Chesney collecting his third consecutive trophy for entertainer of the year, the broadcast of the ''42nd Annual Academy of Country Music Awards'' from 8 to 11 (9.2 million) put CBS in third, just ahead of NBC, which led the 10 o'clock hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (12.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

He had been cast as the warrior prince, the royal who, like a Shakespearean namesake, would lead his troops ''unto the breach'' of southern Iraq. But after weeks of speculation about the risks not just to him but also to soldiers under his command, Britain announced on Wednesday that Prince Harry, the 22-year-old third-in-line to the throne, would not, after all, be heading out with his regiment when it deploys to the Basra region.

Pressed and spotless, their uniforms hang neatly in the clubhouses at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium, but neither pitcher is there. Their lockers are as empty as the slots in their teams' rotations. And until Roger Clemens and Pedro Martínez each reappear, neither the Yankees nor the Mets will really know how high (or how low) they can go this season. In the Mets' success and the Yankees' struggle approaching their annual intramural inspection beginning tomorrow night at Shea, they continue to hold tryout camps for another starting pitcher. Hardly the ideal situation for two teams expected to be competing in October.

They are from left: Glenn, Chuck Jr., and Greg.

A week after its No. 2 debut on the Billboard chart, ''Call Me Irresponsible'' (Reprise) by the Sinatra-esque young crooner Michael Bublé has reached the top spot. Helped by Mother's Day shopping, it moved 145,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. With its first Top 10 hit in a decade (''I Tried''), Bone Thugs-n-Harmony opened at No. 2, selling 119,000 copies of ''Strength & Loyalty'' (Interscope), and Bobby Valentino, an R&B smoothie from Atlanta, sold 92,000 copies of his new ''Special Occasion'' (Island Def Jam), reaching No. 3. Barbra Streisand has her 29th Top 10 album with ''Streisand: Live in Concert 2006'' (Columbia), which opened at No. 7, and ''Volta'' (Elektra) gave Bjork her highest-opening chart position, at No. 9. Last week's best seller, Ne-Yo's ''Because of You'' (Def Jam), fell to No. 4 with 89,000 sales, a 65 percent decline. BEN SISARIO

A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Monday, about the arrest of a man from Glen Cove, N.Y., on homicide charges in connection with a fatal six-car crash on Long Island, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the town where the crash occurred. An article in some copies yesterday about the debate by the 10 Republican presidential candidates at the University of South Carolina in Columbia referred incorrectly to support for the war in Iraq among the candidates. One of them, Representative Ron Paul of Texas, opposes it; they do not all support the war. The article also misidentified the home state of another candidate, Representative Tom Tancredo, in some copies. It is Colorado, not Arizona.

Heavy thunderstorms across the region last night caused nearly 30,000 customers in Westchester County to lose power, Consolidated Edison officials said. The hardest-hit towns were Cortlandt, New Castle, Bedford, Ossining and Mount Vernon. In northern New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas reported that about 7,000 customers lost power. ALAN FEUER

FRIEDMAN--Naomi. Torah Fund and the faculty, students, and staff of The Jewish Theological Seminary all extend their deepest condolences to Cory Schneider on the death of her mother, Naomi Friedman. May her memory be for a blessing. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor-elect Gershon Kekst, Chairman

The union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a contract deal with New York City. The new contract provides raises of more than 23 percent and also establishes a new executive principal position that will pay bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to principals who agree to work for up to three years in a troubled school. The union, the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, said that the ratification vote was 3,633 to 266. The deal, which is retroactive to July 1, 2003, and runs through March 5, 2010, will increase the starting salary of elementary school principals to $123,456 from $100,242. The maximum base pay for high school principals will rise to $154,295 from $125,282. Starting salaries for assistant principals who work all year rather than just the 10 months that schools are in session will rise to $108,869 from $88,398, and their maximum salary will be $130,100, up from $108,869. DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

An article on Sunday about the extensive medical care that Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey received at Cooper University Hospital in Camden after a traffic accident on April 12 misstated the date of Mr. Corzine's release in some copies. It was April 30, not May 1.

MINKOFF--Walter, 81, on May 14 of pneumonia complicated by Parkinson's Disease. Served in WWII Army Airforce with his late twin brother Leonard, graduated Cornell University with a BS in Chemical Engineering and served as President of Peerless Paint & Varnish. Loving husband of Lois, devoted father of Rachelle, Burt, and the late Robert Minkoff, father-in-law of Robert Helfand and adored grandfather of Raphael. His integrity, insight and wit will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Memorial services will be held at Devonshire, Palm Beach Gardens. Contributions may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the Robert Minkoff Memorial Scholarship at Cornell University.
