In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his name to The Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City.
A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday about plans for three Tintin movies misspelled the given name of one of the filmmakers. He is Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

PHILLIPS--James McQuiggan. James (Jim) Phillips formerly of Scarsdale, New York, and Point O' Woods, New York, died of colon cancer on May 13, 2007. He was 37 years old. Jim attended Scarsdale schools, graduated from Salisbury School in Connecticut and Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania. After graduation, he lived and worked in New York City and then moved to San Francisco in 1997. He was employed at Kensington Investment Group in Orinda, CA, before his illness and lived in San Francisco. Jim was a surfer, a reader and a courageous young man in dealing with his disease. He is survived by his mother, Barbara Phillips of Walnut Creek, CA, his sister, Julia Boszhardt of San Francisco as well as several aunts, uncles, cousins and a nephew, Dillon. He will always be remembered as a loyal, caring person. Services were held at The Church of St. Vincent de Paul in San Francisco on Wednesday, May 16th. You may contribute to a charity of your choice.

Design on a Dime, a fund-raiser for Housing Works, the AIDS advocacy organization that runs thrift shops, will begin tonight with a benefit party that includes entertainment, a silent auction and shopping in room vignettes created by interior designers. (Tickets start at $150.) Those rooms will be open to the public tomorrow from 10 a.m to 7 p.m. and Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Everything in them -- new furniture, housewares and artwork -- will be for sale at reduced prices. The Bertoia chair, above, will be $240 (the list price is $800). Design on a Dime will be held at the Altman Building, 135 West 18th Street (7th Avenue), (212) 645-8111, ext. 164. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

IS a six-pack a six-pack if it is hidden under fat? Pilates mat work may strengthen core muscles, but the subtle moves that are often done lying down don't exactly burn a lot of calories. That's why many fans, myself included, supplement regular mat classes with cardiovascular exercise. How else to fit into skinny jeans? To hear Jonathan Urla tell it, Pilates devotees no longer need to squeeze in cardio sessions on the side. Just take Pilates Synergy Flow, his hourlong workout that offers the toning of Pilates bookended by a brisk warm-up and a chaser of squats, lunges and arm work done at a heart-thumping pace. Four props also make the mat work far tougher than when just body weight is used.

Four people were killed in unrelated cases in less than 12 hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, the police said. The figure is unusually high for a year in which an average of less than one homicide per day has occurred, though Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly pointed out yesterday that ''one day doesn't make a trend.'' In the first killing, Donnell McFarland, 18, of Brooklyn was shot in the head at 7:30 p.m. at the corner of Linden Street and Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, the police said; James Kelly, 16, of Linden Street has been arrested. In the second, a young man of 18 who was not identified by the police was shot in the back shortly before 11 p.m. on Tuesday in front of 570 Blake Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. Three hours later, Emrand Hossain, 19, of Queens was stabbed in the chest at the corner of 28th Street and Hoyt Avenue in Astoria. And shortly before 3 a.m., a man of 19 was shot on University Avenue in the Bronx. There were no arrests as of last evening. CARA BUCKLEY

In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in Elaine's name to the Caron Foundation, PO Box 150, Wernersville, PA 19565. www.caron.org

TESTAGROSSA--Robert J. Beloved brother of Albert, Margaret, Janet, Paul and the late Lawrence. Proud uncle of Nancy, Diane, Loretta, Roger, Amy, Sara, Francis, Paul, Tom, Catherine and special friend of many. T-Bird -free spirit. McLaughlin, 9620 3rd Ave, Bklyn, Friday May 18: 25, 7-9.

Hotel chic has reached a fever pitch, with shoppers buying napery and drapery from hotels like the Ritz-Carlton and the W. Now there is another way to bring the aesthetic experience home: The Four Seasons is offering flower-arranging classes to guests who want to achieve that certain hotel-lobby insouciance-in-an-urn. In New York, Dallas, London, Paris, Toronto and Costa Rica, flower-lovers can learn at the elbow of the head florist (like James Pitman, above, in the London hotel), using indigenous flora and techniques. (Prices start at $35 per person; 800-332 3442 for information.) Once you've mastered the art, you can festoon your front hall with bouquets, load up a luggage cart and dress your spouse in a uniform and bell cap. ELLEN TIEN

SCHLAEGER--Ralph, M.D., died March 13, 2007. He was a Radiologist at Presbyterian Hospital and Professor at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons for 51 years. In recent years he served as a consultant at Presbyterian Hospital and an esteemed Emeritus Professor of Clinical Radiology at Columbia University. Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, he received B.S. and M.D. degrees from the University of Wisconsin. After serving as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps he did post doctoral studies at the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine. A life long bachelor, he devoted his life to the practice and teaching of Radiology. He lived modestly, invested wisely and at his death bequeathed the bulk of his estate to The Ralph Schlaeger Charitable Foundation. His life will be celebrated at a Memorial Service to be held at 4:00 p.m., Friday, June 15, 2007 at the Pauline A. Hartford Memorial Chapel of the Columbia University Medical Center, 622 West 168th Street, in Manhattan.

MOST exercise classes are all about you and your body. Veterans and Rookies is about you and your child. This relaxed 90-minute class, one of the few parent-child workouts offered in the city, advertises itself as teaching ''proper techniques in skill development'' for ages 5 to 10. On the Sunday I was there with my 8-year-old daughter, Anya, the parent-child duos evenly split their time among the basketball court, the batting cage and the rock-climbing wall. Given the sports focus, it wasn't surprising that the other parents were all dads -- though a mom or two is known to participate, and there were a couple of daughters.
The presidential candidates Rudolph W. Giuliani and John Edwards reported assets in the $30 million range in personal financial disclosure forms. Page A23.

A theater review in Weekend on Friday about ''Couples,'' a group of eight short plays at WorkShop Theater Company on West 36th Street in Manhattan, misidentified the actors in ''Right Sensation'' and misidentified a character. The actors are Jacqueline M. Raposo and Michael Anderson -- not Cailin McDonald and Anthony Aibel, who appear in ''Invisible Woman.'' The character played by Ms. Raposo is Paula -- not Susanne, a character in ''Invisible Woman'' that is played by Ms. McDonald.

THE problem with most exercise classes is that right around 30 minutes the tedium sets in: Oh, joy, another right hook! This can be especially galling for those afflicted with Fitness Attention Deficit Disorder. Luckily, the folks at the Fitness Guru, a studio with about 300 members in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, have devised Bounce-n-Slide, a cross-training frenzy to combat the monotony. And it does.
To the Editor: Re ''Jerry Falwell, Moral Majority Founder, Dies at 73'' (front page, May 16):

A former clerk at the State Motor Vehicle Commission office in East Orange has been sentenced to five years in state prison for selling drivers' licenses to unauthorized people, Attorney General Stuart Rabner announced yesterday. The clerk, Lawrence McCross, 29, of East Orange, pleaded guilty last June to conspiring to commit official misconduct. He admitted to issuing about 25 licenses to people who did not present any of the required identification documents, for an average fee of $2,500. TINA KELLEY

SURGERY WITH A WARRANTY A hospital group in central Pennsylvania is trying a radically new way to improve its quality of care and avoid mistakes. Taking a cue from the makers of television sets, washing machines and other consumer products, it charges a flat fee that includes 90 days of follow-up treatment. [Page A1.] H.P.'S GROWTH IS LED BY DESIGN Hewlett-Packard's new PC strategy, to transform its personal computers from low-margin commodities into more stylish devices, has started to pay off and has become a major driver of growth for the company. [C1.] FREEING DIGITAL MUSIC Amazon.com is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple. [C1.] ZETSCHE ON THE CHRYSLER DEAL Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, said in an interview that the decision to sell Chrysler, which he led from 2000 to 2005, was ''emotionally a very tough process for me.'' [C1.] DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said. [C5.] QUARTERLY LOSS FOR SONY Sony posted its worst quarterly loss in four years, partly a result of a weak start for its new PlayStation 3 video game console. But officials of the Japanese electronics conglomerate painted a rosier picture for the current fiscal year, and predicted that strong television sales and hit movies like ''Spider-Man 3'' would put it back on course by year-end. [C5.] AMR PAY PROPOSALS VOTED DOWN Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay. [C5.] NEW YORK VS. DELL New York's attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, filed a lawsuit against Dell Inc. and its Dell Financial Services unit, accusing them of failing to provide adequate customer service. [C5.] COUCH POTATO 2.0 The dream of using a PC to bring the bounty of the Internet to the TV is slowly becoming a reality, but finding the right hardware for this convergence still requires some thought. [C9.] DUBAI STAKE IN DEUTSCHE BANK DIFC Investments, the investment arm of the Dubai International Financial Center, has become one of the largest shareholders in Deutsche Bank with a 2.2 percent stake, Dubai officials said. Omar bin Sulaiman, left, governor of the Dubai financial center, is trying to establish a financial hub in the Middle East on a par with London, Hong Kong and New York. [C6.] MEASURING TV AUDIENCES As the big broadcast networks complete a week of previews for Madison Avenue, the talk is not about new series, but about a new way of measuring audience ratings that takes into account people who watch on TiVos, iPods and other devices. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C7.] The Fox Network has ordered a new slate of programming intended to consolidate recent overall gains. [E3.] CHARLES GIBSON'S SECOND WIND Charles Gibson, the ABC newsman, had planned on retiring this year after a 32-year career. But last year he was unexpectedly handed the anchor job on ''World News Tonight,'' and he has helped turn that program into the most-watched of the three network newscasts, at least since Jan. 1. [E1.] Alexandra Wallace, the new executive producer of NBC's ''Nightly News,'' has been handed the job of reversing a slow, season-long exodus of viewers from Brian Williams's broadcast. [E1.] WOLFOWITZ IN TALKS TO RESIGN Paul D. Wolfowitz began to negotiate the terms under which he would resign as president of the World Bank, in return for the dropping or softening of the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said. [A1.] THIS SPACE AVAILABLE It is the largest building site left in Manhattan, 26 acres on the Far West Side, where the Bloomberg administration envisions the equivalent of five Empire State Buildings. Next month, some of the city's biggest developers will have a chance to bid for the rights to make that plan real. [A1.] INVESTORS FIND REASONS TO BUY Wall Street shot higher after investors reacted to a jump in industrial output, a retreat in crude oil prices and new cash pouring into the stock market. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES swung to a profit in the first quarter, but its adjusted earnings missed Wall Street estimates, and it lowered its earnings forecast for the second quarter. (AP) THE A.F.L.-C.I.O., the labor federation, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay approval of a proposed $4 billion public stock offering from the private equity firm, the Blackstone Group, and suggested that the firm be regulated as an investment company. (AP) DEERE & COMPANY'S fiscal second-quarter profit fell 16 percent, because of a one-time gain in the period a year ago, but income from continuing operations improved on strong international demand for farm machinery. (AP) WALGREEN said that it planned to buy Take Care Health Systems, which operates in-store health clinics, as it moves to offer more patient services in its drugstores. (REUTERS)

The M-Tel Masters is proving to be very competitive. Krishnan Sasikiran of India, who surged into the lead in round 7, was beaten in round 8 by the American Gata Kamsky. (The game can be replayed here.) Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania also won, beating Michael Adams of England. (Click here to replay the game.) So with two rounds to play, Sasikiran still leads with 4.5 out of 8, followed by Kamsky, Nisipeanu, Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria and Shakhriyar Mamedyarov of Azerbaijan, all with 4, and Adams with 3.5.

I am planning a photo safari to Kenya and am told I need vaccinations and malaria protection. My tour guide tells me to see my doctor; Condé Nast Traveler magazine tells me to see Johns Hopkins Travel Medicine; the Department of Health and Human Services refers me to Passport Health travel clinics; my doctor refers me to a Centers for Disease Control Web site (www.cdc.gov/travel) and tells me to look up a member of the International Society of Travel Medicine. Please help; there are too many choices.

Long before the immigration deal was announced on Thursday, candidates in the 2008 presidential field and indeed, the down-ballot field, had faced a lot of questions inside and outside the border states over the nation's policies.

The Economist this week offers a huge package on investment banks, tracing their history and all the "thrills and spills" along the way to the highly profitable present and the highly uncertain, risk-laden future. According to the magazine, while buyout firms and hedge funds are getting most of the attention, glory and money these days, investment bankers don't mind. When "bankers discuss the fabulous fortunes accruing to these firms' founders, they do so without envy," The Economist writes.

For all the talk about how hedge funds are raking in cash and earning double-digit returns all the time, it's helpful to remember that they can lose -- and lose big. Witness the letter that Jurg Buhler, managing director of Dighton Capital, recently sent to investors in his small ($34 million) fund registered in the Cayman Islands.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg faces huge hurdles in getting the State Legislature to go along with his congestion pricing proposal, but there were indications at a forum this morning that local officials are sympathetic to his position.

When United Auto Workers president Ron Gettelfinger annouced Monday that his union supported the sale of Chrysler to Cerberus Capital Management, it case caused whiplash for many industry observers. Before the deal was announced, the U.A.W. had publicly opposed selling the beleaguered auto maker to a buyout firm, citing the potential for waves of layoffs that may follow.
Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno spoke after Rudolph Giuliani and before Senator John McCain last night at a Manhattan fund-raiser for the state Republican Party.

Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland. But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so. That is part of the reason Friday's $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising. (The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)
Is the Ford Motor Company the "top pro-homosexual sponsor" on all of network television? That's what the American Family Association said this week.
A company that has made a business out of finding and picking over shipwrecks and then selling the booty announced today that it had a whole lot more booty to sell.

Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday -- just in time to cash in on the company's $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantive's options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google's $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive's call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.
I was never told that my apartment was stabilized and wasn't provided with any information as to why the rent was increased to $2,500. Do I have any options?

Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The "stub equity," as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channel's equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.

I described it in that blog post, where I also said that from time to time, Professor Kimes would fill me in - and I would in turn fill you in - on bits and pieces of what the survey was showing.

Microsoft said Friday it would buy aQuantive, an online advertising firm, for $66.50 a share in cash. The deal, valued at $6 billion, was easily Microsoft's largest acquisition ever and the price represented an eye-popping 85 percent premium to aQuantive's closing price Thursday.

At a news conference this week in Stuttgart, Germany, the usually secretive private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was in the spotlight, announcing an agreement to take control of Chrysler.

UniCredit, Italy's biggest bank, may be close to announcing plans to acquire a smaller competitor, Capitalia, Bloomberg News reported. Shares were halted for the day on Friday pending news, a Milan stock exchange spokeswoman said.

The struggling United States housing market is not the only thing worrying Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke. Speaking at a conference Thursday in Chicago, Mr. Bernanke sounded his first public warning about potential dangers for banks that are helping to finance the recent run of leveraged buyouts. Eager for the lucrative business brought by private equity deals, many banks have been going the extra mile to make loans on friendly terms.

Germany will make a last-ditch effort Friday to persuade the world's top economic powers to tighten their grip on hedge funds and private equity firms. But even before these countries' finance ministers convened at a Group of 8 meeting, the push was being written off as futile, illustrating Germany's isolation in its desire to rein in the booming industry.

After reining in Wall Street analysts, curbing mutual fund trading abuses and corralling some of the biggest insurance companies in the industry, what do you do for an encore? Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company controlled by Donald J. Trump, has received preliminary offers from possible buyers, although details on who the potential suitors might be were not disclosed.
“The Last Time” is a shapeless ode to corporate greed and business school aphorisms.
Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's former chairman and cigar-chomping pitchman, is not mincing words on what led to what he calls Chrysler's "desperation sale to Cerberus Capital Management."
As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

With indications pointing toward the European Union's likely approval of both the SonyBMG merger and the Universal Music Group's purchase of BMG Music Publishing, London-based EMI Group has moved into full sale mode, the New York Post reported citing unidentified sources.

Bankers at Citigroup may celebrate the latest Indian cross-border takeover with a few extra drams of Scotch. The bank played a leading role on both sides of the deal, the buyout of a 163-year-old Scottish distiller by one of India's most aggressive acquirers.

The Rio Tinto Group, a mining company that is a major producer of coal, will join BP to develop power generation plants that will pump their carbon dioxide emissions underground to help curb global warming. The companies said Thursday that Rio would pay BP $32 million for a 50 percent stake in a new company, to be called Hydrogen Energy. BP will fold its carbon capture and storage operations into the new entity.

The Bank of America, which expects to complete its $3.3 billion purchase of Charles Schwab's U.S. Trust private banking arm this fall. said Thursday that its private banking chief, Jane Magpiong, plans to leave the company.

Los Angeles-based KB Home said Thursday it was in exclusive talks to sell its controlling stake in a French homebuilder for 600 million euros ($813 million) to a European buyout shop. Moving quickly to sell an operation that is outperforming its activities in the United States, KB Home said it is in talks to sell the 49 percent stake in the French unit, Kaufman & Broad, for 55 euros a share to PAI Partners, a Paris-based private-equity firm.

A Syrian-born financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago said Thursday that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities.

A former marketing executive of the American-based food distribution unit of the Dutch food retailer Ahold was sentenced to seven years in prison by a federal judge yesterday for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud.

Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers have both experienced high-level departures in their hedge-fund-related businesses, the Financial News reported. The turnover comes as investment banks have been trying to capture more business from these private pools of capital. Bear Stearns's co-head of prime brokerage, Leonard Feder, left the firm for personal reasons, while Lehman lost Jin Park, deputy chief investment officer of its fund of hedge funds unit.

Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said Thursday. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline's annual meeting in October.

Motorola agreed to acquire closely held Modulus Video, a maker of video coding compression systems, for an undisclosed price. Motorola said the Modulus acquisition will complement the company's recent purchases of four other companies involved in the creation and delivery of "an integrated, end-to-end video delivery system for multiple network architectures."

SACI Falabella, the biggest operator of department-stores in Chile, agreed to buy a supermarket owner, Distribucion Y Servicio D&S, for $3.7 billion to form one of the biggest retailers in Latin America and to expand internationally.

The former chief executive of Atmel, George Perlegos, appears unlikely to win back control of his company on Friday when his plan to replace five board members goes before shareholders, according to The San Jose Mercury News.
The Federal Customs Service of Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.

General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabia's largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to press reports.

Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest consumer electronics maker, sold $2.56 billion of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing shares as part of a plan to shed its entire stake in the chipmaker within three years.

A Silicon Valley venture firm, Institutional Venture Partners, raised $600 million in the largest venture fund in its 26-year history, double the size of its previous fund, as it shifts its focus to late-stage investments.

Blackstone Group's proposed initial public offering has become a focal point for criticism, in part because its structure gives the impression that the private equity firm wants to have its cake and eat it, too, The Financial Times's Lex column writes. It seems to be pushing the boundaries in order to get favorable tax treatment while seeking to avoid undesired regulatory restraints. There are good reasons for the firm to go public, Lex writes, but the question is on what terms.

An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by "phantom votes," or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

A biopharmaceutical company, Amicus Therapeutics set its planned initial public offering on Thursday at 5 million shares for an estimated $14 to $16 each. Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, J.P. Morgan, Lazard Capital Markets, and Pacific Growth Equities are underwriting the I.P.O., according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Grupo Ferrovial, the Spanish builder that spent $19 billion buying the British airport operator BAA, is preparing to sell its 65 percent stake in Naples International Airport, Bloomberg News reported. Ferrovial this week asked investment banks to bid for a contract to handle the sale of the stake, which has a value of at least 300 million euros ($409 million), Bloomberg said.

The PIK Group, a Russian residential property developer, said on Friday it planned to raise up to $2.2 billion through an initial public offering in London and Moscow that would value the group at up to $14.1 billion. The I.P.O., which would be one of the largest to date by a European property developer, has been priced at between $25 and $31 a share.
“110 in the Shade” extends through July 29, and the New Group announces its 2007-8 season.
“Journey’s End” will close on June 10, “A Moon for the Misbegotten” recoups its investment and the Grinch finds a new home on Broadway.
What I'm wearing now, Gola sports shoes, Noko baby clothing and more.
ABC calls this show “high action” bingo. Actually it’s a high-concept attempt to low-ball the viewer.

Imaginative attacks ruled the day on the top boards at the Frank Berry United States Championship which is being played in Stillwater, Okla. Alexander Shabalov surged into the lead with his third straight victory, but only a half point behind sit a quartet of strong grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura, Alexander Onischuk, Jaan Ehlvest and Gregory Kaidanov. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.
There is a feeling of finality about “Shrek the Third,” a sense that the tale has at last reached a state of completion.
This small, sentimental “I remember” yarn, laced with vicious jolts, is a relocated “Bronx Tale” grounded in the same old macho shtick.
“Private Property” embraces the banal and the monstrous, and affords Isabelle Huppert opportunity to astonish rather than overwhelm.
“Even Money,” a scare movie about gambling addiction, is as grim and lurid as any in the recent spate of films about the evils of crystal meth.
Too lightheaded to qualify as satire, too poker-faced to register as comedy, “Fay Grim” belongs in its own stylistic niche: the Hal Hartley film.
Whether you like or loathe Bruno Dumont’s movies, his unsettling vision of humanity stripped of cultural finery feels profoundly truthful.
Venture capitalist: that’s the misleading job description preferred by the title character of the slight “Wendell Baker Story.”
Peter Godwin gives us a searing account of what has happened to the besieged and battered land of Zimbabwe in the last 30-odd years.
A crucial negotiating session ended with both sides expressing disappointment and accusing the other of being intractable.
A jury in State Supreme Court made the award to two people who said they were abused by a youth minister.
Estonian officials are declaring that their country is the first to fall victim to cyberwarfare.
A dozen opposition leaders and journalists were detained today, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests.
The Bush administration said it would bring management skills to the job of healing an institution battered by the turmoil over Paul D. Wolfowitz’s tenure.

The back-to-back votes in the House and Senate on plans put forward by liberal Democrats to bring the war in Iraq to a close by ordering a withdrawal of troops were both defeated but the results were something of a surprise.
A crude bomb exploded during Friday prayers at a 17th-century mosque in Hyderabad, a major city in southern India.
Fighting between Palestinian factions and rocket exchanges between Israel and Hamas continued today.

A federal judge set bail yesterday at more than $3 million for a couple accused of keeping two Indonesian women as prisoners for five years, beating them and paying them almost nothing. A court complaint alleged that the couple, Varsha Mahender Sabhnani and her husband, Mahender Murlidhar Sabhnani, who live in East Muttontown, kept the two women in their home as servants, barring them from leaving the house. The Sabhnanis were charged this week after one of the women was found wandering outside a doughnut shop wearing only pants and a towel. They have pleaded not guilty. The women, who arrived in the United States legally on B-1 visas in 2002, were being cared for at a hospital.
Works by the Conceptual sculptor David Hammons, Andy Warhol and Jeff Koons commanded high prices on Thursday at Phillips de Pury & Company.

Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline’s annual meeting in October, said Simon Rushton, a spokesman for Qantas. The buyout attempt, led by the Macquarie Bank and TPG, collapsed two weeks ago when investors rejected a cash offer of 5.45 Australian dollars a share as too low. The buyout group says it will not make another bid. Ms. Jackson joined the board in July 1992 and was appointed chairwoman in August 2000.

Bank of Montreal, stung by a huge loss from natural gas trading, said the debacle would cost at least 50 percent more than originally forecast and started an investigation into potential irregularities. Bank of Montreal said it would record pretax losses of 680 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from the trades, compared with an April 27 forecast of 350 million to 450 million Canadian dollars. Two New York-based bankers involved in the trades have left the firm. The bank said the losses were bigger than it originally forecast after it adopted a different pricing model to better assess the value of its natural gas options contracts. The revision also reflects “increased concerns” about the reliability of quotes from its main broker.

Mexico’s economy grew in the first quarter at its slowest rate in more than a year as construction fell and automobile output declined on slumping demand in the United States. Gross domestic product grew 2.6 percent from a year earlier, the government reported. A growth rate of less than 3 percent suggests Mexico is failing to reduce dependence on exports to the United States, the destination for about 80 percent of the country’s sales abroad. Last year’s 4.8 percent growth, Mexico’s fastest in six years, was driven by strong United States demand, while the weakening economy last quarter similarly tracked the United States slowdown.

Shares in Emap, a British magazine and radio company, jumped on speculation of a private equity interest after the company announced the resignation of its chief executive. Emap said that the executive, Tom Moloney, was leaving after four years by mutual agreement, and that the nonexecutive chairman, Alun Cathcart, had been appointed interim executive chairman until a permanent successor is appointed. Analysts have criticized Emap in recent years as the company, which publishes FHM, Zoo and Grazia magazines, has tried to raise revenue in a weak advertising market. Mr. Moloney conceded last year that Zoo was losing ground to a rival and that the men’s magazine market appeared increasingly close to saturation.
According to M.L.B., Lino Urdaneta’s suspension marked the Mets’ 11th positive test for banned drugs since the beginning 0f 2005.
Chancellor Joel I. Klein is challenging New York City’s public school principals to free themselves as much as possible from outside oversight under a new reorganization.
Two days after fleeing 20-foot flames that licked at their backyards, residents began returning to their mobile homes Thursday.
General Motors said its North American marketing and advertising chief, Mike Jackson, would leave the company June 15.

A sports article on Tuesday about the success of Yankees catcher Jorge Posada referred incorrectly to the career standing of the former catcher Tony Peña, the Yankees’ first-base coach, who spoke favorably about Posada’s potential longevity in baseball. Four catchers in major league history — not three — have spent more games behind the plate than Peña. (Iván Rodríguez of the Detroit Tigers passed Peña on the career list earlier this season; the others are Carlton Fisk, Bob Boone and Gary Carter.).
A music review in The Arts yesterday about Peter Gallagher’s nightclub debut, at Feinstein’s at the Regency, misstated the closing date of his engagement. It ends June 2, not tonight.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Thomson Corporation’s acquisition of the Reuters Group misspelled the name of the Ontario town where Thomson was founded. It is Timmins, not Timmons.

An article on Tuesday about a new branch of the New York Public Library on Jersey Street on the edge of SoHo referred imprecisely to the street. It runs from Mulberry Street past Lafayette Street to Crosby Street — not just from Mulberry to Lafayette, the block where the library is located.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitz’s who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Daniño, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitz’s who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Daniño, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a dispute over fireplace smoke at a Manhattan co-op, the San Remo, that involves Bono, the lead singer of U2, and another rocker, Billy Squier, gave an erroneous age in some copies for Mitch Miller, another resident and the host of the 1960s show “Sing Along With Mitch.” He is 95, not 96.

A “What’s on Tonight” television listing on May 5 about the film “The Day of the Jackal” misidentified the actor who played the French detective who pursues the Jackal. He was Michael Lonsdale (also known as Michel Lonsdale), not Terence Alexander, who played Lloyd in the film.
Three years ago after undergoing open-heart surgery, pitcher Kayleigh Lotti is leading Hofstra into the N.C.A.A. softball tournament.
Tyler Clippard was pulled after striking out the side in the first inning on Thursday for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, a strong indication that Clippard will start for the Yankees on Sunday
A New Jersey man arrested this week in a 2003 killing is wanted in another grisly death: the killing of a college student in Chicago nine days ago.
Paul D. Wolfowitz’s resignation, effective June 30, ended weeks of furor over charges of favoritism that blew up into a global fight over U.S. leadership.
The bill would offer legal status to most of the nation’s illegal immigrants while toughening border security.
Some see New Jersey as entitled to a bit of the glory that has come to the university.
China is facing international pressure to prove that its food exports are safe, weeks after a tainted pet food case.
At Floyd Landis’s arbitration hearing, Tour de France champion Greg LeMond said he had been sexually abused as a child and that the Landis camp had tried to use this fact to blackmail him.
John W. Snow, former Treasury secretary, is one of the latest politicians hired by private equity for their government connections and skills.

The construction budget for the first phase of the Second Avenue subway crept over $4 billion this month after the Federal Transit Administration asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to add $160 million to a reserve fund for unexpected costs. At the request of the federal agency, the authority also pushed back its projected completion date for the long-awaited subway project to 2014 from 2013. The revised budget and timeline were included in material distributed to the authority’s board members this week. The changes came about in response to a risk assessment of the construction costs and schedule prepared by the federal agency. The federal government is expected to provide $1.3 billion in financing.
A judge Thursday dismissed a lawsuit filed by tenants challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project, saying they had filed their suit in the wrong court.
The long-delayed demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building across from ground zero suffered another setback with the incident.

New York City’s unemployment rate edged up to 4.4 percent in April, from 4.3 percent in March, the state’s Department of Labor reported yesterday. The city’s jobless rate, which is adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, was lower than the national rate of 4.5 percent but higher than the rate for the rest of the state, which was 4.1 percent. Statewide, the number of private-sector jobs declined for the first time since July, dipping by 7,900, or 0.1 percent, to 7.18 million.

Three funeral home directors and four former employees of a defunct biomedical supply company removed skin, bone and other body parts from dozens of corpses awaiting cremation at Rochester funeral homes, prosecutors said yesterday. An indictment unsealed yesterday charged the seven with body stealing and unlawful dissection. Parts were illegally removed from 36 bodies in the Rochester area, said Michael Green, the Monroe County district attorney.

The chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Anthony R. Coscia, called on his agency yesterday to reduce carbon emissions at its ports and airports by 80 percent over the long term. That goal, he said, could be met by using geothermal energy to heat and cool buildings, installing fuel cells and harnessing wind and solar energy. Equipment used to service aircraft at airports could use electricity and alternative fuels. The strategy, said Mr. Coscia, above, would help reduce global warming and benefit the renewable energy industry.

A Bronx man was shot and stabbed to death yesterday outside a restaurant he owned, the police said. The man, Douglas Mills, 36, was killed about 2:30 p.m. outside the D&R Jamaican and American Restaurant at Morris Avenue and East 151st Street. The police said they did not know what led to the killing, adding that an investigation was under way. John Mills, Mr. Mills’s father, said his son was one of 17 siblings, only 12 of whom are still alive. “People raise their kids so they can take care of you when you’re old, not so you can take care of them and bury them,” he said.
The $11 billion deal would sell G.E.’s unit to Saudi Arabia’s largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation.

A woman praying in the chapel of a Catholic church drove off an attacker early Wednesday by stabbing him in the neck with a pen, the police said yesterday. The woman, 58, was praying at St. Joseph’s Church in Middletown just after midnight when a man reached into her shirt, said Chief Matthew Byrne of the Middletown police. The woman, who was not named by the police, had been writing in a journal and used her pen to stab him. The man fled, the police said.

A pedestrian suffered minor injuries in Midtown yesterday morning when she fell through a sidewalk grate and into a transformer vault 10 feet below, fire officials said. The woman, whose name was not released, fell through a heavy steel mesh lid, on West 51st Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, about 7 a.m., fire officials said. Two firefighters rescued the woman, who was not in danger of electrocution, said Craig Mosia, a Fire Department spokesman. Con Ed was investigating. Normally, “you need a very heavy tool” to open the grate, said Chris Olert, a Con Ed spokesman.

A 70-year-old man was found dead in his Murray Hill apartment Wednesday, having suffered blunt trauma to the head and compression of the neck, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner, said yesterday. The man, identified by the police as Jose Prieto, though neighbors knew him as Raul, was a retired graphic designer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and had lived in the building on East 35th Street for more than 30 years. The police said the death was under investigation.
Senate Democrats arranged to hold a no-confidence vote on the attorney general as early as next week.

The United States Military Academy at West Point, the City of New York and 74 other municipalities, organizations and corporations in the region have agreed to pay nearly $5 million to help clean up hazardous waste in an Orange County landfill. The agreement was part of a consent decree filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and announced yesterday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Orange County operated the landfill, situated on 300 acres in Goshen, from 1974 to 1992. The landfill was declared a hazardous waste site and was capped in the late 1990s under an agreement with the state in which those responsible for disposing of the waste would eventually help pay for the cleanup. The defendants agreed to contribute toward the cleanup costs, even though they deny wrongdoing.
About a half-dozen universities are giving alumni and faculty the opportunity to have their ashes maintained on campus.
The routine of ordinary life in a Bronx home is a stark counterpoint to the fiery catastrophe that hit a family.
Texas lawmakers are on the verge of rejecting a requirement that state and local governments disclose the cost of the health care they have promised to retired employees.
François Fillon is a close confidant of Nicolas Sarkozy and has a strong record of promoting economic change and successful negotiations with unions.
Steep increases in the cost of fuel, food and power drove up the rate, according to the Central Statistical Office.
Emerging from 17 days in the jungle after fleeing from guerrillas, Jhon Frank Pinchao, a police officer, stunned Colombians with his tale of escape.
It was the bloodiest gunfight in President Felipe Calderón’s five-month offensive against drug cartels.

The police arrested Khaled el-Masri, the German citizen of Lebanese descent who says he was subjected to the Central Intelligence Agency’s practice of extraordinary rendition, on suspicion of setting a fire at a market in the Bavarian town of Neu-Ulm that caused an estimated $675,000 in damage, his lawyer said. A judge ordered him held in the psychiatric ward of a local hospital. The lawyer, Manfred Gnjidic, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Masri, who says he was seized while on vacation in Macedonia in 2003 and flown to Afghanistan, where he was questioned about ties to terrorist groups and beaten, had had a dispute with the store and that his action was a result of not having received the psychological counseling he had sought. “I have asked several times from the beginning for psychological help, but without any luck,” Mr. Gnjidic said. “The very ironic thing is that he will get psychological help now, after he committed a crime, and as a torture victim didn’t get it before, when he asked for it.”.

Budhia Singh, the 5-year-old whose long-distance running set off an outcry from rights activists last year and led to a ban on his future runs, is planning to walk 500 kilometers, about 310 miles, in 10 days beginning June 6, his coach said. After a marathon last year, doctors found him to be undernourished, anemic and under cardiac stress, and the Orissa State government barred him from running. Budhia’s walk is to start in Orissa. Officials were looking into those plans.
The best-of-seven series is now tied, 2-2, after Teemu Selanne snapped out of his scoring slump with a goal and two assists for the Ducks.
A man charged with helping five others plot a terrorist attack on Fort Dix will not be freed on bail, a federal judge ruled Thursday.
The students reported becoming sick on Wednesday after many of them drank free samples of fortified milk drinks given out during lunchtime.
Nearly two decades after the Loma Prieta earthquake caused the collapse of a freeway here, a similar accident has exposed how desperate things remain.
TENNIS.
Friends and critics wonder if Paul D. Wolfowitz’s tenure at the World Bank was doomed from the outset.
A homeowner’s niece faces charges for posting a fraudulent advertisement on the online marketplace Craigslist.
To the Editor:.
The greatest challenge is for Russians to get over their debilitating rancor and responsibly engage the world they are so keen to join.
Henry M. Paulson Jr. introduced proposals for making the nation’s capital markets more competitive by strengthening financial reporting and auditing procedures.

Children develop most of their basic verbal, memory and abstract reasoning skills from ages of 6 to 10, and the effect of family income on these abilities may be smaller than previously thought, scientists are reporting. The findings, which appear online in The Journal of the International Neuropsychological Society, are from a large, continuing government study tracking changes in cognitive abilities and brain structure. The difference in I.Q. scores between low-income and high-income was about 10 points, when youngsters with learning disabilities were excluded; previous studies have found differences of 15 to 20 points. “The purpose is to provide a large, public database of healthy, normal brain development,” said the lead author, Dr. Deborah P. Waber, a pediatric researcher at Children’s Hospital Boston and Harvard University.
Confronted with the growing urgency of the climate change issue, President Bush stepped before the cameras in the Rose Garden the other day and said, essentially, nothing.
Federal forecasters said the extreme drought in the Southwest could moderate in Arizona in July as monsoon rains build but is likely to persist in Southern California into the fall.
The announcement earlier this week that Cerberus Capital Management was taking control of Chrysler has made the clubby, backroom industry the center of attention like never before.
The nomination of Michael Baroody, lobbyist for the powerful National Association of Manufacturers, to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission must surely take the fox-in-the-henhouse statuette.

Foreign workers brought into the United States by companies facing labor shortages are covered by federal minimum wage laws, a judge in New Orleans ruled May 15. In what he said appeared to be the first federal ruling on this issue, which could affect thousands of workers nationwide, the judge, Eldon E. Fallon of Federal District Court, found that workers hired by Decatur Hotels in New Orleans had the right to sue their employer under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The workers are seeking to be reimbursed for thousands of dollars in travel and other costs to get the hotel jobs, arguing that the company’s failure to do so left them working for less than minimum wage.

Oh, the toys that grownups have these days. Back in the 20th century, when Officer Wilton Sekzer kept the peace on the blistering Coney Island Boardwalk, he actually had to use his feet to propel himself from one end to the other.

A Navy lawyer was found guilty of communicating secret information about Guantánamo Bay detainees that could be used to injure the United States and three other charges of leaking information to an unauthorized person. The lawyer, Lt. Cmdr. Matthew Diaz, was acquitted of printing out national defense information with the intent or reason to believe it would be used against the United States. Commander Diaz, 41, of Topeka, Kan., did not testify in the court-martial hearing at the Norfolk Naval Station. He faces up to 14 years in prison. Prosecutors contended Commander Diaz mailed to a human rights lawyer a printout of the names of 550 detainees tucked into an unsigned Valentine’s Day card. Defense lawyers said that the information was not labeled classified and that Commander Diaz had no reason to think the document could be used to injure the United States.

A week after they were told that they were being replaced by workers earning far lower wages, nine workers who clean the offices of the Tommy Hilfiger clothing company were hired by a different contractor yesterday and went back to work.

Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, introduced a bill to sharply increase spending on child and maternal health in poor countries to $600 million next year and $1.6 billion by 2011 from $350 million a year. A companion bill was introduced with bipartisan support in the House last week. Save the Children, the U.S. Fund for Unicef and the Campaign to Make Poverty History, co-founded by the rock star Bono, are supporting the legislation. A recent Save the Children report found that some of the world’s poorest countries have sharply reduced child deaths with practical, inexpensive solutions, but that progress globally has slowed. More than 10 million children die every year before their fifth birthdays, most of them from preventable causes.
The agreement announced Thursday would end a contentious stalemate between the governors of Pennsylvania and New Jersey that had lasted more than 16 months.
An exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History traces the natural history and cultural roots of imaginary beasts from Asia, Europe and the Americas.
The sales gap between the Nintendo Wii and Sony’s competing PlayStation 3 widened during April.
Thousands of soldiers, sifting through hundreds of tips, are searching for the three missing Americans.

Eric Hinske slammed his chin into the ground making a spectacular, run-saving catch, then hit a go-ahead homer two innings later to give the Boston Red Sox a 4-2 victory and a doubleheader sweep of the visiting Detroit Tigers yesterday.
Mark P. Kaiser was sentenced to seven years in prison for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud.
David Chang, the recipient of this year’s James Beard Foundation rising star award for best new chef, is wrestling with stardom.
Senate Democrats said the nominee to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission was unqualified and the appointment posed insurmountable conflicts of interest.
House Democratic leaders scrapped a campaign pledge to double the current one-year ban on lobbying by departing lawmakers.
An investment advisory firm is calling the removal of Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election to the board was aided by “phantom votes.”
Alliance Data Systems said it was being acquired by the private equity firm Blackstone Group in a deal valued at $6.43 billion.
At each level of  horse racing, profits are not guaranteed. But Billy Koch and the Little Red Feather Stables horse racing syndicate have tried to minimize investors’ risk.
Ben S. Bernanke said problems in the subprime market were unlikely to have a major effect on the economy.
Four men are accused of helping a teenager illegally obtain weapons that were used in a shooting rampage on Feb. 12 in Salt Lake City.
Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker told reporters that Iraq would be the sole subject of the talks, which will be held in Baghdad on May 27.
Estonian Defense Minister Jaak Aaviksoo said that the cyberattacks were a threat to national security, and that it was possible the Russian government was behind them.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Bush stood together in the bright sunshine for their last joint appearance in the White House Rose Garden.
Amare Stoudemire and Boris Diaw will return from their suspensions to the scene of Phoenix’s last triumph, desperate to stave off elimination and force Game 7.
After testing the limits of basketball aesthetics, and the tonal quality of their opponents’ rims, the Nets will try to win at home Friday and force a Game 7.
On Air America Radio, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his former political rival Mark Green made a deep showing of how they had moved on since their bruising contest for mayor in 2001.
Simon & Schuster is proposing a change in the way it defines when a book is out of print.
A 2-year-old nearly died from a viral infection he got from his father’s smallpox vaccination.
A platoon leader and a company commander were relieved of their commands for their shortcomings in leadership.
A convicted murderer has been spared the death sentence, instead receiving life in prison without parole for killing seven people.
Kevin Sutherland shot a seven-under-par 65 in favorable scoring conditions to take a two-stroke lead after the first round of the AT&T Classic.
It is Whistle-Blower Week, and there is unusual acclaim for those whose leaks make possible Congressional hearings and newspaper exposés.
The CW network plans shorter ads and ads blended into shows to hold the attention of viewers through commercial breaks.
Mr. Cavaglieri was an architect who took his fascination with how buildings and cities change over time from his native Italy to New York.
On an L.P.G.A. Tour rife with translators and passports, Angela Park may have the most diverse background of all.
Mr. Kuhn was an architect who oversaw many major restoration and reuse projects in New York City.
Richard Hamilton scored 23 points and Rasheed Wallace added 16, as the Pistons surged back to make their fifth straight conference final.
Democrats braced for potential defections by lawmakers leery of any compromise with President Bush.
A team of marine rescuers played recorded humpback songs, hoping to lure two injured wayward whales from the Sacramento River back to the sea.
The approval paves the way for the device to be sold by the wireless unit of AT&T in late June.
A gauge of future economic activity forecasts that the nation’s economy will slow in coming months, reversing recent gains.
Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York Company over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.
Israeli aircraft continued to take aim at Hamas — its military wing and members of a Hamas-dominated police unit.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) — Congress gave final approval on Thursday to a $2.9 trillion budget resolution for the 2008 fiscal year that promises big spending increases for education and health care and envisions a federal surplus by 2012.
Ms. Ryan wrote the book “The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio: How My Mother Raised 10 Kids on 25 Words or Less,” about how her mother kept her family financially afloat by winning jingle contests.

GEORGE--Dr. Bryant, (79), a Presbyterian minister, died on May 8. His distinguished career improved peoples lives around the world. He's survived by a brother, son, daughter, other family and friends. Memorial: 1pm Saturday, May 19, New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, 1313 New York Ave., NW, Washington, DC.

The United States Military Academy at West Point, the City of New York and 74 other municipalities, organizations and corporations in the region have agreed to pay nearly $5 million to help clean up hazardous waste in an Orange County landfill. The agreement was part of a consent decree filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and announced yesterday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Orange County operated the landfill, situated on 300 acres in Goshen, from 1974 to 1992. The landfill was declared a hazardous waste site and was capped in the late 1990s under an agreement with the state in which those responsible for disposing of the waste would eventually help pay for the cleanup. The defendants agreed to contribute toward the cleanup costs, even though they deny wrongdoing. ANTHONY DEPALMA

COSTELLO--Joseph Michael, died Tuesday from complications from a fall. He was surrounded by his family. Joe was born February 28, 1925, in Manhattan to Michael and Mary Costello of County Mayo, Ireland. He graduated from Rice High School and enrolled in Iona College, where his education was interrupted by his enlistment in the U.S. Army. He served in active duty in World War II, arriving in Europe on June 9, 1944. He was taken prisoner in the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944 and remained ''a guest of the German government,'' as he would say in his own inimitable way, until May 8, 1945. After his discharge, Joe finished an accounting degree at Iona, and then completed a law degree at Fordham Law School. He was the founding partner of the New York law firm Costello, Shea & Gaffney, and became a highly respected trial lawyer in the areas of insurance defense, products liability and medical malpractice. He was a member of the Nassau County, New York State (former chairman, Trial Lawyers Section) and American Bar Associations; the Maritime Law Association of the United States; the New York County Lawyers Association; the Defense Research Institute; and the Defense Association of New York. He was a former law lecturer at Fordham University; member of the National Panel of Arbitrators of the American Arbitration Association; fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers; member of the Federal Bar Council; associate trustee of North Shore University Hospital; trustee, justice and police commissioner of the Village of Plandome; and president of Plandome Country Club. Joe loved sharing his wit and wisdom, telling stories, reading, the New York Times crossword puzzle, golf, travel, especially to Ireland, cigars, and most of all his family, the sine qua non of his existence. He is survived by his wife, Marianne Kelly (Clark) of Plandome; his children Michael (Jayne) of Hanover, NH; Kelly (Coleman) King of Columbus, NJ; J. McGarry (Marilyn) of Wilton, CT; Patrick of Glen Head; Renie of East Hampton; Brendan of Port Washington; and Noelle of Cumberland, RI; his grandchildren, Patrick, Nicole, Ian, Christiana, Cosima, Francesca, Caroline, Colin and Elizabeth; his brother, Thomas; his sisters Theresa Honan and Patricia Wright; and many cousins, nieces, nephews, friends and colleagues. He was predeceased by his daughter Mary Ann, his parents and his sister Mary. Visitation will be at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Saturday from 7 to 9pm and Sunday from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral Mass will be at St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Monday at 10am. Interment will be at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions in Joe's memory be made to the West of Ireland Alzheimer Foundation, Main Street, Ballindine, County Mayo, Ireland, or to the Nassau County Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, PO Box 246, Levittown, NY 11756.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Michael Caleo 97 minutes A Michael Keaton outing is always cause for celebration, no matter how ramshackle the vehicle (''First Daughter,'' anyone?) or paper-thin the role. He's an actor who works on the balls of his feet, forever poised for flight or the next reckless opportunity. Unpredictability is his game, and when he's on top of it, he can make you forget that there's a script.

The police arrested Khaled el-Masri, the German citizen of Lebanese descent who says he was subjected to the Central Intelligence Agency's practice of extraordinary rendition, on suspicion of setting a fire at a market in the Bavarian town of Neu-Ulm that caused an estimated $675,000 in damage, his lawyer said. A judge ordered him held in the psychiatric ward of a local hospital. The lawyer, Manfred Gnjidic, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Masri, who says he was seized while on vacation in Macedonia in 2003 and flown to Afghanistan, where he was questioned about ties to terrorist groups and beaten, had had a dispute with the store and that his action was a result of not having received the psychological counseling he had sought. ''I have asked several times from the beginning for psychological help, but without any luck,'' Mr. Gnjidic said. ''The very ironic thing is that he will get psychological help now, after he committed a crime, and as a torture victim didn't get it before, when he asked for it.'' SOUAD MEKHENNET

After hearing that the Mets' starting lineup did not include José Reyes, Carlos Beltrán, David Wright or Paul Lo Duca, the thousands of children who crammed the upper decks of Shea Stadium might have asked their teachers, ''We missed school for this?'' And this is what they may have been told: With Wednesday's game ending at 12:53 a.m., a series against the Yankees on deck and another against the Atlanta Braves after that, Willie Randolph could not be faulted for managing yesterday afternoon's game against the Chicago Cubs with a long-term perspective in mind.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitz's who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Daniño, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel.

New York's housing bubble may never burst, but there is one way to temper -- or, depending on your rental status, inflame -- your real-estate envy. On Sunday the annual Park Slope House Tour gives curious browsers a peek inside that Brooklyn neighborhood's 19th-century gems. The 10 buildings on view, some landmarks, include an 1888 neo-Grec home with original mahogany woodwork and embossed wallpaper, an 1895 carriage house and a 1901 four-story brownstone decorated in Moorish revival style. ''Everyone comes away with something that they can use in their own home, whether it's a renovation or a design sense,'' said Maryann Feeney, a trustee of the Park Slope Civic Council and an organizer of the tour. The excursion is self-guided, but that does not mean you can snoop inside people's bathroom cabinets.

''Journey's End,'' the critically acclaimed World War I drama, could take home as many as six Tony Awards on June 10, including one for best revival of a play. The only problem is, there will be no place to take them home to; the play is closing on the night of the Tony ceremony, when it will have played five previews and 125 regular performances. Despite enthusiastic reviews, some of them raves, the show has struggled for months, never reporting an average weekly attendance of more than 50 percent. The Old Vic revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten,'' on the other hand, is nominated only for its lead actress, Eve Best, but its producers say it has recouped its $2.4 million investment after just 52 performances at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Congressional leaders and the White House began what they said they hoped were the final talks on an Iraq war spending bill on Thursday as Democrats braced for potential defections by lawmakers leery of any compromise with President Bush. The likelihood that any final agreement will specify no withdrawal date for American troops from Iraq raised the possibility that antiwar Democrats will not support it, particularly in the House, and that the measure will need substantial Republican support to pass.

After dominating Fox's ''American Idol'' this season with her consistency and prowess, Melinda Doolittle, 29, right, reached the end of her run on Wednesday. The former backup singer from Brentwood, Tenn., received the lowest vote total of the nearly 60 million cast after Tuesday's performances. She leaves behind Blake Lewis and Jordin Sparks, who will compete for the ''American Idol'' title in next week's finale. ''Idol'' announced the outcome in the closing minutes of its results show at 9 p.m., which Nielsen estimated drew 27.4 million viewers. An hour earlier, CBS commemorated the career of Bob Barker with a prime-time special, ''The Price Is Right Million Dollar Spectacular,'' which attracted 14.1 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, the show edged ahead of Fox's ''Bones'' (10.7 million) to lead the 8 p.m. hour over all. Also at 8, the finale of CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' posted the show's best ratings of the season, finishing third in the time slot in total viewers (6.3 million) but first in the 18-to-34 demographic. Fox led the night's ratings over all. CBS ranked second with finales of ''Criminal Minds'' at 9 (13.3 million) and ''CSI: NY'' at 10 (12.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

A 70-year-old man was found dead in his Murray Hill apartment Wednesday, having suffered blunt trauma to the head and compression of the neck, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner, said yesterday. The man, identified by the police as Jose Prieto, though neighbors knew him as Raul, was a retired graphic designer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and had lived in the building on East 35th Street for more than 30 years. The police said the death was under investigation. CASSI FELDMAN

A sports article on Tuesday about the success of Yankees catcher Jorge Posada referred incorrectly to the career standing of the former catcher Tony Peña, the Yankees' first-base coach, who spoke favorably about Posada's potential longevity in baseball. Four catchers in major league history -- not three -- have spent more games behind the plate than Peña. (Iván Rodríguez of the Detroit Tigers passed Peña on the career list earlier this season; the others are Carlton Fisk, Bob Boone and Gary Carter.)

Interleague play begins today, and guess which two teams Fox and ESPN are featuring this weekend? The Yankees and the Mets. It doesn't matter if they're at Shea Stadium or at Yankee Stadium, or if both teams are great. It wouldn't matter if Roger Clemens were a Yankee or an Astro.

Buyers from all over the world spent millions of dollars at Christie's on Wednesday night as if it were play money. Together they made auction history: the most successful sale of postwar and contemporary art ever. Records were set for 26 artists, including Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Gerhard Richter and Damien Hirst. The two-and-a-half-hour sale totaled $384.6 million, nearly $80 million more than its high estimate of $305.5 million. Only 4 of the 78 works failed to sell.

French Leave Resort WHAT -- Oceanfront residential project. WHERE -- On Eleuthera, one of the Out Islands of the Bahamas. AMENITIES -- A marina, swimming pools and a full-service spa, among others. PRICES -- Various residences starting at $795,000; homesites from $2.9 million. STATUS -- Construction will begin this fall, and the project is expected to begin opening in 2009. DEVELOPER -- EIC Resorts. CONTACT -- (242) 332-3616 or www.frenchleaveresort.com. DETAILS -- In Governor's Harbour on Eleuthera, a 100-mile-long sliver of an island just east of Nassau, this 265-acre project is on the site of a Club Med that closed in 1999. It will be divided between a beachfront area, known for its pink-tinged sand, and a village adjacent to a 51-slip marina. At the beach will be 118 studio to two-bedroom condominiums in two-story buildings; 17 free-standing, four-bedroom villas and 10 one-acre homesites. The condos and villas will be sold furnished. The marina village will have 32 one- and two-bedroom, free-standing cottages and 12 houses of 2,400 to 3,300 square feet. Most of the residences will have terraces or porches, and a rental program will be offered. Slips at the marina, capable of accommodating boats up to 200 feet in length, will be sold separately at $6,000 a foot. A spade-shaped Club Med pool will be retained, and there will be a new oceanfront infinity pool. A restaurant will be built near the water; shops, a fitness center, tennis courts and a basketball court are planned as well. An airport just north of Governor's Harbour has flights from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Nassau; flights arrive in Nassau daily from the United States. There is ferry service between Nassau and Governor's Harbour. Montesoro WHAT -- Desert resort community. WHERE -- Borrego Springs, Calif. AMENITIES -- A golf course and a spa, among others. PRICES -- Homesites from around $250,000; houses from $550,000. STATUS -- The first phase of residences is expected to be completed around the end of this year. DEVELOPER -- GH Capital. CONTACT -- (866) 503-7418 or www.montesoro.com. DETAILS -- This project is in the Southern California desert in Borrego Springs, an unincorporated area enclosed by the Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, one of the largest state parks in the country. About 90 miles northeast of San Diego and 85 miles south of Palm Springs, Montesoro overlooks a valley edged by the Santa Rosa, San Ysidro and Vallecito Mountains. Construction started in fall 2006, and when completed the development will have about 800 houses. The first offering comprises 34 homesites and 11 2,000- to 2,795-square-foot, Spanish-style houses; a rental program will be available. Construction of a 75-villa boutique hotel is planned to begin next year. The golf course, designed by Tom Fazio, began opening early this year with nine of its 18 holes; the rest are planned to open this fall. The ayurvedic spa and wellness center will include a yoga facility and a meditation garden, and additional amenities include swimming pools, a restaurant, a fitness center, tennis courts and a central village with a general store and shops. Also, activities like wildflower walks, hiking, bird watching and horseback riding will be available. The nearest major airports are in San Diego and Palm Springs. NICK KAYE Breaking Ground is a weekly look at projects, planned or under construction, that include weekend or vacation homes.

Around Town Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. Tomorrow, 1 to 4:30 p.m., ''Global Weekend Program: In Celebration of Indigenous People,'' an event devoted to diverse cultures that includes film screenings, music and a panel discussion. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through April 6, 2008, ''Beyond,'' an exhibition of more than 30 large-format photographs of Earth's planetary neighbors, in the museum's Imax Gallery. Through Jan. 6, ''The Unknown Audubons: Mammals of North America,'' a display of more than 40 artworks depicting animals. In the Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins there are more than 200 casts of prehuman and human fossils and artifacts that illustrate stages in physical and behavioral evolution. Also on view: ''Vital Variety: A Visual Celebration of Invertebrate Biodiversity,'' an exhibition of 24 large-format color photographs by the entomologist Piotr Naskrecki in the gallery next to the Imax theater. The Arthur Ross Hall of Meteorites displays the 34-ton Ahnighito meteorite, part of the Cape York meteorite. In the Imax theater through today, ''Roving Mars,'' a film about NASA's Mars Rover. It was a meeting that felt more like a Catskill comedy routine than a reunion of two formerly bitter political rivals: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg visited the studios of Air America Radio yesterday for an interview at the hands of Mark Green, the two men made a show of how deeply they had buried the hatchet since their bruising contest for mayor in 2001.

Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Magnus Gertten and Stefan Berg Not rated; 65 minutes The premise of ''Rolling Like a Stone'' makes it sound like a Christopher Guest comedy: members of the 1960s Swedish rock bands the Namelosers and the Gonks and some of their friends and groupies pore over Super 8 snippets from a 1965 party they attended with the Rolling Stones, trying to remember the event and their lives at that time.

Federal forecasters said the extreme drought in the Southwest, just one step from the top of the scale, could moderate in Arizona in July as monsoon rains build but is likely to persist in Southern California into the fall. The similarly intense drought in the Southeast, partly set up by the lack of hurricanes last summer, is unlikely to break any time soon except in Florida, where increasing thunderstorm activity later this month could moisten vegetation, but add to wildfire risks through more lightning strikes. More information is at www.drought.noaa.gov. ANDREW C. REVKIN
