(Chinen) DARCY JAMES ARGUE'S SECRET SOCIETY (Tomorrow) Led by the composer and arranger Darcy James Argue, the Secret Society is a pointedly modernistic 18-piece big band stocked with top-shelf improvisers like the trumpeter Jonathan Finlayson. Kyle Saulnier's Awakening Orchestra, which plays an opening slot, takes a more mainstream approach but packs a similar punch. At 6 p.m., Bowery Poetry Club, 308 Bowery, near Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 614-0505, bowerypoetry.com; cover, $12, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) LUCIAN BAN-SAM NEWSOME QUARTET (Tonight) The pianist Lucian Ban and the saxophonist Sam Newsome team up to create a modern jazz informed by multiple strains of world music. They have a strong rhythm section: Carlo DeRosa on bass and Nasheet Waits on drums. At 9 and 10:30, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) DAVID BINNEY'S BALANCE (Tuesday) The alto saxophonist David Binney pursues an avant-gardism that embraces harmony, melody and rhythm, along with amplification. In this band he works with some regular collaborators: the keyboardist Craig Taborn, the bassist Thomas Morgan and the drummer Dan Weiss. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) FRANÇOIS BOURASSA (Monday) A pianist and composer of high repute in his native Montreal, Mr. Bourassa favors avant-gardism of a liquid and often lyrical sort. In his first set he performs in a duo with Michel Donato on piano and bass. His second set will feature a group with two saxophonists: André Leroux, a frequent partner, and David Binney, a special guest. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen) JOANNE BRACKEEN TRIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) The pianist JoAnne Brackeen favors a whimsical but sophisticated sort of post-bop in this trio, with Ugonna Okegwo on bass and E. J. Strickland on drums. At 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $25, with a $15 minimum. (Chinen) EVAN CHRISTOPHER'S JAZZ TRADITIONS PROJECT/CYMINOLOGY (Tuesday) Evan Christopher, a gifted New Orleans clarinetist, formed his Jazz Traditions Project with several Parisian musicians during a residency in France last year. Cyminology, led by the singer Cymin Samawaite, is a Berlin-based group with a style informed by Middle Eastern and Asian folk music. At 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $15, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen) ELI DEGIBRI QUARTET (Tuesday and Thursday) An Israeli tenor saxophonist with a taste for burnished sonorities, Eli Degibri explores his own music with help from his fellow tenor Mark Turner, the bassist Ben Street and the drummer Jeff Ballard. Tuesday at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Louis 649, 649 East Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 673-1190, louis649.com; no cover. Thursday at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 252-5091, smallsjazzclub.com; cover, $20. (Chinen) FREESTYLE JAZZ (Sunday) This weekly experimental series presents two ensembles: a quartet consisting of the pianist Borah Bergman, the cellist Daniel Levin, the violinist Jason Hwang and the drummer Dee Pop; and the Victoria Day Trio, which includes the drummer Harris Eisenstadt, the bassist Mark Helias and the saxophonist Matt Bauder. At 7 and 9 p.m., Jimmy's Restaurant, 43 East Seventh Street, East Village, (212) 982-3006, freestylejazz.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen) DIZZY GILLESPIE ALL-STAR BIG BAND (Tuesday through Thursday) Bebop's goateed ambassador did some of his best work with big bands, a fact that this one, led by his former trombonist Slide Hampton, happily exploits. The band includes other veterans of Gillespie's employ, like the saxophonists James Moody and Jimmy Heath. The trumpeter Roy Hargrove is a fine choice to fill Gillespie's shoes. (Through May 27.) At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen) * BRUCE HORNSBY, CHRISTIAN MCBRIDE, JACK DEJOHNETTE (Wednesday) An unlikely but not unpromising summit of Mr. Hornsby, whose identity as a singer-songwriter often overshadows his lithe abilities as a pianist; Mr. McBride, a jazz bassist who has also worked prominently in pop; and Mr. DeJohnette, a drummer whose elastic propulsion creates its own stylistic world. They are preparing for the release of an album together, and raising funds for an arts education initiative called JazzReach. At 8 and 10:30 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $50 in advance, $55 at the door, $100 V.I.P. package. (Chinen) INGRID JENSEN QUARTET (Monday) A fiery post-bop trumpeter with a book of sharp original tunes, Ingrid Jensen leads a group with Orrin Evans on Fender Rhodes piano, Matt Clohesy on bass and Jon Wikan on drums. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * NIÑO JOSELE TRIO (Tuesday through Thursday) On his new album, ''Paz'' (Norte/Calle 54), the Spanish flamenco guitarist Niño Josele interprets the music of the American jazz pianist Bill Evans, often with exquisite results. The album includes a number of guests; here he pares down to a capable trio with Esperanza Spalding on bass and Horacio (El Negro) Hernández on drums. (Through May 27.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen) LOST JAZZ SHRINES: TIN PALACE (Tonight) The Tin Palace, a Bowery night spot that operated through much of the 1970s, receives a spirited tribute from Trio 3, an avant-garde supergroup consisting of Oliver Lake on alto saxophone, Reggie Workman on bass and Andrew Cyrille on drums. There will also be a preconcert interview at 7 with Paul Pines, the club's former proprietor. At 8:30, TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, (212) 220-1460, tribecapac.org; $25; $15 for students. (Chinen) JOE LOVANO NONET WITH HANK JONES (Tonight through Sunday) Joe Lovano, a tenor saxophonist equally at home with balladry and bluster, has intermittently led this bop-flavored ensemble for many years. His guest, Hank Jones, is a venerable pianist who has a new album with Mr. Lovano, ''Kids: Duets Live at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola'' (Blue Note). At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen) * WYNTON MARSALIS SEPTET (Thursday) Fifteen years ago Wynton Marsalis closed the Jazz at Lincoln Center concert season with ''In This House, on This Morning,'' an original commission thematically linked to the customs of the gospel church. Now Mr. Marsalis ends the current season by calling on some of the same musicians, including the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon and the drummer Herlin Riley, to reinterpret that evocative work. (Through May 26.) At 8 p.m., Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 721-6500, jalc.org; $37.50 to $127.50. (Chinen) FRANCISCO MELA QUINTET (Wednesday) Mr. Mela is a subtly dynamic drummer, attuned to the rhythmic depth of his native Cuba but adaptable to seemingly any sort of modern jazz. Revisiting material from ''Melao'' (Avya), his excellent debut album, he leads a group with Nir Felder on guitar, Sam Yahel on piano, Peter Slavov on bass and Joel Frahm on tenor saxophone. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $20. (Chinen) FRANK MORGAN QUARTET (Thursday) The alto saxophonist Frank Morgan is one of the last survivors of the original bebop era (and in his case ''survivor'' is truly the appropriate term). He leads a band with George Cables on piano, Curtis Lundy on bass and Billy Hart on drums. (Through May 27.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25. (Chinen) NIGHT OF THE RAVISHED LIMBS (Wednesday) This week's edition of this adventurous series at Barbès showcases two quartets: Decoupage, led by the trombonist Curtis Hasselbring and featuring Matt Moran on vibraphone, Brandon Seabrook on guitar and Satoshi Takeishi on drums (at 8 p.m.); and a group led by the keyboardist James Carney, with the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby, the bassist Chris Lightcap and the drummer Mark Ferber (at 10 p.m.). Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10 per set. (Chinen) ODE/AUDIBLE MEANS (Tonight) The bassist and composer Lisle Ellis serves as a bridge, or at least a point of overlap, between two adventurous ensembles: Ode, which includes the saxophonist Larry Ochs, the bassist Trevor Dunn and the drummer Gerry Hemingway; and Audible Means, with the saxophonist Ellery Eskelin, the guitarist Bruce Eisenbeil, the drummer Gustavo Aguilar and the keyboardist Erik Deutsch. At 8, the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) REUBEN ROGERS GROUP (Thursday) Reuben Rogers is a versatile bassist whose rousing debut album, ''The Things I Am'' (Renwick), reveals his lesser-known talents as a composer and arranger. He performs here with two of the album's participants, the saxophonist Ron Blake and the drummer Greg Hutchinson, along with the bright young pianist Danny Grissett. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12; $10 for members. (Chinen) NED ROTHENBERG (Tonight) Mr. Rothenberg, an exploratory multireedist, plays in several formats during this benefit for the experimental arts space Roulette: solo improvisation; duets with the saxophonist John Zorn; and a trio with Marcus Rojas on tuba and Brahim Fribgane on oud and percussion. At 8:30, Roulette, 20 Greene Street, at Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 219-8242, roulette.org; $15; $10 for students. (Chinen) ANTONIO SANCHEZ QUARTET (Tonight) Antonio Sanchez, a sensitive and dynamic drummer, leads a group with two fine saxophonists, Chris Potter on tenor and Miguel Zenón on alto, along with the supportive bassist Ben Street. At 10, 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) TODD SICKAFOOSE'S BLOOD ORANGE (Tuesday) A bassist and composer equally fond of rough edges and rounded forms, Todd Sickafoose performs here with two guitarists (Adam Levy and Mike Gamble), two drummers (Allison Miller and Simon Lott) and a front line of Shane Endsley on trumpet, Ben Wendel on saxophones and Alan Ferber on trombone. At 7 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen) * SIM BENEFIT CONCERT (Wednesday) Ralph Alessi, a trumpeter and the driving force behind the School for Improvisational Music (SIM), presides over this benefit for the organization. He has enlisted excellent artists for the task: the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane, the pianist Jason Moran, the bassist Ben Street and the drummer Nasheet Waits. At 8:30 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, near Third Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $15. (Chinen) GRANT STEWART (Tonight, tomorrow and Tuesday) Mr. Stewart is a highly proficient tenor saxophonist, as he confirms on his recent bebop-steeped album ''In the Still of the Night'' (Sharp Nine). He leads a quartet that features the pianist Tardo Hammer. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, 10 and 11:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $28. Tuesday at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 675-7369, smallsjazzclub.com; cover, $20. (Chinen) * HENRY THREADGILL'S ZOOID (Tonight through Sunday) The august composer and multireedist Henry Threadgill has always nursed a fascination with timbre. These days he indulges it best in this superb ensemble, which finds his flute and alto saxophone in a tangle with Liberty Ellman's acoustic guitar, Jose Davila's tuba and trombone, Dana Leong and Rubin Kodheli's cellos, and Elliot Humberto Kavee's drums. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $20; $10 for students. (Chinen) DAVID TORN (Tonight) Mr. Torn is a guitarist and producer whose new album, ''Prezens'' (ECM), suggests a texturally slippery approach to group improvisation. That has a lot to do with the saxophonist Tim Berne, the keyboardist Craig Taborn and the drummer Tom Rainey, who rejoin him here; but it's also an expression of his gift for organizing sound. At 9 and 10:30, Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, near Seventh Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; $5 donation. (Chinen) Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera 'CASTOR ET POLLUX' (Tomorrow) Yves Abel conducts a broad repertory in big houses these days, but he began his operatic conducting career as a specialist in French opera, an interest he explored by founding L'Opéra Français de New York. Mr. Abel's current offering is this Rameau opera of overlapping romantic triangles. At 8 p.m., French Institute/Alliance Française, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6160, fiaf.org; $50; $40 for students and members. (Allan Kozinn) 'DON GIOVANNI' (Tonight and tomorrow night) The scrappy Chelsea Opera, founded three years ago, takes on this Mozart work, which, for all its familiarity, remains a formidable challenge. The production, staged by Lynne Hayden-Findlay and conducted by Carmine Aufiero, is double cast: Justin Ryan and Peter Hakjoon Kim alternate in the title role. Giving singers opportunities to perform is the mission of the company. Though a makeshift stage has to be set up in St. Peter's Church to present productions, there are benefits to experiencing opera in such an intimate space. At 7:30, 346 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (866) 811-4111, chelseaopera.org; $35 to $40 in advance, with $20 tickets for students and 65+; $45 and $50 at the door, and $25 for students and 65+. (Anthony Tommasini) 'ROMULUS' (Sunday and Monday) The Guggenheim's Works and Process series usually offers works in progress; this, however, is the world premiere, fully staged, of a new one-act comic opera by Louis Karchin. Based on a play by Dumas père with a ''Three Men and a Baby''-like plot (only two men in this case), the opera includes the fine baritone Thomas Meglioranza, known as a contemporary specialist, in its cast. Peter Flynn directs; Mr. Karchin will conduct. At 7:30 p.m., Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3587, worksandprocess.org; $15 to $24. (Anne Midgette) WALL TO WALL OPERA (Tomorrow) This year Symphony Space devotes its annual ''Wall to Wall'' marathon to all things operatic, from old (Monteverdi) to new (Derek Bermel), from students (of Mannes and Juilliard) to pros (from City Opera), from a master class (with Renata Scotto) to masterly scenes from Strauss, Verdi and Bizet. From 11 a.m. until midnight, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; free. (Midgette) Classical Music * BARGEMUSIC (Tonight through Sunday, and Wednesday) Barber's Piano Sonata is one of his most remarkable works, but it rarely finds its way onto the concert stage. Olga Vinokur is including it in her recital in this floating concert hall tonight, along with Haydn's Sonata in E flat (Hob. XVI:49) and transcriptions of Bach (by Busoni), Kreisler (by Rachmaninoff) and Schubert and Verdi (by Liszt). Tomorrow at noon, Ms. Vinokur is joined by the violinist Mark Peskanov in an all-Schubert recital, and in the evening (with a repeat on Sunday) the Knights Chamber Orchestra takes over for a rich program of Elgar, Arvo Pärt, Haydn and Vivaldi. Paul Schoenfield's inventive Clarinet Trio is the centerpiece of the Wednesday program, which also includes Bruch's ''Kol Nidre'' and works by Beethoven and Piazzolla. The performers are Nuno Antunes, clarinetist; David Marks, violinist; Adrian Daurov, cellist; and Katya Mihailova, pianist. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at noon and 8 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Wednesday at 8 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083, bargemusic.org; $35 tonight and Wednesday, $30 tomorrow at noon, $50 tomorrow evening and Sunday. (Kozinn) MAYA BEISER (Thursday) This superb new-music cellist offers a program of recent multimedia scores, including several in which video is an important expressive element. Included are works by Eve Beglarian, Joby Talbot and Michael Gordon. The program also includes a collaboration between Ms. Beiser and the violinist Mark O'Connor. At 7:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $20. (Kozinn) CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Sunday and Tuesday) The Chamber Music Society closes its season with works by Dohnanyi, Dvorak and the society's composer for the season, Bright Sheng. Yefim Bronfman gives the premiere of Mr. Sheng's ''My Other Song'' for solo piano and then joins the violinist Cho-Liang Lin, the violist Paul Neubauer and the cellist David Finckel for Dvorak's Piano Quartet in E flat (Op. 87). The program also includes Dohnanyi's Serenade in C for string trio. Sunday at 5 p.m., Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Rose Theater, Rose Hall, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Vivien Schweitzer) EMERSON STRING QUARTET YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT (Wednesday and Thursday) The Emerson Quartet, currently celebrating its 30th-anniversary season, is leading an eight-concert Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall devoted to Beethoven. It is also passing on the fruits of its lengthy collaboration to young quartets in a training workshop. The emerging ensembles will then perform Beethoven quartets they have worked on with the Emerson at two concerts in Weill Recital Hall. At 7:30 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15. (Schweitzer) FREE FOR ALL AT TOWN HALL (Sunday) This happy experiment in classical music populism brings Brahms's three violin sonatas played by Nadia Salerno-Sonnenberg, with Anne-Marie McDermott at the piano. At 5 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 707-8787, freeforallattownhall.org; free tickets will be available at the box office at noon. (Bernard Holland) JUILLIARD STRING QUARTET WORKSHOP (Tuesday) After a week of intensive coaching with members of the Juilliard Quartet, eight student quartets will perform in two public concerts at the Juilliard School. The young ensembles will give workshop performances of two pieces with their mentors, then play their best work in concert. At 3:30 and 7:30 p.m., Paul Hall, Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, at 65th Street, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu; free. (Schweitzer) MET ORCHESTRA (Sunday) This performance by James Levine's elegant orchestra was meant to be a showcase for the French soprano Natalie Dessay. Illness has laid her low, however, and the mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung will step in. There are some usual suspects on the program but also music by Ambroise Thomas. At 3 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $50 to $160. (Holland) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Thursday) Lorin Maazel, the orchestra's music director, takes over for a program of Rimsky-Korsakov (the ''Russian Easter'' Overture) and Bartok (the Concerto for Orchestra). Julian Rachlin is the soloist in Saint-Saëns's Third Violin Concerto. At 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $28 to $94. (Holland) * URSULA OPPENS (Sunday) Arium, an inviting new cafe and concert site in the Meatpacking district of Manhattan, has been attracting some excellent pianists for a series of recitals. This Sunday afternoon the brilliant and adventurous Ursula Oppens offers a typically challenging, and very intriguing, program, with four pieces by the composer Tobias Picker (best known for his opera ''An American Tragedy'') and works by Beethoven, Schubert and Ravel. At 5 p.m., 31 Little West 12th Street, West Village, (212) 463-8630, ariumnyc.com; $50; $30 for members. (Tommasini) NEMANJA RADULOVIC (Tonight) A long-haired violin prodigy from the former Yugoslavia, Mr. Radulovic appears at Carnegie Hall's Weill Recital Hall as part of the Rising Stars series, for which he was nominated by the Cité de la Musique in France, where he now lives. He performs a traditional virtuoso's program: Mozart, Beethoven, Tartini, Franck and Ravel. Susan Manoff is the accompanist. At 7:30, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28. (Midgette) * DANIEL BERNARD ROUMAIN (Wednesday) This composer melds classical forms and timbres with the sounds and structures of hip-hop, rock and other pop styles. With his band, the Mission, and DJ Spooky as a guest, Mr. Roumain will play works from his new recording, ''Etudes4Violin&Electronix'' (Thirsty Ear). At 7 p.m., the Cutting Room, 19 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-1900, thecuttingroomnyc.com; $12 in advance, $15 at the door. (Kozinn) * SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY (Tonight) Michael Tilson Thomas and the players of the San Francisco Symphony have been winning accolades and awards for their bracing and insightful performances of the Mahler symphonies. For the second of two concerts with the symphony at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Thomas performs a group of Mahler songs with a distinguished Mahler interpreter, the baritone Thomas Hampson. The concert ends with Strauss's walloping ''Also Sprach Zarathustra.'' Mr. Thomas, a superb Copland conductor, opens the program with that composer's audacious and unabashedly modern ''Short Symphony,'' composed in the early 1930s. At 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $29 to $98. (Tommasini) JOHN SCOTT (Tomorrow) Mr. Scott, the organist and music director at St. Thomas Church, plays the second-to-last concert in his 10-part series exploring the organ works of Buxtehude, in honor of the 300th anniversary of that composer's death. Built in a style similar to that seen in northern Germany and the Netherlands in the 17th and 18th centuries, St. Thomas's Taylor & Boody organ is ideal for this venture. At 4 p.m., Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 757-7013, saintthomaschurch.org; free. (Schweitzer) Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. BODY BLEND (Tuesday) This installment features Dawn Springer, Hilary Clark and Jillian Peña, and James Mcginn, artists chosen by Isabel Lewis. At 8 p.m., Dixon Place, 258 Bowery, between Houston and Prince Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 219-0736, dixonplace.org; $12; $10 for students and 65+; Theater Development Fund discount vouchers accepted. (Jennifer Dunning) * THE BOOGIE DOWN DANCE SERIES AT BAAD! (Tonight and Thursday night) The folks at BAAD! describe tonight's ''Hit the Dance Floor!'' as featuring ''sensual duos, moving Butoh and heart- stopping hip-hop that bubbles with the energy of the Bronx and the diversity of the city.'' We couldn't have said it better. In ''Bill T. Jones Presents '' on Thursday, choreographers including Eric Montes and Malcom Lowe show their work. At 8, Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point, South Bronx, (718) 842-5223, bronxacademyofartsanddance.org; $15. (Dunning) CHRISTOPHER CAINES DANCE COMPANY (Tomorrow through Wednesday) A double bill with music by Mozart includes ''The Farewell to Music,'' a lyrical nocturne to vocal music, and ''Skittle Alley (Ninepins),'' to a trio Mozart composed during a bowling party. Tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., Monday through Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Clark Studio Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com; $25 in advance, $30 at the door. (Jack Anderson) Darrah CARR DANCE AND BARRY BLUMENFELD'S TAP FUSION (Tonight through Sunday) Darrah Carr specializes in Irish step dancing and modern dance, and Mr. Blumenfeld mixes modern with tap. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 11 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com; $20; $10 for the family matinee tomorrow. (Dunning) DANCE AT THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday nights) This weekend's program is Chase Granoff's ''Boredom!!! (as an amplifier).'' Then it's Michael Helland's ''Dress Up Show,'' featuring an installation in which audience members get costume makeovers. (''Dress Up'' runs through May 26.) At 8, the Chocolate Factory, 5-49 49th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (212) 352-3101, chocolatefactorytheater.org; $15; free on Thursdays for Queens residents. (Dunning) DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM (Sunday) Young dancers, singers and musicians -- and a surprise guest or two -- are the stars in this monthly series. At 3 p.m., Dance Theater of Harlem, 466 West 152nd Street, Hamilton Heights, (212) 690-8100; $18; $14 for children under 12. (Dunning) DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP FAMILY MATTERS SERIES (Tomorrow) ''The Body Eclectic Meets the Hungry Bride,'' a program for children and their adult companions, includes works by Glen Rumsey, Kevin Augustine/Lone Wolf Tribe, the Nation Beat, Lawrence Goldhuber, Ballet Hispanico School Ensemble and the Trinayan Collective. At 2 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20; $10 for children. (Anderson) DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP STUDIO SERIES (Thursday) The latest presentation in a continuing series featuring new choreography offers dances by Mina Nishimura. (Through May 25.) At 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; free. (Anderson) ECLECTIX DANCE COMPANY (Tonight and tomorrow night) This new troupe's debut program emphasizes improvisation. Music for electric flute is composed and performed by Lee McClure. At 8, New Dance Group Theater, 305 West 38th Street, Manhattan, (212) 566-2217; $10; $9 for students and 65+. (Anderson) * EIKO AND KOMA (Thursday) In ''Cambodian Stories Revisited'' these Japanese-American dancers collaborate with Cambodian artists, who will suspend large paintings over a churchyard's gravesites. (Through May 27.) At 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Churchyard, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194; free. (Anderson) * E-MOVES 8 (Tonight through Sunday) Several participants in this annual series of dance by ''e-merging'' and ''e-volving'' choreographers look ready to join the company of the ''e-stablished'' artists who complete the festival. Ayo Janeen Jackson's inventive ''Where Unicorns and Demons Play'' is one winner, as is Camille A. Brown's tumultuously funny ''Evolution of a Secured Feminine.'' Both are part of the first program (tomorrow night). The ''e-stablished'' choreographers are David Rousseve and Tanya Isaac, on the second program (tonight and Sunday afternoon). Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 3 p.m., Harlem Stage at the Gatehouse, Convent Avenue at 135th StreetHarlem, (212) 650-7100, harlemstage.org; $20. (Dunning) JEAN-PIERRE FROHLICH AND 'THE DYBBUK' (Monday) Mr. Frohlich, a ballet master specializing in the Jerome Robbins repertory at the New York City Ballet, will speak about Robbins's ''Dybbuk'' and its score by Leonard Bernstein in a lecture-performance. At 8 p.m., JCC in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, (646) 505-5708, jccmanhattan.org; $20. (Dunning) GORILLA FEST '07 (Tonight through Sunday night) Bill Young/Colleen Thomas & Company have opened their studio for a wide-ranging alternative arts festival of music, film, performance art and dance by Joe Poulson, Walter Dundervill, Erick Montes and Osmany Tellez. At 8:30, Hundred Grand, 100 Grand Street, at Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 925-6573; $15; $12 for students and 65+. (Dunning) JUILLIARD DANCE (Tonight and tomorrow nights) Lincoln Center features blooming, eager, well-trained young student dancers this time of year. Now it's the turn of the Juilliard Dance Division, which presents two shows, ''Choreographic Honors'' (tonight and tomorrow) and ''Senior Dance Showcase'' (Monday). At 8, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 799-5000, juilliard.edu; free. (Dunning) * MOMIX (Tuesday through Thursday) A company that revels in theatrical illusion reviews on a quarter century in ''Momix reMIX.'' (Through June 10.) Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $44. (Anderson) MOVEMENT RESEARCH (Monday) The latest in a series of programs dedicated to experimentation and works-in-progress presents choreography by Vanessa Justice, Gina Graham and Curt Haworth. At 8 p.m., Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, South Village, (212) 539-2611; free. (Anderson) THE NETA DANCE COMPANY: 2007 A.W.A.R.D. SHOW! (Sunday) In the last of these performance-discussion shows, a winner chosen by the audience will perform and receive a $10,000 award. The finalists are Jennie Mary Tai Liu and Hannah Heller; Nelly van Vommell; Kate Weare; and Kiyoko Kashiwagi. At 7 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, between Houston and Prince Streets, netacompany.org; free. (Dunning) STREB S.L.A.M. (Tonight through Sunday) High-flying, wall-crashing thrills and chills and popcorn besides. (Through June 17.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 3 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Streb Laboratory for Action Mechanics, 51 North First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 352-3101, strebusa.org; $20; $10 for children. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through July 29. This show of about 60 works by Durand has as its centerpiece ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet and journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape. He explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage and rocks and ground cover in smaller works, while his larger and more elaborate exhibition pictures, influenced by European masters, are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Grace Glueck) GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'DIVISIONISM/NEO-IMPRESSIONISM: ARCADIA AND ANARCHY,' through Aug. 6. Ultimately this rare, compressed, mercurial exhibition of work by the Italian Divisionists of the 1890s is long on history and short on truly convincing paintings. The inclusion of works by Seurat and his French, Dutch and Belgian followers clarifies how the Italians pushed Pointillism, Seurat's invention, in all directions: toward realism, academic classicism, Symbolism, class consciousness and even Impressionism. The show opens a new, albeit small, window on the genesis of Modernism beyond the French canon. If many of the works are period pieces, they are also immensely appealing, big-hearted and physically robust period pieces. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500. (Roberta Smith) * International Center of Photography: 'Let Your Motto Be Resistance: African American Portraits,' through Sept. 9. This show of photographic portraits is a praise-song in pictures, a shout-out to history. It's also a fancy-dress inaugural party for the yet-to-be-built National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. It tends to be a little too fancy, too heavy on glitz, too short on grit. Still, what a party it is, with a Who's Who of charismatic black statesmen, from Frederick Douglass to Malcolm X, and with Leontyne Price, Mahalia Jackson and the Supremes sharing a stage. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at West 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000. (Holland Cotter) * JAPAN SOCIETY: 'Awakenings: Zen Figure Painting in Medieval Japan,' through June 17. Japan Society has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. And this one, with four dozen paintings of Buddhists gods and saints hung in shrinelike alcoves, is transporting. It covers a broad swath of geography, bringing together 13th- to 16th-century hanging scrolls, not only from Japan but also from China, where Zen Buddhism, called Chan in Chinese, originated. 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, japansociety.org. (Cotter) * THE METropolitan museum of art: 'KING OF FASHION,' through Aug. 5. A revolutionary in revolutionary times, the fashion designer Paul Poiret introduced unstructured garments that freed women from corsets in 1906, the year before Picasso committed his decidedly uninhibited (and unstaid) ''Demoiselles d'Avignon'' to canvas. But the modern painter whom Poiret most resembles, in his love of the exotic, his brilliant use of color and pattern and his penchant for simplified, almost rudimentary form, is Matisse. This rare exhibition -- from the Met's Costume Institute -- does his sartorial genius justice with a spare installation rendered radiant by hand-painted silk backdrops of the leafy parks and luxurious drawing rooms of Paris. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Smith) The Met: 'FRANK STELLA: PAINTING INTO ARCHITECTURE,' through July 29. Crammed into a gallery that feels like an obstacle course, this exhibition spans 43 years with 25 paintings, reliefs, drawings and architectural models, all with the goal of tracing an evolution that has not yet occurred. Taking up most of the space are enlarged versions of models that are considered sculptures -- and that look as if they date from the early 1960s. The main draws are the examples of the paintings and reliefs that are the basis of Mr. Stella's importance as an artist. (See above.) (Smith) The Met: 'FRANK STELLA ON THE ROOF,' through Oct. 28. Two large Pop Art sculptures, two architectural models and a model enlarged into a sculpture-installation piece confirm that one of the greatest American artists of the postwar era doesn't do himself or anyone else any favors when he strays from the wall to work fully in the round. The results have a certain Stella-like verve but are otherwise generic. (See above.) (Smith) MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: 'Apocalypse Then: Medieval Illuminations From the Morgan,' through June 17. The symbolism of the Book of Revelation, with its demons and lakes of fire, has a subversive appeal. This new exhibition at the Morgan Library celebrates a facsimile of ''Las Huelgas Apocalypse'' (1220), the largest surviving Spanish illuminated commentary on the Apocalypse. The show, which includes 50 leaves from the original text, unbound and installed around the gallery's perimeter, offers a walking tour of the medieval imagination. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org. (Andrea K. Scott) Museum of modern art: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Including 30 works by 13 artists from the last 16 years, it alternates between the literal and the arbitrary and favors sincere political intent over genuine artistic quality. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith) * Neue Galerie: 'Van Gogh and Expressionism,' through July 2. The Neue has, as usual, gathered a stellar roundup of Expressionist art. In one of the show's most exciting rooms, a third-floor gallery devoted mostly to self-portraits, two extraordinary van Goghs hang at opposite ends: ''Self-Portrait With Straw Hat'' (1887-88), from the Metropolitan Museum's collection, filled with energetic, radiating brushstrokes, and the National Gallery's vibrant self-portrait of the artist holding a palette and brushes, painted about a year later. The most compelling pairing in this room, though, is van Gogh's ''Bedroom'' from 1889, the second of three versions he painted of his room in Arles, with Egon Schiele's obvious homage, ''The Artist's Bedroom in Neulengbach,'' painted in 1911, in a darker palette and with a perspective tipped precariously toward the viewer. 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, neuegalerie.org. (Martha Schwendener) The Studio Museum in Harlem: 'Philosophy of Time Travel,' through July 1. This flawed show, which was created by a group of artists who studied together at the California Institute of the Arts, is nonetheless an interesting example of one of the art world's latest trends: the art collective. It takes Brancusi's ''Endless Column'' as its point of departure and reimagines this Modernist icon from the point of view of art school grads, who are versed in the language of artspeak and wed to the righteous cause of freedom of expression. 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, studiomuseum.org. (Bridget L. Goodbody) WHITNEY MUSEUM AT ALTRIA: Matthew Brannon, 'Where Were We,' through Aug. 26. Matthew Brannon brings together art, poetry and advertising in a series of letterpress prints that hark back to 1950s and 1960s textile designs by Astrid Sampe and Marimekko. Texts written by the artist and accompanying the images read like song lyrics crossed with Conceptual Art and Language Poetry (which emphasized experimentalism and reader interaction). Consumption and excess are frequent references, as well as how art, design and fashion feed these modern yet primordial urges and desires. 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453, whitney.org. (Schwendener) WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'LINCOLN KIRSTEIN,' through Aug. 27. In the middle of the last century Lincoln Kirstein particularly relished attacking the Museum of Modern Art. Pure abstraction was ridiculous, he thought. It had no standards. Against Mondrian and Pollock, he endorsed, among others, the artists in this show. They are the sculptors Elie Nadelman and Gaston Lachaise and the painters Paul Cadmus, who was Kirstein's brother-in-law, Walker Evans and Pavel Tchelitchew. With the exception of Evans, Kirstein's taste clearly hasn't won the day, but it's never bad to re-examine received opinions or to be reminded of a generous advocate. (See above.) (Michael Kimmelman) Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Taryn Simon,' through June 24. Ms. Simon couches the show in the intellectual, power-to-the-people oratory of leftist politics, yet she clearly delights in exposing, in a quasi-tabloid fashion, America's underbelly. Though she has also worked in war-torn areas, Ms. Simon is best known for ''The Innocents,'' a series of portraits of men and women who were wrongly convicted but later cleared by DNA test results. Ms. Simon can work as long as a year to gain permission to photograph high-security zones like the government-regulated quarantine sites, nuclear waste storage facilities, prison death rows and C.I.A. offices on view in the show. There are also pictures with lighter themes: the sandpit where the Grucci family tests fireworks, ski slopes being dynamited for avalanche control and the second Death Star, from ''Return of the Jedi,'' at George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch. Ms. Simon is at her artistic best when her delight in the strangeness of American culture shines. (See above.) (Goodbody) Galleries: Uptown CLAUDE MONET (1840-1926): A TRIBUTE TO DANIEL WILDENSTEIN AND KATIA GRANOFF This exhibition of nearly 60 paintings by one of the most beloved painters in the world feels a little like having dinner with a celebrity. The gallery setting eliminates the usual distance; the startling intimacy allows you to experience afresh the momentum and innovations of Monet's astounding trajectory in the span of three small galleries. Basically, it is a chance to encounter, up close and in detail, the evolving ways of seeing and painting that established the originality, historical importance and continuing irresistibility of Monet's art. It should not be missed. Wildenstein & Company, 19 East 64th Street, (212) 879-0500, through June 15. (Smith) Galleries: SoHo * 'Gego, Between Transparency and the Invisible' The artist named Gego was born Gertrud Goldschmidt in Germany in 1912, but lived most of her life in Venezuela, where she produced netlike drawings in ink and watercolor and what she called ''drawings without paper'': semi-geometric, see-through, two- and three-dimensional pieces of twisted and knotted wires, suspended in space. Whether you think of them as grids gone haywire or as rational forms charged with emotion, they're out of this world, and this small survey gives a good sense of what is distinctive and radical about Gego's art. The Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, drawingcenter.org, through July 21. (Cotter) Galleries: Chelsea * 'Rebel, Rebel: Remembering Karlheinz Weinberger (1921-2006)' The self-taught Swiss photographer Karlheinz Weinberger, who died last year at 81, began his career taking pictures for a gay club in Zurich, but found his true subject in rebellious, working-class teenagers who dressed to shock in the 1960s and '70s. The Weinberger pictures in this show are fairly tame, as if chosen to complement the cooled-out work of the three younger artists -- Ryan McGinley, Walter Pfeiffer and Collier Schorr -- who surround him. But at his best, he's in a class by himself. Anna Kustera, 520 West 21st Street, (212) 989-0082, kusteratiltongallery.com, through next Friday. (Cotter) Last Chance * THE MET: 'LOUIS COMFORT TIFFANY AND LAURELTON HALL -- AN ARTIST'S COUNTRY ESTATE' Laurelton Hall may have burned to the ground in 1957, but this exhibition does an excellent job of reassembling what remains of this extraordinary house-museum and its gardens, which Tiffany created for himself in the early 1900s. The Gilded Age opulence of the place, which occupied 580 acres overlooking Long Island Sound, is conveyed most blatantly by the Temple-of-Dendur-size Daffodil Terrace, in wood, marble and glass. The main events are the glass windows, vases and lamps, where Tiffany's genius for color, love of the exotic and reverence for nature coalesce into an unforgettable mystical materialism. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org; closes on Sunday. (Smith) P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center: 'Katrin Sigurdardottir: High Plane V' Cut into a space between two levels of P.S. 1 is the Icelandic artist Katrin Sigurdardottir's ''High Plane V,'' a miniature artificial landscape of glacial mountains arranged in a naturalistic, faux-snow-covered setting against a painted white background. Visitors climb ladders and peer into one of two holes in the ceiling to view the work. The installation works best when two people mount the ladders and poke their heads in at the same time: then they can both see a disembodied head floating in the middle of the icy landscape. 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, ps1.org.; closes on Monday. (Benjamin Genocchio) * JOHN ZURIER: PAINTINGS It may be a bit late in the game for sincere monochrome paintings, but this San Francisco artist, who made a wan impression at the 2002 Whitney Biennial and is now having his solo debut, often pulls it off. Mainly, he refuses to be programmatic. His colors range from black to bright. The proportions of his canvases are constantly shifting. And his brushwork is an active, varied ingredient, free of bombast. To some extent he reiterates the monochrome the way James McNeill Whistler foretold it, with a bit too much misty preciousness, perhaps, but with genuine feeling. Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 343-0441, www.peterblumgallery.com/soho.html; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

''Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas!'' made a mint last year at the Hilton Theater, taking in more $1.5 million at the box office some weeks. (With a running time of an hour and 15 minutes, there were 12 performances a week, four more than most shows.) But when the holidays roll around this year, the Hilton will be booked either by a very lucky ''Pirate Queen'' or, more likely, ''Young Frankenstein.'' So ''Grinch'' is moving into the St. James Theater, with performances Nov. 1 to Jan. 6. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

STERN--Sam, of Great Neck and Boca Raton died Wednesday, May 16th, 2007 at age 84. Survived by beloved family: wife Ruth, sons Eric and Fred, grandchildren Derek, Joanna, Candace and Jeremy. Burial Thursday, May 17th, at 1 PM, Mount Hebron, Flushing.
To the Editor: Re ''Ivy League Admissions Crunch Brings New Cachet to Next Tier'' (front page, May 16):

Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, introduced a bill to sharply increase spending on child and maternal health in poor countries to $600 million next year and $1.6 billion by 2011 from $350 million a year. A companion bill was introduced with bipartisan support in the House last week. Save the Children, the U.S. Fund for Unicef and the Campaign to Make Poverty History, co-founded by the rock star Bono, are supporting the legislation. A recent Save the Children report found that some of the world's poorest countries have sharply reduced child deaths with practical, inexpensive solutions, but that progress globally has slowed. More than 10 million children die every year before their fifth birthdays, most of them from preventable causes. CELIA W. DUGGER

The Fox network, emphasizing its position as the network leader in reaching audiences that most advertisers want to reach, announced a prime-time schedule yesterday aimed at solving its chronic problems in the fall, while maintaining its strength in the winter and spring. That meant adjustments on five nights in the fall and a promise of some serious changes in the format of its hit drama ''24'' when it starts again in January.

GRODSKY--Bertha (Pinkofsky), age 97. Beloved wife of the late Barney. Dear mother of Peter (Ellin) and the late Dr. Leonard (Sheila). Loving grandmother of six and great-grandmother of nine. Devoted sister of Ada P. Rosen and the late Mary P. Marcus. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Graveside services, Sunday, May 20, 2007. Memorials may be made to NCJW New York Section, 820 Second Ave., NY, NY 10017.

CHINA'S PERCEPTION PROBLEM -- After a highly publicized pet food recall that involved tainted Chinese ingredients, China is coming under international pressure to prove that its exported products are safe. The question worrying Chinese officials is how to assure that ''Made in China'' means well made. [Page C1.] WOLFOWITZ RESIGNS -- Paul D. Wolfowitz announced his resignation as president of the World Bank, ending weeks of furor over charges of favoritism that revealed widespread dissatisfaction with his leadership at the bank. [A1.] THE VALUE OF JOHN SNOW -- John W. Snow, former Treasury secretary who is chairman of Cerberus Capital Management, the company buying Chrysler, is one of the latest politicians hired by private equity for the connections and skills that are honed while working in the upper echelons of government. [C1.] VOTE ON TEXAS PENSION REFORM -- Texas lawmakers are on the verge of rejecting a requirement that state and local governments disclose the cost of the health care they have promised to retired employees. The proposal is intended to encourage politicians to deal ahead of time with the huge obligations they have imposed on future taxpayers. [C1.] LIMITED IMPACT OF DEFAULTS -- The Federal Reserve does not foresee a broader economic impact from the growing number of mortgage defaults and home foreclosures, its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke said, and he cautioned against excessive regulation of lenders. [C1.] A gauge of future economic activity forecasts that the nation's economy will slow in coming months, and suggests that higher gas prices are beginning to take their toll.[C4.] STITCHING TOGETHER A COMPANY -- Louis Gallois, Airbus's third chief executive in 12 months, took the job last year after Airbus and its parent, EADS, announced a major delay in producing its new flagship, the A380 superjumbo jet. He has made progress toward setting the company back on track. But healing the multinational rifts that led to the delay is a challenge he concedes he did not fully anticipate. [C3.] WPP BUYS ONLINE ADVERTISING FIRM -- The WPP Group, the advertising holding company, agreed to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company. [C3.] FINANCIER DENIES HE IS A TARGET -- A Syrian-born financier, Wafic Said, who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago, said that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities. [C3.] WORKING BOTH SIDES OF A DEAL -- Citigroup played a leading role on both sides of a recent deal when Whyte & Mackay, the whiskey maker, was bought out by United Spirits. Citigroup was an adviser to the distiller, and a lender to the buyer. [C7.] WAYS TO KEEP VIEWERS -- A broadcast network, CW, will soon offer advertisers two more ways to try holding the attention of viewers throughout those commercial breaks that consumers love to hate. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] OUT OF PRINT? NOT SO FAST -- Simon & Schuster is proposing a change in the way it defines when a book is out of print. The change, which reflects new print-on-demand technologies, would allow more books to stay under contract longer, and the Authors Guild is urging a protest. [C3.] AFTER SPITZER -- Under Eliot Spitzer, lawyers in the New York attorney general's office reined in Wall Street analysts, curbed mutual fund abuses and corralled insurance companies. Now that Mr. Spitzer, left, occupies the governor's office in Albany, the options facing these lawyers have ranged from law firm partnerships to state agency heads. And some have chosen to join big Wall Street law firms. [C6.] MARKETS SLIP -- Stocks edged lower as an upbeat report on business conditions in the mid-Atlantic region, coupled with data suggesting strength in the job market, signaled a reduced chance of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. [C9.] UNION'S HELP FOR YOUNG WORKERS -- The Service Employees International Union has created a nonprofit organization that plans to provide health insurance and financial advice to young workers, while also publicly advocating for issues important to labor. [A18.] SEEKING A NOMINEE'S WITHDRAWAL -- Senate Democrats urged President Bush to withdraw his nomination of a lobbyist from the National Association of Manufacturers to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, saying the candidate was unqualified and the appointment posed conflicts of interest. [A23.] SAUDI FIRM NEAR DEAL FOR G.E. UNIT -- General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabia's largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to people briefed on the negotiations. [C2.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. AN INVESTMENT advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by votes cast without guidance from shareholders. (DOW JONES) A FORMER marketing executive of the American-based food distribution unit of the Dutch food retailer Ahold was sentenced to seven years in prison by a federal judge for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud. (REUTERS)

The Native Americans who will be celebrated this weekend in Lower Manhattan have nothing to do with the West, unless you're talking about the far, far West. While frontier figures like Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse may have captured the popular imagination, Hawaiians are Native Americans too. ''Hawaii is a part of the indigenous culture that hasn't been present much at our museum,'' said Shawn Termin, cultural arts manager for the National Museum of the American Indian. ''We thought it was time.''
