A music review in The Arts yesterday about Peter Gallagher's nightclub debut, at Feinstein's at the Regency, misstated the closing date of his engagement. It ends June 2, not tonight.
To the Editor: Re ''A Defense We Just Don't Need (Yet)'' (Op-Ed, May 17):

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Wolfowitz and World Bank Agree on His Resignation Paul D. Wolfowitz announced his resignation as president of the World Bank, ending weeks of furor over charges of favoritism. As part of a negotiated settlement, the bank's board accepted his assertion that his actions were honorably intended, despite a committee recommendation that he be forced to resign for violating his contract. A1 U.S. and Iran to Meet on Iraq The United States and Iran announced plans to hold face-to-face talks this month about Iraqi security, the State Department said. In Mosul, Iraq, the police made mass arrests after a wave of bombings, according to a police spokesman. A10 No Fight for British Premier The governing Labor Party in Britain confirmed that Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, had emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Prime Minister Tony Blair when he steps down in June. A6 Sarkozy Names Prime Minister President Nicolas Sarkozy of France named François Fillon, left, to be his prime minister in a move to carry out his ambitious reform program. A14 Israeli Force Attacks Hamas Israel moved a small number of tanks and troops over the Gaza border and hit Hamas with eight airstrikes, killing at least seven Palestinians. Five other Palestinians died in factional fighting despite a new cease-fire. A12 Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel paid an unannounced visit to the border town of Sderot to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip. A12 Belarus Kept Off U.N. Council Belarus, one of the world's most repressive states, was blocked from gaining membership on the United Nations Human Rights Council after being outvoted in favor of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a late entry. A6 NATIONAL A16-23 Agreement Is Reached On Immigration Bill Senate negotiators from both parties announced that they had reached agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill that would offer legal status to most of the nation's 12 million illegal immigrants while toughening border security. A1 Senate to Vote on Gonzales Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's standing in Congress weakened further as Senate Democrats arranged to hold a no-confidence vote on him and the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee predicted that the furor over Mr. Gonzales's stewardship would end with his resignation. A16 Obama Disputes Claims on War Senator Barack Obama directly challenged former President Bill Clinton's assertions that Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hold the same essential positions on the Iraq war. A22 Dispute Over Bush Nominee Senate Democrats urged President Bush to withdraw his nomination of a top lobbyist from the National Association of Manufacturers to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, saying the candidate was unqualified and the appointment posed conflicts of interest. A23 Universities Housing Ashes For a few thousand dollars, some universities are giving alumni and faculty the opportunity to have their ashes maintained on campus in perpetuity. A16 Steering Lost Whales to Sea Anxious to save two injured wayward whales, a team of marine rescuers played recorded humpback songs hoping to lure the whales from the Sacramento River in California back to sea. A18 SCIENCE/HEALTH Soldier's Vaccine Harmed Son A 2-year-old boy nearly died from a viral infection he got from the smallpox vaccination his father received before shipping out to Iraq, according to a government report and the doctors who treated him. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 For Survivors of Bronx Fire, Sense of Normalcy Returns Ten weeks after six members of the Magassa family -- including five children -- were killed when a fast-moving fire consumed their narrow brick house in the Bronx, most of the family has resettled into a new home. If sadness hangs over the apartment, it is invisible. A1 Agreement on River Plan Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania announced that he and Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, left, had agreed on a plan to deepen the Delaware River shipping channel in a $300 million effort to rejuvenate the once-thriving maritime industry in Philadelphia and South Jersey. The agreement ends a contentious stalemate that lasted more than 16 months. B5 Mythic Creatures in Manhattan The exhibition ''Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns & Mermaids'' is set to open at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. The show, a melding of science and legend, investigates the cultural roots of imaginary beasts from Asia, Europe and the Americas like the sea monster, the griffin and the Cyclops. B1 OBITUARIES B8 Giorgio Cavaglieri An architect who took his fascination with how buildings and cities change over time from his native Italy to New York, where he helped start and define the city's preservation movement, he was 95. B8 Denis G. Kuhn An architect who oversaw many major restoration and reuse projects in New York City, including the transformation of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House into the Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian and the conversion of the old Police Department headquarters in Little Italy into elegant apartments, he was 65. B8 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Disclosing Pension Costs Texas lawmakers are close to rejecting a requirement that state governments disclose the cost of health care they have promised to retired employees -- a rule intended to encourage politicians to deal with the huge obligations they have imposed on future taxpayers. C1 China's Exports Scrutinized Weeks after tainted Chinese pet food ingredients killed and sickened thousands of dogs and cats in the United States, China is facing growing international pressure to prove that its food exports are safe to eat. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Rose Garden charade; rudeness, realism and Russia; private equity goes prime time; appointed hobblers of government. Columns: Paul Krugman, David Brooks. Crossword: E20 TV Listings: E26 Public Lives: B2 Weather C10

SANDERS--Marion. Beloved wife of Ernest H. and mother of Nina and Peter. Oma of Erich, Maia and Aniela. Friend to many. Memorial service on June 15th, 4pm, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave

P.P.O.W. 555 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through tomorrow Bill Smith has degrees in mechanical engineering, biology and sculpture. This playful show comprises chandelierlike sculptures, all made from wire, beads, magnets and the occasional bug. Because each responds to the movement of the viewer, the exhibition suggests the Newtonian principle that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

JOHNSON--Paul C. Novelist, carpenter, peace activist and homesteader, formerly of New Mexico and Brooklyn, passed away peacefully at home, with family, in Las Vegas, New Mexico, on November 20, 2006. A memorial celebration will be held for him at the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, NYC at 1:00pm, on Saturday May 26, 2007. All friends welcome. 505-799-6972.

Zimbabwe's hyperinflation reached a record annual rate of 3,714 percent in April, the government-run newspaper The Herald reported, a 1,500 percentage-point increase over the March rate. Steep increases in the cost of fuel, food and power drove the rate higher, the Central Statistical Office was quoted as stating. The new rate effectively means that average prices in Zimbabwe rose 36-fold between April 2006 and April 2007. MICHAEL WINES

CAVAGLIERI--Giorgio, 95, May 15, 2007. Architect, brother, uncle and special friend, inspired all who knew him active in urban affairs over his long distinguished career. Survived by Natalie Meadow, nieces, nephew, grand, greatgrand nieces and nephews. Memorial to be announced.

A Bronx man was shot and stabbed to death yesterday outside a restaurant he owned, the police said. The man, Douglas Mills, 36, was killed about 2:30 p.m. outside the D&R Jamaican and American Restaurant at Morris Avenue and East 151st Street. The police said they did not know what led to the killing, adding that an investigation was under way. John Mills, Mr. Mills's father, said his son was one of 17 siblings, only 12 of whom are still alive. ''People raise their kids so they can take care of you when you're old, not so you can take care of them and bury them,'' he said. MATTHEW SWEENEY

NICELEY--Vivian ''Elaine''. On Saturday, May 12, 2007, Elaine Niceley of Glenn Dale, Maryland, beloved wife of Christopher Niceley; devoted and adored mother of Karen Louise Niceley and Kelly Lyn Niceley, died suddenly of a heart attack. She was the daughter of the late Donald and Eldora White of the Bronx, NY, and sister of the late Richard C. White. She is also survived by her cousin, Reverend Bernard Ruffin and other cousins; her brothersin-law, Bruce and Ted Niceley, and dozens of close friends who loved her dearly. The Robert E. Evans Funeral Home, Rte 450 and Race Track Rd, Bowie, MD on Thursday, May 17, 2007 from 2-4 and 6-8pm. A memorial service will be held 11am, Saturday, May 19 at Asbury United Methodist Church, 11th and K Sts NW, Washington DC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in Elaine's name to the Caron Foundation, PO Box 150, Wernersville, PA 19565. www.caron.org
HARAGSIM--Karen (nee Platt). A great lover of life; she was adored and will be deeply missed. Love, Jane and Les

BLAME Mark Burnett, the reality-television producer best known for ''Survivor.'' In the mid-'90s, he created the Eco-Challenge race and accompanying TV series, and an exotic new sport called adventure racing was stamped on the American consciousness. Today, hundreds of adventure races are attended by thousands of Eco-Challenge wannabes each year, on wilderness courses in the mountains and deep woods from Maine to Alaska. Trekking, mountain biking, canoeing, climbing, trail running and map-and-compass navigation are all put to the test as teams of two to four people -- typically both men and women -- search for hidden checkpoint flags. Racers need wilderness skills, strength and aerobic capacity as they move nonstop through a prescribed series of activities during events that last from four hours to several days.
To the Editor: Re ''A Human Capital Agenda,'' by David Brooks (column, May 15):

A judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit filed by tenants challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project, saying they had filed their suit in the wrong court. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of offering an unfair package of provisions to relocate tenants at two buildings in Brooklyn, 473 Dean Street and 634 Pacific Street. Justice Walter B. Tolub said the suit should have been filed directly in the Appellate Division of Supreme Court. A. J. Carter, a spokesman for the development corporation, said the agency was pleased with the decision. George Locker, a lawyer for the tenants, said he would file his suit in the appellate court even though he believed the Supreme Court had jurisdiction. ALAN FEUER

This retrospective devoted to the work of the tabloid reporter and crime novelist turned director should really be titled ''Sam Fuller!'' to reflect both his fondness for appending exclamation points to his titles (''Fixed Bayonets!,'' ''Verboten!'') and his filmmaking, which is so loaded with huge close-ups and percussive editing that Jean-Luc Godard once called it ''ciné-fist.'' This program at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens features most of Fuller's major films in hard-to-find 35-millimeter archival prints. The selection for this weekend includes the 1951 ''Bayonets!,'' about a weak-willed officer (Richard Basehart) caught up in combat operations in Korea; ''Park Row'' (1952), his preposterously action-packed tribute to the early days of New York newspapering; and his two color and CinemaScope films for Fox: the cold-war submarine drama ''Hell and High Water'' (1954), with Richard Widmark as a former naval officer out to stop a Communist Chinese plot, and ''House of Bamboo'' (1955), starring Robert Ryan, as an Army veteran using his leadership skills to establish a crime ring in Tokyo, and Robert Stack (above, with Shirley Yamaguchi). (Through June 10, Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, 718-784-0077, movingimage.us; $10.) DAVE KEHR

Emerging from 17 days in the jungle after fleeing from guerrillas, Jhon Frank Pinchao, a police officer, stunned Colombians with his tale of escape after more than eight years in captivity. Mr. Pinchao, left, looking rawboned, said he shimmied off his chains, waded through rivers and endured dehydration, sunburn and insect bites before stumbling across a police patrol. He also offered news of three Americans held hostage by the guerrillas, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia for four years -- Marc Gonsalves, Thomas Howes and Keith Stansell -- as well as of Ingrid Betancourt, kidnapped in 2002 while running for president. All are still alive, Mr. Pinchao said. SIMON ROMERO

To the Editor: Paul Krugman is right that dealing with the negative impact of trade on American workers requires universal health care and a wide variety of pro-worker policies (''Divided Over Trade,'' column, May 14). The reason we do not have such policies is of course the opposition of American business and its Republican allies.

LAWRENCE--Jacob (Jack), 83, on May 16. Retired from his veterinary practice to pursue his many passions. Committed to social justice, an avid fisherman, folk dancer and lifelong learner. His endless curiosity and zest for life inspire us all. He had two wonderful marriages, first to Adele and then to Miriam (Friedman). Father to Jon Lawrence (wife Elisabeth), Vicki Blier (husband Malcolm). Stepfather to Rachel Friedman. Grandpa to Stefan and Marika Lawrence, Sam and Zack Blier. Brother of Rachel Lawrence. Generous anchor of a large and loving extended family. Donations in Jack's memory may be made to Physicians for a National Health Program, NY Metro, 2753 Broadway, #

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Matthew Levin Not rated; 99 minutes There may be a point to ''The Boy Who Cried Bitch: The Adolescent Years,'' a purportedly fact-based psychodrama about the teenage evolution of a future serial killer. But the film is so clumsily written and directed, and the performances so one-note, that any potential for enlightenment is suffocated.

'KING KONG' ''Why, in a few months, it'll be up in lights on Broadway: 'Kong -- the Eighth Wonder of the World,' '' Carl Denham (Robert Armstrong) said in the 1933 film. King Kong did go on to make a Broadway debut in the movie, before he grabbed Ann Darrow (Fay Wray) and bolted to the top of the Empire State Building. Now the big lug, reincarnated yet again, is returning to the stage, in the East Village this time, when ''King Kong'' opens on Thursday at the Red Room Theater. Don't expect to see a sweaty actor in a furry suit: this ''King Kong'' is a production of Horse Trade and RadioTheater, the three-year-old company run by Dan Bianchi. Some of the company's earlier endeavors, like the pulp fiction takeoff ''Hard Boiled'' and another version of ''King Kong,'' strived to recreate the real atmosphere of a 1940s radio station and perhaps went too far. Mr. Bianchi, the group's founder and director, had set out to create something new, inspired by the golden age of radio, but the period costumes and entrances and exits of past productions made the shows too much like regular plays, he said. ''We were creating a museum piece. If you're going to go that far, where is the big King Kong?''
A clutch of trailblazing downtown shops present an idiosyncratic blend of design, art and clothes.

Joe Torre referenced 1951 after the game tonight. For Torre, who grew up a New York Giants fan, that year has powerful resonance. The Giants came storming back from a huge deficit to beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in a classic pennant race.

Alexander Shabalov, who was already leading by a full point, continued his fine play, chalking up a win against Gregory Kaidanov in the fifth round of the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. Shabalov, who is now a perfect five for five, leads a pack of six grandmasters by 1.5 points with only four rounds to go. All the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.
Looking at the possibilities for the presidency of the World Bank, I like the idea of Tony Blair.

In March I wrote about a woman in Pakistan whose daughter had been raped and murdered -- and then her problems really began. The authorities, at the behest of feudal leaders, arrested some innocent poor people and drove the Hasina away when she protested. It's a reminder of just how feudal rural Pakistan can be.
In Hong Kong I had breakfast with an old friend and a man I greatly admire, Han Dongfang. He also makes me a little optimistic about China's evolution.

With the halls of Congress abuzz this week about the Big I's-immigration and Iraq- not to mention new revelations about Attorney General Alberto Gonzales's term as White House counsel, the legislative branch takes center stage on tomorrow's talk shows.
I was talking in the clubhouse yesterday with Darrell Rasner, who improbably would be making his sixth start of the season today. Only Andy Pettitte has made more.

All three games in round 9 of the M-Tel Masters in Sofia, Bulgaria, ended in draws today. So the standings remain the same with Krishnan Sasikiran of India leading by a half-point over Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, Shakhriyar Mademyarov of Azerbaijan, Gata Kamsky of the United States and Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania. With the field so tightly bunched, and with Sasikiran playing Topalov, the tournament will be decided tomorrow in the last round. Games from the tournament can be replayed here at the tournament's Web site.

Oliver Perez pitched an excellent 7 2/3 innings last night. Billy Wagner finished off the Yankees in the ninth, getting Jason Giambi to chase a slider on the ninth pitch of the at-bat to wrap up the victory. So, what happened to the other 1/3 of an inning?
A graphical look at the 132nd Preakness Stakes in Baltimore.

The immigration deal in the Senate is putting pressure on the leading presidential candidates to take a position on the issue. Many of the candidates released statements about the Senate plan, (You can see what they've said previously on the issue here), but Mitt Romney took it one step further with an ad that begins running this weekend that highlights his call for a secure border and an "employment verification system."
The decrepitude of Africa’s colleges is depriving dozens of nations of the homegrown expertise that could lift millions out of poverty.
Curlin and Street Sense in a thrilling finish to the 132nd Preakness Stakes.

Is America ready for its first tech president? Tech-types here are calling for the presidential candidates to catch up with their global counterparts, both on the campaign trail and in their campaign platforms.
Images of the Grand Canyon Skywalk.
In the autobiographical film “Last Days of Left Eye,” Lisa Lopes, whose public pose was typically kinetic and highly styled, lolls in the Honduran countryside.

Alexander Shabalov, a grandmaster who lives in Pittsburgh, is putting on quite a show at the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. In Round 4, he beat Hikaru Nakamura, the highest ranked player in the tournament. All of the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.
Hamas claimed responsibility for a missile strike on an Israeli army bulldozer in an escalation by both sides.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s six-year tenure as a director of Wal-Mart remains a little-known chapter in her closely scrutinized career.
The San Antonio Spurs finally squashed Steve Nash and the pesky Suns Friday night, 114-106, in front of a raucous crowd.
Mets Manager Willie Randolph’s experience coaching the Yankees’ Andy Pettitte came in handy on Friday night.
In Palmyra, N.J., a town of 7,000 people, suspicions have arisen after the arrest of six men who prepared for a spectacular attack on soldiers at Fort Dix.
The state attorney general is seeking information about whether brokers pressured appraisers to inflate property values.
After a season-ending defeat at the hands of the Cleveland Cavaliers, the Nets will move into a summer of uncertainty.
Oliver Pérez baffled the Yankees for seven and two-thirds innings and the Mets rode Endy Chávez’s two-run homer to win the first of three games at Shea Stadium.
The Yankees have scored two runs or fewer in 6 of their 11 games since the team signed Roger Clemens on May 6.
Carlos Gómez, the Mets’ precocious 21-year-old outfielder, does not play with discretion. He takes wide turns on singles to the outfield, dives headfirst for balls and shows no fear at the plate.

An article on Tuesday about a case before the Connecticut Supreme Court that questions whether civil unions for same-sex couples fulfill the state’s constitutional obligation to treat individuals equally misidentified the legal standard that would be applied if the court found that gay men and lesbians were a “suspect class,” a status, like membership in a racial minority, that makes laws that categorize on that basis suspect. The standard is “heightened scrutiny,” which requires the state to prove that discrimination against gay men and lesbians is related to an important or compelling government interest; it is not “rational basis,” a more relaxed standard in which the state is required to show only that it had such a basis for making a distinction between single-sex and heterosexual couples.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns in Congress that Al Hurra, an American-financed television channel in the Middle East, was broadcasting the views of militant groups referred incorrectly to comments by Joaquin F. Blaya, a Hurra executive, about the criticism. He said it was ironic that the government was seeking to promote values like democracy and a free press while trying to censor — not censure — what was shown on the station.

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a partnership of Vornado Realty Trust and Donald J. Trump, which controls two buildings in New York and San Francisco, misstated the role of David H. Pikus in mediation proceedings involving Mr. Trump and his former partners in a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Pikus is the special discovery master, in charge of working out discovery schedules and procedures — not the mediator, who is Simeon H. Baum, president of Resolve Mediation Services Inc.

A front-page article yesterday about the role that Barack Obama’s wife, Michelle, is playing in his presidential campaign rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Valerie Jarrett, a friend of the Obamas who commented on their decision that he would run. She said in a telephone interview, “Barack and Michelle thought long and hard about this decision before they made it” — not that they “fought” long and hard.

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about the Pioneer BDC-2202 computer drive incorrectly described its capabilities. The drive can read Blu-ray discs and can read and record on CDs and DVDs; it cannot record on Blu-ray discs.

A picture in The Arts on Tuesday with an article about the Broadway season was published in error. The photograph, of a scene from “Grey Gardens,” showed the Off Broadway production, not the one on Broadway. The actress on the left, Audrey Twitchell, is not in the Broadway production.

An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea.

The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the pitching situation for the Mets and the Yankees as they approached this weekend’s interleague series, referred incorrectly to the timing of an injury sustained by the Yankees’ Phil Hughes. He pulled his left hamstring while taking a no-hitter into the seventh inning of his second start, not his debut.
An obituary on Thursday about Norman Frank, the spokesman for the New York City Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association in the 1960s, misspelled his surname at birth. It was Fetbrod, not Fetrod.

An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea.

An article yesterday about the Army’s decision to relieve a commander and platoon leader of their commands in Iraq in June 2006 after enlisted men were ambushed and killed misidentified the news organization that first reported the story. It was The Houston Chronicle, not The Associated Press.

If running back Ricky Williams makes a comeback, it will probably be with a new team. “I will not allow our fans to be let down by people that are not on our roster — not again,” said Cam Cameron, the Dolphins’ first year coach. An N.F.L. rushing champion for Miami in 2002, Williams, who turns 30 on Monday, tested positive for marijuana again last month, which will delay his return to the league until at least September. His current suspension began in April 2006 after he violated the league’s drug policy for the fourth time.

Serena Williams made an array of mistakes yesterday in her final match before the French Open, losing to Patty Schnyder, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (5), at the Italian Open quarterfinals in Rome. Schnyder will face third-seeded Jelena Jankovic, who routed Elena Dementieva, 6-2, 6-1. Second-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova and ninth-seeded Daniela Hantuchova will play in the other semifinal.

The N.C.A.A.’s committee on women in sports will review its guidelines amid reports of female athletes being threatened with the loss of scholarships if they became pregnant. Janet Kittell, the leader of the N.C.A.A.’s committee on women’s athletics, said that her group would review the rules on pregnancy in July.Last week, Cassandra Harding, a member of the Memphis track team, told The Associated Press that she lost her scholarship after becoming pregnant, and a Clemson athlete told ESPN that she had an abortion to stay in college.

A California congressman has joined the cause against Falcons quarterback Michael Vick, writing a letter yesterday that urged N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to “act swiftly and forcefully” if Vick was involved in dog fighting on his former property.The congressman, Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, is a senior member of the Oversight and Government Reform Committee. He raised the prospect of government intervention if the N.F.L. failed to discipline Vick. “I am outraged that one of the National Football League’s superstars is affiliated with such a heinous enterprise,” Lantos wrote.

The Giants named Marc Ross as their director of college scouting yesterday, filling a vacancy created when Jerry Reese was promoted to general manager in January. Ross, 34, was 27 when the Eagles made him the N.F.L.’s youngest college scouting director in December 2000. He spent the past three seasons as the national college scout for the Buffalo Bills.

Cincinnati linebacker A. J. Nicholson was arrested on a domestic violence charge yesterday, the first arrest of a Bengals player since Commissioner Roger Goodell cracked down on misconduct last month.Nicholson was already one of nine Bengals players arrested during a nine-month stretch, turning the team into a prime example of player misconduct. The police in Taylor Mill, Ky., arrested Nicholson after a woman called 911 yesterday afternoon to say that she had been assaulted by Nicholson. He was charged with fourth-degree assault, a misdemeanor.

Rafael Nadal extended his record winning streak on clay to 80 matches yesterday by defeating Fernando González, 6-4, 6-4, to reach the semifinals of the Hamburg Masters. Roger Federer also advanced, but he struggled to beat David Ferrer, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. Federer faces Carlos Moyá, who defeated fourth-seeded Novak Djokovic, 7-6 (4), 4-6, 7-5. Nadal will play Lleyton Hewitt after Hewitt, playing in his first clay-court quarterfinal in three years, beat Nicolás Almagro, 6-3, 6-4.
The World Series rematch was a mismatch. This time, the Detroit Tigers came out on top.

Opinion polls suggest that Romanians will reject Parliament’s attempt to remove President Traian Basescu from power in a referendum today. Parliament suspended him last month and called the impeachment referendum on the ground that he had overstepped his authority. Turnout is expected to be high.

Robert Faurisson, a French academic and outspoken Holocaust denier, was prevented from holding a talk at Teramo University in central Italy when the rector, Mauro Mattioli, decided to shut down the university for the day because of rising tensions over Mr. Faurisson’s presence. Mr. Faurisson had been invited to lecture at the university by a professor who runs a master’s program in Middle East studies. The decision to close the campus was taken because of security considerations, Mr. Mattioli said in a statement. In Poland, meanwhile, another well-known Holocaust denier, the British historian and author David Irving, was ordered to leave the Warsaw International Book Fair after he turned up publicize his work, organizers of the fair said.

A 400-pound gorilla escaped from his enclosure and ran amok in a Rotterdam zoo, the Diergaarde Blijdorp, biting one woman, dragging her around and causing panic among dozens of visitors before he was subdued, officials and a witness said. Four people were injured, including the woman who was bitten, the zoo’s director said. The zoo, one of the oldest in the Netherlands, was evacuated and the 11-year-old gorilla, Bokito, was eventually contained in a restaurant within the park, the police said. He was shot with a sedative dart and recaptured, a zoo spokeswoman said. It was not immediately clear how he managed to climb the high stone walls surrounding his enclosure. A witness, Robert de Jonge, told NOS radio: “Everyone was in panic, running away, screaming, wailing, screaming kids running around. It was a total drama.”.

Parliament voted to exempt President Nursultan Nazarbayev from a provision in the Constitution limiting presidents to serving two terms. The vote effectively clears the way for Mr. Nazarbayev, a former Communist Party official who has led Kazakhstan since its independence from the Soviet Union, to become president for life. Mr. Nazarbayev has never been elected by a poll judged free or fair by Western election monitors and has long been dogged by corruption allegations and complaints of crackdowns on the opposition and the news media. But Kazakhstan, which gave up its abandoned Soviet nuclear arsenal after independence, has been spared the wars, terrorism, personality cults and much of the disorder of other Central Asian states. Many of Mr. Nazarbayev’s critics say he has significant popular support.

The military-backed government detained three supporters of Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister ousted in a coup in September, as it opened a nationwide crackdown on radio stations after closing three in Bangkok that broadcast his comments. The detentions were the first against backers of Mr. Thaksin since the coup. The police said the three were preparing an anti-junta rally in Chiang Mai, the home province of Mr. Thaksin, who now lives in London.
The long-dominant National Liberation Front kept its leading position despite a record low turnout.
A thief was killed by a city bus in the South Bronx as he fled on a bicycle after stealing a gold chain from a jewelry store, the police said.
At least 146 contract workers were killed in the first three months of 2007, revealing the increased risks they face as the military steps up its effort.
Microsoft’s $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive signaled its struggle to build an Internet ad business on its own.
A former fashion writer had already planned to carry out a crime spree when he sexually abused a onetime co-worker, a psychologist for the prosecution testified Friday.
Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman at General Motors, declared that its new hybrid-electric concept car may be among the most important vehicles that G.M. has ever developed.
Street Sense is a 7-5 favorite to win the Preakness Stakes, but the field contains several dangerous challengers.
Hours before a bipartisan deal on immigration policy was to be announced Thursday, a tenuous compromise was threatening to unravel.
The delay comes as concerns mount about the safety of drugs in its class and provides a temporary reprieve to rival Amgen.
A small but growing number of intrepid homeowners have figured out a way to make their prime locations pay.
Roger Clemens pitched four innings, allowed one run and three hits and struck out two for the Class A Tampa Yankees in front of a capacity crowd of 10,257 on Friday.
The Mets’ Endy Chávez and his agent, Chris Leible, quickly learned that one remarkable catch last October would change everything.
Clear Channel agreed to accept a revised buyout offer from Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners.
The suit accusing David A. Stockman and 13 others of using fraudulent schemes that worsened the company’s financial troubles.
The military said that two of the six suspected insurgents arrested Friday were considered “key leaders” of a “secret-cell terrorist network.”
A Long Island jury said that the Roman Catholic Church was negligent by hiring and retaining the man who abused the plaintiffs.
Explorers for a shipwreck exploration company based in Tampa, Fla., said that they had located a treasure that may be the richest undersea treasure recovery to date.
At a meeting in New York this week, the leaders of dozens of cities produced a plan that should shame G-8 leaders into at least saying something about climate change at their meeting next month.
A report exposes failures that enabled Ralph J. Phillips to slip away repeatedly from pursuers in western New York who spotted but were unable to snare him.
President Bush protects his embattled advisers because they are doing precisely what he told them to do.
The ground rules for choosing the bank’s leadership should be changed to require merit selection and open up the job to highly qualified applicants worldwide.
From the very beginning, profit mongers who were eager to exploit the federal Reading First initiative, the cornerstone of the No Child Left Behind Act, were given plenty of room to do so.

The state attorney general said he would not bring criminal charges against an electric utility over a 2005 reservoir collapse that seriously injured a family of five. The collapse of the stone retaining wall around the Taum Sauk reservoir spilled more than one billion gallons of water across a state park. A park superintendent and his family were hurt. The attorney general, Jay Nixon, said the Highway Patrol “found no suspects to charge criminally.” But he said it was clear the utility, the Ameren Corporation, “repeatedly put profit over safety. For this they will be held accountable.” The state is pursuing a civil settlement with Ameren, which has accepted responsibility.

A military jury recommended that a Navy lawyer spend six months in prison and be dismissed from the Navy for sending a human rights lawyer the names of 550 Guantánamo Bay detainees in a Valentine’s Day card. The defendant, Lt. Cmdr. Matthew Diaz, was convicted Thursday at his court-martial of communicating secret information about detainees that could be used to injure the United States and three other charges of leaking information. The jury recommended that Commander Diaz receive his pay and benefits while incarcerated, but the sentence must be approved by Rear Admiral Rick Ruehe. The dismissal will also be reviewed by a military appellate court, the Navy said.

Joseph L. Bruno, left, majority leader of the New York State Senate, and his fellow Senate Republicans are expected to endorse Rudolph W. Giuliani for president on Tuesday in Albany. The announcement is significant because the Senate is the Republican Party’s last statewide power base and because the state’s elective influence was bolstered when New York officials recently moved the 2008 primary date to Feb. 5 from March 4. “He’s coming up Tuesday and we’re looking forward to doing some very positive things with him at that time,” Mr. Bruno said of Mr. Giuliani.

Hamid Hayat, left, a Lodi man convicted last year of providing material support for terrorism by attending a training camp in Pakistan, lost his appeal for a new trial and will be sentenced Aug. 10. Mr. Hayat, 24, faces up to 39 years in prison, after Judge Garland E. Burrell Jr. of Federal District Court in Sacramento denied the motion for a new trial Thursday. In the appeal, Mr. Hayat’s lawyer said the trial was unfair because the jury foreman hid a prejudice against Pakistanis. The lawyer also objected to the way testimony from an F.B.I. informant and several expert witnesses was handled.

Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles abandoned his effort to take control of city schools, announcing he would not appeal a court decision that blocked his plan to gain a hand running the huge Los Angeles Unified School District. “It’s time to get out of the courtroom and into the classroom,” Mr. Villaraigosa said. The announcement comes a month after the California Second District Court of Appeal upheld a ruling that the mayor’s plan to shift some district powers to his office was unconstitutional. The school board president, Marlene Canter, who opposed the takeover, called Mr. Villaraigosa’s decision “a new beginning.”.

SCHWARTZ--Helen (nee Climo), beloved wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother passed away May 17 in Florida at age 98. She was the widow of Rabbi Harry E. Schwartz, spiritual leader of Congregation Beth Israel in Hempstead, NY for 35 years. Born in Cleveland, Ohio, she graduated Hebrew Teacher's Seminary and spent more than 40 years in Hebrew and Jewish education as a principal, teacher and music director. She is survived by three sons; Beryl I. Dulsky (Arlene) of Scottsdale, AZ, Dr. Joel M. Schwartz (Florence) of Brooklyn, NY, Professor Shalom H. Schwartz (Penina) of Jerusalem, and by eight loving grandchildren and 19 great-grandchildren. Funeral services on Sunday May 20, 9:15am, at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

One statistic seems to me to give the lie to all the rhetoric about abortion, and it's this: one in three women under the age of 45 have an abortion during their lifetime. One in three. All politicians -- Democrat and Republican -- say they want to make abortion at least rare (as Giuliani did in Wednesday's debate). On, this they could reach agreement. But it's clear they haven't been serious; the U.S. has 1.3 million abortions a year. Reducing unintended pregnancy is the key -- half of pregnancies are unintended, and 4 in 10 of them end in abortion. For a while now, we've had solid evidence about how to effectively do this. But it requires getting specific about two subjects that are perilous in politics: sex and contraception. That, politicians won't do. So let me try to help with four facts everyone needs to know.

It's Taylor's van Gogh An American court ruled on Friday that Elizabeth Taylor can keep her van Gogh, Reuters reported. Ms. Taylor, 75, bought the 1889 painting ''View of the Asylum and Chapel at Saint-Rémy'' at a London auction in 1963 for £92,000 (then about $257,000). South African and Canadian descendants of Margarete Mauthner, a Jewish woman who fled Germany in 1939, sued her in 2004, saying the work had been confiscated by the Nazis and should be returned to them under the Holocaust Victims Redress Act. A three-judge panel of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals backed a lower court, ruling that the family had waited too long in claiming the painting, long known to be in Ms. Taylor's possession. Imus Aide Auditions Bernard McGuirk, who was a producer and on-air personality on ''Imus in the Morning,'' will audition for a spot on a Boston radio talk show, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGuirk, above, who took part in the racist banter that led Don Imus and him to be fired last month, will be on ''Finneran's Forum'' on WRKO-AM on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. He will be on with Tom Finneran, a former speaker of the Massachusetts House, who began his morning show in February after pleading guilty to obstructing justice for lying about his role in a redistricting plan. He was fined and given 18 months' probation.

An article on Tuesday about a case before the Connecticut Supreme Court that questions whether civil unions for same-sex couples fulfill the state's constitutional obligation to treat individuals equally misidentified the legal standard that would be applied if the court found that gay men and lesbians were a ''suspect class,'' a status, like membership in a racial minority, that makes laws that categorize on that basis suspect. The standard is ''heightened scrutiny,'' which requires the state to prove that discrimination against gay men and lesbians is related to an important or compelling government interest; it is not ''rational basis,'' a more relaxed standard in which the state is required to show only that it had such a basis for making a distinction between single-sex and heterosexual couples.

Fourteen-year-old Devante Johnson deserved better. He was a sweet kid, an honor student and athlete who should be enjoying music and sports and skylarking with his friends at school. Instead he's buried in Houston's Paradise North Cemetery. Devante died of kidney cancer in March. His mother, Tamika Scott, believes he would still be alive if bureaucrats in Texas hadn't fouled up so badly that his health coverage was allowed to lapse and his cancer treatment had to be interrupted.

While the Mets edged the Yankees, 3-2, at Shea Stadium, Clemens pitched four innings in Tampa, Fla. ''The only thing I didn't check on,'' Torre said, ''is if he had any hits.''

Readers who claimed they were defrauded by James Frey, the author who admitted making up portions of his best-selling memoir, ''A Million Little Pieces,'' and by his publisher, Random House, have reached a settlement. Readers in several states, including New York, California and Illinois, had filed lawsuits saying Mr. Frey and Random House had defrauded them by selling the book as a memoir rather than as a work of fiction. Neither Mr. Frey nor Random House admit any wrongdoing, but those who bought the book on or before Jan. 26, 2006 -- when the publisher and author released statements acknowledging that Mr. Frey had altered certain facts -- will be eligible for a full refund, provided they submit proof of purchase. Mr. Frey and Random House will pay up to $2.35 million, which includes the cost of refunds, lawyers' fees for both sides and a donation to charity. The settlement was preliminarily approved by Judge Richard Holwell of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. MOTOKO RICH

The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the pitching situation for the Mets and the Yankees as they approached this weekend's interleague series, referred incorrectly to the timing of an injury sustained by the Yankees' Phil Hughes. He pulled his left hamstring while taking a no-hitter into the seventh inning of his second start, not his debut.

The tenure of L. Dennis Kozlowski as chief executive of Tyco International gets more and more expensive for the company. When he was running Tyco, the company paid for such things as a $6,000 shower curtain. Now, as he resides in the Mid-State Correctional Facility in Marcy, N.Y., about a four-hour drive from his former Fifth Avenue apartment in Manhattan, Tyco has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to investors who bought Tyco securities from 1999 to 2002. The investors also get the right to sue, on the company's behalf, its former auditors at PricewaterhouseCoopers. The claim would be accounting malpractice -- essentially an assertion that the auditors should have stopped the company and its management from committing fraud. The Securities and Exchange Commission has weighed in on the job that was done by Richard Scalzo, who was lead auditor on the Tyco account, saying he repeatedly ''was faced with facts that raised serious questions about the integrity of Tyco management,'' but did not follow up on them. FLOYD NORRIS

The Giants named Marc Ross as their director of college scouting yesterday, filling a vacancy created when Jerry Reese was promoted to general manager in January. Ross, 34, was 27 when the Eagles made him the N.F.L.'s youngest college scouting director in December 2000. He spent the past three seasons as the national college scout for the Buffalo Bills. JOHN BRANCH

Your love, smile, gentle nature, sense of humor and kindness will be dearly missed by all. He proudly served his country in the Pacific during World War II. The producers of ''Coram Boy,'' the 18th-century melodrama with a 40-person cast (including Wayne Wilcox, below left, and Alexander Ashbrook) and a price tag of $6 million -- a record for a normal-length straight play on Broadway -- announced that it would close on May 27 unless, according to a statement, ''business improves.'' The play, nominated for six Tonys, began previews on April 16 and officially opened on May 2 at the Imperial Theater. So far it has never reported average weekly attendance of more than 50 percent of capacity. Bob Boyett and Bill Haber, the lead producers, imported ''Coram Boy'' from the National Theater in London, with which they have a production agreement. Just yesterday they announced that ''Journey's End,'' another play from London, would close on June 10 without recouping its investment. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
To the Editor: Re ''Middle School That Manages Distractions of Adolescence'' (news article, May 12):

A dozen years ago, Rabbi Morris Allen stood before his congregation in this Twin Cities suburb to announce a program called Chew by Choice. As Conservative Jews, the members of his synagogue were bound by religious law to eat only kosher food, but as typical Americans, relatively few did so. So the rabbi asked them just to stop eating flagrantly impermissible foods like pork and shellfish as the first step toward fuller observance of the dietary strictures. The campaign at his synagogue, Beth Jacob Congregation, ultimately won Rabbi Allen an invitation to lecture at an Orthodox yeshiva in New York. Closer to home, he served alongside Orthodox rabbis on a kosher-certification panel for the Twin Cities area and collaborated with a local Hasidic rabbi in encouraging supermarkets to stock kosher meat after the last kosher butcher in St. Paul went out of business.

GRAHAM--Colin (1931-2007). Opera Theatre of St. Louis dedicates the 2007 season to the memory of Colin Graham, our artistic director since 1985. An acclaimed director and librettist, he was ''a force in living opera,'' staging 48 new OTSL productions and a record 56 world premiers in the US and the UK. He advanced the careers of many young artist and will be sorely missed.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns in Congress that Al Hurra, an American-financed television channel in the Middle East, was broadcasting the views of militant groups referred incorrectly to comments by Joaquin F. Blaya, a Hurra executive, about the criticism. He said it was ironic that the government was seeking to promote values like democracy and a free press while trying to censor -- not censure -- what was shown on the station.

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about the Pioneer BDC-2202 computer drive incorrectly described its capabilities. The drive can read Blu-ray discs and can read and record on CDs and DVDs; it cannot record on Blu-ray discs.

AIRLINE RECEIVES APPROVAL Virgin America Inc., a new low-cost carrier backed by British billionaire Richard Branson, won final approval to begin flights in the United States and keep its chief executive, Fred Reid, below, for six months. The airline can start flying once it gets needed safety permits and makes agreed-upon changes, the Transportation Department said. The agency eased a March ruling that Mr. Reid be removed immediately because he may be ''beholden'' to foreign interests. Mr. Reid, 56, was hired by Mr. Branson in 2004. The airline plans to begin with New York-San Francisco flights.

An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea.

The bipartisan immigration proposal being taken up by Congress is putting pressure on the leading presidential candidates to take a position on the issue, which could set them up for confrontations with influential constituencies within the two parties. After the announcement of the bipartisan plan on Thursday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the New York Democrat, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor who is one of the Republican frontrunners, were initially noncommittal. Both suggested on Friday that they were open to supporting it, but only with major revisions to some of its main components.

A Parting of the ways Daimler-Benz and Chrysler have had a troubled marriage almost since the start of their merger nine years ago, and this week they filed for divorce. DaimlerChrysler said it was selling the Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, the private investment firm, for $7.4 billion, although it is a sale essentially in name only.

GOSLIN--Charles. The Pratt Institute community notes with sorrow the death of Communications Design Professor Charles Goslin. During his 41-year design and teaching career, Charles educated generations of designers and illustrators and was named a Distinguished Professor in 2003. A memorial at Pratt is planned for fall 2007.

Survived by her loving family; children, Karen and Sandy; brothers, Stanley and Albert; grandchildren, Daryl and Megan; daughter-in-law Linda; her many cousins and dear friend Prame. In lieu of flowers, donations to Vitas Hospice Charitable Fund. Services at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, NY on Sunday at 10am. 516-921-5757.
To the Editor: Re ''Senators in Bipartisan Deal on Broad Immigration Bill'' (front page, May 18):

Joseph L. Bruno, left, majority leader of the New York State Senate, and his fellow Senate Republicans are expected to endorse Rudolph W. Giuliani for president on Tuesday in Albany. The announcement is significant because the Senate is the Republican Party's last statewide power base and because the state's elective influence was bolstered when New York officials recently moved the 2008 primary date to Feb. 5 from March 4. ''He's coming up Tuesday and we're looking forward to doing some very positive things with him at that time,'' Mr. Bruno said of Mr. Giuliani. DANNY HAKIM

A front-page article yesterday about the role that Barack Obama's wife, Michelle, is playing in his presidential campaign rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Valerie Jarrett, a friend of the Obamas who commented on their decision that he would run. She said in a telephone interview, ''Barack and Michelle thought long and hard about this decision before they made it'' -- not that they ''fought'' long and hard.
To the Editor: Re ''Wolfowitz Resigns, Ending Long Fight at World Bank'' (front page, May 18):

On the last official Thursday of the 2006-7 television season, ABC cemented its place as the No. 1 network on the night in the 18-to-49 demographic, a title it has not held in three decades. A 75-minute ''Grey's Anatomy'' finale lifted the network to its fourth Thursday win in the demographic for the May sweeps period. CBS ended the night slightly ahead in total viewers, Nielsen estimated. Opposite the first hour of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which attracted 21.5 million viewers in the 9 o'clock hour, CBS's ''CSI'' finale ranked second, with 20.2 million viewers. NBC came in third over all, and Fox fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF
An obituary on Thursday about Norman Frank, the spokesman for the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in the 1960s, misspelled his surname at birth. It was Fetbrod, not Fetrod.
HARAGSIM--Caren (nee Platt). A great lover of life; she was adored and will be deeply missed. Love, Jane and Les

Parliament voted to exempt President Nursultan Nazarbayev from a provision in the Constitution limiting presidents to serving two terms. The vote effectively clears the way for Mr. Nazarbayev, a former Communist Party official who has led Kazakhstan since its independence from the Soviet Union, to become president for life. Mr. Nazarbayev has never been elected by a poll judged free or fair by Western election monitors and has long been dogged by corruption allegations and complaints of crackdowns on the opposition and the news media. But Kazakhstan, which gave up its abandoned Soviet nuclear arsenal after independence, has been spared the wars, terrorism, personality cults and much of the disorder of other Central Asian states. Many of Mr. Nazarbayev's critics say he has significant popular support. C. J. CHIVERS

If there was one last ounce of drama to be squeezed from these already thrilling Western Conference semifinals, Steve Nash's Phoenix Suns were going to extract it. Down by 20 points early in the fourth quarter against the San Antonio Spurs, who had coolly controlled the tempo all game, Nash fought to bring his team back within 6 points in the final 46.5 seconds.

GLUCKSMAN--Trevor. Founder Wellfleet Pottery Trevor Glucksman, 82, husband of Kathleen, father of sons Maurice, Daniel and Tobias, and grandfather of four, passed away on May 15 after a long illness. Trevor is also survived by sister Lorraine and brother Myron. In 1970, Trevor and Kathleen founded Wellfleet Pottery, their artistic collaboration and livelihood, where they produced Wellfleet Pottery Umber China, now a collectable. Trevor was born and raised in Vancouver, Canada. He studied philosophy and architecture at the University of British Columbia and University of Manitoba. In the 1950s, Trevor and Kathleen helped found Israel's nascent ceramic industry. They subsequently lived in London, England where Trevor undertook doctoral work in philosophy of art and architecture at the University of London, which he later continued at Harvard University, and Kathleen studied at the London School of Drawing and Painting. During the early 1960s, Trevor and his family lived in New York, where he worked as a creative writer in advertising on Madison Avenue, and first began to develop designs for Wellfleet Pottery. During that time, he also received an award for his work on a documentary about the aviators the Wright Brothers. Although Trevor increasingly suffered from a debilitating motor disease, he continued to draw and write short stories until his final weeks. The family will hold a memorial gathering, open to all who wish to attend, at 5 pm on June 9 at 165 Commercial Street in Wellfleet.

An article yesterday about the Army's decision to relieve a commander and platoon leader of their commands in Iraq in June 2006 after enlisted men were ambushed and killed misidentified the news organization that first reported the story. It was The Houston Chronicle, not The Associated Press.

Endy Chávez had tried to bunt Andy Pettitte's first pitch, which was the sensible strategy with a runner on second base and no outs. Manager Willie Randolph figured Pettitte might expect Chávez to try to bunt again and simply throw him a fastball. So Randolph signaled for Chávez to swing away. That became the perfect strategy. Pettitte threw a fastball, and Chávez lined it over the fence in right-center field for a two-run homer. Chávez's shot in the fifth inning erased a one-run deficit and helped the Mets defeat the Yankees, 3-2, on a cool night at Shea Stadium.

To the Editor: In ''Unfriendly Views on U.S.-Backed Arabic TV'' (news article, May 17), you report that none of Al Hurra's top executives understand the language in which this United States-financed programming is broadcast. The article also acknowledges the lack of State Department Arabic speakers as a ''major failing of American public diplomacy efforts in the Middle East.'' And last year the Iraq Study Group noted that of the 1,000 American diplomats and civilian officials in Baghdad only six were fluent in Arabic.
To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Right, It Turns Out, Does Not Take Classes'' (Thursday Styles, May 17):

FORSYTHE--Carol (Mackie), died May 18, 2007, at the age of 55, after a long illness. She was born November 26, 1951, in Gary, Indiana. She attended Indiana State University and Columbia University. Her professional life in New York began at Ziff-Davis Publishing and went on to include Fred/Alan Advertising, Nickelodeon, WILL-TV/PBS Corp. at the University of Illinois, Sesame Street Workshop, and 4 Kids Productions. A multiple Emmy-Award recipient, she was most recently associate producer of the television documentary ''Ten Sisters''. Known to her family as Suzy, Carol is survived by her husband Raymond L. Forsythe and their son Pierce Christopher Forsythe. And Jack, the SuperDog, the perfect pet. Other survivors include parents-in-deed Sarah and Paul Wilczynski, sisters Kim Paulus, Krystina Parker, and Katrina Addis, as well as Mackie sisters Cheryl, Peggy, Debby and Donna, and brother Billy. Carol leaves behind many loving and devoted friends upon whom she relied and to whom she gave much. Funeral services will be held Monday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the National Cancer Center, 88 Sunnyside Blvd., Plainview, NY 11803, Attn: Regina English.

So let's see. We're now into week No. 3 of the business world's favorite new soap opera, ''Mr. Murdoch Lusts After Dow Jones.'' And what a strange week it's been. You'd think that when someone offers $60 a share for a stock that has been stuck in the $30s, as the News Corporation's chairman, Rupert Murdoch, did, the controlling shareholders would, at the very least, want to really grapple with it. But in this case, the controlling shareholders are the three dozen or so adult members of the Bancroft family -- and grappling with things related to Dow Jones has never been their style. Nor is it the sort of thing that their supposed advisers, the trustees at the small Boston law firm of Hemenway & Barnes, tend to encourage. Indeed, family members who dare raise legitimate questions about the asset that forms the bulk of their wealth tend to be ostracized by their elders, and cut out of the loop by the trustees.

Village Chapels Inc. 6767 Eliot Avenue, Middle Village, NY. Cremation will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The American Heart Association.

On the day that the Houston Rockets fired him as their coach, Jeff Van Gundy was back preparing for a playoff game -- once again working as a television broadcaster. The Rockets did not retain the option on Van Gundy's contract, dismissing him as the coach after the Rockets' third first-round playoff exit in four seasons.

A proposal to give Verizon Communications' shareholders a voice in its executive pay practices passed with 50.18 percent of the vote, the company said yesterday -- the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation. Verizon, which has a market value of $124 billion, is the largest and most widely held company where a so-called say-on-pay proposal has received support from a majority of shareholders. A similar resolution passed at Blockbuster this month. During this proxy season, shareholders at some 20 companies have voted on such proposals, which are nonbinding.

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a partnership of Vornado Realty Trust and Donald J. Trump, which controls two buildings in New York and San Francisco, misstated the role of David H. Pikus in mediation proceedings involving Mr. Trump and his former partners in a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Pikus is the special discovery master, in charge of working out discovery schedules and procedures -- not the mediator, who is Simeon H. Baum, president of Resolve Mediation Services Inc.

Amazon.com, which has haltingly moved toward selling digital music for years, said that it would start a new service that sells songs and albums without the copy-restriction software used by most online retailers. The foray by Amazon is seen as a challenge to Apple, which dominates the sale of digital music with its iTunes service. It is also seen as a potentially serious blow to digital-rights management software, which limits copying of music. The recording industry's biggest companies have long required retailers to include such restrictions to protect their music copyrights. But the winds may be shifting.
To the Editor: Re ''Among the Rich and Famous, a New Dispute Over Air Rights'' (front page, May 16):

Consumer spending appears to be slowing. Two of the largest retailers, Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot, reported lackluster first-quarter earnings. Wal-Mart's profit climbed 8 percent, to $2.83 billion. Sales, meanwhile, rose by the smallest amount in at least a decade. The results, while disappointing, still matched Wall Street expectations. The same could not be said for Home Depot, which reported a 30 percent decline in profit for the first quarter. Its earnings declined to $1.05 billion, and overall sales barely edged up. Analysts said the results could portend trouble for retailers in the coming months, as the housing market continues to drag and the economy runs at a slower pace.

There are certain go-to benchmarks of a baseball epoch in which the hope chest of nostalgia has been looted by steroid suspicions: The feel-good chase of Roger Maris in 1998 that turned into a page of bulk fiction as Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa soon found their cartoonish might scrutinized for authenticity.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Contractor Deaths in Iraq Soar to Record Numbers Casualties among private contractors in Iraq have soared to record levels, setting a pace that seems certain to turn 2007 into the bloodiest year yet for the civilians who work alongside the American military, according to government numbers. But with patrols along the Florida coastline making it increasingly difficult to land there, desperate Haitians are looking for alternative routes to Miami, the ultimate goal for most migrating Haitians, and badly straining relations with their neighbors. A3 Anti-Kremlin Protesters Held The police detained more than a dozen opposition leaders and journalists in Moscow, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests. A1 Developments in Padilla Case Despite vigorous defense efforts to bar his testimony, a cooperating witness in the case against Jose Padilla was allowed to describe an a training camp run by Al Qaeda that prosecutors say Mr. Padilla attended. A9 Plans to Ease Katrina Relief After touring empty homes that still bear the scars of Hurricane Katrina, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that bureaucratic red tape was ''strangling people'' trying to rebuild New Orleans, and proposed steps to speed money to current and former residents of the city. A10 Treasure Discovery in Florida Explorers for a shipwreck exploration company said they had located a treasure estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars in what may be the richest undersea treasure recovery ever. A9 Evolution Opponent Up for Post The National Association of State Boards of Education will elect officers in July, and for one office, president-elect, there is only one candidate. Scientists active in the nation's evolution debate want to thwart his candidacy for his efforts against the teaching of evolution. It is the latest twist in a long-running dispute involving Jared Paul Stern, a former freelance contributor. A1 Danger in Lack of Water Valves As many as 85,000 large residential and commercial buildings in New York City lack valves on their water connections that could prevent hazardous substances from being sucked into the public water system, according to city records. B1 Award to Sex Abuse Victims A Long Island jury awarded a total of $11.45 million in damages to a young man and woman who were repeatedly raped as teenagers by a youth minister at their church. Billionaire investors helped drive the markets higher as they unveiled major stakes in a bevy of companies. On Wednesday, an affiliate company of Edward S. Lampert, the hedge fund manager, reported in a regulatory filing that it had bought more than 15 million shares in Citigroup, a purchase worth almost $800 million. That same day, Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren E. Buffett, revealed in a filing that it had raised its railroad holdings, disclosing that it had acquired stakes in Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific worth a combined $1.4 billion. And on Thursday, an affiliate company of Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, reported that as of March 31, he held a $122 million stake in another railroad company, CSX.

Helgi Tomasson, the Icelandic-born artistic director of the San Francisco Ballet, was awarded the Order of the Falcon at the Highest Order, usually reserved for monarchs, by President Olafur Ragnar Grimsson of Iceland as part of the San Francisco Ballet's engagement at the current Reykjavik Arts Festival. At the award ceremony on Tuesday, Mr. Grimsson said this award was last presented to a figure in the arts in 1957, when Halldor Laxness, winner of the 1955 Nobel Prize for literature, received it. ANNA KISSELGOFF

It's busy season for gas station attendants - with prices for a gallon of regular unleaded bopping around $3.11 nationally, they need to change their signs at least once a day. Many drivers hate these price changes, and I see their point: Not only are rising gas prices a financial burden; they also function as a sort of emotional baseball score - an index of American economic health. When prices are high, anxiety rises.

I became immersed in your special issue on aging boomers (May 6). I enjoyed the Ethicist, who wrote that if my wife told me she didn’t want to have sex anymore, I could avoid “abnegation of erotic happiness” with someone else as long as I got her permission. But forget about sex. Forget about everything at my age. That’s why Rob Walker’s article about the “plasticity” of the brain caught my attention (Consumed, “Muscular Metaphor”). Companies are offering “fitter brain” products to keep you on the edge, and boomers are signing up for adult-education classes to “keep their brains at a high level.” Although in “A Longer, Better Life,” Sara Davidson asked if doing crossword puzzles can prevent Alzheimer’s disease, and the answer was not encouraging.

An article last Sunday about a new DVD version of “The Naked City” referred incorrectly to the 1948 film. It was considered a prestige release, not a B movie. (B movies were low-budget features that played second on a double bill.).

An article on May 6 about “The Simpsons Movie” misstated the credits of the movie’s director, David Silverman. He was a co-director of “Monsters, Inc.,” not the director. And he was one of several directors of “The Road to El Dorado,” not the sole one.

An article on May 6 about the actress Nikki Blonsky included incorrect information from the actress and her director, Adam Shankman, about the circumstances of her casting in the film “Hairspray.” Morgit Management, which represented her at the time, sent New Line Cinema an e-mail message with a Web link to a copy of her audition tape. She won a tryout as a result of that e-mail message, not a copy of the tape she sent separately by mail. In addition that taped audition was made with the help of the management company, not solely by Ms. Blonsky.

LIKE the many Eskimo words for snow, a multitude of nicknames exist for the oversize houses commonly referred to as McMansions, and they mirror the uneasiness over the spread of the homes. ''You hear them called starter castles, beltway baronials, mini Taj Mahals, but my favorite is parachute homes, because of the disregard for local styles -- like they were dropped from the sky,'' said Edward J. Trawinski, a lawyer and land-use expert from Morristown, N.J.

Jane Isabel McAndrew and Elizabeth Lacy Norman celebrated their partnership with a commitment ceremony yesterday at the Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge in Brooklyn. The Rev. Mieke Vandersall, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. George LeBlanc, a minister with the Federation of Christian Ministries, led the ceremony. Ms. McAndrew, 30, is an apprentice electrician for Dean Electric, a commercial contractor in Brooklyn. She is also studying for a bachelor's degree in labor relations at the Manhattan campus of Empire State College of the State University of New York. She is the daughter of Martha C. McAndrew of Manhattan.

The lunch in the Capitol was in Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo's honor, but that did not mean it was necessarily in friendly territory. His audience, after all, was a roomful of Assembly Democrats, a group that helped unite the state party against him five years ago when he ran a bruising and ultimately unsuccessful race for governor. Some of the older lawmakers who were at the lunch nursed grudges dating to the days when Mr. Cuomo sometimes played the heavy as an aide to his father, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

What may be the ultimate Hollywood movie about Hollywood, ''THE DAY OF THE LOCUST,'' was released 32 years ago by the director John Schlesinger from Nathanael West's satirical portrait of Tinseltown in the 1930s. The disjointed 144-minute epic manqué crawls with ''locusts'' -- demented, hangers-on and climbers living in the crumbling San Bernardino Arms, an apartment building whose architecture is described as ''early earthquake.'' One resident is the original Homer Simpson, a teetotaling Iowa hayseed played by Donald Sutherland with watery-eyed blankness. He is one of several men besotted with Faye Greener (Karen Black), a dizzy blond starlet-in-waiting who shares seedy quarters with her father, Harry (Burgess Meredith), a broken-down alcoholic magician and door-to-door peddler. Their neighbor, who also falls for Faye, is Tod Hackett (William Atherton), an ambitious, hard-drinking set designer. ''The Day of the Locust'' is the centerpiece of ''TWISTED SOULS: FOUR BY JOHN SCHLESINGER,'' a four-film tribute to this British director, who died four years ago at 77. The retrospective, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, also includes his early ''Billy Liar'' (1963), ''Midnight Cowboy'' (1969) and ''Sunday Bloody Sunday'' (1971). Critically admired but seldom seen since its release, ''The Day of the Locust'' is a panoramic sideshow of grotesques clawing and clamoring for their piece of a tawdry dream. This mercilessly misanthropic swatch of gallows humor culminates in the blowing up of Hollywood at the glittering premiere of Cecil B. DeMille's 1938 adventure-romance, ''The Buccaneer,'' when a celebrity event escalates into a riot. Watching Hollywood self-destruct at the hands of its enraged citizenry is far more satisfying than any disaster movie could ever be. The rot comes from the inside. Friday and Saturday, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 496-3809, filmlinc.org.

MICHAELS--Audrey J. beloved mother of John Ehrlich, grandmother of Andrew, Adam and Matthew, passed away May 11, 2007. A lifelong New York resident, Audrey Michaels was a vital force in the classical music business in a prolific career spanning more than 60 years. The first copy girl in the music department at the New York Herald Tribune, working with Virgil Thomson and other distinguished critics. She then became Public Relations Director of the National Concert and Artists Corp (NCAC). In 1956 she moved to Columbia Artists Management as Director of PR, and in 1963 formed Audrey Michaels Public Relations, serving as its President until her death. She helped shape the careers of hundreds of internationally renown artists. Funeral services will be held on Thurs, May 17 at 11AM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NYC

The evolution of Noah Lowry continues. Lowry, below, by allowing two runs over eight innings last week, lowered his earned run average to 3.04, even though his record fell to 4-4 for the Giants. Last season, Lowry's strikeouts plummeted and he allowed home runs at a higher rate. While his walks are up, he has induced 69 percent more ground balls than fly balls. A 26-year-old left-hander, Lowry is still maturing. Justin Duchscherer is supposed to be the Oakland closer with Huston Street on the disabled list, and normally he would make a fine fill-in. But Duchscherer is battling an arthritic hip and received a cortisone shot last week after losing to Kansas City.

As the azaleas bloom, mothers who are looking for a less precious take on baby clothing are snatching up dresses by Noko, a Japan-based company. The dresses are made of tenugui, a stencil-dyed cotton gauze fabric that has been used to make towels in Japan for more than a thousand years. Noko's take on the art form -- it's protected by an artists guild -- is hand-stenciled patterns that echo traditional graphics but have a modern twist.

Is there about to be a price war among airlines flying the intensely competitive New York-London route? Zoom Airlines, which has been operating low-fare flights from Britain to Canada for three years, is starting service between London and New York on June 21. The company will offer daily flights between Gatwick and J.F.K., with 25 percent of the seats sold for as little as as $199 each way, plus taxes. Zoom is hoping its year-round one-way fares and increased flexibility (travelers do not have to stay over on a Saturday night) will give it an edge over other budget airlines that are expected to join the trans-Atlantic market following the recent ''open skies'' agreement.

I enjoyed the Freakonomics article by Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt on defining the line at which labor (''slaving in the fields'') crosses over into leisure (''tending my garden''). This distinction becomes most vivid for me when walking along any Midtown avenue in New York, glancing up at the health-club windows to see the toiling multitudes on rowing machines or StairMasters.

THE surest way to scatter my family is to mention, oh so casually, that the mulch delivery is imminent. For the last few years, since our teenage son got buff enough to wield the oversize shovel used to spread the small mountain delivered every spring, he and his dad have approached the task with the verve and good cheer of chain gang conscripts. I was never a habitual mulcher -- just a peony bed here and there -- until orthopedic issues and a balky well gave me good reason to start spreading it on thick around seven years ago. A tidy blanket of good, organic mulch keeps parched plants less stressed when I can't water. The stuff I use improves the soil, and it fends off the weeds that thrive mightily here. Keeping after those noxious invaders without mitigating mulch would surely have undone eight weeks of physical therapy for a bum neck.

Does old hat describe how you feel about Adidas and Puma? Slip on a pair of Golas. The British sport shoes have become an underground fashion darling, favored by celebrities like Chris Martin, John Legend and Mischa Barton. Gola -- which began 101 years ago, selling soccer shoes -- introduced the Luxe ballet flat for women this season ($70, in black, white and gold) and it has sold swiftly. Of course, there is still the regular lineup of assorted colorful leather trainers. Men can browse through an equally wide variety of looks, but keep an eye out for the classic Harrier model, right, in suede or calf in saturated colors ($75). Both at golausa.com.

JetBlue's new chief executive, David Barger, is loyal to more than just the blue in the airline's logo. He also is a big supporter of the maize and blue -- the University of Michigan, that is. This month, Mr. Barger, who studied political science at Michigan, gave the university $5.4 million to endow the Barger Leadership Institute in the university's Organizational Studies Program. The money will pay for internships, fellowships and other programs meant to expose Michigan students to leadership ideas.

To the Editor: I find it interesting that Allan Ripp has the time to write an article entitled ''Under the Scaffold, a No-Fight Club'' (New York Observed, May 13), but couldn't make the time to perform his civic duty and properly file a report with the police about his horrible assault. Doesn't he understand that if he doesn't report a crime, it doesn't exist?

A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about the strength of the Manhattan residential real estate market this spring referred incorrectly to the nearest cross street to the Lucida, a new condominium on East 85th Street. It is Lexington Avenue, not Third Avenue.

To the Editor: Each week the Letters page is filled with complaints about how a book was misrepresented or misunderstood (often written by the authors of those books). Doesn't anyone ever write just to say, ''Hey, thanks for the great review''? Well, here you go: Thanks for the great review. Dave Barry's review of ''Send,'' by David Shipley and Will Schwalbe (May 6), had me laughing out loud. By the end, I even thought about reading a 247-page book about, of all things, e-mail! Christian K. Anderson State College, Pa.
An article last week about the photography of Leonard Nimoy referred imprecisely to his acting career. He had some minor roles beginning in 1991; he did not stop acting in 1990.

Turnout was low throughout Westchester County in school budget elections last week, and that was mostly good news for school districts: Low turnout can mean low levels of tax unrest, and that was the case in all but a few districts. Voters in only 3 of 39 districts rejected budgets: Pleasantville, Mamaroneck and Greenburgh. Countywide, 59 percent of voters cast a yes vote, compared with 57 percent last year.

MILITO--Michael, passed away on May 18, 2007, after a long and valiant battle. Mike was a special human being, a loyal friend, a rabid Mets fan, and a gifted computer wizard. Despite years of health problems, he laughed easily and lived life to the fullest. Mike was loved by three generations of the Paul family. He lives on in our hearts and memories forever.
