MICHAEL BLOOMBERG deserves some credit for proposing that New York follow the example of London and other cities and apply congestion pricing to vehicles entering Manhattan below 86th Street weekdays from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. After all, congestion pricing -- a road-use charge levied on certain roads at specific times of the day, presumably those with the most serious congestion when traffic is heaviest -- makes sense. Indeed, it's similar to the peak-period charges paid for electricity and telephone services or the increased charges levied by hotels in high season.

AN EXPENSIVE LEMON The News Nine years after Daimler-Benz spent $36 billion for Chrysler and invested billions more in the company, the German automaker sold Chrysler to a private equity firm for $7.4 billion. Behind the News The 1998 deal was portrayed as a marriage of equals but never resulted in the savings or market power that its creators expected. Chrysler's fortunes were up and down, with profitable years followed by years of losses, including a $1.5 billion loss last year. Now Cerberus Capital Management, which specializes in restructuring troubled companies, will try its luck. ''We obviously underestimated the potential of synergies,'' Daimler's chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, said. BRING YOUR WALLET The News Gasoline prices hit a new record at the pump this week, rising to a national average price of $3.129 a gallon. Behind the News With prices so high, it must mean -- you guessed it -- that the summer vacation season is just around the bend. Refinery outages and tight supplies have sent pump prices soaring by some 40 percent since January, and in some cities, the price is nearing $4. Wal-Mart says high gas prices have kept people from coming to its stores, but the auto group AAA said it expects 38 million Americans to travel at least 50 miles on the Memorial Day weekend. Perhaps they can fantasize that they're filling up at a European petrol station, where astronomic gas prices are the norm. FLUNKING INSPECTION The News Dale Earnhardt Jr., the son of a legend and the most popular driver in Nascar, was severely penalized by Nascar officials, along with his race team and crew chief. Behind the News Nascar officials said Earnhardt's car failed an inspection in what they viewed as a deliberate attempt to circumvent the rules. Inspectors said the rear wing was improperly mounted. Earnhardt was docked 100 points in the Chase for the Nextel Cup, knocking him from 12th to 14th place; his crew chief was fined $100,000 and suspended until after July 4. ''It is what it is,'' said the racing team's president, Max Siegel. ''It was a mistake, and it's unfortunate. But we'll move on.'' REGULATING EMISSIONS The News President Bush ordered government officials to draft regulations to reduce gas consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from new cars and trucks. Behind the News The order came a month after the Supreme Court, rebuffing the administration's arguments, found that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases qualify as pollutants under the law and must be regulated if they endanger public health. Mr. Bush had opposed mandatory limits. It is not clear what the new rules will look like, and the process of writing and implementing them won't be completed until the end of 2008, just weeks before his term ends. Mr. Bush says he wants to reduce gas consumption by 20 percent over 10 years. SELF-PROPULSION The News The City of Light is preparing to make 20,000 bikes available for rent to ease traffic and reduce air pollution. Behind the News Paris may be for lovers, but a lot of them apparently drive cars. That has led to notoriously congested traffic and air pollution. So, borrowing an idea from the city of Lyons to the southeast, Paris is preparing to make the bikes available for rent at about 1,400 rental stations around the city, beginning in mid-July. For a few euros, riders can rent a bike, then drop it off at any rental station. In Lyon, with 2,000 bikes, there are up to 16,000 rentals a day. Each bike is used by as many as 15 people a day; the average trip is 1.7 miles, says Cyclocity, which runs the program.

The interior designer Kelly Wearstler doesn't believe in restraint. This is evident in her color-saturated high-glamour work at the Viceroy resorts in the United States and the Caribbean, the Avalon Hotel in Los Angeles (properties owned by the Kor Group, the real estate company founded by her husband, Brad Korzen) and the BG restaurant in Bergdorf Goodman in New York.

There he goes again. When it comes to comparing profligate politicians to drunken sailors, John McCain is no conservative. ''We spent money like a drunken sailor, though I never met a sailor, drunk or sober, with the imagination of my colleagues,'' the Arizona senator and Navy war hero said last week at the Republican presidential debate at the University of South Carolina. The metaphor has been a McCain staple for years, tapping a stereotype stretching through Shakespeare, British sea shanties, Ronald Reagan's oratory and even this week's sequel to ''Pirates of the Caribbean.'' As the excerpts below show, Mr. McCain is not the only one lately who could be thrown into the brig, lashed and made to walk the plank for three-sheets-to-the-wind metaphor abuse. All hams on deck! TOM KUNTZ

Spas went over the top long ago. And now that we live in an age when ''colonic'' is a punch line, they're looking inward -- or really far out. Here, rated for wackiness on a scale from 1 to 10, the current State of the Spa Treatment. Christian L. Wright
On any night of the week, the back streets of Beyoglu are throbbing with live music. There's a beat here for everyone -- women in itsy-bitsy tops, aging rockers, vertical-haired punks.

When Boston Scientific announced this month that it had hired Sam Leno as its chief financial officer, the company threw in an unusual perk that might make anyone trying to sell a house during the current down market green with envy: it agreed to buy two homes owned by Mr. Leno for a guaranteed minimum price of $1.3 million each. According to the employment letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, one of the homes is in Winona Lake, Ind., near Zimmer Holdings, where Mr. Leno used to work.

GERI RUSSELL's daughter Kate was almost 4 when the mother first became ill. The prognosis was good, and Ms. Russell repeatedly reassured Kate, but it scared the little girl more than the mother understood. ''We had trouble getting her to sleep,'' Ms. Russell said. ''She'd wake me up in the middle of the night to give me a picture.'' Kate was suddenly afraid of wolves. ''She was worried a wolf would come into the house and get us,'' Ms. Russell said. So the mother went to the library here and asked the children's librarian, Paula Lefkowitz, for a good book on wolves for a preschooler. ''We talked about how the wolves lived far, far away in the West, way out there, far away,'' Ms. Russell said. ''I said, 'Everybody knows there's no wolves in Parsippany.' ''

MICHAEL BLOOMBERG deserves some credit for proposing that New York follow the example of London and other cities and apply congestion pricing to vehicles entering Manhattan below 86th Street weekdays from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. After all, congestion pricing -- a road-use charge levied on certain roads at specific times of the day, presumably those with the most serious congestion when traffic is heaviest -- makes sense. Indeed, it's similar to the peak-period charges paid for electricity and telephone services or the increased charges levied by hotels in high season.

MIRAZUR At the Côte d'Azur's most-talked-about new restaurant, the chef Mauro Colagreco -- from Alain Passard's L'Arpège in Paris -- trains his monklike reverence for fresh ingredients on local markets. The result is a sublime, nearly all-raw menu of dishes like gambero rosso, a raw red prawn entangled in ribbons of asparagus and zucchini and showered with olive oil, borage and garlic blossoms. 30, avenue Aristide Briand, Menton; 011-33-4-92-41-86-86; entrees $25 to $51.

COYLE--Elizabeth McConnell, died in her sleep on Monday, May 7th at her home in Tequesta, FL at the age of 83. Born in Bronxville, NY and raised in Middleburg, VA, she then graduated from the Baldwin School and attended Sarah Lawrence College. She served for many years as a docent at the American Museum of Natural History, while living in New York City. Betty and her husband Alfred J. (Bud) Coyle moved to Jupiter Island permanently, where Bud still lives. She is survived also by her brother, Richard McConnell, her sisters, Caryll Hanbury and Mildred Good, her three children: Herbert (Tony), Wendy, and Peter; three stepchildren Barbara Shaefer, Gigi and Jay Coyle, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL at a date to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hope Rural School in Indiantown, FL are greatly appreciated.

TV Land must first acknowledge that its demographic is way too broad (Lorne Manly). Fifty- and 60-year-olds grew up in a different time than 40-year-olds did. Boomers of the 1960s lived through a decade of turmoil, creative explosion and youthful hope for the world.

The hippest show of the spring may be ''NEO RAUCH AT THE MET.'' Mr. Rauch -- a leading figure of the so-called New Liepzig School of young artists reared in the smoke-choked industrial towns and grim housing projects of the former Eastern bloc -- creates haunting, unsettling evocations of muscular workers whose taut torsos and fixed gazes recall the saccharine images of Soviet Realism. But unlike those examples, these are immersed in a world of hybrid creatures and post-industrial decay that could exist only in our dreams. Or our worst nightmares. Tuesday through Sept. 23, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, metmuseum.org. A humorous mix of suburban appliances, frosted cakes, oversize flowers and sexual imagery, LINDER STERLING's collages at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center are a biting critique of consumer culture in the spirit of Hannah Hoch, but with a punk-rock twist. (This artist began her career designing Buzzcocks album covers.) Seen today, the works' feminist perspective and irreverent humor are a welcome throwback in a city being devoured by Donald Trumps, Paris Hiltons and Wall Street brokers. Through Sept. 24, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, ps1.org. For little art lovers ''GODS, MYTHS AND MORTALS: DISCOVER ANCIENT GREECE'' at the Children's Museum of Manhattan is a hands-on chance to explore ancient Greek civilization, from genuine artifacts to recreations of a town square and other physical expressions of a democratic culture. Starting Friday visitors can scale a miniature acropolis, mount a Trojan horse or stage a mock invasion of Troy. But the show's strength is its effort to bridge past and present. Once they get fidgety, children can venture outside and find examples of classical architecture in the city. Through Dec. 31, 2008, 212 West 83rd Street, cmom.org.

THE surest way to scatter my family is to mention, oh so casually, that the mulch delivery is imminent. For the last few years, since our teenage son got buff enough to wield the oversize shovel used to spread the small mountain delivered every spring, he and his dad have approached the task with the verve and good cheer of chain gang conscripts. I was never a habitual mulcher -- just a peony bed here and there -- until orthopedic issues and a balky well gave me good reason to start spreading it on thick around seven years ago. A tidy blanket of good, organic mulch keeps parched plants less stressed when I can't water. The stuff I use improves the soil, and it fends off the weeds that thrive mightily here. Keeping after those noxious invaders without mitigating mulch would surely have undone eight weeks of physical therapy for a bum neck.

Dr. Nicole Esther Hauptman, a daughter of Madeline Hauptman and Dr. Allen Hauptman of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to Dr. Cory Daniel Siegel, a son of Karen Siegel and Stanley Siegel of Massapequa, N.Y. Rabbi Lester Bronstein is to officiate at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y. The bride, 25, and the bridegroom, 27, met at Dartmouth, from which they graduated, the bride cum laude. This month, they received medical degrees, she from New York University and he from the State University of New York at Stony Brook. In July, they are both to become interns in internal medicine at the N.Y.U. Medical Center.

The sports logos of Rutgers University offer little insight into its designation as the state university of New Jersey. Assemblyman Patrick J. Diegnan Jr., a South Plainfield Democrat, wants to change that. Mr. Diegnan took the first steps to nudge Rutgers into serving as a marketing arm of the state on Thursday by introducing a resolution into the Higher Education Committee that requests that the university add an ''NJ'' in the lower right corner of its athletic logo, a block ''R'' that is featured on the football helmets and at center court at basketball games.

Artist, feminist, pioneering lawyer, survived by Elizabeth, Bill, Richard, Doris, Sophia, Rachel, Mike, Emily, Michael, Deborah, Sam, Zach, Ruth, Gloria, and her beloved friend Martin. A dynamic, shrewd, vibrant person who did a lot for others and will be greatly missed. Funeral Monday, 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave at 76th Street.

STRAHL--Martin. Our dear friend Marty. Our loss is painful but our memories are sweet. You were a loving friend. We laughed together, cried together, but most of all we enjoyed life together. Our families were entwined as one. We will miss you terribly. Sam, Sanda, David, Janet and Bruce Cohen

Lampedusa: You won't run into P. Diddy or Donatella on Lampedusa. In fact, the only newsmakers on this rocky Italian island are the large marine turtles that deposit their eggs on its pristine white-sand beaches every summer and the African immigrants who arrive in makeshift boats seeking asylum. Known as ''the door of Europe,'' the seven-mile-long outcropping is just 70 miles off the coast of Tunisia -- and the African influence is felt in everything from the food (fish couscous is the local specialty) to the vegetation (date palms on beautifully barren stretches). The 5,000-strong population is made up mostly of fishermen, but it can swell to about 20,000 in the summer, when Lampedusa becomes a haven for those seeking scenery rather than scenes.

LIKE the many Eskimo words for snow, a multitude of nicknames exist for the oversize houses commonly referred to as McMansions, and they mirror the uneasiness over the spread of the homes. ''You hear them called starter castles, beltway baronials, mini Taj Mahals, but my favorite is parachute homes, because of the disregard for local styles -- like they were dropped from the sky,'' said Edward J. Trawinski, a lawyer and land-use expert from Morristown, N.J.
The once-rarefied sport of polo -- with its style and its studs -- is gaining ground from St. Moritz to Mongolia. So how is it playing out? Julie Earle-Levine

To the Editor: I was deeply disheartened by Diane Johnson's review of Jeffrey J. Kripal's ''Esalen: America and the Religion of No Religion'' (May 6). If I had not been to Esalen and then read this review, I would not go there. However, I have spent a great deal of time at Esalen over the past 20-some years, and I know many others who have been deeply transformed by the integration of our experiences there.
The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly was misidentified in an editorial last week. He is Joseph Roberts Jr.

Q. My cousin's daughter needs a place to stay while she goes to college, and I offered her some space in the three-bedroom co-op I recently bought. Is this permissible? A. ''As long as the shareholder is simultaneously living in the apartment, there is no reason the cousin's daughter can't reside there,'' said Theresa Racht, a Manhattan co-op and condominium lawyer. Ms. Racht said that it is well established that the ''roommate law'' applies to co-ops. Under it, a shareholder is allowed to have one additional person living in the apartment without asking the co-op for approval.

When Dave Mlicki first glanced at the Mets' schedule before the 1997 season, his eyes darted to mid-June. That was when the Mets would play the Yankees for the first time in a regular-season game. Mlicki, a starting pitcher, immediately began forecasting the future. ''I wanted to pitch in that series,'' Mlicki said. ''I had never been to Yankee Stadium. You think about the aura that the Yankees had. They were the champs. So I wanted that chance.''

CAIN--Harriet F., age 86, of 1 Beechwood Dr., Waterford, formerly of New York, died May 15, 2007 at the Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, CT. Miss Cain had been employed as a fashion editor for the New York Times and Conde Nast prior to her retirement. She was predeceased by her twin brother Dr. Edward A. Cain, Jr. and is survived by her sister-in-law Jeanne Cain of New York. For complete obituary please visit: neilanfuneralhome.com

Among former Gov. George Pataki's pet projects were the parks in and along the state's waterways, especially the Hudson River Park in Manhattan and historic Governors Island in New York Harbor. For reasons that are not entirely clear -- envy, perhaps, or lack of interest -- Gov. Eliot Spitzer has shown nowhere near the same enthusiasm, despite the environmental credentials he earned as Attorney General. The net result is that the momentum behind the partly completed Hudson River Park has slowed while the Governors Island project remains stuck in neutral.

To the Editor: As I understand it from his state of the state address, Gov. Eliot Spitzer favors not ''some kind of public financing'' (''Not There Yet, in Albany,'' editorial, May 13) but full public financing.

WEINSTEIN--Harvey J., 82, adored and devoted father and grandfather. Cherished by his children Lori, Mark, Deb, and Dan; Celebrated by his grandchildren Justin, Chloe, Jessica, Kyle, Emma, Rachael, and Hunter; Loved by his longtime partner Susan, her children Gail and David, and as ''Pop'' by Bridget, Lucy, Lena, and Lila; Dedicated uncle to Liz, David, George, and Eve. Revered by everyone whose life he touched. He enlisted in the Marines at the age of 18 and throughout his life was dedicated to the goodness of his country. He was a hero to many, humble to all, intelligent, thoughtful, a true leader. He believed in fairness, and championed those less fortunate. He was successful in all endeavors, business, charity, personal, family. He was the consummate model of integrity, commitment, wisdom, and compassion. He mixed it all up with a grand sense of play and humor. We will carry his torch of goodness and are grateful for the blessing of his extraordinary life. Carpe Diem! Donations are welcomed in his honor to The Doe Fund, 232 E. 84th St., NY, NY 10028 (www.doe.org). Memorial services are Sunday, August 5th at 4PM, Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55th St.

IT'S spring: time to plant perennials, clean closets -- and call the microbial inspector. What does spring cleaning mean in the age of green? For many of us, it means fear. Homeowners whose grandparents beat rugs and washed windows worry about more than dirt. So what if the baseboards are dusty? The lead in the paint could be lowering your toddler's future SAT scores. The air may be fragrant with the season's first blooms, but that doesn't make you safe from colorless, odorless gases like radon and carbon monoxide. And, by the way, you're sneezing. Is it a cold, or is it mold?
SERMAN--Michael. 7 Years. Dad you're missed and loved beyond eternity. Your Family

IT'S spring: time to plant perennials, clean closets -- and call the microbial inspector. What does spring cleaning mean in the age of green? For many of us, it means fear. Homeowners whose grandparents beat rugs and washed windows worry about more than dirt. So what if the baseboards are dusty? The lead in the paint could be lowering your toddler's future SAT scores. The air may be fragrant with the season's first blooms, but that doesn't make you safe from colorless, odorless gases like radon and carbon monoxide. And, by the way, you're sneezing. Is it a cold, or is it mold?

The Spanish Gitano guitarist NIÑO JOSELE comes from the world of new flamenco, a genre obsessed with mixtures and fusions -- much like jazz. Mr. Josele (born Juan José Heredia), 33, has worked with Diego el Cigala and Enrique Morente, two of the greatest flamenco singers alive, and he is a searching, absorbent musician. It was only a few years ago that he came across Bill Evans, and he was bewitched, specifically by Evans's harmonies. In ''Paz'' (Calle 54/Sony BMG), his new album of works associated with Evans, he retains elements of flamenco rhythm and phrasing, especially in his introductions to songs like ''Peace Piece,'' ''Waltz for Debby'' and ''Turn Out the Stars,'' but then he moves into jazz territory. His gig this week at the Village Vanguard is special, not just for the Vanguard, which rarely books a bandleader from outside of the jazz tradition, but also for Mr. Josele. He will play the Evans pieces accompanied by two extraordinary rhythm musicians, the bassist Esperanza Spalding and the Cuban drummer Horacio (El Negro) Hernandez. Tuesday through Sunday, 9 and 11 p.m., 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; $30 cover Tuesday through Thursday, $35 cover Friday through Sunday. EVAN CHRISTOPHER, a clarinetist, is a great counterargument for anyone who thinks jazz should let go of its past. Sidney Bechet is one of his prime fascinations, but Mr. Christopher has played all kinds of jazz. He has a kind of primal ability to energize a bandstand, and this week, in a concert presented by the Sidney Bechet Society, he'll perform with some of the musicians he's been playing with in Paris recently, along with the New York trumpeter Jon-Erik Kellso as a guest. Monday at 7:15, the Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, Manhattan, sidneybechet.org; $35.

Cindie Travis, 45, from Prescott, Ariz., with her husband, Tim, 40: ''It started with Tim coming up with a dream to travel around the world. We gave up our careers, sold our possessions and just started out on our bikes. We've been through Central and South America, China and Southeast Asia, and now Australia, where the wildlife -- platypuses, kangaroos, Tasmanian devils -- is like nowhere else. We're fully self-contained: tent, sleeping bags, cook gear; Tim carries a computer and all our electronics. We originally saved enough money for seven years, at $20 or $25 a day. Now, we basically are living off the proceeds from selling our book and from the advertising on our Web site, downtheroad.org. About the time we got to South America, it turned from a trip into a lifestyle. There is no end in sight. We think of retiring in an R.V. in the States; we don't really see staying in one place as an option. We're modern nomads, I guess.'' As told to Seth Kugel

As work continues on the resurfacing project on the local and express lanes of Route 78 between the Garden State Parkway and Route 24, the State Department of Transportation has begun a traffic-information program intended to help drivers. The second phase of the $42 million resurfacing project, which began last year and is to be completed by November, was needed to improve the roadway, which handles more than 145,000 vehicles daily. Earlier this month, the department announced that it was spending $200,000 on technology to estimate the duration of trips through the construction zone on the local and express lanes.
When the city steams up, do as locals do and head to one of Istanbul's top-notch beaches.

Istanbul, the city that once commanded an empire (and was called Constantinople, New Rome and Byzantium), embodies centuries' worth of East-meets-West history. But that's all water down the Bosporus. A new generation is creating a vibrant cosmopolis that bridges two continents, and cultures, in style. Suna Erdem

I am planning a photo safari to Kenya and am told I need vaccinations and malaria protection. My tour guide tells me to see my doctor; Condé Nast Traveler magazine tells me to see Johns Hopkins Travel Medicine; the Department of Health and Human Services refers me to Passport Health travel clinics; my doctor refers me to a Centers for Disease Control Web site (www.cdc.gov/travel) and tells me to look up a member of the International Society of Travel Medicine. Please help; there are too many choices. -- Deb Tillet, Baltimore Dr. Richard Dawood, a travel medicine expert and editor of the classic ''Traveller's Health: How to Stay Healthy Abroad,'' whom I consulted, writes: ''What an interesting question, since I'm the guy who wrote the advice in the March issue of Condé Nast Traveler. I strongly recommend that you see a specialist; you should go with the nearest center of excellence, which I assume would be Johns Hopkins; and yes, you will need vaccines and malaria protection.'' (Contact Johns Hopkins Travel Medicine, Consultations and Immunizations, Johns Hopkins Outpatient Center, 601 North Caroline Street, Baltimore; 410-955-8931 or travelmedicine@jhmi.edu.)

ZICKEL--Lewis. The West Point Jewish Chapel Fund mourns the death of our founding Vice President who supervised the construction of the Jewish Chapel at West Point. He served as Chairman of the West Point Jewish Community Council that met monthly for the past 10 years. He was instrumental in establishing a Hillell chapter to provide appropriate programming for the Jewish cadets. He will be sorely missed. The West Point Jewish Chapel Fund

A review on May 6 about ''I'll Sleep When I'm Dead: The Dirty Life and Times of Warren Zevon,'' by Crystal Zevon, misspelled the surname of the writer who contributed the book's foreword. He is Carl Hiaasen, not Hiassen.

An article last Sunday about a new DVD version of ''The Naked City'' referred incorrectly to the 1948 film. It was considered a prestige release, not a B movie. (B movies were low-budget features that played second on a double bill.)

Nobody ever says that pitching is 35 percent of baseball. The game's received wisdom includes the nugget that pitching makes up some significant part of the secret to winning, be it two-thirds or three-quarters or, if you are the 2005 Astros, 99.9 percent.

An article on May 6 about the actress Nikki Blonsky included incorrect information from the actress and her director, Adam Shankman, about the circumstances of her casting in the film ''Hairspray.'' Morgit Management, which represented her at the time, sent New Line Cinema an e-mail message with a Web link to a copy of her audition tape. She won a tryout as a result of that e-mail message, not a copy of the tape she sent separately by mail. In addition that taped audition was made with the help of the management company, not solely by Ms. Blonsky.

On May 4, after the final guitar chord from Black 47, the Celtic rock band, faded away, Toad's Place shut its doors for most of the summer. The 32-year-old New Haven music club closed for 90 days and paid a $90,000 fine for illegally serving alcohol to minors. It reopens on Aug. 4, with a show by Badfish, a Sublime cover band.

Bill Finley of The Times highlights some critical moments of the race. Odds are those at post time. At the finish, Robby Albarado and Curlin, left, edged out the Kentucky Derby winners Calvin Borel and Street Sense. Hard Spun, along the rail, was a distant third. EARLY LEADERS Xchanger Ramon Dominguez 23-1 Flying First Class Mark Guidry 16-1 Hard Spun Mario Pino 4-1 Curlin stumbles leaving the gate and is unable to get near the early leaders. The long shot Xchanger is ridden aggressively to take the lead and Flying First Class goes after him. Street Sense settles into his customary position near the back of the field. BACKSTRETCH LEADERS Hard Spun Mario Pino 4-1 Xchanger Ramon Dominguez 23-1 Flying First Class Mark Guidry 16-1 The fast early pace is already taking its toll on Xchanger and Flying First Class. Hard Spun, who had been sitting in third, makes an early attack and sweeps past the frontrunners to take the lead. He is traveling easily and pulls ahead by two lengths. Albarado is still waiting to make his move with Curlin. FINAL TURN LEADERS Hard Spun Mario Pino 4-1 C P West Edgar Prado 25-1 Curlin Robby Albarado 3-1 After shaking off a mild bid from C P West, Hard Spun still leads, but Curlin and Street Sense are closing in on him fast. After being angled off the rail for more room, Street Sense gets past Hard Spun and Curlin and appears on his way to winning the second leg of the Triple Crown. AT THE WIRE LEADERS Curlin Robby Albarado 3-1 Street Sense Calvin Borel 6-5 Hard Spun Mario Pino 4-1 Curlin has fought back and is coming after Street Sense, who had a 11/2-length lead a furlong from the wire. Curlin keeps inching forward, but Street Sense also fights on. The two are on even terms for a few strides approaching the wire before Curlin just gets past his rival as the two cross the finish line.

HOGAN--John Edmund, age 88, died Tuesday May 15, 2007. John was born in White Plains, NY on July 28, 1918. He grew up in Teaneck, NJ and graduated from St. Cecilia's High School in Englewood, NJ. He received a bachelor's in Electrical Engineering from Manhattan College in Riverdale, NY in 1940. He married Margaret ''Pat'' Wulkow in 1953. Pat preceded him in death in 1989. He was employed as a cable and wiring engineer by the Okonite Co. for 44 years except for a period during WWII when he was employed by the US Naval Bureau of Ships. There he worked for Admiral Hyman Rickover in Washington DC. After his retirement in 1982, he moved to Hilton Head, SC, where he lived in the Palmetto Dunes plantation. There he enjoyed many good friendships, frequent visitors and daily walks on the beach near his home. He was an active member of Holy Family Catholic Church. Mr. Hogan moved to Issaquah, WA in 2003 to be near family. He lived at University House in Issaquah where he was an avid reader and bridge player. His primary hobby was researching and investing in the stock market, making his first investment at the age of sixteen. He shared his passion with friends and helped many of them with their own investments. Interested in genealogy, he traced his family's roots back to Ireland. In 1944, he received dual citizenship and an Irish passport, which he was quite proud of. John was preceded in death by a brother, Joseph and a sister Rosemary Cunning. He is survived by his sister Frances Taylor of Redmond, WA and his sister-in-law, Dolores Hogan of Teaneck, NJ. He is also survived by 10 nieces and nephews and 27 grandnieces and grandnephews. A Mass of Christian burial will be held Monday, May 21, 2007 at 10:30 am at Holy Trinity RCC, Hackensack, NJ. A memorial service will be held on June 15, 2007 at 3 pm at St. Louise Church in Bellevue, WA. Services entrusted to Volk Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ.
KANTER--Irma. Beloved wife of Jerry, devoted mother of Robin and Merrill. Loving grandmother, dear sister of Bob Seiden and Ruth Newman.
The promiscuous shopper always packs an extra.

IT'S spring: time to plant perennials, clean closets -- and call the microbial inspector. What does spring cleaning mean in the age of green? For many of us, it means fear. Homeowners whose grandparents beat rugs and washed windows worry about more than dirt. So what if the baseboards are dusty? The lead in the paint could be lowering your toddler's future SAT scores. The air may be fragrant with the season's first blooms, but that doesn't make you safe from colorless, odorless gases like radon and carbon monoxide. And, by the way, you're sneezing. Is it a cold, or is it mold?

ECKSTEIN--Stan, May 13, 2007. Beloved husband of Hariet, father of Chuck, Ken and Missy, father-in-law of Cynthia Eckstein, Jane Eckstein and David Burgess. Uniquely gifted artist and designer, lover of literature and nature. Courageous and funny in the face of debilitating illness. An uncommon man who will be forever in our hearts, and will be missed and loved always.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 5, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. GHOSTWALK, by Rebecca Stott. (Spiegel & Grau, $24.95.) Stott's first novel, a mesmerizing intellectual thriller, connects a 17th-century alchemical cabal in Isaac Newton's Cambridge with outbreaks of post-9/11 violence. THE BIG GIRLS, by Susanna Moore. (Knopf, $24.) A women's prison is the backdrop for the horrendous, intimate violence of Moore's novel. IMPOSTURE, by Benjamin Markovits. (Norton, paper, $13.95.) In this novel, John Polidori, Byron's physician, becomes obsessed with the poet. JOHN DONNE: The Reformed Soul, by John Stubbs. (Norton,. $35.) Stubbs's lively, dependable biography shows fearlessness in approaching the poet's ''frequently convoluted'' emotions. ARE WE ROME? The Fall of an Empire and the Fate of America, by Cullen Murphy. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) A provocative effort to draw serious lessons from ancient Rome's collapse. ANGELICA, by Arthur Phillips. (Random House, $25.95.) Old-fashioned phantoms give way to Freudian nightmares in this Victorian ghost story. THE NEW YORKERS, by Cathleen Schine. Illustrated by Leanne Shapton. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) This novel's pets nudge their lonely owners into a redemptive herd. COLLECTED POEMS FOR CHILDREN, by Ted Hughes. Illustrated by Raymond Briggs. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18; ages 8 and up.) A poetic world with sharp teeth, claws and strange visions. TAMAR, by Mal Peet. (Candlewick, $17.99; ages 14 and up.) A 15-year-old protagonist discovers the fate of two British-trained agents parachuted into wartime Holland, one of them her grandfather. AN INCONVENIENT TRUTH: The Crisis of Global Warming, by Al Gore. (Viking, paper, $16; ages 11 and up.) Better organized than the adult version, with less focus on the author. HURRICANE FORCE: In the Path of America's Deadliest Storms, by Joseph B. Treaster. (Kingfisher/Houghton Mifflin, $16.95; ages 10 and up.) A vivid account of hurricanes, starting with Katrina, which Treaster covered for The Times. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Angela Ragon Tolosa and Emmanuel Victor Ago II were married yesterday at the Church of the Holy Family in Manhattan. The Rev. Robert J. Robbins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Ms. Tolosa, 31, is keeping her name. She is the project director of the Midtown Community Court, a nonprofit organization that works with state courts to provide alternatives to jail for offenders convicted of low-level crimes in Manhattan. She was a producer of a 2000 documentary, ''Kababayan: Filipino-Americans in New York,'' which was shown on public television. She is a member of the board of Filipino American Human Services, a social service agency based in Jamaica, Queens. She graduated from Brown and received a law degree from Brooklyn Law School.

Eugene N. Melnyk, chairman of the Canadian drugmaker Biovail, will be retiring -- a decision he announced the morning after United States regulators notified him that he might be sued for possibly violating securities laws. The company, which makes the antidepressant Wellbutrin, has been under scrutiny by the Securities and Exchange Commission over questionable accounting. That resulted in notices last week to Mr. Melnyk, 47, and Biovail's chief financial officer, Kenneth G. Howling, 49, which were disclosed on the company's Web site.

HALEVY--Irving (born June 24, 1916, Newark, NJ). Irving Halevy, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died on Tuesday, May 8, 2007 en route to his home in Manchester Center, Vermont from his residence in PGA, Florida. At 15, after his family farm in Tom's River, New Jersey was destroyed by a fire set by the Ku Klux Klan, he left home and found work shipping out and organizing for the National Maritime Union, lecturing in parks and on street-corners. He served as a lieutenant in WWII, at war's end escorting from China to Bremerhaven Germans who had escaped the Nazi regime and enemy prisoners. His play ''First Class Passage,'' was produced off-off Broadway. He received his Bachelors and Masters Degrees from Columbia University after the war and became a labor arbitrator and member of the National Academy of Arbitrators, mediating many disputes in the New York/northern New Jersey area serving as the Impartial Chairman at Revlon Industries. From 1952 to 1986, he was a professor of industrial relations and labor economics at Fairleigh Dickinson University. As head of the faculty senate, he was instrumental in FDU's formative years. He also coached FDU's tennis team. In March 2007 he was selected to be installed in FDU's Heritage Hall. He was an executive with Mack Drug Stores and Eveready Label and a member of the Board of Directors of Audiovox, retiring from that post in January at the age of 90. He is survived by his first wife, Jeanne (Bernstein) Halevy, and their four children and spouses, Phyllis and Lou Mutschler, Julia Z. Halevy and Don Brechner; Daniel Halevy and Susan Stewart; and Louise Halevy and Kenneth Erlich, 11 grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. He leaves as well his second wife, Julia E. Halevy, her son Stephen Ellis and his wife Suzanne Picard. Friends and family will meet to remember him in Boston on August 12. Contributions in his name may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center: splcenter.org

GERI RUSSELL's daughter Kate was almost 4 when the mother first became ill. The prognosis was good, and Ms. Russell repeatedly reassured Kate, but it scared the little girl more than the mother understood. ''We had trouble getting her to sleep,'' Ms. Russell said. ''She'd wake me up in the middle of the night to give me a picture.'' Kate was suddenly afraid of wolves. ''She was worried a wolf would come into the house and get us,'' Ms. Russell said. So the mother went to the library here and asked the children's librarian, Paula Lefkowitz, for a good book on wolves for a preschooler. ''We talked about how the wolves lived far, far away in the West, way out there, far away,'' Ms. Russell said. ''I said, 'Everybody knows there's no wolves in Parsippany.' ''

LAWRENCE--Jacob (Jack), 83, on May 16. Retired from his veterinary practice to pursue his many passions. Committed to social justice, an avid fisherman, folk dancer and lifelong learner. His endless curiosity and zest for life inspire us all. He had two wonderful marriages, first to Adele and then to Miriam (Friedman). Father to Jon Lawrence (wife Elisabeth), Vicki Blier (husband Malcolm). Stepfather to Rachel Friedman. Grandpa to Stefan and Marika Lawrence, Sam and Zack Blier. Brother of Rachel Lawrence. Generous anchor of a large and loving extended family. Donations in Jack's memory may be made to Physicians for a National Health Program, NY Metro, 2753 Broadway, #

Volcanic / (val kan ik) / adj. / superhot. Buzzword for destinations that have rapidly and unmistakably become the must-stops of the moment, as in, ''What do you mean you haven't been to Cartagena? That city is volcanic.'' Captures the warp speed at which the hot-not cycle currently moves, e.g., ''Yes, last year it was all about Buenos Aires, but now it's Istanbul that's volcanic -- I mean, everyone's there.''

To the Editor: I lived on the street where the opening scene was shot: 46th Street between Second and Third Avenues. I was hired as an extra for $5, one of a bunch of children playing with a jump rope in the street. We all scattered when the bad guy dropped from the fire escape of the murdered blonde's apartment. Mark Hellinger, the producer, was a perfectionist. We kids were surprised when the crew tracked us down for reshoots. (We were thrilled to get another $5.) A lamppost was moved about 10 feet, the scene was filmed again, and that is what appears in the movie.

SCHIFTER--Sidney, 93, DC 65 Union Activist, formerly of New York, died in Del Ray Beach, Florida on April 24. He was married to the late Gertrude (nee Weiner), survived by his second wife Eva Burck and his daughter Esta Jo Schifter of Philadelphia.

To the Editor: I very much enjoyed Robert R. Harris's review of ''The Joy of Drinking,'' by Barbara Holland (May 6). But it seems as if both Harris and Holland -- as well as The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, which Holland cites -- totally miss the point about the nutritive value of beer: beer is not a beverage -- it is a food group! Elliot Hertzberg Yonkers

To the Editor: I enjoyed ''Indonesia: A Secret Garden of Golf (Mind the Jungle)'' by Raymond Bonner (Journeys, May 6). My husband, who plays golf frequently in Indonesia, would certainly agree with Mr. Bonner's recommendations and comments.

DIRECTOR--James J., of Merrick, NY, died May 18, 2007 at the age of 53. Jim had a wonderful sense of humor and an unquenchable zest for life. He was surrounded by a loving circle of family and friends, and was taken from us too soon, but he will forever live in our hearts. Beloved husband of Susan, treasured son of Barbara and Phil, devoted father of Jason and Scott, cherished brother of David Director, Marsha and Paul Seader, Lenny and Karen Kronen, dear son-in-law of Gilda Kronen, loving uncle, granduncle and cousin. Funeral will be held Sunday, May 20, 2007 at 2pm at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

The Boston Red Sox have been comfortably atop the American League's Eastern Division this season, but the Yankees still lead the standings when it comes to being the most popular baseball team in the state. According to a Quinnipiac University poll released last Monday, 43 percent of residents in the state who said they were ''very'' or ''somewhat'' interested in major league baseball chose the Yankees as their favorite team, while 37 percent said they rooted for the Red Sox. Ten percent said they were Mets fans, and the rest favored other teams.

The prognosis was good, and Ms. Russell repeatedly reassured Kate, but it scared the little girl more than the mother understood. ''We had trouble getting her to sleep,'' Ms. Russell said. Come summer, the Bosporus is the only place to be. The city's main waterway separates Europe from Asia -- and a noisy old city on the left bank from more tranquil shores on the right.

The fate of New York, America, the world will be decided in the final hour of the three-part season finale of ''HEROES'' (NBC, Monday night at 9). A morally sketchy politician, a Japanese comic book geek, a watchmaker turned serial killer, cannibalism, filicide -- with these characters and themes, NBC has created its own compelling answer to long-form, apocalyptically themed television, as well as a hit set to return next season. It has arrived: prestige reality television. Steven Spielberg serves as co-producer of ''ON THE LOT,'' making its debut Tuesday night at 9 on Fox. This series pits aspiring filmmakers against one another in a contest to win a development deal from DreamWorks worth less than the price of many Manhattan apartments: $1 million. Among those making the call are Carrie Fisher and Garry Marshall. Twelve thousand not-yet-Spielbergs tried for spots in the race. Does reality television contribute to insomnia? Do tense shows like ''Heroes,'' ''Lost'' and ''24'' leave us too stressed out to sleep? The director Alan Berliner doesn't tackle this question specifically but does consider the relationship between the anxieties of modern life and the troubles Americans have sleeping in his documentary ''WIDE AWAKE'' (HBO, Wednesday night at 8). Mr. Berliner, an insomniac, chronicles his own struggle with the night and imagines how sleep deprivation might affect politics and the World Series.

To the Editor: Re ''Where Are All the Black Swans?'' [May 6]: As the artistic director of Pennsylvania Ballet from 1982 to 1990 and the founding artistic director of Carolina Ballet from 1997 to now, I can say that Gia Kourlas's article gives ballet a bad reputation that is undeserved. On the contrary, most artistic directors would love to have more black dancers.

At 79, Sidney Kimmel, the chairman of the Jones Apparel Group, may not be the prototypical Barneys shopper. But either Mr. Kimmel or someone in his household can't resist shopping there, especially at a discount of 35 percent.
LANDAU--Samuel J. May 20, 1989. In rememberance, Bob
The 36 Hours column on May 6 about Istanbul misspelled the name of a magazine whose readers might enjoy Istanbul. It is Archaeology, not Archeology.

To the Editor: Regarding Joshua Kurlantzick's ''Thailand: A Beach Resort That's Quiet Enough for a King'' (Next Stop, May 6): Hua Hin is indeed a relaxed and accessible beach town that has avoided the excesses of other Thai beaches. There are many attractive beach hotels at a fraction of the price of the boutique hotel mentioned in the article, Aleenta. One can start the day on deserted sands, shell gathering, and then enjoy almost deserted privacy for swimming, snorkeling and taking small boats to the island outcrops in the sea.
To the Editor: Re ''The Bankable Siren Call of the Misty Isles'' [May 13]:

FORSYTHE--Carol (Mackie), died May 18, 2007, at the age of 55, after a long illness. She was born November 26, 1951, in Gary, Indiana. She attended Indiana State University and Columbia University. Her professional life in New York began at Ziff-Davis Publishing and went on to include Fred/Alan Advertising, Nickelodeon, WILL-TV/PBS Corp. at the University of Illinois, Sesame Street Workshop, and 4 Kids Productions. A multiple Emmy-Award recipient, she was most recently associate producer of the television documentary ''Ten Sisters''. Known to her family as Suzy, Carol is survived by her husband Raymond L. Forsythe and their son Pierce Christopher Forsythe. And Jack, the SuperDog, the perfect pet. Other survivors include parents-in-deed Sarah and Paul Wilczynski, sisters Kim Paulus, Krystina Parker, and Katrina Addis, as well as Mackie sisters Cheryl, Peggy, Debby and Donna, and brother Billy. Carol leaves behind many loving and devoted friends upon whom she relied and to whom she gave much. Funeral services will be held Monday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the National Cancer Center, 88 Sunnyside Blvd., Plainview, NY 11803, Attn: Regina English.

FINISHING my lunch at an open-air restaurant in downtown Bangkok, I felt slightly queasy. But by the time the taxi arrived back at my hotel, sweat was pouring out of my armpits, the folds of my stomach, even my shins, and my leg joints buckled as if a diamond-tipped drill was boring into them. As I got out of the taxi, I collapsed onto the street. The taxi driver shoved me back into his cab, and we wove our way through the city's infamous traffic to Bumrungrad International, a hospital near my hotel. I barely made it to the emergency room before I passed out. When I woke and remembered what had happened, part of me wanted to bolt from my E.R. bed. I knew very little about Thai medical facilities, and recalled a clinic I'd seen in neighboring Myanmar, where patients had to bring their own linens, needles and even bandages to the hospital.

In Europe the same orchestra often appears in the opera pit one night and on the symphony stage the next. Each experience adds a dimension to an orchestra's playing: the world of theater and dramatic expression from one, the spotlight of virtuosic playing from the other. JAMES LEVINE has sought to bring such diversity to the two institutions he serves as music director, striving to program more concert performances of operas with the Boston Symphony Orchestra and building the METROPOLITAN OPERA ORCHESTRA over the years into a shining solo instrument. On Sunday the Met Orchestra has its final symphony concert of the season. The mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung will appear as soloist, but then the Met players, unaccompanied, take on Ravel's ''Daphnis et Chloé'' Suite No. 2. 3 p.m. Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $50 to $160. This week brings two case studies in the transmission of musical knowledge, along with a healthy batch of string quartets. After a week of intensive coaching by the Juilliard String Quartet at a JUILLIARD SCHOOL workshop, seven hatchling quartets will present the fruits of their labor at a pair of concerts. Tuesday at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m., Paul Hall, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, at 65th Street, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu; free. Three other young quartets will culminate a similar exercise with the EMERSON STRING QUARTET, which will have coached them under the auspices of Carnegie Hall's training program. They will play Beethoven quartets. Wednesday and Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall; $15. The NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, just back from a European tour, will presumably have recovered enough from jet lag to perform this week's eclectic program: Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Russian Easter'' Overture, Saint-Saëns's Violin Concerto No. 3 and Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra. Saint-Saëns wrote the concerto for the virtuoso Pablo de Sarasate, and the soloist will be the Lithuanian Julian Rachlin. The Bartok, a showcase of solo playing, is an ideal vehicle for this orchestra, which prides itself on individual virtuosity. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Friday and Saturday 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $28 to $94.

FULTON--Robert E. Dear Bob, hard to believe six years have gone by since that fateful night. Everyday we think of you and miss you. Brilliant Emmy-award winning photographer, astounding pilot, charming, talented wit, gifted teacher, wonderful musician, and rare friend. We know you are flying on the ''Wings of Man'' wherever you go. You are ever near and yet so far. Jordan & Tom Saunders Calvert & George Moore $(6$)FULTON--Robert Edison, was one of the most interesting men I have ever known. He was a philosopher, musician, poet, director, cinematographer, aerial cinematographer, filmmaker, and most of all, an incredible man. Bob was highly skilled in all these areas. He won many awards including an Emmy for his work. He was a devout Buddhist. Bob was extremely humble and never talked about himself or his accomplishments, but only about the love of his work. Bob did everything in such a unique way that his friends and family referred to his lifestyle as Fultonian, as if he had developed an entirely different culture and way of life. To tell one story about Bob was never enough; people always wanted to hear more and know more about this fascinating man. To watch Bob fly a plane was like watching a virtuoso playing an instrument. He taught me many things both in the sky and on the ground. His lessons of ''point of intended touchdown'' is something I will never forget. A wonder with words, Fulton never used profanity; he thought it was an abuse of the English language and demonstrated a lack of a proper vocabulary. I miss my generous mentor and good friend, Bob Fulton, who is in my thoughts everyday. Taz Saunders

To the Editor: I applaud Bono's efforts to elicit support from Group of 8 members to fight global poverty (''Rock Star Still Hasn't Found the African Aid He's Looking For,'' news article, May 15). The numbers show that member countries are not keeping their promise to improve financing for the poverty-fighting Millennium Development Goals, as they pledged at the 2005 Gleneagles summit conference. Bono is doing the world a service by shedding light on G-8 members' failure to fully support the development goals and reminding them that global poverty is a serious threat and needs to be treated as an utmost priority.

WERBEL--Edward, age 83, of Scottsdale, AZ formerly of Oceanside, NY and Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of Nettie. Died peacefully on Friday, May 18. Eddie was a former Democratic Party leader of Oceanside, NY. Former Deputy County Clerk of Nassau County and longtime Chief Engineering Administrator of Nassau County Medical Center. He is survived by his wife Nettie of 59 years. His adoring children Phillip, Wendy and Andrea. His daughter-in-law Cherie and sons-in-law Richard Marx and Joseph Brennan and grandchildren William, Karen, Lisa, Paul, Harrison, and Melissa and brothers Morton and Harvey. He was a loving soul who will be missed.

To the Editor: Great art, like any other matter worth defending, should stand on its own, without the need for cheap shots at other artists. Tom Carson's otherwise insightful review of the Warren Zevon biography ''I'll Sleep When I'm Dead'' (May 6) is marred by its dismissal of Jackson Browne as ''ultra-wimpy.'' If Browne were really as Manilowesque as Carson implies, we wouldn't be listening to him -- or to Zevon, whom he championed despite his ''wimpiness'' -- at all today. Matt Adler Voorhees, N.J.

If psychologists had peeked at the philosophers in their backyards, they would have seen that Kant, Locke, Mill, Spinoza, etc., had been playing with the definition of wisdom for centuries (Stephen S. Hall). They defined wisdom as a happy marriage between reflectiveness and judgment.

IN 19th-century Russia, Czar Nicolas I commissioned an official national anthem known as ''God Save the Czar.'' In 21st-century Washington, the anthem would be more suitably titled ''God Help the Czar.''

To the Editor: Re ''In Divided New Orleans'' (editorial, May 15): If there was one event that turned the nation away from the president regarding Iraq, it was the government's poor performance regarding Katrina. No longer could the government pull the wool over our eyes, as we watched the suffering in one of our great American cities and the failure of the government to ease the suffering over several years.
Designers on the fashion vanguard.

Dathan Ritzenhein, a 24-year-old American, broke the Central Park record for the 10-kilometer run yesterday, winning the Healthy Kidney 10k in 28 minutes 8 seconds. In a field of elite runners, Ritzenhein shaved two seconds off the course record set by Paul Koech of Kenya 10 years ago. In addition to an appearance fee, Ritzenhein collected $7,500 for first place and a $20,000 bonus for breaking the record. Craig Mottram of Australia, who won this race in its two previous runnings, finished second in 28:25. Demesse Tefera, an Ethiopian based in Westchester County, took third in 28:31. Khalid Khannouchi, the American who had twice broken the world record in the marathon, was 14th in 30:06 but said he was pleased with his finish.

At Vik-Hum's, a late-night dive on Harbour Island in the Bahamas, the writing is on the wall -- literally. Were it not for the fact that nearly every inch, including the ceiling, is covered with the signatures of beautiful people like Naomi Campbell, it would be hard to believe that this shabby frump attracts the caftan-wearing beau monde.

A handful of creative chefs are reinvigorating local cooking with experimental techniques and international flavors. Here's where the leaders of modern Turkish cuisine work their magic.

IT'S spring: time to plant perennials, clean closets -- and call the microbial inspector. What does spring cleaning mean in the age of green? For many of us, it means fear. Homeowners whose grandparents beat rugs and washed windows worry about more than dirt. So what if the baseboards are dusty? The lead in the paint could be lowering your toddler's future SAT scores. The air may be fragrant with the season's first blooms, but that doesn't make you safe from colorless, odorless gases like radon and carbon monoxide. And, by the way, you're sneezing. Is it a cold, or is it mold?

Katherine Elizabeth Burton, a daughter of Elizabeth and Harry W. Burton of Oakton, Va., was married yesterday to John Jalbrzykowski, the son of Halina and Adolph Jalbrzykowski of Riverhead, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Reddig performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Md. The bride, 29, graduated from Boston University and received an M.B.A. this month from New York University. In July she is to become an assistant brand manager in the consumer care division of Bayer HealthCare in Morristown, N.J. Her father is a senior partner specializing in labor and employment practices in the Washington office of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, the Philadelphia law firm.
For making snap judgments.

This summer may be your last opportunity to see the Cyclorama Center, the 1962 visitors' center designed by Richard Neutra and Robert Alexander overlooking the battlefields of Gettysburg in Pennsylvania. The building is scheduled for demolition within the next two years. A new visitors center will occupy a structure designed to simulate a round barn from ''ye olde days'' -- an oddly Virginian conceit for a site where General Lee's army went down to bloody defeat.

The great attention-sucking machine of the Broadway season shuts down in early May, which is why some Off Broadway theaters wait until then to offer their shiniest wares. Last year at the Atlantic it was ''Spring Awakening''; this year that theater is staging another new musical: ''10 MILLION MILES,'' with a book by KEITH BUNIN (''The Busy World Is Hushed'') and songs by the recording artist PATTY GRIFFIN. Though some recent attempts to tell theatrical stories with pre-existing pop music have proved dismal (''The Times They Are A-Changin','' ''All Shook Up,'' ''Lennon''), the director MICHAEL MAYER brings to ''10 Million Miles'' the experience of having smoothed over that divide in ''Spring Awakening.'' And Ms. Griffin's folk-ballad style actually makes sense with the story of wounded redneck lovers (MATTHEW MORRISON and MARE WINNINGHAM) on a road trip. In previews, opens June 14, Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com; $65. Meanwhile, over at MCC Theater, it's time for the annual NEIL LaBUTE id-fest. This year's installment: ''IN A DARK DARK HOUSE,'' starring FREDERICK WELLER and RON LIVINGSTON as brothers with a secret. At 44 Mr. LaBute is something of a theatrical Joyce Carol Oates, churning out the goods at a seemingly unhealthy rate. Certainly it had become a bit tiresome to watch each new play wear out its initial welcome as the trick (incest, Sept. 11, a hidden tape recorder) clicked into place partway through. But starting with ''Some Girl(s),'' produced by MCC in 2004, Mr. LaBute seemed to be digging deeper, treating his characters with more affection and (until a dissatisfying ending) letting them shape the story. The question about ''In a Dark Dark House'' is: Which LaBute will we get? In previews, opens June 7, Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com; $70.

An article on May 6 about ''The Simpsons Movie'' misstated the credits of the movie's director, David Silverman. He was a co-director of ''Monsters, Inc.,'' not the director. And he was one of several directors of ''The Road to El Dorado,'' not the sole one.

To the Editor: Justifying bad and stupid books (Joe Queenan, ''Why Not the Worst?,'' May 6) is like trying to justify the Iraq war. The effort is useless. What's really bad? What's really stupid? What's really Iraq? All three are states of mind. Gus Franza Moriches, N.Y.

CONNELLY--William Mowry. A prominent product liability attorney, died Saturday, May 12 from a heart attack. He was 64. Connelly was born February 5, 1943 in Buenos Aires, Argentina and grew up in Greenwich, CT. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University, and was a member of the Society of Book and Snake. He also received his J.D. from Yale. He spent nine years at the Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft law firm in New York City, relocating to Cleveland in 1976 as head of litigation for TRW and joined Walter & Haverfield, a Cleveland law firm in 1986. He retired in 2002. He was a fan of the New York Metropolitan Opera, an avid American history buff, and did the New York Times crossword puzzle, in pen, every Sunday. He is survived by his beloved wife Diane, his daughters Karin Rice, Susan Thompson and Heather, his grandson, Alexander Mowry Thompson, and cousin, Patricia Mudge.
Around every corner is yet another kahve or kebab. So where do you go for quintessential Ottoman treats?
Prime real estate below.

Norbert Schoerner When Norbert Schoerner first took up the camera, he thought his career would be in film. ''This whole thing is a 15-year diversion,'' says the photographer, who shot ''It's a Med, Med World,'' this issue's cover story, on the Italian island of Lampedusa (Page 128). Schoerner, whose monograph ''The Order of Things'' (center) was published by Phaidon in 2001, hasn't given up on the cinema, however. After making several shorts -- including ''Final Call,'' available at nytimes.com/travelmagazine -- he's preparing his first feature, a samurai film shot in Japan. The country is a current obsession: one of his favorite recent finds on the road is the Terrific Power Storage Case (far right), picked up at a supermarket in Aomori.

It's a time for dancing, remembering and rejoicing. The festival ''30 YEARS OF DANCEAFRICA: REMEMBER! HONOR! RESPECT! AN AFRICAN DANCE ODYSSEY'' looks back on three decades of bringing African and African-American dance to the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It's also honoring the 70th birthday of its energetic founder, CHUCK DAVIS. Performers include the Bambara Drum and Dance Ensemble from the Bronx, Forces of Nature Dance Theater Company from Harlem, the Kulu Mele African American Dance Ensemble from Philadelphia, the Ndere Troupe from Uganda and two Brooklyn groups: the Sabar Ak Ru Afriq Dance Theater and the BAM/Restoration DanceAfrica Ensemble. Among other events this year are African films at the BAM Rose Cinemas and an outdoor African bazaar in the spaces around the theater. Performances on Friday at 7:30 p.m., Saturday and May 27 at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Howard Gilman Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $20 to $45 for adults, $10 to $22.50 for children under 16. Momix celebrates more than 25 years of magical stagecraft in ''MOMIX reMIX,'' a theatrical collage that assembles excerpts from past multimedia works by its artistic director, MOSES PENDLETON, a choreographer who can transform dancers into desert flora and fauna, send them soaring into outer space, hurl them like baseballs and make them defy gravity in ingenious ways. Tuesday through June 10, Tuesdays and Wednesdays at 7:30 p.m., Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m., Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m., Sundays at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $44. Last year the Japanese-American dancers EIKO & KOMA worked with young Cambodian performers in a striking collaboration. They're collaborating again in ''Cambodian Stories Revisited,'' an outdoor event presented by the Danspace Project. Large paintings, created by members of the REYUM PAINTING COLLECTIVE of Cambodia, will be suspended over graves to symbolize how different cultures recall the passage of generations. Thursday through May 27 at 8:30 p.m., St. Mark's Churchyard, Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194; free.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Duke Lacrosse Team Uses Work Ethic to Fix Image,'' May 11: It was refreshing to read Pete Thamel's article on the Duke lacrosse team, with a focus on two players who shatter the myth of the team's elite image.

GLUCKSMAN--Trevor. Founder Wellfleet Pottery Trevor Glucksman, 82, husband of Kathleen, father of sons Maurice, Daniel and Tobias, and grandfather of four, passed away on May 15 after a long illness. Trevor is also survived by sister Lorraine and brother Myron. In 1970, Trevor and Kathleen founded Wellfleet Pottery, their artistic collaboration and livelihood, where they produced Wellfleet Pottery Umber China, now a collectable. Trevor was born and raised in Vancouver, Canada. He studied philosophy and architecture at the University of British Columbia and University of Manitoba. In the 1950s, Trevor and Kathleen helped found Israel's nascent ceramic industry. They subsequently lived in London, England where Trevor undertook doctoral work in philosophy of art and architecture at the University of London, which he later continued at Harvard University, and Kathleen studied at the London School of Drawing and Painting. During the early 1960s, Trevor and his family lived in New York, where he worked as a creative writer in advertising on Madison Avenue, and first began to develop designs for Wellfleet Pottery. During that time, he also received an award for his work on a documentary about the aviators the Wright Brothers. Although Trevor increasingly suffered from a debilitating motor disease, he continued to draw and write short stories until his final weeks. The family will hold a memorial gathering, open to all who wish to attend, at 5 pm on June 9 at 165 Commercial Street in Wellfleet.

Bashing the people who sit in the executive suites never goes out of style. That is why Jossey-Bass is rereleasing the 1970 business classic, ''Up the Organization: How to Stop the Corporation From Stifling People and Strangling Profits,'' by Robert L. Townsend. Townsend became famous as the maverick who turned around Avis in the 1960s with the ''We Try Harder'' advertising campaign. He died in 1998, and his friend Warren Bennis agreed to update Townsend's hippie-era book.

Tyler Clippard is listed at 6 feet 4 inches and 170 pounds, but consider this: When the Yankees drafted him in 2003, he weighed 10 to 15 pounds less. The skinny right-hander will get his first start in the majors tonight at Shea. Clippard is not a hard thrower, but he has been a strikeout pitcher in the minor leagues, with 598 strikeouts in 543 innings. He throws about 88 to 92 miles an hour, with a curveball and a changeup.

BELL--Philip, of Rockville Centre, NY, died peacefully early Friday at South Nassau Communities Hospital. Beloved and devoted husband of Gladys; dedicated father of Jack and Robert; cherished grandfather who worshiped Jesse, Samantha and Sadie; dear father-in-law to Theresa and Teresa. Your love, smile, gentle nature, sense of humor and kindness will be dearly missed by all. He proudly served his country in the Pacific during World War II. A memorial service will be held at 1 pm tomorrow, May 20, 2007, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, with burial to follow at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, Queens.

London is the new Rich. With the pound outweighing the dollar around two to one, affording the British capital is the latest travel status symbol. Not a high roller? Try the new Haymarket Hotel, ''affordable'' at about $490 a night.

To the average 20-something who dispenses movie tickets, I certainly look like a senior. When those who are presumptuous or perceptive enough to think I may be under 65 (which I am) and ask me for proof of age, I simply look them in the eye, sigh and say, ''You're not going to card me, are you?'' Recent memories of being asked to prove that they are of legal drinking age prompt them to issue the senior discount without further ado. It's proof that experience and cunning beat youth and energy almost every time.

To the Editor: I was initially very pleased to see that you devoted an issue of the Book Review (April 15) to literature in translation. Many of the books sound wonderful. Most of the reviewers' ability to discuss work in translation, however, seemed fairly limited.

Joining the ranks of the rest of Britain (as well as Italy, Sweden, Norway and Ireland), England will ban smoking in all enclosed public places and offices on July 1 -- a law that will undoubtedly affect England's traditional pub scene. ''We are expecting to see three or four thousand pubs in England hit particularly hard by the ban,'' said Caroline Nodder, editor of The Publican, a trade magazine sent to some 33,000 pub owners each week. ''The pubs that serve food should benefit from the ban, but it is the traditional local pubs, the one tourists often like to visit the most, that may not be able to survive the initial impact.''
Thanks for Bruce Stutz's article. Many people are trapped between wanting to get off antidepressants and fearing the withdrawal symptoms. Stutz draws a good, readable map of what they may encounter.

Among former Gov. George Pataki's pet projects were the parks in and along the state's waterways, especially the Hudson River Park in Manhattan and historic Governors Island in New York Harbor. For reasons that are not entirely clear -- envy, perhaps, or lack of interest -- Gov. Eliot Spitzer has shown nowhere near the same enthusiasm, despite the environmental credentials he earned as Attorney General. The net result is that the momentum behind the partly completed Hudson River Park has slowed while the Governors Island project remains stuck in neutral.

General Manager Brian Cashman said that Roger Clemens intended to make only one more minor league start before returning to the Yankees, presumably on May 28 or 29 in Toronto. Clemens's second start will be for Class AA Trenton on Wednesday. ''He is shooting for two,'' Cashman said. ''I am not saying that is going to happen, but it is possible.''

To the Editor: Re ''Moyduh, He Watched: Commissioner Turns Critic'' by Michael Wilson [May 13]:

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Writing the Book on Hating the Sox,'' May 13: As a lifetime New Englander and member of Red Sox Nation, I appreciate Jerome Preisler's living among us. He, far better than anyone, personifies the welcomed loss of Yankee swagger. Stephen L. Tober Portsmouth, N.H. To the Sports Editor: For years I enjoyed the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry and imagined Sox fans to be as avid and knowledgeable as Yankee fans. Then, five years ago, I moved to Massachusetts, where many Red Sox fans are more obsessed with denigrating the Yankees than with supporting their own team.

ROBERTS--Donna L., died May 17, 2007 age 53. Survived by life partner Leonora Lucon, mother, Evelyn Roberts and her siblings, Hal, Phyllis, Donald, Tessa and Jerry. Your loving smile and gentle nature will be missed by all. Memorial services will be July 21st at Brooklyn Ethical Culture.

''Simplify, simplify,'' Thoreau once wrote. But is it possible to be green without retreating to a cabin in the woods? This issue looks at the ecology of architecture in the age of shrinking forests, urban sprawl and rising anxiety about global warming: A city in Brazil that made recycling a civic religion. An architect in Australia who looked to the land and its early settlers. An entrepreneur with a plan for every house to generate its own power. A Japanese architect who saw the possibilities in paper. An imaginary future home both luxurious and green. And a new generation of European architects who may show us what to do next.

As bad as the fire in the Pine Barrens was last week, it could have been worse had there not been large-scale controlled fires in the area last winter, a United States Forest Service official said. Local, state and federal agencies perform controlled burns every year between October and March, said John L. Hom, deputy program manager of the Forest Service's Global Change Program, which works on fire management in the Pine Barrens and adjacent lands.

To the Editor: Re ''Young Lawyers Sue, and Little Changes'' (Feb. 25), which described the tentative settlement of a class-action lawsuit in which BAR/BRI, the bar review company, was accused of illegal, unethical and anticompetitive acts:

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Suns Are Crying Foul in Wake of Suspensions,'' May 16: The N.B.A. rule that requires players to stay off the court in the event of an altercation makes sense, but it requires them to behave unnaturally. All Amare Stoudemire and Boris Diaw did was take two or three steps forward and the result was automatic suspensions.

To the Editor: Re ''Mammograms in Decline'' (editorial, May 15): While mammography screenings may have declined across the country, New York City's public hospitals have continued to meet a growing demand.

To the Editor: ''New Demographic Racial Gap Emerges'' (news article, May 17) and its chart, ''America's Changing Ethnic Profile,'' highlight a major sociological issue that affects our view of ourselves as a nation: in public parlance, and in social science terms, there is a world of difference between race and ethnicity. Racial divisions are considered biological, although they are, in effect, largely socially constructed. Ethnic divisions have no such connotations in contemporary American society.
BENALLOUL--Maurice. Our sympathy and great sadness for the loss of a very loved man. Karen and Jerry Karlik
KACHURIN--Leon Edward, Beloved husband for 47 years of Penny. Adored father of Pamela and Jessica, and grandfather of Jared, Gabriella and Hailey. Beloved by all who knew him.

To the Editor: Regarding ''The Heel Is Rising'' by Frank Bruni (May 6): Although I'm glad to see that a bon vivant of Mr. Bruni's acclaim could find enough luxury and gourmet dining in Apulia to make it worth the trip, in today's weak-dollar world it's unfortunate that he failed to point out what a great bargain the region can be. Rooms in hotels like the Palazzo Baldi in Galatina, which was carved out of a grouping of 16th-century palazzos, and the Villa Ducale -- a musty but charming 1950s-looking structure on the Piazzetta Sant' Antonio, just steps from the town of Martina Franca -- can be had for under 65 euros a night.

Jennifer Stacy Gellmann and Raul Rothblatt are to be married today in Brooklyn. Rabbi Hara E. Person is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The bride, 36, is a senior librarian in the society, sciences and technology division of the Central Library of the Brooklyn Public Library. She graduated from George Washington University and has a master's degree in library science from the University of Maryland.

Since making his Mets debut a year ago, John Maine has started his share of high-profile games. He spot-started Game 1 of the division series, and he helped the Mets stave off elimination in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series. So does pitching against the Yankees tonight in front of an expected capacity crowd at Shea Stadium pale in comparison?
Istanbul doesn't lack for riches from the ancient world. But it's the modern and contemporary art scene that's making this city a mecca for culture vultures.

To the Editor: Re ''Pop Quiz: Did the Tax Cuts Bolster Growth?'' (Economic View, May 13), in which economists were asked to choose reasons for the expansion of the United States economy since mid-2003: A better question might be whether tax cuts limited growth, rather than bolstering it. The cuts' bias toward wealthier taxpayers placed more money in the pockets of people whose less frequent transactions reduced money's velocity, the speed with which it moves from one economy-spurring transaction to the next.

At the end of a procession of 3,000 graduates, a father stood clad in a cap and gown, embarking on an unlikely doubleheader. Five hours before his team was to play the Yankees at Shea Stadium yesterday, Mets Manager Willie Randolph delivered the commencement address at Fordham University in the Bronx. His daughter Ciara, a communications major, was among the graduates. Later, she and 12 other family members were on hand for the game, which the Mets won, 10-7.

Long known for its cutting-edge music and art, Iceland hasn't made much of an impression on the fashion world, Bjork's eyebrow-raising swan dress notwithstanding. But a nascent style scene is now taking root in the capital, stoked by the city's pervasive youth culture and a fashion program at the Iceland Academy of the Arts. A clutch of trailblazing downtown shops present an idiosyncratic blend of design, art and clothes -- and provide a welcome new daytime diversion in a city that doesn't really come alive until after dark. Jaime Gross

The closest thing to a tourist attraction in the Paris neighborhood of Belleville is a small plaque commemorating the birth of Ãdith Piaf, posted on a drab apartment building on a busy street. ''On the steps of this house,'' the inscription reads, ''was born on 19 December 1915, in the greatest destitution, Ãdith Piaf, whose voice would later turn the world upside down.'' The story isn't quite true -- in fact, Piaf was born in a nearby hospital -- but it's a charming myth that evokes both Piaf's legendary rise from street urchin to international stardom and the hard-boiled mystique of her childhood quartier.
Where, oh where to go? T solves the puzzle.
