A pair of wayward humpback whales appeared to be heading in the right direction late Sunday, moving down a Sacramento River shipping channel toward the Pacific Ocean, marine officials said. By late afternoon, they were about eight miles outside the Port of Sacramento and being escorted by 8 to 10 Coast Guard vessels and other boats, said Bernadette Fees, a spokeswoman for the California Department of Fish and Game, adding, ''It's hard to say what prompted them.''

Alan Bergman ''Lyrically, Alan Bergman'' (Verve) There is no underestimating the value of a lowered voice. To hear Alan Bergman murmur lyrics that Barbra Streisand, Tony Bennett and Neil Diamond have passionately declaimed is to rediscover movie songs divested of red-carpet glitter and dressed in street clothes. Ms. Streisand's high-strung renditions of ''The Way We Were,'' ''How Do You Keep the Music Playing?,'' ''You Don't Bring Me Flowers'' and ''What Are You Doing the Rest of Your Life?'' may be the definitive, weepy, show-stopping interpretations. But as Mr. Bergman, who wrote those songs' lyrics with his wife, Marilyn, shows in his quiet, ruminative readings, emotional balance and wisdom lurk below the Sturm und Drang.

Paquito D'Rivera Quintet ''Funk Tango'' (Paquito/Sunnyside) Funk tango? Sounds like a bad idea. But this new album from the Cuban-born alto saxophonist and clarinetist Paquito D'Rivera works breezily, shrugging off its own title. There are intimations of tango on the album, most obviously in ''Revirado,'' the token Astor Piazzolla song. But even on the title track, composed by the pianist Alon Yavnai, funk is a distant idea. (The mere presence of an electric bass doesn't do it.)

Callie Bachman, a 16-year-old School of American Ballet student, was Peter Martins's original choice for the role of Juliet in his new production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' for the New York City Ballet. But Ms. Bachman was injured halfway through the making of the ballet, and her fairy-tale leap into the spotlight was abruptly curtailed. Curious balletomanes will, however, soon have a chance to see Ms. Bachman in an extract from ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Mr. Martins, who is chairman of the faculty at the school, as well as ballet master in chief of City Ballet, has decided to add the ballet's first-act pas de deux, danced by Ms. Bachman and a fellow student, Russell Janzen, to the program at the school's annual workshop performances on June 2 and 4. Other works to be performed are Balanchine's ''Four Temperaments'' and ''Gounod Symphony,'' Mr. Martins's ''Gentilhommes'' and Sean Lavery's ''Twinkliana.'' ROSLYN SULCAS
To the Editor: Re ''Incredible Shrinking Packages'' (''The Energy Challenge'' series, Business Day, May 12):

A front-page picture caption yesterday with an article about the crisis faced by Africa's finest universities because of mismanagement, neglect and policies that favor basic education referred incorrectly in some copies to the broken piece of equipment being used by a chemistry student. It is a graduated cylinder, not a test tube. An article on Wednesday about American adoptions from Guatemala incorrectly described the accreditation process for adoption service providers. The State Department contracts the process out to the Council on Accreditation; it does not itself accredit them.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Albany last week lobbying state lawmakers on his PlaNYC, a raft of measures -- many needing state aid and approval -- to ensure that New York City grows in an environmentally sustainable way. Legislators were treated to a PowerPoint presentation in which Mr. Bloomberg showed slides depicting a dire future of street traffic and overloaded subways, and he asked for new daytime fees for driving in much of Manhattan, new subway construction and other measures. ''By 2030, every major road into Manhattan will be above capacity,'' blares the caption on one slide. A notation on it says that demand for vehicle crossings from New Jersey into Midtown -- the Lincoln Tunnel, in other words -- will increase by 38 percent by 2030, and demand for mass transit will rise by a whopping 56 percent.
To the Editor: Re ''Documents From Vast Nazi Archive to Be Made Available to Scholars'' (news article, May 16):

There was a seeming rush to get in on the Internet advertising market last week, when WPP Group bought 24/7 Real Media, above, and Microsoft acquired aQuantive. While advertising spending had single-digit gains in most media categories last year over 2005, the increase online was 35 percent. There is a growing effort to reach consumers on the Web, where they are a click away from information and on-the-spot purchases. The battle now among ad companies is to deliver an even narrower demographic slice to clients. SHELLY FREIERMAN

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 40 Die in Lebanon as Army And Qaeda Militants Clash Fierce clashes erupted between Lebanese Army soldiers and Islamic militants tied to Al Qaeda in the northern Lebanese town of Tripoli, leaving 23 Lebanese soldiers and 17 militants dead and dozens injured. A car bomb exploded in a parking lot in a Christian section of eastern Beirut, killing one person and wounding 10 others. A1 India Faces Electricity Hurdle According to the Planning Commission of India, 600 million people -- roughly half the population -- are off the electric grid. The electricity crisis is becoming all the more acute because of the roaring pace of the country's economic growth and the new material aspirations it has generated. A1 6 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq Six American soldiers and their interpreter were killed by a hidden roadside bomb in western Baghdad, the military said, in one of the deadliest attacks against American troops in the capital in recent months. A8 Israeli Airstrike Kills 8 in Gaza The Israeli Air Force struck the home of a Hamas Parliament member in Gaza, killing eight people, Palestinian hospital officials said. The Parliament member was not in the house at the time. A3 Afghan Bomber Strikes Market At least 10 people were killed and 32 were wounded when a suicide bomber struck at a crowded market in the southeastern Afghan province of Paktia, the provincial police chief said. News agencies said the death toll later rose to 14, quoting doctors at the local hospital. A8 Bush Meets with NATO Chief President Bush welcomed the NATO secretary general to his home in Crawford, Tex., for two days of a meetings focusing on holding together the fragile coalition fighting in Afghanistan and on dealing with new tensions with an assertive Russia. A8 Integrating Gay Soldiers Since the British military began allowing homosexuals to serve in the armed forces in 2000, none of its fears -- about harassment, discord, blackmail, bullying or an erosion of unit cohesion or military effectiveness -- have come to pass, according to the Ministry of Defense, current and former members of the services and academics specializing in the military. A8 NATIONAL A12-17 New Group of Leaders Widen Evangelical Agenda The death of the Rev. Jerry Falwell highlighted the fact that the evangelical Christian movement has shifted in potentially momentous ways, with members of a new generation of leaders who have mostly eschewed the partisan approach of their forebears and have broadened the movement's agenda. A1 Concern Over Immigration Bill The Senate is set to begin debating a major immigration bill, but leading members of Congress and employers, who helped shape the bill, expressed unhappiness, alarm and concerns that the bill would take more time and could face significant hurdles. A1 Detective to Hollywood's Stars The evidence uncovered in federal agents' raid of the office of Anthony Pellicano, the private detective known for his clientele of Hollywood moguls, has so far turned up documents and hundreds of recordings, that provide a vicarious tour through the dysfunctional heart of Hollywood. A1 Three Dead in Idaho Shooting An assault on a courthouse in Moscow, Idaho, by a gunman with an assault weapon left three people dead and two wounded. Police officials have not released the identity of the gunman or those injured and have said that they have no information on the gunman's motive. A12 Telecom Company to Be Sold Alltel, the wireless telephone company, agreed to be sold to a consortium of private equity firms for $27.5 billion, making it perhaps the largest buyout ever in the telecommunications industry. A15 Candidates to Unveil Proposals Two presidential candidates plan to unveil domestic policy proposals today, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton calling for a $5 billion plan for universal pre-kindergarten classes and Senator John McCain urging more efficiency and ethics in government. A12 Whales Swim Down Coast Two injured Humpback whales, which were near West Sacramento and about 90 miles off course from their seasonal migration, appeared to be heading in the right direction, moving downriver toward the Pacific and were trailed by Coast Guard boats. A12 Response to Carter Criticism The White House responded to former President Jimmy Carter's blistering critique of President Bush in kind, calling his comments ''sad'' and Mr. Carter himself ''irrelevant.'' A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Study Puts Price Tag On Nature in New Jersey A report commissioned by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection has put a dollar value on the state's natural resources, like the Pine Barrens and the Jersey Shore, in a move that environmentalists and others hope will allow polluters to be fined more accurately for the damage they cause. B1 Saving Hip-Hop's Birthplace Clive Campbell, known as D.J. Kool Herc, believes the west Bronx building in which he invented hip-hop in 1973 should be declared a landmark. The building's residents agree, and there is a growing movement to place the building on the National Register of Historic Places. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-7 China to Invest in Blackstone The Chinese government has announced that it will acquire a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, in the country's first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign exchange reserves beyond United States Treasury bills and into commercial enterprise. C1 Murdoch Family Ties The relationship between Rupert Murdoch and his six children has come under new scrutiny in the three weeks since Mr. Murdoch offered $5 billion to buy Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal. C1 Premiere Parties Downsized With demanding corporate parents, their Wall Street partners and restive shareholders all looking to cut down on extravagant spending, studio executives have been quietly trimming the premiere budgets for movies, sometimes giving filmmakers cash for a private dinner, or even forgoing the party altogether. Brooks A British undercover agent dispatched to France to lead a network of saboteurs who delayed German reinforcements for weeks after the Normandy invasion during World War II, he was 85. He plans to start shooting a Sundance Institute-supported movie in the fall, and a documentary about him is slated for release later this year. The Frugal Traveler visits a classic diner in Baltimore and explores two sides of Latino culture in North Carolina.

Oh, so you want red wine? How does '29 sound, as in 1929? That's right, and I'm talking Beaujolais. You know, that light, fruity inconsequential red that's best drunk within a couple of years. Now let's move onto something serious.

Of course everyone comes here to see the old stones. But this month you can take in Roman history and terrific modern art exhibits in one go. Check out the Julian Schnabel exhibit that just opened in Palazzo Venezia, a grand decaying building that was the first great Renaissance palace in Rome, and later served as a residence for Italian Dictator Benito Mussolini. Schnabel's humongous bright abstract paintings are literally leaned up against the chipping frescos of the palace's cave-like chandeliered rooms. The contrast is perfect. In another room, Schnabel's large glossy signature portraits are hung over sullied frescos of Roman seals and columns.

Alexander Onischuk and Alexander Shabalov drew their games today but retained their lead in the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. Three grandmasters - Sergey Kudrin, Gregory Kaidanov and Yury Shulman, last year's runner-up - trailed by half a point with only one round to go. All the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

With the title of his 1980 book, the journalist Sidney Blumenthal coined a term that has entered the political lexicon: "The Permanent Campaign." The phrase denotes the blurring of the line in modern times between campaigning and governing. Presidents, of course, have always made decisions with an eye on their popularity. But with the advent of television, polling, and professional consultants, presidents of the 1970s and '80s-Nixon, Carter, and Reagan in particular-upped the ante by devoting the full arsenal of modern electioneering tools not just to winning office but to holding office as well.Recently, the permanent campaign has added yet another stage-a final frontier. This is the fight for history, centered on the presidents' libraries. The presidential libraries date from 1939, when Franklin Delano Roosevelt conceived his as a repository for his public papers, to be built with private funds and run by public officials. Since then, chief executives have sought to outdo their predecessors by entombing their archives in extravagant, self-memorializing shrines. These museums extend the permanent campaign by utilizing the same public relations techniques as a race for the White House-and lately requiring comparable fundraising efforts to boot.
In the chat that he inevitably has with Atlanta/New York reporters on the first day of a series down here, Tom Glavine said that victory No. 300 "seems much more in reach than it did before."

One of the great privileges of this job is the annual media game at Yankee Stadium and Fenway Park. Once a year, early in the morning, the Yankees and the Red Sox open their doors to let the New York media take on the Boston media. It's real hardball: umpires, scoreboards, music, a post-game food spread, the works. Everything but those annoying writers asking us questions after the game.

The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission voted today to schedule a hearing on whether to designate the former Domino sugar processing plant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn as a landmark. The decision today, which was made in a unanimous vote, is the first of three steps required to make a building a landmark in New York City. Next, the commission will hold a hearing, then a final vote.

Rudolph W. Giuliani swung by Albany today to receive the support of a wide swath of New York state senators and members of the assembly. Well, not so much Albany -- he flew into a private air terminal, run by the company Million Air, at Albany's airport, received the endorsements and some enthusiastic praise, then got back on his jet and flew off again.Among other things, the former New York City mayor said the Democratic candidates running for president did not understand the threat of Islamic terrorism and that state Republicans would find a way to retake control of the Assembly, a task that would require them to add a couple of dozen seats to the 40-odd controlled by the Republicans today.

The Senate Republicans gathered today at a news conference with law enforcement officers from around the state to demand that Gov. Eliot Spitzer push the Assembly to pass a bill reinstating the death penalty for cop killers. Afterward, Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said that he had already spoken "very directly" to his Assembly counterpart, Speaker Sheldon Silver, about moving a death penalty bill to the Assembly floor for a vote.

Yes, the Preakness Stakes outdid the Kentucky Derby in terms of excitement this year with Curlin's come-from-behind victory. Then again, we're just as happy to watch another horserace in Kentucky today, this one featuring an impressive story of political recovery-even if it's only temporary.
Matt Gross packs up the 1989 Volvo station wagon he bought on Craigslist and heads out for a three-month trip across the continental U.S.

Our colleagues over at The Empire Zone are all over this story about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan, announced today, to replace New York City's entire taxi fleet with hybrid vehicles in the next five years. The Times's Sewell Chan writes:

I'm not normally a fan of "cultural shows," but Siam Niramit, a huge production of acrobatics and special effects (the producers somehow figured out how to recreate a tropical downpour onstage) is worth the trip. It's sort of Thai culture meets Las Vegas.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's May 22 column, "American Cities and the Great Divide."
Readers respond to David Brooks's May 22 column, "America's Admissions System."
Julia Preston, The New York Times reporter who answered some immigration questions last week, today wrote an article that outlines the immigration bill before the Senate.

The feud between Senator John McCain and former Gov. Mitt Romney is heating up, but it seems the McCain-Giuliani Mutual Admiration Society is as strong as ever. While Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mr. McCain share a reputation for tough talk, they only seem to have the kindest of words for one another. Let's take a look at a few examples:

For the next 12 weeks, Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, will be on the road from New York City to Seattle. To make his journey a success, he needs your help. His next stops are in Georgia and Alabama.

As French as the Eiffel Tower, or a smoke-filled bistro, the cheap and cheery Citroën 2CV was originally built to suit the basic transportation needs of country-dwellers. Somewhere along the way, and during its epic production run of 1948-90, the simple 2CV became a symbol of Gallic coolness. The car has a cultlike following and is affectionately known by a variety of nicknames, including "the tin snail," "the duck," or "the flying ragtop" because of its foldable canvas roof.

The Pew Center for the People and the Press has released results from a new poll of Muslim Americans' attitudes on the United States. Good news, according to the Dallas Morning News's headline: "Poll: Most Muslim-Americans reject suicide bombings"
The 44th hottest trend in Google search right now is the phrase "Google Hot Trends."
Wind turbines next to a farm house in Kansas, U.S. Lawrence Journal/AP

In the latest twist in a legal battle that's starting to resemble a corkscrew, Aaron Charney, the former Sullivan & Cromwell associate who has sued the law firm alleging gay bias, added several charges to his complaint Monday. To his initial allegations of discrimination based on sexual orientation, Mr. Charney has added claims of emotional distress and conspiracy, according to the New York Law Journal. Before his suit caused a stir in legal circles, Mr. Charney had worked in the mergers and acquisitions group at one of the leading firms that advises in such deals.

The explosive growth of private equity deals is a well-documented trend by now, but some new numbers from Thomson Financial underscore just how enormous the volume of buyouts has become. Consider this: So far this year, the volume of global announced deals involving private equity firms is $447 billion, more than double the volume from the same period in 2006 -- a year that was no slouch was far as buyouts were concerned. In the United States, the rise has been even sharper. At $281 billion, U.S. private equity deals have more than tripled from a year ago, boosted by the recent buyouts of Alltel, First Data and others.

Wallstrip, the offbeat financial Web show whose host has been known to frolic with hogs for a segment on pork producer Premium Standard Farms, has found a home with Big Media. CBS on Tuesday confirmed that it bought the quirky start-up, whose backers include venture investor Fred Wilson, for an undisclosed price.

Just as the presidential primaries are moving up on the calendar, so, too, are the publication dates of books about the race. And Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign may be most affected, as The Time's Motoko Rich writes:

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's announcement today that the entire fleet of New York City taxicabs -- more than 13,000 vehicles -- will become all-hybrid by 2012 marks a reversal of his administration's earlier slowness in embracing the issue.
Continuing his journey across China, Nicholas D. Kristof visits his wife's ancestral village.
Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, grills a very un-American burger.

Presidential candidates in both parties have been wooing the Wall Street set in a big way this election season. Last Friday, it was the turn of Democrat Barack Obama, who touched down in Greenwich, Conn., the unofficial hub of the hedge fund set, for a pair of fundraisers. The first was co-hosted by George Soros, the financier and former hedge fund manager, and Paul Tudor Jones, who runs the giant hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. That event, held in Mr. Jones's $25 million waterfront mansion -- which Vanity Fair's Nina Munk has described as a "a cross between Tara and a national monument" -- collected $2,300 from each of the approximately 300 attendees, the Greenwich Time reported.

The second video chronicling Nick's journey across China is from our first stop on the Chinese Mainland. Dongguan about 50 miles north of Hong Kong and Nick had first visited here 20 years ago. He later returned to profile a communist party official.

Silda Wall Spitzer, the governor's wife, said this morning that she would hold a public meeting to examine why young people are leaving the state, particularly upstate. The "I Live New York" conference will take place on Sept. 19 at the State University of New York in Cortland, N.Y., with the goal of coming up with a plan to halt or at least slow the exodus.

Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.'s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, "I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy." Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

Fremont General, a California lender stung by recent weakness in the subprime mortgage market, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell its commercial lending business to iStar Financial for about $1.9 billion, leaving the company to focus on its retail operations. Fremont also said that it would sell a minority stake in the entire company to an investor group led by Gerald Ford, the former chief executive of Golden State Bancorp, who will become its new chairman.

Alexander V. Litvinenko, Andrei K. Lugovoi and Dmitri V. Kovtun met in London on Nov. 1. Within hours, Mr. Litvinenko would fall seriously ill, dying later that month from radiation poisoning. The other two would soon become a focus of the investigation.
Charlie LeDuff interviews Gloria Castillo during her shift at a Burger King in Dallas.

Whatever happens at MGM Mirage, it looks like Kirk Kerkorian will walk away a winner. That is what several analysts suggested Tuesday as they pondered Monday's short but highly suggestive announcement by Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian's investment vehicle, that it would begin negotiating to buy two Las Vegas properties from MGM Mirage and consider alternatives for its majority stake in MGM. Mr. Kerkorian has already hit the jackpot, at least on paper. Shares of MGM Mirage surged 26 percent in early trading Tuesday to $79.32. As a result, the value of Mr. Kerkorian's 56 percent stake in the casino company grew by $2.6 billion overnight.

Taxing the other guy -- not the locals who can vote in local elections --has obvious appeal to politicians. It helps to explain the widespread use of discriminatory taxing of municipal bond interest. If you live in New York, bonds issued by that state, and its cities and other agencies, are not subject to state income tax. But those issued by other states are.
As Americans choose cremation in record numbers, cemeteries are repositioning themselves for the afterlife: their own.
This isn't usually a blog about art, let alone "installations." But I thought you'd get a kick out of this one from artist Bill Shackelford.

As he faces criticism from members of his own party over his immigration stance, Senator John McCain has begun to stress the differing positions of one of his chief G.O.P. rivals. For example, Michael Cooper reported on a three-pronged jab he took at Mitt Romney on the issue. Mr. McCain may also be feeling the competition from Mr. Romney, whose performance in polls in Iowa and New Hampshire is starting to match his stellar fund-raising capacity.

OSI Restaurant Partners, which runs the Outback Steakhouse chain, said Tuesday a group including Bain Capital, Catterton Partners and OSI's founders have raised their buyout offer by 3 percent to about $3.18 billion.

British Airways said Tuesday it had joined a consortium led by a private equity firm, the Texas Pacific Group, that is considering a bid for Spain's Iberia airline. British Airways is Iberia's largest shareholder, with a 10 percent stake, and some analysts saw the move as an attempt to retain some influence over Iberia.

For years, house prices in Ireland have been crazy, with costs rising by 146 percent between 1995 and 2003. However, the market has cooled recently, especially with an election coming up that will bring a likely change in the stamp duty. Many people are holding off on buying until after the election, set to be called sometime this summer. But some who are not averse to risk are buying in the belief that any saving made by stamp duty cuts after the election will be offset by subsequent house price rises.
“I Have Never Forgotten You” effectively sketches Simon Wiesenthal’s life, from his tenacity in surviving  genocide, to his determination to find and punish ex-Nazis after World War II.

Is Home Depot having trouble selling its supply unit? According to The New York Post, the softening housing market and other complications are creating challenges for Home Depot as it tries to find a buyer for its professional supply business.

When an activist hedge fund makes headlines, it's generally raising a ruckus over a company's poor management decisions. But now, two activist hedge funds seemed to poised to go head to head over a deal for software company Acxiom. MMI Investments, Acxiom's second-largest shareholder, is objecting to the sale of the company to Acxiom's largest shareholder, ValueAct, and the private equity firm Silver Lake.

In a deal that has been rumored for some time, Electronic Arts announced Monday that it is investing about $167 million to buy a 15 percent stake in The9, a Chinese video game company. As part of the deal, The9 acquired an exclusive license to publish E.A.'s "FIFA Online" soccer game in China.

Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison said it hired Jennifer A. Spiegel as counsel in its corporate department. Ms. Spiegel, previously of Debevoise & Plimpton, will be part of Paul Weiss's investment funds group, which advises on fund organization, registration and compliance as well as the buying and selling of investment advisers. The investment funds group has grown to more than 20 lawyers, Paul Weiss said.

Corporate boards are nearly three times as likely to push out failing chief executives than they were a decade ago, a new study examining turnover among top executives has found. Nearly one of three chief executives who departed last year were either fired or forced out for performance-related reasons, according to the analysis by the global management consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. That compared with roughly one in seven departing executives ousted in 1996.

Chevron, the oil behemoth, intends to sell what amounts to a stake of about 12 percent in the energy company Dynegy through a public stock offering. Chevron U.S.A. will offer 96.9 million Class A Dynegy shares in a sale that will be managed by Goldman Sachs.

The networking equipment maker Cisco Systems said Tuesday it would buy privately-held BroadWare Technologies, a provider of Internet-based video surveillance software. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company said BroadWare's software allows users to monitor, manage, record and store audio and video online, and helps customers gain access to live and recorded surveillance video for faster investigation response.

The Russian airline Aeroflot is seeking up to 900 million euros ($1.2 billion) in loans to finance its bid for all or part of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, in its first merger or acquisition effort outside the former Soviet Union.

Tesla Motors, the electric car start-up that has piqued the interest of stars like George Clooney, announced Tuesday that it had created a new division, the Tesla Energy Group, to sell batteries, and that it has received a $43 million order. Think, a Norwegian maker of electric cars, will buy lithium-ion battery packs from Tesla Energy. The deal, reported in the San Jose Mercury News, will bring Tesla $3 million this year and $40 million in 2008.

Evergrid, a data center software developer, received $10 million in new third-round venture funding, which it will use to bring its first product to market. The latest investors including first-time backer Menlo Ventures and return investor Acartha Group.
What is Kirk Kerkorian up to now?

Agile Software had already seen two of its largest rivals snatched up before Oracle acquired it for $495 million. The Agile deal brings Oracle head-to-head with SAP in the manufacturing-related ERP software arena, The 451 Group wrote in a report. Back in August, when Agile's stock was in the low $5 range, The 451 Group said that it expected the company to be acquired. Earlier this month, Oracle agreed to pay $8.10 a share for Agile.

Residential Capital, a real estate finance company that is part of GMAC, filed with regulators on Tuesday to periodically sell up to $12.5 billion in senior debt securities and subordinated debt securities. In November, a group of investors led by Cerberus Capital Management acquired a majority stake in GMAC from General Motors for $14 billion.

Kenneth Griffin's $13.5 billion hedge fund, the Citadel Investment Group, said Monday that Karl Robijns, the company's head of European energy trading, had resigned. "He's no longer with the firm," Bryan Locke, a spokesman for Citadel, told The Chicago Tribune. Mr. Robijns joined Citadel in 2005 to begin the company's European energy trading, according to SparkSpread, an energy and commodities news service.

Two senior executives have quit the proxy advisory firm Glass Lewis & Company amid questions over whether its China-based parent, Xinhua Finance Media, withheld unfavorable information about its former chief financial officer. Barron's reported on Sunday that the prospectus of Xinhua Finance Media, controlled by Xinhua Finance, based in Tokyo, withheld details about business dealings of the finance chief, Shelly Singhal.

Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal "squawk boxes." Four current and former executives at the day trading firm A.B. Watley Group will also be retried on charges that they had a role in the scheme, the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn said Monday.

The House of Representatives has cut funding for the Army's venture capital affiliate from the 2008 defense appropriations bill amid questions about fees and return on investment, The Red Herring reported. Specifically, a $10 million allocation to OnPoint Technologies from the Army was removed from the bill after Tennessee Representative Jim Cooper raised objections over management fees.

Lots of interesting and thoughtful comments below from readers about health care. A few took a swipe at Leana Wen, the winner of my win-a-trip contest. I had used Leana as an example in my column of someone without health coverage. She posted her comments as No. 133. Here are excerpts:
A musical of "The Addams Family" is in the works, with a planned premiere on Broadway in the 2009-10 season.

The Chinese government's $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group appears to be a move to pounce on a strategy many foreign banks have adopted in China: buy into a company just before it begins its initial public offering. That strategy has given many banks, like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, significant initial gains, at least on paper, on their early investments, The New York Times writes.
Kenneth Lonergan’s “The Starry Messenger” will be part of the Manhattan Theater Club’s 2007-8 season at City Center.

With its deal to buy a 20 percent stake in the New York hedge fund GSO Capital Partners, Merrill Lynch appears to be buying a piece of the "nascent competition," The Financial Times' Alphaville blog concluded Monday.

Two senior partners of J.W. Childs Associates are leaving the Boston private equity shop to start their own firm, according to The Deal.com. Dana Schmaltz and Ted Yun each joined J.W. Childs shortly after its founding by John W. Childs in 1995. Mr. Schmaltz, who now serves as president, joined in 1997, while Mr. Yun, a partner and chairman of the investment committee, came on board in 1999. Their departure is expected at the beginning of June, sources told The Deal.

An Iranian friend sent along this photo. It was taken in Hafteh Tir square when a mother and a daughter were beaten for taking pictures of the vice police treating women badly. Some 2000 people gathered in protest.
Images from a world even stranger than the one Beebe described seven decades ago after the first look into the abyss.
Alcan said the offer did not reflect the full value of the company and advised shareholders not to tender their shares to the bid.
Medtronic reported on Tuesday that its fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose to $812 million, or 70 cents a share.

Alexander Onischuk knocked off Hikaru Nakamura today to join Alexander Shabalov in the lead of the Frank Berry U.S. Championship while Sergey Kudrin beat Ildar Ibragimov to get to 5 points, only a half point back. Another seven grandmasters were at 4.5, so with two rounds to play, the championship has become wide open with many players still with a chance to win. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.
Web sites like whosarat.com expose the identities of witnesses cooperating with the government and provide their names and mug shots.
A frenzied scene of horror unfolded in Iraq after a bomb exploded amid a unit of U.S. soldiers searching for their missing comrades.
An amendment rejecting a temporary-worker program was scrapped in what promise to be long deliberations.
A resolution criticizing Representative John Murtha over his treatment of a fellow congressman was tabled.
The move was a wrenching reversal for some Democrats, who saw their election triumph as a call to force an end to the war.
The number of eighth graders reading on grade level climbed impressively this year, tests indicate.
A gunfight broke out during a robbery in a Chicago bank this morning, leaving a security guard, a bank employee and a customer injured, officials said.
The plan aims to replace New York City’s entire yellow cab fleet with environmentally friendly hybrid vehicles.
Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16, then released on Monday without any charges against them.
Five were also injured in the fire, which  swept through a two-story rowhouse in the northeast section of Baltimore.
The Israeli Air Force mounted three more attacks on Gaza today, as an Israeli woman killed by rocket fire from Gaza on Monday was buried in Sderot, Israel.
Today’s attacks, a car bomb and mortar shells in Sunni neighborhoods in Baghdad, also wounded 85 people.
The Lebanese Army continued battling militants holed up in a refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli.
Britain will seek the extradition of Andrei Lugovoi, a businessman, to face trial for the murder of  a former K.G.B. agent.

A map on Friday of the site of two freeway collapses in Oakland, Calif., incorrectly located the site of the 1989 collapse of Interstate 880. The highway was about 3,500 feet east of Maritime Street, not at its present location, about 2,000 feet east of Maritime.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.).
LeBron James drove and dished to Donyell Marshall who missed a wide-open a 3-pointer with 5.9 seconds left that allowed the Detroit Pistons to escape with a victory.
Starter Chien-Ming Wang held Boston in check for over six innings and Alex Rodriguez hit his major league-leading 18th home run to lead the Yankees to a victory Monday night.
A judge ruled earlier this month over 200 same-sex couples from New York who married in Massachusetts from 2004 to 2006 have legally recognized marriages.

A federal judge issued an order halting enforcement of a voter-endorsed ordinance preventing apartment rentals to most illegal immigrants in Farmers Branch, a Dallas suburb, opponents of the ban said. The ordinance was to have taken effect today, after voters approved the regulation two to one, according to unofficial results. Opponents filed three requests in federal court for an injunction to stop it.
Two executives quit Glass Lewis & Company amid questions over whether its China-based parent withheld unfavorable information.

A front-page article on Friday about the resignation of Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly to the pay package for the job. It was the previous World Bank president — not Mr. Wolfowitz — who was paid a salary of $302,470 and expenses of $141,290 in 2004. (Mr. Wolfowitz, who did not arrive at the bank until 2005, was paid an after-tax salary of $391,440 beginning July 1, 2005. ).

An obituary by The Associated Press on May 14 about Bernard Gordon, a blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter who eventually had some film credits restored, misstated the relationship of the stars of “Hellcats of the Navy,” a film for which he was later credited. Ronald Reagan had already married Nancy Davis when the film was made in 1957; she was not his “future wife.”.

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about a disclosure by The New York Post that its staff had accepted money from a restaurant in return for favorable coverage, included incorrect information in some copies about the amount of money and the recipients. The amount was $1,000 — not $3,000 — and it went to the editor of Page Six, Richard Johnson. No money was given to two other Page Six staff members, Jeanne MacIntosh and Sean Gannon, now the business editor. (The money was spent on an afternoon of drinking by the staff.).

The Cannes Journal article in The Arts yesterday, about new movies at the Cannes Film Festival, referred incorrectly to text at the start of “Terror’s Advocate,” a documentary about Jacques Vergès, a French lawyer. It says that the film’s view of the protagonist may not correspond with his own, not that it may correspond.

An article in some copies on May 13 about a request to dismiss a murder case stemming from the killing of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan in 1990 referred imprecisely to David Lemus, who was convicted in the case in 1992. That conviction was set aside in 2005 and Mr. Lemus is now awaiting a second trial on the same charges. He is not merely “accused” of the crime or otherwise being treated as only a suspect.

A map on Friday of the site of two freeway collapses in Oakland, Calif., incorrectly located the site of the 1989 collapse of Interstate 880. The highway was about 3,500 feet east of Maritime Street, not at its present location, about 2,000 feet east of Maritime.
A headline on Saturday with the obituary of the physicist Donald M. Ginsberg misidentified his area of expertise. It was superconductors, not semiconductors.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.).

A headline in Business Day on Friday with an article about the sale of 24/7 Real Media, the advertising network and technology company, to the WPP Group misstated the price of the deal. As the article noted, it was $649 million, not $64 million.

An obituary on Friday about Denis G. Kuhn, an architect and preservationist, gave an erroneous credit for the master plan for a proposed suburban community in Gaithersburg, Md. The project was overseen by Matthew J. Bell of Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects, not by Mr. Kuhn. The obituary also misstated the reopening date of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan, vacated in the 1970s, which Mr. Kuhn turned into the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian. The building reopened in 1987, when the Federal Bankruptcy Court moved into two floors — not in 1994, when the museum opened on three additional floors.

A front-page article on Friday about the resignation of Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly to the pay package for the job. It was the previous World Bank president — not Mr. Wolfowitz — who was paid a salary of $302,470 and expenses of $141,290 in 2004. (Mr. Wolfowitz, who did not arrive at the bank until 2005, was paid an after-tax salary of $391,440 beginning July 1, 2005. ).

An article on May 13 about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word “revolution” from its name omitted the party’s new name, and a correction in this space on May 15 incorrectly rendered the English version of the new name. It is the Supreme Islamic Iraqi Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.
One snowstorm and 45 days later, the Cleveland Indians and Seattle Mariners finally played nine innings.

Tourists who stayed in Praia da Luz, in Portugal, where a 4-year-old British girl, Madeleine McCann, disappeared from a vacation apartment, were urged to hand over any photographs that might contain clues to her kidnapper. British detectives would use advanced facial recognition software to scan the pictures and pass on any useful information to the Portuguese police. The British police said they wanted pictures from anyone who had been at the Ocean Club resort or the surrounding area in the two weeks before Madeleine’s disappearance on May 3. “Look at your prints and see if there are, for instance, people in the background of the picture that at first you may not have noticed,” said Jim Gamble, the chief of the Child Exploitation and Online Protection Center. “These are the pictures we want.” Photos should be uploaded to <a href=

More than 120 people were taken to the hospital with food poisoning after eating free sandwiches served to lure supporters to a political rally for Guatemala’s leading presidential candidate, Álvaro Colom. The hospital director in the town of Escuintla said the patients had eaten tainted ham sandwiches. It is common to give out food at political rallies.

Malaysia’s 1.2 million civil servants will get a salary increase of up to 35 percent, their first pay raise in 15 years, Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi announced. Their cost of living allowance will also increase, by 100 percent, in one of the most generous incentives in recent times. The announcement came amid speculation that Mr. Abdullah would call early elections, which are not due until 2009.

The lower house of Parliament suspended an outspoken member from Farah Province, Malalai Joya, over a recent interview she gave to a local television station in which she compared Parliament to a stable of animals. Ms. Joya, who has often branded many of her fellow legislators as warlords and war criminals, said that while a cow can give milk and a donkey can carry a load, the lawmakers do nothing.

The head of Shanghai’s new Formula One racing track lost his job as part of an investigation into corruption in the city government. Yu Zhifei, the official, was fired and expelled from the Communist Party, state news media said. He oversaw the introduction of the racing circuit in 2005. The track and related infrastructure cost the city more than $1 billion to develop.
Engineers working for New York City Transit say the new high-tech signal system designed to increase the capacity of the L Train will not be ready for several years.

Residents of Naples have begun burning heaps of garbage that have piled up for more than a week, adding potentially toxic smoke to the foul smell permeating the city, officials said. Mounds of trash have piled 10 feet in some places and blocked entire streets. Collectors stopped hauling it away because they had nowhere to take it. The slums of Naples have been plagued by similar garbage crises in recent years, including one in 2004 that led to weeks of protests. Dumps fill up, and local communities block efforts to build new ones.

A 9-year-old girl in Braunschweig was so upset about having to clean her room she urged passers-by to call the police. Pedestrians saw the girl holding a sign in the window saying “Help! Please call the police!” Officers who rushed to the scene told the girl “to tidy her room,” a spokesman said.

Twenty female farmers were killed when the three-wheeled vehicle they were riding overturned on a mountainous road in Liaoning Province. State news media said they were returning from a day of picking herbs and were crowded onto a trailer towed behind the vehicle. China’s roads are the most dangerous in the world, with 90,000 people losing their lives in accidents in the first quarter of 2007 alone, according to official estimates.
football.

Two wayward injured humpback whales were nearly halfway toward the Pacific Ocean after a detour that started on May 13 and took them 90 miles up the Sacramento River. Escorted by the Coast Guard and a 21-vessel flotilla, the whales traveled 30 miles in 20 hours since leaving the Port of Sacramento on Sunday, the authorities said. The two stopped again yesterday and circled a river channel near Rio Vista, apparently hesitant to swim under an open drawbridge, the authorities said. The whales, injured by a boat propeller, have passed the bridge several times, but always retreated upstream. Jim Milbury of the Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the whales faced threats like pylons, a series of delta islands and sloughs that could ground them.

The sole survivor of a mine explosion last year and relatives of four of the five miners killed sued the coal company, saying it had put production over safety. The suit cited safety violations against the company, Kentucky Darby; a supervisor, Ralph Napier; and Jericol Mining, which provided management, planning, engineering and safety training to the mine, Darby Mine No. 1. The plaintiffs also seek damages against the manufacturer of the emergency air packs that the victims used.

Lawmakers passed a bill last week protecting executioners’ anonymity and letting them sue anyone who discloses their names. The Missouri Press Association said the measure would violate the First Amendment. state’s corrections director, Larry Crawford, said the bill should make it easier to recruit doctors to assist in executions. For a year, Missouri has been unable to recruit a physician with expertise in anesthesia, as a federal judge ordered, and has not executed anyone. A spokeswoman for Gov. Matt Blunt, a Republican, would not say whether he would sign the bill.

The Mars rover, the Spirit, has uncovered the strongest evidence yet that ancient Mars was wetter than previously thought, scientists reported. The robot analyzed a patch of soil in the Gusev Crater and found it unusually rich in silica. Scientists said water was necessary to have produced such a large silica deposit. The Spirit had previously found clues of ancient water in the crater through the presence of sulfur-rich soil, water-altered minerals and explosive volcanism. The new finding raises a possibility that conditions may have been favorable for primitive life to emerge.
More poison-tainted toothpaste has turned up in Latin America, including some made for children.

The former president of a struggling museum was charged with mail fraud and tax evasion, accused of skimming more than $1.5 million for home improvements, artwork and other lavish trappings. The official, John S. Carter, 57, of Osterville, Mass., submitted false invoices to have the Independence Seaport Museum in Philadelphia pay for jewelry, electronic equipment, clothing and an $1,800 espresso machine, the United States attorney, Patrick L. Meehan, said.

The Smithsonian Institution toned down an exhibition on Arctic climate change, fearing that it would anger Congress and the Bush administration, a former museum administrator said. The official text of the exhibition was rewritten to minimize and add uncertainty about the relationship between global warming and people, said the former official, Robert Sullivan, who was associate director in charge of exhibitions at the National Museum of Natural History. Officials omitted scientists’ interpretations of some research and let visitors draw their own conclusions from the data, Mr. Sullivan said. In addition, graphs were altered “to show that global warming could go either way,” he said. Museum officials denied that political concerns had influenced the exhibition, saying the changes were made to increase objectivity.

A woman who rode in the cab of a truck during the nation’s deadliest human smuggling effort and testified against the driver was sentenced to the few days in jail that she had already served. The woman, Fatima Holloway of Cleveland, had pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy related to the smuggling in 2003 that resulted in the deaths of 19 illegal immigrants near Victoria. She spent three days in jail after her arrest, court records show. As part of a plea agreement, Ms. Holloway, 32, testified against the driver of the tractor-trailer, Tyrone M. Williams, who was sentenced to life in prison in January.
From the moment debate started, the crosscurrents buffeting an immigration bill were evident.
The latest S.E.C. filing by Kirk Kerkorian’s company has analysts wondering whether the billionaire plans to take MGM private.

Gen. Pervez Musharraf is being advised to seek conciliation with opponents or risk losing power.
An analysis of trials for Avandia concluded that the drug might significantly increase the risk of heart attacks.
Some question whether efforts to open China to U.S. goods will satisfy a Congress irate over a staggering trade deficit.

A college student from Little Neck was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation for his role in an attack on two Asian-American teenagers last year, prosecutors said. Paul A. Heavey, 21, pleaded guilty in March to third-degree assault as a hate crime, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Heavey admitted punching and kicking the two men — John Lu and Reynold Liang, both 19 at the time and both from Little Neck — during an August 2006 altercation in Douglaston, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Heavey’s co-defendant, Kevin M. Brown, 19, of Auburndale, was sentenced in March to three and a half years in prison after he admitted beating one of the men with a metal steering wheel lock, prosecutors said.

A man has been charged with animal cruelty for allegedly starving his cocker spaniel and then trying to pass off the dog as a stray at an animal shelter, the police said. William Winters, 31, was arraigned yesterday on charges of aggravated cruelty to animals in First District Court in Central Islip. The Suffolk County police said that when Mr. Winters took the 3-year-old dog, Bailey, to the Brookhaven Animal Shelter in March, the animal was so weak from malnutrition that he could not lift his head. Under questioning, Mr. Winters later admitted that Bailey was his, the police said. The dog has since recovered and will be available for adoption, shelter officials said.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday appointed Susan Bass Levin, left, to the post of deputy director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Ms. Levin, 54, has served as the state’s commissioner of community affairs since 2002 under three Democratic governors, except for a brief period in late 2005, when she worked for Mr. Corzine’s campaign for governor. She succeeds James P. Fox, a former chief of staff to Gov. James E. McGreevey. Mr. Fox is forming a transportation and economic development consulting firm with George D. Warrington, the former head of New Jersey Transit, and Eric Shuffler, a former top aide to Mr. McGreevey.

A Florida doctor was convicted yesterday of conspiracy to provide material support to terrorists by agreeing to treat injured Qaeda fighters so that they could return to Iraq to battle Americans. Dr. Rafiq Abdus Sabir, 52, of Boca Raton, was convicted in Federal District Court after a three-week trial that featured testimony by an F.B.I. agent who posed as a Qaeda recruiter. Dr. Sabir, who faces up to 30 years in prison, was charged after an F.B.I. sting operation in 2005 that led to four arrests. Three other defendants have pleaded guilty.

Searchers responding to a distress call from the scallop boat Mary James found a body in the ocean along with an empty life raft and a life ring from the vessel, the Coast Guard said yesterday. The Coast Guard said that it received the Mayday call about 11:15 p.m. on Sunday, and that the empty life raft was spotted at 2:30 a.m. yesterday about 22 miles southeast of Manasquan. The search continued for the other person believed to have been aboard the 40-foot boat.

A Jamaica man was convicted of murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for fatally stabbing a man during a fistfight two years ago behind a public school in Briarwood, prosecutors said. Dwayne Morrison, 26, stabbed Miguel Restituyo, 23, on July 30, 2005, after Mr. Restituyo began to get the upper hand in the fight, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that after someone in the crowd tossed Mr. Morrison a knife, Mr. Restituyo raised his hands in a gesture of surrender, and Mr. Morrison stabbed him.

A driver was killed when his charter bus, which was carrying no passengers, overturned on a Long Island highway that is closed to buses, the state police said yesterday. The driver, Scott Forster, 49, of Staten Island, was thrown clear of the bus and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The crash, which occurred about 11:20 p.m. on Sunday, closed sections of the Northern State Parkway for several hours and led to traffic delays during the morning rush yesterday. The police said the bus flipped after it veered onto the shoulder near the Willis Avenue exit, hit a sign, re-entered the roadway and struck a concrete median.

A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee yesterday approved a $91 million plan to build a Metro-North Railroad station that would serve the new Yankee Stadium, which is under construction in the Bronx. The station is expected to open in June 2009, about two months after the Yankees are scheduled to begin playing in their new home. The station will operate as a regular stop on Metro-North’s Hudson line and will have added service for baseball games, M.T.A. officials said. The transportation authority and the city are to share the cost of building the station, which is meant to handle up to 12,000 passengers after a game. The full board of the M.T.A. is expected to approve the plan tomorrow.
The results exceeded Wall Street forecasts and the company raised its outlook for the rest of the year.

Firefighters said yesterday that they had contained 90 percent of the forest fire that charred more than 17,000 acres of Pinelands last week. Steve Maurer, an assistant fire warden with the New Jersey Forest Fire Service, said that rain on Sunday night helped douse the fire.

A man was indicted yesterday on murder charges in the shooting death of a police detective on Aug. 7, prosecutors said. The man, Raynard Brown, 19, is accused of killing Detective Kieran T. Shields, 32, of the Orange police, who was shot while responding to a report of gunshots.

MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International North America. “Anyone traveling by air today knows that aviation is already stretched to the breaking point,” said Greg Principato, president of the council. In a statement, the group said that “2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays.” Most airport improvement projects — for runways, terminals, gates and the like — are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.

Where is Gary Sheffield when the Yankees need him? He plays for the Detroit Tigers these days, courtesy of the Yankees. General Manager Brian Cashman traded Sheffield to the Tigers last November rather than give him a contract extension and trade another high-priced right fielder instead. By defeating the Red Sox, 6-2, at Yankee Stadium last night, the Yankees trimmed Boston's lead over them to a still formidable nine and a half games. It was but a slight sign of life in what has been a moribund season for the Yankees.

DIABETES DRUG IS QUESTIONED -- An article in The New England Journal of Medicine raises safety questions about the GlaxoSmithKline diabetes pill Avandia while also restarting debate over the quality of work by federal drug regulators. ''They're younger, they're more quickly engaged and more quickly dismissive if they're not engaged,'' said Judy McGrath, above, chairman and chief executive of MTV Networks. [C6.] BIG-BOY LETTERS ARE CHALLENGED -- Correspondence among investors known as big-boy letters are widely used and represent a private contract among presumably sophisticated investors. Now they face a legal challenge. [C1.] TRADE ISSUES WITH CHINA -- As the senior trade officials for United States and China begin talks, some question whether the Bush administration's efforts to open China to American goods can satisfy a Congress irate over a trade deficit with China that rose to $232 billion last year. [C1.] IDEA FROM GOOGLE: AN AUCTION -- Google has proposed that the Federal Communications Commission allocate radio spectrum employing the same kind of auction that the search engine company now uses in selling advertisements to create more competition among cable companies and Internet service providers. [C10.] MYSPACE EXPOSES SEX OFFENDERS -- MySpace, the popular social networking site, has agreed to provide authorities in all 50 states with the names, addresses and online profiles of thousands of known convicted sexual offenders who have opened up accounts on its service. [C8.] LOWE'S PROFIT MISSES MARK -- The Lowe's Company, the No. 2 home improvement chain behind Home Depot, reported a lower-than-expected first-quarter profit and has cut its full-year earnings outlook. [C7.] COURT TO HEAR BOND CASE -- The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on important tax issues involving interest and taxes on municipal bonds in a case with the potential to change the market for such bonds. [C3.] MOVIE MAY ENLIVEN DEBATE -- Insurance industry officials and health policy experts suggest that Michael Moore's movie on the American health care system is likely to provoke debate, not radical change. [C3.] EMI GROUP SALE WINS SUPPORT -- The board at the music giant EMI Group has decided to support a new $4.7 billion offer from a private British investor, Terra Firma Capital Partners. [C3.] JUST LOOKING FOR A RETURN -- The Chinese government's $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group was simply a way to raise returns on overseas investments, a Chinese official says. PLASTICS UNIT -- General Electric agreed yesterday to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation known as Sabic. Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of G.E., said the deal would transform the industry by combining Sabic's low-cost materials and global reach with G.E.'s strong marketing and technology. From the outside, the Chinese government's $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group might look like a prelude to a broader campaign for control of foreign companies. But a Chinese official ruled that out in an interview Monday, saying the purchase was simply a way to raise returns on overseas investments and did not signal any plan to take control of foreign companies.

A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the dismissal of a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misidentified the suit in question. It accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of condemning two apartment buildings on the project site without permission from state housing officials to cancel the tenants' rent-stabilized leases. A separate lawsuit accusing the agency of offering an unfair relocation plan to those tenants is still pending.

To the Editor: Bob Herbert documents the human tragedies and absurd eventual financial costs that result from our fragmented public insurance system (''Young, Ill and Uninsured,'' column, May 19). The trouble is that all of the contemplated expansions of coverage for children have an inherent flaw: they are based on the same month-to-month, prove-you're-eligible, fall-through-the-cracks insurance model that killed Devante Johnson. The difference between universal coverage and universal health care is not semantic; it is real and fundamental. If we truly want all children to get the health care they need, then we must simply give all children the health care they need, not require parents to repeatedly prove that their children are worthy of publicly financed services.

FLOOD--Richard Peter, on May 16, 2007. Loving husband of Katherine D. Flood, deceased. Retired Social Work 26 years, NYC Human Resources Administration. Fordham University 1956; Fordham Preparatory School 1952. Funeral Mass Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th St., NYC.

SELONICK--James B., 81, died peacefully at his Cincinnati home, May 18, 2007. Beloved husband of Peggy Frieder Selonick, father of Ellen, James and William; grandfather of seven treasured grandchildren. Born in New York, graduate of Townsend Harris High School; Ensign in the US Navy during WWII. Received a law degree from the University of Cincinnati and pursued a distinguished career in real estate ending as Senior Vice President for Federated Department Stores. Active in civic affairs throughout his life and a vocal participant in local development issues. Memorial contributions should be made to Congregation Beth Adam or Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.

Ms. Joya, who has often branded many of her fellow legislators as warlords and war criminals, said that while a cow can give milk and a donkey can carry a load, the lawmakers do nothing.
