Rapp or Wadham College Fund, Oxford University.

HILLEL--Meyer, 100 years young, peacefully passed away on Sunday, May 20, 2007. A longtime resident of Teaneck and Fort Lee, NJ, he was the devoted husband of the late Ethel Hillel, loving father of Roberta Epstein Getzoff (Roger), admired grandfather of David (Beth), Lauren (Marc) and Jill (Jonathan), and adored greatgrandfather of Joshua, Matthew, Sara, Emily, Elizabeth, Rebecca and Dena. A former attorney and owner of Lake Mohegan Woodlands Bungalow Colony, he was loved and respected by all, and will be greatly missed.

STEVENS--John, 92, of North Branford and Madison, CT died peacefully May 15th after several months of declining health. A recipient of the Yale Medal in 2003, he was also Trustee Emeritus of Quinnipiac University, Past President of the UConn Foundation and a former Trustee of Kent School and The Foote School. He was Past President of Gaylord Hospital and Chairman of the Connecticut State Commission on Human Services (1986-1988). Born June 12, 1914, in Wallingford, CT, John was a graduate of Kent School and Yale College, Class of 1937. After starting out at J. Walter Thompson, he joined the International Silver Company in 1938 where, after wartime service in the Atlantic and Pacific as Lt. Commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve, he became President, then Chairman, and then Executive Vice President and a director of Insilco Corporation. John was co-founder and first President of The Farms Country Club, Wallingford, Conn. and a Past President of The Madison Beach Club and The 24Karat Club of New York City. Having survived Marcia, his wife of 63 years who died in January, he is survived by his four children, Jay Stevens of New Haven, CT, Mary Stevens of Seattle, WA, Philip Stevens of Guilford, Conn. and Catherine Wilson of Seattle, WA, nine grandchildren and a great-grandchild. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 25 at 11am at First Congregational Church of Guilford, CT Donations (payable to Yale University) may be made to the John B. Stevens Scholarship Fund, c/ o Yale Alumni Office, PO Box 1890, New Haven, CT 06508. Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St, Guilford, CT in charge of funeral services.

VEGA--Lorenzo, of Manhattan, died Friday May 18th at age 43. Memorial service on Friday May 25, 11am at Our Lady of Pompei Church, 25 Carmine St., NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 6th Ave, NY 10013.

Traffic was halted on the Brooklyn Bridge for more than an hour last night as police negotiators stopped a man from jumping. The man, whose name was not released, was described by the police as an emotionally disturbed teenager. The police said he was sitting, with one leg dangling over the side of the bridge, near the Manhattan tower and spoke to police negotiators for nearly an hour before they hauled him to safety. ALAN FEUER

OSTRAU--Eleanor Tananbaum died peacefully at home in Mamaroneck, NY, on May 20th, 2007. Born August 20th, 1926, in the Bronx to Abraham Tananbaum and Feida Levin Tananbaum. She is survived by her husband, Hon. Stanley S. Ostrau; daughters Amy Ostrau and Gail Ostrau Young; granddaughter Saria I. J. Young; siblings Betty Kelman, Elliot Tananbaum and Jeanne Szalay. She received degrees from Cornell University, B.A. 1947 Phi Beta Kappa; MA 1948 Ph.D., 1951 in Government and Political Theory with doctoral research performed in Rome, Italy. She was an Intelligence Analyst at the Department of State from 1952 to 1953. She taught Government and Political Science at Hunter College 1954 to 1956, and later, became Associate Professor at Stern College of Yeshiva University 1962 to 1968. In 1971 she joined the faculty of Manhattan College in the Government and Politics Department and became department chair in 1978. She held the position until her retirement in 1991. She remained active at the college after her retirement. She was an avid and well-rounded reader, prolific in the arts of knitting and needlework, and an enthusiastic gardener. Funeral to be private. A public memorial service will be held in a few months, date and place to be announced. Inquiries and letters of condolence can be sent to Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024.

Scientists have discovered yet another reason that alcohol might be good for you. Using pooled data from 12 studies and more than 750,000 subjects, researchers found that moderate alcohol consumption -- about a drink a day -- is associated with a decreased risk of renal cell carcinoma, one type of kidney cancer. The paper, which will appear in the June 16 issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, covered only prospective studies that involved at least 25 cases of renal cell cancer, that assessed long-term intake of a variety of foods and beverages, and that included information on nondietary factors. During the 7- to 20-year follow-up, researchers found 1,430 cases of renal cell cancer.

Nothing rattles Washington quite like a good violation of unwritten rules, especially when the violator and the violated are both presidents (past and present, respectively). Former President Jimmy Carter was cited for a doozy over the weekend when he called the Bush administration ''the worst in history'' for its impact around the world. Though Mr. Carter tried to take it back on Monday, saying on the ''Today'' show that his remarks were ''careless or misinterpreted'' and that he was ''not talking personally about any president,'' he has still incited a tsk-tsking tsunami in the capital.

To the Editor: Re ''The Immigration Deal'' (editorial, May 20): Your arguments are sound and clear. The progressive bloc has yielded entirely too much to the anti-immigrant and produced an accord that is unjust and unworkable. I would add here, also, that comprehensive immigration reform must include discussion on issues of trade and serious economic assistance to poorer countries that will genuinely help them develop viable economies and other social structures.

An obituary on Friday about Denis G. Kuhn, an architect and preservationist, gave an erroneous credit for the master plan for a proposed suburban community in Gaithersburg, Md. The project was overseen by Matthew J. Bell of Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects, not by Mr. Kuhn. The obituary also misstated the reopening date of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan, vacated in the 1970s, which Mr. Kuhn turned into the Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian. The building reopened in 1987, when the Federal Bankruptcy Court moved into two floors -- not in 1994, when the museum opened on three additional floors.

The trial of Anthony Pellicano, the jailed Hollywood private eye, on federal wiretapping and racketeering charges was pushed back to Feb. 26, allowing defense lawyers more time to plow through the government's evidence, including 150,000 pages and hundreds of telephone recordings, and to file pre-trial motions. The lead prosecutor, Assistant United States Attorney Daniel A. Saunders, said at a hearing yesterday that it would take the government seven to eight weeks to present its case. Judge Dale S. Fischer urged Mr. Saunders to adjust that estimate downward and said the new trial date was a firm one. Mr. Pellicano, who has been held without bail since February 2006, did not object to the postponement. DAVID M. HALBFINGER and ALLISON HOPE WEINER
SCHWARZ--Jack. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

A college student from Little Neck was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation for his role in an attack on two Asian-American teenagers last year, prosecutors said. Paul A. Heavey, 21, pleaded guilty in March to third-degree assault as a hate crime, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Heavey admitted punching and kicking the two men -- John Lu and Reynold Liang, both 19 at the time and both from Little Neck -- during an August 2006 altercation in Douglaston, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Heavey's co-defendant, Kevin M. Brown, 19, of Auburndale, was sentenced in March to three and a half years in prison after he admitted beating one of the men with a metal steering wheel lock, prosecutors said.

MAILMAN--Virginia Shevlin, on May 19, 2007 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness, also of Glen Cove, NY. Widow of the late Norton W. Mailman; beloved mother of Bruce W. Addison and Christopher B. Mailman of New York and Matthew D. Addison of Los Angeles, CA; grandmother of five. Funeral services to be announced, interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Pen American Center, 588 Broadway, Suite 303, New York, NY 10012 or The North Shore Alliance, 151 Post Road, Old Westbury, NY 11568 would be appreciated.

Stallone Fined for Hormone Imports Sylvester Stallone, right, officially became a convict in Australia yesterday. Having already pleaded guilty to charges of importing restricted muscle-building hormones, he was ordered to pay $10,651 in fines and court costs in Sydney. He was not present in court. Paul Cloran, the New South Wales state deputy chief magistrate, said Mr. Stallone, star of the ''Rocky'' and ''Rambo'' films, had failed to establish that he had a valid prescription for dozens of vials of human growth hormone in his luggage when he arrived in Sydney in February for a promotional tour. Although prosecutors said he had legitimate medical reasons for carrying the drug, he also failed to declare the male hormone testosterone on a customs entry form. In an interview with customs officials Mr. Stallone, 60, said he was carrying large amounts of the growth hormone because he was about to spend three months in Thailand and Myanmar, formerly Burma, filming a new ''Rambo'' adventure. ''As you get older, the pituitary gland slows, and you feel older, your bones narrow,'' he said, according to court documents. ''This stuff gives your body a boost, and you feel and look good. Doing 'Rambo' is hard work. Where do you think I am going to get this stuff in Burma?'' Harry Potter: Signed, Sealed, Delivered Images from the covers of all seven Harry Potter adventures will appear on a set of postage stamps to be issued by the Royal Mail in Britain on July 17, commemorating the July 21 publication of the final volume of the J. K. Rowling stories about the boy wizard. The crests of the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry and its four houses will appear on some of the stamps, Agence France-Presse reported. First-class stamps, they will each be priced at 34 pence, or 67 cents. The Royal Mail said it was ''proud to commemorate and celebrate an illustrious British author and a true global publishing phenomenon.'' Among authors previously celebrated by the Royal Mail are Lewis Carroll, Roald Dahl, T. S. Eliot, C. S. Lewis, Beatrix Potter and J. R. R. Tolkien. Julia Roberts's New Project Julia Roberts, below, will collaborate once more with Working Title, the company that made ''Notting Hill,'' when she stars in a film about Joan Root, the renowned British conservationist who was shot to death at 69 in her bedroom in Kenya, in January 2006, Variety.com reported. The untitled project, inspired by the Vanity Fair article ''A Flowering Evil,'' will deal with Ms. Root's earlier life, including the making of nature films with her husband, Alan. After they were divorced in 1981, she turned her 88-acre property in Naivasha, Kenya, into a wildlife refuge and devoted herself into saving Lake Naivasha from ecological damage. Vexation From Cannes Africa and Iran expressed displeasure with the Cannes Film Festival yesterday. The African Filmmakers Producers Guild wondered in a statement if the festival was discriminating against movies from that continent, Agence France-Presse reported. No African film in a decade has been chosen to compete for the top prizes. ''Is this pure chance or linked to color discrimination against our images?'' the guild asked in a statement. No immediate comment was available from the festival organizers. Iran issued a protest to France over the screening of ''Persepolis,'' an animated film about a woman growing up in revolutionary Iran, Agence France-Presse reported. The government-run Farabi Cinema Foundation asked if the selection of ''Persepolis'' was ''a political or even anti-cultural act'' on the part of the festival. The film was adapted from a best-selling series of graphic books by the Iranian émigré Marjane Satrapi.

MURRAY--Joseph A., Sr., 75, on May 19, 2007. Devoted husband of the late Margaret (Peggy) Murray (nee Smith). Loving Father of Linda McDowell and Joseph Murray, Jr. Beloved grandfather of Laura Pullar, Kimberly Gargan, Christopher McDowell, Katie McDowell, and Greatgrandfather of Logan Ainsley Pullar and Margaret Lynn Pullar. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Lung Association or to the Peggy and Joe Murray Memorial Fund for Scholarship in the Addictions. Visitation Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:15am, St. Michael's Church.

The bone loss caused by gum disease is associated with an increased risk for tongue cancer, and the more the bone loss, the greater the risk, researchers report. Scientists evaluated bone loss around the teeth in 51 men with newly diagnosed tongue cancer and in 54 men without the diagnosis. X-rays were taken of the men's jaws, and a radiologist who did not know the cancer status of the men measured the amount of bone loss. The study took place from 1999 to 2005.

A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee yesterday approved a $91 million plan to build a Metro-North Railroad station that would serve the new Yankee Stadium, which is under construction in the Bronx. The station is expected to open in June 2009, about two months after the Yankees are scheduled to begin playing in their new home. The station will operate as a regular stop on Metro-North's Hudson line and will have added service for baseball games, M.T.A. officials said. The transportation authority and the city are to share the cost of building the station, which is meant to handle up to 12,000 passengers after a game. The full board of the M.T.A. is expected to approve the plan tomorrow. WILLIAM NEUMAN

An article on May 13 about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word ''revolution'' from its name omitted the party's new name, and a correction in this space on May 15 incorrectly rendered the English version of the new name. It is the Supreme Islamic Iraqi Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish, poultry and whole grain foods may offer protection against chronic lung disease, a new study suggests, in addition to the other benefits of such a regimen. Researchers studied more than 42,000 male health professionals enrolled in a long-term study that began in 1986. All filled out food frequency questionnaires, and the scientists ranked them by how closely they followed what the authors call the ''prudent'' diet, or how much they stuck to a ''Western'' diet dominated by refined grains, cured and red meats, sweets and French fries. The study appeared online May 15 in Thorax.

To the Editor: David Brooks (''The Insurgent Advantage,'' column, May 18) points out how small bands of insurgents working together can be so successful in combating even the most well-equipped and strongest army in the world, the United States armed forces. They are a swarm of quick-moving and plotting groups who win by disruption.

To the Editor: Re ''Students Gain Only Marginally on Test of U.S. History'' (news article, May 17): The idea of a ''test'' has again hijacked the public debate on education. Because of No Child Left Behind and overzealous states and cities, curriculum and teaching in English and math classrooms have been reduced to test prep, tests, test scoring and test review. Are multiple-choice tests what we want for the teaching of history? Shouldn't we clamor instead for policies that support in-depth inquiry, use of multiple sources and rigorous analysis of historical evidence?

To the Editor: ''Doctors Who Wield the Pen to Heal the Profession'' (Books, May 15): In Abigail Zuger's article, the physician-authors Jerome Groopman and Atul Gawande emphasize the central role of narrative in medical encounters. Unfortunately, the medical narrative is under threat now by the electronic medical record.

BORISOFF--Ida. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on May 19 of Ida Borisoff, beloved mother of our friend and partner, Richard S. Borisoff. We express our deepest sympathies to Richard and to all other members of the family.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday appointed Susan Bass Levin, left, to the post of deputy director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Ms. Levin, 54, has served as the state's commissioner of community affairs since 2002 under three Democratic governors, except for a brief period in late 2005, when she worked for Mr. Corzine's campaign for governor. She succeeds James P. Fox, a former chief of staff to Gov. James E. McGreevey. Mr. Fox is forming a transportation and economic development consulting firm with George D. Warrington, the former head of New Jersey Transit, and Eric Shuffler, a former top aide to Mr. McGreevey. DAVID W. CHEN

A headline in Business Day on Friday with an article about the sale of 24/7 Real Media, the advertising network and technology company, to the WPP Group misstated the price of the deal. As the article noted, it was $649 million, not $64 million.

A map on Friday of the site of two freeway collapses in Oakland, Calif., incorrectly located the site of the 1989 collapse of Interstate 880. The highway was about 3,500 feet east of Maritime Street, not at its present location, about 2,000 feet east of Maritime.

The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about a disclosure by The New York Post that its staff had accepted money from a restaurant in return for favorable coverage, included incorrect information in some copies about the amount of money and the recipients. The amount was $1,000 -- not $3,000 -- and it went to the editor of Page Six, Richard Johnson. No money was given to two other Page Six staff members, Jeanne MacIntosh and Sean Gannon, now the business editor. (The money was spent on an afternoon of drinking by the staff.)

Treating depression in older adults may be a life-saving intervention, a new study suggests. It has been known for some time that depressed people are more likely to die, but it has never been clear that treating their depression would help extend their lives.

An obituary by The Associated Press on May 14 about Bernard Gordon, a blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter who eventually had some film credits restored, misstated the relationship of the stars of ''Hellcats of the Navy,'' a film for which he was later credited. Ronald Reagan had already married Nancy Davis when the film was made in 1957; she was not his ''future wife.''

PAKULA--Judith, on May 19th, 2007. Daughter of the late Ruth and Leonard, sister of the late Peter. Cousin of Cynthia, Michael, Rebecca, Joshua, Lawrence, Steven Krauss and many others. Donations can be made to Mt. Sinai Hospital. $(6$)PAKULA--Judith. My cherished friend. You will be sorely missed. Rest in peace. Rita

To the Editor: ''As Demand for Donor Eggs Soars, High Prices Stir Ethical Concerns'' (The Consumer, May 15): Your piece hits the mark in discussing the risks of egg donation and the temptations of remuneration. The article falls short in implying that these are unusual or apply only to medicine.

Senate Democrats have raised twice as much money this year as have their Republican counterparts, adding more difficulty to the electoral equation for Republicans next year. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee reported raising $4.6 million in April, bringing its total for the year to $18.3 million, compared with the Republican totals of $2.1 million for the same month and $9.1 million for the year. Democrats also have more cash in the bank.

Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, mentioned the possibility of running on an independent presidential ticket with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York last week. Although independent candidates did not win a presidency in the last century, they have changed the dynamic of many races. Party control changed in many elections when there was support for third-party candidates.

One of the most fertile subjects of contemporary European cinema is the desolation of contemporary European life. The extravagance and high spirits outside the Cannes screening rooms thus frequently stand in jarring contrast to the misery displayed within them, where stories of privation, disconnection and violence hold up a corrective mirror to a continent that likes to present itself to the rest of the world as prosperous, unified and at peace. A particular theme within some of these stories is the harshness of existence in Europe's formerly Communist nations. ''Import/Export,'' a disturbing and sometimes brilliant new film by the Austrian director Ulrich Seidl, is set partly in Ukraine, depicted as a place where dirty snow swirls around crumbling Soviet-era housing projects. Not that Vienna, the movie's other main locale, looks much better. In its own way, this Western capital seems like an equally cold and brutal environment.

Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico formally kicked off his bid for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination yesterday, highlighting his Hispanic roots and wealth of experience and issuing a forceful call to end American involvement in Iraq. Breaking with some of his fellow candidates, including Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, on the war, Mr. Richardson pledged to ''leave no troop behind in Iraq.''

Twenty female farmers were killed when the three-wheeled vehicle they were riding overturned on a mountainous road in Liaoning Province. State news media said they were returning from a day of picking herbs and were crowded onto a trailer towed behind the vehicle. China's roads are the most dangerous in the world, with 90,000 people losing their lives in accidents in the first quarter of 2007 alone, according to official estimates. JOSEPH KAHN

Representative Ron Paul, the Texas Republican who is running for president, may be barely registering in public opinion polls, but his supporters are making their presence known on the Internet. They were particularly energized after the second Republican debate, held last week in South Carolina. There, Mr. Paul asserted that American foreign policy might have helped incite the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, swiftly rebuked him as holding a fringe view.

The Cannes Journal article in The Arts yesterday, about new movies at the Cannes Film Festival, referred incorrectly to text at the start of ''Terror's Advocate,'' a documentary about Jacques Vergès, a French lawyer. It says that the film's view of the protagonist may not correspond with his own, not that it may correspond.

NEWMAN--David. Our dear friend. Our loss is painful but our memories are sweet. You were a wonderful friend and we greatly enjoyed being with you and Dorothy. Our condolences to his wonderful family. We will miss you very much. Dee and Arthur Spatt

Beginning in September voters who cannot get enough presidential race news from newspapers, television and the blogosphere will be able to tune into a 24-hour radio channel devoted exclusively to the 2008 campaign, as long as they have access to XM satellite radio. XM said yesterday that it had joined with C-Span to offer a channel called Potus '08 -- derived from a Secret Service code name for the president -- that will be free to anyone with an XM receiver. (Listeners will not have to subscribe to the XM service, which typically costs about $12.95 a month, to hear the channel.) Asked if XM feared being able to fill all that radio time -- more than 10,000 hours' worth -- with presidential campaign news, Nathaniel Brown, an XM spokesman, said, ''We're not concerned.'' In addition to offering polling results, postdebate coverage and fund-raising updates, the channel also expects to provide air time to the candidates and to some bloggers, and to broadcast archival audio (courtesy of C-Span) from prior campaigns. JACQUES STEINBERG
HIRSCHHORN--Herbert H. Remembered and missed beyond measure. Your Family

To the Editor: Re ''Fixing the Student Loan Mess'' (editorial, May 17): The Career College Association takes great exception to the comment that for-profit colleges and technical schools are ''admitting students who don't have a prayer of graduating.''

A Jamaica man was convicted of murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for fatally stabbing a man during a fistfight two years ago behind a public school in Briarwood, prosecutors said. Dwayne Morrison, 26, stabbed Miguel Restituyo, 23, on July 30, 2005, after Mr. Restituyo began to get the upper hand in the fight, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that after someone in the crowd tossed Mr. Morrison a knife, Mr. Restituyo raised his hands in a gesture of surrender, and Mr. Morrison stabbed him.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.)

Al Gore, who recently described himself as an ''unlikely, but not impossible'' candidate for president in 2008, is starting a publicity tour this week for his new book, exposing himself to the intensifying questions about his political plans. The book, ''The Assault on Reason'' (The Penguin Press), includes a critique of the nation's political discourse and the mass media, particularly television, that shape it. So Mr. Gore was probably not surprised yesterday when he went on ABC's ''Good Morning America'' program to promote the book and found himself asked repeatedly if he was running for president and, at one point, whether he had lost weight.

Q. Does wearing someone else's prescription glasses for a short time do any damage to a child's eyes? A. The short answer is no, said Dr. Pamela F. Gallin, director of pediatric ophthalmology at the Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of New York-Presbyterian. It would be uncomfortable but not harmful to wear the wrong prescription for, say, five minutes, she said.

Signing into law a contentious plan to move up his state's presidential primary, Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said yesterday that he might lobby the national Republican and Democratic Parties to bend their ''byzantine'' rules so the state will not be penalized. The new primary date, Jan. 29, puts Florida's election ahead of contests in all but four states. But it also violates the national parties' rules, which bar all but a few states from holding primaries before Feb. 5. Both parties said they would strip Florida of half its delegates to their nominating conventions; the Democrats would also withhold Florida delegates from any candidate who campaigns in the state.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 In Baghdad, Shiite Enclave Points to Fractured Future In the Baghdad district of Kadhimiya, religious Shiite leaders and their militias have consolidated control, transforming the neighborhood into what could be a model for much of Iraq if the Shiites have their way -- a model that may not be democratic, inclusive or just, according to observers. A1 Pressure Builds on Musharraf Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is being advised by his political supporters to make a dramatic change of course or risk losing power after a series of political blunders in the last two months. A1 China Unrest Over Birth Control Acampaign to enforce strict population-control measures, including forced abortions, set off clashes between the police and local residents in southwestern China, alarming officials in Beijing. A12 Lebanon Fighting Goes On Lebanese tanks and artillery pounded a Palestinian refugee camp in Tripoli for the second day, trying to trap members of the radical Islamist group Fatah al Islam. Government officials said at least 60 people had been killed. A13 NATIONAL A14-20 Critics in Senate Vow To Alter Immigration Bill Critics of a comprehensive immigration bill fought back in the Senate, with lawmakers from both parties seeking to alter the measure substantially and Senate leaders agreeing to extend debate beyond the Memorial Day recess. A1 Milestone in Abortion Ruling Last month's Supreme Court decision upholding the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act marked a milestone for a different argument advanced by anti-abortion leaders. They say that abortion, as a rule, is not in the best interest of the woman and that the interests of the pregnant woman and the fetus are, in fact, the same. A1 Birth Certificates for Stillborn During the last six years, 19 states have enacted laws allowing parents who have had stillbirths to receive a certificate of birth. A16 Victory for Families of Disabled A Supreme Court decision gave parents of children with disabilities the right to go to court without a lawyer to challenge their public school district's individualized plan for their child's education. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Long Island Police Jobs Considered Most Desirable More than 28,000 people have registered to take the Suffolk police exam on June 9, some from far-flung states and many from the New York Police Department, who say they are seeking the high pay and lower risk of working in law enforcement on Long Island. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Doubts on Diabetes Drug An article in The New England Journal of Medicine raised safety questions about the diabetes pill Avandia and renewed skepticism about the vigilance of federal drug regulators. It showed that the drug increased the risk of heart attacks. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Macho mistakes at Ground Zero; Iran's centrifuges; paying for college; wealth as a clue in running. Columns: David Brooks and Bob Herbert. Crossword E2 TV Listings E10 Weather D7

COHN--Florence, age 93, died peacefully at home May 19 in Laguna Woods, CA. Born Florence Weiner, daughter of Sam and Rose of Beaver Falls, PA. Sister of Milton, Ruth, Stephen and Helen. A lifelong social activist and tireless advocate for peace and justice. Came to NYC in her late teens where she became a union organizer, married Max Cohn, raised four children, and established a distinguished career in University Press publishing. In her California retirement she began a series of spoken book reviews in Santa Monica which became a popular feature in Leisure World. She also served in leadership positions for Concerned Citizens. She was a gifted artisan and pianist. Florence was loved and admired by many and will be missed by all. Memorial celebrations are planned for the Laguna Woods Community, and for family and friends in NYC.

SWEENEY--John A. H. Winterthur Museum & Country Estate marks with profound sorrow the death of its esteemed curator emeritus, John A. H. Sweeney, on May 17. His scholarship and leadership were tremendously significant to Winterthur and to the American decorative arts community. He joined the museum staff in 1954 after graduating in the first class of Fellows in the Winterthur/University of Delaware Program in Early American Culture, eventually serving as head curator and senior deputy director prior to his retirement in 1991. He worked closely on the restoration of the state rooms of the White House in the early 1960s, serving on the Fine Arts Advisory Committee for the Fine Arts Committee for the White House. He was also the author of numerous publications and was a member of the boards of many arts and historic preservation groups. He is survived by his two brothers, Dr. C. Leslie Sweeney of Raleigh, NC and his wife, Constance M., and Robert H. Sweeney of Navarre, FL. and his wife, Ann F., and by seven nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held May 22 at St. Joseph on the Brandywine, Greenville, DE. The family requests that contributions in his honor be made to Winterthur Museum & Country Estate, The John Sweeney Fund, Winterthur, DE 19735.

A front-page article on Friday about the resignation of Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly to the pay package for the job. It was the previous World Bank president -- not Mr. Wolfowitz -- who was paid a salary of $302,470 and expenses of $141,290 in 2004. (Mr. Wolfowitz, who did not arrive at the bank until 2005, was paid an after-tax salary of $391,440 beginning July 1, 2005. )

As a growing number of Americans are learning, surviving cancer can mean slipping into a rabbit hole of long-term medical problems -- from premature menopause and sexual dysfunction to more debilitating side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, like heart disease and even new cancers. The realization that cancer and its aftermath can go on for years has given rise to a medical specialty known as survivorship. At several major hospitals around the country, survivor programs financed by the Lance Armstrong Foundation are focusing on life after cancer.

Beloved husband of Helene Netter, devoted father of Nancy Voisin and Jeanne Voisin, Drew and Carin Netter, Cathy and Rabbi Philip Bregman. Loving grandfather of Samuel and Jules Paulay, Steven and Amanda Netter, Jeri Netter, Shai, Jordana and Shira Bregman. Great-grandfather of Max Ivan Netter. Services Tuesday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Contributions can be made to PKD Foundation, 9221 Ward Parkway, Suite 4000, Kansas City, MO 64114-3367 in memory of Stuart Voisin. Board of Governors , Ridgeway Country Club

With ''Paranoid Park,'' an intimate character study of an accidental killer, Gus Van Sant has returned to Cannes with one of the most moving and delicately felt films of his fascinating career. (He won the Palme d'Or in 2003 for ''Elephant.'') Shot by the cinematographers Christopher Doyle and Rain Kathy Li with an acute sensitivity to color as an index of feeling and mood, the film unwinds as a series of nonlinear flashbacks, some of which repeat like the refrain of a song. Though based on Blake Nelson's young-adult novel of the same title, Mr. Van Sant's film -- he wrote the lean screenplay, as well as directed and edited -- is a work of art that exploits the plasticity of his own medium to eerie, at times rapturous effect. The angel-faced Gabe Nevins plays Alex, a high school student who spends much of his out-of-class time skateboarding with his friends and fending off a girl who is eager to lose her virginity. One evening while visiting Paranoid Park, a swooping concrete paradise for throwaways and runaways, buzzing with the sounds of grinding wheels and excited young voices, Alex inadvertently causes the gruesome death of a security guard. Mr. Van Sant tells what happened to the teenager, still more boy than man, not a hint of down on his chin, as if he were building a mosaic. Each new fragment adds another piece to the whole, which doesn't fully come into view until late in this precisely shaped one-hour-25-minute story.

KAPLAN--Murray. The Board and staff of Citymealson-Wheels express condolences to Janet Rodgers, a founding member, whose lively, sociable 95-year-old father, Murray Kaplan, died after an automobile accident this week. Janet's caring attention to her father exemplifies the sensitive concern she has always shown to New York's homebound elderly.

An effort by a broadcast television network to present a series beginning in the fall with no commercial breaks has gained the support of a major media agency, whose clients will sponsor each episode of the show. MediaVest in New York agreed to buy all the sponsorships in ''CW Now,'' a 30-minute magazine-style show scheduled for 7 p.m. Sundays during the 2007-8 season.

Heart Attack Risk Seen In Popular Diabetes Pill A leading medical journal published an analysis showing that Avandia, a widely used diabetes pill, significantly increased the risk of heart attacks over regimens of other diabetes drugs, raising safety questions and renewing skepticism about the vigilance of federal drug regulators. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Columbia Aid Director Fired Columbia University dismissed its financial aid director after the release of documents showing he avidly promoted a student loan company in which he had a financial stake. The accusations were revealed after an investigation by New York's attorney general. PAGE B1 Ex-Presidential Protocol Though Jimmy Carter backpedaled after calling the Bush administration ''the worst in history,'' he has incited disapproval in the capital for failing to observe the protocol that former presidents should speak respectfully of successors. PAGE A15 Mysteries of the Deep Modern lights, cameras, electronics and digital photography are revealing a deep undersea world of strange translucent, gelatinous creatures like the dumbo octopus, above. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F3 And Other Small Details Officials at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams are at odds with the Swiss artist Christoph Büchel about the feasibility of his gigantic installation piece, which is set to open on Saturday. As a result of the standoff, the work -- which includes a two-story house, bomb casings and a shiny truck -- may go ''on view'' behind plastic tarps. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Birth Papers for the Stillborn Over the last six years, 19 states have enacted laws allowing parents who have had stillbirths to receive birth certificates. Many people say getting such a certificate is important, although entirely symbolic. Politically, the laws occupy uncertain territory. PAGE A16 Toothpaste Inquiry in China As more poison-tainted toothpaste turned up in Latin America, including some made for children, Chinese authorities have begun investigating whether two companies from the coastal region of Daynyang exported at least some of the suspect product. In the last week, toothpaste containing diethylene glycol, an industrial solvent, has been found in the Dominican Republic, Panama and Australia. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

To the Editor: Re ''A Giant Takes On Physics' Biggest Questions'' (May 15): Indeed, giant particle accelerators generate important physics discoveries, but around the world, accelerators of all sizes yield additional payoffs -- sometimes unexpectedly. The World Wide Web emerged from the accelerator community's need to share visual information. In 1938, accelerated particles first successfully treated a cancer patient. Today, accelerator magnet technology underlies magnetic resonance imaging.

KASSIRER--Karen of Manhattan died May 16 after a long, brave battle with breast cancer. An artist and Senior Partner and Manager of Editorial Services at Ogilvy & Mather, she was recently honored as the 2006 Colby Artist at the Buffalo Seminary. Predeceased by her father, Earle L. Kassirer Esq., she is survived by her mother, Norma Kassirer; her sister, Susan Kassirer; brother-in-law, Thomas Langner; niece, Laura Langner; and cousin, Janet Kaufman. Donations in Karens name can be made to the ACLU, Public Citizen, or the NAACP.

The rapper Ludacris and a ''Counter Truancy Unit'' agent with the voice of Kiefer Sutherland made cartoon cameos (that's Ludacris, below) Sunday on ''The Simpsons,'' as the 18th season of this Fox animated institution came to a close with its 399th and 400th episodes. Nielsen estimated that an average of 9.8 million viewers tuned in to watch the finale in the 8 p.m. hour, attracting the show's best ratings in more than four months. In the next hour, finales of Fox's ''Family Guy'' at 9 (9.1 million) and ''American Dad'' at 9:30 (7.7 million) helped lift Fox to a second-place finish for the night among adults 18 to 49. ABC led the night over all with season finales of its lineup, ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (12.3 million), ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (18.4 million), and ''Brothers and Sisters'' at 10 (12.7 million). Opposite the finales, CBS and NBC broadcast movies from 8 to 11. CBS drew 6.9 million viewers with ''Million Dollar Baby,'' while ''National Treasure'' delivered 7.9 million viewers for NBC. BENJAMIN TOFF

An article in some copies on May 13 about a request to dismiss a murder case stemming from the killing of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan in 1990 referred imprecisely to David Lemus, who was convicted in the case in 1992. That conviction was set aside in 2005 and Mr. Lemus is now awaiting a second trial on the same charges. He is not merely ''accused'' of the crime or otherwise being treated as only a suspect.

ZULLER--Harriet. Died on May 21, 2007, at age 75, after bravely battling cancer. A dedicated teacher. An adoring mother to Michael and Dana, Randi, Eliane and Adrian. A treasured grandmother to Devon, Jillian, Geoffrey, Chelsea, Daniel, Alexander and Chloe, and above all a devoted wife of 55 years to Norman, who passed away only three months ago. She will forever be remembered for her strength, beauty and grace.

An article on May 13 about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word ''revolution'' from its name omitted the party's new name, and a correction in this space on May 15 incorrectly rendered the English version of the new name. It is the Supreme Islamic Iraqi Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

To the Editor: Re ''HPV Vaccine: Few Risks, Many Benefits'' (Personal Health, May 15): As the daughter of a mother who passed away from endocervical cancer, and as the mother of an 11-year-old girl, I appreciate Jane Brody's efforts to demystify many of the issues surrounding the new vaccine against HPV. However, I believe she minimizes some not-so-insignificant concerns.

The head of Shanghai's new Formula One racing track lost his job as part of an investigation into corruption in the city government. Yu Zhifei, the official, was fired and expelled from the Communist Party, state news media said. He oversaw the introduction of the racing circuit in 2005. The track and related infrastructure cost the city more than $1 billion to develop. JOSEPH KAHN

MINCIELI--Michael J., loving and beloved father of Michael and Dennis, father-inlaw of Debra, grandfather of John and Jena Allee, David Allee and Elaine Cohen, and Joey and Janet Quintana, great-grandfather of Jack, Will and Elijah. Born December 5, 1915, died May 20, 2007. A sweet man and dear friend to his Parkchester neighbors. He remembered all of our names, everyone who met him, and we will all miss him greatly. Wake Tuesday, May 22, 3-5 and 7-9pm at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx. Funeral on Wednesday morning, the Church of St. Helena, 1315 Olmstead Ave, the Bronx. Call 718-892-3232 for the exact time of service.

My Thursday column takes on China-bashing protectionists but also notes that China is going to face difficult transitions ahead. I tend to think there's a bit too much China exuberance right now and that most people don't adequately allow for the challenges ahead.

Who needs a BlackBerry or a Treo? David Pogue reviews three free services that send your e-mail to any cellphone.

Alexander Shabalov beat Sergey Kudrin in the last round of the Frank K. Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla., to win the tournament and claim the title of U.S. champion. Alexander Onischuk, last year's champion, had a chance to tie for first, but he was held to a draw in the last round by Boris Gulko. Onischuk finished second and Gregory Kaidanov, Yury Shulman Julio Becerra finished in a tie for third. The games can be replayed here at Monroi.com.

My assistant, Winter Miller, who keeps order as I go gallivanting around the globe, wrote a terrific play called "In Darfur" -- about the ethical issues that arise in reporting in a hellhole like Darfur. It was inspired in part by a trip to the Chad-Darfur border a year ago in which she accompanied me through burned-out villages

Carlos Delgado's struggles have cost him his hold on the cleanup spot in the lineup. Willie Randolph dropped him to sixth, replacing him with David Wright, marking the first time Delgado has started a game and hit that low since May 14, 1997, when he played with Toronto.

If you are shopping on Via Corso or heading back to town from the Coloseum or the Imperial Forum, stop at the wonderful temporary Chagall retrospective exhibit in the Museo Del Risorgimento. The museum is entered through the back side of Rome's ugliest monument, Il Vittoriano, a bright white late 19th Century creation to commemorate Italian unification. (For those who have just done the Schnabel exhibit, Il Vittoriano is the bright white monstrosity right across Piazza Venezia.) The Chagalls could be better organized and displayed, but there are dozens of terrific paintings spanning 6 decades of the artist's work. Particularly interesting for those in Rome who are overdosed on traditional religious art, are Chagall's unconventional renderings of the Bible, in which Jesus is shown with all the trappings of Judaism (notice the Torah), placed in what looks like Chagall's birthplace in a village in Russia. To finish your visit, head upstairs to the museum's outdoor cafe, on a terrace overlooking the ruins of the Imperial Forum. The coffee is excellent. The sangria not bad. Most important, the terrace has one of the best panoramas of Rome, with excellent signs that help you make sense of the forest of spires and arches you are seeing. Just FYI this outing is very kid-friendly; I did this one with my 15-year-old, who loved both the art and the view.

The last time that McLaren Mercedes drivers carried diamonds around like this in Monaco, in 2005, they finished first and fifth in the race. Obviously the team has no objections to doing all it can to facilitate its sponsor, the Steinmetz diamond company, in its efforts to show off the diamonds again.
What does it take to be a comedy writer? Some people ask because they want to be one and some (the more fortunate ones) because they merely want to know.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer, in a speech tonight to the Citizens Budget Commission, plans to announce that he will move up the budget calendar by a couple of months to try to ease the state's tight negotiating timetable.

Rudolph W. Giuliani found a useful foil in Ron Paul during the recent Republican debate, and now he's taking on a Democrat -- John Edwards -- to make his points on the national security front during an appearance today in New Hampshire.

For such a little guy Samuel David Cheney, weighing in at 8 lbs., 6 oz., sure prompted a hefty debate in the run-up to his birth in Washington this morning. He's the son of Mary Cheney, and his grandfather is Vice President Dick Cheney.

The city's Broadband Advisory Committee, created in 2005, includes representatives of the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who are trying to find ways to broaden Internet access across the five boroughs. The committee held a public hearing yesterday at Borough Hall in Brooklyn, led by Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer, a Democrat from Manhattan.

Something seems a little out of whack between the mainstream media and the American people. Take the arguments of the past few days over former President Jimmy Carter's remarks about the Bush administration and the consequences of its particular brand of foreign policy. Carter didn't attack President Bush personally, but said that "as far as the adverse impact on the nation around the world, this administration has been the worst in history," which can't really be too far out of line with what many Americans think.
An ad for Avon.

My wife's aunt was in town for her birthday last week, and to mark the occasion she wanted to treat us all to a 3-star restaurant. We had read a while ago that Yannick Alléno of Le Meurice just got his third Michelin star this year, and my aunt-in-law liked the idea of a lunch in old-style French elegance.

The New Republic's Michael Crowley has read retired-and-still-eight-time-loser Democratic strategist Bob Shrum's new memoir, "No Excuses: Concessions of a Serial Campaigner," so you don't have to. "[N]o one comes in for rougher treatment in this book than Shrum's former client, John Edwards," Crowley writes, who says Edwards is portrayed as an intellectual lightweight and "a hyper-ambitious phony."
Britain has delayed the requirement that anyone selling a home must provide a packet of information about the property after surveyors mounted a legal challenge, Bloomberg News reported.

It is a tale that would have been warm enough to touch the heart of Robert Moses -- well, maybe not. According to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a population of tiny peregrine falcons was recently born atop the Throgs Neck Bridge, the suspension span that connects the Bronx and Queens and opened in 1961 under Moses's supervision.
Beyond telling our architect, Greg Huddy, that the latest version of the house was too big and too expensive, I didn't have any ideas on how to fix it.

It has been 21 years since Hands Across America, when on May 25, 1986, some five million people joined hands in a line to Long Beach, Calif., from New York to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness.
Dear Readers:
Britain and the House budget committee deserted the "war on terror" last month, and now candidates for the White House are starting to weigh in.

The Empire Zone is pleased to bring you an audio clip of Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, doing his impression yesterday of Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker. I asked him to describe how Mr. Silver sounded during their private conversation this week about legislation to reinstate the death penalty in New York. Mr. Bruno will be here all week, folks.

The Spitzer administration and a group of major insurers announced a settlement this afternoon of insurance claims at ground zero, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site -- about half of what is needed. The settlement provides about $870 million to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the land at ground zero and built the trade center, and $1.13 billion to the developer Larry A. Silverstein, who is to build large office towers on Church Street, between Vesey and Liberty Streets.

A senior official in the campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wrote an internal memorandum to the campaign advising Mrs. Clinton not to participate in the Iowa caucuses, arguing that she probably could not win them and that she would be better off spending her time and campaign money in places more hospitable to her campaign.

With an agreement to buy aQuantive under its belt, Microsoft is playing down rumors -- in the air for at least a year, most recently stoked by the New York Post -- that it might try to buy Yahoo. "We have all of the pieces we need to move forward'' in the online-advertising business, Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft's chief advertising strategist, said Wednesday at a Goldman Sachs Internet conference in Las Vegas.

A Brooklyn judge's decision yesterday to hold Emmanuel Constant -- a onetime paramilitary leader and C.I.A. informer -- for further jail time on grand larceny charges underscores the sad and bizarre aspects of a complex legal case that spans Haiti and the United States and has caught the attention of human and civil rights advocates in both countries.

Traveling in Southeast Asia, as in most parts of the developing world, often involves being confronted with jarring contrasts between rich and poor, visitor and local. And the more remote the area, the bigger the disparity.

New York has reported results of English tests in Grades 3-8 taken in all public schools this spring. The tests show that the number of students passing in earlier grades dropped from 2006 levels in most places, but rose compared with last year in middle school grades. The Times unveiled an online tool today that allows readers to look up results by school.

Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst, is taking some pride from a little-noticed milestone: For the first time since he agreed to be barred from the securities industry, shares of Amazon have risen back above $400.
The stork that has represented the Vlasic line of pickles since 1974 is returning to television advertising for the first time in many years.

The European Union placed caps today on mobile-phone roaming charges within its 27 member states, answering a groundswell of complaints that would be easily recognizable to anyone with a cell phone and any semblance of a victim's complex.
Who says buyout firms and unions can't be friends?
Normally, the New York State Assembly has a lovely little Web site with links to lawmakers' home pages, a search function for legislation and more.

Ah, how times have changed. After Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, lost the Democratic primary for mayor in 2001, he found a safe harbor as president of the Drum Major Institute, a liberal policy group.

Illinois Tool Works makes everything from self-drilling screws to commercial meat slicers. But is the 95-year-old industrial conglomerate interested in making a deal? That is what many investors seemed to be wondering Tuesday, as trading in the company's stock and options ratcheted up quite a bit. Shares of the company, which has a market capitalization of more than $29 billion, spiked as much as 6 percent in morning trading Tuesday amid what Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, described as "way above normal" trading volume.
In a new ad out today, Senator Christopher J. Dodd names names, but in his new ad, Mitt Romney declines to name a place.

We've updated our blogroll to include some of the newsier neighborhood blogs from the five boroughs, especially Brooklyn, which seems to be New York City's blogtopia. Or blogistan.Thanks in particular go to Louise Crawford of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, who pointed out that we had not paid enough attention to the list lately.

A couple weeks ago, I wrote about my desire to see a "Web 2.0" site where people could report the details of their illnesses. At a glance, you'd be able to see the clouds of color-coded flu bugs or GI bugs moving through your area or even your town. When you got sick, at least you'd know what kind of duration and intensity you could expect.
We New Yorkers like to think we live in the best restaurant city in the country, and I've not seen any compelling evidence to date that we don't.

Following a years-long search, Mike Myers, the star of the "Austin Powers" and "Wayne's World" movies, has finally found his perfect pad in New York's SoHo district, according to "The New York Post." The celebrity has just purchased a newly constructed penthouse at 72 Mercer Street for $7.95 million. Measuring just over 4,200 square feet, the apartment includes three bedrooms, six bathrooms, a living area with 15-foot ceilings, and a 1,368-square-foot rooftop terrace.

In what may be a sign of the times, oil has trumped hedge funds in New York's contest for real-estate bragging rights. The New York Times, picking up on a story on The New York Observer's blog, reported Wednesday that an unnamed "London-based businessman in the oil business" has agreed to pay $56 million for a triplex penthouse condominium at New York's Plaza Hotel. If the deal closes, it is likely to be the most expensive sale ever of an apartment in Manhattan. It would also break the record set by Daniel Loeb, the head of the hedge fund Third Point Capital, who is known for his exquisitely barbed letters to corporate managers.

Inside the United Nations, the subject of what Kosovo can and can't do is a subject of great debate. It cannot supervise the Serbian province indefinitely, yet plans for effective independence have been hitting hurdles for months.

In the latest video from China, Nick tries to track down his wife's relatives. Sheryl WuDunn's ancestors, like many other Chinese-Americans, hailed from the Taishan region of southeastern China. There's an audio slide show from Nick's last visit in 2003 and a related column with a very provocative headline.

During a speech before the Council on Foreign Relations today, John Edwards plans to call for "greater international strategic partnerships, more aggressive use of diplomacy in place of armed intervention and the creation of a 10,000-member reserve corps to help stabilize troubled nations," reports The Times's Leslie Wayne.
In the documentary “Orange Winter” orange blooms throughout Kiev, Ukraine, the epicenter of turmoil over that country’s stolen 2004 presidential elections.

The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate. Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies -- The Globe and Mail newspaper reported that one of them is the Australian mining giant BHP Billiton -- and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.
In “9 Star Hotel,” the Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar draws us into the precarious world of young Palestinian construction workers scrabbling to survive.

Norilsk Nickel on Wednesday raised its bid for LionOre Mining International to 27.50 Canadian dollars a share, valuing the Canadian miner at about 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.3 billion). The Russian company's revised bid for LionOre, the world's 10th-largest nickel producer, was 10 percent higher than a rival offer from Xstrata, which last week made a bid of 25 Canadian dollars a share, valuing LionOre at 6.2 billion Canadian dollars.

Hertz Global Holdings said Clayton Dubilier & Rice, Merrill Lynch and the Carlyle Group plan to sell shares valued at almost $1 billion after the stock gained 40 percent since its initial offering in November.

Oaktree Capital Management, an investment firm that oversees about $40 billion in assets, became the first company to list on a new market created by Goldman Sachs as a way for private firms to raise money without going public. Oaktree raised more than $800 million selling a stake of about 14 percent to fewer than 50 other large investors, The Los Angeles Times reported.

In what The New York Times describes as Silicon Valley's version of "The Bachelor," Anne Wojcicki not only landed one of America's richest men, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, but she also got her husband's company to finance her start-up. Google said Tuesday that it invested $3.9 million this month in 23andMe, the biotech company co-founded last year by Ms. Wojcicki, a former health care industry analyst, The New York Times reported.

In Europe, the occasional activist has stirred up a revolt at an annual general meeting, led a no-confidence vote against management and even taken executives to court. Those have been the extreme cases.
Payless ShoeSource said Tuesday it is buying shoe company Stride Rite for about $800 million as a way to grab a bigger share of the fast-growing branded and children's footwear sectors.
In a movie culture filled with fake death and callous killing, “Dying at Grace” is not just a shock to the system; it’s an accusation.

It was, as even Home Depot executives will concede, a 37-minute fiasco. In a basement hotel ballroom in Delaware, with the board nowhere in sight and huge timers on stage to cut off angry investors, Home Depot held a hasty annual meeting last year that attendees alternately described as "appalling" and "arrogant."

When Institutional Investor's Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, the eye-popping sums caused grumblings among some investors about the high fees that hedge fund managers are collecting.

More New York City residents would support Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg if he were to run for governor than if he were to run for president, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning.

Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cleared the House on Tuesday. But the bill could lose the support of the Bush administration because of a provision trimming the authority of federal regulators.

Cerberus Capital Management and Oaktree Capital Management will sell the Formica Corporation, the countertop maker they acquired out of bankruptcy protection, for $700 million to a New Zealand manufacturing company, Fletcher Building.

Sichuan Xinhua Winshare Chainstore, which will be the first bookstore operator to list in Hong Kong, has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total deal size of 2.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($274 million).

SLM, the student lender commonly known as Sallie Mae, said Tuesday that its vice chairman and chief executive, Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, was resigning to pursue other interests. The move comes after SLM agreed last month to be sold to a consortium led by a private equity firm, J.C. Flowers & Company.

European regulators approved the estimated $2.1 billion purchase by Vivendi of the Bertelsmann music publishing unit yesterday, a deal that will give Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.

The casino giant MGM Mirage said Tuesday night that its board had formed an independent committee to study an offer by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian to buy two MGM Mirage properties and perhaps restructure the company.
Determined brides have found one way to cut corners by trying to get in shape for less than $20. Ashley Miller, personal trainer, tests wedding workout DVDs.

Morgan Stanley agreed Tuesday to buy Crescent Real Estate Equities, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion. At $22.80 a share, the offer is 5.5 percent more than Crescent's closing price Tuesday of $21.62. The total value of the transaction is $6.5 billion including debt, Fort Worth-based Crescent said.
OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.
Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, left the firm after two years.

In a move to shed an unprofitable business as its turnaround gains traction, Intel said Tuesday it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips. Flash memory is used in cellphones, digital music players and digital cameras and is considered one of the most erratic segments of the semiconductor market.
Angelina Jolie may be going on sabbatical, Rambo is back with a bloody trailer at the Cannes film festival, but what about everyone's favorite action hero-turned-governor?
Opening Ceremony in Manhattan introduces its shoe collection that includes suede, canvas and leather jazz shoe styles for men and women.

The use of "big boy letters" -- which often appear in deals where one party has confidential information about a stock or bond -- is about to face its first significant legal challenge in the form of a lawsuit filed by R2, a Texas hedge fund.
