Wall Street appears to be gearing up for another year of fat bonuses, according to a forecast released Tuesday. Less than halfway through 2007, an executive recruiting firm, Johnson Associates, is predicting that year-end bonuses for investment bankers could exceed last year's total by 10 percent to 15 percent in most areas.

Private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts can go ahead with its $29 billion takeover of First Data without worrying about another suitor. First Data, one of the nation's largest credit-card processing companies, said Tuesday that a period for soliciting competing bids passed without any other takeover proposals.

MuleSource, a provider of open-source business software, said Tuesday that it had raised $12.5 million in its second round of venture funding, adding to an initial $4 million it raised last fall. This latest round was led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger, expressed a desire to "blow the asses off" investors who complained of boardroom extravagance shortly before what was expected to be a contentious annual shareholder meeting in 2002, according to an e-mail presented Tuesday in a Chicago court.

The proliferation of cheap software is allowing entrepreneurs to take bigger risks when starting a company with an unproven, or non-existent business model. In the latest such example, Garage Technology Ventures investor Guy Kawasaki, best known for his early Apple evangelism, recently launched Truerumors.com, a forum to post rumors and comments via phone call, text message, or email.

Canadian buyout firm Onex said Tuesday it plans to sell another billion-dollar share of its stake in Spirit AeroSystems Holdings. Nigel Wright, managing director of Onex, said the sale will come through a secondary offering of about 31.5 million Class A shares at $33.50 each.
Two years after losing a three-goal lead to Liverpool in the 2005 Champions League final, A.C. Milan defeated the England side to win its seventh European Cup title.
Additional images from the Creation Museum in Petersburg, Ky.
Images from "Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns and Mermaids" at the American Museum of Natural History.
In this confessional, even abject, documentary for HBO, Alan Berliner considers the causes and effects of his chronic sleeplessness.
President George W. Bush used declassified intelligence on Wednesday to equate the U.S.-led fight in Iraq with the broader battle against al Qaeda.
La Paz, Bolivia, might be the Pop Art capital of South America.

For the first time since taking power in Congress, the Democrats yesterday publicly agreed to allow a vote on Iraq war financing without a timetable for troop withdrawal. The move apparently ended a legislative battle with President Bush, who had refused to accept time constraints.
A weekend in a metropolitan city that has maintained its brash and flashy side.
To describe “The Boss of It All,” Lars von Trier’s acidic corporate comedy, as “ ‘The Office’ Viewed Through the Looking Glass” only scratches the surface.
The grape meets oak dust and, occasionally, fish bladders.
A jury rejected the defense claim that Peter Braunstein was too mentally ill to intentionally commit a crime.
In a speech, the president described what the White House called previously classified intelligence to build his case that Osama bin Laden is trying to turn Iraq into a “terrorist sanctuary.”
Britain’s counterterrorism police took the highly unusual step of issuing a public appeal for information about three suspected terrorists said to have absconded from a form of house arrest.
A member of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign staff said that time and money could be better invested.
Senators had questioned the suitability of the nominee, a lobbyist for the National Association of Manufacturers.

PRISTINA, Kosovo, May 23 — A Serbian court found two former paramilitary police officers guilty of the assassination of Zoran Djindjic, the pro-reform prime minister who was gunned down in Belgrade in March 2003.
Police in southwestern China arrested 28 people on charges that they instigated riots last weekend over family planning controls.
The settlement ensures that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site.
Officials said they hoped that innovations in air traffic software would minimize delays caused by weather.
Monica M. Goodling said that she improperly weighed political factors in considering applicants for career positions in the Justice Department.
Benedict XVI acknowledged that “unjustifiable crimes” were committed in the European conquest of South America.
The president, from Fatah, and prime minister, from Hamas, also sought ways to quell fighting with Israel.
The horses, eight of which were ponies, died in the stables of Shamrock Farms in Chestnut Ridge after the fire broke out early this morning.
While they often don’t get the attentino of a verbal gaffe captured on YouTube, a candidate’s campaign platform and their issue positions tend to matter -- a lot.
Iraqi police believe the body may be one of three U.S. soldiers who were seized in an ambush on May 12.
Residents fled from a refugee camp during a ceasefire today between the Lebanese Army and a militant group.
On the day he turned 34, Julián Tavárez earned his 34th career victory as a starter in the Red Sox’ 7-3 win over the Yankees Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium.
Starter Jorge Sosa did not make it past the fourth inning in the Braves’ victory over the Mets that drew them within a game and a half of the lead in the National League East.
The independent committee will study an offer by the Kirk Kerkorian to buy two MGM Mirage properties and perhaps restructure the company.
The Yankees and starter Mike Mussina fell behind early and could not recover as the Red Sox restored their 10½-game advantage in the American League East.
A judge has upheld the 40-day suspension a student received because of a video of his teacher which was posted on YouTube.
The prosecution and the defense offered contradictory versions of why — but not whether — a former fashion writer had dressed as a firefighter, and tied up and attacked a woman he barely knew.
The owner of Gotham Book Mart in Midtown had to sell his books after falling behind on rent by about a half-million dollars.
Corrections

A sports article yesterday about efforts by Brett Myers, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, to change his life since being charged with assaulting his wife referred incorrectly to the timing of the alleged altercation. It was last June, not August. (A court date in the case had been scheduled for August.).
A sports article on Saturday about the Cavaliers’ victory against the Nets to win their playoff series misstated the age of LeBron James of Cleveland. He is 22, not 24.

An article in Science Times on May 8 about a study showing how meditation affects attention referred incorrectly to one group that was studied. The 17 volunteers who meditated for 10 to 12 hours a day as part of the research did have previous meditation experience; they were not new to meditation.

An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged, and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding — not Heinz Guderian, who had been promoted to another job.

An article in some copies on Saturday about an open house at the Islamic Center of South Jersey in Palmyra, the mosque where four of the six men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix had worshiped, misstated the date of their arrests. It was May 7, not May 10.

A brief article in Science Times yesterday about a study showing that alcohol consumption can lower the risk of one type of kidney cancer misstated the publication date. It appeared in the May 16 issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute; it is not scheduled to be published in the June 16 issue.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on May 4 about the entry of Merchandise Mart Properties, a Chicago company, into the art business misstated the name of one of the company’s buildings in New York. It is the Architects & Designers Building on East 58th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, not the Design & Decoration Building. (A building called the Decoration & Design Building, on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, is owned by the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation.).

A music review on Saturday about a performance of Rameau’s “Castor et Pollux” at the French Institute Alliance Française in New York, misspelled part of the name of the group that performed. It is L’Opéra Français de New York, not Française.

An article on Thursday about a recent migration of Orthodox Jews to Waterbury, Conn., a struggling and heavily Roman Catholic city, misidentified the New York county that is home to the town of Kiryas Joel, another Orthodox enclave. It is Orange, not Rockland.

A brief article in Science Times on May 1 about research on migraines and mental decline referred incorrectly to the subjects of the study. The researchers looked at men and women, not just women. In addition, among the approximately 1,400 subjects studied over 12 years, more than 200 of them had a history of migraines — not about 20 of them.

A picture in Weekend on Friday with an article about the fall prime-time schedules for Fox and CW was published in error. It showed a scene from “Supernatural,” which will be entering its third season on CW — not “Reaper,” a new show on that network.
He served in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and now immigrant Warren Joseph fights to remain in the United States after being held for three years for violating probation on a weapons charge.

A man charged with operating on animals without a license was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to probation and mandatory psychiatric treatment. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching surgery on a Boston terrier. His case drew worldwide publicity for the involvement of a so-called undercover cat named Fred, used in a sting operation by the district attorney’s office. Mr. Vassall was sentenced after pleading guilty to scheming to defraud and to the unauthorized practice of veterinary medicine. Under the terms of a plea bargain, he must attend an outpatient mental health program five days a week and refrain from involvement in nursing or animal care.

Police officers and state wildlife officials set traps yesterday to catch a coyote that bit a 5-year-old boy in the face and neck on Monday night, the second time in two months that a coyote had attacked a child in Middletown. The boy, Brayden Gazette, required 46 stitches and rabies shots. Police officers fired a shotgun at the coyote, but could not tell if they had hit it, said Robert M. Czech, the township administrator. On April 6, a 20-month-old boy was bitten by a coyote in another section of the township, but was not seriously injured.

German investor confidence rose to an 11-month high in May as company profits surged and economists raised their forecasts for growth this year. The Center for European Economic Research in Mannheim said its index of investor and analyst expectations increased to 24, the highest since June, from 16.5 in April. The center, known by the German acronym ZEW, said a gauge of investors’ assessment of the current situation rose to a record 88 from 76.9 last month.

New York’s two United States senators said yesterday that recent train wrecks in upstate New York showed that Congress must strengthen the Federal Railroad Administration, which is responsible for rail safety. Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats, testified before a Senate Commerce subcommittee that the agency needed more support to carry out its work. Senator Schumer also called for stiffer fines for railroads that violated federal rules. Edward R. Hamberger, president of the Association of American Railroads, said railroads remained the safest form of transportation in the country.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday called for closing the National Guard bombing range where a vast Pinelands wildfire is believed to have started last week. The fire, which burned more than 17,000 acres over six days, is believed to have started when an F-16 fighter jet dropped a flare during a training run. The Air Force is investigating. The Defense Department declined to comment yesterday.

Nortel Networks said it would pay 1 million Canadian dollars ($921,000) as part of a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission. The payment is not a fine. The company called it a contribution toward the cost of the commission’s investigation into accounting irregularities at the company from 2000 to 2003. Nortel, the communications equipment maker, acknowledged in the agreement that its senior executives had improperly altered accounting policies and provisions to improve the company’s apparent financial performance. Under the agreement, the company must give the commission special quarterly and annual reports on efforts to improve its accounting controls. Nortel fired its chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and two other executives over the bookkeeping issues in 2004. The former executives face separate charges by the Ontario regulator. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also charged the three as well as other former Nortel employees. Law enforcement officials in both Canada and the United States are also investigating the company.

A man charged with the murder of two women whose remains were found inside sealed barrels on March 31 died on Saturday, four days after being taken to the Erie County Medical Center for a mental health evaluation, the Erie County Sheriff’s Office said yesterday. Hours before he was stricken on May 15, the man, Robert J. Henchen, 42, of Colden, pleaded not guilty to charges of killing Geraldine Jackson, 87, and Nancy Phelps, 69, both of whom disappeared months before their remains were found. According to his lawyer, Mr. Henchen suffered “a cardiac incident.” But the cause of his death remained under investigation yesterday, the Sheriff’s Department said. He had been hospitalized because of odd behavior, including refusal to wear clothes, at the Erie County jail, said Undersheriff Richard T. Donovan.

A Jamaica man has been charged with holding an acquaintance captive in his family’s garage and sexually assaulting her, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Joseph Burrell, 44, of 171st Street, was arraigned last weekend on charges of attempted rape, criminal sexual acts and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Burrell lured a 42-year-old woman to his family’s furnished garage by inviting her to a barbecue last Wednesday and attacked her, beating her and smashing a glass object on her, then tried to rape and sodomize her.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine Quinn announced a new effort yesterday aimed at improving poor New Yorkers’ access to healthful food. With a $500,000 grant from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, city officials are bringing together public and private groups to recommend ways to increase healthful eating and physical activity. In addition, the Human Resources Administration, the city’s welfare agency, is expanding a pilot program that allows food stamp offices to process electronic applications taken at food pantries and soup kitchens. Two organizations in Queens will be added to the program, with Manhattan groups to follow, city officials said.

The state police yesterday suspended the head of the troopers’ union, Detective David Jones, for five days because he revealed a radio talk show host’s personal details to reporters this month, the union announced. The suspension came after an investigation by the state attorney general. On May 3, Detective Jones showed reporters a piece of paper containing the home address of the host, Craig Carton — half of the team known as the Jersey Guys — along with Mr. Carton’s license plate number and the make and model of his car, the investigation found. The detective’s actions came after Mr. Carton and his co-host disclosed Web postings by state troopers that threatened a “ticket blitz” in response to criticism of troopers’ role in a car crash involving Gov. Jon S. Corzine in April. Mr. Jones did not use law enforcement databases to obtain Mr. Carton’s information, according to the attorney general’s office.

The State Senate voted yesterday to move 16- and 17-year-old criminal offenders, who are now prosecuted as adults, back into the juvenile system. Connecticut, New York and North Carolina are the only states that prosecute 16-year-olds as adults. Proponents of the bill said many of these young offenders needed social services, not jail time with adults. “This is a group you don’t throw in jail,” said Senator John A. Kissel, an Enfield Republican. “This is a group we can save.” The bill, which would still allow prosecutors to transfer any major felony case involving a juvenile to adult court, now goes to the House.

British Airways said it had joined a consortium led by a private equity firm, TPG Capital, bidding for the Spanish airline Iberia. British Airways joined with TPG Capital, Vista Capital de Expansión, Inversiones Ibersuizas and Quercus Equity to investigate a possible consortium offer for Iberia, the airline said in an announcement to the London Stock Exchange. British Airways has a 10 percent stake in the company and the right of first refusal on offers for a further 30 percent of Iberia. TPG Capital, formerly known as the Texas Pacific Group, made a preliminary offer of 3.41 billion euros ($4.59 billion) for Iberia at the end of March and subsequently signed up the Spanish partners Vista Capital and Inversiones Ibersuizas to its consortium.

A dealer who admitted stealing 100 rare antique maps was ordered yesterday to pay $2.3 million in restitution. The dealer, E. Forbes Smiley III, was sentenced in Federal District Court last September to three and a half years in prison. The money is to go to map dealers and libraries in Connecticut, New York, Boston, Maine and Britain, but whether they actually receive any money depends on Mr. Smiley’s ability to pay after he gets out of prison and the government’s ability to sell his assets, said John Koegel, a lawyer for some of the dealers. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Viacom and an Indian media company, the TV18 Group, said they would jointly create Viacom-18, a television, film and digital media company. Viacom-18 will start a Hindi-language entertainment channel later this year, and Viacom’s MTV Networks, which is already present in India, will become part of the joint venture. Viacom’s movie studios, DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, will look for opportunities in India over the next few months, Viacom said. "India is one of Viacom’s priority markets for expansion internationally," Philippe P. Dauman, above, the president and chief executive of Viacom, said during a news conference in Mumbai.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said Tuesday that he was considering a plan that could generate billions of dollars from such state assets as toll roads without ceding control to private companies.

President Bush has chosen Anne W. Patterson to be ambassador to Pakistan, the White House said. If confirmed by the Senate, she would replace Ryan Crocker, who earlier this year became the ambassador to Iraq. Ms. Patterson now leads the State Department’s bureau for international narcotics and law-enforcement affairs. She has previously served as deputy ambassador to the United Nations and ambassador to Colombia.

A 41-year-old American tourist drew complaints when he went for a walk through Nuremberg without any clothes. “The man said he thought walking around naked was tolerated in Germany,” a police spokesman said. The man was carrying his clothes in a bag when the police stopped him.

Switzerland will return $6.2 million next month that it seized in bank accounts of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, Swiss officials said. A large part of the money is to be given to Haiti for humanitarian projects. The officials said the remainder would be returned to Mr. Duvalier, who was overthrown in 1986 and lives in exile in France.

President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev signed several constitutional amendments put forward by Parliament, including an exemption for himself from a provision limiting presidents to serving two terms, effectively clearing the way for him to become president for life. Political opposition groups objected to the provision as the beginning of a Soviet-style personality cult for Mr. Nazarbayev, who came to power in 1989 and whose current seven-year term expires in 2012. Mr. Nazarbayev also signed off on constitutional changes that expand Parliament’s responsibilities, including a greater role in choosing the prime minister.
The decision was a wrenching reversal for leading Democrats, who saw their election triumph as a call to end the war.

Lawmakers endorsed an international adoption protocol under pressure from the United States, which has said it will cease allowing Guatemalan children to be adopted by American parents unless reforms are made in Guatemala’s largely privatized system. That system has been heavily criticized by international human rights organizations for the high cost charged to adoptive parents and for payments that are sometimes made to girls and women who are putting their children up for adoption. But real changes will not come until Congress passes a law implementing the requirements of the protocol, called the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption. The treaty calls for counties to set up a central adoption authority, which has been controversial in Guatemala because of the political clout of private attorneys who now manage adoptions.

The authorities dismissed five mine safety officials for allowing a Siberian coal mine to “break safety rules for the benefit of profit,” an action they said led to an explosion in March that killed 108 miners, the biggest mine disaster in Russia’s recent history. An investigation showed that the mine’s managers deliberately disabled a methane gas detector. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The dismissals, reported by the Interfax news agency, were an exception to the usual blanket impunity enjoyed by government officials.

Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the foreign minister of Germany, whose governments are under pressure at home to withdraw their troops from Afghanistan, made separate visits to that country and met with the president, Hamid Karzai. Mr. Karzai urged the international community to stay engaged. Mr. Steinmeier also visited the province of Kunduz, where a suicide bomber killed three German soldiers over the weekend. Mr. Steinmeier expressed concern about insecurity in Afghanistan and told reporters that the Group of 8 was calling the foreign ministers of Afghanistan and Pakistan to their talks in Germany next week.
The relationship between the governor and a union president is a fascinating topic in New Jersey politics.
Web data that showed a risk for a diabetes drug is likely to spur more efforts to publicly disclose drug study results.
A House committee has started an inquiry after a former museum official accused the Smithsonian of toning down an exhibit on climate change for political reasons.
The blast left a 50-foot-wide crater and a swath of bodies near a crowded market and a security checkpoint.
Utility officials restarted a long-dormant nuclear reactor, 22 years after it was shut down because of safety concerns at Browns Ferry.
Three masked men stormed a community bank on the South Side of Chicago and shot three people, before fleeing with a “small amount” of money, the police said.
On a vote of 306 to 114, the House passed a bill that would limit the president’s power to appoint prosecutors indefinitely.
A 65-year-old man died after his golf cart plunged 75 feet off a cliff and crashed into a road below, the authorities said.
A private pilot was chased by a NASA helicopter after his plane flew near the space shuttle Atlantis as the shuttle sat on its launching pad.
Alinghi, a Swiss team, will not have to face Larry Ellison’s American team in the June 23-July 4 final. BMW Oracle Racing came into the competition as one of the favorites.
The hedge fund stars may gleam, but the average fund did worse last year, after fees, than the S.& P.
The Yankees are 3-6 in Andy Pettitte’s starts, leaving him to pore over the one or two mistakes he seems to make each game.
Winning the Republican primary is a remarkable comeback for Gov. Ernie Fletcher, who took office on a promise to clean up the Capitol but was indicted last year.
Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, has left the firm after two years.
The Trail Blazers, already stocked with young talent, were the big winners in the N.B.A. draft lottery where the three teams that finished with the worst records were bumped from the top draft spots.
The first clear look inside a refugee camp on Tuesday revealed the hellish outcome of a three-day battle.
Soon after the Yankees signed Carl Pavano for $40 million in December of 2004, the Red Sox found their own mediocre pitcher in the free-agent pool. Boston signed Matt Clement for $25 million.
The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, calling the offer inadequate.
Democratic leaders pushing promised lobbying reforms are facing resistance from balky lawmakers.
Mexico’s 47 consulates in the U.S. are acting as influential free agents in a broken immigration system.
Five members of a Brooklyn community board whose terms were not renewed have one thing in common: they voted yes on a resolution denouncing Atlantic Yards, the $4 billion development project.
American soldiers lost one of their own on Saturday in an effort to follow a creed: no soldier left behind.
pro football.
N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league would allow anyone to anonymously report any incident in which a doctor was pressured by a team or coach to return a player to the field.
The number of eighth graders reading on grade level climbed impressively this year, tests indicate.
After weeks of waiting for a stubborn left-wrist injury to heal, Michelle Wie is ready to resume a career visited by promise, disappointment and mystery.
Boston’s Kevin Youkilis is playing like an All-Star, excelling not only at the plate but also at first base, a position he had to learn after playing most of his career at third.
Eight Pakistani officials were among the more than 70 injured in the Ankara attack.

Facing deportation to Haiti, where he is wanted for murder, the onetime commander of a paramilitary group was instead ordered in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to stand trial on charges of grand larceny.
While the Hamas militants in Gaza seem to have taken a lesson from last summer’s inconclusive war against the rockets of Hezbollah, Israel’s own lesson is less clear.
Mike Greenberg and Mike Golic, hosts of the “Mike and Mike in the Morning” radio program, are consciously uncontroversial and it has paid off.
There is a disturbing trend in South Korea: people using the Web to trade tips about suicide and, in some cases, to form suicide pacts.
The contract would be the most expensive Manhattan apartment sale to date when it closes later this year.
Orlando Cabrera homered and made a leaping catch last night to help the visiting Los Angeles Angels defeat the Detroit Tigers, 6-3, extending their winning streak to six.
With Congress considering cutting the Pentagon’s budget for missile defenses, much is riding on a test of an antimissile shield.
The police blamed members of a banned sect for the recent beheadings of four people.
Officials from California demanded on Tuesday that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation.
Forecasters at the National Weather Service projected 13 to 17 tropical storms, with 7 to 10 becoming hurricanes and 3 to 5 of those in the strong category.
On the stand yesterday, Floyd Landis found that his character was as much under attack as his drug tests.
The Coast Guard searched a vast swath of open ocean again Tuesday for Mark Drayton, captain of a scallop boat that went down late Sunday.
Intel will join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips.
Javier Mascherano of Liverpool will play in the European Champions League final today against A.C. Milan. But his move from Brazil to England continues to be scrutinized by British soccer officials.
Carl Linnaeus, the Swedish naturalist, is remembered as the man who gave the world modern taxonomy, the science of classifying organisms.
The gas-guzzling Ford Crown Victoria would be replaced by hybrid vehicles under a five-year plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
To make room for a new Penn Station worthy of New York City, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael Bloomberg will have to encourage the owners of Madison Square Garden to move their arena.
There are fires everywhere, all around us all the time, but fires so wholly controlled that we no longer think of them as fire at all.
The United States belongs on the side of Pakistani democracy.

Civil liberties lawyers overcame major hurdles yesterday in their efforts to force the city to release raw intelligence reports detailing the Police Department’s surveillance and infiltration of protest groups leading to the 2004 Republican National Convention.
Now that David Wright is showing signs of emerging from his malaise, Carlos Delgado is the only Mets regular who has yet to get hot this season.
Failure to approve strict lobbying reform will reduce the Democrats’ vaunted vows to political farce and shorten their chances of retaining the majority.
The death has prompted officials to change the habitats of some zoo animals.
OSI Restaurant Partners agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.
John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate, plans to outline his views on military policy with a call for more aggressive use of diplomacy.
An increase in benefit claims and appeals continues to overload the system.
If the guest worker program had been stripped from the bill, the fragile deal could have collapsed.
The British authorities accused a Russian businessman, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of murdering the agent six months ago.
A hammerhead shark that gave birth in a Nebraska aquarium reproduced without mating, a genetic analysis shows.
Google said it invested $3.9 million this month in 23andMe, a biotech company co-founded last year by Sergey Brin’s wife.
Stanley L. Miller was a scientist whose spectacular discovery as a young graduate student pioneered the study of the origin of life on earth.
The move was expected as many race teams pushed Nascar to move up its implementation because of the expense of building and developing two different racecars at the same time.
The Toronto Raptors re-signed Sam Mitchell, the N.B.A.’s coach of the year, giving him a three-year contract Tuesday with a team option for a fourth year.

An article in Business Day on May 15 reported that law enforcement authorities in Switzerland had begun a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, the British military contractor. It noted a report in The Guardian, a British daily, that said Swiss investigators could examine accounts held by Wafic Said, a Syrian financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago. Mr. Said could not be reached by The Times before the article was published.
Legal experts say the man is the only inmate on death row in the United States who was not convicted of committing or participating in a killing.
While John McCain and Mitt Romney have been mixing it up, Mr. McCain and Rudolph Giuliani have something of a mutual admiration society going.
James Wright, the president of Dartmouth, started a program to provide individualized college counseling to seriously injured veterans.
The Rev. Jerry Falwell was eulogized Tuesday as a daring critic of American life, called by God to his role as a clergyman and political activist.
The blaze consumed letters written by Houdini, the magician and escape artist, posters and cards from his performances.
The narcotics unit of the Atlanta Police Department has been under scrutiny since November, when an elderly woman was shot and killed in a botched drug raid.
Morgan Stanley agreed to buy the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion.
Ben Weisman was a classically trained pianist who helped write nearly 60 songs for Elvis Presley, including many for his movies.
Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16, then released on Monday without any charges against them.
The toothpaste, sold under the brand names Excel and Mr. Cool, have been confiscated by authorities since late last week.
Swiss diplomats seeking to visit Haleh Esfandiari, a leading Iranian-American academic jailed in Iran, have not been given access to her.
When he gets out of federal prison next week, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the former mayor of Providence, R.I., who was convicted of corruption, will not exactly be slumming it.
The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said that he would investigate human rights violations in the Central African Republic.
In Europe, shareholder activism now seems to be moving into the hands of ordinary investors.
Fremont General said it agreed to sell its commercial real estate unit for $1.9 billion and bring in new managers.
Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages cleared the House on Tuesday.
Marian Radke-Yarrow was a researcher in child psychology who did many influential studies on a range of sensitive issues.
An insurance broker is trying to restore its image with an advertising campaign that urges readers to “find the upside.”
Roy De Forest was a Bay Area artist whose paintings depicted a comical, crowded frontier land of people and animals in patchworks of scorched, textured color.
The archbishop of Canterbury did not invite an openly gay bishop and a bishop who heads a conservative cluster of churches to the global gathering of Anglican bishops.
Investors, upbeat about the latest round of takeover activity, remained hesitant to take the market higher ahead of new economic data.
Thomas J. Fitzpatrick is resigning to pursue other interests and will be succeeded by the company’s chief financial officer.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,415 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:.
Analysts said the loss of output at Prudhoe Bay should not have a serious effect on world oil markets.
The F.D.A. approved the pill, called Lybrel and made by Wyeth, that can halt menstrual periods indefinitely and prevent pregnancies.
The chief for the home improvement chain will try to make up for past mistakes by laying out his vision for the future at its annual meeting Wednesday.
The $2.1 billion deal gives Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.
A fire tore through an East Baltimore row house Tuesday morning, killing six people, including three children, and injuring seven others, the authorities said.
The World Bank, the I.M.F. and the W.T.O. are now facing questions about their relevance in a global economy.
The biggest maker of electronic heart devices said profit rose 9.7 percent on higher sales of implantable defibrillators.
Anheuser-Busch Companies said profit would rise on higher sales of imported beers and fewer discounts of Bud Light and Michelob.
The office supplies retailer also gave a cautious outlook for the remainder of the year.
After a sweep yields 49 arrests in one Minnesota community, students head to class fearful their parents will be targeted next by government agents.
The acquisition will increase the original Internet video offerings produced by CBS’s interactive unit.
The basic elements of a responsible energy policy are not complicated, but the politics are horrendous.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about spousal rights, gave an incorrect name for the federal office that tallied the number of rights and responsibilities connected to marriage. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the Government Accounting Office.
Momentum is building to expand the industrial market in New Jersey further, with an emphasis on development near shipping ports.
Spared from demolition by two New York designers, a 1956 Paul Rudolph dwelling will move 200 miles from Watch Hill, R.I., to Catskill, N.Y.

Don Hewitt’s next project: “Radio City Christmas
Spectacular” on television.
With the arrival of “Live Free or Die Hard,” 20th Century Fox bets on the only straight-ahead studio action movie of the summer.
At the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, Greek mythology gets real in an interactive museum show.
When it came to selecting her neighborhood, Lisa Kreutz based her choice “on things that you cannot change.”
Sleaze rarely looks as lovely and plays with such sentiment as it does in Abel Ferrara’s “Go Go Tales.” Plus, a revisit to the “Grindhouse.”

An article last Wednesday about criticism of the Food and Drug Administration’s efforts to protect food safety misstated the agency’s explanation for the cause of a recent contamination outbreak. It believes melamine, a chemical used in fertilizers and plastics that has tainted pet food and animal feed, was in wheat flour imported from China — not in wheat gluten or rice protein. (The agency’s initial assessment was based on the fact that the flour was mislabeled as wheat gluten or rice protein.).

BAMBERGER--Maria. It is with great sadness that Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion records the death of Maria Bamberger, the dear wife of the late Fritz Bamberger, my teacher, beloved member of the HUC-JIR faculty and treasured advisor to my predecessors, Nelson Glueck and Alfred Gottschalk. Maria was a dramatic presence in Israel and instrumental in the founding of our Jerusalem campus. Her life, and that of Fritz, reflected an abiding devotion to HUC-JIR. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem and may Maria's memory be a blessing to all who knew her. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Barbara Friedman, Chair of the Board

Sleek brushed stainless steel grilling tools from Germany include a sharp fork, narrow but efficient tongs and a silicone basting brush. The tools nest together for compact storage, and can be hung from a hook. The head of the brush is removable for easy washing. The set of tools, by Silit, is $60 at Museum of Modern Art shops and at momastore.org.

Nortel Networks said it would pay 1 million Canadian dollars ($921,000) as part of a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission. The payment is not a fine. The company called it a contribution toward the cost of the commission's investigation into accounting irregularities at the company from 2000 to 2003. Nortel, the communications equipment maker, acknowledged in the agreement that its senior executives had improperly altered accounting policies and provisions to improve the company's apparent financial performance. Under the agreement, the company must give the commission special quarterly and annual reports on efforts to improve its accounting controls. Nortel fired its chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and two other executives over the bookkeeping issues in 2004. The former executives face separate charges by the Ontario regulator. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also charged the three as well as other former Nortel employees. Law enforcement officials in both Canada and the United States are also investigating the company. IAN AUSTEN

To the Editor: Re ''Hocus-Pocus, and a Beaker of Truffles'' (May 16): Possibly, Daniel Patterson is laboring under a misapprehension when he disdains truffle oil after discovering that it is artificial. All food flavors come from chemical molecules. If it is possible to create the molecule that produces a particular flavor artificially, there is no difference between that taste and the taste of the natural product except for the snobbery attached to the rarity or the expense of the natural product.

PUBLIC DATA SHOWED DRUG RISK -- A cardiologist found that GlaxoSmithKline's popular diabetes drug Avandia posed a heightened cardiac risk by analyzing the studies that the company voluntarily posted online. The finding is liking to spur efforts to require drug makers to disclose study results. [Page C1.] REHABBING HOME DEPOT -- Home Depot's annual meeting today is a chance for the chief executive, Frank Blake, to use his humble and low-key approach to distance himself from his predecessor, Robert L. Nardelli. Attendees are looking for change in another area, too: Home Depot's flagging performance. [C1.] ALCAN REJECTS ALCOA'S BID -- The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan not only rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, but it said it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa. [C1.] RELEVANCE IN QUESTION -- The crisis over Paul D. Wolfowitz is over, but the World Bank and the other structures of the international economic architecture -- including the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization -- are now is buckling under the weight of globalization, trade disputes and the ambitions of rising economic powers. [C1.] TRADE TALKS WITH CHINA -- Teams of Cabinet members from China and the United States held a day of talks to reduce economic tensions but ran into familiar disagreements over trade, currency issues and at least one new concern, the safety of Chinese food exports. [C3.] FREMONT SELLS PROPERTY UNIT -- The Fremont General Corporation, a financial services company caught up in the subprime mortgage lending mess, has agreed to sell its commercial real estate unit for $1.9 billion and bring in new managers. The new management team will be led by Gerald J. Ford, above, who once ran Golden State Bancorp. Fremont will also receive $80 million for selling a minority stake in the remaining business to a group of investors led by Mr. Ford. [C3.] ACTIVISM WITHOUT LIMOUSINES -- Shareholder activism is beginning to take root in Europe. But the efforts at forcing change are not led by the likes of Carl C. Icahn or Kirk Kerkorian, but often by ordinary investors. [C5.] POLISHING AN INSURER'S IMAGE -- Marsh & McLennan, the giant insurance broker that was staggered in recent years by accusations of rigging bids and taking kickbacks from insurance companies, is trying to restore its image with an advertising campaign that urges readers to ''find the upside.'' Advertising. [C3.] INTEL IN DEAL ON MEMORY CHIPS -- The Intel Corporation announced that it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips. [C3.] CBS BUYS A FINANCIAL WEB SITE -- CBS has bought Wallstrip, an online company whose Web site mixes finance with humor, to add to its daily financial news Web broadcast. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. [C8.] RESTAURANT OWNER IS SOLD -- OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners. The buyout group raised its bid 2.9 percent, to $41.15 a share, OSI said. OSI, based in Tampa, Fla., owns Outback, the largest steakhouse chain in the nation, as well as the Carrabba's, Bonefish and Lee Roy Selmon's restaurants. [C10.] MARKETS STALL -- Several new deals were announced, but Wall Street failed to gain much momentum as it waited for new economic data, leaving the markets little changed. [C8.] SAVANNAH'S GROWING DOWNTOWN -- A developer is proposing the largest expansion of the historic downtown in Savannah, Ga., since the grid of compact streets and squares was first designed in 1733. [C6.] NATION'S STRICTEST EMISSION LAWS -- Officials from California demanded that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation. [A19.] IMMIGRATION BILL SURVIVES -- A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year. [A20.] DIG DEEPER FOR A SIRLOIN -- The cost of producing beef and the demand for it have risen so much that prices are soaring and the supply of top-quality beef has dropped. Contributing to the rising cost is the demand for ethanol and a harsh winter, which have caused the price of corn to rise about 60 percent in recent months. [F1.] ONE CHOICE FOR ACTION MOVIE FANS -- ''Live Free or Die Hard,'' which opens in June, will be the only straight-ahead, major studio action film set for the year's prime moviegoing weeks. Its studio, 20th Century Fox, is betting that the summer movie audience still has a taste for cinematic red meat. [E1.] SALLIE MAE'S CHIEF STEPS DOWN -- SLM, the student lender commonly known as Sallie Mae, said that its vice chairman and chief executive, Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, was resigning to pursue other interests and would be succeeded by the company's chief financial officer. [C2.] anheuser-Busch raises forecast The Anheuser-Busch Companies said that profit would rise more than forecast this year on higher sales of imported beers and fewer discounts of Bud Light and Michelob. [C8.] HOUSE PASSES MORTGAGE BILL -- Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cleared the House. But the bill could lose the support of the Bush administration because of a provision trimming the authority of federal regulators. [C2.] ONLINE THE ENERGY CHALLENGE -- A series of articles examines how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more energy-efficient, environmentally benign future. The series is online at nytimes.com/energychallenge. WEEKEND BUSINESS -- In a podcast, reporters and editors from The Times's Sunday Business section offer perspective on the week in business and beyond. Subscription information is at nytimes.com/business.

The distinctiveness of purple asparagus is only skin deep. Peeling removes the purple. And even unpeeled, the stalks, once they have been cooked, fade to dull, dark green from violet. Unlike purple asparagus that has been shipped from distant farms, the slender-to-medium-size organic purple spears that Norwich Meadows Farms in Norwich, N.Y., sells are so fresh, tender and sweet that they do not need to be peeled -- or even cooked. Snap off the ends, slant-cut them in one-inch pieces, and toss them, in all their purple glory, in a salad. Or serve them whole with a dip.

A sports article yesterday about efforts by Brett Myers, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, to change his life since being charged with assaulting his wife referred incorrectly to the timing of the alleged altercation. It was last June, not August. (A court date in the case had been scheduled for August.)

PALMER--Mary, died May 19 after a short illness. She was retired from Fairchild Publication, where she was executive secretary to the editor and also a columnist who reported on the Men's Ware Trade. She is survived by two sisters, Cynthia Gray of North Carolina, and Suzanne Coppel of New York City, and three nephews James Breeding of Somerville, NJ, Andrew Breeding of Boston, MA, and William Breeding of Champagne, IL. The funeral will be at Redden's Funeral Home on Friday May 25, 11am-1pm.

Sleaze rarely looks as lovely and plays with such sentiment as it does in Abel Ferrara's ''Go Go Tales,'' a down-and-dirty story about a nightclub owner and the beauties and beasts who work for him. The film, which unfortunately, if unsurprisingly, is screening out of competition, is easily Mr. Ferrara's best since ''The Funeral'' (1996) and welcome news for his hard-core, patient admirers. (Its commitment to female pulchritude comes unadorned by self-consciously belabored art and ideas.) An obvious homage to John Cassavetes's underbelly classic ''The Killing of a Chinese Bookie'' (1976), ''Go Go Tales'' also works rather poignantly as a metaphor for the down-and-dirty independence that Mr. Ferrara has pursued his entire filmmaking career. A terrific Willem Dafoe, his Joker-like smile stretched across his face, plays the titular owner of Ray Ruby's Paradise, a strip club pulsing with music and an atmosphere of desperation. Times are tough at Ray Ruby's: the coffers are empty, the strippers haven't been paid and the landlady (Sylvia Miles), parked on a bar stool like a toad on a lily pad, is screeching for the rent. Ms. Miles, whose voice scratches against your eardrums like fingernails on a chalkboard, seemingly a mere decibel away from puncture, provides just one of the many squawks and shouts that create the cacophony that fills Ray Ruby's Paradise to the rafters, flooding it with noise and the vibrant thrum of humanity. Few other performers can upstage a roomful of naked women as effortlessly.

President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev signed several constitutional amendments put forward by Parliament, including an exemption for himself from a provision limiting presidents to serving two terms, effectively clearing the way for him to become president for life. Political opposition groups objected to the provision as the beginning of a Soviet-style personality cult for Mr. Nazarbayev, who came to power in 1989 and whose current seven-year term expires in 2012. Mr. Nazarbayev also signed off on constitutional changes that expand Parliament's responsibilities, including a greater role in choosing the prime minister. ILAN GREENBERG

An article on Thursday about a recent migration of Orthodox Jews to Waterbury, Conn., a struggling and heavily Roman Catholic city, misidentified the New York county that is home to the town of Kiryas Joel, another Orthodox enclave. It is Orange, not Rockland.

The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Richard Trank Not rated; 105 minutes The legacy of the concentration camp survivor and Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal is one of unimpeachable bravery, but ''I Have Never Forgotten You,'' a new documentary, is a suspect monument to his courage.

SILVERBERG--Shirley, 87, died peacefully at home May 19th. Beloved wife of the late Stanley Silverberg. Devoted mother of Margaret (Ira) and David (Ronne). Adoring grandmother of Steven, Laura, and Simon. Long time social worker and West Side community activist. We will miss her and love her always. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

An article in Science Times on May 8 about a study showing how meditation affects attention referred incorrectly to one group that was studied. The 17 volunteers who meditated for 10 to 12 hours a day as part of the research did have previous meditation experience; they were not new to meditation.

If you wanted to identify a moviegoing experience that was the utter antithesis of the grungy, sleazy aesthetic memorialized in ''Grindhouse,'' it would have to be a competition screening at the Palais des Festivals in Cannes. And not only because the patrons are more apt to be wearing evening gowns than dirty raincoats. True, a certain grindhouse spirit lives on in the bowels of the Palais, headquarters of the Cannes Film Market, where slasher movies and action pictures with titles that sound like parodies (''Thunder Man,'' ''The Fear Chamber'') are bought for late-night cable and DVD discount bins. But upstairs, where the official selections are screened, an air of reverence and refinement reigns. The idea that a battered, patchily spliced print would be projected with missing reels and tinny sound -- effects painstakingly reproduced by Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguez in ''Grindhouse'' -- is beyond scandalous.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on May 4 about the entry of Merchandise Mart Properties, a Chicago company, into the art business misstated the name of one of the company's buildings in New York. It is the Architects & Designers Building on East 58th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, not the Design & Decoration Building. (A building called the Decoration & Design Building, on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, is owned by the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation.)

''The army and Fatah al Islam would fire on each other, but the bombs and bullets landed on us. We were waiting for death.'' YASMIN ABDEL AIN, on the fighting in a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon. [A12]
A sports article on Saturday about the Cavaliers' victory against the Nets to win their playoff series misstated the age of LeBron James of Cleveland. He is 22, not 24.

Police officers and state wildlife officials set traps yesterday to catch a coyote that bit a 5-year-old boy in the face and neck on Monday night, the second time in two months that a coyote had attacked a child in Middletown. The boy, Brayden Gazette, required 46 stitches and rabies shots. Police officers fired a shotgun at the coyote, but could not tell if they had hit it, said Robert M. Czech, the township administrator. On April 6, a 20-month-old boy was bitten by a coyote in another section of the township, but was not seriously injured. TINA KELLEY

An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged, and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding -- not Heinz Guderian, who had been promoted to another job.

An article in some copies on Saturday about an open house at the Islamic Center of South Jersey in Palmyra, the mosque where four of the six men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix had worshiped, misstated the date of their arrests. It was May 7, not May 10.

A brief article in Science Times yesterday about a study showing that alcohol consumption can lower the risk of one type of kidney cancer misstated the publication date. It appeared in the May 16 issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute; it is not scheduled to be published in the June 16 issue.

Perilla 9 Jones Street (West Fourth Street), Greenwich Village; (212) 929-6868 I don't mean to take anything away from the cooking, but the new restaurant Perilla isn't buzz-buzz-buzzing with stylishly dressed tastemakers because of its roasted octopus with grapefruit, its spicy duck meatballs or its wagyu skirt steak, appealing as they are.
Retsina Elliniko Estiatorio 115 East 60th Street, (212) 486-8826. If the world's unappreciated wines ever gathered to drown their sorrows, the room would grow quiet as retsina told its tale.

KRATZMAN--E. Arthur, M.D., 87, of Freehold, NJ, died May 21, 2007. Surviving are his wife, Alice C. Kratzman and brother, Vincent C. Kratzman of Lahaina, Hawaii. He was predeceased by his first wife, Ruth L. Kratzman in November 1977. Also surviving are sons E.A. Kratzman, III, and his wife, Teresa of Greenwich, CT, and Val A. Kratzman and his wife, Carol of Fairfield, CT; stepchildren, Jane Ettelson and her husband, Charles of Saint Louis, MO, and Thomas O'Brian and his wife, Carolyn of Boulder, CO; and a niece, four grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, May 30th at 11am at Applewood Estates, Freehold. The family requests memorial donations to Applewood Residence Assistance Fund, 1 Applewood Dr., Freehold, NJ 07728 or a charity of choice. Funeral services are under the direction of Freeman Funeral Homes, Freehold, NJ.

Lawmakers endorsed an international adoption protocol under pressure from the United States, which has said it will cease allowing Guatemalan children to be adopted by American parents unless reforms are made in Guatemala's largely privatized system. That system has been heavily criticized by international human rights organizations for the high cost charged to adoptive parents and for payments that are sometimes made to girls and women who are putting their children up for adoption. But real changes will not come until Congress passes a law implementing the requirements of the protocol, called the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption. The treaty calls for counties to set up a central adoption authority, which has been controversial in Guatemala because of the political clout of private attorneys who now manage adoptions. MARC LACEY

TARNOPOL--Mickey. Died 2 years ago today. Adored and beloved husband, father, and grandfather, whose memory is in our hearts forever. We miss you, we love you. Lynne, Lisa, Lori, David and the grandchildren

Viacom and an Indian media company, the TV18 Group, said they would jointly create Viacom-18, a television, film and digital media company. Viacom-18 will start a Hindi-language entertainment channel later this year, and Viacom's MTV Networks, which is already present in India, will become part of the joint venture. Viacom's movie studios, DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, will look for opportunities in India over the next few months, Viacom said. "India is one of Viacom's priority markets for expansion internationally," Philippe P. Dauman, above, the president and chief executive of Viacom, said during a news conference in Mumbai. HEATHER TIMMONS

Jenn Stuczynski, who broke the American record for the women's pole vault Sunday, was added yesterday to the field for the Reebok Grand Prix, scheduled for June 2 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. In the Adidas Classic on Sunday in Carson, Calif., Stuczynski vaulted 15 feet 10 1/2 inches. That was a half-inch higher than the 2004 American record by Stacy Dragila, who had held the record for 11 years. Dragila, who is returning after an Achilles' tendon injury sidelined her last year, will also compete at Ichan Stadium.

A music review on Saturday about a performance of Rameau's ''Castor et Pollux'' at the French Institute Alliance Française in New York, misspelled part of the name of the group that performed. It is L'Opéra Français de New York, not Française.

PYLE--Page Neville, of Short Hills and Mantoloking, NJ, passed away at Overlook Hospital in Summit on May 18, 2007 after a valiant seven year struggle with a rare lymphatic cancer. She was 67 years old. She was born in New York City on December 1, 1939, the third child of Gregg Neville and Natalie Page Neville. Page is survived by her husband, Robert M. Pyle, Jr.; two daughters, Cynthia (Nina) Pyle Furlanetto of Santa Fe, NM, and Laura C. Pyle of Arlington, VA; her sister, Natalie Neville Ferris of Holden, MA, and one grandchild. She was predeceased by her brother, Richard Gregg Neville in 1971. Page attended Spence School in New York City through ninth grade, and graduated from Miss Porter's School (Farmington) in 1957, and Smith College in 1961. She was an active volunteer of the latter two institutions over the years, serving among other positions as a President of the Farmington Alumnae Association of New Jersey and a President of the Smith College Club of the Oranges and Short Hills. Other volunteer positions included the Board of Trustees of the Cora Hartshorn Arboretum in Short Hills in various capacities during a seven year span, and the Short Hills Garden Club, where she was also a Vice President for two years. At her death Page was a member of the Short Hills Club and the Bay Head Yacht Club in New Jersey and the Hillsboro Club in Florida and several local community and civic organizations. Professionally, Page served in the investment consulting field, principally with Scudder, Stevens & Clark and Stein Roe & Farnham for seven years, and thereafter as the first paid Executive Director of the Investment Counsel Association of America for three years, where she established the first office for that organization in New York. At a later time she served for several years as the Adult Program Director of the Cora Hartshorn Arboretum. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 30, at Christ Church in Short Hills (corner of Forest Drive and Highland Avenue) at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Cutaneous Lymphoma Foundation, PO Box 374, Birmingham, MI, 48012; the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, New York, NY 10003; Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT 06032; or Smith College, Northampton, MA 01063.

To the Editor: As an importer and distributor of sherry, I found your headline in the Food Stuff column about Harveys Orange to be stereotypical and misleading: ''An Off-Dry Sherry Good for More Than Helping the Old Folks Nod Off'' (May 16).

There were two wide cardboard boxes stacked on top of each other by the empty locker at the back of the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday. Written on the top box, in red marker, was, ''Attn Rob Cucuzza/Rocket.'' Rob Cucuzza is the Yankees' clubhouse manager. Rocket is Roger Clemens, who is pitching at Class AA Trenton tonight as he nears his return to the Yankees. The Yankees could have used him last night.

SCHAEFER--Sylvia M., May 22, 2007. Loving mother of Faith Drucker and her husband Howard, Jill and her husband Ken Iscol, and Beth and her husband Victor Sperber. Cherished grandmother of Amy, Adam, Zachary, Kiva, Melysa, and Kimberly, and great-grandmother of Jacob. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service, Wednesday, May 23rd, 5PM at Frank E. Campell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. $(6$)SCHAEFER--Sylvia (nee Friedman), died surrounded by her treasured daughters and many family members on Tuesday May 22 after a valiant struggle to live. Sylvia was born in Hell's Kitchen to Hettie and Abe Friedman on April 30, 1921. She graduated from Hunter High School and attended New York University. She married Milton Weinick in 1941 and together they had three daughters; Faith, Jill and Beth. Known for her beauty, vitality, wisdom, warmth and flair, she was happiest dispensing her infinite insights to her ''girls'', their friends and later to their families. She was predeceased by her husbands, Dr. Herman Wolf and Dr. Harry Schaefer, and her beloved brother, Jack Friedman. She will be enormously missed by her loving children, Faith and Howard Drucker, Jill and Ken Iscol, Beth and Victor Sperber, her adored grandchildren, Amy Drucker and Niall Washburn, Adam Drucker, Zachary and Kiva Iscol, Melysa Sperber and Ryan Epp, Kimberly Sperber, and her cherished great - grandson, Jacob Harkins, as well as her nephew Mark Friedman and his family and her niece, Eve Fox and her family. She would want her loving care givers and friends, Lucy Barbosa, Elena Leon, and Renee and Peter Pardy to know how much she loved them and appreciated there loving and devoted care these last years. You will live on in our hearts forever.

To the Editor: Re ''Principals Act in Plan to Reduce Bureaucracy'' (news article, May 18): Does anyone really believe that Chancellor Joel I. Klein and the Bloomberg administration's school reorganization is going to do anything but replace one unwieldy bureaucracy with another?

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Bush and Democrats Near Deal on Iraq Spending Bill Congressional Democrats relented on their insistence that a war spending measure set a date for withdrawing American combat troops from Iraq and moved toward a deal with President Bush that would instead impose new conditions on the Iraqi government. A1 A soldier in the unit searching for three of its members captured in Iraq this month was killed by a homemade landmine, a reflection of the changing dynamic the soldiers face in an area with unique terrain and a fresh set of American tactics devised to secure it. A1 Russian Accused in Poisoning The British authorities accused a Russian businessman, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of murdering Alexander V. Litvinenko, left, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin poisoned six months ago in London with a radioactive isotope, polonium 210. A3 Bomb Kills 6 in Turkish Capital A powerful explosion tore into a shopping district in Ankara, Turkey, killing six people and wounding more than 70, Turkish officials said. A8 Iran Denies Access to Scholar Swiss diplomats seeking to visit Haleh Esfandiari, a prominent Iranian-American academic jailed in Iran, have not been given access to her, the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars said. A3 NATIONAL A14-20 Rise in Mexican Consulates Extends Aid Nationwide The Mexican government is following its citizens far from the border into the growing quarters of Latino migration. Since 2000, consulates have opened in places where immigration from Mexico has soared, including St. Paul, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Mo., Omaha and Raleigh, N.C. A1 A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test, as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year. A20 Democrats Face Resistance As House Democratic leaders try to push through lobbying reforms, they are facing resistance from balky lawmakers and embarrassing accusations that a prominent member flouted new ethics rules. A1 Test for Antimissile System With Congress considering cuts in the Pentagon's budget for missile defenses and Europe on edge over Bush administration proposals to deploy the system to the continent, much is riding on a test scheduled in the next few days of the antimissile shield based in California and Alaska. A17 Debate on Emission Rules Officials from California demanded that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation. They threatened to sue if the government did not allow them to go forward. A19 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Student Test Scores Climb in New York State The number of eighth graders reading at grade level or above in New York State climbed this year for the first time since 1999, according to scores released from the annual statewide English exam. The results marked the most clear-cut gains in a year in which students in all tested grades, third through eighth, demonstrated better reading ability. A1 Hybrid Cabs for New York? Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed replacing the Ford Crown Victoria, long the vehicle of the city's yellow-cab fleet, with cleaner, more fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles within five years. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Push to Disclose Drug Data Clinical data posted online by GlaxoSmithKline led to the analysis that found its diabetes drug Avandia posed a heightened cardiac risk. Now some medical experts want lawmakers to require makers of drugs and medical devices to publicly disclose study results. C1 Rehabbing Home Depot After Home Depot's hasty annual meeting last year was described as ''appalling'' and ''arrogant,'' the company has taken pains to strike a warmer, inviting tone at its coming meeting. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Propping up the general; the Hollow Promise Reform Act; shifting Madison Square Garden; Verlyn Klinkenborg on California wildfires. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman and Maureen Dowd. Crossword E2 Obituaries A21 TV Listings E7 Weather C12

A man charged with the murder of two women whose remains were found inside sealed barrels on March 31 died on Saturday, four days after being taken to the Erie County Medical Center for a mental health evaluation, the Erie County Sheriff's Office said yesterday. Hours before he was stricken on May 15, the man, Robert J. Henchen, 42, of Colden, pleaded not guilty to charges of killing Geraldine Jackson, 87, and Nancy Phelps, 69, both of whom disappeared months before their remains were found. According to his lawyer, Mr. Henchen suffered ''a cardiac incident.'' But the cause of his death remained under investigation yesterday, the Sheriff's Department said. He had been hospitalized because of odd behavior, including refusal to wear clothes, at the Erie County jail, said Undersheriff Richard T. Donovan. DAVID STABA

PATT--Arthur M., July 7, 1917May 13, 2007. Graduate of Louisiana State University, served with OSS/SO in WWII, joined Schering Corp 1946, retired 1975 as Vice President/ GM of the Australasia Division. Preceded in death by beloved wife, Helen C. Patt. Mourned by those who know.

In Lebanon, Reminders Of Its Own Bloody Past Sniper fire and mortars echoed in the Nahr al Bared refugee camp and bodies lay in streets through three days of fighting, providing reminders of Lebanon's bloody past. Warnings from Palestinian groups elsewhere raised fears that the fighting could further shake the Siniora government. The Giants, who lost place-kicker Jay Feely to free agency in March, traded a conditional draft choice to the Kansas City Chiefs for kicker Lawrence Tynes. Tynes, 29, has scored at least 100 points in each of his three N.F.L. seasons. He has made 68 of 87 field-goal attempts, and his longest conversion is 53 yards. Tynes will compete for the job with Josh Huston, 25, who has no N.F.L. regular-season experience. The Giants released the rookie kicker Marc Hickok.

To the Editor: ''Macho Mistakes at Ground Zero'' (editorial, May 22) did not mention one key point. While the actions of then Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani certainly make him and New York City culpable for endangering ground zero workers and others, the ultimate responsibility lies squarely with the federal government.

Manny Pacquiao, a championship superfeatherweight from the Philippines, took his first defeat in more than two years. This one was outside the ring. Pacquiao, who was running for a congressional seat in his home country, conceded defeat Sunday, nearly a week after election day. Pacquiao trailed the incumbent, Darlene Antonino-Custodio, by a sizable margin. Pacquiao, who has a record of 44-3-2, will shift his focus back to boxing.

SCHULMAN--Lawrence. On Monday, May 21, 2007. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of Daniel and Stewart and daughter-in-law Suzanne. A dynamic but gentle man and a devoted friend. Service on Thursday, noon, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

OSMAN--Beatrice (Skoblow) on May 19th, 2007. Loving wife of late Albert Osman, devoted and cherished mother, sister, aunt, cousin and friend. Survived by her children Norman Osman and Dr. Ellen Richter, Gayle Lopata, Iris and Steven Meier. She will be missed, and always remembered.

To the Editor: Re ''Playing the Hand We've Dealt'' (column, May 20): Not mentioned in Thomas L. Friedman's proposal for the United States to engage Hamas in a dialogue is any responsibility of the terror organization and its Iranian sponsor to come forward with a solution for peace and stability in the region.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Ido Haar In Arabic and Hebrew, with English subtitles Not rated; 78 minutes In ''9 Star Hotel,'' the Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar draws us into the precarious world of young Palestinian construction workers scrabbling to survive in and around the Israeli city of Modiin. Irregularly and illegally employed, the men hide in the wooded hills above the city, sleeping in shelters made from scraps of Sheetrock and constantly on the alert for Israeli security forces.

KIMMEL--Dana Spector, died on May 22, 2007. Beloved wife of Scott. Devoted mother of Jack, David, and Lily. Loving daughter of Joseph and Janet Spector, and daughter-in-law of Louis Kimmel and the late Charlotte. Dearest sister of Douglas Spector and Lisa Rothkrug. Services Thursday, 9:30am at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Rd. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. $(6$)KIMMEL--Dana. Temple Beth' El of Great Neck record with profound sorrow the tragic and untimely passing of our dear member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her entire family. Nina Koppelman, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

A man charged with operating on animals without a license was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to probation and mandatory psychiatric treatment. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching surgery on a Boston terrier. His case drew worldwide publicity for the involvement of a so-called undercover cat named Fred, used in a sting operation by the district attorney's office. Mr. Vassall was sentenced after pleading guilty to scheming to defraud and to the unauthorized practice of veterinary medicine. Under the terms of a plea bargain, he must attend an outpatient mental health program five days a week and refrain from involvement in nursing or animal care. MICHAEL BRICK

UPON accepting an invitation to a barbecue several years ago, I asked the hostess if I could bring anything. ''Sure,'' she said. ''How about spinach dip? It's easy and everyone loves it.'' I agreed and then quickly hung up the phone, not wanting to betray the fact that not everyone loves spinach dip. Some people even abhor it. Namely me.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Andrei Zagdansky Not rated; 72 minutes In the documentary ''Orange Winter'' orange blooms throughout Kiev, Ukraine, the epicenter of dissent over that country's stolen 2004 presidential elections. Outraged Ukrainians adopted the color that winter to express support for the pro-Western presidential candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, who was poisoned with dioxin by unknown enemies to protect his establishment-supported rival, Viktor F. Yanukovich.

The state police yesterday suspended the head of the troopers' union, Detective David Jones, for five days because he revealed a radio talk show host's personal details to reporters this month, the union announced. The suspension came after an investigation by the state attorney general. On May 3, Detective Jones showed reporters a piece of paper containing the home address of the host, Craig Carton -- half of the team known as the Jersey Guys -- along with Mr. Carton's license plate number and the make and model of his car, the investigation found. The detective's actions came after Mr. Carton and his co-host disclosed Web postings by state troopers that threatened a ''ticket blitz'' in response to criticism of troopers' role in a car crash involving Gov. Jon S. Corzine in April. Mr. Jones did not use law enforcement databases to obtain Mr. Carton's information, according to the attorney general's office. KAREEM FAHIM
DURANDO--Isabella, Happy Birthday. We miss you. Nanna and Papa John.

A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test on Tuesday as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year. If the guest worker program, part of the ''grand bargain'' negotiated with the Bush administration by a bipartisan group of 12 senators, had been stripped from the bill, the fragile deal could have collapsed.

CAVAGLIERI--Giorgio, was a great figure in his adopted city. An elegant, energetic and talented architect, he was admired and engaged by the leading figures of his time, Bob Moses, Joe Papp, and the Villages led by Margot Gayle who saved the Jefferson Market Courthouse. As a refugee from fascism, he was active in civic debates where his passion and candor might have been inconvenient attributes in a less courtly figure. Giorgio served the Municipal Art Society for half a century as a trustee, president and a clear-headed voice of conscience. It's hard to imagine New York without him. Municipal Art Society of New York.

An article last Wednesday about criticism of the Food and Drug Administration's efforts to protect food safety misstated the agency's explanation for the cause of a recent contamination outbreak. It believes melamine, a chemical used in fertilizers and plastics that has tainted pet food and animal feed, was in wheat flour imported from China -- not in wheat gluten or rice protein. (The agency's initial assessment was based on the fact that the flour was mislabeled as wheat gluten or rice protein.)

A Jamaica man has been charged with holding an acquaintance captive in his family's garage and sexually assaulting her, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Joseph Burrell, 44, of 171st Street, was arraigned last weekend on charges of attempted rape, criminal sexual acts and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Burrell lured a 42-year-old woman to his family's furnished garage by inviting her to a barbecue last Wednesday and attacked her, beating her and smashing a glass object on her, then tried to rape and sodomize her.

Addison and Christopher B. Mailman of New York and Matthew D. Addison of Los Angeles, CA; grandmother of five. Funeral services to be announced, interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Pen American Center, 588 Broadway, Suite 303, New York, NY 10012 or The North Shore Alliance, 151 Post Road, Old Westbury, NY 11568 would be appreciated.
