BURDE--Helene, on May 21, 2007, in Sarasota, FL. Born in Providence, RI, she was beautiful, gracious, loving, funny, strong and wise. Her concern was for others. She lived most of her adult life in Bridgeport, CT, and Boynton Beach, FL. She was married to Eli Burde for 69 years until his death in 2004. One of life's greatest partnerships. Mrs. Burde is survived by her devoted family, Brenda Burde and Paulette Lipton, Ronald and Sharon Burde, grandchildren, Howard and Evelyn, Brad and Jeffrey Burde, great-grandchildren, Ariel, Simone and Jed Burde, a sister Frances Robbins, nephews Victor and Richard Robbins (Lori Heller) and Albert (Sonia) Guelblum, Kobi (Polly) Kanchuk. Services Friday, May 25, at 3:00pm from The Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd, Fairfield, CT. Shiva Sunday, 4:00-8:00pm at Abbie Marks, 2211 Broadway, NYC, Monday, 2:00pm at Burde, 100 Ocean Pkwy, Brooklyn. Memorial contributions to American Jewish World Service, 45 W 36th St, 11th Floor, NY, NY 10018, or to The Jewish Home for the Elderly, 175 Jefferson St, Fairfield, CT 06825.

The authorities dismissed five mine safety officials for allowing a Siberian coal mine to ''break safety rules for the benefit of profit,'' an action they said led to an explosion in March that killed 108 miners, the biggest mine disaster in Russia's recent history. An investigation showed that the mine's managers deliberately disabled a methane gas detector. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The dismissals, reported by the Interfax news agency, were an exception to the usual blanket impunity enjoyed by government officials. ANDREW E. KRAMER

WALLERSTEIN--Harold, on May 22, 2007. Beloved brother of Ruth Samuel, dear uncle of Robin and Eric Twerdahl and Sandi A. Weiner. Funeral services Thursday, May 24, 1pm at ''Schwartz Bros. -Jeffer'', Queens Blvd and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY. Donations may be made to The Reform Temple of Forest Hills.

Alison Nelson, above, who opened the Chocolate Bar in Greenwich Village five years ago, has added another location, her third, in the Henri Bendel store on Fifth Avenue (56th Street). This airy cafe on the third floor, done in blue, chocolate-brown and ivory, has a bar, banquette seating and a table on the balcony. Boxes of chocolate bars and truffles line the shelves. Ms. Nelson set out her truffles on a display table just before the store opened for business on Monday.

The season finale of NBC's ''Heroes'' not only posted Monday's highest ratings, it also even overshadowed the two-hour finale of Fox's ''24.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Heroes'' led the 9 p.m. hour with 13.2 million viewers, earning 50 percent higher ratings among adults 18 to 49 than ''24'' in that hour. Meanwhile, the sixth-season conclusion of ''24'' attracted 10.2 million total viewers from 8 to 10. It also faced formidable competition in the 8 p.m. hour from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' (19.7 million), the night's most-watched show. ABC edged out NBC to win the night over all, while Fox finished third among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

It was a bad night to be one of the N.B.A.'s worst teams. The league held its draft lottery Tuesday, and the three teams that finished with the worst records were bumped out of the draft's top spots. The Portland Trail Blazers, who had the sixth-worst record, won the No. 1 pick and will have the chance to take Ohio State center Greg Oden or Texas forward Kevin Durant. Scouts rate both players as future stars, the kind who can change a franchise's fortunes.

GROSS--David Alan, on May 7, 2007. Jazz Saxophonist. Beloved husband of Nancy, loving brother of Lesley and Janie. Memorial Services Saturday June 2, 2007, 10:30am12:30pm at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC, call 212-674-8055

I'M sure you know how to make a burger. But do you make a burger you love, one that people notice, one that draws raves? In a world where ''burger'' most often means a thin piece of meat whose flavor is overwhelmed by ketchup, mustard, pickle or onion, it doesn't take much effort to make a better one. In fact, it's almost as easy to cook a really great burger as it is to cook a mediocre one.

A picture in Weekend on Friday with an article about the fall prime-time schedules for Fox and CW was published in error. It showed a scene from ''Supernatural,'' which will be entering its third season on CW -- not ''Reaper,'' a new show on that network.

CRISCI-SANTANA--Anne, 76, died suddenly on May 16 at her home in Boca Raton. She is survived by Elisa, Christopher, and Maria, her children; Alex, her grandson; and Alfred, her brother. A mass will be offered on June 1 at 11am at St. Joan of Arc Church in Boca. The family requests only individual private prayers.

Miriam Novalle's grandest T Salon opens today in the Chelsea Market, adding to her collection, which now numbers three. Sweeping banks of bamboo shelves hold 240 teas in canisters. Above counters made of concrete, tinted ocher with tea, hang balloon-like light fixtures made of tea bags, getting a pre-opening adjustment, above. A circular dispenser behind the bar has spigots for 18 blends of iced tea.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about spousal rights, gave an incorrect name for the federal office that tallied the number of rights and responsibilities connected to marriage. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the Government Accounting Office.

A brief article in Science Times on May 1 about research on migraines and mental decline referred incorrectly to the subjects of the study. The researchers looked at men and women, not just women. In addition, among the approximately 1,400 subjects studied over 12 years, more than 200 of them had a history of migraines -- not about 20 of them.

FITZGIBBON--Sally, age 94, died of natural causes on May 19, 2007. Her husband, Les, died in 2003. She is survived by her daughter Sally Kjellgren, her son Herb, and her especially beloved grandson Christopher. She was a friend to all and will be greatly missed by those who loved her.
KAPLAN--Murray. Heartfelt condolences to Janet and John Rodgers on the loss of Janet's most remarkable father. Susan Zises Green

To the Editor: Re ''Death by Veganism,'' by Nina Planck (Op-Ed, May 21): I am a nutritionist who testified as an expert witness for the prosecution in the criminal trial of the parents of Crown Shakur. As the lead prosecutor in this case told the jury, this poor infant was not killed by a vegan diet. He was starved to death by parents who did not give him breast milk, soy-based infant formula or enough food of any kind.

Switzerland will return $6.2 million next month that it seized in bank accounts of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, Swiss officials said. A large part of the money is to be given to Haiti for humanitarian projects. The officials said the remainder would be returned to Mr. Duvalier, who was overthrown in 1986 and lives in exile in France. JOHN TAGLIABUE

REILLY--Martin W., 69, retired writer. Beloved husband of Dinah; father of Colin and Maura; brother of Mary; dear uncle of several nieces and nephews, died on May 20th of cancer. He was predeceased by brothers John, James, Gerard and Francis. His intelligence, dry wit and kindness made his company a delight to all whom he touched. Friends received at Collins Funeral Home in Norwalk, CT, on May 24th, 5-8pm. A mass of Christian Burial will take place at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Wilton, CT, May 25th at 10:30 am.
Restaurant Sorrel 605 Carlton Avenue (St. Mark's Avenue), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 622-1190. Sometimes what seems like a bargain is too good to be true; other times you walk away happy.
CHAIFETZ--Charlotte. 22 years have passed. Alan is now with you. You are both forever in our thoughts, years do not lessen our love for you. Son Barry, daughters-inlaw Maureen and Lynn.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine Quinn announced a new effort yesterday aimed at improving poor New Yorkers' access to healthful food. With a $500,000 grant from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, city officials are bringing together public and private groups to recommend ways to increase healthful eating and physical activity. In addition, the Human Resources Administration, the city's welfare agency, is expanding a pilot program that allows food stamp offices to process electronic applications taken at food pantries and soup kitchens. Two organizations in Queens will be added to the program, with Manhattan groups to follow, city officials said. DIANE CARDWELL
Julia Preston reports on a nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll addressing immigration reform.

If anyone had doubts about how far the Chinese women have come, they are being dispelled at the First Women's Team Championship in Yekaterinburg, Russia. After five rounds, the Chinese women lead with 9 points out of a possible 10 (two points are awarded for a victory, one for a tie), followed by Russia with 8 and the Ukraine with 7. The tournament began on May 19 and runs through May 30. The official Web site is here.

The game-time temperature here was 79 degrees. There's hardly a cloud in the sky. And on the field are the top two teams in the National League East, only one and a half games separating them, and two of the best pitchers of this era, Tom Glavine and John Smoltz, are pitching. Glavine is five victories from 300, and Smoltz can notch No. 200 tonight. And yet I can see sections on the lower bowl that have a handful of fans, and the upper decks aren't much better.
A performance by Le Musiche Quartet at Carnegie Hall, as part of the Emerson String Quartet Young Artists Concert.
A performance from the Jasper String Quartet as part of the Juilliard String Quartet recital.
A performance from the Calder Quartet as part of the Juilliard String Quartet recital.

After weeks of private negotiations with the Senate and the Assembly, Gov. Eliot Spitzer this afternoon released his version of legislation to bring more oversight and accountability to the state's hundreds of public authorities.
A home video -- made for The New York Times Magazine -- of Judd Apatow and Seth Rogen, the director and the star of "Knocked Up."

The story of Madeleine McCann, the British three-year-old kidnapped from her resort apartment during a family vacation in Portugal, has obsessed the British public and media for the past three weeks. "Harry Potter" author J.K. Rowling, Simon Cowell from "American Idol" and Virgin founder Richard Branson have offered rewards for her return; a findmadeleine.com Web site has received over 65 million hits; Madeleine's aunt, Philomena McCann, has reported more than 2,000 responses to a chain e-mail appeal she sent out internationally in the hopes of increasing the odds of a chance sighting of her niece.

A major rethinking of the legacy of Robert Moses is under way, fueled by a three-part exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, the Queens Museum of Art and Columbia University and a collection of scholarly essays by the Columbia scholars Hilary Ballon and Kenneth T. Jackson. (The three exhibitions have a rich joint Web site.)

WASHINGTON - More than three decades ago, Nixon White House Counsel John Dean called the Watergate cover-up "a cancer on the presidency." Another one exists today, posing a challenge for the next president to restore the office as a credible voice in foreign policy.
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
The Times's Caryn James visits a multimedia exhibition at Grand Central Terminal devoted to films set in the city.
Alix Browne reports on The Wrong Store, a tiny storefront shop in Chelsea featuring limited edition objects by artists and designers.

The morning and afternoon practice sessions of one and a half hours each were, in Monaco, yet more proof for me that Formula One should be outlawing test sessions on circuits where races will happen any time within a few weeks after the test. Formula One cars had not driven in Monaco since the race last year - obviously, since this is a street circuit and they will not close down Monaco for an F1 practice session in, say, February.

It was the show everybody in Washington had been waiting for: the testimony of the former Justice Department official Monica Goodling before the House committee investigating the United States attorney firings. So, was it worth wait? The blog consensus: in terms of new information, no; but in terms of political theater, you betcha.
Representative Ron Paul held a press conference in Washington today to "educate Rudy Giuliani on foreign policy." The intended student, not surprisingly, was absent.

There's more encouraging scientific news on the use of marijuana to alleviate pain: a study has shown that effective doses of cannabis can be delivered with vaporizers, which enable patients to get the therapeutic benefits without inhaling harmful smoke. Meanwhile, though, researchers are still struggling against their biggest bureaucratic obstacle, the Drug Enforcement Administration.
Place du Marché Saint Honoré is a picturesque market square in central Paris filled with terrasse-style restaurants with tables that spill into the paving-stones of the street.

The unofficial, unconfirmed list of Paul D. Wolfowitz successors got a little more interesting, with The Wall Street Journal putting a shiny star next to the name of Bill Frist, the former Senate majority leader.

The headlines today say that new home sales leaped in April. The reality is not quite as good. The increase reported in partly a matter of seasonal adjustments, and may reflect price-cutting as well. The average and median sales prices were down substantially. The seasonally adjusted annual rate rose from 844,000 sales to 981,000. But actual monthly sales rose by just 12,000, to 92,000.

The political pressure to make life easier for small companies has culminated this week in a new, watered-down auditing standard on internal controls. The good news is that it will cut costs and that the efforts to exempt such companies from any audits on controls have failed.
More than 7,000 votes came in to TV.com, a television fan site, in answer to this question: What was the biggest shock when the networks presented their new fall seasons at the upfronts this year?
The first step to solving a problem is recognizing that you have one.

Shareholder resistance is growing, in some cases at least, to take-private offers. (Just ask the folks trying to buy radio giant Clear Channel Communications.) Enter the lawyers at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who are offering some advice on how buyout firms can counter that growing resistance. Many of the suggestions, in the law firm's latest Private Equity Alert newsletter, are surely standard practice for buyout shoppers: Do due diligence, know who the big stockholders are, etc. But some points in the article -- fittingly titled "The Great Pushback" -- bear highlighting.

The heart of London turned bucolic overnight when its tourism department laid 20,000 square feet of turf in Trafalgar Square. The wall-to-wall job took about 40 tons of sod from northern England, which was rolled out in about 3-foot wide strips, The London Times reported.
When you move to New York City, as I did six years ago, people tell you about the high price of real estate, parking and martinis. No one ever mentions rental cars.
Elina Furman attempted to ignore Jay Landauer, but his persistence eventually won her over.

If you are having trouble telling the difference between hedge funds and investment banks these days, the latest ranking from Alpha magazine probably won't help. In a further sign of how deeply Wall Street firms are getting into the hedge-fund business, the hedge fund arms of two bulge-bracket banks, J.P. Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have the No. 1 and No. 2 positions on Alpha's annual list of the biggest hedge funds. Top-ranked J.P. Morgan has $33 billion in hedge fund assets, putting it just above last year's winner, Goldman, which oversees $32.5 billion.
A place that served as a constant in Graham Greene's restless existence.
Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the war began, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

Another player has stepped into the brawl over the baseball card maker Topps, which agreed in March to be acquired by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn and Tornante, the investment vehicle of former chief executive of Disney, Michael Eisner. The new pitch is coming from Upper Deck, a rival baseball card company, which is offering $10.75 a share in cash for Topps -- 10 percent more than the Madison Dearborn team's $9.75-per-share bid, which had a value of $385 million. Three Topps directors are bitterly opposed to the latter offer, calling it too low, and have urged shareholders to reject it at a June 28 vote.

The Danaher Corporation said Thursday it had agreed to buy ChemTreat, a water treatment products and services provider, for $435 million. ChemTreat, based in Glen Allen, Va., had more than $200 million in revenue in its most recent fiscal year. The company focuses on boiler, cooling water and industrial waste water applications.

Internet addicts are making use of Google maps to meet their every whim -- even to track house prices. For example, people are flocking to www.estateangels.co.uk/house_prices, which displays the cheapest and priciest places to buy a house in Britain using heat maps. At the same time, www.londonlandgrab.com allows you to buy your favorite landmark or other property in a virtual London.
McDonald's has opened a campaign in Britain to pressure the Oxford English Dictionary to redefine "McJobs" in a more positive light.

This week's announcement that the introduction of Home Information Packs in Britain would be delayed by two months until Aug. 1 has prompted a collective sigh of exasperation today. (See post below for more info)

Despite his spectacular career, Roger Federer is still missing a French Open trophy. That could change in the next few weeks. But, it makes us wonder: Can someone who hasn't won all four major championships be considered the sport's greatest player ever?

The Toronto-Dominion Bank said Thursday its profit rose 19 percent in the second quarter, helped by a strong performance in all business lines except its retail banking in the United States. Toronto Dominion said it earned 879 million Canadian dollars ($814 million), or 1.20 Canadian dollars a share, up from 738 million Canadian dollars, or 1.01 Canadian dollars a share, a year earlier.

New York State spent $14,119 per student - more than any other state in the nation -- in the 2005 fiscal year, according to a national analysis of public school spending that the Census Bureau released today.

The brokerage firm Merrill Lynch & Company said Thursday it would take a non-controlling stake in a private investment firm, Sterling Stamos Capital Management. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Is a bidding war looming for Bausch & Lomb?
Conducting market research without leaving the house.
Dune opens another branch in Dallas, Zaha Hadid's utensils, baskets out of old newspapers and more.
MapLight.org is a new Web site that correlated lawmakers' voting records with the money they've accepted from special-interest groups.

Congestion pricing is strongly supported by most Manhattan voters and opposed in roughly equal measure by voters in New York City's four other boroughs, according to results of a survey of city voters that Quinnipiac University released this morning.

For the sake of the tourism industry, the identities of hill tribes living in northern Thailand have been distilled into the singular term "long-neck." (Or, for the many French visitors, "giraffe women"). Taxi drivers and tour operators offer trips to see the "long-necks" without any other explanation: most cabbies will drive the 30 kilometers north from Chiang Mai, wait an hour for you and drive back to town for about 400-500 baht. (I'm sure that visitors who spend more effort than we did can find even better deals.)

A Dow Jones & Company director, Christopher Bancroft, an influential member of the family that controls the publishing company, said in an interview that he opposes a sale to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. His comments to The Wall Street Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, came after some members of the Bancroft family met Wednesday in Boston to consider the $5 billion offer.
With “Bug,” William Friedkin continues to be more fascinated by the evil inside our heads than the boogeyman outside.

Bill Richardson, the governor of a heavily Hispanic state who would be the first Hispanic to serve in the White House if elected, is the first Democratic candidate to come out against the new immigration bill in the Senate, but he's reticent to be defined by the issue. The Times's Adam Nagourney takes a serious look at the New Mexican's history on the matter and where he stands today:

Imperium Renewables, a Seattle-based biodiesel company, is seeking to raise up to $345 million from a public stock offering to finance a major expansion into the fast-growing alternative-energy market.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new guidelines on Wednesday that try to balance the need for tighter financial controls with the cost of complying with them. It said the new procedures will make it less costly for smaller companies to assess the state of their internal financial controls.

Duff & Phelps, a financial advisory firm and investment bank, said it plans to raise up to $200 million in an initial public offering of stock on the New York Stock Exchange. The New York-based firm has grown through a series of acquisitions in recent years, including the purchase of Standard & Poor's Corporate Value Consulting business in 2005 and Chanin Capital Partners, a boutique investment bank with a large restructuring practice, in 2006.
The world's billionaire ranks became a little more crowded on Wednesday with the listing in Hong Kong of China's leading retailer of ladies footwear.
The chairman of the Senate's antitrust subcommittee has urged regulators to block Sirius Satellite Radio's proposed acquisition of XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

French financial regulators are questioning leading executives at European Aeronautic Defense and Space, including the co-chairman, Arnaud Lagardère, as part of an investigation into possible insider trading at the parent company of Airbus, Le Monde reported Wednesday.

Google is closing in on an agreement to acquire Feedburner, a provider of Web content syndication tools, for about $100 million in cash, according to TechCrunch, which cited an unnamed source close to the deal. The technology blog, which first broke the news that Google would buy YouTube, said the Feedburner deal is expected to close in two to three weeks, and that "there is nothing that can really derail it at this point." Feedburner, founded in 2003, has raised $10 million in venture capital from Portage Ventures, Mobius Venture Capital and Union Square Ventures.

A ruling by a federal appeals court yesterday could jeopardize a criminal case against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG - a case that has been cited by prosecutors as the showpiece of a broad investigation into the sale of questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes.

Coca-Cola's president, Muhtar Kent, declined to comment Wednesday on speculation that the beverage giant might buy Glaceau, a maker of "enhanced water" drinks, but said his company was open to making acquisitions. "There are some rumors in the marketplace always about us acquiring certain companies," Mr. Kent told reporters attending grand opening events in Atlanta for the new World of Coca-Cola attraction. "We do not comment on rumor and that's all I can say."

The private equity firm Corvus Capital, controlled by the financier Andrew Regan, ruled itself out of the running for EMI Group, the British music group, yesterday, following a report in The New York Post that the company was preparing a rival bid in conjunction with a former EMI executive, Jim Fifield.
Biker coffee tables, scary pillow and one very comfortable chair all at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair.

Alcoa said that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian company's rejection of the offer. But Alcoa's chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate.

Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier.

The Nasdaq Stock Market plans to offer venture capitalists and other private equity players a new avenue to liquidity when it rolls out a computerized trading platform intended to market private placements to institutional investors, such as mutual funds and pension funds, The Red Herring reported.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital Management had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCE's largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid.

Merrill Lynch employees may be looking a bit paler than usual this summer. That is because the investment bank has slashed the number of sick days that United States employees can take without consequences each year to three days from 40 -- an amount that had been unusually generous by American standards -- apparently in an effort to keep its bankers, traders and other workers from skipping off for long weekends at the Hamptons.

Circuit City Stores, whose shares are at their lowest level in more than two years, is one of the most-attractive leveraged buyout candidates in the hardline retailing sector, several analysts say. Its stock has fallen below that $17 buyout offer from a Boston hedge fund that Circuit City rejected in 2005.

Australia's Qantas Airways, recently the target of a failed $9 billion takeover bid, said Thursday it might split off some businesses or return billions of dollars to shareholders. Qantas told investors that as part of a "demerger" plan it was considering, it was reviewing options for its frequent flyer program and might sell its express freight joint venture and other operations.

Parmalat, the Italian food giant that filed for bankruptcy in 2003, said Wednesday that New Jersey's highest court rejected Citigroup's attempt to dismiss its $10 billion lawsuit accusing the bank of helping former management commit fraud. Parmalat, a major producer of milk, said the state supreme court rejected Citigroup's appeal on the grounds that Parmalat brought the case in the wrong court.

Harris Bank, Chicago's third-largest bank, reported a 4 percent decline in second-quarter earnings partly as a result of competition. But the bank said it expects takeover upheaval at the city's No. 2 bank, the LaSalle Bank, to help increase its business and said it is already trying to position itself for the inevitable shakeout.

Qwest Communications International's shareholders have rejected three proposals that would have given them more influence in decisions about executive compensation. At the company's annual meeting Tuesday, its chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, was peppered with questions about salaries and bonuses, including his own, and cuts or caps in benefits for about 49,000 retirees across Qwest's 14-state territory.

Bisys Group, a financial-services provider that recently agreed to be acquired by Citigroup, said Wednesday it would pay $25 million to settle regulators' accusations that it had violated financial reporting rules to inflate earnings by $180 million over three years. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement with Bisys, which was consistent with a tentative agreement that the company and the agency's enforcement staff negotiated in November.

The British government ordered the country's competition regulator Thursday to hold a full inquiry into British Sky Broadcasting's purchase of a stake in broadcaster ITV. The Associated Press noted that the order for the Competition Commission investigation marks the first major test of the influence held over the British media by Rupert Murdoch, BSkyB's chairman and largest stockholder.

A former secretary at Coca-Cola was sentenced Wednesday to eight years in prison for conspiring to steal trade secrets from the company, as her tearful plea for mercy failed to sway a federal judge. Judge J. Owen Forrester of Federal District Court told the former secretary, Joya Williams, 42, that he was giving her a longer sentence than recommended by federal prosecutors and sentencing guidelines because "this is the kind of offense that cannot be tolerated in our society."

General Motors has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday. It also announced plans to replace $1.1 billion in convertible securities with new ones with a later maturity date. After the announcement, Fitch Ratings cut its debt rating for G.M. deeper into junk territory, citing increased leverage from new financing efforts. Separately, G.M. said it received a new request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting practices.

The fight between Daniel Loeb's hedge fund, Third Point, and PDL BioPharma, a drug development company, escalated this week as Mr. Loeb, known for his poison-pen letters to some of the companies in which he invests, released a letter to "unconflicted directors of PDL", urging them to oust L. Patrick Gage, the company's chairman.
American warships moved up New York Harbor to open the city's 20th annual Fleet Week observance, followed by a week of fun in the city for sailors and marines.
Life doesn’t always imitate art. But sometimes it comes surprisingly close.

The British government is considering selling commercial broadcaster Channel 4 to raise up to 1 billion pounds after Gordon Brown becomes prime minister, according to The Times of London. Treasury officials in Britain are weighing economic and political arguments for privatizing the government-owned channel, even though the Labor party manifesto is committed to keeping Channel 4 in public ownership, according to the report.

Amazon.com announced Wednesday its acquisition of an audio-book publisher, Brilliance Audio, in a move to tighten its tie with book publishers and expand the number of audio-book titles it sells. Amazon is seeking to expand beyond offering only best-sellers under an audio-book format. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Hewlett-Packard, the computer maker, put to rest one aspect of the spying scandal that rocked its boardroom last year as it settled an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into how it disclosed the resignation of Thomas Perkins, a prominent venture capitalist, from its board. Though the settlement came with no financial or other penalty, the S.E.C. said it found that Hewlett-Packard "failed to disclose the reasons for his resignation as required by federal securities laws" after Mr. Perkins left the board in May 2006 because of his objection to an internal investigation into leaks to the press. Hewlett consented to an order that it stop violations of disclosure provisions, but did not admit or deny the commission's findings.
The musical “In the Heights” announced plans for a Broadway transfer next season.
Images from "Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era" at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
“Innocent,” the new legal drama on BBC America tonight, makes a fairly good case for the idea that British lawyers simply have a lot more fun than their counterparts here.

Gas prices are spiking again - to an average of $3.22 a gallon, and close to $4 a gallon in many areas - and some oil executives are now warning that the current shortages of fuel could become a long-term problem, leading to stubbornly higher prices at the pump.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
New shows in New York include "Silverland," "Gaslight" and "Cirkus Inferno."
“At World’s End” is the third and perhaps final episode in the swishy, swashbuckling “Pirates of the Caribbean” saga.
The measure does not set a timetable to withdraw U.S. troops but requires the Iraqi government to meet a series of benchmarks.
Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the war began, according to the latest  Times/CBS News poll.
The measure would raise the minimum wage to $7.25 an hour from $5.15 in stages over two years.
The State University of New York has nominated John B. Clark to be the interim chancellor of its 64-campus system starting June 1.
The president said he had directed the secretary of state to work with Europeans to '‘develop further sanctions.’'
Senate Democrats drew up a resolution declaring that they have no confidence in the attorney general.
The Irish voted today on whether Prime Minister Bertie Ahern would receive a third successive term after 10 years in office.
The explosion opened fresh wounds in a community scarred by an accident two months ago that claimed more than 100 lives.
Americans want to allow illegal immigrants to gain legal status and to create a new guest worker program, according to the latest  Times/CBS News Poll.
Israel also mounted new air attacks in Gaza today as part of its efforts to stop rocket fire by Palestinian militants.
A suicide bomber drove into a crowd gathering for a funeral procession in Falluja, killing at least 27 people.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) — The General Motors Corporation has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday.
Wednesday’s game against the Yankees was the worst start of the season for Schilling since opening day, when he gave up five runs in four innings in a 7-1 loss to Kansas City.
The Cuban leader gave no indication of when he might show up again in public or resume leadership of Cuba’s Communist government.
The Mets have defeated the Braves three times this season and the team will leave Atlanta atop the National League East.
The Yankees are far behind the Red Sox in the American League East, but Andy Pettitte gave his team the kind of outing they needed and the hitters finally supported him.
Jordin Sparks, a teenager from Glendale, Ariz., won the sixth “American Idol” singing contest last night in a live finale from Los Angeles.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s public service announcement promoting seat belt use will be made available for broadcast nationally beginning today, the governor’s office announced. Both radio and television versions of the message are being released. Mr. Corzine, who was not wearing a seat belt when he was critically injured in a car crash on April 12, taped the announcements on May 15.
Pitching for the Trenton Thunder, the Yankees’ Class AA affiliate, Roger Clemens gave up three runs in five and a third innings.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he would start negotiations over next year’s budget in November, two months earlier than is traditional in Albany, arguing that an early start would allow more of the talks to be public and minimize the last-minute horse trading that has hampered the budget process in the past.

The Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the bank said. Record mutual fund sales and rising demand for loans contributed to a 24 percent increase in consumer banking profit, countering the commodities losses, which were related to natural gas trading. The bank said on May 17 that it would report a pretax trading loss of 680 million Canadian dollars. Bank of Montreal said profit was 1.31 Canadian dollars a share excluding the trading loss and other one-time items, an increase of 3.1 percent from a year ago. Revenue in the quarter, which ended April 30, rose 2.7 percent, to 2.57 billion Canadian dollars from 2.5 billion Canadian dollars.

Export growth slowed in April as shipments to the United States fell for the first time in more than two years. Exports overall grew 8.3 percent, slowing from 10.3 percent growth in March, the Ministry of Finance said in a report. Shipments to the United States fell 4.8 percent, after growing 2.4 percent the previous month. The slowest growth in four years in the United States, destination of a fifth of Japanese exports, led to reduced demand for automobiles and electronics. Japan’s trade surplus in April rose 51.8 percent, to 926.7 billion yen ($7.6 billion).

The new head of PSA Peugeot-Citroën, the French automaker, detailed a major turnaround plan to restore the company’s sagging profitability, and said he hoped for results this year. “We’re going to fight so that in 2007 we start climbing back up the slope as regards our earnings,” the new chief, Christian Streiff, left, told reporters before the annual shareholder meeting. The four-year recovery plan includes an effort to bring down costs, to bolster weak sales through the introduction of fresh vehicles, and to improve quality and customer service. Peugeot-Citroën recently announced a plan to reduce its work force in France by 4,800 employees this year, offering incentives to avoid forced layoffs.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCE’s largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts have formed a rival group that may make a bid potentially worth about $45 billion.

The aluminum producer Alcoa said in a statement that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian company’s rejection of the offer. But Alcoa’s chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate. “We have studied Alcan’s response and have not seen anything that would lead us to re-evaluate our offer,” Mr. Belda said. He also rejected suggestions by Alcan that Alcoa would have difficulty obtaining antitrust approval for the merger and urged Alcan’s board to resume its examination of the bid.

The Chevron Corporation said it had restored normal production levels at its Pennington oil fields in Nigeria after a militant attack forced the company to cut output earlier this month. Chevron shut off 15,000 barrels a day on May 1 from its offshore Funiwa oil field, which is connected to the Pennington export terminal, after the kidnapping of foreign oil workers by militants.

The Lenovo Group, the personal computer maker, said its profit rose more than 600 percent in its latest fiscal year as it increased sales and restructured after its acquisition of I.B.M.’s PC unit. Profits were $161 million for the year, up from $22 million in the prior year. The Americas operations returned to profitability in the fourth quarter, meaning that all the global regions were profitable for the first time, the chief executive, William J. Amelio, said. Sales for the year, which ended March 31, rose 9.9 percent, to $14.6 billion, helped by strong sales of laptop and desktop computers in its home China market, Lenovo said. The company said its worldwide market share rose 0.2 percentage points, to 7.4 percent.

The European Parliament voted to impose retail price caps on roaming charges, fees that mobile phone consumers pay when making or receiving calls outside of their home calling zones. The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax.

An obituary on Tuesday about the historian Eugen Weber, a leading authority on modern France, referred incorrectly to his book “La Fin des Terroirs.” The book (its full title is “La Fin des Terroirs: La Modernisation de la France Rurale — 1870-1914”) is a French translation of Mr. Weber’s book “Peasants Into Frenchmen: the Modernization of Rural France — 1870-1914.” It is not a separate book.

A schedule note in The Arts on Tuesday with a music review of the pianist Ursula Oppens, at Arium on Little West 12th Street in the West Village, included outdated information from Arium about the next performance there. The recital by Julia Sakharova, violinist, and Natalia Lavrova, pianist, will take place at a date to be determined — not Sunday. The next concert at Arium will be on June 3, with the cellist Diliana Momtchilova and the pianist Vassily Primakov.

An article Tuesday about Steel Winds, a wind farm rising on a former toxic waste site in the Rust Belt city of Lackawanna, N.Y., included incorrect information from the project manager about the power capacity of the eight wind turbines that have been built so far. They can produce 56,000 megawatt-hours of electricity per year, not 20 megawatts per year.

An article on Tuesday about a federal civil rights lawsuit charging that the New York Fire Department’s entrance exam is biased against blacks and Hispanics misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic firefighters in the fire department of another large city, Philadelphia. It is 31 percent, not “more than 40 percent.” (The New York department is 4.5 percent Hispanic and 3 percent black.).

An article on Monday about a $3.5 billion development planned for Stamford, Conn., that is part of the city’s efforts to remain a financial center in the New York region misstated ridership statistics for the Metro-North Railroad. Because of the rise of Stamford and other suburban cities as corporate hubs, Grand Central Terminal is now the final destination of fewer than half the riders at all times — not those on weekday mornings. (During the morning rush, the final destination of most riders is still Grand Central.).

A White House Memo article on Friday, about the last joint appearance by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain at the White House, misstated the name of the medal Mr. Blair was awarded in 2003. It was the Congressional Gold Medal, not the Congressional Medal of Honor.

A map with a front-page article on Monday about a clash between Lebanese troops and Islamic militants at a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon misidentified the city shown south of Beirut, the capital. It is Sidon — not Tyre, which is about 25 miles south of Sidon. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/world/middleeast.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the health care industry’s perception of Michael Moore’s new movie, “Sicko,” misstated the educational affiliation of Elizabeth Teisberg, the co-author of a recent book, “Redefining Health Care.” She is an associate professor at the Darden School of Business at the University of Virginia, not an economist at Stanford University.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about a free folk music series on Governors Island this summer erroneously included a deceased singer among the performers. The concert called “Harry Chapin: A Celebration in Song” will be performed by friends and family members of Mr. Chapin, who died in 1981.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 16 about clashes in Gaza between the military wing of Hamas and forces loyal to Hamas’s rival, Fatah, misidentified the affiliation of seven men who were killed in a jeep and whose weapons were stolen in the attack. They were members of the pro-Fatah National Security Forces, not the Presidential Guard.

An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding, not Heinz Guderian. Because of an editing error, a correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the command Guderian held before a promotion. It was the Second Panzer Division — not the Second SS Panzer Division, which he never commanded.
Corrections: For the Record

An article last Thursday about concerns in Congress over broadcasts of Islamic militant views by Al Hurra, an American government-financed television network in the Middle East, referred incorrectly to the timing of the appointment of the network’s new vice president for news, Larry Register. Mr. Register was already on the job when Al Hurra broadcast a speech by Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, in December; he was not hired to make sure such broadcasts did not recur. The article also misstated the length of Sheik Nasrallah’s broadcast speech; it was 67 minutes, not 30 minutes.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 23 — From his base on a work site underneath the Goethals Bridge, a member of the Gambino crime family gained influence in the affairs of two state unions, ran gambling rings in northern New Jersey and New York and collected a salary from a no-show construction job, prosecutors said yesterday.
The Bisys Group agreed to pay $25 million in restitution to settle accusations that it had violated financial reporting rules in a way that inflated earnings by $180 million over three years.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry published on its Web site an unflattering account of the remote new capital of its ally Myanmar, suggesting that Chinese diplomats might be resisting relocating there. The military government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, relocated its capital from leafy, colonial-era Yangon to Naypyidaw, 200 miles north, in 2005. The Chinese account described an airport whose only building is a VIP terminal, six small hotels, one public hospital and no cellphone reception. “They are also in the process of building four golf courses,” the article dryly noted. It was interspersed with pictures of deserted new roads, lonely government buildings and an empty patch of land earmarked for the new embassy district. “To set up a thriving city in this patch of land will doubtless be a serious test for the government,” it said. “Considering the relatively backward national development level of Myanmar, building such an enormous project will need a lot of time and hard work.”.

The Interior Ministry said it had begun a criminal investigation into allegations that President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev’s son-in-law, Rakhat Aliev, left, who is also the ambassador to Austria, kidnapped and beat two officers of the Kazakh bank Nurbank as part of a real estate and stock extortion scheme. Mr. Aliev’s wife, Dariga Nazarbayeva, is a high-profile member of Parliament often mentioned as a possible successor to her father. Kazakhstan has a highly capitalized banking sector; several of its larger banks recently held lucrative public stock offerings in London.

A dividing wall for a planned factory collapsed on people sitting in an adjacent bar in the southern town of Tirupur during a heavy evening rain, killing 27 of them. The police said most of those killed were laborers.

A 14-year-old student was killed in a high school shooting in north Toronto, the police said. Students and teachers were locked in classrooms for hours while the police searched for a suspect, but no arrests were immediately made. The police released few other details. The last school shooting in Canada was in September, when a gunman entered a Montreal junior college and killed one student and wounded 19 others before he died from police gunfire.

Madame Tussauds in London unveiled a new environmentally friendly wax figure of Prince Charles to reflect his efforts on climate change. Workers updated a 1989 figure of the prince with 82 pounds of organic beeswax, artists used organic pigments for the color, and sculptors worked only with their hands and in daylight to cut down on electricity usage.

In a widening corruption scandal, the sixth to strike the government of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva since he took office in 2003, the minister of mines and energy, Silas Rondeau, resigned. Citing wiretapping and videotape evidence, the police say he accepted a $50,000 bribe from a construction company in return for preferential treatment in the awarding of contracts for a rural electric program.

Japan passed a law to finance the reorganization of American forces in the country and help move thousands of marines from Okinawa to the United States territory of Guam. Japan is to pay $6 billion for the transfer of troops, while Washington is to contribute $4 billion. Under the legislation, local governments will receive financial rewards if they are willing to be hosts for United States troops.

President Traian Basescu was reinstated after he won a referendum on impeachment on Saturday. The Constitutional Court ratified the results — with 74.4 percent of voters rejecting Parliament’s proposal to remove him after it had suspended him. A brief ceremony was held in pouring rain at Cotroceni Palace in Bucharest.
The Cuban-born mayor of West New York, N.J., has announced that this year’s Cuban Parade of New Jersey will not be allowed to pass through his town.
Keyshawn Johnson, who played a great game and talked one as well during an 11-year career, retired yesterday despite several offers to continue playing.

A Far Rockaway man has been convicted of raping a woman in 1999 after a sample of his DNA, taken in an unrelated case, matched a sample from the crime, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Santiago Lugo, 45, of Beach 32nd Street, was convicted of rape in State Supreme Court on Tuesday, prosecutors said. Mr. Lugo, a former salesman, grabbed a 23-year-old woman as she walked home from work on the night of March 3, 1999, forcing her to accompany him to an isolated spot and raping her, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney.

New Jersey lawmakers subpoenaed MySpace.com, the online social networking site popular with teenagers, yesterday to obtain information about convicted sex offenders who used the site. MySpace agreed on Monday to provide states with e-mail and Internet addresses of sex offenders, bowing to requests from attorneys general in eight states who had pressured the company to disclose the information. Late last year, in an effort to crack down on sex offenders who use the site, MySpace hired a company to compare the records of its 175 million members with public records of sex offenders. Officials said about 7,000 profiles had been removed as a result. (AP).

The number of children in New Jersey without health insurance increased 37 percent from 2000 to 2005, compared with a 9 percent decrease nationwide, according to a study released yesterday by New Jersey Policy Perspective, a group that monitors state issues. The increase was greatest for black and Hispanic children. It came even though New Jersey spends about $1 billion annually on a program called FamilyCare that covers 530,000 children. The governor’s budget proposal calls for providing health insurance to 68,000 more children next year.

Police officers pulled two workers from a building that partly collapsed yesterday, police and fire officials said. The workers, whose names were not disclosed by the police, were inside the three-story building, at 51 Woodhull Street in Red Hook, when the second floor collapsed, pushing the first floor into the basement and trapping the workers, the police said. Officers from the Emergency Services Unit entered the building and rescued the workers, who had back and leg injuries. The workers were taken to hospitals, the police said. The Buildings Department said the collapse was caused by demolition work.

A group of the city’s most powerful women gathered outside City Hall yesterday to promote regular breast cancer screening through mammograms, whose use has been steadily decreasing. The group, which included First Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; and the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, announced a public awareness campaign, assisted by Macy’s, to inform women about how and when to schedule exams. Ms. Harris said fewer women were receiving regular mammograms than in the past. According to a study recently published in the medical journal Cancer, the decline could be a result of a shortage of available testing, questions about the effectiveness of the exam and higher patient co-payments.

The Connecticut House of Representatives, after six hours of debate that touched on many lawmakers’ own experiences with debilitating illnesses, approved a bill yesterday that would legalize the medical use of marijuana for some patients. The legislation would allow a doctor to certify that an adult patient’s use of marijuana was for medicinal purposes after determining that the patient had a debilitating condition and could benefit from it. Supporters said the bill was needed to provide legal protection to people who use marijuana to alleviate the pain of diseases like cancer and multiple sclerosis. The bill now moves to the Senate, where a similar bill passed in 2005. That bill then failed in the House. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The state’s chief administrative judge, who is in charge of the daily operation of the state courts, will become the presiding judge of the state appellate court based in Manhattan, Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday. The judge, Jonathan Lippman, above, has served as chief administrative judge for 11 years and has been a key deputy to Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye. He will become presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the First Judicial Department.

A millionaire couple accused of keeping two Indonesian women as slaves in their Long Island home have been indicted on federal charges of forced labor and harboring illegal residents, prosecutors said yesterday. The couple, Varsha Mahender Sabhnani, and her husband, Mahender Murlidhar Sabhnani, who operate a perfume business from their home, were arrested last week after one servant was found wandering outside a doughnut shop. They were indicted on Tuesday and are to be arraigned today. Prosecutors said the two servants were beaten, had scalding water thrown on them and were held against their will. Charles A. Ross, Mrs. Sabhnani’s lawyer, said that the couple traveled extensively and that the two servants were free to leave whenever they wished.

An inmate at Rikers Island was arraigned yesterday on charges that he tried to arrange the murder of a 31-year-old Queens woman who is scheduled to testify against him, prosecutors said. The inmate, Ashumba Bryan, 29, of Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Bryan is awaiting trial on charges of attacking and robbing the woman in October 2005 — beating her and throwing her out of her moving car, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said Mr. Bryan was captured on audiotape in April trying to arrange the woman’s murder for $10,000 to prevent her from testifying.

The chief of personnel for New York City’s Police Department warned yesterday that there might be even fewer recruits for the Police Academy class in January than there are for this summer’s already diminished class because of the low starting pay.
For many smaller businesses, having messages blocked or shuttled into a spam folder can mean lost revenue.
“The Sidewalk Cafe Drink Mix-Off” began far from the cocktail hour Wednesday.
Some executives warn that current fuel shortages could become a long-term problem, leading to higher gas prices.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,418 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:.
The Bush administration failed to achieve an increase in the ownership ceilings that the Chinese impose on joint ventures with American firms, officials said.
Sergei B. Ivanov, a leading contender to succeed President Vladimir V. Putin, criticized a landmark Soviet-United States arms treaty as a “relic of the cold war.”
In a speech on Wednesday, President Bush invoked the Vietnam analogy and argued that withdrawing from Iraq would be dangerous for the United States.
A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter seven years ago that warned of the heart risks of the drug Avandia.
Alex Rodriguez’s controversial play on Tuesday is one of several run-ins he’s had with the Red Sox since joining the Yankees four years ago.
Monica M. Goodling said she had “crossed the line” in considering the political beliefs of job applicants.
Iraqi police officials said the body was partly clothed in a U.S. military uniform.
Gov. Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, has weathered the crosscurrents of the immigration battle.
French President Nicolas Sarkozy’s trip to Brussels, just one week after taking office, suggests that he is eager to swiftly end the European Union’s institutional paralysis.

Fannie Lee Chaney became a target of racial hatred herself after her son James Chaney and two other civil rights workers were murdered by the Ku Klux Klan in Mississippi during the Freedom Summer of 1964.

Lornah Kiplagat of the Netherlands, who has won the New York Mini 10-kilometer run in Central Park three times, will return for this year’s race June 9. The New York Road Runners also announced yesterday that the field would include such world-class runners as Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, Benita Johnson of Australia, Mara Yamauchi of Britain and Nina Rillstone of New Zealand.

The family of Bryan Pata, the University of Miami player who was fatally shot last November, will get $2 million from the insurance companies of the apartment complex where he was murdered, family lawyers said. Pata was shot outside The Colony Apartment in Kendall, Fla., on Nov. 7. The apartment complex did not provide the 24-hour security it had advertised, and several outdoor lights were obscured or not working, particularly where the shooting took place, said the family’s lawyers.
To the Editor:.

Billy Donovan, who coached the Florida men’s team to its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title last month, and Pat Summitt, who coached the Tennessee women to their seventh title in her 33 years on the job, received the annual Winged Foot Awards last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club. The award is given annually to the coaches of the men’s and women’s N.C.A.A. basketball champions, and Summitt may return next season. She lost only two seniors, and she kept the 6-foot-4 Candace Parker, probably the best player in the women’s game. The Volunteers also have one of the strongest recruiting classes in the nation with Angie Bjorklund, a 6-1 guard-forward from Spokane, Wash.; Kelley Cain, a 6-6 center from Atlanta; Vicki Baugh, a 6-4 forward-center from Sacramento; and Sydney Smallbone, a 6-0 guard from South Bend, Ind. “We have a chance to be a very good team next year,” Summitt said at a news conference. Donovan, however, said: “We’re very young. We’re starting over. We lose our top six players.” Four of those six were underclassmen who have declared for the N.B.A. draft.
The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, met with Prime Minister Ismail Haniya of Hamas to try to secure a cease-fire between their factions.
It could be a month or more before arbitrators decide whether Floyd Landis used synthetic testosterone during his victory in last year’s Tour de France.
The agreement ends a three-year effort to account for the damage done by a single bullet fired by a police officer in Brooklyn.
The Bush administration said it would encourage European and Asian allies to seek a major expansion of sanctions against Tehran.
A jury rejected the defense claim that Peter Braunstein was delusional and so mentally ill that he lacked the intent to commit a crime.
The House has approved an overdue remedy that would strengthen whistle-blower protection and the penalties for retaliators.
The decision could have a broad impact on how New York City deals with other Sept. 11 illnesses.
The prospect that many Democrats would be left on the losing side in a consequential vote on the Iraq spending bill has exposed a sharp divide within the Democratic Party.
A late goal from Liverpool wasn’t enough as the Italian team won the European Champions League, avenging its defeat by the England side in the 2005 final.

An aide to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had argued that time and money could be better invested elsewhere.
The deal ends a long legal battle and ensures that $4.55 billion will be available to rebuild the site.
Since the year 2000, when President Vladimir Putin was first elected, at least 14 journalists have been murdered because of their work. None of these murders have been solved.

The Connecticut State Senate set a welcome national example with a bill that would move 16- and 17-year-old offenders out of the adult courts and back into the juvenile justice system where they belong.

The Yankees all but closed a maddening chapter of their recent history yesterday by admitting that Carl Pavano has probably thrown his last pitch for the team.
Monetary policy experts have started putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India to stem the rupee’s rise.

Following are excerpts from the statement by Monica M. Goodling, former Justice Department counsel and White House liaison aide, and answers to questions by Representatives F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. and Elton Gallegly to the House Judiciary Committee yesterday, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc.:.
About 3,000 members of the Navy and the marines will have time off to play in the city. Some plan to see family.
Magglio Ordóñez had his 20th two-homer game last night as the host Detroit Tigers defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 8-7, and snapped their six-game winning streak.
Kian Tajbakhsh, an Iranian-American consultant working for the Open Society Institute, was detained in Iran in the latest detention of an American citizen.
It was the first time Delgado started a game and batted that low in the order since May 14, 1997, when he played with Toronto.
Beijing is trying to position itself as a space benefactor to countries whose natural resources it covets here on earth.
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays held Elijah Dukes out of the lineup Wednesday after a published report said his estranged wife sought a restraining order against him.
Target, the No. 2 discount chain behind Wal-Mart Stores, said profit rose to $651 million, or 75 cents a share, from $554 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.
Government officials and airline executives said they hoped weather delays could be minimized by software innovations.
An attacker riding a motorbike blew himself up close to members of the Afghan Border Police who were guarding a road construction project in eastern Kabul.
Hewlett-Packard broke federal laws when it did not tell investors why a director had abruptly resigned during an inquiry into boardroom leaks last year.
Two former paramilitary police officers were sentenced to 40 years in prison for their roles in a killing widely seen as damaging to the fragile reform process in Serbia.
Shareholders of Qwest Communications International have rejected three proposals that would have given them more influence in decisions about executive compensation.
The Sons of Saad Afifi, the most popular sugar cane shop in Cairo, embodies what the city was in simpler times, and what it is becoming in modern times.
A severance package the nominee was to receive from the National Association of Manufacturers had been at issue.
A Michigan-based retail chain is offering to alert drivers about a pending price increase at its gasoline stations by sending text messages to their cellphones.
Microsoft said Wednesday that it did not need to buy Yahoo to gain scale in online advertising, because it had “all the pieces” to build a successful ad business.
The falcons, four of them chicks, are in a specially built nesting box sitting atop the Queens tower of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

Michigan, which is trying to close an $803 million deficit in this year’s budget, has informed state employee labor unions of possible layoffs, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm said. The state has 53,000 employees, with 38,058 represented by unions, the spokeswoman said.

The president of the State Senate was arrested on drunken-driving charges hours after gaveling the 2007 session to a close. The lawmaker, Senator James P. Metzen, was stopped early Tuesday after an officer observed him weaving in his lane, said the police in South St. Paul. Mr. Metzen faces two misdemeanor charges, including fourth-degree driving while impaired. Mr. Metzen, 61, is a seven-term Democrat from South St. Paul. In a letter to the Senate majority leader, Mr. Metzen apologized “for my lapse in judgment.”.

A sharply divided appeals court threw out the death sentence of a woman convicted of killing her newborn son. The court upheld the woman’s conviction, but it said prosecutors misstated to jurors her likelihood of being a future danger to society. The 5-to-4 ruling from the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals in Houston means the woman, Kenisha Berry, will serve a life term for the 1998 smothering death of 4-day-old Malachi, who was found abandoned and bound with duct tape in a trash bin. The case went unsolved for five years until Ms. Berry was identified as the mother of a newborn girl found alive but abandoned and covered with fire ants in a ditch in 2003. She consented to DNA testing that confirmed she also was the mother of the boy.

A former soldier was sentenced to 30 years in federal prison for sexually abusing five female soldiers in their barracks at Fort Hood and in Iraq. The defendant, Clenard M. Simmons, 26, pleaded guilty on April 5 to four counts of abusive sexual contact and one count of aggravated sexual abuse for five attacks from February 2004 to May 2005. Prosecutors said Mr. Simmons attacked the soldiers in their barracks, groping and threatening them. He was discharged from the Army in May 2005.

A panda at the Memphis Zoo is pregnant, zoo officials said. Ya Ya, a giant panda, above right, was artificially inseminated in January after she and a male failed at mating. Since then, the zoo has closely monitored her. “I’m excited, but I’m also cautious because we have a long way to go before the birth,” said Chuck Brady, the zoo’s president. Panda pregnancies cannot be confirmed until shortly before the delivery date. Gestation lasts about 133 days, which means Ya Ya, who is 6, could give birth soon. She and a male panda, 8-year-old Le Le, are on loan to the zoo from China. Pandas are notoriously poor breeders, one reason the species is endangered, and females have only three days a year in which they can conceive.
Emissions of carbon dioxide from fuel burned in the United States dropped 1.3 percent in 2006 compared with an all-time peak reached the year before.

Foul weather in Alaska has prompted the Pentagon to delay, until tomorrow at the earliest, a test of the new missile defense system, military officials said. The system can operate in all weather in a wartime environment, but safety rules governing tests require that the target missile, to be launched from Kodiak Island, be visible to monitors who can push a destruct button if it veers off course.

California’s economy could sputter over the next two decades because not enough college-educated workers are moving in, and the state cannot graduate current residents fast enough, according to a new report. California needs to nearly triple the number of highly skilled immigrants who arrive every year from other states and countries. If it fails, it will not meet the 20-year benchmarks set by the California Department of Transportation in 2005, reported the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. The state will need at least 8.3 million college-educated workers by 2025 to maintain its current growth rates. That is 3.2 million short of what it will have in 18 years if the state’s immigration and graduation rates remain constant.
The new guidelines are part of an effort to make compliance on accounting less costly for small companies.
Japan’s once vaunted electronics industry has downsized to survive global competition, and is inadvertently setting off a brain drain.
Stocks wilted as comments from Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, and worries about coming economic data deflated a rally fed by takeover activity.
The Philadelphia Daily News named Mark Frisby as its publisher on Wednesday.
Turkish authorities said they had identified the suicide bomber in an attack on Tuesday in Ankara as a man from a predominantly Kurdish city.
Some Boston Red Sox players are sporting a different sort of foot garment: a five-toed sock that fits like a glove popularized by the team’s two new Japanese pitchers.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi defended the “grand bargain,” which has come under heavy fire from the right and the left.
As many as 3,000 people erupted in violence over measures to impose tighter family planning controls in a rural part of the Guangxi autonomous region in China.
The Kiwis were pleased to get a tough contest from their Spanish opponents, taking the best-of-nine Louis Vuitton Cup semifinals, 5-2.
Before planting and harvest time in the United States, it has been common for local recruiters to fan out across Mexico’s parched countryside to sign up guest workers.
The State Senate transportation committee recommended that the Senate not pass a bill requiring adults to wear seat belts.
It was the first time in Britain that suspects under a form of house arrest known as control orders had been identified publicly.
The Rockets had their best record in a decade last season, but lost in the first round of the playoffs. That’s something new head  coach Rick Adelman hopes to change.
About 15,000 Palestinians left the Nahr al Bared refugee camp as the Lebanese Army reinforced its vow to crush a militant Palestinian group inside.

Sinn Fein, the political affiliate of the Irish Republican Army, is hoping to gain seats in the government in the elections on Thursday.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (Reuters) — The business software maker CA Inc. predicted fiscal 2008 results below average Wall Street targets, sending its shares down more than 6 percent on Wednesday.
Criticized in Latin America for his recent comments about the conversion of native populations, Pope Benedict XVI softened his earlier words in a speech on Wednesday.

Pierre-Gilles de Gennes was an expert on the boundary lines between order and disorder in materials like liquid crystals and polymers.

Mary Cheney delivered an 8-pound, 6-ounce boy on Wednesday, the first child for her and her partner of 15 years, Heather Poe.

Iran has failed to engage diplomatically with the United States and Europe, and the jailing of Haleh Esfandiari is a case in point.
Conor Oberst — the heartthrob singer-songwriter better known as Bright Eyes — begins a weeklong, sold-out stand at Town Hall tomorrow.
Kimberly Dozier, a CBS News correspondent who was nearly killed last year by a bomb in Iraq, is finally telling her own story in a CBS special called “Flashpoint.”

Like Hollywood starlets, smartphones are becoming thinner and thinner. The Palm Treo 755p is less than an inch thick and has a 320-pixel-square color touch screen.

Lar Lubovitch’s “Othello,” a full-length ballet from 1997, calls to mind an anguished line from that Shakespeare tragedy: “O heavens forfend!”

9 P.M. (VH1) VH1 ROCK HONORS We salute you! In its second year this awards ceremony honors the golden oldies Genesis; Heart; Ozzy Osbourne, right; and ZZ Top, who prove it’s not over yet in performances at the Mandalay Bay Resort in Las Vegas. Alice in Chains, Queens of the Stone Age, Keane, Nickelback and Gretchen Wilson pay tribute in renditions of the honorees’ hits. Bam Margera of “Jackass” infamy is host.

WHEN Michelle Slatalla began writing the Online Shopper column seven years ago, the Internet was a relative novelty and shopping was the beachhead for many users. Now almost every chapter of family life has an online component. In the Slatalla household, husband and wife live in I.M. windows on each other’s screens. The family stores its photos, vacation itineraries and tax records online. Their youngest daughter, 9, cavorts with friends in the virtual universe Club Penguin. Their oldest, 18, has been offered a summer job thanks to videos she posted on YouTube. Starting today, Ms. Slatalla’s column is acquiring a new name, Cyberfamilias, and a broader scope: the changing landscape of family life under the influence of the Net. It will appear every other week.

JOHNNY G’s original Spinning program includes five moves: standing flat, which means standing on the pedals and slightly increasing the resistance; seated flat, which means pedaling during warm-up and cool down; seated climb, which means sitting on the bike with an elevated resistance; standing climb, which means standing out of the saddle with resistance even higher; and jumps, which means moving up and out of the seat.

So, Major League Baseball, in its current truth and candor phase, wants to finally dig into the seedy depths of its Steroid Era and reveal who injected what, when they did so and in what dosages. Right. Let’s review the current Jason Giambi tempest for what it is: baseball business as usual, which is to say, cynicism as usual.

Q. The lilies of the valley I planted beside my driveway have been wonderful for many years. But recently they jumped to the flower beds and now they’re everywhere. Could I control them without harming other plants by repeatedly cutting the leaves to deprive the roots of nourishment?
Russian mining company OAO Norilsk Nickel on Wednesday raised its bid offer for Canadian gold and nickel producer LionOre to $6.27 billion.
The Target Corporation said today its quarterly profit rose almost 18 percent, helped by its credit card business and strong sales at established stores.
Many urban men are tangled up in fashion knots over whether they should wear shorts to work in the summer.

How do college athletes hurt themselves? For 25 years, researchers with the N.C.A.A. have quietly been compiling data on that subject. This week, with the publication of a special issue of the Journal of Athletic Training, the information is being made public for the first time. Some of the findings are predictable: college baseball players get banged up while sliding, and basketball often causes ankle and knee injuries. But others are eye-opening: female ice hockey players, for instance, sustain almost as many concussions as men, even though they (supposedly) aren’t allowed to body check.“This report should lead to investigations of rule changes or equipment modifications” that would increase player safety, says Randall W. Dick, associate director of research for the N.C.A.A. In the meantime, it makes for revelatory, if wince-inducing reading, with its repeated descriptions of sprains, strains, concussions,

Since it erupted in 2004, Mount St. Helens has been largely closed to all but volcanologists. But this summer, the now sleeping giant is open to anyone with enough enthusiasm to climb it — and enough good sense to reserve a spot well in advance. From now through October, only 100 hikers per day are allowed on Mount St. Helens; permits are available online only — and on a first-come, first-served basis — for $22. The route takes from seven-to-12 hours round-trip, and gains 4,500 feet over five miles to the 8,365-foot high crater rim, into which climbers can peer. Though the hike requires no ropes or crampons, expect to wear hard hats and dust masks, as the mountain still belches. You can hike on your own (with a permit) or with a guide; Oregon Peak Adventures offers day trips from $150 per person, including permits, transportation and food.

Yotam Halperin’s bid to become the first Israeli player in the N.B.A., as described in the October 2006 issue of PLAY, has remained in limbo since he returned to Israel and his team there, Maccabi Tel Aviv. The news media’s attention on his N.B.A. quest wore on him, his agent says, and he struggled through the first half of the season in the Israeli league. But in the second half he turned things around and led Tel Aviv to the playoffs, where the team is still alive. The Seattle SuperSonics chose Halperin in the second round of the 2006 draft and still own his N.B.A. rights, but will likely not make a decision about his future until June, according to the agent, Jason Levien. How does Halperin view a potential future in the N.B.A.? “There was so much media hype and attention about him playing in the N.B.A. that he is not talking to the media about it right now,” Levien said. “He just doesn’t want to talk about it.”.
Opening Ceremony in Manhattan introduces its shoe collection that includes suede, canvas and leather jazz shoe styles for men and women.
Determined brides have found one way to cut corners by trying to get in shape for less than $20.
American officials began talks with China to reduce economic tensions but ran into familiar disagreements and new concerns over food safety.
Three new services from Google, Yahoo and Teleflip can forward e-mail to ordinary cellphones.
Warren Buffett may have fallen into one of the biggest mutual fund traps of all — forgetting how incentives affect fund managers’ behavior.
A.C. Milan won the European Cup perhaps because Coach Carlo Ancelotti didn’t take the advice of the team’s owner, former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.
George Steinbrenner should never even consider embarrassing Joe Torre by firing him next week or next month, if only because Torre has never embarrassed him.
Sarah Jessica Parker joins Madonna and Kate Moss, among others, as the latest media star to affix her name to a cheap-chic fashion brand.
The Senate narrowly rejected two proposals today that would have upset the delicate compromise embodied in a bipartisan bill to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws.

We don’t much talk about getting more control over our lives in nursing homes. And that’s a problem.
