THE guests of House & Home were not the only ones assessing the work on display at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair. As usual, a panel of design magazine editors — this year there were 11, from Britain, France, Italy, Canada and the United States — gave out their own awards. (Interestingly, there was little overlap between their picks and those of the impromptu critics.) At right, from top to bottom, are some of the winners of the 2007 Editors Awards.
Some doctors balk at silicone F.D.A. guidelines, saying they are bureaucratic and unscientific.

Decorate your home with irony at Future Perfect, the up-to-the-moment furniture and design store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

Cannes to See Film On Poisoned K.G.B. Agent In the climax to three weeks of secrecy, a documentary film about the poisoned former K.G.B. agent Alexander V. Litvinenko will have its world premiere on Saturday as an entry in the Cannes Film Festival, The Associated Press reported. Andrei Nekrasov, right, a friend of Mr. Litvinenko's who directed the film, ''Rebellion: The Litvinenko Case,'' said, ''I wanted to make a documentary which goes beyond information, and which looks deeper into people's motives, without which we will never understand why he was killed.'' On Tuesday British authorities accused a Russian businessman, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of using a radioactive isotope, polonium 210, to murder Mr. Litvinenko, 43, a foe of the Kremlin, in London in November. Mr. Lugovoi proclaimed his innocence. Mr. Litvinenko, on his deathbed, accused President Vladimir V. Putin of responsibility for the poisoning, a charge the Kremlin dismissed as ridiculous. Mr. Nekrasov said the organizers of the festival had made the decision to keep his film a secret. ''I can't say the reason was political pressure,'' he said. ''They do this sort of surprise screening sometimes.'' Italian Groups Protest Streisand Ticket Prices Italian consumer groups, incensed by ticket prices of $200 to $1,200, are urging the authorities to cancel a concert by Barbra Streisand, below, scheduled for the 24,000-seat Stadio Flaminio in Rome on June 15, The Associated Press reported. In an appeal to the City of Rome, which owns the stadium, and the Italian Olympic Committee, which manages it, the consumer groups Adusbef and Codacons called the ticket prices ''absurd and shameful.'' Their statement said the stadium was ''public property and cannot be used for immoral deals that are shameful to a civilized country.'' Concert organizers were not immediately available for comment. The performance in Rome, at the start of Ms. Streisand's European tour, would be her first in Italy. Tickets for her London shows in July, also with a top price of $1,200, sold out within minutes this month, organizers said. Literature by the Byte ''Moby-Dick'' is being served up in bite-size pieces by a new Web site that specializes in classic literature delivered in easy-to-digest installments, Reuters reported. The snippets, sent every day by Daily Lit (dailylit.com) to subscribers' hand-held devices or e-mail accounts, are intended to be read in less than five minutes. Jules Verne's ''Around the World in 80 Days'' would arrive in 82 parts, and Tolstoy's ''Anna Karenina'' would unfold in 430. ''Our audience includes people like us, who spend hours each day on e-mail but can't find the time to read a book,'' said Albert Wenger, a founder of the site. So far, he said, 50,000 people have signed up, and since the site's 370 or so titles, mostly classics, are out of copyright, they are offered free. But in a few weeks DailyLit plans to expand and charge for newer titles. ''We're looking to charge under $5 per title,'' said Mr. Wenger's wife and the site's co-founder, Susan Danziger. Through a deal with DailyLit, Berlitz will soon be offering five-minute language lessons.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the health care industry's perception of Michael Moore's new movie, ''Sicko,'' misstated the educational affiliation of Elizabeth Teisberg, the co-author of a recent book, ''Redefining Health Care.'' She is an associate professor at the Darden School of Business at the University of Virginia, not an economist at Stanford University.

Before the final game of a three-game series between the Red Sox and the Yankees last night, the umpires' crew chief, Joe West, quietly met with both teams' managers. He apparently did not want an errant elbow to become an on-field controversy. In the eighth inning of Tuesday night's game, Alex Rodriguez lunged at the Red Sox rookie second baseman, Dustin Pedroia, with his elbow in a forceful attempt to break up a double play.

The aluminum producer Alcoa said in a statement that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian company's rejection of the offer. But Alcoa's chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate. ''We have studied Alcan's response and have not seen anything that would lead us to re-evaluate our offer,'' Mr. Belda said. He also rejected suggestions by Alcan that Alcoa would have difficulty obtaining antitrust approval for the merger and urged Alcan's board to resume its examination of the bid. IAN AUSTEN

Rufus Wainwright, below, Cassandra Wilson, the Black Crowes and Café Tacuba are coming to Central Park SummerStage this year. In addition to concerts already publicized, the City Parks Foundation yesterday announced the rest of its 30 free concerts and 6 benefit shows. Ms. Wilson plays the first free concert, with Olu Dara, on June 15; other performers include Television (June 16), Ozomatli (June 30), Rodrigo y Gabriela (July 1), Nortec Collective (July 10), Femi Kuti (July 11) and Brazilian Girls (July 22), along with comedy presented by the Upright Citizens Brigade (July 19) and readings by Marisha Pessl and Jennifer Egan (July 26). The foundation also presents 1,100 performing arts events in parks throughout the city. Full schedules: summerstage.org and cityparksfoundation.org. BEN SISARIO

An obituary on Tuesday about the historian Eugen Weber, a leading authority on modern France, referred incorrectly to his book ''La Fin des Terroirs.'' The book (its full title is ''La Fin des Terroirs: La Modernisation de la France Rurale -- 1870-1914'') is a French translation of Mr. Weber's book ''Peasants Into Frenchmen: the Modernization of Rural France -- 1870-1914.'' It is not a separate book.

An inmate at Rikers Island was arraigned yesterday on charges that he tried to arrange the murder of a 31-year-old Queens woman who is scheduled to testify against him, prosecutors said. The inmate, Ashumba Bryan, 29, of Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Bryan is awaiting trial on charges of attacking and robbing the woman in October 2005 -- beating her and throwing her out of her moving car, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said Mr. Bryan was captured on audiotape in April trying to arrange the woman's murder for $10,000 to prevent her from testifying.

HOLMES--Dr. Douglas. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the loss of our longtime colleague and friend, Dr. Douglas Holmes. Dr. Holmes' influential research on issues affecting the elderly have been internationally recognized. He has left his mark on the Hebrew Home community and will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Marcia, his children Deborah, Pamela and Gregory and his four grandchildren. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Pres & CEO $(6$)HOLMES--Douglas, Ph.D. The staff of the Research Division of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourns the loss of their leader, Dr. Douglas Holmes. Dr Holmes was an internationally known psychologist and gerontologist who published over 150 articles in the areas of health services research, computer applications in health care, and minority aging research. He was the principal investigator of over 50 federally-funded studies. His research had a major impact on programs such as Head Start, Meals on Wheels, and later on dementia care. He was a pioneer in computer science, and in 1958 was one of the first to develop software for statistical applications. Dr. Holmes was a member of the Columbia University Stroud Center and Faculty of Medicine. He will be remembered by all for his wit, compassion and intellect. We miss him dearly. Jeanne A. Teresi, Ed.D.,Ph.D., on behalf of the Research Division staff.

The European Parliament voted to impose retail price caps on roaming charges, fees that mobile phone consumers pay when making or receiving calls outside of their home calling zones. The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax. KEVIN J. O'BRIEN

In addition to the traditional NY logo behind home plate at Yankee Stadium last night, the grass alongside the baselines was decorated with the interlocking VT of Virginia Tech with a black ribbon underneath. The Yankees also wore the VT symbol on their hats. The designs were in memory of the 32 people killed on the campus April 16 by a gunman who also took his own life. The Yankees donated $1 million to a fund that provides counseling and other assistance to the families of the victims.

To the Editor: Confronted too often with the sentiment so succinctly expressed by Nicholas D. Kristof when he writes that ''even if a single-payer system isn't politically possible right now'' (''A Short American Life,'' column, May 21), I can't help but wonder what makes us different from the other developed nations that made the successful transition to national universal health care systems.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday about a free folk music series on Governors Island this summer erroneously included a deceased singer among the performers. The concert called ''Harry Chapin: A Celebration in Song'' will be performed by friends and family members of Mr. Chapin, who died in 1981.

PYLE--Page Neville, of Short Hills and Mantoloking, NJ, passed away at Overlook Hospital in Summit on May 18, 2007 after a valiant seven year struggle with a rare lymphatic cancer. She was 67 years old. She was born in New York City on December 1, 1939, the third child of Gregg Neville and Natalie Page Neville. Page is survived by her husband, Robert M. Pyle, Jr.; two daughters, Cynthia (Nina) Pyle Furlanetto of Santa Fe, NM, and Laura C. Pyle of Arlington, VA; her sister, Natalie Neville Ferris of Holden, MA, and one grandchild. She was predeceased by her brother, Richard Gregg Neville in 1971. Page attended Spence School in New York City through ninth grade, and graduated from Miss Porter's School (Farmington) in 1957, and Smith College in 1961. She was an active volunteer of the latter two institutions over the years, serving among other positions as a President of the Farmington Alumnae Association of New Jersey and a President of the Smith College Club of the Oranges and Short Hills. Other volunteer positions included the Board of Trustees of the Cora Hartshorn Arboretum in Short Hills in various capacities during a seven year span, and the Short Hills Garden Club, where she was also a Vice President for two years. At her death Page was a member of the Short Hills Club and the Bay Head Yacht Club in New Jersey and the Hillsboro Club in Florida and several local community and civic organizations. Professionally, Page served in the investment consulting field, principally with Scudder, Stevens & Clark and Stein Roe & Farnham for seven years, and thereafter as the first paid Executive Director of the Investment Counsel Association of America for three years, where she established the first office for that organization in New York. At a later time she served for several years as the Adult Program Director of the Cora Hartshorn Arboretum. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 30, at Christ Church in Short Hills (corner of Forest Drive and Highland Avenue) at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Cutaneous Lymphoma Foundation, PO Box 374, Birmingham, MI, 48012; the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, New York, NY 10003; Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT 06032; or Smith College, Northampton, MA 01063.

HIGH GAS PRICES COULD LAST -- Gasoline prices are spiking again -- to an average of $3.22 a gallon and close to $4 a gallon in many areas -- and some oil executives warn that current fuel shortages could become a long-term problem, leading to stubbornly higher prices at the pump. [Page A1.] 9/11 INSURANCE SETTLEMENT -- Gov. Eliot Spitzer's administration announced the settlement of all insurance claims at ground zero, making $4.55 billion available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site and bringing an end to a protracted legal battle over payouts related to the 9/11 terrorist attack. [A1.] GREENSPAN SPEAKS; DOW FALLS -- The Dow Jones industrial average passed 13,600 for the first time, but shares plummeted to close at 13,525 after Alan Greenspan, the former Fed chairman, expressed concern that China's stock market, which has recently been hitting record highs, might be in for a sharp decline. [C11.] TRADE AGREEMENT WITH CHINA -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. announced a limited agreement to open markets in China and develop clean coal-burning technologies. [C1.] EARLIER CONCERN ON DIABETES DRUG -- A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter warning of the heart risks of the drug Avandia seven years ago, and the following year the F.D.A. reprimanded GlaxoSmithKline. [C1.] JAPANESE ENGINEERS GO ABROAD -- As Japan's once-vaunted electronics industry downsizes to survive global competition, thousands of Japanese engineers and other industry professionals are going to Taiwan, South Korea and China to work at fast-growing companies that want to use Japanese technological expertise. [C1.] TARGET'S PROFIT UP 18% -- Target, the No. 2 discount chain behind Wal-Mart, said its quarterly profit rose almost 18 percent, to $651 million, or 75 cents a share, from $554 million a year earlier. The women's apparel retailer Talbots posted a better-than-expected profit. [C11.] NO CRIMINAL CHARGES FOR LAW FIRM -- Federal prosecutors said they would not file criminal charges against Sidley Austin, one of the nation's largest law firms, over its work with questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes. [C1.] LOTT SUPPORTS IMMIGRATION BILL -- Trent Lott, the Senate minority whip and a conservative pro-business Republican, made an all-out pitch for a comprehensive immigration bill as the Senate voted to cut the size of a proposed guest worker program, infuriating employers. [A24.] E-MAIL TO ORDINARY CELLPHONES -- You no longer need a Treo or BlackBerry to get e-mail on the move. Three new services -- from Google, Yahoo and Teleflip -- can deliver mail directly to ordinary nonsmart cellphones, free of charge, but there are compromises. State of the Art: David Pogue. [C1.] SAFETY COMMISSION NOMINEE QUITS -- Michael E. Baroody, a senior lobbyist for the National Association of Manufacturers, withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the association was preparing to give him. [A18.] 'HI' TIMES ON MADISON AVENUE -- The latest buzzword on Madison Avenue seems to be ''hello.'' Companies as diverse as Apple, Avon, the Lincoln Financial Group and Level, a vodka brand, are using the salutation in a consumer-friendly advertising approach. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] ADVANCE GAS PRICE WARNING -- A Michigan-based gas station chain is offering to send text messages to customers, giving them at least two hours' notice of impending price increases. [A22.] RISING RUPEE WORRIES INDIANS -- Concerned that the rising value of the Indian rupee may limit the country's economic growth, especially in the lucrative outsourcing industry, monetary policy experts have started putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India to stem the rupee's rise. [C4.] MINING COMPANY RAISES BID -- The Russian mining company Norilsk Nickel raised its bid for LionOre Mining International of Canada to $6.27 billion, showing its determination to win a bidding war with a rival, Xstrata. [C5.] TWO-WAY G.P.S. IS HERE -- A new two-way radio from Garmin not only tells you where you are, but it maps your location for others. Circuits. [C8.] ONLINE BUSINESS OF GREEN -- The International Herald Tribune provides a global dialogue on the environment at nytimes.com/business. BUSINESS TRAVEL -- With more in-flight food and entertainment options, airlines are giving their business customers the C.E.O treatment. A special section is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. MEMBERS OF CONGRESS complained to the United States trade representative that the complete text of a free-trade deal with South Korea has not been made public, even though a required 90-day Congressional review period is more than half over. (REUTERS)

For those who have been faithfully recycling their newspapers since long before it was the law -- or those who just want to look like committed recyclers -- the Container Store has introduced a new collection of storage baskets made entirely out of old newspapers. The bins, which come in three sizes ($9.99 to $19.99), above, are tightly woven, with two cutout handles. There is no metal involved in the construction, just paper and a coat of light matte lacquer to keep the newsprint from smearing or tearing. There's an exotic element, too: the bins are made from various Asian newspapers, and if you look closely you can pick out individual characters: (888) 266-8246 or containerstore.com. STEPHEN MILIOTI
Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding, not Heinz Guderian. Because of an editing error, a correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the command Guderian held before a promotion. It was the Second Panzer Division -- not the Second SS Panzer Division, which he never commanded.

As Blake Lewis and Jordin Sparks competed for the last time on ''American Idol,'' the speed skater Apolo Anton Ohno, below, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, added another trophy to his collection on Tuesday, becoming the fourth winner crowned on ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars.'' In a rare occurrence, the two-hour dancing finale, which drew 22.7 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, lifted ABC past Fox to win the title of most-watched network on Tuesday night. Fox's ''American Idol'' drew 24.5 million viewers, dominating the 8 o'clock hour but falling considerably short of the 31.8 million who tuned in for the final competition a year ago. Fox still led Tuesday among adults 18 to 49, despite a disappointing debut at 9 for its new reality competition, ''On the Lot,'' from the executive producers Mark Burnett and Steven Spielberg. The show, in which would-be filmmakers compete for a development deal, averaged nine million viewers, losing 40 percent of its audience between its first half and its second. BENJAMIN TOFF

It may not seem surprising that the leading French film festival should feature a number of movies that show France in a flattering light, but the cinematic love letters to the country popping up on Cannes screens this year are not self-addressed billets-doux, even though high self-regard is a longstanding Gallic tradition. Given that a theme of the recent French presidential election was a perceived national identity crisis, it is possible to imagine the present cluster of pro-French movies by non-French directors as a kind of friendly reassurance. Hey, these filmmakers seem to be saying, don't be so down on yourselves. We love you. And so Hou Hsiao-hsien, from Taiwan, paid tribute in ''The Flight of the Red Balloon'' both to a classic French children's movie and to the everyday loveliness of Paris. And Michael Moore, as if saying merci for his Palme d'Or three years ago, turned a paean to the French welfare state into the comic centerpiece of ''Sicko,'' his indictment of the American health care system. So benevolent is the French government, in Mr. Moore's knowingly wide-eyed account, that it not only treats its citizens' maladies, but also does their laundry. (Not all the time, of course. Only when there's a new baby in the house. But still.)

Foul weather in Alaska has prompted the Pentagon to delay, until tomorrow at the earliest, a test of the new missile defense system, military officials said. The system can operate in all weather in a wartime environment, but safety rules governing tests require that the target missile, to be launched from Kodiak Island, be visible to monitors who can push a destruct button if it veers off course. THOM SHANKER

An article last Thursday about concerns in Congress over broadcasts of Islamic militant views by Al Hurra, an American government-financed television network in the Middle East, referred incorrectly to the timing of the appointment of the network's new vice president for news, Larry Register. Mr. Register was already on the job when Al Hurra broadcast a speech by Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, in December; he was not hired to make sure such broadcasts did not recur. The article also misstated the length of Sheik Nasrallah's broadcast speech; it was 67 minutes, not 30 minutes.

HOROWITZ--Frances K. (Ginsburg), 97, of Scarsdale, New York, died on May 23, 2007. The beloved wife of the late Bernard Horowitz. She is survived by her loving sons Larry Horowitz and Dan Horowitz, her devoted daughtersin-law Beth Horowitz and Vicki Horowitz, her loving grandchildren Peter Horowitz and his wife YukikoJane, Roger Horowitz and Alex Horowitz. She was also preceded in death by her loving husband Harold Klipstein. Born in New York, January 22, 1910, to Abraham and Annie Ginsberg. She attended Erasmus Hall High School and New York University. An avid volunteer, she spent a large part of her life in helping others as a volunteer at White Plains Hospital for more than 34 years and also volunteered at Blythedale Hospital for 15 years. She also recorded for the blind. She was extremely active in the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY, where she served on numerous committees. She had a life-long love of the arts and music and filled her home with grace and beauty. Funeral Services will be held Friday, May 25, at 1:00 pm at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Contributions may be made to the Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund at White Plains Hospital Center, care of Development -Patricia Laine, 122 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY 10601 checks should be made to White Plains Hospital Center, on the memo line please write Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund.

At this time of year, many people take stock of their outdoor furniture and discard damaged lawn and patio chairs. But those who have high-quality pieces should consider repairing them instead. Chaircarepatio.com offers detailed instructions, as well as materials like vinyl strapping (precut straps are $2 to $4; a roll is $25 to $75), top left, and custom polyester mesh slings in more than 70 colors ($60 for a one-piece chair sling; $90 for a two-piece chaise sling). The company sells the necessary tools; patio furniture cleaners like Casual Clean ($19.99 for a gallon), left; replacement parts like chair glides, end caps and tires for vintage wrought-iron chaise longues; and furniture covers. It also offers outdoor fabric in dozens of solid colors, stripes and patterns (starting at $21.99 a yard). For information: chaircarepatio.com or (866) 638-6416. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

A White House Memo article on Friday, about the last joint appearance by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain at the White House, misstated the name of the medal Mr. Blair was awarded in 2003. It was the Congressional Gold Medal, not the Congressional Medal of Honor.
IT seems as if Madison Avenue is on some kind of a ''Hi.'' At least half a dozen advertising campaigns are using the greeting ''Hello'' as a way to attract consumer attention.

One of the energizing and occasionally enervating consequences of attending an international film festival is that it forces you to face your own impatience. Much commercial cinema moves at a fairly accelerated clip, with anxious camerawork and nanosecond editing that verges on a flicker effect. Confronted with the longer takes and languorous pacing of some of the festival's offerings, viewers hooked on speed cinema rush toward the exit, fall asleep in their seats or try to slow their biorhythms down, way down. Such was the case with ''The Man From London,'' by the Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr, making his first appearance in the main competition with this austere black-and-white work that had the press fleeing like panicked slaughterhouse cattle. It isn't bad, not at all. But it moves with Mr. Tarr's characteristic deliberation, with leisurely shots that find the camera wending through confined interiors and a few exteriors for minutes at a time without interruption. Based on a novel by Georges Simenon and set in some undefined port town, it involves a night guard who watches over a shipping dock from inside a glassed-in tower. One evening he witnesses the accidental murder of a man holding a suitcase. He retrieves the case, which turns out to be stuffed with enough cash (£60,000) to make at least one Hungarian lose his bearings. An investigation ensues, but mostly there are long takes and long walks and the remarkable transformation of film space into a state of mind.

The Yankees' best chance to significantly dent the American League East standings this week would have been to sweep the Boston Red Sox. That did not happen, because the teams split the first two games of their three-game series. For now, the Yankees must take smaller bites. Their record is still below .500, and they remain far behind the Red Sox. But they won the series, with Andy Pettitte giving them seven solid innings and the hitters finally supporting him in an 8-3 victory last night at Yankee Stadium.

A group of the city's most powerful women gathered outside City Hall yesterday to promote regular breast cancer screening through mammograms, whose use has been steadily decreasing. The group, which included First Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; and the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, announced a public awareness campaign, assisted by Macy's, to inform women about how and when to schedule exams. Ms. Harris said fewer women were receiving regular mammograms than in the past. According to a study recently published in the medical journal Cancer, the decline could be a result of a shortage of available testing, questions about the effectiveness of the exam and higher patient co-payments. DIANE CARDWELL

BASKETBALL N.B.A. HOUSTON ROCKETS--Named Rick Adelman coach. MINNESOTA TIMBERWOLVES--Signed Randy Wittman, coach, to a multiyear contract. NETS--Named Jeff Gewirtz senior vice president and general counsel. Women's N.B.A. CHICAGO SKY--Terminated the contract of G Deanna Jackson for violating her collective bargaining agreement and player contract. FOOTBALL N.F.L. MIAMI DOLPHINS--Signed LB Kelvin Smith, to a four-year contract. HOCKEY N.H.L. COLORADO AVALANCHE--Signed D Jordan Leopold, D Kurt Sauer, D Jeff Finger and F David Jones.

BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCE's largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts have formed a rival group that may make a bid potentially worth about $45 billion. IAN AUSTEN

A map with a front-page article on Monday about a clash between Lebanese troops and Islamic militants at a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon misidentified the city shown south of Beirut, the capital. It is Sidon -- not Tyre, which is about 25 miles south of Sidon. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/world/middleeast

PERLUCK--Gertrude, be loved wife for 63 years of Herbert Perluck, Professor Emeritus at Brooklyn College, passed peacefully at home in the company of her loving family on Monday, May 21. Gertrude, born on Staten Island, NY on December 5, 1916, was the daughter of the late Minnie and Samuel Schulman. Gertrude is best known as the trendsetting proprietor of The Mayan Shop, which she started in Providence, RI in 1950, and later operated in Watch Hill for many years. After retiring from the Mayan Shop, Gertrude took up painting and was a member of the Westbeth Artists Cooperative in Greenwich Village. Her artwork was exhibited in NYC and Mystic, CT. There will be a memorial service and celebration of Gertrude's life at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Gertrude's name to Home and Hospice Care of RI .

Even with the Yankees' 8-3 triumph over the Red Sox last night, it's only a matter of the next losing streak until another proclamation of Steinbrenner Support for Joe Torre is heard. Support, as in a veiled vote of confidence a few weeks ago and again last weekend, has been George Steinbrenner's favorite word lately. As if that were enough to fix what's wrong with a team that has seldom hit well often enough when it pitches well, just as it didn't pitch well often enough early in the season when it hit well.

Billy Donovan, who coached the Florida men's team to its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title last month, and Pat Summitt, who coached the Tennessee women to their seventh title in her 33 years on the job, received the annual Winged Foot Awards last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club. The award is given annually to the coaches of the men's and women's N.C.A.A. basketball champions, and Summitt may return next season. She lost only two seniors, and she kept the 6-foot-4 Candace Parker, probably the best player in the women's game. The Volunteers also have one of the strongest recruiting classes in the nation with Angie Bjorklund, a 6-1 guard-forward from Spokane, Wash.; Kelley Cain, a 6-6 center from Atlanta; Vicki Baugh, a 6-4 forward-center from Sacramento; and Sydney Smallbone, a 6-0 guard from South Bend, Ind. ''We have a chance to be a very good team next year,'' Summitt said at a news conference.

GLYNN--Eugene David, M.D., psychiatrist and art critic, died on May 15, 2007, of lung cancer. He was 81. The son of Isidore Glynn and Tillie Sheinbaum, he was born in Passaic, NJ, and raised by his stepmother, Frieda Helman. A WWII Naval veteran, he attended college and medical school at NYU. He devoted his life to public health in New York, counseling patients, supervising psychiatric care and training social workers. He was the Director of Clinical Services at the Youth Counseling League and a consulting psychiatrist for the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. Dr. Glynn had an abiding love for the arts. His writings on psychoanalysis and art were published in Art News and The Print Collector's Newsletter. His description of Adrian Stokes reads like a self-portrait: ''the passion for art, the intensity of concern, the almost raw hyperactive quality of a sensibility that threatens at times to engulf all else -the nature is a 19th century one determined to order itself by the 20th century's monumental new view, psychoanalysis.'' He is survived by his partner of fifty years, Maurice Sendak, and his sister Muriel Newman. Friends wishing to honor Dr. Glynn are asked to contribute to the American Cancer Society.

Sears Holdings of Hoffman Estates, Ill., is changing agencies on the media planning and buying account for its Kmart and Sears chains, which spend an estimated $750 million a year on advertising. MPG in New York, part of Havas, will take over the media duties from two agencies owned by the WPP Group: MindShare, which had handled traditional ads, and MEC Interaction, which worked on online ads.

An article on Monday about a $3.5 billion development planned for Stamford, Conn., that is part of the city's efforts to remain a financial center in the New York region misstated ridership statistics for the Metro-North Railroad. Because of the rise of Stamford and other suburban cities as corporate hubs, Grand Central Terminal is now the final destination of fewer than half the riders at all times -- not those on weekday mornings. (During the morning rush, the final destination of most riders is still Grand Central.)

Lornah Kiplagat of the Netherlands, who has won the New York Mini 10-kilometer run in Central Park three times, will return for this year's race June 9. The New York Road Runners also announced yesterday that the field would include such world-class runners as Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, Benita Johnson of Australia, Mara Yamauchi of Britain and Nina Rillstone of New Zealand. FRANK LITSKY

Candidate to Lead Consumer Safety Agency Withdraws A lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission as senators questioned a departure payment the association was to give him. PAGE A18 Body Found in Euphrates May Be G.I. The American military started examining a body found in the Euphrates River that Iraqi authorities and local residents believe is one of three American soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12. PAGE A16 Clinton Rejects Strategy to Skip Iowa Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign has considered, and rejected, a plan to stop competing in Iowa and to concentrate instead on later primary states, including the 20 or so that will vote on Feb 5. PAGE A24 These Socks Fit Like a Glove Some of the new Red Sox have introduced their new red socks to the team this year. A number of players are following the lead of Boston's two Japanese pitchers and wearing socks that fit over their toes like a glove. SPORTSTHURSDAY, PAGE D1 Prized Fashion Margot Fonteyn's tutu, left, Madonna's bra and rare couture items from the 1860's are among the 8,000 garments acquired for a fashion museum opening in Santiago, Chile. THURSDAY STYLES, PAGE G1

The director of the Juilliard Choral Union has resigned, raising questions about the survival of the chorus, which has carved out a prominent role in the city's musical scene. The director, Judith Clurman, who has led the group for all of its seven years and counts many loyal followers in it, declined to say yesterday why she was leaving. ''I just say I love my chorus,'' she said. Joseph W. Polisi, Juilliard's president, said Ms. Clurman's resignation had prompted the school to consider putting the chorus on hiatus next season. Its fate is made more tenuous by the lack of future engagements with Juilliard's student orchestras, and by renovations that have made space tight, Mr. Polisi said. The news came on the eve of Juilliard's commencement concert yesterday, when the chorus was scheduled to sing in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The choral union, an amateur group that includes singers from the Juilliard School and the New York area, has also performed with the New York City Ballet and as part of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series. At Carnegie Hall it anchored a communal performance of the Mozart Requiem, led by Ms. Clurman, to mark the fifth anniversary of 9/11. DANIEL J. WAKIN

SCHMEDEL--Paulina, left us April 27, 2007, to share her love, strength, beauty, tenderness, wit, grace, athleticism, and bridge skills on a higher level. Kisses and hugs, min skat, from Scott, Anna, and Richard.

BAMBERGER--Maria E., on May 21, at 88 years. Wife of the late Fritz Bamberger. Devoted to her children and stepchildren, Kochava and the late Yochanan Nussbaum, Michael and Ina Nussbaum, Michael and Phylis Bamberger, and Gabrielle Bamberger; beloved ''Savta Maria'' and Oma of Nurit Nussbaum, Tal Nussbaum, Kenneth Bamberger, Richard Bamberger, and eight greatgrandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th St., on Wednesday, May 30, at 1 pm.

An article on Tuesday about a federal civil rights lawsuit charging that the New York Fire Department's entrance exam is biased against blacks and Hispanics misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic firefighters in the fire department of another large city, Philadelphia. It is 31 percent, not ''more than 40 percent.'' (The New York department is 4.5 percent Hispanic and 3 percent black.)
CONCEPCION--Rene. 11 years went by without you, but your smile and your courage will always stay with those you loved. You'll be in our hearts forever. Love, Steven and Adolfo

An article Tuesday about Steel Winds, a wind farm rising on a former toxic waste site in the Rust Belt city of Lackawanna, N.Y., included incorrect information from the project manager about the power capacity of the eight wind turbines that have been built so far. They can produce 56,000 megawatt-hours of electricity per year, not 20 megawatts per year.

Police officers pulled two workers from a building that partly collapsed yesterday, police and fire officials said. The workers, whose names were not disclosed by the police, were inside the three-story building, at 51 Woodhull Street in Red Hook, when the second floor collapsed, pushing the first floor into the basement and trapping the workers, the police said. Officers from the Emergency Services Unit entered the building and rescued the workers, who had back and leg injuries. The workers were taken to hospitals, the police said. The Buildings Department said the collapse was caused by demolition work.
To the Editor: Re ''Democrats Pull Troop Deadline From Iraq Bill'' (front page, May 23):

A 14-year-old student was killed in a high school shooting in north Toronto, the police said. Students and teachers were locked in classrooms for hours while the police searched for a suspect, but no arrests were immediately made. The police released few other details. The last school shooting in Canada was in September, when a gunman entered a Montreal junior college and killed one student and wounded 19 others before he died from police gunfire. CHRISTOPHER MASON

SCHAEFER--Sylvia. A loving aunt for over 55 years, who with great warmth and great humor we will dearly miss. She was an incredible mother to her girls, Jill, Faith, Beth and a loving friend. We will all miss her. Alan and Terry Blumenfeld

Dune, which sells high-end modern furniture at its TriBeCa store and ABC Home in the Flatiron District, opened another branch last week, in a 30,000-square-foot fashion mini-mall in Dallas. The new Dune outpost occupies 2,500 square feet on the first and second floors of the center, called LFT (for Lifestyle Fashion Terminal). Pieces are also scattered around the building, ''so if you're waiting for your girlfriend to try on a dress, you might sit down on one of our chairs,'' said Dune's owner, Richard Shemtov.

A schedule note in The Arts on Tuesday with a music review of the pianist Ursula Oppens, at Arium on Little West 12th Street in the West Village, included outdated information from Arium about the next performance there. The recital by Julia Sakharova, violinist, and Natalia Lavrova, pianist, will take place at a date to be determined -- not Sunday. The next concert at Arium will be on June 3, with the cellist Diliana Momtchilova and the pianist Vassily Primakov.

In a widening corruption scandal, the sixth to strike the government of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva since he took office in 2003, the minister of mines and energy, Silas Rondeau, resigned. Citing wiretapping and videotape evidence, the police say he accepted a $50,000 bribe from a construction company in return for preferential treatment in the awarding of contracts for a rural electric program. LARRY ROHTER

MERRITT--John C., of Bedford, NY, on May 22nd, 2007, at age 91. Real Estate developer. He is survived by his wife, Natalie Hussar Merritt and his two children, John Jr. and Susan Coates, his four grandchildren, Kevin, Cameron, Allyson, and Chelsea, his sister Marjorie, and numerous nieces and nephews. His extended family includes his wife's children, Jane, Andree and John, grandchildren, James, Margaret, Patrick, Sally, Peri, Andrew, Reed, and Caroline. He was predeceased by his first wife Dorrit and Natalie's children Susan and Nancy. John Merritt was a true gentlemen, generous and gracious and will be greatly missed by his family, friends and all those who dealt with him in his long business life. Viewing at 7-9pm Thursday, May 24th, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral at 3pm Friday, May 25th at the North Greenwich Congregational Church (Church of the Advent), Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Church of the Advent, 4 Connecticut Ave, Greenwich, CT 07830, or to the National Parkinson's Foundation Inc., 1509 North West 9th Avenue/Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136-1494.
