To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The drawings are casual and not too interesting, but the luxurious black-and-white photographs from Paris speak more to Matta-Clark's formal elegance. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Kimmelman) Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Taryn Simon,' through June 24. Ms. Simon couches the show in the intellectual, power-to-the-people oratory of leftist politics, yet she clearly delights in exposing, in a quasi-tabloid fashion, America's underbelly. Though she has also worked in war-torn areas, Ms. Simon is best known for ''The Innocents,'' a series of portraits of men and women who were wrongly convicted but later cleared by DNA test results. Ms. Simon can work as long as a year to gain permission to photograph high-security zones like the government-regulated quarantine sites, nuclear waste storage facilities, prison death rows and C.I.A. offices on view in the show. There are also pictures with lighter themes: the sandpit where the Grucci family tests fireworks, ski slopes being dynamited for avalanche control and the second Death Star, from ''Return of the Jedi,'' at George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch. Ms. Simon is at her artistic best when her delight in the strangeness of American culture shines. (See above.) (Goodbody) Galleries: Uptown CLAUDE MONET (1840-1926): A TRIBUTE TO DANIEL WILDENSTEIN AND KATIA GRANOFF This exhibition of nearly 60 paintings by one of the most beloved painters in the world feels a little like having dinner with a celebrity. The gallery setting eliminates the usual distance; the startling intimacy allows you to experience afresh the momentum and innovations of Monet's astounding trajectory in the span of three small galleries. Basically, it is a chance to encounter, up close and in detail, the evolving ways of seeing and painting that established the originality, historical importance and continuing irresistibility of Monet's art. It should not be missed. Wildenstein & Company, 19 East 64th Street, (212) 879-0500, through June 15. (Smith) Galleries: SoHo * 'Gego, Between Transparency and the Invisible' The artist named Gego was born Gertrud Goldschmidt in Germany in 1912, but lived most of her life in Venezuela, where she produced netlike drawings in ink and watercolor and what she called ''drawings without paper'': semi-geometric, see-through, two- and three-dimensional pieces of twisted and knotted wires, suspended in space. Whether you think of them as grids gone haywire or as rational forms charged with emotion, they're out of this world, and this small survey gives a good sense of what is distinctive and radical about Gego's art. The Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, drawingcenter.org, through July 21. (Cotter) Galleries: Other * MARTIN KIPPENBERGER: PREIS PAINTINGS Seven canvases from two series of paintings rarely exhibited in this country play on the double German meaning of preis (price and prize), some variation of which appears on each surface. They show this famous bad-boy sculptor conveying his usual sarcasm into surprisingly beautiful terms that couldn't get much flatter. Hard-edged and brushy techniques contrast the main tactics of formalist painting while converting the modernist grid into designs redolent of drapery and checked tablecloths. A preponderance of hot pink inveigles for the pleasure principle. 1018 Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 537-0453, www.1018art.net, through July 27. (Smith) SOL LEWITT: DRAWING SERIES If the greatness of Sol LeWitt, the Minimal-Conceptual artist who died in April at 78, has so far escaped you, this exhilarating show of 14 of his mind-teasing, eye-filling wall drawings from the late 1960s and early '70s may do the trick. Selected and arranged by the artist, they proceed in carefully sequenced contrasts and echoes that are both insightful and idiosyncratic. Since their generating instructions are part of their titles, they reduce the creative process to a short, highly visible straight line. But their crisp geometries, accumulating marks and radiating patterns force us to mind the gap between artistic thought and artistic action, to experience the inability of language to account fully for visual outcome. Dia:Beacon, 3 Beekman Street, Beacon, N.Y., (845) 440-0100, through Sept. 10. (Smith) JOAQUÍN TORRES-GARCÍA This choice exhibition concentrates on small, lively ink drawings from the early 1930s, when Torres-García ironed out Cubism into a compartmentalized grid that could either be abstract -- like Mondrian's work -- or a container for assorted symbols and hieroglyphs. Two earlier paintings underscore that, either way, his inspiration came from combined order and disorder of bustling city views. CDS Gallery, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555, through June 9. (Smith) Public Art Madison Square Park: Roxy Paine This installation is made up of two stainless-steel tree sculptures -- ''Conjoined'' and ''Defunct'' -- and a glacierlike boulder, ''Erratic,'' by Mr. Paine. The tree sculptures are made from thousands of pieces of metal pipe and rod elements that have been cut, welded and polished. They are real enough to resemble actual trees but not so real that they form a continuum with the surrounding foliage. What captures your immediate attention is ''Conjoined,'' a 40-foot-tall-by-45-foot-wide sculpture of two trees whose gleaming steel branches cantilever and then improbably connect in midair. It is impossible to tell where the branches of one tree begin and the other end. But the piece is also beautifully eccentric, a futuristic fantasy of streamlined vegetation manufactured in imitation of the real thing, only much more appealing and exciting. Madison Square Park, 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, (212) 538-4689, www.madisonsquarepark.org, through Dec. 31. (Benjamin Genocchio) Last Chance FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,'. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases, elegiac celebrations of farm workers raking and reaping grain, have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org.; closes on Sunday. (Glueck) * 'Rebel, Rebel: Remembering Karlheinz Weinberger (1921-2006)' The self-taught Swiss photographer Karlheinz Weinberger, who died last year at 81, began his career taking pictures for a gay club in Zurich, but found his true subject in rebellious, working-class teenagers who dressed to shock in the 1960s and '70s. The Weinberger pictures in this show are fairly tame, as if chosen to complement the cooled-out work of the three younger artists -- Ryan McGinley, Walter Pfeiffer and Collier Schorr -- who surround him. But at his best, he's in a class by himself. Anna Kustera, 520 West 21st Street, (212) 989-0082, kusteratiltongallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

Jiten Thukral and Sumir Tagra, collaborators from New Delhi, are artists for a new century: passionately partisan, socially engaged, yet pleasantly fresh and stylish with an eye on today's buoyant art market. Their latest offering is an installation at Bose Pacia Gallery meant to raise awareness of H.I.V., especially in India, where more than five million people are infected. But unlike most art projects that tackle social issues, this show skips statistics and documentary material. Instead the artists have created lyrical paintings of couples in bed onto which they have collaged little embroideries of human hands putting on condoms.

Congress Backs First Minimum Wage Rise in Decade The House, in a 348-73 vote, and Senate, by 80-14, overwhelmingly approved the first increase in the federal minimum wage in a decade. The increase would raise the wage to $7.25 an hour from $5.15 over two years. The bill also includes tax breaks for small businesses, which have argued that an increase would be a burden. President Bush said he would sign the measure, part of the Iraq spending package. PAGE A12 Inquiry Into Dow Chemical The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play, and into stock-price spikes that may have resulted from buyout rumors. The inquiry may also look at a real effort for a deal. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 40 Summers Ago Posters, album jackets and graphics are in ''Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era,'' a show at the Whitney Museum ''that remembers a lot, but forgets much more.'' A review by Holland Cotter. PAGE E25 27 Killed in Suicide Attack On Iraq Funeral Procession A tribal leader in Anbar Province was killed and his funeral procession attacked hours later, another sign of tensions between supporters of Al Qaeda and the Sunni tribes that oppose them. Much of the violence across Iraq appeared to have been carried out by Sunni insurgents. PAGE A6 Facebook Crowds MySpace Facebook, the online social network, was originally popular on college campuses. But over the last year it opened to all, and now it is expanding into the turf of MySpace. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

President Bush has nominated Diane G. Farrell to become a director of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, the White House said yesterday. Ms. Farrell, left, a Democrat, is a former first selectwoman of Westport and last year ran unsuccessfully against Representative Christopher Shays for a congressional seat. If approved by the Senate, Ms. Farrell would serve the remainder of a four-year term expiring on Jan. 20, 2011, the White House said.

For the first time since 1996, ABC's evening newscast, now known as ''World News With Charles Gibson,'' can lay claim to being the most-watched of the so-called Big 3 in two consecutive ratings sweeps periods: this past February, and now May, according to figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday by ABC. For the four-week period beginning on April 26, ''World News'' drew an average of about 8 million viewers a night, while ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' attracted an estimated 7.3 million, Nielsen estimated. The ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' trailed well behind, with about 6.1 million viewers. JACQUES STEINBERG

The Public Lives column last Friday, about David Chang, the owner of the Momofuku restaurants in the East Village and the winner of this year's James Beard Foundation award for best new chef, referred imprecisely to the Japanese name for another restaurant he plans to open, Ko. It is more accurately translated as ''child'' than ''son of.''

Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands. While most of Yukos's assets have been unraveled and sold at auction, a company bank account in the Netherlands holding about $1 billion from the sale of a Lithuanian refinery is still in dispute. A Dutch court has yet to rule on Mr. Rebgun's claim to the property, according to a statement by Yukos shareholders. The money is also claimed by Yukos shareholders and creditors. ANDREW KRAMER

Many children might find it appealing to acquire a bug's capabilities. After all, look at where they got Peter Parker. But the protagonist of ''Bug Boy Blues'' is not Spider-Man. He's Gregor Samsa, subject of Kafka's tale ''The Metamorphosis.'' Gregor's transformation did not give him superpowers, and it was not a halfway affair. He had more than the ability to climb walls; he also had the face to go with it.

Federal prosecutors have offered to provide more classified information in open court to keep alive their prosecution of two former pro-Israel lobbyists charged with violating the Espionage Act. The lobbyists, who had been with the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, are charged with illegally giving national security information to Israeli officials and reporters. Citing national security concerns, the prosecutors had tried to close from public scrutiny a substantial part of the information to be used at trial. But Judge T. S. Ellis III of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., ruled in April that the government's proposal would not afford a fair trial to the two defendants, Steven J. Rosen and Keith Weissman. The prosecutors' new proposal was filed under seal, but other government documents said it would allow ''greater public disclosure of a significant amount of classified information.'' NEIL A. LEWIS

If you happened to tune in to 89.9 FM this week, you have already reaped the benefits of the Sam Rivers Festival, a comprehensive celebration of this august saxophonist, flutist and composer. The broadcast, which began last Friday afternoon and concludes tonight at 9, is a characteristic labor of love (and, yes, obsession) by that station, WKCR. And in many ways the marathon format suits its subject. Mr. Rivers, above, has been an indefatigable and often prolix presence in jazz over the last 60 years, and even in his 80s he can seem impervious to fatigue, as anyone who attended last year's Vision Festival will attest.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about a lawsuit over a sale of corporate bonds referred incorrectly to the current status of the Citigroup business that sold the bonds. That business is now owned by Legg Mason; it is not a part of the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. (Citigroup and its affiliates are defendants in the lawsuit; Legg Mason is not.)

Irish voters went to the polls on Thursday in a national ballot that will decide whether Prime Minister Bertie Ahern secures a third successive term after 10 years in office. Mr. Ahern, 55, who campaigned on sustaining Irish prosperity and on stabilizing peace in Northern Ireland, has said the election will probably be his last.

The explosive growth of private equity is underscored by a new report from Thomson Financial. The worldwide volume of deals involving private equity is double from the period a year ago, accounting for more than 20 percent of all mergers so far this year.

KELNER--Eugene J., age 91, of Coconut Creek, FL, formerly of New Rochelle, NY, passed away May 23, 2007. Beloved husband of Marian Pine Kelner; Loving Father of Susan Kelner Freeman and Cliff Freeman and Roger Lawrence Kelner; Cherished Grandfather of Joseph James Kelner and Max Randall Kelner of California; Dear Brother of Lenore Fine. Nicknamed ''Sunny'' as a youth for the warmth of his wonderful smile and the fun-loving generosity of his spirit. His company was a treasure never to be forgotten. Always the perfect gentlemen for any and all who were fortunate enough to be thought of as his friend. He was a decorated WWII Veteran (five years served), a member of the Life Long Learning Society at FAU, the S.A.M. Fraternity, NYU, and was VicePresident of the Aquascutum of London in NYC. Contributions maybe made to your favorite charity. Services Entrusted to Star of David Memorial Chapel, North Lauderdale, FL. 1-800-456-5252

MEMORIAL DAY triggers a series of inexorable actions. Beach romances fly off bookshelves. White pants and Hawaiian shirts tumble out of closets. Pools are opened, rooftop parties commence and patio umbrellas are unfurled in a backyard chorus of cranks and squeaks. And, just as surely, directions from Mapquest shoot out of printers as we plan explorations under sunny, soon to be summery skies.

PAY GAP BETWEEN NO. 1 AND NO. 2 -- As executive pay has surged in most American companies, there has been a widening gap between the top executive's pay and the pay of executives a rank or two down. Few of these people are deprived, but the growing concentration of income among a select group at the top has left many others with similar talents and experience well behind. [Page A1.] INQUIRY INTO DOW CHEMICAL -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play, and the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to people briefed on the matter. [C1.] COKE BUYS MAKER OF VITAMINWATER -- Directors of the Coca-Cola Company approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash and stock, according a person involved in the negotiations. [C1.] CONFRONTING A MANIC MARKET -- One of the biggest challenges for Chinese leaders these days lies in when and how to rein in the country's soaring stock market and, just as important, whom to pick as the next governor of the central bank. [C1.] FACEBOOK WILL HAVE MORE TO DO -- Facebook is escalating its rivalry with MySpace by inviting thousands of technology companies and programmers to contribute features that will allow members to recommend and listen to music, insert Amazon book reviews onto their pages, play games and join charity drives, all without leaving the site. [C1.] ANOTHER DROP IN PROFIT FOR GAP -- Gap Inc., the largest United States clothing retailer, reported its seventh consecutive quarterly decline in profit, and the women's apparel retailer Ann Taylor Stores also reported lower first-quarter profit. Gap said net income dropped 26 percent, to $178 million, and Ann Taylor's profit fell 19 percent, to $31.5 million. Record gasoline prices, in addition to the coldest April in a decade, discouraged shopping during the quarter, said Ann Taylor's chief executive, Kay Krill. [C2.] G.M. EXPECTS $1 BILLION CHARGE -- General Motors said that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission. [C2.] OUT-OF-TOWNER ON A SALES TRIP -- Donald J. Trump, along with some hoopla, came to Chicago to promote his gleaming $850 million, 1,392-foot tall hotel and condominium tower along the edge of the Chicago River. The building, under construction, still has some units for sale. ''We want to give people really good deals,'' he said, as gusts of wind buffeted his trademark hair. [A12.] DELL TO SELL IN WAL-MART -- Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing strategy of selling direct to consumers, said that it planned to offer computers at Wal-Mart stores, starting in June. [C4.] AN EX-CHIEF'S LEGACY -- Home Depot's ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, loomed large over the company's annual shareholder meeting, as directors and executives struggled with, and at times appeared to clash over, Mr. Nardelli's legacy. [C3.] HOME SALES RISE, AND PRICES FALL -- Sales of new homes surged in April by the biggest jump in 14 years, but the median price of a new home dropped by the largest amount on record -- a sign that builders were cutting prices in an effort to move unsold homes. [C8.] The luxury-home builder Toll Brothers reported a 79 percent decline in second-quarter profit. [C8.] RECORDS SEIZED -- Justice Department investigators have seized records from the headquarters of Air Evac Lifeteam, a large operator of medical helicopters, as part of an investigation, apparently into possible health care fraud.[C10.] LONG-TERM CARE POLICIES -- A Congressional committee asked Conseco and the Penn Treaty American Corporation, two of the nation's largest sellers of long-term care insurance, to produce documents showing how the companies market long-term care policies and handle policyholder claims. [C2.] HEALTH CARE, A JOB MACHINE -- Poor-paying jobs in health care and social work have accounted for most of the job growth in New York City in the last 15 years. And in Brooklyn and the Bronx, health care now supplies about one-third of all private-sector jobs and wages. [A1.] ONLINE SPIKING GAS PRICES -- Gas prices are spiking again and some oil executives are now warning that fuel shortages -- and high prices -- could become a long-term problem. Readers weigh in on whether they've changed their driving behavior at news.blogs.nytimes.com. THE ENERGY CHALLENGE -- In a series of articles, The Times is examining how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more energy-efficient, environmentally benign future. The series is online at nytimes.com/energychallenge. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Barnes & Noble, the world's largest book retailer, posted a first-quarter loss, but comparable-store sales rose 1.7 percent. (REUTERS) Hormel Foods posted a lower-than-expected quarterly profit and cut its full-year outlook as it struggled to pass through higher feed costs. (REUTERS)

OGDEN--Jean Sullivan, 87, died Sunday, May 20, in Washington, D.C., following a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. As a longtime resident of Greenwich, Connecticut, she devoted herself to numerous charitable endeavors focusing on the arts and education. She is survived by a brother, three daughters and three grandchildren. She will be buried in her birthplace, Dalton, Massachusetts.

WHO -- Carrie Wilhite, 40, a stay-at-home mother from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., shown at rear with her husband, Brad, 42, an investment banker, as their three children play with two friends. WHAT -- 5-bedroom house WHERE Oceanside, Calif. We bought this house six years ago when it was new and the backyard was a blank slate. With three-quarters of an acre, there was plenty of space to create a yard that had the feel of a nice resort with room to entertain outdoors but that still flowed together.
To the Editor: Re ''Food Safety Joins Issues at U.S.-China Talks'' (Business Day, May 23):
The other night, Billy Wagner responded to a radio reporter's request for an interview by calling out Joe Smith's name. ''Where's Joe Smith?'' Wagner said. ''He'll love to do it.''

A sports article yesterday about the end of the arbitration hearing between the cyclist Floyd Landis and the United States Anti-Doping Agency referred imprecisely in some copies to Landis's potential place in Tour de France history. He could become the first champion in the Tour's 103-year history to be stripped of the title for a doping violation, not the first to be stripped of the title.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who endured a major political setback as first lady when she tried to promote universal health care, revived that crusade yesterday but in a more measured way, offering a plan to reduce costs, through programs like disease prevention, to make universal coverage affordable. Mrs. Clinton, who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, said she would cut health care spending by $120 billion a year through prevention programs, coordinated treatment of chronic diseases and computerized record keeping.

A former accounting assistant at the Riverdale Country School was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $500,000 by skimming cash from school fund-raisers and the cafeteria, prosecutors said. The suspect, Eileen Koranteng, 50, of Peekskill, was charged with grand larceny and forgery, the Bronx district attorney's office said. Ms. Koranteng was an employee at the school from 1997 until 2006. In July 2001, she began embezzling tuition payments and other school money totaling $508,000, prosecutors said. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

TYLER--Patricia, in Washington, D.C., on May 17. Pat was born in Baltimore and graduated from Goucher College. She leaves many friends in New York, Rome and Washington who admired her appetite for life and found their own lives brighter in her company.

To the Editor: Atul Gawande's May 19 column about abortion doesn't mention a significant contributor to abortion: alcohol and drug abuse. Individuals, whether young teenagers or those in the 18-to-25 age group, in which abortions are concentrated, who are high on alcohol or other drugs like marijuana are likelier to have risky sex.

ETON--Maxwell. Beloved husband of Bella, devoted father of Susan, cherished grandfather of Felicia and Richard, Allison and Alan, Jennifer and Marc, greatgrandfather of Simon, James, Annabel, Maya and Sophia.

Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sixty-one percent of Americans say the United States should have stayed out of Iraq and 76 percent say things are going badly there, including 47 percent who say things are going very badly, the poll found.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Congress Accepts War Bill, Ending Impasse With Bush Congress voted to meet President Bush's demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy. A1 The powerful Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr has quietly returned to southern Iraq after a four-month sojourn in Iran, according to American intelligence reports. A1 Rivals Clash in Spanish Voting Spaniards go to the polls Sunday to elect local and regional officials, but parochial concerns have been overshadowed by a debate between the Socialist prime minister and the leader of the conservative Popular Party. The vote is in many ways a dry run for next year's general election. A9 British Terror Trials Criticized Peter Clarke, the head of British counterterrorism at Scotland Yard, criticized what he called excessive secrecy in Britain's terrorism trials. He called for changes that would permit freer reporting and wider discussion of the issue, preventing broad public skepticism and suspicion about the scale of a threat. A11 Israel Seizes 33 Palestinians Israel stepped up its campaign against Hamas, arresting 33 prominent West Bank Palestinians in raids and accusing them of ''terrorist activity,'' army officials said in a statement, describing those arrested as ''senior members of the Hamas terror organization.'' A3 NATIONAL A12-17 Poll Shows Americans Support Immigration Bill As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans -- Democrats, Republicans and independents alike -- for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 Americans view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the poll. A16 House Approves Lobby Bill The House voted to drag into public view the role that lobbyists play in soliciting and collecting contributions for political campaigns, exposing how influence-seekers ingratiate themselves with lawmakers and presidents. A17 Cemeteries in Need of Money Historic cemeteries, desperate for money to pay for badly needed restorations, are reaching out to the public in ever more unusual ways, including dog parades and bird-watching lectures, as Americans choose cremations in record numbers. A1 Congress Backs Higher Wage Congress approved the first increase in the federal minimum wage rate in a decade, handing a major victory to low-income workers. A12 Senate Keeps Immigration Plan The Senate voted to keep a provision that offers legal status to most of the nation's 12 million illegal immigrants, turning aside the most significant challenge to the comprehensive immigration bill now under debate. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Low-Paying Health Jobs Fuel Employment Growth Poor-paying positions in health care and social work -- with little prospects for upward mobility -- have accounted for most of the growth in employment in New York City in the last 15 years, according to the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The jobs accounts for nearly one-third of all private-sector jobs and wages in Brooklyn and the Bronx. A1 H.I.V. Tests for Rape Suspects Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a majority of New York State lawmakers are backing a bill requiring H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges. But its chances of passage are unclear. B1 War Hangs Over Cadets The war in Iraq has hovered over the class of 2007 at the United States Military Academy in West Point. The 1,000-plus cadets who will graduate this weekend were the first to enter West Point after the invasion of Iraq in March 2003. B1 OBITUARIES B7 Philip M. Kaiser A diplomat or political appointee under every Democratic president from Harry S. Truman to Jimmy Carter, he was 93. B7 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Ignoring the warnings, again?; get moving on traffic relief; closer to reform; lighting the way. Columns: Paul Krugman and David Brooks. BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Pay Gap at the Very Top As executive pay surges in most American companies, attention has focused on the growing gap between the earnings of top executives and the average wage of workers. Less noticed is how wide the gap has become between top officers and their immediate subordinates. A1 Business Digest C2 Crossword E31 TV Listings E23 Weather B8

Jordin Sparks was not the only winner on Wednesday, the final night of the television season. As this 17-year-old singer took home the sixth ''American Idol'' crown, the finale's predictably commanding ratings helped make Fox the highest-rated network for the season among adults 18 to 49. Fox has won that title for three consecutive years. Nielsen estimated approximately 29.5 million viewers tuned in to the show's final installment from 8 to 10, down slightly from its performance last year but far ahead of ABC's finale of ''Lost,'' which ranked second for the night. The ''Lost'' finale had 13.7 million viewers from 9 to 11, in line with its performance this season but down more sharply than ''Idol,'' compared with a year ago, falling 17 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS finished third with reruns on the night; NBC ranked fourth as its repeat broadcast of ''Saturday Night Live in the '90s: Pop Culture Nation'' drew just 4.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

An article on Sunday about Wynn Handman, an acting teacher and director in New York who was honored on Monday for his 85th birthday by students and protégés, misspelled the given name of one former student and misstated the name of a drama program for high school students produced by American Place Theater, which Mr. Handman founded. The former student is the actress Allison Janney, not Alison, and the program is Literature to Life, not Literacy for Life.

A Brooklyn man who opened fire at a Queens nightclub in 2004, killing one person and wounding two others, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 75 years to life in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Moises Valerio, 32, of Hull Street in East New York, was convicted on May 4, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Valerio, angry at being ejected from Club Phenomenon in Woodside on May 22, 2004, grabbed a gun from his car, returned to the club and fired on the club's security officers. One, Francisco Rosa, 35, an off-duty state court officer, was killed.

AnamorPoses Bortolami Dayan 510 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through June 23 In ''AnamorPoses,'' the Italian artist Luigi Ontani cleverly plays with anamorphosis, a mode of image making that requires viewers to look at an artwork from a specific angle or with a special contraption to see its intended meaning. Mr. Ontani, for whom every piece is a self-portrait, combines representational tricks with masquerades to demonstrate how art can produce personality.

Rental 120 East Broadway, at Allen Street, Lower East Side Through June 16 Rental, the latest addition to the expanding Lower East Side gallery scene, is the first one to have the light and views -- if not the interior design -- of a Chelsea space, thanks to its location on the sixth floor of a corner building with big windows. But that is not its distinguishing characteristic: true to its name, and like its predecessor in Los Angeles, Rental is for rent to selected out-of-town dealers. The first Rental was founded in 2005 by Daniel Hug and Joel Mesler; the New York version has been set up by Mr. Mesler.

THURM--Evelyn, of Princeton, NJ, died peacefully on May 23, 2007. Born in Lowell, MA she was a former resident of Boston and a graduate of Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing. Mrs. Thurm was a member of The Jewish Center, Princeton Historical Society and Jewish Women International. Wife of the late Dr. Richard H. Thurm, she is survived by two sons David A. Thurm of Bronxville, NY and Dr. Daniel W. Thurm of Sharon, MA, a daughter Karen Thurm Safran of San Jose, CA, a sister Carole Paris of Ridgewood, NJ, and seven grandchildren. Services Friday 10 AM at The Jewish Center, 435 Nassau St., Princeton, NJ. Burial at Union Field Cemetery. Contributions may be offered to Jewish Women International.

KAISER--Philip M., died May 24, age 93, after a brief illness. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Hannah Greeley Kaiser; his three sons, Robert G., David E. and Charles R.; and four grandchildren. Services 1pm Friday, May 25, at Adas Israel Synagogue, 2850 Quebec St. NW, Washington, D.C.

A picture with the Havens column last Friday about San Clemente, Calif., was published in error. The house shown in the photograph was recently sold; it was not a two-bedroom house priced at $2,687,500.

MANOOKIAN--Adrienne, on May 22, 2007. Cherished mother of Susan Mannes and the late Kenneth Manookian. Beloved aunt and friend of Wendy Eberson. Services Sunday, 11:30am, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A man was shot in the shoulder during a gunfight with plainclothes officers in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. Charges were pending against the man, Ron Tribble, 21, who was treated at St. Barnabas Hospital and released, the police said. The confrontation began at 173rd Street and Webster Avenue shortly before 4 a.m., the police said, when Mr. Tribble and another man flagged down an unmarked car carrying three plainclothes officers, possibly believing the car was a livery cab. After an officer rolled down his window, Mr. Tribble ran, the police said. The officers chased Mr. Tribble, and two of them fired after they saw him readying a gun to fire, the police said. After firing at the officers, Mr. Tribble jumped a fence, and was later found hiding in a yard, the police said. CARA BUCKLEY

HOROWITZ--Frances K. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi $(6$)HOROWITZ--Frances K. (Ginsburg), 97, of Scarsdale, New York, died on May 23, 2007. The beloved wife of the late Bernard Horowitz and the loving sister of the late Dr. Meyer Ginsburg and the Lillian Lukashok. She is survived by her loving sons Larry Horowitz and Dan Horowitz, her devoted daughters-inlaw Beth Horowitz and Vicki Horowitz, her loving grandchildren Peter Horowitz and his wife YukikoJane, Alex Horowitz and Roger Horowitz. She was also preceded in death by her loving husband Harold Klipstein. Born in New York, January 22, 1910, to Abraham and Annie Ginsburg. She attended Erasmus Hall High School and New York University. An avid volunteer, she spent a large part of her life in helping others as a volunteer at White Plains Hospital for more than 34 years and also volunteered at Blythedale Hospital for 15 years. She also recorded for the blind. She was extremely active in the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY, where she served on numerous committees. She had a life-long love of the arts and music and filled her home with grace and beauty. Funeral Services will be held Friday, May 25, at 1:00 pm at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Contributions may be made to the Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund at White Plains Hospital Center, care of Development -Patricia Laine, 122 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY 10601 checks should be made to White Plains Hospital Center, on the memo line please write Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund.

Bernard Lagat of the United States and Craig Mottram of Australia, two of the world's leading runners, will compete in the mile June 2 in the Reebok Grand Prix at Icahn Stadium on Randall's Island. Meet officials announced the field yesterday. It includes Alan Webb and Chris Lukezic of the United States, Nick Willis of New Zealand and Kevin Sullivan of Canada. Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia, the women's world champion at 5,000 and 10,000 meters, will run the 5,000.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Manoel de Oliveira In Portuguese, with English subtitles Not rated; 137 minutes The Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira's ''Magic Mirror,'' a dreamy satire about class, is centered on a rich woman named Alfreda (Leonor Silveira), who has been praying for a sighting of the Virgin Mary her whole life and is baffled and annoyed that it hasn't happened.

Works, 1971-1979 Deitch Projects 76 Grand Street, SoHo Through June 2 Portraits Mary Boone Gallery 541 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through June 30 These exhibitions bracket the congenial career of Francesco Clemente, the most resilient of the Italian Neo-Expressionists who took New York by storm in the early 1980s. At Deitch Projects the Clemente of the 1970s, a young, restless proto-Neo-Expressionist, overcomes the gravitational pull of Post-Minimalism and especially Arte Povera. At Mary Boone he assumes the relatively recent guise of suave society portraitist working on commission, operating stylistically somewhere between David Hockney and Andy Warhol.

PALIN--Caryl. Words cannot express our overwhelming sadness. We will miss the great warmth, humor and love of our lifelong friend. Shep, Susan, Steven, Rachel and Marc Forest $(6$)PALIN--Caryl. The Board of Directors, staff, and members of the Food Allergy Initiative mourn the loss of Caryl Palin, our dear friend and dedicated volunteer. Caryl played a key role in FAI's growth, inspiring a family tradition of support for our signature spring luncheon, cochaired today by her daughter-in-law, Roxanne. We offer our deepest condolences to Caryl's husband, Michael; to Roxanne and her husband, Dean; to her daughters, Andrea and Dorothy; and to her nine grandchildren. Through her commitment to finding a cure, Caryl has left a legacy of hope to all who knew her, and to millions of children and families affected by lifethreatening food allergies. Todd J. 'Star Wars,' the Way You Like It Twenty-first-century technology will combine with fantasy of ''a long time ago'' beginning today, when a redesigned StarWars.com, unveiled at the time of the 30th anniversary of the first ''Star Wars'' film, directed by George Lucas, right, will empower fans to get into the action. An online video-editing tool from the Eyespot Corporation of San Diego will make it possible for devotees of the heroes and villains of the epic series to edit their homemade videos into more than 250 scenes and the music from all six of the films. The Web site is also putting online a new collection of hundreds of user-generated ''Star Wars'' videos, five years of ''Star Wars'' Fan Movie Festival shorts and mini-documentaries about the making of the saga. Jeff Ulin, senior director of distribution and online for Lucasfilm, said: ''Since 1977, 'Star Wars' has been built on the idea that our fans are the reason we have been successful, and they have long shown their enormous creativity and desire to have fun and express themselves through 'Star Wars.' Our new site brings our fans innovative tools like the Eyespot editor that let them do just that in exciting ways.'' Seems Like Old Times Paul Simon, above right, Art Garfunkel, left, and Mr. Simon's South African collaborators, the Zulu choir Ladysmith Black Mambazo, brought back the past in two rare reunions in a concert sponsored by the Library of Congress at the ornate Warner Theater in Washington on Wednesday, Reuters reported. Celebrating Mr. Simon's selection as the recipient of the library's first Gershwin Award in recognition of excellence exemplifying the Gershwins, the concert was punctuated by high-fives and hugs. Mr. Simon joined Ladysmith Black Mambazo for the first time since 1999 in a performance of ''Diamonds on the Soles of Her Shoes'' from the 1986 Grammy Award-winning ''Graceland'' album and said, ''I haven't performed with them for a few years, but they're my brothers from South Africa.'' And before launching into ''Cecilia'' and ''Bridge Over Troubled Water'' from the 1970 studio album of the same title, he spoke of ''My dear friend and partner in arguments, Art Garfunkel,'' whom he also embraced. Keira Knightley Wins Lawsuit Over Weight Angered by a newspaper article that depicted her as dangerously thin, Keira Knightley, a star of the ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' films, has gained 3,000 pounds -- 3,000 British pounds, that is, or nearly $6,000, the BBC reported. The money was awarded to this 22-year-old actress by the High Court in London yesterday as damages in a libel suit she brought against The Daily Mail for publishing a photograph of her in a bikini on a beach with remarks about her weight with an article in January about a 19-year-old woman, Sophie Mazurek, who died of anorexia. Ms. Knightley's lawyer said the ''deeply offensive'' suggestions could imply that she had an eating disorder and bore responsibility for the woman's death. Ms. Knightley's mother, Sharman Macdonald, said her daughter planned to match the award and donate the money to charity. An 11-year-old director has settled his lawsuit against the patron who he claimed demanded creative control over his short film, The Associated Press reported. The child, Dominic Scott Kay, the voice of the pig Wilbur in ''Charlotte's Web,'' sued Conroy Kanter after she put about $11,000 into his 15-minute film, ''Saving Angelo.'' Mr. Kay's lawyer said that as part of the settlement, Ms. Kanter will receive a producer credit, and he will get full rights to the film, starring Kevin Bacon and based on Mr. Kay's real-life effort to nurse back to health an abandoned, injured dog. Borat Writes Borat Sagdiyev, the boorish Kazakh creation of the British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen, below, will dispense travel advice when he turns author of two books for the price of one. In a deal with Flying Dolphin Press, an imprint of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group of Random House, Borat will write a guide to the United States for Kazakhs and a guide to Kazakhstan for Westerners. Released as a single volume, the book will have two titles: ''Borat: Touristic Guidings to Minor Nation of U.S. and A.'' and ''Borat: Touristic Guidings to Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan.'' Publication is scheduled for Nov. 6. Sister Helen Prejean, who wrote the best seller ''Dead Man Walking,'' will write ''River of Fire,'' an autobiographical book about her spiritual journey from contemplative and cloistered life to moral and political activism, for Random House. Publication is expected in early 2009. Footnotes The all-author band Rock Bottom Remainders, featuring Stephen King, Dave Barry, Amy Tan and Mitch Albom, among others, will perform for charity on June 1 at 9 p.m. at Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village. Information is available at: rockbottomremainders.com. Debbie Harry of Blondie will release her first solo album in 14 years, ''Necessary Evil,'' on Aug. 7 on Eleven Seven Music. She begins the True Colors tour with Cyndi Lauper, Erasure, the Dresden Dolls and the Gossip on June 8 in Las Vegas. Even before its official opening, on June 14, the run of the Atlantic Theater Company world premiere musical ''10 Million Miles,'' with music and lyrics by Patty Griffin and book by Keith Bunin, has been extended for two weeks, through July 15. The Royal Theater of Denmark has commissioned an opera based on Lars von Trier's 2000 film, ''Dancer in the Dark,'' starring Bjork and Catherine Deneuve, The Associated Press reported. Poul Ruders will write the music; Henrik Engelbrecht, the English-language libretto. The opera is scheduled to have its premiere in the 2010-11 season. Celebrating its 75th-anniversary season, the Royal Ballet of Britain will tour Mexico for the first time in 30 years, visiting Mexico City, Guadalajara and Puebla from June 14 to 30 with Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' Ninette de Valois's ''Coppélia'' and a mixed program.

STECKEL--Cantor Harold, on May 20, at 87 years of age. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Flora, sons Mark and Joph, daughters-in-law Cynthia and Beth, and grandchildren Jenna, Carly, Henry, Isabel, George, and Lily. A graduate of City College with a B.S. and MBA. Worked as the Medicare representative at the Health and Hospital Corporation of New York City. Well known cantor at Tamarack Lodge. Lecturer of operas, symphonic music, musical theater, and Jewish liturgy at Elderhostels in New York and Pennsylvania. He will be dearly missed by family, friends, and Elderhostel seniors.

In the May 23 Editorial Observer about fires in California: John Cheever's journal mentioned burning ghats, not burning gnats. Ghats are stairs from temples to the Ganges River in India, where Hindus traditionally construct funeral pyres. Gnats, of course, are tiny insects.

A day after fracturing a bone in his right foot, Shawn Green said he remained hopeful that he would not need to go on the disabled list for the first time in his career. He will have to wait a few more days until doctors re-evaluate the injury Tuesday in New York.

There's a new video from Nick's journey across China. He visited a petitioner who's in Beijing trying to get party officials to help her with injustices her family suffered after a mining accident. These petitioners, who come from all across China seeking redress for injustices, are already feeling the squeeze from authorities who are afraid that such people will mar Beijing's image during the Olympics. The government destroyed the "petitioners' village" where they lived in Beijing, and the authorities are sending more of them into detention centers or back to their home villages.

As I travel around China, I've been asking about Darfur. Most ordinary people seem unaware of it - and unaware of Chinese support for the Sudanese regime as it conducts genocide in Darfur. But government and Communist Party officials are acutely aware of the situation and deeply sensitive to it. The campaign to tie Darfur to the Olympics is working.

This is not a very original post, as it was surely the biggest moment of the whole day and will therefore be covered by all of the web sites and blogs and newspapers everywhere. But because of that fact, I just felt I had to write about Kimi Raikkonen's disaster in qualifying this time. I suppose the only new insight that I can bring to it is simply to describe the outcry, the roar, the laughter that erupted in the media center when Kimi Raikkonen parked his Ferrari in the Rascasse corner at exactly the same spot where Michael Schumacher parked his during qualifying last year on this day in Monaco.

A tournament that allows players to use computers will begin this Friday on Playchess.com, an Internet chess server. This will be the sixth PAL/CSS Freestyle tournament, all of them sponsored by PAL Group in Abu Dhabi, the developer of Hydrachess, a chess supercomputer. The prize fund is $16,000.
On patrol with the officers of Newark's Fifth Precinct during the violent Friday night shift.

Attention, global-warming wonks. Ronald Bailey has a must-read (and surprisingly readable, given the subject) post at Reason analyzing ways to slow emissions of greenhouse gases. He compares the favorite appraoch of economists, a carbon tax, with the favorite approach on Capitol Hill and the presidential campaign trail, a carbon market that would put a cap on emissions and allow companies to buy and sell emission permits. You can guess which approach looks better, but it's worth learning exactly why.

The Yankees played Saturday's game with the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim without Johnny Damon, their regular centerfielder and leadoff hitter, who left Friday night's game in the seventh inning with sore calves in both legs and also pain in his right Achilles.
On patrol with the officers of Newark's Fifth Precinct during the violent Saturday night shift.
The search for three abducted American soldiers produced four more casualties and highlighted the dangers of the new American strategy for Iraq, Damien Cave reports.

The "Surreal Things" exhibit which is one from now until July 22nd at the Victoria and Albert Museum is a small multifaceted gem and even fun for kids. I saw it a couple of weeks back in London, and would fly back just to see it again. Thats how wonderful it is!
Like bacon, eggs and cereal, the topics of immigration, Iraq and presidential politics once again dominate Sunday's Breakfast Menu.
Days after a comrade was killed during a search for missing soldiers, a team is back out on patrol.
There's a press release out from Jaguar celebrating the 50th anniversary of its dominating finish at the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1957, when D-Types finished first, second, third, fourth and sixth.

It's tragic that the Arab news media haven't covered Darfur more effectively, for that would put real pressure on Sudan. Particularly in the aftermath of the catastrophic American invasion of Iraq, it's easy for Sudan to dismiss American complaints about Darfur, but it would be harder to dismiss accounts in the Egyptian or Saudi press.
The week ends on a defensive note for the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, with early reports of two new, critical biographies and now a lawsuit against a benefactor.

Taking the lead this month is "At the Center of the Storm," the controversial new book by former C.I.A. director George Tenet.
Amy Smith, the sales director at Chesterton estate agency in London, had this to say about the importance of open days:
In early May, retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic Military Sports Camp in Colorado and discovered unknown athletic talent.
Ukraine’s President Viktor Yushchenko ordered extra troops into the capital as he haggled with his main rival over a date for parliamentary elections.
Rudolph W. Giuliani showed up at the graduation of his daughter, Caroline, who is now bound for Harvard.
The fighting came a day after the Mahdi Army militia’s leader, the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, came out of hiding.
Israel bombed a series of Hamas buildings and arrested another Palestinian cabinet minister.
Green broke his right metatarsal bone when he fouled a pitch off his foot. He will be out for an undetermined amount of time.
Poor relief pitching plagued the Yankees Friday, as the bullpen gave up three runs in the fifth inning and four more in the sixth.
Orlando Hernández joined in the Marlins’ celebration of Cuban Heritage Night by allowing only two hits over six scoreless innings.
NEW YORK.

Two people were hospitalized and dozens more were evacuated from nine residential buildings in Brooklyn last night after an overloaded electrical system caused a carbon monoxide leak, the Fire Department said.
General Manager Brian Cashman kept his options open when addressing the question that every Yankees fan wants answered: When will Clemens join the team?
Pedro Martínez vowed that he will return to his outstanding late-1990s form with Boston and boldly remarked that he could pitch better than Roger Clemens.
When he competes in the Coca-Cola 600 on Sunday, Bill Elliott will join the  list of acclaimed drivers who have raced in the No. 21 Ford owned by the Wood Brothers.

Ronny Paulino’s bases-loaded double highlighted the Pittsburgh Pirates’ biggest rally in nearly three years, an eight-run splurge in the 10th that set up a 10-4 victory against the host Cincinnati Reds last night.
The Newark Bears’ stadium has minor league baseball all summer but, for now at least, no beer to go along with it.
Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, said his trans-Atlantic cruise, paid for by a company that does business with the city, was a working trip.
Albert L. Lord will receive $224.9 million for his stock options as part of the company’s $25 billion takeover.

The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “Pearl Harbor,” by Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchen, misstated the phrase that President Franklin D. Roosevelt used in referring to Dec. 7, 1941, the day of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. He called it “a date which will live in infamy,” not a “day” that will live in infamy.

A report in the Metro Briefing column on May 17 included incorrect information from the New York City Department of Education about the number of charter schools that are overseen by the department, New York State and the State University of New York. The department oversees 31 such schools, not 38. The state and SUNY oversee a total of 27, not 20.
Schedule information on Thursday with a theater review of “Gaslight,” at the Irish Repertory Theater in Chelsea, misstated the box office telephone number. It is (212) 727-2737.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about economic talks between China and the United States misstated the American trade deficit in 2006, a contentious issue between the two countries. The total deficit was $765 billion last year — not $232 billion, which is the amount of America’s trade deficit with China.

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Philip M. Kaiser, a former ambassador to Austria, Hungary and Senegal, gave an incorrect year in some copies for the beginning of his service as ambassador to Senegal. It was 1961, not 1962. The byline also misspelled the given name of the writer in some copies. He is Steven R. Weisman, not Stephen.
Corrections: For the Record

An article on Thursday about the presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, and how it could be affected by the battle over immigration, referred incorrectly in some copies to his state’s Hispanic population. New Mexico has the highest percentage of Hispanics in the country; it does not have the highest percentage of Hispanic immigrants in the country.

An article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News poll that measured opinion about the Iraq war misstated the date of the first Times/CBS News poll that included a question about whether the United States did the right thing in taking military action in Iraq. It was December 2003, not January 2003. (The war did not begin until March 2003.).
An article in The Arts on Tuesday about plans for 3-D movies using new technology referred incorrectly to the showing of 3-D movies on DVDs. Such films can in fact be shown on DVDs, and have been.
The reaction is mixed to a new proposal by Mayor Michael Bloomberg that would make it easier for traffic agents to write tickets for “blocking the box.”

Radovan Stankovic, a former Bosnian Serb soldier who was the first war-crimes defendant sent from the United Nations court in The Hague to be tried and convicted in Bosnia, escaped from custody while being taken to a hospital after complaining of feeling ill, the authorities said. Local news reports said he was grabbed by accomplices who cut off the vehicle as it approached the hospital in the town of Foca. Foca was the site of a rape house set up by Mr. Stankovic after Bosnian Serb forces took control of the town in 1992. His sentence of 16 years in prison for war crimes included detaining Muslim women and turning them into sex slaves for fellow soldiers.

The center-left government announced that it had agreed to an amnesty for up to 30,000 failed asylum-seekers. The amnesty, a clear break with the tough immigration policies of the former center-right government and its immigration minister, Rita Verdonk, applies to failed asylum-seekers who entered the country before 2001. As part of the plan, the government will give municipalities $74 million to provide housing and integration courses.

Jenny Bailey, 45, was installed as mayor of Cambridge, and her partner, Jennifer Liddle, 49, a former council member, assumed the honorary title of mayoress, which is given to the partner of the mayor. Both were born male and had gender reassignment surgery in their 30s. “It is the council’s firm view that someone’s gender and sexual orientation has no bearing on their suitability to hold public office,” said Rob Hammond, the Cambridge Council’s chief executive.

Bertie Ahern, who presided over Ireland’s transformation into one of Europe’s most successful and competitive economies during his 10 years as prime minister, appeared headed for a third term, according to preliminary results from parliamentary elections on Thursday. But while the numbers indicated that his centrist Fianna Fail party would have the most seats in Parliament, the question awaiting the final count, which could extend through the weekend, was which other parties might join a coalition government and give Mr. Ahern a majority.

A roadside bomb killed a Canadian soldier on patrol with Afghan troops near Kandahar. The soldier was part of a team training Afghans to help bring security to the south of the country. He was the 55th soldier Canada has lost since sending troops to Afghanistan in 2002.

President Nicolas Sarkozy broke with tradition and decided there would be no amnesty for petty driving offenses to accompany his election. “The law must apply in the same manner to all,” his spokesman said. It has been the norm for newly elected French presidents to waive hundreds of thousands of fines pending against motorists. Road safety advocates have lobbied hard for it to be stopped.
College Baseball.

The military dictatorship extended the house arrest of the pro-democracy leader and 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi for another year. Her current one-year detention was due to expire tomorrow. The extension was expected despite calls by international groups and world leaders for her freedom. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, 61, has not left the country, formerly Burma, since 1988 and has been confined to her residence in Yangon for more than 11 of the past 18 years.

The top prosecutors of Russia and Britain quarreled over a British demand to extradite a former K.G.B. security officer accused of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko in London last November. After a meeting of justice officials from the Group of 8 countries in Munich, Russia’s prosecutor general, Yuri Y. Chaika, said the suspect, Andrei K. Lugovoi, could face trial in Russia, provided the British provide “evidence proving Lugovoi’s guilt,” but he reiterated Russia’s refusal to extradite him. The British attorney general, Peter Goldsmith, responded that British justice should decide the matter. “This murder was committed on U.K. soil,” he said in a statement. “The evidence is in the U.K. A U.K. citizen was killed and other people put at risk. And it is therefore right a suspect should face justice in a U.K. court.”.

North Korea test-fired several short-range missiles from its eastern coast into the Sea of Japan. The tests, believed to be part of annual drills, did not constitute a “grave issue for Japan’s security,” Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said. The launchings occurred even as American officials continued to try to obtain the release of North Korean funds from a bank in Macao, a critical step in February’s nuclear agreement.

A police campaign to crack down on pickpockets has come too late to help Oslo’s top crime fighter. Police Chief Anstein Gjengedal’s wallet was snatched on a train by a pickpocket as the campaign was set to begin, the newspaper Dagbladet reported. A group of people jostled him, and when he checked a few minutes later, his wallet was gone.

’ The National Park Service will recommend paying a cash settlement rather than complete the so-called Road to Nowhere in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, officials said. The recommendation will be part of a Final Environmental Impact Statement, which will probably be published in September, the park superintendent, Dale Ditmanson, said. The road, from Bryson City to Fontana Dam in far western Swain County, was designed to replace one that was flooded in the 1940s. The federal government promised to replace it as long as Congress provided financing, but environmental concerns and high costs halted construction in 1972. An earlier draft of the impact statement estimated it would cost about $600 million to complete the road. Swain County requested $52 million to settle.

The freeway that collapsed after a fiery tanker crash has reopened just 25 days after the accident. The elevated section of highway that carries traffic from the east end of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge was leveled April 29 after a gasoline tanker truck crashed and burned. Officials and commuters initially thought it would take weeks, possibly months, to fix. But traffic exited the bridge Thursday night and cruised for the first time over a new 165-foot stretch of highway. The lower deck reopened within 10 days of the collapse. The California Highway Patrol suspended the hazardous-materials license of the trucking company involved in the fire.

Congress has agreed to a tenfold increase in special immigrant visas for Iraqi and Afghan translators and interpreters, whose work with American military personnel and diplomatic officials makes them targets for terrorists. The legislation, approved by voice vote in the Senate late Thursday, would authorize the issuance of 500 such visas a year over the next two years to translators. The government now issues 50 visas a year to translators who have worked a year for the American military.

The body of a man was discovered in a ventilation shaft above the cafeteria of a Phoenix elementary school after a parent noticed a foul odor coming from the school, Sgt. Andy Hill said. A maintenance worker climbed to the roof and found the body, Sergeant Hill said. The police in Phoenix, where temperatures have hovered around 100 degrees for the past week, believe that the man was trying to break in to the school, and they are investigating how long the body had been in the air duct and the cause of death. “We have an adult male who took the top off and forced his way into the vent and died,” the sergeant said. School officials evacuated about 850 students and closed the school on what was a regularly scheduled early release day.

A former Red Cross executive in Orange County has pleaded guilty to federal charges that she embezzled at least $110,000 of the organization’s money. The woman, Karen Shuerger, 58, pleaded guilty to four of five charges Wednesday and will be sentenced this summer. Investigators are still trying to determine how much money was involved. Ms. Shuerger, who now lives in Henderson, Nev., resigned in October 2005 as assistant director of accounting. Red Cross officials then discovered the misappropriated money, spent largely on vacation spots, and said they had since put in place better monitoring of finances.

The space shuttle pilot at the center of a love triangle that included a former astronaut who now faces charges of attempted kidnapping is leaving NASA. The pilot, Cmdr. Bill Oefelein, will leave NASA on June 1, nearly four months after the authorities believe his cooled relationship with another astronaut, Lisa Nowak, led her to drive 900 miles from Houston to Orlando, Fla., and confront her romantic rival. NASA requested a reassignment. The Navy expects to assign Commander Oefelein, 42, to the Naval Network Warfare Command in Norfolk, Va.

The House Judiciary Committee chairman asked Paul J. McNulty, left, the deputy attorney general, to appear before the panel to respond to accusations by Monica M. Goodling, a former Justice Department aide, in her testimony to the panel earlier this week. Ms. Goodling said Mr. McNulty failed to testify fully when he appeared in February before a Senate panel and knew more than he had acknowledged about the extent of White House involvement in last year’s dismissal of federal prosecutors. The chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said in a letter to the Justice Department that the testimony was “clearly necessary.”.
A teenager was charged with felony hate crimes yesterday for tearing off the turban of a Sikh schoolmate and shearing his hair, the authorities said.
Thousands of consumers are lining up to buy small cars, but they are not giving up their S.U.V.’s and pickups.
Going into the French Open, which begins Sunday, Novak Djokovic has won five singles titles on the ATP Tour, including this year’s Masters Series event in Miami.
Some of the 4,450 patients enrolled in a large clinical study have dropped out because of safety concerns about Avandia.
The supply of unsold properties on the market ballooned and prices declined compared with those a year earlier.
President Bush is waging an aggressive battle with Republicans as he tries to persuade them to support an immigration bill.
Allegations surfaced that an area set aside for peace talks, which a foreign diplomat helped oversee, turned into the party ground for outlawed Colombian paramilitaries.
Details have emerged about the relationship of former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton with Vinod Gupta, the founder of infoUSA.
On the 2008 budget, the president should stop posturing and start working with lawmakers, for the good of his own legacy and for all the people who need the government’s services and protections.
It would be more than stunning if the Utah Jazz, a contender built out of mostly spare parts, won four of the remaining five games to win the series against the Spurs.
George Steinbrenner created anxiety around his underperforming team with comments that put pressure on General Manager Brian Cashman.
The scheme by employees at a Sterling Financial subsidiary could cost as much as $165 million and might force the sale of the company.
Internal deliberations described by senior officials are the first indication that the Bush administration is considering what happens after the troop increase.
Shareholders at roughly 20 companies have pushed say-on-pay proposals. And Congress appears ready to act if companies don’t.
The preliminary decision applies to patients over 60, which is most of the 43 million people Medicare covers.
As New Jersey’s Gov. Jon Corzine makes clear in a new public service commercial, he would’ve been a lot better off if he had been wearing his seat belt.
Summer on Fire Island starts with a hyperventilating scramble to prepare houses for seasonal residents.
If there is progress in the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan, news about how 9/11 affected people’s health only gets worse.
Chelsea D. Gerlach was sentenced to prison time for her role in “the family,” a group of people who have been convicted of arson and other destructive actions.
The forum in St. Petersburg will focus on gains in the economy that have been overshadowed by negative political news from Russia.
When Rudolph W. Giuliani was an official at the Justice Department, he bristled at the way a reporter inquired into his ownership of a Yankee Stadium seat.
Rochester, N.Y., spent millions on a high-speed ferry to Canada, but the effort seems to have aggravated the woes of a city already beset with serious problems.
The Glacéau deal offered evidence that coming up with a new beverage, or putting a new twist on an old one, can be lucrative.
Governments in Gulf Coast areas devastated by the 2005 hurricanes will no longer be required to pay 10 percent of the cost of repairing their public works.

THE United States and China ended talks with unfinished business, as China took a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group. The Tracinda Corporation of Kirk Kerkorian sought to buy two Las Vegas properties for an estimated $12 billion, and Coca-Cola moved to broaden its noncarbonated beverage portfolio with a $4.1 billion deal. On Monday, an affiliate company of Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire stock trader, reported in a regulatory filing its interest in buying two of the more expensive Las Vegas properties held by MGM Mirage: the stylish Bellagio casino-hotel and the partly built CityCenter, a vast condominium-hotel project that MGM says is the most expensive privately financed project in United States history.

To celebrate its 60th anniversary, the festival commissioned 30 filmmakers -- all but one of them men, in unfortunate adherence to the Cannes alpha-male tradition -- to direct a series of three-minute shorts on the subject of movies. The results, an anthology called ''To Each His Own Cinema,'' has been screened several times in its entirety, but the best way to see these films has been one at a time, as a series of tasty screening room hors d'oeuvres before the start of officially selected features. Each short is stamped with the personality of its director. Lars von Trier's is a sick joke (and a pretty funny one) about how a filmmaker might deal with a boorish patron at a gala screening. Claude Lelouch tells his life story as a series of memorable moviegoing moments, starting with his parents' first meeting at a cinema in 1937.

Roger Clemens will start for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Monday, General Manager Brian Cashman said yesterday. But Cashman kept his options open when addressing the question that every Yankees fan wants answered: When will Clemens join the team? ''We'll take it start by start,'' Cashman said. ''We're evaluating him after each start. I've said prior to this that we want him when he's ready, no sooner than that and no later than that. His preparation is to get back and try to help this team. He takes his next step into Scranton, and we'll see what we see after Monday's start.''

The Smithsonian Institution's proposed budget should be cut by $26 million, a House subcommittee voted on Thursday, down from the $678 million requested by the White House in February. The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Interior, Environment and Related Agencies, which oversees federal cultural appropriations, recommended the 4 percent cut to the fiscal 2008 budget ''based on significant problems of governance and fiscal policies at the institution.'' The Smithsonian has been plagued by problems. Its top official, Lawrence M. Small, resigned in March after disclosures of extravagant spending. In April, a Senate committee insisted that the institution improve its governance and try to raise more of its own money. The Smithsonian gets 70 percent of its $1 billion annual operating budget from the government. The Board of Regents, its governing body, has been addressing questions of financial oversight under a new acting secretary, Cristián Samper. ROBIN POGREBIN

INTERNATIONAL A2-8 U.S. Said to Be Developing Plan for Troop Reduction The Bush administration is developing what are described as concepts for reducing American combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year, according to officials familiar with the debate. It is the first indication that political pressure is forcing the White House to turn its attention to what happens after the current troop increase runs its course. The critics in Cannes are a notoriously contentious bunch, but something close to a consensus has formed that this festival has new vitality at 60. Some years, a disappointing lineup in the main competition sends impatient crowds to the sidebar programs, but this year the big show is receiving most of the attention and acclaim. Joining the list of top-tier contenders for the Palme d'Or is ''Secret Sunshine,'' from the South Korean director Lee Chang-dong. Mr. Lee, who turned to filmmaking after a long career as a novelist (and who has also served as his country's minister of culture), brings a contemplative, literary sensibility to a story that might easily have lent itself to melodrama and sensationalism. It is about a young widow from Seoul who moves with her son to her husband's hometown, a small city where she knows nobody.

THE United States and China ended talks with unfinished business, as China took a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group. The Tracinda Corporation of Kirk Kerkorian sought to buy two Las Vegas properties for an estimated $12 billion, and Coca-Cola moved to broaden its noncarbonated beverage portfolio with a $4.1 billion deal. Coca-Cola agreed to pay a hefty $4.1 billion in cash for Glacéau, the maker of Vitaminwater, which earned an estimated $350 million last year.

North Korea test-fired several short-range missiles from its eastern coast into the Sea of Japan. The tests, believed to be part of annual drills, did not constitute a ''grave issue for Japan's security,'' Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said. The launchings occurred even as American officials continued to try to obtain the release of North Korean funds from a bank in Macao, a critical step in February's nuclear agreement. NORIMITSU ONISHI

To the Editor: While the common view is that Haiti is an economic basket case, resulting in Haitians' losing their lives trying to flee to the United States (''New Routes and New Risk to Flee Haiti,'' front page, May 19), the Haitian people remain strong, hard-working and innovative survivors.

The decision by two of the leading Democratic presidential candidates to vote against a bill providing more money for the war in Iraq because it did not set a timetable to withdraw the troops reverberated on the campaign trail yesterday, underscoring the deep divisions over the war between Democrats and Republicans. The two Democrats, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama, quickly found their votes attacked by Republicans.

The question isn't how the French filmmaker Catherine Breillat and that international woman of mystery, Asia Argento, found each other; the question is why did it take them so long? A match made in heaven (for some) or perhaps hell (there were walkouts), ''Une Vieille Maîtresse'' marks a strong return to form for Ms. Breillat and offers continued evidence that Ms. Argento is the reigning queen of Cannes. In the past week, Ms. Argento, the Italian-born actress and sometime director, has torn through Olivier Assayas's ''Boarding Gate,'' where she carries the film on her slender shoulders, and helped keep the flame lighted inside Abel Ferrara's ''Go Go Tales,'' where she bellied up to a stripper pole and exchanged slobber with a Rottweiler. Leave it to Ms. Breillat, whose films include ''Romance,'' a raw, philosophical inquiry about the bedroom, and her last film, the gravely miscalculated ''Anatomy of Hell,'' to push Ms. Argento further yet, and with exhilarating results. Set in 1835 and based on a novel by Jules Barbey d'Aurevilly, ''Une Vieille Maîtresse'' tells the story of a young nobleman, Ryno de Marigny (the newcomer Fu'ad Ait Aattou), who on the eve of his wedding to a delectable sweet named Hermangarde (Roxane Mesquida), finds his future threatened by his scandalous past. Her name would be Vellini, the film's title character and resident outrage, and a creature of such intensely burning, mad passions that it's difficult to imagine any contemporary actress in the role other than Ms. Argento.

It was third time lucky for Robert Greifeld, the chief executive of Nasdaq, who succeeded after failing twice to expand into Europe. Nasdaq, the largest electronic stock market in America, agreed Friday to buy OMX, the operator of seven Nordic and Baltic exchanges, for 25.1 billion Swedish kronor ($3.7 billion).

An article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News poll that measured opinion about the Iraq war misstated the date of the first Times/CBS News poll that included a question about whether the United States did the right thing in taking military action in Iraq. It was December 2003, not January 2003. (The war did not begin until March 2003.)
An article in The Arts on Tuesday about plans for 3-D movies using new technology referred incorrectly to the showing of 3-D movies on DVDs. Such films can in fact be shown on DVDs, and have been.
To the Editor: Re ''Couple Learn the High Price of Easy Credit'' (front page, May 19):

An article on Thursday about the presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, and how it could be affected by the battle over immigration, referred incorrectly in some copies to his state's Hispanic population. New Mexico has the highest percentage of Hispanics in the country; it does not have the highest percentage of Hispanic immigrants in the country.

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Philip M. Kaiser, a former ambassador to Austria, Hungary and Senegal, gave an incorrect year in some copies for the beginning of his service as ambassador to Senegal. It was 1961, not 1962. The byline also misspelled the given name of the writer in some copies. He is Steven R. Weisman, not Stephen.

The prosecutor who in March won the conviction of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on four felony counts in the C.I.A. leak case asked a federal judge on Friday to sentence him to 30 to 37 months in jail. Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the chief federal prosecutor in Chicago who was the special counsel investigating the leak, said Mr. Libby, the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, did not deserve any leniency because he had shown no remorse for his crimes.

He will be missed by his friends and entire family.

The Tracinda Corporation of Kirk Kerkorian sought to buy two Las Vegas properties for an estimated $12 billion, and Coca-Cola moved to broaden its noncarbonated beverage portfolio with a $4.1 billion deal. A ruling this week by a United States appeals court means the firm will not have to stand trial over its refusal to pay the legal fees of 16 indicted former employees.
Schedule information on Thursday with a theater review of ''Gaslight,'' at the Irish Repertory Theater in Chelsea, misstated the box office telephone number. It is (212) 727-2737.
WILKER--Lewis A., May 1, 1911-May 24, 2007. Forever in our hearts. Your Loving Family

GLAZER--Bennett, 81, passed away at his home on May 22, after a long battle with respiratory disease. Bennett was and will continue to be known as the founder of Graphic Image and for his 50 years of design work in the publishing industry. His company, now run by his children, created books that are among the finest leather bindings in the world. His diary designs stand as his masterpiece and are treasured by loyal users everywhere. He is survived by his loving wife Phyllis, his two surviving children, Tom (Elizabeth) and Carol O'Connell (John), and the late Janice Barbone (Luca), and eight loving grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.
