Memorial Day NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only; main post office on Eighth Avenue at 32nd Street is open. BANKS -- Most are closed. PARKING -- Alternate-side and parking meter regulations suspended. SANITATION -- No pickups, street cleaning or recycling. SCHOOLS -- Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS -- Stock and bond markets are closed. TRANSPORTATION -- New York City subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North trains will operate on Sunday schedules. NEW JERSEY GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Federal and state offices are closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only. BANKS -- Most are closed. SCHOOLS -- Most are closed. TRANSPORTATION -- New Jersey Transit trains will operate on weekend and holiday schedules on most lines. Riders should check schedules at njtransit.com. PATH trains will operate on a Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Federal and state offices are closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only. BANKS -- Most are closed. SCHOOLS -- Most are closed. TRANSPORTATION -- Metro-North trains will operate on a Sunday schedule.

Bertie Ahern, who presided over Ireland's transformation into one of Europe's most successful and competitive economies during his 10 years as prime minister, appeared headed for a third term, according to preliminary results from parliamentary elections on Thursday. But while the numbers indicated that his centrist Fianna Fail party would have the most seats in Parliament, the question awaiting the final count, which could extend through the weekend, was which other parties might join a coalition government and give Mr. Ahern a majority. EAMON QUINN

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about economic talks between China and the United States misstated the American trade deficit in 2006, a contentious issue between the two countries. The total deficit was $765 billion last year -- not $232 billion, which is the amount of America's trade deficit with China.

SILVER--Irma Richling, on May 24th, 2007. Survived by her devoted husband of 60 years, Robert H. Silver, two daughters Susan Silver, and Robin Newman, her son-inlaw Demarest (Nick) Newman, her granddaughter Annabel Stephanie Newman and three step-grandchildren Lauren Stein, Stephen Newman, and Christopher Newman. Service Sunday, 1pm at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
To the Editor: Re ''U.S. Casualties May Spike This Summer, Bush Warns'' (news article, May 25):

The top prosecutors of Russia and Britain quarreled over a British demand to extradite a former K.G.B. security officer accused of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko in London last November. After a meeting of justice officials from the Group of 8 countries in Munich, Russia's prosecutor general, Yuri Y. Chaika, said the suspect, Andrei K. Lugovoi, could face trial in Russia, provided the British provide ''evidence proving Lugovoi's guilt,'' but he reiterated Russia's refusal to extradite him. The British attorney general, Peter Goldsmith, responded that British justice should decide the matter. ''This murder was committed on U.K. soil,'' he said in a statement. ''The evidence is in the U.K. A U.K. citizen was killed and other people put at risk. And it is therefore right a suspect should face justice in a U.K. court.'' STEVEN LEE MYERS

To the Editor: ''Bilking the Elderly, With a Corporate Assist'' (front page, May 20) rang disturbingly familiar to me. During the late 1990s, I worked in telemarketing for a telephone carrier.

The Mets lost Shawn Green for an undetermined amount of time Friday night when he broke his right foot during the fifth inning of their 6-2 victory against the Florida Marlins. Green broke his right metatarsal bone when he fouled a pitch off his foot, but he stayed in the game until the ninth, when he was replaced in right field by Carlos Gómez.

ALPERSON--Leo, on May 24, 2007. Beloved husband of June, loving father of Ruth, Myra and Philip, father-in-law of Rockwell and Jane, doting grandfather of Jeremy, Sadie and Reva. A sweet, wonderful and caring man, beloved by all, he was born on May 31, 1920 in Omaha, NE. He served in the US Navy in WWII and lived in White Plains, NY. Funeral Services Sunday May 27, 1:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt Vernon. Donations in his memory to a favorite charity.

A combination of skills -- from shotmaking to mental toughness -- is required to win a Grand Slam event like the French Open, which begins tomorrow. But the individual strengths of players can make a difference at key moments in a match. Here is a look at the best at the game within the game, with the help of a panel of players, former players, executives and coaches: Paul Goldstein, Mary Joe Fernandez, Jürgen Melzer, Sven Groeneveld, Tracy Austin, Larry Stefanki, Brad Gilbert and Roger Gatchalian. WOMEN Forehand Justine Henin Airborne, trunk-twisting physics provide a boost for this 5-foot-5 3/4 Belgian. Svetlana Kuznetsova The big base of success for the most Spanish-like player among the Russians. Ana Ivanovic If only she could move as well as she rips this shot. One-handed backhand Justine Henin Sliced or driven, an enduring thing of beauty. Amélie Mauresmo Less spectacular than Henin's, but heavier. Francesca Schiavone Plenty of Italian flair and a Baroque follow-through. Two-handed backhand Maria Sharapova More technically sound than her unconventional forehand. Jelena Jankovic Best when hit down the line on the run, with elastic limbs flailing. Li Na It is the key to her (and China's) rise into the top 20. Return of serve Serena Williams Best recent reference is her rout of Sharapova in the Australian Open. Elena Dementieva With her serve, it is best to have world-class returns. Lucie Safarova She sees serves very clearly. First Serve Serena Williams It is the key to her revival, and more potent than many of the men's. Maria Sharapova It is better if she gets the first one in these days. Nicole Vaidisova Smooth motion and 6-foot frame serve this 18-year-old well. Second serve Serena Williams Deliberate and, no surprise, forceful. Samantha Stosur Needs to be great to give her a chance to get to the net. Svetlana Kuznetsova The heaviest second serve in the women's game. Touch Martina Hingis Still subtle after all these years. Patty Schnyder Drives bigger women batty with left-handed craft. Amélie Mauresmo A true all-court player, with the spins to match. Volleys Justine Henin Having that one-handed backhand helps at the net. Amélie Mauresmo Won Wimbledon last year by pushing forward. Samantha Stosur Wins doubles titles all year, also by pushing forward. Movement Justine Henin Natural mover who shifts direction like a W.N.B.A. point guard. Jelena Jankovic Hingis 2.0; more about anticipation than pure athleticism. Venus Williams Huge wingspan with foot speed to match along the baseline. Mental toughness Serena Williams Self-belief personified; see life story. Justine Henin Brittle early in career; hard (too hard?) later. Maria Sharapova Despite the occasional meltdown, generally hard to crack. MEN Forehand Roger Federer Conservative grip, outrageous spin and variety. Rafael Nadal Kicks like a second serve on red Paris clay or dry English grass. Fernando González His bazooka shot barely gets the nod over James Blake's. One-handed backhand Richard Gasquet Perpetually surprising, and many insiders' favorite shot in tennis. Roger Federer Nadal has broken it down, but hardly anybody else has. Tommy Haas Even career-threatening shoulder surgery could not dull this weapon. Two-handed backhand Novak Djokovic Stable and huge, and his forehand is coming on strong, too. Andy Murray A delight whether he is on or off balance, but most fun on the run. Marat Safin Not what it was (like the rest of his game) but still a 21st-century classic. First serve Ivo Karlovic At 6 feet 10 inches, he had better have a great serve. Ivan Ljubicic Shorter Croats can slam lots of aces, too. Andy Roddick His coach and head cheerleader, Jimmy Connors, did not teach him this. Second serve Ivan Ljubicic Shorter Croats can win quick points without aces, too. Andy Roddick It does not fool Federer or Murray, but it beats virtually everyone else. Tommy Haas It helped him reach this year's Australian Open semifinals. Returns Lleyton Hewitt With Andre Agassi now a returner emeritus, Hewitt has become the dean. Roger Federer The latest most-underrated part of his game. David Ferrer Hard-working and hard-running, he leads the Tour in return games won. Volleys Tim Henman Henmania has subsided, but this skill remains. Roger Federer As if he did not have enough in the toolbox already. Radek Stepanek He gets plenty of practice with it as a rare serve-and-volleyer. Touch Fabrice Santoro Savor the angles and the artistry; he is 34. Andy Murray No rush; he is 20 (and out of the French Open). Roger Federer Virtuosity is the mother of invention. Movement Rafael Nadal Brad Gilbert calls him the best mover on clay ever. Roger Federer This was an underrated part of his game, until victims started rating it too highly. Nikolay Davydenko Still quick, even after 32 tournaments last year. Mental toughness Lleyton Hewitt Perhaps there is still time for Stallone to watch a Hewitt movie. Rafael Nadal He has faltered here and there, but positive energy is the rule. Roger Federer Why not believe after winning six of the last seven majors?
To the Editor: Re ''Putting More Profit Before Education'' (editorial, May 19):

THE United States and China ended talks with unfinished business, as China took a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group. The Tracinda Corporation of Kirk Kerkorian sought to buy two Las Vegas properties for an estimated $12 billion, and Coca-Cola moved to broaden its noncarbonated beverage portfolio with a $4.1 billion deal. Alcan, the Canadian aluminum producer, rebuffed a $27.4 billion hostile bid from Alcoa this week. But Alcan's position that the offer is inadequate and may run into antitrust problems was not unexpected.

The summer television season arrived Thursday with the third-season debut of Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance.'' Nielsen estimated that the 90-minute premiere drew an average of 9.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., giving Fox a victory for the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox's ratings dipped at 9:30, however, when its new series, ''On the Lot,'' attracted only 5.2 million viewers. CBS beat out Fox in total viewers, taking the 9 p.m. hour over all with a repeat of ''CSI'' (13.8 million). CBS finished second in the 18-to-49 demographic, ahead of NBC and ABC, which tied for third. The first of six remaining episodes of NBC's canceled ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' drew just 3.9 million viewers at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

A report in the Metro Briefing column on May 17 included incorrect information from the New York City Department of Education about the number of charter schools that are overseen by the department, New York State and the State University of New York. The department oversees 31 such schools, not 38. The state and SUNY oversee a total of 27, not 20.

A new regulation proposed by the governor says that before students are allowed to buy Gatorade or other sports drinks, they must have "engaged in vigorous athletic activity lasting for more than one hour." The requirement is included in Gov. Eliot Spitzer's array of proposals aimed at making food served and sold in schools healthier.

A battle looms this week between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature over the details of a bill that would bring new levels of disclosure and oversight to the state's hundreds of public authorities. Though there is broad agreement on a number of issues, the Legislature favors allowing the state comptroller to approve all authority contracts and giving subpoena power to the office that monitors authorities' finances. The Spitzer administration, in private talks with lawmakers, balked at those positions.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed his fourth bill last week, rejecting an extension of a law limiting the number of check-cashing facilities in any one area. Since 1994, new check-cashing facilities have been banned within three-tenths of a mile of an existing one. This year, the Legislature voted to extend a 2002 law that broadened this prohibition to other financial institutions that open branches mainly devoted to check cashing, including banks and credit unions.

"The Constitution has never greatly bothered any wartime president," wrote Francis Biddle, F.D.R.'s attorney general during World War II. Biddle was writing about Roosevelt's shameful 1942 decision to evacuate Japanese-Americans from the Pacific Coast and place them in internment camps. But Biddle's comment applies to all presidents in times of crisis. National survival or, perhaps more accurately, the president's perception of national survival always takes precedence. George W. Bush has been no exception.

There was a great deal of gritty, fighting chess as eight matches to select candidates for the world championship got underway today in Elista, Kalmykia. The winners of the matches will play each other to determine which four will qualify for a championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

Gov. Bill Richardson followed up the formal announcement of his presidential bid with his turn among the candidates for a grilling by Tim Russert on NBC's "Meet the Press." While acknowledging that he didn't have the "celebrity" status or the money of some of his top Democratic rivals, he called himself "the insurgent candidate'' who could bring the country together because of his experiences as a lawmaker, a governor (of New Mexico) and as a former United Nations ambassador and member of the Clinton cabinet.

If you thought only children were interested in zoos, then visit Berlin's city zoo, located in the heart of old west Berlin. Since March, when a little polar bear called Knut was born, the Zoo has become a major attraction, for young and old. In the past 3 months, a staggering 700,000 people have visited the Zoo -- to see Knut. The Zoo's management is delighted. Not just because of the added revenues. It costs Euro 11 a shot to enter. Shares in the Zoo have soared.

(HBO) BURY MY HEART AT WOUNDED KNEE Dee Brown’s 1971 epic history of the displacement and decline of the American Indian has gained a new character in this adaptation, the better to attract a wide audience. At the story’s heart now is Charles Eastman (Adam Beach), a Dartmouth-educated part-Sioux doctor who is shown at the Battle of the Little Bighorn but in real life was nowhere near it. Anna Paquin plays Elaine Goodall, the white schoolteacher Eastman marries; Aidan Quinn portrays Senator Henry Dawes, who sponsored the General Allotment Act of 1887, which authorized the government to survey and divide tribal lands; and August Schellenberg, above, is Sitting Bull, the Lakota chief who refused to budge.

A report in the May 13 In Transit column about Dickens World, a Charles Dickens-based theme park in London, included incorrect information from the park’s founder about the inspiration for one of the attractions, a Victorian-style schoolroom. It is based on a place described in “Nicholas Nickleby.” There is no such schoolroom in “Oliver Twist.”.

The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about a plan to build 1,500 apartments on a site in Anaheim, Calif., zoned for tourist facilities, misstated the corporate affiliation of Discovery Cove in Orlando, Fla., which was cited as a boutique attraction of the sort that the Walt Disney Company might decide to add in Anaheim. It is owned by the Anheuser-Busch Companies, not Disney.

Summer promises to be fashionably full of holes, with eyelet showing up as the latest retail confection. In accessories, separates and dresses, the lightweight feminine fabric -- characterized by its whipstitched cut-out designs -- can be found in an array of patterns and colors. Take a peek. 1. An OpArt oval print smock dress by Maggy London gives traditional eyelet a graphic spin ($158 at Macy's stores); a simple shift by Vince makes summer dressing simple ($290 in white or black at saksfifthavenue.com). 2. Clean rows of flower eyelets on a white linen baby-doll top by DKNY are especially chic in a fresh espresso-brown embroidery ($195 at DKNY stores). 3. A sky blue skirt by Gap is trimmed with crochet detail at the hem ($59.50 at gap.com; ruffle-sleeved T-shirt also by Gap). 4. A gilt and taupe Bellette dress by Diane Von Furstenberg ($495 at DVF the Shop in New York, 646-486-4800) is a glamorous wrap over Shoshanna's sexy yet demure white bikini ($190 at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, 212-753-4000). 5. Juicy Couture's eyelet and terry shorts ($148) and hoodie ($238, both at Juicy Couture, 368 Bleecker Street at Charles Street, 646-336-8151) are a sweet way to suit up. 6. Searle's sunny A-line dress with pockets ($398 at searlenyc.com) and Shoshanna's bright azure '50s-inspired dress ($305 at Bloomingdale's New York, 212-705-2000) are perfect for afternoon weddings or luncheons.

Dr. Stephanie DeBlois Malliaris, a daughter of J. Holly DeBlois of Annisquam, Mass., and the late Athanasios C. Malliaris, was married yesterday to Benjamin Franklin Stapleton IV, the son of Jane Stapleton and Mr. Stapleton III of New York. The Rev. Benjamin J. King, the Episcopal chaplain of Harvard, performed the ceremony at St. John's Bowdoin Street Episcopal Church in Boston. The bride, who is 28 and a cum laude graduate of Harvard, received her medical degree last week from Tulane. Next month she is to become an intern at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in New York.

FUCHS--Sylvia. Our lovely sister and aunt passed away on May 22nd, 2007, at her home in Boca Raton, FL. She was our helper and friend all her life. We will always remember her gentle kindness and her beautiful smiling face. She is survived by Albert and Judy Fuchs, and Melvin Fuchs, and her niece Blair Ford and nephew Jack Fuchs, and grandnephews and grandnieces.

CAAMANO--Raphael, Reverend, beloved and esteemed priest of Opus Dei who died at Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts on May 21 at the age of 82. He was born in Ferrol, Spain, graduated from the Spanish Naval Academy and the School of Naval Architecture in Genoa Italy. He retired with honor from the Spanish Navy in 1961. He had become a member of Opus Dei in 1949 and worked closely with Saint Jose Maria Escriva, the Founder of Opus Dei. He was ordained a priest in 1978 and was the Vicar of Opus Dei in the United States from 1980 to 1988. He lived in Boston from 1992. He became a beloved and insightful member of the Board of Directors of the Homeland Foundation, established by the late Chauncey Stillman who revered Father Caamano as have Mr. E. Lisk Wyckoff, its President and all the members of the Foundation. They welcome his friends who will attend a mass for the repose of the soul of Father Caamano on Tuesday May 29 at 6:15pm at the Church of Saint Jean Baptiste at Lexington Avenue and 78th Street in Manhattan.

Last June, Seyran Ates, a lawyer, was waiting for a U-Bahn train in Berlin's Mockernbrucke subway station with a client for whom she had secured a divorce when the client's husband stormed onto the platform. He began beating up his ex-wife. Then he turned on Ates. Ates recalls seeing a number of men standing around, watching it all happen, as she danced from side to side with her attaché case, trying to fend off his heavy punches and kicks. It was not the first time she had been attacked in the line of duty.

One of the reigning kings of cinematic photography -- that lushly lighted, stage-set tributary of the documentary tradition -- PHILIP-LORCA diCORCIA makes pictures that tell stories, rarely the kind that are easy to summarize. ''The more specific an interpretation suggested by a picture, the less happy I am with it,'' he has said. Since his start in the late 1970s his subjects have included carefully posed family members, male prostitutes and, more recently, pole-dancing strippers whose twisting bodies take on almost classical, caduceuslike forms. His work will be the subject of a retrospective, the largest survey of his career to date, opening Friday at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, where more than 100 prints from every stage of his career will be on display. They will include examples from the highly publicized series he began in the mid-1990s, when he photographed unsuspecting pedestrians in Tokyo, Paris, New York and other cities who were caught in a strobe flash as they walked down the street. The photographs took the idea of street photography to a new level of detail and proximity. They also landed Mr. diCorcia in court. He was sued by a retired diamond merchant who saw his picture in the exhibition catalog and claimed that his privacy had been violated. The suit was dismissed last year by a New York State Supreme Court judge who ruled that the right to artistic expression outweighed the privacy issues. The exhibition is a homecoming of sorts for Mr. diCorcia, who studied at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and is often mentioned among other ''Boston school'' photographers like Nan Goldin and Jack Pierson. Through Sept. 3, (617) 478-3100, icaboston.org. For a photography show in a much different conceptual vein there is ''HAITI UNMASKED.'' The exhibition includes images taken by child domestic workers in Haiti, who were taught photography as part of Kids With Cameras, a nonprofit program that helps marginalized children around the world. Wednesday through June 27, Point of View Gallery, 638 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 967-3936, pointofviewartgallery.com.

THE federal government seems to have forgotten about West Nile virus, which terrorized New York City and the metropolitan region in 1999, resulting in more than 60 confirmed cases and seven deaths that year and more than 237,000 cases and 900 deaths nationwide since then. Indeed, the Department of Health and Human Services has cut $9.9 million from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's $35 million annual budget to deal with this deadly virus. Next year, an additional $7 million will be cut, leaving the entire program with only $18.1 million, a reduction of almost 50 percent. These cuts will force big reductions in federal support for the surveillance and control of West Nile virus in 57 state and local jurisdictions, including Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

SPRING -- the season for house selling -- is here, and the national picture continues to be bleak at best. The national data released so far this year have been extremely weak and worrisome. Existing and new home sales declined sharply in the first quarter of this year and permits for future construction in April were down 28 percent from their year-ago levels. A large backlog of unsold new and existing homes is growing, with almost eight months of supply up for sale.

Immigration is the big issue; proponents say we need immigrants from Mexico to take the jobs Americans don't want to do. Now, don't confuse that with India, where the people are taking the jobs Americans want to do. That's totally different.

To the Editor: Having read ''Mr. Right, It Turns Out, Does Not Take Classes,'' by Stephanie Rosenbloom (Thursday Styles, May 17), let me say that after years attempting to meet decent men in Manhattan through activities and classes, it finally dawned on me where the single, gainfully employed are: having a late and hasty pizza dinner at the local joint.

The state could face one of the largest nursing shortages in the country by the end of the next decade if current trends continue, according to a report released this month by the Connecticut Hospital Association, which represents 29 acute care hospitals in the state. The report said there was a combined 6.6 percent vacancy rate for registered nurses at those sites last year, with the vacancy rate in the emergency and psychiatric departments at nearly 11 percent. The report said those numbers were expected to grow.

To the Editor: In rejecting Mayor Bloomberg's congestion pricing plan, Ellen F. Crain made a flawed ''common sense'' prediction: that neighborhoods outside of the pricing zone will suffer a scourge of drivers trying to beat the $8 charge by parking near transit stops then hopping on the train (''Red Light for Breathing,'' Op-Ed, May 20).

THIS long sliver of a town climbs up the western slope of the Meadowlands, where most of its 6,000 residents are packed into a dense hillside grid barely five blocks wide, bound together tightly enough by geography and genealogy that they slip easily into the first-person plural, especially when talking about what has happened to them since the morning of 9/11. ''When we got the call about Michael ,'' Police Capt. Frank Smith started to say at police headquarters one day recently, and then his voice caught, just the way many other voices in town do when the subject is Michael A. Schwarz, the latest local casualty of the war in Iraq, a war that has taken far more from Carlstadt than anyone ever expected.

The Art entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report misspelled the name of the school of art that includes Neo Rauch, whose work is the subject of a Met show. It is the New Leipzig School, not Liepzig.

GOLDMAN--Charles. The Board of Trustees, Administration, Teachers, Parents and Students of the Hannah Senesh Community Day School are profoundly saddened by the untimely loss of our beloved friend and leader, Chuck Goldman. President of the Board 2003-2006, and its dedicated member from 2001 until his death, Chuck skillfully led the school through an extraordinary period of transition, development and planning for the future, culminating in a successful capital campaign and the acquisition and construction of the school's beautiful new home at 342 Smith Street in Brooklyn. Only days before he entered the hospital last week, Chuck defied his illness to attend a lengthy board meeting, at which, as always, he devotedly immersed himself in critical decisions for the school. We will deeply miss his quiet strength, wisdom and kindness. Our hearts go out to his wife Debra Rubenstein, a cherished member of our school's administration, his daughter Molly, a beloved student in our 6th Grade, his mother Edie, and sisters Jill and Ricki. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lisa Kleinman, President, Board of Trustees Susan Weintrob, Head of School Hannah Senesh Community Day School $(6$)GOLDMAN--Charles. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of our esteemed friend and colleague, Chuck Goldman, vice president of UJAFederation's Planned Giving & Endowments Department. A gifted lawyer and consummate professional, Chuck helped ensure there would always be the resources necessary for the Jewish community to take care of those in need, rescue those in harm's way, and renew and strengthen the Jewish people. In doing so, he helped establish a legacy of his own that will be felt in New York and throughout the Jewish community for years to come. Our condolences go out to his wife, Debra Rubenstein; his daughter, Molly; his mother, Edith; and to the entire Goldman family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. $(6$)GOLDMAN--Chuck. The Silverman Charitable Group mourns the passing of a dear friend and much admired professional. Chuck was both a gentle man and a gentleman. His efforts to make the world a better place will have a lasting impact. We pray for his family. He will be sorely missed and fondly remembered.

HOROWITZ--Frances K. (Ginsburg), 97, of Scarsdale, New York, died on May 23, 2007. The beloved wife of the late Bernard Horowitz and the loving sister of the late Dr. Meyer Ginsburg and the Lillian Lukashok. She is survived by her loving sons Larry Horowitz and Dan Horowitz, her devoted daughters-inlaw Beth Horowitz and Vicki Horowitz, her loving grandchildren Peter Horowitz and his wife YukikoJane, Alex Horowitz and Roger Horowitz. She was also preceded in death by her loving husband Harold Klipstein. Born in New York, January 22, 1910, to Abraham and Annie Ginsburg. She attended Erasmus Hall High School and New York University. An avid volunteer, she spent a large part of her life in helping others as a volunteer at White Plains Hospital for more than 34 years and also volunteered at Blythedale Hospital for 15 years. She also recorded for the blind. She was extremely active in the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY, where she served on numerous committees. She had a life-long love of the arts and music and filled her home with grace and beauty. Funeral Services will be held Friday, May 25, at 1:00 pm at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Contributions may be made to the Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund at White Plains Hospital Center, care of Development -Patricia Laine, 122 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY 10601 checks should be made to White Plains Hospital Center, on the memo line please write Frances Horowitz Memorial Fund.

To the Editor: Re ''Where Are All the Black Swans?'' by Gia Kourlas [May 6]: It is about time someone screamed out loud! My daughter is an aspiring ballerina, and we, her parents, have been doing all we can to help her. I tell her to stay focused and not worry about the color of her skin.

RICHMAN--Irwin. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Irwin Richman, beloved father of Steven, and father-in-law of Jodi Schwartz, esteemed members of the New York Jewish community. Jodi is a committed member of UJAFederation's Executive Committee, Board of Directors, and of our Lawyers Division and whose dedication has helped sustain the Jewish community in New York and around the world. We extend our sympathies to Steven and Jodi; to Steven's mother, Anita; to Steven's sisters, Julie and Sabrina, and their husbands, Gerald and Timothy; and to the entire Richman family. Morris W. Dr. Martin B. Leon, a cardiologist at Columbia University Medical Center, is still denying accusations that he prematurely disclosed the basic result of a major clinical trial. Nor is he willingly retreating from his roles as a prominent agenda-setter for debate in his profession and a go-to guy for companies working on new medical devices. But he is accepting the punishment meted out by the American College of Cardiology for comments about the clinical trial, which studied the value of treating clogged arteries with heart stents in addition to drugs. The college said last week that Dr. Leon would be barred from presenting research or participating in expert panels at its annual scientific meeting in Chicago next year.

To the Editor: I am pleased that medical technology has allowed young otherwise healthy amputees to participate in life more fully. And it will be a major achievement when the initial reaction to the disabled moves beyond pity.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In Heart of Its Season, N.H.L. Is Lost in Shuffle,'' May 22: Game 5 of the Buffalo Sabres-Ottawa Senators Eastern Conference finals was switched from NBC to Versus when it went into overtime last Saturday so that NBC could begin its coverage of the Preakness Stakes. That is indicative of a disturbing pattern.

To the Editor: Re ''Oil Price 'Gouging': A Phantom Menace?'' (Economic View, May 20), about reactions in Congress to the recent path of oil prices: Selling at prices that some people feel are too high violates no one's rights -- there is no such thing as a right to cheap gasoline. Moreover, ''price gouging'' has no objective meaning or definition -- it is in the eyes of the beholder. People who complain about it merely want a product at a lower price than it's being sold for.

New Jersey may soon add a second public wind project, with a wind turbine generating electricity for a public agency. The board of the Bayshore Regional Sewerage Authority, in Monmouth County, wants to study the possibility of erecting a wind turbine, 380 feet at its highest point, that would provide most of the authority's energy needs. The board voted on Monday to solicit bids to build a 160-foot tower to measure local wind speeds, a key component in determining the feasibility of erecting a wind turbine.

BROWN--Leon, 84, attorney of Syosset, died May 11, Palm Springs, CA. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of William (Bill) and David.

The theater entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report misidentified the actress playing one of a pair of redneck lovers in the musical ''10 Million Miles.'' She is Irene Molloy, not Mare Winningham, who plays all the other women in the show.

Talya Margalit Stein and Mohamad Aly Elleithee are to be married today by Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia, at the Torpedo Factory Art Center in Alexandria, Va. The bride, 31, and bridegroom, 34, work in Washington for the presidential campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton; the bride is the finance chief of staff, and the bridegroom is the senior spokesman.
To the Editor: Re ''Putting the Skinned Knees Back Into Playtime'' by Alex Williams (May 20):

PERTSCHUK--Leo, age 86 of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of NY, died May 19, 2007. He is survived by his loving wife of 57 years, Gladys, his children Daniel, Nina, son-in-law Darryl Clopper and two grand-daughters, Sarah Pertschuk and Marissa Clopper. Leo, also, is survived by his brother, Michael and sister, Anita Finkelson. He was a truly unique individual; a wonderful husband, compassionate father, dedicated grandfather, loving big brother and great friend to all who knew him. Leo attended University College School in London, L'Universite de Sorbonne in Paris, New York University, and was a Life Member of ASHRAE (the American Society of Heating, Ventilating & Air - conditioning En gineers). He was an extremely talented and gifted person. His interests were numerous. A few of his main hobbies were composing/playing music and photography. In the past, he was an avid golfer, tennis player and enjoyed boating/fishing. Leo will be missed by all who had the pleasure of knowing him. He brightened many lives with his humility, fabulous sense of humor and total devotion to living life to the fullest.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 12, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. THE ATOMIC BAZAAR: The Rise of the Nuclear Poor, by William Langewiesche. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A journalist travels the globe to discover how hard, or easy, it is to gain possession of nuclear weapons or technology. FELLOW TRAVELERS, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $25.) In Mallon's appealing seventh novel, a State Department official navigates the anti-gay purges of the McCarthy era. THE GENTLE AXE, by R. N. Morris. (Penguin Press, $24.95.) A period murder mystery dressed as a ''sequel'' to ''Crime and Punishment. ''THE SECRET OF LOST THINGS, by Sheridan Hay. (Doubleday, $23.95.) Unrequited love suffuses a used-book shop in this coming-of-age story. EINSTEIN: A Biography, by JÃ1/4rgen Neffe. Translated by Shelley Frisch. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) Beyond the science, which he describes with brio and insight, Neffe detects a naïve idealist. RECLAIMING HISTORY: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy, by Vincent Bugliosi. (Norton, $49.95.) In an exhaustive examination, a prosecutor determines that Oswald acted alone. THE DESCENDANTS, by Kaui Hart Hemmings. (Random House, $24.95.) A Pandora's box of family tragicomedy is loosed on a Honolulu lawyer. THE CRUEL STARS OF THE NIGHT, by Kjell Eriksson. Translated by Ebba Segerberg. (St. Martin's Minotaur, $23.95.) The elderly are prey to a serial killer in this melancholy Swedish policier. RALPH ELLISON: A Biography, by Arnold Rampersad. (Knopf, $35.) Ellison was seemingly cursed by his failure to follow up ''Invisible Man. ''THE DOOR OF NO RETURN: The History of Cape Coast Castle and the Atlantic Slave Trade, by William St Clair. (BlueBridge, $24.95.) This account of Britain's role in the slave trade focuses on life at its major entrepÃ$(4$)t, in Ghana. THE CLARKS OF COOPERSTOWN: Their Singer Sewing Machine Fortune, Their Great and Influential Art Collections, Their Forty-Year Feud, by Nicholas Fox Weber. (Knopf, $35.) A portrait of an American dynasty. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

The network ''season,'' to the extent that the term still has any meaning, would seem to be ending with the ''House'' finale on Tuesday (9 p.m., Fox). So on to summer: This week brings us the premieres of Mark Burnett's new reality treasure hunt, ''PIRATE MASTER'' (8 p.m. Thursday, CBS), and Kevin Williamson's ''O.C.''-in-the-desert melodrama, ''HIDDEN PALMS'' (8 p.m. Wednesday, CW). Taylor Handley, who played the evil Oliver Trask in the first season of the real ''O.C.,'' now gets to play the Ryan character, a troubled teenager who moves to Palm Springs and discovers that he's the normal one. My own mindless-fun pick: the second season of ''HEX'' (8 p.m. Saturday, BBC America), the cheap-and-dirty, and highly entertaining, British ''Buffy'' clone. A full night of ''The Real World'' on MTV culminates in the first episode of a new six-episode spinoff, ''REUNITED: THE REAL WORLD VEGAS'' (10 p.m. Wednesday), in which cast members from the 2002 Las Vegas season reconvene in the same suite at the Palms. How long will it be before Steven, Brynn and Trishelle get back in the hot tub? Start your office pool now. Three months after Bob Woodruff's ''To Iraq and Back,'' CBS presents a special about the other high-profile American television journalist to be seriously wounded (so far) in Iraq: ''FLASHPOINT: KIMBERLY DOZIER AND THE ARMY'S FOURTH ID'' (10 p.m. Tuesday). Katie Couric anchors the program. Ian Somerhalder, whose Boone was one of the first casualties of ''Lost,'' turns up as the prettiest explorer you've ever seen on the Hallmark Channel's ''MARCO POLO'' (8 p.m. Saturday). The three-hour movie is a Robert Halmi production and as corny and campy as that suggests (Brian Dennehy as Kublai Khan!); watch for the moment when B. D. Wong, as Marco's assigned servant, Pedro, looks deep into Mr. Somerhalder's eyes and murmurs: ''I am to be your slave. My master's every desire is my only happiness.''

To the Editor: I enjoyed Henry Fountain's ''Father and Son, Just Two More Soccer Fans'' (Family Travel: England, May 13) about taking his son to see the English football (soccer) team, Arsenal, play in their new stadium. However, Arsenal supporters in the United States should know that there is a much simpler way of getting tickets to see their team. Arsenal America (www.arsenalamerica.com) offers its members the opportunity to buy tickets to all home and away Arsenal matches. Annual membership costs $20 and all tickets are offered at face value, plus a nominal service charge for processing/currency exchange.

Elina Furman and Jay Frederik Landauer are to be married today at the Ceiba del Mar Spa Resort in Puerto Morelos, Mexico. Cantor David Laor is to officiate. The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a freelance writer and the author of several books, including ''Kiss and Run: The Single, Picky and Indecisive Girl's Guide to Overcoming Her Fear of Commitment'' (Fireside, 2007). She graduated from the University of Illinois. She is a daughter of Mira Furman of New York and Roman Furman of Chicago.

Because of an editing error, a review on Page 11 of the Book Review today misstates part of the title of the book by Barbara Kingsolver with Steven L. Hopp and Camille Kingsolver. As noted in the table of contents, it is ''Animal, Vegetable, Miracle'' -- not ''Mineral.''

LEVITAN--Florence, of New Rochelle, NY, died on Thursday, May 24, at her home. She was 87. Florence, daughter of Harry and Goldie Husid, was predeceased in 2006 by her beloved husband George and in 2005 by her cherished daughter Geordie Levitan. She was also predeceased by her brother Harry Husid and sister Edith Levitan. She is survived by her loving daughters Carol Smolen of Las Vegas, NV, Barbara Muller of Stamford, CT, and Joanne Levitan of Pelham, NY; and her granddaughters Jamie Kristofco of Denver, CO, Danielle Smolen and Brooke Feingold, both of Manhattan. Private funeral services were held on Friday, May 25.

I KEEP coming across advertisements that assure teenagers that this is ''Not Your Mother's Prom.'' One designer promises that her sexy gowns are ''definitely not the prom dress that your mother wore back in the 60s or 70s.'' A florist featuring corsages studded with gems and orchids sprinkled with glitter insists ''these are definitely not your mother's prom flowers.'' The stretch Hummers as the transport of choice? You guessed it -- not your mom's limo. I find these advertisements amusing -- not for the incredible materialistic excess, but for the presumptions about the proms of this generation's parents. Most parents of high school seniors are Baby Boomers, and if you grew up in the tristate region, to say that proms were no big deal is a gross understatement. Proms, like any other event organized by adults, were decidedly uncool. I went to high school in the 1970s, and it was a disillusioning time to be a teenager. During that decade, the Vietnam War ended; the chaotic airlift off the roofs of Saigon was our iconic image. The president resigned. The Beatles broke up.

ROWLEY--Henry Nelson, Jr. Died peacefully at home in New York City on Thursday, May 24. Hank was born in Lake Forest, IL in 1928. He attended Yale University and served in the Korean War before pursuing a career on Wall St. Upon retiring, Hank devoted his time to volunteer tutoring in New York City Public Schools and at the English Speaking Union. A talented athlete, Hank shared his love of nature and sport with his family through skiing, tennis, golf and horseback riding. He was an avid reader of history, a life long student of literature and lover of jazz. Most importantly, Hank was a loving father and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Francine, his son, John Rowley, and daughters Maria Rowley Leas and Alexandra Rowley, John's wife Georgiana, Maria's husband, Rodman and Alexandra's husband, Stephen Wallis; two grandsons, Spencer and Alexander Rowley; his sister Andria Lawson and her family; two nephews, Jamie and Nelson Rowley. Burial service at Woodlawn Cemetery will be private. There will be a memorial service at St. Vincent Ferrer Church at 4pm on Thursday, May 31. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Henry's name to St. James School, (care of St. Vincent Ferrer Church) or City Meals on Wheels.

WHEN it comes to her seventh and eighth graders, Sister Mary Bernadette is a stickler for good handwriting. She teaches a 20-minute penmanship class several times a week, her students get a penmanship grade on their report cards, and they lose points in other subjects if their handwriting is not neat. ''Good penmanship is a sign of self-discipline,'' says Sister Mary Bernadette. ''We're trying to create good students, upright human beings, good citizens, good members of their families. Penmanship is a sign of character.''

STECKEL--Cantor Harold, on May 20, at 87 years of age. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Flora, sons Mark and Joph, daughters-in-law Cynthia and Beth, and grandchildren Jenna, Carly, Henry, Isabel, George, and Lily. A graduate of City College with a B.S. and MBA. Worked as the Medicare representative at the Health and Hospital Corporation of New York City. Well known cantor at Tamarack Lodge. Lecturer of operas, symphonic music, musical theater, and Jewish liturgy at Elderhostels in New York and Pennsylvania. He will be dearly missed by family, friends, and Elderhostel seniors.

To the Editor: In writing ''In the Footsteps of Linnaeus: A Vast Garden of Knowledge, Still Blooming Today'' (Family Travel, May 13), about the botanist Carolus Linnaeus whose tricentennial is being celebrated this year, it would seem that Richard Conniff must have made a concerted effort not to mention the name Olof Rudbeck. Both Olof Rudbeck the Elder (1630-1702) and his son, Olof Rudbeck the Younger (1660-1740), played important roles in Linnaeus's career. Both were professors of medicine at Uppsala University in Sweden, and both were botanists.

ALEX ROSENZWEIG, 41, has a problem: People are tired of hearing him talk about ''Star Trek.'' ''At work they complain incessantly,'' said Mr. Rosenzweig, 41, an editor at an environmental consulting firm who is wearing a polo shirt with spaceship insignia. His colleagues give him guff about the 2-foot-by-3-foot ''Star Trek'' poster he displays prominently. And at home in North Brunswick, he knows better than to greet neighbors with a Vulcan salute.
DENNIS--Charles C., passed away on May 22nd, 2007 after a short illness. Survived by his wife Barbara and children Charles, Meg and Faith.

ZIMBABWEANS could be forgiven for feeling a perverse nostalgia for last February. Back then, the country's annual inflation rate, the highest in the world, was estimated to be 1,730 percent. Over the 12 months ending in April, it was officially 3,714 percent. But many experts believe government numbers badly understate the problem.

SILVER--Irma Richling, on May 24th, 2007. Survived by her devoted husband of 60 years, Robert H. Silver, two daughters Susan Silver, and Robin Newman, her son-inlaw Demarest (Nick) Newman, her granddaughter Annabel Stephanie Newman and three step-grandchildren Lauren Stein, Stephen Newman, and Christopher Newman. Service Sunday, 1pm at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

To the Editor: Re ''A Prince of Pulp, Legit at Last'' by Charles McGrath [May 6]: In July 1981, I worked on the ''Blade Runner'' marketing team. That summer, Philip K. Dick made some negative comments about an early draft of a ''Blade Runner'' screenplay, but I couldn't help but think that once he saw the final draft he would change his mind. I offered to bring him that script and some production paintings. This began a series of visits where I found him to be warm, funny, gracious and extremely enthusiastic about the film.

WHEN it comes to her seventh and eighth graders, Sister Mary Bernadette is a stickler for good handwriting. She teaches a 20-minute penmanship class several times a week, her students get a penmanship grade on their report cards, and they lose points in other subjects if their handwriting is not neat. ''Good penmanship is a sign of self-discipline,'' says Sister Mary Bernadette. ''We're trying to create good students, upright human beings, good citizens, good members of their families. Penmanship is a sign of character.''

ENGEL--Syliva (SeRoy). Beloved wife of the late Philip. Devoted mother of Congressman Eliot Engel of New York and Dori (Devorah) Kaplan of Passaic, NJ, and motherin-law of Pat Engel and Jordan (Yehuda) Kaplan. Cherished grandmother of Julia, Jonathan, Philip, Dovid, Rachel, Yosef, Yaacov, Naomi, Esty, Malky and Ricky and great-grandmother of Sarah. Services Sunday, 1:15 pm, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

A report in the May 13 In Transit column about Dickens World, a Charles Dickens-based theme park in London, included incorrect information from the park's founder about the inspiration for one of the attractions, a Victorian-style schoolroom. It is based on a place described in ''Nicholas Nickleby.'' There is no such schoolroom in ''Oliver Twist.''

The hot weather is scarcely upon us, but you would think it was high summer from the number of theater festivals under way or getting ready to start. Brits Off Broadway is in full swing at the 59E59 Theaters, and this week sees the kickoff of three more extravaganzas of new work. The venerable ENSEMBLE STUDIO THEATER has been producing its short-play marathon for a whopping 29 years now. The first of two collections of one-acts begins on Thursday. It includes new work by the prolific Neil LaBute, Julia Cho and Wendy MacLeod, along with lesser-known names like Edith Freni and Billy Aronson. A second evening follows, beginning June 15. 549 West 52nd Street, Clinton, (212) 352-3101, ensemblestudiotheatre.org; $18. The quirky downtown troupe CLUBBED THUMB has been holding its Summerworks festival for an also impressive dozen years. Three full-scale productions -- ''Greedy'' by Karl Gajdusek, ''Amazons and Their Men'' by Jordan Harrison and ''One Thing I Like to Say Is'' by Amy Fox -- will be presented for a week each, beginning next Sunday. But the celebration begins on Wednesday with ''A Pageant of the 50 States (and more),'' a one-night-only compendium of 59 one-minute plays about all the states and territorities. Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 352-3101, clubbedthumb.org; $18. And the most endearingly named theater smorgasbord of all starts this week too. THE PRETENTIOUS FESTIVAL: THE MOST IMPORTANT THEATER FESTIVAL ON EARTH begins Friday at the Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It kicks off with a free evening, a cabaret preview of coming attractions. Outraged at being called ''egalitarian and unpretentious'' by The Village Voice last year, the company's co-artistic director Michael Gardner has thrown down a gauntlet, saying in a press release, ''The Brick is as self-indulgent and impenetrable as the most oblique and experimental performance organizations in the city.'' Anyone want to demur? 575 Metropolitan Avenue, between Union Avenue and Lorimer Street, (212) 352-3101, bricktheater.com; $10.

MUTEK, a festival devoted to ''electronic music and digital creativity,'' begins on Wednesday in Montreal. And MOVEMENT, another electronic music festival, is under way in Detroit. That's great news for dance music fans in New York: This week, Manhattan's clubs are full of highly anticipated dance parties starring D.J.'s and producers on their way to or from Montreal and Detroit, or just here by coincidence. The Brazilian-born producer GUI BORATTO recently released ''Chromophobia'' (Kompakt), a sumptuous full-length debut full of unpredictable tracks built from drips and clicks; when the synth-pop song ''Beautiful Life'' finally arrives, it sounds like a revelation. Expect a thoroughly immersive experience on Thursday night, when Mr. Boratto plays Cielo with MICHAEL MAYER, who can make minimalist dance tracks sound warm, even sentimental. And on Tuesday night the celebrated Chilean-raised producer LUCIANO will be there; expect a long, delirious night of dance tracks that find subtle ways to evoke psychedelia. Tuesday and Thursday at 10 p.m., 18 Little West 12th Street, West Village, (212) 645-5700, cieloclub.com; $15 in advance, $20 at the door or $20 total for both nights. There's still more: The jittery Detroit techno veteran STACEY PULLEN plays the Sullivan Room on Saturday. 9 p.m., 218 Sullivan Street, Greenwich Village, sullivanroom.com; $20, $15 with flier. The Swiss producer MICHAL HO (from the duo of Samim & Michal) comes to Element on Friday, along with LOSOUL, known for sneaky, insinuative tracks 10 p.m., 225 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, elementny.com; $10 advance, $15 at the door. For revelers in search of something less elusive, there's ABOVE & BEYOND, a British team sometimes associated with the populist (and, not coincidentally, much-maligned) genre known as trance; expect snarling bass lines, bucolic synthesizer passages and dramatic buildups when they arrive at Pacha on Friday night 10 p.m., 618 West 46th Street, Clinton, pachanyc.com; $20. Finally there's Curtis Jones, known for the freaked-out techno records he releases as GREEN VELVET and for the gentler house music credited to his alter ego, CAJMERE. Now his Web site (myspace.com/greenvelvet) documents his conversion to Christianity; explaining one new (and typically propulsive) track, ''Love Peace Not War,'' he writes, ''People nowadays have more faith in war and bombs than they have in God.'' Expect a joyful noise on Thursday night at the Sullivan Room 10 p.m.; $15.

Q. Are there any laws in New York that govern how a co-op board handles buyers' private financial information? Are board members free to go over applications outside of board meetings? Must applications be shredded or returned to applicants at the end of the review process? A. Eva Talel, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said there are no New York laws that specify how a co-op board treats information it receives from prospective purchasers, nor are there any laws limiting the locations at which purchasers' applications can be reviewed.

Josie Natori, who left investment banking in 1977 to found the Natori Company, which makes women's clothing and bedding, has yet another talent: she is a classically trained pianist. She made her debut with the Manila Symphony Orchestra at 9, but, she says, she decided to go into a career in business. She has, however, continued to study, and celebrated her 50th birthday in 1997 by hiring Carnegie Hall to play Schumann and Rachmaninoff with the Orchestra of St. Luke's. She considered performing again in public for her 60th birthday but decided against it because she is too consumed with company matters and her son's wedding in June, she said last week at a benefit for the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York.

To the Editor: I read with great interest your May 20 article about mold, ''What's Furry and Thirsty and Loves the Dark?'' I was somewhat troubled, however, by the lack of doctors' opinions. I think the opinion of a pediatric pulmonologist would have added to the power of the article.

Dr. Sara Beth Immerman, the daughter of Marjorie and Harry F. Immerman of Wyckoff, N.J., is to be married this evening to Dr. David Matthew Epstein, a son of Toby and Gary M. Epstein of Old Bethpage, N.Y. Rabbi Noam Marans is to officiate at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J., with Cantor Ilan Mamber taking part. The bride and bridegroom met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated.

COWIN--Daniel. Dear Daniel, it is hard to believe it has been fifteen years since you left us. Your friends still talk about you with great affection and admiration. Those who knew you best, continue to miss your encouragement, kindness, keen intelligence and unerring eye. Would that you could come back! With Love, Joyce and Family

How tiresome were the negative responses (Letters, May 13) to Jon Mooallem's refreshing article about Kink.com (April 29). To produce materials for adults' sexual enjoyment is decent and honorable when the performers are also adults, are fairly compensated and enjoy their work.

Jerry Cloud, 15, right, from Everett, Wash., with his brother Nick, 12 : ''We'd never really been to the desert, so we just wanted to see everything -- to get the whole desert effect. We were with our grandpa, which was pretty great, because we really like hanging out with him. He's a fun guy, and he had a camera, so it was kind of fun taking pictures of all the animals. It felt really adventurous. Coming from the Pacific Northwest, it's just kind of mind-blowing because it's really new; you've never even seen it before. It's a first-time experience -- basically like you're having your first Christmas or something.'' As told to Austin Considine

BORROWERS have used the Internet for years to shop for mortgages. Now a growing number are actually closing their loans online, too. Companies like E-Loan, Wachovia and other big mortgage lenders have in recent months begun offering a service called ClosingStream, which allows borrowers to complete documents online for refinanced and home-equity loans.

Shyra Lynnette Cooper, a daughter of Lynnette W. Omar of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Samuel Cooper III of Washington, is to be married this evening to Keeth Thomas Smart, the son of A. Liz Smart of Winter Springs, Fla., and the late Thomas R. Smart Jr. The Rev. Miles M. Fisher IV, a Baptist minister, is to officiate at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C. The bride, 28, is a production manager for the Web site of VH1 in New York. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.

To the Editor: Re ''An Old Steel Mill Retools to Produce Clean Energy'' (news article, May 22): The community in Lackawanna, N.Y., should be applauded for its use of wind power to revitalize contaminated land.

Nora Ephron has made her living as a humorist, so perhaps she's joking when she says, ''It's hard to think of much that is genuinely better'' about growing older (Questions for Nora Ephron, Deborah Solomon, May 6). Here's something that's better: you get to stop worrying about the lines around your eyes and put your energy toward important things. I believe Ephron may have fallen prey to a marketing scheme that the beauty industry foists upon boomers that aging is ugly.

GLAZER--Bennett, 81, passed away at his home on May 22, after a long battle with respiratory disease. Bennett was and will continue to be known as the founder of Graphic Image and for his 50 years of design work in the publishing industry. His company, now run by his children, created books that are among the finest leather bindings in the world. His diary designs stand as his masterpiece and are treasured by loyal users everywhere. He is survived by his loving wife Phyllis, his two surviving children, Tom (Elizabeth) and Carol O'Connell (John), and the late Janice Barbone (Luca), and eight loving grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 12, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

At the end of the Yankees' 3-1 loss to the Los Angeles Angels yesterday at Yankee Stadium, Bobby Abreu stood near home plate arguing with Jeff Nelson, the home plate umpire, who had called him out on strikes with two on and two out. ''It was way away from the plate,'' Abreu said later of the 1-2 pitch. ''I'm not happy about that call. Way, way, way far away. You can't even make contact on that. It's not right.''

Terri Marissa Landon, the daughter of Marlene Landon and Leonard Landon of New York, is to be married today to Jay Fleet Bacow, a son of Adele Fleet Bacow and Lawrence S. Bacow of Medford, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey Summit, the executive director of Tufts Hillel, is to officiate at Tufts University in Medford, of which the bridegroom's father is the president. The bride, 28, is a psychotherapist in the predoctoral internship program at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, N.Y., where she works with children and adolescents. She is completing studies for her Ph.D. in clinical psychology at Boston University. She graduated magna cum laude from Brown and received a master's in clinical psychology from Boston University.

Lovely to look at and ornery to handle, artichokes are -- like roast turkey and hand-wrapped tamales -- ideal ritual food. The rites that artichokes serve, of course, are spring's, the annual cleaning and regreening of the palate after the long winter. (Even in their oddball alcoholic form -- the Italian digestivo Cynar -- artichokes serve as a quasi-medicinal cleanser.) Other greens and tender young herbs are there as part of the vernal celebration, but artichokes are almost alchemical in their appeal. What other food would you forgive for pricking your fingertips, overflowing your compost bucket and killing your best wines? The artichoke makes up for all this, of course, with its distinctive flavor -- a nutty, herbal fusion with an everlasting finish.

Driving in a new city is never easy, particularly if you prefer sightseeing to map reading. But surfacing from a subway miles from your target destination can also be frustrating. Enter PublicRoutes.com, which gives public transportation directions for 15 American cities, two metro areas (in Connecticut and New Jersey) and one European city, London.

An article last Sunday about the planting of trees near the new Yankee Stadium in the South Bronx paraphrased incorrectly a comment by Adrian Benepe, the parks commissioner, about the natural benefits of trees. Mr. Benepe said that trees reduce -- not produce -- carbon dioxide in the air by absorbing it. (Trees do emit some carbon dioxide the same way that animals do, but the emission is far outweighed by the absorption that occurs during photosynthesis.)

In which country will the Tour de France start this year? It may sound like a trick question, but there have been five occasions in the race's 104-year history when the route began outside France: in Amsterdam, Brussels, Berlin, Luxembourg and Dublin. This year, the race will start in London on July 7 with the prologue -- a 4.9-mile time trial that starts by Trafalgar Square passes Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and Buckingham Palace. The following day, Stage 1 will take the riders from the Mall, along the Thames, past the London Eye, St. Paul's Cathedral and the Tower of London. Racers will later pass the prime meridian in Greenwich before heading through Kent to the finish line in Canterbury.

The veteran defenseman Sean O'Donnell spoke up during last week's semifinals, complaining of dirty play and a lack of respect for opponents on N.H.L. rinks. ''It's gotten bad in the last couple of years,'' he told The Canadian Press. ''Head shots seem to be more common, and late hits.''

FIRE ABOARD The News -- The Cutty Sark, the famous 19th-century British clipper ship that transported tea from China to England, suffered heavy damage from a fire early Monday. Behind the News -- The ship was in the midst of a $50 million renovation in London, when firefighters were called to the fire, which the police were investigating. Launched in 1869, the Cutty Sark was built for speed in the intensely competitive tea trade; in 1885, its 72-day voyage from Australia to England set a record. The name comes from a Scottish poem and refers to a woman's undergarments. And, yes, a well-known blended Scotch whiskey bears the ship's name. LOST, NO DIRECTION HOME The News -- Scientists were having little luck in helping two lost, injured humpback whales find their way back to the Pacific Ocean after they wandered 90 miles up the Sacramento River. Behind the News -- The Coast Guard and volunteers in boats spent much of the week trying to herd the mother and her calf back to the Pacific. But as of Friday, the whales, nicknamed Delta and Dawn, were unwilling to swim past a bridge located about 70 miles upriver. Both whales had deep cuts, possibly from a run-in with a boat, and scientists said they seemed to be suffering physically from being in freshwater. The two were first spotted in the river on May 13. BETTER LUCK NEXT TIME The News -- The United States again failed in its quest to win the America's Cup, the most prestigious regatta in sailing. Behind the News -- BMW Oracle Racing, backed by the software billionaire Larry Ellison, lost in the Louis Vuitton Cup semifinals to an Italian team, 5-1, in the best-of-nine series. Facing a must-win race on Sunday, the team replaced its helmsman, to no avail, making this the first time in 28 years the Vuitton final will be without an American team. The winner will go on to challenge the holder of the America's Cup, which the United States last won in 1992. What went wrong? ''They outsailed us,'' said Chris Dickson, BMW Oracle's skipper. BATTEN THE HATCHES The News -- Government weather experts are predicting a busy storm season, with 7 to 10 Atlantic hurricanes, up to half of them capable of causing extensive damage. Behind the News -- The prediction follows a relatively quiet season last year, only the 12th since 1945 without a hurricane making landfall in the United States. This year, forecasters said two to four hurricanes could hit. They based their forecast on two factors: continuing warm temperatures in the Atlantic, and unusually cold ocean temperatures in the equatorial Pacific. Michael Chertoff, the Homeland Security secretary, warned against complacency. ''It's a big mistake to count on being lucky,'' he said. 'X' MARKS THE SPOT The News -- Britain and Spain said they might lay claim to sunken riches recently discovered by American treasure hunters that may be worth $500 million or more. Behind the News -- Olympic Marine Exploration of Tampa, Fla., says the treasure lies in a Colonial-era shipwreck in the Atlantic. Where, exactly? Olympic isn't saying. Code-named ''Black Swan,'' the wreck so far has yielded over 500,000 silver coins, plus hundreds of gold coins and other artifacts. Britain and Spain are waiting to see if they have a claim. Some scholars speculate it may be the Merchant Royal, a British ship that sank southwest of England in 1641 while carrying coins from Spain to Belgium.

After playing home games at Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands for 26 seasons, the men's basketball team at Seton Hall University will begin playing at the new Prudential Center in Newark this fall, officials announced last week. The 18,500-seat Prudential Center, set to open in October, will also be the home of the New Jersey Devils hockey team. The $370 million Prudential Center, nicknamed the Rock, is part of a plan by Newark to revitalize the downtown area.

To the Editor: Re ''Sound and Fury Over Private Equity'' (DealBook, May 20), in which Andrew Ross Sorkin described a House Financial Services Committee hearing on the private equity industry: First, there is zero basis for the assertion that I think the buyout business must be like the 1991 film ''Other People's Money,'' because this is not a case of hostile takeovers. We understand how private equity works. In fact, one of our concerns is whether there are sufficient safeguards against C.E.O.'s and other corporate decision makers being unduly influenced by special enrichments for themselves in deciding to sell to private equity firms.

To the Editor: Your overture in ''My Dear Fellow Species'' (Week in Review, May 20) to the 150th anniversary celebration of Charles Darwin's ''Origin of Species'' through his letters is a fine attempt to briefly summarize his personality.

To the Editor: Men don't take the classes because we know the only man in the room most of the women will want to be with is the instructor. It's basic human nature that women will usually only want the alpha male. Andrew Bennett Spark Sarasota, Fla.

To the Editor: I read with great interest your May 20 article about mold, ''What's Furry and Thirsty and Loves the Dark?'' I was somewhat troubled, however, by the lack of doctors' opinions. I think the opinion of a pediatric pulmonologist would have added to the power of the article.

THIS long sliver of a town climbs up the western slope of the Meadowlands, where most of its 6,000 residents are packed into a dense hillside grid barely five blocks wide, bound together tightly enough by geography and genealogy that they slip easily into the first-person plural, especially when talking about what has happened to them since the morning of 9/11. ''When we got the call about Michael ,'' Police Capt. Frank Smith started to say at police headquarters one day recently, and then his voice caught, just the way many other voices in town do when the subject is Michael A. Schwarz, the latest local casualty of the war in Iraq, a war that has taken far more from Carlstadt than anyone ever expected.

After weeks of gains, the broad stock market gave up ground last week, while trading volumes declined in advance of the Memorial Day weekend. Economic reports were equivocal or outright contradictory. For example, data provided Friday by the National Association of Realtors on sales of previously owned homes showed an unexpectedly sharp decline in April, while a government report a day earlier showed that sales of new homes had surged, perhaps because developers had cut prices to spur demand.

My brother turns 40 in a few months, and we'd like to take a collective vacation to a not-too-expensive Caribbean beach spot during the week of Thanksgiving. Can you recommend a place that is not too hard to get to (parents are in their 70s, so not a plane to small plane to ferry, please) and can deal with little kids (mine, ages 11, 9, 6)? None of us requires organized activities. We might enjoy the option to take a day trip or two, if there's a town or jungle nearby. Mostly, we just want a beautiful, relaxing beach place where we can enjoy each other -- Hali Lee, Brooklyn Two islands in the Caribbean might meet all of your requirements: Aruba and Grand Cayman.

Just in time for the summer season, a report on the state of the Jersey Shore has found the beaches in relatively good condition. The report, released last week by the New Jersey Marine Sciences Consortium, says that a lull in storm activity last winter slowed erosion along the shoreline and gave beaches time to recover from strong storms last fall. The report also praised the state for securing funding for sand replenishment programs or ''simply repairing breaches and shoring up dunes after major storms.''

VOISIN--Shep, January 11, 1930-May 20, 2007. Stuart J. ''Shep'' Voisin, beloved father of Jeanne and Nancy, husband of Helene Netter and the late Dulcie Jane Gecker. Carpe Diem was his philosophy, and seize the day he did as a member of the NYSE, founder of Stuart Coleman & Co., mentor to many, co-founder, trustee and the first president of Childrens Medical Fund of NY, a founding associate of The Hospital For Joint Diseases Foundation and an honorary Trustee of NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases. Shep-we keep your lessons with us always. You will be greatly missed by all. Jeanne and Nancy

To the Editor: Re ''The Bankable Siren Call of the Misty Isles'' by Claire Dederer [May 13]:

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board last Wednesday unanimously approved building a Metro-North station at the new Yankee Stadium. According to the railroad, fans taking the New Haven line to the stadium on weekends will have direct service to and from the station, which will be on the Hudson Line, just north of 153rd Street in the Bronx, and direct service back on weeknights. Because of the large number of trains going through the Bronx during the evening rush hour, however, fans going to weeknight games and leaving weekday games may have to take a shuttle between 125th Street in Harlem and the station. Fans now must ride Metro-North into the city and switch to the subway to get to the stadium.

I do agree with William Safire that the phrase ''you're welcome'' is disappearing (On Language, May 13). However, my husband and I believe that it is being replaced by the phrase ''no problem.'' Once used primarily by teenagers, ''no problem'' has become common usage for adults. Just the other day, after I thanked my physician for assisting me with a medical decision, he said, ''No problem.''
An article last Sunday excerpting the letters of Charles Darwin misstated the age of ''The Origin of Species.'' It will be 150 years old in 2009, not next year.

''Fakes and Forgeries: The Art of Deception,'' at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science, brings together more than 60 examples of creative duplicity, from Cycladic and Egyptian sculpture to Renaissance and modern paintings, works on paper and decorative arts. Among them are pieces that constitute some of history's more esteemed feats of artistic deceit, including paintings by the great Dutch forger Han van Meegeren that fooled old master experts for decades. Nancy Hall-Duncan, the Bruce Museum's senior curator, devoted several years to researching this highly unusual show. She has borrowed objects from museum collections worldwide that have been exposed as fakes, as well as artwork impounded by the major theft squad of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the body charged with investigating art fraud crimes within the United States. Alluring and slightly dangerous, this is one of the summer's more engrossing museum exhibitions.

INTERNATIONAL 3-17 A Post-Occupation Iraq Behind the debate over troop withdrawal from Iraq is widespread concern about what the country would look like after American troops left. Wide-ranging interviews with Iraqis found a surprising consensus with American commanders' views that a troop withdrawal soon would allow sectarian violence to run wild and might implode the government. 1 American, British and Iraqi forces battled fighters from the Mahdi Army militia in Baghdad and Basra, a day after the militia's leader came out of hiding. Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond wizard, should have no trouble getting a prime table for lunch at the Grill from now on. His wife practically owns the place. A company controlled by Mr. Milken's wife, Lori, has quietly become the biggest shareholder in Grill Concepts, which built the Beverly Hills restaurant the Grill on the Alley into a coast-to-coast chain of 25 restaurants. Most are casual restaurants called Daily Grill, but the Grill on the Alley is where Hollywood power brokers like Ron Meyer, the head of Universal Studios, and David Geffen, a co-founder of DreamWorks, do lunch.

To the Editor: I read ''A Childhood Issue? Ask a Librarian,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 20) with great interest. I am a children's librarian and a great proponent of utilizing well-written children's books to help youngsters cope with a variety of issues, from bullying to friendships to divorce and illness. I recommend a particular book to the children's librarian Paula Lefkowitz, who mentioned in the article that she could not find any books on the subject of ''Daddy not coming to see me.'' ''Always My Dad,'' by Sharon Dennis Wyeth, shows how a girl deals with her absentee father, who sees her only once in a while.

An article last Sunday about a dispute over the use of a tennis court in Washington Market Park misstated the year during which a plaque was erected designating it the John Jones Tennis Court. It was 1995, not 1996.
