It appears that 90 percent of TV Land's airtime is a continuous looping of a 17-show repertory of ''classic TV,'' 13 shows of which are sitcoms and all of which I've no interest in watching again, ever (Lorne Manly, May 6). Thousands of television shows were in production between 1950 and 1975. Is offering a few more than 17 too adventurous? ''Lou Grant'' would send me into a deep nostalgic swoon.

I KEEP coming across advertisements that assure teenagers that this is ''Not Your Mother's Prom.'' One designer promises that her sexy gowns are ''definitely not the prom dress that your mother wore back in the 60s or 70s.'' A florist featuring corsages studded with gems and orchids sprinkled with glitter insists ''these are definitely not your mother's prom flowers.'' The stretch Hummers as the transport of choice? You guessed it -- not your mom's limo. I find these advertisements amusing -- not for the incredible materialistic excess, but for the presumptions about the proms of this generation's parents. Most parents of high school seniors are Baby Boomers, and if you grew up in the tristate region, to say that proms were no big deal is a gross understatement. Proms, like any other event organized by adults, were decidedly uncool. I went to high school in the 1970s, and it was a disillusioning time to be a teenager. During that decade, the Vietnam War ended; the chaotic airlift off the roofs of Saigon was our iconic image. The president resigned. The Beatles broke up.

New York State government has two parts, one public and one carefully tucked out of sight. The public part includes the Legislature and the governor, who enact laws and hold news conferences. The shadow government, also known as ''the authorities,'' controls most of the state's debt, manages most state construction and runs entities like the New York Thruway and utilities.

ALPERSON--Leo, on May 24, 2007. Beloved husband of June, loving father of Ruth, Myra and Philip, father-in-law of Rockwell and Jane, doting grandfather of Jeremy, Sadie and Reva. A sweet, wonderful and caring man, beloved by all, he was born on May 31, 1920 in Omaha, NE. He served in the US Navy in WWII and lived in White Plains, NY. Funeral Services Sunday May 27, 1:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt Vernon. Donations in his memory to a favorite charity.

ALEX ROSENZWEIG, 41, has a problem: People are tired of hearing him talk about ''Star Trek.'' ''At work they complain incessantly,'' said Mr. Rosenzweig, 41, an editor at an environmental consulting firm who is wearing a polo shirt with spaceship insignia. His colleagues give him guff about the 2-foot-by-3-foot ''Star Trek'' poster he displays prominently. And at home in North Brunswick, he knows better than to greet neighbors with a Vulcan salute.

THE federal government seems to have forgotten about West Nile virus, which terrorized New York City and the metropolitan region in 1999, resulting in more than 60 confirmed cases and seven deaths that year and more than 237,000 cases and 900 deaths nationwide since then. Indeed, the Department of Health and Human Services has cut $9.9 million from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's $35 million annual budget to deal with this deadly virus. Next year, an additional $7 million will be cut, leaving the entire program with only $18.1 million, a reduction of almost 50 percent. These cuts will force big reductions in federal support for the surveillance and control of West Nile virus in 57 state and local jurisdictions, including Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

WHEN it comes to her seventh and eighth graders, Sister Mary Bernadette is a stickler for good handwriting. She teaches a 20-minute penmanship class several times a week, her students get a penmanship grade on their report cards, and they lose points in other subjects if their handwriting is not neat. ''Good penmanship is a sign of self-discipline,'' says Sister Mary Bernadette. ''We're trying to create good students, upright human beings, good citizens, good members of their families. Penmanship is a sign of character.''

An article on May 6 about Robert Caro and his biography of Robert Moses referred imprecisely to Moses' role in Westway, a 1970s proposal for a superhighway and park development on the West Side of Manhattan. Although Moses proposed early versions of what would become the Westway superhighway, and although he did not agree with some Westway opponents' view that money for the proposal should be diverted to public transit, he spoke against Westway after he had lost his last public authority chairmanship.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.)

LORDI--William J., died on May 24th, 2007, age 86. Devoted husband, father and grandfather. Graduated St. John's University in 1943. World War II veteran. Coowner of Lordi Petroleum. Member of American Legion Post 754. Member of the New York Athletic Club since 1938; former NYAC Governor, award winning squash player and winner of the 1977 NYAC All Around Athlete Competition (Senior group). Leaves wife Susan, son Bill, daughterin - law Marianne, grand daughters Diana and Christina, niece Francine and niece Georgetta. Predeceased by his brother Joseph and his sister Doris. Died the same day as his sister Rose. Wake at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, corner of Madison Avenue and 81st St., Sunday, May 27th, 2-5pm. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, corner Park Avenue and 84st Street on Tuesday, May 29th, at 10am.

A subheading on May 13 with a review of ''John Donne: The Reformed Soul,'' by John Stubbs, misspelled the surname of the poet who is the subject of the book. As noted elsewhere in the review, it is not Dunne.

Jeff Ma is best known as a card counter, a member of the rogue blackjack team from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the 1990s that won millions of dollars. Then its elaborate and reckless -- if legal -- schemes were discovered, and casinos barred Ma and his group from their tables. The team's adventures were the subject of the 2002 book ''Bringing Down the House,'' by Ben Mezrich. A film version starring Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth is almost completed.

To the Editor: The reality of what I call the disabled lifestyle may best be glimpsed in a scene from ''Scent of a Woman,'' when Al Pacino's blind character emerges from the Ferrari he's been driving to become clumsy and disoriented on the uneven cobblestone street.

Nir Rosen does an excellent job describing the realities of the refugees' exodus from Iraq (May 13). Congress and the 2008 presidential candidates would do well to address the needs of these victims of our ill-conceived war.

To the Editor: I read with great interest your May 20 article about mold, ''What's Furry and Thirsty and Loves the Dark?'' I was somewhat troubled, however, by the lack of doctors' opinions. I think the opinion of a pediatric pulmonologist would have added to the power of the article. I frequently see an illness called hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which is often caused by Cladosporium, Penicillium and Aspergillus, among others. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a common and ominous masquerader of asthma and rarely gets diagnosed until a child fails common asthma therapy and one investigates the home environment. Treatment involves the use of steroids and removal of the offending agents.

SCHULMAN--Lawrence. On Monday, May 21, 2007. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of Daniel and Stewart and daughter-in-law Suzanne. A dynamic but gentle man and a devoted friend. Service on Thursday, noon, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

KENJI MIZOGUCHI's 1954 masterpiece, ''SANSHO THE BAILIFF,'' hasn't been available in the United States market since a VHS edition went out of print years ago. But now the Criterion Collection has issued ''Sansho'' as an impeccably produced DVD. This medium allows the viewer to pause and linger over Mizoguchi's magnificent chiaroscuro compositions, and to rewind and re-view the long tracking shots that were the apotheosis of his distinctive style. The plot is simple, borrowed from a 1915 short story by the Japanese writer Ogai Mori, which was in turn based on a much older folk tale. (Criterion includes both versions of the story in a supplementary book.) In 11th-century Japan a brother and sister, Zushio and Anju, are separated from their aristocratic mother (Kinuyo Tanaka) and sold to the spiky-bearded Sansho (Eitaro Shindo), the brutal overseer of an estate that belongs to a distant nobleman. Through years of tragedy and temptation, Zushio (played as an adult by Yoshiaki Hanayagi) struggles to remain true to the democratic principles that sent his father into political exile, while continuing to search for his missing mother. A simple story, but one that Mizoguchi has filled with vivid emotions, complex thematic contrasts and images of an unsurpassed formal elegance. The father's world is that of human society and moral responsibility; the mother is associated with unruly nature and flowing water, as if she were drawing her spiritual values and emotional strength from the earth itself. Once you know ''Sansho the Bailiff,'' it's a film that can be watched without subtitles, and even without sound. Mizoguchi doesn't depend on language to convey meaning, but instead on the unique resources of the movies: a shaft of light that cuts through a dense forest; rhythms that vary from stillness to frenzy; a subtle panning shot that turns just a few degrees to the left at the unforgettable climax, linking the characters to a suddenly palpable sense of eternity. Criterion.com, $39.95.

LeBron James walked into the Cleveland Cavaliers' locker room Friday wearing black sunglasses as if to shield himself from the lightning storm of debate around him. It had been a long week for James, who had to face another round of scrutiny surrounding his role in the Cavaliers' two losses to the Pistons in the Eastern Conference finals.

One designer promises that her sexy gowns are ''definitely not the prom dress that your mother wore back in the 60s or 70s.'' A florist featuring corsages studded with gems and orchids sprinkled with glitter insists ''these are definitely not your mother's prom flowers.'' The stretch Hummers as the transport of choice? To the Editor: Where do the men go? Try the Home Depot. I can't think of a better place to meet men. There are tons of them there, there is little or no competition, and a ''damsel in distress'' strategy would do wonders to validate any man's masculinity. Men simply want to be needed, and going to class would weaken the case for someone to need them. Geoff Hargadon Somerville, Mass.
In early May, retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic military sports camp at the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs. For some, it was a step toward rehabilitation.

IHLE--William Arthur, Dr., of Delray Beach, Florida died on May 24, 2007 after a noble life of 92 years. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Elizabeth Tracy Ihle. Dr. Ihle will be sorely missed by his family: John Ihle and George Thulin of Hypoluxo, Florida, Kathy and Joseph Sweeney of Summit, New Jersey and Robert and Mary Ihle of Kew Gardens, New York. He was the son of Katherine Fitzgibbons and Henry John Ihle. Dr. Ihle was a graduate of Fordham University and Georgetown University School of Dentistry. He was a former resident of Port Chester, New York where he was in private practice and was a member of Dental Staff at United Hospital. Dr. Ihle was a retired Captain in the US Naval Reserve and a former member of the New York Academy of Dentistry and the Navy League of Boca Raton, Florida. Relatives and friends are invited to attend Arthur's Life Celebration service at Kraeer Funeral Home at 1353 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Florida on Tuesday, May 29, 2007 from 2:00pm to 4:00pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, May 30, 2007 at Ascension Catholic Church in Boca Raton, FL at 10:30am. Interment will be held at a later date with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

Tuscany will be alive this summer with classical music, lots of it. Three music festivals will be inaugurated this year near Siena, an area that already has three other summer festivals. First up are soloists from the Stockholm Royal Opera, many of whom have performed at the Met and La Scala, who will take part in three evening concerts (June 28 to 30) at a private home near San Giovanni D'Asso, about 45 minutes south of Siena. During intermission, a four-course dinner paired with wines will be served by the Siena chef Michele Sorrentino. Tickets start at 80 euros, about $110 at $1.38 to the euro, and include the performance and the meal (www.musictuscany.com).

A Style picture layout on May 13, featuring women wearing their mothers' clothing or clothing like it, misstated the price and store location of the Balenciaga by Nicolas Ghesquiere dress worn by Sharmila Desai. It costs $2,975, not $1,325, and is available at the Balenciaga boutique, 542 West 22nd Street, not at Blake, Chicago.

To the Editor ''Courage in Southampton'' (editorial, May 13) praises Mayor Mark Epley of Southampton Village for spending tax money to alter part of a public park to accommodate day laborers and people who hire them.
To the Editor: Re ''Clearly, Frankly, Unabashedly Disabled'' by Mireya Navarro (May 13):

To the Editor: The rapidly deteriorating -- even chaotic -- conditions illustrated in ''Africa's Storied Colleges, Jammed and Crumbling'' (front page, May 20) are one legacy of an international development agenda that continues to relegate higher education in Africa to second-class status.
Chapter 8

Joan Murray's Lives column on what to do about the aged hitchhiker had universal appeal and raised the question of how children can maintain the delicate balance between duty and respect (May 13). My mother, at 90, confronted me with her desire to live on her own as long as possible. Her mental acuity blinded me to her diminishing physical strength. Finally, I forced her to accept help at home, which, in the end, enabled her to continue living there.

THIS long sliver of a town climbs up the western slope of the Meadowlands, where most of its 6,000 residents are packed into a dense hillside grid barely five blocks wide, bound together tightly enough by geography and genealogy that they slip easily into the first-person plural, especially when talking about what has happened to them since the morning of 9/11. ''When we got the call about Michael ,'' Police Capt. Frank Smith started to say at police headquarters one day recently, and then his voice caught, just the way many other voices in town do when the subject is Michael A. Schwarz, the latest local casualty of the war in Iraq, a war that has taken far more from Carlstadt than anyone ever expected.

Since DaimlerChrysler agreed to sell off its money-losing Chrysler division, Chrysler executives have had to tread a fine line in expressing their reactions to the automaker's return to American ownership. After all, their old bosses in Germany will still be, in a sense, nearly 20 percent their new bosses. The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will own the other 80 percent of Chrysler. On one hand, as Chrysler's chief executive, Thomas W. LaSorda, jubilantly said, ''We'll be able to run it the way we want to run it.'' But Mr. LaSorda did not want to talk about how his vision had differed from the way his bosses in Germany made him run the company.
SULZBERGER--Maye. May 28, 1910-November 26, 2005. Our darling Maye loved her birthday. And we loved her. Very very much. The Family

American Ballet Theater's eagerly awaited new ''SLEEPING BEAUTY'' does not set the story in an asylum narcolepsy wing. But advance word -- and avid gossip -- suggests that its three creators have done more than the usual 21st-century streamlining. For one thing, the prince, a cardboard character, will go beyond simply puckering up. Kevin McKenzie, who directs the company, chose to work with Gelsey Kirkland, known for her emotionally nuanced approach to teaching and coaching. Michael Chernov, a dramaturge, has joined the two in mining material from centuries of fairy tales and ballet productions. Ms. Kirkland will also dance the evil fairy Carabosse. Friday at 8 p.m, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, abt.org; $24 to $168. DANCEAFRICA, now 30, has grown from an ebullient community event to an even more ebullient full-fledged show, featuring African dance companies from around the world. This year's international visitor is the Ndere Troupe of Uganda, which will present East African dances, songs and poetry on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Opera House. The New York-based Forces of Nature Dance Theater Company will perform choreography by Abdel R. Salaam that fuses styles and myth and social history. The festival has played a role in developing African-American dance companies and programs across the nation, three of which will also perform. As always, the larger-than-life, irrepressible founder of the festival, Chuck Davis, will preside. Come prepared to learn a little Swahili and splurge at the outdoor bazaar. Friday at 7:30, Saturday and Sunday at 2 and 7:30, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $20 to $45, half off for children 16 and under. The lineup for the annual NEW YORK TAP EXTRAVAGANZA on Sunday includes Jimmy Slyde, Mable Lee, Savion Glover and Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards. Awards will be presented, too. But the great pleasure of the event promises to be the way that tap, practiced by several generations of dancers, comes alive once again. 7 p.m., Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street, Chelsea, nytap.org; $25 to $65.

To the Editor: Re ''Would a Sing Sing Museum Be in Bad Taste?,'' by Kate Stone Lombardi (column, May 20):
To the Editor: Re ''When Tennis Elbows Are Sharp'' (May 20):
GRIFFING--Melissa. May of 2006. Your family and friends miss you every day. You're in our hearts forever.

This is a notable week for complete surveys of classical repertory, one courtesy of a young pianist, the other from a veteran string quartet. The pianist is KONSTANTIN LIFSCHITZ. Last year, for the invaluable Free for All at Town Hall series, this Russian-born artist won high critical praise and grateful ovations for performing the 24 preludes and fugues of Shostakovich in two programs on a single Sunday. He returns to the series this Sunday to play the 48 preludes and fugues of Bach. Here is a rare chance to immerse oneself in arguably the most fundamental, influential and ingenious body of keyboard works in music history. And you can't beat the price. 2 and 7 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 707-8787, freeforallattownhall.org; free, but tickets are required. The veteran string quartet is the EMERSON, which has just commenced its Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall. Performing a cycle of the 16 Beethoven string quartets, while always challenging, is no longer unusual. But the Emerson players aim to demonstrate the impact of Beethoven's seminal quartets on the entire genre by performing them alongside quartets by previous, contemporaneous and subsequent composers, from Bach and Haydn through Schubert and Brahms to Shostakovich, Webern and Kaija Saariaho. And more. The inaugural program offers quartets by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven (the ''Razumovsky,'' Op. 59, No. 3). Thursday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $32 to $79. On Sunday the dynamic and boyish conductor PAUL HAAS has his final performance as music director of the NEW YORK YOUTH SYMPHONY. The gifted and hard-working players of this impressive ensemble excelled for Mr. Haas during his five-year tenure. The formidable program includes arrangements of Bach chorales, the premiere of Dan Visconti's ''Some Day the Sun Won't Shine'' and Mahler's daunting Ninth Symphony. 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall; $7 to $55.

To the Editor: I am troubled by the seemingly reactionary use of obese female models by Leonard Nimoy and others (''Girth and Nudity, a Pictorial Mission'' by Abby Ellin, May 13). Fat is not beautiful -- obesity is one of society's worst public health problems.

Because of Connecticut's early and active participation in legal action against the tobacco industry, the state will receive approximately $27 million more a year over the next decade than it already does as part of the 1998 settlement. This year, that amounted to nearly $112 million. But if Connecticut's track record with the nearly $1 billion in settlement money it has already received is any indication, little of the windfall will go toward the antismoking efforts that the money, under the terms of the settlement, is supposed to pay for. This year, the state allocated less than 10 percent of the $21 million that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta recommends it should spend. This was one of its best years; the allocation last year was 0.2 percent.

The case for ocean no-fishing areas is more complicated than Paul Greenberg suggests (May 13). Ideologues who insist that every protected area must be closed to all fishing, or that every place must remain open to all fishing, are equally mistaken. A mixed approach that uses traditional fisheries regulations, market incentives, informed consumers and comprehensive ocean zoning -- not just closed areas -- is needed.

To the Editor: Halfway through Elizabeth Fitzsimons's account of meeting her sickly new daughter in China (''My First Lesson in Motherhood,'' Modern Love, May 13), I burst into tears.

BACK in 2001, Nissan badly needed a hit to revive its floundering business in North America, and the Altima delivered. The third-generation Altima, transformed from a dowdy, unloved compact into a sleek midsize sedan with sporty handling, brought younger customers to Nissan showrooms and gave the carmaker a serious competitor to the mighty Toyota Camry and Honda Accord. Nissan's recent woes, a dip in sales and profits, is hardly the sort of crisis that confronted the company six years ago. But Nissan is again turning to the Altima to refresh its image. While the fourth-generation car isn't as big a leap as the third, this redesigned 2007 model gives Nissan a bit of needed sizzle in the crowded market for midsize, midprice front-wheel-drive sedans.

To the Editor: Re ''A Great Idea Lives Forever. Shouldn't Its Copyright?'' (Op-Ed, May 20): Mark Helprin makes the alarming suggestion that copyrights should be extended as far as the Constitution will allow. He complains about treating intellectual property differently than other property. But different treatment makes sense.

Charter Member Trevor Hoffman of the Padres is five saves from becoming the first pitcher with 500. His first two saves came in 1993 with the Marlins. They traded him in June of that season. Florida, which joined the majors in 1993, has 542 saves in its history. Rare for N.L. Shortstops Brewers shortstop J. J. Hardy leads the National League in total bases with 118. The last shortstop to lead the N.L. in that category was Ernie Banks with 379 in 1958. Milwaukee, with a 17-7 record at home, is scheduled to be home for 10 straight games starting tomorrow. Behind the Pace Alfonso Soriano of the Cubs, who hit 46 home runs last season as a member of the Nationals, has hit only four so far this season. In 2006, he had 19 through May 31. Bad Beginners With his loss Friday night against the Nationals, Anthony Reyes of the Cardinals is 0-8. The record for most consecutive games lost from the start of a season is 14, shared by Joe Harris with the 1906 Boston Americans (later the Red Sox) and Matt Keough with the 1979 Oakland Athletics. Beckett Set to Return Josh Beckett of the Red Sox (7-0) is expected to be activated from the disabled list Tuesday to make his first start since May 13. He is set to start against the Indians in Boston, where he is 4-0 this season. The Watch List Frank Thomas is healthy again, but his numbers are not. His home run Thursday tied him with Lou Gehrig on the career list. But he has only 7 homers and 20 runs batted in this season and is hitting .228. Thomas, right, who signed a two-year, $18 million deal with the Blue Jays in the off-season, has averaged 36 homers and 104 R.B.I. in his past three full seasons. Those numbers are not out of the question. Even in his best seasons, he has had similar droughts. Sure, Edwin Encarnación was hitting around .200 when the Reds sent him to the minors. But the roster move probably had more to do with his benching after he failed to run out a pop-up and with his six errors at third, including two that cost the Reds a game the day before he was demoted. Encarnación hit .413 with 3 home runs in 11 games at Class AAA Louisville before being called back up, a sign that his offense could help make up for the absence of the injured Josh Hamilton. But he also committed three errors at Louisville, a sign that the Reds could miss the third-base play of Ryan Freel, who took over for Hamilton in the outfield. Kevin Kouzmanoff of the Padres is hitting .217, but that is a long way from where he was in April, when he hit .113 with 4 R.B.I. He has rebounded by driving in 18 runs and batting .367 this month. Statistics through Friday night. (Sources by MLB.com, STATS LLC, Baseball-reference.com)
ORR--Jack Douglas, of Nashville, TN. My friend and lover for almost 30 years. A rock-nroll original, truly one of a kind. I will miss you always. Marcy
Sexy sofas, not-so-precious metals, homey handwork. At his year's Milan Furniture Fair, design lightens up. Seriously.

THE federal government seems to have forgotten about West Nile virus, which terrorized New York City and the metropolitan region in 1999, resulting in more than 60 confirmed cases and seven deaths that year and more than 237,000 cases and 900 deaths nationwide since then. Indeed, the Department of Health and Human Services has cut $9.9 million from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's $35 million annual budget to deal with this deadly virus. Next year, an additional $7 million will be cut, leaving the entire program with only $18.1 million, a reduction of almost 50 percent. These cuts will force big reductions in federal support for the surveillance and control of West Nile virus in 57 state and local jurisdictions, including Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

Diane Louise Gross and Khalid Rasuli Pitts were married last evening at the Dumbarton House, a museum in Washington. The Rev. Ronald Stief, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated. Ms. Gross, 37, is keeping her name. She was until last November a consulting counsel for the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, which is based in Washington. From July 2003 to October 2005, she was the counsel to Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland. She graduated from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and received a law degree from New York University.

How bad is the National League Central? In games against nondivision teams last Monday through Friday, Central teams won 2 and lost 16. In that five-day period, the division-leading Milwaukee Brewers lost three of four games but increased their lead by half a game. So what would the Brewers rather do: lose games but increase their lead or win games and take their chances?
To the Editor: ''What's Furry and Thirsty and Loves the Dark?'' misses the forest for the mold. You leave the reader with the impression that there are lingering health effects from mold.

HESSERT--Richard Collings, 83, passed on May 23rd. Born in Los Angeles on November 29th, 1923, Dick was Navy Officer during WWII and a graduate of Thunderbird. His career in International Banking took him to Cuba, Columbia, Mexico and the Carribean. In addition, his love of travel extended from the Amazon to Tibet. Known as ''Poppy'' to his family, he leaves four children, Kel, Lois, Rich and Chris, their spouses, five grandchildren and many friends and relations. He is predeceased by his wife of 55 years ''Tink'', whom he cherished. His humor, kindness and love of life will be missed.

HEFFERNAN--Daniel E., of Laurel Hollow on May 24, 2007 at home after a long illness. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Kristine Heffernan-McCann, Daniel Jr., Kathryn Heffernan Macmillan and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Meghan, Shannon, Caitlin and Tommy. Dear brother of Sybil Keane. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday at 9:30 am at St. Dominic's Chapel, Oyster Bay, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to American Cancer Society, Memorial Processing Center, 6725 Lyons St., P.O. Box 7, East Syracuse, NY 13057 would be appreciated.

ALEX ROSENZWEIG, 41, has a problem: People are tired of hearing him talk about ''Star Trek.'' ''At work they complain incessantly,'' said Mr. Rosenzweig, 41, an editor at an environmental consulting firm who is wearing a polo shirt with spaceship insignia. His colleagues give him guff about the 2-foot-by-3-foot ''Star Trek'' poster he displays prominently. And at home in North Brunswick, he knows better than to greet neighbors with a Vulcan salute.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Children's Museums: Just Made for a Girl and Boy'' (Weekend in New York, May 13): We were disappointed that the article did not mention the New York Transit Museum, which offers free family workshops (museum admission not included) every weekend. Workshops include mosaic making, ''Create A City,'' bus and bridge building, ''Poetry in Motion'' and ''Hands On History.'' The museum is host to seven exhibitions exploring public transportation's importance in the development of New York City, including 20 vintage subway and elevated trains on the platform level of our 1936 subway station home.

New York State government has two parts, one public and one carefully tucked out of sight. The public part includes the Legislature and the governor, who enact laws and hold news conferences. The shadow government, also known as ''the authorities,'' controls most of the state's debt, manages most state construction and runs entities like the New York Thruway and utilities.

To the Editor: ''Last Go-Round'' (May 13) instantly evoked a spasm of nostalgia for the days of Long Island's own Mineola Roller Rink. I was sad not to read even a brief epitaph commemorating this departed, quintessentially Long Island giant.

To the Editor: In his review of Christopher Hitchens's ''God Is Not Great'' (May 13), Michael Kinsley cites the novels of Graham Greene as one of the sources of the ''character'' Hitchens has established for himself. That is interesting. But, then, what could Hitchens possibly make of Greene's own religiosity? Unlike the literal-minded believers scourged in ''God Is Not Great,'' Greene rather flexibly combined a Roman Catholic vision with an agnostic conscience -- which, it has been famously observed, gets you the medieval picturesqueness of the one with all the modern conveniences of the other.

A column last Sunday, about the publishing of police reports, misstated the readership of The Day, a daily newspaper in New London. The paper's daily circulation is nearly 37,000, which translates, according to the Newspaper Association of America, to more than 86,000 readers, not 26,000.

Dr. Grace Sangyun Lee, a daughter of Dr. Hei Suk Lee and Dr. Jae Yoon Lee of Todt Hill, Staten Island, was married last evening to Dr. William Gee Chang, a son of Ya-Huey Chang and Dr. Ho-Huang Chang of Charleston, W.Va. The Rev. Gerald Fierst, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Hilton Garden Inn in Bloomfield, Staten Island. The bride, 27, and bridegroom, 30, met while at New York University, where they received medical degrees and where he also received a doctorate in molecular oncology and immunology. In June, she is to become an intern in internal medicine at Yale-New Haven Hospital, where he is to become a second-year resident. The bride graduated summa cum laude from University of California, Los Angeles. The bridegroom graduated cum laude from Harvard.
Twenty-one years later, Ron Darling still remembers the pitch that he threw to a young, lean rookie on the Pittsburgh Pirates. ''It was a big, fat one, right down the middle,'' Darling said.

So the FIA has decided to investigate this story about McLaren giving team orders to "fix" the race results in Monaco. I would laugh this off were it not for the fact that I have not yet seen the FIA do anything to help McLaren. So I worry that the FIA might do something that resembles fixing the championship - if McLaren were to be disqualified, Ferrari would win...65 seconds behind. On the other hand, knowing that the FIA could never do such a thing, I ultimately do not worry about it.

Rome of course has its share of decent lunch places, but it's hard to sit down in a restaurant here for under 20 Euro and there's little appealing outdoor dining, despite this city's extraordinary weather. So here is my suggestion from this gorgeous spring day: There are myriad bread bakeries offering cheap delicious sandwiches (panini) consisting of meats, local cheeses, fresh vegetables, and more -- all on warm fresh-baked Italian flat breads. Have a picnic!
Michael Powell, who started covering Rudolph Giuliani 15 years ago, talks about how the candidate has changed, or not, as he runs for president.

Three of the eight games on Day 2 of the candidates matches ended decisively, with one of the favorites, Judit Polgar of Hungary, losing to fall behind 0.5 to 1.5. The matches are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for a world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

It's four hours or so before game time, and many of the Yankees are out on the field at Rogers Center, taking early batting practice, as they do before the first game of every road series. No sign of Joe Torre, but Reggie Jackson is behind the batting cage. Mariano Rivera is horsing around in center field, where he'd probably be a heck of a player.
Hyperactive, hyper-organized Hong Kong has planned a whopping 460 events to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the handover from British to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997.
On this day, to fallen soldiers of all wars with chronicles of fallout from the war in Iraq, the everpresent reminder that Memorial Day transcends generations.
Some residents fear that a munitions depot in Maputo, Mozambique, will explode due to government neglect.

Ron Daniels is director of the only needle exchange program in Washington. The city is prevented by law from financing such programs.
President Bush called those who have died in Iraq and Afghanistan "a new generation of heroes."
The San Francisco Giants are in town on Tuesday, and that means that Barry Bonds and his controversial pursuit of home run supremacy will take center stage at Shea Stadium.
Nikolay Davydenko did not play entirely calmly against Stefano Galvani, who was fiery and animated throughout the match, but still won 6-3, 6-1, 6-1, in the first round.
Initial results left no doubt that Defense Minister Amir Peretz would lose the Israeli Labor Party chairmanship.
Researchers say they have found six new sites of variation in the genome that increase the risk of breast cancer.
Some governments have been reluctant to sign extradition treaties with China because of concerns about its widespread use of the death penalty.
The United States and Iran held the first high-profile, face-to-face talks in nearly three decades today, adhering to an agenda that focused strictly on Iraq.
The agricultural minister, Toshikatsu Matsuoka, was to face parliamentary questioning on a political scandal.

From his first thundering drive and rim-rattling dunk to his last clutch shot in the fourth quarter, LeBron James elevated his game, his team and this series with a dominating performance.
Casey Mears in his first year at Hendrick Motorsports, took the Coca-Cola 600 on Sunday night at Lowe’s Motor Speedway.

A 22-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday afternoon on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Christopher Darns, of Brooklyn, was shot at 3:10 p.m. in front of 866 Madison Street, the police said. There have been no arrests, the police said.

A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 15 about a study by ACT, the Iowa testing organization, on the effectiveness of college preparatory courses, misstated a finding of the report. In analyzing about 1.2 million high students who took the ACT college admissions test before graduating last June, the study found that 26 percent of those who took the core curriculum were college ready; it did not find that 26 percent of all students tested were college-ready.

An obituary on April 25 about Warren E. Avis, founder of the chain of car-rental agencies, misstated the year of an interview in which Mr. Avis discussed the difficulties he faced over his idea to open such agencies at airports. It was 1985, not 1987. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 20.

A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces.

An article on Thursday about a decision by a New Hampshire legislative panel to reject a seat belt law misstated the state’s rate of seat belt use and referred imprecisely to its rank in the nation. The rate is 63.5 percent, not 49.6 percent. New Hampshire and Wyoming — not just New Hampshire — rank last.

An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday about the presence of financial firms at the Cannes Film Festival referred incorrectly to the role of the studio Summit Entertainment in the film “Pompeii.” While Summit negotiated financing for the film, it did not invest in it.

A front-page article last Monday about a further decline in India’s electricity supply, even as its economy has expanded, incorrectly compared the per-capita annual energy consumption between India and the United States. The typical Indian consumes about one-fifteenth as much energy per year as the typical American — not one-fifth.

A picture caption on Thursday about an announcement by Silverio A. Vega, the Cuban-born mayor of West New York, N.J., that the annual Cuban Parade of New Jersey would not be allowed to pass through his town gave the incorrect date in some copies for Mr. Vega’s news conference. It was last Monday, not Wednesday.

An article on May 18 about a reported robbery attempt at the country estate in South Kent, Conn., owned by the socialite Anne Bass, misstated the year that she arranged for a herd of 130 Randall cattle to live on her land. It was 2004, not 2005. The article also referred imprecisely to the herd’s ownership. Of the roughly 180 cattle that are now in the herd, Mrs. Bass owns about 40 — not the entire herd — according to the cattle manager, Cynthia Creech, who owns the rest.

A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 17 about a low-cost camcorder called the Flip Video referred incorrectly to its retail availability. Although CVS, Rite Aid and Wolf Camera are among the locations where video from the cameras can be processed into DVDs, those stores do not sell the cameras.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Ben Weisman, a songwriter, included erroneous information from a family member about his illnesses before his death. He suffered a stroke and had pneumonia; he did not have Alzheimer’s disease. The obituary also erroneously included a group among the performers for whom he wrote songs. He did not write for the Beatles.

A front-page article on April 26 about the restricted activities of city councilmen chosen in municipal elections in Saudi Arabia two years ago attributed an erroneous distinction to those elections. While they were the first in which all men outside the military could vote (women are not allowed to vote), the elections were not the first ever held in Saudi Arabia. (A far more limited form of voting was introduced in Mecca in 1925, which lasted for roughly a decade. In later years, until the 1960s, some councilmen were elected in selected cities by small groups of voters.) A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of work by Eva Rothschild, at 303 Gallery in Chelsea, misidentified the gallery that represents Liz Larner, a sculptor whose creations Ms. Rothschild’s works were said to resemble. Her principal dealers are the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery in New York and Regen Projects in Los Angeles — not 303 Gallery, which she left in 2004.

A Perth Amboy man who shot and killed a woman and wounded three other people outside a neighborhood bar on Saturday fatally shot himself in the neck as a police officer fired at him, the authorities said yesterday. An autopsy showed that Edwin Cordero Jr., 27, died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, according to the Middlesex County prosecutor, Bruce Kaplan. Mr. Cordero was also hit by five rounds fired by Perth Amboy Officer Ganagioti Bouleris, although none of the bullets hit vital organs, Mr. Kaplan said. The shooting, which began shortly after 2 a.m. when Mr. Cordero opened fire at a parked car and people standing nearby, was still under investigation, Mr. Kaplan said. The woman killed, Fabia Aguilar of Plainfield, described by the authorities as an acquaintance of Mr. Cordero’s, was found dead inside the car with 12 wounds from his Tec-9 handgun. Two of the other people Mr. Cordero shot remained hospitalized yesterday, the police said. The third was treated for a gunshot wound to the leg.

A 27-year-old man was shot in the back and killed early yesterday in an East Harlem apartment, the police said. The man, identified as Delvon Hairston, of 2370 Second Avenue, was shot at about 12:20 a.m. in an apartment at 2390 Second Avenue, the police said. He was taken to North General Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Investigators were seeking three suspects yesterday, the police said.

A woman was arrested at a Wal-Mart store on Saturday after she was caught snorting heroin while pushing her 3-year-old son in a shopping cart, the Suffolk County police said. The woman, Stacy Roe, 35, of Farmingville, was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and criminal possession of a controlled substance. She was seen on surveillance video snorting a substance through a straw while pushing the cart inside the store at 6:10 p.m., the police said. When the police confronted her, she admitted she had just snorted heroin and said she had a bag of the substance in her wallet, the police said. The woman told officers she was shopping for a toy train for her son, the police said. The child was removed and placed in the custody of his father, and the case was referred to Child Protective Services, the police said. Ms. Roe was ordered to be in court on July 17.

The case was being investigated and an autopsy was to be performed to determine the cause of death, the police said.

(TCM) COMMAND DECISION (1948) Turner Classic Movies salutes the armed forces with a Memorial Day marathon starring some A-list heroes, beginning with Clark Gable in this colorized World War II drama about a general who must battle his own government to send his planes deeper into Germany. The tribute continues with Humphrey Bogart in “Action in the North Atlantic” (1943), at 8; “From Here to Eternity” (1953), the Oscar-winning romance with Montgomery Clift, Donna Reed and, above, Deborah Kerr and Burt Lancaster, at 10:30; “Sergeant York” (1941), the Gary Cooper classic, at 12:30 p.m.; Michael Caine and Laurence Olivier in “The Battle of Britain” (1969), at 3; “Where Eagles Dare” (1969), starring Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood as fearless fliers, at 5:15; “A Soldier’s Story” (1984), in which Howard E. Rollins Jr. plays an African-American officer assigned to investigate a racially charged murder, at 8; the William Holden classics “Stalag 17” (1953), at 10, and “The Bridge on the River Kwai,” at 12:15 a.m.; and “Wake Island” (1942), with Brian Donlevy as a Marine major trying to keep the Japanese off his island base, at 3. Day breaks on a more melodic note with Tab Hunter and Frankie Avalon in “Operation Bikini” (1963) at 4:30.

A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces.

Dr. Walter J. Koroshetz, deputy director of the National Institute on Neurological Disorders and Stroke, lists five things everyone should know about strokes: A KILLER -- Strokes can cause permanent brain damage and are the leading cause of permanent disability in adults. They are the third-leading cause of death in the United States. There are two main types of stroke: ischemic, caused by blockage of a blood vessel in the brain, and hemorrhagic, caused by bleeding into or around the brain. PREVENTION -- The best way to prevent most strokes is to keep blood pressure in the normal range. WARNING SIGNS -- A number of conditions place people at high risk for stroke and should lead to intensive investigation and therapy.

To the Editor: ''Shifting Madison Square Garden'' (editorial, May 23) gets it absolutely right: the arena must be moved to accommodate the new and beautiful Penn Station that New Yorkers have dreamed of.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Ben Weisman, a songwriter, included erroneous information from a family member about his illnesses before his death. He suffered a stroke and had pneumonia; he did not have Alzheimer's disease. The obituary also erroneously included a group among the performers for whom he wrote songs. He did not write for the Beatles.

''I called 911, but nothing would come out of my mouth. I said 'stroke' in this long, horrible voice.'' DIANA FITE, an emergency room doctor in Houston, recalling the stroke she had after years of ignoring high blood pressure. [A1]

Richard Thompson ''Sweet Warrior'' (Shout! Factory) ''Dad's Gonna Kill Me'' is the bleakest song on Richard Thompson's new album, ''Sweet Warrior.'' Dad is Baghdad, and the song, filled with military slang Mr. Thompson found online, details the thoughts of a soldier stationed there, watching his comrades die: ''Vultures pecking the eyes out of his head/Another day that could have been me there instead/Nobody loves me here.''

SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY It will be a heavy week for economic data. On Friday, the government will issue its employment report for May, as well as reports on personal income and spending for April. In addition, the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for May will be released along with the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index. Also on Friday, automakers will report sales for May.

A front-page article last Monday about a further decline in India's electricity supply, even as its economy has expanded, incorrectly compared the per-capita annual energy consumption between India and the United States. The typical Indian consumes about one-fifteenth as much energy per year as the typical American -- not one-fifth.

A battle looms this week between Mr. Spitzer and the Legislature over the details of a bill that would bring new levels of disclosure and oversight to the state's hundreds of public authorities. Though there is broad agreement on a host of issues, the Legislature favors allowing the comptroller to approve all authority contracts and giving subpoena power to the office that monitors authorities' finances. The Spitzer administration, in private talks with lawmakers, balked on those positions. But the biggest sticking point may be something else entirely. Buried in the governor's bill is a provision that would shake up the obscure but powerful Public Authorities Control Board, which must approve projects begun by the state's biggest authorities, such as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority or the Empire State Development Corporation.

Von Südenfed ''Tromatic Reflexxions'' (Domino) Mark E. Smith, the singer of the British postpunk band the Fall, has legitimized his catarrhal snarl, his malignant susurrations, by running a band for 30 years in the image of his voice, one that plays broken-spoke repetitions with musical imperfection. The sound of the Fall, taken as a career average over its many lineups, is organic, real, even squalid (in the best way). Why would we want to hear him in a different band with metronome-beat electronics? After all he's too good as a mode of resistance against machines.

A 22-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday afternoon on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Christopher Darns, of Brooklyn, was shot at 3:10 p.m. in front of 866 Madison Street, the police said. There have been no arrests, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

BAILEY--Helen Phelps. On the 5th anniversary of her death, she is remembered with affection and admiration by friends, family, colleagues and students. Professor of French Language and Literature for 43 years and Dean of Studies for 15 years at Barnard College, she was a graduate of Barnard and earned a Ph.D. from Columbia University. She studied also at McGill University and at the Sorbonne. She authored a book, ''Hamlet in France from Voltaire to Laforgue,'' and did the first known translation from French of a play by St. Therese of Lisieux. The French Government awarded her the Palmes Academiques for her fostering of French culture and arts. Until shortly before her death at age 90, she was a lector and choir member at her church, St. John's of Leonia, NJ. She encountered everyone on an equal footing, with a rare combination of kindness and objectivity that made her a dear and valued friend.

Perry Farrell's Satellite Party ''Ultra Payloaded'' (Columbia) No, Perry Farrell's high voice doesn't change suddenly for ''Woman in the Window,'' the last song on ''Ultra Payloaded'' That song's familiar baritone belongs to Jim Morrison of the Doors, singing a previously unreleased vocal track with mysterious, quasi-biblical lyrics. Mr. Farrell's newly devised accompaniment starts as chill-out music and builds with strings and Beatles allusions while Morrison croons, ''Just try and stop us, we're going to love.''

A front-page article on April 26 about the restricted activities of city councilmen chosen in municipal elections in Saudi Arabia two years ago attributed an erroneous distinction to those elections. While they were the first in which all men outside the military could vote (women are not allowed to vote), the elections were not the first ever held in Saudi Arabia. (A far more limited form of voting was introduced in Mecca in 1925, which lasted for roughly a decade. In later years, until the 1960s, some councilmen were elected in selected cities by small groups of voters.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

Watch those vending machines, school hall monitors. A new regulation proposed by the governor says that before students are allowed to buy Gatorade or other sports drinks, they must have ''engaged in vigorous athletic activity lasting for more than one hour.'' The requirement is included in the governor's array of proposals aimed at making food served and sold in schools healthier. Among the other requirements: high school students could be served decaffeinated coffee or tea, or hot chocolate if it had no more than 180 calories per eight-ounce serving, but only at breakfast. Vending machines in high schools could offer only products meeting a lengthy set of criteria, such as ''nonnutritive-sweetened, noncaffeinated, noncarbonated, nonfortified beverages that contain less than five calories per serving.'' Further, schools must install timing devices in vending machines so they work only ''after the end of the last class period'' of the day.

Internment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery Yonkers, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Family Circle at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

SULLIVAN--John N. (Jack), of Port Washington, NY died May 25, 2007 at the age of 79. Beloved husband of MaryAnne. Loving father of Susan Graham, Karen Garry, Kelly Dennis and John Sullivan. Cherished grandfather of Katie, Ryan, Kieran, Dylan and Riley. Graduate of St. Andrew Avellino (1941), Fordham Prep (1945) and Fordham University (1951). Student at Fordham College at 60, Lincoln Center. US Army Veteran. Dedicated Latin and Greek teacher for 41 years at Fordham Prep where he was also well-known for coaching basketball and lacrosse. Led student tours to Italy for over 25 years. Wake Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. Funeral Wednesday 9:30 am at St. Peter of Alcantara Church, 1321 Port Washington Blvd., Port Washington, NY. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. Donations in his honor may be sent to the St. Vincent de Paul Society. Carpe Diem -Ave Atque Vale.

SWERN--Ruth, (nee Feingold). Beloved wife of Leonard. adoring mother of Anne and Susan Swern. Loving mother-in-law of Steven Brounstein. Extraordinarily devoted grandmother of Genna and Sam. Caring sister of Annie, Rosie, Sammy, Bea and the late Joe and Shirley. Service Tuesday, 2 PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to The Kempe Foundation, 1825 Marion Street, Denver, CO 80218.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 As Allies Become Enemies, Some G.I.'s Disillusioned In interviews with more than a dozen soldiers in an 83-man unit of Delta Company in Iraq, most said they were disillusioned by repeated deployments, by what they saw as the abysmal performance of Iraqi security forces and by the finding of Iraqis once considered allies in the ranks of the enemy. A1 Two more American soldiers have died from roadside bombs, the military said, and United States forces began making DNA tests on a body that could be one of the remaining two missing soldiers abducted in an ambush on May 12 south of Baghdad. A7 Hamas Rocket Kills Israeli An Israeli man died from a Qassam rocket launched from Gaza, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert vowed to continue Israel's military assault on Hamas as an effort to stop the rocket fire, warning that ''no one involved in terror is immune.'' In a statement, Hamas took responsibility for the rocket and expressed support for the squad that fired it. A6 Ruling in Libya AIDS Case A Libyan court acquitted five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor on charges of slander. They were accused of making false accusations that Libyan officials had tortured them to extract confessions in an investigation into H.I.V. infections at a children's hospital in Benghazi. A6 NATIONAL A9-13 Lost Chances for Survival Before and After a Stroke Strokes are the third-leading cause of death in this country, killing 150,000 Americans a year, leaving many more permanently disabled and costing the nation $62.7 billion in direct and indirect costs. But from diagnosis to preventing it altogether, a stroke can bring a litany of missed opportunities. A1 Greenwich's Sway in Campaign As Connecticut's richest town, Greenwich has always held some allure for politicians looking to raise money and make influential friends. But with several of the current presidential contenders wanting to raise upward of $500 million to stay competitive through the general election, the richest of the town's 61,000 residents are being wooed more than ever. A1 Outbreak of Rare Eye Infection Health officials and eye doctors are puzzled by a new outbreak of a rare but potentially blinding eye infection that has led the manufacturer of a lens cleaning solution to withdraw one of its products this weekend. A9 Native American Scholarships The University of Maine and several other colleges and universities around the country have scholarship programs that waive tuition, fees and room and board for any undergraduate or graduate student who can prove membership in a state or federally recognized tribe or direct descent from a member. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Mandarin Classes Become Lessons in Adaptation A weekly Mandarin class arranged by City Councilman John C. Liu has drawn an assortment of non-Asian students who have lived in Flushing, Queens, since before a wave of Asian immigrants arrived. Many in Queens have decided that the time has come to adjust. A1 Fallen Soldiers Honored As part of a project that identified nearly 3,000 Civil War soldiers buried in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, 1,200 of them are being honored with new gravestones. Dozens of veterans' descendants, some from as far away as Spain, will join volunteers and Civil War re-enactors today for a public ceremony. B1 First Biodiesel Plant in City A fuel terminal in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, may soon be home to one of the largest biodiesel manufacturing plants in the country, and one of the first in the city. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-6 BET Invests in Originality Despite being the first and largest African-American cable channel, BET has developed few marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs. With 16 new shows planned for the fall, BET is on a mission to reverse that trend. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Fixing the alternative tax; an even better farm bill; Mr. Spitzer's DNA proposal; Adam Cohen on the history of Memorial Day. Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E8 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather D9

A 27-year-old man was shot in the back and killed early yesterday in an East Harlem apartment, the police said. The man, identified as Delvon Hairston, of 2370 Second Avenue, was shot at about 12:20 a.m. in an apartment at 2390 Second Avenue, the police said. He was taken to North General Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Investigators were seeking three suspects yesterday, the police said. MICHAEL WILSON

STAPEN--Manuel, MD, age 92, of New York, NY. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of this prominant psychoanalyst who died peacefully in his sleep on May 25, 2007. Born in Brooklyn, NY on August 19, 1914 , he served as a medical officer during WWII. After further training he practiced in Manhattan, and was a member of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. Dr. Stapen will be remembered for his kindness, generosity, and intellectual curiosity. He was a devotee of the Opera, Synphony, and Ballet, and had a great interest in art. He is survived by his devoted wife Tatiana, and her daughters Elena and Karen; by his former wife Bonnie, and beloved daughters Anita (Richard) and Nancy (Ron); and grandchildren Rachel, David, Sarah, and Julia. He will also be mourned by brothers Milton and Irving, and sister Annabelle, as well as numerous neices and nephews. Funeral to be held at Schwartz Brothers -Jeffer Memorial Chapel on Tuesday, May 29, at 1:30 pm.

Assembly Democrats are resisting Gov. Eliot Spitzer's proposal to expand DNA collection to all misdemeanor convictions without taking more steps that they say will protect the wrongfully accused. On Friday night, Speaker Sheldon Silver and Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, both New York City Democrats, introduced their own bill that would expand the DNA database to all misdemeanors, as the governor proposed in his bill this month. Currently DNA samples are collected from people convicted of all felonies and a few misdemeanors.

CAAMANO--Raphael, Reverend, beloved and esteemed priest of Opus Dei who died at Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts on May 21 at the age of 82. He was born in Ferrol, Spain, graduated from the Spanish Naval Academy and the School of Naval Architecture in Genoa Italy. He retired with honor from the Spanish Navy in 1961. He had become a member of Opus Dei in 1949 and worked closely with Saint Jose Maria Escriva, the Founder of Opus Dei. He was ordained a priest in 1978 and was the Vicar of Opus Dei in the United States from 1980 to 1988. He lived in Boston from 1992. He became a beloved and insightful member of the Board of Directors of the Homeland Foundation, established by the late Chauncey Stillman who revered Father Caamano as have Mr. E. Lisk Wyckoff, its President and all the members of the Foundation. They welcome his friends who will attend a mass for the repose of the soul of Father Caamano on Tuesday May 29 at 6:15pm at the Church of Saint Jean Baptiste at Lexington Avenue and 78th Street in Manhattan.

A picture caption on Thursday about an announcement by Silverio A. Vega, the Cuban-born mayor of West New York, N.J., that the annual Cuban Parade of New Jersey would not be allowed to pass through his town gave the incorrect date in some copies for Mr. Vega's news conference. It was last Monday, not Wednesday.

GORDON--Jack L., of New Canaan, CT, passed away on May 26, 2007 at the age of 78. Survived by his wife Zahava, and five children. Services to be held at 12PM on Monday, May 28, 2007 at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT.
