The Bravery ''The Sun and the Moon'' (Island) ''Every word from your mouth is a knife in my ear/Every thought in your head is like poison to hear,'' sings Sam Endicott, the Bravery's songwriter, on this band's second album, ''The Sun and the Moon.'' What really matters is what he sings immediately afterward: ''Oh, oh oh oh-oh-ohhh/Oh, oh oh oh-oh-ohh.'' Because for all the angst in the Bravery's latest songs, the hooks come first. The Bravery is a pop-rock band and glad of it. That means plenty of nonsense syllables to invite singalongs, and utter shamelessness about borrowing other bands' sounds and tricks.

The governor vetoed his fourth bill last week, rejecting an extension of a law limiting the number of check-cashing facilities in any one area. Since 1994, new check-cashing facilities have been banned within three-tenths of a mile of an existing one. Earlier this year, the Legislature voted to extend a 2002 law that broadened this prohibition to other financial institutions that open branches mainly devoted to check cashing, including banks and credit unions. In supporting the extension, the bill's Assembly sponsor, Darryl C. Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat, wrote that it had helped check-cashing facilities keep fees low by maintaining a stable flow of business.

RECRUITING BATTLES As much of the high-tech industry is enjoying a renewed boom, the competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields is as intense as ever. Companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo find themselves going after the same candidates or recruiting in one another's backyards. At the same time, they are running up against a myriad of start-up companies across Silicon Valley. To lure talent, these companies have expanded their recruiting arsenal far beyond the traditional job fair to include events like technology lectures, cocktail parties, pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests, called ''code jams'' or ''hack days.'' [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR STARS Despite being the first and certainly the largest African-American cable channel, Black Entertainment Television has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs. It relies on reruns, movies and music videos for the bulk of its lineup. The chief executive of BET, Debra L. Lee, has tried to reverse that trend, this year increasing the channel's production budget 50 percent and plunging into original programming with 16 new shows for the fall. [C1.] POLICEMAN, NOT A REPORTER David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter named Peter MacKay from the free daily tabloid 24 Hours Vancouver. But when Mr. Cunningham arrived outside a shopping mall for what he thought would be an interview, Peter MacKay turned out to be a plainclothes police officer who arrested him. Someone in the Vancouver Police Department thought the deception was a clever way to lure Mr. Cunningham, but the ruse provoked widespread criticism from civil rights and journalism groups. [C4.] HIGH ASPIRATIONS Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo, the Russian telecommunications investment company, has aspirations of becoming a global power. But the problem it faces, some analysts say, is that at this point, Altimo has made few allies. If it is known beyond Russia at all, it is for its propensity to fight tenaciously in court and on corporate boards for its ambitions, some say. [C5.] THE MALE DIETER The face of dieting may be changing. Of the 72 million people dieting in the United States, 38 percent -- about 28 million -- are men, according to Marketdata Enterprises, a market research company. It estimates that the diet industry will be $58.7 billion this year. And NutriSystem has hired its first male spokesman, the former quarterback Dan Marino, and has started advertising in Sports Illustrated, Men's Health and ESPN magazine. [C3.] MAINSTREAM PROMOTION Mel Gibson's 2004 film ''The Passion of the Christ'' demonstrated to Hollywood just how many evangelical moviegoers there are and how much money can be made from them. Mindful of that market, Universal Pictures has teamed up with Grace Hill Media, a public relations firm that reaches out to religious groups, to publicize the mainstream film ''Evan Almighty.'' Scheduled for wide release on June 22, it stars Steve Carell as a politician who abandons Congress in order to build an ark, taking off on the story of Noah. [C3.] TALLYING GLIMPSES When the sleek yacht of the Luna Rossa team sailed away with a victory in the America's Cup semifinals, there were two vital results. The Italian crew eliminated the American team of BMW Oracle Racing with a 33-second lead. And fleeting glimpses of the flapping mainsails -- branded with logos of Telecom Italia Mobile and the broadband service Alice -- reached millions of television viewers. Those glimpses are now being counted down to the second, categorized by clear and partial visibility, tallied by major countries and then compared with the cost of traditional spot advertisements. [C2.] WEB PROPERTY DEVELOPER NameMedia, a privately held owner and developer of Web sites based in Waltham, Mass., is best seen as an online property developer, its chief executive, Kelly P. Conlin, said. Analysts suggest that NameMedia and its competitors could represent the next wave of Internet initial public offerings, while also providing a peek at a significant change in what people see when they stumble onto obscure Web properties. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report. [C5.] THE TOUCH-UP In a situation not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O.J. Simpson's mug shot on its cover a decade ago, no fewer than three magazines were reacting to claims last week that they had doctored their covers -- and one retouched celebrity even cried foul. [C4.] A PULITZER AWARD Often the writing and photography that win Pulitzer Prizes require heroic efforts. For one recipient, Jahangir Razmi , the process of receiving the award also took 27 years. In 1979, Mr. Razmi stood near executioners as they shot Kurdish prisoners in Sanandaj, Iran. One picture was picked up by the wire service United Press International. To protect Mr. Razmi, his name was never printed. But after decades of keeping silent, Mr. Razmi allowed his name to appear in a December 2006 article in The Wall Street Journal, which prompted the Pulitzer Prize Board to seek out Mr. Razmi to award him the prize in person. [C4.] VIEWER REVOLT The cancellation of the CBS series ''Jericho'' has led to a viewer revolt that has included not only the usual petition drives, but also the delivery of tons of nuts (mostly walnuts, but also peanuts and pecans) to the two responsible CBS executives. [C4.] THE PRETEEN MARKET With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive, bolstered by last year's enthusiasm for new stars from the Disney Channel's hit ''High School Musical,'' which made household names not only of Zac Efron and Corbin Bleu, but also of Ashley Tisdale and Vanessa Anne Hudgens. [C1.]

OLDHAM--Brent, passed away on May 22, 2007 in Murray, Utah. Brent was born in Salt Lake City, Utah on June 18, 1948. He lived in New York City pursuing his passion for the arts. We were touched by his energy, wicked sense of humor, and his passion for life. He will be missed but not forgotten. Brent was survived by his three brothers, Steve, Rich, and Brian. Condolences www.jenkins-soffe.com

An article on May 18 about a reported robbery attempt at the country estate in South Kent, Conn., owned by the socialite Anne Bass, misstated the year that she arranged for a herd of 130 Randall cattle to live on her land. It was 2004, not 2005. The article also referred imprecisely to the herd's ownership. Of the roughly 180 cattle that are now in the herd, Mrs. Bass owns about 40 -- not the entire herd -- according to the cattle manager, Cynthia Creech, who owns the rest.

A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of work by Eva Rothschild, at 303 Gallery in Chelsea, misidentified the gallery that represents Liz Larner, a sculptor whose creations Ms. Rothschild's works were said to resemble. Her principal dealers are the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery in New York and Regen Projects in Los Angeles -- not 303 Gallery, which she left in 2004.

Chick Corea and Béla Fleck ''The Enchantment'' (Concord) The notes fly fast and in tight formation on ''The Enchantment,'' a duet album by the pianist Chick Corea and the banjoist Béla Fleck. That shouldn't be a surprise, given the histories of these virtuosos. Both are dazzling improvisers with effusive tendencies, and both could reasonably be called percussionists at heart. So this easily could have been a messy riot of an album, with too much happening at once. But for the most part it isn't because there's so much focused listening going on and -- just as crucially -- because both artists are such eager omnivores. Jazz is to Mr. Corea as bluegrass is to Mr. Fleck: a formative discipline and an ongoing fascination, but hardly the whole story. They actually have a lot in common stylistically, including an overstimulated brand of fusion that thankfully makes no incursions here.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 15 about a study by ACT, the Iowa testing organization, on the effectiveness of college preparatory courses, misstated a finding of the report. In analyzing about 1.2 million high students who took the ACT college admissions test before graduating last June, the study found that 26 percent of those who took the core curriculum were college ready; it did not find that 26 percent of all students tested were college-ready.

Without realizing it, about half a century ago Yogi Berra, baseball's old philosopher, described the perilous situation of these Yankees. Asked about the shadows in left field at Yankee Stadium when all World Series games were played in the afternoon, he shrugged. ''It gets late early out there,'' he grunted.

A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 17 about a low-cost camcorder called the Flip Video referred incorrectly to its retail availability. Although CVS, Rite Aid and Wolf Camera are among the locations where video from the cameras can be processed into DVDs, those stores do not sell the cameras.

Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo likes to compare its aspirations to Vodafone, the world's largest cellphone network, which owns pieces of phone companies from the East Coast to England to India. Altimo, essentially a telecommunications investment firm, already owns stakes in several phone companies in and around its home base, Moscow. Now it wants to expand both east and west, by buying phone assets in Asia and Western Europe.

An article on Thursday about a decision by a New Hampshire legislative panel to reject a seat belt law misstated the state's rate of seat belt use and referred imprecisely to its rank in the nation. The rate is 63.5 percent, not 49.6 percent. New Hampshire and Wyoming -- not just New Hampshire -- rank last.
The Frugal Traveler arrives in Armuchee, Ga., just in time for the Armuchee Bluegrass Festival.

CDW, a technology products retailer aimed at business, said late Tuesday that it has agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for about $7.3 billion in cash. In a statement Tuesday, CDW said that the deal values the company at $87.75 a share, or a 16.3 percent premium over its closing stock price on Friday.

Commissioner William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles Police Department faced off with his overseers today on the immigration protest gone awry on May Day. At the time, he called it "worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years" in law enforcement.

Without a mention of the most eye-grabbing names to lead the World Bank (Tony Blair and Bill Frist, anyone?), the White House has picked a man who has plenty of appropriate experience in Republican government, respect abroad and ties to President Bush that date back to the early days of his 2000 campaign, when a group led by Condoleezza Rice known as "the Vulcans" advised a candidate inexperienced on foreign policy.
Next stops on the Frugal Traveler's itinerary are Tennessee and Kentucky. Have you been or do you live near by? Share a suggestion what Matt should see, eat and do on his way through these states.

"Blind Light," an exhibit of the work of the British sculptor Antony Gormley, has drawn mixed reviews from the critics. Some observers have found deep meanings in installations like an enormous glass cube filled with a hazy vapor. Others are simply confused.
Taxpayers are helping to pay for corporate executives to travel to a destination golf resort in the hard-luck town of Bandon, Ore.

Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney said today in New Hampshire that he would donate to charity at least a part if not more of his presidential salary (should he win) -- given that he's the wealthiest among the candidates.

Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary took overwhelming leads of 2.5 to 0.5 over their opponents in the candidates matches taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The matches are to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

The political party that claimed it would restore "honor and dignity to the White House" has done nothing of the sort. Having on false pretenses led us into the disaster of Iraq, the administration and its supporters are now beginning - cravenly and shamefully - to shift blame onto the Iraqi people. The administration continues to hold hundreds of people without charges in secret prisons around the world, while arguing that torture is O.K. and that President Bush can disregard the laws he doesn't like. I haven't even mentioned illegal spying or efforts to keep scientists quiet if they're saying the wrong thing.

Barry Bonds, perhaps one of the most polarizing players in the history of baseball, will be sitting on the bench for the opener of the Giants' three-game series at Shea Stadium. The Giants like giving Bonds two consecutive days of rest, and with an off day yesterday and a lefthander, Oliver Perez, starting for the Mets tonight, benching him was the natural move.
Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, cooks a New Orleans favorite. (Warning: Contains images of violence to crabs.)

Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged a high-profile investment banker in Pakistan with taking part in a $7.5 million insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker. In a new complaint filed in federal district court in Manhattan, the United States attorney's office accused Ajaz Rahim, the former head of Faysal Bank Limited, of profiting from confidential information fed to him by Hafiz Mohammed Zubair Naseem, at the time a junior associate in Credit Suisse's energy team.
Senator Barack Obama: activist, author, presidential candidate artist?

Mechai Viravaidya was recognized by The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation today with a $1 million award for confronting "taboo subjects like sex and HIV/AIDS directly in order to save lives," the foundation said.

The Chinese women won the First Women's Team Championship with an undefeated score in nine matches. The only blemish on their record was a tie against Georgia (formerly of the Soviet Union), who were led by former women's world champion Maia Chiburdanidze. The championship, which was held in Yekaterinburg, Russia, began on May 19. The official Web site is here.
The conservative editorial cartoonist Allen Forkum offers some illustrated commentary, followed by the more literal kind:
It is the question that every presidential candidate must have a good answer to: Why do you want the job?
In order to cut back the size of the house, we had to lose something - but what?
What does an organization called Ultimate Fighting Championship do when its ultimate fighter is badly beaten in front of tons of adoring fans?
An 18-year-old art student has told police that he killed more than 30 people in Moscow, according to reports in Russian newspapers.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer had this to say today when asked about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing plan:
Charles Nelson Reilly appeared on "Match Game" prefamous. As a kid I believed he must have been very, very famous before I was lucky enough to catch him cooling his heels in the afterschool hours.

I'm mildly curious about what people wear (and don't wear) at the Cannes Film Festival, and I'm thinking that next year I ought to go and see for myself, and maybe combine the trip with the Grand Prix at Monaco, just to see a different kind of action. I'd go for the simple reason that I don't know what to expect from those events, and not from any illusion that I can compete with Hello! for fawning reportage of the latest sequined coated babe. It ain't gonna happen. Nonetheless, I will have to deal with the expectation that this is what "most people" want to read. "To write what you are interested in writing, and to succeed in getting editors to pay for it, is a feat that may require pretty close calculation and a good deal of ingenuity. You have to learn to load solid matter into notices of ephemeral happenings; you have to develop a resourcefulness at pursing a line of thought through pieces on miscellaneous and more or less fortuitous subjects; and you have to acquire a technique of slipping over on the routine of editors the deeper independent work which their over-anxious intentness on the fashions of the month or the week have conditioned them automatically to reject." This is from Edmund Wilson, in a 2005 piece by Louis Menand, and I keep its essence in the back of my head. Very often writers don't know what they want to say about subject, only that something deserves to be written which hasn't been sufficiently said.

Bankers can be forgiven for being very careful about what they say around the office. Acid-laced books, both fictional and nonfictional, written by former employees of investment banks, seem to have replaced drug-strewn memoirs as the current era's "it" genre.
Forty-seven percent of New Yorkers oppose gay marriage, while 43 percent support the idea, according to a new poll from Siena College.

Two decades ago, a favorable environment for junk-bond financing helped fuel a wave of leveraged buyouts. Citi's equity strategists say they are feeling a bit of a flashback these days, as yields on risky debt are relatively low, making it cheaper to borrow money to take companies private. The atmosphere "is reminiscent of the L.B.O. heyday back in the latter 1980's," they wrote in a report published Tuesday. Citi's analysts compared companies' cash flows with junk-bond yields and found that certain sectors look especially ripe for buyouts: These included the commercial services industry (which includes waste management, employment services, etc.) and retailing.

Options traders are on a shopping spree with Kroger, the grocery chain. Trading in the company's options skyrocketed Tuesday, a development that OptionMonster.com's Jon Najarian chalked up to fresh speculation about a possible buyout of the company.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, pledged in a speech in Manchester, N.H., this morning to reduce corporate tax breaks and eliminate incentives for companies that move overseas in order to combat "rising inequality and rising pessimism in our workforce."

The Indy 500 gave us one of the better feel-good stories in recent IndyCar memory when Dario Franchitti won a rain-shortened race, and the camera found his wife, Ashley Judd, running down the pits, barefoot and wet.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed an executive order today creating a commission to look at overhauling the State University of New York system. The goal is a lofty one: to put SUNY on par with elite public university systems in states like California. But it would also be expensive to accomplish that, and the governor would only say that "how funding will fit into this I remain to wait and see."

Jim Cramer wants to know why he has become "a polarizing figure" since he started his CNBC stock-picking show, "Mad Money," in which he yells and sweats a lot, throws things, and sometimes wears a diaper or jumps into a pile of lettuce "to illustrate," he cheekily writes, "the finer points of investing."
Fresh off campaign stops in New Hampshire over the weekend, Senator Barack Obama traveled to the University of Iowa to outline his own plan to try to provide health insurance coverage for everyone.
As reports surface that more bidders might jump into the fray for Alcan, Canadian politicians are calling for greater protections against takeovers by foreign companies.

Volvo has had plenty of admirers over the years, and we are not just talking about affluent Northeasterners who like its sensibly Swedish version of luxury. Renault of France and Fiat of Italy have, at various times, considered buying or merging with Volvo. With reports percolating that Ford Motor Company might put the business up for sale -- it is part of Ford's Premier Automotive Group, which has already sold Aston Martin -- attention naturally turns to who else might cast an eye Volvo's way.

The latest housing price numbers have a tinge of hope -- at least in some bubbly markets. The Standard & Poor's/Case-Shiller indexes for March, out today, actually went up in the Boston and San Francisco regions. In each case, the bounce came after nine consecutive monthly declines. And the Portland and Seattle markets, which had shown signs of slipping although their year-over-year gains remained substantial, each showed improving month-over-month numbers.
Too big for a deal? Not these days.
- Tobin Harshaw

The presidential race was consumed last week with discussion of the immigration bill and financing of the Iraq war. This week, health care may take center stage, with Senator Barack Obama planning to release his long-awaited health care proposal today.
The man applauded by an F.B.I. agent as the "unsung hero" of Fort Dix case stepped into the spotlight today on CNN.

The chief executive of Bradley Pharmaceuticals has bid $21.50 a share to buy the company, valuing it at about $363 million, the company said in a regulatory filing. The chief executive, Daniel Glassman would remain in his position and would retain the current top management, the company said.
Additional images from the Karen Kilimnik survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia.

As he travels around the country seeking the G.O.P. nomination, Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered a calmer side to his personality than what he often displayed while mayor of New York. The Times's Michael Powell looks back on his political journey:

Shares of British Airways, Europe's third-largest airline, rose the most in almost a year on speculation the carrier might attract a private-equity bid, Bloomberg News reported Monday. Shares of the airline advanced as much as 22.5 pence, or 4.9 percent, to 483.5 pence, the biggest gain since June 15, 2006 at midday.

The proposal trumped ABN's agreed deal with Barclays, already the largest banking takeover.

CDW, a computer reseller with a market capitalization of about $6 billion, is in talks with private equity firms about a possible buyout, The Wall Street Journal reported. Madison Dearborn Partners is considered to be in the lead to buy the company, the Journal said.

At a charity event in New York last week, during which some of the biggest names in hedge funds offered investment advice, James Chanos, the short seller who catapulted to fame by questioning Enron, offered the Macquarie Bank, the Australian financial group, as a stock that might be in for a fall. He even drew some comparisons between Enron and Macquarie, which has raised a lot of big investment funds that it used to buy assets and sell them to related entities.

New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, when he was attorney general, aggressively policed the financial services industry, is forming a committee of Wall Street chief executives, lawyers, consumer groups and regulators to modernize financial-services regulation in New York State, The Financial Times reported.

For the first time since World War II, bankers in Europe are on the verge of earning more from initial public offerings than their counterparts in the United States, prompting Bloomberg News to state that "the lights may be going out on Wall Street."

The British private equity firm Apax Partners will not earmark any of the new fund it is raising for venture capital investment, according to Electronicsweekly.com, instead funneling the cash it raised for such purposes into private equity buyouts.

South Korea's financial regulators are looking into whether Credit Suisse violated disclosure rules in its purchase of shares in a small domestic building material company. A recent series of acquisitions or potential acquisitions of Canadian corporations has prompted a growing public debate over foreign control. On Monday, in the latest sign that the takeovers had become a growing political issue, the opposition Liberal Party said that it wanted to freeze foreign takeovers of Canadian companies for three months to allow a review of investment laws.

Allison Stokke, the 18-year-old high school pole vaulter whose face launched thousands of searches in the past month, was introduced today to a whole new crowd: readers of The Washington Post. A story that chronicles how she struggled with the unwanted attention was played at the most prominent spot on the Web site -- the top section of the home page -- with a picture of her looking quite serious. Judging by her top ranking on the "most viewed articles" list, her appeal stretches beyond her almost completely male fan base.

House price growth in England appears to be slowing -- at long last. A new survey from Hometrack, a leading property Web site, shows that house prices rose by 0.6 percent in May from April, a slight dip from the previous month's growth of 0.7 percent. Annual house price inflation also declined from 6.8 percent to 6.7 percent in May.

The article says high cholesterol is a risk factor. Could you detail what you mean by high cholesterol? High numbers overall or just high LDL? Or both? How high is too high? - Laura

Does having one stroke increase your chances of having a second? - Edward Yes. Overall, the highest risk factor for stroke is having had a previous stroke. This is why so much research has gone into reducing this risk. A stroke prevention plan between patient and their neurologist is essential in persons with a history of stroke. - Dr. Koroshetz
What are some of the key differences of stroke symptoms, if any, between men and women? - Sandra Holtzman
Why does aortic valve replacement increase risk for stroke? - Mark Gordetsky

Can people reverse the possible damage caused from years of high blood pressure? That is, if they lose weight and control their blood pressure, will the buildup in their blood vessels decrease and return to normal? - Maureen Aldakheel

If tPA causes bleeding in the brains of 6 percent of people who get it, it does not seem like such a great drug. Would you ever give it to someone who seems to be having a relatively mild stroke? If so, why? - Donna
How can one evaluate a local hospital ER's stroke diagnosis and treatment standards and protocols? - Don Porter
In the emergency room, how do doctors diagnose the type of stroke - ischemic or hemorraghic - and decide whether tPA would be useful? - John Niesyn
Is mild to severe dizziness considered a possible warning sign for stroke? - John
Can significant bumps to the head increase your chances later in life for a stroke or aneurysm? - Julie
Are coated and uncoated aspirin equally effective at helping to prevent strokes? - Joel
Are any new therapeutic advances on the immediate horizon that may improve the efficacy of acute stroke care with fewer side effects than tPA? - Paul Roberts

Would it be practical to cut diagnostic costs, and so expand the reach of effective care, by placing M.R.I. machines in more locations and sending the scans electronically to be read by neurologists at regional centers - - or overseas for that matter? - Irv Federer The cost of M.R.I. is not related to reading the scans. In fact, acute stroke damage on a high quality-diffusion M.R.I. is one of the easiest things for a doctor to pick out. The cost is in the M.R.I. machines themselves, with their multi-million dollar price tags, and upkeep and staffing costs. M.R.I. scanning also takes more time to perform and many people -- such as those with pacemakers, claustrophobia, confusion with inability to hold still -- can not undergo M.R.I. scans. - Dr. Koroshetz
Do strokes always show-up on M.R.I.s? - Janell Fowell

An obituary and picture caption on May 17 about Yolanda King, an actor and the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., misstated the name of a surviving brother. He is Martin Luther King III, not II.

A caption on June 8, 1944, with a photograph of Army officers at mess on the Pacific front, misspelled the given name of the first officer seated at the left side of the table. He was Col. Girard B. Troland of New London, Conn. — not Gerand. The error was called to the attention of the editors by his grandson yesterday.
Corrections

Because of an editing error, a sports article on May 20 about a player from Israel who was selected by the Liberty in the W.N.B.A. draft in April misspelled her given name in some copies. As the article noted elsewhere, she is Shay Doron, not Shea.

An article and picture caption on Wednesday about an International Criminal Court investigation of atrocities committed in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003 misspelled the surname of a general who seized power there in 2003 and remains president. He is François Bozize, not Boizize.

An article on May 18 about a Tacoma, Wash., woman who lost her belongings because of a fraudulent advertisement on the Web site Craigslist misspelled her surname in one reference. She is Laurie Raye, not Ray.

A picture caption with a sports article on May 20 about the graduation ceremony at Fordham University in which Mets Manager Willie Randolph received an honorary doctorate misspelled, in some copies, the given name and surname of the faculty member who sponsored Randolph for the degree and who was shown with him. She is Maryanne Kowaleski, not Maryann Howaleski.

An article in Business Day on Friday about efforts by Chinese officials to convince skeptics in Washington that there are benefits to Chinese-American economic relations, misspelled the surname of a Chinese finance ministry official. He is Zhu Guangyao, not Xhu.
A music review on Thursday about the International Contemporary Ensemble, at P.S. 122, misstated the surname of the sound engineer. He is Ryan Streber, not Steber.

An article yesterday about a blackout at WABC-TV in New York on Sunday night because of a fire at its Lincoln Center headquarters misspelled the surname of the news director. He is Kenny Plotnik, not Plotnick.
Because of an editing error, a film review on Wednesday about “9 Star Hotel” misspelled the name of the character who scavenges for garbage. He is Ahmad, not Ahmed.

A chart last Tuesday in Science Times, with the Personal Health column about jet lag, omitted the recommended dose of melatonin for changing the body clock. The dose should be a half-milligram or less — preferably 300 micrograms — except at bedtime, when 3 milligrams is acceptable. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/health.

An article on Wednesday about the addition of Mexican consulates in the United States misspelled the surname of the lead demographer for the Urban Institute, which conducted a study on illegal immigrants in Arkansas, where a new consulate has opened. He is Randy Capps, not Kapps.

10 P.M. (CBS) FLASHPOINT: KIMBERLY DOZIER AND THE ARMY’S FOURTH I.D. — A STORY OF BRAVERY, RECOVERY AND LIVES FOREVER CHANGED The title just about says it all. A year ago today Ms. Dozier, a CBS News correspondent, was nearly killed by a roadside bomb in Baghdad after she and her crew left their armored vehicle to report a story about American soldiers working with Iraqi security forces. Her colleagues Paul Douglas, a cameraman, and James Brolan, a soundman, as well as Capt. James A. Funkhouser of the Army and his Iraqi translator, died. Ms. Dozier, above right, was given a 50-50 chance of survival; after 25 operations she returned to television two days ago on “CBS News Sunday Morning.” This hourlong special, with Katie Couric, above left, as anchor, follows Ms. Dozier as she reconnects with some of the people who were injured alongside her on that Memorial Day blast, and remembers the lives that were lost.

FEWER TRAVELING TO EUROPE Passenger traffic from the United States to Europe last year was just short of 13 million and the 2000 record of 13.1 million, said Donald N. Martin & Company, quoting new Commerce Department data. European destinations, however, are losing overall market share. In 2006, visits from the United States to all foreign destinations (excluding Canada and Mexico) were up 12.2 percent over the year 2000, to 30.3 million. Last year, Europe’s share of total overseas traffic from the United States was 43.1 percent, compared with 48.9 percent in 2000.

The presidential race was consumed last week with discussion of the immigration bill and financing of the Iraq war. This week, health care may take center stage, with Senator Barack Obama planning to release his long-awaited health care proposal today. Mr. Obama, the Illinois Democrat, will unveil his plan in the first caucus state, Iowa, and will outline how he wants to reduce the costs of health care and expand coverage to more people. He has already said that he would pay for his proposals by repealing President Bush's tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans.

JAMES--David William. Born David William James on April 25, 1949 in Norman, Oklahoma to John and Mary James and beloved by those who knew him, David passed over, after a long and courageous battle with lung cancer on Saturday, May 26, 2007 at 2:28pm surrounded by his loved ones at the home he shared with his partner, Dinda Andrews in Manhattan. A devoted father himself, David is survived by his own father John James, sisters Bonnie and Jennifer, brother John and his two most cherished daughters ''The Girls'', Maris and Dana. Diverse in skills and abilities, talented yet humble and extremely human, David would be more prone to describing himself as an electrical contractor, however, his artistry infused his work which has contributed to the success of many upscale projects in SOHO and Tribeca. His craftsmanship was respected and admired by owners, architects and other tradesmen who worked with him. David graduated from the University of Georgia and went on to acquire his Masters of Fine Arts from the University of Wisconsin. He then became a Professor of Painting at the University of Georgia. David moved to New York City in 1977 where he has lived since. Pursuing his artistic goals he was affiliated with the Semaphore Gallery in SOHO and the Ruth Siegal Gallery on 57th Street. He established himself as a noteworthy New York artist most known for his large 3-D abstract paintings. Jacketless in the depth of winter with his tools in hand David will be most remembered for his warmth, generosity, forgiveness, talent, insights, honesty, integrity, overall humanity and not least his humor, all of which will undoubtedly leave smiles on so many faces for the years to come. A ''Celebration of his Life'' will be held at The Conservancy at Central Park near 105th Street and 5th Avenue from 4-5pm on Wednesday, May 30, with a reception to follow at Hotel Wales at 92nd Street and Madison Avenue from 58pm.

The telecommunications company Avaya is in negotiations to sell a part or all of itself, in what may be the latest round of deal making in its industry, executives briefed on the negotiations said last night. The company, based in Basking Ridge, N.J. and valued at $6.1 billion, has retained the investment bank Credit Suisse as an adviser, the executives said. Among those interested are two rivals -- Cisco Systems and Nortel Networks -- and the equity buyout firm Silver Lake Partners.

Imagine that the top presidential candidates are all at an airport, trying to get on a flight. There is one seat left on the plane, and there are six people ahead of them in line. What does each of the candidates do? The scene was described last week to 12 voters at a focus group in suburban Baltimore by Peter Hart, the Democratic pollster, on behalf of the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania. The voters -- half Republicans, half Democrats, and varied by other demographics -- had a pretty easy time picturing how each would behave.

BECK--James H. Professor James H. Beck, 77, one of the world's foremost scholars of Italian Renaissance art, died Saturday, May 26 in New York. Professor Beck was known as a great teacher and as a mentor to generations of students at Columbia University, where he was a member of the Department of Art History and Archaeology and former department chairman. The faculty, students and staff of the department mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, teacher and friend, whose passion for art and for life inspired us all. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Darma, his son Mr. Lawrence Beck, his daughter Professor Eleonora Beck, his sister Ms. Antoinette Beck, and his grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at Columbia in the fall.

To the Editor: Re ''Cleveland to Cairo, in Coach? Ways to Outwit the Body Clock'' (Personal Health, May 22): I have found that one of the best cures for jet lag is, on arrival, a 20-minute steamy shower. You are dehydrated, no matter how much water you have consumed, and the steam is a wonderful soother. If you then want to sleep, you are very relaxed, and if you do not want to sleep, once dressed and outside, you are refreshed and ready to go. It truly does work. Patricia T. Smalley Larchmont, N.Y.

Q. What makes coffee bitter? A. Coffee is a complex chemical soup, and many of its chemicals, including some that produce astringency rather than bitterness, and even some acids, have been implicated in the perception of bitterness. Bitterness also depends on variables including the coffee variety; how it is processed and roasted; the brewing method, temperature and time; and even the chemical content of the water.

To the Editor: Re ''Mysteries to Behold in the Dark Down Deep: Seadevils and Species Unknown'' (May 22): I am sure my reaction to the photo of the Dumbo octopus was like millions of adults everywhere. REILLY--Charles Nelson. Dear CNR, you made the world laugh but we who knew and loved you saw your many other attributes. Your keen insight into life's problems, your compassionate love and knowledge of opera and the world-acclaimed singers you befriended, your unique instinctive theatrical insights that guided so many performers, your magical personality that always changed a cloudy day into bright sunshine. How on the streets, strangers would stop you and years later, meeting again, you would always remember their names. Yours was the bright spark of love, of caring, of concern for others that many of us seek to find in our lives. As we laugh at your stories at dinner, we all know that they are now laughing at them in heaven. We will always love and miss you. Adio! Joseph and Mario

To the Editor: Re ''This Is Your Life (and How You Tell It) '' (May 22): This otherwise fine article leaves out an important piece of the narrative puzzle. Our stories are not always composed by us, but come to us in powerful ways from others. If, as children, family members describe us in a particular way, these family stories often remain the same no matter how we change. What others believe about us, what we learn in school, in the media and from the reactions of strangers, define our stories.

To the Editor: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's announcement that the city's yellow taxi fleet will become completely hybrid within five years (news article, May 23) callously ignores the immediate transportation needs of people with severe physical disabilities who cannot enter or exit currently approved hybrid taxi vehicles, as well as New York City's growing aging population, who are much more likely to acquire a physical impairment.

Pope Benedict XVI signaled a renewed emphasis on relations between Catholics and Muslims, a year after the Vatican seemed to sideline the issue by eliminating a separate office for dialogue with other faiths. The Vatican's second-in-command, Secretary of State Tarcisio Bertone, told the newspaper La Stampa that the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue would again become a ''separate department.'' The council's collapse, in March 2006, into another Vatican department came up against heavy criticism, especially after a speech by the pope a few months later that many Muslims charged was hostile to Islam. IAN FISHER

A chart last Tuesday in Science Times, with the Personal Health column about jet lag, omitted the recommended dose of melatonin for changing the body clock. The dose should be a half-milligram or less -- preferably 300 micrograms -- except at bedtime, when 3 milligrams is acceptable. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/health.

People with diabetes have too much sugar in their blood, so a drug that lowers blood sugar ought to be a good treatment, right? Maybe not. Consider the diabetes drug Avandia, or rosiglitazone, which was approved in 1999. It lowers blood sugar, and about a million people in the United States have been taking it for Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease. But last week, doctors reported that Avandia might increase the risk of heart attacks.

Six agencies are proceeding in a review by the Census Bureau for an assignment to create advertising to promote participation in the 2010 census. Spending was estimated at $200 million to $300 million. Three of the agencies are owned by the WPP Group: the Atlanta office of JWT, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York and Y&R Advertising in New York; Y&R handled the assignment for the 2000 census. Two agencies are part of the Interpublic Group of Companies: Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., and Draft FCB in Chicago. The sixth is GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. A final decision is expected before the end of summer.

A3 NATIONAL A12-16 Needle Exchange Program Alone in City's AIDS Fight Washington is the only city in the country barred by federal law from using local tax money to finance needle exchange programs. It is also the city with the fastest-growing number of new AIDS cases. The city's only needle exchange program, Prevention Works, subsists on a shoestring budget of private donations. A1 For Sale: Uranium Furious lobbying has broken out over who should end up with 25 million kilograms of uranium that the government is looking to sell. One of the companies most vocal in making its case for the uranium, estimated to be worth at least $750 million, says it should be given the material free. A12 Cancer Genome Advance Researchers say they have found six new sites of variation in the genome that increase the risk of breast cancer. Together with already known genes, the discovery means that much of the overall genetic risk of breast cancer may now have been accounted for, researchers say. A13 Anger Over Immigration Deal Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, a Republican who garners top ratings from conservative groups every year, is the unlikely linchpin to the fragile alliance of Democrats and Republicans trying to push the immigration bill through the Senate. That role has made Mr. Kyl into a lightining rod in the immigration debate. A14 Bush Speaks at Arlington President Bush used his traditional Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery to speak directly, in deeply personal terms, to the families of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, assuring them that Americans ''will never forget the terrible loss you have suffered.'' It was one of the enduring mysteries of the 2004 campaign: Who leaked to The New York Post that John Kerry had picked Richard A. Gephardt as his running mate, leading the paper to run with an erroneous front-page story? A former gossip reporter at the paper, Ian Spiegelman, claims the paper was duped by Democrats, saying in a statement that the bum tip was given to Lachlan Murdoch, then the publisher of The Post. The publisher, in turn, ordered Col Allan, the editor in chief, to run the article, Mr. Spiegelman said.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in unusually pointed and broad language, criticized Congress yesterday for parts of a comprehensive immigration bill now being debated in the Senate. FENTON--Katharine Douglas died May 18 at her home in Pebble Beach, California. Mrs. Fenton, a widow since the death of her husband, Martin, in 1982, was known by her children and grandchildren as one who was always delighted to have them visit and who constantly made an especial effort to entertain them. ''Babe'' Fenton, the daughter of Archibald and Edith Douglas, was brought up in Spuyten Duyvil, in Yonkers. She attended Miss Chapin's School in New York City (as did a daughter and a granddaughter), the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, Connecticut and Barnard College (her father served as a life trustee of Columbia University of which Barnard is a part). A talented athlete and a fierce competitor, Babe for years held ladies singles titles at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club in Bedford, New York and later at the Wilmington Country Club in Wilmington, Delaware. Babe was also involved in charitable works; her favorites were her work at the Delaware Hospital and her efforts as a co-founder of the Visiting Nurses' Association chapter in Wilmington. Mrs. Fenton was a member of the Cypress Point Club, Pebble Beach, California, the Vicmead Hunt and Wilmington Country Clubs in Wilmington, Delaware, a life member of the Colony Club in New York City and the Adirondack League Club. She is survived by her five children, Alice and Prudence of Los Angeles, Martin of La Jolla, Edith of New York and Wendell of Chadds Ford, PA, 14 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Fenton Chair in Humanities at St. Mark's School, P.O. Box 9105, Southborough, Massachusetts 01772.

Following in his Father's footsteps, Barry began his career in the Food and Beverage business as a young man in Ellenville, New York. His career took him to many places around the country. Barry was Director of Food and Beverage at the Sheraton Hotel, La Guardia and at 57th Street in New York, The Regency, NYC, El San Juan in Puerto Rico, and the Prince George. He worked an unprecedented 22 years for Bally's Casino Hotels beginning as Director, Vice President and finally Senior Vice President of the East Coast Division. He has left a great legacy in the food and beverage industry. Visitation will be held from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm at AdamsPerfect Funeral Home in Northfield, NJ on Wednesday May 30th. Burial service will be on Friday, June 1st at 11:00 am at the Cemetery of the Resurrection in Staten Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the CardioVascular Institute at Shore Memorial (http:// www.shorememorial.org/ cardiac/) or the American Diabetes Association (www.diabetes.org). www.Adams-Perfect.com

To the Editor: Re ''Executive on a Mission: Saving the Planet '' (May 22): It's always quite refreshing to read about business executives who consider their company's environmental friendliness as a source of competitive advantage. It's even more refreshing to read about a C.E.O. like Ray Anderson who has made that part of the mainstream decision-making process in his company. Let's hope that the current environmental and energy problems make all business leaders realize for good that protecting the environment is directly connected to the top and the bottom line. Zino Vogiatzis Timonium, Md.

To the Editor: Re ''Legal Status Brings Security to Some Same-Sex Marriages'' (news article, May 22): It is heartening to learn that a judge in Massachusetts has ruled in favor of same-sex couples from New York who went to the state in pursuit of legally recognized unions.

ROWLEY--Henry Nelson, Jr. Died peacefully at home in New York City on Thursday, May 24. Hank was born in Lake Forest, IL in 1928. He attended Yale University and served in the Korean War before pursuing a career on Wall St. Upon retiring, Hank devoted his time to volunteer tutoring in New York City Public Schools and at the English Speaking Union. A talented athlete, Hank shared his love of nature and sport with his family through skiing, tennis, golf and horseback riding. He was an avid reader of history, a life long student of literature and lover of jazz. Most importantly, Hank was a loving father and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Francine, his son, John Rowley, and daughters Maria Rowley Leas and Alexandra Rowley, John's wife Georgiana, Maria's husband, Rodman and Alexandra's husband, Stephen Wallis; two grandsons, Spencer and Alexander Rowley; his sister Andria Lawson and her family; two nephews, Jamie and Nelson Rowley. Burial service at Woodlawn Cemetery will be private. There will be a memorial service at St. Vincent Ferrer Church at 4pm on Thursday, May 31. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Henry's name to St. James School, (care of St. Vincent Ferrer Church) or City Meals on Wheels.

LOW--Martin L., of Sleepy Hollow, NY, died on May 25. A WWII fighter pilot, he was at Pearl Harbor and D-Day. He owned a motion picture studio in Manhattan. He was recognized by the NY State Assembly for his work as Chairman of the Ossining Open Door Family Medical Centers. He is survived by his loving wife Alice, two surviving children, Andy and Kathy, and four admiring grandchildren. Memorial service at a later date.

To the Editor: Re ''Macho Mistakes at Ground Zero'' (editorial, May 22): As a nurse in the emergency room at St. Vincent's Hospital on 9/11, I can verify that all of the victims and all of the emergency responders who came to us for help that day were covered from head to toe in a layer of white dust.

MORRISON--Sylvia Willner, 93. Danbury, CT. Formerly Brooklyn, West Palm Beach. Beloved wife of Morton for 69 years. Cherished mother of Laura Bardash (Manuel), Marjorie Brook (Joel). Adored grandmother, bubbe, sister. Baruch College, 1935. ''How we loved you, how we miss you.''

The government lashed out at Globovisión, the country's only remaining television channel that is critical of its policies, accusing it of manipulating images to incite an assassination attempt against President Hugo Chávez. Willian Lara, the communications minister, called for an investigation of Globovisión, a 24-hour news channel, saying semioticians hired by the government had determined that video run by the channel of an assassination attempt in 1981 against Pope John Paul II could be interpreted as hostile to Mr. Chávez. Mr. Lara, who also denounced CNN's coverage of Venezuela, made his claims as the police dispersed protests for a second day against a decision forcing the dissident network RCTV off the air on Sunday. SIMON ROMERO
SELVERNE--Martin M. A bright light was lost 25 years ago today. Rest in peace. We miss you and love you. Your Family

U.S. Cellular, Chicago, shifted its creative account to Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe, from Doner, Southfield, Mich. Spending was estimated at $75 million to $100 million. Spending for the coming year was estimated at $60 million.

The posters said it all: "The most beautiful French are coming from New York to Berlin." Its true! The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has lent a fabulous collection of its 19th century French artists to the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin. Starting June 1, and lasting until October 7, more than 150 works are on display. They range from Ingres and Corot, Courbet and Manet to Degas, Pissarro, Monet and Cezanne. Its a very, very big exhibition of French Impressionists. MOMA has also lent Berlin sculpturs by Rodin and Maillol. The Nationalgalerie, located close to Berlin's famed Philharmonie, home to one of the world's great orchestras, has had a great relationship with MOMA. Just a warning. Its coming up to the holiday season. Berlin is becoming one of the big tourist attractions. The queues will be long. Check out the museum website for special offers or how to book tickets in advance. Also Tel (00 49) 30 226 2651, or EMail: nng@smb.spk-berlin.de

O.K., so the Thursday column is actually about more than China and religion. In a larger sense it's about the emergence of a bit more personal space, a bit more rule of law, and the hope that China will follow Taiwan and South Korea toward greater pluralism and freedom. But the most striking manifestation of that trend for now is the boom in religion in China, and the way most people in most of the country can worship freely most of the time. And I agree with Li Baiguang that in 20 or 30 years China could have several hundred million Christians, making it the largest Christian country in the world. In most of the world, economic development has eroded religious faith, but in China it's working the other way and there's a considerable parallel with South Korea and its embrace of Christianity in the 20th century.
OK, I'm always happy to accept recognition in any form.

Talking about comedy writing last time, I omitted an interesting phenomenon thereto: the fact that the gag-writer's brain often works independently of his conscious mind. Sometimes alarmingly so. Because the topical joke-writer's livelihood depends on his ability to crank out - if the show is on daily - good, current stuff, fast and for immediate use. And after a great deal of this, there's something that develops and takes on a life of its own.

After the Lenovo Group acquired I.B.M.'s personal-computer division two years ago, many investment bankers started to believe that Chinese companies would soon increase their overseas acquisitions. The analysis of China's buying habits comes amid a steep selloff in the Chinese stock markets, volatility that could make it even harder for Chinese firms to broker cross-border deals.

I spend a lot of time thinking about all sorts of wines, but I confess I haven't thought much recently about pinot gris. For whatever reason, it's a wine that I've largely ignored, except in its Italian manifestation, pinot grigio, which I wrote about last summer. But recently I've had some delicious pinot gris wines, all from different places, and I've wondered whether it's just me who lost track of what can be a compelling category of wines.
